column2: COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 31 -- A record shipment of forty-two porcelain enameled all-steel Lustron houses yesterday chalked up a record week and a record month for the Lustron Corporation, it was announced here today by Joe Tucker, senior vice president.

WASHINGTON, July 31 (AP) -- Housing Expediter Tighe Woods said today that Senate investigators handling the "five per center" inquiry had combed files of his agency in tracking down the activities of a former Army officer.

WASHINGTON, July 31 (AP) -- War veterans who want to go to school this fall under the GI Bill of Rights should start making the arrangements now because otherwise, the Veterans Administration said today, they may get caught in a last-minute jam. The first step is for the veteran to make sure his certificate of eligibility is in order.
NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., July 31 -- A dead calm forced a cancellation of today's yacht racing association championship.

CHICAGO, July 31 -- Release of official estimates on stocks of wheat, corn and oats as of July 1 by the Department of Agriculture discloses record supplies of feed grains are available for the next year while supplies of wheat are far in excess of all domestic and export requirements.
SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., July 31 (AP) --- Henry Laskau of New York City today won the thirty-eight-mile grand walking marathon. His time was 5:58:01.

The Division of Placement and Unemployment Insurance of the State Labor Department runs the largest employment agency in the United States. More than half a million unemployed workers come in each week looking for jobs. But when the division has $45-a-week jobs of its own to fill, it relies on Republican district leaders as one of its major sources for obtaining qualified applicants.

The city's latest heat wave was ended yesterday when for the first time in five days temperatures here failed to exceed the eighties. With the sun obscured a considerable part of the day, strollers no longer bothered to loiter in front of air-conditioned movie lobbies.

PLAINFIELD, N. J., July 31 -- Ground has been broken here on the Cole estate East Front Street and Leland Avenue, for construction of a 256-unit garden apartment project by the G. G. Construction Company of Leonia, N. J., builder-owner.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 31 -- A threat to the eight-month peace along the San Francisco waterfront was developing today with the announced plan of the Matson Navigation Company to load a ship this week for strikebound Hawaii.

LONDON, July 31 -- A fuller account of the flight of the British sloop Amethyst from Communist territory in China disclosed today that the warship escaped by a ruse and then made a high speed run down the Yangtze River in darkness, smashing through a boom and eluding the heavy guns of two sets of forts.
WASHINGTON, July 31 -- Plans for a $171,000,000 Air Force Academy comparable to West Point and Annapolis have been put before Congress by Secretary of Defense Louis Johnson, it was disclosed today.
The Hebrew Immigrant Aid Society releasing a semi-annual report yesterday, asserted that it had aided 11,079 persons of fourteen European nations to find homes.

A former patient shot and critically wounded Dr. Louis Blitzman, a 39-year-old physician, yesterday morning while the doctor was riding down a self-service elevator with his wife and infant daughter in the Peter Cooper Village apartment house where they lived.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 31 -- Syria's new constitution, scheduled to come before President Husni Zayim's Cabinet this week, has astonished the political and diplomatic community in the Middle East by providing for restoration of the fundamental structure of a republican government.

MOBILE, Ala., July 31 -- Representative Frank W. Boykin, Democrat representing the Mobile district, said today a "U. S. A. Recovery Plan" for the American lumber industry would be needed soon unless foreign lumber buying under the Marshall Plan is stopped.

Net income of the Commonwealth Edison Company, big Illinois utility concern, for the first half of 1949 was $16,288,958, equal to $1.19 a share, compared with $14,287,902, or $1.04 a share in the comparable 1948 period, it was reported yesterday.

I want to commend your editorial on the wise testimony of Jackie Robinson before a Congressional committee concerning Paul Robeson's statement on behalf of all Negroes that they would not fight in a war against Russia.
Small apartment buildings formed the bulk of properties passing to new control in Manhattan and Bronx deals reported over the week-end.
SHANGHAI, July 31 -- Former United States Navy employes, Chinese and Sikhs, agreed today to lift their siege of the United States Consulate, which they invaded Friday in an effort to force ...

DETROIT, July 31 -- A flat-bottom, twin-hull vessel of unconventional design, which utilizes the catamaran principle for maximum stability, has been constructed by Gar Wood after twenty-eight years of planning, it was announced here today.

Savings from the price cut on key worsted fabrics last week will not exceed $2 a suit at retail and this has already been reflected in men's fall suit prices by a number of manufacturers, according to the open letter sent to 5,000 retailers over the week-end by Jerome I. Udell, president of Max Udell Sons Co., Inc., maker of Gramercy Park Clothes.

One of the most attractive figures of English literature takes on a new and fascinating importance for Americans with the announcement from Yale University that it has acquired and will put to press, in collaboration with American scholars and publishers, the private papers of James Boswell.

NEWARK, N. J., July 31 (AP) -- Bud Heslet's home run with one out in the seventh inning gave the Newark Bears a 5-4 victory over the league-leading Buffalo Bisons today and a split on the day's work. The Herd won the opener 8 -- 2.

In a letter printed on this page today the question is raised of the effect on the employment situation of admitting displaced persons to this country. In a time of rising unemployment this question is to be expected, and it deserves a full answer. We believe that an examination of the facts will show that admission of DP's constitutes no threat to the American worker.
Citations for meritorious acts were awarded to 340 members of the Police Department yesterday by Commissioner WiIliam P. O'Brien.
SARATOGA SPRING, N. Y., July 31 -- The Saratoga Association will be open for business at the old home stand tomorrow.

HATTIESBURG, Miss., July 31 (AP) -- Howard M. Rinehart, 64 years old, who once was chief test pilot for Orville Wright, was found shot to death yesterday. A coroner's jury returned a verdict of suicide.
Patrolman William R. Lane shot and killed his estranged wife and a man whom he found with her yesterday in her father's apartment at 4313 Eighth Avenue, Brooklyn. Then he committed suicide.

Some Russian school children are allowed to learn English, dangerous though the language of Milton and Adam Smith. Keats and Winston Churchill, Jefferson. Thoreau and Abraham Lincoln, Shakespeare and Mark Twain. Bunyan, Whitman and Horatio Alger may be to their only partially fledged minds.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 31 -- Delegates representing the constituent unions of the Associated Actors and Artists of America, the AFL entertainers' international, heard arguments today by the Eastern talent unions designed to persuade the Screen Actors Guild to take part in a proposed television authority. This would administer the field of television acting.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (AP) -- The House today passed and sent to the Senate a bill putting a $10,000-a-year ceiling on pensions for Federal employes who are paid on a fee basis.
The Lighthouse of the New York Association for the Blind at 111 East Fifty-ninth Street will be expanded, modernized and streamlined at a cost of $1,000,000, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- In passing over the federal and state judiciary to find a nominee for the Supreme Court of the United States the President followed a growing custom. Of twenty-nine appointees to the high court since 1900 seventeen had no previous judicial experience and eleven served on the bench in varying degrees of time -- some very briefly.

BONN, Germany, Aug. 1 (UP) -- A high spokesman for the Christian Democratic Union said today that his party would refuse to enter any coalition with the Socialists after the Aug. 14 election as the result of Socialist leader Kurt Schumacher's denunciation of a pastoral letter read in Catholic churches yesterday.

More than 100 United States-flag tankers, or approximately one-fifth of the country's privately owned tanker fleet, are in laid-up status in various American ports, according to a survey made public yesterday by the American Merchant Marine Institute.

Just when the utility industry is almost constantly preoccupied with winning an understanding public and a sympathetic body of customers, the divestment provision of the Holding Company Act presents to it an opportunity that would appear to be more attractive than much of the effort now being expended.

OMAHA, Aug. 1 -- Eugene Stefan, 54 years old, immigrant cousin of Representative Karl Stefan, Republican, of Nebraska, today was the center of a strike that made idle more than 500 employes of the Omaha Steel Works.
New Yorkers, enjoying normal, comparatively comfortable Summer temperatures yesterday, could look back unregretfully upon July as the hottest month in the records of the local Weather Bureau.
The cotton market on the New York Cotton Exchange fluctuated within a narrow range yesterday and final prices were 2 to 8 points net lower.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Aug. 1 -- The 2,500 county employes of Westchester, whose cost-of-living bonuses were cut on July 1 by an escalator arrangement that had kept the payments rising in the years of inflation, told the county Board of Supervisors this afternoon that they would fight any continuance of the downward trend.

The Packard Motor Car Company reported yesterday a net income of $4,798,631, equal to 32 cents a common share, for the first six months of 1949, compared with $6,213,805, or 41 cents a share, in the first half of last year.
An exhibition of the art work of disabled former service men and women will be opened to the public today at the Art Students League, 215 West Fifty-seventh Street.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 1 (AP) -- Left-hander Warren Spahn pitched the Boston Braves to an 8-1 victory over St. Louis tonight that shaved the league-leading Cardinals' margin over Brooklyn to half a game. Ed Sauer slammed a three-run homer, and Bob Elliott hit one good for two runs.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (AP) -- John Maragon, who rose from bootblack to man-about-Washington, today denied any link with "5 percenters." But he said a Senate committee might have subpoenaed his bank accounts.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- The House moved quickly today to continue temporary appropriations as existing stop-gap authority expired with a half-dozen money measures that involve almost $27,500,000,000 in direct appropriations and billions more in contract authorizations awaiting action. The original deadlines were a month ago, or June 30, the end of the old fiscal year.

The Grand Central Terminal's lower level, used exclusively by commuters, is to be closed for an eight-hour period on Saturday nights, beginning at 11 o'clock, to curtail expenses, it was learned yesterday.

The actual construction of the First Avenue vehicular tunnel and rearrangement of public utilities in front of the United Nations development on the East Side will be performed under a carefully balanced thirteen-month schedule that has taken about two years to work out, Borough President Hugo E. Rogers of Manhattan said yesterday.

LONDON, Aug. 1 -- A band of modern Saxon invaders from Denmark, who rowed and sailed their open long boat more than 600 miles across the North Sea to reach England last Thursday, made an ignominious entry into London today in a green motor bus.

Six national Jewish organizations have expressed themselves in favor of Federal aid to public education but opposed to the use of Federal funds to support schools under religious control, it was announced yesterday.

LONDON, Aug. 1 -- Before its first tour of the United States and Canada, the Sadler's Wells Ballet Company opened a four-week season tonight at the Royal Opera House, Covent Garden, during which it will present all the ballets to be seen in the autumn in its engagement at the Metropolitan Opera House in New York.

Marcus Bach, author of "They Have Found a Faith" and "Report to Protestants," has a novel on Bobbs-Merrill's list for publication on Sept. 6. "The Dream Gate" is a story set in a Hutterite colony in South Dakota. The author, who studied religious groups on a Rockefeller fellowship, became interested in the Hutterites while doing research in attempts at a communistic living in the United States.
NASHVILLE, Ga., Aug 1 (AP) -- A South Georgia sheriff today told of coolly taking an unintimidated Negro from a mob bent on avenging the attempted rape of a housewife.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (UP) -- Senator Millard E. Tydings, Democrat, of Maryland, chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee, today introduced a bill to authorize the establishment of an Air Force academy comparable to the training installations at West Point and at Annapolis.

Sir Thomas Beecham will serve as the musical commentator in a series of transcribed programs to be launched by WQXR in the fall. The title of the disk jockey type of program is "Sir Thomas Beecham Turns the Tables."

Combined net assets of the ten Keystone Funds at market value on June 30 amounted to $165,657,1500 it was shown yesterday in the semi-annual reports of the Keystone Funds ]31 and K2. The number of shareholders of the ten funds had reached a new record of 51.828 at the end of June.

LONDON, Aug. 1 -- Sir Charles Reid, one of Britain's leading mining engineers, delivered a detailed indictment today of the National Coal Board, of which he formerly was a member, charging it with "inefficiency, frustration and loss of initiative" in its management of the nationalized coal mines.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Aug. 1 -- The first meeting of the editorial board to sift the mass of Boswell material acquired by Yale University will be held here Aug. 23, it was announced today.

SHANGHAI, Aug. 1 -- After a two-week delay caused by local Communist regulations for exit visas, United States Ambassador John Leighton Stuart is scheduled to leave China tomorrow for a report and consultation in Washington.

Coffee futures continued their advance, with Contract "S" showing gains of 7 to 32 points for a day of active trading on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. Prices on near-by delivery months were held in check because of profit-taking and trade hedging.

The release of many large building programs which have been deferred by nationally known corporations since the last Presidential election was predicted yesterday by Otto F. Sieder, executive vice president and general manager of the H. K. Ferguson Company, industrial engineering and building concern.

CHICAGO, Aug. 1 (AP) -- Miss Marlene Bauer of Los Angeles and Miss Barbara McIntire of Toledo both carded five-over-par 80's to share medal honors today in the eighteen-hole qualifying round of the women's Western Golf Association junior open championship.

DEAL, N. J., Aug. 1 -- Representing the Inwood Country Club, Mrs. Bernard Freeman fired a 77 gross score over the hilly, par-72, Deal golf course today to take a one-stroke lead in the first day's play of the three-day women's Metropolitan Golf tournament.

Your recent editorial dealing with the schism between those groups which affirm the right of individual conscience and those which deny it put the matter excellently. Your firm stand behind the principles that "deny the right of government or of any other force to coerce the private conscience" must certainly have met with enthusiastic approbation on the part of the great majority of your readers.

Reporting on the results of another six months of work in its delicate and desperately important field, the United States Atomic Energy Commission catches the eye with its assertion that today's atomic bombs are more effective than those used in the Second World War and that they are now being produced on an "industrial basis."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- The United States today for the second time invoked the peace treaties with Bulgaria, Rumania and Hungary in an effort to end the violations of human rights that have become prevalent in those countries since they came under Russian influence.
BUCHAREST, Rumania, Aug. 1 -- Rumania's Communist-led Government today gave all Roman Catholic welfare orders in the country until Aug. 15 to wind up their affairs.

The use of rubber in highway construction is likely to open large new fields for the consumption of both natural and synthetic rubber, it was declared yesterday in Akron by Harvey S. Firestone Jr., chairman of the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 1 (AP) -- Robert G. Braden, third secretary and vice consul of the United States Embassy in Belgrade died today. He was stricken with poliomyelitis three days ago.

A split of potentially major proportions developed yesterday within the Fusion movement. The two principal units backing the Morris-Uviller-Diserio ticket, which was named to oppose the present city administration headed by Mayor O'Dwyer, differed sharply and openly last night to the extent that there were threats that they would unite only on Newbold Morris for Mayor and run separate candidates for Controller and President of the City Council.

JERSEY CITY, N. J., Aug. 1 -- The strike of 400 longshoremen on Piers D and F of the American Export Lines, Exchange Place, entered its third week today as several hundred of the men, eager for work, showed up but went home again when the shape-up whistle was not blown.

As one who has been in contact with the mentally and physically ill for many years, may I add a few words in support of the letter by Herman Billings published recently in THE NEW YORK TIMES. He questions the psychological approach in campaigns for raising funds to fight disease.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Aug. 1 (UP) -- The British, seeking to break the American monopoly on atomic bomb manufacture, are bidding for one-fourth of the Belgian Congo uranium ore output, usually well-informed sources said today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- Guerrilla strength is at last on the decline in Greece and the possibility of the Greek Government collapsing is more remote than at any time since 1944, President Truman said today in a quarterly report to Congress on Greek and Turkish aid.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (AP) -- An East Liverpool, Ohio, pottery worker told a Congressional committee today he had been barred from holding a union office because he challenged a salary rise for international officers.

Strict disciplinary action against military or naval pilots who interfere with civilian aircraft in flight was demanded yesterday by Senator Edwin C. Johnson, Colorado Democrat, as a result of the mid-air collision Saturday in which sixteen persons lost their lives near Fort Dix, N. J.

CHICAGO, Aug. 1 -- Frank Frisch's cellar-groveling Cubs put on a sad exhibition of pitching and defense this afternoon. At the same time Leo Durocher's Giants continued the hitting spree begun last week and belted fourteen hits for a victory measured by 11 -- 3.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed a decline of 19 per cent in July, compared with the corresponding month last year, according to the survey made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES.
With the possible exception of Long Island, New York City's "mild epidemic" of poliomyelitis apparently has not spread into the suburbs, according to reports from county health officers yesterday.

A close balance between supplies and requirements promises stability in hides and skins for the remainder of this year, according to the report on raw materials and markets to be presented to the board of directors of the National Shoe Manufacturers Association at their meeting today at the Waldorf Astoria Hotel.

SHANGHAI, Aug. 1 -- The deadlocked labor dispute between former local employes of the United States Navy and the United States Consulate General, which led on Friday to the locking-in of three top-ranking consular officers, appeared nearer a solution today after both sides had accepted the good offices of the Shanghai General Labor Bureau as mediator.

A new playground will be opened at Amsterdam Houses, a housing project for 1,084 families bounded by West End and Amsterdam Avenues and Sixty-fourth and Sixty-first Streets, at 3 P. M. tomorrow, it was announced yesterday by the City Department of Parks.
Federal Judge Harold R. Medina called on the United States Marshal yesterday to make a defense lawyer sit down and stop interfering with the orderly administration of justice at the Communist trial.

NEW LONDON, Conn., Aug. 1 -- Clustered tonight in the harbor here were scores of craft, sail and motor, which had come for the rendezvous of the New York Yacht Club cruise. Steam palaces of old, which used to roam the seven seas were missing, as they have been since the first World War, but there were the present-day creations, most of them within a hundred feet.

In recent discussions of THE TIMES editorial "A Unified Transport Policy" the report on public aids to transportation issued under the name of the late Joseph B. Eastman, Federal Coordinator of Transportation, has been cited as authority for the statement that heavy commercial trucks on the highways pay more than their proper share of road and street costs.
SYRACUSE, N. Y., Aug. 1 -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey told the annual convention of the State Federation of Labor here today that an economic depression could be prevented
PITTSBURGH, Aug. 1 -- Forbes Field ought to be the favorite ball park of the Dodgers, and especially of Ralph Branca.

An airplane weighing 250 tons should be included in the prospects of the shape of things to come through the air, it was predicted yesterday by Glenn L. Martin. The veteran aircraft manufacturer spent the day in New York quietly celebrating by himself the fortieth anniversary of his first flight, which was made in a flimsy "pusher-plane" he made with his own hands.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (AP) -- Leaders of the pottery industry in Buffalo, N. Y., who are protesting competition from Puerto Rico, have been invited to Washington to talk things over with the Department of the Interior.

GENEVA, Aug. 1 -- A Polish family of displaced persons whose ten-year separation ended today with a reunion in Naples became the object of a bitter international dispute in today's session of the United Nations Economic and Social Council.

First reports for July business for industrial supply, metals and equipment distributors in the New York area show an increase in sales volume over June ranging from 10 to 15 per cent, spokesmen disclosed here yesterday. Only a few hardware wholesalers did not share in the upturn in durable goods wholesaling, according to a canvass of distributors.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- A loan of $12,500,000 was granted to Finland today by the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development. Eugene R. Black, president of the bank, said that it was the first loan to an "Eastern European country."

The sale of twenty-four surplus war-built merchant vessels in the three-month period ended June 30 brought the grand total of vessels sold under the terms of the Merchant Ship Sales Act of 1946 to 1,806, for a return to the Government of $1,731,000,000, according to the quarterly report of the Maritime Commission, as submitted to Congress by Maj. Gen. Philip B. Fleming, chairman.

LAKE SUCCESS, Aug. 1 -- The Commission for Conventional Armaments today approved a French proposal for an international census of the armed forces and armaments of members of the United Nations. The vote was 8 to 3, with the Soviet Union, the Ukraine and Egypt opposed.

Cornelius P. Kyrimes, 30-year-old former Navy pilot, saved himself from death yesterday by leaping from a disabled seaplane an instant before it crashed and burst into flames about 500 feet east of Flatbush Avenue, near the Belt Parkway, in Brooklyn. He suffered a possible leg fracture.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 1 -- Twenty-two recommendations on race relations, including the advice to city administrative officials that segregation in municipally operated public facilities was a violation of civil rights and contrary to law, were put before Mayor Joseph M. Darst today.

The Daily Mail of London has reprinted an article by your chief Washington correspondent summarizing the various critical attitudes in Congress toward the political policies of the United Kingdom and its serious financial condition. These criticisms are justified by the facts as I see them.
BOSTON, Aug. 1 (AP) -- The Red Sox turned back the Indians, 4 -- 3, as left-hander Mel Parnell pitched his fifteenth victory today before a surprising Monday turnout of 35,248 fans.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- LeRoy A. Lincoln, president of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, told a House "monopoly" investigating committee today that the large direct loans made by insurance companies to corporations constituted a logical development that benefits alike the borrower, the lender and the public which supplies the money.

Adding his voice to that of many other authorities on the subject, General Marshall has likewise impressed on Congress that the foreign military aid program is urgently necessary to bolster up Western defenses as the best available means of stopping Soviet aggression and averting war.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 1 -- Brookmeade Stable, winner of the last of the Saratoga-at Jamaica stakes with Chains on Saturday, took the first of the Saratoga Association's at-home features as the four-week session at the Spa opened today.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Aug. 1 -- The integration of the modest-sized Luxembourg Army and the internationally - restricted Italian military forces into the huge defense system envisioned by the North Atlantic pact was discussed today by representatives of those nations with the United States Joint Chiefs of Staff.

WARSAW, July. 25 -- The Polish merchant marine, which has been beset by a large number of accidents this year, is now offering premiums to captains and senior engineers who maintain safety records. Special cash bonuses will be given to captains or senior engineers whose ships suffer no accidents or encounter demurrage charges during a six-month period.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 1 -- Borba, official newspaper of the Yugoslav Communist party, named Pavel Nikolayevitch Eliseyev, second secretary of the Soviet Embassy in Belgrade, today as head of the Soviet Communist Information Bureau espionage service in Yugoslavia.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Aug. 1 -- Officially speaking Czechoslovakia does not dislike the American people but detests United States Government policy. Certainly an American is kindly treated both by the man in the street and state officials.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Aug. 1 -- Foreign Minister Moshe Sharett told the Knesset (Assembly) tonight that the Israeli delegation to the United Nations Palestine Conciliation Commission meeting at Lausanne, Switzerland, had been instructed to define the country's contribution toward a solution of the Arab refugee problem through resettlement if peace were achieved and the Arab countries made appropriate contributions.
BOSTON, Aug. 1 -- Gov. Paul A. Dever of Massachusetts signed into law today a bill barring Communists from holding jobs on public payrolls in Massachusetts.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- President Truman and his party leaders on Capitol Hill agreed today that Congress should stay in session until "a number of constructive bilils" had been acted on. The prospect was for at least another month of legislative work.

The appointment of Sidney Jones as manager of Cunard White Star Line's Park Avenue office was announced yesterday by Harold P. Borer, general manager of the company in the United States. Mr. Jones succeeds Charles H. Fecke, who will continue to serve the line as special passenger representative.

TOKYO, Aug. 1 -- Japanese police with an impressive display of strength today raided Tokyo headquarters of the Japan Communist party and departed with an armload of papers alleged to be evidence that the Communist press had been used to forge official Government documents.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- President Truman declared today that Americans and all who rely upon the strength of the United States "have reason for reassurance and faith" in the progress this nation has made in the development of atomic energy.
DETROIT, Aug. 1 -- Discovery of a shortwave radio broadcasting station built into an automobile has disclosed a plot of Eastern gamblers to swindle bookies, Detroit police said today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- The United Mine Workers' Welfare and Retirement Fund pays two of its trustees, Senator Styles Bridges, Republican, of New Hampshire, and Ezra Van Horn, Ohio coal operator, $35,000 a year each, the Senate Banking and Currency Committee learned today.

A motion to dismiss the Long Island Rail Road's petition for a 16 2/3 per cent passenger fare increase was entered yesterday by Philip Hodes, Public Service Commission counsel, as hearings were resumed at the commission's offices at 233 Broadway.

NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 1 -- The Indian Socialist party, which has been attacking the Congress party recently on the grounds that the Congress Government and the new national constitution fail to guarantee civil liberties, may embark on a passive resistance movement to "prevent the growth of fascism," Jai Praksh Narain, Wisconsin-educated president of the Socialist party, told the meeting at Patna last night, according to a dispatch from there.
HONG KONG, Aug. 1 (UP) -- Communist armies in South Central China were reported maneuvering to step up their drive on Canton and big successes were said to have been scored in Northwest China.

The whacking of crowbars this morning against a four-story red brick tenement at 142 Macdougal Street will signalize the demolition of a 120-year-old residential Washington Square block that by the fall of 1950 will contain New York University's elaborate Law Center.
CAMDEN, N. J., Aug. 1 -- Tomatoes by the truckload have begun rolling up to canneries in this area about ten days ahead of schedule.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Aug. 1 -- A Syrian decree empowering the Ministry of Defense to requisition sections of the population for roadbuilding and other construction of importance to national defense, and last night's grant of the equivalent of $7,000,000 more to the Army, are regarded authoritatively as proof of the seriousness of the informal Egyptian-Syrian defense agreement.

TUCKAHOE, N. Y., Aug. 1 -- Charley Pucillo, veteran public links performer and caretaker of Memorial Park in Mount Vernon, arched a shot 2 feet 4 inches from the pin to take the lead in the opening session of the sixteenth annual World-Telegram hole-in-one competition today at the Leewood Golf Club.

ROME, Aug. 1 -- The existence of considerable quantities of oil in the subsoil of the Po Valley was confirmed by Minister of Finance Ezio Vanoni to the National Council of the Christian Democratic party in Fiuggi today.

What is believed the first joint advertising campaign to sell exporters on advantages of having their ocean freight packing done by specialist companies at the Port of New York will be started next month under auspices of the Export Packaging Association of New York, Inc., it was learned yesterday.

BUFFALO, Aug. 1 -- Although the cost of distributing grocery products at wholesale and retail is now the lowest it has ever been, social planners have dug up the old bugaboo about "distribution costing too much," and are using it in their attacks upon business, it was charged here today by Thomas V. Guerdat, president of the New York State Food Merchants Association.

SYDNEY, Australia, Tuesday, Aug. 2 (AP) -- Australian troops began working nine open cut coal mines in New South Wales today to dig the first coal in Australia since 24,000 miners walked out five weeks ago.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (AP) -- The Senate voted $63,054,424 today to meet administrative costs of the Maritime Commission after turning down a demand by Senator John J. Williams, Republican, of Delaware, that this amount be cut $3,152,721.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 1 -- Officials of the Matson Navigation Company grappled most of the day with the question whether to try resumption of cargo shipments to strikebound Hawaii, in line with a plan announced last Friday. No decision had been reached tonight.

The Creole Petroleum Corporation earned $51,500,000 after taxes and all charges in the first six months of this year, compared with $100,020,000 in the corresponding period of 1948, according to the unaudited figures announced yesterday by A. T. Proudfit, president.

That retailers do not have the discounts that were traditionally theirs in many classes of merchandise is shown in the second annual discount survey by the vendor relations committee of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, released yesterday.
The national amateur golf championship at Rochester, N. Y., will have a distinct international flavor with nine United States and British champions, past and present, competing.

A years' effort by the American Jewish Committee, the World Council of Churches and the International Red Cross has resulted in the freeing of fifty prominent Egyptian Jews who had been interned for "security reasons" by the Egyptian Government in May, 1948, it was announced yesterday by the committee. The Jews had been interned at El Tor on the Red Sea at the time the State of Israel was constituted.

The Port of New York Authority asked the Interstate Commerce Commission yesterday to force the railroads to comply at once with a ruling that a complete set of rail competitive freight rates to and from the docks at Edgewater, N. J., be maintained by the rail carriers serving New York Harbor.

VIENNA, Aug. 1 -- Erwin Scharf, head of the extreme left-wing Progressive Socialists, announced today that his party had decided to present joint lists of candidates with the Communists in the Oct. 9 elections.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- President Truman casually walked out of the White House executive offices this afternoon and announced to waiting reporters that Attorney General Tom C. Clark had accepted appointment as an associate justice on the United States Supreme Court and Senator J. Howard McGrath had agreed to become Attorney General.

The Chicago, Ill., Sanitary District announced yesterday that it will receive bids on Aug. 18 on $8,300,000 of construction bonds, series 14, dated Sept. 1, 1949, due on Jan. 1, 1969, and callable from 1962 to 1968.

CHICAGO, Aug. 1 (AP) -- Colosal, 6-year-old importation owned by Fred W. Hooper of Montgomery, Ala., came back to his favorite race track, Washington Park, today, to score a clear-cut triumph in the $23,550 Clang Handicap.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- The Truman Administration will move soon to placate the Republican opposition to the present form of its program for foreign military aid, but intends to stand firm for the full $1,450,000,000 authorization that it has asked.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 1 -- The television convention of the Associated Actors and Artists of America, AFL, reconvened this afternoon for its third session to discuss variations on a proposed plan for a television authority to administer the video field and bargain collectively for actors and performers in the new medium.

MYSTIC, Conn., Aug. 1 (AP) -- More than 700 members attended the twentieth annual meeting of the Marine Historical Association here today. They witnessed the dedication of the old New York Yacht Club Station 10 building as a part of the marine museum, devoted to whaling memorabilia, and two other buildings.

OYSTER BAY, L. I., Aug. 1 -- Arthur Menger, who retired in July from the Long Island Rail Road after forty-six years, will devote the next few years to preaching the gospel, he said today at his home, 57 Simcoe Street.

CHICAGO, Aug. 1 -- Grain markets were unsettled on the Board of Trade today, an early upturn being lost in wheat because of scattered selling and the failure of the Government to announce the subsidy that would be paid on wheat and flour. Closing trades were 1/8 to 1/2-cent lower.
A few new pieces are included with the familiar favorites from Knoll Associates in the collection of furniture by that concern now available at McCreery's.

Plans are being advanced here for a "freedom ship" that will tour the Western Hemisphere exhibiting industrial, cultural and scientific accomplishments of all freedom-loving nations of the Americas, it was learned yesterday.

DETROIT, Aug. 1 (AP) -- A thirty-foot California speedboat streaked around the Detroit River Harmsworth course today to capture the historic British international trophy for the Lake Tahoe, Calif., Yacht Club.

Col. Robert R. McCormick, president and publisher of The Chicago Tribune, announced here yesterday that he would place his niece, Mrs. Maxwell Peter Miller Jr., in charge of The Washington Times-Herald, his most recently acquired publishing property.

Lexington and Eighth Avenues got "facials" yesterday. Down each thoroughfare at 11 A. M. the Department of Sanitation sent a shiny black 1 1/4-ton truck carrying a two-man team equipped with brushes and baskets, brooms and burlap bags.

SHANGHAI, Aug. 1 -- The first official Chinese "Red Army Day" was celebrated here today on the heels of a speech by Gen. Chen Yi in which the Communist commander of the Shanghai area declared that the party led by the People's Liberation Army expected to conquer all of China "within this year."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- Forty-nine Senators -- twenty-three Democrats and twenty-six Republicans -- today protested to President Truman the recent treaty with Canada opening the New York-Montreal air route to Canadian operation in competition with Colonial Airlines, Inc., which has flown the route for nineteen years.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- The Northern Indiana Public Service Company, Hammond, Ind., today filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering 311,654 shares of its no par value common stock.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed a decline of 14 per cent last week in comparison with the corresponding period last year, according to the "flash" report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

Lola Albright will play the leading role opposite Willard Parker in Columbia's "Strangehold." . . . Fred Clark has joined the cast of "The Eagle and the Hawk" at Paramount, and that studio's "Where Men Are Men" has acquired Fred Sweeney and Kit Guard.

RICHMOND, Va., Aug. 1 -- Senator Harry F. Byrd, Democrat, of Virginia, denounced as "a lie" today the report that a source close to him had offered $10,000 to be used against one of the four Democrats running in tomorrow's Gubernatorial primary.
Alexander Bittelman Communist leader who is reputed to be responsible for interpreting the party line handed down by Moscow, will take the stand on his own defense at his next deportation hearing.

BATAVIA, Java, Aug. 1 (UP) -- Dutch and Indonesian leaders hailed a cease-fire agreement sighed here today as the forerunner to a final settlement in the four-year-old conflict in Indonesia. The cease-fire becomes effective at 7:30 P. M. local time (8:30 A. M. Eastern Daylight Time) Wednesday, Aug. 3.

Wool jersey has blossomed into a leading fashion fabric. Once relegated to the simple blouse or inconspicuous little basic dress, it is soon .to be the fabric darling for all age groups in fall costumes by almost every leading, designer.

PARIS, Aug. 1 -- The United States Joint Chiefs of Staff are expected to reach Paris Thursday night. Here they will meet Field Marshal Viscount Montgomery, chairman of the Commanders-in-Chief Committee of the Western Union powers; Gen. Jean de Lattre de Tassigny, Commander-in-Chief of the Western Union ground forces; Lieut. Gen. Georges Revers, French Chief of Staff, and Belgian and Netherlands military leaders.

GOTEBERG, Sweden, Aug. 1 (AP) -- Craig Dixon of U. C. L. A., who this spring equaled the world record for the 220-yard low hurdles, won the 110-meter hurdles today in a dual meet of United States and Swedish track forces. Dixon's time was 0:14.3.

IN the year 1504, when he had not yet reached his twenty-ninth birthday, Cesare Borgia, Duke of Valentinois and Romagna, Gonfalonier and Captain-General of Holy Church, former Cardinal and Archbishop of Valencia, was incarcerated in the Castle of San Angelo in Rome. The extraordinary son of Rodrigo Borgia, Pope Alexander VI, was the prisoner of Pope Julius II, a lifelong enemy of the Borgia family.
Actors in an off-Broadway play about the Scottsboro case protested to Acting Mayor Vincent Impellitteri yesterday that several members of the cast had been beaten by West Side "hoodlums."

SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., Aug. 1 -- The Eastern grass court championships started today at the Orange Lawn Tennis Club with most of the ranking men and women players of the country in the list, as well as representatives of Australia, South Africa, the Philippines and India.

MONMOUTH PARK, N. J., Aug. 1 (AP) -- With New York racing at up-state Saratoga Springs, many metropolitan racegoers journeyed to this course for the thoroughbred sport, with the result that the attendance reached near Saturday proportions, a total of 17,566 fans being on hand.

The Maritime Commission and the Department of Agriculture are half way through the port's grain preservation program and have loaded six freighters with surplus grain for storage, it was announced yesterday.
PARIS, Aug. 1 -- Madame Legroux adopts height in hats of expert craftsmanship, displaying a sculptor's concern for line and balance.

The Federal regulations governing 1949 open seasons for migratory waterfowl were announced last week, but because of their national nature were treated from Washington in a general way and omitted an important detail -- the dates.
PHOENIX, Ariz., Aug. 1 (AP) -- Mrs. Anna Roosevelt Boettiger, daughter of the late President Roosevelt, today received a divorce from John Boettiger.

BATAVIA, Java, Tuesday, Aug. 2 (AP) -- Indonesian Republicans and non-Republican Federalists were reported today to have reached agreement on the structure of the forthcoming United States of Indonesia and a union with the Netherlands.

New York State's Department of Insurance will seek further clarification of a recent ruling classifying certain types of service contracts on television receivers as illegal insurance, it was learned yesterday.

Trustees of the Third Avenue Transit Corporation, which serves 1,800,000 persons a day in Manhattan, the Bronx and Westchester, asked Federal Judge Samuel H. Kaufman yesterday for authorization to put an eight-cent fare into effect immediately.

Consolidated net earnings of the American Viscose Corporation for the six months ended with June declined to $7,682,000 or $3.47 a common share from the $15,629,000 or $7.35 a share earned in the initial half of last year, according to the report issued yesterday.

Billy Rose advocated yesterday a return to the old "buy" system of theatre ticket allotments to brokers, and declared he would resign from the League of New York Theatres if that organization sought to prevent such a method of seat distribution.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Aug. 1 -- John J. McCloy, United States High Commissioner-designate, outlined today to leading members of the present United States Military Government staff his plan for organization of his staff when the West German Government is established and the Allied High Commission begins to function.

The thirty-eight tenants of a nine-story apartment house at 11 West Sixty-ninth Street have organized to protest a ruling of the Office of Housing Expediter that would increase their rent by 37 per cent, it was learned yesterday.

The sixth semi-annual report to Congress by the Atomic Energy Commission, informing the American people and the world that we are now producing the improved Eniwetok model of the atomic bomb on an industrial basis, must be viewed from the perspective of the already known effects of the Hiroshima and Nagasaki models of the bomb, if certain misconceptions are to be avoided.

The defense opened the thirty-fourth day of the "lonely hearts" trial in Bronx County Court yesterday with two attempts to show that Mrs. Martha Jule Beck, accused with Raymond M. Fernandez of the bludgeon murder of Mrs. Janet J. Fay, was mentally unbalanced at times.

Several lessons can be quickly read in the balance sheet of the New York City transit system for the first full year under the ten and seven cent fares. One is that the seven-cent fare for a surface ride is too low. Another is that it takes a long time to recover lost ground when transit wages are raised before anybody knows where the money is coming from to pay those higher wages.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 1 -- Collier Young, former executive of Warner Brothers and Columbia, and Ida Lupino (Mrs. Young) have formed a new independent film company which will produce as its first venture "Never Fear," a documentary photoplay about infantile paralysis written by Young and Miss Lupino.
SCARSDALE, N. Y., Aug. 1 -- Two teams tied for low gross honors in the first Westchester P. G. A. pro-lady all-day tournament over the Sunningdale Country Club course today.

The stock market returned yesterday to the recovery side after its inconclusive performance during the greater part of last week. Stocks needed only to creep fractions higher, however, to reclaim the ground surrendered since last Tuesday, and the composite rate showed a rise of 0.47 point on the day.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- The International Wheat Agreement became effective today, with Government subsidies for the first day's trading well below advance estimates.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 1 -- Reversing a previous decision, trustees of the War Memorial Opera House tonight voted, 6 to 5, to permit Kirsten Flagstad, Wagnerian soprano, to sing in the opera house and thus saved San Francisco's 1949 opera season, scheduled to open on Sept. 20.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (AP) -- Bob Dillinger pounded out three hits in four attempts tonight to lead the St. Louis Browns to a 2-to-0 victory over Washington, behind Karl Drews' eight-hit pitching.

Earnings of the Willys-Overland Motors, Inc., were reduced to $191,573 in the quarter ended with June from the $2,019,029 net profit realized in the corresponding three months of last year as a result of a strike in the plant of a key supplier and changes in production plans, which curtailed output in April and May, the report disclosed yesterday.

VALLEY, Neb., Aug. 1 (AP) -- Two youths were killed and the president of the National Association of Real Estate Boards, T. H. Maenner of Omaha, was injured today in a head-on auto collision near here. Three other persons also were hurt.

With seventy-eight teams competing and some of the district's top-notch pros and amateurs forming the personnel, the Glen Oaks team of Oscar Zinn and Pete Burke won the Long Island P.G.A. amateur-pro tourney over the Pomonok Country Club course, yesterday by a margin of one stroke.

BERLIN, Aug. 1 -- Brig. Gen. Frank L. Howley announced today that he had officially requested to be relieved of his position as United States Commandant in Berlin. It was indicated here that his successor would be Maj. Gen. Maxwell D. Taylor, wartime commander of the 101st Airborne Division and former commandant of West Point.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (UP) -- The Congressional joint committee on atomic energy today neared the end of its investigation of Senator Hickenlooper's charges against the Atomic Energy Commission. It met in closed session with Mr. Lilienthal to study the records of thirty-two AEC employes.

The Administration, as the Washington Bureau of this newspaper reports, "has no intention" of sponsoring legislation before this session of Congress for the repeal of the wartime increases in federal excise taxes. The loss in revenue entailed, its financial experts believe, cannot be faced at this time.

The New York Philharmonic-Symphony began the seventh and next to last week of its summer season last night at the Lewisohn Stadium. The conductor was Efrem Kurtz, who returned to the outdoor ampitheatre after a two-year absence.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (AP) -- Heavy purchases of American wheat, and of industrial metals and hides and skins from Latin America, were approved today in $13,628,000 worth of new European recovery spending. The Economic Cooperation Administration announced the latest Marshall Plan grants to five European countries and Western Germany.

ROME, Aug. 1 -- The signing of the Italian-Yugoslav commercial agreement, which the Italian Government had postponed indefinitely in protest against Belgrade's recent decision to replace lira with dinar as legal tender in Zone B of the Free Territory of Trieste, was expected shortly, well-informed Italian circles said today.

Insurance protection for widows of employes in the steel industry was characterized as "substandard" yesterday by Murray W. Latimer, insurance consultant, who testified as a witness for the United Steelworkers of America, CIO, before the Presidential fact-finding board in the Federal Court House.

The pattern of Soviet policy in the Far East is again emerging with the announcement that the Soviet Union has concluded a trade pact with the "Manchurian People's democratic authorities." Manchuria has been the focus of Russian interest in East Asia for more than fifty years.

LONDON, Aug. 1 (Reuters) -- Trevor Bailey, the England and Essex all-rounder, today took five Worcester wickets to become the first cricket player this season to complete the double of 100 wickets and 1,000 runs.

DETROIT, Aug. 1 -- Business and employment conditions in Detroit are on a generally sound basis, Secretary of Commerce Charles Sawyer said today after a day of meetings with representatives of labor, small business and industry.

The Columbia Gas System, Inc., announced yesterday that the Federal Power Commission had approved its request to construct a 26-inch gas pipeline from West Virginia to Rockville, Md., for the transmission of 30,000,000 cubic feet of natural gas daily.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- A request that the public meet the current upswing in poliomyelitis with a calm and informed attitude was made today in a joint statement by Basil O'Connor, president of both the American Red Cross and the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis, and Dr. Leonard A. Scheele, Surgeon General of the Public Health Service.
Executives of businesses with successful profit-sharing plans are overwhelmingly enthusiastic about their benefits to both company and worker, a survey of company experience with such plans shows.

As a result of the drought, this year's pack of frozen produce verges on being short. But undersupplies, particularly of peas and strawberries, will not show up until next winter. Nor are they likely to push up prices. These should even decrease a bit, reflecting lower costs of packers and adjusted margins at wholesale.

Three times yesterday residents of Borough Park blockaded auto traffic at the intersection of Fifty-eighth Street and Nineteenth Avenue, Brooklyn. The action was taken as the result of a collision at 2 P. M. between a truck and a private car.

The coming of deficit financing foreshadows a restriction in the Treasury's post-war use of the War Loan Account system to promote balance in the money market, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York asserted in its monthly review of credit and business conditions, published yesterday.

HARTFORD, Conn., Aug. 1 -- Connecticut's mixed-up minor courts, which have had two judges for every bench, were straightened out today by the State Supreme Court of Errors. The court ruled unanimously that judges appointed by Gov. Chester Bowles were legally entitled to their posts.

GREAT RIVER, L. I., Aug. 1 -- A treacherous wind, which blew from a southerly direction and shifted suddenly just as the first gun was ready to sound, resulted in a ten-minute postponement today of the opening sail of the annual Race Week, sponsored by the Great South Bay Yacht Racing Association off Timber Point.

BERLIN, Aug. 1 (UP) -- A Soviet zone audience broke into cheers today when Thomas Mann, Nobel Prize winning German author, said that in the present world crisis, "the freedom and dignity of the individual must be kept sacred."

BERLIN, Aug. 1 (UP) -- A Soviet zone audience broke into cheers today when Thomas Mann, Nobel Prize winning German author, said that in the present world crisis, "the freedom and dignity of the individual must be kept sacred."

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 2 -- Stewart Granger, British film star, has been signed by M-G-M to play opposite Deborah Kerr in "King Solomon's Mines," which will go before the cameras on location in British East Africa in October. Granger, who was signed in London, will report to the "King Solomon" company in Africa in mid-October and then will come to Hollywood for interior sequences for the film.

Out-of-town buyers registered in the New York market for the week ended yesterday numbered 1,464, compared with 1,484 last week and 1,118 in the similar week a year ago, according to the listings appearing in THE NEW YORK TIMES.

LAKE SUCCESS, Aug. 2 -- Aubrey S. Eban, Israeli representative to the United Nations, today requested permission to take part in the discussion of the final report of Dr. Ralph J. Bunche, Acting Mediator for Palestine, when the Security Council meets Thursday. Mr. Eban has spoken frequently during previous Council debates on Palestine, but this will be his first appearance since Israel was admitted to the United Nations last spring.

American casualness and the dash of Paris were teamed happily at Russeks yesterday in a back - to - college showing majoring in such topnotch favorites as corduroys, velveteens and jerseys. The clothes were youthful, with an awareness of high style that made them doubly attractive.

Bicycles, tricycles, scooters, skates and even baby carriages figured yesterday in the eleventh annual "Anything on Wheels" Derby sponsored by the Children's Aid Society at Sloane Center, 630 East Sixth Street. Sidewalks were well lined with rooters as the "jockeys" pushed past the center between Avenues B and C. Neighbors leaned from windows and hung on fire escapes to cheer the 125 contestants.

GRAFENWOEHR, Germany, Aug. 2 -- United States Occupation Army and Air Forces supported by a token company of sailors on behalf of the Navy put on today the mightiest American military display in Europe since the end of the war in honor of the visiting Joint Chiefs of Staff.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 2 -- In a speech today to 350,000 Macedonians in Skoplje, capital of the Macedonian Republic of Yugoslavia, Premier Tito asserted that the time would come when the proCominform rulers of Bulgaria and Albania would be swept out of office and the peoples of Yugoslavia, Bulgaria and Albania would once again resume close collaboration. Marshal Tito spoke at a ceremony commemorating the fifth anniversary of the founding of the Macedonian People's Republic.

Three succinct and lucid exhibitions, typical of those which the Museum of Modern Art circulates to colleges, clubs, museums and other institutions throughout the country, will go on view today in the museum's auditorium gallery for a pre-tour showing.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (AP) -The Indians pounded Mickey Harris and Al Gettel of the Senators for fifteen hits and an 8-1 victory tonight. Early Wynn scattered nine hits to annex his ninth triumph against two defeats.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., Aug. 2 -- The State Federation of Labor barred four delegates from its annual convention here today because of alleged left-wing ties and for the first time made known the details of its own loyalty code.

A police plane, a police launch and a Coast Guard PBY aircraft had to be sent to the surf about a half mile off Beach 120th Street, Rockaway Beach, at 6:30 P. M. yesterday, to persuade two young men on a rubber raft to come ashore.
RUMSON, N. J., Aug. 2 -- A slight drizzle met the field of seventy at the Rumson golf course today for the second round of the women's Metropolitan Golf Association's annual tournament.
BOSTON, Aug. 2 (AP) -- A suggestion that production in New England may be nosing upward was offered today in two separate surveys.
A downpour of rain at 3 P. M. yesterday failed to dampen the enthusiasm of 500 children awaiting the opening of the new Dean Street playground in Brooklyn.
DALLAS, Tex., Aug. 2 (AP) -- Texans today dropped five of the sixteen national skeet titles they held.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (AP) -- W. Ray Bell, New York City, president of the Association of Cotton Textile Merchants, said today proposed labeling of cotton products "would more likely be harmful than helpful in sale and distribution of cotton textiles."

The President's latest report on the progress of the war in Greece furnishes a timely commentary on the Senate hearings on the foreign military aid program. Greece is one country to which American military help has been extended. It was given gingerly and meagerly at first, for here, as in Western Europe, it was thought that economic assistance would be enough to win the battle for independence.

SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., Aug. 2 -- The Eastern turf court championships, in progress at the Orange Lawn Tennis Club, got into full swing today, with the members of the Australian Davis Cup team and Frank Parker arriving on the scene and Earl Cochell checking in after his flight from Europe.

At least 58 per cent of the $42,000,000,000 expenditure proposed by President Truman in his January budget message for the current fiscal year is for all practical purposes untouchable in any budget-balancing efforts, the Institute of Life Insurance reported yesterday.
The Jesuit weekly America, in an editorial in the Aug. 6 issue, declares that it wishes to "moderate" its earlier criticism of the book, "God's Underground."
PARIS, Aug. 2 -- Fashions for fall will be presented beginning tomorrow despite unfinished collections and the continuing strike of an estimated 10,000 organized midinettes or seamstresses.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- Industry is not moving into the South because it is looking for cheap labor but as a result of finding good markets, available materials and a good labor supply in that region, the National Planning Association's Committee of the South reported today.

SHANGHAI, Aug. 2 -- As the Chinese Communists opened an attack on the escape of the British warship Amethyst from the Yangtze, another British ship sailed up the river today and became the first foreign vessel to break the Nationalist blockade.

In naming the recipient yesterday of this year's Sidney Howard Memorial Award, the purpose of which is to encourage the development of new playwriting talent, the Playwrights Company took an unprecedented step. Instead of turning over $1,500 as had been the custom, the sum of $3,000, covering this year and next, was allocated to the Dramatists Guild.

LONDON, Aug. 2 -- The main points from Hardy Amie's collection are envelope skirts, an uplift movement on jackets and bodices contrived by means of shaped seams, high stand-up collars and wide revers, a less exaggerated and slightly lower waistline.

A young Chinese artist, a newcomer to New York, has the distinction of bringing the first public art exhibition to Chinatown. The show opens today at 4:30 P. M. at the Lin Sing Association, 47 Mott Street, with ceremonies in which P. C. Chang, Chinese Consul General in New York, and community leaders will take part.

LAKE SUCCESS, Aug. 2 -- Secretary General Trygve Lie today backed up the actions of United Nations staff members, who have vigorously denounced charges made recently before a Senate subcommittee alleging that employes of the world organization were "terrorized" by Communist agents.

Although fifty-seven new cases of poliomyelitis were reported yesterday by the Department of Health, officials emphasized that this does not mean a sudden increase in the polio incidence for this area.

OCEANPORT, N. J., Aug. 2 (AP) -- Michael Belasco's Easy Chance won his seventh race this year when he triumphed easily today in the mile-and-a-sixteenth Deal Purse feature event at Monmouth Park. Janet N. Kelly's Kel's Love was second, two lengths behind the winner and well in advance of Edward Hilles' Napango.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- Samuel Wahrhaftig, who served as a political analyst with the Army in Germany, today won complete exoneration of charges that resulted in his dismissal seven months ago.

Railway management should counter new truck competition "aggressively and openly," Robert R. Young, chairman of the Federation for Railway Progress, says in an article in the August issue of that organization's publication.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 2 (AP) -- A Federal jury heard transcriptions of "Tokyo Rose" wartime broadcasts today as the Government continued its prosecution of Mrs. Iva Toguri D'Aquino on treason charges.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Aug. 2 -- At the request of exiled King Leopold two six-member delegations of the Christian Social party and the Liberal party left for Switzerland today to lay before him their separate views on the question of the percentage of a plebiscite vote necessary to warrant his return to the throne.

An exhibit continuing to Aug. 19 on the Bourges system of preparing art work for reproduction was opened yesterday at the gallery of Arthur Brown Brother, art materials store, 2 West Forty-sixth Street. The system, originated by Albert Bourges, veteran photo engraver, employs Colotone and Solotone plastic sheets for achieving a variety of color, black and white tone effects in engraving reproductions of drawings and photos.

Freedoms Foundation, Inc., organized two months ago to preserve and extend the American way of life, announced yesterday an increase in annual awards to $84,000 to those Americans who advance that cause.
SYDNEY, Australia, Aug. 2 (AP) -- Two hundred police clashed with 1,000 demonstrating wharf laborers in Sydney streets today. Twelve men were arrested.

The manner in which unconventional colors in table cloths and place mats may be used as an effective background for patterned and plain dinnerware was demonstrated in an exhibition of seven table settings at the Commodore Hotel yesterday.

Imports from the United States by Uruguay will depend in great measure upon the success Uruguay has in marketing its wool in this country, John P. Hoover, first secretary of the United States Embassy at Montevideo said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- Secretary of State Dean Acheson rejected today Soviet allegations that Italy's participation in the North Atlantic pact was a violation of the Italian peace treaty. The charges had been made in a Soviet note dated July 19.
Sales of television receivers will jump as much as 50 per cent as the result of producers entering the low-price competitive market, Irving Sarnoff predicted yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- Several hundred of the capital's leading personalities attended an unusual feast given tonight in honor of Speaker Sam Rayburn by Representative Frank W. Boykin of Mobile, Ala.

On July 26 your paper carried an A. P. story on page 10 with a Washington dateline about a so-called "will" in a "manila envelope" "which was ultimately placed" in my hands by Joseph Bernstein. As the story was full of innuendo and mystification, I think it is only fair that the actual events, which are a matter of record, should be correctly presented.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., Aug. 2 -Miss Patricia Bancker sailed the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club entry to a slim lead in the annual Syce Cup series for the women's sailing championship of Long Island Sound as the first two races of the scheduled nine were staged off Larchmont Yacht Club today.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Aug. 2--Part of the old city of Beersheba will be flooded as a 500-acre water reservoir for the projected new Negeb city on the heights overlooking Beersheba, under a Government plan. The reservoir would be formed by damming the Wadi Saba, rocky watercourse through which 10,000,000 cubic meters of rainwater sweep into the Mediterranean every winter.

Another broadbill has been taken off Montauk, Mickey McCann of the Montauk Yacht Club wired yesterday that a man from Missouri who wanted to be shown, C. Lee Wadon of Richmond Heights, was convinced when he boated one that weighed 359 1/2 pounds.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- The Reconstruction Finance Corporation "is not doing a damn thing" to collect an $80,000,000 loan made to the Baltimore Ohio Railroad over ten years ago, Senator Charles W. Tobey, Republican, of New Hampshire, declared today.

A dapper ex-convict was arrested by Secret Service agents yesterday as the alleged East Coast distributor for a gang of Chicago counterfeiters that has flooded the country with more than $1,000,000 in bogus currency in the last year.
Italian-speaking Roman Catholic parishes here are understaffed, Cardinal Spellman declared yesterday when he received nineteen young Italian priests who will serve in the New York Archdiocese.

The average pension paid by the United States Steel Corporation to its retired production employes is $9.35 a month, Murray W. Latimer, an insurance consultant, testified yesterday before the Presidential fact-finding board for the steel industry.
No action was taken yesterday by the directors of Collins Aikman Corporation on the common dividend usually declared at this time. The company previously paid 25 cents a share at quarterly intervals.
CINCINNATI, Aug. 2 (AP) -- The Reds, who couldn't score one run in eighteen innings Sunday, exploded with base hits tonight to crush the Phillies, 11 to 3.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 2 -- The Fairmount Park Art Association has purchased seven works from its third sculpture international, now being held at the Philadelphia Museum of Art, Sydney E. Martin, the president, announced today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- Congress today unanimously approved a resolution extending greetings to former President Herbert Clark Hoover on his seventy-fifth birthday anniversary, Aug. 10.

Strength in coffee futures yesterday again featured the day's trading on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. New seasonal high prices were established in all the active delivery months in both coffee contracts. A new high price was recorded in futures when the spot September "S" contract sold at 28.51 cents a pound.

CHICAGO, Aug. 2 -- In their aimless wanderings about the cellar depths of the National League the Cubs struck a new low for the regime of Frankie Frisch today on Wrigley Field, before 11,103 of the club's die-hard followers.

NEWPORT, R. I., Aug. 2 -Strong head winds, dense fog and rain made late and rough going today on the first run of the New York Yacht Club cruise, that of thirty-seven and one-half miles here from New London, Conn.
LONDON, Aug. 2 (Reuters) -Relaxation of the London Stock Exchange's rule governing securities quoted on overseas stock exchanges was announced today.

Although disappointed at the White House statement opposing any reduction of excise taxes during this session of Congress, cosmetics and toiletries industry members are still hopeful of action on a bill to lift the 20 per cent retail levy on many of their products, it was learned yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (AP) -- Housing Expediter Tighe E. Woods today said two race tracks got construction permits from his agency not because of influence but because post-war building controls were a "farce."

WHEN General Ronca led his Democratic-Republican revolution with the slogan "the land to those who till it," a flame of hope burned brightly all across the land, in the jungles by the Caribbean, in the mountains of the interior, on the shores of the Pacific. The villagers turned out with enthusiasm to kill the senors in their haciendas.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- A young Navy pilot who faced an attack of polio as courageously as he might have met any other enemy was buried with honors today in Arlington National Cemetery. Lieut (jg) James Olin Chiles of Lakeland, Fla., a pilot at the Anacostia Naval Air Station here, died last Thursday at the Bethesda Naval Hospital of bulbar poliomyelitis -- one of the worst but least common forms of the dread disease.

In Edwin L. James' otherwise informative article on Soviet political slave camps in THE TIMES of July 24 there was one extraordinary under statement: "Indeed, the British say, it is pretty much like the system under the Czars."

The Mast-Foos Manufacturing Company, producer of lawn mowers, has purchased a 50 per cent interest in the farm equipment business of the Graham-Paige Motors Corporation, Joseph W. Frazer, chairman and president of Graham-Paige, announced yesterday. It was not disclosed whether the sale was for cash or stock considerations.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- Senator Styles Bridges, Republican, of New Hampshire, said today a substantial part of his $35,000 annual pay as a trustee of the United Mine Workers welfare fund was used to pay his expenses and counsel fees.

NEW CITY, N. Y., Aug. 2 -- Establishment of a Rockland County Nature Center on 100 acres of woodland at Summit Park Sanatorium in Pomona will get under way this week with the taking of a wildlife and nature census by the Rockland County Audubon Society.

People in East Harlem are tired of being talked down to about cleaning up their community, Mrs. Elizabeth Farkas, chairman of the committee on sanitation for the East Harlem District Health Committee of the Health Council of Greater New York, said yesterday.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Aug. 2 -- A decline of 8 to 10 per cent in this resort's seasonal business as compared with the 1948 record, was forecast in the Atlantic City Chamber of Commerce Newsletter received by members.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Aug. 2 (UP) -- The Alabama Ku Klux Klan leader, William Hugh Morris, went to jail a second time today for failing to deliver a list of Klan members to a grand jury investigating hooded violence. He was jailed for an "indefinite" sentence without bond.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (UP) -The Senate today unanimously approved a bill to provide $467,450,000 for interest payments that will be included in a $2,800,000,000 dividend to World War II veterans on their National Service Life Insurance.

Much has been written recently about the conservation of private land. It is timely to report an abuse of land in one of our national forests. Management of this land is directly controlled by the United States Government through the Departments of Agriculture and Interior.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- A group of prominent judges and lawyers has resigned as consultants to the Civil Service Commission on the appointment of hearing examiners. It was learned that the consultants told the commission their relationship had deteriorated into a sham.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (AP) -- Following is the text of the statement made by Ambassador W. Averell Harriman before the House Foreign Affairs Committee today:

LONDON, Aug. 2 -- Admiral Denfeld said today that the United States oJint Chiefs of Staff envisaged no increase in the size of American military forces in Europe either in the near future or ultimately under the Atlantic pact.

" Rope of Sand," which arrives at the Paramount, is this morning's lone film newcomer. The melodrama, which was produced by Hal Wallis for Paramount release, features Burt Lancaster, Paul Henreid, Peter Lorre and a newcomer, Corinne Calvet. William Dieterle directed from a story and screen play by Walter Doniger.

GENEVA, Aug. 2 -- The World Health Organization ran into rough weather today in its effort to get a large slice of United Nations Point Four funds if and when special allocations of money for technical assistance and economic development become available.

SHANGHAI, Aug. 2 -- The last group of Chinese workers camping out in the lobby of the United States Consulate General here left the building today after Reuben R. Thomas, Consulate administrative officer, agreed to transmit to Washington a recommendation by the Shanghai Labor Bureau for the settlement of the severance pay dispute with about 800 former employes of the United States Navy on the basis of three months' severance for each worker.

CHICAGO, Aug. 2 (AP) -- Miss Marlene Bauer, Los Angeles, and Miss Barbara McIntire, Toledo, the co-medalists, today came through with first round victories in the Women's Western junior golf championship at the Onwentsia Country Club in suburban Lake Forest.

SEOUL, Korea, Wednesday, Aug. 3 -- President Syngman Rhee left Kimpo airfield here at 9:30 this morning aboard a United States Navy plane for Chinhae Bay, on the southern tip of Korea, where he will confer within a few days with Generalissmo Chiang Kai-shek of China on a Pacific defense pact.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- The Army's "fleet," consisting of 320 ocean-going vessels, will be transferred as a unit to the Navy, starting in October, under orders issued today by the Secretary of Defense, Louis Johnson.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 2 (AP) -- The Cardinals backed up Red Munger's five-hit pitching with five doubles and a triple to hand the Boston Braves a 7-to-2 defeat tonight. Stan Musial had one of the doubles and the triple.

SWANSEA, Wales, Aug. 2 (Reuters) -- Making its lowest score of the season today, Glamorgan, the county champion, was all out for 73 runs in drawn match with the New Zealanders, who had declared their first innings at 378 for six wickets.

The Continental Oil, Company and its subsidiaries reported yesterday for the second quarter of this year net income after all charges of $9,530,002, compared with $15,086,128 in the similar three months of last year.

The city's waterfront is gradually losing its tatterdemalion look under the rehabilitation drive of the Department of Marine and Aviation, Commissioner G. Joseph Minetti said yesterday after a three-hour tour.

A mother and her nine children were evicted yesterday from their five-room cold-water flat in the East Bronx on a Municipal Court judgment holding the family two months in arrears of the $28 a month rent.
BELGRADE, Aug. 2 (UP) -- The Government announced today that it had arrested and expelled a Russian citizen for "insults publicly made against the Yugoslav state."

King Paul of Greece is confident that the guerrillas in his country will be driven "across the border" but he feels that United States aid will be required to keep them out of Greece, according to Arthur M. Tode, of 240 Grassy Sprain Road, Yonkers, N. Y., a consulting marine engineer who is honorary president of the Propeller Club.

LONDON, Aug. 2 -- Simultaneously with the United States, the British Government has replied to the Soviet Union's protest against the Atlantic pact and Italy's inclusion in the alliance. The British reply was to the same effect as that of the United States.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- Without a vote in opposition, the House passed and sent to the Senate today a bill raising veterans' pensions and disability payments by more than $112,000,000 a year.

CHICAGO, Aug. 2 -- The Central-Illinois Securities Corporation bought in 3,450 shares of its own preference stock in the first six months of 1949 at a total cost of $46,171, C. Arvid Johnson, president, told stockholders today in his semi-annual report.
Raymond Fernandez withdrew yesterday a plea of insanity as his defense in the trial for the slaying of Mrs. Janet Fay, a 66-year-old widow he met through a "lonely hearts club."
WESTFIELD, N. J., Aug. 2 -William J. Mangin of Aldecress won low gross honors in a Metropolitan Golf Association one-day tournament with two-over-par 35, 39--74 at the Echo Lake course today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- Twenty-four local housing authorities today sold $34,573,000 in short-term loan notes in competitive bidding, the Public Housing Administration announced today. The successful bids were at interest rates of .80 to .85 per cent.

LAKE SUCCESS, Aug. 2 -- The International League for the Rights of Man asked today that the United Nations Security Council step in and stop what the league called South Africa's "brutal" treatment of minorities before a fast-widening native hostility openly erupts throughout Africa and Asia.

Mayor O'Dwyer alighted by seaplane in the East River, off East Twenty-third Street, at 7:10 o'clock last night, ending the vacation that he had spent at an undisclosed spot. Where the Mayor had gone and what he had done while he was away was a closely kept secret.

New Yorkers may expect to see their historic City Hall criss-crossed by wooden scaffolding during most of the good-weather months of next year if plans for the work develop under a time-schedule announced yesterday by Frederick H. Zurmuhlen, Commissioner of Public Works.
CHICAGO, Aug. 2 (AP) -- Two teams were tied at 38 1/2 matches apiece today in the mixed teams division of the World Championship Summer National Contract Bridge tournament.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Aug. 2 -- Strong reports are circulating in Arab Palestine and Amman to the effect that King Abdullah of Jordan plans to make of Arab Palestine a separate Hashemite kingdom to come, first, under his own crown and, later, under that of young King Feisal of Iraq, together with the crown of Jordan.

The Wheeling Lake Erie Railway borrowed yesterday $6,870,000 on general and refunding-mortgage bonds maturing over twenty-five years at an indicated interest cost of about 2.86 per cent. The railroad sold the bonds at competitive bidding to a banking syndicate composed of Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., and R. W. Pressprich Co. at a bid of 98.132 for an interest coupon of 2 3/4 per cent.

BUFFALO, Aug. 2 -- There are no indications of any major business slump in the independent retail food stores of the nation, it was reported here today by Mrs. R. M. Kiefer, secretary-manager of the National Association of Retail Grocers.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (AP) -- Senator Clinton P. Anderson, Democrat, of New Mexico, stirred up yet another farm price tonic mixture today. It calls for flexible Government supports for some crops, rigid control programs for others and authority to try out the Brannan subsidy plan on some perishables.

The five Democratic county organizations in New York filed a total of 193,923 signatures yesterday designating Mayor O'Dwyer, Controller Lazarus Joseph and Council President Vincent R. Impellitteri for party renominations. As these names were the only ones filed by the Democrats at the Board of Elections before the deadline at 5 P. M., they will be the party candidates on primary day, Sept. 6, unless declinations and substitutions are filed before next Tuesday at midnight.

Federal Judge Robert R. Nevin held yesterday that Westchester County and the Westchester Cross County Parkway Authority had infringed the patents of Benjamin Cooper by using at their Fleetwood Bridge his method of automatically registering automobile tolls.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (AP) -- An application to extend a pipeline into New England for the transmission of natural gas from Texas and Louisiana was filed today with the Federal Power Commission by the Tennessee Gas Transmission Company of Houston, Tex.
