RICHMOND, Va., Aug. 2 -- State Senator John S. Battle was nominated today to be Virginia's next Governor in a Democratic primary that beat back the first serious threat to the party leadership of Senator Harry F. Byrd in twenty-five years.

GREAT RIVER, L. I. -- A sure cure for any drought is to schedule the Race Week activity of the Great South Bay Yacht Racing Association. There was rain today and the accompanying easterly wind brought in plenty of rough water off the Timber Point Yacht Basin for the second day of this regatta.

The Department of Parks had the carcasses of two sharks yesterday to prove the seriousness of its warnings to swimmers at beaches on the south shore of Staten Island to be on their guard. The two sharks were dragged out of the water on Monday afternoon at Great Kills and South Beach.
The grand old Lady of the Harbor is having her home redecorated. But that doesn't stop thousands from dropping in on America's most inspiring hostess every day.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (AP) -Five Western Senators are seeking a new approach to the problem of supporting the metal mining industry. Senator Joseph C. O'Mahoney, chairman of the Interior Affairs Committee, today named himself, Senators Arthur V. Watkins, James E. Murray, Robert S. Kerr and George W. Malone to work out some method for using Federal powers to halt the closing of nonferrous mines and stimulate exploration for and development of new ore bodies.

Appointment of Ambassador at Large Philip C. Jessup to head a group of distinguished consultants to the State Department on Far Eastern policy coincided last week, as your editorial of July 29 pointed out, with Gov. Thomas E. Dewey's speech at Colgate University calling for further aid to the Chinese Nationalists.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (AP) -Manufacturers' sales increased in June, although that month normally registers a decline from May. In reporting this business pick-up the Department of Commerce today estimated the value of manufacturers' sales in June at $16,500,000,000, an increase of $200,000,000 over the May total.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- By a vote of 356 to 7, the House gave final Congressional approval today to the bill strengthening the unification of the armed forces. The bill aims at greater efficiency and economy in military operations.

CHICAGO, Aug. 2 -- Grain markets were irregular on the Board of Trade here today. Announcement of an export subsidy on wheat and flour failed to have much effect as a price-making influence, and there was sufficient hedging and scattered selling to result in lower prices on the active futures with the finish 1/2 cent lower to 1/4 cent higher, on the day.

LONDON, Aug. 2 -- Another phase in the review and reorientation of British policy in the Middle East opened here today with the arrival in London of Gen. Nuri as-Said, Iraq's pro-British Premier, who will be conferring soon with Foreign Secretary Bevin.

A reduction of 27 per cent on bulk railroad rates for the shipment of milk in tank cars into the metropolitan area of New York was placed in effect Aug. 1 by four eastern railroads, spokesmen for the carriers revealed last night.
PARIS, Aug. 2 -- The French Government has told the United States that in any board of strategy set up under the Atlantic pact France should be represented on an equal footing with Britain.

Ship repairing and ship construction are declining throughout the country, J. Lewis Luckenbach, president of the American Bureau of Shipping, reported yesterday at the semi-annual meeting of the classification society's board of managers.

DUBLIN, Aug. 2 -- The American military jumping team, led by Col. Earl F. Thomson, made a good showing in its tryout at the first military competition of the Dublin Horse Show which opened today. This city is filled with overseas visitors for the event.
The cotton market on the New York Cotton Exchange had a slow session yesterday and final prices were 8 points lower to 3 points higher than on Monday, with the far months showing the most strength.

ROME, Aug. 2 -- Reports reaching the Vatican today indicated that the excommunication decree against active Communists was having repercussions throughout Italy. Catholics were crowding churches, especially in the small towns and villages, to seek advice and explanations from parish priests, it was said.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 2 -- The Argentine Broadcasters Association today declared the Government had nothing to do with the fact that the United States Embassy cultural division's radio program had failed to go on the air July 22 and 23.

Four officials of the New York Central Railroad testified for four hours before the Public Service Commission, 233 Broadway, yesterday in an effort to establish the line's need for increased commutation fares on its Hudson. Harlem and Putnam divisions.

The American Bankers Association expressed yesterday dissatisfaction with the Federal Home Loan Bank's revised regulations for Federal Savings and Loan Associations. Under revisions promulgated last month, the associations still would be permitted to refer to their investment share accounts as "savings accounts," and would be permitted to abbreviate their formal name from "Federal savings and loan associations" to "Federal associations."
WESTBURY, L. I., Aug. 2 (AP) -- Lusty Song won the $10,000 Dean Hanover Trot tonight in 2:06 3-5, best mark of his career, in the feature of the Grand Circuit program at Roosevelt Raceway.
VIENNA, Aug. 2 -- Upon terminating a visit to Czechoslovakia, one is forced to conclude that this most recent people's democracy represents rather an anomaly.

BERLIN, Aug. 2 -- The commandants of the three Western sectors of Berlin today "authorized" the City Government to pay the wages of 1,922 railroad workers who have received no salaries from the Russian-controlled State Railways since June 28, when Berlin's crippling railroad strike was ended.

The announcement yesterday by the Graham-Paige Motors Corporation that it has sold a 50 per cent interest in its farm equipment business to the Mast-Foos Manufacturing Company and is relinquishing management of that business to the latter, removes Graham-Paige from the list of American industrial enterprises after forty years of operations.

Everything a young homemaker might want, from the newest can-opening device to a complete living room decorated to the last detail, has been gathered together in the Young Homemakers Shop, which opens today at B. Altman Co. on the seventh floor.

CRESTWOOD, N. Y., Aug. 2 -Golfers continued to demonstrate today that one of the virtues required of their sport is patience. Not since 1947, when Emery Thomas, present New Jersey open champion, scored an ace at the Forest Hill Field Club, Bloomfield, N. J., has any competitor in The World-Telegram hole-in-one tournament turned in a perfect performance.

A defendant at the Communist trial yesterday denied any advocacy of force and violence by the Communist party and gave a party formula under which it could justify a revolution by either peaceful or violent means.

TRENTON, N. J., Aug. 2 -- East Orange officials and the State Department of Conservation and Economic Development approached a deadlock today over which would manage an East Orange housing project of 119 dwelling units. The department served an ultimatum that it would take over next Tuesday, but city authorities indicated that they would ignore this because of pending litigation.

The difficulties within the Fusion ranks, which have led to threats of a split city ticket being presented in opposition to that presented by Mayor O'Dwyer and the Democrats, appeared yesterday to have melted away.
An angry utility executive called upon 43,000 stockholders yesterday to support his opposition to a "Government-guided economy (the Welfare State)" by making "another declaration of their rights."
PITTSBURGH, Aug. 2 -- The Dodgers received their greatest lift in many weeks tonight, when Rex Barney hurled them to a 5-2 victory over the Pirates.

ANNECY, France, Aug. 2 -- Countries signatory to the Havana charter of the International Trade Organization have virtually abandoned a British-sponsored effort to activate immediately the part of the charter dealing with world commodity agreements, it was learned today.

In general we can take a degree of satisfaction in the new Fire Department figures released by Commissioner Frank J. Quayle showing that last year the number of fires in the city, 40,522, marked a drop from the 40,704 of the previous year, while 1948 fire losses amounted to $19,784,125, somewhat lower than the $21,488,280 sustained in 1947.

Some business executives who introduced employe profit-sharing plans during or after the war are fearing that their efforts to share the rewards of capitalism with their subordinates will boomerang this year, according to a survey of company experience with profit-sharing plans.
CHICAGO, Aug. 2 -- James V. Hunt, key figure in the Senate investigation of "5 per centers," is president of a Chicago corporation, bearing his name, at 135 South La Salle Street.

BATAVIA, Java, Aug 2 (AP) -- Representatives of the Indonesian Republic and fifteen Dutch-backed states of the East Indies agreed today to form a United States of Indonesia that will accept sovereignty under the Netherlands crown.

The extension of the maturity limit on Reconstruction Finance Corporation loans to business, as proposed in the midyear report of President Truman's Council of Economic Advisers, "would put that organization in the position of furnishing what is tantamount to permanent equity capital," the National City Bank declares in its monthly business letter published today.

Soviet trade union leaders, discussing the recent wave of strikes in various non-Communist countries, say they are part of a "struggle" being waged by the Communist-dominated World Federation of Trade Unions, a Moscow dominated broadcast heard by United States Government monitors discloses.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- Tradition has prevailed and the White House will be preserved, although it will be rebuilt internally. The decision was announced today by Senator Kenneth McKellar, chairman of the Commission on Renovation of the Executive Mansion.

LONDON, Aug. 2 -- British motion-picture executives, top technicians and many actors and actresses will have their salaries reduced as much as 20 per cent as an economy measure, the British Film Producers' Association announced today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- The Administration and its Congressional leaders took today their first direct steps toward conciliating the Republican opposition to the present form and scope of the $1,450,000,000 foreign military aid program.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Aug. 2 -- The Israeli Government virtually admitted in the Knesset (Assembly) tonight that the reported figure of 100,000 Arabs to be accepted in a resettlement program in Israel was correct. At the same time it indicated that the number of refugees already in Israel would be included, thus reducing the future repatriation figure to 65,000.

HOBOKEN, N. J., Aug. 2 -- A work stoppage by 370 longshoremen, members of five locals of the International Longshoremen's Association, AFL, early today halted the movement of freight on four local piers and delayed the sailing of the Holland-America Line's Veendam for fifty-six minutes.
A new naval expedition to the Antarctic, to be headed by the veteran Polar explorer, Rear Admiral Richard E. Byrd, is planned for next winter, it was learned yesterday.

TRENTON, N J., Aug. 2 -- In reporting today that New Jersey veterans of World War II received $139,000,000 in service men's readjustment allowances, the state division of employment security said the "52-20 club" was not "a gravy train for the majority.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (AP) -- Secretary of Agriculture Charles F. Brannan today supported creation of a Columbia Valley Administration in the Pacific Northwest as "of vital importance" to the region's agriculture.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 2 -- The Matson Navigation Company today stood by its plan to try to resume general cargo shipping to strike-bound Hawaii. Cargo was being accepted conditionally at a Matson pier and the longshore hiring hall was to be asked to supply stevedores to load the freighter Hawaiian Refiner upon its arrival at the dock.
LONDON, Aug. 2 -- After firm opening British Government bonds came under heavy selling in the stock market here today.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 2 (AP) -- The Athletics ended a three-game losing streak and a twenty-seven-inning scoreless drought tonight when they counted one run in the first inning and went on to defeat the White Sox, 5 -- 2, before 4,970 fans -- the smallest night turnout of the year.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- A national school lunch program for the coming school year $5,750,000 larger than was offered last year was announced today by the Department of Agriculture.

PEAPACK-GLADSTONE, N. J., Aug. 2 -- A rare and valuable Tibetan terrier that fled three weeks ago from luxurious surroundings and learned the hard way about life on the open road, was found today, somewhat the worse for wear, in an alfalfa field here.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (AP) -Military mail-order business will be abandoned at once and commissaries will be closed in metropolitan areas by the end of this year, the House Armed Services Committee was advised today. Representative Philip J. Philbin, Democrat, of Massachusetts, chairman of a subcommittee assigned to investigate retail activities by the military forces, reported that the services have agreed to follow recommendations made by his group.

New York State's authority over educational standards in all localities is broad. It embraces qualifications of teachers, their minimum salaries, subject-matter in the classroom, length of terms and many other matters. Now a seldom-used method of exerting power over standards of school building facilities may be brought to bear on the South Huntington and West Hills schools in a Long Island district.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (UP) -The Civil Aeronautics Board said today that last year's crash of a United Air Lines DC-6 at Mount Carmel, Pa., might have been avoided if the crew had followed proper emergency procedure.

A set of murals by the late Arthur B. Davies that has been an enigma to people for a long time, is in process of being removed from the main lobby of International House on Riverside Drive. A trip there yesterday revealed that one set over a central mantel had already been taken down to make way for another decorative scheme.

Eddie Albert, now starred in "Miss Liberty" on Broadway, will begin a daytime variety program series over the National Broadcasting Company's radio network early in September. The performer has just signed an exclusive contract with NBC covering his future radio and television activities.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- The House Committee on Education and Labor kept a faint breath of life in the Federal aid-to-education program in rejecting today by a vote of 13 to 12 a motion to drop the subject entirely for the balance of the session.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 2 -- Less than a length separated first from fourth at the finish of the $17,525 Wilson Stakes at Saratoga today, with a 10-to-1 shot the winner. Members of the Gordon Glisson Rooting, Marching and Ticket-Cashing Society, who had been doing no ticket-cashing since the start of the meet yesterday, did some jigging in the aisles when the numbers went up.

Recently they exerted enough pressure to cause the head of the house to move into another room. This pressure was indirect and tacit, and except for one or two occasions was exerted in a conversational tone.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- Ambassador John Leighton Stuart has laid a protest against the mistreatment of two United States newspapermen in Shanghai before the Aliens Affairs Office of the Chinese Communist forces in Nanking, the State Department learned today.

The law of averages, vigorously enforced by the Tigers, caught up with Allie Reynolds last night. While a banner turnout of 57,238 spectators at the Stadium looked on in utter dismay, the fourth place Detroiters knocked out the Yankee right-hander in the fifth inning and went on to detonate the league-leading Bombers by the humiliating score of 10 -- 2, behind Hal Newhouser.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- The $5,647,724,000 foreign aid bill was sent back to the Senate floor tonight after Appropriations Committee reconsideration of amendments which led to its shelving last week after four days of debate. There was time before the night's recess, however, only to square off for a new fight over the measure.

BOSTON, Aug. 2 (AP) -- Dom DiMaggio singled as the first batter in the ninth and then raced home from third base with the winning run on a fielder's choice as the Red Sox defeated the Browns tonight, 4 -- 3.

The hearings and off-stage debates on the "Foreign Military Assistance Act of 1949" are rapidly clarifying the issue to the point at which it becomes possible to distinguish between what is essential to accomplish the broad purpose of the whole military assistance program and what is of secondary importance in the text of the Act itself.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (AP) -The White House notified Senator Warren G. Magnuson, Democrat, of Washington, today that the military establishment had been directed to include in its budget for the fiscal year starting July 1, 1950, such sums for merchant ship repair as were necessary for national defense.

Based on current demands, when Government buying agencies' requirements for lead are filled, domestic industry buyers will have to import this metal to supply their inventories during the balance of the year, it was learned yesterday, following an increase of 1/4 cent in the price of pig lead.
Genevieve Cuprys can think of a lot of things that are more fun than a shipload of monkeys.

The General Public Utilities Corporation reported yesterday that consolidated net income for the twelve months to June 30 was $17,222,499, equal to $2.28 a share, compared with $14,355,733, or $1.90 a share in the preceding twelve months.

HONOLULU, Aug. 2 -- Hawaii's Legislature today continued to beat down all efforts to substitute Government seizure for temporary Territorial stevedoring operations in measures being drafted in the special session to end the ninety-four-day-old dock strike.

Picnics immediately come to mind as one of the occasions for which Dorset's new frozen barbecued chickens will be particularly appropriate. The birds may be eaten cold at the beach as soon as they defrost, which takes three or four hours at room temperature.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (AP) -The railroad industry today reported a sharp drop in net income for the first six months of 1949, compared with the same period a year ago.

Broadway managers were canvassed yesterday for comment anent Billy Rose's remarks that any producer objecting to the restoration of the "buy" (a device, now outlawed, whereby brokers obligated themselves to purchase blocks of tickets in advance from producers) would be suspected of profiteering and that ticket conditions were better under the old procedure.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- The Civil Aeronautics Board today affirmed in final form its tentative decision splitting the air cargo business over the United States among three airlines that are licensed to fly exclusively in this field for five years without subsidy from the Government.

It is to be hoped that action will be taken at this session of Congress on the bill introduced by Senator Edwin C. Johnson of Colorado to separate payments to the certified airlines for carriage of airmail from such subsidies as may be deemed necessary under the Civil Aeronautics Act of 1938.

The stock market surpassed the high mark set in July and fringed the May levels yesterday as the list plodded forward. The fresh rise lacked vigor, though, and gains proved selective, with the composite rate up 0.32 point on the day and representative of the additions through the main section of the list.

Creative Age Press plans to publish "Eugenio Pacelli: Pope of Peace," in the spring of 1950. The author, Oscar Halecki, was Professor of European History at the University of Warsaw from 1919 to 1939, a member of the Polish delegation to the Paris Peace Conference in 1919 and later a Polish delegate to the League of Nations.

New York, Washington and St. Louis continued their unbeaten pace in the annual Union Printers International Baseball League championship yesterday, each scoring second victories. New York, with Bill McGarry starring, crushed Chicago, 12 -- 4, at Ebbets Field, and Washington routed Indianapolis, 22 -- 2, at the Brooklyn Parade Grounds, where St. Louis also took the measure of Baltimore, 13 -- 9.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Aug. 2 -- Publicist Andre Simone made the charge in the Communist organ Rude Pravo today that the heads of an "organization X," including Allen Dulles and Francis Cardinal Spellman, had decided to make Archbishop Josef Beran of Prague into a new martyr because they were displeased by recent signs that East-West tension was relaxing.

It was twenty-five years ago today, Aug. 3, 1924, that Dr. Sun Yat-sen resumed his course of lectures that was to constitute his political testament. Knowing that he had not long to live, he began those lectures in January of that year and spoke of nationalism and democracy as the first two of his three principles.

ALBANY, Aug. 3 -- Governor Dewey today ordered a speed-up in the state's $575,000,000 public works program to combat rising unemployment. His action was based on recommendations of a special interdepartmental committee that found joblessness a serious "but not alarming" problem in the state at this time.

IT was Joe McCarthy who once gave utterance to a profound discourse on the importance of watching the .500 mark in a pennant race. He wasn't perhaps the first to think of it but he attached so much value to it that since then virtually all managers have come to accept it as their standard gauge of measurement.
SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 3 -- The order of favoritism was the order of finish in today's four-horse feature frolic at old Saratoga.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- Unemployment passed the 4,000,000 mark in July for the first time since January, 1942, the Census Bureau reported today. The estimated total of 4,095,000 for the week ending July 9 was about 330,000 higher than the June figure.

SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., Aug. 3 -- It was a day of travail, spills and the unexpected in the Eastern grass court championships today and play went on into the evening after rain had held up the program for almost two hours at the Orange Lawn Tennis Club.
There was supposed to be a garden party yesterday afternoon in the neat green yard back of Hartley House Settlement at 413 West Forty-sixth Street, just west of Ninth Avenue.

A fashion show for teachers was held here last night with the theme that teachers who feel "I can't afford what I want, so what do I care what I wear?" are hurting themselves, their pupils and their schools.

One of the broadest attempts to sell British goods, attuned to the needs of the American market and merchandised in the American manner, is now being undertaken by the Hambro House of Design, founded last June by the Hambro Bank of London, it was disclosed yesterday at its headquarters at 19 East Fifty-third Street.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- The United States Government moved today to consult with the other American republics over the continuing threat to peace in the Western Hemisphere grow ing out of the unrest and political imbalance in the Caribbean area.

SEOUL, Korea, Aug. 3 -- Korean National Defense Headquarters today reported than an "extremely heavy" exchange of artillery fire between the Republican Army and North Korean Communists was continuing in the area of Kaesong, border city between the two zones, forty-five miles north of here.

LONDON, Aug. 3 -- A proposal for the protection of individual rights and political liberties in countries that will be members of the Council of Europe was published today by the European Movement with a view to having it debated at the council's first meetings, beginning next week in Strasbourg, France.

Accused of shooting a man near a Bronx tavern while intoxicated, Detective Joseph Bijou, 27 years old, of 2924 Lafayette Avenue, the Bronx, attached to the safe and loft squad, was held without bail by Magistrate Simon Silver in Bronx Court yesterday for hearing today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- The meeting of the Republican National Committee tomorrow to act upon the resignation of Representative Hugh D. Scott Jr. of Pennsylvania as chairman and to elect a successor may develop into a bitter fight.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- Under a bill that President Truman signed today, the nation will get twenty-seven new Federal judgeships to help relieve court congestion.

PARIS, Aug. 3 -- The wife of the Aga Khan, immensely wealthy leader of Ismaili Moslems, was robbed of the greater part of her tremendous collection of jewels this afternoon as the couple were leaving their villa at Le Cannet near Cannes in their car.

After a fiery seven-hour session during which two competing stockholder groups sought to wrest control of the company from its present management, the annual meeting of stockholders of the Segal Lock and Hardware Company, Inc., of New York was adjourned yesterday until 10 A. M. next Thursday with the control issue still in doubt.

GREAT NECK, L. I., Aug. 3 -Mrs. Bruce Brodie of The Creek Club, finishing even with par, matched cards with Mrs. Campbell Garrett, also of The Creek, and won the first prize in the Women's Long Island Golf Association match play against par at the Deepdale Club today.

The detention at Ellis Island of Dr. Tage Lindbom, chief librarian of archives of the Confederation of Unions in Sweden, since his arrival here on Tuesday was revealed yesterday by immigration authorities. No reason was given.

Two new films will open in midtown theatres this morning. At the Radio City Music Hall, the attraction is "In the Good Old Summertime," a Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer musical romance, starring Judy Garland and Van Johnson. Joe Pasternak produced and Robert Z. Leonard directed the Technicolor offering, which includes S. Z. Sakall, Spring Byington and Buster Keaton among its principals.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- The Reconstruction Finance Corporation is "too aggressive" in granting loans, and any further liberalization of the agency's lending powers would lead the Government "even more deeply into the channels of private business and industrial production," a spokesman for the American Bankers Association said here today.

After dissipating a 4-0 lead, the Yankees came surging back with a three-run rally in the eighth inning to down the Tigers, 7 -- 5, before 15,253 spectators at the Stadium yesterday. Lefty Joe Page, who took over after Tommy Byrne had faltered, was the ultimate winner of the tense and thrilling contest, a very important one to the Bombers.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- The mimeograph machines in the national and state offices of the labor organizations were freshly inked, and their engineers, the clever young press-agents and ghost writers whom the unions have recruited from the colleges, were ready last night to turn out jubilant statements about the outcome of the Virginia Democratic primary.
The nation's gasoline stocks last week declined an additional 605,000 barrels to 109,964,000 at the weekend, according to the American Petroleum Institute. A year ago, they were 99,201,000 barrels.

"Tonight on Broadway," a series of sketches and excerpts from Broadway shows, will return as a half-hour weekly television series over the Columbia Broadcasting System network on Sunday, Oct. 2, at 7 P. M. Martin Gosch is the producer of the series, which will be presented with the cooperation of the various unions and guilds connected with the legitimate theatre.

A new electronic device that employs both visible and invisible light as "scales" for determining the quantities of the constituents of single cells, of which all living matter is composed, was demonstrated yesterday at Columbia University.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 3 -- Two references to Spruille Braden, former United States Ambassador to Argentina, in speeches by President Juan D. Peron have touched off the bitterest campaign against the former United States envoy in the peronista press since Mr. Braden left here.

BLOOMFIELD, N. J., Aug. 3 -Ace shooting moved from Westchester to New Jersey today and 166 players fired away at the Forest Hill Field Club under lowering skies, with occasional showers. A two-foot shot hit by Anthony Caporaso, 38-year-old attendant at the Veterans Hospital in Lyons, N. J., was the leading effort.

VANCOUVER, Aug. 3 (Canadian Press) -- Curiosity about a placard covered with Chinese characters on the cabin wall of an Italian freighter today unraveled a dramatic tale of the rescue of 200 starving Chinese whe were nearly drowned fleeing the Communists.

Aaron Gold, a middle-aged leather goods worker from the Bronx, with a keen faculty for remembering musical works and names of composers, ran true to form last night on the Mall in Central Park. For the twelfth consecutive year he achieved top honors in the twenty-fourth annual music memory contest of the Guggenheim Memorial Concerts given by the Goldman Band.

Newspapers continued to show the greatest increase in national advertising during June, it was reported yesterday by Printers' Ink. The magazine's national advertising index placed newspapers' gain at 9 per cent above the level of June, 1948.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- United States exports of domestic and foreign merchandise increased from $1,078,400,000 in May to $1,104,000,000, a rise of $25,600,000, in June, while imports dropped from $540,500,000 to $526,100,000, a decline of $14,400,000 in that month, the Department of Commerce reported today.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Aug. 3 -- Allied "interference" in "everything German" was assailed today by Dr. Kurt Schumacher, leader of the Social Democratic party, in a speech whose bitterness and nationalism epitomized the present trend of the election campaign in Western Germany.

British members of the building industry, in New York on the first day of an inspection tour to study American "know-how," expressed themselves yesterday as amazed by the speed and teamwork in construction work here.

CHICAGO, Aug. 3 -- The board of directors of the American Contract Bridge League, which is holding its summer national championships tournament here, voted early today to refer to the league membership the question of admitting Negroes as members.

Trustees of the Third Avenue Transit Corporation promised yesterday to give an answer by 2 P. M. today to demands of Local 100 of the Transport Workers Union. CIO, for arbitration of both a schedule of payments for retroactive pay and a new contract.

Determination of pastors and laymen to survive restrictions placed on Protestants in Czechoslovakia was reported yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Franklin Clark Fry, president of the United Lutheran Church in America, when he returned from a month in Europe.

GENEVA, Aug. 3 -- The Soviet Union acknowledged the existence of a "corrective" labor system in the Soviet Union today and asserted before the Economic and Social Council of the United Nations that the Soviet Government would continue to subject to this system those who "undermine the Socialist system."
Crops and pasture lands in northern and southeastern New York State were most severely damaged in the recent drought, a survey of county farm agents by The Associated Press revealed yesterday.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 3 (AP) -- Ken Raffensberger hurled two-hit ball today as the Reds downed the Phils, 2 to 0. It was the veteran southpaw's fifth shut-out of the season and his eleventh victory against as many defeats.
CANNES, France, Aug. 3 (AP)-"Guns were put upon us," the Aga Khan said, "but we were not fired upon. There were no shots fired."

Although the number of poliomyelitis cases in New York City and outlying districts continued to rise yesterday, city, state and national medical authorities declared that the situation was well in hand and 1949 might not be so bad a polio year as had been expected.

LONDON, Aug. 3 -- General uneasiness regarding the financial and economic outlook and talk of a higher interest basis were responsible for further losses in British Government bonds in the stock market here today.
DALLAS, Tex., Aug. 3 (AP) -Texans won all four small-gauge trophies in the national skeet tournament today but a New Yorker took the champion of champions Bob Canfield Memorial Trophy.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 3 -Harry Bridges, president of the International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union, CIO, won Federal Court permission today to go to Hawaii in connection with the ILWU strike there.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- The underlying theme of the new White House restoration will be to put it back into the period of 1810 instead of 1902, it was disclosed today.

HOBOKEN, N. J., Aug. 3 -- Eight hundred longshoremen, taking part in wildcat strikes here and in Jersey City, remained off their jobs today and voted to continue the work stoppage, which is in its sixteenth day in Jersey City and in its second day here.

WARSAW, Aug. 3 -- A declaration issued today by the Central Committee of Polish Jews condemned newspaper articles appearing in the United States about Jewish life here and stated that reactionary editors should be "pilloried."

MADISON, N. J., Aug. 3 -- Kenneth Wolcott of Trenton, a new member, won low gross honors in the New Jersey State Senior Golf Association midsummer one-day tournament with a 3-over-par 40, 36 -- 76 at the Braidburn Country Club today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- The National Labor Relations Board today challenged the sufficiency of the non-Communist affidavits filed by the Food and Tobacco Workers, CIO.

CHICAGO, Aug. 3 -- Chicago's 13,000 teachers would receive pay increases averaging 7 1/2 per cent and the 8,000 civilian employes of the School Board would get a flat 7 1/2 per cent rise under plans announced today to twenty-eight employe groups by Herold C. Hunt, Superintendent of Schools, and William B. Traynor, President of the School Board.

LONDON, Aug. 3 -- A new Constitution for Gibraltar, giving to the British Mediterranean fortress a Legislative Council, was announced today by the Colonial Office. The Constitution, which also provides for an executive council, will be introduced soon.
The long war between the Basketball Association of America and the National Basketball League ended yesterday.

There is a strong possibility that the Bureau of Internal Revenue may reverse its present ruling which permits the sale on a tax-free basis of certain fur garments or garments of which fur is an important component. This was revealed yesterday by Dane Hahn, manager of the Retail Fur Council of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, after a recent conference with officials of the Revenue Bureau.

Judge Harold R. Medina summoned Federal marshals at the Communist trial yesterday to put down two defense lawyers and make them stop "trying to bring the whole administration of justice into disrepute."

LAKE SUCCESS, Aug. 3 -- Secret testimony given recently before a Senate Judiciary subcommittee, alleging a reign of Communist terror among United Nations employes, was in effect derided today by Secretary of State Dean Acheson.

Contributions by employes are required in more than three-quarters of 261 group insurance plans just surveyed by the National Industrial Conference Board, according to a report of the study released for publication today. In an earlier study, the board noted that nearly half of such plans were paid for entirely by the employer.

A tract of about five acres of land on Parkway Post Road and Taylors Lane in Rye, N. Y., has been sold by the Town of Rye to Lewis Ginsberg in a cash transaction. Frank J. Macri was the broker and title was insured by the Inter-County Title Guaranty and Mortgage Company.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (UP) -President Truman today praised the United States Coast Guard for its fidelity and valor in a message marking observance of Coast Guard Day tomorrow.

A recent communication to this column complained of motorists' failure to respect the right of way of pedestrians who started to cross the street before the light changed. A reader from Jersey City advocated intermediate amber lights as a remedy.

LONDON, Aug. 3 -- Admiral Louis E. Denfeld, chief of United States Naval Operations and spokesman for the three United States Chiefs of Staff who are visiting Europe to discuss the proposed North Atlantic pact military organization, said here today that the new organization might be set up "before the end of this year."

Further contributions to highway safety coupled with increased utility of design are emphasized in the 1950 Studebaker models shown yesterday at a press preview at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, according to H. S. Vance, president and chairman of the board of the Studebaker Corporation.

LAKE SUCCESS, Aug. 3 -- Yugoslavia submitted a long list of charges to the United Nations today accusing Greek military forces of thirty-two separate frontier violations. This latest list of accusations in the long-standing dispute between Greece and neighboring Balkan nations was turned over to the United Nations by Dr. Joza Vilfan, Yugoslav delegate.

The six-story building at 365-369 Broome Street, southeast corner of Mott Street, containing ten stores and fifty-one apartments, has been sold by Chobol Navone to the Ritan Realty Corporation. The property, on a plot 72 by 108 feet, is assessed at $105,000.
The cotton market on the New York Cotton Exchange continued somewhat irregular yesterday and closed 5 points higher to 6 points lower than on Tuesday.

Another increase in the price of copper may occur soon, metal traders stated here yesterday, based upon continued strength in copper orders. For some companies orders have been larger this week than last week, they said.

The apartment building which will go up on the former site of the Schwab mansion will house 651 families and the construction cost will be about $8,000,000, according to plans filed yesterday with the Department of Housing and Buildings.

BERLIN, Aug. 3 (AP) -- Frau Erika Raeder, wife of the admiral who built Hitler's fleet, has fled from Eastern Germany and revealed that her living conditions during four years of Russian captivity ranged from caviar rations to dark cellars.

JONES BEACH, L. I., Aug. 3 -- Governor Dewey will cut a birthday cake here tomorrow and intone an oratorical "happy birthday" in honor of a celebrated stretch of sand and surf. The occasion will be the twentieth anniversary of Jones Beach, once bitterly opposed as "socialistic."

SHANGHAI, Aug. 3 -- A more detailed account of the Amethyst's escape in tonight's Peiping broadcast accused the British warship of using the steamer Kiangling as a shield against Communist guns. The incident apparently occurred below Chinkiang, near where the sloop had been anchored.

CHICAGO, Aug. 3 -- Grains broke sharply in the late trading on the Board of Trade today after showing strength early, scattered liquidation by longs disclosing a lack of support, and wheat and corn broke as much as 3 cents and soybeans 6 cents from the top.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- The so-called "blank-check" provision in the military aid bill is understood to be based in part on the possibility that swift American help might be needed in certain foreign areas.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Aug. 3 -- The Communist-led Czechoslovak Government announced tonight the sentencing of a Roman Catholic priest on charges of treason for allegedly having refused to administer the last sacrament to a sick old woman because she held a Communist membership card.
Avon Allied Products, Inc., which in the two preceding quarters paid 20 cents a share on the common, declared yesterday a dividend of 25 cents, payable on Sept. 1.

The congregation of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Holy Trinity, Brooklyn, announced last night through its "Melish Case Defense Committee" its intent to appeal to the triennial General Convention of the Protestant Episcopal Church the removal of the Rev. Dr. John Howard Melish, the rector.

The trim coastal liner Puerto Rico, reconditioned for first-class passenger service between New York, Puerto Rico and the Dominican Republic, was opened to public exhibition yesterday for the first time since her arrival from the yards of the Maryland Drydock Company. She is docked at Pier 6, East River.

OMAHA, Aug. 3 (AP) -- A sevenyear-old boy who swallowed twentythree sleeping pills, awoke today after thirty-six hours of unconsciousness. Hospital attendants said they believed he would recover. The boy, sandy-haired Trevis Wissenburg talked and took liquid nourishment.

The Richfield Oil Corporation, in its report covering the first six months of this year, issued for publication today, revealed an increase in the net income after taxes and all charges to $10,201,639 from $8,489,525 earned in the initial half of 1948.

SHANGHAI, Aug. 3 -- Communist armies sweeping along two highways toward Lanchow, gateway to Central Asia, are less than two hundred miles from the city on both routes and may have cut the last motor road into northwest China, according to situation maps based on official reports here.

The Perennial Bed A friend of ours has no use for gardeners. He insists that they have no proper sense of time, that they live only in the past or the future and have no interest in the present. "For them," he will say at the drop of a petal, "it is always yesterday or tomorrow.

In a purchase for expansion, the Well Maid Products Company, manufacturer of syrups, has acquired the former substation of the old Union Railway Company at 1068 Brook Avenue, the Bronx, from the G. I. S. Realty Corporation.

VINEYARD HAVEN, Mass., Aug. 3 -- Dense fog and lack of wind were encountered today on the second run of the New York Yacht Club cruise of thirty-seven miles here from Newport. Conditions were even worse than on the run yesterday from New London to Newport.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (AP) -The Department of Agriculture is seeking to encourage expansion of grain storage facilities by farm cooperative and private commercial enterprises. It said yesterday it would agree to occupy and use such additional space for a short time.

The corporate and labor affairs of the Third Avenue Transit Corporation, beset by complexities that include several "sides" among its security holders, were enlivened further yesterday with formation of an Income Bondholders Committee that is at sharp variance with management and its policies.

LAWRENCE, L. I., Aug. 3 -- A New Jersey National Guard fighter plane crashed and exploded here today on the lawn of the threeand-a-half-acre estate of S. Ralph Lazrus, president of the Benrus Watch Company, killing the pilot. A frame house 200 yards away was set afire and the neighborhood was showered with plane fragments and live ammunition.

Enough has been said, perhaps, about the personal phase of the encounter between Cardinal Spellman and Mrs. Roosevelt. But the militant tone of the Cardinal's letter and the restraint characterizing Mrs. Roosevelt's utterances on the subject have elicited censure and praise which leave the real issue clouded.

With the arrival tomorrow of 1,155 bodies of service men aboard the transport Carroll Victory, the bodies of 152,000 Americans who lost their lives overseas in World War II will have been returned home, it was announced yesterday by the New York Port of Embarkation, Brooklyn.

The stock market flattened out yesterday as moderate resistance developed in the recovery movement and left the list slightly irregular. Few major changes were posted except for high-price stocks and the composite rate declined 0.19 point.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, the following principal changes for the week ended July 27:

Tammany Hall's executive committee will meet at 4 P. M. today at its headquarters at 331 Madison Avenue to consider, and probably nominate, its candidate for the Borough Presidency of Manhattan, the office being vacated by the Hall's former leader, Hugo E. Rogers.

Television prices have hit bottom, Thomas J. Hodgens, general manager of the New York branch of the Admiral Corporation, said yesterday. He spoke at the first showing of the company's 1950 television and radio receivers in the house.

PRETORIA, South Africa, Aug. 3 -- Seven executions today in Basutoland revealed the extent to which ritual murder (voodoo) has gripped this British protectorate enclosed within the South African Union.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- Norris E. Dodd, director of the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations, predicted today that the organization would vote to move overseas next November unless Congress acted this session on inviting it to set up permanent headquarters here.

VIENNA, Aug. 3 -- Leopold Figl, Chancellor of the Austrian Republic, expressed conviction today that the Communists would not attempt a putsch in this country after the four-power occupation terminates and that if such a coup were tried it would not succeed.

Since the end of the Second World War Finland has had loans of about $127,000,000 from the United States. These loans were based on the expectation, justified by experience after the First World War, that the Finns would repay. Now the little country on the Baltic, maintaining a coalition government almost inside the Russian claws, has been granted a loan of $12,500,000 by the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (AP) -The Department of Agriculture announced today it will support grower prices of 1949 crop farmers-stock (unprocessed) peanuts at an average of about $210 a ton, or 10.5 cents a pound.

DEAL, N. J., Aug. 3 -- Mrs. Sophie Untermeyer of the Century Club fired her worst round of the tournament today, an 85, over the tough Hollywood course but still had a large enough lead to annex the Women's Metropolitan Golf Tournament.

CHICAGO, Aug. 3 -- The Borg-Warner Corporation's sales of household appliances, which reflected the industry's steep down-trend last winter and spring, recovered in June and are running well ahead of earlier months, C. D. Davis, president, said today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 3 -Ricardo Montalban will play the leading role in Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer's "Mystery Street," formerly "Murder at Harvard," the studio announced today. Joseph Losey has been assigned to direct the film, which will start early in September.

BERLIN, Aug. 3 -- Soviet occupation authorities have rejected a note in which commandants of the three Western sectors of Berlin complained that the Russian-controlled railroad system had not lived up to its pledge to pay workers living in West sectors but working in the East 60 per cent of their pay in West marks.
SHANGHAI, Aug. 3 -- The entire Shanghai press swung into high gear today in praise of the new one-year trade agreement between the Soviet Union and the Chinese Communists in Manchuria.

The Bergen County Sewer Authority, a new agency set up under New Jersey laws to function in the Bergen County-Hackensack River Sanitary Sewer District, executed its first borrowing on tax exempt revenue bonds yesterday.

PARIS, Aug. 3 -- Lieut. Gen. Georges Revers, chief of staff of the French Army, said today that the Western European Union staff committee established at Fontainebleau for strategic studies of European defense should be retained as part of the military organization under the Atlantic pact.
HONG KONG, Aug. 3 (AP) -- Lieut. Comdr. John S. Kerans, captain of the Amethyst, said he had tried fruitlessly for weeks to get the Chinese Communists to release his ship.

WEEHAWKEN, N. J., Aug. 3 (AP) -- Commuters, autos -- and elephants on the hoof -- today face the possibility of having to pay higher fares on the New York Central Railroad's West Shore ferry to New York.

TOKYO, Aug. 3 -- The break-up of excessive concentrations of economic power in Japan, one of the basic tasks of the occupation since 1945, now is complete, it was stated today in a press interview by Joseph Robinson, chairman of the Occupation's Deconcentration Review Board.

Criminal prosecution of the first of 883 longshoremen alleged to have chiseled the state out of at least $115,000 through repeated and flagrant false claims for unemployment benefits will be opened today by the Attorney General's office.

Two Russian Navy officers arrived yesterday at the New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, to take part in negotiations between the Soviet and United States Governments involving the return of lend-lease naval vessels.

Frank J. Forster, 31-year-old former civilian disbursing officer for the Army Transportation Corps who pleaded guilty last May to embezzling $51,000 of the corps' funds, was sentenced yesterday by Federal Judge Gaston L. Porterie to a year and a day in jail and three years probation.

Maritime labor groups announced yesterday that they would continue their opposition to the training program of the United States Maritime Service despite the action of the Senate, which on Monday approved the full training budget of the agency as originally submitted by the Maritime Commission.

In addition to its long-term debt, the United States Treasury has a "floating" (short-term) debt, consisting mainly of so-called certificates of indebtedness and discount bills, which is constantly being "turned over." In the past three years the practice has been that as one outstanding series matured it was refunded with a new issue of the same kind and the same amount.

Despite anti-American propaganda by the Government-controlled radio and press, the vast majority of the Polish people are friendly to this country, Waldemar J. Gallman, United States Ambassador to Poland, declared yesterday.

It should be a source of relief to all of us that the question of adequate parking facilities at the proposed new $32,000,000 New York University-Bellevue Medical Center has been cleared up so that the Board of Estimate has been able to take the last steps needed to discharge its responsibilities in connection with the project.
The meaning to the United States of the military assistance program, still under debate in Washington yesterday, is simple.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Aug. 3 (AP) -- A group of four United States educators and clergymen suggested today that the United States relax its restrictions on trade with Czechoslovakia in the interest of "friendship and understanding."
SYRACUSE, N. Y., Aug. 3 -- An attempt by teacher delegates to the convention of the State Federation of Labor to censure the organization's president, Thomas A. Murray, was defeated here today.

HAVANA, Aug. 3 -- It has been learned here that the Cuban Government has reached a tentative financial agreement for the sale of a bond issue of $40,000,000 the first year, $30,000,000 the second year and $30,000,000 the third year at an interest rate of 3 7/8 per cent.

The Republic of Cuba is planning to finance a program of self-liquidating public works projects through floatation of dollar bonds in the United States market, it was learned here yesterday. The initial borrowing, now in negotiation with First Boston Corporation, may approximate $40,000,000 to $50,000,000, according to estimates made in underwriting circles here.

Controversy over the precise amount of military aid to be given Europe to implement what General Bradley recently described as our "strategy of deterring a potential aggressor," must not be permitted to detract from the task of implementing the economic provisions of the North Atlantic Pact.

PARIS, Aug. 3 -- By order of the Paris Prefect of Police, Communist demonstrations "against the presence of General Bradley in Paris" were forbidden today and measures were prepared to prevent any gatherings around the American Embassy during the visit of the United States Chiefs of Staff.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- The anti-trust laws require "interpretation" even more than amendment to create "fair and impartial enforcement," a House monopoly investigating group was told today by Edward R. Johnston, a Chicago legal specialist in anti-trust work who was invited to testify before the committee.

Drivers under 25 years of age are adding $125,000,000 annually to the nation's premium charges for private automobile insurance because the accident rate in the age group of 18 to 24 years is at least 50 per cent higher than average, J. A. Mills, vice president of Lumbermen's Mutual Casualty Company, said in Chicago yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- Gen. Omar N. Bradley, Army Chief of Staff, marched today far ahead of any other individual in speculation concerning the appointment of the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff -- a new position created under the Armed Services Unification bill.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 3 (AP) -- Howard Pollet hurled his fourth shut-out and fourteenth victory of the season as the St. Louis Cardinals held on to first place in the National League race with a 7-to-0 victory over the Boston Braves tonight. The Redbirds lead the Dodgers by a half game.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (UP) -Senator Pat McCarran, Democrat, of Nevada, chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee, said today that he had "facts" to back up a charge that United Nations staff members were terrorized by Communists.
PARIS, Aug. 3 -- Despite strike conditions, Balmain's press showing got under way this morning on schedule with no apparent signs of inconvenience. This couturier offers much to talk about.

Service on the last eleven stations of the New Lots Avenue line in Brooklyn of the IRT BroadwaySeventh Avenue subway was suspended yesterday for an hour and twenty minutes when a brief but heavy downpour caused the tunnel to be flooded.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Aug. 3 (AP) -- Gov. Luther Youngdahl today put a watchdog over Minnesota's trust funds as a result of disclosures concerning the recent purchase of $5,208,000 worth of Arkansas highway bonds.
A little donkey that gave rides to children in the Bronx Zoo for nineteen years has been immortalized in the American Museum of Natural History.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (UP) -Julius A. Krug, Secretary of the Interior, today laid down rules for selling power in the Missouri River basin and authorized contract negotiations to start immediately.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- Following is the roll-call by which the Senate voted today, 52 to 32, to sustain Vice President Barkley's ruling that the farm surplus amendment of Senator John L. McClellan, Democrat, of Arkansas, to the Foreign Aid Appropriation Bill was new legislation subject to a point of order:
WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- The State Department acted today to smooth over a Uruguayan grievance.

The New York Telephone Company, largest operating telephone subsidiary in the Bell System, reported yesterday that operating revenues for the twelve months to June 30 amounted to $418,515,620, an increase of $36,146,803 over the $382,368,817 shown for the preceding twelve months.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (AP) -Construction activity, spurred by a pick-up in private homebuilding, scored a more-than-seasonal climb in July and set a new dollar volume record both for that month and for the first seven months of 1949.

Five jurors were chosen yesterday to sit in the General Sessions trial of John G. Broady, attorney and private investigator, and Edward M. Jones on charges of grand larceny, wiretapping and conspiracy. During the questioning of twelve blue ribbon veniremen, the defense exercised use of four of its twenty peremptory challenges and the state one.
Mayor O'Dwyer declared yesterday that he could not believe that the stand taken by Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt on Federal aid for parochial schools was prompted by bigotry.

ATHENS, Aug. 3 -- The rebel 192d Brigade was ambushed by Government forces while attempting to get out of beleaguered positions in the Grammos area, according to a General Staff communique today. Eighteen rebels were reported killed.

PARIS, Aug. 3 -- Throughout Marcel Rochas' collection fabric is turned back on itself at the hemline so that overskirt and underskirt, the double peplums of the jackets are all in one piece. Slender underskirts turn over at the hem straight up to the waist, thus forming an equally slender overskirt left open at one side, in the center, front or back.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- Joseph Curran, president of the National Maritime Union, CIO, and Harry Lundeberg, president of the Seamen's International Union, AFL, told a House labor subcommittee today that if the maritime industry aolished the hiring hall chaos would result.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- A Senate vote of 52 to 32 defeated again today efforts to require that $1,954,000,000 of the $5,647,724,000 proposed to finance foreign aid through the present fiscal year be spent for surplus American agricultural commodities, or not be spent at all.

New high record beer sales during the first six months this year definitely indicate that the American public is becoming more temperate in its drinking habits, E. V. Lahey, president of the United States Brewers Foundation and Smith Brothers, Inc., New Bedford brewery, declared yesterday.

An account of the famous trial of Gen. Tomoyuki Yamashtta, "the Tiger of Malaya," and an analysis of the manner in which it was conducted will be published on Sept. 9 by the University of Chicago Press, entitled "The Case of General Yamashita."

The decision to preserve the traditional external appearance of the White House, despite extensive renovation of the interior, is one that, we are sure, will be welcomed by most Americans. As Mrs. Roosevelt, who lived there longer than any other First Lady, has said: "The proportions are beautiful, and the house has great dignity and simplicity."

BOSTON, Aug. 3 (AP) -- Ellis Kinder set a 1949 high for Red Sox pitchers today by striking, out 14 as he paced Boston to a 9-3 triumph over the last-place Browns. The American League record for strikeouts is 18, held by Cleveland's Bob Feller.

HONOLULU, Aug. 3 -- The Hawaiian Legislature today reversed itself after a meeting of its leaders with Gov. Ingram M. Stainback and agreed to give the Governor a free hand in the hiring of strikers and the personnel of struck concerns in the Territory's contemplated stevedoring operations.
BATAVIA, Java, Aug. 3 (AP) -The Dutch and the Indonesian Republicans formally ended their four-year war today, but both sides made clear that only an armed truce existed for the present.

Salary increases for civil service employes were proposed by five speakers yesterday at the fifth hearing on Mayor O'Dwyer's plan for a $150,000 survey of reclassification and wage adjustment in the city's civil service system. Three of the speakers favored the plan.

Sweden and Great Britain are continuing to be "completely unrealistic" about price levels, Walter Rothschild, president of Abraham Straus, declared yesterday upon his return on the Queen Elizabeth from a month's tour of those countries.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- The United States Government will use a performance budget for the fiscal year 1951, Frank Pace Jr., budget director, announced today.

CHICAGO, Aug. 3 (AP) -- Reorganization of a part a of the munitions combine once run by the Garsson brothers appears improbable, Assistant United States Attorney John P. Lulinski said today. He made the observation during a hearing being conducted by Wallace Streeter.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (UP) -The Government's stocks of butter purchased for price support purposes have increased one-third as a result of heavy buying this week, it has been disclosed.
COPENHAGEN, Aug. 3 (AP) -- American track and field stars won all but one event, the hammer throw, tonight in competition with a Danish team.
ROME, Aug. 3 -- The Italo-Yugoslav commercial treaty, which has been under discussion for many months, will be signed in Rome tomorrow, it was officially announced today.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 3 -- The Dodgers were riding high, wide and handsome on a four-game winning streak after young Carl Erskine, making his second start, had hurled them to a 10-5 victory over the Pirates today.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 3 (AP) -First baseman Hank Biasatti's first hit of the season paved the way for a 3-2 victory by the Athletics over the White Sox tonight. Biasatti's eighth - inning double with two out followed Wally Moses' single, and when right fielder Dave Philley booted the ball, Moses came home with the winning run.

GREAT RIVER, L. I., Aug. 3 -Great South Bay's famous wind, usually a sturdy sou'wester, was completely lacking today and the water was as flat as intermittent showers could make it as the Great South Bay Yacht Racing Association's regatta moved into its third day.

Emphasizing a concept that many cases of so-called incurable diseases respond favorably to medical and surgical care, Montefiore Hospital announced yesterday that construction of two new wings has been started to expand facilities on its compound at Gun Hill Road and Bainbridge Avenue in the Bronx.
A Broadway production of August Strindberg's play, "The Father," has been scheduled by Richard Krakeur and Robert L. Joseph for the coming season, it became known yesterday.

CHICAGO, Aug. 3 (UP) -- The Professional Golfers Association announced today that Ben Hogan has been elected captain of the United States Ryder Cup squad, although he will not be able to play in the competition.

The British Walker Cup players, here to participate in a renewal of the international golf series with the United States, were among those arriving on the liner Queen Elizabeth yesterday. Also on board was the Italian Davis Cup team which will meet the Australian tennis squad here.

One point was proved conclusively yesterday at the Saks Fifth Avenue showing at the Ritz Tower Hotel, that college and career girls' tastes are the same. Indeed, so many ohs and ahs were heard from the audience at the steady succession of attractive costumes that this writer believed the interest extended beyond that of college girl or young careerist.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (AP) -The House of Representatives approved by voice vote today a bill providing machinery for Southern and Western farmers to reduce their cotton acreage. Such a reduction is intended to prevent severe cotton price breaks in the years ahead.

RICHMOND, Va., Aug. 3 -- Candidates backed by the Democratic machine headed by United States Senator Harry F. Byrd were generally victorious in Virginia's biggest primary election, according to the vote count being completed today.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., Aug. 3 -By winning two of four races held today in the series for the Syce Cup and the women's sailing championship of Long Island Sound, Miss Suzette Spitzer, representing the Pequot Yacht Club of Southport, Conn., gained an 8 1/4-point lead.

LAUSANNE, Switzerland, Aug. 3 -- Acceptance by the Arab delegations of the Israeli conditions for discussion of the return of a substantial number of Arab refugees to Palestine means that the United Nations Palestine Conciliation Commission can now get down to work, commission sources said today.

WESTBURY, L. I., Aug. 3 (AP) -Grattan McKlyo and his driver, Neal Houslet, will be shooting at a double target tomorrow night in the Nassau two-mile pace -- the winer's share of the $50,000 pot and a world record.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 3 -- The discovery of large deposits of manganese, nickel, molybdenum, iron ore and other strategic raw materials was announced today by the newspaper Politika in a survey of Yugoslavia's mineral resources.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- Members of the military services have contributed $2,400 toward a fund to obtain a bronze bust of the late James Forrestal, first Secretary of Defense, it was announced today. Additional contributions, not to exceed $1 each, will be received until Aug. 31.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (AP) -President Carl G. Strandlund of the Lustron Corporation, of Columbus, Ohio, said today "it would be tragic" if a Congressional investigation into Federal loans to the company resulted in refusal of further such aid.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (AP) -- Bills to curb "five per centers" were introduced by two Senators today while a House committee invited Secretary of the Army Gordon Gray to testify Friday in a widening investigation.

The demand of Mailers Union No. 6, International Typographical Union, AFL, for a wage increase for members employed by twelve New York newspapers was denied in an arbitration award handed down yesterday.

Prices of coffee futures sagged on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange, Inc., yesterday. This was the first major decline in coffee futures since the second week in July. Contract "S" showed the sharpest declines and closed the day 43 to 61 points off for the day.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (AP) -- Secretary of Defense Johnson took steps today to mesh the nation's military machine with Federal agencies fighting political battles abroad.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 3 -- A 14-month shopping-news publishing venture here by associates of Henry R. Luce, New York magazine publisher, which had been locally construed as an effort to enter the daily newspaper field, suspended operations today.

Four apartment houses in the Birchwood Manor garden apartment development known as Auburndale Village at Crocheron Avenue and Utopia Parkway in the Auburndale section of Queens have been resold by Lillian Horowitz to Auburndale Apartments, Inc., represented by Earl Gallant, attorney.

It was a brave man who first ate an oyster, Jonathan Swift once said. We say it was a brave cook who first ventured to put ice cream into a hot oven. We have the baked Alaska as the result of her courage.
LEWISBURG, Pa., Aug. 3 (AP) -United States District Judge Frederick V. Follmer ruled today that the Federal courts have jurisdiction in rent control cases "irrespective of the amount involved."

John A. Stephens, vice president of the United States Steel Corporation, declared yesterday that the United Steelworkers of America, CIO, had made a definite oral commitment last year not to raise the issue of pensions in 1949 negotiations.

Seeking living quarters for tenants of the Washington Square South block upon which it plans to erect a new law center, New York University's School of Law has conducted extensive negotiations in the hope of using the former Lafayette and Brevoort Hotels, it was learned yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- A trial examiner for the National Labor Relations Board found today a group of unions and employers guilty of causing six workmen to lose their jobs. He recommended that they make up to the workers the wages they lost.
HONG KONG, Aug. 3 -- The escape of the British sloop Amethyst from detention by the Chinese Communists on the Yangtze River has been a tonic for British morale here.

The successful completion and subsequent economies of full-scale operation of a new manufacturing unit in St. Louis has resulted in a substantial reduction in the price of Monsanto Chemical Company's caffeine, it was announced yesterday.

OCEANPORT, N. J., Aug. 3 (AP) -- William G. Helis' Rippey found the sloppy track to his liking today and drove to a head verdict over Al-Jo Stable's Cacique in Monmouth Park's featured six-furlong Oceanport Handicap. Christopher T. Chenery's Mangohick was third, less than a length behind Cacique.

CHICAGO, Aug. 3 -- For a brief period today on Wrigley Field it appeared Mr. Frank Frisch, the eminent horticulturist of New Rochelle, and his aimless Cubs, were to feel the strange sensation of victory.

CHICAGO, Aug. 3 -- More than $71,000,000 would be required to put the near-bankrupt Tucker Corporation in condition to produce automobiles on a commercial scale, a management engineering concern said today. The project would take seventeen to eighteen months and would involve various major and minor changes in the design of the Tucker car.

Washington remained unbeaten by defeating New York, 3 -- 2, in the feature game in the Union Printers International Baseball League yesterday at Ebbets Field. The setback was the first in three starts for the local nine. The winners have won three.

Professional boxers competing in New York State will be protected by compulsory accident insurance after Sept. 1, according to new regulations announced yesterday by Col. Edward P. F. Eagan, chairman of the New York State Athletic Commission.

BOSTON, Aug. 4 -- The American Federation of Labor is counting on a war chest of at least $1,000,000, through voluntary contributions, to "try to elect a Congress which will vote the issues the people want," Joseph D. Keenan of Chicago, director of the AFL Labor's League for Political Education, said today.

Every day of late Sam's been rolling a lucky seven. Since last March 21 when he reduced his beer to 5 cents for a 7-ounce glass. Sam's business has been brisk as a polka. At 10 cents a glass he sold six barrels a week, at a nickel he's selling seven barrels a day.

With men's wear worsted lines for next spring yet to be priced by several leading mills, no marked upturn in fabric buying by clothing manufacturers is now expected until after Labor Day, it was reported in the clothing industry yesterday.

Probably typical of a large group of American college girls were those who modeled the clothes yesterday at the formal opening on Franklin Simon's college shop, on the third floor. They were the girls who work in the shop.

LAKE SUCCESS, Aug. 4 -- Premier Stalin has laid down five major steps that must be taken as a minimum basis for East-West peace, including a treaty between the United States and the Soviet Union formalizing the commitments contained in the Yalta and Potsdam pacts. This was asserted in an article published today in the United Nations World.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Aug. 4 (AP) -- Roman Catholic authorities reported several new arrests of priests here today as the controlled Czechoslovak press thundered threats of further treason trials against the clergy.

A substantial increase in sales resulted in profitable operations for the Boeing Airplane Company in the first six months of 1949, compared with the deficit recorded in the first half of last year, according to the financial statement issued yesterday.

Sympathy for Yugoslavia is stirring among anti-Tito Yugoslav- Americans now that that Federal republic has become embroiled in a Balkan "cold War" with the Soviet Union and the Communist Information Bureau countries, it became known yesterday.

VIENNA, Aug. 4 -- If the Western Allies should agree to the latest Russian claims raised at the conference of Foreign Ministers' deputies on the Austrian peace treaty in London, high Austrian officials warned tonight, "the Danube will become a 'Red' river extending through the heart of Austria to the German frontier."
The ranks of the Military Police -- heretofore regarded as muscular, martial prototypes of the civilian "John Law" -- have been invaded by skirts and frills.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 4 (AP) -- The St. Louis Cardinals retained their half-game grip on the National League lead today by battering the Boston Braves, 10 -- 2, while Al Brazle and Ted Wilks held Boston to six hits.

Monogram and its subsidiary, Allied Artists, will produce forty-eight feature films for the 1949-50 season, it was announced by Steve Broidy, president, at the company's annual sales meeting at the Drake Hotel in Chicago. Forty of the films will be made by Monogram and eight, two of which are to be produced in England, are slated for Allied Artists release.

ADAMS CORNERS, N. Y., Aug. 4 -- The "matriarch" of this hamlet in southeastern Putnam County will be 108 years old on Sunday. She is Mrs. Emely Frances Baxter Perry, believed by relatives and local historians to be the second oldest person in the state.

These midsummer days are witnessing one of the great annual anguishes of the American male -- the transportation of his family to the holiday place by car. It isn't so much the feverish preparations for weeks ahead or the nervous excitement of his brood careening around the rear seats.

A decree calling for construction a $6,000,000 oil refinery to take care of the total requirements of the Dominican Republic and eventually to provide for the export of certain specialized types has been signed by President Rafael L. Trujillo, after approval of the project by Themistocles Messina, Minister of Trade and Commerce.

PARIS, Aug. 4 -- The alternates of the Foreign Ministers of ten Western European countries will meet here tomorrow for a last discussion of the report drawn up by the preliminary committee for the Consultative Council of Europe which meets in Strasbourg next Monday.

DUESSELDORF, Germany, Aug. 4 -- Although ultra-nationalist parties, groups and associations continue to appear in North Rhine- Westphalia, Western Germany's most populous state, the prospect that any of these would poll as much as 5 per cent of the votes in the coming elections in remote.

BERLIN, Aug. 4 -- The West Berlin Government today urged its citizens not to buy in the Soviet- controlled Eastern sector. Louise Schroeder, acting Lord Mayor of Berlin, said in a newspaper article that West Berlin citizens spending their marks in the East sector were

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (AP) -- Theodore Roosevelt III, Secretary of Commerce of Pennsylvania, and Representative Ivord Fenton, Republican, of Pennsylvania, were told today that the Reconstruction Finance Corporation will lend $200,000 to the M S Coal Company, Minersville, Pa., but only on a matching basis.
DALLAS, Aug. 4 (AP) -- Texas gunners won three of the four available trophies today in 20-gauge competition of the national skeet shoot at the Dallas Gun Club.

The First Army announced yesterday the monthly selection of four outstanding soldiers who for that distinction will enjoy a week-end in town, beginning today. Four young actresses will be escorted by the four GI's when they make a tour of Manhattan by Army boat this afternoon.

MAMARONECK, N. Y., Aug. 4 -- The father and son combination of Al and Dick Mayer of Innis Arden won the medal with an eight-under-par 64 in the John G. Anderson Memorial tournament, staged over the east course of the Winged Foot Golf Club today.
Nothing could be sweeter to a vamp (volunteer fireman) than to beat the supermechanized apparatus of the New York City Fire Department to a fire. And sometimes it does happen.

The invasion of South Korea by a force of 4,000 to 6,000 men cannot be casually dismissed as a mere border foray on the Thirty-eighth Parallel. Manifestly the Communists from the north are both probing the south's defenses and undertaking to strengthen their own positions.

A three-day spell of muggy weather that crumpled collars and wrinkled dresses is due to be dissipated today as skies clear gradually. By tonight the humidity, which never dropped below 80 per cent yesterday, will have decreased sufficiently to provide the most pleasant weather since the beginning of the week for New Yorkers.

BRONXVILLE, N. Y., Aug. 4 -- An old New York City water pipeline that parallels the Bronx River Parkway broke here at 5:20 A. M. today near Palmer Avenue and sent so much water and mud cascading on to the parkway that traffic had to be detourned for twelve hours.

The Hebrew Sheltering and Immigrant Aid Society has for sixty-four years been helping the persecuted and the homeless Jews of Europe start life anew in happier lands. In carrying out its unceasing mission, it has grown to be an organization with over 100 offices in some fifty countries.

A board of special inquiry will meet at Ellis Island at 9:30 A. M. today to determine whether Dr. Tage Lindbom, Swedish librarian, will be admitted to the United States. He has been detained since his arrival on Tuesday.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (UP) -- The Senate Expenditures Committee today voted to veto President Truman's plan to create a powerful new Federal Department of Public Welfare.
PARIS, Aug. 4 -- Jean Desses' showing was held last night in the open court of a beautiful old building on Avenue Matignon. The colorings seemed particularly suited to the beauty of the night.

A companion volume to Thomas Merton's autobiography, "The Seven Storey Mountain," has been scheduled for October publication by Harcourt, Brace. "The Waters of Siloe" is an informal account of the meaning and purpose of Trappist life, presenting a monk's day, from the time he rises at 2 o'clock in the morning until he goes to bed at 7 in the evening.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 4 -- Miss Judy Johnson didn't say so, but her motto must be: "Woman's place is in the winner's circle." For Miss Johnson is a race-horse trainer by trade -- a trainer chiefly of jumpers -- and she has been in winners' enclosures more often this season than any other member of the infield brigade on the big-track circuit.

VIENNA, Aug. 4 -- Schlamperei is a word belonging to Vienna's special argot and it can be interpreted approximately as meaning a sort of happy-go-lucky, easy-going fashion of doing things with a decided overtone of wangling. The liberation of Vienna, and incidentally Austria, has represented a triumph for schlamperei.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- The National Labor Relations Board gave a union today a clear right to engage in picketing which has been stopped for nearly a year by a temporary injunction.

PARIS, Aug. 4 -- The death penalty was asked in Lille today against Obersturmfeuhrer Walther Hauck and eight other former members of the Twelfth SS Division. The nine, charged with the massacre of seventy-seven French civilians in the town of Ascq in the spring of 1944, are being tried as war criminals before a military court.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (AP) -- Following are the two roll-calls in the Senate today on rulings by Vice President Barkley. In the first the Senate voted by 55 to 36 to sustain his ruling that an amendment to include Spain in the Economic Cooperation Administration was out of order.

Federal Judge Kaufman's authorization to trustees of the Third Avenue Transit Corporation to apply to the Public Service Commission for an 8-cent bus fare has the merit of being founded on common sense. The trouble is that common sense on the fare question does not extend as far as City Hall or, at best, arrives only belatedly.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- President Truman said today that Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt had submitted a resignation from her United Nations position, as she does annually, but that she would not accept it, and that she would be on the job at the next General Assembly meeting.
A suit to restarin R. H. Macy Co. from advertising and selling DuMont television receiving sets at cut prices was filed yesterday in Supreme Court here.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- The Alaska Airlines, Inc., one of the major post-war carriers that operates scheduled services in Alaska, Canada and the northwestern portion of the United States, plus non-scheduled services to South America and Europe, today drew drastic penalties for alleged infractions of safe-flying rules.
LONDON, Aug. 4 (Reuters) -- Warwickshire's cricket team today gained the advantage against the New Zealand tourists in the match at Birmingham.

A stronger market and increased shipments of hosiery for the remainder of this year is anticipated by the National Association of Hosiery Manufacturers. This conclusion, the association said yesterday, is based on a study of the market movements during the last eleven months.
