CHICAGO, Aug. 4 -- The left-handed Johnny Schmitz and the club-wielding Andy Pafko collaborated for a Cub victory at Wrigley Field today that snapped a 6-game winning streak for the Giants and pulled Frankie Frisch's cellar-dwellers out of an 8-game nose-dive.

PITTSBURGH, Pa., Aug. 4 -- Business in the Pittsburgh district last week continued the sharp recovery which began early in July, according to the bureau of business research of the University of Pittsburgh. Increased operating rates were reported by many of the major industries in the district and originating freight shipments were up appreciably.

Sir Laurence Olivier doesn't like to devote all of his time to acting. Every once in a while he takes a fling at theatrical producing in London, and so far has fared rather well in that field. He rang the bell twice before with "Born Yesterday" and "Daphne Laureola," which has just passed the 150 mark.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 4 -- With three homers driving in seven of their runs, the Dodgers today rolled relentlessly over the Pirates, 11 -- 3, sweeping the series and running their winning streak to five games before a ladies' day crowd of 24,687.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (AP) -- The National Petroleum Council named a 24-man committee to study the problem of petroleum imports.

CHICAGO, Aug. 4 -- The American Meat Institute today characterized Samuel Slotkin's statement as "a collection of wild assertions against a large and responsible group consisting of hundreds of American business men in the meat packing industry, and is pure fiction.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (AP) -- The Agriculture Department notified Representative Hal Holmes of Washington today that it had authorized purchase of 1,000,000 cases of canned peaches on the Pacific coast for use in the school lunch program.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Aug. 4 -- Analyzing the water at Westchester beaches and docks, the County Health Department today gave ratings of "good" to twenty-two places, "satisfactory" to six, "substandard" to two and "bad" to five.

CHICAGO, Aug. 4 -- Steelmakers must reduce operating costs and improve quality to stimulate sales and profit in the second half in the year. Carl J. Sharp, president of Acme Steel Company, said today. Customers are again very choosy and are ready to reject products they believe are not made to highest standards, he said, adding that this was a factor in the company's earnings decline in the first six months of 1949.

After tangling with a husky, six-foot ex-Marine officer in a liquor store at 2462 Jerome Avenue, near Fordham Road, the Bronx, at 6:15 o'clock last evening, a would-be hold-up man tried to shoot it out with an off-duty patrolman. The policeman wounded him in the jaw and, with the help of another off-duty member of' the force, captured him at Jerome Avenue and 190th Street.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. -- The two-way trade agreement for one year signed today in Rome by the Italian and Yugoslav Governments is the most important trade agreement signed by the Yugoslav Government with any Western powers since the Communist Information Bureau's resolution and imposition of the Eastern European blockade against Yugoslavia.

HONOLULU, Aug. 4 -- Striking members of the International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union, CIO, walked off the Canadian Australasian motorship Aorangi here today shortly after it had arrived from Vancouver with a relief cargo to augment the Territory's dwindling food supply

Royal pastel mutation mink sold up to $42 yesterday for a lot of pale clear skins at the sale held by Lampson, Fraser Huth. Prices ruled firm as compared with the May sale, with 83 per cent of the offering of 2,746 skins sold. "Breath of spring" silverblu mink brought a top of $36, also firm as compared with May levels.

Robert Haig, one of the country's outstanding shipbuilding engineers and senior vice president of the Sun Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company, Chester, Pa., has retired at the age of 88 to catch up on some long-delayed travel.

NANTUCKET, Mass., Aug. 4 -- Fog and more fog, rolls and rolls of it, accompanied by another miserably dripping rain, were factors again today on the New York Yacht Club's racing run here from Vineyard Haven, the old whaling ship harbor on Martha's Vineyard, a larger island than this ocean mound and no drive over or under.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- Thanks to American service men of the last war the export of American-made chewing gum reached a record peak of 11,000,000 pounds in 1948, an increase of 11.8 per cent over 1947, the Department of Commerce reported today.

NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 4 -- India has indicated to the other Commonwealth countries her willingness to accept a 25 per cent reduction in dollar imports for 1949 provided that the other Governments do likewise, Dr. John Matthai, Finance Minister, said today.

THE NEW YORK TIMES forgets that there has been a great deal of strong criticism from the most temperate and informed sources of the "unconditional surrender" policy enunciated by President Roosevelt at Casablanca in 1943. Many persons believe that the war would have been greatly shortened and many American lives would have been saved had these words never been spoken.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (AP) -- A spokesman for the Munitions Board recommended today that the Government retain for the present three wartime industrial alcohol plants in the Midwest. Maj. Gen. S. P. Spalding, acting director for industrial programs of the Munitions Board, told a Senate agriculture subcommittee the plants should be kept "in condition."

Retail meat prices will decline about 25 per cent if leaders of the industry are willing to cooperate with the Government to gain a stabilized market, Samuel Slotkin, chairman of the board of Hygrade Food Products, one of the country largest independent meat producers, declared yesterday.

GENEVA, Aug. 4 -- Despite firm British speeches pursuing relentlessly the available facts about Soviet forced labor camps it seemed probable as today's session of the United Nations Economic and Social Council closed that few countries would support the United States proposal for a commission of inquiry to investigate forced labor throughout the world.

Bank lending in this area for the week ended on last Wednesday reverted to the decline broken the week before for the first time in twenty-one weeks. Figures made public yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported a decrease of $2,000,000 in commercial, industrial and agricultural loans for the weekly reporting member banks, compared with an increase of $3,000,000 the week before.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- More than $11,500,000 has been overpaid to Government war contractors through fraud and waste, Lindsay C. Warren, the Controller General of the United States, charged in a report to Congress today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (AP) -- An official report indicated today that Americans may be using sugar at a greater rate than that set by the Government under a marketing-control program. The report -- issued by the Department of Agriculture -- bobbed up as some users contended the Government was not permitting enough sugar to be imported to meet the nation's needs.

Two men took a payroll of $4,768 from a porter at 2:15 P. M. yesterday on the Avenue of the Americas as he was walking back from the bank to his concern with the money, according to the police of the West Twentieth Street station.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., Aug. 4 -- Thomas A. Murray, president of the State Federation of Labor, closed the organization's annual convention here today by reporting a victory over Communists in the ranks of the federation.
CANTON, China, Friday, Aug. 5 (AP) -- The Nationalists today officially admitted the loss of Changsha, rice bowl bastion 365 miles north of this refugee capital.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (AP) -- The United States Export-Import Bank today granted $17,900,000 more in loans for rehabilitation and development of Mexican railroads. There were two new credits:

For some time I have been reading the editorials of THE NEW YORK TIMES and other American newspapers that reach me about the persecution of the Catholic Church and her hierarchy by the Soviets and their satellites. I am surprised and deeply regret that nothing has been mentioned about liquidation of the Ukrainian Catholic Church in Western Ukraine and Carpatho-Ukraine, which has been persecuted for so long.

A glimpse back at the schoolday styles of our mothers and grandmothers introduced the latest in college fashions, shown by Abraham Straus last night. Whether the student was planning to earn her degree in northern Maine or southern California, her needs could be met from the clothes featured in this show.

Federal Judge Harold R. Medina warned defense witnesses at the Communist trial yesterday that they would be jailed if they refused, without valid constitutional reasons, to obey orders of the court to name secret party members.

Robert F. Wagner Jr., chairman of the City Planning Commission and son of the recently resigned senior Senator from New York, was nominated yesterday by Tammany Hall for Borough President of Manhattan.

SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., Aug. 4 -- On a wet, soggy court, slippery to the point of precariousness, Eric Sturgess of South Africa was beaten in the Eastern turf championship at the Orange Lawn Tennis Club late today.

GREAT RIVER, L. I., Aug. 4 -- Owen Torrey, the Noroton Y. C. skipper, showed considerable adeptness at spotting zephyrs today and as a result his Cygnet captured her third straight race in the competition for the Corry Trophy.

A year's free use of an invention, tested for three months in California last winter, that is claimed to reduce fog formations over airports by fifty per cent, was offered yesterday to commercial airlines and the Port of New York Authority.

Joe Louis cast an appraising eye on Ezzard Charles at Pompton Lakes, N. J., yesterday as the National Boxing Association heavyweight champion sparred seven rounds in preparation for his bout with Gus Lesnevich at Yankee Stadium next Wednesday night.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (AP) -- Following is the roll-call vote by which the Republican National Committee elected Guy George Gabrielson as its chairman today:

LONDON, Aug. 4 -- Murderers, and what to do with them, was the subject of an inquiry undertaken today by a new Royal Commission in London. Before the commission at its first public session was a 20,000-word memorandum from the Home Office reviewing eighty years of argument for and against the death penalty for murder.

Cortisone, the recently synthesized adrenal gland hormone that has shown itself to be the most promising substance found so far for the control of arthritis and rheumatic fever, will henceforth be distributed by a committee of the National Academy of Sciences, it was announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- President Truman said during a discussion of his well-known souvenir book matches today that he did not know Mr. Hunt.

TRENTON, Aug. 4 -- Judge Charles P. Hutchinson in Mercer County Court ruled today there was too much evidence against them to warrant releasing in bail six Trenton Negroes charged with the hold-up murder of a shopkeeper.

Bulk export cargo is declining so rapidly in volume that thirty to forty privately-owned American-flag freighters are in Atlantic Coast ports without assignments, shipping men reported here yesterday.
LONDON, Aug. 4 -- The United States Joint Chiefs of Staff have indicated that they favor locating headquarters of the organization in Europe, preferably in London, but not in the United States.

CHICAGO, Aug. 4 -- One hundred eighty-six pairs started play this afternoon in the Masters Pair event, for custody of the Waldemar von Zeedtwitz cup, emblematic of what has long been regarded as the most important pair event in tournament contract bridge.
Motorists who dawdle and daydream and who slow up cars behind them were designated yesterday as increasing factors in traffic accidents.

"WHAT'S that you're reading?" asked the office visitor on his daily call. "It looks like a book for children, 'The Pirates in the Deep Green Sea.'* What do you think you're doing? What about all those books you never did read?"

CHICAGO, Aug. 4 -- Price changes in the grain markets were rapid today on the Board of Trade, due largely to professional operations. Somewhat higher prices were established early, followed by a rapid decline under general selling, but an oversold condition developed on the break and a strong rally followed, the best prices of the day on wheat and corn being made shortly before the close.

Fifteen longshoremen, who had pleaded guilty to unemployment insurance frauds, were sentenced yesterday by Magistrate Robert F. Mahoney in Municipal Term Court to workhouse terms ranging from five days up to one year.

CHICAGO, Aug. 4 -- An ex-convict was shot and killed this afternoon in a pitched gun battle with twenty-nine squads of police in the freight shed of the North Western Railway Station after he had shot and seriously wounded a policeman who had halted him for a traffic violation.

The report of Warner Bros., Pictures, Inc., and its subsidiaries, released today, for the nine months ended on last May 28, shows a net profit, after provision of $4,900,000 for taxes, of $7,363,168, compared with $10,321,000 in the same period of the previous year.

LAKE SUCCESS, Aug. 4 -- Member countries of the United Nations Security Council gave an enthusiastic reception today to the report of Acting Mediator Dr. Ralph J. Bunche successfully winding up the Israeli-Arab armistice negotiations.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- The Government is distributing $74,000,000 worth of stand-by orders for cutting tools to become effective in case a new emergency should arise, it was announced tonight by John R. Steelman, Acting Chairman of the National Security Resources Board.

John K. Collins has been promoted to personnel administrator of Macy's New York, effective on Aug. 8, it was announced yesterday by Richard Weil Jr., president. In the new position he will direct employment, training, wage administration, employe services, health and safety activities for the New York store, its branches and warehouse.

Advertising in the eight major New York City newspapers during July totaled 9,605,912 lines, an increase of 5.95 per cent over the like month of last year, an analysis of Media Records showed yesterday. Categories recording gains were: Automotive, up 41.44 per cent; genera], 21.01 per cent, and retail, 3.37 per cent.

ROME, Aug. 4 -- The Italian and Yugoslav Governments signed a commercial agreement this afternoon for the exchange of 54,000,000,000 lire (about $94,000,000) worth of goods during the next twelve months. The agreement runs from today to Aug. 3, 1950, and contains no provision for automatic extension on expiration.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 4 -- Negotiation of a new basic agreement for the fourteen local unions of the International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employes will get under way tomorrow with presentation of demands to film producers' representatives by Richard Walsh, president of the IATSE.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- President Truman announced today that the long-expected China White Paper would be released by the State Department tomorrow with a view to dispelling "considerable misapprehension, distortion and misunderstanding" that had surrounded Sino-American relations of recent years.

Money market observers noted yesterday that the Treasury's announcement of its next sale of discount bills designates $1,000,000,000 as the total borrowing for the second week in succession. However, the new issue will represent an increase of only $100,000,000 more than the one it will replace on Aug. 11.

The stock market moved yesterday within a narrow range, reached no decisive decision and closed slightly on the lower side. The session was devoid of color and, except for an outcropping of interest in the gold mining issues, the list lapsed into a typical hot-weather affair.

The New York City Housing Authority received bids yesterday ranging from 0.82 to 0.86 per cent interest for issues of $23,500,000 of temporary-loan notes intended to continue the temporary financing of four non-cash-subsidy, city-aided housing projects.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (AP) -- Senator Ernest W. McFarland of Arizona suggested today a 4-to-6 cent a pound tariff on copper, instead of the 2 cents recommended, to meet competition from Chilean producers. He was among witnesses testifying before the Senate Finance Committee on a bill to bring back the 2 cents a pound pre-war duty on imported copper.

Aided by a sharp increase in revenues and an effective economy program, American Airlines, Inc., realized a net profit of $3,536,000 in the first six months of 1949, compared with a net deficit of $4,098,000 in the similar period of last year, the airline announced yesterday.
TOKYO, Aug. 4 -- The Japanese Government is planning by the end o this year to re-establish at least in part its pre-war diplomatic service, it was credibly reported here today.

JONES BEACH, L. I., Aug. 4 -- While a torrential rain poured down upon deserted sands outside, Governor Dewey cut a birthday cake today that symbolized the twentieth anniversary of the opening of Jones Beach.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- Department store sales in the week ended July 30 were 11 per cent lower than sales in the corresponding week of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. The following lists percentage changes from like periods of 1948:

The normally active Hoboken waterfront presented a ghost-like appearance yesterday with half its major steamship piers strikebound for the third successive day by a "wildcat" walkout of 370 longshoremen. Only one ship was being worked along the one-mile stretch from Weehawken to Jersey City.

A jury of eleven men and one woman, as well as two men alternates, was selected yesterday and will begin hearing evidence on Monday in the General Sessions wiretap trial of John G. Broady, private investigator, and his assistant, Edward M. Jones, a former Treasury Department agent.

NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 4 -- Representatives of India and Pakistan met here today in an attempt to solve the question of water rights on the rivers that rise in this dominion and flow into Pakistan. Foreign Minister Sir Mohammed Zafrullah Khan, leader of the Pakistani delegation, said his country was prepared to submit the dispute to the International Court of Justice should no settlement be reached.

A Federal District court authorization permitting the Surface Transportation Corporation to request an interim eight-cent fare on its forty-nine lines in Manhattan and the Bronx was granted by Judge Samuel H. Kaufman yesterday to trustees of the Third Avenue Transit Corporation, of which Surface is a subsidiary.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended last Saturday totaled 723,810 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 5,294 cars or 0.7 per cent more than for the preceding week, 170,565 cars or 19.1 per cent fewer than for the corresponding week last year, and 197,781 cars or 21.5 per cent fewer than during the corresponding week two years ago.

BLOOMFIELD, N. J., Aug. 4 -- Emery Thomas, the home golf professional and 1949 New Jersey open champion, today came within two and one half inches of duplicating the ace he made in 1947 on the same special World-Telegram acing hole at the Forest Hill Field Club.

SHANGHAI, Aug. 4 -- Communist armies driving toward Lanchow and northwest China are entering the broad belt of Moslems that runs across Asia, the Middle East and North Africa to Gibraltar. Today ten new rules for the behavior of Red troops entering the world of Islam were published here.

When Gov. Chester Bowles recently signed a bill prohibiting discrimination because of race, color or creed in all public places, including housing projects, the State of Connecticut joined seventeen other Northern and Western states which make similar guarantees in their civil rights statutes.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- The Senate voted by 55 to 36 today to bar Spain from receiving $50,000,000 in Marshall Plan recovery loans by upholding a decision by Vice President Alben W. Barkley that the proposal was not in order for inclusion in the $5,647,724,000 foreign aid bill. Spain is not in the sphere of the Economic Cooperation Administration.
OCEANPORT, N. J., Aug. 4 -- Mrs. Ann Schuling is observing her fifteenth anniversary this week as the nation's leading woman fashioner of jockey silks.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Aug. 4 -- Israel's proffered contribution toward resettlement o Arab refugees in this country is expected to be underwritten, at least in part, by International aid, it was disclosed today by Foreign Minister Moshe Sharett.

Daniel Frisch, president of the Zionist Organization of America, who returned this week from a four-week mission to Israel, emphasized yesterday the need for the Israeli Government to adopt a "pro-Western orientation." Such a policy, he maintained, would encourage a more rapid influx of private capital and also lead to Marshall Plan aid for Israel.

Dr. Richard H. Hoffman, psychiatrist, took the witness stand for the second day at the "lonely hearts" trial of Mrs. Martha Jule Beck and Raymond Martinez Fernandez in Bronx County Court House yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (UP) -- Three of the nation's top union officials were invited today to testify before a Senate Banking subcommittee investigating alleged labor-union monopolies.

LONDON, Aug. 4 -- Bruce Woodcock, Britain's top heavyweight boxer who is scheduled to meet Lee Savold here on Sept. 6 for the British version of the world heavyweight championship, was injured today in a truck accident.

President Truman has put his finger on the one essential element in the whole foreign military aid program when he declares that the important thing is to provide the money necessary to restore the defensive bulwarks of Western Europe and implement the North Atlantic alliance, and that this should be done as quickly as possible.

Combining good styling and quality with lowered price tags was the not-so-simple task accomplished yesterday at Gimbels in a showing of furs. Although prices are approximately 35 per cent lower than last year's, there was no lack of luxury in the sweep of backs, the combinations of fur, the deep cuffs or wide sleeves.

SHANGHAI, Aug. 4 -- A financial settlement amounting to about $155,000 has been accepted by the Navy at Washington as a final step in disposing of separation wage claims here by about 800 former Navy employes, it was learned today.
PARIS, Aug. 4 -- The quotation for gold rose suddenly on the Paris market today, bars being marked up from 578,000 francs to 601,000 and the gold Napoleon from 4,090 to 4,200.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday closed firm, 7 to 10 points net higher on the day.

For the first time in the sixty- seven-year history of the electric utility industry in this country, production of power reached 289,000,000,000 kilowatt hours in the twelve months to June 30, according to Federal Power Commission reports received yesterday.
HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Aug. 4 -- Students at Hofstra College will begin thumbing through the pages of history next month to discover the story behind the textbook.

Negotiations between four major international airlines and the Port of New York Authority looking to a settlement of the two-year-old dispute over use of Idlewild Airport in Queens were resumed yesterday with Governor Dewey again acting as mediator.

SARANAC LAKE, N. Y., Aug 4 -- The New York Giants, opening training today for their twenty-fifth season in the National Football League, announced that a conditional deal is pending for the acquisition of Ed Kolman, 230-pound tackle, from the Chicago Bears.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 4 -- Premier Marshal Tito announced today to the generals and officers of Yugoslav garrisons stationed along the southern frontiers that the Yugoslav Army was prepared to defend the territorial integrity of Yugoslavia against any invading army, including the Soviet Army.

Faced with an acute shortage of nurses and fifty-eight new cases of poliomyelitis here for the second successive day, officials of the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis and doctors of the United States Children's Bureau prepared last night to map broad plans to stem the slowly rising tide of the epidemic.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 4 -- Dick Powell, who recently signed with Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer to star in "The Reformer and the Red Head," has been engaged by the studio for a second film, "Right Cross," which will follow "The Reformer."

The year 1948 was the most successful in the history of the Municipal Broadcasting System, according to the annual report of WNYC, the city's station, submitted yesterday to Mayor O'Dwyer by Seymour N. Siegel, Director of Radio Communications.
Members of a Korean industrial cultural mission gave assurances here yesterday that machinery will be set up to place the new republic's international trade on a stable and responsible basis.

SEOUL, Korea, Friday, Aug. 5 -- Korean army headquarters this morning stated that the situation in the Ongjin Peninsula, where the North Korean Communist forces yesterday opened a large scale attack against the republican army, had been "stabilized."

BOSTON, Aug. 4 (AP) -- Boston's Red Sox supported the six-hit pitching of right hander Joe Dobson with a fourteen-hit attack for a 12-2 victory today over the American League's last place St. Louis Browns.

LONDON, Aug. 4 -- Particulars of last month's working of some thirty South African gold mining companies received here today show that production costs have been lowered. As a result, kaffirs received a boost in the stock market here today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- Mustering a bare majority necessary for election, Guy George Gabrielson of New Jersey, 58-year-old lawyer-business man, today became the new Republican National Chairman.

OSLO, Norway, Aug. 4 -- The most powerful man in Norway today is Erik Brofoss, who runs the nation's economy in accordance with the Crippsian doctrine that austerity is not only necessary but really rather noble.

With an explanation that the state expects a declining crop of GI students and an increased yield of grain, plans for converting the post-war emergency college at Sampson, N. Y., into a storage depot for 2,500,000 bushels of wheat were announced here yesterday.

TRENTON, N. J., Aug. 4 (AP) -- Deposits in New Jersey commercial banks dropped 2.3 per cent in the 1948 fiscal year, while deposits in savings institutions increased 3.9 per cent, the State Banking Department said today.

ATLANTA, Aug. 4 -- A full investigation of a state-wide illegal liquor ring was under way here today after evidence was made public of a million-dollar lawless operation in dry Georgia counties "apparently under state protection."

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 4 -- A statement seeking to reassure shippers by saying the West Coast CIO longshoremen did not expect the Hawaii strike to spread here, but nevertheless carrying a work-stoppage threat for this coast, was issued here today by the International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union, CIO.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- During the week ended Aug. 3 member bank reserve balances increased $133,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board announced today.

The summer is many things to many people. To a couple of cool million, it is Coney Island. To some it is the seashore, to others the mountains, and to a not inconsiderable number it is the comfort of an air-conditioned movie house.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (AP) -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican, of Wisconsin, told the Senate today that Secretary of Agriculture Charles F. Brannan apparently has a "Brannan plan for Polish and Russian farmers."

Clarification of "what the ultimate objective of the Roman Catholic Church's hierarchy is as to the appropriation of public funds for denominational organizations" was called for yesterday by Dr. John K. Norton, Professor of Education at Columbia University's Teachers College.

The National Dairy Products Corporation achieved a new high record in earnings in the first six months of this year despite price reductions on its products and yesterday voted an increased dividend to stockholders.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., Aug. 4 -- Kept on shore this morning because there was no wind at all, the nine crews gathered at Larchmont Yacht Club for the Syce Cup series made an effort to complete the Women's Long Island Sound sailing championship program this afternoon, but the air was so light only two of three remaining races could be staged.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (AP) -- James V. Hunt, Washington management counselor whose business dealings are under scrutiny by Senators investigating "5 per centers," asserted today that he once saved a client $400,000 by getting the Army to repossess 1,000,000 DDT "bombs."

Coffee futures continued yesterday their decline of Wednesday in early trading on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. The "S" contract was off about 25 to 45 points around midday but rallied somewhat from the low levels on support from trade houses with producer connections.

Twenty million index guide cards, 41,250 feet of lamp cord, 200 electric toasters and 27,355 gallons of ice cream are among the miscellaneous volume needs of government purchasing agencies for which invitations to bid are listed in the current bulletin of the New York City Department of Commerce.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (AP) -- Cleveland shaved the lead of the New York Yankees to two and a half games tonight by sweeping a twilight-night double-header from the Senators before a crowd of 24,299. The Indians traveled twelve innings to capture the opener, 6 -- 3, then coasted to a 14-1 victory behind Bob Feller's six-hit pitching.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- Dr. Shields Warren, Director of the Division of Biology and Science, Atomic Energy Commission, today said that treatment for radiation sickness was "way behind the times" and must be stepped up as a matter of preparedness against atomic warfare.

DETROIT, Aug. 4 -- The Ford Motor Company vigorously protested today to the State Labor Mediation Board against the board's ruling regarding the conduct of the scheduled strike vote among 87,000 Ford workers in Michigan.
ANNECY, France, Aug. 4 -- The United States has completed four of its most important tariff negotiations at the Annecy tariff conference and is well along on others, it was learned here today.

LONDON, Aug. 4 -- India was readmitted as a full member of the sterling area under the terms of a new financial agreement with Britain, it was announced today. As a result, India will be entitled to draw on central gold and dollar reserves equally with other members of the sterling area, who have agreed to make a 25 per cent cut in dollar imports.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 4 (AP) -- The Reds knocked off the fading Phillies in both ends of a doubleheader today, 8 -- 5 and 9 -- 1, to sweep a four-game series. The Reds clipped three Philadelphia pitchers for 11 hits in winning the opener and Johnny Vender Meer, veteran Cincinnati southpaw, threw a five-hitter in the nightcap.

PITTSBURGH, Pa., Aug. 4 -- Philip Murray, president of the CIO United Steelworkers Union, denied today that his union last year reached agreement with the United States Steel Corporation not to bargain on pensions this year.

PARIS, Aug. 4 -- The three United States Chiefs of Staff arrived in Paris today to face the problem of the differences between the British and French that have handicapped agreement on European defense in the committee of commanders in chief of the Western European Union group with headquarters at Fontainebleau.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- President Truman said today that there was no prospect of repealing any wartime excise taxes before the next session of Congress, at least. This position, taken along with the jammed legislative situation in the Senate, appeared to foreclose any possibility of canceling the levies before January.
THE TIMES editorial of Aug. 2, "Wartime Excise Taxes," seemed to overlook or minimize many significant matters.

Pat Mullin, a .250-hitter elsewhere but a pest against the Yankees, singled home the winning run in the eleventh inning as the Tigers conquered the league-leaders, 3 -- 2, yesterday at the Stadium. Mullin's fourth safety cost Vic Raschi his sixth defeat of the campaign and the big right-hander still is looking for his first victory over the Detroit club.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 4 -- Darrell Clingman, an ex-Coast Guardsman who ate himself out of his peacetime job while serving his Uncle Samuel, gave an 8-year-old gelding named Galactic an estimable ride today to win the forty-sixth running of Saratoga's Shillelah Steeplechase.

I believe that I express the sentiment of tens of thousands of Americans of Lebanese descent when I tell you how grateful I am for the detailed and careful news THE NEW YORK TIMES has carried of events in Lebanon during the last troubled weeks.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Aug. 4 -- Islam would no longer be the state religion of Syria and there would be no requirement that the President be a Moslem under the new Constitution, whose draft terms are becoming known. However, it has been reported that the requirement on the President's religion, part of the old Constitution, is being reinstated.

Vegetables and fruits offer the most opportunities for thrifty buying this week-end. Nor is the choice limited, for the local office of the United States Department of Agriculture recommends as many as fourteen different vegetables and six fruits as being moderately priced.

Television seems headed for another milestone in October when, for the first time, viewers in every major league baseball city will be able to watch all games of the World Series, no matter where they are played. This will be possible because all baseball cities have been linked by the coaxial cable and relay points since the last World Series.
Some deeds of derring-do afloat came to the notice of this department yesterday from points as far apart as Bermuda, Massachusetts, Missouri and Canada.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- Administration forces, with the consent of President Truman, withdrew today the most controversial section of the $1,450,000,000 foreign military aid bill, but stood firm for no reduction in the figure itself.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- President Truman's statement of July 28 on the atomic energy discussions with representatives of Great Britain and Canada fully sustained the general position taken in the Atomic Energy Commission and before the joint Congressional committee by Rear Admiral Lewis L. Strauss, USNR, retired.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- Friends like to refer to Guy George Gabrielson, the new Republican National Chairman, as "an Iowa farm boy who made good," but those farm days now are far behind him.

A two-hour mass picketing demonstration was held yesterday morning by 1,000 members of Local 116. United Automobile Workers, CIO, at the American Machine and Foundry Company, 5502 Second Avenue, Brooklyn, where a strike began May 2.

ROOSEVELT FIELD, L. I., Aug. 5 -- Memories of the days when Roosevelt Field was the best-known airport in the world -- the start or finish of many epoch - making flights -- were stirred here today with the establishment of a new private plane service headquarters.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- The Chinese National Government is on the verge of collapse solely because of the military, political and economic incapacity of the Kuomintang's leaders, the State Department found in a China White Paper made public today.
LONDON, Aug. 5 -- Professional evening-up before the week-end caused a firmer tendency in the stock market here today.

The views expressed in the letter of Dr. George F. Lull, published July 27, concerning President Truman's proposal for a National Department of Welfare, reaffirm the narrow perspective of the American Medical Association.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 5 -- It was $10.80 to win and $11.80 to place on Royce G. Martin's Woodvale Farm entry in the $9,725 Test Stakes at Saratoga today. For Lady Dorimar won it and her stablemate, Tall Weeds, carrying the Woodvale Farm's second colors, easily was second at the end of the seven furlongs.

A strong market in coffee futures featured the final trading session of the week on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange as prices resumed the advance interrupted the previous two days. Trading was light in volume with most of the buying for trade-house connections with offerings from profit-taking on a scale-up.

Capt. Harold E. Snow has been placed in command of the Exilona, the first of four modern freighters purchased by the American Export Lines from the Shepard Steamship Company at a cost of $1,050,000 each, it was announced yesterday by L. S. Andrews, operating manager of the Export Lines.
Federal authorities here expressed belief yesterday that another counterfeiting ring had been uncovered since the arrest Thursday night by Secret Service police of two alleged dealers in fake bills.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Aug. 5 -- Despite all the talk in Washington about the importance of Norway, Denmark and the Benelux countries to United States foreign policy and the North Atlantic treaty, it is generally agreed in diplomatic quarters that the United States is about as poorly represented in these countries as it has been since the heyday of isolationism.

QUITO, Ecuador, Saturday, Aug. 6 (AP) -- A witness broadcasting by radio from Ambato said early today about 200 persons were killed there by an earthquake that shook Ecuador's populous central mountain district yesterday.

A summer conference of the World's Student Christian Federation to be attended by 200 Christian student leaders of this and thirty other countries will be held Aug. 24 to Aug. 31 at Bowling Green State University, Bowling Green, Ohio.

Market bids for United States Government bonds moved up briskly yesterday, bringing the quotations for the long-term obligations to within slight fractions of peak prices reached in mid-July in the first reaction to the Federal Reserve System's rededication to cheap money.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (UP) -- Dr. J. Leighton Stuart, United States Ambassador to China, believes that the destiny of China, as a Communist or democratic nation, will be decided in the long run by the rising generation of educated youths, it was revealed today.

MUNICH, Germany, Aug. 5 -- Dr. Kurt Schumacher, leader of the Social Democratic party, stated publicly tonight for the first time that his party was conducting an "underground" resistance to Soviet rule in Eastern Germany. The Socialists were banned in the Soviet zone in 1946 after the Russians had forced an "amalgamation" with the Communists.

BELGRADE, Aug. 5 -- Marshal Tito's speech in Skoplje to generals and officers commanding forces along the southern frontiers that warned them against the possibility of an attack was received calmly in Belgrade and the rest of Yugoslavia, as far as could be determined.
Irving Katzenbogen, sought for seven months as the leader of a hold-up gang that took $100,000 at gunpoint in this and other cities, was arrested in his home territory of Brownsville early yesterday.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Aug. 5 (AP) -- Murray D. Lincoln, a farm leader with labor support, said today he might oppose Senator Taft in the Republican primary next year. Republican leaders had figured that Mr. Taft would win renomination with little trouble before a bitter fight for re-election.

The Union Printers International Baseball League championship, handicapped all week by rain, moves into its semi-final and final rounds today. A heavy schedule was played yesterday and by the time the morning and afternoon games had been contested New York, St. Louis, Washington and Detroit had qualified for today's competition.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., Aug. 5 -- An 18-year-old student at Bryn Mawr, who has sailed a lot for fun during the past five years but never before competed in a major event, today won the Syce Cup, emblematic of the women's sailing championship of Long Island Sound, as the four-day, nine-race series ended at Larchmont Yacht Club.

The difficulties between Local 968 of the International Lorgshoremen's Association, AFL, and its parent organization stems from the "influence" of the Communist party on the leadreship of the affiliate, it was charged yesterday in Brooklyn Supreme Court.

CHICAGO, Aug. 5 -- Reports that the Senate was considering new farm price-support measures that would result in an estimated advance of 6 per cent in parity for loans on next year's harvest, led to general buying of grains on the Board of Trade here today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- The General Advisory Committee of the United States Atomic Energy Commission unanimously denounced today the proposal that would require all holders of AEC fellowships to be investigated by the Federal Bureau of Investigation.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (AP) -- The Southwestern Power Administration has the right to buy electric power and to rent transmission lines from other systems, the Department of the Interior said today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- Following are the texts of two documents included in the White Paper on United States-Chinese relations issued by the State Department today. The first is Secretary of State Dean Acheson's letter transmitting the White Paper to President Truman; the second [on the following page] is the report on China submitted to Mr. Truman in September, 1947, by Lieut. Gen. Albert C. Wedemeyer.

PARIS, Aug. 5 -- Strict limitation of the agenda for the Consultative Assembly of Europe when it meets in Strasbourg next Wednesday was undertaken here today by the alternates of the ten foreign ministers who form the Committee of Ministers, which will have the final word on all the assembly does.

Alaska Airlines, Inc., penalized by the Civil Aeronautics Board on Thursday following charges of safety violations, declared in a statement issued from its New York office yesterday that the company did not admit the validity of the charges but consented to the CAB action to avoid litigation.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (AP) -- Mickey Haefner, fired for "indifferent performance" by Washington a month ago, won his first game since then at the expense of his former team-mates tonight. Playing for Chicago, the little left-hander held the Senators to seven hits as the White Sox posted a protested 4-1 victory.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., Aug. 5 -- Benjamin F. Fairless, president of the United States Steel Corporation, defended competitive constructive enterprise and warned graduating Bryant College students here today that they must not accept Governmental regulation and dictation as logical conditions in peacetime.

BLOOMFIELD, N. J., Aug. 5 -- At the conclusion of play in the New Jersey Women's Golf Association one-day tournament at the Forest Hill Field Club today, there was a tie for low gross honors between Mrs. H. C. Ramsey of Baltusrol, who posted 36, 41 -- 77, and Miss Maureen Orcutt of White Beeches, whose nines were 39, 38 -- 77.

As fifty-six new poliomyelitis cases were reported yesterday by the city Department of Health, an encouraging trend was painted into the pessimistic picture of the situation by local citizens, who were starting "to do something about it."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (UP) -- Civil Aeronautics Board lawyers today said the proposed purchase of American Overseas Airlines by Pan American Airways was part of "a relentless drive to establish a private empire controlling a strategic sector of our national life."

SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., Aug. 5 -- Felicisimo Ampon, the little man from the Philippines who eliminated Eric Sturgess of South Africa, was defeated by Arthur Larsen of San Francisco today in the semi-final round of the Eastern Turf Court championships at the Orange Lawn Tennis Club.

About forty-five guests collected at the bar of the Villa Sweden Thursday evening, and after a cocktail or two proceeded at the invitation of John Persson, the proprietor, to the restaurant's garden to open the crawfish season.

Dr. Tage Lindbom, Swedish librarian, was released yesterday from Ellis Island after having been detained since his arrival on Tuesday. A board of special inquiry convened at 9:30 A. M., and after an hour's interrogation admitted Dr. Lindbom.

The First Army broke a significant rule yesterday -- to the satisfaction of the four "outstanding soldiers of the month." Four pretty young actresses were in the company of the GI's as they started their week-end in New York as a reward for their outstanding qualities as soldiers.

Smarting under widespread American reports that Britain's present dollar crisis was of that country's own making, the British Information Service issued here yesterday a defense of the nation's post-war recovery efforts.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- President Truman today filled two vacancies in the Department of the Army by appointing civilians who had broad military experience in responsible positions in the last war.

BREMERHAVEN, Germany, Aug. 5 -- United States Army customs agents impounded an Israeli ship today and ordered her officers to unload millions of dollars' worth of contraband machinery and vehicles that allegedly were to have been smuggled into Israel.
DALLAS, Tex., Aug. 5 (AP) -- Twenty-seven perfect scores were recorded today as skeet's biggest prize -- the all-gauge championship -- went on the block in the national tournament.

Police and pickets battled again yesterday outside the Brooklyn plant of the strike-bound American Machine and Foundry Company, and four men, including the regional director of the United Automobile Workers, CIO, were arrested.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture announced today it would support the price of 1949 cottonseed with a 90 per cent of parity loan program, guaranteeing growers $49.50 a ton.

DETROIT, Aug. 5 -- The Ford Motor Company today made a new proposal in its contract dispute with the United Automobile Workers, CIO. At the same time the company accused union officials of deliberate misstatements to influence members to vote for a strike.

PARIS, Aug. 5 -- While about 6,000 heavily armed police and security troops surrounded the Place de la Concorde to prevent a Communist-led demonstration against their visit, the three United States Chiefs of Staff spent today discussing the military organization under the North Atlantic pact.

MADISON, Wis., Aug. 5 (UP) -- Angry labor leaders fought today to put an end to a new state rent decontrol law. The law wiped out Federal controls in the state today and within hours protests started coming from tenants, veterans' groups and labor organizations.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- President Truman, like most citizens this summer, is trying to beat the heat, but unlike most of them he is able to do it in his air-cooled quarters aboard the yacht Williamsburg.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Aug. 5 -- Arab refugees will be resettled in Israel even before actual peace terms are signed with the Arab states, Foreign Minister Moshe Sharett disclosed today. This country will consider that peace obtains when it is proclaimed by the United Nations.
MINEOLA, L. I., Aug. 5 -- Walter O. Feser of Bellmore may have a chance to take part in a grand jury investigation into the death three years ago of his 17-year-old son, Walter, Jr.

CHICAGO, Aug. 5 (AP) -- James E. Day, president of the Chicago Stock Exchange, announced today that representatives of the midwestern stock exchanges preparing to merge would meet here on Aug. 15 and 16 to set an effective date for the merger.

SHANGHAI, Aug. 5 -- With the exception of those held accountable for "major offenses," all landlords and rich farmers who had fled to Shanghai from Communist-held rural areas are now being invited to join the "Back to the Village" movement and participate in the drive to boost agricultural production.

JERSEY CITY, N. J., Aug. 5 -- Striking longshoremen withdrew today an offer to remove 4,000 cases of perishable goods from the strike-bound American Export Lines piers here when the company officials insisted that the men be paid through a boss loader.

An exuberant art show, staged by children 5 to 12 years old on the rooftop of Public School 125 at 425 West 123d Street, produced a volume of work and color yesterday that vied with similar demonstrations in the grown-up world.

LONG BEACH, L. I., Aug. 5 -- Long Beach's primary campaign entered into a definite stage today as the deadline for declination of nominating positions found only the American Labor party switching candidates, and contests pending primary day Sept. 6, in both Democratic and Republican primaries.

CHICAGO, Aug. 5 -- In the crowded ballroom of the Stevens Hotel, 186 pairs this afternoon came to the half way mark of the four session master pairs contract bridge championship. With two afternoon sessions yet to play in this, the most important pair event conducted by the American Contract Bridge League, many of the teams are already too far behind to have much chance of catching the leaders.

Government, transportation and hotel officials, and all business men connected with tourism are "going all out" in Italy in preparation for millions of visitors expected for the Catholic Church's Holy Year observances of 1950, George C. Gaede, passenger traffic manager of the American Export Lines, said yesterday.

Wine sales this year will equal or exceed the record levels reached last year, according to present indications, Godfrey Irwin, local representative of the Wine Institute predicted yesterday. The institute represents the California industry which produces between 85 and 90 per cent of the wine used in this country, he explained.

More than 250 production engineers representing leading plants in American industry have collaborated to produce the first comprehensive "stockpiling" of the technical "know-how" of metalworking production in an indexed form, printed and ready for use, Harry E. Conrad, executive secretary of the American Society of Tool Engineers, Detroit, announced here yesterday.

BERLIN, Aug. 5 -- An all-out drive to make Berlin rather than Bonn the capital of the new West German state is to be a major plank of the Social Democratic campaign for the Aug. 14 elections, it was learned here today. A very high Western source explained that the other parties were expected to follow the Social Democratic lead.

Ad Gains Defy Pessimism The continued gain in volume of newspaper advertising during the first half of 1949 was cited by a marketing director yesterday as evidence that many companies have been waging determined selling drives despite ups and downs of optimism during the period.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (UP) -- Senator Pat McCarran, Democrat, of Nevada, said today that the Senate judiciary subcommittee, of which he is chairman, was studying how more displaced persons could be admitted to this country without depriving native Americans of jobs and homes.

Philip Hodes, Public Service Commission attorney, yesterday challenged a cost income schedule prepared by the Long Island Rail Road at a hearing on the road's petition for a 16 2-3 per cent one-way passenger fare increase.

George Eliopoulos, who has been described by Federal officials as "a notorious drug smuggler," has received sixty days to leave the country or face deportation, the office of Attorney General Tom Clark announced yesterday.

EAST NORTHFIELD, Mass., Aug. 5 -- America must recover its sense of a divine mission in the world if it is to prevail over the diabolical moral and spiritual forces that threaten us, Dr. Stanley High, editor, educator and churchman, declared here tonight.
NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 5 -- The Communist drive throughout Southeast Asia that was started in March, 1948, has been checked in India, Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru told a press conference tonight.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (AP) -- The Interstate Commerce Commission today blocked scheduled reductions in automobile hauling charges by rail and barge lines south of St. Louis and Kansas City, Mo.
Because Raymond Johnson became homesick for his wife and young son he was on his way back to Richmond, Va., yesterday to resume serving a twenty-year prison sentence for fatally shooting a man.

In transmitting the White Paper on China to the President, Secretary Acheson placed emphasis on the value of "informed and critical public opinion." Presumably it is in the interest of the formation of that opinion that this report has been compiled and published.

China's history is replete with examples of encroachment, arbitrary action, special privilege, exploitation, and usurpation of territory on the part of foreign powers. Continued foreign infiltration, penetration or efforts to obtain spheres of influence in China, including Manchuria and Taiwan (Formosa), could be interpreted only as a direct infringement and violation of China's sovereignty and a contravention of the principles of the Charter of the United Nations.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (UP) -- The House of Representatives ignored today a White House veto threat and passed, 183 to 131, a bill to exempt so-called independent natural gas producers from the rate and service regulations of the Federal Power Commission.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- The new and vivacious Treasurer of the United States, Mrs. Georgia Neese Clark, was giving away Some of Uncle Sam's money today.

LAKE SUCCESS, Aug. 5 -- Taking note of charges and countercharges made by the Yugoslav and Greek Governments concerning the latest of scores of border incidents -- the so-called Skra incident -- the United Nations Special Committee on the Balkans reported dispiritedly today that both sides were to blame.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Aug. 5 (AP) -- The Government's order that priests must defy the Vatican decree on excommunication of Communists drew a defiant rejection tonight from Roman Catholic authorities in western Bohemia.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 5 -- Clark Gable will play the leading role in Metro - Goldwyn - Mayer's "Across the Wide Missouri," which Talbot Jennings is adapting to the screen from a novel by Bernard de Voto about the fur traders of the early nineteenth century, the studio announced today.

Price irregularity prevailed in a moderately active cotton futures market yesterday. Active contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange closed mixed, 8 points lower to 28 points higher than Thursday's final quotations.

Two new films will have local premieres today. "The Window," an RKO melodrama featuring Bobby Driscoll, Barbara Hale, Ar thur Kennedy, Paul Stewart and Ruth Roman, will be presented at the Victoria. . . . The Stanley's new attraction will be "Maid of Formosa," which is said to be the "first modern" Chinese film drama.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (UP) -- Representative James T. Patterson, Republican, of Connecticut, warned the northern and eastern parts of the nation today that they were giving up their wealth to the South land Southwest. He said many measures passed by Congress helped the movement mainly by providing money which "comes, in great measure, from the hard-pressed taxpayers of the so-called wealthy states in the northern half of the country."

PARIS, Aug. 5 -- Maggy Rouff, known for her superb dressmaking, offered as her special theme the extravagant use of bows and bow trimmings. Loops puffed and ends floated at the sides of long and short dresses.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- Julius A. Krug, Secretary of the Interior, today announced the appointment of a nineteen-member United States Citizens Committee to take part in the meeting of the United Nations Scientific Conference on Conservation and Utilization of Resources Aug. 17 at Lake Success. Mr. Krug is chairman of the United States group for the conference.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, Aug. 5 (AP) -- Exiled King Leopold III tonight told Belgium's three leading political parties only Parliament could decide whether he should return to the throne.

NANTUCKET, Mass., Aug. 5 -- After three squadron runs in fog, rain and calms, twenty-three of the sailing craft on the New York Yacht Club cruise left harbor on this Atlantic island today looking for a race out on the ocean. There still was some fog and they encountered what is known as an "Irish hurricane," that is no wind at all.

New Yorkers have good reason to be proud of what Governor Dewey described the other day as "the finest and most varied park system" in the country. He was speaking at the twentieth anniversary celebration of perhaps the most famous state park of them all "and the one we are most proud of": Jones Beach.

There are few things that give a calmer, cooler look to a room on a hot, sultry day than fresh foliage massed in glass bowls or other containers and scattered about a room. Several new groups of hand-blown glass have such interesting shapes, textures and colors that it is possible to achieve an extremely decorative effect with them using only leaves and greens and omitting the more perishable flowers.

A dispatch from Batavia, Java, appearing in THE NEW YORK TIMES Aug. 1 attempted to define the position of Indonesian Republicans and Federalists by saying "the Federalists are pro-Dutch, and the two factions have differed in the past over relations with the Netherlands."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (UP) -- A Senate subcommittee investigating "five percenters" has subpoenaed State Department files on John Maragon, former Kansas City boot-black and one-time frequent White House visitor, it was revealed today.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 5 -- Public display of the historic American flag raised on Mount Surabachi today featured the first annual convention of the Fifth Marine Division, which played a vital part in seizing the island of Iwo from the Japanese.
WASHINGTON. Aug. 5 (AP) -- A House-approved plan to kill off the War Assets Administration was rejected today by the Senate Appropriations Committee.

United States exports of cotton textiles for the first six months of this year exceeded trade expectations, it was reported here yesterday. The showing in fact was regarded as extremely good in view of the world shortage of dollars and the restrictions placed on textile imports into several countries, particularly Cuba.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 5 (AP) -- The Indians cashed in on four infield errors to score two unearned runs tonight as they defeated the Athletics, 3 -- 2.
TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Aug. 5 (UP) -- The 12,000-acre plantation "Forshalee" was sold today for $605,000 to Mrs. Louise H. Ingalls of Chagrin Falls, Ohio, and R. L. Ireland of Cleveland, Ohio.
Forty-three of the nation's 531 savings banks have deposits in excess of $100,000,000 apiece, the National Association of Mutual Savings Banks reported yesterday.

CHICAGO, Aug 5 (AP) -- The Chicago Cubs battered Warren Spahn and three successors for 15 hits and trounced the Boston Braves, 8 to 3, here today before a gathering of 8,994. It was the fourth straight loss for the Braves.

HONG KONG, Aug. 5 (UP) -- Nationalist defense lines in South China crumbled today with the discovery of a widespread plot by former government officials to surrender all of Hunan Province to the Communists.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- The Standard Gas and Electric Company, New York, asked the Securities and Exchange Commission today for permission to sell at competitive bidding either 250,000 shares of the no-par-value common stock of the Louisville Gas and Electric Company or 200,000 shares of the $20 par-value common stock of the Oklahoma Gas and Electric Company.

HONOLULU, Aug. 5 -- Harry Bridges, president of the International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union, CIO, made his long-awaited appearance on the scene of the ILWU ninety-seven-day Hawaiian dock strike today and announced that in his opinion there was no way to settle the stubborn wage dispute except by arbitration.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 5 (UP) -- Marshal Tito's Government charged the Soviet Union today with "keeping only its own narrow interests in mind" in having agreed with the West on an Austrian treaty and having shelved Yugoslavia's territorial claim.

There is little in prospect in the schedule of new securities to be floated next week to relieve what is becoming regarded increasingly as a market shortage of high-grade bonds. Underwriters and dealers with scanty supplies are reluctant to run out of offerings altogether.
Contracts were signed yesterday for a production by Daniel Melnick and Bernard Carson this fall of Franz Werfel's "Class Reunion," adapted by Burnet Hershey and Lyon Mearson.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- The Administration submitted today and its leaders promptly introduced in Congress a revised foreign military aid bill that met the major objections of the Republican foreign policy leaders.

The Public Service Commission did not give its sanction yesterday to an eight-cent fare, effective at 12:01 A. M. Sunday, on forty-nine Manhattan and Bronx lines of the Surface Transportation Corporation.
GENEVA, Aug. 5 -- The United States lost its struggle today for a United Nations inquiry into the practice of forced labor.

Highlights of the hearings into the activities of Washington's so-called "5 per centers" will be carried by the American Broadcasting Company each day that the Senate Investigating Committee meets. The taking of testimony is scheduled to begin on Monday before the Senate Investigating Subcommittee of the Committee on Expenditures in Executive Departments.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- Average primary prices declined 0.1 per cent in the week ended on Aug. 2, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. The index was 152.6 per cent of the 1926 average, 0.1 per cent below four weeks ago and 9.9 per cent below the comparable week in 1948.

At a time when the Yankees appeared to be floundering and the contenders narrowing the gap the schedule brought the last-place Browns to the Stadium yesterday. Not even if Casey Stengel himself had planned it, could the timing of the St. Louis visit been better.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- The State Department, in its account of United States military and financial aid to China, today published excerpts from a letter of thanks written on May 5, 1949, by Acting President Li Tsung-jen to President Truman, attributing China's failure to "make judicious use of this aid" to the Chiang Kai-shek regime.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (AP) -- The Department of Commerce reported today that sales of wholesalers specializing in particular lines totaled $5,268,000,000 in June, an increase of 4 per cent over May after allowance for seasonal factors.

The recent and deserved promotion of Gordon Gray to be Secretary of the Army has now been followed by the welcome advancement of Tracy S. Voorhees to the post of Under Secretary. The Department of the Army has been strengthened by these appointments, not least because they have been made from within the ranks and carry no political connotations whatsoever.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- Secretary of State Dean Acheson said today that he had never heard of the so-called Stalin peace offer reported in The United Nations World and said to have been propounded in private conversations in New York by Deputy Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko, Soviet representative to the United Nations.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- After six days of parliamentary tangle over the $5,647,724,000 foreign aid appropriation bill, the Senate defeated decisively today an amendment that was declared to threaten the whole Marshall Plan, and then pressed the measure almost to passage.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (AP) -- Representatives B. W. Kearney and Dean P. Taylor, both Republicans, of New York; said today that Army occupation authorities in Japan had promised relief to the American knit glove industry by reducing cheap Japanese imports. American manufacturers have protested that they cannot compete with the Japanese product because the latter is produced at far below American costs.

Mayor O'Dwyer's proposed survey of wages paid to 140,000 city employes should not be carried out by an outside agency, leaders of civil service employe groups said yesterday at the sixth in a series of twelve scheduled hearings in the Municipal Civil Service Commission's offices at 299 Broadway.

CHICAGO, Aug. 5 -- In an address today at the opening session of the Illinois American Legion's convention, Senator Paul H. Douglas, Democrat, of Illinois, praised the Legion for its aid in obtaining passage by Congress of the housing and slum-clearance measure.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- President Truman today put the full facilities of the Executive establishment behind the projected task of the House Judiciary Committee to rewrite the anti-trust statutes.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 5 (AP) -- An error by Shortstop Granny Hamner allowed Ralph Kiner to score from third in the last of the ninth tonight and gave the Pirates a 1-0 victory over the Phillies. A crowd of 24,944 watched the game.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- A large body of Congressional opinion today opposed Secretary of State Dean Acheson's proposal to abandon direct aid to China in the face of Communist conquest. Criticism of the White Paper sent by Secretary Acheson to President Truman crossed party lines. One Democratic Representative called it an "alibi" for United States failure.

Dr. Lawrence B. Hobson has been appointed associate medical director of E. R. Squibb Sons, where he will work in the field of infections and infectious diseases. He will continue his work in clinical investigations as a member of the staff of the New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Department.

The two-story taxpayer at 1191-1197 Springfield Avenue in Irvington, N. J., containing four stores and four apartments, has been sold by Charm Shop, Inc., to the Daron Realty Corporation for cash above mortgages of $45,500. The Jordan Realty Company and Harry Treister were the brokers.

Commenting on 2,485 complaints received at the Smoke Control Bureau offices in the Municipal Building since he became acting director on July 11, William H. Byrne said yesterday that careless operation of apartment house incinerators and boilers was responsible for many.

Retail Sales Dropped in Week Retail sales continued to decline last week in comparison with sales last year. Department store sales were estimated to be 15 to 20 per cent below the corresponding week in 1948. Sales last week were 14 per cent below last year.
LONDON, Aug. 5 -- There seemed to be a strong disposition in Allied quarters in London today to reduce drastically or halt altogether deliveries of Western German reparations to the Soviet Union.
Difficult questions are on the front pages of newspapers this summer. Shall we arm the nations of Western Europe? Shall England devaluate the pound?

CINCINNATI, Aug. 5 -- When two winning streaks meet one usually is snapped -- unless the Cardinals and Dodgers are involved in one of their ties -- and tonight it was the Reds' modest string that was broken at four games, while the Brooks extended theirs to six games with a 6-4 victory.

At first glance the conclusion of a commercial treaty between Italy and Yugoslavia seems like a triumph of economic necessity over political differences. No nations in Europe have greater need to trade with each other than these Adriatic neighbors, each seeking desperately for what the other can supply.

Samuel J. Kessler has purchased the five-story building at 989-93 Amsterdam Avenue, containing five stores and thirty-nine apartments, from Ella W. Brinker. The property, assessed at $102,000, was sold subject to a mortgage of $55,000, and a purchase money mortgage of $11,000 was executed at the closing.
The report of the Amerada Petroleum Corporation and its subsidiaries, issued yesterday, for the quarter ended on June 30, shows a net profit of $3,194,375, after taxes and all charges.

Complete replacement of all high frequency radio receiving equipment on American merchant ships may be necessary within the next two or three years if certain proposed frequency changes are put into effect, the National Federation of American Shipping has warned its members.
OCEANPORT, N. J., Aug. 5 (AP) -- King Ranch's Prophets Thumb won his fourth purse at Monmouth Park today when he cleverly trounced the five 3-year-olds pitted against him in the featured fifth race.

BOSTON, Aug. 5 -- A New England industrialist told the Massachusetts Federation of Labor today that the future of the nation depended "much more upon the development of statesmanlike leadership in labor than in management."

SHANGHAI, Aug. 5 -- Fears that escape of the Amethyst and consequent sinking of a Chinese vessel might lead to retaliation in some form eased today as the story was dropped off the front pages of several local newspapers, including the party organ Liberation Daily.
The rival political slates that will contest the municipal elections in November were completed yesterday except for a few changes of minor consequence to be made by next Tuesday.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 5 -- One of two outbursts of wildness which overtook Montia Kennedy tonight at Sportsman's Park ruined the Giants' chances of strengthening their grip on third place in the National League standing, and, didn't exactly enhance Brooklyn's chance of overhauling the rampant Cards.

Possibilities of approval of a more liberal schedule for industrial equipment depreciation allowances were envisaged by management executives here yesterday, partly as a result of recent visits by Government officials in New England.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (AP) -- Senator George W. Malone, Republican, of Nevada, said today American industry no longer can compete with world markets just because it has technical know-how, skilled workers and mass production methods.

JERSEY CITY, N. J., Aug. 5 (AP) --Jersey City captured both ends of a double-header from Rochester tonight, taking the opener 3 -- 2, with a two-run rally in the seventh and bagging the nightcap, 4 -- 1, with a 3-run spurt in the eighth.

Last night's Stadium Concert was one that had been postponed by threatening weather from the previous evening and drew an enthusiastic 5,500 listeners. The attractions were Carroll Glenn, violinist, and her husband, Eugene List, pianist, with the Philharmonic-Symphony under the direction of Efrem Kurtz.
BERLIN, Aug. 5 (AP) -- The Sachsenhausen concentration camp near Berlin is being used as a depot to provide Soviet Russia with slave laborers, Frau Erika Raeder asserted today.

Emmett A. Scanlan of Kansas City, Mo., whom President Truman recently made United States representative on the Italian-American Conciliation Commission, was among 811 passengers who sailed yesterday for the Mediterranean on the Italian liner Saturnia.

Another marker in what Federal authorities describe as the counterfeiting trail of Michael Maione, accused as head of an Eastern Seaboard fake money gang, was uncovered yesterday afternoon when 2,000,000 three-cent counterfeit stamps were found in a lot near the Bronx River.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- A conference today between President Truman and Democratic leaders in Congress on the Thomas bill to provide Federal aid to education failed to produce any assurance that the controversial measure would be acted on at this session.

Child psychologists today are confronted with the problem of how to counteract the bad effect on children of comics, movies, radio and television. These inventions are robbing children of all creative ability and initiative and of their capacity to think for themselves and do things on their own.

Skish tournaments in Central Park and New Hampshire provided part of the grist for this space yesterday. The New York Casting Club of Brooklyn came up with an announcement that it again would run a casting tournament at Belvedere Lake, Central Park, on Sept. 10 and 11.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- The Federal power commission said today that the Ohio Fuel Gas Company, Columbus, had applied for one of the largest rate increases ever proposed to the commission by a gas utility company.

A memorandum of agreement to be used as the basis for new leases at the New York International Airport at Idlewild, Queens, was signed yesterday by five major airlines and the Port of New York Authority, thus ending two years of stalemate.

LAVALLETTE, N. J., Aug. 5 -- To cope with the problem of alleged laxity by groups of young visitors here, Police Chief Joseph Borrelli tonight made four recommendations at a meeting of the Borough Council. They included a midnight curfew for minors, to be enforced at the discretion of the police chief, and a minimum of one chaperone for each eight minors at house parties, each chaperone to be a parent.

Michael Quill, international president of the Transport Workers Union, CIO, upon departing yesterday morning by air for a vacation in Ireland, expressed confidence that labor would vote for Mayor O'Dwyer and Robert F. Wagner Jr., Democratic-Liberal designee for Manhattan Borough President.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- Among other aspects of the Far Eastern situation the State Department attemped to explore in the China White Paper made public today was the thesis that the Chinese Communists had no connection with or direction from Moscow. This belief was widely held in the United States on V-J day and for some time thereafter.
ALBANY, Aug. 5 -- The State Banking Department announced today it had approved an application of the Bay Ridge Savings and Loan Association to move from 7511 to 7502 Fifth Avenue, Brooklyn.

PARIS, Aug. 5 -- International telegraph communications will be divided into two categories only from July 1, 1950, according to final decisions of the International Telegraph and Telephone conference which closed at the Grand Palais here today.

CHICAGO, Aug. 5 (AP) -- Lloyd Mangrum, who took everything but the doorknobs at Tam O'Shanter last year, looks as if he's even going after those now. He uncorked an 8-under-par 64 in today's first round of the Tam golf circus.

The right to join a labor union and the right to engage in labor union activities without the fear of losing one's job is a well-established right today. But, as so many other things, it has been carried to an excess. It has become necessary to protect those individuals who could not or would not join a labor union.

BOSTON, Aug. 5 (AP) -- Right-hander Jack Kramer, who has been of little assistance to the Red Sox this season, turned in his best job of the campaign tonight, when he pitched and helped bat Boston to a 9-0 victory over the Tigers.

The stock market yesterday finally bettered the price levels of May and reached the best marks since March in the strongest rally in almost two months. Gains of fractions to two points, and more in selected issues, showed at the close with the composite rate raised 1.40 points.

HONG KONG, Aug. 5 -- Ill feeling between the Chinese Communists and the British was intensified today by a move on the part of the Hong Kong Government against the Communist New China News Agency here.

CHICAGO, Aug. 5 -- Thirty-one of Chicago's sixty-nine banks tomorrow will start Saturday closings permitted by a recent Illinois law which made the five-day week optional. Among those closed will be eighteen downtown institutions, nine on the west side, one northwest and three southwest.
KALAMAZOO, Mich., Aug. 5 (AP) -- The two top-seeded doubles teams were eliminated in the boys' division in the National junior tennis tournament today.

A syndicate formed by Hy. D. Agar, Inc., has purchased the two twenty-family apartment houses at 560-566 Prospect Place, Brooklyn, from Lucifer Estates, Inc. The properties are assessed at $95,000. Dallas Smith was the broker. Title was insured by the Title Guarantee and Trust Company.

In his years as a Pullman conductor with the New York Division of the New York Central, Mark H. Smith has done a bit of traveling -- most of it between New York and Chicago. So when he had his vacation the last two weeks in July, he and his wife stayed home.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- The Navy League today locked horns again with the Air Force Association in their long-drawn battle over the question of control of air warfare in event of a future war.

LONDON, Aug. 5 -- Returning from a merchandising expedition to North America, Sir Graham Cunningham, chairman of the British dollar exports board, reported today that American business men were critical of the Labor Government.

PELHAM MANOR, N. Y., Aug. 5 -- Five college boys living in comfortable circumstances here with their parents found that summer jobs this year were not as plentiful as they hoped they would be. Undaunted, they were busy today painting houses in competition with union painters.
A New Jersey motorist speeding in New York State, 150 miles north of Times Square, received a summons last week from a New York City policeman.

NEWARK, N. J., Aug. 5 (AP) -- The Pennsylvania Railroad has filed a supplemental tariff with the State Public Utility Commission asking for lower commutation rates between Jersey City and points on the line.

GREAT RIVER, L. I., Aug. 5 -- Weather conditions apparently mean little to Owen Torrey, Noroton Yacht Club skipper. With his wife sailing as crew, he remains undefeated in the Great South Bay Yacht Racing Association's annual regatta off Timber Point Yacht Basin, and so far there has been plenty of variety.

Orange County, Fla., sold yesterday an issue of $3,000,000 of Special Tax School District No. 1 bonds due from July 1, 1952, to 1971, to John Nuveen Co. and associates at a bid of 100.04112 for interest rates of 5 per cent, 2 per cent, 2 1/2 per cent and 2 3/4 per cent, an interest cost of 2.7699 per cent.
STOCKHOLM, Aug. 5 (AP) -- Sweden's Gaevle Athletic Club bettered the four-mile relay world record tonight in a Swedish-United States track and field meet at the Olympic Stadium.

Retiming of traffic-signal lights to speed rush hour travel on the over-crowded Grand Concourse in the Bronx was ordered yesterday by the Traffic Commission. The plan soon will be extended to all main through city highways, the agency added.

WESTBURY, L. I., Aug. 5 -- Fighting off a last-second challenge by Harry Eckert's Brother Harmony, Grattan McKlyo, the veteran campaigner owned by Mrs. Ben F. Owen of Omaha, Neb., raced to victory in the $50,000 Nassau Pace at Roosevelt Raceway tonight.

PARIS, Aug. 5 -- In his beautifully tailored collection, Robert Piguet uses a perfect proportion of daring and restraint. He gives new importance to shoulders with flyaway wings. With rigid peplums he adds interest to silhouette essentially as slim as a minaret.

TRENTON, N. J., Aug. 5 -- New Jersey police and highway authorities have devised a plan to relieve week-end traffic jams on major roads, which will encourage the motorists to use alternate routes and may bring into use a helicopter to regulate travel.

Cardinal Spellman, in a statement last night clarifying the position of the Roman Catholic Church with respect to the use of Federal funds for parochial schools, declared that aid was sought solely for "auxiliary services" and that public funds were neither sought nor expected for school construction, maintenance and teaching services.
OZARK, Ala., Aug. 5 -- Two Negro youths today became the first persons to be convicted under Alabama's new law prohibiting the public wearing of masks.

Edwin Way Teale, an authority on nature, has edited a book about the French entomologist, J. Henri Fabre, whom Victor Hugo called "the Homer of the insect world." Mr. Teale selected from Fabre's ten-volume work, "Souvenirs Entomologiques," forty of the famous insect stories, to which he has added an introduction and interpretive comments.
