With the exception of newsprint, a general upturn in prices of paper is developing trade sources reported yesterday.

LAKE SUCCESS, Aug. 5 -- The creation of an international committee of experts to advise the Secretary-General and the Social Commission of the Economic and Social Council of the United Nations in the prevention of crime and the treatment of offenders was recommended today by six of the world's leading criminologists.
ROME, Aug. 5 -- Italy's Communist-led Confederation of Labor (CGIL) signed a major wage agreement with industry tonight promising peace on the factory front.

MAMARONECK, N. Y., Aug. 5 -- In a long golfing day that found twelve teams continuing yesterday's qualifying in an 8:30 A. M. play-off, followed by two match-play rounds, the Kuntz brothers, Bob and Bill, representing Bonnie Briar, were among those to share a good portion of the honors in the John G. Anderson Memorial tournament over Winged Foot's east course today.

Another defense witness under cross-examination at the Communist trial refused yesterday to name secret members of the Communist party, but escaped being jailed. Though Federal Judge Harold R. Medina held the question relevant and material, United States Attorney John F. X. McGohey did not ask the judge to direct the witness to answer.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- The State Department, in the China White Paper released today, sought to cast up a balance sheet of the military and financial assistance extended since V-J Day to the Chinese National Government by the United States. Congressional critics frequently have asserted that it was insufficient.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- The letter of resignation submitted to President Truman by Maj. Gen. Patrick J. Hurley at the conclusion of his mission to China, dated Nov. 26, 1945, was printed as an annext to the China White Paper released by the State Department today.
Governor Dewey turned a deaf ear yesterday to a demand from Representative W. Kingsland Macy, Suffolk County Republican leader, that he run for the United States Senate this fall.

SHANGHAI, Aug. 5 -- The capture of Changsha, capital of Hunan Province and one of the chief cities of Central China, by the Communists last night followed the defection to the Reds of the recently deposed provincial governor and one of the top Kuomintang [Government party] generals, the Peiping radio announced tonight.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- The Federal Reserve Board announced late this afternoon that between today and Sept. 1 it would reduce the reserve requirements of member banks of the Federal Reserve System by $1,800,000,000, all of which would be available for lending or other purposes.

BERLIN, Aug. 5 -- The anti-Communist independent trade unions of Berlin (UGO) are dangerously near financial collapse, it was learned here today. More than 25 per cent of the members did not pay their dues last month because of unemployment.

HOLLYWOOD. THE extent to which the economic recession has hit Hollywood is evidenced by the fact that Gino Corrado, for almost three decades a well-known movie character actor specializing in headwaiter roles, has temporarily at least forsaken films and become a headwaiter in real life.

THE American Federation of Labor entertainment unions, known as the Associated Actors and Artistes of America, convened here last week to try to solve the television problem, which has been troubling them for nearly a year.

THERE was a time when Ronald Knox, producing in rapid succession those dazzling essays in polemics collected in such books as "Essays in Satire" and "Memories of the Future," was known as the brilliant chaplain to Roman Catholic students at Oxford.

VIENNA, Aug. 5 -- Despite the fact that Austria is technically a "liberated" country and the treaty that will decide her future is called a "state treaty" and not a "peace treaty," a fact remains that cannot be negated by semantics: Four armies of occupation remain on Austrian soil.

KARACHI. PAKISTAN, the world's largest Moslem state and the fifth largest nation in the world, is finding its own identity. It achieved independence twenty-odd months ago, and many political and economic questions remain to be solved.

THE faraway and the familiar are blended with unusual success in the story of Henry, the brown American boy of St. Thomas in the Virgin Islands. As soon as one opens the book, attractive, stylistic pictures in turquoise, yellow, coral, brown and dark green arouse pleasant anticipation of the story.

The dollar shortage abroad, coupled with the political unsettlement in a few countries, is cutting drastically into the movement of oil by United States oil companies in international trade. In fact, most of the oil being sold abroad for which payment in dollars is being made is through the Economic Cooperation Administration with funds supplied by the United States Government.

The United States House of Representatives gets things done a lot faster than the Senate. For one thing, under the Constitution the House must originate all revenue bills; the Senate cannot get to work on such a bill until the House passes it. For another, the House has strict limits on debate to prevent its membership of 435 from getting out of hand.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- James F. Byrnes, the former Secretary of State, is being deluged with requests to run for Governor of South Carolina, his native state, according to advices reaching Washington.

MR. BLACKSTONE in "English Blake" adds what is certainly the best organized and most readable contribution to that stimulating group of studies which in recent years have been considering William Blake against the background of his period, the early Industrial Revolution.

Frank Datich, former Czechoslovak Minister to the Allied Control Authority in Berlin, who quit his country's diplomatic service and fled to Frankfort rather than serve the interests of the Soviet Union, arrived here yesterday to settle in the United States.
I am much indebted to Professor Sumner Slichter for "The Upturn in Business Is Not Far Away," and I hope his prediction will have a good psychological effect.

HERE is another addition to the I-Remember-Mama-and/or-Daddy Shelf (turn-of-the-century division) -- a genial enough memoir, at that, with all the standard ingredients the patient reader has come to respect, or dread, since Clarence Day started it all.

WARSAW, Aug. 6 -- Acting to forestall possible church reprisals against Roman Catholic members of the United Workers (Communist) party, the Polish Government today announced issuance of a decree that will make priests liable to five years' imprisonment should they implement the Vatican's excommunication edict.

Ezzard Charles of Cincinnati and Gus Lesnevich of Cliffside, N.J., will clash over the fifteen-round route at Yankee Stadium next Wednesday night in a contest that should help clarify the world heavyweight title picture, left in a somewhat scrambled state by the retirement of Joe Louis.

ALCHEMY is not dead. It lives on at Oak Ridge and Los Alamos. The A-bomb alchemists have failed to give us a cheap process for making gold, but they have worked the miracle of transmutation through the uranium pile.

WHEN Barry Elwell and his pal, Bruce Todd, junior forest wardens, get summer jobs in a forester's camp they pick up some highly valuable knowledge and Barry has a string of adventures with bears, cougars and cheap sportsmen.

THIS is vacation time for countless city folk who spend their one, two or more weeks in the country during midsummer. At no other time do so many people become conscious of wild flowers and their beauty. In comparison with the few who seek them in their haunts in the spring woods, thousands have them thrust upon their attention this month.

TWENTY-ONE excited student actors and actresses will gather this week on the campus of Howard University to begin rehearsing for a unique dramatic adventure. For, on the last day of August, this group of Howard students and three of their faculty members will sail for Norway to present Ibsen to audiences in Oslo, Bergen, Stavanger and Trondheim.

A ROUTINE inquiry seemed called for when someone stole a half bottle of whisky from Sir John Soane's Victorian mansion, but the old man, raised such a row that Chief Inspector Rivers of the C.I.D. had to order an exhaustive investigation.

From Annecy, France, where delegates from thirty-six nations have been working since April 12 to broaden the Geneva Tariff Agreement of 1947, comes word that the United States has completed four of its most important negotiations. While details of the compacts are not revealed, it is announced that the countries involved are Sweden, Denmark, Finland and Greece.

IN 1916, at a nursery in Riverton, N.J., a small oval-shaped insect with reddish bronze wing covers was observed on Iris plants brought in from Japan. The following year this alien pest had entrenched itself in a surrounding area of three square miles: the flight of the Japanese beetle (Popillia japonica) had begun.

IN her second novel, "The Face of Love," Marianne Roane presents the story of a girl's efforts to find her own identity after her emotional dependence upon her father has been cruelly ruptured. Miss Roane has chosen a theme that calls for a profound treatment of emotion and human relationships.

KALAMAZOO, Mich., Aug. 6 (AP) -- Gil Bogley of Chevy Chase, Md., today advanced toward his second straight singles title in the national junior tennis tournament by beating fourth seeded Whitney Reed of Alameda, Calif., 6 -- 3, 6 -- 4, in a semi-final match.

Although the civilian population may not have known about it, most of New England was in "enemy hands" during the last two weeks, the 52d Fighter Wing of the New York National Guard announced yesterday.

A subcommittee of the House Committee on Expenditures in the Executive Departments will hold an open hearing in Washington this week on the question of Maritime Commission handling of ship construction subsidies.

THE study of the history of medicine is a fascinating and rewarding experience. Sometimes it is also a humbling experience, for it is often astonishing how much our predecessors were able to know and do. It is easy to overlook the debts that modern medicine owes to its far-distant past, for most of the writings cover the beginnings of medicine very sketchily.
Nearly 1,800,000 persons using Third Avenue Transit Corporation buses will pay a fare of 8 cents instead of 7 beginning tomorrow at 12:01 A. M., it was announced yesterday.

The letter of Edward C.W. von Selzam of July 31 suggests that the real tragedy of the unconditional surrender declaration at Casablanca was that the German resistance movement, which aimed at the overthrow of Hitler, was weakened at a time when encouragement from the Allies might have assured a successful putsch.

SALT LAKE CITY, Aug. 6 -- Western shippers, growers, business men and consumers this week were choosing sides in a major rail-freight rate battle initiated by the Denver Rio Grande Western Railroad against the Union Pacific.

The ability to do the job, without regard to age or physical handicaps, is becoming more and more the general employment requisite of industry and business across the nation, according to a study of 300 industrial and business concerns in key cities by the National Association of Manufacturers and the United States Chamber of Commerce.
Although the excess-profits tax was repealed in 1945, it is likely, because of its complexity, that many phases of its provisions will remain unresolved for many years hence.

BOSTON, Aug. 6 -- Massachusetts farmers declared themselves this week against this commonwealth's being named a drought disaster area by an average of 14 to 1. Spokesmen for the 32,897 persons classified as farmers called the move by Secretary of Agriculture Charles Brannan little more than an "empty gesture."

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 6 -- Adrian Zabala, the Cuban refugee from the ball fields of Mexico, hasn't quite shaken off the habits he acquired in his sojourn south of the Rio Grande, but he conquered the Cardinals, 3 -- 1, tonight before a gathering of 28,193 at Sportsman's Park nevertheless.
ALBANY, Aug. 6 (AP) -- The estimated sales value of this state's farm products in 1948 was $966,422,000 -- twelfth highest in the country.

One of America's wealthiest men, yet virtually unknown outside of the oil industry, still has that restless itch to discover "black gold." Michael L. (Late) Benedum has just passed his eightieth birthday and has amassed a fortune of $75,000,000, but he's too busy to grow old.

SHANGHAI, Aug. 6 -- Both Chinese and foreign owners of property in Shanghai, accustomed to paying their taxes in depreciated currency under the Kuomintang, are rubbing their eyes at whopping bills now being rendered for land tax by the Communist Government here.
CHICAGO, Aug 6 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows: HOGS Salable...

BOULDER CITY, lev., Aug. 6 --A record construction program for the fiscal year that began July 1, aggregating upward of $350,000,000 in dams and other projects for irrigation and power development, was mapped in detail this week by the hundred top officers of the Breau of Reclamation at their annual conference on program here.

ALBANY, Aug. 6 (AP) -- Three administrative surveys will be undertaken soon in connection with development of the state university system. President Alvin C. Eurich said today the studies would cover financial and personnel procedures and an analysis of curriculum and admission policies.

A middle-aged Bronx housewife, the mother of three children, was held in $10,000 bail in the Bronx Magistrate's Court yesterday on a charge of grand larceny in connection with a pseudo-divorce-loan racket. The District Attorney's office said the proceeds might exceed $60,000.
ATHENS, Aug. 6 (AP) -- The Greek Army unleashed today a full-scale offensive, supported by planes and tanks, against the estimated 5,000 Communist-led guerrillas in the Grammos Mountains.

NATHAN ROGERS was an orphan of 10 when he traveled West with the uncle for whom he was named. That was in the early Seventies. The West of the Mountain Men had vanished long before, but there were wild corners left and Nate saw them all.

THE task of interpreting Shakespeare is endless and ever-changing for actors and critics alike. Their efforts prove mutually stimulating in the days of John Gielgud and Dover Wilson, even as they did in the days of David Garrick and Dr. Johnson.

Retail trade showed no improvement here last week compared with the same period last year. In fact, estimates indicated that department store sales showed a larger percentage decline than in previous weeks. The drop was put between 15 and 20 per cent.

IN spite of its title, Mrs. Davis new novel is only partially concerned with young love. Its larger theme, as in the author's "Stand Fast and Reply" and "A Sea Between," is that of a girl's discovery of her own capabilities and her changing values in a suddenly expanding world.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., Aug. 6 -- The Winged Foot pair of Ed Vaughan and Bill Schappa, who won the John G. Anderson Memorial tournament over their home club course a year ago, gained the final once more today by beating Stanley E. (Ted) Bishop, former National amateur champion and member of the 1949 United States Walker Cup team, and his partner, Ed Wyner of Boston, by 2 and 1.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 6 (AP) -- Dick Sisler's pinch single scored Del Ennis from second with two out in the ninth inning today to give the Philadelphia Phils a 4-to-3 edge over Pittsburgh and their seventh over the Pirates by a one-run margin this season.

PRETORIA, South Africa, Aug. 6 -- Following upon the action by the white citizenry to open a public subscription to feed the Negroes suffering from drought in the eastern Cape Province, the Government announced today that it had approved a relief plan to be put into operation soon.

One needn't be old to know that August brings the end of summer. One merely needs to be alive and sentient. For the trees show it, in their wearied leaves; and the ripe-headed grasses show it, scattering their seeds and falling before the gusty rains. The frantic pace has slackened.

The appeal that an empty cigar box holds as a toy for children has been turned into an effective promotional device by the specialty division of the Container Corporation of America in a manner now winning increasing use as a sales stimulant.
ATLANTA, Aug. 6 -- A group of Atlanta business men bought the Atlanta baseball club of the Southern Association from the Coca-Cola Company today.

In promotions here last week retailers stressed leather handbags, children's slippers, girls' cotton print dresses and cashmere sweaters, according to a survey made especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by the Retail News Bureau, Inc.

The Port of New York Authority, the Brooklyn Chamber of Commerce and a number of other civic agencies have filed briefs with the Interstate Commerce Commission in the pending grain rail-rate case, which the agencies believe of vital importance to New York's future as a major port.

THE modern revival of the puppet theatre in America, which began around 1915, has recently taken on new importance through the widespread appearance of puppet programs in television. Entertainers who formerly looked askance at puppets and thought them an unimportant offshoot of the theatre are trying to become puppeteers overnight.

CHICAGO, Aug. 6 -- The board of directors of the American Contract Bridge League decided today that the controversial issue of admitting Negroes to league membership and participation in tournament play should be determined by replies to only two questions in a referendum among the organization's 26,000 members.

MOSCOW, Aug. 6 -- The Literary Gazette, organ of the Soviet Writers Union, today characterized Somerset Maugham as an unsuccessful British spy who has now placed himself at the disposal of Wall Street bosses to aid in the "spiritual disarmament of the masses."

MUNICH, Germany, Aug. 6 -- The papal excommunication of Communists is expected to have little practical effect in Germany, according to observers here. They point out that, unlike the Church leaders in Eastern Europe who have had to be careful about expressing their sentiments against Communist governments, Catholic priests in Western Germany have been denouncing Communists as heathens all along.
A country auction, an elegant variant of the farm sale, will be held at Southampton, L.I., on Thursday, Friday and Saturday, offering antiques and art objects valued at $1,000,000.

HOLLYWOOD'S surprise personality of the year may be a juvenile delinquent from Harlem's 118th Street who has, at long last, found the job he likes. He has been seen, up to now, only in a few small parts, and as the ill-fated Cherry in "Red River."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- With the important 1950 Congressional election just fifteen months away, both the Republicans and Democrats are changing national leadership, but the occasion has vastly different implications for the two great political parties.

Plans for a loan to Brazil by the Export-Import Bank have not crystallized and ultimately will depend upon the success of the new "austerity" import and dollar exchange controls being instituted by that country, it was learned yesterday.

ADD George Burns and Gracie Allen to the list of long-established radio veterans who have a very decided let's wait-and-see-what-happens attitude about television. This was revealed informally last week when the couple stopped over a few days on their way to London for two weeks at the Palladium.

MOSCOW, Aug 6 -- A headline printed this week in Pravda, Communist party paper, read as follows: "Americans Are Hastening to Bring Aggressive Military Atlantic Treaty Into Force -- American Generals Strive to Establish Their Leadership of Armies of West European Countries -- Regarding Stay of Chiefs of Staff of American Army in Western Europe."

BAY HEAD, N.J., Aug. 6 -Friends of Guy George Gabrielson, newly elected Republican National Chairman, predicted here today that the New Jersey lawyer and industrialist would end factional fighting in the Republican National Committee by bringing divergent wings of the party together.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Aug. 6 -The Socialists called tonight for King Leopold III's abdication and broke off negotiations with Gaston Eyskens of the pro-Leopold Catholic party for the formation of a coalition ministry.

THIS biography of Shakespeare is in reality an account of English life in the sixteenth century as it influenced, and was influenced by, the great dramatist. The first three chapters, "The Building of the Globe," "Young William Shakespeare" and "William Shakespeare's London," form an excellent introduction to the study of Shakespeare.

So much fear and hysteria are engendered by epidemics of infantile paralysis, we are informed by a spokesman for the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis, that "the panic is worse than the disease itself." For polio is a widespread general infection, especially during the summer months, and the case that reveals paralysis is a rare one.

ALTHOUGH painters prefer to be acclaimed for their major efforts, they frequently reveal more secrets in he by-ways of their art -- the drawings that catch a fleeting idea or the graphic work that encourages adventurous experiments with color and techniques.

CAROLINE WEST wanted to get away from her late husband's relatives and a couple of equally persistent suitors; all very understandable and human and probably universal, especially the part about the relatives. But fate, or Miss Cadell, in this frequently amusing novel, sends Caroline to High Ambo and into a dreary house called Lilac Cottage.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Aug. 6 -- The approach of the round-table conference on Indonesia, to be held here soon, has brought to the people of the Netherlands a full realization of the significance of the transfer of power to a sovereign independent Indonesia.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- Senator Harry F. Byrd of Virginia sharply assailed organized labor today for tactics used against him in the recent campaign for the nomination of a Democratic candidate for Governor of Virginia. In the primary election Tuesday John S. Battle, supported by the Byrd organization, defeated Francis Pickens Miller, the candidate backed by the labor organizations.

A NUMBER of the nation's orchestras have admitted their finances are rickety, but the majority have managed to stay on their feet. Two of them, however, have collapsed. From Ohio comes the news that the Columbus Philharmonic will not give a season in 1949-50.

The number of poliomyelitis cases in the city rose yesterday to 599 as the Department of Health announced that fifty-six new cases of the disease had been reported for the twenty-four-hour period ending at 9 A.M. There were five more deaths, the largest number so far in a single day, to bring the year's fatalities to forty-five.

THE character of war is changing. Munitions no longer exclusively weigh the balance in power politics. Ideas have become as much a part of the national stock pile as bombs and bullets. No national leader can afford to ignore the fact that it requires more than a dike of munitions and war craft to deter an ideological movement of such messianic character as seems now prevalent on the planet.

TRAVELERS whose budgets do not permit a vacation at the resorts of the South and the Caribbean during the winter, are now finding it practical to visit these spots during the summer, taking advantage of the very considerable off-season reductions in plane fares and hotel rates. Eastern and National Airlines have/ reduced their fares 67 per cent on the return-trip portion of their/ twenty-one-day excursions to Mi- ami, which allow for stop-overs en route.

Promotion executives of department and specialty stores are increasing and improving their plans for fall in preparation for the final four months of the year. During this period nearly half of the entire sales for the year are made.

Freedom to criticize the conduct of public affairs is surely one of the most important functions of the press. It is so much a part of the democratic tradition and so deeply ingrained in American law and custom that sometimes newspapers and newspaper men lose sight of the corollary of that freedom: a sense of responsibility to the public.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Aug. 6 -- Six or seven persons were killed and twenty-seven injured in the bombing last night of a synagogue in Damascus, Syria, by terrorists believed to have been demonstrating against the Palestine peace negotiations conducted by the United Nations Conciliation Commission in Lausanne, Switzerland.
HONG KONG, Aug. 6 (UP) -The Communist advance rolled unchecked toward Canton today as additional thousands of Nationalist troops deserted.

A GREAT deal of honesty of purpose and sincerity of effort is wrapped up in the "Academy Theatre" television series presented by the National Broadcasting Company Monday evenings at 8 o'clock. In its quiet way, the project represents a major effort to help video drama get out of the crawling stage and onto its feet.

NIGEL BALCHIN'S study of Cesare Borgia, presented in a testament he imagines that gentleman wrote in Sant Angelo while waiting for death, is a skillful and thoughtful account of the rise of the Borgias, and the story of the struggle for dominance in fifteenth-century Italy is developed brilliantly in Cesare's summing-up of his own success and failure.

Eleven-year-old Patrick (Packy) Ryan came back yesterday to his home at 481 Seventeenth Street, Brooklyn, from Methodist Hospital -- to a quiet welcome from 300 youngsters and some 700 adults, all of whom live in Packy's block.

WHETHER you are old enough to be able to look back over a good deal of living, or whether you consult the reports of health departments and life insurance companies, you are likely to come to the conclusion that during the past two generations medicine has acquired a considerable control over many diseases.

The New York State Conservation Department has sent out a six-page single-spaced typewritten tabulation listing the names, addresses and offenses of Conservation Law violators during May. Biggest fines outside of pollution cases were meted to two Watertown men who were caught with short trout in Jefferson County and parted with $100 each.

PARIS, Aug. 6 -- With all the experts and the leaders demanding European unity as essential, it is a matter of wonder that the progress toward fusion of the political entities upon this Continent has been so slow.
CHICAGO, Aug. 6 (AP) -- The Chicago Cubs continued their batting rampage here today, pounding out 13 hits, including two homers and two triples, to wallop the Boston Braves, 10 to 4, before 15,284.

HAMILTON, Bermuda -- So far this has been a very busy summer for Bermuda, with the tourist business virtually back to its former pre-war levels after four years of steady recovery. The total number of tourists here during the first six months of this year was only 10,000 below the first half of the peak year of 1937, according to Trade Development Board statistics.

After two years of effort, the first step in removing obstacles to mergers of national banks with state banks was taken last week in the passage of the Spence bill in the House of Representatives. The bill is now in the Senate, where Senator Charles W. Tobey of New Hampshire, it is understood, has championed a similar measure.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- The fate of the $1,450,000,000 foreign military assistance program will rest on the justification this country's military leaders give for it, Senator Millard E. Tydings of Maryland, chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee, predicted today.

Despite hopes for progress toward a closer balance between United States imports and exports this year, the "trace gap" is again beginning to widen. For the first six months of this year, the gap was $3,226,400,000, compared with $3,031,000,000 for the same period of 1948.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y. -- While thousands of American tourists are motoring in Europe this summer, either in their own cars or rented ones, and with the likelihood that thousands more will follow their example in years to come, the United States Government has prepared a memorandum on international travel to be submitted to the United Nations Road and Motor Transport Conference in Geneva this month.

Every so often when things go wrong, I find myself wishing I were back in the service. I think of all the pranks played, the laughs had, the good friends made. I'm almost convinced, "It really wasn't so bad, after all."

A TOP speed of 1/800th of a second, almost double the previous peak, has been reached in a between-the-lens shutter introduced last week in a new Kodak Tourist camera. The shutter is the Kodak Synchro-Rapid 800 shutter, with speeds down to one second.

The "dog days" of summer affected financial markets last week. In keeping with other business trends, trading drifted along at a leisurely pace as investors awaited more definite indications of a fall recovery and a solution to some of the economic problems here and abroad.

TOKYO, Sunday, Aug. 7 -- As the fourth anniversary of the Japanese surrender approaches, Gen. Douglas MacArthur has informed subsidiary commands under his control that the basic aims of the occupation have now been achieved, it was reported here today.

LINDENHURST, L. I., Aug. 6 -- Long Island was threatened with an "attack" from the sea today, but the "enemy" marauder, lurking deep in the glassy waters off Jones Beach, was spotted by a civilian pilot flying a small plane and the "invasion" halted.

ALBANY, Aug. 6 (AP) -- A $200,714 death claim has been filed against the state by Mrs. Ruth Parker of South Salem, Westchester County, who charges that the state Health Department distributed blood plasma containing jaundice germs.

ANGELA THIRKELL, according to a list thoughtfully printed on the second page of her most recent work, has written twenty-three books -- nineteen of them novels. CHICAGO, Aug. 6 (AP) -- The grain market drifted along with small price changes today. For the most part the trend was a little lower, although a mild rally got under way shortly before the close and sent some contracts above the previous close.

IF the business being done this season by motor-tourist information centers in New York City is any indication, 1949 may well set a record for automobile travel in the United States, Canada and Mexico. Officials of the local branch of the American Automobile Association and of the free tourist information centers maintained by gasoline companies report that so far this has been the biggest year in their history.

In what may become a pattern for future refresher training for salesmen, two national organizations of manufacturers and distributors of machine tools have joined hands for the first time this summer to conduct an industry-wide program of sales training.

With business sentiment giving signs of an improvement that is not yet reflected conclusively in statistics, the Federal Reserve Board saw fit last week to intensify the use of its resources for easying credit conditions throughout the nation.

SYDNEY, Australia, Sunday, Aug. 7 (Reuters) -- The Australian Government, already using troops in strike-bound coal mines, plans to use naval personnel to man coal ships, on which the Seamen's Union last month imposed a "sympathetic blockade," usually reliable sources said here today.

Before the first August dawn broke in 1909 an odd procession wound through the streets of Santa Ana, Calif. The first airplane constructed by Glenn L. Martin was being towed to a level field outside of town for its initial flight. Fashioned of bamboo and silk, and braced with thin wires, it had a four-cylinder, fifteen-horsepower engine amidships, and behind that was mounted a long wooden propeller, hand-carved by Martin himself.
BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 6 -- President Juan D. Peron, who was inaugurated June 4, 1946, is two months past the midway mark in his six-year term and, in a manner of speaking, is doing fine.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- The national significance of the emphatic personal triumph of Senator Harry F. Byrd and his state organization in the Virginia Democratic primary on Aug. 2 can readily be exaggerated. But responsibility for that rests with the labor leaders outside the state, the Americans for Democratic Action and others who arrogate to themselves a monopoly on the fine title of "liberal."

CHICAGO, Aug. 6 -- Harry Todd of Dallas, Tex., making brilliant approaches for a seven-under-par 65, today barged within a stroke of yesterday's pace-setter, Lloyd Mangrum, as the first round of the $20,000 all-American professional tourney ended.

THE subject of collaboration between architects and artists has become a sort of skeleton in the closet. The skeleton is taken out and given lip-service at forums, dinner meetings and exhibitions, but at the end of the specific occasion the door is slammed again.
SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 6 -- Round View, at 6 to 1, and More Sun, at close to 3 to 1, shared horse-of-the-day honors on the Saratoga Association's first Saturday program of the season today.

HOBOKEN, N.J., Aug. 6 -- As the wildcat strike of 370 longshoremen on four local piers entered its sixth day, hope was expressed today by delegates of the five Hoboken locals that Joseph Ryan, International Longshoremen's Association president, would be able to effect a settlement Monday.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- Luke Appling established a major league record today by playing his 2,154th game as the White Sox scored a 6-5 victory over Washington in twelve innings.
Mounting reports from Ecuador's earthquake-ravaged area said late last night that more than 1,400 persons had been killed and thousands injured.

NEWPORT, R. I., Aug. 6---With the invitation tennis tournament at the Casino getting under way on Monday, the social summer season here is expected to reach its peak with a gala round of entertaining this week.

It seems important to point out serious deficiencies and errors of judgment in the uniformly eulogistic articles on Goethe which have been appearing in connection with the two-hundredth anniversary of his birth. Thomas Mann's "Goethe: 'Faust and Mephistopheles'" is no exception.

The battle of the fourth-round wage increase between the million-member United Steelworkers of America, CIO, and the steel industry is a full-dress, public affair in a walnut-paneled, air-conditioned courtroom in the Federal Building on Foley Square.

GLASGOW, Scotland, Aug. 6 (UP) -- A squad of United States track and field athletes, part of the touring squad now competing in Scandinavia, won only one event today in the Glasgow Rangers sports meet at Ibrox Park.

AMUSEMENT parks throughout the nation are packed. Some of our most profound thinkers attribute the crowds to a story in a May issue of Krokodil, the Soviet satirical publication, describing the goings-on at that archetypal amusement center, Coney Island. The rides there were reported as so terrifying that a couple would emerge from the car. "the man pale and perspiring. with a half-dead xqfe in his arms."

One thousand Marines and Marines Corps veterans, meeting on the eve of the ninth anniversary of the assault on Guadalcanal, paraded down Fifth Avenue yesterday afternoon to the cheers of 30,000 spectators along the route.

CHICAGO, Aug. 6 (AP) -- Calumet Farm's Bewitch, queen of the nation's fillies as a juvenile two years ago, today charged to a half-length victory over the speedy Dandilly in the $28,200 Misty Isle Handicap at Washington Park.

AN International Technical Conference on the protection of nature is being sponsored by the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization. Scientists from all over the world will discuss problems that trouble the home gardener at the meeting to be held at Lake Success from Aug. 22 to Sept. 1.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 6 -- A growing West Coast, vitally interested in the "aging population," watched Californians working out strategy this week in an old-age pension battle that has potentially great political consequences.

STONINGTON, Conn., Aug. 6--This town did not seem very old today, although it began celebrating its 300th birthday. Amid a robust county fair atmosphere it received messages from President Truman and the Vatican, and 2,000 persons cut loose in the opening of a three-week celebration.

PRAGUE, Aug. 6 -- The principal effect of the Vatican's excommunication of Communists has been to give pause to the vacillating members of the Catholic clergy who had been inclined to collaborate with the Communist Government.

PARIS, Aug. 6 -- Despite the prolonged drought that has affected all parts of France, the Ministry of Agriculture issued today an optimistic report on crop prospects.
SOFIA, Bulgaria, Aug. 6 -- Bulgaria got a new Foreign Minister and Minister of the Interior tonight.

THAT huge old backyard sunflower (Helianthus annuus) is the most familiar member of a large family. Although this species is too coarse for planting in a perennial border, several of its relatives are well adapted to background use.

Since we wanted to return via the famous inland water route, we decided to sell our 1941 sedan at Anchorage and take a plane on the last leg of the journey from Seattle back to New York where our long-ordered new car would be waiting.

DEVOTEES of modern time theory, as expounded by J. W. Dunne and J.B. Priestley, will be interested in this novel, which is published some five months before the events it relates will begin to happen. Its appeal to less specialized readers, however, may be questioned.

Howard S. Cullman, chairman of the Port of New York Authority, yesterday cabled his appreciation to Governor Dewey for the "great public service" he said the Governor had performed in ending the two-year deadlock between five major airlines and the Port Authority over leases at the New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Aug. 6 -- Moonshine whisky, which since the Prohibition era ended was only a minor problem for law enforcement officials, is making headlines again in the Deep South as agents of the Federal alcohol tax unit battle illicit distillers to reduce the supply of untaxed spirits.

More than 32,000 acres of land once owned by German Lutheran Missions are in process of being expropriated by the Territorial Government of Tanganyika, Africa, as trustee for the United Nations, the National Lutheran Council announced here yesterday.
PORTLAND, Me. -- The historic lighthouse on Portland Head, one of several guardians of Portland's harbor, is once more receiving its annual quota of summer visitors.

WITH the recent opening of Staten Island's Great Kills Park on a limited scale, a brand-new beach playground, virtually on the doorstep of the metropolitan area and destined to cost $10,000,000 when completed, has been made available to millions of New Yorkers as well as residents of near-by Jersey communities.

MOSCOW, Aug. 6 -- Alexius, Orthodox Patriarch of Moscow and all Russia, declared today that the excommunication of all persons supporting Communism "would fundamentally contradict the main tenets of the orthodox Christian faith."
ALBUQUERQUE, N.M., Aug. 6 -- Development of natural gas resources was the focus of much interest in New Mexico and the Southwest this week.

WOR-TV, now reported planning to begin telecasting "sometime in October," probably will function on a five-day rather than a seven-day-a-week schedule, and will institute a number of other measures designed to keep the station operating within budgetary boundaries, according to Julius Seebach, vice president in charge of programs.

IN January, 1863, Walt Whitman became a self-appointed daily visitor to the sick and wounded in the hospitals of Washington. "The Wound Dresser," an account of his experience up through 1864, pieced together from letters home and from newspaper articles, has been out of print for fifty years.

LONDON, Aug. 6 -- When the British frigate Amethyst slipped her cables below Nanking a week ago and sped 140 miles down the Yangtze River to the open sea and the protection of the British fleet, the whole Western world hailed her escape from the Chinese Communists as though it were a major naval victory in a hot war.

A new cooperative, non-profit, co-educational institution of higher learning, to be known as Stamford College, will be opened Sept. 26 at Stamford, Conn. Enrollments for the fall quarter are now being accepted.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Aug. 6 -Present low prices in the world copper market will prevail for some time, Rodolfo Michels, vice president of the Anaconda Copper Mining Company, said today. He added that the entry of the United States Government into the market to buy large quantities of copper would not solve the problem although it would help to "tone up" the situation.

More students from the United States are now studying abroad than ever before. There are no exact figures available from official sources on the number of young men and women who have gone abroad to study, but it has been conservatively estimated that the total is about 12,000.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 6 -- Philadelphia women's apparel shops last week reported sales were off 8 per cent, and for the four-week period were 3 per cent less than a year ago. Pennsylvania Railroad carloadings last week totaled 101,473, against 141,405 a year ago, a decrease of 28.2 per cent.

ALL too often the gathering of material for winter bouquets is neglected until too late in the season. Starting the collection at this time of year will afford a wide variety in color, texture and form; a worthwhile accumulation will then be ready for use by the first killing frost.

SUCCASUNNA, N.J., Aug. 6 -Gerald B. Emerson, assistant Professor or English at New York University, died last night soon after arrival at Dover General Hospital from a bullet wound in his head that the State Police said was self-inflicted. He was 49 years old.

THE month of August in a major league pennant race might be likened to the last turn on a racetrack. It is that stage in the grind where everyone girds himself for the final stretch drive, which in the baseball campaign would be September.

MINNEAPOLIS, Aug. 6 -- Beginning of the grain harvest has reversed the downtrend in bank loans for business, the Federal Reserve Bank in Minneapolis reported last week in its monthly review of business. Commercial and agricultural loans in city banks went up $9,000,000 during the six weeks period ending in mid-July, the reports showed.

Despite the belief that the wholesaler is gradually losing his foothold in the American system of merchandising, he is still an important cog in the movement from producer to consumer in the deep Central South. This was pointed out yesterday by Dr. Harry A. Mitchell, Professor of Marketing in the College of Commerce and Business Administration at Tulane University.

Yesterday was the fourth anniversary of the dropping of the atomic bomb on Hiroshima, the first to be used in warfare (Aug. 6, 1945). Tuesday will be the fourth anniversary of the second and last nuclear explosion on an inhabited city, which ended in a blinding flash the greatest war in history.

HANDONFIELD, N.J., Aug. 6 -- Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll of New Jersey, mentioned last night as a potential candidate for the Republican Presidential nomination in 1952 by Representative Hugh D. Scott Jr. of Pennsylvania, today declined to say whether his hat was in the ring.

PARIS, Aug. 6 -- The three United States Chiefs of Staff finished their visits in Western Europe today by talks with the military leaders of Belgium, the Netherlands and Portugal. They will depart tomorrow for Vienna to inspect the United States occupation forces there.
BERLIN, Aug. 6 (AP) -- Maj. Gen. Maxwell D. Taylor, wartime paratroop leader, officially was named today to command the United States Military Government and Army forces in Berlin.

LAKE SUCCESS, Aug. 6 -- Admiral Chester W. Nimitz told 250 garment workers today that the United Nations was still the world's "best formula" for peace. He then gave them an idea of why the most bitter variety of diplomatic debate did not get him down.

LONDON, Aug. 6 -- The United States Joint Chiefs of Staff, currently in Europe discussing the future North Atlantic pact military organization with their European colleagues, are considering four alternative types of organization, it is authoritatively learned here.

AN ex-Military Intelligence officer, restless under the even tenor of life in peacetime London, lends a willing ear when his former superior officer asks him if he'd like to take on one last assignment. While the subsequent mission hasn't the spectacular rigors of wartime, he soon realizes that it is just as dangerous, and that the alternating roles of hunter and quarry are just as menacing now as they were then.
HONOLULU, Aug. 6 -- Governor Stainback signed into law today a bill giving him temporary powers to act in the dock strike which began ninety-eight days ago.
WICHITA, Kan., Aug. 6 (AP) -A $1,199,464 contract for lifts for the Air Force's biggest bombs--,50,000 and 22,000 pounds --was announced by Boeing Airplane Company today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- The State Department is trying to cut down the number of international organizations in which the United States participates because the costs are too high.

STANDING at the junction of Park and South Streets, just around the corner from London's swanky Dorchester Hotel in Mayfair, is an unpretentious concrete-faced eight-story building -- the British Government's own hotel.

A continued rise in college enrollment, despite the fact that most veterans have completed their education, was predicted last week by Dr. Arthur S. Adams, president of the University of New Hampshire. Originally, he said, educators believed that the post-war enrollment increase -- from 1,300,000 in 1940 to 2,410,000 at present -- was only temporary.

WHEN "The Transient Hour," Marcel Ayme's first novel to appear here, was published last year, readers were impressed. The book, indeed, was an impressive one; it had a genuine freshness, and the impact was of the strange and the new.

SALT LAKE CITY -- Slow and circuitous though it admittedly is, the Royal Gorge Route of the Denver Rio Grande Western Railroad is carrying a full quota of Western sight-seers this summer, proving that a considerable number of present-day tourists are willing to forgo shiny streamliners and mile-a-minute schedules for a long, slow look at spectacular scenery.

Recent price reductions have brought an increase in the rate of ordering by wholesale distributors of metal and durable goods products, it was learned here yesterday. Full-sized stock orders for brass products, for example, have been issued.

PARIS, Aug. 6 -- A correspondent of THE NEW YORK TIMES recently made a tour of the villages of the Paris environs having Communist mayors or large Commu nist populations, looking for French reaction to the Vatican edict excommunicating Communists.

AS the seasons sift through the calendar, from spring to summer, on to autumn, and now to winter. Mrs. Keeler has drawn (verbally and with skilled soft pencil) their pictures for children of 6 to 10 in her stories of Meadow Brook Farm.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- Four railroad brotherhoods of operating employes were accused today of holding to policies that tended to nullify the Railway Labor Act.

MR. CHAMBERLAIN'S faithful following will probably spend as many pleasant hours with "Midnight Boy," his twenty-ninth novel, as with "Scudda-Hoo! Scudda-Hay!" and "The Phantom Filly." Indeed it reveals Mr. Chamberlain's craftsmanship at its best.
DETROIT, Aug. 6 -- The Ford Motor Company began an intensified campaign today to persuade its 87,000 hourly paid workers in Michigan to vote against a strike in an election beginning Monday.

I have been favored with reprints of Mrs. McCormick's reports from Greece to THE TIMES which are very illuminating and convincing. It remains to be determined just what we shall do to bring about a definitely happier state of affairs in that unfortunate country.
AUGUSTA, Me., Aug. 6 (AP) -- A former Montana municipal judge said today he would take legal steps seeking to bar religious devotions in Maine's Boothbay Harbor district public schools.

UNLIKE so many fathers in novels who have been drawn in the blackest colors, Lev Simon, the central character of Norman Katkov's "A Little Sleep, a Little Slumber," has been painted with affectionate warmth and brightness.

COLLEGE fashions are in a class by themselves. They are distinctive because the American college girl, while following the current styles, gives them an interpretation all her own. These same clothes appeal to many who don't go to college.

LEESBURG, Va. DOWN a sharp right turn from the first traffic light in this village and then up again over a rolling rise are the broad white gates of Dodona Manor. Off up above them, in the trees, stands the eighteenth-century stone manor house, a great place of eighteen rooms and seven baths, surrounded by four green and flowering acres.
CANTON, Ohio, Aug. 6 -- The first test runs to produce steel from Argentine pig iron have been completed successfully, officials of the Timken Roller Bearing Company report.

ON Austria's Gebhard Mountain, in Bregenz on Lake Constance, ceremonies are being held today, with others planned for Aug. 27 and 28, for the millenary of the birth of St. Gebhard (949-995), who was Bishop of Bregenz.

ROME, Aug. 6 -- Hard on the heels of the commercial agreement signed two days ago, the Italian and Yugoslav Governments concluded another agreement in Rome today. It concerns the disposal of Italian war materiel in excess of that permitted by the peace treaty, restitution by Italy of property removed from Yugoslavia and restitution of all property rights and interests that Yugoslavia possessed in Italy before the war.
BUDAPEST, Hungary, Aug. 6 (Reuters) -- Hungary is declared a "people's republic" and a "state of workers and working peasants" under the new constitution released in draft text here tonight.

FAR be it from this department to assume the responsibility of urging anybody either to go or not to go to "Miss Liberty," but followers of the career of the talented Jerome Robbins, who has staged its dances and musical numbers, will certainly not want to pass it by.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 6 (AP) -- Dick Fowler outpitched Bob Lemon today as the Philadelphia Athletics took a 2 to 0 verdict over the Cleveland Indians. The second-place Indians are now only one and one-half games ahead of Boston, the Red Sox taking a 3-0 victory over Detroit at Boston today.
Charles Van Maanen has been appointed vice president of the J.J. Columbo Company, exclusive distributor for Andrea television sets in Boston.

OCEANPORT, N.J., Aug. 6 -- Count-A-Bit, 3-year-old son of Count Fleet, notched the most important triumph of his career today when he turned in a front-running effort to win the $25,000 added Choice Stakes at Monmouth Park.
EDGARTOWN, Mass., Aug. 6 -- After four days of fog, rain and fitful breezes, the New York Yacht Club cruise fleet was rewarded for both patience and endurance today.

LANGUAGE is a messy and mutable phenomenon at which, of all commentators, perhaps only Mencken has been able to laugh. In the van we have philologists and semanticists admitting change yet exhorting us to stop changing, to be precise, uniform.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 (UP) -The House Armed Services Committee said today that thirty-one top-flight military leaders and aviation executives would help it determine the truth or falsity of charges of irregularities in the Air Force bomber-purchase program.

LITTLE EDDIE, you will remember, is that enterprising collector whose passion for junk, or, in his own words, "valuable property," often brings surprising and hilarious results. This new saga revolves around his unquenchable love for a retired fire engine.

ROBERT HILLYER, president of the Poetry Society of America, winner of the first award of the Lyric Associates (a Foundation for Traditional Poetry), and sometime Boylston Professor of Rhetoric and Oratory at Harvard University, has published a narrative poem which, according to the dust jacket, is Mr. Hillyer's "major work."

MUNICH, Germany, Aug. 6 -The Bavarian State Parliament is virtually "on strike" against the United States Military Government. All its members voted with rare unanimity on July 26 to adjourn in protest against an alleged "interference" in what they considered a purely German matter.

MELBOURNE, Australia, July 26 -- The British Medical Association has challenged in the High Court of Australia the constitutionality of the Commonwealth Government's Pharmaceutical Benefits Act. This act orders doctors to prescribe as free medicine all specifics and compounds listed in the Government's formulary of about 600 items.

BOSTON, Aug. 6 (AP) -- Hidden in the pack through the back stretch, Mrs. Dodge Sloan's Greek Ship began moving at the far turn and fought to victory by a head today in the fifteenth running of the $20,000 added Mayflower Stakes at Suffolk Downs.

CHINHAE BAY, Korea, Aug. 6 -- Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek arrived here today at 3:30 P.M. accompanied by five top-ranking advisers. China's retired President was greeted as he stepped from a Chinese Air Force twin-engined transport by President and Mrs. Syngman Rhee.

MARTINSBURG, W. Va., Aug. 6 -- A commercial apple crop of about 3,750,000 bushels, 50 per cent larger than last year's, was forecast today for the Eastern Panhandle producing area after a survey of grower's estimates.

A CONTROVERSIAL corpse was in the process of being revived last week on Broadway. Known simply as the "buy," it is an old process of theatre ticket distribution that flourished in the easy currency days before 1929.

The first Italian Davis Cup team ever to appear in the United States will make its American debut this week in the Interzone Round of the international tennis team championship against Australia.

We who are stationed on the "Bataan" of any possible future war view all the commotion back in the States often with bewildered hearts. Even without our telescopes, the newspapers (and I have in mind your edition of June 19, 1949), we can feel, if not quite hear, this spy and "red" commotion.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 (AP) -House Democrats disclosed today that a quiet party conference, with the White House represented, had brought informal agreement on patronage problems and campaign financing.

HOMESTEAD, Pa. THE main entrance to the enormous Carnegie-Illinois steel works in Homestead is at Amity Street, and Henry J. Mikula is one of 14,000 workers for whom, in a city freighted with a legacy of strife and bloodshed, it symbolizes a new era in peaceful labor relations.

AS New York State motorists prepare to renew their driving licenses before Sept. 30, they may find consolation in the fact that only one state in the entire nation does not require driving licenses. That is South Dakota, which only recently defeated a bill to require such licensing.

Little crowds come nightly, and often several times a day, to see the "show" at Hayden Planetarium called "The End of the World." They see a model of the solar system running smoothly, as it has for some millions of years, the planets moving majestically in their courses around the sun and only the moons of Jupiter and Saturn cutting up in what seems a slightly drunken fashion.

AT one of these windows. I see the queen of my soul, in the attire which I have just described, leaning with a wistful expression on the balcony, and behind her a little Negro holding her fan and her parakeet. THE film future of "Death of a Salesman," largely a matter of gossip and conjecture heretofore, was made a bit more definite last week by Arthur Miller, author of the smash hit drama. Mr. Miller, who just returned from London with director Ellia Kazan after attending to the staging of the play there, put it simply.

A WESTON photoelectric exposure meter in the low-price bracket was announced last week at $21.50. It is the Weston Cadet and is designed for travelers and casual photographers. The Cadet is small enough to fit into a vest pocket or purse, can be used for measuring either reflected or incident light, and is equipped with the standard Weston instrument movement and Photronic Cell.

WARSAW, Aug. 6 -- If the Vatican's decree ordering the excommunication of All Communists and supporters of communism was intended to have an immediate effect, it has failed in that purpose in Poland. Catholicism's greatest stronghold in Eastern Europe.

The Secretary of State has taken the occasion of the issuance of the White Paper on China to set forth five basic principles on which future United States policy in the Far East should be based. Presumably this is the answer to the expected criticism that the White Paper is largely negative and largely defeatist.

Climb three flights of stairs to the furnished room at 126 West Sixty-eighth Street and you will find 68-year-old Louis Meiboon deep in the easy chair listening to a tiny, battered radio, invariably pouring forth something from the operatic or symphonic repertoires.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Aug. 6 -- Denmark today is a defenseless, flat landing field at the mouth of the Baltic -- an ally of the United States and Britain and more than a little worried about it.

THE month-long-Holland Music Festival has come to a close with a volley of its big guns -- the Vienna State Opera, Katherine Dunham's "Caribbean Rhapsody" and the world premiere of Benjamin Britten's "Spring Symphony" -- all of which attracted large crowds and were huge successes.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- The thorough review of United States policy toward the Far East, which the State Department is to undertake, starting next week, is expected to receive an initial impetus from the state visit of President Elpidio Quirino of the Philippine Republic, who will reach Washington on Monday.
CHICAGO, Aug. 6 -- The masters' team-of-four championship, blue ribbon event of contract bridge, continued today under the auspices of the American Contract Bridge League at the Stevens Hotel.

Leaders of the City Fusion party criticized the nomination of Robert F. Wagner Jr. for Manhattan Borough President by the Liberal party yesterday on the ground that "he would play ball with no team but the old team."

LONDON, Aug. 6 -- To a certain extent the Labor Government's implied threat of imposing some sort of discipline on the British press may succeed in its purpose. There is a strong possibility that, as demanded by the Government, the newspapers themselves will organize an agency to deal with their own shortcomings.
QUITO, Ecuador, Aug. 6 (UP) -A rich farming and industrial area in central Ecuador dug out from its ruins today after a devastating earthquake that left 30,000 homeless in its wake.

Solicitation of capital in other countries to underwrite new enterprises in non-industrial countries is becoming a growing feature of post-war financing operations, according to officials of the American and Foreign Enterprises, Inc., sponsors of projects in the Caribbean and in South America.

AMONG this morning's new record releases are two works that were composed in Europe in the mid-Thirties. Both represent styles that have become familiar, if not tarnished, through their creators' influence on younger composers.

The Town and Country convertible coupe, an addition to the 1949 Chrysler line, was announced yesterday by the Chrysler division. Chrysler Corporation. The f.o.b. Detroit price is $3,969. The New York delivered price will be announced later.

SUMMER in London, even at its fiercest, is never hot enough to compel a closed season in the theatre and no surprise need be felt that the production here of an important play like Arthur Miller's "Death of a Salesman" should be timed exactly at the beginning of the holiday season.

SOMETHING new in the way of guidebooks appeared in Paris last week with the publication by Editions Par Monts et Par Vaux of an itinerary from Paris to the Riviera and return. This book, with text by Paul Pujol, is richly illustrated with unusual and original photographs by Mme. Y. Sauvageot, consisting of views of many interesting sites and scenes along the way.

More than 2,000 part-time teachers are supervising the vacation activities of 115,000 children who are registered in the board's playground program and of thousands more who participate occasionally.

The upturn in scrap metal prices in major markets last week -- the first this year -- engendered a feeling in scrap and steel circles that a moderate increase in business for both industries may occur within thirty to sixty days.

CHICAGO, Aug. 6 -- Parents who pace the floor with their infants during the early hours can look with hope to a new research project at the University of Chicago. Scientists there have a $10,000 grant from Swift Co. for a study of the sleeping habits of babies.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- The United States Chamber of Commerce today announced its opposition to a bill to legalize maritime hiring halls on the grounds that it would "emasculate provisions of the Taft-Hartley Act relating to prohibitions against the closed shop."

Commissioner G. Joseph Minetti of the Department of Marine and Aviation made public yesterday the new standard lease form covering city-owned piers and announced that long-term leases with major steamship lines were now being negotiated.

ROME, Aug. 6 -- A favorite theme of Cominform propaganda these days is that a depression is preparing to engulf the United States and that the Marshall Plan is failing. WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg of Michigan, ranking Republican member of the Foreign Relations Committee, stated today that the United States Government must make clear, in reviewing its Far Eastern policy, its support of the Chinese people and of freedom in the Far East.

HIGHLANDS, N.J., Aug. 6 -- A delegation of nine members of the House Public Works Committee, accompanied by Representative James C. Auchincloss of Rumson, N.J., made an off-shore tour of the North Jersey coast today from Sandy Hook to Manasquan to determine the effects of beach erosion.
Catherine Mackenzie is on vacation. The authors of this week's column are specialists in progressive education and community work. They wrote "The Happy Home."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- The major decision that the 149-year-old White House walls shall stand, made last week by the Joint Congressional Commission on Reconstruction of the White House, started the wheels rolling on a project which has been stalled for nine months.
CANTON, China, Aug. 6 -- A Foreign Office spokesman announced today that pending thorough consideration of the contents of the United States White Paper on China, there would be no formal comment.

THE Committee on Public Debt Policy has done an outstanding service in its study of the Federal debt. Its report, issued originally as separate chapters, and now published in book form, cannot be regarded as the last word on the subject; but it does have the merit of presenting, in simple language, some of the facts about the debt and of stating clearly some of the issues involved in its management.

Following a national trend, durable goods industries in the New York area gave local employment its biggest boost during the period from 1939 to 1947, according to a study of the industries of this area by the National Industrial Conference Board, released for publication today.

DARIEN, Conn., Aug. 6--Twenty-eight Fairfield County girls will be presented to society at a Debutante Cotillion on Sept. 9 in the Wee Burn Club here. Sponsors of the event, first to be held in this area, hope to establish the Cotillion as all annual affair.

The Yankees once again climbed all over the tail-end Browns at the Stadium yesterday to maintain their lofty position in the American League flag race. But it took a deal of climbing, including the blasting of six home runs, to do it.

IT is one thing to develop a science of nutrition, another to make its findings acceptable to people. Food not only has calories, minerals and vitamins, but emotional significance, too. The New York School of Social Work, Columbia University, will begin this week the first phases of moving into its new quarters, the sixty-six-room Georgian mansion at Fifth Avenue and Ninety-first Street which Andrew Carnegie built in 1900 at a cost of $1,000,000.

The hard-hitting Washington nine crushed its two opponents yesterday to win the thirty-fifth annual Union Printers International Baseball League championship. In a morning clash in the semifinal round, the Capitals trounced Detroit, 20 -- 5, at Macombs Dam Park. Washington then blanked New York, 11 -- 0, for the title at the Polo Grounds.

Attracting, as it invariably does, an entry list of more starters than any other regatta, the National Sweepstakes at Red Bank, N.J., on the North Shrewsbury (or as sticklers for facts, purists and chart readers know it, Navesink) will be held Saturday and Sunday.

Capt. Jan Cwiklinski, master of the Gdynia America liner Batory, denied yesterday morning that the Gold Cross of Merit he recently received from the Polish Government had anything to do with the escape from the United States of Gerhart Eisler, the German Communist party leader.

BOSTON, Aug. 6 -- Left-hander Mel Parnell became the major leagues' first 16-game winner today as he pitched the Boston Red Sox to their seventh consecutive victory, a convincing 3-0 de cision over the Detroit Tigers.

SELDEN, L.I., Aug. 6 -- Mushrooms grow wild near this community. They are good with meat, good in a sauce for spaghetti, good by themselves. But today was no day to extol their virtues to the local police, to the volunteer firemen, to two airplane pilots, or to the state troopers at Hawthorne, N.Y., who train bloodhounds.
The military weakness of Western Europe is the principal reason for the United States arms-aid program.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- A National Labor Relations Board trial examiner held today that the Building and Construction Trades Council of Denver had violated the Taft-Hartley secondary boycott ban by causing four men who were installing a soda fountain to strike because the manufacturer of the fountain was on the council's unfair list.
LYNN, Mass., Aug. 6 -- The general Electric Company announced today a fluorescent street light which engineers say provides the most comfortable light yet devised for motorists and pedestrians.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- Charles F. Brannan, Secretary of Agriculture, suggested today to a Senate subcommittee with which he met in an effort to salvage a new farm-price program that it drop any effort to write a test of his "production payments" plan into a pending bill.
HELENA, Mont., Aug. 6 (AP) -Montana's deadliest forest fire in years ravaged hundreds of primitive acres hereabouts today.

EVERYTHING about the "Happiness Exchange" radio show is big except the small, wee hours, 2 to 5 A.M., during which it is broadcast daily by WOR. Under the irrepressible guidance of "Big Joe" Rosenfield, cracker-barrel warmth is transplanted to the audiences by the sensible device of making listeners feel what they most want to be -- happy.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 (UP) -Republican sources said Senator Vandenberg may move next week to kill President Truman's nomination of a new Assistant Secretary of State for Far Eastern and China affairs. Mr. Truman last May named W. Walton Butterworth to the post.

OMAHA, Aug. 6 -- With the formal setting of state, county and local tax levies for fiscal 1950, Midwest residents are learning that the Federal Government has no monopoly on high spending. All along the line the cost of state and local government in this area is increasing.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 6 -- Because Billy Cox made three errors in one inning to tie a National League record the Dodgers today had their winning streak snapped at six games, the Reds beating them, 5 -- 2, before a ladies' day crowd of 18,204.

ROME, Aug. 6 -- Preliminary reports of Italian Bishops sent to the Vatican after gathering information from parish priests of their dioceses indicate, according to Vatican circles, that the decree of excommunication issued last month has had widespread repercussions among Italians of all walks of life.
Another cache of counterfeit three-cent stamps, this one totaling at least 5,000,000, was found yesterday in the Bronx, less than two blocks from where 2,000,000 had been discovered the day before.

Hunt announced today that he was preparing a libel suit against The New York Herald Tribune for its publication of material about him which precipitated the "five per center" inquiry now being conducted by a Senate subcommittee headed by Senator Clyde R. Hoey, Democrat, of North Carolina.
