ONE of the most important questions now facing the Civil Aeronautics Board is to decide the place of air-coach service in regularly scheduled domestic airlines. The new low-price service has been tried experimentally by five airlines under permits lasting until Sept. 30.

ALTHOUGH William Sansom is often described as "a promising young writer," his four volumes of short stories already represent a considerable achievement. (The first two, "Fireman Flower" and "Three," have been published here, but "Something Terrible, Something Lovely" and "South" have thus far been published only in London.)

HELEN MACINNES, an English novelist who has made her home in the United States since 1937 and whose earlier works have all been set on the other side of the ocean, has discovered at length that the Western hills are greener -- especially in Wyoming.

GREAT RIVER, L.I., Aug. 6 -It was a touch-and-go finish today but Owen Torrey's Cygnet was home first a second before Eddie Ketcham's Draco today to register a clean sweep in the Star Class competition of the Great South Bay Yacht association race week.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Aug. 6 -- Gardnar Mulloy of Coral Gables, Fla., gained his most notable victory of the tennis season today at the expense of the player with whom he holds the national doubles championship.

AFTER three weeks of intensive location shooting, Republic Pictures last week completed the storming, landing, taking and surrender of Tarawa and Iwo Jima as reenacted for a motion picture about the United States Marine Corps, "Sands of Iwo Jima."

PARIS, Aug. 7 -- France should firmly resist attempts to exclude the Saar from the council of Europe or to change the status quo by which that area is economically attached to France, Rene Mayer, former Minister of Finance and a member of the National Assembly, declares in an article to be published tomorrow in the financial paper, Agence Economique et Financiere.

The announcement last week by the International Federation of Transport Workers that it would recommend to its 5,000,000 members a boycott of Panamanian shipping as soon as possible was described here yesterday as "precipitous and premature," by Carlos Berguido Jr., Panama Consul General at Philadelphia.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Aug. 7 -- Britain's estimate of her dollar deficit, which has been interpreted as a request for increased United States aid, has subjected economic cooperation in Western Europe to its severest strain since the inception of the European Recovery Program.
BOSTON, Aug. 7 (AP) -- Although he gave up a dozen hits, right-hander Art Houtteman today celebrated his twenty-second birthday by pitching the Tigers to a 6-4 victory over the Red Sex.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 7 -- By sweeping a double-header with the Reds today the Dodgers headed for home tonight in an exact first-place tie with the Cardinals and with a record on the western trip of having won ten, lost three and tied one.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (UP) -- The Department of Agriculture today told American farmers to expect a cutback -- possibly a "painful" one -- in exports of farm products.

A definite slowing up of collections in the manufacturing and wholesale fields during the last six months, with the general trend apparently advancing, is revealed in a survey released yesterday by the Credit Research Foundation, affiliated with the National Association of Credit Men.
BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 7 -- Although this metropolis got the first of five subway lines as far back as 1914 and the last one a decade ago the phenomenon of rush hour is just making itself known.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- Dispatches published in American newspapers quoting Marshal Tito as having said in a speech at Skoplje on Aug. 2 that Yugoslavs would help the Bulgarians "remove those individuals who have so far put obstacles in the path of creating and preserving brotherly relations" were based upon an incorrect translation, Sava N. Kosanovich, the Ambassador of Yugoslavia, said in a statement issued today.
Five new films will arrive in midtown theatres this week. The programs follow:

VERNON, France, Aug. 7 -- The little Norman city of Vernon, in the valley of the Seine, is fast becoming a major center for the study and development of guided missiles in France. This work is being carried out in an unusual community situated in the middle of a wide tract of woodlands near here, rarely visited by outsiders, but vitally related to the defense of Western Europe.
PARIS, Aug. 7 -- Molyneux brings subtle variations, definitely 1950, to his well-tailored daytime clothes of simple elegance.

Hanson W. Baldwin, in his article on the "Inquiry on B-36 Bomber" (July 21), expresses "no doubt that public opinion, partly because it was fed a diet of air 'facts' during the war that have proved to be erroneous in many major respects, has greatly overemphasized in the period since the war the effects of wartime strategic bombing."

The Ohio Oil Company and its subsidiaries reported in its mid-year statement issued for publication today a net income of $17,512,007 for the first half of 1949 after all deductions, compared with $24,879,098 earned in the first six months of 1948.
Although he would promise no immediate cold spell, the Weather Man was in a kindly mood yesterday. Nearly everybody got a break, in the city and at its surrounding resorts.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- A bill that would make some of the major provisions of the Securities and Exchange Act of 1934 applicable to all unregistered corporations having assets of at least $3,000,000 and no less than 300 stockholders will be introduced in the Senate tomorrow by Senator J. Allen Frear Jr., Democrat, of Delaware.

Mr. Ransom is quite right in stressing the importance of air power in war, and I would agree that, on the whole, the public has correctly assessed that importance. The public has, however, been misguided, as my article pointed out, by a diet during the war of erroneous air "facts," in its analysis of the effects of strategic bombing.

URBANA, Ohio, Aug. 7 (AP) -- Lightning struck a baseball diamond here today, killing the first baseman of Urbana's semi-pro team and injuring three other players, none seriously. Five players were knocked off their feet and stunned by the bolt.

The various slates of candidates for the New York City election next November have now been completed. The nature of the candidates, together with the fact that the Democratic organization will be opposed by a fusion of interests, assures a warm and illuminating campaign.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (AP) -- Two Republican members of Congress who want an investigation of a $1,000 poetry award made to Ezra Pound while he was under treason indictment said today that their request would go before a joint committee.

JERSEY CITY, N. J., Aug. 7 (AP) -- Johnny Yuhas and George Copeland pitched a pair of 10-0 fourhitters today to give Rochester a double victory over Jersey City. The Jerseys, however, captured the series, three games to two.
CHICAGO, Aug. 7 (AP) -- A program to extend aid to underprivileged children in more than 3,000 communities in the United States and Canada was begun today by the Kiwanis International.

NEWARK, N. J., Aug. 1 (AP) -- The Newark Bears won their first double-header since April 24 today when they defeated the Toronto Maple Leafs 6 -- 4 and 5 -- 4. Three-run homers by Bud Heslet in each game helped the Bears to victory.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (UP) -- Formation of a new "Patriots' Executive Committee" to fight world gorvernment proposals was announced here today.

IRON CITY, Ga., Aug. 7 (UP) -- Mayor C. L. Drake said today that a posse of "my friends" exchanged gunfire early today with members of a Ku Klux Klan parade. Authorities said one Klansman was wounded.

"How poor a thing is man!" exclaimed a sixteenth-century English poet. Such thoughts inevitably pass through our minds when nature stirs and cruelly manifests her power, destroying as with a single breath the cities man has laboriously built, or with equal disdain of consequences consuming forests patiently grown through the years.

There was a listless air about the foreign exchange market last week as it slid off that lull which always follows a feverish movement, and pound sterling was the one unit which had provided that element up to a fortnight ago when opinion veered to waiting out the IMF meeting next month for a settlement of the question -- devaluation or no. The result, business was small in all sections.
MILWAUKEE, Aug. 7 (AP) -- A Capital Airlines passenger plane with twenty aboard landed saafely today after a mid-air collision with a small cabin plane over Maitland Field.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 7 (AP) -- University of California medical researchers contradicted today what they said were rumors that chymotrypsin, a milk-curdling substance produced in the small intestine, is beneficial against cancer.

The eight-story and penthouse office building at 12 East Forty-fourth Street has been sold by Albert H. Graham and A. B. B. B. Block to an investing client of Brener Lewis, brokers. The deal was made for cash above a mortgage of $117,000.

There are three structures in this country which over the years of our history have become throughout the world symbols of our greatness -- the Capitol, the White House and the Statue of Liberty. It is regrettable that the Statue has not been maintained with the same care that we have given to the Capitol and the Executive Mansion, and it is good to know that this condition is being corrected.
MARIENSKE LAZNE (Marienbad), Czechoslovakia, Aug. 7 (AP) -- An all-Czech jury awarded to Russian movies most of the major prizes at the close of the fourth International Film Festival here today.

The twelve-foot section of the thirty-six-inch water main that burst under Lafayette Street, between White and Franklin Streets, at 1:35 A. M. Saturday was fully repaired by emergency crews at 10:30 A. M. yesterday. A half hour later the trunk main was reported functioning normally.

Chicago Southern Air Lines, which on Saturday began its fourteenth consecutive year of accident-free operation, is among the outstanding United States air carriers with long records of safe flying. It has flown 750,000,000 passenger-miles without injury to either passenger or crew member since 1936.
HELENA, Mont., Aug. 7 (AP) -- The Gates of the Mountain blaze -- slayer of thirteen men -- rolled inexorably up Willow Mountain tonight despite dogged efforts of 500 fire-fighters.

STRASBOURG, France, Aug. 7 -- The red sandstone city of Strasbourg today gave a spontaneous welcome to the delegates who were gathering here from ten Western countries for the session of the Council of Europe, the Continent's first experimental parliament.

Two theatre benefits have been arranged for the Spence-Chapin Adoption Service. The first, which will take place on Oct. 19, will be "The Playbill," two short plays by Terence Rattigan, starring Maurice Evans and Edna Best, at the Coronet Theatre.

SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., Aug. 7 -- Gardnar Mulloy of Coral Gables, Fla., came from two sets down to defeat Arthur Larsen of San Francisco today in the final of the Eastern grass court championship at the Orange Lawn Tennis Club, 5 -- 7, 1 -- 6, 6 -- 2, 6 -- 3, 6 -- 2.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- Conversations with members of Congress revealed today a growing belief that the Administration will have to accept less than the full authorization of $1,450,000,000 for its foreign arms aid program.
PURCHASE, N. Y., Aug. 7 -- If Argentina's great El Trebol quartet is to be stopped, high-goal poloists will have to go all-out in order to field the combination to turn the trick.

Trustworthy sources are convinced that everything has been ironed out for Carol Channing, one of the principals in the hit revue, "Lend An Ear," to assume the central-feminine role of Lorelei in the song and dance version of "Gentlemen Prefer Blondes."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- Bishop G. Bromley Oxnam of the New York Methodist area charged tonight that the Roman Catholic hierarchy was "responsible for killing the bills that might have brought Federal aid to our public school system."
The case rate of poliomyelitis rose yesterday to 8 for 100,000 of population as forty-two new cases were listed by the Department of Health to bring the total to 641.

ALBANY, Aug. 7 -- Dr. Francis T. Spaulding, the State Education Commissioner, announced today the promotion of Dr. Warren W. Knox, director of the Division of Secondary Education, to the position of Assistant Commissioner for Instructional Supervision.

The need to "Christianize Christianity" is "timely and urgent," the Rev. Ethelred Brown of the Harlem Unitarian Church said yesterday morning in a sermon at the Unitarian Church of All Souls, Eightieth Street and Lexington Avenue.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 7 -- Joe Van Blerck, Freeport, L. I., manifold manufacturer, today won the Delaware River speed boat championship in the third annual sanctioned regatta of the Wissinoming Yacht Club.

CHICAGO, Aug. 7 -- Lard futures continued to advance on the Board of Trade last week with September in the lead, the latter being affected by removal of hedges against sales of 3,700,000 pounds to the Army and development of a tight situation in the cash lard market.

CHINHAE, Korea, Monday, Aug. 8 -- Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek of China and President Syngman Rhee of Korea called today on President Elpidio Quirino of the Philippines to summon a conference for formation of an Asian union to combat communism.

The pattern of juvenile delinquency is changing. The annual report of Hawthorne-Cedar Knolls School in Westchester, an internationally known resident treatment center for children committed by the courts or referred by community agencies, shows that the children sent there this year are more emotionally disturbed than in the past and also that more of them come from families in the higher economic levels.
CANTON, China, Aug. 7 -- The effect of the United States White Paper on China on the Nationalist regime appeared here today to be less drastic than many Americans had anticipated.

HOBOKEN, N. J., Aug. 7 -- The 64-year era of the trolley car in Hudson County's transportation system ended officially at 5:25 o'clock this morning when Thomas McKenna, veteran motorman, completed his run on the Jackson Line from the Lackawanna Terminal here to the Gates Avenue car barns in Jersey City.
The visitor was a modest, elderly gentleman, neat but not gaudy, and we offered him the one available chair. "I have a song to sing-o," he said, and we begged him to proceed.

VIENNA, Aug. 7 -- The United States Joint Chiefs of Staff arrived in Vienna by plane this afternoon for a visit of little more than twenty-four hours during which they will inspect the headquarters of Lieut. Gen. Geoffrey Keyes, commanding general of United States forces in Austria.

Fears were expressed here last week by publishing and advertising spokesmen that the nation's daily, weekly and periodical press may soon be called on to pay even higher postal rates than those proposed in bills now before Congress.

Justice Jacob Panken of Domestic Relations Court announced a decision yesterday in which he had ruled that a mother, whose divorced husband has disappeared, need not obtain employment to support her two children if grandparents are financially able to support them.

PALO ALTO, Calif., Aug. 7 -- A new era in the treatment of American history, made necessary by the growing vastness of the subject, was predicted by Prof. Allan Nevins of Columbia University, at a two-day session of history teachers this week-end at Stanford University here.

After ten days of testimony, the House Foreign Affairs Committee is ready to conclude its hearings on the foreign military aid program, and Representative Kee, its chairman, is confident that both the committee and the House will approve the measure with the total of $1,450,000,000 asked by the Administration kept intact.

The Cory Corporation and its subsidiary Fresh'nd-Aire Company to the Chicago office of Dancer-Fitzgerald-Sample, Inc., for Cory coffee brewers and other Cory products and Fresh'nd-Aire fans, air circulators and humidifiers.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- The House is set to tackle tomorrow the controversial and long-deferred issue of a revised minimum wage law.

CRYSTAL BEACH, Fla., Aug. 7 (UP) -- A man armed with a sawed-off shotgun and a knife invaded a two-story house here today, killed a 75-year-old man and injured four persons, including a 7-months-old baby.

Taking ethics and the Golden Rule as the central essence of Christianity represents "cut-flower religion," the Rev. Dr. James A. Pike, new chaplain of Columbia University, said yesterday in his first sermon in the university's St. Paul's Chapel. Dr. Pike was formerly rector of the Protestant Episcopal Christ Church in Poughkeepsie, N. Y.

Joseph T. Sharkey, vice chairman of the City Council, announced yesterday that he would introduce at its next meeting legislation for a 15-per-cent ceiling on apartment rent increases sought by landlords under the Federal "net income" formula. The next regular meeting of the Council is scheduled for Aug. 23.

WARSAW, Aug. 7 -- Roman Catholic church leaders maintained silence today on the Government's new "freedom of religion" decree, but told their followers to prepare for a contest in which "we must and shall win."

GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 7 -- The Indian Harbor Yacht Club played host to the twenty-first scheduled Y. R. A. championship regatta today, but for a while it looked as though there would be "no contest" for the third successive time.
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 7 -- The Cardinals had Vice President Alben W. Barkley as their guest today at Sportsman's Park and they put on a super-colossal production for the country's second-in-command.
The famed Coney Island Mardi Gras, a post-season fixture since 1903, will not be held this year, it was announced yesterday.

Faith in God, which is esential to individual peace of soul, is in danger of being "choked off by the distractions and attachments of modern life," the Rev. Charles J. McManus of the staff of St. Patrick's Cathedral warned in a sermon there yesterday at solemn mass, at which Cardinal Spellman presided.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (AP) -- The American bill for all taxes, Federal, state and local, rose to $54,500,000,000, a record, for the fiscal year ended June 30, 1948. This averaged $372, also the highest ever, for each person.
CANTON, China, Aug. 7 (AP) -- The Chinese Nationalist Government strongly protested to Russia today against the recently announced Soviet trade pact with Communist Manchuria.
The men who stormed the beaches of Guadalcanal shortly after dawn on Aug. 7, 1942, remember the "waiting and waiting" of the night before.
William Townsend has been appointed vice president in charge of sales of Pennsylvania Flexible Metallic Tubing Company, Philadelphia. He was formerly sales manager of the company.

MAMARONECK, N. Y., Aug. 7 -- Wearers of the Winged Foot, Bill Schappa and Ed Vaughan today won the John G. Anderson Memorial golf tournament over their home club's east course for the second successive year as they turned back Ken Gordon and Billy Dear Jr. of Montclair, 7 and 5, in the thirty-six-hole final.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (AP) -- Rookie Lloyd Hittle snapped Washington's seven-game losing streak with an eight-hit pitching performance to edge Chicago's Billy Pierce, 1 -- 0, in the second game of a double header today. The White Sox won the first game, 4 -- 1, behind the eight-hit hurling of Randy Gumpert.

ROME, Aug. 7 -- Diplomatic reports from Moscow have given rise to growing speculation that the Soviet Union, despite the Communist Information Bureau's continual talk about an impending American depression and imminent collapse of the Marshall Plan, might be sincerely interested in arranging an East-West commercial modus vivendi on a large scale.

CHICAGO, Aug. 7 -- Business in the first three days of the Chicago Fall Market, sponsored by the Chicago Association of Commerce, was good in some lines and disappointing in others, the association reported today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- The following Statement was made today on the United States Government's White Paper on China by the Chinese Ambassador, Dr. V. K. Wellington Koo:

GENEVA, Aug. 7 -- A proposal to raise the price of gold in terms of all world currencies is likely to be pushed by a number of European governments during the September monetary discussions in Washington, it has been learned here.

Net income of the North American Company for the twelve months ended on June 30 was $10,500,300, equal to $1.22 a common share, compared with $12,300,800, or $1.43 a year earlier, it was announced yesterday by Herbert C. Freeman, president.

SUMMIT, N. J., Aug. 7 (UP) -- Nearly 1,500 fans -- the largest crowd in this training camp's thirty-year history -- looked on today as Gus Lesnevich completed preparations for his fifteen-round National Boxing Association title fight with Ezzard Charles at New York Wednesday night.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 7 -- Contracts between the Pacific Maritime Association and five West Coast maritime unions are to be opened for wage review this fall and in the cases of three of them welfare and pension plans are scheduled for discussion.

SAYVILLE, L. I., Aug. 7 -- It could have been a bit rougher here today to make the weather conditions more ideal for the Narrasketucks, but there is one veteran flat bottom skipper who was contented. He would be the granddaddy of all Narrasketuck racing on Great South Bay, Wilbur Ketcham, who captured the annual Queen of the Bay race off here in his Defiance.

The eight-cent fare, which became effective at 12:01 A. M. today on the seventy-six Manhattan and Bronx bus lines operated by the Surface Transportation Corporation, a subsidiary of the bankrupt Third Avenue Transit System, was drawn last night into the political arena.

By considering each tax entirely apart from the budget as a whole and by concentrating solely on its shortcomings one could, without too much difficulty, argue the whole revenue system out of existence. For without reference to the needs of the budget every tax is obviously -- for someone at least -- a bad tax.

LONDON, Aug. 7 -- All eyes in the City continue to be fixed on the stock markets, where the fall in Government bonds overshadows and conditions everything else in the markets. The best that can be said for the market in Government securities is that the decline has become rather more orderly, with the 3 1/2 per cent War Loan definitely emerging as its leader.

BLAUVELT, N. Y., Aug. 7 -- Patrons of the Greenbush Summer Theatre, in the former Bradley cow barn, now have access to baby sitters who do not demand television, cold snacks and other coddling, but, for 50 cents an hour, give the children a professional reading of nursery rhymes and children's stories with gestures.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 7 -- Alan S. FitzGerald, electrical engineer of San Francisco, was named here today as recipient of the Louis Edward Levy Medal of the Franklin Institute.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- A representative of the Matson Steamship Lines charged here today that Senator George D. Aiken, Republican, of Vermont, had acted on a "complete misrepresentation of facts" when he moved Tuesday to vote out of the Independent Offices Appropriation Bill authority for the Maritime Commission to purchase one Oceanic Steamship Line ship, the Monterey, and finish reconverting another, the Mariposa.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- Thomas B. McCabe, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, recommended to Congress today that, among other things, it start "a thorough review of the tax situation from the point of view of its effect, frequently inadvertent, upon the availability of equity capital."

CHICAGO, Aug. 7 -- Price changes in the grain markets on the Board of Trade last week were fairly rapid, with the distant deliveries coming in for more attention from traders and investors. The feeling was that Government loans would ultimately cause the markets to tighten up despite above-normal production of wheat and oats plus a liberal carryover and prospects that corn might establish a new record if weather conditions were favorable.

James B. Nolan, Deputy Police Commissioner and president of the Police Athletic League, will speak on juvenile delnnquency at 10 o'clock this morning in the Plaza Hotel, where the New York State Sheriffs Association will open its fifteenth annual three-day convention.

TOKYO, Aug. 7 (UP) -- Japan's number one swimmer, Hironoshin Furuhashi, has unofficial world record times to his credit but he has high respect for the American swimmers he will meet within nine days in Los Angeles.

HAMBURG, Germany, Aug. 7 -- The prestige and influence of Britain and to a lesser degree that of the United States have reached so low an ebb in the British zone of occupation, the most populous and economically the most important part of Western Germany, that a considerable number of Britons, many of them highly placed officials, admit they have "lost control" of the Germans.
QUITO, Ecuador, Aug. 7 -- Mounting reports from Central Ecuador's earthquake-ravaged area put the death toll today beyond 4,600. Unofficially, property damage was estimated at $20,000,000.

A new evil inherent in the nature of the longshore industry is now disclosed in revelations of dishonest applications for unemployment relief on the part of dock workers. As we pointed out the other day, there are far too many dock workers in the port for any great number of them to make a decent living.
HONOLULU, Aug. 7 -- Hawaii's Gov. Ingrain M. Stainback is in favor of eventual Territorial ownership and operation of all Hawaiian dock facilities, including stevedoring operations.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 7 (AP) -- The Chinese Communist radio in Peiping reported today that the people of Manchuria were hailing the trade agreement with the Soviet Union in a series of rallies.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 7 -- After eight days of conferences, delegates of the constituent union of the Associated Actors and Artistes of America, AFL, who met here to consider organization of the television field, have called a recess "until a date in the near future, to be mutually agreed upon, when the conference will reconvene in New York," Paul Dullzell, international president of the AAAA, announced today.

Mr. and Mrs. Isaac Baskin of 1143 Forty-third Street, Brooklyn, celebrated their seventy-fifth wedding anniversary last night at a dinner in their honor, at which their six surviving children of the original fourteen, sixteen grandchildren and twelve great grandchildren were the hosts.

Donald Harrington, minister- elect of the Community Church of New York, 40 East Thirty-fifth Street, challenged the Federal Government from his pulpit yesterday morning to put him in jail or release Larry Gara, the Bluffton College history instructor, Bluffton Ohio, recently imprisoned for advising Charles R. Rickert not to register under the 1948 Selective Service Act.

MOSCOW, Aug. 7 -- Replying to the British "forced labor" charges placed against the Soviet Union in the United Nations Economic and Social Council, Pravda stated today that Soviet citizens in correction labor camps had guarantees of "rights that so-called free citizens in capitalist countries might envy."

HONOLULU, Aug. 7 (AP) -- The Government of Hawaii was preparing today to seize the docks and go into the stevedoring business in an attempt to end the 99-day-old longshore strike, but indications were that it might be several days before it can get its program going.

A ruling made by the House Armed Services Committee that excise taxes would be collected on all taxable merchandise sold through Army PX's and Navy ship stores, has been commended by Gordon K. Creighton, assistant general manager of the National Retail Dry Goods Association.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (AP) -- Despite an increase expected in construction work this year, less lumber and brick will be needed, the Department of Commerce reported today. Other materials are slated to gain.

LONG BEACH, L. I., Aug. 7 -- Favorites were upset in the New York State A. A. U. women's swimming championships today at the Lido Beach Club, with representatives of the Women's Swimming Association of New York taking all events.

An economical and practical gadget that simplifies the broiling or roasting of chicken or a small turkey is the Flame-Kist rotisserie. Offered at Hearns and Abraham Straus in Brooklyn for $1.59, it consists of handled skewer arrangement that fits on to a square or oval roasting pan.

An important contribution toward easing the current housing shortage is being made by the nation's merchant marine through record deliveries of sorely needed framing lumber from Pacific Coast mills to East Coast distributing centers, it was reported yesterday by the American Merchant Marine Institute.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 7 (AP) -- Dick Sisler, whose ninth-inning pinch single won yesterday's game for Philadelphia, went in as a pinch hitter today and hit a three-run homer in the ninth frame of the nightcap to defeat Pittsburgh's faltering Pirates, 5 to 4, after the Quakers took the opener, 7 to 3.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 7 (AP) -- The Athletics jolted the Indians' pennant hopes today by taking a double-header, 5 to 4 and 4 to 2. Outfielder Elmer Valo and Catcher Mike Guerra supplied the big batting punch.

JERUSALEM, Aug. 7 -- The body of Dr. Theodor Herzl, the founder of political Zionism, who in the Eighteen Nineties promoted the first practical steps which led ultimately to the establishment of Israel, will be reinterred in Jerusalem on Aug. 17.

It was Italian night at Lewisohn Stadium on Saturday, and the promise of a fusillade of favorite arias drew an audience of 14,900. To perform the music were the Philharmonic-Symphony, under Alfredo Antonini; Florence Quartararo, soprano; Jan Peerce, tenor; Salvatore Baccaloni, bass, and a chorus.
HONG KONG, Aug. 7 (UP) -- The Chinese Communists appeared today to have opened up a new drive down the east coast toward the important ports of Foochow and Amoy.

CHICAGO, Aug. 7 -- For the second time in the history of the American Contract Bridge League a woman has won the von Zedwitz Gold Cup masters pair championship. Late this afternoon Mrs. Ruth Gilbert of Philadelphia and Leo Roet of New York outpointed a field of 186 pairs and with a score of 954 1/2 points captured the highly prized Masters pair championship title.

While the trade marked time pending the issuance today of the Government's first official forecast of the 1949 domestic cotton crop, activity in the cotton futures market last week was rather slow, and prices held within a narrow range. Active contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange ended the week mixed, 5 points lower to 31 points higher than the final prices of the preceding week.

TEHERAN, Iran, Aug. 7 (AP) -- Premier Mohammed Maraghei Said declared in an interview today that the United States. Imbria, tamo, avoidire, paldao, teak and peroba may have the exotic sound of whistle stops for a tramp steamer plowing tropical seas but any of them may be seen right here in the city. Elpidio Quirino, President of the Philippine Republic, is scheduled to arrive in Washington today. Washington will reflect the sentiment of the American public if it extends to him the warmest welcome in its power. Mr. Quirino is the chief executive of a young state that stands in an especial relation to the United States.

CHICAGO, Aug. 7 (AP) -- The Braves snapped their five-game losing streak today when they crushed the Cubs, 11 to 0, in the opener of a twin bill. But Boston dropped the nightcap, 4 to 3, in ten innings before a crowd of 36,961.

CHICAGO, Aug. 7 (AP) -- Lloyd Mangrum pulled up at the halfway mark of the rich Tam O'Shanter men's pro golf tourney with a 10-under-par 134 today to maintain a one-stroke lead over his archrival, Sammy Snead.

AMSTERDAM, Aug. 7 -- The inter-Indonesian conference held this week preparatory to the Hague round-table conference laid down the following principles regarding the economic financial policy of the new Indonesian Republic.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 7 -- Charles Vidor, Columbia contract director who attempted unsuccessfully last year to get a release from the studio in a court action, has been suspended from salary by Columbia, it was learned today.

Charles J. ADAMS CORNERS, N. Y., Aug. 7 -- Mrs. Emely Frances Baxter Perry of this place celebrated her 108th birthday today as her family brought her a cake that had no candles.

John Brondello, 36-year-old Italian engineer and flier, announced yesterday that in two weeks he expected to fly the Atlantic non-stop from Lisbon to La Guardia Airport as the first step in a four-month fund-raising tour that will take him and his single-engine plane to sixty-six cities in North and South America.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- Dr. V. K. Wellington Koo, Ambassador of the Chinese Nationalist Government, commenting for the first time on the State Department's White Paper on United States policy on China, admitted today that his Government might have been guilty of "acts of commission and omission" in the past.

This city's 1949 political campaign, which will get under way this week with the opening of headquarters for the Fusion mayoralty ticket headed by Newbold Morris, is regarded as likely to furnish a significant test of the value to the major parties of minor party endorsements.

Sufferers from New York's heat wave were advised yesterday by a leading evangelist to get out of town -- not just to cool off but to find out at country revival meetings the real meaning of the prayerful exclamation "Amen.

The initial consumer response to August coat and suit promotions is good, according to reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices. The large number of reorders for worsted and gabardine suits received by the wholesale apparel market here last week indicates that retailers underestimated the sales possibilities of these suits, it was said.

ZURICH, Switzerland, Aug. 7 -- Complaints about obstacles to intra-European trade raised by the way the Marshall Plan operates broke out anew last week among business leaders in Switzerland when the official communique issued at the close of four and a half weeks of hard bargaining in Vienna to draft a new trade and payments agreement between Austria and Switzerland gave no visible sign that any real progress had been made.

CHICAGO, Aug. 7 -- An additional 1,000 new employes are being hired by Motorola, Inc., bringing the company's total employment to more than 4,500, the highest number of radio and television employes in the history of the concern, it was announced here today by Paul V. Galvin, president.
PARIS, Aug. 7 -- Mme. Schiaparelli shows a collection that is challenging, sometimes sound, sometimes bizarre. She holds to a simple silhouette, but line and technique are never simple.

After the Yankees had attained their season's high for runs and hits with a 20-2 (22-hit) victory over the Browns in the opener, they were held to two singles and a 10-inning 2-2 tie by Al Papai in the nightcap at the Stadium yesterday.

STONINGTON, Conn., Aug. 7 -- Solemnity and a sense of history were strong in a small church here today packed with people gathered to offer reverent thanks to God on the 300th anniversary of this town.

ROME, Aug. 7 -- The first step toward the creation of a united anti-Communist labor front has been taken with negotiations now under way to fuse the two leading Italian labor organizations that have rejected Communist leadership.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (UP) -- Postmaster General Jesse M. Donaldson strongly objected today to a recommendation of the Commission on Organization of the Executive Branch of the Government, headed by former President Herbert C. Hoover, that the Post Office be decentralized into fifteen separate regions.

Senator Henry Cabot Lodge, Jr., in his letter appearing in your issue of July 31 makes one erroneous assumption which seems worth calling attention to although it does not affect his principal contention.

A short-term technique based on psychoanalysis is being used with success in the treatment of delinquents and criminals in London, it was reported yesterday by a world-famous psychiatrist, Dr. Denis Carroll.

NEWPORT, R. I., Aug. 8 (AP) -- Richard (Pancho) Gonzales, national singles champion from Los Angeles, was forced to thirty-four taut games today before downing Richard Mouledous, third ranking junior from New Orleans, in the first day's play of the Newport Casino's invitation tennis tournament.

LONDON, Aug. 8 -- An American businessman who came to Britain with some of the misgivings that now are being expressed so strongly in the United States concluded today after looking around for himself that "real improvement" is in sight for the country's economic situation.
CEDAR RAPIDS, Iowa, Aug. 8 (AP) -- Dr. Robert C. Rutledge Jr. was sentenced today to seventy years "at hard labor" for the slaying of his wife's admirer.

Graphs, maps and numbers always have fascinated Maryrose Hanavan. In her formative years engineering talk held a prominent place in the family home in Upper Montclair, N. J. Training with the Waves as a supply officer whetted her interest in industrial economics.
Insect destruction of agricultural crops saddened the entomologist, but the waste of human resources in displaced persons camps shocked him into action.

Offered as a new entry in the lower-priced automotive brackets, the Buick Special with Dynaflow transmission as optional equipment was announced in three models yesterday by the Buick Division, General Motors Corporation. The unofficial listed city-delivered prices, exclusive of sales tax, are Model 46, three-passenger, two-door coupe, $1,899; 46S, six-passenger, two-door sedanet, $1,954, and 43, six-passenger, four-door sedan, $2,007.

Nothing could more dramatically bring home the suddenness, the magnitude and the awful quality of a major earthquake than the poignant words of the President of Ecuador in his broadcast describing the tragedy that has stricken the garden spot of his country:

PARIS, Aug. 8 -- Jacques Fath, whose collection was shown in the garden of his establishment, describes the line he has selected for his fall and winter silhouette as "flashing." It is a movement that suggests action.

STRASBOURG, France, Aug. 8 -- Greece, Turkey and Iceland were approved today for admission to the Council of Europe by the ten Foreign Ministers composing its Committee of Ministers, which held its opening session here.
QUITO, Ecuador, Aug. 8 -- One hundred thousand Ecuadoreans were officially reported homeless today as a result of the earthquake that ripped fifty cities and villages last Friday.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -- Advance approval of "all interviews" with Army, Navy and Air Force officials is required under a new order of the Military Establishment.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 (AP) -- Raymond S. McKeough, member of the Maritime Commission, told a House subcommittee tonight that the commission had used "irregular procedures" in granting ship-construction subsidies, particularly on a $70,000,000 superliner now being built.

LAKE SUCCESS, Aug. 8 -- The past twelve months have been, on the whole, "a year of progress toward a more peaceful world," and the fear of war has decreased, Secretary General Trygve Lie said today in his fourth annual report to the United Nations General Assembly.

LONDON, Aug. 8 -- More than 150 motion pictures representing twenty-five countries will be shown at the third Edinburgh Festival from Aug. 21 to Sept. 11. This record entry list includes about twenty films of feature length and many shorts.

Spokesmen for shipowner groups, who last week voiced their opposition to the proposed Magnusen-Lesinski amendment to the Taft-Hartley law at a House committee hearing, were assailed yesterday by officials of the American Radio Association, CIO, in a broadcast to union members at sea.

In sharp contrast to the charges of injustice that were hurled at the Securities and Exchange Commission when it began to administer the Holding Company Act more than a decade ago, a large body of investors is beginning to realize tangible benefits from it, with the result that enmity has been displaced by amity.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -- President Truman reaffirmed United States friendship for the Philippine Republic and mutual solidarity between the two countries in the struggle against communism this afternoon as he welcomed Elpidio Quirino, the Philippine President.

SWAN LAKE, N. Y., Aug. 8 (AP) -- A young Brooklyn mother jumped from a burning summer camp building near this community today while ninety New York City schoolboys filed out to safety. The early morning blaze of unknown origin destroyed the three-story main building of Camp Yeshiva. Loss was estimated at $30,000, according to Swan Lake's fire chief, Lester Sherwood.

The effort to organize the Atlantic world as a bulwark of peace with freedom is proceeding along two fronts this week. One front is in Washington, where the Administration forces are battling to preserve the program for strengthening the defenses of Western Europe from being slashed to bits by an opposition all the more formidable because it is being led by Republican Senators who heretofore have been the stanchest exponents of a bipartisan foreign policy.

OAK RIDGE, Tenn., Aug. 8 -- The Oak Ridge Institute of Nuclear Studies opened its tenth training school on radioactive isotopes today with the disclosure that it had more than tripled the number of courses scheduled under the original training program.

A dual price market has reappeared in refined lead, with St. Joseph Lead Company accepting orders at the lower price level which appeared yesterday. This was 15 cents a pound, up 1/4 cent from prices prevailing here last week. Custom smelters, however booked orders at 15 1/8 cents a pound, and both 15 cent and 15 1/8 cent price levels were quoted throughout the day, according to metal traders.

MOST people who decide to walk along the fairways at the Winged Foot Golf Club, Mamaroneck, N. Y., August 19 and 20 are not likely to be carrying record books. Warm August sunshine is not considered a suitable light by which to read statistics, even if they pertain to golf.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -- When the Secretary of Agriculture, Mr. Brannan, was expounding his new farm plan before a committee of Congress recently, a member asked who would pay the costs (Mr. Brannan has declined to estimate these) of a support policy which would maintain floors under farm prices but let them find lower levels in consumers' markets. The Secretary, with candor unusual in Washington, replied, "Well, it comes out of the taxpayer."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 (UP) -- Creation of a new Department of Welfare should await a Congressional study of a program for Government health, education and welfare services, the Senate Executive Expenditures Committee said today.

The existence or a "secret register" of favored automobile customers, including Brooklyn racketeers and police officials, was revealed yesterday as John M. Broady and Edward M. Jones went on trial in General Sessions on charges of conspiracy, wiretapping and grand larceny.

HONOLULU, Aug. 8 -- Hawaii's territorial government will enter the stevedoring business formally tomorrow, it was announced here tonight after day-long conferences of territorial officials and representatives of seven stevedoring firms. But whether the authorization bill passed at a special session of the territorial legislature last week will open Hawaii's strikebound ports is still a matter for conjecture

Reporting on this year's operations of the Celanese Corporation of America, Harold Blancke, president, told shareholders in the statement issued yesterday, that the March quarter sales decline continued into the second quarter, with the low point reached in April.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores declined 14 per cent last week compared with the corresponding period last year, according to the "flash" report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The decline for the four weeks ended last Saturday was 12 per cent.

GENEVA, Aug. 8 -- The Swiss papers and Government circles are criticizing the United States Government for in effect blocking on a formality Swiss participation in the joint intra-European credit plan to revive trade.

The largest advertising campaign in the history of the gas equipment industry is now scheduled in a "National Old Stove Round-up Drive," officials of the American Gas Association announced yesterday. More than $454,000 will be spent in three months, more than 160 Eastern utility men and equipment dealers were told during an all-day conference of AGA promotional experts at the Statler Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -- By a vote of 63 to 7 the Senate passed tonight a $5,647,724,000 appropriation bill to finance foreign aid -- the Marshall Plan, Army occupational costs and continued assistance to Greece and Turkey -- through the current fiscal year.

ITHACA, N. Y., Aug. 8 -- Establishment of an annual scholarship at Cornell University in honor of the Rev. William J. Kelley of Buffalo, former chairman of the State Labor Relations Board, was announced here today.

With prices showing continued firmness and the danger of inventory loss removed, buyers of industrial fabrics are indicating their willingness to depart from hand-to-mouth buying practices, it was pointed out yesterday. Current buying, which is strong for almost all types of industrial cloth, wil tend to build up low stocks in the next sixty days, according to Worth Street commission men.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Your editorial "Hot Days on the Potomac," in your July 31 issue, said in part, referring to the temporary removal of the foreign aid program from action on the Senate floor, "Worse yet, the delay was due to an attempt sponsored by Senator John L. McClellan of Arkansas to reduce a considerable part of ECA to the level of a log-rolling rivers and harbors bill."

City Councilman Stanley M. Isaacs, Republican incumbent elected under proportional representation, was endorsed for reelection yesterday by the New York County Executive Committee of the Liberal party. He will appear on the ballot as the Liberal party nominee in the twentieth district, where he is also the Republican organization designee.

ATHENS, Aug. 8 -- Soviet jamming of Voice of America radio programs has mounted to such a degree that it is estimated reliably that in areas of concentrated interference such as Moscow only 10 per cent of the United States now are heard.

OCEANPORT, N. J., Aug. 8 (AP) Registering her third consecutive victory over the local racing strip, W. J. Walden's fleet Fighting Fox filly, Fighting Fan, today won the six-furlong Lakewood Purse, honoring the New Jersey township.
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 8 (AP) -- Enos Slaughter walloped two homers and drove in six runs as highflying Cardinals overpowered the Reds tonight, 9 to 3.

An American edition of Winston Churchill's "Painting as a Pastime" will be published by Whittlesey House early in 1950. Illustrated with reproductions in full color of eighteen of Mr. Churchill's paintings, the book describes what the hobby of painting has meant in his busy life.
GLEN HEAD, L. I., Aug. 8 -- There was a three-way tie at 78 for qualifying honors in the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association four-ball best-ball tournament at the Glen Head Country Club today.

LENOX, Mass., Aug. 8 -- Benjamin Britten, the gifted young British composer, is having a vogue these days on several continents, and during this, the final week of activities at Tanglewood, he is receiving American premieres of two major works.

After three months of suspended activity in the diamond cutting industry in this country, Baumgold Brothers, Inc., largest cutters in the United States, announced yesterday that it plans to reopen its two big New York factories next Monday and resume large scale operations.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 8 -- Economic Missions from Italy and Czechoslovakia are here to negotiate barter treaties. Since Brazil, like those nations, is short of dollars, she is expected to agree to exchange her products.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Aug. 8 -- Following a ban by the board of censors on the American film, "Home of the Brave," the United Artists management here is trying the experiment of showing it privately to cross-sections of the population.

Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek and President Syngman Rhee of Korea have moved away from the field of speculation and toward the field of action in calling upon Elpidio Quirino, President of the Philippines, to "convene in the immediate future" a conference designed to lay the framework for an anti-Communist Pacific alliance. Just how effective that move can or will be is still speculative, but it is a move and it is in the right direction.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -- Paul D. Grindle, Massachusetts manufacturer, testified today before a Senate Investigations subcommittee that James V. Hunt boasted that he had only influence "to sell" and of his ability to "go to the White House any time."

Officials of the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis dismissed yesterday as "without scientific basis" many popular notions about how the disease is contracted and spread. An upsurge of poliomyelitis is a "fertile field for rumor," they declared.

" Knit trim" has pushed its way right to the top in the fashion picture this fall. In coats, suits, dresses, hats, almost every type of clothing, designers have incorporated knitted worsted as part of the style.

CHICAGO, Aug. 8 (AP) -- Slammin' Sammy Snead collapsed for a 2-over-par 74 as pace setter Lloyd Mangrum plodded along with a second-straight 70 and a 54-hole lead of 4 strokes in the $20,000 All-American professional golf tourney today.

LONDON, Aug. 8 (AP) -- Bruce Woodcock intends to fight Lee Savold for the British version of the world heavyweight boxing championship if doctors report his condition is favorable, The Daily Mail said today.

VIENNA, Aug. 8 -- Gen. Omar N. Bradley, United States Army Chief of Staff, said today that he thought the military organization of the North Atlantic pact might be set up "within a few months." He made this statement as the three United States Chiefs of Staff completed their ten-day tour of Europe.

NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., Aug 8 -- History repeated itself today as the Wykagyl Country Club played host to a one-day pro-amateur tournament sponsored by the Westchester County Golf Association, with Bonnie Briar's pro, Sal Di Buono, partnered by the New Rochelle city judge, Thomas N. Fasso, of Wykagyl, the victors.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Aug. 8 -- Kerosene lanterns and candles lighted the dining rooms, lobby and guest rooms at the Haddon Hall Hotel this evening after a fire in the transformer room damaged electric circuits.
PINE CAMP, N. Y., Aug. 8 (AP) -- National Guardsmen appeared tonight to be winning a fight to control a raging forest fire that swept out of control on this military reservation.
EAST HARTFORD, Conn., Aug. 8 (AP) -- The wife of an internationally known construction engineer was injured fatally when a private plane crashed and burned here today.
CINCINNATI, Aug. 8 (AP) -- The major league player pension and insurance plan is not in jeopardy, Walter Mulbry, its secretary treasurer, said today.
LONDON, Aug. 8 (Reuters) -- Denis Compton saved Middlesex from being routed by Surrey in today's English cricket.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 (UP) -- The National Association of Manufacturers recommended today that labor unions be made subject to the anti-trust laws and that industry-wide bargaining be prohibited.

The National Distillers Products Corporation is not contemplating any price reductions this year, Tom Balfe, vice president of the company, declared yesterday at an annual sales meeting in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 (UP) -- Negotiations are being conducted for a possible merger of the American Veterans Committee and AMVETS, the two largest veterans organizations to grow out of World War II, it was announced tonight.

Two Federal court opinions deciding that charges of membership in the Communist party were insufficient cause to detain aliens without bond pending deportation hearings were handed down by Judge William Bondy yesterday.
TEHERAN, Iran, Aug. 8 -- The Shah of Iran, Mohammed Riza Pahlevi, will visit the United States late in November to inspect American farming and industrial methods.

NEW HYDE PARK, L. I., Aug. 8 -- Daniel McCarthy, 22-year-old former GI who tried to renounce his American citizenship in Frankfort to become a German, returned to his home at 1 Tryon Court here tonight, still declaring his determination to change his nationality.

An audience of 11,000 assembled at the Lewisohn Stadium last night as the New York Philharmonic-Symphony opened the eighth and final week of its summer season. Dimitri Mitropoulos returned to conduct the first of four concerts and Joseph Szigeti, violinist, made his second appearance as a stadium soloist.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -- Secretary of State Dean Acheson sharply rejected today Republican proposals that the Administration settle now for a small military aid program that would indicate an American intention to give more help later.

LAKE SUCCESS, Aug. 8 -- Mr. Corwin issued a statement today declaring that he was proud to be attacked by Senator McCarran, whom he described as "a political mad dog and a subversive influence in the United States."

ELIZABETH, N. J., Aug. 8 -- In a "drive to make the Singer Manufacturing company negotiate a speedy decent settlement" of the strike that has kept 9,000 employes of the sewing machine factory idle here since May 1, Local 401, United Electrical.

In a battle under the Ebbets Field lights last night in which the tension did not snap until Willard Marshall lifted a towering fly to Carl Furillo to end the game, the Dodgers squeaked through to a 2-1 victory over their ancient rivals, the Giants.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 (AP) -- Senator Pat McCarran, Democrat, of Nevada, told the Senate today that persons had gone "directly from fields of subversive activity" in the United States to positions of authority in the United Nations.
Lyman A. Wine has been appointed assistant to the president of the Electric Auto-Lite Company. He joined the company in 1942 as sales manager of the lamp division at Cincinnati, Ohio.

Elizabeth Taylor has been withdrawn from the cast of "Father of the Bride" at Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer so that she can go to Paramount on a loan-out for "An American Tragedy," with Montgomery Clift. Spencer Tracy is still tentatively scheduled for the paternal role.

The defense rested yesterday in the murder trial of Raymond Fernandez, 34 years old, and Mrs. Martha Jule Beck, 29, after their thirteenth witness testified that shorthand notes of statements made by the "lonely hearts" pair in Michigan last March had been changed.
HELENA, Mont., Aug. 8 (AP) -- Weary, grimy men worked doggedly today to halt the spreading menace of forest fires throughout the Northwest.

Man in the Cellar Man is not much in the face of the weather. The fact was confirmed by a disturbing story that reached our ears. It concerned one man's encounter with our heat wave. The man, it seems, retreated before the heat-charged atmosphere to the dank but cool confines of his cellar.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 8 -- Woodvale Farm's Halt, under one of Conn McCreary's patent-applied-for rides, astounded most of the 11,238 winner-seekers at Saratoga today by skipping home first in the seven-furlong sprint that headed the program.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -- The House plunged into debate today on the second major labor issue of the session -- the proposal for a minimum wage of 75 cents an hour -- with a North-South coalition supporting the Lucas substitute featuring a flexible minimum starting at 65 cents.

The week-old strike of longshoremen in Hoboken ended last night as the men voted to accept a settlement arranged by a rank-and-file committee and the Jarka Corporation, contracting stevedores. The longshoremen will return to work this morning.

Garry Moore will be starred in a new full-hour afternoon variety show to be heard five times a week over the Columbia Broadcasting System radio network beginning the latter part of next month, it was learned yesterday. Final details of the arrangement are yet to be worked out but it was reported the program will be broadcast from 3:30 to 4:30 P. M. Mondays through Fridays.

The generous, warm-hearted services performed for the blind and for those whom Helen Keller has called "the loneliest people in the world," the deaf-blind, by the American Foundation for the Blind, Inc., of 15 West Sixteenth Street, New York 11, are described in succinct detail in the annual report of the organization.

DETROIT, Aug. 8 -- An estimated 30,000 ballots were cast in the first day of a strike vote by the CIO United Automobile Workers against the Ford Motor Company. The results will not be known for several days after the voting ends Wednesday night.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -- Eleven million persons would be added to social security rolls and old-age benefit payments would be increased under action taken by the House Ways and Means Committee today. This would raise the total of insured persons to 46,000,000.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -- The National Geographic Society received word today that the American expedition that will study cosmic rays at great heights over Hudson Bay reached its base at Churchill, Man., last Friday. The party left Swarthmore, Pa., on July 27.

MANCHESTER, Mass., Aug. 8 (AP) -- Miss Louise Brough of Los Angeles, 1947 United States titleholder and current Wimbledon champion, was the only player in a field of forty-six to reach third-round brackets in today's opening play of the Essex County club women's tennis tournament.

COLUMBIA, Mo., Aug. 8 -- Secretary of Agriculture Charles F. Brannan defended his agricultural program again today and attacked critics who branded as regimentation the efforts of the Federal Government to deal with economic problems.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 8 -- Herbert Marshall, who has been inactive since 1947 except for one picture, will be starred in "The Whip," with Dan Duryea and Gale Storm, Hal E. Chester, who will produce the film for United Artists release, announced today.

LONDON, Aug. 8 -- The Sadler's Wells ballet company achieved a notable triumph tonight with the presentation of "The Sleeping Beauty," a spectacular production that will open the company's tour of the United States and Canada at the Metropolitan Opera House in New York on Oct. 9.

LONDON, Aug. 8 -- Millions of pounds again were lopped off market values of British Government funds in the stock market here today. Dealers reported continued and heavy selling from the opening and prices consequently dropped back rapidly to close at the lowest levels of the day, up to one and a half points down the list.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -- Although unification of the three armed services was voted, by Congress two years ago, the number of civilian employes as compared with men in uniform has not decreased, Senator Harry F. Byrd stated today.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In your issue of July 31 you published a letter of Edward C. W. von Selzam, contending that the policy of "unconditional surrender" had the worst possible effects on the efforts of some military and civil leaders to overthrow Hitler and his regime.

NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 8 -- India and the independent Kingdom of Bhutan, buffer Himalayan state between Tibet and the Indian province of Assam, signed a treaty today suggesting an adjustment in international relations of those remote mountain reaches sometimes referred to as the "roof of the world."

CHICAGO, Aug. 8 -- Delegates to the Illinois American Legion Convention, representing 226,000 members, urged today by resolution that the nine Justices of the United States Supreme Court sign loyalty oaths.

The stock market broke through yesterday to fringe the shadows of the year's high under an accumulation of week-end demand that raised prices fractions to 2 points in the leaders and from 6 1/2 to as much as 11 points in some of the thin-market and high price issues.

SHANGHAI, Aug. 8 -- The "back-to-the-village" movement continued in full swing today as the Political Affairs Commission disclosed that 400,000 refugees either had left voluntarily or had been evacuated from Shanghai since the Communist take-over on May 25.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -- Representatives John Davis Lodge, Republican of Connecticut, and Francis Walter, Democrat, of Pennsylvania, in a fresh China-aid move today introduced a bill in the House authorizing $200,000,000 in military aid.

Twenty local housing authorities will receive bids next Tuesday on issues of temporary loan notes totaling $57,175,000 under the Federal Public Housing Administration program, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -- The Senate Banking and Currency Committee today cleared the second half of the Administration's ambitious housing program, a bill setting up $4,510,000,000 in Federal insurance and loan aids to spur the construction of private building.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- The St. Regis Paper Company of New York, today filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering 860,000 shares of its $5 par value common stock.
PARIS, Aug. 8 -- Jacques Griffe's opening leaves an impression of beautiful wearable clothes that avoid any suspicion of dullness.

CANTON, China, Aug. 8 -- Evacuation of Government personnel and equipment quickened over the week-end as the Canton branch of the Nationalist regime continued obvious preparations for shifting its seat of operations.
MONTREAL, Aug. 8 (AP) -- The Montreal Royals took two games from the Newark Bears tonight, winning the opener, 7 -- 5, and the nightcap, 15 -- 1, before 9,416 fans.

LONDON, Aug. 8 -- Gen. Jean de Lattre de Tassigny, French Commander in Chief of the Western Union ground forces, issued today a denial that there was any fundamental disagreement on strategy at Western Union defense headquarters. He declared that all the Commanders in Chief were committed to "an effective defense of all the territories of Brussels Pact nations."

Coffee futures continued to advance yesterday during the day's trading on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange, Inc., with prices in the "S" contract up 24 to 40 points on sales of 25,000 bags. The "D" contract was also strong, with final prices 19 to 55 points higher with transactions amounting to 9,000 bags.

Although some scientific sources admitted yesterday the possibility that the Gulf Stream may have veered toward the New Jersey coast from its normal position eighty miles out to sea, a Navy Department spokesman characterized this as "highly improbable."

More than 80 per cent of the cases of serious juvenile delinquency handled by the New York Police Department show no religious affiliation for either the offender or his parents, James B. Nolan, Sixth Deputy Police Commissioner, said yesterday.

LAKE SUCCESS, Aug. 8 -- The Soviet Union recommended today that the United Nations withdraw from Palestine, leaving Israel and the neighboring Arab states free to reach final peace settlements without "outside pressure" or interference.

Two sightless members of the Lighthouse Players of the New York Association for the Blind will be in the cast of "Summer and Smoke" when the drama is offered the week of Aug. 22 at the Mountain Playhouse, Jennerstown, Pa.

Mayor O'Dwyer announced yesterday his support of the proposal advanced by Joseph T. Sharkey, vice chairman of the City Council, whereby residential rent increases granted by Federal authorities would be restricted to a maximum of 15 per cent by a city law.

EDGARTOWN, Mass., Aug. 8 -- Away on an aquamarine sea, ruffled only by a southwest breeze that wafted up to fourteen knots, twenty-five sailing beauties of the New York Yacht Club fleet today went after the Astor Cup, an event which used to be the social magnet of the year off shore.

CHICAGO, Aug. 8 -- Labor productivity has increased in many plants in the last year, Mill Factory, industry management publication, said today in releasing results of a survey among 1,000 companies of all types and sizes.
Time in Times Square was a bit awry last night. Two of the square's best known clocks were running three minutes apart.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Aug. 8 -- The most satisfactory development of Western Germany's election campaign in the view of United States and British officials is the failure of the Communist party to generate any popular support threatening the position of the two leading non-Communist parties, the Social Democratic and the Christian Democratic Union.
A three-man committee headed by a Negro clergyman was appointed by Mayor O'Dwyer yesterday to investigate charges of unlawful acts by the police in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn.

Gus Calvacca, a 30-year-old butcher from Brooklyn, put the ball one foot five inches from the cup at the special 142-yard hole to show the way among the Long Island acers during the first day of the sixteenth annual World Telegram hole-in-one tournament at the Bayside links in Bayside yesterday.
DETROIT, Aug. 8 (AP) -- A Negro physician has been named to the policy-making body of the American Medical Association for the first time since the group's founding 103 years ago.

SOME people never seem to do things by halves. Arthur Pocock must be one of them, for during the war he established an intimate acquaintance with the icebergs and Eskimos of Greenland and since the war he has been hunting for oil in the deserts of Arabia. As a young geologist from Cleveland Heights he might have got to Arabia considerably sooner if it hadn't been for the war.

At a time when they can least afford to operate at sub-par strength, the Yankees, who open an important three-game series against the Red Sox at Boston tonight, will have to go along without two of their mainstays. With Yogi Berra side-lined for three weeks with a fractured left thumb, the news concerning Tommy Henrich yesterday was most discouraging.

CHICAGO, Aug. 8 -- The masters' contract bridge team-of-four championship play continued today at the Stevens Hotel with only four teams remaining of the fifty-eight that started in the event last Thursday.

PARIS, Aug. 8 -- In a personal letter sent today to Bao Dai, former Emperor of Annam and now head of the new government of Viet Nam, President Vincent Auriol said that France had granted independence to the Viet Nam state and that peace in Indo-China now was "in the hands of the Viet Nam people and of them alone."

A simplified "home" course in speech correction designed to help parents and teachers rectify faulty pronunciation habits of otherwise normal youngsters between the ages of four and eight has been published by The Press of Western Reserve University, Cleveland.

BOOTH BAY HARBOR, Me., Aug. 8 -- A number of salty characters were gathering at this fishing and resort town today, heading for the waterfront and asking questions about tuna. Their pointed interest devolved from the circumstance that they would begin competing in the State of Maine tuna tournament for four days, starting tomorrow.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The American public has been assured that the billions of dollars poured into Germany are a temporary expedient which will become unnecessary once the Germans are permitted to make their "proper contribution" in the markets of the world.

PARIS, Aug. 8 -- Proposals considered by experts here as marking a notable step toward freer trade within Europe are expected to be adopted this week by the European Marshall Plan Council. They will go before the council Thursday backed by the unanimous recommendation of its trade committee in which all Marshall Plan countries are represented.

Operations of the Phelps Dodge Corporation and its subsidiaries in the six months ended with June resulted in a consolidated net income of $17,954,965 after taxes and all charges, but before mine depletion, according to the report issued jointly by Louis S. Cates, board chairman and Robert G. Page, president.

Continuing the management reorganization program started earlier this year by Paul Shields when he became chairman of the corporation, directors of the Curtiss-Wright Corporation yesterday elected as president and a director Roy T. Hurley, director of manufacturing engineering for the Ford Motor Company.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -- The United States has declined a recent request by Iran for 200,000 tons of wheat, Lincoln White State Department press officer, confirmed today. The Iranian Government was informed that plenty of wheat was available at open-market prices.

A simplified "home" course in speech correction designed to help parents and teachers rectify faulty pronunciation habits of otherwise normal youngsters between the ages of four and eight has been published by The Press of Western Reserve University, Cleveland.

BOOTH BAY HARBOR, Me., Aug. 8 -- A number of salty characters were gathering at this fishing and resort town today, heading for the waterfront and asking questions about tuna. Their pointed interest devolved from the circumstance that they would begin competing in the State of Maine tuna tournament for four days, starting tomorrow.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The American public has been assured that the billions of dollars poured into Germany are a temporary expedient which will become unnecessary once the Germans are permitted to make their "proper contribution" in the markets of the world.

PARIS, Aug. 8 -- Proposals considered by experts here as marking a notable step toward freer trade within Europe are expected to be adopted this week by the European Marshall Plan Council. They will go before the council Thursday backed by the unanimous recommendation of its trade committee in which all Marshall Plan countries are represented.

Operations of the Phelps Dodge Corporation and its subsidiaries in the six months ended with June resulted in a consolidated net income of $17,954,965 after taxes and all charges, but before mine depletion, according to the report issued jointly by Louis S. Cates, board chairman and Robert G. Page, president.

The Board of Education's law committee held a preliminary meeting yesterday to study methods of applying the Feinberg Law, which bars subversive persons from public school jobs. The meeting, at board headquarters, 110 Livingston Street, Brooklyn, was closed to the public and lasted two and one-half hours.

A heavy police detail, officially said to consist of 120 men, stood watch yesterday morning outside the American Machine and Foundry Company in Brooklyn, scene of several bitter fights last week between pickets and the police.

Harris H. Murdock, chairman of the Board of Standards and Appeals, took issue yesterday with what he called a prevailing tendency of the City Plaaning Commission toward "spot zoning" throughout the city.

United States Attorney John F. X. McGohey introduced documentary evidence at the Communist trial yesterday to show that secret party schools since World War II have used textbooks in violent revolution that the defense contends have long been superseded.
Only a limited amount of delay or confusion was reported yesterday on the Manhattan and Bronx bus lines of the Surface Transportation Company as the eight-cent fare took effect.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 (AP) -- An estimated 1949 cotton crop of 14,805,000 bales foreshadowed today a return next year to rigid Government marketing controls to hold down surpluses. Such controls last were applied in 1942. They were not needed during the war, because much cotton land was diverted to food crops.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -- The Treasury announced that the tenders for $1,000,000,000, or thereabouts, of 91-day Treasury bills to be dated Aug. 11 and to mature on Nov. 10, 1949, which were offered on Aug. 5, were opened at the Federal Reserve Banks today.

Leaders of the meat industry were again accused yesterday of being a monopoly of a few companies who "manipulate prices for selfish purposes." Addressing delegates representing more than 10,000 meat retailers at the annual convention of the National Association of Retail Meat Dealers in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, Hugo Slotkin, president of Hygrade Food Products Corporation, enlarged upon charges made last week by his father, Samuel Slotldn, chairman of the company's board of directors.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 8 (AP) -- Yugoslavia plans to increase her commercial shipping tonnage 50 per cent by 1951 under her five-year program for promoting economic independence.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was moderately active yesterday and closing prices were 11 to 32 points net higher.

Prices of United States Government bonds advanced again by substantial fractions of a point yesterday in the first period of market trading since the announcement of the pending sweeping and progressive reductions in the reserve requirements of Federal Reserve banks.
NANKING, Aug. 8 (UP) -- The Communist New China News Agency reported today that more than 170 village societies had revolted against Communist rule in Honan Province since last spring.

STUTTGART, Germany, Aug. 8 (UP) -- Dr. Kurt Schumacher, Social Democratic leader, charged today that the Western Allies had agreed at the recent Paris Foreign Ministers conference to postpone the establishment of a Western German state in exchange for a renewal of trade with the Soviet Union.

Cutting off 20,000 of the force of 46,000 longshoremen working on New York piers and a registration system to cover the employment of the remainder were proposed yesterday by the Rev. John M. Corridan, associate director of the Xavier Labor School.

Aided by lower prices, new styles and colors and heavy buyer attendance, the National Luggage and Leather Goods Show got off to a good start yesterday at the Hotel New Yorker. Prices were reported firm as compared with June levels but averaged about 15 per cent below this time last year, with quality and finishes improved.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was moderately active yesterday and closing prices were 11 to 32 points net higher.

Prices of United States Government bonds advanced again by substantial fractions of a point yesterday in the first period of market trading since the announcement of the pending sweeping and progressive reductions in the reserve requirements of Federal Reserve banks.
GENEVA, Aug. 8 -- Communist speakers in the United Nations Economic and Social Council turned the full force of their propaganda guns on the world economic crisis today.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Aug. 8 -- Western Germany's Social Democratic party is favored to win a plurality over the Christian Democratic Union in next Sunday's balloting in the United States Zone, in preliminary estimates of vote released this afternoon by United States Military Government sources.

STOCKHOLM, Aug. 9 (AP) -- James Fuchs of Yale University, holder of the world shot-put record, covered a total distance of 339 feet 7 1/2 inches tonight with six mighty heaves in the international track and field meet at Malmoe.

Homemakers who would like to introduce the mellow shadowy flavor of old candlelight into a contemporary setting have had a somewhat difficult time finding suitable holders for their tapers. For the most part, they have had to resort to traditionally designed accessories, or, if they could afford it, indulge in one of the exquisite but expensive hand-wrought sterling candelabra that have been among the few contemporary examples to be found.

The prospective September supply of copper from domestic sources is down to 62,000 tons, compared with combined industrial requirements that will average 100,000 tons for each month of the third quarter, C. Donald Dallas, chairman of the board, Revere Copper and Brass, Inc., said in a statement prepared for the Senate Finance Committee.

Two Army sergeants, the winners in a rigorous competition conducted among the personnel of the First Division in Germany to decide the "best" soldier, landed in New York yesterday to start an "all expenses paid" leave.

Completition of the official poster for National Hat Week, Oct. 2 to 8, was announced yesterday by E. A. Korchnoy, president of the Hat Research Foundation. The Foundation is sponsoring the nation-wide promotion, which will open with a heavy Sunday ad drive by manufacturers and dealers.

Terrified passengers on a northbound Eighth Avenue IND express train pushed and shoved out to the Forty-second Street station platform at 9:43 A. M. yesterday when a short circuit caused an explosion, flash fire and dense smoke. Six persons were treated for hysteria and shock.

SALZBURG, Austria, Aug. 9 -- The popular verdict following today's world premiere of Carl Orff's one-act opera "Antigone" was "interesting." Like most works about which the best that can be said is that they are "interesting," this "Antigone" was actually about as uninteresting as an opera can be.

PARIS, Aug. 9 -- Sources now in Paris who are acquainted with Middle Eastern events report that President Husni Zayim's betrayal of the fascist-oriented chief of the Syrian Popular party, which staged a feeble and abortive rebellion in Lebanon at the beginning of July,

Forty ticket offices and 120 freight offices of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad in New York and Connecticut will be closed on week-ends after Sept. 1, it was announced last night by the railroad.

Democracy exists in the United States trade union movement because so much of its direction is carried out in locals where members can initiate and determine the decisions, sixteen German labor leaders and experts reported yesterday after a two months' survey.

NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 9 -- A trade war between India and Pakistan may be the outgrowth of the boycott on Indian goods announced last week by the Pakistani Federation of Chambers of Commerce and Industry, authoritative quarters indicated today.

GOSHEN, N. Y., Aug. 9 -- The luck of the draw for starting positions in tomorrow's Hambletonian -- The Kentucky Derby of harness racing -- in which eighteen 3-year-old trotters will go to the post, went against the favorite today. Bangaway, the undefeated bay colt of Saunders Mills, drew No. 18 and will start from the extreme outside with the second tier.

BOSTON, Aug. 9 -- Unmindful of their aches and bruises, the Yankees made an heroic effort tonight to check Joe McCarthy's onrushing Red Sox in the opening clash of their momentous three-game series. But it was no go.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 -- Five percenters will have a slim chance indeed to get in on White House reconstruction contracts, W. E. Reynolds, Public Buildings Administrator, said today.

MANCHESTER, Mass., Aug 9 (AP) -- American favorites advanced, but all foreign seeded stars were eliminated from the Essex County Club women's tennis tournament today. Three of the invaders were forced to default and the fourth lost in three-set competition under a blazing sun and in 100-degree temperature.

A price spurt yesterday morning engendered by active trading in Contract "S" sent coffee futures in that contract up 12 to 17 points on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. A reaction later, however, sent final prices for the day in the "S" contract 3 to 20 points below Monday's closing levels.
