WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 (AP) -- The Government proposed today to change its meat grading system so as to give the economy-minded consumer a wider selection of beef.

Second Lieut. Samuel H. Miller, a 32-year-old Army officer who had been accused by his divorced wife of kidnapping their 6-year-old son, Robert Clark Miller, surrendered with the boy at 9 o'clock last night at the Sheepshead Bay police station in Brooklyn.

CANTON, China, Aug. 9 (AP) -- At least 11,000 Communist troops, according to an official account, were encircled today on the front north of Canton. If true, the Communist drive on this refugee capital should be seriously blunted.

The most interesting fact about the Council of Europe is that nobody dares to take it lightly. As the Assembly meets for the first time today in the arcaded hall of the University of Strasbourg, to inaugurate an experiment that calls for more drastic barrier-breaking than the United Nations, its most earnest supporters view it with very restrained optimism.
Conversations are now taking place between the Department of State and its top Far East advisers. The problem to be solved is our future attitude toward China, Indonesia, etc.

LAKE SUCCESS, Aug. 9 -- The kingdom of Nepal today pressed its six-month-old request for United Nations membership and assured the Security Council that it was submitting its application as a completely sovereign state.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 -- A budgetary compromise that would keep intact the $1,450,000,000 foreign military aid program but would charge part of the cost to the future was accepted today by Secretary of Defense Louis Johnson.
A Federal investigation of the New York waterfront has been urged on Congress by the Rev. John M. Corridan, associate director of the Xavier Labor School and a student of longshore problems.

TRENTON, N. J., Aug. 9 -- Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll, who returned today from a short vacation, urged the construction of a third tunnel under the Hudson River north of the present tubes as a means of relieving traffic congestion between New York and New Jersey.

The Grumman Aircraft Engineering Corporation of Bethpage, L. I., reported yesterday net income of $1,457,734, equal to $1.46 a capital share, for the first six months of 1949. The net income was after provision of $975,000 for Federal income taxes and the estimated effect of the Vinson-Trammell Act's profit limitations.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 (UP) -- Charles Copeland, business agent for Local 601, in Pittsburgh, of the United Electrical Workers, CIO, testified today he was convinced that between 200 and 300 of the local's members were affiliated with the Communist party.

A memorial exhibition of the work of Yankel Adler, expressionist painter who died last April, has opened at the Jewish Museum, where it will be on display until Oct. 6. The artist, who served in the French Polish Legion and was evacuated from Dunkirk, has had only one other full-scale showing in America.

Two or three steps down from the hot sidewalk, at 35 West Fifty-eighth Street, is a bakery that dispenses such fresh, delicious breakfast breads that they make that first meal of the day, often so difficult, rather easier to take.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 -- The White House today made its second move to funnel Government spending into areas that have been hit hard by unemployment and designated eleven industrial communities in which 12 per cent or more of the labor force has been thrown out of work.
The record of the First Army in both world wars was hailed yesterday by Lieut. Gen. Walter Bedell Smith, its commander, on the eve of its thirty-first anniversary.

A series of six documentary radio programs designed to show the need of world reliance upon the United Nations for peace, welfare and security will be broadcast in weekly Sunday installments by the National Broadcasting Company, starting Sept. 11.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 -- The Columbia Gas System, Inc., New York; its subsidiary, the Atlantic Seaboard Corporation, Charleston, W. Va., and three wholly owned subsidiaries of the latter company have requested authorization from the Securities and Exchange Commission to consummate various financial transactions.

Sir Alexander Cadogan, permanent United Kingdom delegate to the United Nations, charged last night that Soviet Russia's use of "surprise" in presenting issues before the Security Council, without first seeking agreement or settlement, had caused a worsening of relations between nations.

PRINCETON, N. J., Aug. 9 -- The incoming freshman class at Princeton University for the 1949-1950 academic year will receive a total of $205,000 in scholarship aid and student employment, a record high in the history of the university, according to figures released today by Minot C. Morgan, director of the Princeton Bureau of Student Aid and Employment.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 -- American Airlines, one of the "Big Four" certificated carriers, today asked the United States Circuit Court of Appeals here to revoke a decision by the Civil Aeronautics Board that certificated three large air freight carriers for five-year periods, under an order issued Aug. 2.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 (AP) -- The texts of addresses by President Elpidio Quirino of the Philippines to the House of Representatives and the Senate today:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 -- A movement took shape in the House today to head off the Administration's 75-cent minimum wage bill by writing that figure into the Lucas substitute, a North-South coalition proposal.

MATTAPOISETT, Mass., Aug. 9 -- Rails down and under at times, twenty-two craft in the New York Yacht Club racing fleet today made the final squadron run of the cruise. It was a sail of twenty-nine miles here from Edgartown on Martha's Vineyard.

OCEANPORT, N. J., Aug. 9 (AP) -- Samuel Greenfield's High Trend was placed first in today's feature at Monmouth Park when Cacique, even-money favorite, was disqualified. Cacique, who finished first, was dropped to third for having bothered Mrs. James V. Stewart's Singing Doll.

Increased demand for cloth with nylon content has brought about a revival of the "gray market" for the fiber, it was learned yesterday. Premiums upward of 50 cents a pound have been offered to hosiery knitters who enjoy a yarn position with E. I. du Pont de Nemours, the sole manufacturer in the United States of nylon yarn and staple.

A wax product worth $20,000,000 in annual exports and the first stable, dry tortilla flour acceptable to the Mexican public are among the technical contributions made to the Mexican economy by the Armour Research Foundation of Illinois Institute of Technology.

SOUTHAMPTON, L. I., Aug. 9 -- The theft of jewelry valued at $93,000 from her summer home on Ox Pasture Road here was reported tonight to the Southampton village police by Mrs. Elizabeth Dunnington, wife of Walter G. Dunnington, New York attorney.

The delivery of Fort William McKinley, just outside Manila, to the Philippine Government by the United States Army is something more than the routine transfer of an Army post to the young republic. It also hands over to the Philippine Government a rich and happy tradition.

A 52-year-old grandmother was held yesterday in $5,000 Federal bail charged with being the contact woman between a gang of stamp and money counterfeiters here and "the underworld element" in Connecticut.

A plea for reduction of the $25,000 bail for George Pirinsky, being held on Ellis Island pending deportation proceedings on a charge of being a member of the Communist party, was denied in Federal District Court yesterday by Judge Alexander Holtzoff.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9--The national executive committee of the Marine Engineers Beneficial Association, CIO, after a referendum, announced today that the union was accepting the terms of a new contract with ship-owners.

Ground was broken yesterday for an addition to Public School 87, Edson and Grace Avenues; in the northeast section of the Bronx. The $637,595 project is the eighth unit to be undertaken in the Bronx and the thirty-sixth in the city since the Board of Education's post-war building program began.
Forest fires, destroying timber in five Eastern and Western states, were under control last night, except in Idaho, where wind fanned a 5,000-acre blaze, The Associated Press reported.

H. LeVan Richards of New York prominent tournament official and a familiar figure in the umpire's chair at the Forest Hills Stadium for some years, has been named as referee of the Interzone Round Davis Cup match between Australia and Italy, to be played on the turf courts of the Westchester Country Club in Rye Friday, Saturday and Sunday.

NEWPORT, R. I., Aug. 9 (AP) -- Top-seeded Richard (Pancho) Gonzales of Los Angeles, national singles champion, had to go all out before turning back Tom Molloy of New Orleans, 7 -- 5, 6 -- 4, today in third-round competition in the Newport Casino's thirtieth annual lawn tennis tournament.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 -- Speedy confirmation of Attorney General Tom C. Clark as a Supreme Court Justice was urged today in letters and telegrams from scores of prominent persons as the Senate Judiciary Committee started to consider his nomination by President Truman.

Plans were filed with the Department of Housing and Buildings yesterday for the new $1,000,000 building of St. Mary's Hospital for Children, to go up on a six-acre site at 216th Street and Twenty-ninth Avenue in Bayside, Queens. George B. Post Sons are the architects.
QUITO, Ecuador, Aug. 9 (AP) -- Fear and panic gripped survivors as damage continued to mount in the earthquake - stricken Patate Valley today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 -- John W. Snyder, Secretary of the Treasury, called today for the enactment of Government guarantees on private United States investments abroad as a first step in President Truman's "bold new program" to assist underdeveloped areas of the world.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 9--The House Ways and Means Committee approved today a social security tax structure designed to put the system on a permanently sound basis and to permit unlimited expansion.

The State of North Carolina yesterday sold $7,500,000 of port bond anticipation notes dated Aug. 17, 1949, and due on Feb. 17, 1950, to First Securities Corporation, Durham, at 0.5233 per cent discount.

DETROIT, Aug. 9 -- The National Medical Association, composed of Negro physicians, dentists and druggists, today heard a plea by the president-elect of the American Medical Association for doctors to "prevent the adoption of political medicine," in the national compulsory health insurance proposed by the Truman Administration.
The Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company has been appointed trustee for $2,000,000 of first mortgage 3-4 per cent bonds due July 1, 1950-69 of G. F. Heublein and Brother, Inc.
Throughout the city, the suburban areas and New York State yesterday the total number of polio cases slowly increased as expected by medical statisticians on the basis of experience.

BLOOMINGTON, Ill., Aug. 9 (UP) -- A group of engineers today announced development of a "wooden iron" lung that can be built by any polio-stricken community in twenty-four hours from an inner tube, washing machine motor, alarm clock and other ordinary materials.

A biography of Wade Hampton, Southern planter, Confederate general, twice Governor of South Carolina and twice elected to the United States Senate after the war, has been scheduled for September publication by Scribners, entitled "Giant in Gray."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 -- McCrory Stores Corporation, with headquarters in New York, the Manufacturers Association of Connecticut, and other New England interests today asked the Interstate Commerce Commission to block plans of the New Haven, the Jersey Central, the Central of Pennsylvania, the Reading Company and the Boston Maine to cancel free pick-up and delivery service at many points in the metropolitan areas of New York.
The Manufacturers Trust Company announced yesterday that it has put into effect the common trust fund which it set up several months ago following approval by the New York State Banking Board.

Prof. Linus Pauling of the California Institute of Technology, who is president of the American Chemical Society, announced yesterday that Dr. Henry A. Lardy, Associate Professor of Biochemistry at the University of Wisconsin, had won the $1,000 Paul-Lewis Laboratories Award in Enzyme Chemistry.

A prosecution witness yesterday at the wiretap and grand larceny trial of John G. Broady quoted the defendant as having said that Frank Costello had posted a $2,000 bonus for any Supreme Court clerk who informed him when a wiretapping order had been issued.

The 1949 Gladiolus Show of the Horticultural Society of New York opened yesterday in the Colonnades Ball Room of Essex House. Spikes of all sizes and colors were entered in eighty-five competitive classes of the show, which was staged in cooperation with the Eastern New York, New Jersey and Connecticut Gladiolus Societies.

PARIS, Aug. 9 -- Madame Gres, in defiance of the prevailing trend to shorten skirts, or at least to keep them some fourteen inches from the floor, maintains about an even twelve inches off the floor for her daytime fall and winter fashions.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 (AP) -- Aided by fifteen bases on balls, the Athletics defeated Washington, 8-3 tonight. Carl Scheib won his seventh game. He had a shut-out until the ninth inning, when the Senators scored all their runs on four of their nine hits.
GENEVA, Aug. 9 (UP) -- A Red Cross conference of forty-nine nations decided today that a Russian resolution asking it to outlaw the atom bomb and biological and chemical warfare was out of order.

PARIS, Aug. 9 -- The expectation of the Europeans and Americans in closest touch with Marshall Plan diplomacy here is that, in adapting the European dollar requests to the reduced appropriation to be made by Congress, the European Council will cut the original estimates of virtually all countries for the current year.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 (UP) -- The Senate passed a bill today to reform administrative procedures of the Federal Communications Commission, and raise the salaries of its members from $10,000 to $15,000 a year.

HAMPTON, Va., Aug. 9 (AP) -- Ranking officers of the nation's armed forces stood around a table-like glass-topped cabinet here today to observe some electronics "black magic" that promises to revolutionize marine navigation.

SEOUL, Korea, Aug. 9 -- The Korean Republic is preparing to mark its first anniversary this coming week-end under the shadow of threatened violence and sabotage at the hands of the Communist underground.

GLEN HEAD, L. I., Aug. 9 -- After a long, hot day, during which two rounds were completed, the two medalist teams were eliminated as Mrs. W. R. Kirkland Jr. of Piping Rock and Mrs. V. D. Crisp of The Creek, reached the final in the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association four-ball best-ball tournament along with Mrs. Percy Uris of Inwood and Miss Evelyn Odom of Wheatley Hills.

George Lynch of Flushing, a member of the Plandome Golf Club, used a No. 7 iron to place his second shot ten inches from the cup at the special 142-yard hole yesterday to take the lead among the Long Island contingent in the sixteenth World-Telegram hole-in-one tournament at the Bayside Golf Club.

LONDON, Aug. 9 -- After renewed weakness at the opening of the stock market here today, bear covering on the last day of the twenty-one day account brought about a recovery in British Government bonds, which advanced as much as one point.

ATHENS, Aug. 9 -- The pattern, although not the timetable, of Kremlin plans for completing the revolutionizing processes not only of Eastern European states but of the Soviet Union itself is apparent. Stage Number One is to bring about creation of a "people's democracy."
CLEVELAND, Aug. 9 (AP) -- Bob Feller pitched the Indians to a 9-2 victory over the Browns tonight for his fourth straight victory and tenth of the season against eight defeats.
Morris Kugler was the broker in the recent sales by the estate of Rose Matzner of the properties at 1892 and 1893 Lexington Avenue to George Weneler and at 1886 Lexington Avenue to Joseph Panica.

THE trouble with the world, says H. A. Overstreet in "The Mature Mind,"* is that so few people in it ever grow up. Psychologically, emotionally and intellectually immature, they perpetuate a vicious circle. Their family life, their educational system, their politics and their entire culture cannot be mature because they are shaped by immature persons; and these environ mental factors in their turn are powerful influences for immaturity.

The Senate investigation into the extent, cause and cure of "five per centism" in Washington has got off to a good start. The personal drama involved should not be allowed to obscure the underlying principles. Complex and gigantic a Leviathan as our Government may be, the citizen who has something to sell should not need the services of a middleman to guide him, at a price, to the appropriate federal agency.

HONOLULU, Aug. 9 -- Gov. Ingram M. Stainback signed tonight two executive orders putting him in a position to seize the struck Hawaiian stevedoring industry after the first day of recruiting of longshoremen to work the docks under the seizure had brought 295 job applications.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 9 (AP) -- The government fined a British oil company, Shell-Mex, Ltd., $297,910 for alleged violation of foreign exchange regulations. The fine, levied by the Ministry of Finance, almost equals the amount Shell-Mex paid under protest when the government first accused it of exchange infractions in 1948.

New regulations intended to spur construction of rental apartment housing for families of moderate income by private builders and investors were announced yesterday by Thomas G. Grace, New York director of the Federal Housing Administration.

Carl Williams of Brooklyn, top-seeded entrant, had little trouble disposing of Joseph White, New York, 6 -- 0, 6 -- 2 yesterday in the third round of the thirty-first annual Negro open championships being staged by the New York Tennis Association at the Cosmopolitan Tennis Club. Teddy Dubison of New York upset DeWitt Willis of Scotch Plains, N. J., ranked twelfth, 6 -- 1, 7 -- 5.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 -- Describing James V. Hunt, Washington management counselor, as "the kingmaker," Tighe E. Woods, Federal Housing Expediter, told a Senate Expenditures subcommittee today that Mr. Hunt might have been partly responsible for getting him his job.
COLUMBIA, S. C., Aug. 9 -- A 10-year-old boy confined to the South Carolina Penitentiary for housebreaking and larceny said today he preferred the prison to a reform school.

Although many people in Germany are "growing more assertive," there is "enough sense of freedom and decency in the Germany people on which there can be built a healthy and peaceful state," John J. McCloy, United States High Commissioner-designate and Military Governor for Germany, declared last night.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 9 (AP) -- The Cardinals kept pace with the Dodgers in the tight National League race by downing the Reds, 4 to 1, tonight. Harry Brecheen allowed seven hits and no walks for his ninth victory of the year for the Redbirds.

CHICAGO, Aug. 9 (AP) -- A team headed by Arthur Goldsmith, Cleveland, tonight defeated a team led by Oswald Jacoby, Dallas Tex., by 170 points in a 56-boar final match to win the world masters' team contract bridge championship.

The subject of forced labor has been up before the Economic and Social Council at Geneva and, by a natural association of ideas, it seemed proper to the British to produce a copy of the Russian forced labor code and to the United States to introduce a resolution calling for the establishment of an eleven-man United Nations commission to travel around and look into the matter of forced labor anywhere in the world.

Formation of a "draft Lehman" committee, designed to persuade former Gov. Herbert H. Lehman to accept the Democratic and Liberal party nominations for United States Senator was announced yesterday. Representative Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. is honorary chairman, and Henry Modell is chairman. The committee has headquarters at the Commodore Hotel.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 (AP) -- Secretary of the Interior Krug said today that the Idaho Power Company was trespassing on public land in Idaho and must be stopped.
ATLANTA, Ga., Aug. 9 -- Equal Educational facilities for Negroes Irwin County, Ga., were demanded today in a suit filed in the United States District Court at Valdosta.

By edging out the Braves, 4--3, while the Dodgers were polishing off the Phillies, the Giants last night tightened their hold on third place. Larry Jansen won the game, for his twelfth victory against eleven defeats, with ninth-inning help from Adrian Zabala, who came in to fan Ed Sauer for the game's final out.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Aug. 9 -- It was officially announced tonight in Damascus, Syria, that eleven young men, some of them students, had been arrested on a charge of participating in the bombing of the Damascus synagogue last Friday night that cost the lives of twelve Jews and injured eighteen.

Robert G. Thompson, New York State chairman of the Communist party, took the stand in his own defense at the Communist trial yesterday, and quickly ran afoul of Federal Judge Harold R. Medina's new policy for shortening the triad.

Dimitri Mitropoulos had a conspicuous success last night, both as pianist and conductor, for he repeated at the Lewisohn Stadium the same feat he accomplished six years ago at Carnegie Hall--that of simultaneously playing and leading Prokofieff's Third Piano Concerto.

As a member of the La Guardia Fusion Administration for more than six years and a lifelong resident of Manhattan, I would like to express my delight and satisfaction in the nomination of Robert F. Wagner Jr., Chairman of the City Planning Commission, by the Democratic and Liberal parties, as President of the Borough of Manhattan.

The report of the White Motor Company issued yesterday for the first six months this year shows a decline in net profit to $185,491, or 27 cents a share, from $1,831-621, or $2.66 a share, in the same period of 1948.
HONG KONG, Aug. 9 -- Moves in the Philippines, Formosa and Korea for the promotion of an Asiatic anti-Communist pact were viewed with considerable skepticism and lack of interest here.

District Attorney Miles F. McDonald of Kings County told 100 members of the New York State Sheriffs Association yesterday that they could aid prosecutors substantially by obtaining information on unsolved crimes from their prisoners.
Underwriting syndicates here will place on the market today two new issues of public utility stock comprising both common and preferred valued at more than $14,800,000. The offerings are as follows:

Passaic County is drawing the attention of many New Jersey builders, particularly those attempting to supply the demand for houses in the $9,000 class, and reports of expanding operations in this field were received from that area yesterday.

Long ago in what a few people these days still call normal times -- whatever they were -- newspaper men used to view the arrival of August with lack-luster eyes. Washington, more often than not, slept in the hot sun; the nation's pulse slowed.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 9 -- While his mates pummeled two of four Philadelphia pitchers for thirteen of their fifteen hits, young Carl Erskine limited the Phils to three blows and the Dodgers coasted to an 8-1 triumph under the Shibe Park lights tonight.

Visiting buyers registered in the market in the week ended yesterday totaled 1,398, against 1,464 last week and 1,341 in the corresponding week of last year, according to lists published in THE NEW YORK TIMES. There were 745 arrivals yesterday compared with 495 last Tuesday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 -- A Pacific Union, even without the immediate participation of the United States, was advocated here today in an address to the Senate by President Elpidio Quirino, of the Republic of the Philippines, to halt the advance of communism in Asia by non-military means.

Coincidental with announcement of a 45-cent quarterly dividend payable on its common stock on Sept. 30, the $410,000,000 West Penn Electric Company disclosed yesterday an extensive refinancing plan complementary to its corporate simplification program which was approved by the Securities and Exchange Commission on July 28.
BERNE, Switzerland, Aug. 9 (UP) -- A high postoffice official has been arrested as a spy for a foreign power and other government officials are believed to be involved, it was disclosed today.

Gardeners in this vicinity have been observing with joy -- not unmixed with wonder -- that the annual plague of their old enemy Popillia japonica, the Japanese beetle, is less severe this year than usual. This does not mean, alas, that the Japanese beetle as a species is going to join its ancestors.

Herbert Hoover, our only living ex-President, is 75 today. He comes to that milestone with the respect and the heartfelt good wishes of a nation. Behind him is an extraordinary career which really divides itself into four careers. The first was that of the energetic and highly successful mining engineer.

Exactly forty-nine days after he gained recognition as the world heavyweight champion from the National Boxing Association, Ezzard Charles, Cincinnati Negro, tonight will risk his partial claim to the title Joe Louis surrendered upon his retirement last year.
Taking a definite public stand on radio liquor advertising for the first time, the Distilled Spirits Institute, representing about 70 per cent of the industry, condemned any such move yesterday.

It is to be hoped that the revived interest in monetary standards shown by recent letters to THE NEW YORK TIMES and other publicity is sustained. For the chaotic conditions in international trade seem to show either that "managed currencies" do not work very well or else are managed very badly.
One of the biggest and one of the most amazingly simple jobs of housekeeping goes on every morning of the year in the vast vault of Grand Central Terminal.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 (AP) -- Chairman Porter Hardy Jr., Democrat, of Virginia, said today a House Expenditures subcommittee investigation of the Maritime Commission's ship subsidies has "uncovered evidence, not of dishonesty, but of extremely poor administration."

Joseph L. Ennis Co. have purchased the three-story dwelling at 214 East Thirty-fifth Street from William A. Gallagher and Charles A. Briody, trustees of the estate of John Gallagher. The property, which became a corner when the approach to the Queens Midtown Tunnel was built, is assessed at $16,000 and was reported held at $25,000.

Tallulah Bankhead's long search for a new script is ended. Yesterday it was announced she had selected "Lily Henry" as her next starring vehicle and that it would be jointly produced "this coming season" by a trio of sponsors -- Richard Aldrich, Richard Myers and John C. Wilson.

Brooks Brothers 131-year-old men's clothing shop, originator of an easily recognized male fashion "look" and guardian of a conservative tradition, yesterday confirmed rumors of a new feminine style note. Two days hence Brooks will place on sale a boldly-colored pink shirt especially cut for women.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 9 -- Mrs. F. Ambrose Clark's remarkable ex-hurdler, Tea-Maker, who can stay with the routers and turn it on with the sprinters, did a handsome bit of sprinting at Saratoga today. Under the sting of young Bill Passmore's whip in the final yards, he won a six-furlong handicap in the fastest time of the meeting.

GENEVA, July 27 -- The total population of Europe, excluding Russia, fell from 392,100,000 to 383,800,000 during World War II and the first two post-war years. Nearly all of this net decline was the result of a fall in the populations of those countries bordering on Soviet Russia and most of the loss is accounted for by transfers of population to Russia.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Aug. 9 -- The United States Military Government has reversed itself and approved the general claims restitution law for indemnification of victims of nazism as the result of an extraordinary and virtually one-man battle on behalf of the measure by John J. McCloy, High Commissioner-designate.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 -- As a result of a $600,000,000 increase in farm income in June, the total personal income of the country was at the annual rate of $213,500,000,000 compared with $212,900,000,000 in May, the Commerce Department announced today.
CHICAGO, Aug. 9 (AP) -- Cliff Chambers and Clyde McCullough, both traded to the Pirates by the Cubs last winter, combined to pace an 8-3 victory over their former mates today before 11,313.

The nation's meat dealers have reached a point where it is imperative for them to know more about nutritive values of meat, Max O. Cullen, director of the department of meat merchandising, National Live Stock and Meat Board, declared yesterday.

PRAGUE, Aug. 9 (AP) -- Residents of a mountain town in Catholic Slovakia, armed with scythes and flails, recently revolted against the Communists and set up their own local government, it was disclosed today.

The sun beat down on a sweltering city yesterday, sending the mercury to 97.6 degrees at 3:25 P. M. This made the day the hottest Aug. 9 on record but failed by two-tenths of a degree to equal the high mark for the year, 97.8 degrees on July 29.

LONG YEAR CITY, Spitsbergen, Aug. 9 -- In a snow storm, with the temperature at 35 degrees, Norway's Crown Prince Olaf placed a wreath today on the mountainside grave of Capt. T. H. Vigtel, killed in a raid by the German battleship Tirpitz in 1943.

STRASBOURG, France, Aug. 9 -- A proposed discussion of a human rights agreement was eliminated today from the agenda of the European Consultative Assembly by the Committee of Ministers, composed of the Foreign Min isters of the twelve member states. The vote was seven to four, with one abstention.

The stock market hit a snag yesterday after Monday's sharp rise, as moderate profit-taking dampened a furtherance of strong buying support. Although the offerings were not general, they proved sufficient to produce a loss of 0.44 point in the price average.

Saks-34th showed yesterday such wanted items as simple wools with chic pocket interest, attractive separates, youthful suits and a wide array of fashionable corduroys and velveteens for career and college girls.

TOKYO, Aug. 9 -- The Japanese today again are discussing the controversial question of a Pacific Alliance against communism. The general viewpoint here appears to be that although Japan is both unable and unwilling to commit herself to any course of action, at least as long as the occupation lasts, no pact is likely to be successful in the long run that does not take into account Japan as a potential Pacific power.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Aug. 9 -- Until the Board of Czechoslovak Bishops adopts a policy on implementation of the Vatican's decree, there will be no general excommunication on the ground of Communist party affiliation in Czechoslovakia.

FARMINGDALE, L. I., Aug. 9 -- The black widow spider scare spreading throughout Nassau County was debunked today by Dr. Harvey Burke, entomologist at the Long Island Technical and Agricultural Institute.

Westchester and Long Island jumped to the front by scoring convincing triumphs as play in the three-day Junior Davis Cup intersectional team matches opened yesterday on the courts of the West Side Tennis Club, Forest Hills.

BOOTHBAY HARBOR, Me., Aug. 9 -- On the last of the slack tide, at 1:30 P. M. today, one of the first fish in the State of Maine Tournament took the hook. At 3:53 P. M. the fish was boated but disqualified. His captor, Dr. Julian C. Barton of San Antonio, Tex., was all in and so was the bluefin resting near the bottom in 140 feet of water.

Pickets belonging to the United Electrical Workers, CIO, demonstrated yesterday in front of offices of the State Division of Placement and Unemployment Insurance in New York and elsewhere in the state.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 -- Robert A. Lovett told a House committee today that nothing influenced the 1941 selection of the B-36 as the Air Force super-bomber of the future except the ability of the Consolidated Aircraft Company to produce approximately the type of airplanes requested by Air Force engineers.

CHICAGO, Aug. 9 (AP) -- Lloyd Mangrum, Tam o'Shanter's favorite son, unwound a pressure-packed one-under-par 35 on the final nine today to rally for a regulation 72 and win the All-American men's pro golf tourney with a 276 total to Sam Snead's 277.

Shoe manufacturers do not wish to be caught in a "cross fire" between major suppliers in the "battle" between leather and so-called substitute sole materials, the National Shoe Manufacturers Association declared yesterday.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange turned somewhat easier yesterday and final prices were 3 to 15 points net lower than on Monday.

Fourteen Greek seamen were arrested by immigration officers at 11 A. M. yesterday as they were about to board the Gdynia America liner Batory, which sailed at noon for Poland from Pier 88, North River.

ESSEX FELLS, N. J., Aug. 9 -- Topsy, a brown and white pinto pony that has been running wild through the wooded countryside near here for the last three months, was captured early today in a corral built for the purpose near the Essex Fells Country Club.

LAKE SUCCESS, Aug. 9 -- A special committee of the United Nations General Assembly today approved Secretary General Trygye Lie's recommendation that each annual session of the Assembly be opened with a minute of silence for prayer or meditation.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 -- By a vote of 210 to 164 the House instructed its managers of the foreign aid appropriation bill late today to resist in conference all Senate efforts to continue the Congressional "watch dog" committee which checks up on Marshall Plan operations.

The Ridge Towers at 7501 Ridge Boulevard, in Brooklyn, containing sixty-four suites, has been purchased by the Foster Holding Corporation from the Tuscan Apartments, Inc., in a deal negotiated by Sam Kutay. Title to the property, which is 100.18 by 140 feet, was insured by the Title Guarantee and Trust Company. Baron Baron were attorneys for the buyer.

HAVANA, Aug. 9 -- Fifteen Cuban banks today notified President Carlos Prio Socarras that they are willing to underwrite a Government bond issue of $35,000,000 with an option to subscribe to an issue of $32,500,000 in each of the two succeeding years. The offer was made in a visit by the banks' representatives to the President.

CLEVELAND, Aug 9 (AP) -- The New York State Public Service Commission has developed a plan which it hopes will save smaller telephone companies from threatened extinction, Spencer B. Eddy, deputy chairman of the N. Y. State PSC, said today.

ROME, Aug. 9 -- Premier Alcide de Gasperi expressed optimism about the possibility of an Italian-Yugoslav agreement in an interview published today by the Gazzettino of Venice. He added, however, that negotiations could not start until Yugoslavia gave adequate guarantees that Italians on Yugoslav territory would be well treated.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 9 -- Frank P. Rosenberg has signed Howard Duff for the leading male role in "Night Cry," a novel by William L. Stuart, which Rosenberg's company, Colony Pictures, will film independently in October, the producer announced today.
Eight residential sales in the West Hudson area of New Jersey were reported yesterday by J. I. Kislak, Inc.

It is only August, but there is an undercurrent in the air that bodes ill for someone. That someone is now sprawled comfortably in his easy chair reading a book and smoking a pipe. He is at peace with the world.

A salary increase for civil service employes was recommended by six speakers yesterday at the seventh hearing on Mayor O'Dwyer's plan for a survey on reclassification and wage adjustments for city employes. Only one speaker objected to an "outside agency" conducting the $150,000 study.

DETROIT, Aug. 10 -- Upward of 75,000 Ford Motor Company workers in Michigan had cast ballots today a few hours before the polls closed in a strike election held to determine if the United Automobile Workers, CIO, in Ford plants will walk out in support of contract demands.
Warehouse operation -- a major factor in costs -- will be surveyed by the National Wholesale Druggists Association, it was learned yesterday.

The Beacon Wax Company of Buffalo and Boston has launched lawsuits totaling $2,000,000 against forty New York City retailers, charging violation of state fair trade laws, Attorney Samuel Schaeffer said yesterday.
WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Aug. 10 -- The Westchester Health Department made a few analysis today of waters at beaches and docks in the county and reported ten changes in conditions since a week ago.

PARIS, Aug. 10 -- Superb artistry dominates the Christian Dior collection. From beginning to end -- when a dress of fairy tale beauty, its petaled skirt embroidered in jeweled beads the color of a dragonfly's wings, was shown -- this great couturier demonstrated his mastery of his materials.

The borough in New York with the greatest need for welfare and health services is Manhattan. This was reported yesterday in a study of city needs by the Greater New York Fund, the most comprehensive ever made.

The action of Canada in easing restrictions on imports of costume jewelry is giving a "boost" to the industry here, and serves as an example to be followed by other countries wherever possible as foreign buyers are hungry for American goods, according to Jack Ruderman, treasurer of Kaufman Ruderman, Inc., costume jewelry manufacturers.

Jimmy Flood, Yorkville's promising young middleweight, will be seeking his twenty-seventh ring victory tonight at the Queensboro Stadium when he tackles Danny Ruggerio, Yonkers slugger, in the eight-round main event. Ruggerio replaces Joe Governale, who was forced out of the match through illness.

Robert G. Thompson, a defendant at the Communist trial, denied yesterday that the party teaches overthrow of the United States Government by force and violence, but confirmed these major points in the prosecution's case:

The documentary type public health series "It's Your Life," which has been an outstanding success in the Chicago area where it is now broadcast, will be presented by WNYC as a weekly Sunday night series from 9 to 9:30 o'clock, beginning Sept. 4.
BUDAPEST, Hungary, Aug. 10 (AP) -- Hungary's Communist-led Parliament met today, minus former Foreign Minister Laszlo Rajk and three other deputies arrested two months ago on treason charges.

STOCKHOLM, Aug. 10 (AP) -- Don Budge of Oakland, Calif., tennis professional, said tonight he would retire from competition at the end of his present European tour with Jack Kramer of Los Angeles, Dinny Pails of Australia and Pancho Segura of Ecuador.

VIENNA, Aug. 10 -- Reports that the Russians are dismantling or preparing to dismantle some factories of the Soviet company, USIA, that are to be turned over to Austria for $150,000,000 according to the draft of the Austrian state treaty are reaching Austrian and Western quarters with growing frequency and detail.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 (AP) -- The Pentagon sent out word today that reporters do not need advance approval from the chief of the press branch to interview defense officials.

PALO ALTO, Calif., Aug. 10 (AP) -- "I have had every honor to which any man could aspire," Herbert Hoover said years ago, and in that spirit the only living former President of the United States today celebrated his seventy-fifth birthday anniversary.
There will be a wedding this morning in the chapel of the Hebrew Immigrant Aid Society at 425 Lafayette Street.

Attorney General Nathaniel Goldstein filed a suit in State Supreme Court yesterday seeking to prohibit the Jewish Consumptives Relief Society of Denver from soliciting funds in New York State on the ground that patients were not getting proper care.

HONOLULU, Aug. 10 -- Gov. Ingram M. Stainback served notice today that defiance of territorial laws "will not be tolerated by this Government." In a message delivered before a suddenly called joint session of the territorial Legislature he retorted to new declarations by CIO unions in connection with the strike that has tied up Hawaiian ports for 102 days.

BERLIN, Aug. 10 -- Communists warned the German jitterbug today that his "wild convulsions" are "prostituting Germany's musical heritage. "Swing heini," the German counterpart of the American jitterbug, was told that according to the official German Communist party line he is guilty of:

Although 500 bids already have been received for fifty concessions in the Port Authority Bus Terminal, the Port of New York Authority issued yesterday an illustrated brochure to interest more applicants for space in its "great new $24,000,000 landmark in the heart of New York City."

MANCHESTER, Mass., Aug. 10 (AP) -- Surprising no one, the nation's eight top-ranking women tennis players paraded through the third round of the Essex County Club's twenty-second invitation tournament today in 101 degree heat. The eight will battle tomorrow in the quarter-finals.
Following is the text of former President Herbert Hoover's address last night at Stanford University on the occasion of his seventy-fifth birthday, as recorded and transcribed by THE NEW YORK TIMES:
LONDON, Aug. 10 -- The twelve-year-old Dalai Lama of Tibet, the most powerful spiritual influence in vast Central Asia, has proclaimed a religious war against Communism, reliable advices said today.

Eleven residents of the Green-point section of Brooklyn, including a City Court Justice, yesterday contributed blood to help save the life of a 28-year-old neighbor who is seriously ill of a kidney ailment.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- The command of the Air Force today took categorical responsibility for decisions in the last year to enlarge the fleet of B-36 superbombers at the cost of cancellation of hundreds of millions of dollars worth of contracts for other types.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 10 -- Striking, 2-year-old full sister to Busher and Mr. Busher, had command of the situation from gate to wire in the $10,725 Schuylerville Stakes at Saratoga today. The 9-to-10 favorite, she won by two and a half lengths.
LONDON, Aug. 10 (AP) -- United States airmen in England made public today a voluntary good conduct code whose theme is, "Don't Let's Be Beastly to the British."

Plans to increase the number of crosswalk markings at important street intersections and make them more visible are being studied by the City Traffic Commission in an effort to reduce traffic congestion and help pedestrians.

Early next month common stockholders of the General Public Utilities Corporation will be offered the right to acquire the 835,000 common shares of the utility's subsidiary, the Rochester Gas and Electric Corporation, on the basis of one share for each ten shares of GPU they hold, it was learned yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- Senate Democratic and Republican leaders moved today toward action to blast the long-blockaded displaced persons legislation from the hands of the Judiciary Committee and carry it to a floor decision.

CHICAGO, Aug. 10 -- James Montgomery of Waukegan, Ill., a Negro who had served nearly twenty-six years of a life sentence for rape, was freed today after Judge Michael L. Igoe in Federal District Court called his trial "a sham" and said Mr. Montgomery was convicted because the state suppressed vital evidence.

Ezzard Charles weighed 180 pounds for his NBA heavyweight title defense last night against Gus Lesnevich, who scaled 182. Ruby Goldstein was the referee and the judges were Frank Forbes and Jack O'Sullivan.

Controller General Lindsay C. Warren is again in the news with his annual charge of lax government procedures in contract procurement and contract settlement. This year, because the charges are made as Congress prepares to investigate "five per-centers," Mr. Warren's story makes the front page.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- A $344,000 item in the $5,647,724,000 foreign aid appropriation bill threatened tonight to present the greatest obstacle to Senate and House agreement on a measure already a month-and-a-half overdue.

King Arthur wasn't a knight in shining armor at all, but he was still a great guy to a group of children in the Armor Hall of the Metropolitan Museum of Art yesterday. For they saw a suit of chain mail dating from his era and dull in colors it was, they could believe that any one of the Knights of the Round Table could have made it glisten with his gallantry.

Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., was high bidder yesterday for two issues of railroad equipment trust certificates totaling $2,730,000. For $1,710,000 of serials of International - Great Northern Railroad, maturing annually from 1950 to 1964, the banking house bid 99.482 for 2 3/8s, a cost basis of about 2.45 per cent.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Aug. 10 -- Industrial and labor leaders took hope today that the new Federal program for spurring employment in Bridgeport and Waterbury would avert a serious economic crisis. Both cities have been listed by President Truman as "critical areas" so far as unemployment is concerned.

FRANKFORT, Aug. 10 -- On statistical charts, women in Western Germany outnumber the men by 3,216,300. But in the election campaign they have by consensus been classed to date as a disproportionately feeble factor.

Reflecting both reduced operating rates and lower average prices, consolidated earnings of the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) and affiliates declined $72,900,000 in the first half of 1949 from the corresponding six months a year ago, according to the semi-annual statement released yesterday.

The proposed new world federation of trade unions is regarded with great interest all over Europe and in his opinion all non-Communist unions there will affiliate with the organization, John F. Gibson, assistant Secretary of Labor declared yesterday.

The second $1,000 Lieut. Ben Toland Memorial Fellowship for a study of employer-employe "teamwork for productivity" was awarded yesterday to Dr. John P. Troxell, director of the division of industrial research at Stanford University.

His brown hair bleached white, his weight down twenty pounds and the edge definitely off his earlier belief in the romance of sailing the Atlantic alone, a slim young Englishman yesterday morning brought in his 29-foot yawl to City Island in the Bronx after an eighty-one-day voyage from Gibraltar.

As the mercury crept steadily past 95 yesterday afternoon, Ralph Soller climbed the steep stone staircase of the medieval tower. After three perspiring flights, he emerged on the lofty sun-drenched platform, leaned over the carved battlements and examined a tube of gleaming glass.

Robert W. Lehrfeld, Inc., New York, will follow up an introductory trade campaign for its new-type clothes and utility brush, the Brushoff, with ads in key city newspapers and national magazines, it was announced yesterday. Ferwerda-Boone, Inc., New York, has been appointed to handle the account. Consumer ads will follow extension of distribution, which will be started through large department stores in major markets.

BOOTHBAY HARBOR, Me., Aug. 10 -- Harold Brown of New York, fishing aboard Salimar, brought a tuna weighing 547 pounds to fishermen's wharf here this evening to establish at least a temporary lead in the State of Maine tournament. It was well ahead of the opening day's high, 496 pounds, boated by Walter McDonough of Brielle, N. J.

ATHENS, Aug. 10 -- Forty-nine "Helldivers" described as capable of delivering accurately two tons of bombs each at pinpoint targets will be delivered to the Greek Air Force within a few days, according to an announcement today by Lieut. Gen. James A Van Fleet, Director of the United States Military Group in Greece.

Radio officers on 300 American-flag merchant vessels will have the "spread" in which they work their normal eight-hour day reduced from sixteen to thirteen hours under an arbitration award announced yesterday by Frederick R. Livingston, mediator for the American Radio Association, CIO, and the Committee for Companies and Agents, Atlantic and Gulf Coasts.

MATTAPOISETT, Mass., Aug. 10 -- Despite thirteen years on her shoulders and a carriage as an infant across the Atlantic, the twelve-meter sloop Anitra today won the King's Cup, premier prize in American yachting.
Ground has been broken by Morton Brothers, builders, for two new housing centers in Jamaica Estates North, Queens, designed eventually to represent an investment of more than $1,500,000.

GOSHEN, N. Y., Aug. 10 -- Miss Tilly, an eye-catching, fast-stepping filly captured the twenty-fourth Hambletonian Stakes in straight heats today at Good Time Park. A crowd of 15,291 sun-drenched harness-racing enthusiasts saw the good-looking bay, owned by C. W. Phellis of Greenwich, Conn., show the way to seventeen other 3-year-old trotters in the sport's counterpart of the turf's Kentucky Derby.
MUNICH, Germany, Aug. 10 -- An ugly riot in which six Jews and three German policemen were injured seriously flared in the Friedensengel Platz here today.

James A. Johnston, who retired last year after fifteen years as warden of Alcatraz, has written an account of the island prison which Scribners has set for Aug. 29 publication. It has been titled "Alcatraz Island Prison and the Men Who Live There."
" Yes, the weather man takes a beating, but by the time he's ready to jump into the river somebody gives him a pat on the back."
The anti-trust suits of two St. Louis Cardinal pitchers, Max Lanier and Fred Martin, against organized baseball have been ordered to jury trial during the November, 1949, calendar.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- James V. Hunt, Washington management counselor, has received $71,000 of a total fee of $86,000 for his efforts to have the Lido Beach Hotel at Long Beach, N. Y., which was bought by the Navy in 1945 for $1,300,000, returned to its former owners for $635,000, Senate investigators were told today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- The Administration experienced a certain amount of difficulty today in attempting to define the degree of support it can promise President Elpidio Quirino of the Republic of the Philippines in his proposal for a Pacific Union.

Reflecting the imposition of import controls by Brazil on July 15, Brazilian imports from the United States in July dropped $17,286,309 from June, according to a report issued yesterday by Mario da Camara, delegate of the Brazilian Treasury in New York.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- Gen. Omar N. Bradley told Congress today that prompt military aid to free Europe would win "a supreme test of leadership" in an area where communism already was being brought to a halt.

New York City Housing Authority announced yesterday plans for borrowing $1,250,000 on temporary loan notes for the financing of seven emergency housing projects which the Authority operates. The note issue is to be sold at competitive bidding on Aug. 18.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- O. John Rogge, a former Assistant Attorney General and a leader in the Progressive party headed by Henry A. Wallace, sharply attacked today the selection of Attorney General Tom C. Clark for the Supreme Court.

While improved results were reported by the finance and insurance company operations in the first six months this year, compared with the 1948 period, the reduced income of the manufacturing companies was responsible for the $378,555 decline in the consolidated net income reported today by the Commercial Credit Company.
CLEVELAND, Aug. 10 (AP) -- Outfielder Dick Kokos' ninth-inning home run off Bob Lemon gained a 5-4 victory for the Browns tonight over the Indians.

LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., Aug. 10 -- Leading a record field, Mrs. Harriet Trepner of Glen Head and Billy Edwards of Hempstead, current holder of the metropolitan junior title, captured the Long Island Golf Association's twelfth annual mixed foursome championship at the Piping Rock Club course today.
Butterfly Green have been named agents for Regent Homes, a new group of fifty houses in the medium price range going up at 228th Street and 115th Avenue in Cambria Heights, Queens.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 10 -- The Yugoslav press is speaking more openly than ever before of an early collapse of the Greek rebellion. Certain allusions that have been made recently indicate that the Yugoslav Government feels itself fully documented on what is described as a decision of the Soviet Government and the Communist Information Bureau to liquidate the Greek rebellion, and the conspiratorial technique used by them to bring this about.
AMBATO, Ecuador, Aug. 10 (UP) -- Men, Women and children buried alive by the earthquake no longer cry out. Six days of thirst, starvation and injuries have silenced them.

Deportation hearings in the cases of some of fourteen Greek seamen detained Tuesday as they were about to sail for Poland on the liner Batory will begin at Ellis Island within the next few days, it was announced yesterday by Edward J. Shaughnessy, district director of immigration and naturalization.

BOSTON, Aug. 10 -- Tommy Henrich, a fellow who seems to thrive on cracked elbows and broken toes, returned to the Yankee line-up today and, while the box score may not show that he contributed anything of material value, the mere presence of Old Reliable had a most inspiring influence upon his colleagues.

The pause in the recovery of the stock market proved short-lived and prices swung back yesterday to the higher side. The stumbling performance of Tuesday was corrected mostly through technical means and the selective improvement left the composite rate 0.97 point higher on the day, although gains in some stocks ranged well beyond that figure.

New Yorkers suffered the hottest day of the year yesterday, the fourth straight day of this latest heat wave of a very hot summer. The official temperature touched a high point of 98.7 degrees at 2:50 P. M., and was over 90 virtually all afternoon.
PARIS, Aug. 10 -- Continuing her technique of significant form without trimming, Mad Carpentier introduces a bodice that is barrel in back and billows along a central horizontal seam.

CHICAGO, Aug. 10 -- The Department of Agriculture's estimate of the grain crops issued after the market had closed on the Board of Trade today was about in line with general expectations, although the forecast on corn was somewhat smaller than had been expected, but brokers were not inclined to regard the limited increase ver the total a month ago as of much consequence as a lasting market factor.

LENOX, Mass., Aug. 10 -- An anonymous gift of $3,000 for Berkshire Music Center scholarships was received here this morning and was added, by a vote of the trustees of the Boston Symphony Orchestra, to the Jascha Heifetz Fund for Violinists.

Former Governor Herbert H. Lehman promised yesterday either to accept or decline the Democratic and Liberal party nominations for the United States Senate within the next two weeks. The Democratic nomination was offered to him early in July and the Liberal party has made repeated offers of its support.

CHICAGO, Aug. 10 -- The team of Alvin Landy and Sol Mogal of New York, Arthur S. Goldsmith of Cleveland, Bruce Gowdy of Toronto and Jeff Glick of Miami won the American Contract Bridge League's 1949 masters team-of-four championship by the slim margin of 130 points last night.
DETROIT, Aug. 10 (AP) -- The White Sox rallied for three runs in the tenth inning to defeat the Tigers, 6 to 3, today and even the two-game series at a game apiece.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- A Senate battle that may determine the whole pattern of future American business relations broke into the open today as a determined anti-monopoly bloc sought to prevent the so-called basing point bill from being sent to conference.

The Hardot Realty Corporation, of which Harry Marx is president, has sold the four-story thirty-family apartment house at 993 President Street, Brooklyn, to the Clayton Investing Corporation, represented by Korotkin Oppenheim, attorneys.

The City Bank Farmers Trust Company as trustee for the William Waldorf Astor estate has purchased the property at 249-259 West Forty-first Street, 260 West Forty-second Street and 644-646 Eighth Avenue. The property includes a vacant parcel on Forty-first Street used as a bus terminal, a building on Forty-second Street used as a waiting room and ticket office for the buses and a store parcel on Eighth Avenue.
STRASBOURG, France, Aug. 10 -- Edouard Herriot, France's noted liberal statesman, delivered the inaugural address today at the opening meeting of the Consultative Assembly of the Council of Europe.
The 130 lads on the roof of the Madison Square Boys Club, 301 East Twenty-ninth Street, gathered around the birthday cake yesterday.

For several years we have been urging Congress to relieve the congestion in the Federal Courts by creating additional judicial positions. We are glad that legislation has now been enacted and signed by the President to accomplish this. The President is to appoint four new judges to sit in the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Aug. 10 -- A new racial zoning ordinance was in operation here today while lawyers squabbled over its constitutionality.

The shipping industry has been advised unofficially by members of the United States Maritime Commission that the current hearings in Congress on the shipping agency's handling of vessel construction subsidies would not delay work on six passenger liners now on order, it was reported last night.

MARY M'CARTHY is the scourge of the southpaw intellectuals. Her knouts draw blood all over the Marx-and-Kafka set. At a lonely vantage point, somewhere between Tess Slesinger and Voltaire, she stands and observes the peculiar lords and ladies bountiful of the professionally proletarian world, the "premature anti-Stalinists" and the Stalinist Charlie McCarthys (no relations, of course) with an equally penetrating disenchantment.

Vernon Morgan, seeded third, and Jeff Craig, defending champion, ranked fourth, were among the third-round victors in the men's singles division as play in the New York State open tennis championships continued on the courts of the Cosmopolitan Tennis Club yesterday.

With cries of religious bias and bigotry making the headlines recently and causing sides to be taken. to no one's advantage, but rather to the disadvantage of all Americans, two organizations located on New York's lower East Side have undertaken to prove that prejudice has no place in a democratic community.

ANNECY, France, Aug. 10 -- The Cuban delegation announced today its withdrawal from the session of contracting parties to the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (the Geneva tariff agreement of 1947.) now nearing its end here.

The teen-age set that thrives on banana splits and chocolate milk should find a product new at Macy's much to their palate. It combines two favorite flavors -- banana and chocolate -- in a syrup of not too thick consistency. A pound jar for the home soda fountain is 46 cents.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 (AP) -- Sherry Robertson's grand slam homer and six double-plays enabled Washington to edge the Athletics, 8 -- 7, tonight. The Senators compiled a 7-0 lead and staggered to victory after the Athletics rallied for six runs in the sixth inning.
TOKYO, July 30 -- Banned herself from the sealanes of international commerce, Japan now rapidly is developing her shipbuilding industry on the basis of foreign orders.

Production of raw steel by domestic mills in July fell sharply to 5,780,777 net tons, the lowest monthly output since December, 1946, when operations were affected by a coal strike, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

The August Grand Jury, which has been investigating a $50,000,000 rigged policy racket, returned a fifteen-count indictment yesterday charging nine men with conspiracy and conspiracy to contrive a lottery, it was announced by District Attorney Frank S. Hogan.
In the first strong general price increase since the market stopped falling in June, aluminum alloy casting ingots rose yesterday on a broad list, ranging from 1/2 cent to 3/4 cent per grade.

The direct examination of a principal stockholder in Kings County Buick, Inc., was completed yesterday in the General Sessions wiretap trial with the placing in evidence of a "secret register" of sponsors and "preferred" customers for agency automobiles.

PARIS, Aug. 10 -- As always, Jacques Heim's coats and suits are outstanding. In handsome, loose swingback topcoats, he combines plaid and plain. A pale blue reversible blanket cloth coat reveals in motion the blue and gray plaid backing of a hem-length back panel.

Last April German representatives of the four states of the United States Zone of Germany jointly approved a law difficult to carry out but appealing strongly to the American sense of justice. Under this law, indemnity would be paid the victims of Nazis for wrongs they suffered under the Hitler regime.

LONDON, Aug. 10 -- The new account opened on the stock market here today with a fresh spasm of weakness in British Government bonds and activity in dollar, gold and base metal shares, which were bought as "hedges" as sterling devaluation talk continued.

LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., Aug. 10 -- Mrs. George F. Baker Jr., whose summer place, Vikings Cove, is on Peacock Point here, has put an end to a three-year-old problem of the Associated Boys Clubs of Locust Valley, Inc. She has given the clubs two acres of land and $31,500 with which to build and equip a clubhouse and construct an athletic field.

Woolen broadcloth used for women's apparel listed at $2.87 1/2 a yard is bringing $3.50 to suppliers who have goods on hand, it was learned yesterday. Jobbers in the trade said that pressure is still on for lower prices on gabardines and worsteds for popular-price suits.

PARIS, Aug. 10 -- In proposing a drastic cut in the British request for Marshall Plan dollars, experts of the European Council here contended that the British had been far too pessimistic in estimating their dollar deficit for the current year.

TOKYO, Aug. 10 -- The Japanese Government is preparing to crack down on communized repatriates from the Soviet Union who have been creating a series of violent incidents here with the encouragement of the Japanese Communist party since the repatriation program was resumed last June.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Aug. 10 -- The pre-election overture, which has been on a rising tempo for some weeks past, abruptly changed key last night when junta President Figueres announced he was not resigning from the junta leadership after all.

The nation's gasoline stocks in the week ended on last Saturday declined 1,520,000 barrels to 108,444,000 according to the American Petroleum Institute. This compared with 97,838,000 barrels on Aug. 7, 1948. Light fuel oil supplies were up 1,344,000 to 72,222,000 and heavy fuel oil stocks were increased by 115,000 to 67,281,000.

Despite an aggressive economy drive and savings from extensive mechanization of the $207,000,000 Western Union Telegraph Company, operations in the six months to June 30 resulted in a deficit of $3,672,241, Walter P. Marshall, who became president of the communications system last December, reported yesterday.
The latest national census of polio cases, published yesterday by the United States Public Health Service, revealed that there were 10,748 polio victims this year up to the week ending Aug. 6.

Although the final day entry failed to better the mark of George Lynch of the Plandome Club, who put the ball 10 inches from the cup on the second day of play, a new all-time entry of 1,234 was established as the sixteenth annual World-Telegram hole-in-one tournament drew to a close at the Bayside links yesterday.

In his State-of-the-Union message to Congress last January President Truman reminded us that "the present coverage of the social security laws is altogether inadequate and benefit payments are too low." One-third of our workers, as he said, are not covered. Old-age and survivors' insurance payments are running at an average of $25 a month.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 10 -- For a few brief moments the Dodgers threatened to lose a game to the Phils tonight when Ralph Branca was knocked out in the seventh and the Blue Jays tied the score at 5 -- all.

SALZBURG, Austria, Aug. 10 -- Last night's revival of Mozart's "La Clemenza di Tito" was a considerably more palatable novelty than the premiere of Carl Orff's "Antigone" had been the day before, and yet there are important points of similarity between the two works.
In his address at Stanford yesterday former President Hoover undertook to supply one of this country's most urgent present needs -- a credo for a sound liberalism.

Henry Payson, operator, has purchased the fourteen-story and penthouse apartment building containing seventy-two suites at 370 Riverside Drive from the H. B. Management Corporation. Harold M. Silverman was the broker.

Mae West will be coming East to resume her run in "Diamond Lil" here on Sept. 7. The saga of sin in a Bowery saloon in the Gay Nineties, which was written by the star, has been booked for the Plymouth Theatre.

Two new films will open in Broadway theatres this morning. At the Capitol the attraction is "Anna Lucasta," the adaptation of the Philip Yordan play featuring Paulette Goddard in the title role. Mr. Yordan produced and collaborated with Arthur Laurents on the screen play of the drama, which was directed by Irving Rapper.

Joseph T. Sharkey of Brooklyn, vice chairman of the City Council, said yesterday that he might call a special meeting of the Council next week to act upon his proposed local law to fix a 15 per cent ceiling on apartment rent increases.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- The Household Finance Corporation, Chicago, filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering 60,000 shares of its no-par value common stock.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- Senator Hubert H. Humphrey, Democrat, of Minnesota, Chairman of the Senate Subcommittee on School Construction, predicted today that "the long range answer to aid to education may well be aid to the physical plant."

NEWPORT, R. I., Aug. 10 (AP) -- Richard Pancho Gonzales, national singles champion from Los Angeles, led a list of seven other seeded entrants into the quarterfinal round of the casino invitation lawn tennis tourney today.

OCEANPORT, N. J., Aug. 10 (AP) -- Reaffirming the fact that he is the outstanding handicap through-bred to have campaigned at Monmouth Park this season, Mrs. E. L. Hopkins' Three Rings turned in a game effort to establish a new mile and a furlong track record of 1:50 in winning the closing-day Omnibus Handicap.
QUITO, Ecuador, Aug. 10 (AP) -- Ecuador observed the 140th anniversary of her independence today in mourning for thousands killed in Friday's earthquake.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Aug. 10 -- Judge George W. Smyth of the Westchester County Children's Court, who is vice president of the National Probation and Parole Association, asked the Federal intervention today to end the imprisonment of Robert Lewis Hamilton, 10 years old, in the South Carolina Penitentiary for a $7 theft.

Held to five scattered hits by Warren Spahn, who went the distance in recording his fourteenth victory, the Giants bowed to the Braves, 4 -- 1, before 7,535 parboiled onlookers at the Polo Grounds yesterday. Boston's triumph, evening the series, cut the third-place margin of the home side to a single game.

Early cables from Brazil reporting declining prices on the coffee market there affected trading in coffee futures on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange, Inc., yesterday. Prices in both the "S" and "D" contracts fell off here, with the market closing 12 to 26 points down on the "S" and 24 to 33 points down from Tuesday's close on the "D" commitments.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., Aug. 10 -- Miss Judy Webb of the Riverside Yacht Club held a big lead for the Long Island Sound junior sailing championship as the five finalists completed three of the four necessary races off Larchmont Yacht Club today. The last will be sailed tomorrow.

DETROIT, Aug. 10 -- A sharp split over whether to support President Truman's health program was widening today in the convention of the National Medical Association, which covers 5,000 Negro physicians.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 (AP) -- The House Ways and Means Committee voted today to exclude about 400,000 of the 600,000 self-employed professional workers from its expanded social security program.

While the subject of Russian forced-labor camps is under discussion both within the United Nations and in the columns of American newspapers, the Soviet Union, unmoved by the world public anger, proceeds in its further exploitation of the human race.

CHICAGO, Aug. 10 -- William L. Keady today relinquished his position as president of United States Gypsum Company. Mr. Keady disclosed his step after a meeting of the company's directors. He said that Sewell L. Avery, the company's 75-year-old chairman, has decided to resume active direction of the company's management.

There is an angle to the role of DP's in the labor situation which has not been brought out in the discussion in your columns. It is necessary for an industrial firm to guarantee a DP's job with a contract approved by the United States Army before such a person can be brought over to work as a specialist.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 (AP) -- A corn crop missing last year's record by about 3 per cent, but running 30 per cent above average, was forecast today by the Department of Agriculture.

Dr. K. V. Ostrovityanov, director of the Institute of Economics of the Soviet Academy of Sciences, who regained a top position among Soviet economists when he led a successful attack against Academician Eugen S. Varga in October, 1947, is now being stripped of his posts himself, it became known yesterday.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Aug. 10 -- The political crisis that has crippled Belgium since the general election more than six weeks ago ended today with the Liberal party reluctantly joining the Christian Socialist (Catholic) party in a Government under the premiership of 44-year-old Gaston Eyskens, Christian Socialist, who was Minister of Finance in the most recent Cabinet.
A 5-year-old boy sued in Supreme Court yesterday through his mother, as guardian, to set aside a Reno, Nev., divorce decree obtained by her. The suit is believed to be without precedent.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, the following principal changes for the week ended Aug. 3:

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 10 (AP) -- The big bats of the Cardinals were clicking in fine fashion tonight and Al Brazle was sharp as he turned in his fifth successive victory -- 8 to 0 -- with the Cincinnati Reds the victims. But the Brooklyn Dodgers won also so the Cards and Dodgers stay deadlocked in the red-hot National League race.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- An investigation by Congress of influence-sellers and lobbyists is, always has been and always will be a sure-fire box-office hit. Testimony is certain to bring in big names, and the detail that they have been misused doesn't lessen the pleasure of the audience merely because it has given pain to the victims.

Ezzard Charles, Cincinnati heavyweight who is recognized as the champion by the National Boxing Association, advanced a step nearer universal recognition last night at the Yankee Stadium where, before a crowd of 16,630 overheated boxing followers who paid gross receipts of $75,832, he knocked out the aging Gus Lesnevich in the seventh round of their scheduled fifteen-round battle.
The cotton futures market closed firm on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday and final prices were 9 to 15 points net higher than on Tuesday.

LAKE SUCCESS, Aug. 10 -- The United Nations "Little Assembly" decided today to ask the General Assembly to continue its existence "for an indefinite period" when the fifty-nine member nations meet next month at Flushing Meadow for their fourth regular session.

Directors of the United States Rubber Company yesterday cut in half the quarterly dividend on the company's common stock. The board declared a dividend of 50 cents a share on the common from earned surplus as of Dec. 31, 1948. The disbursement, which compares with dividends of $1 each on June 18 and March 10, will be made on Sept. 10.

CHICAGO, Aug. 10 (AP) -- Ky. Colonel, owned and bred by Joseph A. Goodwin of Lexington, Ky., furlongs by two-fifths of a second by sizzling home in 1:21 2-5 in the $25,000 added Sheridan Handicap for 3-year-olds at Washington Park today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 10 -- Edward Small announced today that his much-publicized, eleven-year search for an unknown actor to play Rudolph Valentino in the long-scheduled cinema biography of the silent screen star, has produced a 29-year-old war veteran who will be known as Tony Dexter. Dexter's real name was not disclosed, but he was described in the announcement as a "dead ringer" for Valentino.

LAKE SUCCESS, Aug. 10 -- Dr. Albert Einstein today urged the establishment of an international center of sociological studies "where the ways and means would be studied to establish a better understanding among nations." His comment was included in a report by Secretary General Trygve Lie on a proposal for the establishment of United Nations research laboratories to be submited to a committee of experts in Paris next Tuesday.

MOSCOW, Aug. 10 -- The Soviet educational journal Teachers Gazette charged today that American educators had launched a worldwide campaign to undermine national sovereignties and instill bourgeois cosmopolitanism, utilizing as a spearhead of the offensive the Carnegie-sponsored Institute of International Education.

Thomas M. Chalmers has joined the Blaw-Knox Company as engineering consultant on steel mill equipment. He formerly was vice president in charge of operations of Tennessee Coal, Iron and Railroad Company, Birmingham, Ala.

Universal-International has concluded an arrangement with the British movie producer, J. Arthur Rank, whereby the American company will be able to unfreeze practically all of its blocked sterling credits, it was revealed yesterday by Joseph H. Seidelman, vice president and foreign distribution chief of U-I.

RYE, N. Y., Aug. 10 -- Teaming together in perfect sisterly accord, Miss Louise Nichols and her sister, Mrs. Harry J. Nevil, of Hudson River took a two-stroke lead in the Women's Westchester and Fairfield Golf Association two-day best-ball tournament with one-over-par 35, 39 -- 74, over the Apawamis Club course today.

Philip Hausfeld, furrier, has sold his twenty-acre property on Peekskill Hollow Road in the town of Putnam Valley, near Peekskill, N. Y., to Jack Horowitz, textile manufacturer. The main dwelling contains seven rooms and two baths, and one of the farm buildings has been remodeled into two large apartments.

Official and private welcomes were arranged yesterday for President Elpidio Quirino, of the Republic of the Philippines, who is to fly here this morning from Washington. He is to remain until Saturday afternoon, when he will leave by plane for home via San Francisco.

BLOOMINGTON, Ind., Aug. 10 (AP) -- Fifteen persons met death as a Greyhound bus turned sidewise and burned after it hit a bridge abutment near here early today. The twelve other passengers and the driver were injured.
COLOGNE, Germany, Aug. 10 -- The German election sounds ominous and reads even worse, but as elections and politicians go it is really not such an extraordinary affair.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- The National Federation of American Shipping called today for enactment of a long-range shipping legislative program to alleviate unemployment in twelve coastal shipping centers.
The enactment of the new unification law by the signature of the President yesterday does not herald a golden era of efficiency, economy and service unity.

Despite strong opposition in the industry to labeling provisions of a pending bill to regulate standards of American food, drug and cosmetics exports, the measure now is regarded as more than likely to pass at this session of Congress, trade sources asserted yesterday.
LONDON, Aug. 10 (AP) -- Albania, smallest of Russia's satellites, charged today that she was being invaded by the Greek Government forces fighting Communist guerrillas along the frontier.

The International Nickel Company of Canada, Ltd., and its subsidiaries had a net profit of $8,220,950 after taxes and all deductions in the quarter ended with last June, according to the report yesterday of Robert C. Stanley, board chairman.

The music of Brahms received top billing at Lewisohn Stadium last night, but the spectacle of the evening was Dimitri Mitropoulous' virtuoso handling of the Philharmonic-Symphony. Stell Andersen was soloist in the Piano Concerto in B flat major and the program included the "Academic Festival" Overture and the Fourth Symphony.

In the belief that all frozen food prices are too high, Snow Crop Marketers, Inc., will cut prices on all its products 2 to 7 cents a package, effective on Monday, J. I. Moone, president of the company announced yesterday.

The Dominion of Canada plans to float an issue of $100,000,000 of dollar bonds in the United States market in the near future in order to refund certain 5 per cent debt of the Canadian National Railway Company and the Harbor Commissioners of Montreal which is soon subject to call.
Francis S. Baer has been elected a senior vice president and director of the Bankers Trust Company, it was announced yesterday by S. Sloan Colt, president.

Following weeks of negotiation, a syndicate of more than sixty investment houses headed by First Boston Corporation and B. J. Van-Ingen Co., undertook yesterday to underwrite an issue of $22,700,000 of revenue bonds of the Puerto Rico Aqueduct and Sewer Authority.

PASSENGERS aboard New Haven trains bound in the direction of Rye the next three days are hereby warned not to be surprised if the coaches are filled with cries of "Viva L'Italia!" Motorists traveling along the Hutchinson River Parkway similarly should be prepared to be passed by cars loaded with excited readers of Il Progresso shouting, between bites of pizza pie, "Viva Cucelli, Del Bello, Canepele and Quintavalle!"

Jack Rubin, head of the Manhattan Theatre Ticket Service, 264 West Forty-seventh Street, refused again yesterday to surrender his records to License Commissioner Edward T. McCaffrey at department offices, 112 White Street.

Hammered copper ashtrays, intricately tooled leather wallets and busts sculptured in plastics were among the 600 articles on display yesterday at New York University's School of Education. The articles were produced by summer students in arts and crafts classes conducted at the school.

Edwin C. Barringer, executive vice president of the Institute of Scrap Iron Steel, Inc., Washington, D. C., yesterday called upon the Government to "call a halt on the unnecessary depletion of reserves of iron ore at a time when iron and steel scrap is going begging and much scrap that is not being collected will be irreparably lost."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- President Truman signed the National Security Bill today, putting in effect a new program for strengthening and streamlining both civil and military control of the armed forces.
