WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- The House voted decisively today for a rise in the minimum wage from 40 to 75 cents but withdrew its application from many workers who are now covered.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Aug. 10 -- About 5,000,000 out of an estimated 11,000,000 refugees from Eastern territories and the Soviet zone will be eligible to vote in the West German elections Sunday and, according to political experts from all parties as well as Allied military governments, they may swing the balance.

Seven thousand employes of Macy's, members of Local 1-S, unaffiliated, are covered by a health plan that protects them against doctors' and hospital bills, the store and the union announced yesterday.

PALO ALTO, Calif., Aug. 10 -- Herbert Hoover warned the nation today, on the seventy-fifth anniversary of his birth, that because of pressure groups and spendthrift policies the United States was "blissfully" driving at top speed down the "back road" to collectivism.

Sam and William Praver, builders, have received a commitment from the Federal Housing Administration on a loan of $3,320,874 for the Laurelton Terrace apartments near Laurelton Parkway, 131st Avenue, 133d Road and 232d Street, in Laurelton, Queens, according to J. Halperin Co., brokers.

Municipal bond inventories have been shrinking rapidly during the last week, according to reports in tax-exempt bond circles. The Blue List's total of bonds advertised by dealers had moved up last week to beyond $135,000,000, but the continued sales from new-issue syndicate accounts are cutting into this drastically.
FRANKFORT, Germany, Aug. 10 (UP) -- A trade agreement amounting to almost $100,000,000 was signed by Turkey and Western Germany today, O. T. Guenden, Turkish consul general in Frankfort, announced.

Fifty-two of the sixty-four merchant vessels of 1,000 or more gross tons now under construction or on order at United States shipyards are tankers, according to a recent survey by the Shipbuilders council of America. The council's figures were dated Aug. 1.

CHICAGO, Aug. 10 (AP) -- Doyle Lade, a right-hander recently promoted to starting duty, blanked the Pirates with a four-hitter today to give the Cubs a 2-0 triumph before a Ladies' Day crowd of 21,122.

CHICAGO, Aug. 10 -- Book clubs, department stores as booksellers, and the increase in reprints have worked a revolution in the book industry, to the grave detriment of serious writing, it was held today by William Miller, a writer of New York.

Dissolution of the Cotton Textile Institute was voted yesterday by its board of directors, and the trade association will merge with the American Cotton Manufacturers Association in a new association to be known as the American Cotton Manufacturers Institute, Inc.

DETROIT, Aug. 11 -- With a seven-to-one vote in favor of a strike cast at the three-day Ford strike election, President Walter P. Reuther of the United Automobile Workers, CIO, will go before the union's international board here tomorrow to request approval to call a strike against the Ford Motor Company.

HONG KONG, Aug. 11 -- Conditions of misery and disruption unsurpassed in this century are foreseen here for China in the coming year by experts of the United States and other countries on Chinese affairs.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- The late-hour drive in the Senate to insure that anti-monopoly provisions of the so-called basing point pricing bill cannot be removed when it goes to conference gained momentum today.

Mayor O'Dwyer called yesterday upon both sides in the fourteen-week strike of employes of the American Machine and Foundry Company to confer at City Hall at 11 A. M. on Monday with a three-man citizens' panel in an effort to end the controversy.

When Michael J. Quill, international president of the Transport Workers Union, left on Aug. 6 for a vacation in Ireland, he was asked how he felt about the settlement of the eight-day Manhattan bus strike in July. "I'm very happy over the success of the union in that strike," said Mr. Quill.
PHOENIX, Ariz., Aug. 1 (AP) -- Mrs. Anna Roosevelt Boettiger, daughter of the late President Roosevelt, today received a divorce from John Boettiger.

New Yorkers consumption of water has reached a daily total of 1,400,000,000 gallons, a record high for this year, with the result that supplies at the city's reservoirs are being "dangerously depleted," Stephen J. Carney, commissioner of water supply, gas and electricity, said yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (AP) -- The head of the General Accounting Office said today the Government took in and spent "millions of dollars" each year without proper accounting.

Substantial improvement in income for the quarter ended on July 2 over the corresponding period of last year was reported by Paramount Pictures, Inc., in its midyear statement issued for release today.
PARIS, Aug. 11 -- Jeanne Lafaurie's collection shows adroit manipulation of fabric. Her combination of curves and angles is modernistic, suggestive of certain contemporary schools of painting.

SHANGHAI, Aug. 10 -- The proposal of Northwest Airlines to make ten special flights into blockaded Shanghai with a Nationalist safe conduct was turned down today by the United States State Department. The department is reported to have discouraged any flights by American airlines into Communist China, at least until the blockade is lifted.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Aug. 11 -- Despite the heat, vacations, and seeming remoteness of war, 101 women of New York, Long Island, Westchester County and Southern Connecticut have volunteered to work in the White Plains filter center in the "defense" of the North Atlantic seaboard during Operation Lookout from Sept. 10 to 16, the Air Defense Command said today.

Production of dresses for fall has been cut more than half as a result of the heat wave, it was learned yesterday from manufacturers of popular-price dresses. A great majority of the women operators in both inside and contractors' shops have failed to show up for work in plants where temperatures range over 100 degrees.

RYE, N. Y., Aug. 11 -- Billy Sidwell was named in place of the veteran John Bromwich to play the singles for Australia with Frank Sedgman as the draw was made today for the Davis Cup interzone round with Italy, starting tomorrow on the turf tennis courts of the Westchester Country Club.

David J. Coddaire, member of the Maritime Commission, said yesterday that not only did he fully support the granting of subsidies for six new passenger liners but that he would recommend further grants if necessary to insure this country's maritime pre-eminence.

RICHMOND, Va., Aug. 11 -- The Virginia Boxing and Wrestling Commission voted today not to recognize Ezzard Charles as the world's heavyweight boxing champion. Charles is recognized as champion by the National Boxing Association, of which the Virginia commission is a member.

About fifty enlisted men sweating out a four-hour written examination at Fort Wadsworth, Staten Island, yesterday represented the New York area's part in the Army's new program revolutionizing the promotion of enlisted personnel by throwing it open to competition.

A severe electrical storm, accompanied by blinding sheets of rain, halted yesterday's activities at the Polo Grounds in the bottom half of the eighth inning, just when the Giants were striving desperately to break out of a 7-7 deadlock with the Braves.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 11 -- The Belber Trunk and Bag Company, luggage manufacturer since 1891, announced today that it would cease production and close its only plant, in Woodbury, N. J., next Monday.

A resolution requesting the Government to establish a fund for furthering the educational program of the scientific feeding of hogs was adopted yesterday at the final session of the sixty-fourth annual convention of the National Association of Retail Meat Dealers, Inc., in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
CLEVELAND, Aug. 11 (AP) -- The Indians won their thirteenth out of fourteen extra inning games this season tonight, defeating the White Sox, 6 to 5, in the twelfth inning.

HEWLETT, L. I., Aug. 11 -- Peter K. Davis and John Desiderio of the Clearview Club shot 35, 34 -- 69, three strokes under par, to take the lead among sixty-two teams in the qualifying round of the fifteenth Arthur Man Memorial golf tournament at the Seawane Harbor Club today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- Loadings of revenue freight in the week ended last Saturday totaled 716,823 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.

TRENTON, Aug. 11 -- John E. Bosshart, New Jersey Commissioner of Education, gave a formal opinion today to public school officials that it would be illegal to send New Jersey classes on trips to Washington or elsewhere if any members were subjected to segregation.

JERSEY CITY, N. J., Aug. 1 -- The strike of 400 longshoremen on Piers D and F of the American Export Lines, Exchange Place, entered its third week today as several hundred of the men, eager for work, showed up but went home again when the shape-up whistle was not blown.

NEWPORT, R. I., Aug. 11 (AP) -- Richard (Pancho) Gonzales battled his way into the semifinals of the Casino's thirtieth invitation grass courts tennis tournament today by defeating Herb Flam of Beverly Hills, Calif., 4 -- 6, 7 -- 5, 6 -- 2, 6 -- 1.

RYE, N. Y., Aug. 11 -- The former Westchester and Fairfield open champion, Mrs. Donald C. O'Brien of Winged Foot, and Mrs. Joseph A. Nesbitt of the Westchester Country Club tied with Mrs. Richard Hellmann of Scarsdale and Mrs. E. M. Pullen of Woodway for best-ball honors with 152 for thirty-six holes as the annual two-day tandem tournament of the Women's Westchester and Fairfield Golf Association closed at the Apawamis Club today.

A Navy AD dive bomber caught fire at 6,000 feet at 3:35 P. M. yesterday and was forced down into the surf three miles west of Montauk Point, L. I. The pilot, the sole occupant, escaped without injury and was rescued by a Coast Guard boat.

The Sinclair Oil Corporation and its subsidiaries in a report issued yesterday, covering the first six months of this year showed a net income of $29,270,068 after all charges including $8,400,000 provision for estimated Federal income tax.

AN early start is always desirable. You can change the oil and fill up with gasoline the day before. You can even open the lid of the luggage compartment before you go to bed, but you can't put any of the suitcases in because suitcases always have to stay open for those last-minute items.

The volume of outstanding commercial bank loans of the weekly reporting New York City member banks of the Federal Reserve System increased $38,000,000 to $4,523,000,000 in the period ended on last Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank here announced yesterday.

The fashion for camel color was evident up and down the runway at Martin's college shop show in Brooklyn yesterday afternoon. From the classic top coat to the brand new styles in velveteen and genuine potato-sack burlap, the color was initiated as this store's No. 1 casual shade for the year.

BUENOS AIRES, Friday, Aug. 12 -- Dr. Juan A. Bramuglia, President Juan D. Peron's Foreign Minister since the President took office in June, 1946, and internationally, the best-known figure in the regime, resigned yesterday. President Peron has not yet acted on the letter of resignation but all circumstances late last night indicated that it would be accepted.

LONDON, Aug. 11 (UP) -- A British former United Nations official stationed in Yugoslavia charged today that he had been discharged because he refused to cooperate with the Communist Information Bureau Communists.

New York City Controller Lazarus Joseph announced yesterday that the city had borrowed $50,000,000 from twenty-six local banks on 1 1/4 per cent tax anticipation notes. Of the total, $20,000,000 is payable on Oct. 14 and $30,000,000 on Oct. 21.

CHICAGO, Aug. 11 (AP) -- The newly organized National Basketball Association today was split into two divisions -- the National and American. The nation's eighteen top pro teams which are members of the new loop were divided further into Eastern and Western sections of each division.

Strong response by smaller retailers throughout the country to plans for "Anti-Depression Week," to be held beginning Aug. 22, featuring an "extra" price cut of 10 per cent in line with President Truman's request for lower prices, was reported yesterday by Henry Modell, chairman of the Smaller Business Men's Association and head of a chain of sporting goods stores.

In its annual report for 1948, just made public, the Federal Reserve Board declares that while it needs additional anti-inflation powers, it "is much better equipped than ever before to meet the credit needs of the economy in a period of downward readjustment."

Convinced that Denmark is ripe for baseball, six Danish boys aged 13 to 15 sail today for their homes in Copenhagen on the Swedish American liner Gripsholm after six weeks of camping at Spring Hill Farm in the Pocono Mountains as guests of Karl J. Hansen, advertising executive of 68-11 Clyde Street, Queens.
GOSHEN, N. Y., Aug. 11 (AP) -- Rodney, R. H. Johnston's big bay, won the first and third heats today to take the $5,000 Trotting Derby as the Grand Circuit meeting ended at Good Time Track.

CHICAGO, Aug. 11 (AP) -- Pittsburgh whipped the Chicago Cubs, 3 to 2, in the rubber tilt of their three-game series today. The Pirates capitalized on a fielding miscue by Frank Baumholtz in the eighth for the decisive run.

Rent control became one of the issues of the mayoralty campaign yesterday. From Fusion headquarters, as it was opened at the Hotel Astor, came a series of attacks on the Sharkey bill, backed by Mayor O'Dwyer, which would limit, by city ordinance, rent increases to 15 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- A bipartisan compromise farm bill was unanimously approved today by all seven members of a subcommittee headed by Senator Clinton P. Anderson, formerly Secretary of Agriculture. The last change made in the bill before it was reported was the striking out of the "trial run" production-payment phase of the farm plan of Secretary of Agriculture Charles F. Brannan.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission today turned down an application of Public Service Interstate Transportation Company of Newark, to purchase operating rights of De Camp Bus Lines of Livingston, N. J., which, in addition to rights within New Jersey, include operations between New York City and Orange, N. J., through the Holland Tunnel.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- A trial examiner for the National Labor Relations Board held today that a labor organization did not violate the Taft-Hartley Act's secondary boycott ban by picketing a building on which two subcontractors employed nonunion men.

The handy movable tea cart that was so popular in the early Twenties is being revived in a new guise. Instead of being a mere decorative accessory, the modern version has taken on the importance of a fine piece of furniture. As such, it is often expensively priced and handled with all the careful design and construction of an unusual cabinet piece.

Significant of the action taken on Tuesday by directors of the American Woolen Company, Inc., in reducing the dividend to 50 cents a share is the unfavorable operating results reported yesterday in the semi-annual statement revealing that earnings were $9,000,000 below those in the corresponding six months of 1948.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- Hearings on the nomination of Attorney General Tom C. Clark to be a Supreme Court Justice ended today with indications that the Senate Judiciary Committee would vote its approval tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- Only a group of experts, with full access to all the official records in Chungking and Moscow as well as in Washington, could write a sequel to the State Department document, "United States Relations With China," which would comprehensively expose its shortcomings and omissions and those of our post-war policy in the Far East.

As the mercury has risen, appetites have fallen. If we can believe the market men who should know, New Yorkers are forgetting to eat during this too-hot wave. "Demand slow to languishing," was the report received yesterday from representatives of the produce, meat and fish trade.
TOKYO, Friday, Aug. 12 -- Gen. Douglas MacArthur announced today he would not return to the United States to take part in a conference on United States policy in the Orient.

Another record corn crop of over three billion bushels plus a huge wheat crop and other abundant farm products normally should be good news for consumers. Bumper grain crops usually have meant lower food prices for millions of Americans. Yet under present conditions big crops give little joy to consumers now overburdened by high prices and heavy taxes.
MANCHESTER, Mass., Aug. 11 (AP) -- Top-seeded American players enjoyed uninterrupted marches into the semi-finals of the Essex County women's tennis tournament today in both singles and doubles.

NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 11 -- Five adibasis, or leaders, representing some of India's 25,000,000 to 30,000,000 aboriginal tribesmen came to New Delhi today to check on whether the Constitution being formulated by the Constituent Assembly here sufficiently safeguarded the interests of their bow-and-arrow culture.

Two new films will open in midtown theatres this morning. At the Roxy, the offering is "Slattery's Hurricane," a Twentieth century-Fox romantic melodrama bout Navy meteorologists, staring Richard Widmark, Linda Darnell and Veronica Lake.

Jeffrey Garden Apartments Section II, Inc., headed by Kessler-Hess, builders, has obtained a first mortgage loan of $1,168,700 from the Bowery Savings Bank on the four three-story garden apartments being constructed on the block bounded by Forty-seventh and Forty-eighth Avenues and 216th and 217th Streets in Bayside, Queens, according to White White, brokers.

The mercury climbed yesterday to 98.1 degrees to shatter the record for the date by 2.1 degrees, but heat-weary New Yorkers received a brief respite as a violent storm raked the city at the height of the evening rush hour and the temperature toppled 14 degrees in fifteen minutes.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (UP) -- A majority of the House Labor Committee has worked out a new compromise aid-to-education bill and is in a position to force action on it at this session of Congress, Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr., Democrat, of New York, reported today.

LONDON, Aug. 11 -- After early uncertainty, British Government funds began to pick up in the stock market here today, largely because of quoted bear covering. A few small buying orders helped the movement and prices were as much as a half point better at the close.
LAKE SUCCESS, Aug. 11 -- Following are the texts of resolutions on the Palestine situation adopted today by the United Nations Security Council:

The number of new polio cases in New York City decreased for the second consecutive day yesterday, fifty-three more cases being recorded by the Department of Health during the twenty-four hours ending at 9 A. M.

The final stages of the "Mrs. America" beauty contest to be held in Asbury Park, N. J., will be televised by the American Broadcasting Company network on Saturday, Sept. 10, from 10 to 10:30 P. M. and the next evening from 7 to 7:30 o'clock.

The Maritime Commission and the Department of Agriculture are half way through the port's grain preservation program and have loaded six freighters with surplus grain for storage, it was announced yesterday.

More than 100 United States-flag tankers, or approximately one-fifth of the country's privately owned tanker fleet, are in laid-up status in various American ports, according to a survey made public yesterday by the American Merchant Marine Institute.

LENOX, Mass., Aug. 11 -- The first announcement that Charles Munch, who will take over the post of conductor of the Boston Symphony Orchestra next fall, will share in conducting the concerts at Tanglewood next season came today with a brief note that appeared in the program book for the final week of concerts at the Berkshire symphonic festival.

When a designer of printed fabrics turns his hand to a treatment of texture he is apt to achieve results that are somewhat off the beaten track. This was illustrated yesterday in a showing at 15 East Fifty-third Street of three weaves by Ben Rose, who formerly devoted his efforts to creating abstract motifs for drapery and upholstery fabrics and wallpapers.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Aug. 11 (UP) -- Ezra Van Horn resigned today as chairman of the negotiating committee of the Northern and Western Soft Coal Producers, reportedly forced to do so because of his $35,000-a-year job as trustee of the United Mine Workers Welfare Fund.
In his letter to THE NEW YORK TIMES, published July 25, "Parent" reports incorrectly that the American Automobile Association sponsored a bill to reduce the driving age to 16 in New York State.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Aug. 11 (UP) -- A West German politician, who may become Minister of Economics, has charged that American and British plans to break up the giant German film monopoly UFA are purely "for the one-sided benefit of foreign movie interests."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- President Truman today attributed the log-jam of nearly $27,000,000,000, in appropriation bills in Congress to Republican filibustering. By implication, he expanded this charge to legislative measures as well. He said that such oral delaying tactics had been employed by Republicans on every bill in every committee.
MELBOURNE, Australia, Aug. 11 -- The central executive of the Miners Federation in Sydney today authorized the 23,000 strikers to resume work Monday.

QUITO, Aug. 11 (AP) -- A country doctor from Brea, Calif., told today how it looked after last Friday's earthquake swallowed a town and buried 600 villagers in a mile-wide pit more than 1,500 feet deep.

BOSTON, Aug. 11 -- If there is a reasonably fair chance of the Dodgers and Cardinals carrying their current dog fight right down to the wire to produce another last-day deadheat in the National League as they did in 1946, there is an equally strong possibility that the American League will bob up with another three-cornered battle such as had the nation's fans by the ears a year ago.

TOKYO, Aug. 11 -- The Japanese Government began today the second round of dismissals of surplus public employes in the face of Communist opposition, which, while it is virulent as ever, seems to be finding dwindling support from rank and file union members.

The appointment of the Presidential fact-finding board in the dispute between the United States Steelworkers, CIO, and the steel industry was condemned yesterday by Clarence B. Randall, president of the Inland Steel Company, as presaging the establishment of a socialist or corporate state and the end of collective bargaining.

Two construction inspectors for the Department of Hospitals were indicted yesterday in connection with a painting contract racket in which District Attorney Frank S. Hogan estimates the city was defrauded of $560,860.

The Metropolitan Life Insurance Company declined yesterday to comment on the action of one of its tenants in Stuyvesant Town who has invited a Negro couple to share his apartment for the remainder of the summer.

MOSCOW, Aug. 11 -- Pravda, in the first Soviet comment on the United States White Paper on China, today characterized the State Department's recital as "One failure after another! One foolishness after another!" and predicted further American policy failures.

The question of how the present Welfare Council can be put on a firmer financial basis so it can effectively coordinate welfare activities, preventing duplication and overlapping of services and planning for the future, is being studied by a special committee.
LONDON, Friday, Aug. 12 -- Russia termed Yugoslavia today an "enemy of the Soviet Union" and charged that Premier Marshal Tito's Government was bound to the "camp of foreign capitalists."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (AP) -- Charles Luckman, president of the Lever Brothers Company, said today that the soap industry was not responsible for a sharp drop in fats and oils prices in late 1948 and early 1949. Testifying before a Senate agriculture subcommittee studying farm surpluses, Mr. Luckman said:

LARAMIE, Wyo., Aug. 11 -- The United States should provide military supplies and support to Chinese nationalists as a part of the global fight against communism, Dr. Stanley K. Hornbeck of Washington, former State Department expert on Far Eastern affairs, said today.

The head of the Police Department's Confidential Squad denied yesterday in General Sessions Court that wiretaps ever were put on the switchboard of Kings County Buick, Inc.; its executives' home telephones, or a Brooklyn restaurant characterized as the "hangout of unsavory racketeers.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- Taking note of predominantly Republican demands in the Senate, President Truman said this afternoon at his press conference that he would sign an order for the return of General Douglas MacArthur from Japan to give his views on the military assistance program if the general desired to come here.
The cotton market on the New York Cotton Exchange was steady yesterday and closed 7 points higher to 2 points lower than on Wednesday.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (AP) -Clark F. King, assistant corporation counsel, today suggested setting up a local board of censors to protect the public from obscene, profane or lascivious performances.
WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Aug. 11 -- Sub-par golf on the part of Lloyd D. Ribner brought the Fenway star medal honors in the Westchester amateur championship at the Knollwood Country Club today.

The four-story building at 23-05 Twenty-ninth Street, Long Island City, Queens, containing five stores, has been sold by the Oriole Holding Corporation tto Joseph Costella and Marco Fenaroli. Edwin R. Iorio was attorney for the seller and Charles J. Vallone acted for the buyer.

CHICAGO, Aug. 11 (AP) -- Philadelphia's Eagles, champions of the National Football League, are ten-point favorites to defeat a squad of seventy college all-stars before an expected crowd of 95,000 to 100,000 at Soldier Field tomorrow night.

CHICAGO, Aug. 11 -- Grain markets showed a heavy undertone today on the Board of Trade, after a small advance in the early trading. Corn was under considerable pressure, especially the September, which went to a smaller premium over the new-crop months.
The Seventy-seventh Division, Organized Reserve Corps, under the command of Maj. Gen. Julius Ochs Adler, will begin on Sunday a two-week training program at Pine Camp, N. Y.

Attempting to obtain for all grocers an equal chance in a free market, the National Association of Retail Grocers has begun a nation-wide campaign to improve food industry trade practices and to correct abuses within the industry, it was announced yesterday.

What could have been done for China that was not done? For instance, should our Government, knowing the harsh truth, have sent billions of dollars more down the drain where the other three or four billions went? Or to be again siphoned off into the pockets of private persons? Or should it have established a "government in China" to insure that our "help" functioned properly?

Brisk trading in rubber futures marked yesterday's activity on the Commodity Exchange. The market opened at prices up slightly from Wednesday's close and quotations had advanced 12 to 15 points by mid-afternoon. Profit-taking and other influences in the closing hours of trading brought prices down at the close to levels 2 and 5 points above Wednesday's quotations.

The sale of twenty-four surplus war-built merchant vessels in the three-month period ended June 30 brought the grand total of vessels sold under the terms of the Merchant Ship Sales Act of 1946 to 1,806, for a return to the Government of $1,731,000,000, according to the quarterly report of the Maritime Commission, as submited to Congress by Maj. Gen. Philip B. Fleming, chairman.

ATHENS, Aug. 11 -- The Greek National Army is now fully engaged in a general offensive against the Communist-led rebels concentrated in two major mountain salients protruding into this country from the Albanian border along the Vitsi and Grammos massifs.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Aug. 11 -- Professor Millar Burrows, in charge of publications for the American Schools of Oriental Research, which is centered here at Yale University, said today of Professor Driver's statements that the American Schools had cooperated frequently with British scholars and had provided material for them.

Human tragedy as well as great property loss has marked the forest fires which have been raging in the mountains of Montana and elsewhere in the Northwest. Of thirteen known dead in the huge fire which has already burned over some 6,000 acres north of Helena, twelve belong to that intrepid company of parachute firefighters known as "smoke jumpers."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- An attempt to cut in half the Administration's two-year program for helping arm this country's associates in the North Atlantic Treaty was defeated tonight in the House Foreign Affairs Committee by a tie vote.

Mrs. Albert Orsborn, wife of the international leader of the Salvation Army, arrived yesterday at La Guardia Airport on a British Overseas Airline plane for a month's visit to the United States. Mrs. Orsborn is the international leader of the Salvation Army's women's division and the daughter of the late General Edward J. Higgins, one-time international leader of the Army.

To accelerate country-wide interest in the theatre, Washington is slated to be the scene of a three-day convention, tentatively scheduled to be held Jan. 13-15, of a National Theatre Assembly, comprising all diversified factors connected with the stage, it became known yesterday.
DUESSELDORF, Germany, Aug 11 -- The most astonishing street in Germany today is the Koenigsallee in Duesseldorf. It runs through the heart of this severely bombed city like a bazaar in a cemetery.

Some say that Christmas Eve is the best time of the year, and that the stately march of a series of Christmas Eves constitutes the best times of life. No. Some say that the day before the wedding is the best time not only of the year, but of life.
President Elpidio Quirino of the Philippine Republic received one of the city's world famous welcomes yesterday.
Apparently not satisfied with only five boroughs and 8,000,000 people, New York gave birth yesterday to a new community, a residential development to be known as "The City of Timesquare, U. S. A."
BOSTON, Aug. 11 -- There was no checking Boston's battling Bosox today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- President Elpidio Quirino of the Philippines left the capital today with the assurance of United States sympathy in his efforts to unite the peoples of southeast Asia to protect their own independence. Expressed was the desire and intention of the United States to give "all feasible assistance" to the courses of action suggested by Mr. Quirino.

Summer tea sales have greatly exceeded the industry's expectations, representatives of the Tea Bureau, Inc., reported yesterday. Credit for the large jump in sales was divided beyond increased demand for iced tea in hot weather intensive tie-in promotions by cracker producers and results from better brewing instructions sent to restaurants.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 11 -- The field of five went under the wire three times in the forty-fourth running of the North American Steeplechase Handicap at Saratoga today, and on each occasion Robert W. Grant's Sun Bath was leading the way.

STRASBOURG, France, Aug. 11 -- The Consultative Assembly of the Council of Europe unanimously elected Paul-Henri Spaak of Belgium its president today. It then immediately entered into a series of lively argumentative discussions.

If the Gulf Stream were to change its course permanently and drastically the results would be unfortunate. The climate of the British Isles, which some people think is not perfect even now, would be worse. Our own climate might also deteriorate if, after this summer's experience, that is considered possible.
A wide array of colorful separates in velveteen, corduroy and tweed, many of them created exclusively for this store, figured prominently in the back-to-college showing yesterday at Ohrbach's.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Aug. 11 (AP) -- Istan, a game 4-year-old, won the fourth running of the $10,000 added Inaugural Handicap, top event of the opening day's card before a sweltering crowd of 16,311.

Evidence of considerable movements of secondary and scrap aluminum to the United States last year from Western Europe at !the same time that some of the countries there were receiving Marshall Plan funds to buy primary metal in Canada was found by an investigating American mission sent abroad earlier this year by the Economic Cooperation Administration.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 11 -"Spring Kill," a screen story by Guy Endore, has been purchased by Warner Brothers for $17,500, it was learned today from the Willner-Goldstone Agency, which represented Endore in the deal. The story deals with a man who completes a twenty-year prison term at the age of 31, having been convicted of murdering his own father when he was 11.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- Robert P. Patterson, wartime Under-Secretary of War and subsequently Secretary, took full responsibility today for the original ordering of 100 B-36 bombers.
OTTAWA, Aug. 11 -- Defense Secretary Louis Johnson paid a one-day visit to Ottawa today and described it as "a worth-while day of complete understanding with no misunderstanding."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- The House completed action today on the bill raising the minimum wage from 40 to 75 cents an hour and sent it to the Senate. President Truman declined to say at his news conference whether he would sign the bill when it reached him.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- Senate investigators were told today that Maj. Gen. Harry H. Vaughan, President Truman's military aide, received a deep-freeze unit paid for by the Albert Verley Company of Chicago, a perfume manufacturer. The testimony was given during the "five percenters" inquiry conducted by the Investigations Subcommittee of the Senate Committee on Expenditures in the Executive Departments.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- During the week ended Aug. 10 member bank reserve balances decreased $272,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

MUNICH, Germany, Aug. 11 -- Anti-Semitism as exemplified by the letter that caused a riot between Jewish displaced persons and German police here yesterday is "not a serious menace at present," according to Murray D. Van Wagoner, director of the United States Military Government in Bavaria.

The appointment of Sidney Jones as manager of Cunard White Star Line's Park Avenue office was announced yesterday by Harold P. Borer, general manager of the company in the United States. Mr. Jones succeeds Charles H. Fecke, who will continue to serve the line as special passenger representative.

LONDON, Aug. 11 -- On view in London today were fragments of what are reputed to be the oldest texts of the Bible in existence, the fragments being gleanings from a much larger find of documents that are now in the United States and Israel.

Advertising in the eight major New York newspapers during the first seven months of 1949 totaled 87,692,994 lines, a gain of 5.23 per cent over the like period of last year, an analysis of Media Records showed yesterday. Categories recording gains were: automotive, up 49.86 per cent; retail, 5.71 per cent, and general, 4.82 per cent.

Strict disciplinary action against military or naval pilots who interfere with civilian aircraft in flight was demanded yesterday by Senator Edwin C. Johnson, Colorado Democrat, as a result of the midair collision Saturday in which sixteen persons lost their lives near Fort Dix, N. J.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 11 -- By beating the Phils, 10 -- 7, under the Shibe Park lights tonight, the Dodgers moved into sole possession of first place in the National League for the first time since the Cardinals passed them on July 24.

A resolution calling upon the Export-Import Bank to rediscount in dollars, without recourse, the drafts of American exporters drawn on Brazilian importers when payment has been made in Brazil through bank deposits of local currency, was adopted last night by the board of directors of the American-Brazilian Trade Council, 150 Broadway.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- The Federal Reserve System is "much better equipped than ever before to meet the credit needs of the economy in a period of a down readjustment," the Federal Reserve Board said today in its thirty-fifth annual report to Congress.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Aug. 11 -- The United States, probably in collaboration with France and Turkey, its fellow members on the United Nations Palestine Conciliation Commission, is preparing a compromise plan on the Arab refugees designed to bring peace to the Middle East, it was learned authoritatively tonight.

Sir Thomas Beecham will serve as the musical commentator in a series of transcribed programs to be launched by WQXR in the fall. The title of the disk jockey type of program is "Sir Thomas Beecham Turns the Tables."

TEL AVIV, Israel, Aug. 11 -- A former Haganah intelligence chief, Lieut. Col. Iser Beeri was charged today with manslaughter, by execution, of Meir Tobiansky for treason. Mr. Tobiansky's execution by a firing squad in June, 1948, was officially declared a year later to have been a miscarriage of justice.
Robert G. Thompson, a defendant at the Communist trial, admitted on the witness stand yesterday that the party teaches:

The stock market paused again yesterday in its erratic recovery. Isolated corporate developments, such as the dividend reduction by United States Rubber, which followed similar action by American Woolen, apparently acted to restrain any furtherance of the upswing.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission authorized today another rise in the railroad freight rates averaging 4 per cent. This completes action on the railroads' petition last fall for a 13 per cent increase. The commission issued an interim order on Dec. 29, last, granting an average rise of 5.2 per cent.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (AP) -- Senate and House conferees agreed today on a bill to apply production controls to cotton if growers by a two-thirds vote approve such restrictions.

Half of the fast-growing Italian merchant marine consists of vessels from the American surplus war-built fleet, sold on the same terms as American buyers received, according to a review made public yesterday by the National Federation of American Shipping.

HONG KONG, Aug. 11 (UP) -- Gen. Pai Chung-hsi, defender of Nationalist China's central front in Hunan Province, ordered a "strategic retreat" today, pulling his headquarters back fifty miles to Kiyang from Hengyang.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- President Truman today nominated Gen. Omar N. Bradley to the newly created chairmanship of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, highest office in the Military Establishment. The President also renominated Admiral Louis E. Denfeld to serve an additional two-year term as Chief of Naval Operations.

CHICAGO, Aug. 11 (AP) -- As favorites faltered, Clayton Heafner scored a six-under-par 66 for a one-stroke lead in the first 18-hole round of Tam O'Shanter's $35,200 carnival, the "world" championship of golf, today.

Michael J. Quill, president of the Transport Workers Union, CIO, yesterday blamed "small minorities'' in the union for calling the recent strike against the New York City Omnibus and Fifth Avenue Coach lines. He appealed to the membership to take more part in union affairs and to help "the executive board of Local 100 put on the brakes."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission today gave to the Philadelphia Company, Pittsburgh, permission to purchase 40,000 shares of the no par value common stock of the Kentucky West Virginia Gas Company, Pittsburgh, from the Louisville (Ky.) Gas and Electric Company for $2,500,000.

BOOTHBAY HARBOR, Me., Aug. 11 -- The tale of tuna today in the State of Maine tournament was one of anti-climax. Not a fish was legally boated, but at 4:58 P. M., exactly two minutes before the official close of fishing, Dr. Roy R. Schubert of Paterson, N. J., aboard the Eastwind hooked one.

TRENTON, N. J., Aug. 11 -- Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll conferred late today with representatives of the Singer Manufacturing Company and union officials in a personal move to try to end a strike that has made 9,000 workers idle.

In a report to be made public today on operations of the C. I. T. Financial Corporation in the first six months of 1949, Arthur O. Dietz, president, has informed shareholders that the high level of motor vehicle production and the continued increase in the percentage of automobile time sales had been responsible for the corporation's improved earnings.

ATLANTA, Aug. 11 (UP) -- Margaret Mitchell, Pulitzer Prize winning author of "Gone With the Wind," was injured critically tonight by an automobile while walking across Peachtree Street, the setting for some of the most stirring action of her novel about the Civil War.

BOOTHBAY HARBOR, Me., Aug. 11 -- The tale of tuna today in the State of Maine tournament was one of anti-climax. Not a fish was legally boated, but at 4:58 P. M., exactly two minutes before the official close of fishing, Dr. Roy R. Schubert of Paterson, N. J., aboard the Eastwind hooked one.

TRENTON, N. J., Aug. 11 -- Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll conferred late today with representatives of the Singer Manufacturing Company and union officials in a personal move to try to end a strike that has made 9,000 workers idle.

In a report to be made public today on operations of the C. I. T. Financial Corporation in the first six months of 1949, Arthur O. Dietz, president, has informed shareholders that the high level of motor vehicle production and the continued increase in the percentage of automobile time sales had been responsible for the corporation's improved earnings.

ATLANTA, Aug. 11 (UP) -- Margaret Mitchell, Pulitzer Prize winning author of "Gone With the Wind," was injured critically tonight by an automobile while walking across Peachtree Street, the setting for some of the most stirring action of her novel about the Civil War.

LAKE SUCCESS, Aug. 11 -- The Security Council relieved Dr. Ralph J. Bunche, Acting United Nations Mediator on Palestine, today of his duties and ordered Israel and the Arab states to continue observing the present armistice agreements pending a permanent peace settlement.

WEST ORANGE, N. J., Aug. 11 -- Maurrie O'Connor of Hendricks Field took a one-stroke lead in the New Jersey P. G. A. championship with a four-under-par 35, 33 -- 68 over the Crestmont Country Club course today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- President Truman believes that endurance of the weather is largely a state of mind and he was abiding by that rule today -- the worst of Washington's dog days so far this summer. It was 97 in the shade, much worse in the sun.
LAKE SUCCESS, Aug. 11 -- Maurice Pate, executive director of the United Nations International Children's Emergency Fund, defended tonight the record of his organization's mission in Belgrade.
QUITO, Ecuador, Aug. 11 (UP) -- Sister American Republics, led by the United States, sent a swelling stream of mercy planes to this earthquake-devastated country today.

Mayor O'Dwyer assured a delegation of City College. Alumni yesterday of his support for the plan to have the city buy for the college the eighteen-and-a-half acre plant of the Manhattanville College of the Sacred Heart. He said the city already was negotiating for the property.

STRASBOURG, France, Aug. 11 (Reuters) -- Police here today seized all available copies of the German-language edition of the French Communist party organ l'Humanite' for "disrespect toward foreign statesmen."

SPRINGFIELD, Mo., Aug. 11 -- The plant of the strike-ridden Springfield Newspapers, Inc., publishers of this city's newspapers, was dynamited at 4 A. M. today. A piece of dynamite apparently was thrown against a plate glass window of the new one-story plant.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (AP) -- The Senate voted $63,054,424 today to meet administrative costs of the Maritime Commission after turning down a demand by Senator John J. Williams, Republican, of Delaware, that this amount be cut $3,152,721.
Mrs. Oksana Stepanovna Kasenkina, a former Russian school teacher, predicted yesterday that the Russian people eventually would rid themselves of the Communist regime and obtain freedom.
ANNECY, France, Aug. 11 -- An organization that has frequently ben hailed as the "most successful venture in international cooperation" is in danger of disintegrating for lack of funds.

G. Joseph Minetti, Commissioner of Marine and Aviation, announced yesterday that the first major step in the department's new-pier program had been taken with the awarding of a contract for drawings, specifications and estimates for new Pier 57, Fifteenth Street, North River.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (AP) -- The Federal Reserve Board threw its weight today against a proposal, suggested by President Truman, to expand the lending powers of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation.

Arthur Whittemore and Jack Lowe, duo-pianists, joined with Dimitri Mitropoulos last night at the Lewisohn Stadium in presenting one of the most attractive concerts of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony's summer season. It made one regret the series was almost over.

Mayor O'Dwyer yesterday paid tribute to the movie industry for bringing "messages for the public good that otherwise could not be so well told," but told theatre owners to remember their responsibilities in the use of the medium for educational purposes.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Aug. 11 -- So unobtrusively that it has gone virtually unpublicized, one democratic institution insinuated into German community life by United States Military Government representatives has been registering steady but gratifying development. The "town meeting" was put to a test here tonight. Its success is best measured against the contrast of the Nazi era.
LONDON, Aug. 11 -- Britain's dollar crisis, a Whitehall official said facetiously today, has been postponed until September.

HONOLULU, Aug. 11 -- The territorial Legislature moved doggedly ahead today toward passage of additional labor legislation despite a threat by striking members of the International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union that such measures would not force the reopening of Hawaii's strike-bound ports.

Belgium has a government again after a fifty-day crisis, and the change has released the leading figure in the former cabinet, M. Paul-Henri Spaak, to become the first president of the Consultative Assembly of the Council of Europe. Thus Belgium's loss is Europe's gain.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (UP) -- Pat McCarran, Democrat, of Nevada, chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee, charged today that about 225 persons, including many Communist agents, had slipped into the United States since 1947 aboard the Polish ships Batory and Sobieski.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission refused today to undertake a study of past operations of the Railway Express Agency to determine what rates the agency charged the railroads for carrying express matter.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- Admiral Louis Denfeld, Chief of Naval Operations, reminded Navy fliers today that the pilot who stunts may wind up in prison.

WARSAW, July 25 -- The Polish merchant marine, which has been beset by a large number of accidents this year, is now offering premiums to captains and senior engineers who maintain safety records. Special cash bonuses will be given to captains or senior engineers whose ships suffer no accidents or encounter demurrage charges during a six-month period.

SHANGHAI, Aug. 11 -- Despite official efforts to maintain a united British-American diplomatic attitude on China, there are clear-cut divergences of viewpoint among British and American business leaders here on how to deal with the Chinese Communist regime.

John Martin, 43 years old, of 2446 Lyvere Street, the Bronx, was crushed to death at 9:52 A. M. yesterday when he was wedged between a northbound IRT train and the platform at the 177th Street and Boston Road station. The accident caused a sixteen-minute delay.

Belgium has a government again after a fifty-day crisis, and the change has released the leading figure in the former cabinet, M. Paul-Henri Spaak, to become the first president of the Consultative Assembly of the Council of Europe. Thus Belgium's loss is Europe's gain.

SHANGHAI, Aug. 11 -- Despite official efforts to maintain a united British-American diplomatic attitude on China, there are clear-cut divergences of viewpoint among British and American business leaders here on how to deal with the Chinese Communist regime.

John Martin, 43 years old, of 2446 Lyvere Street, the Bronx, was crushed to death at 9:52 A. M. yesterday when he was wedged between a northbound IRT train and the platform at the 177th Street and Boston Road station. The accident caused a sixteen-minute delay.
STRASBOURG, France, Aug. 12 (UP) -- Following is the text of the speech by Winston Churchill today at a meeting here sponsored by the European Movement:
WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (AP) -- Federal employment experts accel-J erated their drive today to whittle down the nation s jobless total of about 4,000,000 persons.
Fourth Avenue, one of Brooklyn's trunk thoroughfares, is soon to be widened and partly repaved to cope with increasing traffic, Borough President John Cashmore said yesterday.

The A. A. Boxing Corporation has leased the recently completed industrial building at 37-29 Fifty-fifth Street, Woodside, Queens, from James Landers and will use it for executive offices and manufacturing warehouse. The Roman-Caswell Company was the broker.
Encouraging results were reported yesterday at the close of the five-day trade show of the Luggage and Leather Goods Manufacturers of America at the New Yorker Hotel.

TRENTON, N. J., Aug. 2 -- East Orange officials and the State Department of Conservation and Economic Development approached a deadlock today over which would manage an East Orange housing project of 119 dwelling units. The department served an ultimatum that it would take over next Tuesday, but city authorities indicated that they would ignore this because of pending litigation.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- The Reconstruction Finance Corporation "is not doing a damn thing" to collect an $80,000,000 loan made to the Baltimore Ohio Railroad over ten years ago, Senator Charles W. Tobey, Republican, of New Hampshire, declared today.

City departments and agencies have submitted to the City Planning Commission requests for a total allocation of $607,955,954 in the capital outlay budget for 1950, Robert F. Wagner Jr., chairman of the commission, announced yesterday.

Construction is proceeding on a new edifice in Hiroshima for the Roman Catholic Church of the Assumption of the Virgin Mary to replace the structure destroyed by the atom bomb. It is planned to have it ready by Aug. 6, 1950, the fifth anniversary of the dropping of the bomb.
A solemn pledge that the Philippine Republic will resist the spread of communism in the Far East was given yesterday by Elpidio Quirino, president of the young nation.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- With a deadline only seven days away and obstacles appearing, President Truman declared today that "the great endeavor" to reorganize the Federal Government was "imperiled" by the threatened rejection of two plans, one to create a Welfare Department, and the other to transfer the Bureau of Employment Security to the Labor Department.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 12 -- The resignation of Foreign Minister Juan Atilio Bramuglia, like a stone in the pool of Argentine politics, has caused rumors of all kinds to disturb the surface. Actually no other resignations could be confirmed, although reports were current that anywhere from one other Minister to the entire Cabinet had quit too.

The report of the Philco Corporation, issued yesterday by William Balderston, president, disclosed a decline in net income to $1,998,000 for the first half of this year from the $4,215,000 earned in the corresponding six months of 1948.

OCEANPORT, N. J., Aug. 2 (AP) -- Michael Belasco's Easy Chance won his seventh race this year when he triumphed easily today in the mile-and-a-sixteenth Deal Purse feature event at Monmouth Park. Janet N. Kelly's Kel's Love was second, two lengths behind the winner and well in advance of Edward Hilles' Napango.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Aug. 12 (AP) -- A high Roman Catholic churchman reported today he had evidence that some Catholics arrested in the church-state war were being mistreated in Czechoslovak prisons.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Certainly it's welcome news that fewer of the bothersome Popillia japonica, the Japanese beetle, will be around this year to plague gardeners, farmers and householders. Your editorial defense, however, of the beetle-eaters, the starlings, fails "to balance things out."

Imports from the United States by Uruguay will depend in great measure upon the success Uruguay has in marketing its wool in this country, John P. Hoover, first secretary of the United States Embassy at Montevideo said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (AP) -- United States imports from countries in the Marshall Plan aid program declined to $65,500,000 in June from $72,400,000 in May and a monthly average of $95,100,000 for the first quarter of 1949.

At Ebbets Field last night the Dodgers were the unhappy hosts at a Boston tea party at which a large portion of rhubarb was served on the side. One result was a 5-3 triumph for the Braves and another, which may be far-reaching, was that Manager Barney Shotton announced 40 minutes after the game ended that he would file a protest with President Ford Frick of the National League.

New York, Washington and St. Louis continued their unbeaten pace in the annual Union Printers International Baseball League championship yesterday, each scoring second victories. New York, with Bill McGarry starring, crushed Chicago, 12 -- 4, at Ebbets Field, and Washington routed Indianapolis, 22 -- 2, at the Brooklyn Parade Grounds, where St. Louis also took the measure of Baltimore, 13 -- 9.

A former member of the Communist party of Canada testified at a deportation hearing here yesterday that he had been sent in 1930 to a school in Moscow where he studied methods of overthrowing governments by force and violence.

NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 12 -- Indians abroad who have not adopted citizenship of the country in which they live will be considered citizens of India if they, their parents or their grandparents were born here, according to an article in the new Indian Constitution adopted by the Constituent Assembly today.

NEWPORT, R. I., Aug. 2 -- Strong head winds, dense fog and rain made late and rough going today on the first run of the New York Yacht Club cruise, that of thirty-seven and one-half miles here from New London, Conn.

David B. Costuma, a member of the Board of Elections, said yesterday that the board would hold a hearing Monday on whether Alfred C. Muscio, a Manhattan lawyer, was eligible to run for the City Council because he allegedly lived in New Jersey.

HONG KONG, Aug. 12 -- The uncertain future of the airlines in China was illustrated today in a suit filed against the Hong Kong Government by the China National Aviation Corporation, a Chinese-American enterprise.

The tragic case of James Montgomery may yet have a happy ending; but it is none the less a tragedy. Twenty-six years ago Mr. Montgomery was a 30-year-old veteran of the First World War, married, a property owner and law-abiding citizen of Waukegan, Ill. He was also a Negro; and in 1923 the Ku Klux Klan was running rampant in certain parts of the Middle West.

The vogue in unusual cocktail accompaniments is likely to swing to a new smoked shrimp just appearing in stores here. Sold in bulk rather than in tins or jars, these agreeably pungent tidbits are prepared by the Mutual Smoked Fish Company of Paterson, N. J. The concern has been curing salmon, sturgeon and herring in this way for more than twenty-five years.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- Industry is not moving into the South because it is looking for cheap labor but a result of finding good markets, available materials and a good labor supply in that region, the National Planning Association's Committee of the South reported today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- Before taking off for Frankfort today, to witness Sunday's Western German elections, John J. McCloy, United States Military Governor and High Commissioner-designate said that he hoped shortly to be able to announce that the Economic Cooperation Administration would help Western Berlin.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- Vice President Alben W. Barkley, a courtly man with the ladies and master of the bon mot, endured a sort of kangaroo court trial at the White House today before he got a medal for distinguished service. And when it was over the press questioned him rather bluntly about his romance.

Increased purchases of caustic soda and soda ash have virtually eliminated price-cutting on less-carload-lot shipments, chemical companies disclosed yesterday. While prices have not risen, active demand from cotton and rayon industries has caused a general firming of the market, they said.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (AP) -- Gov. Ernest Gruening told Congress today that Alaska was defenseless and that the territory could be captured tomorrow by a minor-scale airborne invasion.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- W. Stuart Symington, Secretary of the Air Force, took responsibility today for the entire B-36 bomber program. In vigorous language, he answered attacks on himself and on the big plane.

Last week, in the letter with which he transmitted the State Department's White Paper on China, Secretary Acheson touched on China's oldest and most grievous problem. This is simply that the Chinese people as a whole do not get enough to eat. No Chinese government has so far solved this problem.

NEWPORT, R. I., Aug. 12 (AP) -- Felicisimo Ampon, the mighty mite from Manila, and Gardnar Mulloy of Coral Gables, Fla., filled out the semi-final round of the Newport Casino's singles tennis tournament today before play was halted by a series of showers.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (AP) -- The White House notified Senator Warren G. Magnuson, Democrat, of Washington, today that the military establishment had been directed to include in its budget for the fiscal year starting July 1, 1950, such sums for merchant ship repair as were necessary for national defense.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (UP) -- The Senate unanimously approved today a bill authorizing a $311,000,000 expansion in research facilities on supersonic aircraft and guided missiles.

Eddie Albert, now starred in "Miss Liberty" on Broadway, will begin a daytime variety program series over the National Broadcasting Company's radio network early in September. The performer has just signed an exclusive contract with NBC covering his future radio and television activities.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (AP) -- W. Ray Bell, New York City, president of the Association of Cotton Textile Merchants, said today proposed labeling of cotton products "would more likely be harmful than helpful in sale and distribution of cotton textiles."

As a result of its study of pollution throughout the state, the special legislative Committee on Pollution Abatement, in its 1949 report to the Legislature, just published, estimated the cost of sewage works needed in this city at $180,000,000 and for the state at $248,674,294.
PATERSON, N. J., Aug. 12 -- William G. Dodds and Edgar H. Ellis, Republican members of the four-man fire-police commission, submitted their resignations today to Democratic Mayor Michael U. Devita.
OCEANPORT, N. J., Aug. 12 (AP) -Directors of Monmouth Park race track finished counting the money today and announced that the recent meeting was up to expectations.

The announcement yesterday by the Graham-Paige Motors Corporation that it has sold a 50 per cent interest in its farm equipment business to the Mast-Foos Manufacturing Company and is relinquishing management of that business to the latter, removes Graham-Paige from the list of American industrial enterprises after forty years of operations.
WESTFIELD, N. J., Aug. 2 -- William J. Mangin of Aldecress won low gross honors, in Metropolitan Golf Association one-day tournament with two-over-par 35, 39 -- 74 at the Echo Lake course today.

PARIS, Aug. 12 -- The European Marshall Plan Council decided today to invite Paul G. Hoffman, head of the Economic Cooperation Administration, who will arrive in Paris on Sunday, to sit with it Tuesday morning. It also decided that the report on the screening of dollar requests for this year, which was to have been made to it Tuesday, should be finished Wednesday and submitted to the Council Thursday.

Art lovers who "know what they like" and want colored reproductions to hang on their walls will find comprehensive collections available at museums and art galleries in the city. New prints to satisfy every taste from Botticelli to Bracque range from 25 cents to $20.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- The combined Senate Foreign, Relations and Armed Services Committee closed today the hearings on the Administration's foreign military aid bill without having heard any opposition witness.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., Aug. 2 -Miss Patricia Bancker sailed the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club entry to a slim lead in the annual Syce Cup series for the women's sailing championship of Long Island Sound as the first two races of the scheduled nine were staged off Larchmont Yacht Club today.
Robert G. Thompson, a defendant in the Communist trial, refused under cross-examination yesterday to name secret members of the Communist party.

W. Averell Harriman, special Presidential representative to the Economic Cooperation Administration, praised the military assistance program as an added war deterrent in an interview at La Guardia Airport yesterday before boarding a Trans-World Airline plane for Paris.

SWANSEA, Wales, Aug. 2 (Reuters) -- Making its lowest score of the season today, Glamorgan, the county champion, was all out for 73 runs in drawn match with the New Zealanders, who had declared their first innings at 378 for six wickets.

The Continental Oil Company and its subsidiaries reported yesterday for the second quarter of this year net income after all charges of $9,530,002, compared with $15,086,128 in the similar three months of last year.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (UP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board said today that last year's crash of a United Air Lines DC-6 at Mount Carmel, Pa., might have been avoided if the crew had followed proper emergency procedure.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 12 -- Rain bucketed into the premises today during the running of the American Legion Handicap, which went to Henry W. Collins' Manyunk, winner of the Wilson Stakes ten days ago. Manyunk took command in the last thirty yards and scored by a head over Belair Stud's Whirling Fox, the all-the-way pacesetter.

Although Dr. Harry S. Mustard, Commissioner of Health, announced yesterday that "the number of polio cases seems to be leveling out," figures released by his department showed fifty-seven new cases, four more than the previous day.

BOSTON, Aug. 12 (AP) -- Boston's Red Sox hopped over Cleveland into second place in the American League by twice outstruggling the Washington Senators, winning 15 -- 7 in an afternoon contest and 13 -- 11 in the night affair. The Sox are five games in back of the leading Yankees and a half game ahead of the Indians.

DUBLIN, Aug. 2 -- The American military jumping team, led by Col. Earl F. Thomson, made a good showing in its tryout at the first military competition of the Dublin Horse Show which opened today. This city is filled with overseas visitors for the event.

A flurry in the over-the-counter market in bank stocks carried the quotation for Brooklyn Trust Company shares at one time yesterday to 140, a gain of 25 points, and set loose renewed conjecture as to the likelihood of a change in the status of the closely-owned institution.

Vernon Morgan, New York, ranked third, moved a round ahead of the field as he eliminated Ronald Fieuellteau, Washington D. C., No. 11, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 4, in the quarterfinal bracket of the men's singles title play in the New York State Negro open Tennis championships yesterday at the Cosmopolitan Tennis Club.

LENOX, Mass., Aug. 12 -- For five hours this afternoon and evening Tanglewood was on parade. Students and faculty of the Berkshire Music Center and the Boston Symphony led by Dr. Serge Koussevitzky, who has been the catalyst of this exciting musical enterprise, showed the world what they could do.
PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Aug. 12 -- A bomb exploded under the unoccupied automobile of Capt. John Childs of Lewiston, Me., assistant United States air attache, last midnight.

Heartened by their initial success in a campaign for greater utilization of twisted 15-denier monofilament yarn, throwsters are giving serious consideration to promotion of a variety of twists in all types of nylon hosiery, it was learned yesterday.

ALBANY, Aug. 12 -- The right of the Mount Vernon Board of Education to select the so-called "Wartburg property" as the location for a new multi-million-dollar "comprehensive" high school has been upheld by Francis T. Spaulding, the State education commissioner.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 12 (AP) -- The Government late today rested its case against Los Angeles-born Iva Toguri (Tokyo Rose) D'Aquino, on trial for treason for her wartime broadcasts from Radio Tokyo to American troops in the Pacific areas.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- Average primary market prices advanced 0.1 per cent in the week ended on Tuesday, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. The index was 152.7 per cent of the 1926 average, 1 per cent below four weeks ago, and 10 per cent below the comparable week in 1948.

HELSINKI, Finland, Aug. 2 (AP) -- Craig Dixon of Los Angeles won the 100-meter dash and the 110-meter high hurdles today as the touring American track team completed its rout of Finland in a dual meet.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- Donald Henderson filed a non-Communist affidavit today as national administrative director of the Food, Tobacco, Agriculture and Allied Workers, CIO. The National Labor Relations Board accepted it but announced that it came too late for the union to get on the ballot in an election among employes of Alaska Salmon Industry, Inc.

LARAMIE, Wyo., Aug. 12 -- The Communists themselves face many grave economic and social problems in China, and it remains to be seen whether they can succeed in providing a permanent solution where others have failed, Francis H. Russell, director of the State Department's Office of Public Affairs, said tonight.

GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 12 -- The custody of Eligio Del Guercio Jr., 17-year-old Timken Roller Bearing heir, was given to his father, Eligio Del Guercio Sr., a Mamaroneck attorney, in an agreement accepted today by Greenwich Probate Judge L. Paul Burke.

Another broadbill has been taken off Montauk. Mickey McCann of the Montauk Yacht Club wired yesterday that a man from Missouri who wanted to be shown, C. Lee Wadon of Richmond Heights, was convinced when he boated one that weighed 359 1/2 pounds.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (AP) -- Manufacturers' sales increased in June, although that month normally registers a decline from May. In reporting this business pick-up the Department of Commerce today estimated the value of manufacturers' sales in June at $16,500,000,000, an increase of $200,000,000 over the May total.

The extension of the maturity limit on Reconstruction Finance Corporation loans to business, as proposed in the midyear report of President Truman's Council of Economic Advisers, "would put that organization in the position of furnishing what is tantamount to permanent equity capital," the National City Bank declares in its monthly business letter published today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- Maj. Gen. Harry H. Vaughan, President Truman's military aide, is willing to testify at the "five percenters" inquiry, Senator Clyde R. Hoey, Democrat, of North Carolina, said today. The Senator is chairman of the Investigations Subcommittee of the Senate Committee on Expenditures in the Executive Departments, which is conducting the inquiry.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- The Senate Labor and Welfare Committee reported favorably today on the first two steps in a school construction bill. These were a $5,000,000 state-by-state survey of needs and an emergency construction program for "distressed districts."

The stock market lost ground again yesterday. The drift to lower levels was not accompanied by any liquidation rush and was largely the result of buying apathy. While fractional losses predominated, with the composite rate down 0.49 point, the rubber and tire issues remained depressed more than the average and a few other stocks slumped more than a point.

Secretary of Agriculture Brannan likes to apply the terms "hoary" and "specious" to the arguments raised by critics of the farm program which bears his name. They would find it difficult, however, to surpass in this respect his own effort this week at Columbia, Mo.

In naming the recipient yesterday of this year's Sidney Howard Memorial Award, the purpose of which is to encourage the development of new playwriting talent, the Playwrights Company took an unprecedented step. Instead of turning over $1,500 as had been the custom, the sum of $3,000, covering this year and next, was allocated to the Dramatists Guild.

WEST ORANGE, N. J., Aug. 12 -- Vic Ghezzi of Deal fired a 5-under-par 32, 35 -- 67, which added to his first round 69 for a 36-hole total of 136, gave him a one-stroke lead at the halfway mark in the New Jersey P. G. A. championship being contested over the Crestmont Country Club course today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (AP) -- Two bills, one to give Logan International Airport at Boston $600,000 and the other to give it $1,000,000 for improvements were introduced today.

TRENTON, N. J., Aug. 12 -- The testimony of more than twenty witnesses was taken today in the Civil Aeronautics Board's one-day hearing on the fatal crash of an Eastern Air Lines plane and a Navy fighter near Fort Dix, N. J., on July 30, killing sixteen persons.

Out-of-town buyers registered in the New York market for the week ended yesterday numbered 1,464, compared with 1,484 last week and 1,118 in the similar week a year ago, according to the listings appearing in THE NEW YORK TIMES.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 2 (AP) -- The Cardinals backed up Red Munger's five-hit pitching with five doubles and a triple to hand the Boston Braves a 7-to-2 defeat tonight. Stan Musial had one of the doubles and the triple.

At least 68 per cent of the $42,000,000,000 expenditure proposed by President Truman in his January budget message for the current fiscal year is for all practical purposes untouchable in any budget-balancing efforts, the Institute of Life Insurance reported yesterday.

John M. Hancock, a partner in the banking firm of Lehman Brothers and chairman of the American Management Association, told the Presidential fact-finding board in the steel dispute yesterday that a wage increase for steelworkers would set up a chain of events leading to inflation and unemployment.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (AP) -- The text of President Truman's letter to Vice President Barkley urging Senate approval of two reorganization plans follows:

CHICAGO, Aug. 2 (AP) -- Miss Marlene Bauer, Los Angeles, and Miss Barbara McIntire, Toledo, the co-medalists, today came through with first round victories in the Women's Western junior golf championship at the Onwentsia Country Club in suburban Lake Forest.

HEWLETT, L. I., Aug. 12 -- E. E. Smith and M. B. Reach Jr., his guest from the Long Meadow Club in Brookline, Mass., carded a 34 36 -- 70 to lead the final-day qualifiers in the fifteenth Arthur Man Memorial member-guest golf tournament at the Seawane Harbor Club today.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Aug. 12 -- Norman H. Collisson, chief of the Economic Cooperation Administration mission for Germany and ECA representative here since this country was incorporated in the Organization for European Economic Cooperation, has resigned and will return to the United States around Sept. 1, it was learned today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (AP) -- An application to extend a pipeline into New England for the transmission of natural gas from Texas and Louisiana was filed today with the Federal Power Commission by the Tennessee Gas Transmission Company of Houston, Tex.

Railway management should counter new truck competition "aggressively and openly," Robert R. Young, chairman of the Federation for Railway Progress, says in an article in the August issue of that organization's publication.
LONDON, Aug. 2 -- After firm opening British Government bonds came under heavy selling in the stock market here today.

The General Public Utilities Corporation reported yesterday that consolidated net income for the twelve months to June 30 was $17,222,499, equal to $2.28 a share, compared with $14,355,733, or $1.90 a share in the preceding twelve months.

A lot of cars went down to the end of Sugarbush Road the other day. That was surprising, for old Mrs. Brown lives there alone in a house a hundred years old, and rarely has any visitors except weekends when her daughter comes down from Malone.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (AP) -- The Indians pounded Mickey Harris and Al Gettel of the Senators for fifteen hits and an 8-1 victory tonight. Early Wynn scattered nine hits to annex his ninth triumph against two defeats.

LONDON, Aug. 2 -- British motion-picture executives, top technicians and many actors and actresses will have their salaries reduced as much as 20 per cent as an economy measure, the British Film Producers' Association announced today.

Until the last lap the German electoral campaign was characterized by general apathy among the German population and general indifference elsewhere. It took an outburst of nationalistic speeches, directed primarily against occupation policies, to bring the contest to life inside Germany and capture the attention of the outside world.

With the important difference that the Giants were trailing the Phillies, 2 -- 0, at the time, a ball game at the Polo Grounds was called because of rain for the second straight day yesterday. Seven full innings had been completed when the skies darkened and let loose a deluge.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 12 -- Two story purchases were announced today by major film companies. RKO acquired "Macao," an unpublished short story by Robert Williams, described as a melodrama laid in the Portuguese protectorate in China.

Based on current demands, when Government buying agencies' requirements for lead are filled, domestic industry buyers will have to import this metal to supply their inventories during the balance of the year, it was learned yesterday, following an increase of 1/4 cent in the price of pig lead.

The American Bankers Association expressed yesterday dissatisfaction with the Federal Home Loan Bank's revised regulations for Federal Savings and Loan Associations. Under revisions promulgated last month, the associations still would be permitted to refer to their investment share accounts as "savings accounts," and would be permitted to abbreviate their formal name from "Federal savings and loan associations" to "Federal associations."

The law of averages, vigorously enforced by the Tigers, caught up with Allie Reynolds last night. While a banner turnout of 57,238 spectators at the Stadium looked on in utter dismay, the fourth place Detroiters knocked out the Yankee right-hander in the fifth inning and went on to detonate the league-leading Bombers by the humiliating score of 10 -- 2, behind Hal Newhouser.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 12 (AP) -- Gerry Staley, Joe Garagiola and Stan Musial combined their talents tonight to lift the Cardinals back into first place in the nip-and-tuck National League pennant chase. Staley stopped the Pirates with six hits while Stan and Joe pounded three-run homers to give the soaring Redbirds an 8-to-2 victory.

SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., Aug. 2 -- The Eastern turf court championships, in progress at the Orange Lawn Tennis Club, got into full swing today, with the members of the Australian Davis Cup team and Frank Parker arriving on the scene and Earl Cochell checking in after his flight from Europe.

CHICAGO, Aug. 12 -- General selling developed in September corn on the Board of Trade here and carried that delivery off 2 3/8 cents a bushel at one time to a new low since May 31, and led to pressure on other grains. Although the low prices were not maintained, because of short covering, September corn closed 1 5/8 cents down, and the new-crop months were 1/8 cent off to 3/8 cent up.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 12 -- Gaining fresh momentum for a drive which they hope will soon add further discouragement to their ardent pursuers, the Yankees tonight flattened Connie Mack's Athletics, 7 to 3, in the opener of a five-game series.

Ship repairing and ship construction are declining throughout the country, J. Lewis Luckenbach, president of the American Bureau of Shipping, reported yesterday at the semi-annual meeting of the classification society's board of managers.

LAKE SUCCESS, Aug. 12 -- Maj. Gen. Terence S. Airey, commander of the British-United States zone in the Free Territory of Trieste, reported to the United Nations Security Council today that a substantial economic advance has been made by the Allied Military Government, and that unemployment was slowly declining.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- The Civil Aeronautics Board today affirmed in final form its tentative decision splitting the air cargo business over the United States among three airlines that are licensed to fly exclusively in this field for five years without subsidy from the Government.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (AP) -- Dr. Leonard A. Maynard, director of the School of Nutrition at Cornell University, said today that a proposed change in Federal food standards might give bakers of white bread a monopoly on the use of the unqualified word "bread."
CHICAGO, Aug. 12 (AP) -- Buck White's seven-under-par 65 today gave him a halfway total of 135 and a one stroke lead in the $10,000 Tam o'Shanter world golf meet.

There were increases in both the number and dollar volume of distress conveyances of Manhattan real estate during July as compared with June, according to figures just compiled by the Real Estate Board of New York. The board pointed out, however, that the July increase was not enough to keep the number of such transfers for 1949 to date from comparing favorably with similar periods of preceding years.
The Congressional investigation of the B-36, which started early this week, has not yet approached the "heart of the matter."
CLEVELAND, Aug. 12 (AP) -- Herb Adams' single with the bases loaded and two out in the ninth gave the Chicago White Sox a 6-to-5 victory over the Cleveland Indians tonight.
LONDON, Aug. 12 (Reuters) -- Bert Sutcliffe, New Zealand's opening batsman, set two records in the drawn cricket match against Essex at Southend today.
LONG BEACH, L. I., Aug. 12 -- With eleven charter members officiating, the Bachurei Chemed Synagogue will open tomorrow morning as this congregation realizes a $50,000 dream come true.
