GARDEN CITY, L. I., Aug. 12 -- William J. Byrne Sr. and Charles Amandoles of La Tourette captured the medal honors today by firing a 68, three-under-par, in the qualifying round of the annual member-guest tournament at the Garden City Country Club.

HONOLULU, Aug. 12 -- Hawaii's dock strike passed through its 103d day today as Harry R. Bridges, chief of the striking International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union, conferred with Paul I. Fagan Sr., San Francisco and Honolulu industrialist, and Paul H. Anderson, president of the Honolulu Chamber of Commerce.

CHICAGO, Aug. 12 (AP) -- Championship class paid off tonight as the Philadelphia Eagles smothered the College All-Stars, 38 -- 0, to roll up the most decisive margin in the 16-year-old charity series.

WITH THE GREEK ARMY, at Kozani, Greece, Aug. 12 (AP) -- Communist-led guerrilla bands were believed fleeing into Albania tonight after the United States-trained Greek Army had ripped into the heart of their stronghold in the Vitsi Mountains in forty-eight hours of heavy fighting.

BOOTHBAY HARBOR, Me., Aug. 12 -- For the second day no fish were caught in the state of Maine tuna tournament today. The reason was different, though. Heavy fog rolled in on a light easterly breeze early in the morning and final day's activities were deferred.
The cotton futures market was steady yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange, and final prices were 4 points higher to 14 points lower on the day.

Abel Wolman, head of the Sanitary Engineering Department of Johns Hopkins University at Baltimore, left here yesterday aboard the Swedish American liner Gripsholm for Geneva, Switzerland, where he will attend as United States representative the first session of the World Health Organization.

City and country dwellers find August a month that offers a wide selection of flowers for arrangements about the house. To enjoy the blossoms bought at a florist shop or gathered from a garden or roadside, an assortment of vases and of holders to be placed within vases is important.

LONDON, Aug. 12 -- Douglas Jay, Economic Secretary to the Treasury, declared tonight that Winston Churchill, in his recent attack on Socialist policies, had uttered "one of the most out- rageously malicious falsehoods heard in British politics for a long time."
PITTSBURGH, Aug. 2 -- The Dodgers received their greatest lift in many weeks tonight, when Rex Barney hurled them to a 5-2 victory over the Pirates.

Coffee futures continued and broadened yesterday their advance from the late rally of the previous day on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. Prices in the "S" contract were 5 to 17 points higher in sales of 17,500 bags. Quotations in the "D" contract rose 2 to 16 points above Thursday's close in a volume of 1,250 bags.

The Texas Company and its subsidiaries, in a report covering the six months ended on June 30, last, estimated yesterday net income at $62,719,253, which compares with $68,266,915 for the same period a year ago.
BOSTON, Aug. 2 (AP) -- A suggestion that production in New England may be nosing upward was offered today in two separate surveys.

"The Twentieth Century: A Mid-Way Account of the Western World," a new book by Hans Kohn, will be published on Sept. 13 by Macmillan. It is an analysis of the ideas of the last fifty years that are making, or destroying, Western civilization --nationalism and pacifism, racialism and imperialism, communism and fascism, individualism and collectivism, isolationism and world order.
Sales of television receivers will jump as much as 50 per cent as the result of producers entering the low-price competitive market, Irving Sarnoff predicted yesterday.

HOBOKEN, N. J., Aug. 2 -- A work stoppage by 370 longshoremen, members of five locals of the International Longshoremen's Association, AFL, early today halted the movement of freight on four local piers and delayed the sailing of the Holland-America Line's Veendam for fifty-six minutes.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Aug. 12 (U.P.) -- A threatened complete shutdown of the nation's soft coal mines was averted today when Northern and Western producers decided not to challenge the three-day-work-week order of John L. Lewis, head of the United Mine Workers.
RUMSON, N. J., Aug. 2 -- A slight drizzle met the field of seventy at the Rumson golf course today for the second round of the women's Metropolitan Golf Association's annual tournament.

CHICAGO, Aug. 2 -- The Central-Illinois Securities Corporation bought in 3,450 shares of its own preference stock in the first six months of 1949 at a total cost of $46,171, C. Arvid Johnson, president, told stockholders today in his semi-annual report. Mr. Johnson's alleged refusal to retire preference shares was a subject of dispute at the company's annual meeting in February.

Local 140 of the United Furniture Workers, CIO, representing 1,000 mattress workers, announced yesterday that it would strike against New York manufacturers next Tuesday because of inability to agree on terms of a new contract.
DALLAS, Tex., Aug. 2 (AP) -- Texans today dropped five of the sixteen national skeet titles they held.

GENEVA, Aug. 12 -- The British Government plans to open crucial financial talks with the United States, Canada and France in Washington in September with no new program for adapting the British economy to meet the critical dollar shortage, in the conviction not only of British observers with a pipeline to the Labor party leaders but of top United States and Commonwealth statesmen.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 12 -- Little change was reflected in the level of business in the Pittsburgh district last week, according to the Bureau of Business Research of the University of Pittsburgh in the four previous weeks. Business had recovered sharply from the low level reported over Independence Day.
CINCINNATI, Aug. 2 (AP) -- The Reds, who couldn't score one run in eighteen innings Sunday, exploded with base hits tonight to crush the Phillies, 11 to 3.

Led by the Most Rev. Joseph F. Rummel, Archbishop of New Orleans, 210 Roman Catholics from Brooklyn and from the South sailed at noon yesterday on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary on a pilgrimage to the shrine of Lourdes and to the Vatican.

Strength in coffee futures yesterday again featured the day's trading on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. New seasonal high prices were established in all the active delivery months in both coffee contracts. A new high price was recorded in futures when the spot September "S" contract sold at 28.51 cents a pound.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- The Senate voted today to send the disputed basing point bill to conference with the House, in order to compromise differences between measures passed by both Chambers.

The Tennessee Gas Transmission Company, whose application for extension of its natural gas pipeline system to Buffalo and New England is pending before the Federal Power Commission, reported yesterday that net income for the second quarter of 1949 was $2,198,084, equal to 60 cents on each of the 3,333,333 common shares outstanding.

A brochure issued for the benefit of prospective concessionaries and tenants in the Port Authority's Union Bus Terminal in west midtown Manhattan gives an attractive picture of what the public can expect in comfort and convenience in this $24,000,000 passenger station. Although the terminal is not expected to be ready for use before November, 1950, five hundred applications for space have already been received.

Paul Padower and Eli Hahn, young Air Force veterans who operate the Midwood Restaurant, 1143 Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn, led a parade of ninety-seven blood donors in their establishment yesterday and passed out free dinners to all comers, including policemen, housewives and humble workmen.

The city's waterfront is gradually losing its tatterdemalion look under the rehabilitation drive of the Department of Marine and Aviation, Commissioner G. Joseph Minetti said yesterday after a three-hour tour.
The cotton market on the New York Cotton Exchange had a slow session yesterday and final prices were 8 points lower to 3 points higher than on Monday, with the far months showing the most strength.

The Wheeling Lake Erie Railway borrowed yesterday $6,870,000 on general and refunding-mortgage bonds maturing over twenty-five years at an indicated interest cost of about 2.86 per cent. The railroad sold the bonds at competitive bidding to a banking syndicate composed of Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., and R. W. Pressprich Co. at a bid of 98.132 for an interest coupon of 2 3/4 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- The Senate Judiciary Committee voted, 9 to 2, today for a favorable report to the Senate on the nomination of Attorney General Tom C. Clark to be an Associate Justice of the Supreme Court.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 12 -- Two members of the Regency Council, a Minister of the Royal Court and a newspaper editor, accused of responsibility for the pro-Axis policy that eventually led to the German invasion of Yugoslavia, were placed on trial today in the Belgrade District Court.

The stock market surpassed the high mark set in July and fringed the May levels yesterday as the list plodded forward. The fresh rise lacked vigor, though, and gains proved selective, with the composite rate up 0.32 point on the day and representative of the additions through the main section of the list.

King Paul of Greece is confident that the guerrillas in his country will be driven "across the border" but he feels that United States aid will be required to keep them out of Greece, according to Arthur M. Tode, of 240 Grassy Sprain Road, Yonkers, N. Y., a consulting marine engineer who is honorary president of the Propeller Club.

LAKE SUCCESS, Aug. 12 -- Byron Price, Acting Secretary General of the United Nations, announced today that the United Nations Fund for Palestinian Arab Refugees had "enough money now to carry us well into October, at least."

It took a driving rain yesterday afternoon to chase Paddy Walsh's audience of 250 from their special spot just west of Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street. From 8 A. M. to 4 P. M. daily there are no fewer than that number when Patrick Walsh drives his steam shovel in a wide arc, ripping up big chunks of asphalt, track and cobblestone on Forty-second Street.

GREAT RIVER, L. I. -- A sure cure for any drought is to schedule the Race Week activity of the Great South Bay Yacht Racing Association. There was rain today and the accompanying easterly wind brought in plenty of rough water off the Timber Point Yacht Basin for the second day of this regatta.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (AP) -- Russia shipped manganese ore -- a vital steel-hardening metal that the United States stockpiles against a war emergency -- to this country in June for the first time in three months, the Bureau of the Census reported today. June receipts of the ore were only $100,000 in value, compared with $600,000 in March and a monthly average of $800,000 last year.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Can't something be done about the incinerators here in New York? During the war there were far more important things than smoke control and the cause and elimination of soot. Now I believe it is time for people in New York to do something about it.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 2 -- I Stewart Granger, British film star, has been signed by M-G-M to play opposite Deborah Kerr in "King Solomon's Mines," which will go before the cameras on location in British East Africa in October. Granger, who was signed in London, will report to the "King Solomon'' company in Africa in mid-October and then will come to Hollywood for interior sequences for the film.

BOSTON, Aug. 2 (AP) -- Dom DiMaggio singled as the first batter in the ninth and then raced home from third base with the winning run on a fielder's choice as the Red Sox defeated the Browns tonight, 4 -- 3.

CHICAGO, Aug. 12 -- Federal District Judge Walter J. Labuy denied today motions by Preston Turker, president of the Tucker Corporation, and two former business associates, to examine a confidential report made on the corporation by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Aug. 12-- A{iss Isabella Carr Leighton, daughter of lr. and /%rs. Delmar Leighton, was married this afternoon in th Harvard ]%[emorial Church to Dr. Cheves A{eCord Smythe of lexv York, son of Mr. and A{rs. Augustine T. Smythe of Charleston, S. C.

BUFFALO, Aug. 2 -- There are no indications of any major business slump in the independent retail food stores of the nation, it was reported here today by Mrs. R. M. Kiefer, secretary-manager of the National Association of Retail Grocers.
An angry utility executive called upon 43,000 stockholders yesterday to support his opposition to a "Government-guided economy (the Welfare State)" by making "another declaration of their rights."

CRESTWOOD, N. Y., Aug. 2 -- Golfers continued to demonstrate today that one of the virtues required of their sport is patience. Not since 1947, when Emery Thomas, present New Jersey open champion, scored an ace at the Forest Hill Field Club, Bloomfield, N. J., has any competitor in The World-Telegram hole-in-one tournament turned in a perfect performance.

ALBANY, Aug. 12 -- The State Controller, Frank C. Moore, made public tonight a report on the fiscal affairs of Hamilton County which charges scores of illegal acts by and illegal payments to supervisors and other officers of the thinly populated Adirondack Mountain county.

STRASBOURG, France, Aug. 12 -- Speaking in French here on a balcony above the Place Kleber tonight, Winston Churchill drew an ovation from a crowd of 30,000 when he said it was possible to organize Western Europe to resist the threat of tyranny.

There is something heartening and refreshing in the breezes that are blowing from Strasbourg. In the third day of its life, the Consultative Assembly of the Council of Europe has already given every evidence of impatience with the restrictions imposed upon it by the executive committee of Foreign Ministers of the member states.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (AP) -- Five Western Senators are seeking a new approach to the problem of supporting the metal mining industry. Senator Joseph C. O'Mahoney, chairman of the Interior Affairs Committee, today named himself, Senators Arthur V. Watkins, James E. Murray, Robert S. Kerr and George W. Malone to work out some method for using Federal powers to halt the closing of nonferrous mines and stimulate exploration for and development of new ore bodies.

Safeway Stores, Inc., operators of a nation-wide chain of more than 2,000 grocery stores, more than doubled its earnings in the twenty-four weeks ended on June 18, last, over the corresponding period a year ago, a report disclosed today.

In a decision that probably will have a far-reaching effect on this country's general export policy, Federal Judge Samuel H. Kaufman ruled yesterday that the United States Alkali Export Association and others have violated the Sherman Anti-Trust Act by engaging in an international cartel to divide the world's alkali markets in restraint of trade.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Aug. 12 (AP) -- Ella K. Bryson's Abbe May won today's featured Vaughn Monroe Purse over a field of seven juveniles before a crowd of 11,500. The son of Abbe Pierre paid $4.80. Jockey Bobbie Strange had him in the lead by a half length at the end of the six furlongs.

DETROIT, Aug. 12 -- Cooperation between labor and management on a program to employ the country's physically handicapped was urged today by Vice Admiral Ross T. McIntire, chairman of the President's Committee on Employment of the Physically Handicapped.

ATLANTA, Aug. 12 (AP) -- Margaret Mitchell showed definite improvement tonight from injuries inflicted by a speeding car. Her husband, John R. Marsh, reported from the hospital that she was "definitely better compared with last night."

NEWPORT, R. I., Aug. 12 -- Miss !Diana Davies, daughter of Mrs. !Diana Ryan and Frederick Martin Davies of New York and Newport, made her debut tonight at a "pink and white" ball given by her mother for 600 guests at Vaucluse, her Portsmouth estate overlooking the Sakonnet River.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- A bell jangled, but not too alarmingly, as the massive door of the bank vault swung open. Inside was not money but a lot of books.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission today approved a plan of reorganization for the Missouri Pacific Railroad, with a capitalization of $611,931,952 for the system.
BOSTON, Aug. 12 -- Gifts totaling $440,000 to various Massachusetts charities from the Joseph P. Kennedy Jr. Memorial Foundation were made known today.

MADISON, N. J., Aug. 12 -- For the second week in a row, Miss Maureen Orcutt of White Beeches captured low gross honors in the New Jersey Women's Golf Association one-day tournament with 40, 40 -- 80 over the Briadburn Country Club course today.

More persons today are asking for help with personal and family problems owing, in part, to economic pressures, that seem to bring out other troubles and, in part, to wider acceptance of the constructive work done by family service agencies.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- The Commodity Credit Corporation announced today that export rates on wheat and flour from Gulf of Mexico ports under the international wheat agreement will vary with the port of destination.

"Rope of Sand," which arrives at the Paramount, is this morning's lone film newcomer. The melodrama, which was produced by Hal Wallis for Paramount release, features Burt Lancaster, Paul Henreid, Peter Lorre and a newcomer, Corinne Calvet. William Dieterle directed from a story and screen play by Walter Doniger.

LENOX, Mass., Aug. 12 -- Warren R. Austin, chief of the United States delegation to the United Nations, warned tonight against the dangers of plumping for "world government" as a thing that can be accomplished at once.
WESTBURY, L. I., Aug. 2 (AP) -- Lusty Song won the $10,000 Dean Hanover Trot tonight in 2:06 3-5, best mark of his career, in the feature of the Grand Circuit program at Roosevelt Raceway.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 2 (AP) -- The Athletics ended a three-game losing streak and a twenty-seven-inning scoreless drought tonight when they counted one run in the first inning and went on to defeat the White Sox, 5 -- 2, before 4,970 fans -- the smallest night turnout of the year.

Veterans of two infantry divisions of World War II fame opened three-day reunions here yesterday. Former members of the Twenty-fourth Division, known as the Victory Division, are meeting at the New Yorker Hotel, while Eighty-eighth Division veterans, nicknamed the Blue Devils, are at the Commodore Hotel.

The Mast-Foos Manufacturing Company, producer of lawn mowers, has purchased a 50 per cent interest in the farm equipment business of the Graham-Paige Motors Corporation, Joseph W. Frazer, chairman and president of Graham-Paige, announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (AP) -- The railroad industry today reported a sharp drop in net income for the first six months of 1949, compared with the same period a year ago.

ATHENS, Aug. 12 -- In the Vitsi Mountains north of the little fur-stitching center of Kastoria, sprawling beside a northern Greek lake, United States foreign policy in Eastern Europe now is being tested.

Square dances will be a feature of the Harvest Ball on Sept. 20 at the re-opening of the Pierre Cotillion Room for the winter season, which will benefit the Henry Street Settlement. The guests are being asked to come in country attire, and Ralph Tefferteller, assistant program director at the settlement and a native of Eastern Tennessee, will call the figures for the dances.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Aug. 12 -- Twenty-one and one-half million persons, representing about 70 per cent of the eligible voters in West Germany's population of about 50,000,000, are expected to go to the polls Sunday in the first free federal elections this country has enjoyed since 1933, when Hitler came into power.

ROME, Aug. 12 -- The first official Communist reply to the recent Vatican decree excommunicating all active Communists and all other persons who help to spread Communist ideas has been made by the National Office for Cultural Work of the Italian Communist party directorate.

CHICAGO, Aug. 2 -- In their aimless wanderings about the cellar depths of the National League the Cubs struck a new low for the regime of Frankie Frisch today on Wrigley Field, before 11,103 of the club's die-hard followers.
PARIS, Aug. 12 -- Originally placed pockets and bloused panel backs are two of the many features giving interest to Paquin's wearable, well-tailored coats and suits.

MUNICH, Germany, Aug. 12 -- The Bavarians are approaching Sunday's elections for a federal parliament with apathy more marked than anywhere else in Western Germany and with singularly few proofs that this state is prepared to become a mature and responsible unit of a free and democratic republic.

"So I said to myself, 'I must go up to the roof and see how the flowers are doing,'" Miss Frances Benjamin explained yesterday. She had left her stifling room on Ninety-sixth Street a few minutes earlier and was now mending a shopping bag on the terrace of the Friendship Club in the Lenox Hill Neighborhood Association, at 331 East Seventieth Street.

ATHENS, Aug. 12 -- The "Free Greece" radio, operating in Bucharest, predicted today that the Vitsi and Grammos Mountains would become "the graveyard of the National forces now engaged in an all-out drive against the Communist-led guerrillas.

The Newspaper Guild of New York, CIO, filed unfair labor practice charges yesterday with the National Labor Relations Board against The New York Post Home News, alleging that the paper's management had refused to reduce to writing an agreement reached on July 29 in the presence of a Federal mediator.

WALL, S. D., Aug. 12 -- A 14-year-old St. Paul, Minn., girl, painfully injured in an automobile accident that killed her parents, climbed an almost vertical 100-foot slope in South Dakota's badlands today to seek medical aid.

There was a marked decline in shipping activities at the Port of New York during July though airport activities increased over the corresponding period of 1948, according to customs statistics released yesterday by Harry M Durning, Collector of the Port.

DETROIT, Aug. 12 (AP) -- Virgil (Fire) Trucks gave up only two hits as he pitched the Detroit Tigers to a 4-to-1 victory over the St. Louis Browns tonight in the opener of a three-game series. It was his fourteenth victory against eight losses.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 12 (AP) -- W. Frank Marshall, Philadelphia's Receiver of Taxes, was impeached today on eight charges accusing him of mismanagement and failure to perform his duty.

Although disappointed at the White House statement opposing any reduction of excise taxes during this session of Congress, cosmetics and toiletries industry members are still hopeful of action on a bill to lift the 20 per cent retail levy on many of their products, it was learned yesterday.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Your editorial of Aug. 9 entitled "Mr. Harrington's Defiance" seems to me to have missed the three basic issues of my sermon. They were:

With the closing of title yesterday to the W. J. Sloane Building at 571-577 Fifth Avenue, southeast corner of Forty-seventh Street, Joseph Durst, operator, obtained financing of $2,350,000 on the properties. The two parcels were purchased by Mr. Durst from Gerry Estates, Inc., of which Robert L. Gerry Jr. is president.

CHICAGO, Aug. 2 -- Grain markets were irregular on the Board of Trade here today. Announcement of an export subsidy on wheat and flour failed to have much effect as a price-making influence, and there was sufficient hedging and scattered selling to result in lower prices on the active futures with the finish 1/2 cent lower to 1/4 cent higher, on the day.
Phase two of a ship grain-storage program involving more than 6,000,000 bushels of the country's surplus wheat crop was announced yesterday by the Department of Agriculture in Washington.
ANNECY, France, Aug. 12 -- One hundred and thirty-three bilateral tariff negotiations have been completed at the Annecy trade conference thus far, conference headquarters announced today.
CHICAGO, Aug. 2 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- Gen. J. Lawton Collins, a hero of the St. Lo break-through, was nominated by President Truman today to become Chief of Staff of the Army to succeed Gen. Omar N. Bradley.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Aug. 12 -- Fred Fiore, Harrison, N. Y., physical education instructor and former N. Y. U. halfback who was a member of the Eastern all-stars in 1938, gained the semi-final of the Westchester amateur golf championship at the Knollwood Country Club today.

BROOKLAWN, N. J., Aug. 12 -- Ronald Bears, 15-year-old boy scout, agreed today he probably had done his good deed for the rest of the summer. By several sweating hours' work of cleaning up the debris of a wrecked cinder block wall between the properties of two feuding neighbors, he saved one of them from a ten-day jail sentence.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (AP) -- A newspaper executive who helped bring the Reconstruction Finance Corporation into being in 1932 today urged Congress to trim the powers of the giant Government agency.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In your issue of Aug. 11 Drew Middleton reports from Munich a clash between German police and Jewish displaced persons.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 2 -- Less than a length separated first from fourth at the finish of the $17,525 Wilson Stakes at Saratoga today, with a 10-to-1 shot the winner. Members of the Gordon Glisson Rooting, Marching and Ticket-Cashing Society, who had been doing no ticket-cashing since the start of the meet yesterday, did some jigging in the aisles when the numbers went up.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: That "perilous stretch" of highway on Grand Central Parkway between Horace Harding Boulevard and the Kew Gardens Loop is exactly two miles long. I pass over it twice a day and nearly always see a wrecked car somewhere on this stretch on the morning trip or the evening trip.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- Twenty-four local housing authorities today sold $34,573,000 in short-term loan notes in competitive bidding, the Public Housing Administration announced today. The successful bids were at interest rates of .80 to .85 per cent.

DETROIT, Aug. 12 -- The last obstacle to a strike against the Ford Motor Co. was removed here today when the twenty-three-member international executive board of the United Automobile Workers, CIO, wrote a "blank check" authorization for a walkout.

LARAMIE, Wyo., Aug. 12 -- An unofficial Soil Conservation Service estimate showed today that 12,100,000 acres of land in the Great Plains, which produce the bulk of the country's wheat, should definitely be taken out of cultivation as a protective measure.
LONDON, Aug. 12 -- Further bear covering advanced British Government issues in the stock market here today and the close was at the best levels of the day, with gains up three-eighths point.
HONG KONG, Aug. 12 (UP) -- Heavy fighting was reported today in the suburbs of Kanhsien, 210 miles north of Canton, and the last major government defense base before the refugee Nationalist capital.

RYE, N. Y., Aug. 12 -- Australia won the opening match of the Davis Cup interzone round with Italy today as rain interrupted the play for two and a half hours and made it impossible to put on the second contest at the Westchester Country Club.

Joshua Logan, who returned here last night from Europe, said that he hopes to produce and direct his new play, "The Wistaria Trees," an adaptation of Chekhov's "The Cherry Orchard," on Broadway this fall.

The National Federation of American Shipping has notified constituent members of the International Chamber of Shipping that a meeting of the organization's steering committee will be held at the chamber's headquarters, in London, Nov. 8 and 9.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- Discussions with British officials over their determination to retain control of Hong Kong have thus far resulted in no firm commitments for United States assistance, Secretary of State Dean Acheson indicated today.

"Too Late for Tears," a drama about a money-mad girl whose greed leaves a trail of murder and suicide behind her, will open an engagement this morning at the Mayfair. Lizabeth Scott is the girl and her co-stars are Don DeFore and Dan Duryea.

The Indian Seamen's Club at 100 West Thirty-eighth Street, whose many turbaned and bearded visitors in the last six years have provided a colorful spectacle in New York's garment center, will close on Aug. 31, the Indian Government announced yesterday.

NEW LONDON, Conn., Aug. 12 -- The second annual American Dance Festival sponsored by Connecticut College opened tonight in the Palmer Auditorium here before an audience of enthusiasts who had defied the heat and the rain to attend this oldest and most disstinguished of modern dance festivals, which traces its origin back fifteen years to the original festivals at Bennington College.
Prospects for a pleasant, sunny week-end developed yesterday after a heavy ninety-minute rain-storm that began at 4 P. M. dropped the temperature from 84 to the day's low of 73 degrees at 4:20 P. M.

A recrudescence of Nationalist Socialist sentiment has occurred in Germany because of the pressure of post-war conditions and because of regulations imposed under occupation, Dr. Thomas Mann, the author, declared last night as he returned from three-months tour of Europe.

continuing to Aug. 19 on the Bourges system of preparing art work for reproduction was opened yesterday at the gallery of Arthur Brown Brother, art materials store, 2 West Forty-sixth Street. The system, originated by Albert Bourges, veteran photo engraver, employs Colotone and Solotone plastic sheets for achieving a variety of color, black and white tone effects in engraving reproductions of drawings and photos.

THE Lemonade Opera has unearthed another small opera by a famous composer not commonly associated with the operatic stage. He is Mendelssohn and the piece is "Die Heimkehr aus der Fremde," an hour-long, romantic fantasy that he composed in 1829 to celebrate the silver wedding anniversary of his parents.

WEST ORANGE, N. J., Aug. 13 -- Vic Ghezzi of Deal, making his first appearance in New Jersey P. G. A. competition since he won this event in 1939, walked away with the twenty-third annual championship with a record of 272 for the 72-hole tourney which was completed over the Crestmont Country Club course today.
LONDON, Aug. 13 -- The British Government today "categorically" rejected recent charges by the Rumanian Government against Roderick Sarell, Charge d'Affaires of the British Embassy in Bucharest.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 (UP) -- Controller General Lindsay C. Warren charged in a report to Congress today that millions of dollars in government revenue never reached the United States Treasury.

During the last three and one-half years many problems of rehabilitation affecting veterans and civilians have been discussed in this column. Of all the physically and mentally handicapped groups, however, there is none in greater need of public understanding and of the opportunities of a total rehabilitation program than the group who suffer from alcoholism.

PELHAM MANOR, N. Y., Aug. 13 -- Joe Angyal, host club star, who was recently crowned sculling champion of this country and Canada, turned in another standout performance today when he won the quarter-mile invitation senior single sculls event at the captains' rowing regatta conducted by the New York Athletic Club on Pelham Bay Lagoon off Travers Island.
Sam Boal in his stirring and capable "West Point of the Air" is guilty -- as so many before him have been -- of placing this remarkable group of men once again in the Army.
Congress last week gave two examples of the political virtuosity that so often has been the despair of the believers in representative government.

Re Edward S. Corwin's article, "Who Has the Power to Make War?": * * * The picture of President Wilson addressing the Congress in 1917 shows the American flag behind him hung with the stars to the onlooker's right.

IT is an interesting fact that when Napoleon at Saint Helena was engaged in justifying his decisions for posterity, he had nothing good to say about the attempt to reconquer France's richest colony. "It was a bad mistake," he told Las Cases, "to try and force it [Haiti] into submission.

CHICAGO, Aug. 13 (AP) -- Bill Fischer, Notre Dame guard, was chosen by newsmen as the most valuable player on the college all-star football team which lost by 38 -- 0 to the Philadelphia Eagles last night.

Nearly three-fourths of the public school systems in the United States did not have any program of religious education during the 1948-49 school year, according to a nation-wide survey by the research division of the National Education Association, released last week.

The American Radio Association, CIO, offered yesterday to help members of the Radio Officers Union, AFL, either individually or organizationally, to obtain a shorter watch spread similar to that awarded to them last Wednesday after an arbitration hearing.

NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 13 -- Pakistan's second anniversary as a nation tomorrow may be her last as a dominion in the British Commonwealth, in the opinion of highly place Pakistanis interviewed here and in Karachi this summer.

" DAD says he's all right, but how can he be when he goes around in a costume like that?" asked Bob Sullivan, American boy on a visit to China. Bob soon found, however, that his young Chinese host wore the old-style clothes only at home, that he could out-box Bob, that he knew two languages to Bob's one, and enjoyed mystery as much as any junior sleuth in the States.

STOCKHOLM, Aug. 13 (UP) -- A crowd of 43,000, largest in Scandinavian boxing history, was expected to jam Raasunda Stadium tomorrow night for the 12-round heavyweight match between Jersey Joe Walcott of Camden, N. J., and Olle Tandberg, Swedish champion.

The American "experiment" in the Philippines, aimed at fitting a dependent people for democratic self rule, has long been considered one of the most successful examples of United States foreign policy. Its result -- the establishment three years ago of the free Republic of the Philippines -- was seen as proof of America's ability to export democracy.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- Senator J. Howard McGrath of Rhode Island, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, today called a meeting of the committee for Aug. 24 in Washington, to elect his successor. Senator McGrath has been nominated by President Truman to be Attorney General of the United States and his confirmation is expected next week.

Dr. Slichter's article in THE NEW YORK TIMES Magazine, entitled "The Upturn in Business Is Not Far Away," is both highly informative and provocative. His argument, as usual, is well supported by pertinent data and careful analysis.

NEWPORT, R. I., Aug. 13 -- The Misses Anne Colby and Elsie French Vanderbilt, twin daughters of former Governor William H. Vanderbilt and Mrs. Vanderbilt entertained 150 at a large dinner dance at the Clambake Club here this evening.

STRASBOURG, France, Aug. 13 -- In front of the main building of the University of Strasbourg, where the first meeting of the Council of Europe is convened, stands a heroic statue of Pallas Athene. Seen from a distance the gilded lady seems to be peering down the Avenue de la Liberte from under a raised left hand in the attitude of an old Western plainsman looking for a waterhole or a marauding Indian band.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- The Atomic Energy Commission today announced establishment of a three-man temporary advisory committee to recommend ways for cooperation with the electric power industry in the reactor development program.
Record temperatures again adversely affected retail trade here last week. Department store sales were estimated at 15 per cent or more below the same week last year.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- The new bipartisan compromise farm bill which was unanimously voted Thursday by a seven-member agriculture subcommittee ran into opposition and delay today.

Advances in our knowledge of the functioning of the brain have provided evidence that the difference between the intellectually gifted and those of average mentality, or even lower, lies not in the structure of the brain itself but in the manner in which the billions of brain cells are nourished, and in the quality and quantity of the nourishment they receive through the circulation.

NEW LONDON, Conn., Aug. 13 -- The second performance in the American Dance Festival sponsored by Connecticut College in Palmer Auditorium was a matinee program today by the Dudley-Maslow-Bales trio, assisted by the New Dance Group.

THIS book is by one of the leading members of the Vienna school of the philosophy of science, for many years domiciled in this country as lecturer on philosophy and physics at Harvard University. It consists of an introduction and sixteen chapters, most of which appeared at one time or another as essays.

A FELLOW who has been on vacation finds upon his return that the doggondest things have been happening. Every amateur expert he has met has portentously declared: "If the Yankees beat out the Indians for the pennant, the turning point came when Larry Doby made his crazy attempt to steal home with the bases full and none out a few weeks ago."
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 13 -- Under cover of a leaden sky the Yankees almost had their backs pinned to the floor today.

PROFESSOR BRADEN of Northwestern University is one of the most careful and instructive reporters of today's religious thought and activities. In this book on American cults and minority religious movements he presents some of the recent phenomena.
QUITO, Ecuador, Aug. 13 (UP) -- The Venezuelan military junta today donated $1,000,000 for relief of the survivors of last week's earthquake.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- A reported plan to use the Reconstruction Finance Corporation to get the foreign arms program started on a large scale was criticized sharply today by Senator Burnet R. Maybank, Democrat, of South Carolina, chairman of the Senate Banking and Currency Committee.

Seventy new cases of poliomyelitis were reported yesterday to the Department of Health, the highest number in any twenty-four-hour period so far this year. It brought the total number of victims of the disease to 918 since Jan. 1.

SOME of the doom has been taken out of the gloom which was spread over business prospects not so long ago, and there has been a general perking up process going on over recent weeks. The results trade-wise are not apparent for the simple reason that heat and the polio scare have been taking toll of sales.

THE only satisfactory times to plant or replant the oriental poppy are during its dormant period in August or the period of early fall growth in September. Placed in a permanent location when set out, they are divided only for the purpose of obtaining more plants.

Ozie Harold Johnson, Dean of the School of Law of the Texas State University for Negroes, Houston, Tex., in a letter to THE NEW YORK TIMES, has called attention to certain regrettable errors and omissions in a Houston dispatch published in THE TIMES on July 24.

CHICAGO, Aug. 13 (AP) -- James Liguori lost part of his basement today. But one of his two puppies was alive, thanks to twelve hours of hard work by police, firemen, the Animal Welfare League and the city's sewer department.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 13 (UP) -- A powerful six-man Japanese team, tired after its thirty-six-hour flight from Tokyo, arrived today for the United States national swimming championships next week. They are the first Japanese athletes to compete in the United States since before the war.

According to newspaper reports, Great Britain; in order to meet new balance of payments difficulties, is seeking a substantial increase in her share of Marshall Plan aid for the second year, and it is proposed that the amounts going to other countries should be cut, the severest cut ($150-$200 millions) to be borne by Italy.
FOURTEEN-year-old Hoxie and his little sister Irene are half-Indians, orphans, who live at an Indian school in Oregon. They accept an invitation to visit their great-aunt, whom they have never seen.
ATLANTA, Ga., Aug. 14 -- Margaret Mitchell, author of "Gone With the Wind," was "definitely improved" today but her condition still is critical, physicians reported early tonight.

CHICAGO, Aug. 13 (AP) -- Selling from commission houses and local traders pushed grain prices lower today on the Board of Trade. Losses ran to around 2 cents in corn at times and dealings, slow at the start, picked up speed as prices slid late in the session.

With increased employe efficiency and productivity a major factor in store cost reduction programs, leading stores here and throughout the country are offering larger employe benefits and incentive plans to obtain better results.

THE Secretary of the Treasury, John W. Snyder, startled skeptics at a press conference recently when he declared that the public "very appropriately can find $1 billion to put into savings bonds." The occasion was the opening of the so-called Opportunity Drive to persuade Americans to invest their money as regularly in bonds now as they did during the war -- when these same Series E bonds were called, appropriately, war bonds.
CHICAGO, Aug. 13 -- The Chicago area began to run out of gasoline today, with thousands of gallons stored in the city out of reach of consumers.

BOOKS are able ambassadors -- though, like the frock-and-protocol-coated kind, they can do only so much to drum up love among nations. Still, it would be a fine idea were every Russian, say, given a chance to read freely in our best books, and were we able to do as much in theirs.

Moving to prevent transshipment of strategic materials to unlicensed destinations, the Office of International Trade took its first definite action last week in a case involving such violation of export regulations. OIT stopped an attempt to ship ball bearings to Czechoslovakia under a license giving Belgium as the ultimate destination.

SAVANNAH, Ga., Aug. 13 -- Clarks Hill Dam, the $76,000,000 key unit in the vast Savannah River Basin project designed to provide multi-purpose river resources for two Southern States, is now one-third completed.

" TAKE heed what you put into the King's head, for you can never get it out again," Cardinal Wolsey said shortly before he died in disgrace. A really willful man at a crucial point in history is a challenging subject for the serious biographer, and the ideas in Henry VIII's head are still the essential ideas of modern nationalism and the heritage of the Reformation.

CENTERPORT, L. I., Aug. 13 -- Eagle's Nest, the forty-three-acre estate of the late William K. Vanderbilt, was formerly transferred to Suffolk County by the trustees under Mr. Vanderbilt's will at ceremonies here today.
CHICAGO, Aug. 13 (AP) -- Dutch Leonard finally got some batting support today and he pitched the Chicago Cubs to a 5-4 victory over the Cincinnati Reds before a gathering of 14,097.

APPROPRIATELY enough, this is summer fare, with much action and mystification (at least Hortense Clinton, the heroine, is mystified), some aggressively bright chatter, and a rather surprising broad jump from Manhattan to a resort hotel in Nova Scotia.

LONDON, Aug. 13 -- Britain's emphasis in the Washington dollar talks next month is expected by well-informed persons in London to be placed on increasing the dollar earning capacity of the British Commonwealth and colonies as distinct from the United Kingdom itself.

PIERMONT, N. Y., Aug. 13 -- The excursion boat Ossining, with nobody aboard, suddenly burst into flames at about 4:50 o'clock this afternoon while she was being towed by a tug down the Hudson River to Jersey City.

MESSRS. TEKEYAN and Freund -- one a newcomer, not to say a novice, the other an author established enough to have written a book called "How to Become a Literary Critic" -- are both like that beautiful youth who saw his own reflection in a fountain and was entranced.

MRS. FOSTER'S distinguished writing has again enriched our historical literature for children. No ordinary skill could create in such a brief volume, in such simple language, a thrilling new biography of George Washington.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- As the State Department begins its review of the policy the United States is to follow in the Far East of the future, it is possible to obtain only the most general outlines of what is likely to emerge. Many counsels will be heard and many brains will be cudgeled before any firm conclusions are reached, if they can be reached.

FERNDALE, N. Y., Aug. 13 -- Mrs. Hazel Barr, Queens Village housewife and mother of two children, captured her sixth women's diving championship in two years as she led the field in the revived New York State title event today at the Grossinger Country Club Olympic pool.

Vigorous August coat and suit promotions and heavy reorders have failed so far to bring fall ready-to-wear business up to last year's level, according to a report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES. In the wholesale apparel market here last week reorders were received for fancy worsted and tweed suits.
SHRUBS with white flowers suit places in the garden where plain green would be too dull and colored flowers too overpowering.

ATLANTA, Aug. 13 -- Unusually warm weather continued a big factor in slowing retail sales in the Southeast last week. All leading centers experienced declines for both the week and four weeks. Cattle arrivals at Montgomery, Memphis, Louisville and at eight major packing plants in Georgia, Florida and Alabama totaled about 16,000 head in comparison with 13,800 last week and 21,200 head the same week last year.

GRINDELWALD, Switzerland -- Many American tourists, having caught a glimpse of the Paris boulevards, the ruins of Rome and London's bobbies, are likely to leave for home again without ever having stepped off the tourist trail long enough to discover any of Europe's less extensively publicized but equally spectacular scenic spots.

A rabbi and his wife -- the former a fugitive and the latter under arrest in Bellevue Hospital, after giving birth to a boy Friday morning -- are accused by the police of having swindled Israeli sympathizers here of more than $250,000 in less than ten weeks.
ENGLEWOOD, N. J., Aug. 13 -- A cat with a weakness for hitch-hiking gambled on two-ninths of his life expectancy here today by riding uninvited astride the rear axle of two different automobiles.

A suggestion that a Western Hemisphere Import-Export Conference be held to wrestle with the growing problem of the dollar famine among Latin-American countries has been suggested in Uruguay and is under discussion by foreign trade groups here, it was learned yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- As part of its program for the perfection of guided missiles, the Air Force will start next week a series of additional tests to determine the character of the atmosphere up to 75 miles above the earth's surface, it was announced today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- The nimbus of elder statesmanship from which all personal ambition has vanished enveloped Herbert Hoover when he addressed the nation this week on the occasion of his seventy-fifth birthday. Consequently, though the substance of his appeal and warning to his fellow-countrymen was not his first, and other distinguished Americans have uttered it lately in increasing measure, the effect of Mr. Hoover's words on Washington was palpable.

DAVID LORD knows Jewish life intimately, and his portraits of the denizens of Joey Levine's neighborhood, in the Boyle Heights section of Los Angeles, are reminiscent of those novels which have described life among the Jews on New York's East Side.

IN this successor to "Let's Go Outdoors" and "Let's Go to the Seashore" Mrs. Huntington introduces the child to fascinating aspects of the American desert. Striking photographs show the bizarre beauties of the ocotillo, the Joshua tree, various kinds of cacti, followed by close-ups of their respective fruits or flowers.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 (AP) -- President Truman has scheduled four out-of-town speaking engagements in the next few weeks, starting with an address before the Veterans of Foreign Wars at Miami, Fla., on Aug. 22.

Squalls with accompanying wind and seas yesterday cut the championship regatta of the Bayside Yacht Club to a small group of venturesome sailors. Only thirty-one craft started and one of them, Jerry Fagan's One-Ten Lady Jim, was dismasted.

REGULAR releases are being issued here under three labels from across the Atlantic and a comment on the most interesting recordings at hand is in order. The companies are London Gramophone Corp., Deutsche Gramophon Gesellschaft and Capitol-Telefunken.

An estimated 6,000 persons have died and fifty towns and villages have been devastated in the earthquake in Ecuador. Such quakes come without warning and there is no way of predicting them. They arise from a quick shock which is produced when the rocks in the earth's crust suddenly yield to strain; they occur five to twenty-five miles below the surface.

The Government move toward channeling a portion of Federal purchasing into eleven areas designated as hard-hit by industrial unemployment was criticized last week by marketing research authorities as ignoring economic as well as political fundamentals.

ONE of the few satisfactory radio dramatic shows which has come along this summer can be heard on the NBC network each Thursday (10:30 P. M.) under the title "Dragnet." The stories are adaptations of true cases taken from the files of the Los Angeles Police Department.
FIRE ISLAND, L. I. -- This island, which has been a haven for the few, is gradually being prepared for a new use as a summer playground for thousands of New Yorkers.
ATHENS, Aug. 13 -- A special communique issued by the General Staff tonight said that Government forces had reached the village of Mikrolimni and in doing so had cut the Vitsi sector in two.

TO celebrate a century of mountain climbing in New York State, members of more than a dozen hiking clubs in the East will make a centennial climb to the summit of Mount Haystack on Saturday. Mount Haystack, fourth highest of the Adirondack Mountain peaks, is 4,918 feet above sea level.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 (AP) -- A downward trend in contract awards for public construction has shown up in some of the major centers of unemployment, Jess Larson, General Services Administrator, said today. In some cases awards for private construction also have dropped sharply, he said.
THIS is a book born partly out the loneliness of soul, partly out of one man's sensitive reaction against the "clock and machine" tone of our civilization.

HEWLETT, L. I., Aug. 13 -- Peter K. Davis and John Desiderio of the Clearview club, winners of the medal honors with a 69, led the way into the semi-final round of the fifteenth annual Arthur Man Memorial member-guest golf tournament at the Seawane Harbor Club today with a 6 and 4 victory over Herb Kleigl and Abbot Van Nostrand Jr., Pomonok.

FRANKFORT, Aug. 13 -- When the people of Western Germany troop to the polls tomorrow to elect a Bundestag (Parliament) of the German Federal Republic, they will set in motion a chain of events which within months will complete the establishment of that republic and inaugurate a new relationship between Germany and the rest of the world.

Fears that seller's market conditions are returning in many industrial materials have caused company purchasing agents to start tightening up requirements for vendor performance, it was learned here yesterday.

WHEN the American and Russian forces met along the Elbe and Mulde in Germany in the war's twilight of April, 1945, military hospitality proceeded somewhat cautiously, at first. Unlike the GI's, who drank in hilarious comradeship, the American and Russian regimental commanders exchanged the field equivalent of calling cards and met in a rather gingerly way for drinks and dinner.

STRAGGLING across a green headland that juts into Penobscot Bay, Rockland, Me., looks, at first glance, like any New England seaport that has grown and prospered without losing any of the individual flavor of a small town. Past and present meet in its seemingly endless Main Street, where late Victorian municipal buildings confront quick-lunch rooms; divide in the tree-shaded streets whose prim white and yellow clapboard houses simply ignore the Woolworth-Texaco civilization around the corner.

When President Quirino addressed the House of Representatives last Tuesday he said: "I have come to your country in furtherance of mutual understanding between your country and mine; for the preservation not only of freedom and prosperity but also of the peace of the world in our part of the globe."

IF it were anyone else in her position who was reaching her seventieth birthday on Monday, she probably would be designated "the grand old lady of the American theatre." But with Ethel Barrymore that epithet seems singularly unsuitable.
HONG KONG, Aug. 13 (UP) -- The Chinese Communists today isolated the east coast port of Foochow and cut off the key defense city of Kanhsien, 210 miles north of Canton.

THE facts and figures expert for MAP -- the vast military assistance program proposed by the President -- is a former radio "ham" of Sleepy Eye, Minn., who has traveled up a long road with few halts for napping, but with a lot of time spent in looking.

The police recovered yesterday afternoon the body of a 10-year-old boy who had been missing from his home since Friday afternoon. The body was found in a water-filled excavation in a vacant lot at Tremont Avenue and West Farms Road.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- Maj. Gen. Harry H. Vaughan, President Truman's military aide, assumed full responsibility today for the gifts of deep-freeze units to himself and other persons close to the Chief Executive. He issued a statement to the press giving his side of the controversy and denying any impropriety.

LONDON, Aug. 13 (Reuters) -- After scoring 233 runs for the loss of three wickets by the tea interval, New Zealand had 320 for eight at close of play on the first day of the fourth and final cricket test against England at the Oval today. The previous tests were drawn.

ABOARD UNION PACIFIC'S CITY OF SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 13 -- Herbert Hoover was in a chipper mood tonight, discounting a gall bladder attack that struck him as he traveled across the country to keep commitments in New York.

A delegation of union officers last week visited Maximilian Moss, president of the New York City Board of Education, to urge him to refuse to enforce the Feinberg law, which prohibits subversive persons from holding public school jobs. A few hours afterward the board's law committee held its first meeting preliminary to putting the law into operation.

TWO guides to the United States have been published simultaneously and competitively, and the tourist, travel writer or editor who traverses this country literally, or in his imagination, without knowing that Nashua is the second city in size in the state of New Hampshire and that its United States Fish Hatchery has sixteen rearing ponds in a thirty-five-acre tract on Broad Street, now has only himself to blame.

SCHIERSTEIN, Hesse (By Wireless). ALTHOUGH the air is clear and sunsets are lovely along the Rhine these summer evenings, the women of Schierstein complain that their men-folk spend their evening hours in hot debate at the Nassauerhof, a little restaurant and bar that stands at the head of a cobbled street looking down toward the river.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 13 -- The West Coast will be surprised if much autumnal snow falls on the High Sierra before James Roosevelt, eldest son of the late President, makes a forthright declaration of his candidacy for the Governorship of California. And Coast residents were becoming intrigued over the possibility of seeing a California Republican primary in which Governor Earl Warren would be challenged by a fellow Republican, Lieutenant Governor Goodwin J. Knight.

THE adventure - romances of Hammond Innes are not easy to classify. To some extent they suggest Erskine Childers, whose classic "The Riddle of the Sands" you may remember; they have even been compared, somewhat extravagantly, to those of John Buchan.

INCREASED competition among states and resorts for a larger share of the motor tourists' dollars is nearing the pre-war peak, according to a survey by the American Automobile Association. The "take it or leave it" attitude adopted in many sections during the lush days of the post-war period has disappeared, it is reported, and a spirit of courtesy and hospitality is being emphasized throughout the country.

West Coast shipping men are expecting a showdown with the International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union, CIO, if the prospective reopening of Hawaiian trade materializes under Hawaiian Government auspices.

American Airlines, in conjunction with the Navy, has just completed a long series of test flights with air-borne radar in one of the company's fleet of two-engined Convairs that engineers regard as having brought all-weather flying closer to actuality.

INDIVIDUAL reactions to the glass and steel house which Designer Philip C. Johnson has built for himself in New Canaan, Conn., are apt to be very personal -- and as divergent as personal reactions usually are. One visitor might find it stark and cold; another, welcoming. It might be considered as modern as tomorrow, or as antique -- in concept -- as a Greek temple.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., Aug. 13 -- Favored teams advanced to the quarter-finals today in the member-guest golf tournament at the Garden City Country Club. The medalists, William J. Byrne Sr. and Charles Amandoles of Latourette routed Johnny Dobbs and Bill Govern of Wheatley Hills, 5 and 4.

THOSE sounds of bottles chinking and harsh voices batting the summer breeze possibly may be "the boys" in town again. Once a year they hold their division reunion to recount the stories which, unlike some of the storytellers, never seem to fade. The Army's Historical Section, which takes a fatherly interest in these get-togethers, notes that the military fraternal season reaches its peak just about now.

Reading David Cushman Coyle's "No Splintering of Our Party System," I could not help reflecting that perhaps America is politically doomed to a two-party-one-philosophy system, the terms "Republican" and "Democratic" signifying not two divergent political credos, but politically identical camps.

EDWARD SMALL, independent producer, who has more regard for the box-office than for the critics, ended eleven years of alarums and excursions last week, with the disclosure that Tony Dexter, an unknown, will play the role of Rudolph Valentino, in the biography of the silent screen star, which Small has been about to film ever since 1938.

A proposed merger between the two largest veterans' organizations open exclusively to those who fought in the second World War -- the American Veterans Committee and the American Veterans of World War II -- has been approved by their national commanders, subject to approval later in the year by the membership in national conventions.

BOSTON, Aug. 13 -- Mighty Assault, the King Ranch's 1946 triple champion attempting a comeback, wound up out of the money in a five-horse field today as the Cherry Oca Stable's 4-year-old First Nighter stormed into a head victory over Brookmead's Going Away in the $50,000-added Massachusetts Handicap at Suffolk Downs.

THIS guide to the fun of fishing is likely to win a wide audience among boys, be they 9 or 90. The authors (both experts, although they modestly disclaim it) do an effective job of sparking up theories and hard facts with stories from their own experiences.

NEW DELHI, Aug. 13 (AP) -- Walter White, executive secretary of the National Association for Advancement of Colored People, said today he and Poppy Cannon, a white woman, were married July 6 and were collaborating on a book about racial discrimination.

THOSE who relish, as I do, the exploits of Dr. Fu Manchu -- the finest achievements in their field since Hamilton Cleek renounced the throne of Mauravania -- will be desolated to learn that this time the creator of the insidious doctor has devoted his talents to nothing more exotic than a standard British countryside houseparty murder.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 13 -- The resignation of Foreign Minister Juan Atilio Bramuglia was accepted by President Juan D. Peron after an extraordinary Cabinet meeting this morning at which Hipolito Jesus Paz, a 32-year-old lawyer, was named Dr. Bramuglia's successor. The new Foreign Minister will be sworn in Tuesday.
THE tall, slender boy with wavy brown hair, wry amusement glinting in his proud dark eyes, pauses to ask a light for his American cigarette on the dirt road leading to his block house. His name?

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Aug. 13 (AP) -- Trygve Lie, Secretary General of the United Nations, said tonight that "there has been too much loose talk about a third world war and it is time that this talk stopped."

CHICAGO, Aug. 13 (AP) -- Curtice, a fast finishing son of Roman, today carried the colors of Mrs. Emil Denemark, Chicago, to a surprising three-quarters of a length victory over the Calumet Farm's Re-Armed in the $72,750 Washington Park Futurity.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 13 (AP) -- Federal Judge Michael J. Roche today denied a motion to acquit the woman known as Tokyo Rose of treason charges.

CHICAGO, Aug. 13 (AP) -- Training courses for "straw bosses" have become an indispensable tool in modern business and industry. With this thesis, the University of Illinois has just published a bulletin discussing the "why, what, how" of a training program for management.

ANNECY, France, Aug. 13 -- The contracting parties to the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, twenty-three nations responsible as a body for overseeing compliance with the Geneva trade agreement of 1947, ended their third session here today.

BOOTHBAY HARBOR, Me., Aug. 13 -- Harold Brown of New York City held the lead of fifty-one pounds he established on the second day of fishing in Maine's fourth annual tuna tournament when only the slight competition of a 138-pound school fish resulted from today's fishing.

Strasbourg before the Second World War was a place where tourists stopped over on their way to the Rhine, the Black Forest, and Switzerland. It was a pleasant, open city with at least one restaurant approved by high authorities on French cuisine.

ALTHOUGH the flower arranger builds a composition along certain classic lines, she is -- whether aware of it or not -- influenced by prevailing modes and mores. Modern American arrangements, for the most part, show a somewhat stylized and intellectual approach, typical of the times.
Rent control has grown more complex nationally and locally and rents have risen steadily since the amended Federal controls went into effect last April 1. The prospect is that they will go higher.

HOLLYWOOD. THE recent intelligence that a couple of fellows named Epstein had been engaged to write and direct a film for Samuel Goldwyn presumably sent no boulders crashing down Alpine slopes nor caused any Australian bushman to choke on his planked platypus.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Aug. 13 -- A former Army Air Force major, 33-year-old Lloyd Ribner of Fenway, became the Westchester amateur golf champion today by beating Fred Fiore, physical education instructor and one-time N. Y. U. football player, 2 up, at the Knollwood Country Club.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 24 -- King Farouk of Egypt has launched a program for the establishment in Madrid of an Arabic Islamic institute to renew contact between the living Arabic culture of today and the Arabic Islamic heritage in Spain, which was one of the three or four greatest centers of Arabic civilization in its golden age.
MALVERN, England, Aug. 13 -- There are two ways of taking George Bernard Shaw's new play, "Buoyant Billions," produced here today on the last day of the first week of the revived Malvern Festival.
ODESSA, Tex., Aug. 13 (AP) -- Tuskegee Institute made a runaway of the junior division of the National AAU women's track and field meet last night, rolling up 87 points.

ANN CROWFORD, 16, and a junior in high school, was an absolute social flop and she knew it. Trying to analyze the techniques and tactics by which the girls around her won the attentions of the boys in the class was useless, for she just couldn't seem to get the hang of easy repartee and careful casualness.

An official of the New York Yankees of the All-America Football Conference revealed yesterday that Len Dobelstein, a star New York Giants' guard for the past three seasons, has been working out at the Yankees' training camp at Cheshire, Conn., for the past week, The United Press reported.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Aug. 13 (AP) -- The Czechoslovak Army, concluding its summer maneuvers near the nation's frontier with Western Germany, was told today by Defense Minister Gen. Ludvik Svoboda that "these borders will remain Czechoslovak forever."
WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 (UP) -- The cost of race segregation comes high in the seventeen states where separate school systems are maintained for Negroes and whites.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Aug. 13 -- On the eve of tomorrow's election, to the Lower House of the Parliament of the German Federal Republic, Western Germany's party leaders turned from attacks upon the occupation powers to the basic issue facing their countrymen: Socialism versus a free economy.

FOR uncloying fragrance in the garden and piquant flavor in fruit cups and beverages, the herbs with lemon-scented foliage are unexcelled. Some of these plants grow readily from seed and others are propagated by cuttings or division.

The new passenger liner African Endeavor, sister ship of the African Enterprise, which is now on her maiden voyage to South Africa, will leave New York on her initial trip to Capetown Aug. 31, it was announced by Farrell Lines, operators of the vessel.

Carl Williams of Washington, D. C., the top-seeded entrant, and Jeff Craig of Plainfield, N. J., the defending titleholder, were upset in the men's singles group of the annual New York State Negro open championships yesterday at the Cosmopolitan Tennis Club courts.

SHOOTING a picture on a city street is the same the whole world over. Whether it is a street in New York or in Los Angeles, or in London or wherever you please, a motion picture camera and a filming crew are an irresistible magnet for the citizenry.

Three men and the 14-year-old son of one of them, starting out for a cruise on the Harlem River, were burned about the head and body yesterday as an explosion destroyed a twenty-six-foot cabin cruiser.

INDIAN literature, which during the past two decades has found its most poignant expression in the Bengali language, is caught today in a crossfire of political ideas. While the Communist party of India seeks to rally the literary community to its standards, the official Congress party tends to encourage literary development in a super-patriotic vein.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 (UP) -- A renking member of the House Armed Services Committee said tonight he would demand that the author or authors of an anonymous document alleging corruption in the Air Force's B-36 bomber purchase program be called to testify.

THE term triple-threat man, usually confined to newspaper sports pages, in recent years has become almost as commonplace in the film world. Laurence Olivier, Orson Welles, Robert Montgomery and Richard Whorf have demonstrated versatility and won acclaim by serving in the triple capacity of writer, director and actor on a number of films.

GLEN COVE, L. I., Aug. 13 -- Taxpayers, principally estate owners, have asked the city of Glen Cove for almost $1,000,000 in reductions on their assessments for 1950, it was learned today following the counting of protests filed this week with the city assessor, Eliot Whitely.

THAT part of the capitalistic machine which emits the loudest squeaks is labor relations. How the prices of most things are arrived at is explained in the textbooks, but not so with wages and the terms of employment, which make up the price of labor.

Ninety-nine reporters crowded into the Executive office in the White House last Thursday for President Truman's 193d press conference. Washington was hot, but the President was chatty and affable. In the course of the fifteen-minute conference, the reporters threw forty-two questions to him.
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 13 -- John Frazier, 68 years old, today sought $100,000 damages from a judge who haled him into court on grounds that his "inhuman, giraffe-like" laughter disturbed the peace.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 13 -- Strikebound since May 1, the Hawaiian Islands this week-end waited for the Territorial Government to plunge seriously into the stevedoring business. Impatient over the failure of the islands' stevedoring companies and the striking longshoremen to settle their costly dispute, the Territorial Legislature authorized Governor Ingram M. Stainback to seize and operate the waterfronts.

THE history of North Carolina, as Mr. Harden observes, began with an unsolved mystery: the cryptic one-word message left behind by the vanished colony of Roanoke Island. It is meet that the state should continue its tradition of giving birth to the inexplicable; and John Harden earns our gratitude by gathering twenty of the more mysterious Tarheel phenomena into this volume.

More than two-thirds of the German people in approximately one-half of the former Reich go to the polls today to elect a new national Parliament as the cornerstone of a new national Government in a new German state to be known as the Federal Republic of Germany.

BOSTON, Aug. 13 -- Vern Stephens couldn't have selected a more opportune time today for his thirtieth home run of the season, lining it into the left field nets with three Red Sox mates on base in the twelfth inning for a 5-1 Boston decision over the Washington Senators.

A COMBUSTIBLE subject flared up recently when an eminent British scholar, speaking of public art collections in Southern California, remarked to a reporter of The Los Angeles Daily News: "Here, on an impressive platter, the students are served muck."
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 13 (UP) -- Vice President Alben W. Barkley met Mrs. Carleton S. Hadley at the Municipal Airport here today and flew with her to Paducah, Ky., to meet the hometown folks.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Aug. 13 (AP) -- A tense racial zoning row erupted today in the dynamiting of two Negro ministers' homes and answering gunfire by Negroes guarding the houses.
MIAMI -- Florida's east coast tourist centers this summer are counting their visitors in plain numbers, not in dollars and cents, and the total is mounting pretty high.

ALMOST swamped by local color, the slim, engaging story of Wheeler, an undersized London urchin, who had his day of fame in the fourteenth year of Queen Victoria's "retirement," emerges from Mr. Bonnet's pages as a semi-historical novel.

PATERSON, N. J., Aug. 13 -- David L. Cole of this city, president of the board of trustees of the Shapiro Foundation, 1441 Broadway, New York, announced today the award of scholarships to sixty-seven young men and women in thirty-three colleges and universities.

IT is just a trifle over 1,000 miles from New York City to the tip of Canada's famed Gaspe Peninsula -- over concrete, macadam, tar, gravel, dirt and sometimes loose stones. But it is a journey into another century and another land.

GLASGOW, Aug. 13 (Reuters) -- The soccer season began in Scotland today, a week in advance of the English schedule, and a crowd of 70,000 watched Celtic trip the Rangers, 3 -- 2, in the day's top match. Left-winger Haugney, a newcomer to Celtic, scored the winning goal in the second half.

RUNNING through our mind as these second thoughts on a handful of newly arrived movies begin to take form, typographically at least, is the question, "What makes a motion picture good?" Generally speaking, the answer could be "a balanced combination of artistic and mechanical elements all dovetailing to form a precise pattern."

NEWPORT, R. I., Aug. 13 -- Richard (Pancho) Gonzales of Los Angeles, and Gardnar Mulloy of Coral Gables, Fla., the top-seeded players, today registered impressive victories to gain the final of the Newport casino invitation tennis tournament.

JERUSALEM, Aug. 12 -- Three of the ancient Hebrew scrolls discovered by a Bedouin near Jericho in 1947, and now in the possession of Hebrew University here, were today described by Prof. E. L. Sukenik, Professor of Palestinian Archaeology at the university and a director of the Museum of Jewish Antiquities, as the greatest discovery in the field of Hebrew text.

FOR THIS WEEK: Spray weeds in bluestone or ash driveways with a weedkiller or salt solution (one pound of salt in one gallon of hot water). . . . Feed dahlias with liquid fertilizer and start to disbud the flower stems.

BOSTON, Aug. 13 -- The season's fourth heat wave, pouring in across New England with record-breaking 100-degree temperatures this week, slowed down all normal activity to a walk. City streets were comparatively deserted by mid-afternoon as many business houses and most government offices released workers early.
GEORGE SANTAYANA, one of the deans of the philosophic world -- he is now in his eighty-sixth year -- has decided to learn about modern English and American poetry.

With a frankness that was in refreshing contrast to the "disclosures" of some top executives, Maj. Gen. William H. Harrison, president of the $540,000,000 International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, yesterday gave his views on the affairs of the world-wide communications system. It was his first press interview since he assumed the post on last Sept. 1.

More general adoption of pre-packaging processes for meat and other products can be speeded through demonstrating the technique's value as a competitive cost and price-cutting factor, it was recommended yesterday by packaging industry officials.

PERRYOPOLIS, Pa., Aug. 13 -- Streets, street-lights, shade trees and parks, an educational center, a municipal building and a water and sewage system are what this village has decided to buy with the nearly $1,320,000 it inherited a year ago for civic improvement, it was announced today.

In "West Point of the Air," Sam Boal reveals rather admiringly that the Training Command at Randolph Field suffers from a series of elementary misconceptions about what constitutes a man and an officer.

BERLIN, Aug. 13 -- The Office of Military Government of the United States announced here today that it would move to Frankfort tomorrow. Berlin city officials expressed some surprise that the "expected" announcement had been made before the new Western German government had been activated but felt compensating satisfaction in learning that the United States was planning to send direct Marshall Plan aid to Western Berlin.

LAKE SUCCESS, Aug. 13 -- Fleet Admiral Chester W. Nimitz said today that he had been greatly encouraged by the decision of India and Pakistan to start direct negotiations for a truce in Kashmir, and that he hoped an agreement could be reached by the end of August.

DETROIT, Aug. 13 -- The deadline for a possible strike against the Ford Motor Company, by the United Automobile Workers, CIO, was set for Sept. 13 today when the State Labor Mediation Board certified the returns of the recent strike election.

QUITE often there are locations where repeated attempts at growing grass fail to produce good results. In such situations, groundcovers are the answer, for they give fine coverage in areas that would otherwise be completely bare -- at any rate, unattractive.

PARIS, Aug. 13 -- There will be no solution to the problem of Europe without at least partly solving the problem of integrating Germany into the European system, Foreign Minister Robert Schuman declared in an interview published today in the Parisian daily newspaper Monde.

WHILE awaiting the Albert Camus play, "The Halter," and the dramatization of Ludwig Lewisohn's novel, "The Case of Mr. Crump," the firm of Robert Whitehead and Oliver Rea is working on other projects. They hope to duplicate the quality of "Medea" and "Crime and Punishment" with an adaptation of Chekhov's "The Cherry Orchard," to be entitled "With No Awakening," and a revival of Pinero's "The Magistrate."

The new increase in freight rates granted the railroads last week by the Interstate Commerce Commission will go a long way toward easing the burdens of the carriers in shifting the work week of non-operating employes from a six-day to a five-day basis.
