For certainly Miss McCarthy's style is almost perfect -- almost too perfect in its avoidance of pathos and delight.
SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 13 -- The Man o' War Cup, which goes to the winning owner in the Travers Stakes for 3-year-olds, is Toronto bound.
BOSTON -- Promotional - minded Florida has turned to statistical-minded New England for advice on how to interpret tourist trends.
Maritime labor leaders are planning to bombard members of Congress with demands for the employment of American ships in the transport of cargo under the foreign military aid bill.
CHICAGO, Aug. 13 -- Buck White and Johnny Palmer rolled into a 54-hole deadlock at 11-under-par 205 today, only one stroke ahead of Sam Snead in the Tam O'Shanter $35,000 "world" pro golf tourney.

CHICAGO, Aug. 13 (UP) -- President Ford Frick of the National League, here on business today, studied the protest of Manager Burt Shotton of the Brooklyn Dodgers over Umpire Art Gore's decision which changed a long hit by Duke Snider from a home run to a triple in last night's 5-to-3 defeat by the Boston Braves.

OF all of the creatures that live upon this earth there are but a few about which nothing good can be said. The mosquito, whose nuisance value has been attested in writings from every era of human civilization, is a charter member of this group.

MILWAUKEE. Aug. 13 (AP) -- There may have been some defective steel in the cabinets of the deep freeze units sent to several top Washington officials, an officer of the firm which made the cabinets said tonight.
Extension of Federal subsidies to the field of tramp shipping was recommended to the Maritime Commission last week by the agency's Tramp Shipping Committee following a two-year study.

OFF SANTA CRUZ ISLAND, Calif., Aug. 13 -- The five-foot steel ball in which scientists hope to explore the ocean to unprecedented depths was lowered -- empty -- to a record distance of 5,800 feet today in a successful test of resistance to vast submarine pressures.

It is heartening to read that there is one place in our Military Establishment that hasn't changed beyond all recognition. The Training Command, USAF (as portrayed by Sam Boal in "West Point of the Air") stands firm -- training gentlemen, Sir!

OMAHA -- With the recent completion of a new blacktop. all-weather road into the heart of Nebraska's Cherry County. a region which once figured prominently in the tales of America's "wild and woolly west" has at last been made easily accessible to motor tourists.

A HUNDRED years ago next February Herman Melville began a book which he thought of as a description of a whaling voyage. He had made such a voyage, on board the Acushnet, returning to the United States in 1844.

NORTON, Mass., Aug. 13 -- Dr. A. Howard Meneely, president of Wheaton College, announced today the appointment of Miss Margaret Dow of Cambridge, Mass., and Warner, N. H., as director of fund raising at the college. She will take over her new duties late in August.

STRASBOURG, France, Aug. 13 -- A list of new items for its agenda, submitted by the Consultative Assembly of the Council of Europe, was accepted tonight by the Ministers Committee of the Council. It will be appended to the three topics set down by the Ministers themselves.

THE recently announced plan of the B. F. Goodrich Company to institute a "giveaway" commercial on the "Celebrity Time" program over the American Broadcasting Company television network was scotched by the ABC continuity acceptance and legal departments.

The quiet ponds are scummed over, now, and full of algae; and one gets the feeling that anything could happen in such waters, any kind of life arise from them. Here, in the dead heat of late summer, is the marshy margin and the primordial ooze with cattails growing in it, and he who approaches it might be walking backward in time toward remote beginnings.

THE philosophy of "Rabbi Ben Ezra" expanded to nearly three hundred pages is the substance of this suave, mannerly, yet occasionally disconcerting and even alarming, book by the sometime Professor of Philosophy in the College of the City of New York.

PALMYRA, N. Y. -- On the slopes of Hill Cumorah, the gentle rise less than four miles from this pleasant town, a religious pageant which may become an institution is to be presented this Thursday, Friday and Saturday.

Lieut. Gen. Robert L. Eichelberger, top infantry commander in the war in the Pacific and commander of the Eighth Army in the occupation of Japan, told five hundred veterans of one of his favorite divisions the Twenty-fourth -- in annual reunion at the New Yorker Hotel last night that the fruits of their victory would be lost if Russia or the communists ever took over Japan.

LENOX, Mass., Aug. 13 -- Through a happy conjunction of program-making, major works by leading contemporary composers of Great Britain, France, Russia and the United States are listed for the Berkshire Symphonic Festival's final week.

Television studios, not movie theaters, are attracting recent graduates of motion picture operating courses, a survey taken by the Trade and Technical School of the Young Ten's Christian Association indicates.

Milk producers will get a uniform price of $3.94 a hundredweight for milk deliveries made in July to the 437 pool-approved plants in the New York milkshed, Dr. C. J. Blanford, market administrator of the New York metropolitan milk-marketing area, announced yesterday.

CHICAGO, Aug. 13 (UP) -- President Will Harridge of the American League tonight sought to mollify irate Bill Veeck, owner of the Cleveland Indians, who wanted to know why Umpire Charley Berry officiated at the All-Star football game last night instead of in the Cleveland-Chicago baseball game.

CASTEL GANDOLFO, Italy, Aug. 13 -- Pope Pius said today he believed the controversy between Cardinal Spellman and Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt over the question of Federal aid to Catholic schools had been resolved satisfactorily.

A program to cultivate drug-bearing plants in the United States which may free this country from reliance on foreign sources for many vital medicinal compounds has been started in Arkansas by Dr. O. K. Cosla. The publication Industrial and Engineering Chemistry reports that the College of the Ozarks, Clarksville, Ark., has set aside a twenty-acre tract for Dr. Cosla's experiments.
WHEN mice get together, their best bravuras are how they bound up the lion's wounded paw.

Since Monday, when the General deserted his quarters, an intensive search for him has been pressed. All through the Kips Bay, Turtle Bay and Beekman sections, the alarm has been sounded. The Salvation Army has joined the hunt, as well as the Kips Bay Boys Club, youngsters, singly and in groups, and sympathetic grown-ups.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Aug. 13 -- The veterans bonus was a topic of universal interest in the Midwest this week as Iowa officials mailed out approximately 45,000 state bonus checks.

Leading traffic experts of the Eastern states will study the latest methods of reducing accidents and promoting traffic safety at Yale University's Institute of Traffic Training, Sept. 6 through 16. The institute, sponsored by Yale in cooperation with the National Committee for Traffic Training, will offer courses on all types of traffic problems.

ALTHOUGH the camera field trip has become increasingly popular since it was first developed several years ago as a combination cycling and camera trip, its best opportunities for picture-taking have been missed by most amateurs. The advantages of such a trip are low travel cost for the individual, a chance to photograph new material and technical help from the instructor-guide in charge of the expedition.
KASTORIA, Greece, Aug. 13 (AP) -- Greek troops cut off the main supply route from Albania for 8,000 guerrillas in the Vitsi Mountain redoubt today.
PARIS, Aug. 13 -- The European Marshall Plan Council adopted today proposals for freer European trade and a new payments plan to finance this trade.

IT can be said, in the first place, apropos'of Calvin Brown's book published by the Georgia University Press, "Music and Literature," that it is vastly refreshing to read a book by a man who knows what he is talking about.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Aug. 13 -- The Israeli Government has accepted the challenge stemming from the United Nations Security Council's abrogation of arms embargo to the Middle East. If arms are to be purchased openly this country will be among the first to buy them to protect itself.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- The disagreement over "jurisdiction" between the National Labor Relations Board and the General Counsel, Robert N. Denham, was illustrated pointedly today in the decision of a trial examiner.

HAWTHORNE, N. Y. -- On the Taconic State Parkway at Kitchawan Hill in Yorktown just south of the Croton Reservoir. Troop K of the State Police here and the Taconic State Parkway Commission in Albany have created an emergency traffic system that puzzles bumper-to-bumper motorists on humid Sunday nights but actually tends to exact six-lane efficiency from a four-lane highway.

A heavy shower about an hour before game time turned the Polo Grounds into such a quagmire yesterday that the double-header scheduled between the Giants and the Phillies had to be postponed. It was announced that the twin bill would be played on Sept. 6, previously an open date on the Giants' schedule.

HOLLYWOOD. ETHEL BARRYMORE is, perhaps, the best testimony that Hollywood has come of age. Tomorrow, Aug. 15, Miss Barrymore will mark the occasion of her seventieth birthday and, with it, more than a half-century of achievement on both stage and screen.

WASHINGTON; Aug. 13 -- The [Hoover] Commission on Organization of the Executive Branch of the Government, which made a detailed study of how the Federal Government can save money, has closed its books and returned to the United States Treasury $31,000 from a $1,938,600 appropriation, the Citizens Committee for the Hoover Report said today.

LET us open with a confession of faith: John Dickson Carr is the finest contemporary writer of detective stories. " A SEA CHANGE" is sophisticated and irreverent entertainment for intellectuals, with some of the deceptive sprightliness of the early E. M. Forster though with none of Forster's economy. It is "A Room With a View" rewritten for our darker modern world. Morgan, epileptic son of the backer of a progressive weekly, is the George Emerson whose soul is to be won or lost.

THERE are more than 250 brief, simply written accounts of Christian saints in this pocket-size volume. Few of the accounts are longer than a page, and they range from the two sentences allotted St. Hybald (about whom little is known but to whom four Lincolnshire churches are dedicated) to a page and a half on St. Mary the Virgin.

IN form, Mr. Barr's book is a brief history of Europe and its expansion since the Middle Ages. It is a history concerned rather with interpreting human actions and institutions than with detailed description and analysis -- a history addressed to the general reader, but with a hopeful eye toward the enlightened college instructor who wants for his students relief from thick textbooks clogged with undigested detail.

Children with cerebral palsy face a future "the brightest of any time in the history of medicine," Dr. William Benham Snow, Associate Professor of Physical Medicine at Columbia University's College of Physicians and Surgeons, declared yesterday in an interview.
GUILFORD, Conn., Aug. 13 -- This town played host today to about 1,000 visitors who inspected a group of seventeenth and eighteenth century houses. These houses are still being used as homes.

LONDON, Aug. 13 -- The Ministry of Labor publicly warned the British Colliery Winders Federation today that their threatened strike to secure wage increases would be illegal under existing British labor legislation.
DETROIT, Aug. 13 (AP) -- The Tigers climbed into the American League's first division today, beating the Browns, 12 to 9, in one of the wildest games Briggs Stadium has seen this year.

Major Radonov, an American of White Russian descent, member of the Signal Corps in our army of occupation in Germany, has been assigned to work out a technical agreement with a Soviet commission which, surprisingly, has consented to visit the American zone for the purpose.

BOEUF a la mode is pot roast gone to heaven. It is the French way of presenting that thrifty cut so that none of the usual complaints can be lodged against it. The meat is not dry or tasteless, does not shred.

IN temperament as well as in appearance, "shaggy" is the epithet which best describes the old-fashioned, traditional revolutionary or radical, as he exists in the popular imagination and in fact. And by a natural inversion, "smooth" is the best epithet for his successor -- the "new revolutionary" -- who has played, and plays, so commanding a role in successive Communist coups since the war.

ATLANTA, Aug. 13 -- A Federal Court suit seeking equal educational facilities for Negroes and a statement by former Gov. Ellis Arnall indicating that he would run for Governor next year were subjects which stirred warm discussions in this area this week.

It has no formal salutation, but it is a letter all the same -- postmarked this month of August, 1949, and addressed to many brave and tender young people I do not yet know -- the "new" actors of the "new" season, some of whom will be writing similar articles (or letters) a generation from now.

Efforts in New Jersey to create a post of wholesale trade administrator in the liquor industry of that state have encountered difficulties, it was reported yesterday. Meanwhile, New York liquor wholesalers have temporarily or permanently abandoned similar action.

CHICAGO, Aug. 13 -- Construction of a new set of longer and deeper locks in the Illinois Waterway was urged this week by shippers, who said that the present locks would not handle expanding barge traffic even if shutdowns for repairs could be avoided.

THE fourth annual Eastern International Gladiolus Show will be held at Kalurah Temple, Binghamton, N. Y., Tuesday and Wednesday. The exhibit is sponsored by the Chambers of Commerce of Binghamton and Johnson City, in cooperation with the Triple Cities Show Committee.

Trailing by two runs, the Yankees staged a four-run rally in the ninth yesterday to defeat the Athletics, 9 to 7. The Red Sox stayed in second place, five games back of the Yanks, by downing the Senators, 5 -- 1, in twelve innings on a four-run homer by Vern Stephens.

THE first issue of Modern Photography, successor to the magazine Minicam Photography, goes on sale tomorrow. Aside from its increased size of 8 1/2 by 11 1/2 inches, the new magazine is similar to its predecessor both in content and viewpoint, which is chiefly documentary.

Lower prices for linseed oil for late August delivery, plus recent price cuts on ready-mixed paints, have brought an active market, with increasing "future" buying trends in linseed oil, oil refiners disclosed here yesterday. Refiners hope low linseed oil prices will hold through the fall and prevent a recurrence of the stagnant markets of May, June and July.

While the Eighty-first Congress is not expected to approve or even to consider any civil rights legislation during this session, more hopeful results are now in from many of the adjourned state legislatures. The accomplishments of the states indicate that they did not follow the example of inaction set by the Federal Government.

LONG BEACH, L. I., Aug. 13 -- A spokesman for the Seiden Hotel chain, which repurchased the Lido Beach Hotel here from the War Assets Administration with the help of James V. Hunt, said the chain had actually taken a "great loss" on the transaction.

Long-standing reports of dissension among the Braves were revived yesterday when it became known that two of the Braves' stars, Earl Torgeson and Jim Russell, had engaged in a fist fight, The United Press reported.

The need for acquisition of the 18 1/2-acre plant of the Manhattanville College of the Sacred Heart as an addition to the facilities of City College will be stressed tomorrow at a hearing before the City Planning Commission, the Board of Higher Education announced yesterday.

RYE, N. Y., Aug. 13 -- The Interzone Round Davis Cup tennis matches ran afoul of the weather again today at the Westchester Country Club and the afternoon's program had to be canceled by Referee H. Levan Richards after consultation with the captains of the Australian and Italian teams.

Although four years have passed since the formation of the United Nations, most Americans have at best only a superficial knowledge of how that organization works. The Girls Service League will be the beneficiary of the first benefit performance, on Oct. 17, of "Double Bill" by Terence Rattigan, co-starring Maurice Evans and Edna Best, which opens at the Coronet Theatre the evening of Oct. 12.
GENEVA, Aug. 3 -- The Economic and Social Council virtually completed action today on an outline of a United Nations program for technical assistance to underdeveloped areas.

Ground-breaking ceremonies for the construction of the new St. Raymond's School in the Bronx will take place at noon tomorrow, Msgr. Thaddeus W. Tierney, pastor of St. Raymond's Roman Catholic parish, announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- From Tuesday morning until last evening through the working hours of the day this week, most of the leaders of the Air Force sat in the court-like room of the House Armed Services Committee.

" IT'S YOUR LIFE," the highly acclaimed public health series of programs which originated as a purely local program in Chicago last fall, is headed for a wider circulation. WNYC has arranged to broadcast the series each Sunday at 9 P. M., effective Sept. 4, under the auspices of the Health Council of the City of New York.

NEWS comes from Prague of the death of Vitezslav Novak at the age of 79. It could be said that in the passing of this vigorous yet sensitive composer three generations of Czechoslovak music had gone at one stroke.

CHICAGO, Aug. 13 -- A shipment of about 1,800 tons of lead by barge this week from Brownsville, Tex., to Chicago is one of the first long-distance shipments to move through the newly completed extension of the Gulf Intercoastal Waterway from Corpus Christi, Tex., to Brownsville, spokesmen for waterways operators said this week.

THE Baedekers are going to start publishing their Guides again. The youngest survivor of the mysterious benefactors of the "traveler in a hurry," for whom their books were first written, is on his bicycle collecting material on the byways of Schleswig-Holstein. Where is Schleswig-Holstein? It does not matter: the news is excellent.

U E Maung, Foreign Minister of Burma, declared yesterday that his country would probably be willing to enter into a Pacific pact similar to the Atlantic pact if it were "sponsored by the right people and at the right moment."

Several economic developments, and particularly a more cooperative attitude on the part of Washington officials, buoyed sentiment in financial markets last week. Coupled with other indications that the current recession in business is "healthier" than expected, they stimulated greater interest in the stock market, sending prices to their best levels since January, in heavy trading.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- One of the pleasant things about the business downturn is that so many persons believe that it is over, or soon will be.

Two of the Greater New York Fund vacation contest winners received a "bon voyage" from Grover Whalen, chairman of Mayor O'Dwyer's reception committee, as they left La Guardia Airport yesterday for Bermuda on two-week vacations.

ATLANTIC CITY, Aug. 13 -- Hill Prince, the 2-year-old colt from the stable of Christopher T. Chenery who has been creating quite a stir among the juveniles this season, continued to display winning form today, when he outraced seven horses to capture the $15,000 added World's Playground Stakes at the seaside course.
The police disclosed yesterday the arrest on Friday of five women in a raid on a Bronx apartment that netted 1,260,800 policy slips -- the play for the last week.
BELGRADE, Aug. 13 -- Yugoslav authorities are giving serious thought to the latest Soviet note which designated Yugoslavia as "an enemy of the Soviet Union."

CANNES, France, Aug. 13 (UP) -- Police today named a 38-year-old Frenchman as leader of the machine-gun gang that robbed the Aga Khan and his wife of $785,000 in jewels. They sent out an international alarm extending to the United States to pick him up on sight.

As a New York City high school teacher, I read Chester Bowles' "A Governor's Job as Seen by a Governor" with great curiosity, hoping to learn what this liberal and dynamic Governor had to say about school and educational matters in his state.

NEW DELHI. ON Aug. 15, 1947, a giant named India burst his fetters and stood free. In the two years since then the giant has been occupied with stretching himself and feeling his muscles while the world watched for the first uncertain steps of this new colossus in Asia.

PRETTY soon now the last of the roisterous, laughing, sun-tanned and freckled youngsters who have been off to camp for part or all of the summer will pile off their homebound trains and buses, and parents will start to plan for next summer's camp adventures.

SALT LAKE CITY, Aug. 13 -- United States Forest Service officials consider the fire hazard this year the worst since 1931 because of the month-long lack of rainfall and the searing heat which has kept the mercury in the upper 90's even at high altitudes.

ONE of the greatest of all naturalists began life as a laborer in France, and for almost twenty years taught science -- at an annual salary never exceeding $320 -- in the Lycee at Avignon. He died, a very old man, in 1915.

Sales of pre-fabricated steel swimming pools in popular-priced lines, starting at $2,775 each, are continuing to hold an increase in volume of orders each month of 100 per cent above 1948 sales levels, and inquiries now indicate an even larger volume for 1950, William D. Birch, director of engineering sales for L. O. Koven Bros., Inc., Newark, N. J., said yesterday.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Aug. 13 -- Czechoslovak authorities will not try prevent the consecration of the two new Roman Catholic bishops at Trnava tomorrow, although their installation without Government approval is a "provocative act," a spokesman of the Commission of Education of Slovakia said today.

LONDON. ONCE again, there are signs of economic crisis in Europe. Once again, the symptom, as in 1947, is a drain upon the Sterling Area's reserves of gold and dollars. The situation is sudden and surprising. Only six months ago, the Sterling Area had achieved an overall balance in its trade and in Europe Marshall aid had produced an upsurge of hope and production.

THE author of "The Web of Days" has turned out another sinister little romance peopled with characters of high estate and mean souls. Jen, the inevitable ingenue of such stories, pays a long visit to her Aunt Eva, beautiful and rich, who treads the primrose path to dalliance with as much subtlety as the buzzing queen bee she emulates -- and with as much treacherous sting.

New York's weather men are best known and most discussed because of their forecasts. Sometimes they're right, sometimes they're wrong; everyone wants to know what the weather man thinks tomorrow is going to be.

HONOLULU, Aug. 13 -- The test of whether Hawaii's new temporary seizure law affecting Territorial stevedoring is effective is expected to come early next week when officials will endeavor to open the port of Honolulu by loading and unloading strike-bound ships.

ONE of the most persistent and pathetic demands to be heard from editors today is the demand for humor. They have a cliche for it, and they run it all together as if it were one word: they are cryingforhumor.

PREMIERES abound this week in the summer dance world. At Palmer Auditorium, New London, where Connecticut College is sponsoring the second American Dance Festival, there are five new works scheduled, along with repetitions of three which were given in the first sessions of the festival last week.

Today in Western Germany the first free national elections since 1933 are being held -- for the "parliament" of a new Bundesrepublik Deutschland. It is an historic election. It is part of the changeover in West Germany from military government to German self-rule subject to civilian Allied supervision. Late this fall the new German Government is to be functioning.

For the first time since Aug. 4 the temperature yesterday stayed below 80 degrees. Rain that helped keep the maximum temperature at 79 also created considerable inconvenience in some parts of the city.

Pig was not only an extremely gifted porker but an understanding, generous-minded one, too. When small Gary grieved over his separation from his English friend, Howard, Pig simply said "Let's go," He took a deep breath, swelled up to balloon size and with Gary and three dogs piled on his back took off to England.

SHANGHAI, Aug. 13 -- In a long editorial unprecedented in recent months in bitterness and sarcasm the official New China News agency tonight attacked the State Department's White Paper as a blueprint for undermining the Communist regime and said the United States would back the Kuomintang so long as it still had "a single soldier or secret agent."

Some three years ago the national poultry research director of the A. P. Food Stores, Howard C. Pierce, suggested to the poultry industry that a real effort be made to improve chickens grown for meat in the same way that turkey growers had improved their product through the development of the broad-breasted varieties.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 13 -- Joe DiMaggio said today he may have called Ted Williams a "crybaby" in an "offhand remark" but added quickly that he "did not emphasize it by saying 'certainly he's a crybaby.'"

MANCHESTER, Mass., Aug. 13 (AP) -- Miss Doris Hart of Jacksonville, Fla., the nation's third-ranking player and defending tourney champion, today scored a sharp upset with a 6-4, 3-6, 6-1 victory over Miss Louise Brough of Los Angeles, current Wimbledon champion, in the semi-finals of the Essex County women's tennis tournament.
