LONDON, Aug 13 -- European officials are pleased with the proposed compromise on Capitol Hill on the United States Military Aid Program, not because the compromise would give President Truman almost everything he wanted but because it apparently foreshadows a large measure of agreement between the Administration on the one hand and Senators Vandenberg and Dulles on the other.

The Bronx police said yesterday they had virtually closed their books on a robbery and a mugging committed between midnight and sunrise yesterday. By 6:30 A. M. they had shot and killed two persons and arrested four others who, they said, were responsible for these unconnected crimes.

BELGRADE, Aug. 13 -- The Soviet Government's sharp note to the Yugoslav Government, made public by the Moscow radio this week, in which Moscow plainly labels Marshal Tito's regime an enemy of the Soviet Union, has brought the relations between the two countries to a new climax of strain.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Aug. 13 -- Westchester officials have been notified of the awarding by the state Department of Public Works of an $853,859 contract for a highway improvement the county had been seeking since long before the war.

Mr. Churchill, like other great leaders, has his impressive moments and those that are less impressive. Sometimes, when he has been occupied with the domestic politics of Britain, it has been hard to recognize the voice that spoke so valiantly after Dunkerque. But when the former Prime Minister shakes off the dust of partisan conflict and comes into the clear and noble air of world-shaking issues, his literary and oratorical greatness returns.

CHAUTAUQUA, N. Y., Aug. 13 -- Ligia Berezynska, Polish pianist and wife of Franco Autori, associate conductor of the New York Philharmonic - Symphony Orchestra, made her American debut tonight as soloist with the Chautauqua Symphony Orchestra, with Mr. Autori conducting before a capacity audience.

Stiffening prices in the cotton and rayon textile markets has hastened spring 1950 purchasing by mail order houses and chains, it was revealed in an analysis of market activity last week. Mail order houses, seeking to build up selective lines for new catalogues, are making extensive samplings for women's light apparel, children's lines and domestics, and in some instances have ordered goods for delivery through December.

The American aluminum industry, under fire last year when it charged that European recipients of Marshall Plan funds had been guilty of double-dealing in aluminum, won vindication of its allegations here last week.

Manufacturers doing business with the Quartermaster supplied goods to the extent of more than $400,000,000 in the fiscal year ended June 30, without intermediaries or agents, it was pointed out last week.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 13 -- The Pirates forced the Cardinals to share the National League's top perch again with the Dodgers tonight when they snapped the Redbirds' five-game winning streak, 6 to 3, before 25,745 disappointed fans.

A fashion show titled "Prophecy for Winter" will be given in conjunction with a luncheon on Oct. 11 in the Chanticleer Room of the Sherry-Netherland for the benefit of the New York City Mission Society, which is observing its 137th anniversary.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- Because the Federal Government has billions of dollars' worth of contracts to let every year, Washington has become the mecca of the "five percenters" and the "influence peddlers." But for the little business man seeking a contract, it is the most confused place in the world.

In promotions here last week retailers emphasized "Sparkle Plenty" dolls, Swiss watches, coats with zip-out fur linings, boys' jacket and overall sets, juniors' camels' hair coats and corduroy jumpers, according to a survey made especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by the Retail News Bureau.

Federal Attorney John F. X. McGohey, who is now engaged in the prosecution in Southern District Court of eleven of the nation's top Communists, is scheduled for promotion to a Federal judgeship, informed quarters said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -- The first legislative progress for the Administration's arms program to strengthen the countries of Europe adhering to the North Atlantic treaty will come tomorrow. The House Foreign Affairs Committee is expected to report out the bill authorizing funds.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -- With the purchase of five Victory and two Liberty ships from the United States Maritime Commission, the privately owned American merchant marine increased in size for the first time in several months, the National Federation of American Shipping reported here today.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Aug. 14 -- The political and economic revival of Western Germany has created a whole range of new problems for which the Western Allies in general and the United States in particular are not yet prepared.

The city may safely incur a maximum debt of $200,900,000 in 1950 for public improvements chargeable against its constitutional debt limit, Controller Lazarus Joseph declared yesterday in a report submitted to the Board of Estimate, City Council, City Planning Commission and Budget Director Thomas J. Patterson.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Aug. 14 -- Today was thirty years almost to the day after the Wiemar Republic had been proclaimed and the Germans were voting in their first free federal elections since that ill-fated republic died.

A complete new variable traffic signal layout for Columbus Circle has been designed by the Department of Traffic Engineering and will be installed when the area is rehabilitated, it was announced yesterday.

The efforts of the Religious Society of Friends, working through the American Friends Service Committee, to demonstrate practical Christianity in war and peace were summarized yesterday morning for the congregation of the First Moravian Episcopal Church, Lexington Avenue and Thirtieth Street, by Lyman W. B. Jackman of the Friends Meeting, 144 East Twentieth Street.

ATHENS, Aug. 14 -- As the Greek Nationalist offensive against the rebel bastions in the Grammos and Vitsi Mountains increased in intensity, Panayotis Kanellopoulos, the Minister of War, disclosed today the Government's terms for guerrillas who capitulate.

ATHENS, Aug. 14 -- "The Vitsi area no longer exists as a defensive position [of the Greek guerrillas]," today's General Staff communique announced. The bulletin asserted that "there remain only some isolated strongposts that are being destroyed by the National Army."

STOCKHOLM, Aug. 14 (UP) -- Olle Tandberg, big and game, did his best to beat Joe Walcott, but he lacked the artillery. Although Walcott is an "old man" of the ring and the father of six children, he still is an explosive puncher.

A plan for the establishment of Western Union as advanced by Lionel Curtis, English author of several books on world peace, will be issued by Macmillan on Aug. 30, under the title "World Revolution in the Cause of Peace." The author contends that the fear of war can be removed by following a pattern, similar to that which united the thirteen original states.
BRUNSWICK, Me., Aug. 14 -- Bowdoin College has awarded about $23,000 in scholarships to thirty-five students who will enter the college this fall, Huber S. Shaw, director of admissions, said today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 (By Science Service) -- Safety in the Pacific area will be promoted by Pacific and Alaskan stations maintained by the Civil Aeronautics Administration which have now been made a part of a system for detecting and reporting tidal waves resulting from undersea earthquakes, it was revealed here today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 (AP) -- A call for an "American Continental Congress for Peace" in Mexico City apparently will be "Moscow directed," the State Department said today.

GLOUCESTER, Mass., Aug. 14 -- Gloucester fisherfolk set flowers adrift on the ocean today to honor 10,000 townsmen lost at sea in the past 300 years, but for the first time in the fifty-eight-year-history of the ceremony not a single new name was added to the "roll of missing dead."

ANNECY, France, Aug. 14 -- Negotiations among European countries as part of the world tariff conference here have demonstrated for the first time a practical method of achieving "integration" of European industry, in the opinion of trade experts.

Air-freight shipments of small packages at rates comparable to those of rail transportation will be started today by Skyways Freight Forwarding Corporation, 543 West Twenty-fifth Street, according to an announcement released today by the company.

HAMBURG, Germany, Aug. 14 (UP) -- A British-licensed newspaper said today that twenty high-ranking Soviet officers, including at least one General, were killed by a time bomb at Soviet headquarters in Potsdam July 25. [A previous report Aug. 10 said twenty Russian soldiers hat been killed in the explosion.]

DETROIT, Aug. 14 -- James S. Nonen, head of the Detroit local of the National Association of Letter Carriers, has been suspended from his carrier's job, it was learned today. The suspension followed a hearing before a loyalty review board at the Postoffice Department in Washington.

SHANNON, Ireland, Monday, Aug. 15 -- A four-engined Transocean Air Lines plane with fifty-eight persons aboard set down in the Atlantic Ocean fifteen miles off Ireland early today. A British fishing boat picked up thirty-six survivors, Transocean Air Lines officials said.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 (UP) -- Left-wing members of the CIO Executive Board have defied President Philip Murray's order to follow CIO policy or resign, the CIO News said today.

RYE, N. Y., Aug. 14 -- Australia settled matters today in the interzone round Davis Cup matches with the first Italian tennis team ever to play in this country and qualified to challenge the United States for the international team trophy at Forest Hills Aug. 26, 27 and 28.
Municipal bonds coming up for sale this week total $119,443,266, compared with $49,102,451 for last week and a weekly average of $68,338,383 for the year to date, according to The Daily Bond Buyer.

LARAMIE, ryo., Aug. 14--AI program aimed at taking 20,000,-i 000 acres of Great Plains crop land out of production as a necessary conservation measure and as an aid to stabilizing the region's economy was recommended today by the Great Plains Agricultural Council.
AMSTERDAM, Aug. 14 (AP) -- American athletes won five of the nine events they entered today in an international track and field meet held in sunny weather before 5,000 fans at Olympic Stadium.

The trouble with summer is that everything grows too much. That is, the wrong things grow too much. A large tomato, ripening on the vine, is a very fine sight, as is the increasing circumference of a watermelon.

STRASBOURG, France, Aug. 14 -- The elections in Western Germany were being watched with special interest here tonight for the influence that their outcome is expected to have upon debates in the Consultative Assembly of the Council of Europe.
Junior Merchant Marine Naval Reserve officers who have no Naval service may obtain twelve months of active duty afloat, it became known yesterday.

SHANGHAI, Aug. 14 -- Any lingering doubt that Peiping would be the capital of the new "People's Democratic Republic of China" melted yesterday when Mao Tze-tung declared that the city should unite for "the construction of the people's capital."

OLD WESTBURY, L. I., Aug. 14 -- George H. (Pete) Bostwick turned in one of the finest jobs of his polo-playing career today when he led the twenty-seven-goal Bostwick Field side to a thrilling 8-7 victory over the powerful El Trebol quartet of Argentina.

The jacket plays a number of fashion roles and shapes up differently every season. Listed among the important features in college shops this year are the separate jackets that become part of a suit, top slacks and skirts and make smart evening wraps too.
PADUCAH, Ky., Aug. 14 (AP) -- Smiling broadly, Vice President Alben W. Barkley today dedicated his hometown airport, renamed in his honor, and crowned and kissed seven queens of a military air show.

BRONKO NAGURSKI started it and everyone in football knows that it was practically impossible to stop the Bronk once he got started. Even today Stout Steve Owen will ruefully rub the top of his head and drawl, "I still got nobs on my noggin from trying to stop Nagurski." Thus forewarned, this craven reporter will begin sprinting toward his own goal-line in order to give the Bronk all the running room he needs.

Thirty-five new cases of polio-myelitis were reported in this city in the twenty-four hours up to 9 A. M. yesterday. The Department of Health announced there had been no deaths here from the disease in that period.

An important new interpretation of the Federal lottery laws, construing as a "consideration" the time expended by a contestant for awarding of certain "bonus" prizes, has been made by the solicitor of the Post Office Department in response to a request by the National Better Business Bureau, it was learned over the weekend.

Councilman Joseph T. Sharkey defended yesterday his record on rent legislation and denounced "politically minded individuals" who, he said, were trying to make it appear that he and Mayor O'Dwyer favored a 15 per cent rent increase.
GENEVA, Aug. 14 -- Russia carefully avoided an all-out attack on the United Nations technical assistance program today in the Economic and Social Council.

LONDON, Aug. 14 -- Although the fall in British Government securities has been less precipitate than in some preceding weeks it has continued and has naturally carried the prices of most other fixed interest stocks down in sympathy.
CLEVELAND, Aug. 14 (AP) -- Pitchers Bob Lemon and Mike Garcia won a double-header for the Cleveland Indians over the Chicago White Sox today, 4 to 3 and 5 to 0, before a crowd of 46,212.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -- Senate investigators prepared today to cross-check Maj. Gen. Harry H. Vaughan's explanation of the way a select group, close to the White House, came to receive gifts of deep-freezers for their homes.
LONDON, Aug. 14 -- A career that many observers of Arab affairs regarded as a promising one came to a quick end today with the execution of Husni Zayim, self-made President of Syria.
W. J. Howell has been appointed assistant to Tomlinson Fort, manager of apparatus sales of the Westinghouse Electric Corporation, Pittsburgh.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 (UP) -- Representative Francis Case, Republican, of South Dakota, today threatened to resort to an unusual parliamentary maneuver to end the Congressional delay on appropriation bills. Mr. Case is irritated because, he said, President Truman "wrongly blamed" the Republicans for the failure of Congress to have all money bills approved before the last fiscal year ended at midnight on June 30.
CHICAGO, Aug. 14 (AP) -- The National Collegiate Athletic Association's Bowl Games Committee today adopted a six-point policy for governing post-season football.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 14 -- Elpidio Quirino, President of the Philippine Republic, said here today that he believed he had the cure for communism -- at least in his country. It was, he stated, to improve the economic condition of the average Filipino.

DETROIT, Aug. 14 (AP) -- Freddie Hutchinson and Art Houtteman pitched Detroit to a double victory over the St. Louis Browns today. Hutchinson won, 6 to 2, in the first game and Houtteman gave a seven-hit performance to take the nightcap, 4 to 3, before 35,289 fans.

Declaring that the proposed modernization of Brooklyn Bridge would make its beautiful silhouette "nothing but a memory," Francis Keally, president of the Municipal Art Society, has appealed to Mayor O'Dwyer to "save the situation."
Four new films, including importations from England and Germany, are slated to open in midtown theatres this week. The programs follow:

FRANKFORT, Germany, Aug. 14 (AP) -- John J. McCloy, United States Military Governor for Germany, returned tonight from the United States and said that he had found the men to fill a half dozen key jobs when the Military Government was replaced.

GREEN HARBOR, Spitsbergen, Aug. 14 -- In the only Russian settlement this side of the Iron Curtain, a community of 2,500 Russians is on view to the outside world and more particularly to Norwegian neighbors in the nearby mining town of Longyear City, some twenty-five miles from Isfjord.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 (UP) -- The current "nasty" controversy over Federal aid to education may be only a sample of what might be expected if Congress approves "any Federal school aid measure," the Council of State Chambers of Commerce asserted today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 (AP) -- Senator Arthur V. Watkins, Republican, of Utah, said yesterday he would press the Air Force for a progress report on its promised survey of three suggested sites in Utah for an aerial engineering research center.

The report of Best Co. for the six months ended on July 31, last, announced for publication today by Philip Le Boutillier, president and general manager, put net sales at $17,387,968, compared with $18,216,348 in the corresponding period a year ago.

CHICAGO, Aug. 14 (AP) -- The Cincinnati Reds swept both ends of a double header with the Chicago Cubs today before a crowd of 32,770. They captured the 12-inning opener, 4 -- 2, then took the nightcap, 8 -- 0, behind the five-hit pitching of Johnny Vander Meer.

What is the value of humor in selling? This question was asked by a number of advertising officials last week in commenting on a marked increase in a humorous treatment of advertising's selling "message." Creating an amiable association with a product has always been considered good advertising, it was noted.

PARIS, Aug. 14 -- Balenciaga continues to create in the grand manner. This is especially true of his evening gowns, in which richness of fabric and embroideries abounds. While he resorts to colors associated with Renaissance paintings -- reds, purples and those mellow browns always present on his color palette -- he has launched a new black and white theme this season.

"A Candle for St. Jude," Rumer Godden's novel dealing with two days in the life of a small London ballet theatre and school, is being dramatized by the author and Dorothy Heyward. When it reaches the stage, it probably will bear the title of "Cygnets," meaning baby swans, which aptly describes the subject in hand.

Although radio microphones of the CBS network will be at ringside for coverage of the Ray Robinson-Steve Belloise boxing bout at Yankee Stadium on Wednesday, Aug. 24, television coverage will not be permitted. This marks the fourth time within the last two months that fight promoters have banned video pick-ups of their special summer attractions.

THE HAGUE, The Netherlands, Aug. 14 -- To keep European governments in the Atlantic Pact up to date on the Military Assistance Program, the State Department has been sending special missions to Europe during consideration of the aid bill by Congress.

August (Gus) Helmecke began beating a heavy drum sixty-four years ago with a youngsters' band in his native Yorkville section of Manhattan. Now Gus is in his eighty-first year and still applying an artistic and rhythmic beat to the bass drum in Goldman's Band on the Mall in Central Park.

"Look at the splendid qualities that go into the making of a good housebreaker," the Rev. Eugene C. Kreider, missionary superintendent of the New York Synod of the United Lutheran Church in America, suggested in his morning sermon yesterday at St. Peter's Lutheran Church, Lexington Avenue and Fifty-fourth Street.
PITTSBURGH, Aug. 14 (AP) -- A leading steel producer today announced development of a new type steel which may reduce the cost of future television sets.
ALICE, Tex., Aug. 14 (AP) -- Vandals tried to burn down early today the night club which figured in the slaying of W. H. (Bill) Mason, crusading radio commentator.

The Middle East, which appeared to be stabilizing itself after the end of the Palestine war, has again been thrown into turmoil as a result of a new military coup in Syria in which Marshal Zayim, the military dictator who seized power by a like coup last March, has himself been overthrown and executed by his former confederates.

NEWPORT, R. I., Aug. 14 (AP) -- Richard (Pancho) Gonzales, national singles champion from Los Angeles, today stroked his way to the singles honors with a 10 -- 8, 19 -- 11, 6 -- 3, 6 -- 4 victory over Gardnar Mulloy of Coral Gables, Fla., in the thirtieth annual Casino invitation lawn tennis tournament.

CHICAGO, Aug. 14 (AP) -- The cost of smoking jumped this year for cigarette users in nine states, Alaska, and Washington, D. C. The federation of tax administrators predicted, however, that the nation's record high consumption of 348,000,000,000 cigarettes in 1948 will not be cut by the increase in state taxes.

The need of more painted lines on New York streets to designate traffic lanes and pedestrian rights and responsibilities at corner crossings is so evident and so neglected that the City Traffic Commission should not have to "study" this matter long before going into action.

The members of the Old-Timers Symphony, who are nearly all past 60, had a big night at the Music Grove in Brooklyn't Prospect Park last night. They gave their most important concert to date and there was an audience of more than 4,000 to applaud them.

Of 185 manufacturers queried by the National Industrial Conference Board on the business outlook for the balance of the year, three-quarters foresee a decline in profits while half expect fewer orders, the NICB announced over the week-end.

The first post-war readjustment of business will be substantially completed within the next six or eight months, it is predicted by Henry H. Heimann, executive manager of the National Association of Credit Men, in his monthly business review, released today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 14 -- Ezio Pinza will make his screen debut in "Deburau" a French play by Sacha Guitry which Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer has owned for some years, the studio has announced. Mario Lanza, another singer under contract to Metro, will appear with Pinza as his son, according to the statement.
SAN DIEGO, Calif., Aug 14 (AP) -- Pictures of a new naval weapon -- a radio-guided anti-aircraft rocket -- were released here today.

BOSTON, Aug. 14 (AP) -- Junior Stephens lashed his thirty-first homer as the Red Sox completed a double-header sweep over the Senators by a 13-4 margin today before a 35,985 crowd. Mel Parnell chalked up his eighteenth victory as the Sockers captured the opener, 9 -- 3.

CHICAGO, Aug. 14 (AP) -- Jimmy Demaret, finishing explosively with a 67, and Johnny Palmer, who got the high-pressure 70 he needed, deadlocked today for the $10,000 top prize in Tam O'Shanter's "world" golf meet with 13-under-par 275's for the 72-hole route.

TOKYO, Aug. 14 -- The Conservative Government tonight had won a battle against the Japanese Communist party over the Administration's policy of retrenchment through dismissal of surplus public workers.
CHICAGO, Aug. 14 -- Lard prices declined sharply last week as the result of liberal profit-taking sales and the development of weakness in the vegetable oil markets, after a sharp advance previously.

Consolidated net earnings of Best Foods, Inc. for its fiscal year ending on last June 30, were $4,705,576, equal to $3.14 a share, the annual report revealed today. (Mon.) Including $1,307,000 taken from the reserve for contingencies, the net income for the period totaled $6,012,576 or $4.01 a share.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 (UP) -- Robert J. Bishop of Orlando, Fla., today was named Executive Director of the Atlantic Union Committee, and organization advocating a federation of the Atlantic Pact nations. The appointment was announced by Owen J. Roberts, former Supreme Court Justice who is president of the committee.

WILLIAMSBURG, Va., Aug. 14 -- Proposals that three Negro Baptist churches of Williamsburg unite with a $100,000 contribution from John D. Rockefeller Jr. to carry forward their program are being discussed by the congregations. Official representatives of the First Baptist, Union Baptist and Mount Ararat Baptist Churches will meet in September to go into the proposals.
Some of the warm lush quality of the tropics has appeared on the local scene in the form of eight spongy hand-loomed fabrics imported from the Caribbean and shown here for the first time yesterday.

BERLIN, Aug. 11 -- One week ago the Soviet Army in Berlin let it be known that photographs could be taken by Western Allied personnel in the Soviet sector of Berlin. Yesterday this correspondent photographed the new Soviet war memorial, with the permission of a Russian Army guard.
GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 14 -- The Greenwich Hospital Association has started construction of a 200-bed general hospital to cost $3,500,000.
MOSCOW, Aug. 14 -- The Soviet press reported today what were described as "suspicious" activities in Finland.

The pound sterling, like almost all other European currencies, is "considerably overvalued," and a readjustment in its exchange value may have to take place, according to a study of the outlook for the convertibility of Western European currencies by New York University's Institute of International Finance.

DAMASCUS, Syria, Aug. 14 -- Marshal Husni Zayim, Syrian chief of state since the coup d'etat March 30, and his Premier, Mohsen el Barazi, were executed this morning after having been taken from their homes and tried by a court-martial at Mezze Prison, it was announced today.

FREEVILLE, N. Y., Aug. 14 -- Long-range expansion plans for the George Junior Republic, an institution here for youngsters in need of special help, were disclosed yesterday by Donald S. Stralem, president of the board of directors.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- Construction of natural gas facilities which will add about 4,900 miles of new pipelines to the nation's natural gas systems, was authorized during the six-month period ended on last June 30, the Federal Power Commission announced today.

AMSTERDAM, Aug. 14 -- Finance Minister Pieter Lieftinck, in an exclusive interview today, emphasized the imperative necessity of achieving a new balance of exchange between dollar and other countries.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 14 (AP) -- Yugoslavia's bid for a loan from the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development is to come under an on-the-spot scrutiny by a special bank commission this week. The Government expects the commission to arrive tomorrow.

The Philharmonic - Symphony (figuratively) clipped some more of its (theoretically) long hair for its final concert of the season at the Lewisohn Stadium Saturday night. The occasion was a performance of show tunes by Richard Rodgers and Oscar Hammerstein 2d.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -- Senator Walter F. George, Democrat, of Georgia, top-ranking Senate tax spokesman, today called for an "immediate" reduction in taxes to stimulate business and expand the nation's economy.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Monday, Aug. 15 -- More than 75 per cent of the eligible voters in the three western zones of occupation turned out to mark 23,926,775 ballots for candidates to the Bundestag, or lower house, of the National Parliament and give the German federal republic a thumping endorsement.

BOSTON, Aug. 14 -- Although projected Federal spending in six hard-hit New England cities is being hailed as a "shot in the arm" for business here, many industrialists feel that repeal of wartime excise taxes would be a more lasting and effective form of relief.
NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., Aug. 14 -- Gentle waves of breeze and water greeted a fleet of 118 sailing craft today in the championship regatta of the Huguenot Yacht Club out on Long Island Sound.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Aug. 14 -- Almost the entire Council of Catholic Bishops of Czechoslovakia defied the Government today by gathering with some 12,000 believers at Trnava in Slovakia for the consecration of two new Catholic Bishops.

Eight major sewers costing more than S4,000,000, in Manhattan's first large-scale sewer construction in two decades, have been built in the last three and a half years. Borough President Hugo E. Rogers of Manhattan reported to Mayor O'Dwyer yesterday.

It is charitable to assume that the recent heat wave got your usually sensible Arthur Krock down. Otherwise how explain his fantastic theory that the advocates of what he calls "the welfare state" are superior in their "articulateness" to the propagandists of the Right?
WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -- The first test of the degree of cooperation President Truman will get from Congress in his reorganization plans for the executive branch of the Government comes up this week.

Larry Jansen pitched the best game of his major-league career yesterday at the Polo Grounds. The right-handed ace of Leo Durocher's mound corps blanked the Phillies, 1 -- 0, with a superlative two-hit masterpiece in which he retired the last twenty-one batters in a row, fanned eight and walked none.

Activity in the wholesale apparel market here last week centered on heavy reorders for fall coats, with emphasis on zip-out lining and fur-trimmed coats, according to reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.

Cotton prices in the domestic market moved higher last week in more active trading. Active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange were up 10 to 35 points for the week. Excepting the near-by October delivery, all active months registered new life-of-contract highs.

GREEN LAKE, Wis., Aug. 14 -- As a memorial to eleven Northern Baptist missionaries killed by the Japanese in the Philippines in December, 1943, the Vesper Circle Amphitheatre and the Cathedral in the Glen were dedicated here today at the Northern Baptist Assembly.

Prompt action by the Board of Estimate and the City Council to increase the salaries of the city's top elected officials by amending the City Charter was urged yesterday by the Citizens Budget Commission in letters to the members of both bodies.

That "cold" front, which came in along with Saturday's rain, did nothing to cool off the Dodgers, who hammered the one-time ace, Johnny Sain, for thirteen hits and beat the Boston Braves, 7 -- 2, at Ebbets Field yesterday.

LENOX, Mass., Aug. 14 -- The twelfth season of Berkshire symphonic festivals ended at Tangle-wood this afternoon with something extra special in the way of fond farewells for Serge Koussevitzky, conductor of the Boston Symphony Orchestra and head of the Berkshire Music Center.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 (AP) -- Senator A. Willis Robertson said today that testimony before the Senate Banking Committee indicated John L. Lewis' United Mine Workers "has a monopoly" that is controlling coal production and that it would lead to higher consumer prices.

CHICAGO, Aug. 14 -- Herbert Hoover passed through Chicago today en route from Palo Alto, Calif., to New York, appearing completely recovered from the gall bladder attack he suffered on the train the night before.

STOCKHOLM, Aug. 14 -- Joe Walcott of Camden, N. J., knocked out Olle Tandberg, the Swedish heavyweight champion, at Raasunda Stadium tonight in the fifth round of a scheduled twelve-round fight. A record Scandinavian boxing crowd of 43,000 paid the equivalent of $175,000 to see the bout.

American Overseas Airlines announced yesterday that it was starting its first scheduled European flight from Idlewild International Airport Wednesday. Governor Dewey issued a statement calling the flights "concrete evidence of the new spirit of cooperation between the airlines and the Port Authority that marked the conferences I had with them recently."

RED BANK, N. J., Aug 14 -- Skimming past some of the fastest boats in the country and even lapping them as if they were tied to mooring buoys, the amazing combination of Wild Bill Cantrell behind the steering wheel of My Sweetie captured the National Sweepstakes title for 1949 on a flat, fast, perfect North Shrewsbury River regatta course today.

Man must choose between two levels -- to be honest or dishonest, to be true or untrue, to spread good report or evil report, the Rev. Dr. Frederick K. Stamm of the Congregational Church of Chicago said in a morning sermon yesterday in the chapel of the Collegiate Church of St. Nicholas, 1 West Forty-eighth Street.

MOSCOW, Aug. 14 (UP) -- The Communist organ Pravda, in a Berlin dispatch captioned "The Comedy of Elections in Western Germany," said today that Berlin press reports from the Western zones indicated the "main mass of the population show complete indifference to the elections."
Aug. 15 has a special place on the calendar of the Pacific. It is a day of anniversaries, a day of beginnings and a day of endings.

The Household Finance Corporation, in its semi-annual report issued for release today showed a net income of $5,362,331, equal to $2.12 a common share, for the first six months of this year. It compares with $4,689,108 or $1.84 a share earned in the six months ended on June 30, 1948.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Aug. 6 -- Swedish shipyards are working full time but, with future orders beginning to thin out because of world competition, some of them now are bidding on Russian small craft, which up to a short while ago they spurned.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 14 (AP) -- The Pittsburgh Pirates solved Ace Hurler Howard Pollet for seven hits in five innings, while their own Cliff Chambers pitched a three-hit 4-to-0 triumph over the St. Louis Cardinals today -- dropping the Redbirds into second place in the National League race.

The three-story dwelling at 129 East Eightieth Street, wllich was purchased recently by Michael C. Berg, operator, has been resold by him to William Green, builder, who will remodel it into small apartments. L. J. Phillips Co. negotiated both deals. Leo Feinberg was attorney for lVIr. Berg, and !Vfurray Trayrnan of Max E. Greenberg Company represented Mr. Green.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 14 -- Airing of the serious differences between Dr. Juan Atilio Bramuglia, who resigned last week as Argentine Foreign Minister, and Dr. Jeronimo Remorino, Ambassador to the United States, on the question of commercial relations with the United States is likely to complicate the task of United States Ambassador James Bruce's successor.
Higher pensions for Protestant Episcopal clergymen will be recommended at the church's triennial general convention to be held Sept. 26 to Oct. 7 in San Francisco.

In its annual report for 1948, just published, the Federal Reserve Board calls attention to the fact that it is "better equipped today than ever before to help offset deflationary forces, should they actually develop." The report goes on to say that the system "has almost unlimited means of supplying the market with additional reserves through purchases of Government securities."

Transportation equipment valued at $45,638,865 was the principal commodity supplied to the Federal Government by New York State manufacturers and dealers in April, May and June under the Walsh-Healey Public Contracts Act, according to a statement issued for publication today by Arthur J. White, regional director of the wage and hour public contracts divisions, Department of Labor, for New York and New Jersey.

MANCHESTER, Mass., Aug. 14 -- Mrs. Margaret Osborne du Pont of Wilmington, Del., reigning national champion, today won both the singles and doubles championships in the Essex Country Club tennis tournament.

TUCKAHOE, N. Y., Aug. 14 -- Jack Mallon, Cold Spring Harbor pro, topped a big field for both individual and team honors in the first annual pro-member benefit golf tournament at the Vernon Hills Country Club today.

Additional proof that designs of the present and the past may be combined successfully, even on the dining table, is offered by McCreeery's in a series of four table settings on display in the eighth floor "salt box" shop. The tables should suggest many ideas to homemakers who have incomplete sets of china or single heirloom pieces they have ben unable to use in complete settings.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 (AP) -- The Army and Air Force announced today a joint clemency and parole board would be established Aug. 18 to review periodically sentences pronounced by courts-martial.

An erratic movement in the pound sterling on Friday in which the demand for spot carried to the best price of the week, while forwards widened to sharp discounts, featured an otherwise stagnant market in the foreign exchanges.

QUITO, Ecuador, Aug. 14 (UP) -The United States "mercy airlift" carried 42,000 tons of supplies into Ecuador's earthquake-wrecked interior and brought out 603 persons during its first week of operations, it was announced today.

LONDON, Aug. 14 -- Some of the best-informed foreign observers of the British economic scene consider that many of the criticisms of British policy that now are being made in the United States are either unjust and unreasonable or irrelevant.
HONG KONG, Aug. 14 -- Independent Chinese reports tonight said Communists had captured three of the strategic Miao Islands off Shantung in a heavy amphibious assault that is still under way.

Dr. Albert George, Professor of Romance Languages at Syracuse University, has been appointed director of the European office of the Institute of International Education in Paris, Donald J. Shank, vice president and acting director of the institute, announced yesterday.
I want to thank you for the space that you gave to the report of the decision of the Court of Appeals in the so-called Bercu case.
The Congressional investigation of the B-36 has, so far, given the Air Force its very rightful day in court.

We heartily endorse the proposal by the Citizens Budget Commission that the salary of the Mayor of New York City be raised from $25,000 to $35,000, the Controller's from $20,000 to $25,000, that of the President of the City Council from $15,000 to $20,000, and of the Borough Presidents from $15,000 to $18,000.

New concepts of the adequacy of bank capital in relationship to deposits and to loans and investments has resulted in the discarding of some of the old rules and substitution of others for the measurement of the soundness of commercial banks, the recent report of the Controller of the Currency to Congress indicates.

Because of the demand by parents for a film on sex education that can be shown to younger children, Eddie Albert, producer of the movie "Human Growth," is planning the second in a series, it was learned yesterday.
Msgr. Abbot Enrico De Vivo celebrated his fiftieth anniversary in the Roman Catholic priesthood last night with a dinner attended by 300 relatives and friends in the Cascades of the Biltmore Hotel.
WINDOW ROCK, Ariz., Aug. 14 -- A nationwide appeal was issued here today for trained nurses to remedy a serious shortage of such trained personnel in hospitals on the Navajo Indian Reservation.

Citing the extremely high accident record of youthful drivers, the State Insurance Department announced yesterday that it had approved an increase of 15 to 20 per cent in automobile liability rates for cars operated by drivers under the age of 25.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -- Television will help industry move a far greater volume of goods than ever before, according to a report published today by the Department of Commerce. Television, the report said, is destined to create new desires and needs.

During an eleven-month period recently ended the thirty-six scheduled United States airlines flew almost 6,000,000,000 passenger-miles without a passenger fatality, according to the Air Transport Association. The only comparable period in American aviation history was the seventeen months from March, 1939, to August, 1940, when there were no fatal accidents.

The need for application of full Christian standards to charity and the need for understanding the meaning of almsgiving have never been more urgent than in our time, the Rev. Michael J. Deacy, of the staff of St. Patrick's Cathedral declared in a sermon there yesterday at solemn mass.

NEW LONDON, Conn., Aug. 14 -- Now at the end of its first weekend, the American Dance Festival being held in the Palmer Auditorium here under the auspices of Connecticut College, has presented the premieres of four works by as many choreographers. The percentage of success, however, has not been high, for of them all, only one has been in any way notable.

Gen. Mikulas Ferjencik, former Secretary of State in the Czechoslovak War Office, and his wife, Milada were detained yesterday by Federal authorities as suspected Communists on their arrival here from Europe.

CHICAGO, Aug. 14 -- Many companies are placing orders for longer terms ahead, order backlogs are rising in some instances, production is making a better showing, and the decline in employment is leveling off.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 14 -- Steel ingot output advanced 1 point last week to 82.5 per cent of rated capacity and partially confirmed for the second week in a row the betterment in new order volume. For the time being, at least, it was believed here that the downward trend had been stopped.

Less than fifty miles south of Lake Geneva in France is Chamonix. It is hardly more than a stone's throw from the Swiss border in the shadow of the Alps. A bit to the south of it, still in the same department of Savoie, is picturesque Albertville.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 14 -- The Yankees came within a couple of whiskers of grabbing two more games from Connie Mack's Athletics today, but in the last few minutes the law of averages, or something of the sort, intervened to ruin a perfect afternoon for Casey Stengel.

ODESSA, Tex., Aug. 14 (AP) -- Tuskegee Institute ran away with the women's senior National A. A. U. track and field championship last night, but the aging Stella Walsh of Cleveland, for twenty-two years a star of the cinder path, closed out her career in a three-way defeat.

LAKE SUCCESS, Aug. 14 -- A majority of the Latin-American countries favor holding the 1950 session of the United Nations General Assembly at Rio de Janeiro, Buenos Aires or Paris, rather than at Flushing Meadow.

The lightnings that flash between Belgrade and Moscow are burning new holes in the Iron Curtain. Actually, indeed, it is not nearly so good a screen as it was. When Russia moved her frontier westward she carried with it not only the Soviet system but the secrecy and isolation that go with it.

National Airlines, it was learned here yesterday, is seeking Civil Aeronautics Board approval for the first air coach service by a scheduled airline between New York and Florida. The fare contemplated would be $46.80 to Miami, compared with the current standard air fare of $75.70 and rail coach service at $35.87.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 (AP) -- An examiner for the Federal Power Commission has held that the commission lacks jurisdiction over proposals by three New York City utilities to pool natural gas received from Trans-Continental Pipe Line Corp., Longview, Tex.

A three-month period, during which the Federal Trade Commission could have sought review of a decision setting aside its order against alleged price-fixing in the tag manufacturing industry, has expired without such action being taken, it was made known yesterday.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 15 -Ethel Barrymore, doyenne of the American stage and screen, received congratulations by radio tonight on her seventieth birthday from nearly 100 friends and admirers, headed by President Truman. The messages and felicitations were broadcast in a half-hour, pre-recorded program over the ABC network scheduled for release at 10:30 o'clock in each time zone across the country.

Meter sales campaigns on household refrigerators have been producing "phenomenal results" in every section of the country since the lifting of Regulation W on July 1, it was reported yesterday by the International Register Company of Chicago, maker of Meter-Matic coin meters. Sales of fifteen refrigerators a day by smaller dealers to 300 a day by larger dealers are not unusual, according to the company.

Cooks whose salad repertoire remains extensive after last week's heat wave merit the tall toppling hat and snowy neckerchief reserved for the finest professional chefs. By now, most of us have rung every cooling change we know on potato salad, cole slaw and tossed greens, and are about ready to start the cycle over again.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 15 -- Eight right-wing and three left-wing candidates led the heavy balloting today for eleven positions on the Local 601 Westinghouse delegation to the United Electrical and Radio Workers, CIO, to the international convention at Cleveland on Sept. 19.

HONOLULU, Aug. 15 -- Harry Bridges, president of the striking International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union, defied a territorial court order restraining picketing of Government pier operation soon after it was issued today.

Joe Adonis, Brooklyn racketeer and reputed gambling overlord, was named yesterday in the General Sessions wiretap trial as a principal stockholder in a New Jersey conveyance company that transports "all Ford automobiles" to New York City and vicinity.

NEWARK, N. J., Aug. 15 -- Superior Court Judge Nathan L. Jacobs today continued until Thursday morning hearing on arguments in two segregation and discrimination cases involving four East Orange state housing projects.

BUFFALO, Aug. 15 (AP) -- The Bell Aircraft Corporation said tonight that 1,148 employes had passed picket lines to report for work today. Members of the striking United Automobile Workers, CIO, asserted that their demonstrations had "stopped the company cold."

The building at 391-393 Fifth Avenue, occupied by I. J. Fox, Inc., furrier, has been sold and resold in a series of transactions which also involved a change in owner of the property occupied by Oppenheim Collins Co. at 31-39 West Thirty-fourth Street and 46-60 West Thirty-fifth Street.

Add to the list of films opening this week "Siren of Atlantis" and "Special Agent," both of which will arrive in first-run theatres on Saturday. "Siren of Atlantis," which has its local premiere at the Globe, is a romantic adventure featuring Maria Montez, Jean-Pierre Aumont and Dennis O'Keefe.

LONDON, Aug. 15 -- British Treasury experts are now marshaling a great array of statistics to be used in defense of the Labor Government's economic policies at next month's dollar crisis conference in Washington.

Directors of the E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., yesterday declared an interim dividend of 65 cents on each share of the common stock, payable Sept. 14. This is equal to $2.60 a share on the old common stock, which was split four for one on June 15.

MOSCOW, Aug. 15 -- United States Ambassador Admiral Alan G. Kirk held a forty-minute Kremlin conference with Premier Stalin tonight -- the first personal discussion between the Soviet leader and an American diplomat in almost exactly a year.

The city's Department of Health reported forty-one new cases of poliomyelitis yesterday, six more than the previous day, and released figures indicating an increase in incidence of the disease among adults.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (AP) -Following is the text of a statement by Senators Vandenberg and Dulles explaining their proposed amendments to the Administration's $1,450,000,000 foreign arms bill:

Frank Parker lost his place on the United States Davis Cup team to Richard (Pancho) Gonzales of Los Angeles, the National tennis champion, with the announcement yesterday of the combination that will defend the trophy against Australia in the challenge round to be played in the Forest Hills Stadium Aug. 26, 27 and 28.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- The Administration's full $1,450,000,000 program for helping arm this country's allies in the North Atlantic treaty and other non-Communist lands was approved tonight by the House Foreign Affairs Committee.

LONDON, Aug. 15 -- Malta's 33-year-old Deputy Prime Minister Dom Mintoff publicly resigned in London today because he believed the island's Prime Minister, Dr. Paul Boffa, was not being firm in his demands on the British Government.

TAIPEH, Formosa, Aug. 15 -- A setback in the Nationalist efforts to blockade the Communist North China coast was admitted by Admiral Kwei Yung-ching, naval commander in chief, here today. Admiral Kwei confirmed the Communist capture of three islands off the Shantung coast opposite Penglai which Nationalist ships had been using as operating bases.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 15 -- Veterans' organizations must cease bickering among themselves and utilize their combined strength to fight adverse legislation if they were to achieve their goals, Ray Brannaman of Greeley, Col., past commander in chief of the Veterans of Foreign Wars, today warned delegates to the twenty-eighth national convention of the Disabled American Veterans.

In Washington recently I had the privilege of talking with Gen. Albert C. Wedemeyer, Gen. Claire Chennault, a number of Senators and Representatives, and an official high in the Far Eastern Division of the State Department about China. I also heard Gen. George C. Marshall and Henry R. Grady, our Ambassador to Greece, discuss the Military Aid Program with the House Foreign Affairs Committee.
TEL AVIV, Israel, Aug. 15 -Israel is seeking a credit from the Soviet Union similar to the $100,000,000 United States loan.

DAMASCUS, Syria, Aug. 15 -Col. Sami Hinnawi, who became head of the Syrian Army and of the Supreme War Council in the Sunday morning coup d'etat in which President Husni Zayim was overthrown and killed, turned over the Government today to a new civilian Cabinet.

PARIS, Aug. 15 -- At a meeting with the European Marshall Plan council here tomorrow, Paul G. Hoffman will call upon Europe to make greater efforts to earn dollars by exporting to the United States and to take bold measures this year to reduce trade barriers within Europe.

A defense witness at the Communist trial testified yesterday that the purpose of the party's post-war ideological campaign was not to teach force and violence but to defend the party against "misrepresentations" by "big business."

Mayor O'Dwyer charged yesterday that the United States Public Health Service was using "the well-known blackjack" when it said it would take back the Veterans Administration Hospital at Manhattan Beach if the city reclaimed the Neponsit Beach Hospital at Beach 149th Street, Rockaway Beach, Queens.

LONDON, Aug. 15 -- The rally in British Government funds toward the close of last week continued in the stock market here today. Early advances were due to technical adjustments but business broadened during the afternoon and all-round gains up to 1.5 points were seen throughout the list.

The New York Life Insurance Company has retained Skidmore, Owings Merrill, architects, to prepare plans for the redevelopment of a blighted area in the heart of Chicago's South Side, which will provide apartments for 1,400 families and an adjacent shopping center.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 15 (AP) -- Wimbledon champions, Richard (Pancho) Gonzales and the veteran Frankie Parker, launched their bid for the national doubles tennis title in heavy-handed fashion today at Longwood.

Demolition of the old extension building back of the Astor Hotel, abutting Shubert Alley, is scheduled to be completed today. Then excavation will begin immediatly to make way for recon struction of that familiar theatrical by-way connecting Forty-fourth and Forty-fifth Streets between Seventh and Eighth Avenues.

Postmaster General Jesse M. Donaldson has announced that a commemorative stamp honoring the Grand Army of the Republic would be issued on the first day of their last reunion, Aug. 28, in Indianapolis.

Because of an adverse decision from the Board of Elections, Arnold L. Fein, Fair Deal Democratic candidate for the City Council from the Eighteenth Senatorial District, went into the Manhattan Supreme Court yesterday afternoon in his fight to have himself made the only Democratic candidate for the Council from the lower East Side district.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- An irate House of Representatives refused today to approve immediately a third stop-gap appropriations bill to sustain the flow of funds into more than a score of Government departments and agencies, including the National Military Establishment.

Kidder, Peabody Co. and Mitchum, Tully Co. will offer to the public today a new issue of $8,000,000 of 2 3/4 per cent sinking-fund debentures due on Aug. 15, 1969, of Food Machinery and Chemical Corporation. The debentures are priced at 100.76 per cent and accrued interest to yield approximately 2.70 per cent to maturity.

A high-record volume of $37,593,541 in sales is reported by Grayson-Robinson Stores, Inc., national chain of apparel stores, in its statement for the six months ended on June 30, released today. This is an increase of 12.56 per cent over the $33,399,588 sales of the first half of 1948.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- The Federal Communications Commission today made public a letter to Senator Edwin C. Johnson, chairman of the Senate Interstate Commerce Committee, saying that FCC has no legal authority to ban hard liquor advertising in radio and television.

Those who hold the theory that rod and gun editors do not need a vacation almost have convinced us that there is considerable truth in their contention, for after one look at the accumulated mail we decided to give the vacation idea more thought next summer.

ATHENS, Aug. 15 -- The bodies of twenty Albanian Army regular soldiers were found in the vicinity of Kroustalopiyi a few miles within Greek territory and seven Albanian Army regulars were captured along with files pertaining to one Albanian Army company, a late Greek General Staff communique announced tonight.
NEW DELHI, India. Aug. 15 -India celebrated the beginning of her third year of independence today in the familiar mixed atmosphere of self-criticism and austere dedication to the tasks ahead.

BRONXVILLE, N. Y., Aug. 15 -Mrs. Donald O'Brien of Winged Foot won the qualifying medal in the Women's Westchester and Fairfield Golf Association's twenty-fourth annual tournament today by touring the sunburnt fairways of the Siwanoy Country Club course in 41, 38 -- 79.

CHICAGO, Aug. 15 (AP) -- Johnny Palmer, belting some phenomenal recovery shots, carded a four-under-par 68 to Jimmy Demaret's 70 today to bag the $10,000 top prize in a play-off for the Tam O'Shanter "world" golf championship.

The State of Montana sold $5,000,000 of building bonds yesterday for the University of Montana. The bonds, which were dated Sept. 1, 1949, are due on Sept. 1, 1950, to 1969. They were awarded to the Chase National Bank of New York and associates, who bid 100.579 for a 1.60 per cent coupon.

SHANGHAI, Tuesday, Aug. 16 -- That China's Communist leaders consider as a serious threat United States Secretary of State Dean Acheson's proposals of United States support for "democratic individualism" within Communist China was shown today by a second official editorial on the United States White Paper.

Beginning next Monday, Westinghouse Electric Corporation will increase refrigerator production 50 per cent, George H. Meilinger, household refrigeration manager, disclosed yesterday. The company cut back refrigerator output 50 per cent in June.
Vacationers coming back into town from the mountains and beaches will find the collections of autumn fashions now being delivered to the stores in a new range of fall colors -- misty and mellow.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (AP) -- A move for a round-table discussion of Federal aid to education met opposition today from Representative Graham A. Barden, Democrat, of North Carolina, author of a bitterly contested education bill. He termed the move a "wholly foolish gesture."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (AP) -Col. Robert R. McCormick's Chicago Tribune paid $4,500,000 cash for The Washington Times-Herald, morning and afternoon newspaper that Mrs. Eleanor M. Patterson willed to seven "faithful employes" a year ago.

Representatives of the twenty-three nations which are the contracting parties to the General Agreement on Tariffs of 1947 (the so-called Geneva Trade Agreement) have just ended their third session, representing four months of work, at Annecy, France.

TY COBB once remarked grimly, "Hits are my bread and butter." It's true, perhaps, that other ballplayers never bothered to voice the same words as succinctly or as belligerently as the Georgia Peach. But every man jack of them always has felt the same way about his base hits. Nor have the diamond heroes continually seen eye to eye with the official scorers on their judgments.

ON BOARD YACHT VELERO IV, Off Santa Cruz Island, Calif., Aug. 15 -- In a tense and hazardous descent 2,300 feet into the Pacific Ocean in a five-foot steel ball, Otis Barton, 48 years old, a Boston engineer, set a record today for deep-sea diving by a single individual.
Two floors of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel were transformed yesterday into a mammoth -- and very expensive -- jewelry mart.

Rubber futures advanced sharply in active trading on the Commodity Exchange yesterday. The active interest reflected moderately stronger tones in both the London and Singapore markets. The market here closed 27 to 35 points up compared with Friday's close.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Aug. 15--Official sources indicated today that the Government would not make an issue at this time either of the consecration of the two bishops without Government approval at Trnava yesterday or of the unauthorized meeting of the Board of Bishops at the same time.

EAU CLAIRE, Wis., Aug. 15 -Ralph Wright, assistant Secretary of Labor, told the Wisconsin Federation of Labor today that "the solid foundation of social and economic legislation laid in President Roosevelt's New Deal and President Truman's Fair Deal serves today as a cushion to prevent a depression."

LONDON, Aug. 15 -- Deputies of the Big Four Foreign Ministers, who are drafting an Austrian peace treaty here, moved ahead slightly today by approving another treaty article, thus reducing to eleven their list of unagreed articles. The deputies have till Sept. 1 to finish their treaty draft or report disagreement to the coming conference of the Foreign Ministers in the United States.

Cyrus Sulzberger certainly had a wonderful time in our country, as his recent article about Czechoslovakia shows. His description of the Communist, paradise, however, would justify the Czechoslovak people in exclaiming in amazement -- if they were allowed to read it, of course.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Aug. 15 -- The United States will give strong economic and political support to the conservative Government of the German Federal Republic that will be formed as a result of yesterday's elections, United States political officials here said today.

Investigation Commissioner John M. Murtagh recommended yesterday that the licenses of three ticket brokers be revoked. The suggestions were contained in an interim report to Mayor O'Dwyer on the inquiry into ticket scalping ordered by the Mayor on May 3.

Policemen all over the city were placed on a special alert yesterday after a strike was called against the Holmes Patrol, which provides electric burglar alarm protection for 17,000 of the city's business establishments, including banks, jewelry houses and many large stores.

Citing the increased volume of Suez Canal shipping, a British shipowners' group has appealed to the canal operators to reduce tolls on merchant ships, the National Federation of American Shipping reports.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday closed steady, unchanged to 10 points higher than Friday's final quotations.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- A reader of some current dispatches from American writers on the subject of the forthcoming American-British conversations here with respect to the latest British economic crisis might assume the following:

A grant of $45,000 has been made by the Josiah Macy Jr. Foundation to the World Federation for Mental Health to enable it to keep the World Health Organization carry out the mental health program it adopted recently in Rome.

WALTHAM, Mass., Aug. 15 -- A stockholders' meeting today elected a new board of directors for the Waltham Watch Company and authorized steps necessary to consummate the reorganization plan approved on June l0 by the Federal Court.

Stimulated by the service of new and fast United States flag merchant ships and by the strong liking for American goods acquired by the people from "down under" during the war, trade between the United States, Australasia and Oceania is now virtually double that of the pre-war period, the American Merchant Marine Institute reports.

GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 15 -The Hampshire team of Gus Salerno, pro, and Mort Cummings, 20-year-old ex-G. I., posted a best ball score of 32, 33 -- 65 to win top honors over a field of seventy-eight pro-amateur teams at Tamarack Country Club today in the weekly one-day event of the Westchester P. G. A.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (AP) -Senator Robert A. Taft, Republican, of Ohio, today accused President Truman of interfering with the decisions of Congress on government reorganization.
FRANKFORT, Germany, Aug. 15 -- European Command Headquarters lent weight today to recent statements that the United States was not reducing its armed strength in Germany.

BOSTON, Aug. 15 (AP) -- Ted Williams capped a 2-run rally by singling in Dom DiMaggio with two out in the eleventh inning to give the Boston Red Sox a 3-2 victory over the Washington Senators and a six-game sweep tonight before 30,619 fans.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores declined 22 per cent last week compared with the corresponding week last year, according to the "flash" report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. Sales declined 15 per cent in the four-week period ended last Saturday.

LONDON, Aug. 15 (Reuters) -England's batsmen, in the second day of the last cricket test match at the Oval, today hammered the New Zealand attack to finish the day 87 runs ahead with six wickets to fall. By close of play England had 432 for four in reply to the tourists' total of 345.

A budget of $804,000, including the initial expenditure from the $8,000,000 Kress Foundation grant, has been authorized for the first year's operation of the Post-Graduate Medical School as a unit of the New York University-Bellevue Medical Center, Dean Robert Boggs announced yesterday.

The stock market followed a course of least resistance yesterday as prices again backed away from the peaks of last midweek. Trading was extremely tempered and losses of fractions to approximately a point resulted, primarily from lack of bidding rather than from outright pressure.

Prospects for a good Christmas trade in jewelry have brightened in the last few weeks, following an estimated decline of 7 per cent in the first six months of this year, Maurice Adelsheim of Minneapolis, president of the American National Retail Jewelers Association, said yesterday.

On Aug. 5 and 6 there appeared in your paper two dispatches from your Middle East correspondent, Gene Currivan, written from Tel Aviv, Israel. Conclusions in these special dispatches to THE TIMES were incorrect at the following points:
LAUSANNE, Switzerland, Aug. 15 -- Israeli and Arab delegates will meet tomorrow for the first time since the United Nations Conciliation Commission began its quest for a settlement in Palestine.
Mayor O'Dwyer endorsed yesterday a proposal by the Citizens Budget Commission calling for salary increases for the city's top elected officials, including a $10,000a-year rise in his own pay.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (UP) -Americans for Democratic Action today praised J. Howard McGrath, Democratic National Chairman, for "unmasking the Dixiecrats" in his call for a National Committee meeting here Aug. 24.

Dwight Deere Wiman and the Columbia Broadcasting System are working together to develop "The Little Show," a Broadway stage production of twenty years ago, into a half-hour intimate revue for television. A closed circuit telecast will be staged for try-out purposes within the next few weeks but the proposed series has no starting date as a regular CBS feature.

JERUSALEM, Aug. 15 -- Some mystery surrounds the last-minute decision to postpone the detonation of three-and-a-half tons of explosives mining the Nablus Gate in the Old City and less than 500 yards from the Holy Sepulchre.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- The Treasury announced that the tenders for $1,000,000,000, or thereabouts, of ninety-one-day Treasury bills to be dated Aug. 18 and to mature on Nov. 17, 1949, which were offered on Aug. 12, were opened at the Federal Reserve banks today.

Stokely-Van Camp. Inc., in its annual statement to be mailed to stockholders today reports net sales of $95,037,212 for the fiscal year ended on May 31, compared with $95,110,041 transacted in the preceding fiscal year.

CHICAGO, Aug. 15 (AP) -- The St. Louis Cardinals whittled the idle Brooklyn Dodgers' first-place lead in the National League race to a half-game today when they whipped the Chicago Cubs, 5 to 2, before a crowd of 19,754.

ALBANY, Aug. 15 -- The State Controller, Frank C. Moore, in a letter to Governor Dewey, charged today that evidence of "larceny, payment of false claims, perjury, forgery and conspiracy" had been uncovered during his department's examination of Hamilton County.

LARAMIE, Wyo., Aug. 15 -- Representatives of private and public interests found only one area of agreement today on the development of the country's great river valleys, namely, that the basins should be developed along the accepted national policy of river drainage lines.

MOSCOW, Aug. 15 -- A clear indication of the importance that is attached here to diplomatic exchanges between the Soviet Union and Yugoslavia has been provided today by Pravda. The paper devoted five of seven foreign news columns to the reaction to the latest Soviet denunciation of Marshal Tito and new reports of Belgrade's gravitation into the Western camp.

ATHENS, Aug. 15 -- One of the most noteworthy developments in Greece, as her Army seeks to put an end to the military rebellion, is the gradual emergence of this country from a form of diplomatic isolation and the reshaping of her foreign policy.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- The House, seeking to eliminate a loophole in the anti-trust code, today passed a bill designed to prevent large corporations from taking over smaller competing firms by acquiring their assets.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 15 (AP) -Pinch hitter Hal Peck socked a bases loaded single in the tenth inning tonight and gave Bob Feller a 4-to-3 victory over the Detroit Tigers. It was the Cleveland fireballer's sixth straight triumph.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (AP) -- June, the month of marriages, brought a $7,000,000 pick-up in retail jewelry store sales compared with May. The Department of Commerce reporting this today, said the estimated $87,000,000 in sales was, however, $16,000,000 below June, 1948.

Loft's candy factory in Long Island City, Queens, one of the world's largest, was tied up yesterday by a strike of 900 production workers represented by Local 550, Bakery and Confectionery Workers International Union. AFL.

LAKE SUCCESS, Aug. 15 -- President Truman is expected to select Oct. 24 -- United Nations Day and the fourth anniversary of the coming into effect of the United Nations Charter -- for a long-promised visit to the United Nations to lay the cornerstone of the permanent headquarters in Manhattan.
BOSTON, Aug. 15 -- A state building program calling for expenditure of $35,000,000 was presented today to the Massachusetts State Legislature by Gov. Paul A. Dever, Democrat.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 15 -James Mason will leave for Paris on Sept. 4 to play opposite Greta Garbo in the Walter Wanger-Eugene Frenke production, "La Duchess de Langeais," it was learned today.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 15 -- The Yankees ran into an ambush tonight that all but put them in the mood to call off next Sunday's Connie Mack Day at the Stadium.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., Aug. 15 -- Mrs. Shelby Torrance of Garden City, unheralded competitor in the New York State women's tennis championships, today scored her second major upset of the competition to gain the final round at the Cherry Valley Club.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Aug. 8 (AP) -The Arabian-American Oil Co. (Aramco) is slicing its roll of American employees from 2,700 to around 1,350 in Saudi Arabia.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (AP) -Ingalls Shipbuilding Corporation, Pascagoula, Miss., entered a bid of $4,864,006 today to construct a new-type successor to the wartime liberty ship as the backbone of the American merchant fleet.

WATERTOWN, N. Y., Aug. 15 -- Soldiers of the Forty-second Infantry Division, New York National Guard, and the Seventy-seventh Infantry Division, organized reserve, received instruction today at Pine Camp Cantonment from the First Battalion of the Seventh Regiment, Fort Devens, Mass., preparatory to starting two weeks of intensive field exercises.

Irene Holmes began living Chapter 3 of her unwritten novel yesterday. Chapter 2 started last February, when she went to work in an H. L. Green chain store. It ended this week with a nail polish and lipstick manufacturer finding her "a million dollar baby" among 10,000 other 5 and 10 cent store salesgirls.
TORONTO, Aug. 15 -- The Executive Council of the American Federation of Labor today branded recession talk in the United States as a deliberate propaganda campaign designed to hold down wages.

CHAUTAUQUA, N. Y., Aug. 15 -- "The greatest single evil of our time is the neglect of little children," said Prof. Howard Lane, special consultant at New York University, today as he opened a series of lectures to be delivered this week by educators in child development at the first annual Family Life Institute.

Joseph T. Sharkey, vice chairman of the City Council, announced yesterday that he had called an emergency session of that body for 4:30 P. M. tomorrow to consider a revision of the local rent laws designed to block the eviction of tenants who refuse to pay "excessive" rent increases granted by Federal authorities.

The German people gave emphatic endorsement to the new Federal Republic of Germany when nearly 80 per cent of the eligible voters turned out to cast their ballots in the first election in the new state. Repudiating the extremists of both left and right, the West Germans gave the bulk of their votes to moderate, middle-of-the-road parties which, whatever their other differences, are united in their dedication to democracy.

RYE, N. Y., Aug. 15 -- With the verdict sealed in the first three matches, Australia took the two remaining singles from Italy in the Davis Cup Interzone round at the Westchester Country Club today for a 5-0 sweep.

Among the post-mortems that utility men are discussing in the wake of the convention that the National Association of Railroad and Utilities Commissioners held in Cleveland last week is the remark of Walter F. Roberts, chairman of the Nebraska Railway Commission.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- The Republic of Colombia filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering $40,824,720 of thirty-year, 3 per cent, sinking fund dollar bonds.

THERE are three different countries in the fictional world of John O'Hara and Mr. O'Hara doesn't think much of the inhabitants of any of them. He paid his discourteous respects to the country-club and serious-drinking set in his first novel, "Appointment in Samarra," which was published just fifteen years ago. His second, "Butterfield 8," was a brutal and explicit exploration of sottish debauchery in New York during the speakeasy era.

Gertrude Lawrence arrived here last night from England and said she expected to have a "short season" in the United States, returning to Britain on April 1 to star in Noel Coward's "South Sea Bubble."
Although more passenger vessels are on order in domestic shipyards than at any time since the war, shipyard employment is at a new low, figures showed yesterday.
President Truman "acted outside the law" in creating the steel industry dispute panel, Ira Mosher, former president of the National Association of Manufacturers, said yesterday.

Former President Herbert Hoover returned yesterday to his suite at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel to resume work as head of the Government Reorganization Commission. He appeared fully recovered from the gall-bladder attack he suffered on the train trip from Palo Alto, Calif., where he celebrated his seventy-fifth birthday recently.

Departmental hearings on the 1950 capital budget, which began yesterday before the City Planning Commission, showed that the cost of school construction had dropped in the last two years from $1.35 to $1.04 a cubic foot.

CHICAGO, Aug. 15 -- Grain markets staged a strong rally today on the Board of Trade after early liquidation had carried September corn off around 2 cents to a new low since early last February and September wheat sold at the lowest in over a month.

We have had several reminders of late that Cooper Union is well along in its ninetieth year, and that the brownstone pile at the head of the Bowery houses a free school of art and science, founded when those two departments of human activity were not so closely associated as they are today.

LADENTOWN, N. Y., Aug. 15 -- Pincus Margulies, who opened a country store here forty-five years ago and who has been chairman of the Rockland County Board of Supervisors since 1945, is attempting to revive the lost Ramapo mountaineer art of making baskets, scoops, salad bowls, spoons, choping bowls and various other wooden utensils.

August wanders through its days on sticky feet and Summer's heat weighs hard against Earth's breast. Grass and shrubs beside country roads are gray with dust and leaves on woodland trees have lost their spring-green flush. Stubble on upland fields is brown; grass stems around pasture boulders have faded to amber gold.

LONDON, Tuesday, Aug. 16--Russia has relieved Anatoly Y. Lavrentiev, her Ambassador to Yugoslavia, of his duties and named him a Deputy Foreign Minister, Moscow announced early today.

GALWAY, Ireland, Aug. 15 -- Forty-nine persons were saved in a tense, flare-lit air-sea rescue operation today after a Trans-ocean Air Lines plane en route from Rome to the United States ran out of gas and landed in the Atlantic fifteen miles off the Irish coast.

The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company, in its statement covering the half year ended with last June, showed consolidated net sales of $311,823,235, compared with the $346,079,544 volume for the same six months of 1948.

" Heredity, East and West: Mendel Versus Lysenko," by Julian Huxley, scientist, author and former Director General of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization, has been scheduled for October publication by Henry Schuman.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- The National Committee for Free Europe, whose primary purpose is to aid non-Fascist and non-Communist leaders in restoring fundamental freedom in Iron Curtain satellite countries, is proceeding rapidly with its plans, a report showed today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- In its monthly comment on transportation statistics the Bureau of Transport Economics and Statistics of the Interstate Commerce Commission finds important increases in efficiency of railroad freight service.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 15 (AP) -- The Pittsburgh Pirates overtook Cincinnati with a four-run sixth inning tonight and then went on to defeat the Reds, 9 -- 7, before a crowd of 11,371. Rip Sewell, who took over from Starter Bill Werle during a fifth-inning Redleg uprising, gained credit for his sixth victory as against one defeat.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- The Hawaii Employers Council said today that recent speeches by Senator Wayne L. Morse, Republican, of Oregon, dealing with the protracted stevedoring strike in Hawaii were "shocking, both in their implications and as disturbing examples of partisanship."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (UP) -The House Committee on Un-American Activities reported today that the mysterious "Scientist X" was involved in a "positive" case of Communist espionage at the atomic research center at Berkeley, Calif.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 15 -- The state's law designed to curb persons who join or work with subversive organizations was declared unconstitutional today in its first court test. The state immediately promised an appeal.

Buyers of linens and domestics are looking beyond their immediate needs and have ordered through October, according to manufacturers exhibiting lines this week at the domestics and linen show in the New Yorker Hotel. Stable prices and reduced inventories, they said, have been a factor in stepping up buying tempo for early fall.

James W. Bridges, a partner of Keystone Company, an investment trust of Boston, Mass., told 300 colleagues at the first session of their four-day convention in the Statler Hotel yesterday that "the farther we stay away from stock and bond selling techniques, the more quickly and more clearly the distinction will be made" between the two businesses.

STRASBOURG, France, Aug. 15 -- In a ceremony held today at noon in the Hotel de Ville, Winston Churchill was made an honorary citizen of Strasbourg for having obtained during the Battle of the Bulge on Jan. 3, 1945, Allied consent to reinforcement of the defense of Strasbourg from which Supreme Headquarters of the Allied European forces had ordered Allied troops withdrawn.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 15 (AP) -- Lefty Bill Wight blanked the St. Louis Browns with two hits tonight while the Chicago White Sox combined timely hits with Cliff Fannin's wildness to register an 8-to-0 victory before 2,000 fans.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 15 -- Detective, who cost Mrs. Aksel Wichfeld $25,000 at the Keeneland sales last summer, completed the process of winning himself out today -- and made a down payment on his one year board bill.
Day workers of the Triboro Coach Company in Queens voted last night to strike at midnight tonight and the night workers are expected to vote similarly at a meeting this morning.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- Declaring that Mrs. Harry S. Truman was one of the "finest things about the White House," Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican, of Wisconsin, today absolved the First Lady of anything "improper" in accepting a deep-freeze unit from Maj. Gen. Harry H. Vaughan, President Truman's military aide.

A high majority of wage earner families like advertising and follow it with interest for helpful suggestions, new ideas, information, news of new products and price information, according to a Wage Earner Forum survey announced yesterday.
OAKLAND, Calif., Aug. 15 -- A spokesman for the printing industry told the International Typographical Union here today that wage increases at this time would be "unrealistic."
A woman's voice came sharply over the telephone at the temporary Smoke Control Bureau offices at Room 1836 in the Municipal Building.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- The seed of an African plant holds the answer to the prayers of millions for cortisone, the recently synthesized adrenal gland hormone that pours buoyant new life into bodies tortured by arthritis and rheumatic fever, and promises new hope for victims of other chronic ills as well as the mentally afflicted.

The Hammond Instrument Company of Chicago, manufacturer of Hammond organs, is moving its New York headquarters from the large store it occupied for many years at 50 West Fifty-seventh Street to the Squibb Building at 745 Fifth Avenue.
GENEVA, Aug. 15 -- The United Nations Economic and Social Council concluded tonight its ninth and what most delegates regarded as its most successful session.
