SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 15 -- Detective, who cost Mrs. Aksel Wichfeld $25,000 at the Keeneland sales last summer, completed the process of winning himself out today -- and made a down payment on his one year board bill.
Day workers of the Triboro Coach Company in Queens voted last night to strike at midnight tonight and the night workers are expected to vote similarly at a meeting this morning.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- Declaring that Mrs. Harry S. Truman was one of the "finest things about the White House," Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican, of Wisconsin, today absolved the First Lady of anything "improper" in accepting a deep-freeze unit from Maj. Gen. Harry H. Vaughan, President Truman's military aide.

A high majority of wage earner families like advertising and follow it with interest for helpful suggestions, new ideas, information, news of new products and price information, according to a Wage Earner Forum survey announced yesterday.
The Port of New York Authority probably will build another tunnel under the Hudson River, Howard S. Cullman, its chairman, said last night.

A six-day session of the Summer School of Catholic Action opened at Fordham University yesterday. More than 2,000 persons have enrolled for the courses, which are designed to present a central theme of the "Christian in action."
CLEVELAND, Aug. 16 (AP) -- Big Al Benton baffled the Tigers today with a six-hit shut-out as the Indians closed their current home stand by winning, 5 -- 0.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 16 (AP) -- An eighth-inning homer by Sam Chapman started a four-run rally that carried the Athletics to a 7-4 victory over the Red Sox tonight.

Howard Johnson, a defense witness at the Communist trial, admitted under cross-examination yesterday that a Communist revolution in this country would not "necessarily" be peaceful, and that he had recommended for study in party schools definitions of "revolution" that stressed the need for violence.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 -- Guy G. Gabrielson, new Republican National Chairman, said today that a survey of the operations at Republican national headquarters indicated a marked overlapping of functions, which he intended to eliminate to produce "a business organization."

Too much "being nice" in the administration of the Marshall Plan can be blamed for "sharp dealings" injurious to United States exporters, members of the Export Managers Club were told yesterday in the Statler Hotel.

HONG KONG, Aug. 16 (UP) -- The China National Aviation Corporation suspended all operations today after the Hong Kong Government had requisitioned the Chinese-American owned firm's facilities at Kaitak airport.

American Overseas Airlines will begin non-stop service to London by Boeing Stratocruiser out of New York International Airport at Idlewild, Queens, at 3 P.M. today. Pan American Airways yesterday stepped up its Stratocruiser service from Idlewild to a daily basis, the planes leaving at 5 P.M.

Northbrook, one of the most sumptuous lodges in the Adirondacks on Osgood Lake at the town of Paul Smiths, N. Y., has been placed on the auction block. It will be sold along with the luxurious furnishings of the group of buildings on Saturday, Aug. 27, by Joseph P. Day, Inc., on the property.

STRASBOURG, France, Aug. 16 -- Two distinct trends -- one favoring immediate authority for the creation of a European legislative body and the other urging a more gradual approach to European unity -- developed here today in the course of sixteen speeches to the Consultative Assembly of the Council of Europe.

Plans for making the proposed new $1,017,500 downtown branch of the Brooklyn Public Library in Brooklyn's civic center a foremost institution of its kind were announced yesterday by Henry J. Davenport, president of the board of trustees of the Brooklyn Public Library.

The metropolitan area was exposed to its full complement of television stations last night for the first time when WOR-TV broadcast its initial program -- a baseball game at Ebbets Field between Brooklyn and Philadelphia. The station plans to carry the eight remaining night games of the Dodgers to be played at home.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 -- The United States Government will maintain diplomatic relations with the Chinese National Government, no matter where it may move its capital, it was said at the State Department today. Thus far, the department has no official information that the National Government intends to move from Canton.

RYE, N. Y., Aug. 16 -- The fourth international championship of the international-110 class, also constituting the sixth national championship of the group got under way at the American Yacht Club today.

A Frankfort dispatch in THE TIMES of July 31 conveys the thought that the current attacks on the Roman Catholic Church began with Hitler and Rosenberg. It winds up: "* * * nearly ten years before Russia's satellites launched their campaign against the Roman Catholic Church."

LAKE SUCCESS, Aug. 16 -- With 700 scientists from forty-four countries in attendance, the United Nations Scientific Conference on the Conservation and Utilization of Resources will open tomorrow at 10:30 A.M. with an address of welcome by J.A. Krug, United States Secretary of the Interior.

New York City's appetite for tunnels and bridges is apparently insatiable, and in spite of the tremendous cost a fourth crossing of the Hudson River is being considered by the Port of New York Authority. The Holland Tunnel was finished in 1927 and, with its approaches, cost $50,000,000. The George Washington Bridge was opened in 1931 and, with the improved approaches now being built, will have cost $80,000,000.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 16 -- The Soviet Government's announcement that Anatoly Y. Lavrentiev, its Ambassador to Belgrade, had been relieved of his position and appointed a Deputy Minister of Foreign Affairs has produced a plethora of speculation, some of it alarmist, among the diplomatic representatives of the Western powers.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 16 -- After being sworn in by President Juan D. Peron this morning, Argentina's new Foreign Minister, Hipolito Jesus Paz, declared tonight that he was replacing "a man, not a policy."

Plans are being completed for the two final horse mackerel contests of the season, the International Tuna Cup Matches and the Atlantic Tuna Tournament, both of which are scheduled to be bigger and better than ever.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Aug. 16 (AP) -- It was bargain day for the fair sex at this resort course today with "Ladies Day" inaugurated here for the first time. The top weekday crowd of the meeting brought out 17,000 with the distaff side well-represented.

The Seatrain Havana of Seatrain Lines, Inc., received a Naval Reserve pennant yesterday morning at a ceremony on the vessel's bridge at her berth at Edgewater, N.J. Capt. John J. Mockrish, USNR, Merchant Marine Reserve field representative of the Third Naval District, presented the blue flag to Donald W. Smith, Seatrain's vice president in charge of operations, and to Capt. Roswell E. King, master of the vessel.

MANHASSET, L.I., Aug. 16 -- William J. Levitt, builder of the world's largest veterans' housing development, closed at 1:10 o'clock this morning the largest of his six mass home sales, when the 650th ex-GI signed on the dotted line for a ranch house in the newest section of Levittown, to be ready for occupancy on Dec. 1.
PARIS, Aug. 16 -- Anny Blatt chooses metlon, a shimmering aluminum yarn, to bring a touch of brilliance to hand knit cocktail frocks of spidery delicacy.

LONDON, Aug. 16 (Reuters) -- John Reid, the 21-year-old star of the New Zealand cricket team, played the innings of his life against England at the Oval today and did most to allow New Zealand to draw the match like the other three tests.
A warrant of attachment was issued here yesterday against the property of Archduke Anton, a member of the former Austro-Hungarian royal family, and his wife, the Archduchess-Ileana.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Aug. 16 -- Pete Burke of Glen Oaks and Mike Izzo of Engineers captured the Long Island Professional Golfers Association scotch-foursome tournament with a 73, two over par, today at the Garden City Country Club.

THE destinies of kingdoms, it has often been pointed out, can be changed all for the want of a horseshoe nail. It is the romantic fancy of Theodore Bonnet that the destiny of Victorian England was shaped, at least in part, by a 7-year-old orphan from the London docks, a half-starved, dirty, wretched, ignorant urchin who caused a national scandal by falling down an open coal chute at Windsor Castle.

PORTLAND, Ore., Aug. 16 (UP) -- Senator J. Howard McGrath of Rhode Island said tonight that the elimination of "the guiding hand of spirituality" from American educational institutions would sap the foundations of American democracy.

TOKYO, Aug. 16 -- The Japanese Government is laying plans to maintain a continuous check on the activities of the thousands of communized repatriates that the Soviet Union has been returning here since last May. It is indicated that the "purge" laws may be used against a considerable number who continue to engage in politics.

Heavy wood planking and steel cable held in place yesterday the crumbling four - and - a - half-story brick building at 136 Macdougal Street, where alarmed tenants viewed ruefully the handiwork of demolition experts.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 (AP) -- An extra $11,500,000 to enable the Voice of America to penetrate the Iron Curtain despite increased Russian jamming was recommended by the House Appropriations Committee today.

Students of our culture say the American family is no longer so sturdy an institution, because it is being deprived of its functions. Things that used to be done within the household are now performed outside. Children learn at nursery school instead of at mother's knee; the movies replace games in the living-room, etc.
CHICAGO, Aug. 16 (AP) -- The Cubs broke loose for three runs in the ninth inning today to upset the high-flying Cardinals, 5 to 4, before a ladies' day crowd of 36,607.

Cats and canaries, guppies and goldfish and man's best friend and lesser friends, were well represented yesterday at the Children's Aid Society's tenth annual pet show at the Lower West Side Center. 219 Sullivan Street.
Representatives of 65,000 members of the International Longshoremen's Association have started annual deliberations here to formulate wage and working demands.

OAKLAND, Calif., Aug. 16 -- The ninety-first convention of the International Typographical Union, AFL, voted here today to continue its "no surrender" policy on working agreements, which underlies the twenty-one-month-old newspaper strike in Chicago.

Authoritative financial circles are admittedly perplexed as to what new requisitions can reasonably be made on the United States by Great Britain and other world states threatened by the financial wringer. As the "dollar shortage" crisis and world trade narrows, financiers see significance in the fact that recurring mention is made abroad of remedies which smack more of money sleight-of-hand than of competitive productivity and competitive price.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Aug. 16 -- The body of Theodor Herzl, founder of modern Zionism, whose vision of a Jewish state half a century ago has become a reality, was flown to Israel today from Vienna. It will be reinterred tomorrow on "Mount Herzl" in suburban Jerusalem, thereby fulfilling another hope he expressed before his death in 1904.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 -- The Davidson Baking Company, Portland, Ore., and its officers have agreed that a certain prize awarded to them will no longer be represented as received in a nation-wide contest, it was announced here today by the Federal Trade Commission.

Net income of the United Aircraft Corporation for the six months ended June 30 amounted to $3,595,421, equal to $1.10 a common share, compared with $5,743,731, or $1.91 a share, in the first half of last year, the company reported yesterday.
Fifty-six new cases of poliomyelitis but no additional deaths from the disease were reported yesterday by the city's Department of Health.

Gen. Mikulas Ferjencik, former Czechoslovak Minister of the Interior being detained on Ellis Island with his wife as a suspected Communist, is "not a Communist," Jan Papanek, former chief Czechoslovak delegate to the United Nations, declared yesterday.

Margaret Mitchell was a tiny Southern lady with bright, blue eyes and dark auburn hair who wrote one book. It made her one of the most famous writers of our time. "Gone with the Wind" was published in 1936, was awarded the Pulitzer Prize in 1937, and in thirteen years has sold 8,000,000 copies.

Robert Lee Roberson, 22-year-old ex-Marine of Rector, Va., was held in $15,000 Federal bail yesterday on a charge of cashing part of the $340,000 in travelers checks stolen last April 8 from the American Express Company's Philadelphia office.

Inventories in men's wear stores throughout the country at the end of July were spotty, both as compared with a theoretical normal as well as with the same period last year, the National Association of Retail Clothiers and Furnishers reported yesterday.

NEW LONDON, Conn., Aug. 16 -- The Dudley-Maslow-Bales trio opened the second week of the American Dance Festival in the Palmer Auditorium of Connecticut College tonight with their second program in the series, and a very good program it proved to be.

COHASSET, Mass., Aug. 16 -- The premiere of "The Fundamental George," a comedy by Max Wylie and John C. Gibbs, was given here last night by the South Shore Players, with Elliott Nugent returning to the stage in the starring role. Mr. Nugent also directed.

Councilman Edward Rager, Manhattan Republican, yesterday took to the Manhattan Supreme Court his fight to stay on the primary day ballot. He is seeking another four-year term as the Republican candidate from the Twentieth Senatorial District.

A statement yesterday by Arthur B. Homer, president of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, that the Presidential fact-finding board appeared to be a vehicle designed to force concessions upon the steel industry evoked a request for an apology from Samuel I. Rosenman, one of the three panel members.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 (AP) -- A Senate Agriculture subcommittee studying the fats and oils market was told today that the synthetic detergent industry made a rapid growth since the war.

BERLIN, Aug. 16 -- Contrary to all predictions of violence and disorder, the Gelsenberg benzine plant, at Gelsenkirchen near Essen, was hushed today at 200 German workers arrived to begin the dismantling of the huge synthetic gasoline enterprise.

Announcement was made yesterday that the Metropolitan Sewer District of Louisville and Jefferson Counties, Ky., will receive bids Aug. 30 on an issue of $4,000,000 sewer revenue bonds dated Sept. 1, 1949, and due Sept. 1, 1951 to 1974.

Mrs. Harry S. Truman and her daughter, Margaret, were among eighty guests who attended a luncheon yesterday on the United States liner America honoring Mrs. Perle Mesta, newly appointed Minister to Luxembourg.

LARAMIE, Wyo., Aug. 16 -- A farm organization leader said today that the only way to avoid Government controls over agricultural production in the effort to maintain farm income in relation to the income of other groups was to find some way to eat surpluses.

PARAMUS, N.J., Aug. 16 -- Mrs. Dorothy Bentham, playing her home course, won the New Jersey division of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Associations 50th point-par tournament over the West and East nines of the Ridgewood Country Club today.

For twenty minutes yesterday forty women, some of them pushing baby carriages, obstructed traffic at a Brooklyn intersection after a 10-year-old boy had been killed two hours earlier in a traffic accident.

It is odd -- and a little frightening -- how an idea sometimes comes to be fixed in one's head simply through repetition, said our visitor in the rumpled linen suit. This suit covered, with obvious reluctance at points, the form of our man with the unlikely name of Balboa Prawn.

Dr. Amos Turk, formerly of the chemistry department at City College, has been named director of research and development of the W.B. Connor Engineering Corporation, manufacturer of activated carbon air purification equipment.

Mr. and Mrs. Girard Van Barkaloo Hale have gifts galore for the children of Maille, a small French farming village adopted by the Santa Barbara, Calif., couple in 1946. Perhaps the greatest treat will be the one they described yesterday in the Plaza Hotel as they were preparing to sail Friday for Europe on the Queen Elizabeth.

CHICAGO, Aug. 16 -- Grains closed with a heavy undertone on the Board of Trade today after moderate early advances. September corn was the exception, closing 1/8-cent a bushel higher, while the new crop months were 1/8 to 5/8-cent lower.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 -- Four high-ranking Government officials explained today the great scientific importance of the discovery that cortisone, new "miracle drug" for treating arthritis, rheumatism and degenerative diseases, may be processed from the seed of an African vine of the Strophanthus genus.

Advised by his physician to wait until there is no recurrence of the heat wave, Alfred Lunt isn't rushing into rehearsals with "I Know My Love." Accordingly, he has extended his vacation, thus delaying practice sessions of the S.N. Behrman adaptation for a month to around Oct. 10.

ON BOARD YACHT VELERO IV, off Santa Cruz Island, Calif., Aug. 16 -- In his second attempt in two days in rough seas off Santa Cruz Island, Otis Barton today went down in a five-foot steel ball 4,500 feet below the surface of the Pacific -- man's farthest penetration of the ocean depths.

Solomon Eichenstein, who has been sought by the local authorities since last week for allegedly mulcting $90,000 from persons seeking to help Israel's economy, surrendered yesterday morning to the police of the West Forty-seventh Street Station.

ADAMS, Mass., Aug. 16 -- Soil conservation was dramatized here today before a crowd of 20,000 on the 160-acre farm of Walter N. Hadala. The Federal Soil Conservation Service was represented by its chief, Dr. Hugh Hammand Bennett.

CHICAGO, Aug. 16 -- David Bennett, Chicago manufacturer who paid for the deep freeze units presented to Mrs. Harry Truman and others prominent in the Truman Administration, has suffered a serious setback to his health by "such a personal affair being aired in a haphazard way," his attorney said tonight.

ATHENS, Aug. 16 -- Government forces penerating into the Pyxos Peninsula, the tiny land strip between Big and Little Prespa lakes, have liquidated the last of organized rebel resistance in the Vitsi area that had become the main theatre of operations five days ago.

Leonard Engel, science editor of The Nation and writer on scientific subjects, discusses the role of science in social and economic advancement in his forthcoming book. "What This Country Needs." It is an account of what science is doing to meet the need for greater food supply, more energy, increased consumer goods and improved facilities for prolonging life.
TRENTON, N.J., Aug. 16 -- A state board of appeals today awarded unemployment benefits to 4,000 Ford workers in New Jersey who were laid off during a strike in the company's Detroit plant.

The B.F. Goodrich Company, in its report yesterday covering the first six months of 1949, showed a sales decrease of only 2.8 per cent to $192,149,550 from the $197,688,828 for the same period a year ago.

SHANGHAI, Aug. 16 -- The fourth anniversary of the end of the Japanese war was celebrated here last night as the date on which "Soviet Russia defeated Japan." Today's Sin Wan Jih Pao in reporting on the celebration also noted that Aug. 15 marked the birthday of the "friendship alliance" between China and the Soviet Union.

"Modern Masters, Young and Old," the title of the summer show of paintings, drawings and sculpture at Carlebach's, sums up well enough its varied offerings. For in it, big names mix surprisingly well with new ones.

LONDON, Aug. 16 -- Concerned over "inadequate appreciation" of Britain's economic situation, the Federation of British Industries sounded an alarm today in a statement declaring that the country was in grave danger of being unable to buy essential food and raw materials and soon would have to face further austerity and unemployment unless a solution was found.

Sidney Moses, secretary of Tammany Hall, is scheduled to resign soon, it was learned yesterday. Mr. Moses has indicated to Carmine G. De Sapio, the new leader of Tammany, his willingness to step aside as soon as Mr. De Sapio has arrived at his own choice for the post.
ANKARA, Turkey, Aug. 16 (UP) -- The Government has granted Dr. Aaron J. Smith, of Greensboro, N. C., permission to explore Mt. Ararat for the hull of Noah's ark, the explorer announced today.

SHANNON, Ireland, Aug. 16 (AP) -- Flier Ruth Nichols disclosed tonight she had piloted the Trans-ocean airliner for two hours Sunday night several hours before it was forced down in the sea off the Irish coast.

Congratulations on the fine article by Charles Hurd in THE NEW YORK TIMES for Aug. 13 on the collapse of the charges made against the Air Force on matters of B-36 procurement. This fine job in reassuring the public will do much to repair the damage done to the national defense by these irresponsible charges.

Disclaimed by a circus with which they say they have a contract and unable to post sufficient bond to enter the country, a family of five Austrian high-wire walkers were left "up in the air" yesterday morning after their arrival on the United States liner Marine Tiger.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 -- Senator Wayne L. Morse, Republican, of Oregon, issued a sharp reply today to accusations of an employers' spokesman that his statements on the Hawaiian longshore strike were "shocking" examples of partisanship.

HONOLULU, Aug. 16 -- Both parties in Hawaii's 108-day longshore strike today agreed to resume negotiations at once "from scratch" and to call Cyrus S. Ching, Director of the United States Conciliation and Mediation Service, to Hawaii within three days to mediate if the strike is not settled by that time.

The Nelson Desk Company, dealer in new and used office furniture and equipment, has acquired the six-story and basement warehouse building at 123 Maiden Lane for its new quarters. The property, on a plot 25 by 84 feet, containing about 12,500 square feet, was leased from Mitchell P. Garretson and others in a transaction negotiated by Raymond E. Ryan, Inc., as broker.

Drastic price reductions on jeweled watches are unlikely, in view of high labor costs, James G. Shennan, president of the Elgin Watch Company, Elgin, Ill., said here yesterday. He indicated that retail sales of watches had been retarded this year because the public appeared to be waiting for such reductions.
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 16 (AP) -- Three Eastern railroads today won judgments totaling $635,219 from four western lines which they charged had failed to pay them correct freight rates for war shipments.

DAMASCUS, Syria, Aug. 16 (AP) -- Hashem el-Atassi, Premier of the new temporary government here, said today that Syria's future Parliament would have the final say on the United States oil pipeline concession.

A superintendent of a Brooklyn apartment house, where the prosecution contends a wiretap had been rigged on the telephone switchboard of Kings County Buick, Inc., testified yesterday that two men gave him $5 to use his cellar workshop.
BONN, Germany, Aug. 16 (AP) -- Dr. Konrad Adenauer, probable Chancellor of the new West German Federal Republic, said today he would not collaborate in any way with the Russians.
LONDON, Aug. 16 (AP) -- Policemen related in court today how they saved a 25-year-old typist from a mob of 1,200 persons who accused her of throwing scalding water on 2-year-old baby.

The construction cost index of Engineering News-Record advanced 8/10 of a point to 478.28 for August, which was back to the November, 1948, value. The index has now picked up six of the eight points dropped in the decline from October's peak of 480.2.

It looked yesterday as though thieves in New York were growing so bold as to steal armored cars right off the streets in the heart of the financial district. But it looked that way only for half an hour or so.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 16 (AP) -- Two amazing Japanese swimmers took turns at breaking the world record for the 1,500-meter free-style today in the preliminary of the National AAU men's swimming and diving championships.

Smaller furniture stores and carpet specialty shops placed substantial orders in July, several leading manufacturers reported yesterday. They said buying was on a healthy level for the first time since the second quarter slump in the carpet market and added order volume from outlets other than department stores continued brisk through the first week of the current month.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 -- The railroads will file with the Interstate Commerce Commission this week tariffs making effective on Sept. 1 freight rate increases ranging from 8 to 10 per cent.
Domestic airlines are seeking permission from the Civil Aeronautics Board to extend "air coach" and "family plan" tariffs beyond the Sept. 30 expiration date, it was learned yesterday.

LONDON, Aug. 16 (AP) -- Jaroslav Drobny and Vladimir Cernik, who gave up their Czechoslovakian citizenship to play tennis, arrived today en route to the United States national singles championship starting Aug. 29 at Forest Hills, N.Y.

A conflict among officials of the Investors League, Inc., centered about an attempt to oust Benjamin A. Javitz from the board as well as from his posts of first vice president and general counsel, came to light here yesterday.
FRANKFORT, Germany, Aug. 16 -- High Commissioner-designate John J. McCloy said today he agreed "in principle" with the idea of admitting the new German Republic into the Council of Europe.
The Lynmarc Sales Co. wholesale jewelry and appliances, in 225-41 W 34th St: American Bankers Association, additional space in 200 Madison Ave -- Charles F. Noyes Co. broker.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 (UP) -- Gen. Omar N. Bradley became the United States' ranking military officer on active duty today when he took the oath as the first statutory chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff.

LONDON, Aug. 16 -- Although British Government funds closed with gains up to 3/8 point in the stock market here today, they did so only after a fresh bout of selling in the afternoon by speculators -- who came in at last week's low levels -- had lopped off part of early gains.
LAKE SUCCESS, Aug. 16 -- Secretary General Trygve Lie, tanned and rested after a six-week Scandinavian vacation, returned to his desk today in an optimistic frame of mind.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 16 -- Norman Mailer's novel about the war in the Pacific, "The Naked and the Dead," has been acquired for the screen by Norma Productions, the Burt Lancaster-Harold Hecht company, Hecht announced today.

RYE, N.Y., Aug, 16 -- A visitor from California, 20-year-old H. McGregor (Mac) Hunter from the Riviera Country Club, Los Angeles, led the qualifiers in the Metropolitan District's sectional qualifying round for the national amateur golf championship over the Westchester Country Club's south and west courses today with a 36-hole aggregate of 142.

A hundred lifeguards, members of six teams competing in the annual competition of guards on the New York municipal beaches, put on a battle royal yesterday afternoon before 1,000 spectators at Rockaway Beach, Queens. The fight followed hot words over a claim of foul made in a crucial event.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, Aug. 16 (UP) -- The Belgian Socialist party announced tonight that it would use force if necessary to prevent King Leopold from returning to the throne.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 16 -- Job opportunities for disabled veterans are declining steadily because employers are demanding only the best trained and highly skilled workers, Perry Faulkner of Washington, chief of the Veterans Employment Service of the United States Employment Service, told the Disabled American Veterans today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 (AP) -- Senator Robert A. Taft, Republican, of Ohio, joined today in Republican protests against the way the Senate Judiciary Committee approved Attorney General Tom C. Clark's nomination to the Supreme Court.

BERLIN, Aug. 16 (AP) -- The three Western military commandants have approved provisionally a West Berlin city budget of 1,719,789,440 deutsche marks (approximately $516,000,000) for the fiscal year 1949-50.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 (AP) -- The House Agriculture Committee decided today to conduct a first-hand study of the nation's commodity markets.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 (AP) -- A Maritime Commission official hinted before a Congressional committee today that subsidies for some ships now under construction might be slashed if examination showed that the Goovernment had been too generous.

DENNIS, Mass., Aug. 16 -- Helen Hayes appeared before an S.R.O. audience in a new comedy, "Good Housekeeping," by William McCleery, at the Cape Playhouse last night. She provided a merry evening for all, and her supporting cast contributed excellently to a smooth first performance.
SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 16 -- John Hay Whitney, co-owner of Greentree Stable, watched the saddling of Ogden Phipps' Striking for the fifty-eighth running of the Spinaway Stakes today.

With savings at record levels, 300 investment dealers gathered in the Georgian Room of the Statler Hotel yesterday at the second session of their first convention to discuss means of attracting these funds into investment trusts, or mutual funds, as they are coming to be known.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Aug. 16 (AP) -- The Sheraton Corporation of America today offered to buy all the stock of Ford Hotels Company, Inc., at $30 a share. John C. Udd, president of Ford Hotels, said Sheraton had bought his holdings and "has agreed at my insistence to extend the same offer to all other stockholders."

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Aug. 16 -- In tribute to the Eastern International Gladiolus Show, which opened in Kalurah Temple today, this city is observing Gladiolus Week. In his proclamation, Mayor Walker B. Lounsbery asked that citizens display gladioluses throughout the city.
CINCINNATI, Aug. 16 (AP) -- Lloyd Merriman's single in the tenth inning today gave Cincinnati a 2-1 victory over the Pirates.

GREAT NECK, L.I., Aug. 16 Mrs. William Mendelsohn of the Willow Brook Golf Club won the point-par tournament of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association at the Glen Oaks Club today with a point card of +44.
Ken Heintzelman, the 34-year-old left-hander who had beaten the Dodgers four times previously this season, made it five last night at Ebbets Field.
The tug John E. McAllister of the McAllister Lighterage Line of New York was hove to off Norfolk, Va., last night with a heavy tow in a gale, after completing a rare rescue.
CANTON, China, Aug. 16 -- Foreigners fled this refugee capital of China today amid reports that Communist armies were little more than 155 miles away.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 16 -- The members of the Australian and Italian Davis Cup teams joined the field competing in the national doubles tennis championships today and another large gathering of 3,000 turned out for the play at the Longwood Cricket Club.

It is good to receive Director William H. Byrne's assurance that, despite its inadequate staff and incomplete equipment, the newly organized Bureau of Smoke Control has lost no time in attacking the city's smoke-nuisance problem vigorously and, we hope, effectively.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 16 (AP) -- The first National girls' golf tournament today was narrowed to eight players.

It is to be regretted that the recent proposal to prohibit parking on one side of every street originated with a garage owners' association. This may cause authorities to dismiss the suggestion as selfishly motivated.
WESTBURY, L.I., Aug. 16 -- Robert E. Strawbridge Jr., chairman of the United States Polo Association, tonight was honored at the annual press barbecue dinner tendered at the Meadow Brook Club.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was steady early in yesterday's trading, but profit-taking caused a late sell-off, and final prices were 9 to 17 points net lower.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Aug. 16 -- Isolation of a virus producing poliomyelitis symptoms without producing the disease itself was announced today by Yale University scientists.

SEA BRIGHT, N.J., Aug. 16 -- The $703,000 solid granite sea wall put up jointly by the State of New Jersey, Monmouth County and the Borough of Sea Bright two years ago is paying off in multiple dividends.

Many meanings will be read into the election in Western Germany, but its greatest significance lies in the size of the vote and the mood of the voters. When 80 per cent of the eligible electors go to the polls it does not prove that the Germans have gone democratic, but it does indicate that they think more of the central act of democracy than millions of Americans do.
SCHENECTADY, N. Y., Aug. 16 -- The Atomic Energy Commission asked construction bids today on what was expected to be the first plant to produce "significant" amounts of atomic power.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 -- President Truman will make the first of four major speeches next Monday when he talks at the Golden Jubilee National Convention of the Veterans of Foreign Wars in Miami, Fla.
Underwriting syndicates will place on the market today issues of public utility and natural gas pipeline securities valued at more than $5,000,000.

The stock market emerged yesterday on the recovery side after sliding back for the three preceding sessions from the midsummer rallying highs. While the reversal of form was selective and spotty, it marked a definite change of pattern with an accompanying increase in volume and breadth of interest.
A youth who feigned blindness to make a living as a street beggar was sentenced last night to serve six months in the workhouse for his deception.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 -- The average life span in the United States, on the basis off 1947 figures just compiled, is 66.8 years, the Public Health Service announced today.

The United Nations Scientific Conference on the Conservation and Utilization of Resources opens today at Lake Success to discuss for three weeks the plight of a world in which population is increasing more rapidly than are resources of food, vegetation and minerals. A major step in carrying out the United Nations program of technical aid to under-developed countries is thus taken.

Out-of-town buyers registered in the market for the week ended yesterday numbered 1,464, compared with 1,398 last week and 1,432 in the similar week a year ago, according to the listings appearing in THE NEW YORK TIMES. There were 707 arrivals yesterday against 745 last Tuesday.
ALBANY, Aug. 16 -- Governor Dewey today ordered an extraordinary grand jury investigation of alleged official misconduct and fiscal irregularities in Republican-controlled Hamilton County.

"Jolson Sings Again," which arrives at Loew's State, is this morning's lone film newcomer. This sequel to "The Jolson Story" again stars Larry Parks in the title role for which Al Jolson himself recorded the songs. Barbara Hale, William Demarest, Ludwig Donath, Tamara Shayne, Myron McCormick and Bill Goodwin are among the principals in the biographical drama.

AN event of considerable significance in the world of sports is under way. A team of Japanese swimmers is competing in the National A.A.U. championships at Los Angeles, their first formal appearance in international competition since Pearl Harbor. What is more, they probably will bring back a couple of American titles with them as souvenirs because this is not a mere token visit.

BOSTON, Aug. 16 -- Montia Kennedy constituted himself a one-man wrecking crew of Boston's third-place hopes in the National League race tonight at Braves Field, and did better than fair to the dismay of Warren Spahn and 12,341 onlookers.
CHICAGO, Aug. 16 -- Representatives of five Middle Western stock markets that will become part of a new combined exchange today selected Sept. 15 as the effective date of consolidation.

The radio program known as the "Voice of America" has benefited on Capitol Hill by recent evidence that the Russian Government doesn't like it. Yesterday the House Appropriations Committee, after listening to testimony from Lieut. Gen. Albert C. Wedemeyer, the Army's director of psychological warfare, voted to add $11,500,000 to the "Voice's" allotment for the current fiscal year.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 (UP) -- The Standing Committee of Correspondents, which governs the Congressional press galleries, announced today it had denied, by a 3-to-2 vote, gallery membership to the Labor Press Associates.

The amendment to the local rent laws suggested by Joseph T. Sharkey, vice chairman of the City Council, to block the eviction of tenants who refuse to pay residential rent increases granted by Federal authorities was denounced yesterday by the Metropolitan Fair Rent Committee and leaders of the American Labor party.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 -- The House's feud with the Senate over delays in enactment of money bills continued today, while the National Military Establishment, the Department of the In-...

Dr. Benjamin Kopp has sold his home at 7610-12 Bay Parkway, Brooklyn, to Dr. Morton W. Shomstein, who will occupy it as his office and residence. Slomka Brothers were the brokers. Title was insured by the Home Title Guaranty Company.
WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Aug. 16 -- A field of 122 participated in the Westchester Division of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association fiftieth anniversary tournament at the Century Country Club today.

The program for the military rehabilitation of our West-European allies as our own first line of defense passed its first test in Congress when the House Foreign Affairs Committee approved the Mutual Defense Act, with the full amount of $1,450,000,000 left intact.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 -- Emil Schram, president of the New York Stock Exchange, said today that the market for equity capital had been deteriorating for years under the impact of a "faulty tax structure." He recommended a four-point program of remedial action.

The American public is growing increasingly antagonistic to Socialist Britain, feeling that Marshall aid funds are being poured down a drain pipe, and that other countries, like Belgium, are succeeding under free enterprise where Britain is failing.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 -- The House will begin tomorrow its decisive work on the Administration's $1,450,000,000 foreign military aid bill, and almost certainly will pass it in some form before the week is out.

SHANGHAI, Aug. 15 -- Prospects for the departure of foreigners left stranded here by the Kuomintang blockade improved markedly today as the American President Lines disclosed it had received written permission from Communist authorities to bring in the SS General Gordon on or about Sept. 15.

ATHENS, Aug. 16 -- As the Greek rebellion shows signs of disintegrating reliable reports have been received here of a mounting crisis in Albania. Although Premier Enver Hoxha's police force has the situation in hand so far, the atmosphere is described as tense. Dramatic developments before the end of the year are not to be excluded as a possibility.

MOSCOW, Aug. 16 -- The diplomatic opinion in Moscow characterizes the Kremlin meeting of Premier Stalin and United States Ambassador Admiral Alan G. Kirk last night as an important step toward what is described by some as "normalization" of relations between the United States and the Soviet Union.

LONGYEARBYEN, Spitsbergen, Aug. 10 -- Norway is determined to hang on to Spitsbergen and will not sell, lend or lease it to Eastern or Western countries, but, if Norway were to be attacked by Russia, Spitsbergen would be made available as a base for the North Atlantic pact powers.
Coffee futures were strong as trade demand for the near-by delivery positions advanced prices in Contract "S" 14 to 20 points in trading on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange yesterday.

LONDON, Aug. 16 -- The timing and perhaps the result of the British general election will hinge on the crucial Anglo-Canadian-American economic conference to be held in Washington next month. Talks with many British Government officials this past week and with non-British authorities here and in Paris and Rome all point to the common belief that the Western democracies are approaching a crisis of first-rate proportions.

PARIS, Aug. 16 -- Addressing the European Marshall Plan council today, Paul G. Hoffman urged greater efforts to "make good on pledges of mutual aid" to counteract "the notion in the United States that the Marshall Plan is a political success but not an economic success."

The proposed increase in the salaries of the city's top elected officials was criticized yesterday by Representative Vito Marcantonio, American Labor party candidate for Mayor, and Joseph Goldsmith, president of the Taxpayers Union of the City of New York.

LONDON, Aug. 16 -- Thanks to a minor Soviet concession, deputies of the Big Four foreign ministers made further progress today in their efforts to draft an Austrian peace treaty here before Sept. 1. The treaty draft must be completed by that date or the deputies must report failure to the coming foreign ministers conference.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 -- George McKee Elsey, young former assistant to Clark M. Clifford, special counsel to the President, was back in the White House today with a $10,000-a year job.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 (AP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today tentative approval of plans to dissolve Niagara Hudson Power Corporation of Syracuse, N. Y., and to merge its three major subsidiaries.
BOSTON, Aug. 16 (AP) -- Billy Southworth, manager of the defending National League champion Boston Braves, tonight accepted a leave of absence for the rest of the season, because of poor health.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 -- A coalition of Republicans and Southern Democrats in the Senate dealt another setback to the Administration today by defeating the first of President Truman's reorganization plans. The vote was 60 to 32.

CHAUTAUQUA, N.Y., Aug. 16 -- Continuing the series of Family Life Institute lectures here, Dr. Ernest Osborne, Professor of Education at Teachers College, Columbia University, declared today that "marriage is an experience and cannot be legislated into goodness by rigid divorce laws."

Private philanthropic foundations in the United States have total assets exceeding $2,000,000,000 and contribute annually more than $100,000,000 to philanthropic causes, the Alfred P. Sloan Foundation estimated yesterday in reporting on its activities for the last two years.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 -- Maj. Gen. Alden H. Waitt, suspended chief of the Army Chemical Corps, testified today at the "five per centers" inquiry that he prepared a memorandum evaluating adversely the abilities of officers eligible to succeed him.
LONDON, Aug. 16 (AP) -- British investors are shedding Government bonds with frantic haste.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 (AP) -- The Senate today passed and sent to the White House a bill designed to cut into heavy cotton surpluses by reducing the 1950 planting.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 -- Britain shipped $60,892,786 in gold to this country during the week ended July 27, the Bureau of the Census reported today. In the same period, $2,223,778 in silver was shipped from this country to Hong Kong.

A tract of twenty-nine acres on Bradley Avenue in Mount Vernon, N.Y., has been purchased from the Wartburg Orphans Farm School, Inc., by the Board of Education of the City of Mount Vernon. The land will be used as a site for a comprehensive high school which will include the present A.B. Davis High School and the Edison Vocational Technical High School.
ELIZABETH, N. J., Aug. 16 -- A strike that nobody wants has been costing this industrial community of 110,000 persons $500,000 a week since May 1 and there is no sign of a settlement.

Fashioned of gabardine, worsted and sharkskin, the Murray Sices suits offered yesterday in a showing at Russeks were not only proportioned to fit women five feet five and under but designed to create an illusion of height and slenderness.

ROME, Aug. 16 -- Supporters of communism, even those who profess, propagate and defend its materialistic and anti-Christian doctrines, will under certain conditions be permitted to marry Catholics, according to a decision of the Congregation of the Holy Office made public today.

Mayor O'Dwyer won yesterday a week's postponement of the strike that had been threatened for today against the Triboro Coach Company in Queens. He assigned William Reid, chairman of the Board of Transportation, to go over the company's financial set-up with its officials during that period.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 (AP) -- The Department of Commerce said today the nation's total output of goods and services fell off to an annual rate of $256,100,000,000 in the second quarter of 1949 -- a drop of 2.4 per cent after a slump of nearly 2.9 per cent in the preceding quarter.

The Board of Education staged a morning and afternoon "double-header" yesterday to break ground for two new Brooklyn schools. Maximilian Moss, board president, said this "brought to a close the most exciting eight-day period in the history of school construction in New York City."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 -- Donald R. Richberg, Washington lawyer with an extensive knowledge of labor and anti-monopoly laws, recommended to a Congressional committee today an amendment to the Clayton Act to restrict unions to "legitimate" activities.

Net earnings of the Eastman Kodak Company for the twenty-four weeks ended on June 12 declined 24 per cent to $21,368,830 from $28,017,724 earned in the corresponding period a year ago, according to the report issued yesterday by Perlsey S. Wilcox, board chairman, and Thomas J. Hargrave, president, to the company's 55,000 shareholders.

With less than three weeks remaining until Labor Day, resident offices and buyers are pressing for quicker deliveries to get adequate stocks of women's fall apparel for the peak September selling period.

WATERTOWN, N.Y., Aug. 16 -- Artillery of the Seventy-Seventh Infantry Division, organized reserve, Maj. Gen. Julius Ochs Adler commanding, now in training at Pine Camp Cantonment with the Forty-second Infantry Division, New York National Guard, will go into action with live ammunition tomorrow, under the direction of Col. George E. Nichols.

The tension between the city and the United States Public Health Service over the use of the Neponsit Beach Hospital at Beach 149th Street, Rockaway Beach, Queens, was eased considerably yesterday when Mayor O'Dwyer said the city would extend the service's lease on the property beyond Jan. 1 if necessary.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 (AP) -The text of Secretary of State Acheson's statement on the German election follows:

In protest against lack of traffic signal lights at Marion Street and Hopkinson Avenue, Brooklyn, 200 women, many with babies in carriages and children, formed a double line at the intersection, blocking automobile traffic yesterday from 8:40 to 10:30 A. M. The demonstration ended when the police gave assurance that steps would be taken to eliminate the traffic hazards.

Bids designating interest costs ranging from 2.7207 to 2.77499 per cent were submitted yesterday by banking syndicates competing for the purchase of $17,700,000 of taxexempt revenue bonds of the Lower Colorado River Authority due serially from Nov. 1, 1949, to Nov. 1, 1975.

In a letter published in THE NEW YORK TIMES on July 6, the statements made by Gertrude S. Legendre indicate that she has been misinformed concerning the use of housing in Salzburg by the United States Forces in Austria. Since her statements led her to a number of charges against United States Forces in Austria, which are quite unjust, we would like to inform your readers, and Mrs. Legendre, of the facts in this matter.

WHERE there's smoke, there's fire. That's what they say, anyway. Even during spring training the rumors were persistent that the Boston Braves were torn by dissension. The stories were denied with considerable vehemence. But the entire situation apparently has reached a climax. Manager Billy Southworth has taken a leave of absence for the remainder of the season, a denouement that is as shocking as it is unexpected.
PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Aug. 17 (AP) -- The text of the letter sent by Archbishop Josef Beran to the Czechoslovak State Prosecutor:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 (AP) -Senators H. Alexander Smith and Robert C. Hendrickson, New Jersey Republicans, called today for "a better balance between Republicans and Democrats on the Federal bench as a means of strengthening our historic principles of an independent judiciary."

SHANGHAI, Aug. 17 -- The Public Safety Bureau responded swiftly today when four discharged delivery boys demanding reinstatement locked in Fred Hampson, Shanghai bureau manager of the Associated Press. Answering a telephone summons by Mr. Hampson, police officers -- after interviewing both parties and inspecting records in the dispute -- told the delivery boys to take their case to the local labor bureau and warned them against resorting to force.

BERLIN, Aug. 17 -- Russian political strategists in Germany are weighing the relative merits of two counter-measures against the establishment of the German Federal Republic in Western Germany next month.

ALBANY, Aug. 17 -- Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein announced today the appointment of Charles S. Wilcox, president of the Rochester Bar Association, as special prosecutor in the extraordinary grand jury investigation of Hamilton County affairs ordered by Governor Dewey.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 (AP) -The Commodity Credit Corporation said today it would seek storage facilities for up to 500,000,000 bushels of grain surpluses.

A series of otherwise unavailable classics in paper-bound editions is to be initiated by the Grove Press. The first volume, to be published later this month, will be "The Confidence Man" by Herman Melville, which has been out of print since its first publication in 1857. Other authors included are Richard Crashaw, William Beckford, John Skelton, Mrs. Aphra Behn and Matthew G. Lewis.

Joseph T. Sharkey, vice chairman of the City Council, introduced yesterday at a special meeting of that body his bill to amend the existing local rent control law to safeguard apartment tenants against "excessive" rent rises granted by Federal authority under the "net operating income" formula set up by the Federal Housing Expediter.

Expressing fear of certain execution should he be forced to return to his native Yugoslavia, Toma Babin, former Yugoslav Embassy attache, received a writ of habeas corpus yesterday to contest an Immigration and Naturalization Service deportation warrant.
CHEBOYGAN, Mich., Aug. 17 (AP) -- State police arrested the cashier of Purdue University and reported today he had admitted fleeing from Indiana with $2,000 of university funds.

This member of the rose family does not rate as high as its cousins, the raspberry, strawberry and apple. Rubus fruiticosus is an opponent worthy of a man's best. It requires fortitude, patience and persistence to get a five-quart lard pailful of the big, gleaming, juicy fruits.
The United States Public Health Service announced yesterday that this year's total of poliomyelitis cases throughout the nation had risen to 13,795 as of last Saturday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- Administration forces in the Senate mustered enough Republican and Southern Democratic support today to stop a Congressional veto of two Presidential reorganization plans due to become law at midnight Friday.

A new flight service between New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, and London was begun yesterday by American Overseas Airlines when one of its double-deck Stratocruisers, the flagship Europe, departed on a non-stop trip to the British capital.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 (AP) -In a bitter statement, Maj. Gen. Philip B. Fleming, chairman of the Maritime Commission, tonight accused counsel for a House Expenditures subcommittee of "browbeating" commission officials in an investigation of ship subsidies.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 17 -- The Belgrade radio rebroadcast tonight a communique of the Albanian Ministry of War reporting that 5,026 Greek civilians and 276 wounded Greek rebel soldiers had crossed the frontier and sought refuge in Albania as a result of the fighting in the Vitsi region Aug. 13, 14 and 15.
Justice Henry Clay Greenberg will decide today whether to vacate a stay barring Macy's from advertising and selling DuMont television sets at cut prices, he said in Supreme Court yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- The House broke by 275 to 47 today the first oblique thrust at the Administration's $1,450,000,000 foreign military aid bill and then opened direct debate upon it.

Frederick H. Zurmuhlen, Commissioner of Public Works, said yesterday that the beauty of the Brooklyn Bridge would not be harmed in any way by the plans drafted by David B. Steinman, consulting engineer, for reconstruction of roadways and trusses.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 17 -- Tighe E. Woods, National Housing Expediter, said today that one-third of the country's rent-control areas would be decontrolled because a joint Congressional committee cut his budget.

Although income from domestic sales and service activities of the Burroughs Adding Machine Company in the first half of this year improved slightly to $45,656,414 from $45,454,956 in the 1948 period, total net earnings declined $1,682,324, John S. Coleman, president, reported yesterday.
The Diamond Match Co, through Cross Brown Co, in 155 E 44th St; Pennurban Housing Corp, in 522 5th Ave -- Cushman Wakefield Inc, brokers.

Alexander Bittleman, one-time national committeeman of the American Communist party, denied yesterday that he or his party had ever advocated the violent overthrow of the United States Government, a charge upon which the United States Department of Justice is seeking his deportation.

A primitive Eskimo tribe of forty, Oriental in character, that disliked classical music, hill-billy songs and bebop, were the only human beings a three-man ornithological expedition met in three months in uncharted Arctic regions. This was reported yesterday by Paul Queneau, research scientist of Westport, Conn., a member of the expedition.

Completely rebuilt for luxury service at a cost of more than $750,000, the liner Puerto Rico of the Bull Lines will sail at 4 P. M. today from Pacific Street, Brooklyn, for San Juan and Trujillo City. Her sailing will mark the re-establishment for the first time in eight years of regular first-class passenger service to Puerto Rico and the Dominican Republic.
EVANSTON, Ill., Aug. 17 -- Indifferent parents who criticize a child and compare him unfavorably with brothers and sisters may be responsible for his poor reading ability.

NEWPORT, R. I., Aug. 17 -Herbert C. Pell of Hopewell Junction, N. Y., former United States Minister to Portugal, and Mrs. Pell were enjoined today from disposing of or exhibiting their collection of Portuguese art, when a preliminary injunction sought by the National Portuguese Museum-Pell Foundation Inc., was granted in Superior Court here by agreement of counsel.

PINE CAMP, N. Y., Aug. 17 -Reservists of the 77th Infantry Division and National Guardsmen of the 42nd Infantry Division, in summer exercises here today continued their combat schooling under instruction by veterans from the Seventh Regiment and Battery A, Tenth Field Artillery, Regular Army.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 17 -- Celeste Holm has been signed by George Moskov and Harry Popkin to star with Ronald Colman in "Champagne for Caesar," an independent production for United Artists, which will go before the cameras tomorrow at the Motion Picture Center, Popkin announced today.

An interesting letter from C. Monteith Gilpin appeared Aug. 9 pointing out that the economic administration of Germany is at variance with the objectives of the Marshall Plan. Mr. Gilpin then blames this condition on the Germans.

What little chance the Dodgers had to save themselves from a second straight defeat by the Phillies yesterday at Ebbets Field was ruined by some of the craziest base-running -- or was it coaching? -- since the balmy years of the Babe Herman era. The 3-hour 6-minute marathon ended with the Phillies on top, 11 -- 7, as the Flatbush forces got themselves entangled in a jig-saw puzzle on the basepaths.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 (AP) -Three representatives of the fur industry opposed proposed fur-labeling legislation today.

Rubber futures continued in active trading on the Commodity Exchange here yesterday with prices declining 19 to 23 points. Turnover increased to 1,460 long tons, the highest so far this week, with interest centering on the December and September deliveries. September outran December in the decline, narrowing the spread between these two deliveries to 41 points.

John E. Slater of Essex Fells, N. J., was named president of the American Export Lines yesterday at a late afternoon meeting of the company's board of directors. Mr. Slater, one of the port's leading shipping operators, has been executive vice president of the line since 1935 and has been active in the field of transport since 1913.
BINGHAMTON, N. Y., Aug. 17 -- An attendance of 40,000 persons was estimated for the fourth annual Eastern International Gladiolus Show this afternoon.

LAKE SUCCESS, Aug. 17 -- Fairfield Osborn, president of the Conservation Foundation, warned an assemblage of scientists and experts from forty-four countries today that the world's "explosive upsurge" in population threatened to impose severe strain on the earth's resources.

The stock market broke through yesterday the previous high level of the year by a sustained rally which had its climax in the last hour in a strong buying wave. Increases of 1 to 2 points were scattered liberally throughout the list on the Stock Exchange, while some wider gains were made by stocks recently under pressure. The composite rate rose 1.27 points. It was the strongest market since Aug. 8.

LONDON, Aug. 17 -- Foreign Secretary Bevin and Sir Stafford Cripps, Chancellor of the Exchequer, will go to the dollar crisis conference in Washington next month with an agreed Labor Government policy and full formal backing of the British Cabinet.

While the world watches in paralyzed inactivity, the Communist armies continue to overrun one part of China after another, and the Chinese National Government, which all countries, including Soviet Russia, still recognize as the legitimate Government of the country, continues its fighting retreat to bastions from which, as during the war with Japan, it can organize a last-ditch stand.

Opposition to New York University's expansion plans around Washington Square was acknowledged as "discriminatory" before a special conference yesterday of Greenwich Village groups and the City Planning Commission at the Municipal Building.

Despite State Department and Belgian Government intervention, the Spanish Government has moved closer to approval of a move by which Juan Albert March, one of the world's richest men, would gain control of the Barcelona Traction, Light and Power Company, Ltd., it was asserted yesterday.

PARIS, Aug. 17 -- Stubborn resistance by the British to a heavy cut in their dollar aid proposed by the "screening" committee of the European Marshall Plan council is considered by continental officials as increasing doubts held here that the council can make a division of the dollars this month as scheduled.
The song was a round dance, "The Spinning Waltz." The priest -- a former football coach -- chanted: "Step, kick and step, kick and circle the girls; then glide and back and back and twirl."

For the first time since 625 employes of the Holmes Electric Protective Service went on strike last Monday, three incidents involving the breaking of plate-glass door panels in Holmes-protected establishments were reported to the police within a half hour last night. All three places were near each other in the downtown area.

Considerably more than $300,000,000 of insurance coverage against the hazards of employing atomic or radio-active processes or materials in industry is going begging in the United States today, Schiff, Terhune Co., Inc., insurance brokers, said yesterday. The estimate is based upon a survey of 1,000 representative companies in all parts of the country, made by the insurance brokerage house.

Something of a little field day took place yesterday in the market for bank stocks. Virtually the whole list of prime market names moved up by a point or more, many to new highs for the year. National City reached 41 3/8; Guaranty Trust, 282, and First National, 1,280 -- all new highs.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Aug. 17 -- Roman Catholic Archbishop Josef Beran, in a letter to the state prosecutor, made public today, protested that since June 19 he had been kept "interned" in his palace and had not been permitted to receive visitors or correspondence, except post cards and publications.

The nation's gasoline stocks declined 270,000 barrels to 108,174,000 at the last week-end, according to the American Petroleum Institute. This compared with 108,444,000 a week earlier and 96,634,000 on Aug. 14, 1948.

CHICAGO, Aug. 17 (AP) -- The White Sox scored their third straight shut-out victory tonight beating Detroit, 1 -- 0, before 20,919 persons. In winning his eighth game, third for Chicago, Mickey Haefner checked the Tigers on seven hits. The contest was played in 1 hour and 38 minutes.
Recognizing the mass circulation that comic magazines have among children, the National Social Welfare Assembly has decided to try to use the "funnies" for socially constructive purposes.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 (UP) -These are the roll calls by which the Senate approved today President Truman's plans to transfer the Federal Employment Bureau to the Labor Department and the Bureau of Public Roads to the Commerce Department. The vote on the job agency shift was as follows:

HUNTINGTON, L. I., Aug. 17 -Mrs. C. B. Garver of the Piping Rock Club shot 99-21 -- 78 to win the low net prize during the weekly one-day tournament of the Women's Long Island Golf Association at the Huntington Country Club today. The second low net prize went to Mrs. Martin Victor of The Creek with 98-19 -- 79.

The American Friends of Slovak Freedom, headed by Lowell E. Jones, announced yesterday that it was turning over to immigration authorities statements by Slovak refugees about their treatment at the hands of Gen. Mikulas Ferjencik when he headed the Czechoslovak police.

A group of striking papers intended to be administered to walls in small doses was presented yesterday at the Katzenbach Warren showroom, 49 East Fifty-third Street. Two of the patterns appeared as free-standing single panels, three, designed as "side-wall" papers, might be used for an entire wall, and the last, a stylized architectural balustrade, was a dado meant to cover only the bottom part of a wall.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- The non-Communist affidavits of Donald Henderson, of the Food and Tobacco Workers Union, CIO, and Maurice Travis, of the Mine, Mill and Smelter Workers, CIO, have been referred to the Justice Department without recommendation, Robert N. Denham, general counsel of the National Labor Relations Board, said today.

LAKE SUCCESS, Aug. 17 -Julius A. Krug, Secretary of the Interior, told scientists from forty-four countries today that "conservation and wise development of our resources would help insure world peace." He pledged the help of the United States in developing backward countries.

Mayor O'Dwyer's plan for a survey on reclassification and wage adjustments for city employes met with strong opposition from the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association yesterday. The Uniformed Firemen's Association, however, endorsed the plan.

The security salesmen's assumption that "all people are speculators at heart" was dismissed as a mistake by Louis H. Whitehead yesterday in addressing 300 investment trust dealers at the third session of their first convention in the Hotel Statler.
Travel films produced by James A. Fitz Patrick will be presented by WJZ-TV in a thirteen-week series starting early in September. The time of broadcast will be announced later.

THERE has been no question of Eudora Welty's sensitive and graceful talent since the appearance of her first book, "A Curtain of Green." And since then, she has written many beautiful stories. But she has written none more beautiful than "Moon Lake," one of seven related stories (or novellas, or prose-poems, or fantasias) that form her newest book, "The Golden Apples,"* an oblique chronicle of a bizarre and yet typical town in Mississippi called Morgana.

PORTLAND, Ore., Aug. 17 (AP) -- A slogan that has no meaning is being used to fight Federal aid to parochial school children, Archbishop J. Francis A. McIntyre of Los Angeles told the Knights of Columbus convention here today.

The National Retail Dry Goods Association is organizing permanent committees in eight branches of home furnishings to attack marketing problems, David H. Woog, manager, home furnishings and appliance group, announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- A surprise move by the House leadership today suddenly forced the release of operating funds that had been withheld for two days from more than a score of key Government agencies -- including the National Military Establishment, the Economic Cooperation (Marshall Plan) Administration and the Veterans Administration -because of the Senate-House feud over appropriations.

High accident figures for drivers under twenty-five years of age, as compared with their elders, have now brought an insurance penalty in New York. The State Insurance Department has put in effect an increase of 15 per cent in New York City and 20 per cent elsewhere in the state, on premiums in those cases where one or more drivers in the family are less than twenty-five years old.
Please accept my gratitude for the message of sympathy to the people of Ecuador as conveyed in your editorials of Aug. 7 and 8.
MAMARONECK, N. Y., Aug. 17 -- Win or lose, the British Walker Cup team is well prepared for the matches with the United States golfers that start at the Winged Foot Golf Club here Friday.

ON BOARD YACHT VELERO IV, Off California, Aug 17 -- Homeward bound from his record-breaking 4,500-foot dive into the Pacific Ocean yesterday, Otis Barton today began planning modifications in the equipment of his 7,000-pound spherical steel "benthoscope" to pursue his undersea researches at unprecedented levels.
Your cogent editorial "Extending Social Security" says: "We believe the present bill deserves careful and sympathetic study." True enough, but how much more study than it has already received?
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 17 -The International Typographical Union, AFL, hit today at local contracts that contain provisions contrary to the union's anti-Taft-Hartley Law policy.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 17 -- Three top executives of two aircraft companies testified before a Congressional subcommittee today that they were aware of no undue pressure or dishonest influence in the awarding and cancellation of airplane manufacturing contracts by the Air Force.

The Regal Shoe Company, shoe manufacturer and operator of eighty stores, has reduced its price from $8.95 to $8.80 for all its American-style shoes, it was announced yesterday in Whitman, Mass., by J. A. Holmes, executive vice president. This is the first all-style, all-store Regal price reduction since 1933.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- The Labor Press Association, which has been denied admission to the Congressional press galleries by the Standing Committee of Correspondents, hinted today it would appeal to Congress if correspondents themselves did not charge the rule.

A vacant irregular plot about 70 by 128 feet at the southwest corner of Forty-third Avenue and 201st Street in the Auburndale section of Queens has been purchased by the Bayside Holding Corporation from the Frepand Realty and Holding Corporation for improvements with a commercial structure.
Repetition in the speech of children, often falsely believed by worried parents to be stuttering, may actually be developed into the affliction if parents overemphasize the problem.

The Guaranty Trust Company has been appointed paying agent for $1,710,000 of Charlotte, N. C., bond-anticipation notes of Aug. 15, 1949. The bank also has been made co-registrar and paying agent here for principal and interest on Illinois Power Company first mortgage 2 7/8 per cent bonds due 1979.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 17 -- Richard Gonzales and Frank Parker, champions of Wimbledon, kept the crowd on tenterhooks past the dinner hour tonight before they were able to extricate themselves from a position of dire peril in the national doubles tennis tournament at the Longwood Cricket Club.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 (AP) -Leon Keyserling, one of President Truman's three economic counselors, said today that America's No. 1 problem was to lift consumption to the level of production capacity.

Henry Hickey, who used to be a doorman at the Statler Hotel, Seventh Avenue and Thirty-third Street, until he was discharged recently for his "proven mistreatment of a guest," was back at his old post last night -- picketing. And with him were his wife and nine children.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 17 (AP) -Hironoshin Furuhashi, the Japanese distance champion, tonight won the National AAU 1,500-meter free style by four yards over his team-mate, Shiro Hashizume, after a thrilling near-record battle.

GENEVA, Aug. 17 -- There is serious danger that the expensive modernization programs of European industries, many of which have been financed with Marshall Plan aid, may become "frustrated" by the restrictive price policies creeping through the European economy, industrial specialists here say.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- Maj. Gen. Harry H. Vaughan, President Truman's military aide, was denounced at the "five per center" inquiry today by Senator Karl E. Mundt, Republican, of South Dakota, as a "finagling bargainer and a fumbling bungler" who used "pressure and intimidation" in an attempt to get an Agriculture Department employe to violate the law.

TOKYO, Aug. 17 -- In the future Japanese Government employes must take an oath, not only that they will be loyal to the Constitution, but that they will be diligent and efficient in their duties and will "practice" democracy.

The Interstate Sanitation Commission yesterday gave the city of New Rochelle ninety days in which to chart a working schedule for construction of a new sewage disposal plant that will decrease pollution in the Long Island Sound along the city's nine-mile waterfront.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -The current inquiry into "five per centers" and deep freezer gifts has not slowed the gifts that continually flow into the White House. Today it was melons and ear stoppers.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 17 (AP) -Pitcher Freddie Martin singled home Enos Slaughter from second tonight with the run which enabled the Cardinals to defeat the Reds, 4 -- 3, in thirteen innings and move into undisputed possession of first place in the National League. The victory gave the Cards a half-game advantage over the Dodgers who lost to the Phillies today.

LAKE SUCCESS, Aug. 17 -- Following are the texts of addresses delivered today by Secretary of the Interior Julius A. Krug and Fairfield Osborn at the opening of the United Nations Scientific Conference on the Conservation and Utilization of Resources:

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Aug. 17 (AP) -- W. J. Walden's Fighting Fan, proved best in a stirring stretch drive to take the honors of the Brigantine Purse, six furlong dash for 3-year-olds which headlined today's program.

Proposals for increasing the industry promotion fund for millinery by 50 per cent will be made next week to manufacturers and other interested groups, it was learned yesterday. Such an increase, it was said, will bring to well over $100,000 the budget used in combating "hatlessness" and getting coordinated retail effort behind sales of women's and children's hats.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- Yugoslavia will be allowed to buy material in the United States for a $3,000,000 steel-finishing mill to be assembled there.
Illustrating the generous amount of fashion being offered in budget-priced frocks, designer Nellie Don of Missouri presented her new fall wools and crepes at the Pierre Hotel yesterday.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Aug. 17 -- The Chamber of Deputies gave the new Christian Social-Liberal Government a vote of confidence today by 125 to 64, with one Liberal abstention. The Chamber then recessed until November.

The Senate's action in approving President Truman's Reorganization Plan No. 2 yesterday is in welcome contrast to its disapproval of Plan No. 1 the day before. Plan No. 2, the other reorganization plans that go into effect Saturday and the legislation already passed at this session together represent a very considerable start toward giving effect to the complex and thoroughgoing recommendations of the Hoover Commission to streamline the government.

CHAUTAUQUA, N. Y., Aug. 17 -- Dr. Ernest Osborne, Professor of Education at Teachers College, Columbia University, pointed out today before the Family Life Institute that "most people believe that there is a kind of magic in marriage."
Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll of New Jersey announced in Trenton late yesterday that he would take "immediate" action in the month-old pier strike in Jersey City.

LARAMIE, Wyo., Aug. 17 -"The stabilizing budget principle advanced by the Committee for Economic Development is helping to cushion the current recession," W. Walter Williams of Seattle, Wash., chairman of the committee, said today.

JERUSALEM, Aug. 17 -- The body of Theodor Herzl, who is credited with transforming Zionism from a mystic dream to a practical movement leading to the establishment of the Jewish State, was reinterred here today on the peak of Jerusalem's highest hill.

Orrin G. Judd as special counsel for Nassau County filed yesterday in Federal Court, Brooklyn, a petition asking permission to intervene in the reorganization proceedings involving the Long Island Rail Road. Argument on the motion will take place tomorrow before Judge Harold M. Kennedy.

A young Buenos Aires lawyer, a political exile from Argentina who is planning to press action against the Peron regime before the United Nations General Assembly, told yesterday of being tortured by electric-shock treatment and beating after his arrest in the alleged assassination plot of September, 1948.

STRASBOURG, France, Aug. 17 -- In a personal appeal to the President of the Assembly of the Council of Europe, Winston Churchill made a formal request today for steps to be taken with the Committee of Ministers for an early invitation to the new Western German State to become a member of the Council.

LONDON, Aug. 17 -- Hopes that the deputies of the Big Four foreign ministers might be able to agree on a draft treaty for Austria before the stipulated deadline of Sept. 1 have now virtually disappeared, informed Western diplomats said today.

BRIELLE, N. J., Aug. 17 -- With school tuna conspicuous by their absence and the big bluefins still scarce, charter captains in this area would seldom leave the docks if it were not for the good run of bluefish.

The one-story taxpayer building recently completed at the northwest corner of Hillside Avenue and Kent Road in New Hyde Park, L. I., has been purchased by A. B. B. B. Block and Albert H. Graham from Joseph and Rose Moscioli. The building, 130 by 88 feet, is occupied by a super market, a department store and a toy and juvenile furniture store.

GLEN HEAD, L. I., Aug. 17 -Mrs. Robert Trepner and Mrs. Gertrude Witt of Glen Oaks put together 39 and 35 for a sub-par 74 to carry off the best-ball net honors in the annual women's member-guest golf tournament today of the Glen Head Country Club. The event, which attracted forty teams, had the individual players using 75 per cent of their handicap.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 17 -- Women become addicted to alcohol more quickly than men, the e xecutive committee of the Women's Christian Temperance Union was told today.

A majority of food and grocery product manufacturers had higher tonnage sales in the first half of 1949, compared with with the corresponding period of last year, it was reported yesterday by Paul S. Willis, president, Grocery Manufacturers of America, Inc. Some of the companies, however, experienced lower dollar volume and reduced profits, he said.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Aug. 17 -- Military Government Law No. 75, which laid the groundwork for the complete reorganization of the heavy industries of the Ruhr, is being re-examined by the United States Government with an eye to possible revision.

Michael Maione, alleged Eastern head of a national counterfeiting ring that has flooded the country with $2,000,000 in fake 3-cent stamps and $10 and $20 bills, was indicted by a Federal grand jury yesterday along with two women and six other men on charges of conspiring to possess and sell quantities of counterfeit money.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 17 -- A combination of circumstances, including a downpour during the first two races, resulted today in the maintaining of Ted Atkinson's stake-a-day pace this week at Saratoga.
MAPLE SHADE, N. J., Aug. 17 -- State authorities today began the legal clean-up of South Jersey's biggest gambling raid staged last July 30, when 187 were arrested.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, the following principal changes for the week ended Aug. 10:

This city's hopes for a waterfront park at Manhattan Beach are tied up in a Congressional bill that has met unexpected obstacles in a House judiciary subcommittee. Similarly at stake are the claim of New York State to a larger acreage in the same section, part of which may be used eventually for a housing project or other public improvement.

John J. Broderick, retired city detective, who seeks to be the Tammany leader of the Times Square area, received a sharp setback yesterday when the Board of Elections rejected his slates of county committee candidates in eleven of twenty-five election districts.

The City Planning Commission announced yesterday approval of the proposal to transfer city-owned land at Coney Island and Rockaway Beach to the Park Department. This action disclosed plans of Park Commissioner Robert Moses to spend $827,000 for new parking fields, to be operated at a fee basis, at the two resorts.

The defense at the Communist trial introduced documentary evidence yesterday that it teaches that the United States Government, under the domination of the National Association of Manufacturers and other "monopoly capitalists," is heading the American people toward another great depression, a Fascist dictatorship and an "imperialist" war against the Soviet Union.

ATHENS, Aug. 17 -- The whole of the Vitsi salient has now been sealed off, with units of the Greek National Army taking positions along the Albanian border from the Slimnitsa Gap northward to the Yugoslav frontier, according to today's General Staff communique.
