The futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was moderately active yesterday and final prices were 7 points lower to 2 points higher than the day before.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- J. Edgar Hoover, director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, today struck back at critics of his agency, accusing them of "politics," "selfishness" and "wanton disregard for the truth."
WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- State governments employed 982,000 persons in April, 1949, a rise of 56,000 in a year, the Census Bureau reported today.

A syndicate of investors represented by Albert W. and Louis M. Gribourg, attorneys, has signed a contract for the purchase of a group of eight buildings in West Harlem from the United States Trust Company as executor of the estate of Eugene Higgins. Adelsberg Co. are the brokers.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 17 (UP) -Investigators said today they might be able to solve the 1947 murder of Bugsy Siegel, gangster, from "tips" in recorded conversations of Mickey Cohen, who allegedly succeeded Siegel as czar of Los Angeles' rackets.
The Empire City race track was formally transferred yesterday to the Algam Corporation of 745 Fifth Avenue.

HONG KONG, Aug. 17 (UP) -- The Nationalist Government today admitted the Communist capture of Foochow, one of its two principal east coast ports and the main debarkation point for troops and supplies from Formosa.
Further increases in automobile insurance rates in this state are in the offing unless drivers in the 18-25 age group cease to flout speed laws and other protective highway measures.

LAUSANNE, Switzerland, Aug. 17 -- The first meeting of Arab-Israeli political representatives went off smoothly, according to participants. The meeting, held yesterday under the auspices of the United Nations Palestine Conciliation Commission, opened discussions of the problem of releasing blocked Arab funds in Israel and blocked Israeli funds in the Arab countries.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Aug. 17 -- The Innis Arden team of Alvin B. Mayer and his son, Richard, regained the Westchester father-and-son championship at the Westchester Hills Golf Club today after a year's lapse.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- A drastic curtailment of the functions of seven regional offices, including the one in New York, because of reduced appropriations was made known today by a spokesman for the Office of the Housing Expediter.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- The Supreme Court may have to interpret the main provisions of a new wage-hour bill because of the scanty "legislative history" behind the House bill adopted last week.
" Smile when you say that, pardher!" twelve tough-looking hombres chorused yesterday in the eighth-floor offices of the Sanitation Department at 125 Worth Street.
MINEOLA, L. I., Aug. 17 -- The village of North Hills, a residential North Shore community of large estates, today became open territory for small-home building developers.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Aug. 17 -- Seven persons were killed in rioting in downtown Santiago today and Congress was called into special session tonight to hear a Cabinet request for extraordinary powers to cope with the situation.

As a result of a successful newspaper test campaign introducing an American blend of Du Maurier cigarettes, the Columbia Tobacco Company will extend distribution to major cities of this country, it was announced yesterday. The cigarettes, a luxury brand, originated in England and have long been sold in world capitals.

VIENNA, Aug. 17 -- Austria's biggest post-war business scandal is developing out of the investigation of twenty-two persons now under arrest in connection with illegal shipments of tens of millions of dollars' worth of scrap iron, nonferrous metals and other valuable goods from Austria to Eastern European countries.

A contingent of ninety-seven British exchange teachers, coming here to spend a year in American schools under the teacher interchange program sponsored by the Federal Security Agency, will arrive today aboard the Cunard White Star liner Queen Elizabeth.

Though clambakes traditionally take place at the seashore, we recently attended one beside a small lake in the country. It suggested that the old-fashioned gathering might be urbanized with no great violence to ritual. The setting? A backyard or terrace in city or suburb. The ingredients? Everything that goes to make such an affair a success -- except the salt breezes and sandy beach.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- The Burmese Government has reversed its current policies so as to admit the limited investment of foreign capital in the country, it was announced here today by Foreign Minister U E Maung. For the year and a half of its existence, the new nation has forbidden investment by foreigners.

KINGS BAY, Spitsbergen. Aug. 11 -- Spitsbergen may be the blue chip in the big power game for military bases but the handful of people living up here on Latitude 79, less than 700 miles from the North Pole, do not lose much sleep over politics.

DAMASCUS, Syria, Aug. 17 -- Present indications are that a constituent assembly will be elected under a new electoral law to be promulgated by the provisional Syrian Government to correct abuses of the previous electoral law.

The New York Botanical Garden drawn attention yesterday to its Strophanthus sarmentosus plant, the seed of which presents a potentially unlimited source for the raw material of cortisone, a synthesized hormone recently discovered as a treatment for arthritis and rheumatic fever.

Attendance figures for the trade show and convention of the American National Retail Jewelry Association at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel climbed yesterday above the 10,000 mark. Officials of the association looked for last year's record registration to be shattered when the convention closes tonight.

ATHENS, Aug. 17 -- Paul G. Hoffman, who is expected in Athens tomorrow with his Economic Cooperation Administration party, will find that economic reconstruction in Greece as envisioned under the Marshall Plan has made relatively little advance.

The basic insurance protection of all citizens should come from the Social Security program, Dr. J. Douglas Brown, dean of the faculty of Princeton University, said yesterday before the Presidential fact-finding board for the steel industry.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 17 (AP) -- The Red Sox, featuring doubles by Birdie Tebbetts and Al Zarilla, staged a four-run uprising in the tenth inning tonight to defeat the Athletics, 5 to 1, and move into second place in the American League pennant race.

Reprisals by the "Voice of America" and the British Broadcasting Corporation against Soviet jamming of their Russian-language broadcasts in recent weeks have driven some Soviet domestic short-wave broadcasts off the air, according to "Voice of America" officials.

The "lonely hearts" murder trial decision was in the hands of a Bronx jury at 7:56 o'clock last night, after a charge by Supreme Court Justice Ferdinand Pecora that lasted for five hours and twenty minutes.

Writing from London of the approaching conversations in Washington on the British exchange crisis, THE TIMES correspondent, Herbert L. Matthews, reports that "a mutual understanding of the problems involved has been growing in recent days." He adds, however, that the improvement in climate "is confined largely to the levels of high statesmanship and technical authority."
GLOVERSVILLE, N. Y., Aug. 17 (AP) -- The Fulton County Tanners Association said today it would "never again deal with the Communist-led Local 202 of the International Fur and Leather Workers Union."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 (UP) -John V. Van Sickle, Economics Professor at Wabash College, Crawfordsville, Ind., told the Senate Banking Committee today that labor unions had grown so strong that they threatened "our democratic way of life."

Reform of the Japanese tax system through lowering rates on individual and corporate income to levels that can be sustained and the establishment of a realistic basis in the terms of the depreciated yen for computation of capital for taxation of corporate excess income were urged yesterday by the National Foreign Trade Council.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- One of the two points of business discussed with Premier Stalin last Monday by United States Ambassador Alan G. Kirk was Russian jamming of the "Voice of America" broadcasts, Secretary of State Dean Acheson said today. The other was the current negotiations in Washington seeking a settlement of the Soviet Union's wartime lend-lease account.

HONOLULU, Aug. 17 -- Gov. Ingram M. Stainback of Hawaii declared the territory's ports open by proclamation today as issues in the 109-day waterfront strike continued to be fought out across the bargaining table, in the courts and along the Honolulu waterfront.

ROME, Aug. 17 -- Pope Pius XII intimated today that he was convinced of the advisability and effectiveness of the decree issued by the Congregation of the Holy Office last month excommunicating Communists and supporters of Communism and barring them from receiving the sacraments

CLEVELAND, Aug. 17 -- The DAV has a perfect right to maintain its stand for adequate national defense without being accused of "rattling the saber," Gen. Jonathan M. Wainwright today told delegates to the Disabled American Veterans convention.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 17 -Red and black posters appeared in midtown Buenos Aires this morning announcing a Peronista district meeting Saturday night at which 25,000 copies of the newspaper La Prensa are to be burned "as an example and warning to all who try to oppose a great, powerful and just Argentina."

An "accumulation of threats" brought about the resignation of Augustus R. Southworth Jr. from a $7,500-a-year job as assistant to the president of Kings County Buick, Inc., he testified yesterday in the General Sessions wiretap trial.

Atlantic and Gulf shipping operators defied Local 33, National Marine Engineers Beneficial Association, CIO, yesterday in a dispute over contract interpretation and demanded that the union rescind objectionable local shipping rules affecting its members.

Yesterday's temperate weather stimulated trade at many theatres that held matinee performances. The Barrymore, housing "A Streetcar Named Desire," reported receipts the highest for any matinee since Memorial Day, with ten standees in attendance.

Winston Churchill sits with the "C's" in the second row of the Consultative Assembly of the Council of Europe. He was Number 25 in the list of speakers scheduled to address the meeting. But although he is just one among 101 delegates, taking his turn with the rest, his was the voice the others were waiting to hear.

PRETORIA, South Africa, Aug. 17 -- Meeting for the first time since Parliament recessed six weeks ago, the South African Cabinet gave much time yesterday and today to consideration of the economic situation.

Two new films will open in midtown theatres this morning. At the Sixtieth Street Trans-Lux, the attraction is "The Agitator," a British-made drama, featuring William Hartnell and Mary Morris. John Harlow produced and Louis H. Jackson directed from a screen play by Edward Dryhurst and a novel by W. Riley. Four Continents Films is distributing the importation.

CHICAGO, Aug. 17 -- Grain markets developed a strong tone in the late trading on the Board of Trade today after showing easiness early. September wheat lost 1/4 cent a bushel, selling at a new low on the current downturn, while deferred months were unchanged to 1 3/4 cents up, the latter on the May position.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Aug. 17 -- The determination to forestall any possible regrowth of Communist influence in Costa Rica caused the election tribunal last night to cancel the registration of the new "National Democratic" party for the Congressional elections next October.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- Secretary of State Dean Acheson warned the inhabitants of the German Federal Republic today against abuse of their newly found freedoms.

The boy in June is promised ten weeks' vacation. As Time is apprehended by the young, this is a very long period. Viewed from the June end it stretches away in a glorious vista, ten golden years of freedom.
Babe Ruth Plaza -- stretching two short blocks, in back of left field in the Yankee Stadium -- was dedicated last night in tribute to baseball's late home-run king.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- A wise provision in the law that gave to the President powers to reorganize the Federal Government structure is responsible for the Administration's failure to drive an entering wedge for socialized medicine into that structure. This provision permits a "constitutional majority" -- one more than half of the total membership -- of either branch of Congress to reject any reorganization plan submitted by the President.

LONDON, Aug. 17 -- British Government funds had an erratic session in the stock markets here today. Sellers, believed to be bears, took their cue from the report of the Federation of British Industries on the dangers of Britain's economic situation and Paul A. Hoffman's blunt warning to Europe about dollar earnings and prices, fell sharply.

BRONXVILLE, N. Y., Aug. 17 -- One major upset, one extra hole contest and one default featured the first round of match play in the twenty-fourth annual Women's Westchester and Fairfield Golf Association championship over the Siwanoy Country Club course today.

The six-story apartment building at the northwest corner of Freeman Street and Hoe Avenue, the Bronx, has been purchased by the Braco Corporation from the 1271 Hoe Avenue Corporation. The property, on a plot about 43 by 90 feet, is assessed a $90,000. Title was insured by the Home Title Guaranty Company.

BERLIN, Aug. 17 -- Maj. Gen. Alexander G. Kotikov, Soviet commandant in Berlin, is expected to suggest at tomorrow's commandants' meeting that a new municipal election be held for the whole of Berlin. The conference will be the second since the talks were resumed following the lifting of the blockade.
ALBANY, Aug. 17 -- The State Education Department announced today that 152 high school graduates had won state-paid tuition scholarships to Cornell University.

Vic Raschi registered his long-deferred sixteenth victory last night, thanks to a ninth-inning Yankee rally that beat the Senators, 4 -- 3, before 27,275 spectators at the Stadium. The Bombers bailed out their ace right-hander by scoring twice in their last turn at bat.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- An Interstate Commerce Commission examiner recommended approval today of a modified plan for revision of the capital structure of the Boston Maine Railroad that would create two types of stock, preferred and common, in place of the eight classes now outstanding.
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 17 (AP) -- The Browns took both ends of a twilight-night double-header from the Indians, 10 to 6 and 5 to 2, dropping the Indians to third place in the American League race.

BOSTON, Aug. 17 -- The magnificent pitching which swept the Giants from the second division to the third slot in the National League in recent campaigning underwent a violent crash tonight as the Braves blasted three of Leo Durocher's hurlers into subjection by a count of 13 to 4.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 (AP) -United States Government guarantee for private investments abroad was urged on Congress by the State Department today as another means of discouraging the growth of communism.

A contract for 1,000,000 square yards of unbleached cotton drill has been awarded to the Federal Prison Industries, Inc., a division of the United States Department of Justice, it was announced yesterday by the New York Quartermaster Purchasing Office. The award price was $0.3496 a yard.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- Senator Irving M. Ives, Republican, of New York, said today that the bipartisan move for a displaced persons bill would move rapidly from now on.
The American college girl dressed in the modes of 1949 and typified by her clean-cut look represented the fashion theme presented yesterday morning at Altman's college show.

The number of persons enlisted in the United States under some form of voluntary insurance providing hospital care had risen by the end of 1948 to 60,995,000 and no doubt will increase further this year, the Health Insurance Council reported yesterday.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was down yesterday and final prices were 8 to 10 points higher, at about the best levels of the day.

Ferenc Kormendi, Hungarian author of fifteen books, only two of which have been published here, will have his third novel brought out by Crown on Sept. 1. "The Happy Generation" is the chronicle of a Hungarian family, covering the first thirty years of this century.

The Esso Standard Oil Company, an affiliate of the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) will advance today the price of heating oils from three-tenths to seven-tenths of a cent a gallon throughout its marketing area.
BOULDER, Col., Aug. 18 (AP) -The lack of well-trained personnel handicaps efforts to combat juvenile delinquency, Dr. Hyman S. Lippman of St. Paul, Minn., declared today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- Those who have approved the foreign policy of the Truman Administration, from its inception in the Greek-Turkish aid program to the submission of the North Atlantic Treaty and the corollary arms assistance bill as drafted, may be witnessing the latest show of Congressional resistance with surprise.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (AP) -- The population of the United States probably will rise above 150,000,000 before 1950 it was noted today by acting Census Director Philip M. Hauser in a report showing that:

A defense witness at the Communist trial who refused to name secret members and allies of the Communist party yesterday escaped jail only when defense counsel dropped efforts to have him refute Government evidence that the party takes orders from Moscow.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 18 -- William Talbert and Gardnar Mulloy, the defending titleholders, were defeated by a pair of young colts from Down Under today in the national doubles tennis championship, and Australia's Davis Cup stock took a rise.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- The Administration appeal to farmers in the 1950 Congressional elections was revealed by President Truman himself today -- it's the Brannan Plan.

A guarded opinion that the poliomyelitis epidemic may have passed its peak was expressed yesterday by Dr. Harry S. Mustard, Commissioner of Health, who based his views on New York's experiences in the epidemics of 1916 and 1931.

STRASBOURG, France, Aug. 18 -- Six committees were ordered formed today by the Consultative Assembly of the Council of Europe. On their work will depend the success or failure of the first experiment in European unity.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- A virtual state of war exists in the Caribbean area, a delegation from the Dominican Republic is understood to have told the Inter-American Peace Commission today. The Dominican Republic delegates said, after the meeting, that they had presented proof of a forthcoming armed operation.

Chicago (Ill.) Sanitary District yesterday sold $8,300,000 of construction bonds due in 1969 and callable in 1952 and thereafter to Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company and associates at a bid of 100.799 for 2 1/4s. The bonds were reoffered at prices to yield from 1.15 per cent to 2.25 per cent.
DALLAS, Aug. 18 (AP) -- George Trautman, boss of the minor leagues, said today he hoped the Mexican League would be affiliated with organized baseball soon.

Steel warehouses in this area have started to feel their first shortages and steel mills are deferring deliveries in a definite reversal of a two-month trend toward earlier shipping dates, it was learned yesterday. Items principally affected are plain and galvanized sheets, some grades of wire, some hot rolled items, steel pipe and some thicknesses of plates.

Word was received here yesterday of a Treasury call on war loan account balances in B banks. The requisition will be made Aug. 23 to the extent of 5 per cent of deposits at the close of business on Aug. 17. For banks in this district, the call will amount to $53,944, and for banks throughout the country, to $119,245,000.

HELSINKI, Aug. 18 -- The Cominunist-led strikes crippled activity in Finland's shipping, building, foodstuffs and brewing industries today. They were the first of a wave of walkouts scheduled to spread to nearly a dozen fields in the next few days.

This is by way of being a still small voice with a "beef." I am a copywriter and have been looking for an advertising agency job since April. In addition to visiting the employment agencies I am registered at the New York State Employment Offices, where all unemployed talent with any sense goes the first day after getting the reducing-staff-for-economy routine.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 18 -- Police authorities announced today that a vast Communist revolutionary plot had been timed to take place in several states of Brazil on the same day and at the same hour.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- The United Mine Workers Welfare and Retirement Fund paid $12,000 for private actuarial advice received by Senator Styles Bridges, Republican, of New Hampshire, and this was in addition to his $35,000 pay as a trustee of the fund, minutes of the trustees' meetings showed today.

JERSEY CITY, N. J., Aug. 18 -- The month-old wildcat strike of 460 stevedores, members of Local 1247, International Longshoremen's Association, which tied up American Export Line Piers D and E here, was settled today in a three-hour conference in the office of Deputy Mayor William Flanagan.

Taking a long stride toward simplification and uniformity of motor carrier tariffs, a special committee of the American Trucking Association, Inc., announced yesterday in Washington the publication of its Tariff Compilation Manual No. 1.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- A bill that would determine this country's future in the supersonic aircraft field is up for a decision tomorrow in a House Armed Services subcommittee.

OAKLAND, Calif., Aug. 18 (AP) -- The convention of the International Typographical Union turned down today a demand that the union's leadership give a full accounting on a secret strike defense activity.
PITTSBURGH, Aug. 18 (AP) -- The Pirates shut out the Chicago Cubs, 2 -- 0, today on Rookie Jim Walsh's three-hitter. Ralph Kiner's hits accounted for both Pittsburgh tallies.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 18 -- Drinking by American officials at the Yalta and Potsdam Conferences "was greatly responsible for the concessions made to the Soviets," Mrs. D. Leigh Colvin, president of the Woman's Christian Temperance Union, asserted tonight.

Payments on 1,500 of the 5,700 pending claims for unemployment insurance benefits filed by seamen are being delayed, it was disclosed yesterday after a protest demonstration by 300 National Maritime Union pickets in front of the State Unemployment Insurance office at 165 Joralemon Street in Brooklyn.

LONDON, Aug. 18 -- Reports from the United States suggesting that Britain's gold reserves in this quarter of the year would show a further heavy fall brought bears back into the British Government fund section in the stock markets here today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- Representative Emanuel Celler, chairman of the House Judiciary Committee, moved today to end seven weeks of inaction on a bill that would give New York State a tract of land at Manhattan Beach, Brooklyn, part of which is to be developed as a city park.

Directors of the Amalgamated Leather Company, Inc., did not consider a dividend on the common stock at yesterday's meeting. The only payment this year was 10 cents on April 15, while in 1948 common stockholders' received 20 cents in April and 10 cents in August.

LAUSANNE, Switzerland, Aug. 18 -- The future status of Jerusalem now appears to the United Nations Palestine Conciliation Commission as one of the most difficult problems involved in any general Palestine settlement.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (UP) -- The Air Force today announced splitting of its Training and Requirements Division and named Maj. Gen. Gordon P. Saville as new Requirements Director.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- The House approved a foreign military aid program tonight but cut in half its largest section, the $1,160,990,000 that had been sought for this country's associates in the North Atlantic Treaty.

LONDON, Aug. 18 -- The Sadler's Wells Ballet Company scored a brilliant success at the Royal Opera House tonight when the troupe, led by Britain's premier ballerina. Margot Fonteyne, and Michael Soames, danced "Le Lacdes Cygnes" in its entirety.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 18 -- Dr. Ralph J. Bunche, director of the United Nations trusteeship division, tonight called the Senate Judiciary Committee "irresponsible" and said its cognizance of false charges against the United Nations Secretariat constituted an "absurd witch hunt."

In the quiet and darkness of last midnight, the Dodgers sneaked out of town and headed for Boston, where they hoped for better treatment than they received at home. Humiliated in the afternoon by a 9-5 setback that gave the Phillies a clean sweep of the 3-game set at Ebbets Field, the Brooks were a somewhat disillusioned second-place outfit, trailing the idle Cards by a full length.

The festivities of Connie Mack Week-end will be launched today when the 86-year-old owner-manager of the Philadelphia Athletics will take part in an elaborate parade up Broadway from the Battery to City Hall, where he will be welcomed by Mayor William O'Dwyer at 12:15 P.M.

LAKE SUCCESS, Aug. 18 -- The British Government is expected to present a modified version of the Bevin-Sforza plan, which would provide for early home rule for Tripolitania, at the September session of the United Nations General Assembly.

Dealers in domestic scrap metal have asked the Department of Commerce to remove export quota restrictions on iron and steel scrap. The request was made in Washington on Wednesday by a subcommittee of the export-import committee of the Institute of Scrap Iron and Steel, Inc., the national trade organization.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Aug, 18 -- Although persistent broadcasts of the "Voice of America" and the British Broadcasting Corporation and a score of other European radio stations today amply informed the Czechoslovaks about Roman Catholic Archbishop Beran's letter to the state prosecutor protesting his internment, it was not mentioned by the Czechoslovak press or radio.

The news from Greece indicates that the victory of the national armies is at last in sight. The Greeks claim to have driven the rebels out of their strongholds in the Vitsi Mountains -- an operation not unlike chasing eagles from their nests -- and to have sealed the Albanian frontier, chief line of supply and retreat for the guerrilla forces.
Though the only price declines in meat from last week to this have been on two pork cuts, this is a far more encouraging sign than it might appear at first glance.

CHAUTAUQUA, N. Y., Aug. 18 -- "We are moving toward a sounder idea of marriage, based not upon society's demands, but upon willing cooperation," Dr. Earl Lomon Koos, chairman of the University of Rochester's Department of Sociology, said today in outlining "a constructive program for family life."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- Col. Louis Huber Renfrow, former assistant Military Aide to President Truman, who is a close friend of Gen. Harry H. Vaughan, was nominated by the Chief Executive today for promotion to Brigadier General.
The Board of Estimate approved yesterday a contract for the building of three fast streamlined ferryboats in the Staten Island shipyard of the Bethlehem Steel Company at a cost of $6,453,000.

DAMASCUS, Syria, Aug. 18 -- The deaths of President Husni Zayim and Premier Mohsen el-Barazi and the apparent restoration of republican government in Syria have, ironically, wrecked the basis of existing plans for a solution of the Palestine problem and the restoration of peace in the Middle East.

If airliners flying from New York to Europe were refueled in mid-air at several points along their route the number of passengers, mail and cargo they could carry would be greatly increased at no extra cost, Sir Alan J. Cobham, veteran British pilot and managing director of Flight Refueling, Ltd., of England, said yesterday.

Without any apparent let up, radio or television is steadily gobbling up Broadway playhouses. The latest to be lost to the legitimate fold is the Mansfield, owned by Michael Myerberg. Yesterday he confirmed a report that the 1,041-seat house had been leased for a year until Sept. 1, 1950, to DuMont Television.
New York and New Jersey joined forces yesterday in a full-scale effort to end the 110-day-old strike of 7,000 employes of the Singer Manufacturing Company in Elizabeth, N. J.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Aug. 11 -- The Czechoslovak Government is now reorganizing industry and working out its economic plan for 1950 in the hope of increasing and rationalizing production in spite of shortages of skilled labor, raw materials and dollar income.

The report of the Kennecott Copper Corporation and its subsidiaries to be released today will disclose that earnings for the first half of this year were less than half that shown in the initial six months of 1948.

Left-wing affiliates of the Congress of Industrial Organizations in New York may be laying the groundwork for secession from the CIO and the establishment of a labor federation of their own, it was indicated yesterday.

Investment companies, to which more than $1,500,000,000 has been entrusted, shed their role as a secondary factor in the securities industry yesterday when Commissioner Harry A. McDonald of the Securities and Exchange Commission told 350 investment dealers that they are "probably in one of the fastest growing businesses in this country."

On the eve of his seventy-ninth birthday, Bernard M. Baruch, financier and elder statesman, said last night at his home, 4 East Sixty-sixth Street, that his doctor had assured him he might live to be "well over 100 unless you get hanged or shot."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- President Truman disclosed today that he had authorized the sale of a $3,000,000 steel-finishing mill to Yugoslavia after the National Security Council had recommended that he do so. Officials disclosed yesterday that an export license for the mill had been granted.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 18 (AP) -- A union whose officers have not signed anti-Communist affidavits can get National Labor Relations Board action against an employer in certain instances, a Federal court ruled today.
BOSTON, Aug. 18 -- Skipper Leo Durocher dug deep in his pitching strength today in an effort to check a noisy Tribal uprising at Braves Field, but it all added to disappointment and disillusionment.

The Automobile Club of New York has called attention to hazardous conditions on Grand Central Parkway, west of the Kew Gardens loop, due to a slippery condition of the surface. Police Department records show that fifty accidents occurred on this comparatively short stretch from January to July this year.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Aug. 18 -- Tate Mann and Tommy Mann of the home club scored 91 -- 22 -- 69 to earn a tie with Ernest M. Vandeweghe Sr. and Ernest M. Vandeweghe Jr., Rockville, 85 -- 16 -- 69 in the Long Island Gol Association father-and-son championship at the North Hempstead Country Club today. The teams will play-off Sunday.

The Board of Estimate approved yesterday the expenditure of $19,230,000 for construction of the first section of the Hunts Point sewage treatment works in the Bronx, bringing to about $50,000,000 the amount thus far committed by the city to the $94,830,000 program it has promised the Interstate Sanitation Commission it will complete by Dec, 31, 1953.

Representative Vito Marcantonio, American Labor party candidate for Mayor, was accused yesterday of having a candidate for a Tammany leadership in the East Harlem section to improve his chances of getting a Democratic nomination for the House of Representatives next year.
CARRINGTON, England, July 31 (Canadian Press) -- Parents of the children who attend headmaster John Knock's school feel they missed something.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 18 (AP) -- The Indians turned on the Browns with a vengeance tonight, burying them under a 14-to-4 score to wipe out partially the stigma of last night's double defeat by the tail-enders.

Westinghouse Electric International Company has received an order from French steel interests for $9,500,000 of electrical steel mill equipment, William E. Knox, president, announced here yesterday. The order, the largest single order of its type ever placed, consists of electrical equipment for two new steel mills at Hayange and Ebange, towns in the iron-ore producing Moselle sector of northeast France, he said.

BERLIN, Aug. 18 -- After today's four-hour meeting of the four Berlin commandants Brig. Gen. Frank L. Howley, United States commandant, accused the Russians of "attempting to turn these quadripartite meetings back into the old Kommandatura procedure" that was dropped as hopeless more than a year ago.

A jury that for forty-three days had listened to testimony on how elderly women were fleeced of their savings through "lonely hearts" clubs by two weird schemers yesterday found Martha Beck and Raymond Fernandez guilty of first degree murder.

BAR HARBOR, Me., Aug. 18 -A summer school and biological research laboratory for talented high school science students is planned here as part of the new Roscoe B. Jackson Memorial Laboratory, now rebuilt after the disastrous fire that swept this area two years ago.

Hide futures edged a little higher on the Commodity Exchange yesterday, setting a new peak for the third successive day. The December delivery touched 20.42 but reacted toward the close and finished at 20.30, a net advance of 9 points. More distant deliveries advanced 10 to 15 points.

Lumber and plywood prices, which declined steadily for eight months preceding July 15, have leveled off in the last several weeks and scattered increases in several items have been made, mill and yard leaders agreed yesterday. They said increased demand definitely had ended the long downward trend in lumber and plywood and believed more increases were possible in the fall.
SANTIAGO, Aug. 18 -- Santiago took on a quieter appearance, today.

The short-interest position in stocks on the New York Stock Exchange exceeded the 2,000,000-share mark on Monday and was the largest in about seventeen years. The Exchange reported yesterday that the total short interest was 2,006,119 shares, an increase of 161,806 over the figure of 1,844,313 on July 15.

A SIN and a shame it is, too, the way some of the most original and diverting writers of our time are as little known as if they wrote in Ashanti instead of in the King's English. An oblique, obscure and pretentious manner may catch the respectful attention of that small group whose nerves jangle in the presence of lucidity and verbal grace.

The $1,000 Fisher Award in Analytical Chemistry will be given to Dr. G. E. F. Lundell, who retired last year as chief of the chemistry division, National Bureau of Standards, it was announced yesterday. The presentation will be made on Sept. 19 at the national meeting of the American Chemical Society in Atlantic City, N. J., by Prof. Linus Pauling of the California Institute of Technology, who is president of the society.

DULUTH, Minn., Aug. 18 -- Invasions by hungry bears had residents of several northern Minnesota cities on the defensive today. One bear at Virginia, described as "plenty big," invaded a home and "ate everything but the kitchen sink" and then ruined that, while a frightened mother and her two children barricaded themselves upstairs.

CHICAGO, Aug. 18 -- The present form of the Sparkman bill, a measure to supplement the provisions of the 1949 housing act recently enacted, contains the first threat of what would amount to socialization of the real estate financing industry, Aksel Nielsen, president of the Mortgage Bankers Association of America, said today.

The Supreme Court of the United States is and ought to be the most deeply respected institution of the Federal Government. On its independence and integrity rest the precious rights of every citizen. Its members ought to be chosen for their proven judicial ability and temperament, and not merely for their political and social opinions or their amiable personalities.

Dear Comrade Chevresky: Greetings to you, dear comrade, and to all the others in free and democratic Totalitaria! How I wish that I might be with you to share in your inspiring existence, instead of vegetating here in the United States among these bourgeois poltroons who know nothing of work and who think only of money.

Since the Iron Curtain descended on the once-free nations of Eastern Europe a steady trickle of political refugees has been coming into the United States. Some had important positions in their governments; some were intellectuals who sought freedom from the stifling blanket of thought-control in the Communist state; most have left their native countries in fear for their lives.

As the result of the termination of certain experimental projects initiated by the previous management, the Curtiss-Wright Corporation and its subsidiaries suffered a net loss of $1,909,309 in the first six months of this year, contrasted with a net profit of $2,681,367, equal to 23 cents a common share, in the similar period of 1948, the corporation's report revealed yesterday.

HONOLULU, Aug. 18 -- The stubborn issue of wages continued today to be a barrier to settlement of Hawaii's 110 - day - old longshore strike as members of the International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union, CIO, continued their special three-day bargaining session, with twenty-four hours yet to go.
ST. LOUIS, Mo., Aug. 18 -- Twin bed accommodations are provided in the Spirit of ST. Louis of the Pennsylvania Railroad, the fastest train running between St. Louis and New York and Washington.
COLUMBIA, S. C., Aug. 18 (AP) -- Senator Burnet R. Maybank was elected Democratic National Committeeman from South Carolina today in a move to heal a sharp party split. He accepted.

WASHINGTON Aug. 18 -- The $5,500,000,000 foreign aid appropriation bill remained snagged in conference today as managers for the Senate and the House failed for a second time to reach agreement on any major item.
SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 18 -- Theodore F. Atkinson is in a rut. He likes it.

Establishment of Portuguese-flag cargo and passenger service between New York and northern European ports under an expansion program of the Portuguese Line (Companhia de Navegacao Carregadores Acoreanos) has been announced here by Jose Bensaude, president of the Flomarcy Company, Inc., 90 Broad Street, agents in this country for the line.

LONDON, Aug. 18 -- King Abdullah of Jordan, Britain's closest ally among the Arabs, arrived here today for a seventeen-day visit dedicated to good-will and friendship -- and, no doubt, political conversations.

The National Football League will open its thirtieth successive championship campaign on Thursday night, Sept. 22, at the Polo Grounds with the New York Bulldogs opposing the Philadelphia Eagles, 1948 champions.

In a letter in your issue of Aug. 10 signed by Robert Alfredson he states: "* * * millions of people on both sides of the Russian border belong to the same race and speak the same language. Those living within the borders of the Soviet Union are definitely better off economically than those living in the surrounding countries.
C. T. Krug has been appointed field sales manager in the New York sales office of Cluett, Peabody Co., Inc., to succeed George S. Robinson, who has resigned to join Swank, Inc.

LONGYEARBYEN, Spitsbergen, Aug. 12 -- Coal mining is on the upgrade in Spitsbergen as far as the Norwegians are concerned. Seven million tons have been taken out by various concessions since coal first began to be mined here and experts estimate that another 1,500,000,000 tons remain.

Mrs. Fiorello H. La Guardia, widow of the former Mayor, yesterday urged the people of New York to vote for Newbold Morris for Mayor. Mrs. La Guardia announced her support of the Fusion candidate at the Astor Hotel, as she accepted appointment as head of the women's division of the Morris-Uviller-Diserio campaign committee.

MINERAL WELLS, Texas, Aug. 18 (AP) -- Texas crude oil producers received today their first increased allowable of 1949 as the Texas Railroad Commission set September production at 2,077,905 barrels a day. This is a rise of 132,268 barrels a day over the current allowable of 1,945,637.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- A loan of $34,000,000 was granted to India today by the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development. It will be used for the reconstruction and development of India's government-owned and operated railways.

Despite yesterday's rain there was sunshine reflected in the faces of 1,200 mothers and children who were the guests of the Uniformed Sanitation Men's Association on an outing at sea aboard the floating hospital, the Lloyd I. Seamen of St. John's Guild.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Aug. 18 -- Christian Democratic party leaders, who are faced with the major responsibility of forming Germany's new Federal Government, began today a series of conferences on a possible invitation to the Social Democrats to join in a coalition.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (AP) -The American Association for the Advancement of Science, the world's largest general organization of scientists, today assailed President Truman's "loyalty order" affecting Federal employes as "basically objectionable."

Beginning Sept. 12, Congoleum-Nairn, Inc., will support dealers in its smooth-surface floor and wall covering products with a five-week national newspaper campaign in 1,001 newspapers in 826 cities, it was announced yesterday. The program, running through the peak selling weeks of the fall season, is said to be unprecedented in the industry.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 18 (AP) -- The incomparable Hironoshin Furuhashi of Japan put on another world record shattering performance tonight to win the 400-meter free style final in the National A. A. U. swimming meet. The Nipponese swept the first four places in the event. He was timed officially at 4:33 flat, 1 9/10 of a second under the listed world record.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- President Truman confirmed today the projected lifting of Federal rent controls in one-third of the areas in the country now under ceilings. In response to questions at his news conference, the President showed annoyance at the cut in appropriations which, he said, necessitated the action.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 18 -- A resolution recommending the continuance of the House Committee on Un-American Activities as a permanent body to "investigate, discover and expose individual and group activities of a subversive nature" was adopted by the Disabled American Veterans' convention today.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., Aug. 18 (AP) -- Four milk-producer cooperatives charged today that price reductions accepted by dairy farmers this year were turned to profits for milk distributors and manufacturers.

Burma has just announced the modification of a trade policy pursued since the country became independent. Foreign investment in certain fields and under certain conditions will now be permitted. This is a significant and valuable step on two counts. First, it will put Burma in line for some of the type of assistance forecast by the Point Four program.

ATHENS, Aug. 18 -- The Greek rebellion, which is now commencing to disintegrate, not with a bang, but with a whimper, has had as its principal raison d'etre the blatant propaganda contention that the Athens Government was "monarcho-fascist," a cliche of dialectical materialism conceived for Hellas.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended last Saturday totaled 728,029 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 11,205 cars, or 1.6 per cent more than for the preceding week, 163,247 cars, or 18.3 per cent fewer than for the corresponding week last year, and 178,276 cars, or 19.7 per cent fewer than during the corresponding week two years ago.

ATHENS, Aug. 18 -- The Greek press generally urged the Government today to present a clear, realistic picture of the country's economic needs to Paul G. Hoffman, Economic Cooperation Administrator, who arrived in Athens this afternoon.

With an impoverished Europe no longer able to provide investment capital, the Union of South Africa is now looking to United States business interests, which heretofore have been interested in the country only as a market, Nicolaas C. Havenga, South Africa's Finance Minister, declared here yesterday.

Dr. Thomas Naolerio has purchased a dwelling at 257 Hamilton Avenue, West Hempstead, L. I., in the colony of new houses being constructed by Junard Homes. The building is in a group of more than 100 being constructed on a twenty-acre site.

The teakwood steering wheel of the derelict iron-hulled barque Otago, the first command of Joseph Conrad, British novelist and mariner, will leave for Great Britain today aboard the Cunard White Star liner Media, escorted by Christopher Morley, who has been instrumental in recovering the memento.

Ruth Nichols reported yesterday a desperate need of milk for children in Europe arid Asia. The aviatrix spoke as a special volunteer correspondent of the United States Committee for the United Nations International Children's Emergency Fund.

LAKEHURST, N. J., Aug. 18 -- Crack Navy fighter pilots who accumulated decorations by gunning planes at 300 miles an hour are arriving here from all over the world to learn the trick of floating aloft at one-tenth that speed.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- Attorney General Tom C. Clark was confirmed as an Associate Justice of the Supreme Court in the Senate today by a vote of 73 to 8.

NEW LONDON, Conn., Aug. 18 -- Valerie Bettis and her company gave their second program in the American Dance Festival at Connecticut College's Palmer Auditorium here last night, and included on it their second premiere of the series.

The Strand Theatre, which dropped its stage show with the opening of "The Fountainhead" on July 8, will revert to its former policy of combined stage and screen programs on Sept. 2 with the premiere of the James Cagney-Virginia Mayo film, "White Heat," and a stage presentation headed by Xavier Cugat and his orchestra, it was learned yesterday.
SANTIAGO, Chile, Aug. 18 (UP) -- Modified martial law was enforced in Santiago today in a move to end two days of bloody rioting, officially described as a Communist revolutionary attempt.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- Preparations to close the United States consulate general in Canton tomorrow have been completed, it was learned at the State Department today. Official announcement will be made in Canton.

Jack Dempsey, former world's heavyweight champion, whose business career has included the operation of a restaurant and hotel, and various mining and real estate holdings, is entering the motion picture production field, it was reported by United Artists yesterday.

President Truman was urged to alter his attitude with respect to excise tax relief in a resolution adopted yesterday at the closing session of the convention of the American National Retail Jewelers Association at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

Morris Kavy, builder, has obtained a building loan of $4,381,700 from the Bank of the Manhattan Company on the second section of the Vanderveer Estates at New York and Newkirk Avenues, Brooklyn, where a 2,520-family garden-type community is being developed.

The B. J. M. Realty Corporation sold the 1-story taxpayer containing seven stores at 4226-4260 Third Avenue, the Bronx, to the Nathan Lieberman Realty Corporation. The property is on a plot about 95 by 225 feet. Alexander Fischer was the broker.

TOKYO, Aug. 18 -- Japanese officials are considering a plan to reinstate approximately 70,000 "purgees" who have been barred from public or semi-public activity since the early days of the occupation on the basis of Allied directives, it is reported tonight.

The Public Service Commission has been considering the possibility of retaining independent engineers to make a survey of the operations of the Long Island Rail Road, Commissioner George A. Arkwright declared yesterday.
CHICAGO, Aug. 18 (AP) -- The fifth-place Detroit Tigers blanked the Chicago White Sox today, 2 -- 0, to gain an even break in their two-game series.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- Differences between the American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations over their participation in the forming of a new global labor federation have been amicably adjusted.

PARIS, Aug. 18 -- Coincident with reports of the continuing drain of dollars from British reserves, members of the European Marshall Plan council expressed the view today that the British would either veto the proposed division of dollars by the council or would accept a new negotiated amount for themselves with reservations stipulating that it was not enough.

BRONXVILLE, N. Y., Aug. 18 -- Miss Polly Andrews of Innis Arden, four-time champion, reached the semi-finals of the Westchester and Fairfield Women's Golf Association championship by defeating the favorite, Mrs. Harry J. Nevil Jr. of Hudson River, 1 up in nineteen holes, over the Siwanoy Country Club course today.
Martin's of Brooklyn presented a teen-age show to an applauding audience of high-school students yesterday.

Ira Mosher, former president of the National Association of Manufacturers and at present the association's finance chairman, told the Presidential fact-finding board for the steal industry yesterday that its proceedings were part of a "grand strategy" by the United Steelworkers of America, CIO, to "replace collective bargaining with coercive bargaining."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- Chairman Emanuel Celler of the House Judiciary Committee today asked Senator Pat McCarran, Democrat, of Nevada, chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee, to report favorably the Celler Displaced Persons Bill "and let the Senate take a whack at it."

SAG HARBOR, L. I., Aug. 18 -A collision at 10:40 A. M. today of two Air Force fighter planes 8,000 feet over near-by Gardiners Bay killed the two occupants of one craft and endangered the lives of a group of church campers.

RIVERSIDE, Conn., Aug. 18 -- The Riverside Yacht Club crew captained by Henry Benjamin won the midget championship of Long Island Sound today by a one-point margin over the Manhasset Bay crew led by Charles Barrington.

Augustus R. Southworth Jr. testified yesterday in General Sessions that he and his father were "decidedly surprised" when John G. Broady billed them $500 for an alleged police wiretap on Kings County Buick, Inc.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (UP) -- Israeli Ambassador Eliahu Elath said today that events in Syria had proved the Israeli contention that "nothing could be more dangerous than the lifting of the United Nations arms embargo to the Middle East."

LOVELAND, Col., Aug. 18 -- The addition of steam or Diesel power plants to the Missouri River Valley development program loomed as a definite possibility today as the Missouri Basin Inter-Agency Committee studied surveys showing that hydro-electric power would be unable to fill basin demands after a few years.

A brisk, continuing demand for rayon textiles in the primary market has brought prices up 10 per cent above those prevailing in June, according to a survey. Primary sellers said yesterday that rayon weavers were almost back to full production and m some instances were taking looms off cottons to increase the rayon output.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 18 -- Anonymous charges of political pressure and corruption in military aircraft procurement were branded false by additional aviation executives at a hearing today of a House Armed Services subcommittee. The subcommittee is investigating the Air Force's purchase of the Consolidated-Vultee B-36 bomber.

A second successive rise in the commercial loans of New York City member banks of the Federal Reserve System was registered by weekly reporting banks for the period ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank here announced yesterday.
CANTON, Friday, Aug. 19 (AP) -- The fall Of a key city only 170 miles from this refugee capital of Nationalist China was reported tonight by the Defense Ministry.

Five innings of hitless relief pitching by Allie Reynolds featured the 5-to-4 victory of the Yankees over the Senators at the Stadium yesterday in a contest interrupted for forty-five minutes by rain.

The primary needs of children in New York City center on a lack of facilities for special groups for whom present resources under voluntary auspices are not adequate rather than any pressing problem of borough imbalance in the field of child care.

Gene Tunney, Branch Rickey and other notables from various fields will be among the substitute news commentators for Lowell Thomas on the CBS radio network from next Monday until the middle of September when Mr. Thomas returns from a trip to the Far East.

SEOUL, Korea, Aug. 18 -- Increasing Communist-directed sabotage of public utilities in south Korea in preparation for a Soviet-inspired coup to overthrow the Korean Republic Sept. 20 was reported here today by the Government's Public Information Office.

Psychiatric bed units are to be provided in general hospitals for patients temporarily disturbed mentally, and each borough will have a mental hygiene clinic and a psychiatric commitment service, Dr. Marcus D. Kogel, Commissioner of Hospitals, told the City Planning Commission yesterday.

The stock market proceeded yesterday along the recovery trail, but the further advance was less spirited and forceful. Moments of hesitancy were noticeable throughout the session and some shading of extreme gains developed in the last hour.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- The State Department indicated today that it was fully supporting Gen. Douglas MacArthur in his encouragement of the Japanese to resume semi-diplomatic relations with the outside world. The Far Eastern Commission, it is understood, has been sharply divided on the advisability of this policy.

RYE, N. Y., Aug. 18 -- Driving through hard rain out on Long Island Sound, the scheduled international championship of the One-Ten Class of sloops was concluded today and the winner was Warner Willcox of the Western Sound fleet.

Directors of the Missouri-Kansas Pipe Line Company have voted to extend and modify the company's offer to stockholders to exchange their stock for common shares of the Panhandle Eastern Pipe Line Company, it was announced yesterday.

Although a large percentage of the anglers encountered seem to be discouraged at the fishing situation, whether in fresh or salt water, yesterday's mail brought several "you should have been here" letters from scattered points.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 18 -- "You Belong to Me," a screen comedy by Robert Riskin, which he and his brother, Everett, originally planned to produce independently, has been acquired from the author by Paramount as a prospective vehicle for Ray Milland, it was learned today.

LAKE SUCCESS, Aug. 18 -- The United Nations' first science conference heard a Canadian official make a pointed attack today against the "prostitution" of the world's scientific brains in the uses of war.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (AP) -- A Southern coal operator charged today the three-day work week imposed on coal fields by the United Mine Workers was part of long-term union plans "to fully monopolize and control" the coal industry.

Applications are now being accepted for Kingsbridge House, the modern six-building annex to the Home for Aged and Infirm Hebrews of New York, 121 West 105th Street, it was announced yesterday by James S. Hays, president of the board.

Financial aid from the United States of America Committee of the Lutheran World Federation will not be continued to the Lutheran Church of Hungary unless conditions are met similar to those under which such aid is sent to other countries, the committee announced yesterday.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Aug. 18 (AP) -- Birmingham Negroes appealed to the City Commission today to reconsider its past action and abolish racial zoning in this Deep South city.

ATLANTA, Aug. 18 -- Dr. Samuel Green, imperial wizard of the Associated Klans of Georgia, died at his home tonight of a heart attack at the age of 59. He had been promoted from grand dragon to the wizard post at a "Konklave" two weeks ago.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- During the week ended Aug 17 member bank reserve balances decreased $251,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Aug. 18 -- Paul Kelly of Sleepy Hollow, the favorite, led a record field of fifty-six in the qualifying round of the twenty-fifth Westchester junior golf championship with a par 70 at Westchester Hills this morning. He then easily won his opening match in the afternoon.

HELSINKI, Finland, Aug. 18 -Troops were called out today following the first outbreak of violence in a new Communist strike offensive. A Government official said that the offensive was designed to make Finland into a Communist state.

Sales of table model radios are increasing seasonally, buyers reported yesterday. They emphasized that gains do not exceed expectations and added that consoles generally still were lagging badly. In a few instances, unexpectedly good volume has been realized in top name radio-phonograph combinations sold at lower suggested list prices.

Prompt action to prevent a sugar crisis was asked yesterday in Washington by Truman M. Gill of Beeville, Tex., president of the American Bottlers of Carbonated Beverages. The fundamental difficulty, he said, is in the Sugar Act of 1948, but the Secretary of Agriculture has power to relieve the situation.

The property at 621-623 XTest I Forty-second Street and 604-628 West Forty-third' Street, recently purchased from the Eugene Higgins estate, has been resold by Wrebb Knapp, Inc., to the Gerosa Paladino Holding Corporation.

We congratulate the Board of Estimate for its action yesterday starting the city on a more businesslike operation of the Willetts Point Parking Field in Flushing Meadow Park in Queens. In the fall of 1947 the Police Department began operating this part of the old World's Fair site as a parking area for drivers who want to take the Flushing elevated line to go to their jobs in various boroughs of the city.

Ferns thrive in both glens and glades. But there is something especially appealing about a glen when August's hot-air quilt is weighing on fields, woods and meadows. A glade is an open sunny spot surrounded by woods; a glen is a narrow, secluded ravine where trees lay shady hands on steep banks and ferns write green pictures among trees and lichen-traced rocks.

MAMARONECK, N. Y., Aug. 18 -- The challenging team of golfers from the British Isles, who will oppose the United States forces in the twelfth meeting of the Walker Cup series tomorrow over the Winged Foot Golf Club's west course, will include four Irish and four English players.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Aug. 18 (AP) -- That argument over the top 3-year-old trotters of the season, begun at the Hambletonian last week, was still unsettled today after three heats had been raced in the Review Futurity Trot at the Illinois State Fair.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 18 (AP) -- An American Army officer testified today that he never trusted Toyko Rose "or any other Japanese."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- Senator John Foster Dulles of New York, serving by appointment on an interim basis, said today he still had "no expectation" of becoming the Republican candidate for the final fourteen months of the term.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Aug. 18 (AP) -- That argument over the top 3-year-old trotters of the season, begun at the Hambletonian last week, was still unsettled today after three heats had been raced in the Review Futurity Trot at the Illinois State Fair.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 18 (AP) -- An American Army officer testified today that he never trusted Toyko Rose "or any other Japanese."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- Senator John Foster Dulles of New York, serving by appointment on an interim basis, said today he still had "no expectation" of becoming the Republican candidate for the final fourteen months of the term.

THE beak-busting industry has been tinged of late with attar of limburger, the rich fragrance arising undisturbed on delicate summer nights. There have been some truly remarkable bouts. There was Walcott-Charles and Charles-Lesnevich and, bestest of all, Walcott and Tandberg, the horizontal Swedish novice. There may even be others.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (AP) -- The Marine Engineers Beneficial Association, CIO, warned its locals on the Atlantic and Gulf coasts today to rescind any working rules contrary to the national union's recent agreement with ship operators.

The property at 621-623 XTest I Forty-second Street and 604-628 West Forty-third' Street, recently purchased from the Eugene Higgins estate, has been resold by Wrebb Knapp, Inc., to the Gerosa Paladino Holding Corporation.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 19 -- Richard Gonzales and Frank Parker, holders of the British title, stood as the United States' last line of defense in the national doubles tennis championship as they gained the semi-final round today with John Bromwich and Billy Sidwell of Australia.

BALLSTON SPA, N. Y., Aug. 19 (AP) -- Mrs. Rose Weiss of Saratoga Springs who said her husband gambled away thousands of dollars sought a court order today to close all gambling establishments in Saratoga County. She also demanded a "complete investigation" by Governor Dewey.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- The Federal Communications Commission ruled today against the broadcasting of radio and television give-away programs, holding they were in violation of the United States Criminal Code section on lotteries.

CANTON, Aug. 19 (AP) -- The United States Consulate General closed this afternoon and the embassy planned to go on a commuter basis from the near-by British colony of Hong Kong tomorrow because of the Communist advance on this Chinese Nationalist capital.

The five-story dwelling at 128 East Sixty-fifth Street, purchased last month from Mrs. James G. King, has been resold by Joseph L. Ennis Co., operators, to Marc Hermelin, attorney. The new owner plans to occupy the property after extensive alterations have been completed.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 19 -- The Phillies celebrated Eddie Waitkus Night in approved fashion at gaily decorated Shibe Park tonight, before a roaring gathering of 19,654 slightly chilled fans.

First reports of sales of non-ferrous metals by warehouses in the New York area indicate that August totals are now 62 per cent ahead of July monthly totals, and more than 150 per cent ahead of June, according to industry members.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- After only a bare explanation of its proposed use, $11,500,000 of additional funds for the Voice of America was approved by the House today to overcome Moscow's "jamming" of broadcasts beamed to the Russian people.

LAKE SUCCESS, Aug. 19 -- The chief of the United States Soil Conservation Service issued a warning today that civilization faced a "tragic decline" unless the world learned to protect and save its present supply of farming land.
The number of poliomyelitis cases here declined yesterday for the second consecutive day. On Thursday Health Commissioner Harry S. Mustard expressed a cautious opinion that the peak may have passed.

BOSTON, Aug. 19 -- After battling for three hours and eighteen minutes and fraying the nerves of Manager Barney Shotton and those of some of the 25,720 cash customers, the Dodgers tonight finally beat the Braves, 6 -- 4, in twelve innings.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Aug. 19 (AP) -- Pat Keller McCormick of the Los Angeles Athletic Club today won the national women's AAU 10-meter platform diving championship. The Californian had a total of 70.38 points for six dives.

Cooler weather brought sharp improvement in retail trade here this week in comparison with preceding weeks. Volume remained under a year ago, but estimates cut the drop for department stores to around 10 per cent, or less than half of that noted last week when extremely high temperatures prevailed.
MEXICO CITY, Aug. 19 (AP) -- Mexico has broken a silver smuggling scheme so vast its operations affected the price of silver on the New York market.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 19 -United States Ambassador James Bruce and his wife will leave by air tomorrow morning. The envoy, who said recently that he had brought to his two-year mission the "approach of a business man to a very important economic problem," will leave hopeful that the Peron regime will take further measures to ease trade with the United States before long.

ALBANY, Aug. 19 -- One hundred winners of 1949 special state scholarships provided for children of deceased or disabled New York State soldiers, sailors or marines were announced today by the State Education Department.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 (AP) -- Ellis Kinder won his fifth straight game and his fifteenth of the season tonight, restricting Washington to three hits as the Boston Red Sox capitalized on Dick Weik's wildness to defeat the Senators, 6 -- 0.

TRENTON, N. J., Aug. 19 -"People in Washington and elsewhere" are trying to break down state unemployment insurance administrations through insufficient financing in order to win federalization of the program, former Gov. Harold G. Hoffman charged today.

GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 19 -- Charles Wood and his guest from Knollwood, long-hitting Fred Fiore, coupled a pair of 34's for a 3-under-par 68 and medal honors as 42 teams vied today at the Tamarack Country Club for eight positions in the championship flight of the club's annual member-guest tournament. Four teams tied for second honors at 71.

Yesterday's closing of the United States Consulate General in Canton, coupled with the prior announcement that the United States Embassy staff would leave the city if and when the Chinese Government did and would accompany it, marks the end of an unsuccessful experiment.

MOSCOW, Aug. 19 -- Pravda sharply attacked today what it charged was a vast expansion of militaristic influence in the United States, contending the plan of military aid for Europe was designed to expand speculative profits of American arms merchants and increase "this legalized plunder of peoples masses."
WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 (AP) -- The Air Force said tonight that "there is a good chance" that the wreckage of two battered aircraft found in a Maryland barn "are prototypes" of the flying saucers.

The stock market was unable yesterday to maintain its greatly improved position under moderate realizing which chipped fractions to about a point from prices. Selling never proved urgent but there was no sustained demand to out-balance the liquidation.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- The Department of Justice challenged today the claims of New York State to filled-in land at Manhattan Beach, Brooklyn. The department's position, which endangers the project for a city park in the area, was made known by Assistant Attorney General A. Devitt Vanech, in charge of the Lands Division.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- A House Armed Services subcommittee today cut more than 50 per cent off a proposed program for construction of supersonic wind tunnels and an Air Force engineering development center.

LONDON, Aug. 19 -- British Government funds dominated the stock markets here again today. American estimates of Britain's current gold and dollar losses caused fresh weakness at the opening. After a flurry of bear covering had brought prices back to over-night levels around mid-day, renewed selling had stocks sinking again to close with all-round losses up to 5/8 point.

Two large vacant plots at the southeast and southwest corners of Main Street and Franklin Avenue in Flushing, Queens, have been purchased by the Bobb-Pat Realty Corporation from Harry Posner for improvement with taxpayer buildings.

BAR HARBOR, Me., Aug. 19 -- Medical science's greatest problems require a precise knowledge of the relation between heredity and individual susceptibility to disease, Dr. Walter E. Heston of the National Cancer Institute declared here today.

Peter Quennell, English author of two books on Byron, has a new biography listed for October publication by the Viking Press. In "John Ruskin: The Portrait of a Prophet" the author presents a character study of the famous critic and essayist, his relations with the Pre-Raphaelites and the nature of his genius.

Firmly and surely the Secretariat Building of the United Nations is rising toward its goal of thirty-nine stories above Forty-second Street, near the East River. And the eighty-three steel workers who toil at setting up the skeleton of the building say they are finding that their belief in the ideals and principles of the United Nations is building up almost in proportion to the floors they add.

Some of the newest dinnerware has been very appetizingly decorated. Fruits and vegetables instead of conventional floral motifs have been hand-painted in bright naturalistic colors on plates of porcelain and pottery to lend a fresh note to fall tables.
TOKYO, Aug. 14 -- For the fourth successive year, agricultural experts are promising Japan an excellent rice crop to ease the nation's food shortage.
Two cutstanding Navy air squadrons in the Berlin airlift received a hearty welcome yesterday on their arrival here after six-and-a-half-months' duty in Germany.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Aug. 19 -- Foreign Minister Fadmel Jamali of Iraq and Premier Riad es-Solh of Lebanon were reported today endeavoring to keep the Arab states from a new outbreak of the old fight over the Fertile Crescent issue, the Syrian plan for greater size and influence through union with neighboring areas.
ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Aug. 19 (AP) -- Grandview Stables' Yazdegerd, 6-to-5 choice, won the featured $4,000 Mt. Holly Purse by a length here today before a crowd of 14,288.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- Administration Senate leaders set out today to try to restore the heavy cut made by the House in the foreign military aid program.

LAKE SUCCESS, Aug. 19 -- The Palestine Conciliation Commission of the United Nations will probably suspend next week its efforts to bring about a permanent peace settlement and begin work on its interim report to the General Assembly, informed sources said today.
CHAUTAUQUA, N. Y., Aug. 19 -- Dr. Earl Lomon Koos declared today that "the principal problems of our youth cannot be solved by the family alone, but must be met by social action."

ROCKLAND, Me., Aug. 19 (AP) -- Harold C. Haskell, general counsel for E. I. duPont de Nemours Co., said today most anti-trust actions against business were due to "shifting interpretations" of the law or "misunderstanding." He spoke at a Rockland Rotary Club meeting:
A 200-year-old violin was found in Stewart's Cafeteria at 1265 Broadway and turned over to the police at 4:30 A. M. yesterday by Joseph B. Troster, the restaurant manager.

A saving of about 10 per cent in construction costs under contracts let recently for work on the Delaware Water System was reported to the City Planning Commission yesterday by Irving V. A. Huie, president of the Board of Water Supply.

CHICAGO, Aug. 19 -- Two moves designed to rescue the near-bankrupt Tucker Corporation were made today. In one action Federal District Judge Walter J. LaBuy approved an order permitting Preston Tucker, president, to leave the country for ten days to confer with unnamed Canadian financiers.
Norman Thomas, Socialist leader and many times candidate for President, declared last night that "if the present arms race is to be continued, it will make war within the next generation inevitable."

ATHENS, Aug. 19 -- Paul G. Hoffman. Economic Cooperation Administrator, said at a news conference today that the economic struggle in Greece should be fought with the same tenacity as the military one. He warned that as a result of the military victories leading to the rebels' collapse, new problems would necessarily follow.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- The initiative of the United States in calling attention, in a session yesterday of the Inter-American Peace Committee, to a suspected threat to the peace in the Caribbean region is in the nature of a preventive move, according to all indications today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican, of Wisconsin, said today that the Senate Investigations Subcommittee conducting the "Five Per-center" inquiry would demand that the Justice Department explain why John Maragon had not been prosecuted for attempting to bring costly perfume oil into this country by describing it as champagne.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- John W. Snyder, Secretary of the Treasury, will preside at the discussions among United States, British and Canadian officials when they meet here next month to consider the British financial crisis, it was announced today in a joint statement by the State and Treasury Departments.

Life insurance purchases in the United States in July showed a decrease of 13 per cent compared with purchases in the corresponding month of last year and were 14 per cent below the aggregate reported for July, 1947, the Life Insurance Agency Management Association of Hartford, Conn., reported yesterday.

A strike at its products division at South Bend, Ind., was chiefly responsible for the loss of $176,269 reported yesterday by the Bendix Aviation Corporation in its statement covering the quarter ended with last June. The loss, equivalent to 8 cents a share, contrasts with the consolidated net income of $2,837,543, or $1.34 a share, realized in the corresponding three months last year.
Gimbels held a preview yesterday morning of college fashions that will be presented this morning during a style show for customers.

ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L. I., Aug. 19 -- John J. Humm and his guest, Dr. Ray M. Bowles of Cherry Valley, scored 35, 32 -- 67, five strokes under par, to win the medal as the qualifying round ended in the Rockville member-guest golf tournament today.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Aug. 19 -- William C. Fitts Jr. of Mamaroneck, Westchester Democratic county committee designee for County Executive in the Nov. 8 elections, is ineligible to run for public office in Westchester because he has not been a property owner here for the required five years, it was learned today.

Christopher Morley went to sea yesterday grinning happily over the prospects offered by his latest mission -- to deliver a rare Joseph Conrad relic to the Honourable Company of Master Mariners in England.

BERLIN, Aug. 19 -- The reorganization of United States representation in Germany, which involves a basic change from control to supervision, is progressing better than seemed possible a month ago, according to a highly placed source in the military government.
OAKLAND, Calif., Aug, 19 (AP) -The International Typographical Union refused today to order its officers to sign non-Communist affidavits.

A cocaine smuggling operation so vast in proportions that it involved an abortive South American revolution and resulted in United Nations action, was disclosed here yesterday by Federal authorities with the arrest of Eduardo Balarezo, 48 years old, of North Great River, L. I.

MAMARONECK, N. Y., Aug. 19 -- The defending United States team gained a substantial edge of 3 points to 1 against the British golfers in the opening Walker Cup matches over the Winged Foot Golf Club's west course today.
Unloading of the first cargo of sugar shipped here from Hawaii since the 111-day-old dock strike began there started yesterday in Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 (AP) -- President Truman has assured Representative Walter Norblad, Republican, of Oregon, that he need not be apprehensive about the Federal Government paying off its Savings Bonds. The President also told him that the Government is interested in "prudent debt management."

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 19 (AP) -- Hironoshin Furuhashi, the Japanese champion, swam to his third world record performance tonight in the 800-meter free style, but the Japanese domination of the National A. A. U. men's crawl events came to an end with an upset victory in the 100-meter by Robert Gibe of the Detroit Athletic Club.
Soviet authorities have begun a new campaign to eliminate persistent and widespread violations of Government regulations on collective farms, recent issues of Soviet newspapers indicate.

Councilman Edward Rager, whose designating petition for the City Council from the Twentieth Manhattan District was invalidated Thursday by the Board of Elections, lost another fight yesterday before Supreme Court Justice Henry Clay Greenberg in his move to have his name placed on the Primary Day ballot.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- Chairman Elmer Thomas of the Senate Agriculture Committee today issued a statement that on Monday he will recommend to his committee a year's extension of farm price supports at 90 per cent of parity.

Last March Congress passed, and President Truman signed, a bill extending Federal rent controls for another fifteen months. Now it appears that Congress has moved, by indirection and almost unnoticed so far as the general public is concerned, to repeal one-third of the law.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 (AP) -- H. C. Howard, Interstate Commerce Commission examiner, today disproved a proposed exchange plan for the Chicago Great Western Company's preferred stock. Mr. Howard recommended that the ICC turn down the proposal on the ground that it is "not in the public interest."

Any form of unrest in Finland -- and particularly a Communist-led labor dispute erupting into violence -- is a cause for deep concern in the democratic world. The reason is not hard to find: it lies along 700 miles of Finland's eastern border. Soviet Russia is Finland's next-door neighbor; and every event that occurs in Finland must be interpreted within that frame of reference.
The defense at the Communist trial yesterday attempted to refute Government evidence that the Communist party in this country takes orders from Moscow.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Aug. 19 (UP) -- Two hundred members of the outlawed Communist party, including several leaders and former legislators, have been arrested in connection with this week's bloody riots here, it was announced today.
A court test of the power of the Federal Communications Commission to curb give-away programs was promised last night by the American Broadcasting Company.

BUFFALO, N. Y., Aug. 19 -- The Bell Aircraft Corporation and the sheriff of Niagara County today asked Governor Dewey for armed intervention after a disturbance in the United Auto Workers' strike here.
CHICAGO, Aug. 19 (AP) -- The traffic death of Margaret Mitchell, the author, was described today by a safety leader as a killing "by mass indifference of the public."

BRONXVILLE, N. Y., Aug. 19 -- Miss Polly Andrews of Innis Arden and Mrs. John H. Bartol of Greenwich C. C. reached the final round of the Women's Westchester and Fairfield Golf Association championship over the Siwanoy Country Club course today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- Senator J. Howard McGrath of Rhode Island will resign his Senate seat Tuesday and be sworn in as Attorney General the next day, it was announced this afternoon.
MONTREAL, Aug. 19 (AP) -- About $200,000,000 in risk capital is needed now to develop the vast iron ore deposits of Labrador and northern Quebec.
Abuses in New York home relief grants will "explode one of these days in the worst scandal you ever heard," Magistrate Hyman Bushel declared in Mid-Manhattan Court yesterday.
