It will be interesting to note the progress of the second step in the moves which Motor Vehicle Commissioner Magee is directing against traffic accidents in New Jersey. The over-all plan of the New Jersey Highway Safety Coordinating Committee, of which the Commissioner is chairman, is to put special emphasis on special kinds of accidents in the state for successive periods.

LAUSANNE, Switzerland, Aug. 19 -- Arab refugee representatives are "boiling mad" over treatment they are getting both from the United Nations Palestine Conciliation Commission and from Arab Government representatives, a source in close touch with Arab affairs said here today.

HONG KONG, Aug. 19 (AP) -- On the word of a Chinese ship captain it was Communist shore guns -- not the British sloop Amethyst -- that fatally shot up his ship during the Amethyst's escape down the Yangtze July 30 and 31.
ALBANY, Aug. 19 -- Governor Dewey gave final approval today, and this state became a member of the New England Interstate Water Pollution Control Compact.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Aug. 19 -- The Disabled American Veterans today elected David M. Brown of Akron, Ohio, National Commander, selected San Francisco as the organization's 1950 convention city and adopted resolutions dealing with veterans' benefits and national defense at final business sessions.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- The Senate engaged in sharp debate this afternoon over a motion to reconsider the 40 per cent cut in the funds for the Housing Expediter, Tighe E. Woods. As a result of the fiscal slash, Mr. Woods proposed, on Wednesday, a reduction by one-third of the areas now under rent-control ceilings.

Seven American students, participating in the Smith College Junior Year in Italy program, will sail at noon today aboard the Vulcania for a year's study at the University of Florence. Dr. Aldo M. Mazio, Italian Consul General here, will be at the ship to convey his Government's good wishes to the group.

PARIS, Aug. 19 -- The British Government flatly rejected today, even as a basis of discussion, the $840,000,000 that the "screening" committee of the Marshall Plan council had suggested should be Britain's share of United States aid this year.

Wilbur Chapman, who indirectly was responsible for a $2,000,000 movement for leprosy missions, arrived at La Guardia Airport yesterday on a Pan American World Airways plane after visiting thirty- five leper colonies in India, the east coast of Africa, the Belgian Congo, French Equatorial Africa and Nigeria.

CHICAGO, Aug. 19 -- Trading in soybeans highlighted operations on the Board of Trade, prices being up as much as 4 3/4 cents a bushel at one time with all deliveries selling at new highs for the year and closing 3/4 to 3 1/4 cents higher than yesterday in the face of heavy realizing sales.
STRASBOURG, France, Aug. 18 (AP) -- Delegates to the European Consultative Assembly applauded today a proposal that the slogan. "My Country Right or Wrong" be outlawed.

More "down-to-earth" marketing and advertising research is being demanded by advertisers before campaigns are started, a research organization official said yesterday. The increased interest of advertisers in pre-testing of advertising for selling quality is characterized also by desire for concentrating efforts on the most promising local markets, it was noted.

The Berley Realty Corporation, of which Gerald Roberman is president, has purchased the Chrystie property at the northwest corner of Broadway and Main Street in Hastings-on-Hudson, N. Y., for improvement with a garden type apartment project to accommodate about 300 families.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- William R. Faricy, president of the Association of American Railroads, said today that developments after establishment of the forty-hour week for non-operating employes of the railroads -- their largest group of workers -- would determine whether it would be feasible for the carriers to get along without seeking further freight-rate increases.

LONDON, Aug. 19 -- The forthcoming Washington conference among the United States, Britain and Canada will settle the issue of whether there are to be three worlds or two, one of the highest British authorities said privately today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- The Military Sea Transportation Service has no present intention of replacing civilian crews with military personnel when it takes over the Army transport fleet of approximately 200 vessels, according to Rear Admiral William M. Callaghan, director of the new service.
HALIFAX, N. S., Aug. 19 (Canadian Press) -- Rescue ships plunged through high-running seas tonight toward two vessels crippled by a vicious Atlantic storm.

An Ithaca (N. Y.) real estate agent stepped from the General Sessions witness stand yesterday to point out Edward M. Jones, former Treasury agent, as one of four men who set up and monitored the wiretap on a Brooklyn automobile agency executive's home telephone.

Trading in rubber futures reached a peak for any day in more than a year on the Commodity Exchange yesterday. The volume touched 2,670 long tons for the day, a figure that was exceeded only slightly by trading on June 1, 1948. Prices were up 5 to 8 points in the day of active trading.

D. A. Walter Davies has been appointed sales manager of the Columbia Tobacco Company of New York, manufacturers and distributors of du Maurier Cigarettes and of Fryers and Allen's Pibroch, imported smoking tobaccos. Mr. Davies formerly was vice president in charge of sales at the Webster Tobacco Company.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 19 (AP) -- The Pirates put a crimp into the pennant campaign of the Cardinals tonight with a smashing 8-2 victory before a crowd of 32,476. Pittsburgh kayoed starter Jerry Staley with six runs in the fifth, three of them on Ralph Kiner's thirty-third homer of the season.

C. M. White, president of the Republic Steel Corporation, declared before a Presidential fact-finding board here yesterday that strikes were "a hell of a good way" to work out disputes that could not be settled around a collective bargaining table.
Rex Harrison indicated yesterday that he may leave the cast of "Anne of the Thousand Days" at the end of this year to do a film in Italy with Lilli Palmer (Mrs. Harrison).
ATHENS, Aug. 19 -- The necessity for political and economic reforms in Greece is coming to the fore as the Communist-led insurrection apparently is dwindling into disintegration.
Judge Harold M. Kennedy in Federal Court, Brooklyn, acted favorably yesterday on three petitions in connection with the reorganization of the Long Island Rail Road.

The Barium Steel Corporation of New York will purchase from the Kaiser-Frazer Corporation the Phoenix Iron Works Corporation and the Phoenix Bridge Corporation in Phoenixville, Pa., it was announced yesterday in a joint statement by C. P. Bedford, executive vice president of Kaiser-Frazer, and J. A. Sisto, chairman, and Rudolph Eberstadt, president, of Barium.

As a former resident of Indonesia and a student of its affairs for several years, David Anderson's dispatch from The Hague dated Aug. 6 alarms me greatly. He reports that the Dutch expect the coming round-table conference to drag on for several months and perhaps end in failure.

LAKE SUCCESS, Aug. 19 -- Scientists working in laboratories and in the skies are learning the art of producing rain and snow but are nowhere near solving the eternal problem of drought, the United Nations Scientific Conference on the Conservation and Utilization of Resources was told today.

Stockholders have followed with some perturbation the course of the steel dispute in which the corporate citizens are represented solely by management, heir and heiress to old feuds between management and labor, industry and government, despite the evolution of the modern stockholder.
The cotton futures market opened 2 to 8 points lower on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday and closed irregular, 11 points lower to 13 points higher.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 19 -- The fiftieth running of the Beverwyck Steeplechase Handicap was a soft touch for Robert W. Grant's Sun Bath at Saratoga today. Only three ran against the winner of last week's North American Steeplechase, and the closest of the three was eight lengths away at the end of the two-mile journey.

LAKE SUCCESS, Aug. 19 -- Nicaragua has proposed that the United Nations General Assembly pay tribute at its September session to Woodrow Wilson and Franklin D. Roosevelt, Secretary General Trygve Lie announced today.
VERBANK, N. Y., Aug. 19 -- A convertible drove up the winding road into Sprout Lake Camp here today and out stepped the driver, Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt.

The Tex McCrary and Jinx Falkenburg television Show will be dropped by its current sponsors, Philip Morris Cigarettes, which, beginning Monday, Sept. 12, will stage the Allen Funt "Candid Camera" interview program over WCBS-TV at 9 P. M., it was learned yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- Congress today moved to avoid disputes such as that over Ezra Pound's poetry prize by ordering the Library of Congress not to hand out any more literary awards.
LONDON, Aug. 19 -- No great attention was paid in London today to the action of the House of Representatives in halving the United States military assistance program for Europe.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 19 -Gen. H. H. "Hap" Arnold, wartime commander of the Air Forces, claimed full responsibility for the controversial B-36 bomber here today. He called it "the world's outstanding bomber."

The Federal Court of Appeals, in a decision filed yesterday, has given the Wages and Hours Division of the Labor Department the right to sue employers for back overtime pay even though the workers involved do not themselves seek it.
Many British students have an erroneous and incomplete picture of United States history and often they know little except that England "lost the colonies" in the eighteenth century.

The Traffic Commission announced yesterday that it would embark on a broad program for setting up off-street parking facilities in heavily congested business areas, but conceded that a method of financing the projects still was unresolved.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 (AP) -Maj. Gen. Philip B. Fleming, chairman of the Maritime Commission, will spend five weeks in Europe this summer.

In preparation for construction of the South Street Elevated Highway, last link in southern Manhattan's peripheral "loop" express road system, the taking of test borings will begin Monday, Borough President Hugo E. Rogers said yesterday.

In an effort to stimulate trading on the New York Stock Exchange the Board of Governors yesterday relaxed floor trading rules to give floor traders more freedom in the purchase of stocks for their own long accounts.

VANDALIA, Ohio, Aug. 19 (AP) -- The fiftieth Grand American trapshoot winged away to a flying start today as 219 gunners from thirty-two states, Cuba, Canada and the Canal Zone participated in preliminary warm-ups.

In your editorial of Aug. 4 you seemed to be searching for an answer to the old and vexing utility lines problem. Naturally, as you commented, this is the result of haphazard piecemeal city development. However, not only is the utility lines problem affected by this ruthless lack of over-all planning, but all phases of our urban life are marred by it.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- Average primary market prices declined 0.5 per cent in the week ending last Tuesday, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today. The index was 151.9 per cent of the 1926 average, 1.6 per cent below four weeks ago and 10.6 per cent below the comparable week in 1948.

The city gave a rousing reception yesterday to "Mr. Baseball" -- Connie Mack, 86-year-old owner-manager of the Philadelphia Athletics. Under a rain of ticker tape, the tall, agile veteran rode in an open car in a parade up lower Broadway. Three hundred thousand persons cheered and applauded. Then at City Hall, where 10,000 persons were gathered, the venerable Philadelphian received from Mayor O'Dwyer the city's certificate for "distinguished and exceptional public service."'

LARAMIE, Wyo., Aug. 19 -- Russian farmers are to become "stepchildren" even more than before because plans of the Soviet Union clearly involve a continuing shift of agricultural production toward absolute market control, the American Farm Economic Association was told today.
CHICAGO, Aug. 19 -- Bill Veeck, president of the Cleveland Indians, will retain his post for at least another year.
Big birthday parties are for little boys. That's why Bernard M. Baruch didn't think he should have any special sort of celebration on his seventhy-ninth anniversary yesterday.

HONOLULU, Aug. 19 -- Negotiations seeking an end to Hawaii's 111-day longshore strike broke off here tonight without a settlement and the parties to the dispute immediately sent a radiogram to the Federal mediation director, Cyrus S. Ching, asking him to come to Hawaii to mediate the strike.

With large stores beginning to place orders for substantial quantities of fall colors, the full-fashioned nylon hosiery market has firmed considerably, it was learned yesterday. Some recovery has been made in the price structure, manufacturers pointed out, and it is their opinion that the current buying marks the end of the recent period of price declines.
Beneath clouds of spray and stonedust that eddy about the scaffolding on Brooklyn's Borough Hall an unusual restoration project is under way.

Except for the scheduled marketing of $100,000,000 of Government of Canada long-term 2 3/4 per cent bonds, underwriting houses face a period of little activity next week. The Canadian obligations, which are to finance the call of high-interest-cost railroad obligations guaranteed by the Canadian government, are expected to reach the market next Thursday.

PINE CAMP, N. Y., Aug. 19 -- Clear skies after yesterday's rain brought the Forty-second and Seventy-seventh Infantry Divisions, which are training here, into the field today. However, members of the 305th Infantry of the Seventy- seventh, Col. Benjamin J. Cothran commanding, heard lectures on intelligence and other military subjects.

It is hard to tell just what the majority in the House of Representatives was thinking about Thursday night when it cut down the foreign military aid program from $1,450,000,000 to $869,505,000. A great many speeches were made but they were not really illuminating.
Ipswich Bay seems to be holding its own as the top tuna resort along the Atlantic Coast, both in the numbers taken and the size of the fish.

LONDON, Aug. 19 (AP) --Great Britain named eight veteran international golfers and two newcomers to its Ryder Cup squad today. The British pros will oppose an American side at Ganton, in Yorkshire, Sept. 16-17.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Aug. 19 -- Billy, Edwards, the defending titleholder from Hempstead, scored a one under par 35, 36 -- 71 to win the medal and followed with an 8-and-6 victory over Dick Quinlan of the home club in the opening round of match play as the twenty-eighth junior championship of the Long Island Golf Association got under way at the North Hempstead Country Club today.

The British people this summer have no sense of impending doom. The shadow of the so-called "dollar crisis" hangs over Whitehall and Lombard Street. The Labor Government looks forward to the financial talks in Washington, now set for Sept. 7, about as happily as a man faces the day when a note is due which he cannot pay.

One way to deal with the high cost of eating in free city restaurants is to lunch rather than dine in them. In an effort to attract noontime patronage, many excellent establishments offer luncheon at a much lower price, relatively speaking, than dinner.
LONDON, Aug. 19 (AP) -- Mrs. Richarda Morrow-Tait, a red-haired artists' model and mother, completed her single-engine plane flight around the world today.

MADISON, Wis., Aug. 19 (UP) -- Federal Bureau of Investigation agents began a "preliminary investigation" today to determine whether forty Negroes were being held in "involuntary servitude" on a farm near here.

A man walked into Budd's liquor store at 30 Church Street at 5:30 o'clock yesterday afternoon, held out a pistol wrapped in a paper bag and said, "Give me the money: I'm. not fooling." The clerk, Harry Winterfield, gave him $150 from the cash register and the thief ram out.

A policy statement explaining points of state law that make particular forms of television and other service contracts illegal insurance will be issued next week by the New York State Department of Insurance, it was learned yesterday.
CANAAN, N. H., Aug. 19 -- Forty-four persons were injured today when the north-bound section of the Boston-to-Montreal Ambassador ran head-on into the southbound section as it stood on a siding.

While the Red Sox were feasting on the more vulnerable Senators at Washington last night, the Yankees were handed a decidedly tougher nut to crack here at the Stadium, where Casey Stengel's pace-setters were confronted with the ever-dangerous Athletics.

HELSINKI, Finland, Aug. 19 -- Finnish Army units were put on a continuous alert tonight to meet the threat of a spreading Communist-fomented strike, which the Government fears may turn into a Red bid to seize power by a coup.

LEE, Mass., Aug. 19 -- The Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival, of which Ted Shawn is the director, this afternoon gave the first performance of "The Dreams of Jacob,'' choreographed by Mr. Shawn to music by Darius Milhaud. The work was commissioned by the Elizabeth Sprague Coolidge Foundation of the Library of Congress.

The Sanitation Department's experiment in which daily "facials" have been given to heavily used streets by mobile litter patrols has proved "successful enough to warrant continuation," William J. Powell, Sanitation Commissioner, said in a report yesterday.
A substantial upswing in buying by retailers of staple and semi-staple merchandise around Labor Day, or before if cooler weather persists, was foreseen yesterday in merchandising quarters here.

Behind the first few irregular lines of dunes, in the sheltered hollows where pools of water are the heart of life through the heat of summer, the lovely rose mallow lifts its blossoms. The dune hollows are miniature worlds. Around them may be complete circles of barren sand, a part of the dune formation.
CHICAGO, Aug. 19 (AP) -- Bob Kennedy's sixth home run of the season highlighted the Indians' 2-0 victory over the White Sox tonight before 38,336 persons.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 19 (AP) -- The Detroit Tigers and the St. Louis Browns divided a twilight-night double-header tonight, the Browns winning, 4 to 3, on Dick Kokos' three-run homer and then dropping a 4-to-2 decision to Hal Newhouser. The second contest was called after six innings because of rain.

MAINZ, Germany, Aug. 19 -- Andre Francois - Poncet, new French High Commissioner, formally assumed authority today with a flourish designed to command German respect and a sober address to remind German officials that the history of the last thirty years had not been forgotten.
MANCHESTER, England, Aug. 19 (UP) -- Twenty-eight persons were killed today in two flaming plane crashes eighteen miles apart in fog-shrouded Yorkshire.

All Lutheran World Federation aid to European displaced persons and refugees overseas will be administered hereafter through one office in Geneva, Switzerland, by its new Department for Service to Refugees, the executive committee has decided.

The new grievance machinery for labor disputes between the National Maritime Union, CIO, and Atlantic and Gulf shipping employers is being put to its first test in a case involving a waitress and a stewardess, it became known yesterday.

Cook County, Ill., announced yesterday plans for borrowing $6,850,000 on bonds dated July 1, 1949, due July 1, 1959 and payable July 1, 1951 to 1958. Of the total, $6,100,000 are designated highway and working cash fund obligations, and $750,000, forest preserve and working cash fund bonds. Bids will be received on Sept. 7.

SHANGHAI, Aug. 19 -- Communist armies in Northwest and South China appeared tonight to be nearing their objectives unchecked. They are almost at the gates of Lanchow, key to Northwest China. In the south, their spearheads are at the borders of Kwangtung, whose provincial capital.
WASHINGTON, AUG. 19 (UP) -- A long-planned, bipartisan drive to bring displaced persons legislation to the Senate floor began today.

In promotions here last week retailers stressed wool and angora sweaters, cultured pearl jewelry, luggage, nylon and rayon pleated skirts and men's woven stripe shirts, according to a survey made especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by the Retail News Bureau, Inc.

ASIDE from its strong claim to be considered the summer capital of American art, one of Provincetown's chief attractions is the surprise that it gives the arriving visitor. As he drives up Cape Cod, noticing with lowering spirits that the weather-beaten towns lie further and further apart and that the countryside is getting to look like an abandoned golf-course, he wonders what exactly can lie at the end of U. S. 6.

HELSINKI, Finland, Aug. 20 -- The Communist party called today for nation-wide anti-Government rallies, and implied that the Soviet Union and Britain might intervene if the Cabinet continued to fight the Red-led strike wave that had crippled key industries and made 150,000 workers idle.

TO classify this tale of an Egyptian physician's life in the fourteenth century B. C. as nothing more than the usual historical romance would be a mistake. Although it suffers from some of the flaws common to the genre, its intention is more serious.

Safety warnings through advertising and other media will be greatly intensified during the two weeks preceding the Labor Day week-end in an effort to prevent another fatality toll on the record-breaking scale of last July 4, it was learned yesterday.

At the annual meeting of the Great Plains Council, held at Laramie, Wyo., last week, Washington officials sounded what was described in news dispatches as a pessimistic note on the prospects for farm exports in the next few years. Actually, these statements could be regarded as "pessimistic" only on the assumption that the wartime and post-war level of exports could be expected to continue indefinitely.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Aug. 20 -- To the tune of riveting machines, swinging hammers and cement mixers, in full cacophony, the community competition between Frankfort and Bonn for honors as the future capital of the West German Republic has reached the sizzling stage.

Forty-six debutantes will be presented to society at the Westchester Debutante Cotillion to be held at the Shenorock Shore Club, Rye, N. Y., on the evening of Sept. 9. This year marks the tenth anniversary of the founding of the cotillion by Mrs. Winfred Byron Holton Jr. of Pelham, who has been its general chairman throughout the decade.

The question concerning the propriety of various campaigns and drives against polio, cancer, tuberculosis, heart disease, etc., raised by Herman Billings in your issue of July 20 and by Dr. Louis J. Lewis on Aug. 2 opens for discussion a vital problem confronting American medicine today.

MISS STARKEY, who teaches English at the University of Connecticut, has done so well with her day-by-day report on Salem's witchcraft delusion of 1692 that it is hard to see how anyone could do better. Unless the reader knows the source material he may think Miss Starkey has made up those amazing dialogues, or added the dramatic detail that rounds out character, gives flesh to history's usually bare bones.

HIGHWAY accidents and traffic congestion in many sections of the country stem from the failure of many states and cities to keep pace with the increasing needs of the motoring public, according to the Traffic Institute of Northwestern University.

NEW LONDON, Conn., Aug. 20 -- Jose Limon's new work, "The Moor's Pavane," had its second performance here this afternoon in the American Dance Festival, sponsored by Connecticut College, in the Palmer Auditorium. Because of the multitudinous activities of the summer season,

MAMARONECK, N. Y., Aug. 20 -- The United States team retained the Walker Cup by beating the golfers from the British Isles, 10 to 2, after an impressive exhibition in the singles that closed the two-day series at the Winged Foot Golf Club today.

THE effect of dollar shortages throughout the world will be noticeable at the 1949 Canadian National Exhibition, which opens for two weeks at Toronto on Friday. Exhibits from British Commonwealth countries, except Great Britain and South Africa, will be missing this year, but a number of American manufacturers will exhibit at the fair for the first time.

Last spring and this summer, the following appeared in one of the nation's medical journals, "Wanted: Graduate Registered Occupational Therapists for progressive all-inclusive program for patients. Modern home, good food, maintenance optional. Liberal retirement plan and illness policy. Paid vacation and holidays. Write . . ."

Edward S. Corwin in "Who Has the Power to Make War?" made a good point when he contended that the diplomatic power should be the responsibility of Congress as well as that of the President. But this seems to me less important

New speed records in shipping orders to dealers have been achieved by the Hickok Manufacturing Company, it was announced last week in Rochester, N. Y., by Alan Hickok, executive vice president and general manager.

Fifty - two - year - old Lawrence Sandusky clung dangerously to a pipe thirty-five feet above ground yesterday for almost eight and a half hours after his leg was caught between a drain pipe and the building at 118 East Fifty-ninth Street.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 20 -- Mrs. Deering Howe's Donor, as game a horse as there is in the business, took the biggest chunk of the $30,400 gross in the forty-seventh running of the Saratoga Handicap today.
WATCHING foreign television has begun in Europe, though it hardly compares yet with the wild craze for listening to foreign radio which soon followed the beginning of broadcasting in the Twenties.

The American Red Cross has worked out a junior accident prevention educational program, beginning this fall, that within a year is expected to reach every student in the first nine grades of the city's public school system.

PINE CAMP, N. Y., Aug. 20 -- Saturday was no holiday for officers and men of Maj. Gen. Brandon A. Burns' 42nd Infantry Division of the National Guard, and Maj Gen. Julius Ochs Adler's 77th Infantry Division, Organized Reserve, both of New York.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Aug. 20 -- To meet the eventuality that Gaza may revert to Israel when peace comes, Egypt is transferring her Arab refugees from Ismailia to the Gaza-Rafah coastal strip. Estimates of those being moved run from 38,000 to 48,000.

THE musicians themselves have saved the Portland Symphony. When it was announced that the orchestra's 1949-50 season was canceled because not enough money could be raised for the concerts projected by Werner Janssen, the players put their heads together and decided they would gamble on ticket buyers supporting the orchestra well enough to give them some financial return.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 20 -- The elimination of Juan Atilio Bramuglia from President Juan D. Peron's Cabinet removed the Argentine statesman best known and most respected by world leaders -- and probably the best friend of the United States here, although his friendship did not preclude occasional strong criticism.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Aug. 20 -- While total Czechoslovak trade, particularly with Russia, is now running ahead of last year's, the country's trade with the Western world, particularly with the United States, is declining steadily.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 20 -- With a crash that was observed by a Ladies Day gathering of 19,266 at Shibe Park today, Leo Durocher's Giants cracked up in a variety of directions and skidded gently out of third place into fifth in the National League standing.

A PECULIARITY of modern American fiction is the dearth of young women writers of great promise. Normally, a large proportion of fiction is produced by gifted women -- who usually tell straight stories better than men -- and it is strange to find the American lists so relatively barren.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Aug. 20 -- Iraq is convinced that the development of her own immense oil resources is being neglected in favor of Iranian and Persian Gulf oil. She is determinedly opposing the construction of the biggest oil outlet yet planned for this region -- the joint British-American Middle East Pipeline, which would pump nearly twice the volume of oil that the tapline of the Trans-Arabian Pipeline Company feeds to the Mediterranean.
FEW kids in New York City's forty-three play streets are aware that their asphalt recreation ground, urban substitute for green meadows and tree-shaded swimming holes, is a crime-prevention measure.

BRONXVILLE, N. Y., Aug. 20 -- How a state can solve problems of housing and education is exemplified by New York, which in these respects leads the country, State Housing Commissioner Herman T. Stichman said tonight in a talk before the board of governors of the Association of New York State Young Republican Clubs in the Gramatan Hotel.

THERE are two schools of thought about when to transplant needled, or coniferous, evergreens. One believes in early spring, the other in late August and September. In the vicinity of New York City, many feel that this month and next is the ideal time.

The dean of the rubber industry knew what he wanted in his early twenties, and now in his seventy-fourth year, Paul W. (Weeks) Litchfield has helped guide the destinies of the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company for forty-nine of its fifty-one years of existence.
The New York State Mediation Board, which on Thursday began efforts to settle the Singer Manufacturing Company strike in Elizabeth, N. J., stepped out of the dispute yesterday for the time being.

THE second American Dance Festival, which closes this afternoon in the Palmer Auditorium of Connecticut College in New London, is an event of considerable historical significance, for it establishes the third generation of American dancers on the level of maturity and independence.

CAMBIUM borers in trees are the insidious after-effects of drought. Now, weeks after the drought has been broken, many trees are beginning a struggle against these damaging insects that will continue this fall and next spring.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -- Six Government reorganization plans took effect today without noticeable impact on the 217,237 Federal employes here.
The first four of the following fourteen lines will explain why I'm paying my bet a few days late:
With the wild rice ripening on the stalk and the season opening in Connecticut and New Jersey on the 1st, the rail bird hunters are getting ready for the first shooting of the season.

LAST Tuesday WOR-TV became an experimental reality when it telecast a baseball game from Ebbets Field, thus putting into operation the seventh and final video station authorized for the metropolitan area. The station announced it would also carry the remaining eight night home games to be played this season by the Brooklyn Dodgers.

OF all the ties which bind the British Commonwealth together, the most important on this particular Sunday is a petite brunette with a mind of her own -- Her Royal Highness, Princess Margaret, who turns 19 today.

College and university plants in the United States which were built for a pre-war peak gross enrollment of 1,500,000 students accommodated 2,408,000 students last fall with varying degrees of success. Education officials expect that by next year the gross enrollment will reach 2,675,000.

AFTER John Child, an intelligent young Indian, finished his training at a government school, he returned in 1872 to his people, the Nez Perces, in the Snake River Valley of Idaho. At a time when many Indians were settling on reservations, the proud Nez Perces fought stubbornly to retain their old way of life.

Some fifty areas in the city have been earmarked as possible sites for public housing projects to be constructed with state and Federal aid, the New York City Housing Authority reported to Mayor O'Dwyer yesterday. It said the new projects would add about 80,000 apartments to the 47,600 built or being built under the city's post-war program.

LEWISBURG, Pa., Aug. 20 -- Appointment of Horace A. Hildreth, former Governor of Maine, as president of Bucknell University, was announced here today as the university held summer commencement exercises and awarded degrees to 166 men and women.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 (AP) -- Boston's Red Sox disposed of some unfinished business by beating Washington, 8 -- 4, in a continuation of a July 7 game today. Boston then polished off the Senators, 7 -- 1, in a regular scheduled game behind the five-hit pitching of Mel Parnell, who posted his nineteenth victory of the campaign.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 (AP) -- About 3,300 Government employes are involved in the reorganization of departments and bureaus that went into effect today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -- The Inter-American Peace Committee was sharply criticized today by Ambassador Don Mario A. Esquivel of Costa Rica for the secrecy with which it has surrounded its investigation of allegations of a threat to the peace in the Caribbean region.

SHANGHAI, Aug. 20 (UP) -- Communist occupation authorities published today a new labor code for this captured city, banning strikes and limiting management's control of production and employment policies.

OLIVER HILLARD, delicate connoisseur of food, wine and lovemaking, is a pale descendant of Sade's Valmont, Dos Dostoevsky's Stavrogin, and Gide's Lafcadio. At 51 he has tasted all esthetic experience except the esthetic experience of murder; and he suddenly discovers that he is "no longer bound in any way by the rules of the herd."

HERE are brought together twenty-three public lectures delivered in Paris in November and December, 1946, on the occasion of the first assembly of UNESCO -- the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization.
PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Aug. 20 -- Tantalizing breezes that came and went just about tied the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club's regatta into knots today.

THE accent of Charles Williams is unique. Although he follows in the great tradition whose activity runs down through Dante and Donne from St. Paul, exploring and expounding the Affirmative Way, he remains a wholly original mind, and the first encounter with him is apt to be startling and unforgettable.
AMENIA, N. Y., Aug. 20 (AP) -- Seventy scientists today made a field trip into Dutchess County to study soil conservation practices.

APPARENTLY modern man is so susceptible to the bludgeoning techniques developed by commercial radio advertising that the same methods are now being used to sell ideas -- from democracy and racial tolerance to safe driving.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -- Secretary of State Dean Acheson was charged today by Representative Walter H. Judd, Republican, of Minnesotan, with suppressing a secret military report that indicated pursuit of a Chinese policy different from that which the State Department has followed.

ON a summer Sunday evening, when the children are at last in bed, when the last departing tail-light has winked away down the drive, fathers and mothers may or may not have the energy for taking inventory of the presents the week-end visitors brought to the children.

To say that the use of income, as a tax base, has been abused is no exaggeration. As and when the need for more Government revenue was experienced, additional taxes on income have been unscientifically imposed.

Foreign trade circles here hailed the grant last week of a $34,000,000 loan to India by the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development as marking another milestone in the unfolding of the huge economic program of that country.

WITH the hay fever season at hand, thousands allergic to the pollen of ragweed are seeking spots where the plant does not grow. This weed, said to be responsible for more than 60 per cent of the hay-fever cases, flourishes between mid-August and mid-October and during this time hay-fever victims traditionally migrate to upper New York State, New England, Canada or the upper Great Lakes area.

BRONXVILLE, N. Y., Aug. 20 -- Mrs. John H. Bartol of Greenwich Country Club today defeated Miss Polly Andrews of Innis Arden, the only four-time winner of the title, 4 and 3, in a 36-hole final at Siwanoy Country Club to win the twenty-fourth championship of the Women's Westchester-and-Fairfield Golf Association.

WASHINGTON. IN spite of the hot weather and what is called, in other environments, the vacation season, the various arms of the Federal Government for the last few weeks have been performing their accustomed chores at something just short of a killing tempo.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -- The United States Government -- the President on the one hand, and Congress on the other -- stands now in its world policy at a point of pause and self-questioning, the like of which it has not known since the war.
FRANKFORT, Germany, Aug. 20 (AP) -- Tighter controls on gift parcels from the United States probably will be set up next week to keep such shipments out of the black market.
ROME. IN the daily battle that the Rome staff of the ECA mission to Italy is waging to foil Communist propaganda against the Marshall Plan, comic strips have proved an effective weapon.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 20 -- A whispering campaign alleging that the national economy of Yugoslavia is on the point of grinding to a halt is making the rounds in Belgrade. The campaign has become more vocal since the arrival of the mission from the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development to study projects submitted by the Yugoslav Government for financing.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Aug. 20 (AP) -- Swedish observers generally said today the Communist labor uprisings in Finland were doomed to failure because of bad timing.

Last April 20, Dr. Philip S. Hench, rheumatologist, and Dr. Edward C. Kendall, chemist, of the Mayo Clinic, announced at a staff meeting at Rochester, Minn., that cortisone, a hormone from the cortex (outer layer) of the adrenal gland, produced remarkable effects in completely reversing the crippling and other symptoms of rheumatoid arthritis, which claims 7,000,000 victims in the United States alone, and rheumatic fever, the "No. 1 killer" of children.

A United States track and field contingent of forty, led by Dan Ferris, secretary-treasurer of the A. A. U. and acting manager of the team, returned yesterday aboard a Scandinavian Airliner from a month's competitive tour of Norway, Sweden, Finland, Denmark and other countries.

" SAINT AMONG THE HURONS" is the story of Jean de Brebeuf, the great, burly Jesuit who came out to Canada in 1625, labored for twenty-four years among the Hurons, with dreadful trials of soul and body, and was captured, tortured, killed and eaten by the Iroquois.

Five city offiials, four American and one Canadian, sailed yesterday from Pier 84, North River, aboard the Italian liner Vulcania as a delegation representing cities of North America at the general assembly meeting of the International Union of Cities to begin Sept. 12 in Geneva.

The rate of credit adjustments and company liquidations in the New York area declined progressively in each of the three months preceding Aug. 1, according to a survey made last week by the New York Credit Men's Adjustment Bureau, Inc. The decline was deemed significant, bureau officials said, because of deteriorating business conditions in May, June and July, and it denoted the ability of business concerns to survive a difficult period.

PRETORIA, South Africa, Aug. 20 -- Ruth Williams, 24-year-old London stenographer who last September married Seretse Khama, chief-designate of the Bamangwato tribe in Bechuanaland, arrived in her new country today in pursuance of her dream to become a "White Queen" in Africa.

NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 20 -Faced with a breakdown in the negotiations betwen India and Pakistan for a truce in the disputed princely state of Jammu and Kashmir, the United Nations Commission on India and Pakistan will recommend to the Security Council that Fleet Admiral Chester W. Nimitz be sent out at once as mediator, it is understood here.

Courses in city and regional planning will be opened this fall to political science, economics and sociology students, as well as engineering students, under a new elective program to be introduced by Rutgers University. The new sequence replaces a former curriculum designed primarily for engineering students.

AMMAN, Jordan, Aug. 20 (AP) -- King Abdullah's Government asked the United Nations today to blame Israel for planting explosives near Jerusalem's holiest places and to have expert sappers dismantle the cache if possible. The Israelis intended to blow up the dump last Monday, but did not carry out their plans.

The Yankees, who seem to be going all out in an effort to make this a memorable week-end in the fabulous career of ageless Connie Mack, overplayed their hospitality at the stadium yesterday in bringing down the Athletics, 7 -- 3, before a ladies' day gathering of 63,577.
SEED and cuttings are familiar methods of growing plants or of making several from only one. Layering, which may be done in spring or summer, is not as well known or as frequently practiced.

PETRIFIED FOREST, Ariz. -- While California may boast of the world's oldest living trees, Arizona has probably the world's most imposing collection of extinct ones in this awe-inspiring 150-square-mile reservation.

SOMETHING as rare as a film without drum beaters has been in the process of production in these precincts for the past fortnight or so. The picture, an RKO melodrama entitled "The Tattooed Stranger," is not being trumpeted about at the moment.

LONDON, Aug. 20 (Reuters) -- Nearly a million fans gave the 1949-50 soccer season a hearty send-off today. In almost tropical heat they packed stadiums throughout the country following the fortunes of eighty-eight English League clubs with traditional enthusiasm.

AL JOLSON, a unique figure in the entertainment world for more than thirty years, is one of the select few living personalities to have his life portrayed on the screen and, moreover, he now is in a class by himself as the only individual about whom two pictures have been made.

GIRLS who have followed the college career of attractive Joan Foster in two previous books will be eager to start on this sequel. Joan finds that being an upper-classman doesn't mean that all her troubles are over. With greater maturity come increasingly delicate problems to be solved, and situations that demand more skill and tact and understanding than ever before.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., Aug. 20 -- Favored teams advanced to the final round of the annual member-guest tournament today at the Garden City Country Club as John Sproul and Frank Strafaci of Pomonok trimmed Harry Opsahl and Walter Redmont, unattached, 3 and 1, and Burt Braun and Frank Simonson of Cherry Valley vanquished Ed Kowalski and Ralph Strafaci of Hempstead, 5 and 3.

MOSCOW, Aug. 20 -- The Soviet Union placed Yugoslavia under a warning tonight that it would be compelled to "resort to other more effective measures" to protect its citizens in Yugoslavia unless the Tito Government promptly corrected what Moscow called the present "inhuman practices."

THE Upanishads form the final sections of the Vedas; they are handbooks for the Hindu who, having passed through the preliminary stages of study, experience and contemplation, seeks the liberation of his soul through direct experience with Brahman, the unconditioned Absolute whose essence is the ultimate reality.

" CITIES of the Deep" is, in effect, the saga of the outcast-hero who returns to his native soil with a fortune to win the hand of the princess who had rejected him in childhood because he was of low station.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -- Senator Karl E. Mundt, Republican, of South Dakota, said today that the Senate subcommittee investigating "five per centers" had been informed that Maj. Gen. Harry H. Vaughan interceded for certain distillers in 1946.

I'll take some of Maxwell Geismar's theories on Hemingway because it's a pleasant article, but I can't swallow his opinion that the work of Dashiell Hammett and James Cain "stem from Hemingway's work."
THE demand for steamship travel in Caribbean, South American and other southern services is leveling off and losing its abnormal post-war character, shipping and travel men report.
A series of automotive improvements and a new distinctive utility front end styling were emphasized in the 1950 passenger car line presented yesterday by the Studebaker Corporation.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 20 -- Officials of the Pacific American Steamship Association said this week they were tired of paying disproportionate tolls to finance Government operations in the Panama Canal.

WESTBURY, L. I., Aug. 20 -- Thirteen players, five of them members of Argentina's El Trebol team, and Laddie Sanford's Hurricanes rode in a spirited seven-period tune-up match on No. 2 field of the Meadow Brook Club today.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 20 -- Frederick (Ted) Schroeder of La Crescenta, Calif., Wimbledon champion and member of the United States Davis Cup team, announced today at the Longwood Cricket Club that he will compete in the national tennis championship at Forest Hills and also that he definitely will not turn professional.

BUFFALO, N. Y., Aug. 20 -- Sid Street, the automotive veteran from Kansas City, Mo., who acquired the habit last week at Red Bank, N. J., of dominating the 135 and 225 speedboat classes, had another big afternoon in the first regatta of the famous old Launch Club since the mid-Thirties.

HAMBURG, Germany, Aug. 18 (Reuters) -- Germany's shipbuilding and ship repairing capacity, in spite of war damage and dismantling, still will be capable of supplying not only all Germany's needs but also of carrying out a large number of foreign orders.
Three men charged yesterday with forgery were accused of having cashed $10,000 in money orders that came from a $340,000 robbery of an American Express Company office in Philadelphia in April.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -- A settled distrust of the words and methods of the Administration in seeking legislation is at the root of the growing disposition of Congress to deny or fundamentally to revise programs submitted by the President. This feeling, which manifests itself on both sides of the party aisle, was expressed this week in both the foreign and domestic field. It has been solidifying for a long time.

BASED on his seventeen years' experience as official lecturer at the National Gallery, London, this volume by Charles Johnson is designed to reach readers who know something about art and want to know more. It is illustrated with examples of European painting from Duccio to Renoir -- chiefly works in the National Gallery collection.
For its annual theatre benefit the Play Schools Association has taken over the evening performance on Oct. 25 of "Double Bill," co-starring Maurice Evans and Edna Best, at the Coronet Theatre.

LUBBOCK, Tex., Aug. 20 (AP) -- A Lubbock physician said a 4-year-old polio patient showed no symptoms of the disease today, twelve hours after her grandfather, a Chicago doctor, gave her an injection of a special serum. She is in a hospital here.

THE beautiful young wife suspected of killing her heel of a husband is a fairly familiar creature in mystery fiction. But Alice Campbell, in this, her twelfth book, employs the well-used situation to fashion an absorbing drama.
CINCINNATI, Aug. 20 (AP) -- Harry (Peanuts) Lowrey's eighth- inning double, his third two-bagger of the game, drove in three runs to give the Reds a 7-4 victory over the Cubs.

MR. HUSTON'S "The Right People" follows a pattern should be familiar by now to readers of novels with a religious theme. We are immediately confronted with two wealthy families who can match each episode in their lives with the more standard newspaper accounts of family debacles.

DESPITE the current American impression, contemporary Italian literature does not begin with Carlo Levi. To be sure, Signor Levi's novel-like diary, "Christ Stopped at Eboli," published here in translation in 1947, and hailed as harbinger of the new Italian renaissance, did come as a bolt from the blue.

Northwest Airlines announced yesterday that it would seek permission to operate a third type of service at fares in between those charged on the new fast Strato-cruisers and those of the "air coach" service.

SHANGHAI, Aug. 20 -- The Washington White Paper thesis, that the Nationalists had ceased to be an effective vehicle for stemming the Communist tide in China, was underlined here this week in a series of military developments which brought panic to two of the most important centers left to the Kuomintang on its dwindling mainland perimeter.

A simplified multiplication chart, invented and copyrighted by John L. Garwood and distributed by the Disbursing Agents Computing Company, Inc., of 26 Broadway, is undergoing tests in the Navy and may eventually be adopted by the entire Department of Defense, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -- The National Labor Relations Board made its first ruling today under a section of the Taft-Hartley Law that holds a union, as well as an employer, liable for back pay in certain cases of discrimination against employes.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Aug. 20 -- Billy Edwards of Hempstead became a three-time winner of the Long Island Golf Association junior championship today when he defeated Dick Calvelli, North Hempstead, 5 and 4, in the final on the North Hempstead links.
Hungary's annual national holiday in honor of St. Stephen, first Christian King of Hungary, was observed yesterday morning at St. Patrick's Cathedral at a solemn high mass.

FANNY JENSEN, officially Minister without Portfolio in Denmark's Government and unofficially "Minister for Housewives," is the country's best-loved administrator. If she has any enemies, they keep quiet about it.

ATHENS, Aug. 20 -- Although unquestionably a fairly large number of insurgents escaped into Albania when the Greek National Army crushed the largest rebel center in the Vitsi salient this week, there is an increasing if hesitant optimism here which holds that the three-year-old civil war is on the verge of ending.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 20 -- Australia ruled supreme in the National doubles tennis championship this evening at the end of the semi-final round of the sixty-eighth annual tournament at the Longwood Cricket Club.

For the third consecutive day the number of poliomyelitis cases reported here dropped yesterday, but the Department of Health said it was "far too early" to draw any encouraging conclusions from the figures.

A NUMBER of edifying or alarming deductions may be drawn from the literary testimony tabulated today on Page 3. As there set forth, eight men and women who work at the novelist's trade were invited to list recent fiction titles which had struck them as "of particular interest or merit."

EACH one of us * * * makes for himself an illusion of the world -- poetic, sentimental, joyful, melancholy, ugly or gloomy according to his nature. And the writer has no mission other than to reproduce faithfully this illusion. The great artists are those who impose their particular illusion on humanity.

THIS collection of thirty-nine pieces by Damon Runyon covers a long span, more than half the sixty-two years he had accumulated before he died in 1946. They are some of his earliest writings thrown in with his last two stories. Clark Kinnaird does a starry-eyed foreword for the book.

LONDON, Aug. 20 -- It took less than five months for the old gang to get back into office in Syria. Husni Zayim, who seized control of the state on March 30, was removed from the Presidency on Aug. 14 in the same fashion that he had used to evict his predecessor -- at the point of a gun -- and was summarily executed.

IN the centenary year of Strindberg's birth the Provincetown Playhouse is giving shelter to his best-known work. The young people of Studio-7, as they call themselves, are staging a vivid and harrowing production of "The Father." In its sixty-second year,

A seafaring man whose ruddy features indicated that he had stopped being embarrassed by anything years ago strode into the American Merchant Marine Library Association's headquarters at 45 Broadway last week and, with a sheepish grin, laid a dog-eared copy of Bowditch on the counter.

WE think that one of the most original and constructive ideas that the Berkshire Music Center at Tanglewood has put into effect this summer is the opportunities it has held out to young writers and poets in the form of scholarships to study the making of opera librettos.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 (AP) -- The secret of where flying saucers might come from is still a secret, so far as the United States Air Force is concerned. It decided today that the two experimental aircraft found in a Maryland barn "have absolutely no connection with the reported phenomena of flying saucers."

JUDGING by the noise coming from New Jersey recently, one might think that Orson Welles and his men from Mars were at it again. Instead of trying to invade the earth this time, they seem to be trying to swing the earth around so that New Jersey is in the tropics.

JACKSON, Miss., Aug. 20 -- An issue of far-reaching importance for Mississippi -- and for the entire South -- has emerged this week as a result of the proposal by Gov. Fielding L. Wright to equalize educational facilities for Negroes with those of white persons. Curiously, it is States' Rights thinking that has brought about this remarkable change in attitude toward the problem of Negro education.
LONDON. HOW much communism is there in the economic structure of the Soviet Union? Is Soviet society now really passing from socialism to communism, as it is claimed in Moscow?

ALUG lived with his family in a small settlement in the jungle on the island of Mindanao. He was gentler than the other boys, and was therefore called a coward. One day he went into the jungle to free a baby monkey caught in a trap and lost his way.

A detailed analysis of the aims and principles of Christianity and communism together with a listing of the "crucial" points at issue between the two ideologies has been prepared by the faculty of Garrett Biblical Institute, Evanston, Ill., it became known yesterday.

The new cargo-passenger vessel Vila do Porto, last in a four-ship post-war construction program of the Portuguese Line, is due here Tuesday on her maiden voyage from Lisbon, it was announced yesterday by the line's agents, Flomarcy Company, Inc., 90 Broad Street.

TOKYO, Aug. 20 -- The Japanese Communist party was today observing with displeasure the Amateur Athletic Union's swimming meet in Los Angeles and the triumph there of the Japanese team, the first from this country allowed to participate in an international athletic event since the war.

Two of the nation's important industries -- aluminum and iron and steel scrap metal -- recently have implored Government agencies to aid them in opening export markets now that the abnormal post-war domestic demand for their products has subsided.

Slowed by unfavorable weather in the first half of the month women's apparel retailers belatedly getting into full swing on early fall promotions, it was pointed out last week. Store features in the next two weeks will include stepped-up campaigns for back-to-school apparel, pre-Labor Day millinery, fur-trimmed coats, dresses and suits.

DETROIT, Aug. 20 -- The CIO United Automobile Workers are in the best financial condition in the history of the union to face a long strike, it was declared today as plans were worked out for a possible walkout against the Ford Motor Company, should one be called.

CHICAGO, Aug. 20 -- Illinoisans are watching with interest a perceptible coolness between two of the state's most important Democratic figures, Mayor Martin H. Kennelly of Chicago and Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson.

NEWARK, N. J., Aug. 20 -- The decision last night of the Political Action Committee of the New Jersey Congress of Industrial Organizations to withhold endorsement of Senator Elmer H. Wene, Democratic candidate for Governor, was viewed in state political circles today as a serious and possibly a decisive blow to his chances of victory in November.
SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Aug. 20 (AP) -- Miss Zoe Ann Olsen of Oakland, Calif., twisted and somersaulted her way to a second successive Women's National A. A. U. ten-meter diving championship today.

HUGH MARLOWE is resigned to the fact that his rise to cinematic prominence has been cloaked more or less in anonymity. At the same time, he has a feeling that this state of affairs, which no actor relishes, is undergoing a change.
MOSCOW, Aug. 20 -- The popular morning newspaper Moscow Bolshevik published one day this week a cartoon entitled "Vain Attempts to Maintain Altitude."
CHARLESTON, S. C., Aug. 20 (UP) -- The South fired the last shots of the Civil War today.

American oil companies operating abroad are experiencing increased difficulty in the marketing of their products because of the growing shortage of dollar exchange. Because a large part of their expenses must be met in dollars, they must receive at least enough dollars in the disposal of their foreign oil products to cover expenses if they are to continue operations.

United States sales to Russia continued their toboggan slide through the second quarter of the year, according to Government figures compiled here by the American-Russian Chamber of Commerce. The downward glide in shipments reflects the continued coldness of the United States toward sending supplies to the Soviet.

LAKE SUCCESS, Aug. 20 -- Approximately 150 delegates from seventy-two countries and twenty international organizations are expected to attend the International Technical Conference on the Protection of Nature, which will convene here Monday for a two-week period.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 (AP) -- Individual incomes rose to a record figure last year in nearly every state. The average was $1,410 for each person.
CHICAGO, Aug. 20 -- The Calumet Farm's mighty Coaltown streaked to a world record of 1:34 for the mile today in winning the $32,250 Whirlaway Stakes at Washington Park.

IN the early morning hours of Aug. 24, 1939, Radio Moscow announced that a German - Soviet non - aggression pact had been signed. Statesmen all over the world, routed from sleep, hurried to their chancelleries. Some were incredulous, like Daladier, who vehemently declared: "It's a canard, it's idiotic."

The police demonstrated again yesterday their willingness to aid those who come to them in time of trouble, including a truck owner allegedly involved in a theft, who appealed for help in establishing an alibi.
Eight hundred and thirty-nine displaced persons disembarked at Pier 60, North River, at 9 A. M. yesterday from the United States Army transport Marine Marlin, which sailed from Bremerhaven, Germany.

AMONG the Atlantean influences in American life, the merger of such colossi of showmanship as Cecil B. De Mille and Ringling Brothers and Barnum and Bailey appears to be shaping up as something that reasonably might be described as epochal.

HONOLULU, Aug. 20 (AP) -- Hawaii's Attorney General today sought both temporary and permanent injunctions to restrain striking members of the International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union, CIO, from picketing or otherwise interfering with any government stevedore operation in Honolulu.

When Hemingway wrote in the Book Review (July 31), "I once read an excellent book by Maxwell Geismar on American writing in which he knew so much about how and why I wrote that he had me groggy for what seemed like a decade," it brought to mind an experience I once had with the late Jack Donahue, dancer and musical comedy star.

SHANNON, Ireland, Aug. 20 (AP) -- Michael J. Quill, president of the Transport Workers Union, CIO, cut short a vacation in his native County Kerry tonight to fly back to New York on union business. Mr. Quill said he wanted to be present in New York for the appointment of an arbitrator in a bus dispute.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -- The friendship between Harry S. Truman and Harry H. Vaughan has come full circle -- or one full circle at least. In one respect, they are back where they started.

THIS is the story of one group of participants in the seventh aliyah to Israel. Of all the aliyot -- waves of immigration to Palestine -- the present is the most dramatic and, in terms of numbers and ultimate goals, perhaps the most important. To the desperate and the idealistic streaming in the new State of Israel is a miracle born of years of longing.

Under sunny skies and with gentle breezes blowing, 500 girls in picturesque costumes of varied nationalities, took part yesterday afternoon in Brooklyn's thirty-fourth annual dance festival, sponsored by the Department of Parks, on Long Meadow of Prospect Park.
NANKING, Aug. 20 (AP) -- The Communist-controlled press today fired its heaviest propaganda broadside thus far against the United States.

The productivity of the post-war United States economy is eight and one-half times that of the Soviet Union, according to research into the levels of real national production a man-hour conducted by Colin Clark, Australian Government economist.

THE truth about fiction is not strange. It is simply that there are always fewer masterpieces among the novels you have read than there are among the novels you have not read. It is a truth that turns up again pretty forcefully when you look through the publishers' breathless broadsides to see what stories will be published between now and the end of the year.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., Aug. 20 -- Casper G. Peterson, much better known as Gus to thousands of club men in the metropolitan area since the turn of the century, celebrates tomorrow his golden wedding anniversary, as well as fifty years as a club steward.

THE HAGUE, The Netherlands Aug. 20 -- The Netherlands Government will protest to the United States and Britain against new Military Government regulations in Germany concerning Rhine River shipping -- one of the keystones of the Dutch economy.

MANCHESTER, England, Aug. 20 -- Like most crises that are minimized and postponed, the British dollar crisis is coming up again under the most unfavorable circumstances. Almost every conceivable factor in time, politics and personality is already working against an objective appraisal and solution of the problem.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 20 -- Senator Margaret Chase Smith, Republican, of Maine, told the diamond anniversary convention of the Women's Christian Temperance Union tonight that the greatest need of America and the world was "total mobilization of our moral force."

ROVO, Utah -- For persons who have an urge to climb a man-sized mountain but do not care to do it the hard way, Utah's Mount Timpanogos, which rises a respectable 12,008 feet, has all the attributes of the better known Western peaks plus one very distinct advantage -- a summit that is easily reached.

After a twenty-five-hour turnaround, described as a record for the line, the French liner Ile de France sailed at 5 P. M. yesterday from Pier 88, North River, with 1,124 passengers for Plymouth and Le Havre. It was her second return trip to Europe since her post-war overhauling.

OMAHA, Aug. 20 -- Midwest interest in the next Congressional elections is building up earlier than usual, with major attention now centering on the nineteen-state Republican Farm Conference which is scheduled for Sept. 23-24 in Sioux City, Iowa.

Isolation of a new virus, which at times causes a disease closely resembling polio in its non-paralyzing form, was announced last week in the Proceedings for the Society for Experimental Biology and Medicine by Dr. Joseph L. Melnick, Ernest W. Shaw and Edward C. Curnan of Yale University.

Washington dispatches yesterday describing a meeting of the Inter-American Peace Committee were full of echoes of times gone by, of romantic characters long dead, of authors such as Richard Harding Davis and O. Hinton, describes as "a nebulous and flexible organization that specializes in throwing out dictators -- or would like to do so."

IN her new novel Pamela Frankau has achieved a remarkable fusion of wit, character and craftsmanship. "The Willow Cabin" is at once moving and intelligent. This is the story of Caroline Seward and Michael Knowle, their love and the kind of people they were.

AGRICULTURAL experiment stations have been established in every one of the forty-eight states. When the oldest, which is Connecticut's, holds its annual field day on Wednesday, gardeners as well as farmers will gather at the Mount Carmel Experiment Farm in New Haven to hear staff members explain progress in growing and breeding plants.

BAR HARBOR, Me., Aug 20 -- An elementary timetable for the mysterious sequence of events between the time of fertilization of the female egg and the birth of a living animal was exhibited to scientists here today at the Roscoe B. Jackson Memorial Laboratory.

The editors of THE NEW YORK TIMES Book Review asked a number of novelists, whose latest books are reviewed in this issue, to list three to six works of fiction (preferably of 1949 vintage) which struck them as "of particular interest or merit." Herewith the replies, arranged alphabetically by author.
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 20 (AP) -- Just barely 21, Hironoshin Furuhashi has become one of swimming's immortals.

A Federal court decision declaring Maryland's Ober law unconstitutional may have some ramifications in the application of New York State's Feinberg law, which prohibits "subversive" persons from holding public school jobs.

CAMBRIDGE, England, Aug. 20 (AP) -- Scientists have found a new vitamin, but do not yet know what it does. Its name is biocytin, and it is colorless. Only a tiny amount of it has been produced yet in pure form. Eight tons of yeast extract have yielded less than one-thirtieth of an ounce of biocytin.
LONDON, Aug. 20 (UP) -- The Labor Government, smarting for weeks under United States criticism, struck back tonight.
CANTON, China, Aug. 20 (AP) -The Chinese Nationalists were credibly reported today to be throwing strong reinforcements into the path of the Communist advance about 170 miles northeast of Canton.
PITTSBURGH, Aug. 20 -- Customs red tape has snarled a shipment of two hundred dolls destined for needy children overseas.

CRISP days and cool nights that bring swift relief to hay fever sufferers are only part of the late-summer attractions of the country around "the Soo," as local residents call the twin cities of Sault Ste. Marie which face each other across the island-dotted St. Mary's River on the international boundary dividing Michigan's Upper Peninsula from the Province of Ontario.

EVERY Sunday during the winter of 1875-76, the 25-year- old Guy de Maupassant took lunch with Gustave Flaubert at the latter's apartment in Paris, and the two discussed writing in general and, in particular, the stories, poems and plays that Guy had written during the week and submitted to his "master."

WASHINGTON. ONCE a week the President of the United States faces the free press and endures a barrage of questions. It is the biggest show in Washington. It is also a great institution, uniquely American. It has become a factor in our checks-and-balances system of government.

EDINBURGH, Scotland, Aug. 20 (UP) -- Edinburgh's Festival of Arts will open here tomorrow with more than 1,500 internationally famous artists presenting two weeks of music, plays, ballets and films. Half a million people are expected to attend the 150 performances that will comprise the third festival since the war.

NOT very long ago a stranger accosted Connie Mack in a hotel lobby. The 86-year-old manager of the Philadelphia Athletics is such an unmistakable figure that he's often greeted by strangers no matter where he is. But his watery blue eyes blinked at this particular salute.

NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 20 -India does not intend to assist in the formation of any Asian or Pacific union chartered solely on the basis of combating the spread of communism in these countries. The Government, while sternly suppressing Communist violence at home, feels that an out-and-out anti-Communist pact would only strengthen the influence of the Soviet Union with Communist China.

Recorded music presented by the New York Public Library at outdoor concerts in Bryant Park tomorrow through Friday from noon until 2 P. M. will include requested selections from Indy, Beethoven, Bartok, Stravinsky, Ravel and Lalande.

BERLIN, Aug. 20 -- It now appears reasonably certain that the first Government of the German Federal Republic will be conservative, elderly, deliberate and, for Germany, experienced. It will represent a coalition in which the Christian Democratic Union, which won the largest number of votes and of seats in the lower house of the Parliament at last Sunday's elections, will be the leading party and the Free Democratic party the second organization.
Spurred by renewed confidence, plans for advertising during the balance of 1949 present a general pattern of accelerated schedules, a check of key executives in major agencies showed last week.

Families in New York State received $118,936,000 in life insurance death benefit payments in the first half of this year, compared with $123,032,000 in the same period of last year and $86,479,000 in the first half of 1941, it was reported yesterday by the Institute of Life Insurance.

BRENSHAM is in the Midlands not far from Stratford upon Avon. It is in a country of orchards from which the village has never "sorted itself out." A person is likely to read a good way in John Moore's account of it under the title of "The Blue Field" before he decides that, despite the reality of its inhabitants, he probably won't find it on any map.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -- An apparent change in Communist party tactics has posed a problem for the Department of Justice that was not contemplated when the Taft-Hartley Act went into effect two years ago.

THERE is a small band of novelists who have chosen the field of crime as their theme, and have handled it on such a high level that their books have escaped the fate of being classed as "mystery fiction" and are accorded the privileges and perils of being treated as "straight" novels.

CHICAGO -- The photographic trade show of the fifty-eight convention of the Photographers' Association of America, held at the Stevens Hotel here last week, was largely a token display of miscellaneous new items rather than a major exhibition highlighted by important products.

POTTING a collection of annuals for indoor flowering provides the means by which part of summer's largess can be enjoyed long after frost has blackened the border. Placed on a window sill, they will brighten the indoor scene until the traditional holiday plants enter the picture.

THE newest edition of "The New York Times Index," covering the people and events of 1948, appears with changes in page size, format and indexing that are designed to make this annual volume even more valuable to its users. The pages are larger, the columns narrower, with three columns to the page instead of two.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 (UP) -- The $1,450,000,000 foreign military-aid program for Western Europe and other countries will be approved by the Joint Foreign Relations and Armed Services Committee of the Senate, a poll of the 25-member group revealed tonight.

ASYNCHRONIZER two inches square for cameras with accessory shoes and built-in synchronization has been developed by the Kalart Company. Powered by two C-type cells, the new device clips into the accessory shoe of the Kodak Tourist and the Polaroid Land cameras.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Aug. 20 -- Unable to impress in two recent outings at Monmouth Park, Papa Redbird, Joseph A. Goodwin's fast-breaking colt, showed his heels to thirteen rivals today to capture the $10,000 added Ocean City Handicap.

ATHENS, Aug. 20 -- In the process of winning its war against the Communist-led insurrection the Greek Government is torn between a popular desire to wreak vengeance upon those who have ruined the country and established a bloody record of savagery, and world opinion calling for justice of a peacetime nature and gentle treatment of the rebels.

" THE frontier with its continuous influence is the most American thing in all America." So wrote Frederick J. Turner; so repeated Fred L. Paxson when in 1924 he brought out the first synthesis of our Western history, his "The American Frontier, 1763-1893."

PARIS, Aug. 20 -- A committee of two was named today to try to break the deadlock in the European Marshall Plan council over the division of the dollars that Congress is expected soon to vote as recovery aid to Europe for 1949-50.

VANDALIA, Ohio, Aug. 20 (AP) -- Heavy wind swept across the Amateur Trapshooting Association's grounds today, holding down scores in preliminary events to Monday's opening of the golden Grand American Trapshoot.

Metal working and electrical industries around New York are among the principal beneficiaries of the patent licensing system of Western Electric Company, which authorizes production of manufactured products from basic developments of the Bell Research Laboratories of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, it was learned here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -- Administration forces in the Senate will have a hard time restoring the cut made by the House in the authorization for foreign military assistance, according to indications today. Several Democrats have indicated their intention of joining the Republicans to keep the House reduction standing.

The United States Maritime Commission has taken steps to provide the nation's merchant marine with adequate insurance protection in the event of another major conflict or threat of one, it was revealed last week in a statement by Maj. Gen. Philip B. Fleming, chairman of the Government agency.

WHEN Grace Livingston Hill died in 1947, she left a warm spot in the memory of the loyal readers of her uplift-and-love stories. She had written more than a hundred light novels with an inspirational angle, and they sold in astonishing numbers.

Bonn, on the west bank of the Rhine near Cologne, is a peaceful residential city whose main attractions have been its university and its mementos of Beethoven, who was born there. Last week Bonn had an atmosphere of new energy. Workmen were putting the finishing touches on a newly constructed addition to the Pedogogical Institute, a long, modern building that looks like something from the New York World's Fair.

ATLANTA, Aug. 20 -- The death of Margaret Mitchell, author of "Gone With the Wind," who was the victim of a speeding automobile, aroused public indignation throughout this area over lax enforcement of traffic laws.

Walsh, Regent of Georgetown University's School of Foreign Service and one of the world's leading authorities on geopolitics, observed last week.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 20 -- Reacting to hot weather, women's apparel stores in Philadelphia last week reported sales were off 33 per cent from a year ago. Their four-weeks sales were less by 17 per cent than during the like 1948 period.

Leonard D'Attolico, 28-year-old paratrooper with a penchant for taking pictures while coming down in a parachute, performed that stunt over midtown Manhattan late yesterday afternoon for the second time within two years. This time it brought him a $50 fine.

CHICAGO. Aug. 20 -- Much cooler weather combined with further "no-down-payment" sales of big ticket household appliances to bring about a marked upturn in retail trade this week. Store traffic increased perceptibly in the Loop and outlying districts and back-to-school promotions met with much better success.

OTTAWA, Aug. 20 -- Canada will send its most experienced negotiators in addition to financial and economic experts to the tripartite conference on the dollar situation that begins in Washington on Sept. 6.

PARIS, Aug. 20 -- One of the purposes of creating the Council of Europe, at least on the part of the French, was to provide some framework into which Germany might fit as a part of Europe without becoming again a dangerous part.

BOSTON, Aug. 20 -- With Warren Spahn swinging the whitewash brush most artistically, the Dodgers subsided before the Braves tonight by a 4-0 score and dropped a full game behind the first-place Cardinals in the National League race. The Braves, incidentally, moved into a third-place tie with the Phillies while the Giants were dropping to the fifth slot.

ATLANTA, Aug. 20 -- Miss Christine Smith, Atlanta movie censor, has refused to issue a permit for the showing of "Lost Boundaries," a film dealing with racial tolerance, it was revealed today.

CHICAGO, Aug. 20 (AP) -- With soybeans setting the pace, prices of all commodities moved higher on the Board of Trade today. Soybeans soared into new seasonal high territory on gains which extended to around 5 cents a bushel at times. Dealings were active.

Two homers by Gene Woodling and one by Phil Rizzuto paced the Yankees to a 7-3 triumph over the Athletics yesterday. BY a process of literary alchemy, James Thurber has combined two of his scripts into "Make My Bed." Early this year he had jettisoned "The Chadwick Profile," the subject of which was The New Yorker magazine, a publication the writer-canine fancier has served long and well.
BOSTON, Aug. 20 -- New Englanders, still waiting for the cost of food to dip discovered this week just how much gold there was in those Aroostook County (Me.) potato hills.
LONDON, Aug. 20 (AP) -- The text of a Soviet note to the Yugoslav Government, as distributed by the Soviet monitor in London:

LONDON, Aug. 20 -- Britain's sensitivity to foreign criticisms of her policies is increasing. This is due to the growing awareness of the gravity of the country's shortage of dollars with which to buy essential food and raw materials for her industry.

It seems that we Americans still continue to miss the boat when it comes to the care and upkeep of our own musical organizations. But perhaps the report of Arthur Cohn's travels in Europe on behalf of the Edwin A. Fleischer Collection will cause other eyebrows besides my own to raise in wonder.

ALONG-RANGE highway construction program that will cost more than half a billion dollars is taking shape in New York, New Jersey and Pennsylvania under municipal, state and Federal sponsorship. The projects, many of them already under way include express highways and parkways, through routes by-passing all cities and towns and traffic lights, and bridges to provide short cuts to beaches and recreation areas and open new regions to motorists.

ONE more publishing season will bring to an end the Nineteen Forties, ten years that seem to be not so much a time of transition in the American novel as an episode, an affair with history. The literary scene is crowded with new, unpredictable talents, and some established writers have begun to show signs of change, as if they were ready to make fresh beginnings.
Few of those who condemned the Public Utility Holding Company Act as the "most cumbersome law ever passed by Congress" will mark on Friday the fourteenth anniversary of its passage.
