WITH sour recollections of how they went wrong after 1929 in believing that "prosperity was just around the corner," business men are now inclined to take similar ideas with a bit of salt. For sound reasons they do not entertain the notion that this is another 1929. On the other hand they are viewing the firming up here and there with hopeful but rather skeptical eyes.

IT is eleven years since we have had a novel by the author of "Appointment in Samarra," and the appearance, after so long an interval, of a big book by John O'Hara is a matter of real literary interest. The new book is a double portrait: the picture of the dominant personality in a growing small town, and of the town itself.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 20 -- Lou Klein's ninth-inning double scored Glenn Nelson and gave the St. Lous Cardinals a 4-3 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates today. Howie Pollet, who relieved George Munger in the sixth, won his sixteenth game of the season as against seven losses. Harry Gumbert was the loser.

Frederic A. Johnson, attorney for Danny Gardella in the latter's suit against organized baseball, obtained Federal Court permission yesterday to examine baseball Commissioner A. B. Chandler before the trial but lost an attempt to see his records.

I HOPE all your readers enjoyed Olin Downes' recent article about the music-hunting adventures of Arthur Cohn of the Edwin A. Fleischer Collection in Philadelphia. I know I did, for in the summer of 1947 I went on a similar hunting trip for the benefit of the Weintraub Music Library (private).

WHEN Lily's slate sponge carefully rubbed away the white chalk-line that had divided the double desk, Kate knew Lily was accepting her as seatmate and friend. Everything immediately brightened, and that was good because, for Kate, the change from being a country child to being a town child was painfully hard.

EIGHTY miles from London, in one of those delightful, dead towns where the cinema is generally empty and shows drastically cut versions of the worst films two years late, some enterprising ladies have started what they derisively call a "culture bus."

Reviewers will have a busy time at the International Festival of Music and Drama that Sir Thomas Beecham and the Royal Philharmonic will open tonight in Edinburgh. There is hardly a night during its three weeks that does not have five events listed occurring simultaneously.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 20 -- The Pacific Coast rubbed its growing pains this week. The Census Bureau directed attention to the sore spots with an estimate that 5,263,000 persons had moved into the area since the last census in 1940 -- an increase of 37.9 per cent.

TAIPEH, Formosa, Aug. 20 -The Communist capture of Foochow has stirred an excitement here reminiscent of the feelings of disaster following the fall of Shanghai. By pushing down through Fukien, the Communists are taking hold along the coast that would be used if they crossed 100 miles of sea and invaded this island refuge of the majority of the top Nationalist Government leaders.

On July 31 you published a letter from Prof. John Q. Stewart stressing the need for a scientific approach to social problems. Professor Stewart cited one of the theories of Henry Charles Carey, "an articulate but neglected American pioneer in social science." Henry Carey was not only an articulate pioneer but a significant figure in the development of America.

ST. LOUIS. Aug. 20 (AP) -- Trailing, 1 -- 0, after a fast-played seven and a half innings, the St. Louis Browns ganged up on Virgil Trucks in the eighth frame for five runs on two triples, a double and a homer to defeat the Detroit Tigers 5 to 1 today.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Aug. 20 --The Chilean Government, acting against what was termed a widespread Communist revolutionary plot, declared today that all Chilean territory was an "emergency zone." This declaration gives the Government powers similar to those it would have in a state of siege.

The United Nations Scientific Conference on the Conservation and Utilization of Resources (UNSCCUR) opened a three-week session Thursday at Lake Success, N. Y. The conference was called in response to a proposed by President Truman in 1946. It marks the first time that scientists and engineers from all parts of the world have gathered around a conference table to discuss problems of conserving and utilizing the world's land, water, forest and mineral resources.

THIS is probably the broadest and clearest work of its kind yet presented to the lay reader. Its publication without any furor indicates how far we have come since 1832 and the appearance of Knowlton's pioneering "Fruits of Philosophy."

The news that the New York National Arts Foundation has invited the star and director of the Oberammergau Passion Plays to serve as the first Germans on the theatre advisory committee should be taken in well informed circles with astonishment.

ST. ANDREWS, N. B., Aug. 20 -- Senator A. Neil McLean, Canada's "sardine king," expressed strong opposition yesterday to any attempt to develop electric power by harnessing the tides of Passamaquoddy Bay.

Salaries of top personnel officials for 1949 in 300 companies increased substantially compared with 1948. This was disclosed last week in a study prepared for the American Management Association by Dale Yoder and Lenore P. Nelson of the University of Minnesota's industrial relations center.

THIS beautiful novel, or poem, of life in the fictitious small town of Morgana, Miss., is made up of seven short stories, or cantos; these are of varying length, and each, although more or less complete in itself (several have been published separately), is greatly strengthened and enriched by the presence of the others.

An improvement in sentiment, following suggestions by leaders in business and Government, had a bolstering effect on financial markets last week. Reflecting the optimism, stock prices in the third month of the summer rise forged ahead to new high levels for the year after some hesitation early in the period.

MANY airline passengers and tourists making their first visit to the temporary administration building at the New York International Airport, more commonly known as Idlewild, have remarked that the vast spaces and broad runways surrounding the air terminal reminded them of the face of the moon.

EVER since I was a little boy writing book jacket blurbs and advertising copy in a publishing house I have admired authors. For some years, my contacts with those who actually wrote the books I slaved to present to the public were rare indeed.

THE intelligent use of annuals may well mark the difference betwen the competent gardener and the tyro. Far from being a beginner's flower, this group of plants offers a test of real skill, as well as an opportunity for brilliant display and all-season bloom.

AGAINST the background of Renaissance Italy, the author has woven a cloak-and-dagger tale of adventure involving the hazardous search for the lost manuscript of an ancient Greek play. We follow young Alan Drayton in his perilous travels from England to Venice where Aldus, the printer, gives him a clue to the location of the gloomy, mysterious Balkan monastery, where the rare manuscript is supposedly hidden.

Dual policy lines of cost reduction and increased output have become clearly established in America's domestic industries as major objectives for the fourth quarter of 1949, industrial leaders disclosed here yesterday. Reflecting little surprise at recent reductions in allotment of dollars to Marshall Plan countries, and armament spending, executives said comparable plans are being set for trimming wasteful spending in industrial sales and production budgets here at home.

THERE is a new pioneer in television -- the man who took a vacation without it. In a reckless moment he cut off NBC, CBS and DuMont, along with the Borden deliveries, and decided to see the world. What is more, it is said, he may recover from his spell outside the intellectual deep freeze.

Retail trade here improved last week with the arrival of cool weather. Sales volume continued below that of the comparative week last year, but the drop was much less than in the immediately preceding week. Estimates put department store sales at about 10 per cent under 1948.

THERE'S no denying that wenches and crooked gamblers and venal private operatives are enticing story material; the trouble is that they're usually written about on a level of taste which might strike even the subjects as slightly offensive.
I wish to take the liberty to contradict the statements printed with the pictures, "Not Paris but New York."

GREATLY improved service is now in effect over the 612-mile route between Jacksonville and New Orleans through the recent establishment of the Gulf Wind, a new train, jointly operated by the Seaboard and the Louisville Nashville.

Now come the rich purples in the fields and meadows, denoting not only a time but a maturity. It is as though the whole summer had been building toward this deep, strong color of royalty, to match the gold of late sunlight and early goldenrod.

IN the forty-two essays assembled in these volumes an impressive array of social scientists and educators consider the function of social work, the state of its present techniques and some of its most pressing substantive problems. The individual papers vary widely in competence and in interest.
BERLIN, Aug. 20 -- Russian-approved attempts to weaken the authority of the Western German state through conversations among Germans on unity will be resumed at Bad Godesberg on the Rhine Aug. 28.

" I see the drought hasn't hurt the water lilies," remarked a visitor to the Botanical Garden in the Bronx last week. With a friendly city furnishing plenty of water from Catskill streams, New York water lilies are doing fine -- and just at a time when most gardens are turning drab and no birds sing.

A FUNNY thing happened to Mr. Fox's picnic basket. The squirrels saw it, and they took it from behind the tree while Mr. Fox was fishing. The raccoon took it from the squirrels. The strong, big bear took it from the raccoon. Then he slipped and dropped it.

I BELIEVE that theatre-minded Negroes everywhere are thrilled over the invitation the Norwegian Government has given the Howard University student drama group to perform two of Ibsen's plays in Norway, Sweden and Denmark.

FOR two decades Emma Brock's books have found well-deserved favor with early readers, and this new book of short stories is one of her best. Unified by an underlying wisdom, and the characteristically sturdy style in which they are written and illustrated, they make a wholesome collection for 6-to-9-year-olds.

THIS book about the Columbia River has been read by this reviewer in just the right place. I read it in a cabin in the Canadian Rockies which looks down on the Columbia's birthplace. Its headwaters foam past the cabin threshold, on their way to the Pacific Ocean, 1,270 miles downhill

THIS is Mrs. Ginzburg's first book to be published in this country, although, as her publishers note, her literary reputation in Italy, where she lives, was established before the war. Both novelettes, "The Dry Heart" and "The Road to the City," are written in the first person, and in each a girl tells the story of her marriage.

ATLANTIC CITY -- This veteran resort, jammed to the closets now, preparing for its Miss America Pageant which begins on Labor Day, and with a heavy schedule of conventions from then on, is casting hopeful glances in a new direction.

The Tuberculosis Preventorium for Children, which is celebrating its fortieth anniversary, has taken over the Oct. 24 evening performance of the new musical revue, "Touch and Go," for its annual autumn benefit. George Abbott's production is scheduled to open at the Broadhurst Theatre the week of Oct. 10.

Without benefit of a public opinion poll, it was a perfect day. Spirits were up, the laundering of summer suits was down. New York's asphalt was firm underfoot. WE 6-1212 was a forgotten phone number. Not spoil-sports but devoted to duty, the Weather Bureau had to report that the summer had hung up another record.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 21 (AP) -- Paul Campbell's eighth-inning homer with two on and Don Kolloway's double that scored Aaron Robinson in the same inning gave the Tigers an 8-to-7 victory over the Browns in the second game today after dropping the first contest of the double-header, 4 to 2.

With previous doubts over television's current effect on other media resolved in a Department of Commerce report that shows TV to be a general all-around benefit, a number of advertising executives started some mild worrying last week about what color television will do to magazines.
A dice player who figured his percentages closely emerged with an estimated profit of $1 last night after pleading guilty to a disorderly conduct charge in the Brooklyn-Queens Night Court.
Matthew G. Finnerty has been appointed vice president in charge of the hard surface sales division of Stitt Howell, Inc., wholesale distributor of floor coverings.

LARAMIE, Wyo., Aug. 21 -- It isn't a question of "How're you going to keep 'em down on the farm" in the Great Plains of the United States and Canada. It's a matter of getting rid of some people to balance population and resources.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 (AP) -- Boring into the motive for the gift of home freezers to Washington notables, Senate investigators today studied new information obtained from the head of the perfume firm that paid the bill.

OLD WESTBURY, L. I., Aug. 21 -- Stephen Sanford's Hurricanes, who are scheduled to open the National open polo championship on International Field at the Meadow Brook Club next Sunday against Templeton, vanquished the Bostwick Field team by 10 -- 6 today.

New impetus is provided to the proposal for refueling in air for commercial planes, which has often been urged, by the recent statements of Sir Alan Cobham, veteran British pilot. This intriguing idea to increase payload and therefore augment profitable operation with both passengers and cargo received strong stimulus by the successful round-the-world refueling bomber flight of the Air Force earlier this year.
At an age when most men in his position are resting on their laurels, James Hubert Blake decided there was a lot he could learn about music.

GENEVA, Aug. 21 -- Measured by value, Switzerland's exports for July, 1949, exceeded her imports for the first time in any single month since September, 1946. By comparison with June, imports in July dropped twenty-five million francs, to 278,500,000 francs, while exports rose two and a half million francs to 290,100,000, the export surplus being thus 11,600,000 francs.

In the Aug. 13 issue of the THE NEW YORK TIMES Robert Brightman, in commenting on the temporary pavement on Grand Central Parkway between Horace Harding Boulevard and Kew Gardens Loop, asked the question as to why this section of the parkway was constructed with an experimental pavement when the adjacent sections are paved with concrete.

Rhythmic breathing and the use of the imagination were recommended yesterday morning as adjuncts to prayer by Bishop Austin Pardue of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of Pittsburgh, in his final sermon of a series at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

They're doing great things in residential architecture nowadays, one hears. Indeed, this must be so, because even the contented Manhattan cliffdweller keeps hearing about it, or seeing examples on the Building Page; and if he is like most of us he must wonder now and then how it would be to live in one of those streamlined, chrome-plated, air-conditioned, glass-bedizened (or completely windowless) habitations that so many people nowadays are calling home, sweet home.

SHANGHAI, Aug. 20 -- An intensive drive aimed at wiping out "Kuomintang special agents" and "armed bandit forces" has been started by the East China Military District. The campaign was launched following a recent six-day "bandit suppression" conference held here by more than forty representatives of various Communist garrison units in this area.

MOSCOW, Aug. 21 -- The question of the next step in the relations between the Soviet Union and Yugoslavia preoccupied diplomatic observers today in view of the Soviet warning to Belgrade that "other more effective measures" might be necessary to protect Soviet citizens in Yugoslavia.

In early July Mayor O'Dwyer issued the first of a series of departmental and agency reports to the people on progress since he took office on Jan. 1, 1946. It dealt, rather inadequately we thought, with the Health Department. Yesterday the second of these reports was published, and told of achievements in housing construction in the last three and a half years.
HELSINKI, Finland, Aug. 21 (AP) -- The Communists' official newspaper charged today that Finnish police action against Communist-led strikers was aimed at preparing for war against the Soviet Union.

The person who neglects to carry his "daily cross" will be unfit when the chance comes "to perform one heroic act for confessing Christ," the Rev. Edward R. Supple, summer staff member of St. Patrick's Cathedral and teacher at St. Mary's Roman Catholic Seminary, Ferndale, Norwalk, Conn., declared yesterday at the cathedral's solemn mass.

HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Aug. 21 -- Secretary of Defense Louis Johnson and the nation's "big brass" may be having unification headaches, but at Mitchel Air Force Base here, air reservists and regular Air Force personnel worked out a little "unification" program of their own yesterday and today -- and quite successfully, too.

Distribution of New Testaments among the nation's school children will help prevent a "coming generation of Godless men and women,'' Leslie N. Allen, assignment secretary and past president of the Gideon Society, declared yesterday at mornin services at the First ,oravian Episcopal Church, Lexington Avenue and Thirtieth Street.

TAIPEI, Formosa, Aug. 21 -The Nationalist Government's loss of most of the Chinese mainland has substantially severed the economy of Formosa from that of China proper. The effect of this productive subtropical island refuge of Nationalist anti-Communist resistance has been to force major readjustments but the overall result has been beneficial.

Oren Root, Republican candidate for Borough President of Manhattan, attacked the O'Dwyer administration, and his Democratic opponent, Robert F. Wagner Jr., yesterday for their attitude on pier rehabilitation.

David T. Houston Company, specializing in industrial realty, has leased new quarters at 200 Washington Street, in Newark, N. J., after seven years at 730 Broad Street. The Levy Management Corporation owns the property.

Representative Emanuel Celler, Brooklyn Democrat and chairman of the Judiciary Committee of the House of Representatives, said yesterday that he would reconvene the subcommittee concerned with the matter in an attempt to resolve the difficulties between the New York State and Federal governments concerning the Manhattan Beach land transfer.

They turned back the calendar a lot of years for Connie Mack at the Stadium yesterday, but the day revealed nothing to the ageless skipper of the Athletics that he had not learned long ago. And beating Yankee teams of any vintage, he admits, is still a difficult feat.
SANTIAGO, Chile, Aug. 21 (AP) -- The Government claimed "complete control" throughout Chile today and the breaking of what it termed an attempted revolutionary action based on a general strike.
LONDON, Aug. 21 (AP) -- Following are excerpts from the Yugoslav reply to a Soviet note dated Aug. 11, as transcribed today from a Belgrade broadcast:

The major radio and television networks will launch their coverage of college football games approximately one month from now and two of the radio chains -- CBS and MBS -- have announced that their schedules are virtually complete.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 (UP) -- Widespread belief that atomic energy can work miracles in medicine has led to a rich harvest for quacks peddling panaceas, officials of the Food and Drug Administration said today.

SHANKS VILLAGE, N. Y., Aug. 21 -- Eleven hundred Shanks Village families in Columbia University's veterans housing project have received a "stern reminder" that tenancy in the apartment units is offered only to those veterans who maintain a prescribed program.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 (AP) -- Representative Richard B. Wigglesworth, Republican, of Massachusetts, accused the Federal Communications Commission today of attempting to censor radio through its new rules designed to put most prize give-away programs off the air.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 21 (AP) -- The Cincinnati Reds and the Chicago Cubs split a double-header today in their cozy little battle for seventh and eighth places in the National League. Red errors helped the Cubs take the opener, 5 to 4, and Ken Raffensberger hurled five-hit ball to give Cincinnati the nightcap, 4 to 1.

Four countries -- Cuba, the Dominican Republic, Haiti and Panama -- with identical ratings, ranked highest in both credits and collections in the forty-second semi-annual survey of commercial credit and collection conditions in Latin-American markets during the first half of 1949, made by the Foreign Credit Interchange Bureau of the National Association of Credit Men.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Aug. 21 -- The most hopeful effort yet made to bring peace to Indonesia will begin here Tuesday with the formal opening of the roundtable conference between the Netherlands, the Indonesian Republicans and the Federalists, who represent vast, scattered areas of the archipelago outside the Republic.

Fourteen of the thirty-eight planned range stations of the new Federal airways system already have been installed in this region of the Civil Aeronautics Administration and the others are due for operation before seasonal poor weather.
PITTSBURGH, Aug. 21 (AP) -- The Cardinals, heading into the home stretch, increased their National League lead to a game and a half today as they divided a double-header with the Pirates.

The Civil Aeronautics Board's policy of permitting non-scheduled airlines to pioneer and develop points of potential air traffic without seriously affecting the operations of the regularly scheduled airlines, which has been the subject of some criticism, has received the approval of one of the irregular air carriers.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 (AP) -- The Cooperative League urged President Truman today to support a cooperative housing feature in pending multi-billion dollar legislation designed to stimulate private dwelling construction.

ROME, Aug. 7 -- The bones of Saint Peter, "Prince of the Apostles," who, according to Christian tradition, was crucified in Rome during the second half of the first century A. D., are understood to have been found less than twenty feet below the pavement of St. Peter's Basilica.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- The National Education Association announced today that it had accepted "with misgivings" an invitation from Representative John Lesinski, Democrat, of Michigan, chairman of the Committee on Education and Labor, to take part in a round-table discussion of Federal aid to education.

BERLIN, Aug. 21 (AP) -- A special report by the United States Military Government for Berlin said today the Russians' current air of friendliness here was a pose to mask the real goal of the Kremlin -- Communist domination of all Germany.

SMYRNA, Turkey, Aug. 21 -The changing pattern of Turkish trade was illustrated as the Stars and Stripes and the black-red-gold flag of Western Germany made their first appearance at the annual Smyrna Fair, which opened last night.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Aug. 21 -- If the Christian Democratic Union, strongest party in Western Germany, over harbored the thought of inviting the Social Democrats to form a coalition government, this idea was definitely abandoned today.

SHANGHAI, Aug. 21 (UP) -- A Chinese transportation company sued an American official of the Civil Air Transport today for alleged non-delivery of cargo and overcharging of freight rates. The action was the first civil case involving an American in the Communist regime's newly opened people's court.

Doubtless feeling that he had shown all the appreciation necessary for the many fine tributes New York had paid him the past few days, Connie Mack decided yesterday at the stadium to do something for himself.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 (AP) -- Jack Kramer scattered seven Washington hits to post his fourth victory today as the Red Sox defeated the Senators, 4 -- 0. It was Washington's eleventh successive loss.

LONDON, Aug. 21 -- As the date draws nearer for opening of the economic conference of the United States, Canada and Britain in Washington, the sensitiveness of the financial markets here increases. This has been amply demonstrated by the behavior of the stock markets in the past week.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- The votes of the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on important roll-calls during the period Aug. 13 to 19 are given in the appended tabulation:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 (UP) -Senator George D. Aiken, Republican, of Vermont, asserted today that the farm price support plan backed by Secretary of Agriculture Charles F. Brannan would plunge the country into a depression.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- The possibility of a Congress in session until Thanksgiving if it took that long for it to pass important legislation was suggested today by Senator Scott W. Lucas of Illinois, Democratic leader in the Senate.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 21 -- The screen biography of John J. Broderick, the New York policeman known as "Broadway's One-Man Riot Squad," which was shelved last year by RKO when Howard Hughes acquired control of the company, has been revived and assigned to Jerry Gottlieb for production in New York late in the fall, RKO has announced.

PARIS, Aug. 21 (AP) -- Officials of the Economic Cooperation Administration here have issued a booklet comparing the purchasing power of the American workingman with his counterpart in the Soviet Union.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 21 -- The steel ingot rate last week again was advanced when mills pushed their national activity up one point to 83.5 per cent of rated capacity. This was said to be further confirmation of a stronger steel market.
New York's weather came back to normal yesterday after the short spell of coolness that followed the protracted heat wave.
DETROIT, Aug. 21 -- Nearly 4,000 Ford Motor Company employes, 60 years of age or older, heard the CIO United Automobile Workers' pension plans outlined today by UAW President Walter P. Reuther.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 (UP) -Former Senator Joseph H. Ball, Republican, of Minnesota, who helped draft the Taft-Hartley Law, received $3,475 this year from sums paid by the General Motors Corporation and the General Electric Company to help defeat Administration efforts to have the law repealed, it was revealed today.
LONDON, Aug. 21 (UP) -- British critics today assailed the American film, "Command Decision," as "contemptuous" and possibly insulting in its attitude toward Britain's war effort.

NEWINGTON, N. H., Aug. 21 (AP) -- "Lost Boundaries," a film on racial tolerance banned in Memphis, Tenn., and Atlanta, Ga., will be shown in those cities on television, the movie's producer announced tonight.

ALBANY, N. Y., Aug. 21 (AP) -Cold storage holdings of foodstuffs in New York State on Aug. 1 were "generally below" the level of a year ago. The State Agriculture Department today listed these totals and percentages of decline:
Continued gains in the membership of religious bodies in the United States are indicated in the annual report of The Christian Herald released here yesterday.

PARIS, Aug. 21 -- The deadlock in the European Marshall Plan Council over the division of dollar aid for this year -- which the leaders will spend this week trying to overcome -- is regarded by expert observers here as probably marking a turning point in the history of this singular experiment in European cooperation.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 21 (AP) -- The Woman's Christian Temperance Union was told tonight that drinking brought on a host of "disasters and near-disasters to the Allied armies" in World War II.
ZURICH, Switzerland, Aug. 21 (AP) -- A team of touring American track stars won every event it entered today in a meet with a picked Swiss and French squad. A crowd of 12,000 turned out.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 (UP) -- Another anonymous document -- this one injecting the name of Glenn L. Martin, airplane builder, into the investigation of alleged irregularities in B-36 bomber procurements -- is under study by the House Armed Services Committee, it was disclosed today.
PARIS, Monday, Aug. 22 -- More than eighty persons have lost their lives in fires that have raged for several days through the forests of the Gironde Department in southwestern France.

ALBANY, Aug. 21 -- The University of the State of New York made public today the names of high school pupils who have won University scholarships for 1949. Ten times as many scholarships are issued in each county as there are Assembly Districts in the county.

BUFFALO, N. Y., Aug. 21 -- The same Louisville daredevil, Wild Bill Cantrell, who ran away with the national sweepstakes at Red Bank, N. J., last week, who romped off with the 1949 Gold Cup at Detroit last month and who looked unbeatable for the President's Cup at Washington next month, was the star performer on the Niagara River near here today.

MIAMI, Fla., Aug. 21 -- The fiftieth annual national convention of the Veterans of Foreign Wars got under way today with a reminder from a wartime chaplain that freedom "is never on the bargain counter" and that it "must always be purchased at a price."

CHICAGO, Aug. 21 -- Government loans to farms on this year's grain crops have not been sufficient to hold prices of the grains above the loan levels, as the result of bountiful yields that, in the cases of corn and oats, have been materially above the nation's requirements.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 (UP) -President Truman was reported today to be backing Murray Lincoln, president of the Ohio Farm Bureau Federation and vice-president of Americans for Democratic Action, to run against Senator Robert A. Taft, Republican, of Ohio, in next year's Senatorial election.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 21 -- The question of whom Australia will use for the doubles match in the Davis Cup challenge round against the United States at Forest Hills this week was pretty much answered today.

A few weeks ago this column discussed the reluctance then being shown by some of the steel companies to present their case for a fourth round wage increase before a Fact Finding Board appointed by the President. Excerpts were quoted from the Brookings Institution study, "A National Labor Policy," which indicated that, in the latter's words, the labor unions had in recent years made such intervention "an essential part of union strategy."

Caring for 16,091 bed patients and 241,178 out-patient visits last year, Mount Sinai Hospital, 100th Street and Fifth Avenue, cost $4,555,600 to operate. It received from patients $2,875,921, according to the 1948 report made public yesterday.

LONDON, Aug. 21 -- The continued reluctance of some British trade unionists to participate in measures to increase the productivity of industry, owing to fear of unemployment, was recorded today by the General Council of Trades Union Congress in its annual report.

Reopening for business tonight after a hiatus of eight weeks are "Anne of the Thousand Days" and "The Madwoman of Chaillot" at the Shubert and Royale, respectively. Theatregoers enjoyed both last season not only for their acting, but also for their literary quality.
The city he says he fell in love with when he stopped here as a soldier bound overseas in 1943 showed Jack Willis Davies yesterday that it had a heart.

Ten walkie-talkie frequency modulation radio units have just been added to the city's fire-fighting equipment to increase operating efficiency and provide better communication facilities, Fire Commissioner Frank J. Quayle disclosed yesterday.

Pravda will get many quotes and a lot of pleasure out of the petty and angry comment currently sizzling back and forth across the Atlantic. If the British dollar crisis could be aggravated into a crisis in Anglo-American relations, it would be a great break for Moscow, worth more than all the Soviet efforts to sabotage the Marshall Plan by strikes and undermine it by propaganda.
FRANKFORT, Germany, Aug. 21 -- John J. McCloy, High Commissioner for United States-occupied Germany, announced today the names of seven members of his "cabinet" in the United ...
PELL CITY, Ala., Aug. 21 (AP) -- A highly advertised parade of 1,000 members of the Ku Klux Klan faded to a mere trickle here last night.

MILWAUKEE, Aug. 21 -- Five hundred delegates of the 60,000-member American Federation of Teachers who are here from all parts of the country to consider such matters as academic freedom, loyalty oaths and civil rights heard a message tonight from President Truman urging all teachers to accept the challenge of educating for a better America and a better world.

CHICAGO, Aug. 21 -- A virtually complete gasoline drought in the Chicago area is forecast for tomorrow instead of the creeping paralysis which has been developing since gasoline truck drivers struck on Aug. 11 to enforce their demand for a wage increase.
EDINBURGH, Scotland, Aug. 21 -- Edinburgh's third International Festival of Music and Drama opened today with two ceremonies and an orchestral concert.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- Senator Kenneth S. Wherry, Republican of Nebraska, and minority leader in the Senate, warned the Administration today that any major agreements resulting from the forthcoming United States-British-Canadian discussions on the British financial crisis would have to be approved by Congress.

Three fires in the Payette National Forest in Idaho were out of control yesterday. Winds swept flames against one crew of fire fighters and one of the men was critically burned. Several received hospital treatment.

Mid-August may not seem like the most logical or pleasant time to think about next winter's heating problems, but experts at the Anthracite Institute yesterday advised home owners to check on the efficiency of household heating systems during the summer when repairs can be done slowly and with greater care.

BUFFALO, N. Y., Aug. 21 (AP) -- The Bisons increased their first-place margin in the International League race to 5 1/2 games by sweeping a double-header from the Bears, 9 -- 5 and 8 -- 7, before 9,335 fans today.

DURHAM, N. C., Aug. 21 -- A campaign to establish a memorial to the late Dr. James E. Shepard, founder and president of North Carolina College at Durham, was begun here last night with a statewide broadcast by national and state figures and officials of the memorial foundation.

WILLIAMSTOWN, N. J., Aug. 21 -- John Baptist Rizzo, 43 years old, and his wife, Mrs. Margaret Ann Rizzo, 37, of Blackwood, were killed today in a collision here between two automobiles. The drivers of the two cars were said to have been friends who had left the same tavern a few minutes before the crash.

A new lower-price policy effective today in all its forty-four stores throughout the country was announced over the week-end by Howard Stores Corporation, manufacturer and retailer of nationally advertised Howard Clothes. The policy covers the entire Howard line of men's and boys' clothes and furnishings, it was said by Samuel Sennet, president of the company.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 (AP) -The job outlook for the next few years in the printing trades is for "a continued but much more moderate and irregular growth," says the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

TOKYO, Aug. 21 -- The Communists' plan to penetrate deeply into Japanese country districts and control the future of the occupation-sponsored land distribution program has suffered a severe setback. Conservatives scored almost a clean sweep in the little-publicized but highly important elections for land committees that have been going on for the past three days in rural towns and villages.

BAR HARBOR, Me., Aug. 21 -- The new buildings of the Roscoe B. Jackson Memorial Laboratory were dedicated today, just less than two years after the scientific facilities of the institution were destroyed in the fire that swept Mount Desert Island.

BOSTON, Aug. 21 -- If the Dodgers are pennant conscious, as has been stated, they must have been suddenly afflicted with amnesia, for they've shown no signs during the last two games here that they remember their 1949 objective.
El Trebol's poloists returned to winning ways yesterday, but the accurate-hitting Argentines had to go all out to do it.
LONDON, Aug. 21 (Reuters) -- After four post-war boom years, British shipyards fear that they may soon be driven to serious retrenchment.

Mrs. Mary Pallilon of Dorchester, Mass., sewed her name and address on a pair of gloves she made five years ago for Red Cross distribution to Europe's needy. Soon the gloves were warming the hands of Mrs. T. J. Visgarda in a refugee camp in Western Germany.
I should like to take exception to Jean Wunderlich's letter in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Aug. 6.

The King Taggart Corporation, headed by Maurice Magid and Victor Polstein, is speeding work on its eight-story eighty-family apartment house at 100 Remsen Street, Brooklyn, which is expected to be ready for occupancy on Nov. 1.

A revolutionary type of plate and spoon set and a revamped version of a child's "low-chair" have been designed to make the modern baby's mealtime easier for mother and more comfortable for the small fry.

LONDON, Aug. 21 -- To meet its current dollar deficit the sterling area needs to increase its exports to the dollar area by something like 40 per cent, examination of official figures indi cated today. To get along after 1952 without United States aid and still maintain its present level of dollar imports the sterling area would need to increase its sales to dollar countries by about 100 per cent.
MAMMOTH HOT SPRINGS, Wyo., Aug. 21 (UP) -- Four forest fires raged out of control late today over nearly 2,000 acres in Yellowstone National Park.

CHICAGO, Aug. 21 (AP) -- The Cleveland Indians pulled within five games of the league-leading New York Yankees today by splitting with the Chicago White Sox. The Indians scored a 7-4 victory after a first game 5-4 loss before 47,254 persons.

CHICAGO, Aug. 21 -- A majority of the country's large food products manufacturers had a larger physical volume of sales in the first half of 1949 than a year earlier, Paul S. Willis, president of Grocery Manufacturers of America, Inc., said today.

EDINBURGH, Scotland, Aug. 21 -- Sir Thomas Beecham, top British conductor, today described the 1951 Festival of Britain as a "monumental piece of imbecility and iniquity" to be staged at the expense of the United States.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 (UP) -- Some 25,789,000 elementary and high school students will start classes this fall facing the same teacher shortage that has plagued the educational system for many years, afficials said today.
SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Aug. 21 (AP) -- Miss Zoe Ann Olsen today came back from a nasty tumble to win her fourteenth National diving championship.

Banks here that have handled a major part of the banking transactions associated with the foreign-aid program have realized small profits, it was learned last week. The modest fees are nearly offset by the costs.

The city's welfare case load increased for the eighth successive month in July, but the rise was the smallest since the upswing began last December, Welfare Commissioner Raymond M. Hilliard said in his monthly report yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- Four Senators issued a joint call today for "immediate and adequate assistance for the free areas in China," and a policy of active cooperation with the countries bordering on China.

Prices of cotton futures in the domestic market moved irregularly within a narrow range last week, while prices of spot cotton went lower. At the close active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange showed net changes for the week ranging from a decline of 15 points to an advance of 15 points, with the most distant months registering the improvement.

LONDON, Aug. 21 (AP) -- The Russians, who get nervous when foreigners head for biblical Mt. Ararat just across the border in Turkey, made known tonight one of their scientists had been digging close to it.

In the further liquidation of the industrial center in Paterson, N. J., which it bought from the Wright Aeronautical Corporation, Webb Knapp, Inc., has sold 208,000 square feet of space to the December Corporation of Hoboken.

The Maritime War Emergency Board, reactivated by President Truman last month to study the question of continued payment of so-called "war bonuses" to American seamen, has issued a call to all offshore shipping companies and maritime unions to attend a hearing in Washington Sept. 28, it became known yesterday.

HALIFAX, N. S., Aug. 21 (AP) -- The United States Coast Guard cutter Unimak headed for Halifax tonight with the 100-foot refugee schooner Amanda in tow. The Unimak reached the disabled two-masted vessel late yesterday after a day-long dash from a point near New York.

The War Assets Administration has sold to Godfrey Co. Inc., realty investing group headed by Philip Godfrey, a group of one-story warehouse buildings with steel frame and asbestos siding on a tract of about forty-five acres at Hoswell and Industrial Streets, in the Bronx.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 (UP) -- A check showed today that forty-seven former Senators and Representatives are drawing an average of $3,131 a year under the Congressional pension system, but their identities are kept secret by Civil Service regulations.

Cooler weather spurred retail trade here last week, and although stores are not meeting last year's figures, traffic volume has improved, according to a report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.

Daniel Frisch, president of the Zionist Organization of America, asserted yesterday that he had been assured by George McGhee, head of Near Eastern and African Affairs for the State Department, that the United States Government did not intend to exercise "special pressure" on Israel to admit a specified number of Arabs into the new country.

The number of cases of poliomyelitis reported in New York dropped yesterday for the fourth consecutive day, prompting the Department of Health to announce that this week may tell if the epidemic has been halted.

A typewritten article of several hundred words modestly headed "editorial suggestion" and dealing with the question of state aid for public libraries is being distributed, presumably to newspapers all over the state, by the Citizens Public Expenditure Survey, Inc., of Albany, a taxpayers' organization.

NEW LONDON, Conn., Aug. 21 -- The Second American Dance Festival under the auspices of Connecticut College closed here this afternoon with a gala performance in Palmer Auditorium before a capacity audience. All three companies that have divided the programs among them appeared, with the program consisting of five works selected from among the eight premieres of the series.

RIVERSIDE, Conn., Aug. 21 -- There was more sunshine over Long Island Sound today than wind, so the championship regatta of the Riverside Yacht Club, instead of being confined to an afternoon session of racing wound up for many into a hopeless sundown drag.

The continuations committee of the Conference on Peaceful Alternatives to the Atlantic Pact announced yesterday that 847 "leading Americans" from forty-five states and the District of Columbia, including 572 clergymen and religious leaders of all denominations, had joined in signing a letter to all Senators urging the defeat of President Truman's arms program.

Combined headquarters for Mayor O'Dwyer, Controller Lazarus Joseph and Council President Vincent Impellitteri are being set up at the Commodore Hotel in preparation for what friends of the Mayor described yesterday as one of the most vigorous Mayoralty campaigns ever planned in the city.

MAKRONISOS, Greece, Aug. 21 -- On this barren island opposite Sunium (Cape Colonna), where Byron scratched his name on a famous ancient temple to Poseidon, and across from the little lead mining village of Lavrion, the Greek Government is conducting its first experiment in mass de-communization.

ABOUT 3,300 years ago there lived in the black land of Egypt a Pharaoh of the Eighteenth Dynasty named Amenhotep IV. He was one of the great and tragic figures of history, a man possessed by a noble vision, a man whose efforts to bring his dream to reality brought death and suffering to thousands of innocent persons who were incapable of under standing the greatness of his ideal.

BERLIN, Aug. 21 -- The formation of an "all-German government" in the Soviet zone of occupation, Russia's most spectacular answer to the establishment of the German Federal Republic, has been postponed to await further developments in the West, according to Wilhelm Pieck, German Communist leader.
MIAMI, Fla., Aug. 21 (AP) -- A small Atlantic hurricane, increasing in size and intensity, whirled toward the Florida coast tonight.

The improvement in the volume of Manhattan realty trading which was noted in June continued during July and at about the same rate as for the previous month, according to the monthly sales survey of the Real Estate Board of New York.
PRETORIA, South Africa, Aug. 21 -- Negroes in South Africa today observed a national day of prayer "in this period of humiliation and dispossession," in the hope of achieving unity.

CHICAGO, Aug. 21 -- A liberal export demand for lard, coupled with pronounced strength in vegetable oils, led last week to fairly general buying of lard futures and higher prices on the Board of Trade. The September and October contracts led the advance, the former going to a substantial premium over October.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Aug. 21 -- A visit by a prospective buyer to a 24-foot Jersey dory led to the arrest of the craft's owner, William Frey, 21 years old, at the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club here today.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 21 -- The Giants ran into a new high in excitement at Shibe Park today as they made off with a 9-0 forfeit victory when irate fans showered the field with a pop-bottle barrage.

The college shops of all the stores are crammed with smart clothes for the campus-bound. Along with last-minute decisions on courses and room assignments, young women across the country are taking their wardrobe problems under serious consideration.

I have followed the initial activities of the Council of Europe in your news and editorial columns. I certainly agree with the observation in your Aug. 13 editorial, "Nations and People": "There is something heartening and refreshing in the breezes that are blowing from Strasbourg."

Rabbi Nathan A. Perilman of Temple Emanu-El, speaking yesterday from the pulpit of the Community Church, 40 East Thirty-fifth Street, characterized our civilization as "effete" and warned that if we persist in making "freedom from care" the goal of our existence, we should probably fail to meet the paramount challenge of our time.
Four new films, including a Swedish importation, will have local premieres this week. The schedule follows:

LAKE SUCCESS, Aug. 21 -- Secretary General Trygve Lie today asked for a bigger budget of $44,314,398 to run the United Nations next year and to cover such new costs as financing the peace organization's plans for technical assistance to underdeveloped nations.

Representative Walter H. Judd's revelations concerning a military intelligence appraisal of the Chinese Communists that was prepared in 1945 and his charge that it was suppressed by the State Department in assembling the White Paper on China are grave in their implications.

An automatic passenger-operated ticket-vending slot machine will be placed in experimental operation on Wednesday by the Long Island Rail Road in the Long Island Concourse at Pennsylvania Station, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 (AP) -- William T. Faricy, president of the Association of American Railroads, said today that future developments would determine whether further railroad rate increases would be asked.

In your issue of Aug. 17 W. Barton Leach, Colonel, Air Force Reserve, attacks Hanson Baldwin as "a consistent detractor of the Air Force." He also attempts to show that "there is no disagreement by any responsible military or civilian authority in any one of the services" as to the priority to be given to so-called "strategic" -- i.e., long-range -- bombing.

It is with great attention that I read in your Aug. 7 issue the letter by Robert P. Skinner with regard to Greece. During his work as a Minister of the United States to Greece Mr. Skinner has learned to love that country and his feeling toward Greece is expressed once more in his letter.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 21 -- Yugoslavia accused the Soviet Government today not only of a double-cross but also of preparing a trap for the Yugoslavs that would justify such duplicity.

The rehabilitation and enlargement of the city's hospital facilities and their extension into new fields of public service were stressed yesterday by Mayor O'Dwyer in a report on the progress of the Hospital Department since he took office on Jan. 1, 1946.

The charge that campus liberalism has been stunting the religious growth of undergraduates in American colleges was made yesterday by the Rev. Dr. J. Edward Dirks, counselor to Protestant students at Columbia University.

It's peach time. The "downy fruit" -- this description is straight out of Virgil -- is deluging this market; the Northeastern crop is about a million bushels larger than the ten-year average. Peak period began last Thursday, will close about Labor Day.

It's peach time. The "downy fruit" -- this description is straight out of Virgil -- is deluging this market; the Northeastern crop is about a million bushels larger than the ten-year average. Peak period began last Thursday, will close about Labor Day.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 -- A registration statement covering 100,000 shares of no par value common stock was filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission by the National Film Exhibitors Corporation, New York.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 22 -- In an unprecedented move the official newspaper of the Yugoslav Communist party published today an advance reply to the Soviet Government's violent note of last Saturday that described Yugoslav leaders as "Fascist lunatics."

EDINBURGH, Scotland, Aug. 22 -- The Edinburgh Festival plunged into full musical activity today, with its morning chamber concerts, the opening of the Glyndebourne Opera and the first of visiting orchestras from abroad, not to mention its drama and films.
Four young American farmers, representing the Future Farmers of America, returned yesterday from a six-week tour of England and Wales where they studied British farming methods.

Mrs. Martha J. Beck and Raymond M. Fernandez were sentenced yesterday to die in the electric chair for the "lonely hearts" slaying last January of Mrs. Janet J. Fay, 66-year-old Albany widow, in Valley Stream, L. I.

MILWAUKEE, Aug. 22 -- Charges of "double-dealing and deceit" were brought here today against the Executive Council of the American Federation of Teachers by the president of the former Los Angeles Local 430, which was expelled last fall because of alleged leftwing activities.

A 14,000 - horsepower double-deck Boeing Stratocruiser, one of the 145,000-pound airplanes that Northwest Airlines will place in nine-hour coast-to-coast service on Sept. 1, was put on public display yesterday at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens.

CHICAGO, Aug. 22 (AP) -- Miss Peggy Kirk, a personable 27-year-old tournament campaigner from Findlay, Ohio, breezed around the Westmoreland Country Club course in a record-breaking 3-under-par 73 today to win medalist honors in the women's Western amateur golf qualifying test.

PARIS, Aug. 22 -- Engineers close to the problem of producing armaments for the French Army, although elated at the prospect of massive assistance from the United States, are fearful lest the pressure for standardization and interchangeability undermine, if not actually destroy, the metric system of measures in French industry.

The five-story sixty-six-family apartment house at 2000 Prospect Avenue, the Bronx, has been sold by the New York Life Insurance Company to the Wasmil Realty Corporation. The property is assessed at $225,000. A purchase money mortgage of $138,000 was executed at the closing.

Although more persons are asking family service agencies for help with their problems, the great majority of them eventually find a way of making a go of family living rather than separating, Dr. M. Robert Gomberg, who will be the new executive director of Jewish Family Service, declared yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- No apparent progress was made today at a "round table" discussion avowedly called by Representative John Lesinski, Democrat, of Michigan, chairman of the House Education and Labor Committee, in an effort to reach a peaceful compromise on a Federal-aid-to-education bill.

I have just gotten around to reading Topics of The Times for Aug. 1. You write: "After all, the world knows that the Russians have a large streak of gambling blood in them. Didn't they originate that most incautious of games, Russian Roulette?"
Following is the text of President Truman's address yesterday at the Golden Jubilee Convention in Miami of the Veterans of Foreign Wars, as recorded and transcribed by THE NEW YORK TIMES:

Some time ago John Mason Brown wrote -- and most engagingly -- about what he called the "pleasant agony" involved in putting words together -- "coercing" them to do what the writer would have them do.

In the dullest session of the month, stock prices drifted fractionally lower yesterday. There was a dearth of enthusiasm for either side of the market as the volume of transactions dropped to 710,000 shares from 840,000 shares on Friday.

John J. Broderick lost another round yesterday in his fight to be the Tammany leader of Times Square, but he is taking his case to the Appellate Division today in the hope of having his supporters' names on the ballot on Primary Day, Sept. 6.

CEDARHURST, L. I., Aug. 22 -- The International Club of Great Britain defeated the International Club of the United States today in their annual tennis match at the Rockaway Hunting Club, 22 points to 14. Visiting English, French, Italian and South African players composed the winning team.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 22 -- Marshall Grant, who recently joined Columbia as a producer, has transferred his circus project, "Gainesville, U. S. A.," to the studio and will produce it himself under the title, "The Gainesville Circus," with John Derek in the leading role, Columbia announced today.

Unless a buyer steps in by tomorrow morning with a "reasonable" offer for a $16,000 prefabricated house won last month by an ex-GI and his wife in a charity drawing, the dwelling will be removed from its perch at Fifty-second Street and Avenue of the Americas and transported to a storage place in Plainfield, N. J.
A city chain reports it stocks half a hundred canned meats under a variety of company trade names. Just one packer (Swift Co.) says it tins forty meat products; before the war the figure was twenty.

A belated rush by dry goods wholesalers and retailers for fall and winter merchandise has flooded knitwear producers with orders, it was learned yesterday. The demand centers mainly on eight and ten-pound cotton underwear for men and five and six-pound goods for women, and in most instances immediate delivery has been requested.

HELSINKI, Finland, Aug. 22 -- The Government still maintains the upper hand in the Finnish strike situation but one of its spokesmen in an informal talk with the press tonight warned against "hasty optimism." The Communists still may have some trump card up their sleeves, he said.

FLORAL PARK, L. I., Aug. 22 -- Thirteen years ago fifty students at Sewanhaka Central High School here enrolled in a trial agricultural program. Their sole project was raising plant sets in a small greenhouse on the roof of the main building.

RYE, N. Y., Aug. 22 -- An incredibly large field of ninety teams that streamed over the fairways from dawn to dark took part in the Westchester pro-amateur best-ball golf championship over the Apawamis Club course today.
Fires in the Payette National Forest in Idaho took the life of one man yesterday as high winds whipped the flames to new fury over 14,000 acres, The Associated Press reported.

SHANGHAI, Aug. 22 -- As the Nationalist hold on China's coast shrank today to barely more than three beleaguered ports, a report from Hankow, released here by the official New China News Agency, said almost 80,000 "bandits" had been killed, wounded or arrested in Honan Province alone during the past year

With 1,000 crippled and disabled passengers singing, playing games or just relaxing in holiday mood, the sixty-year-old steamboat Sandy Hook shoved off yesterday morning from Pier 80 to visit its namesake and then returned for a leisurely afternoon cruise up the Hudson River.
MOSCOW, Aug. 22 -- The newspaper Pravda devoted nearly one-fourth of its issue today to dispatches and articles dealing with the Yugoslav question.

PINE CAMP, N. Y., Aug. 22 -- Units of the Forty-second Infantry Division, New York National Guard, received final instructions here today before taking the field tomorrow morning for a two-day bivouac. The Seventy-seventh Division, Organized Reserve Corps, got further training, leading to two days of maneuvers in attack and defense, which will end its two weeks of exercises this week.

The Investors League, Inc., "has failed on Mr. Forbes' own admission," Benjamin A. Javits, co-founder of the seven-year-old organization with B. C. Forbes, declared yesterday when he announced his resignation from the posts of first vice president and general counsel.
Rubber, cottonseed oil and wool-top futures were higher yesterday, while most other commodities registered moderate losses.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 -- The Senate investigations subcommittee has received a letter, written by a former member of the armed forces, about perfume oil worth 2,500,000 French francs that may prove valuable in the "five percenter" inquiry, it was disclosed today by Senator Karl E. Mundt, Republican, of South Dakota.
Despite a ready willingness to join those who feel that there is little to commend in the starling, we should, I suppose, try, in a truly American way, to be fair to an immigrant.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (UP) -- A spokesman for the American Medical Associated charged today that the Department of Justice tried to "raid" its Chicago offices in reprisal for the AMA's opposition to President Truman's compulsory health insurance plan.

Mayor O'Dwyer made public yesterday an appeal he sent to President Truman more than two months ago for support of legislation to transfer from Federal ownership to New York State fifty-two acres at Manhattan Beach, part of which would be used for a new city park.

The second annual congress of the United States National Student Association will meet Aug. 24 to Sept. 3 on the University of Illinois campus. Representatives of more than a million students from 350 colleges and universities are expected to attend. Founded two years ago, the NSA has succeeded in dispelling the skepticism that a national students' organization cannot be an effective force on the educational and political scenes.
LONDON, Aug. 22 -- Neither the Soviet-Yugoslav clash nor the approaching Washington economic conference had any effect today in the stock market here which, although quiet, had a steadier appearance.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Aug. 22 -- The statute of union between the Netherlands and the new state of Indonesia that is expected to emerge from the round-table conference opening here tomorrow will likely be couched in the loosest terms.

The Long Island Rail Road should be the finest commuting railroad in the world, Martin W. Clement, president of the Pennsylvania Railroad, asserted on his arrival here yesterday. But no commuting railroad can operate under present Government regulations, he added.

Department store sales in this city last week showed a decline of 12 per cent, as compared with the corresponding week of last year, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday in its "flash" report. In the preceding week the decline was 22 per cent.

LAUSANNE, Switzerland, Aug. 22 -- Paul A. Porter, United States representative on the United Nations' Palestine Conciliation Commission, arrived from Washington today for what seems likely to be the final effort at high-level conciliation of the Arab-Israeli dispute over Palestine.

ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L. I., Aug. 22 -- James Baldwin and Don Brown of the Piping Rock Club scored 31, 35 -- 66, six strokes under par, to capture the twenty-eighth annual amateur-pro championship of the Long Island Golf Association at the Rockville Club today.

Albania would have been absorbed by Yugoslavia if it had not been for substantial economic aid from the Soviet Union and other anti-Tito Eastern European countries, Premier Enver Hoxha of Albania asserts in the latest issue of the Communist Information Bureau newspaper.

The Pembrooke Realty Corporation has purchased the two-story dwelling at 14 Prospect Street and the frame office building at 150 Willis Avenue in Williston Park, L. I., from William F. Chatlos. The property, on a plot 170 by 175 feet, is to be developed by the Howard Johnson Company for a restaurant.

Harmonious labor relations in the shipping industry will not exist until both labor and management live within the framework of the law, John E. Cushing, president of the Matson Navigation Company, said in the company's semi-annual report to stockholders, issued in San Francisco yesterday.

VIENNA, Aug. 22 (UP) -- British military police today forcibly removed an Austrian civilian from the hands of four armed Soviet soldiers after an angry crowd of 1,000 Austrians had thrown stones at the Russians and blocked their alleged kidnap attempt.

An additional charge of illegal entry into the United States after each of several alleged visits to Russia was made yesterday at the completion of the Government's deportation case against Alexander Bittelman, important member of the Communist party leadership.

The French town of Dun-sur-Meuse again has fine bronze railings on its bridge. People throng from the Meuse valley and from the whole Argonne region to see the bridge and to remember the "buddies" of the United States Fifth Division and the day in October, 1918, when they stormed across the bridgeless river to cut the vital rail line through Sedan and force the collapse of the whole northeast German front.

According to an article by Harry Schwartz in THE NEW YORK TIMES of July 31, Soviet press reports claim "sharp gains in industrial and agricultural production" for Estonia, Lithuania and Latvia. These reports are not only untrue but they conceal completely the terrible tragedy of destruction into which the Baltic farmers have been plunged by the start of total collectivization since the beginning of the year.
William Bronson White has been a railroad man for fifty-one of his seventy-one years, thirty-nine of them as a steward on the Pennsylvania Railroad.

HANOVER, N. H., Aug. 22 -- Dartmouth College's 1949 alumni fund has exceeded its $375,000 objective with $386,611 of unrestricted gifts to the college from a record total of 14,519 Dartmouth men, John R. Mason, the fund's chairman, announced today.

A wage increase of 22 cents an hour headed a score of demands by the International Longshoremen's Association, AFL, as the union opened negotiations for a new contract yesterday with the New York Shipping Association, an employer group.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (AP) -- The first official move to bar States' Rights adherents from the Democratic National Committee since they bolted the Truman ticket last fall will be made tomorrow.

DETROIT, Aug. 22 (AP) -- The nation's auto dealers will have a lot of new cars to sell in September. So far there has been no material drop in sales but most industry sources look for a leveling off after the end of August. Something in excess of 545,000 new cars are expected to be shipped from the factories this month.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was moderately active yesterday and final prices were 7 to 12 points net higher.

Federal Judge Harold R. Medina gave preliminary notice to both sides yesterday to get ready for the end of the Communist trial. As the trial entered its thirty-second week, he announced from the bench that requests from counsel for inclusion of material in his charge to the jury must be in his hands one week before summing-up arguments begin.
A half dozen young European artists -- painters, sculptors, musicians and actors -- inspected an American art school yesterday.
The trend of infection in the poliomyelitis epidemic in New York continued downward over the week-end, it was reported yesterday.
Waterbury. Conn., announced yesterday that it would offer $3,i 269,000 of its obligations in vaous rates and types on Aug. 31. The 'offering, dated Sept 1, 1949. will be due on Sept. 1, 1952 to 1971.

Twelve hundred persons saw the police stage a monkey hunt at York Avenue and Sixty-seventh Street yesterday afternoon. After efforts to lure the animal from its perch at the top of a seventy-five foot elm tree failed, sharpshooters bagged their game with four shots.
CHICAGO, Aug. 22 (AP) -- Lowell North, 19-year-old skipper from San Diego, Calif., won today's opening race of the International Star Class yachting championships at Belmont Harbor on Lake Michigan.

VANDALIA, Ohio, Aug. 22 (AP) -- Joe Hiestand, 42-year-old Hillsboro, Ohio, farmer who has won more trapshooting championships than any man in history, stole the show again today as the golden Grand American opened.

EASTPORT, Me., Aug. 22 -- An international joint commission was told today that the economic future of industrial northern New England depends in large measure on development of electric power from the tides of Passamaquoddy Bay.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (AP) -- Treasury plans to reduce the interest rate paid by the Government on money it borrows for one year were disclosed tonight.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (UP) -- Both Israel and the Arab states may have to make further concessions on territorial and refugee questions "if a real peace agreement is to be reached," State Department spokesman Lincoln White said today.

DENNIS, Mass., Aug. 22 -- Gertrude Lawrence, who arrived in this country a week ago tonight from a triumphant London engagement in Daphne DuMaurier's "September Tide," was welcomed back to the Cape Playhouse here tonight with a rafter-ringing ovation from a capacity audience that displayed a decided enthusiasm for this, the only American production of the British success.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 22 (AP) -- Archduke Anton, descendant of Habsburg royalty, who now earns his living by installing machinery in Argentine factories, expressed surprise and regret today that a brother was suing him for $949,999.

THE confused and befuddled "liberals" who mistook the present autocrat of all the Russias and points West for a paladin of freedom were bound to have a strong appeal for writers in search of a subject -- particularly if the writers knew some good specimens themselves. Writers, good ones at least, know psychologically interesting people when they see them.

JABLONEC, Czechoslovakia, Aug. 21 -- Czechoslovak settlers who, since the war, have replaced Germans in this frontier town, formerly called Gablonz, of the former Sudetenland have transformed the making of imitation jewelry from a cottage industry to a mass production factory industry.

A concerted effort toward countering unjust criticism of advertising and marketing by explaining these operations in business-sponsored educational material was urged yesterday by the Committee on Consumer Relations in Advertising.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (AP)--The Civil Aeronautics Board today denied the request of two operators for permission to run all-expense air tours in this country.

MIAMI, Fla., Aug. 22 -- President Truman pleaded imperatively today for his military assistance program, declaring that it was our most advanced bulwark against the tyrannous traps that he said "organized communism" has set up around the universal desire for peace and freedom.

LAKE SUCCESS, Aug. 22 -- Scientists and nature specialists from eighteen countries opened a ten-day session here today under the aegis of the United Nations to seek ways of protecting and preserving animal and plant life through international action.

BERLIN, Aug. 22 -- Fifty Berlin Communists announced today that they had formed an anti-Soviet "Free Communist party." The group's first act was to send a telegram of "sympathy and support" to Premier, Marshal Tito of Yugoslavia.

The round-table discussions opening today in The Hague may well prove to be one of the most significant conferences in recent history. Representatives of the Netherlands, the Indonesian Republic and the Indonesian Federalists are meeting to arrange for a transfer of sovereignty from the Netherlands to a United States of Indonesia.

CHICAGO, Aug. 22 -- Grain markets developed a heavy undertone in the late trading on the Board of Trade today after moderate strength early when November soybeans sold at a new seasonal high. Liberal profit-taking developed, however, and wheat reacted over 2 cents from the top and closed 7/8 to 1 3/8 cents a bushel lower.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 -- Republican foreign policy leaders are trying to persuade the Administration to put voluntarily into the military aid program some form of help to Nationalist China.

SHANGHAI, Aug. 22 -- The revolution and blockade, which have cut off Communist-held Shanghai from vital imported raw materials, already have transformed the lives of thousands of Chinese here and radically altered the complexion of this once gaudy, glittering, supercharged metropolis.

LONDON, Aug. 22 -- Another hot-tempered retort to American critics of the British Labor Government was made tonight by Tom O'Brien, trade union leader and Member of Parliament, who asserted that Britons "would rather take the risk of civilizing communism than being kicked around by the unlettered pot-bellied money magnates of the United States."

LAKE SUCCESS, Aug. 22 -- A. I. Levorsen, Professor of Geology at Stanford University, said today that although known oil reserves totaled 70,000,000,000 barrels -- enough to last only twenty years at the current rate of consumption -- the world's undiscovered deposits were estimated at 500 times present annual consumption.

Johnny Mize became a New York Yankee yesterday. Eddie Brannick, New York Giants' secretary, announced last night that the hard-hitting first baseman had been sold to the American League pacesetters for an undisclosed amount of cash.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 -- Total sales of all retail stores in July declined about one per cent from June, after adjustment for seasonal factors and differences in the number of trading days, the Department of Commerce announced today.

The United States Steel Corporation asked the Presidential fact-finding board yesterday to consider "the insufferable race for position by union leaders" in weighing the evidence for the fourth-round wage demand of the United Steelworkers of America, CIO.

A small black dog with a wagging tail leaped in joy yesterday at a reunion with his three masters, one of whom he hadn't seen for a year and a half. The meeting took place at the Ellin Prince Speyer Hospital, 350 Lafayette Street, and the participants were Pips, the little dog, Dr. and Mrs. Irwin Kasvandik, an Estonian displaced couple, and Mrs. Kasvandik's sister, Miss Asta Tamm.

MADISON, Wis., Aug. 22 -- Farmer cooperatives no longer merely can take the place of other middlemen but must concentrate on setting the pace for service in all phases of agriculture, members of American farm cooperatives were told today at the opening of the annual American Institute of Cooperation.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (AP) -- The Senate's Majority Leader, Scott W. Lucas of Illinois declared today that the Government had gone too far in its farm price-support program.

The members of the Australian and United States Davis Cup teams took up quarters at Forest Hills yesterday and began practice for their meeting in the challenge round there Friday, Saturday and Sunday.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 22 -- Prohibition sentiment is on the increase throughout the world, Mrs. Margaret C. Munns, treasurer of the Woman's Christian Temperance Union, said tonight in an address at the organization's seventy-fifth national convention.

SEOUL, Korea, Tuesday, Aug. 23 -- The United Nations Commission on Korea decided yesterday to reject the Korean Foreign Minister's request that it take custody of the Soviet Consulate caretaker and his wife, who have been under arrest here since Aug. 10 on charges of espionage.

The world's largest seagoing hopper dredge, the 10,700-ton Essayons, now under construction for the Army Corps of Engineers, will be launched Thursday at the Chester (Pa.) yards of the Sun Shipbuilding and Drydock Company, it was announced yesterday.

BORDEAUX, France, Aug. 22 (UP) -- A pall of black smoke hung over Bordeaux tonight from forest fires that have taken eighty-three and possibly eighty-five lives. Persons in the outlying districts prepared to flee should new outbreaks sweep closer to the city.

It is about time we heeded the prophetic words, Stop! Look! Listen! in regard to our subsidizing the Socialist Labor Government in Great Britain. We have doled out over $50,000,000,000 to our former ally, much of it, of course, under Lend-Lease, which helped put down Nazi aggression, but which, instead of giving us world peace, gave us the evil of world communism.
MIAMI, Fla., Aug. 22 (AP) -- A small Atlantic hurricane was about 320 miles east of Palm Beach tonight with a "pretty good" chance that it would turn to the north within twelve hours.
Mayor O'Dwyer used a helicopter yesterday afternoon to bring him back to City Hall after he made a speech in one of the far corners of the city, Mariners Harbor on Staten Island.

LONDON, Aug. 22 -- "Sword in the Desert" was shown here privately today before British newspaper reviewers. No date for a public presentation has been fixed, but Ben Henry, London representative of Universal - International, said it would definitely be shown here.

The new lower-price policy made effective yesterday by the Howard clothing chain was seen as another important development in the price line readjustment through which the clothing industry is now passing.

May I refer to Julius Henry Cohen's letter in the Aug. 15 issue of THE TIMES under the heading, "Advice on Income Tax Law." In that letter Mr. Cohen takes exception to my statement for press release, as president of the New York State Society of Certified Public Accountants, upon the rendition by the Court of Appeals of its decision in the Bercu case.

After a series of broken windows and false alarms on the premises of customers of the strike-bound Holmes Electric Protective Service, policemen throughout the city were ordered last night to give extra protection to Holmes-protected clients.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 22 -- Life was a little brighter today for an 82-year-old mother who traveled half way across the country to see her son only to become stranded in Pittsburgh without money for almost twenty-four hours.

The big tuna seem to be quite plentiful along the rim of the Mud Hole and near Shrewsbury Rocks, for several seekers reported having sighted or hooked fish over the week-end, but only Maurice Meyer of Elberon, N. J., reported having one on the boat.

MIAMI, Fla., Aug. 22 -- Gen. Lucius D. Clay, former Military Governor of Germany, declared today that the obvious economic improvements engendered by this country's assistance to the free nations of Western Europe had created a "restlessness" that was "destroying the police states of Eastern Europe."

The New York Central System assured its commuters yesterday that they would have 100 new air-conditioned cars to make their travel more comfortable on parts of the Harlem and Hudson Divisions before hot weather sets in next year.

TAIPEI, Formosa, Aug. 22 -- Formosa is at present under the control of what might be termed the Chiang Kai-shek branch of the Nationalist Government, as distinct from the Li Tsung-jen branch at Canton.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (UP) -- Republican members of the House Ways and Means Committee asserted today that the Social Security revision bill supported by the Democratic majority might result in a complete breakdown of the system.

The General Council of Britain's Trades Union Congress (T. U. C.) has refused to concur in the demands of some 5,000,000 trade unionists for immediate wage increases. In its annual report, just made public, the Council takes its stand beside Sir Stafford Cripps and the Labor Government on the question of wage policy.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Aug. 29 -- The Government has threatened to close 103 monasteries and convents in Slovakia if they do not apply for state approval to operate, and to outlaw any religious order that does not declare loyalty to the present regime.

With a strike deadline still set for midnight tonight, representatives of the management and employes of the Triboro Coach Company in Queens will meet today with municipal officials in an effort to find answers to a series of complicated problems.

SHANGHAI, Aug. 22 (UP) -- The United States Information Service, closed on July 15 by Communis order, today rejected a request by its former employes for eight months' termination pay at the opening of negotiations on the payments.

As he did in the case of the North Atlantic Treaty, President Truman has again gone to the nation over the heads of the Congressional opposition to win added support for the foreign military aid program as part of a broadly conceived American policy to preserve peace and our own security.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (AP) -- Tracy S. Voorhees of New York, who has been Assistant Secretary of the Army, was sworn in today as Under-Secretary. Archibald S. Alexander of Bernardsville, N. J., took the oath as Assistant Secretary.

LONDON, Aug. 22 -- Diplomatic officials who have been following the dispute between the Soviet and Yugoslav Governments did not see much likelihood today of an armed conflict in the near future. In fact they felt that the Soviet Government, which has assiduously proclaimed its devotion to peace, would be restricted by its own propaganda to continuing the cold war rather than starting a hot war against the Tito government.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Aug. 22 (AP) -- It took all of Johnny Gilbert's riding skill to get Palatine Stable's Some Town home a half length before the favored Blue Stone Farm's Val's Kid in the featured Sandy Hook purse today. W. S. Cotton's My Celeste, winner of the New Jersey Homebred Stakes here last year, was third, another half length away.
