New York City's Department of Hospitals, working on a current budget of $77,874,363, operates thirty hospital institutions. Mayor O'Dwyer's report on the department's activities from the time he took office, Jan. 1, 1946, cautiously refrains from any claim to present perfection.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Aug. 22 -- Paul G. Hoffman warned today against the idea that currency devaluation was a "cure-all palliative" for any country's economic ills and stressed his view that it was more important to create sound basic conditions within the countries troubled by dollar shortages.

LONDON, Aug. 22 (Reuters) -- Middlesex, driving for its second post-war championship in English county cricket, today gained a first innings lead of 100 runs in the important match against Surrey at Lords.

The Bohn Aluminum and Brass Corporation omitted the common dividend due at this time. Shareholders had received 25 cents quarterly, the last of which was disbursed on July 1. In view of the loss sustained in the first six months of the year, the company said directors decided that no dividend should be declared at this time.
PARIS, Aug. 22 -- The French Government has drawn up a six-year plan designed to pull the country's nationalized aviation industry out of the morass in which it has floundered since the end the war.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 -- General Carl Spaatz, retired head of the United States Air Force, today described the B-36, this country's intercontinental bomber, and the atomic bomb as "the greatest forces for peace in the world."

Columbia Pictures will release thirty-one "top" productions between September of this year and September, 1950, and also will make an additional twenty-two feature films available to theatres, according to A. Montague, general sales manager.

LONDON, Aug. 22 -- The four principal ballerinas of the Sadler's Wells Ballet -- Margot Fonteyn, Moira Shearer, Pamela May and Beryl Grey -- already are preparing for their visit to the United States in September. During the past week they have been choosing the clothes they will wear not as ballerinas but as unofficial envoys of British fashion when they attend their many social engagements.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 -- Breaks came in the $27,000,000,000 appropriations log-jam in Congress today, seven weeks after the money was supposed to be ready for current fiscal year operations of the Government. Developments included these:

The first of twelve vessels earmarked for the temporary storage of surplus grain will begin loading at 8 A. M. today at Pier K, Weehawken, it was announced yesterday by the Maritime Commission. According to the joint arrangements of the commission and the Department of Agriculture, loading of the remaining eleven ships will follow at intervals with completion of the last vessel scheduled for Sept. 6.

BRIARCLIFF MANOR, Aug. 22 -- American generosity may turn Girl Scouts in foreign lands into "poor relations" unless the foreign children are allowed to do things in return, Miss Janet Cozens of England warned today at the international conference here of Girl Scout and Girl Guide administrative workers.

HONOLULU, Aug. 22 -- Hawaii's stevedoring firms tonight dispatched a radiogram to Federal Mediation Director Cyrus S. Ching declining, at least for the time being, his invitation to negotiate the Hawaiian longshore strike in Washington.

BOSTON, Aug. 22 -- Ralph Branca and the Dodgers blew a 6-5 lead in the ninth inning today, dropped their third straight to the Braves, 7 -- 6, and headed for home tonight two full games behind the first place Cardinals, who will be their opponents tomorrow.

Joseph D. McGoldrick, who was City Controller for nine years under the late Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia, assumed yesterday the chairmanship of the campaign committee for Harry Uviller, nominee for Controller of the Republican, Liberal and City Fusion parties.

NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 22 -- Several movements for organization of Asian and Middle Eastern countries into a bloc of one sort or another are taking shape in India and Pakistan. These plans, which are engaging some of the leading minds in both dominions, envisage at this stage cultural and economic relationships and the mutual approach of these countries to common concerns.

Advertising in newspapers of fifty-two cities during July totaled 164,040,183 lines, a gain of 1.6 per cent over the like period of last year, an analysis of Media Records showed yesterday. Categories recording gains were: automotive, up 20.9 per cent; general, 7.8 per cent, and retail, 3.1 per cent.

The Columbia Broadcasting System announced yesterday that it would seek a legal test of the right of the Federal Communications Commission to outlaw giveaway shows. On Friday, when the FCC rules were announced, the ABC chain stated that it would seek relief in the courts from the governmental ban.

John G. Broady's bail of $32,500 was revoked and the 47-year-old private investigator was remanded to jail for the rest of his General Sessions trial after a prosecution witness testified yesterday that the defendant had offered her a job last Friday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 -- The chairmen of the tax-raising committees in Congress found themselves in sharp disagreement tonight over whether the present session should give relief to the American taxpayer.

Cheryl Crawford has added still another offering to her production schedule for the season, a new melodrama by Alexander Knox called "The Closing Door." The producer made the purchase over the week-end. Under the contractual agreement, Mr. Knox will undertake the leading male role, while Doris Nolan will act the leading feminine part.

ATHENS, Aug. 19 -- At the end of October Greece's first municipal elections since before World War II will be held. Although the smaller political parties opposed the balloting at this time on the ground that the passions engendered by the civil war tended to simplify the issue to that of support or non-support of the Government's military policy, United States advisers agreed with the Cabinet that some form of vote should be arranged.

BUFFALO, Aug. 22 -- The strike by production workers of the Bell Aircraft Corporation, which holds Government contracts for more than $31,000,000, entered its eleventh week today on a note of mounting bitterness.

Prices of both linseed oil and soybean oil advanced yesterday, trade sources reported. Linseed oil advanced 1 cent a pound for both August and September orders, and 1/2 cent a pound for October to December orders. Soybean oil advanced 1/2 cent, marking a total advance in recent weeks of about 2 1/2 cents a pound.

ROME, Aug. 22 -- The report published in THE NEW YORK TIMES today that the bones of Saint Peter had been found beneath the main altar in St. Peter's Basilica came as a complete surprise to most persons in the Vatican.

" Desert Calling: The Biography of Charles de Foucauld," by Anne Fremantle, has been scheduled for Oct. 17 publication by Holt. It is the first full length English story of the French Army officer and explorer who became a Trappist monk and later a hermit-priest in the South Sahara.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 -- Pressure of disputes affecting 3,000,000 to 3,500,000 employes compelled the Government today to ask the disputants in the Hawaiian dock strike to confer in New York or Washington.

The Fire Department became the third city agency to report a sharp drop in construction costs to the City Planning Commission when one of its deputy commissioners announced yesterday that a fireboat for which $1,600,000 was asked two years ago could now be built for $900,000.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 22 -- Sky Miracle, a 3-year-old gelding claimed from Brookmeade Stable by Burton D. Chait for $12,500 nine days ago, missed Saratoga's nine-furlong record by only two-fifths of a second today in winning the afternoon's best race.

The Permanente Metals Corporation, of which Henry J. Kaiser is president, reported yesterday in its annual statement covering the fiscal year ended with last May, record highs in production, sales and earnings.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., Aug. 22 -- Two architectural students from the University of Buenos Aires, one 18 and the other 19 years old, today won the first race for the International Snipe Class championship.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., Aug. 22 -- Edward L. Leahy of Bristol, R. I., lawyer and tax expert and former state finance director and tax administrator, was appointed today to the United States Senate to serve out the term of Senator J. Howard McGrath.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (UP) -- George F. Kennan, the State Department's top policy planner, tonight called the Communist conquest in China a catastrophe that would make real peace in the Far East impossible for a long time.

The biologists and cancer specialists who were dismayed two years ago when a forest fire swept away the Roscoe B. Jackson Memorial Laboratory at Bar Harbor, Me., and with it thousands of inbred mice, have reason to rejoice that last week new buildings were dedicated.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 -- Pressure of disputes affecting 3,000,000 to 3,500,000 employes compelled the Government today to ask the disputants in the Hawaiian dock strike to confer in New York or Washington.

The Fire Department became the third city agency to report a sharp drop in construction costs to the City Planning Commission when one of its deputy commissioners announced yesterday that a fireboat for which $1,600,000 was asked two years ago could now be built for $900,000.

A strange phenomenon that started in 1947 and continued through the early part of last year -- the sale of steel companies to consumers at the time of the greatest boom in steel history -- is ending just as most industrial observers predicted. It was said that these plants would either be sold back to steel companies or scrapped when the general demand for steel in this country fell.

By its investments in electric power facilities, industry and housing in the post-war period, the nation's life insurance industry "assisted in enlarging the real national income to a scale never known before," Louis W. Dawson, executive vice president of the Mutual Life Insurance Company of New York, declared yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (UP)-- John Maragon, whose name has cropped up repeatedly in the Senate's "five percenter" investigation, once had his face slapped in Rome by Brig. Gen. William L. Lee.

A belief that certain landlords are making "ridiculous" complaints against tenants in Magistrates Court in the hope of strengthening later eviction proceedings was voiced by Magistrate Matthew F. Fagan in Coney Island Court yesterday.

The Hilton Hotels Corporation had gross revenues of $20,803,223 in the first six months this year, or slightly less than the $21,116,929 from operations in the corresponding half of 1948, according to the semi-annual statement of Conrad N. Hilton, president, released today.

One of the best vacations in years has just ended. It has left the spirit refreshed and the eye clear. It has made it possible to greet this morning with a smile and good-will, social custom alone preventing that greeting from being one of song and street dancing.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 23 -- The Yugoslav Government maintained today the furious pace of the propaganda war with the Soviet Government by releasing for world-wide publication a sharp and cutting reply to the Soviet Government's latest note concerning the arrest of thirty-one Soviet citizens who were apprehended as "spies, saboteurs and counter-revolutionaries."

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt said yesterday that she was counting on former Gov. Herbert H. Lehman being a candidate for United States Senator. Mrs. Roosevelt sent a telegram making that declaration at the opening of a renewed "draft Lehman" drive at the office of Henry Modell, at 700 Broadway.

TOKYO, Aug. 23 -- The Government will ask a special session of the Diet in November for a supplementary appropriation of 4,000,000,000 yen -- $11,000,000 at the current exchange -- for relief of unemployment, it was predicted, as a result of the industrial rationalization program urged by the Allied occupation. In addition, the Government hopes to use part of the United States counterpart fund for public relief works.

Hampered by a shortage of funds, the National Theatre Conference, a non-profit organization which helps directors of community and university theatres and is subsidized by the Rockefeller Foundation, has discontinued its playwriting fellowships, it became known yesterday.

NEWARK, N. J., Aug. 23 -- A fall and winter schedule that contemplates the elimination of 1,735 trips a week on the Hudson Manhattan Railroad was made public today by officials of the carrier, who filed it last week with the Board of Public Utility Commissioners of New Jersey.

Hide prices broke sharply on a volume of commission-house selling on the Commodity Exchange yesterday. In the sharpest price reaction in two months, quotations were driven down 45 to 50 points on the day. The market opened lower than Monday's close and rallied briefly in mid-day trading but could not withstand the selling sentiment in the closing hours of the day.

LAKE SUCCESS, Aug. 23 -- Though the United States is now spending its irreplaceable mineral wealth at an "extravagant" rate, this is justified by the present good standard of living and the fact that the nation is helping develop the potentialities of other parts of the world, in the view of some scientists heard today at the United Nations Scientific Conference on the Conservation and Utilization of Resources.

MIAMI, Fla., Aug. 23 -- Carl R. Gray Jr., Administrator of Veterans Affairs, told delegates to the fiftieth annual national convention of the Veterans of Foreign Wars today that the post-war record of the country's veterans represented "an outstanding contribution" to the nation's progress and security.
LAUSANNE, Switzerland, Aug. 23 -- The United States proposed a new approach to a Palestine settlement in today's meeting of the United Nations Palestine Conciliation Commission.

Because the United States is far ahead in caring for its blind, European nations are looking to this country for guidance in the problem of the sightless, Joseph Clunck, chief of the services for the blind of the National Security Agency, said yesterday morning after his arrival from London at the New York International Airport at Idlewild, Queens.

TAIPEI, Formosa, Aug. 23 -- Possibility of United States or Allied action to prevent Formosa from falling into the hands of the Chinese Communists continues to be one of the liveliest topics for speculation here.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (AP) -- Dr. Joseph M. Dawson, a prominent Baptist, announced tonight that he had withdrawn from a conference called to discuss Federal aid to education.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -- The combined Senate Foreign Relations and Armed Services committees approved today a big part of the Administration's foreign military aid bill, but did not reach the two greatest issues in it.
LONDON, Aug. 23 -- Revision of the Ministry of Health's housing manual has created controversy among British housewives as to the most convenient height of a kitchen table.
ALBANY, Aug. 23 -- Eleven persons, including two former State Troopers, who retired because of injuries, were indicted today in connection with a state investigation of disability pension frauds.
CANTON, China, Aug. 23 (AP) -- Chiang Kai-shek arrived today for important talks in an atmosphere of official nervousness over a possible Communist-inspired uprising in Canton.
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 23 (AP) -- Jack Graham knocked his twentieth home run of the year with a runner on base in the seventh inning to help the Browns upset the Red Sox, 5 to 4, tonight.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -- Member nations of the North Atlantic treaty, which will formally go into effect tomorrow, have begun talks on the formation of the council called for in the pact, the State Department announced today.
LAKE SUCCESS, Aug. 23 -- The Membership Committee of the Security Council voted today in favor of admitting the small Asiatic kingdom of Nepal to the United Nations.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -- The Carolina Power and Light Company, Raleigh, N. C., filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering 30,000 shares of $5 preferred stock, no par value, and 200,000 shares of no-par value common stock.
The little yellow house that has been sitting on part of a parking lot at the northeast corner of Fifty-second Street and the Avenue of the Americas was finally sold late yesterday afternoon.

LONDON, Aug. 23 -- Closely connected with Britain's dollar problem is the question of whether the sterling area as a whole must settle its debts in Japan in dollars or in sterling. This issue is under discussion between British and American economic experts in Tokyo, but it may well be raised at the coming Washington conference on restoring a financial balance between the old world and the new.
MADISON, Wis., Aug. 23 -- International farm and consumer cooperatives were viewed today at the annual American Institute of Cooperation as promoters of international trade in a dollar-hungry world.

LAKE SUCCESS, Aug. 23 -- The United Nations Trusteeship Council reported to the General Assembly today that it had been unable to examine reports on South Africa's administration of South-West Africa because South Africa had stopped sending any information.

Charges that gangsters helped city officials to obtain automobiles from the Kings County Buick Company and that policemen did similar chores for known criminals were made repeatedly yesterday in General Sessions.
WILMINGTON, Del., Aug. 23 (AP) -- A stock-purchase plan for employes of General Mills, Inc., was reported today at the annual stockholders' meeting here.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -- At the office of the Marine Engineers Beneficial Association today it was announced that the telegram sent last week under the name of President Samuel J. Hogan to all Atlantic and Gulf Coast locals dealing with ship operators' complaints had been authorized by Mr. Hogan.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., Aug. 23 (AP) -- Ku Klux Klansmen from six states joined forces today in inviting all other Klan groups to come into one nation-wide organization.

Enough dynamite to blow up a city block -- thirty-eight sticks and eight detonating caps -- was found on an extension roof of the United Lubavitcher Yeshivoth, 19 Grant Square, in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn, by two boys seeking to retrieve a ball at 10:30 A. M. yesterday.

Slackening demand for textiles and lower prices caused the decline in consolidated net sales of Reeves Brothers, Inc., and its subsidiaries during the fiscal year ended in June, J. M. Reeves, president, reported in the annual statement to be released today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (UP) -- Private power interests were dealt a setback today when the Senate restored to the Interior Department appropriation bill money to build transmission lines in the Southwest.

NORFOLK, Va., Aug. 23 -- A movable hold within a hold, so designed that it can be loaded directly beneath the cargo hatch of a ship and then rolled to fit against the hull's ribs, was demonstrated for the first time today at the Norfolk Shipbuilding and Drydock Company by the inventor, Capt. Valdemar C. Farrell of Englewood, N. J.

The demand of the railroad firemen's union for the employment of an extra fireman on Diesel-electric lomotives is "an ambitious scheme to extend its power, wealth and influence," counsel for the nation's railroads asserted here yesterday before a Presidential fact-finding board.

The Eighty-first Congress has been in session since Jan. 3. It met with the hopeful vision of adjourning on July 31, as stipulated by the Legislative Reorganization Act. It did not adjourn then and possibly won't until the leaves have fallen. During the first six months of the session the Senate spent a little less than one-seventh of its time in quorum calls.

DETROIT, Aug. 23 -- The next move in the United Automobile Workers' pension and wage drive in the automobile industry calls for a strike election among 69,000 Chrysler Corporation employes under the supervision of the State Labor Mediation Board, it was disclosed today.
A detective, a patrolman and two other persons were shot last night in a fusilade of bullets that followed an attempt by a prisoner to escape from the Classon Avenue police station in Brooklyn.

SHANGHAI, Aug. 23 -- A report of maladministration by Communist leaders and lesser officials in Chahar Province, North China, was published here today as an example of the dangers inherent in the poor indoctrination of administrators and in the "backwardness of a peasant society."
LARCHMONT, N. Y., Aug. 23 -- Two more races for the world championship of the snipe class were concluded today at the Larchmont Yacht Club.

Having expelled Marshal Tito from the Soviet camp and having denounced him as a "Fascist lunatic" and a "traitor." Generalissimo Stalin now announces through an Albanian amanuensis in the Moscow Pravda that sentence of death has been passed on the Yugoslav heretic and that the latter will have to pay for his defection with his head, like other "traitors."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -- The 140,000 lawyers in the United States engaged in independent practice had an average net income in 1948 of $8,121 per lawyer, an all-time peak, the Department of Commerce announced today.
GLENS FALLS, N. Y., Aug. 23 -- Stockholders of the Imperial Paper and Color Corporation held their annual meeting here today.

Supreme Court Justice Thomas L. J. Corcoran held yesterday that Alfred C. Muscio was a legal resident of New York County and not New Jersey and therefore had a right to decline as the Tammany candidate for the City Council seat in the Eighteenth Senatorial District.

While New Yorkers scramble to find places to live or room to recuperate from making a living, harbor breezes flow through nearly a score of empty buildings and toss yellow sunflowers and goldenrod along deserted concrete causeways on two forgotten islands in lower New York Bay.
WALTHAM, Mass., Aug. 23 -- The first post-war national conference of B'nai B'rith Hillel Foundation opened today at Brandeis University with representatives from 197 colleges attending.

LONDON, Aug. 23 -- Paul G. Hoffman, head of the Economic Cooperation Administration, arrived in this dollar-conscions capital today and turned aside questions about rumored plans for an Anglo-American economic union with diplomacy and finesse.

The "Operator 25" service, through which consumers may get in contact with local dealers of nationally advertised products, will be further improved, it was announced yesterday by A. K. Mitchell, assistant vice president of the Western Union Telegraph Company.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 23 (AP) -- A walk, double and long fly ball scored Andy Seminick with the winning run in the thirteenth inning as the Phillies defeated the Reds, 4--3, tonight.

A vacant irregular plot about 120 by 90 feet at the northeast corner of Beach Boulevard and Malone Avenue, East Atlantic Beach, L. I., has been purchased by Waldemar Wydler for improvement with three dwellings. The seller was the West Long Beach Development Company, represented by Karelsen, Karelsen, Rubin Rosenberg, attorneys.

The new duck stamp, now a $2 item, will be available within the next three weeks, with the additional dollar going toward increased enforcement of waterfowl regulations and to improve and increase the waterfowl refuges.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (AP) -- A compromise bill to set up flexible farm price supports got a half-hearted boost from the National Grange today but ran into opposition from the National Farmers Union.
BLOOMINGTON, Ill., Aug. 23 (AP) -- Charles F. Brannan, Secretary of Agriculture, said today that living happily in the midst of abundance was a strangely complex problem for America.

Why send armies of inspectors to find what could be the cause of increasing victims of polio? Look at our filthy streets, our subway stations. Into homes dirt is carried on shoes. There it is wafted about by dry mops, and what clings to these mops is shaken from windows by slovenly housewives breaking existing housing regulations prohibiting this unclean habit.

STRASBOURG, France, Aug. 23 (AP) -- British Conservatives and Socialists argued from different standpoints at the European Consultative Assembly today that Europe could not live half planned and half free.
STRASBOURG, France, Aug. 23 (Reuters) -- Appealing for swifter action, M. Reynaud said:

DOVER, England, Wednesday, Aug. 24 -- Philip Mickman, 18-year-old British schoolboy, today swam the English Channel. According to the timekeepers who accompanied him, Mickman's time was 23 hours and 48 minutes, one of the slowest on record.

District Attorney Miles F. McDonald of Kings County moved yesterday to appeal to the Appellate Division, Second Department, an order by Judge Nathan R. Nobel dismissing indictments against six professional bondsmen and two alleged runners.

Basic ingredients of the usual college dormitory room are apt to be limited to the absolutely necessary requirements -- a bed, plain rough dresser, a student's desk and chair and gooseneck lamp set starkly against a dull buff wall. Since the grim, bare bed usually occupies a large proportion of the total space, choice of a new, cheerful and appropriate covering for it can brighten the room considerably.

VANDALIA, Ohio, Aug. 23 (AP) -- Two marksmen who have been shooting only three years won the North American clay target championships today in one of the toughest competitions at the golden grand American.

BOSTON, Aug. 23 -- The New England Council's industrial development committee was informed today that one of the major steel companies is considering construction of a $200,000,000 plant in New England to process high-grade iron ore from Labrador.
CLEVELAND, Aug. 23 (AP) -- The Indians suffered another chilling blow to their pennant hopes tonight when they bowed to the Senators, 4 to 2.
In his dispatch o he Senate's disapproval of the government reorganization plan to establish a federal Department of Welfare, your correspondent, Clayton Knowles, accurately reported:

The longest and heaviest transatlantic air traffic in history was forecast yesterday for 1950, the Roman Catholic Holy year, by Clyde S. Fullerton, general sales manager of Transcontinental and Western Air, Inc., who recently returned from an extensive overseas survey.

The musical profession was well represented among the 1,280 displaced persons who arrived here yesterday aboard the Army transport Gen. C. H. Muir. The ship, which brought about fifty performers, docked at 10 A. M., at Pier 61, North River, after a ten-day voyage from Bremerhaven, Germany.

The Giants scored five runs in the last inning yesterday, but even this big splurge was not enough to wipe out the early advantage piled up by the Cubs. So the locals went down, 7 -- 5, before the smallest Polo Grounds crowd of the season, 3,845 paying spectators.

ROME, Aug. 23 -- Despite political pledges dating back to wartime days when the anti-fascist parties were rallying the people against Benito Mussolini's German-occupied northern republic, Italy's desperately needed agrarian reform program has not yet really got underway.

DETROIT, Aug. 23 -- The Yankees brought an imposing array of power to Briggs Stadium today, the display including such renowned sluggers as Johnny Mize, fresh from the Giants, Joe Di-Maggio, Yogi Berra and Charlie Keller.

The vacant block bounded by Clarkson Avenue, East Ninety-sixth Street, Kings Highway and Rockaway Parkway in Brooklyn has been purchased by Joseph G. Goldring from Sterling Investing Corporation for improvement with a service station and automobile showroom.

A banking syndicate headed by Blyth Co., Inc., submitted the best bid yesterday for $6,000,000 of electric revenue bonds of the Imperial Irrigation District, California, due July 1, 1953 to 1979. The bid designated an interest cost of 2.89 per cent.

In order to discover new creative talent, each year the Contemporary Arts Gallery, 105 East Fifty-seventh Street, opens its season with a large group exhibition. All interested American artists are invited to submit work to a jury, which will select those to be sponsored for one-man shows.

LINDEN, N. J., Aug. 23 -- King Haakon VII of Norway and Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt are among scores of persons throughout the world who have been stirred by the plight of Brownie, the Eskimo-type dog that has maintained a fourteen-month vigil for his master on the docks of the Bayway Refinery of the Standard Oil Company here, it was revealed today by Irving Schwartz, U. S. Customs inspector at the refinery.
BUFFALO, Aug. 23 -- Governor Dewey intervened today in an effort to settle the ten-week-old strike here of 1,700 production workers at the plant of the Bell Aircraft Corporation.

CHICAGO, Aug. 23 -- Wheat assumed leadership in the grain markets on the Board of Trade today, reports indicating that sales could be made to the Government at 1 to 2 cents a bushel better than yesterday being the dominating influence. Closing trades were 1 7/8 cents higher to 7/8 cent lower than yesterday, the former on September.

Abner W. Berry, a twenty-year member of the Communist party, testified at the Communist trial yesterday that the party, its policies and its teaching and advocacy had been no different since 1945 than they were before 1944.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -- President Truman indicated today he may visit South Carolina, stronghold of the States Rights movement led by its Gov. J. Strom Thurmond, after a delegation of 118 men and women came from that state to invite him there.

LONDON, Aug. 23 -- One of the fundamental theses of the British delegation at the Washington financial talks in September will be that the economic dislocation of the sterling area that would result from a protracted dollar famine might be harmful to political and strategic interests as vital to the United States as to Britain.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -- Proved States Rights adherents came in for rough treatment today before the credentials committee of the Democratic National Committee. Charges and counter-charges flew thick and fast, with the word "Dixiecrat" taking on the same meaning as "collaborationist" to a Frenchman.
Clarence H. Le Vee has been named Eastern division sales manager of the electrical wire and cable department of the United States Rubber Company, with headquarters in New York.
The African Endeavor, the second of two luxury vessels to be placed on the New York to South Africa run by the Farrell Lines, will be commanded by Capt. John G. Waller, it was announced yesterday.
American tourists, gift-laden and happy as they stream home from Europe this summer, may find a shock awaiting them as they face customs officials.

MOSCOW, Aug. 23 -- The Communist party newspaper Pravda asserted today that Marshal Tito was busily engaged in placing his country at the service of reactionary capitalists through the intermediary of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development.

Higher tariffs on Swiss watch imports would be reflected in reduced purchases by Switzerland of United States goods, and by removing the present healthy competition might well tend to make the American watch industry too complacent for its own good, Paul A. Tschudin, United States representative of the Watch Makers of Switzerland, said in an interview here yesterday.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Aug. 23 -- The Westchester County Bar Association, at a special meeting today, approved a committee report that listed seven possible candidates as qualified for appointment as a Federal judge for the Southern District of New York. It failed to approve four others.
LAUSANNE, Switzerland, Aug. 23 -- Switzerland was host today to one of the "hottest" political refugees yet to come from behind the Iron Curtain to seek asylum in the West.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (AP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission began hearings today on a plan for liquidation of the Pennsylvania Gas and Electric Corporation, Jersey City, N. J.

We would like to think that what Chairman Doughton of the House Ways and Means Committee has just said about tax reduction was to be the last word heard on the subject for some time to come. Up to recently Mr. Doughton believed, he says, that a case could be made for a cut in the wartime excise taxes.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday closed irregular, 1 point higher to 10 points lower.
The publication of the United States White Paper on China by the State Department demands much consideration. The points I should like to bring up are as follows:

Dissolution of the American Newspaper Advertising Network, as of Dec. 31, was voted yesterday at a special meeting of stockholders. The network was organized in 1945 to sell national advertising in member newspapers on a group continuity basis.

CHICAGO, Aug. 23 (AP) -- Pitcher Joe Coleman hit his first major league home run tonight as the Athletics defeated the White Sox, 4 -- 2, before 14,559 persons. Later Coleman pulled a muscle in his right shoulder and Charley Harris and Lou Brissie took turns saving his twelfth victory.

It is appropriate at this time to remind the United States Government and the American people that three years ago -- on Aug. 19, 1946 -- five United States Army flyers were deliberately shot down over Yugoslavia on Tito's orders, on the ground that they were making a "military demonstration."
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 23 -- Following is the text of the new Yugoslav note replying to the note of the Soviet Government of Aug. 18:

HAMBURG, Germany, Aug. 23 (AP) -- Former German Field Marshal Gen. Fritz Erich von Mannstein pleaded not guilty to seven war crimes charges today when his trial opened before a British military tribunal.

MIAMI, Fla., Aug. 23 (AP) -- Storm warnings flew at Cape Hatteras tonight to signal a hurricane with 100-mile winds which pounded the steamship Mormac Surf. The disturbance was swirling northward off the Atlantic Coast.

ATLANTA, Ga., Aug. 23 -- Margaret Mitchell, author of "Gone With the Wind," who died last week of injuries received when struck by a speeding automobile, left an estate exceeding $250,000, it was indicated today when her last will and testament was probated in the Fulton County (Atlanta) Ordinary's Court.

LAKE SUCCESS, Aug. 23 -- A proposal that a "nature umpire" or review board be appointed to prevent the over-exploitation of animal and plant life was made today by Dr. Ira N. Gabrielson, president of the Wildlife Management Institute of Washington, D. C.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 23 -- The King Ranch's 2-year-old colt Middleground, a candidate for Saturday's Hopeful Stakes, made a show-stealing run at Saratoga today. As far as the opposition was concerned, it was a runaway.

MILWAUKEE, Aug. 23 -- William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, re-emphasized today his organization's support of federal aid to raise teachers' salaries and to provide services for all school children "without discrimination for any reason."

A writ of habeas corpus asking that thirty-seven Pakistanis being held on Ellis Island be admitted to bail pending deportation proceedings was signed yesterday by Federal Judge Alexander Holtzoff. The writ is returnable Tuesday.

Creation of a new agency, the Emergency Council for Displaced European Professionals, to handle resettlement in the United States of 25,000 European technicians and specialists now in DP camps in Europe was announced yesterday. These specialists have been accredited as qualified by the International Refugee Organization.

Fuller use of the improved machinery that many mills have installed can save New England's textile industry with its 250,000 jobs, it was declared jointly yesterday by Nathaniel M. Mitchell, president of Barnes Textile Associates, Inc., and Gilbert F. Van-Blarcom, treasurer of Ralph E. Loper Company.

Elderly drivers are a more complex highway accident problem than teen-age motorists, Ned H. Dearborn, president of the National Safety Council, asserted yesterday at a luncheon at the Roosevelt Hotel given by the Association of Casualty and Surety Companies.

Investing clients of Newman Neumann, attorneys, who recently bought the fifteen-story apartment building at 229-35 East Seventy-ninth Street from the Bermerton Holding Corporation, through Joseph S. Lynn, have taken title, according to the Home Title Guaranty Company which yesterday reported that it had furnished title insurance in the deal.

Visiting buyers registered in the market for the week ended yesterday totaled 1,862, against 1,464 last week and 1,688 in the corresponding week of last year, according to lists published in THE NEW YORK TIMES. There were 799 arrivals yesterday, compared with 707 last Tuesday.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -- President Truman nominated three generals today for promotions in the Army's high command.

The most severe price reaction in the hide market in two months caused considerable discussion on the Commodity Exchange yesterday. Hides, which closed the day as much as 50 points below Monday's final quotations, had been rising at a moderate pace since late June, and there was considerable feeling last week, when the market continued to show strength, that they would continue to rise in what traders considered a buying period for shoe manufacturers.

There's a scarcity of canned pineapple because of the strike of Hawaiian stevedores now in its 116th day. One of the leading chains here reports that in most of its stores this tinned fruit is entirely out of stock. Another, which has none at present, anticipates at least a temporary supply when a shipment arrives from the Philippines.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 23 (AP) -- All sixteen matches were decided in straight sets today in the third round of the thirty-second United States girls' lawn tennis singles tournament at the Philadelphia Cricket Club.

HELSINKI, Finland, Aug. 23 -- A split in the Finnish Federation of Labor now appears a fact, because none of the five trade unions involved in the present strike wave has obeyed the federation's order to return to work. They are considered expelled.

CHICAGO, Aug. 23 (AP) -- Medalist Miss Peg Kirk's 19-hole victory over Miss Margaret Gunther and the surprise elimination of the defending champion, Miss Dot Kielty, today marked the first round of the forty - ninth annual Women's Western Amateur golf tournament.

A brief protesting proposed extra charges for use of the West Shore Ferry by New York Central commuters was filed yesterday with the Interstate Commerce Commission in Washington, according to Carl Beck, one of four commuters sponsoring the brief.
HONG KONG, Aug. 23 (UP) -- Generalissimo Chiang flew to Canton today to bolster the morale of his Nationalist Government, now divided on the problem of defending the capital.

The veteran Canadian Pacific passenger ship Princess Charlotte has been withdrawn from service after plying the coastal waters of British Columbia for forty years, it was announced here yesterday by her operators.

The story of 30,944 city, county and state employes banded together to invest their savings, ward off "loan sharks" and meet the financial emergencies of family life was unfolded yesterday in the annual report of the Municipal Credit Union of the City of New York.

State Senator Francis J. Mahoney reported yesterday that he had been advised that a state lottery could raise $500,000,000 over a five-year period in New York. He had previously announced that he would sponsor a constitutional amendment to legalize such an operation.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -- Louis Johnson, Secretary of Defense, denounced the House investigation of the billion-dollar B-36 long-range bomber program today as an inquiry based on rumors and anonymous letters that were "utterly untrue."

CHICAGO, Aug. 23 -- A plan of nine striking locals of the Teamsters Union, AFL, to provide the Chicago area with about 70 per cent of its normal gasoline supply through independent gasoline jobbers was rejected today by the independents.

BONN, Germany, Aug. 23 -- Dr. Konrad Adenauer, chancellor-designate of the Western German Federal Republic, said today he would bid for West German participation in the North Atlantic pact. Dr. Adenauer also confirmed his choice as Christian Democratic nominee for the Chancellorship.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -- Maj. Gen. Herman Feldman, suspended chief of the Army Quartermaster Corps, testified today at the "five percenter" inquiry that he had "no knowledge" of James V. Hunt's position as a "so-called five percenter."

Misery is still widespread throughout Europe despite Marshall Plan aid and CARE (Cooperative for American Remittances to Europe, Inc.) still fills a vital need for the average workingman existing on "a mere subsistence level," Irving Abramson, vice president of the organization, declared here yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (UP) -- Louis Johnson, Secretary of Defense, invited Congressmen today to meet with him tomorrow to hear the bad news about cuts in military spending in their districts.

Arthur S. YIodgkiss, executive officer of the Department of Parks, said yesterday that he would present at a Congressional hearing in Washington tomorrow additional facts in support of a bill that would make possible a new city park at Manhattan Beach.

Although the number of new cases of poliomyelitis in the city rose moderately yesterday for the second consecutive day, Health Commissioner Harry S. Mustard maintained his optimism that the peak of the epidemic was past.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -- The Radio Manufacturers Association urged the Federal Communications Commission today to protect the investments of the present two million television set owners in the country.

Prize winners for the first national Japanese fashion contest were announced yesterday at the home of New York designer Tina Leser. First place went to Miss Michiko Konishi of Ashiya, Hyogoken, who sent in designs for two dresses, one daytime, the other evening, made in accordance with the regulations of the competition
BRUGES, Belgium, Aug. 23 -- Plans are under way here for a Roman Catholic-sponsored University of Europe that will be open to Protestants and members of other denominations as well as Catholics.

The Securities and Exchange Commission will mark today a milestone in its administration of the Public Utility Holding Company Act when it receives an amended plan of corporate simplification and dissolution from the $591,000,000 Niagara Hudson Power Corporation.

BOSTON, Aug. 23 (AP) -- By scoring a pair of runs in both the seventh and eighth innings, the Boston Braves overcame an early deficit tonight, and whipped the Pittsburgh Pirates, 5 --2. A paid crowd of 14,405 saw the Tribesmen win their fourth in succession and the sixth out of eight since they returned home. The box score:

SEABRIGHT, N. J., Aug. 23 (AP) -- Robert Abdesselam of France, second-seeded on the foreign list, turned back August Ganzenmuller of Sea Cliff, L. I., 6 -- 4, 6 -- 4, in the first international match of the sixty-first Seabright Lawn Tennis Club invitation.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -- Nine out of ten times you find the other fellow is trying to do the right thing, when you get to understand him, President Truman said today. He applied this home-made aphorism to "all the different peoples of the world."

BERLIN, Aug. 23 -- The governments of the five states of the Soviet zone are undergoing another of the periodic shake-ups that usually precede some new development of Russian policy, according to German sources here.

The future course of Ray Robinson's ring career may be decided tonight in the Yankee Stadium, in the battle that will swing the Harlem Negro into the century class among boxing's professionals -- it will be his 100th fight. Holder of the world welterweight title, Robinson will determine after tonight whether he will surrender his 147-pound crown and seek the middleweight title.

Emphasizing the need for playgrounds in congested areas, the Park Department asked the City Planning Commission yesterday for $14,700,430 for 1950, of which $7,790,600 has been earmarked for forty new playgrounds.

Philip Murray, president of the United Steelworkers of America, CIO, declared yesterday that the steel industry's attack upon the appointment of the Presidential fact-finding board was "plainly designed to intimidate the board."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -- A jangled and impatient House of Representatives was on its toes today to recess for twenty-six days, starting Saturday, while the Senate caught up on appropriations and other legislation.

American motion pictures are being viewed with "renewed respect" by leaders of public opinion in Europe, who heretofore constituted "Hollywood's most relentless critics," according to John G. McCarthy, managing director of the international division of the Motion Picture Association of America.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Aug. 23 -- Konrad Cardinal von Preysing of Berlin, together with Josef Cardinal Frings of Cologne as chairman, today headed the annual conference of Catholic Bishops of Germany that began deliberations at Fulda on church problems.

Congress is expected within the next few days to reopen the question of setting aside a "minute-man" fleet of high-quality surplus ships now in the Government's reserve fleet anchorages, for readiness in case of emergency, according to shipping reports received in New York from Washington yesterday.
LONDON, Aug. 23 (AP) -- Britain's Labor Government, waving aside protests from dealers, said tonight it would order clothing price cuts in a few days.

A three-bedroom house handled in a contemporary manner and filled with the kind of furniture usually reserved for decorator's showrooms or model settings in stores will be opened to the public on Sunday. The one-story, ranch type house is part of the Lakeville Estates development in New Hyde Park, L. I.

Mayor O'Dwyer's trip to Staten Island to turn on the city's first flow of pipeline natural gas, and his return flight by helicopter, start a ruffling of the history pages. The company on Staten Island has been supplying artificial gas since the middle Eighteen Fifties, but gas was first offered to Manhattan as early as 1825.

Plans for the reconstruction of a major part of the Metropolitan Museum of Art and the addition of at least one large new wing have been completed by museum officials in cooperation with the city, it became known last night.

Even though several of the leading producers of wool goods have not announced their new prices, all the manufacturers are pressing for spring business, it was learned yesterday. Advance buying, however, has been light and activity is concentrated on goods for fall and winter that will be billed on the basis of the spring price lists.

Sears, Roebuck Co., in its semi-annual statement issued yesterday covering the twenty-four weeks ended on July 16, showed a decline in net profit to $33,106,509 from $51,499,010 for the corresponding period of last year.

The victory drought for the Dodgers ended at Ebbets Field last night when, after dropping the afternoon game to the Cardinals, 5 -- 3, for their fourth straight loss, they came back under the lights to nose out the Redbirds in a brilliantly played affair, 4 -- 3, and cut St. Louis' first-place lead to two games again.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 23 -- Representative Joseph R. Bryson, Democrat, of South Carolina, asserted tonight that the alcoholic beverage industry had gone "far beyond good taste" in its advertising and was attempting to "put across the idea that liquor is traditional in the American way of life."

First signs of a slight upturn in the tool and die manufacturing industry have appeared on a national basis, but New York shops still find business spotty, C. W. Holmberg, past president, New York Tool and Die Institute and an official of August W. Holmberg Co., New York, declared yesterday.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 23 -- Jan Clayton, former Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer actress who has been absent from the screen since 1945, will play the feminine lead opposite Kirby Grant in Monogram's "The Wolf Hunters," the studio announced today.

A revised version of the Mundt-Nixon bill "to protect the United States against subversive activities" is now before the Senate Judiciary Committee, after approval by a subcommittee. This measure, S. 2311, is akin to the one that passed the House last year but died in the Senate.

NEITHER the Dodgers nor the Cardinals have been in particularly vigorous health of late, physically or as regards their won-and-lost percentages. Injury lists were long on both sides but the electric spark generated by the current clash between the league's two best teams brought out everyone at a gallop. Varsity line-ups were virtually intact yesterday afternoon.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -- The personal representative of Acting President Li Tsung-jen of the Chinese Nationalist Government disputed today a section of the United States White Paper on United States-Chinese relations charging an agreement between the Acting President and the Soviet Union.

One of the largest popular music record producers, Decca Records, Inc., announced yesterday that it would soon make available its entire catalogue of albums on the long-playing, unbreakable microgroove type of disk that plays at 33 1/3 revolutions a minute.

Worry over how to handle Britain's desperate dollar shortage is not a monopoly of the United States Government. While official Washington is divided on what our attitude should be when the British negotiators arrive to discuss the question, it is not nearly so divided as reports published here and abroad would indicate.

PARIS, Aug. 23 -- With thousands of soldiers and civilians still fighting the fires that in the last few days have ravaged the Gironde forests in southwestern France the French Government announced tonight that a national day of mourning for the victims of the catastrophe would be observed tomorrow.
Mayor O'Dwyer's plan for a survey on reclassification and wage adjustments for city employes was backed yesterday by the Citizens Budget Commission and seven other civic organizations.

LAKE SUCCESS, Aug. 23 -- Australia proposed today that the United Nations General Assembly take up the question of human rights in Rumania at the same time that it reviews the religious trials in Hungary and Bulgaria.

Several hundred persons, including three women with their hair in curlers and towels wrapped about their shoulders, were driven to Central Park South yesterday at 1 P. M. by a fire in the beauty salon in the basement of the St. Moritz Hotel.

LONDON, Aug. 23 -- Bear covering on the last day of the account was responsible for the small amount of activity in the stock markets here today, and the opinion is that quiet conditions will rule until the outcome of the economic talks in Washington by Britain, Canada and the United States is known next month.

Slipping fractions to 3 points on light selling, stock prices yesterday closed with the widest losses in two months. Singled out for attack were the "blue chip" stocks generally used in computing the "averages." Activity in the final hour, when prices were weakest, expanded sales to 840,000 shares from the 710,000 traded on Monday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (AP) -- The Federal Trade Commission announced today dismissal of a complaint charging the Northwest Dried Fruit Association, Portland, Ore., and its members with conspiring to create a monopoly in the sale of dried prunes.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt resumed yesterday her discussion of Federal aid to education for the first time since the controversy on the subject between herself and Cardinal Spellman was ended in jointly released statements.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -- The 113 largest manufacturers in the United States control 46 per cent of the total capital assets of all manufacturing corporations, the Federal Trade Commission said today in a report sent to Congress. The study covers 1947.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (AP) -- The Commerce Department announced today that new orders placed with manufacturers picked up 8 per cent in May and June, marking the "first significant break" in a downturn that began last fall.

STRASBOURG, France, Aug. 23 (UP) -- Former French Premier Paul Reynaud, speaking in the European Consultative Assembly today, urged the creation of a European economic union to avoid "catastrophe" when Marshall Plan aid ended in 1952.

RYE. N. Y., Aug. 28 -- At the end of the first round of the Westchester open golf championship today. 38-year-old Jim Marotta, professional at Maplemoor, the Westchester County Park Commission course at White Plains, led the field of eighty-four starters with a three under par 69.

EDINBURGH, Scotland, Aug. 23 -- For its opera, the Edinburgh Festival relies on the Glyndebourne organization, which is only natural, seeing that Rudolf Bing, before he became director of this festival, was operatic manager of Glyndebourne. A direct inheritance from pre-war Mozart festivals at Glyndebourne itself is "Cosi fan Tutte,' which was revived here in Edinburgh last year with delightful new sets by Rolf Gerard, and was once again heard tonight.

" THE JUNGLE IS NEUTRAL,"* by Col. F. Spencer Chapman, D.S.O., is one of the great records of personal war experience. It does not benefit from any literary artifice. It does not plumb depths of emotion nor make any effort to convey the terrific drama of its material. A plain, unvarnished tale is this, written with spare precision, with restraint, with typically British understatement and with modest dignity.
FRANKFORT, Germany, Aug. 23 (AP) -- Maj. Gen. Frank W. Milburn was appointed today as deputy commanding general of the United States Army in Europe.

House dress volume in units in the last half of 1949 will exceed that of the similar period in 1948, according to a survey just completed for the Association of Cotton Textile Merchants of New York by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Aug. 23 (AP) -- Form players have had a banner season at the shore course, where 41 per cent of the favorites have reached the winner's circle, but there was little joy for "chalk" players in the crowd of 17,536 today, after the featured Beacon Purse.

Fires raging out of control in Idaho's Payette National Forest yesterday caused the area to be closed to vacationers, while in Maine a dozen brush and timberland blazes were reported, the Associated Press said.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Aug. 23 -- With words of great hope for success and a warning of the "fatal consequences" of failure, the long-awaited round-table conference on Indonesia opened here today.

" Sword in the Desert," an adventure drama based on the British-Jewish strife in Palestine, will open an engagement this morning at the Criterion. Dana Andrews, Marta Toren and Stephen McNally head the cast of the film, which was written and produced by Robert Buckner for Universal-International.

Eric Sturgess of South Africa, runner-up last year to Richard (Pancho) Gonzales in the championship, and Jaroslav Drobny, the Czech exile who was a finalist against Ted Schroeder at Wimbledon this year, head the foreign seeded list in the national amateur tennis tournament, which will start Monday at the West Side Tennis Club, Forest Hills, following the Davis Cup challenge round there.

An agreement that would have averted a threatened bus strike by Local 100 of the Transport Workers Union, CIO, against the Triboro Coach Company in Western Queens was upset by the company's day workers at a meeting last night in National Hall, Woodside, Queens.

The National Broadcasting Company is setting up an opera department which will present a series of one-hour operas in English over its television network during the fall and winter season. In the first step toward launching the activity, Peter Herman Adler, director of touring opera companies and on several occasions conductor of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, has been named director of opera for NBC television.

SAN JOSE, Calif., Aug. 23 (UP) -- The United Steelworkers of America, CIO, and the American Can Company today settled their wage and working condition dispute to end the threat of a strike in twenty-eight plants across the nation.
SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 24 -- It's not too far-fetched to say that the sixty-ninth running of the Alabama stakes was won in the Saratoga jockey-room hot box today.

The reconciliation of Cardinal Spellman and Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt was completed last Friday, so far as their personal relationship was concerned, when the Cardinal dropped in and stayed for tea at the Roosevelt family's Hyde Park estate.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 -- John W. Snyder, Secretary of the Treasury, indicated today his belief that no good purpose could be served by devaluing what he called the only sound currency left in the world -- the United States dollar.

The leasing by the American Can Company of more than six entire floors containing about 180,000 square feet in the new 36-story office building at 100 Park Avenue was announced yesterday by 100 Park Avenue, Inc. At 230 Park Avenue since 1929, American Can will use the eighth through the thirteenth floors and part of the third floor in its new Park Avenue location.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (UP) -- An attempt to force House Labor Committee consideration of the controversial Federal aid-to-education issue fell through today when a quorum failed to appear for a meeting.

A new inflatable rubber lifeboat, a larger and improved version of the familiar aviator's emergency float, was demonstrated yesterday off Rockaway Point by the Coast Guard, which has ordered it for many of its sea-going ships.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange had a quiet day yesterday and final prices were 1 point lower to 3 points higher.

Robert S. Fougner in his recent letter urges delay in enacting further rent legislation, and proposes "careful and calm deliberation before any decision is reached." This view is understandable from the standpoint of the landlords, who have a great deal to gain from delay.

The five-story Aldrich Building, occupying the entire easterly blockfront on Church Street between Warren and Chambers Street, and the adjoining five-story store and lofts at 32 Warren Street have been sold by the 149 Church Street Corporation, headed by Robert W. Dowling, who is also president of the City Investing Company.

ROME, Aug. 24 -- The Government announced today that it would undertake an all-out campaign against Sicilian outlaws and especially against bandit Salvatore Giuliano, who has for years been terrorizing the countryside within a stone's throw of the Sicilian capital, Palermo.

Decisive gains in the "cold war" were made in 1948 through the voluntary action of American business in using weapons of ideas developed by the Advertising Council, Inc., according to the seventh annual report of the council released yesterday.

An underwriting syndicate of 135 banking houses headed by Morgan, Stanley Co. will place on the market today an issue of $100,000,000 of twenty-five-year 2 3/4 per cent bonds of the Government of Canada.

HAVANA, Aug. 24 -- President Carlos Prio Socarras, who early this morning unexpectedly removed Gen. Genovevo Perez Damera as Chief of Staff of the Cuban Army, today continued reorganization of the armed forces.

Vigorous attempts to increase export sales are being made by many American steel companies now that they believe the domestic market has found its level. Outlets for this country's excess steel supply are being sought principally in Western Europe and the Middle East.

BERLIN, Aug. 24 -- Soviet zone Communists charged today that the recent West German elections were machinations of capitalism. At the same time they urged German workmen to increase their work quotas as an aid to spreading, the "progressive status" of East Germany to the whole country.

The electric power networks of Rumania and Bulgaria have been linked since the beginning of August under an exchange agreement worked out within the program of Moscow's Council for Economic Mutual Assistance, according to a Rumanian broadcast of the Sofia radio reported by United States Government monitors.

Charles Ress, president of the Palestine Foundation Fund, arriving yesterday at the New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, predicted the growth of a "middle-of-the-road" political party in Israel, as represented by the General Zionists, to stimulate the development of private economic interests.

Forty-nine new cases of poliomyelitis were reported yesterday in this city, the third straight day that an increase has been recorded. Health Department officials said they were not disturbed, as the daily total was still well below the peak numbers of last week and two weeks ago.

More than 100 persons who listened yesterday to the broadcast of the Dodgers-Cardinals baseball game at Ebbets Field, Brooklyn, responded to a special appeal for blood put on the air during the game, the American Red Cross reported.

With a death toll of more than eighty in France and of more than twenty in this country, forest fires on two continents and in many of our states still rage. It has not been determined that the disastrous blazes in the Gironde were not criminally set, but it is known that preventable human acts were responsible for them and for all but one of the major fires in this country.
R. W. Rummel, former manager of aircraft procurement for Trans World Airline, has been appointed chief engineer of TWA. He succeeds L. R. Koepnick, who has resigned to enter the Air Force.

The second Israeli-flag vessel to ply transatlantic waters will enter service on or about Sept. 15, it was announced yesterday by the American-Israeli Shipping Company, agents here for the Israel America Line.

In our preoccupation with the present "sterling crisis" are we losing our perspective on the recovery progress of Western Europe as a whole? Economists G. Rowland Collins and Marcus Nadler of the Institute of International Finance of New York University believe we are.

At least 4,500 civilian employes of the armed forces are scheduled to be laid off in the city and at near-by military installations under Secretary of Defense Louis Johnson's curtailment order yesterday. The New York Naval Shipyard at Brooklyn, where 3,385 were ordered dropped from the payrolls, was the hardest hit in this area.

Frederick R. (Ted) Schroeder of La Crescenta, Calif., Wimbledon champion, was seeded ahead of the defending titleholder, Richard (Pancho) Gonzales of Los Angeles, as the draw was made yesterday at the Hotel Vanderbilt for the national amateur tennis championships in men's, women's and veterans' singles.
Newly imported Bavarian dinnerware and a group of glassware patterns will be exhibited in a series of table settings on Macy's eighth floor starting Monday.

Calvert Distillers Corporation will spend more money in newspaper advertising during its new fiscal year than ever before, it was declared by W. W. Wachtel, Calvert's president, in a speech prepared for delivery last night at the company's annual management conference in the Montauk Manor, Montauk Point, L. I.

The Emerson Radio and Phonograph Corporation will place its entire television receiver line on allocation to distributors beginning Sept. 1, Benjamin Abrams, president, announced yesterday. He said it was impossible to say definitely how long quota selling would be retained but added: "I don't see how we can do anything else for the rest of the year."

LONDON, Aug. 24 -- Britain's Labor Government faces the grim necessity of restricting Government expenditures for social services, in advance of a general election, unless an unexpected miracle of loaves and fishes occurs in Washington when Foreign Secretary Ernest Bevin and Sir Stafford Cripps arrive for the international monetary talks next month.

George H. Knutson, executive chairman of the Project Committee and chief of the Equipment Branch of the Economic Cooperation Administration's Industry Division, was among 630 passengers who sailed for Europe yesterday on the French liner De Grasse.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (AP) -- The text of President Truman's informal address to the Democratic National Committee tonight follows:
WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (AP) -- Incomes of farmers may-drop in the next few years, Congress was told today as two national farm organizations urged passage of a compromise price-support bill.
MADISON, Wis., Aug. 24 -- The National Council of Farmer Cooperatives recorded officially today its "unalterable" opposition to the Brannan farm plan.

CHICAGO, Aug. 24 -- Short covering in the late trading resulted in a strong rally on the Board of Trade today after an early decline. Advances of 1/2 to 1 cent a bushel in premiums for cash corn, with reports of an aggressive demand, started early sellers of September corn to buying and disclosed a lack of offerings.

The downward trend in stock prices which had prevailed for three days was slowed yesterday and trading was reduced. After extending losses moderately in the early part of the session, prices moved in a narrow range with transfers falling to 720,000 shares, from 840,000 traded on Tuesday.
LARCHMONT, N. Y., Aug. 24 -- The United States today took the lead in the Snipe international series being held at the Larchmont Yacht Club with a second front-running performance.

MONTAUK, L. I., Aug. 24 -- The best indication of successful fishing is the weariness of the angler, provided the fatigue is not the result of seasickness, and the anglers who stepped from their boats to the Montauk Yacht Club dock this afternoon were a weary lot.
ALBANY, Aug. 24 -- The State Department of Commerce said today that its study of the dress industry revealed that New York State produced three of every four quality dresses worn by American women.
TEL AVIV, Israel, Aug. 23 -- An inter-ministerial committee surveying the Dead Sea development prospects has recommended to the Cabinet that the Government take over control of chemical production.

CLINTON, N. Y., Aug. 24 -- United States Representative William L. Pfeiffer, Republican state chairman, believes John Foster Dulles should be nominated by the GOP to succeed himself as United States Senator. He is hopeful Mr. Dulles will accept.

PEORIA, Ill., Aug. 24 -- R. G. Le Tourneau, president of R. G. Le Tourneau, Inc., said today the directors had omitted a preferred dividend due at this time because of objections made by the Penn Mutual Life Insurance Company of Philadelphia.

SCOUTS from the Dodgers, Giants and a few other major league teams are currently taking a gander at the finals of the championship tournament of the Little League in Williamsport, Pa. -- which just goes to show the extremes that modern talent searches have produced. On second thought, though, it may be the idea rather than the individuals that the majors are investigating.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Aug. 24 -- The United Nations Social Welfare Congress of the Arab States here has been warned in a report presented by a professor of economics at the American University in Beirut to expect a revolution, with heavy losses in life and property, unless radical changes are made in the Arab world.

Loeser's held its college fashion show yesterday in the fifth floor restaurant. The store featured clothes that would fit a college girl's budget and still fulfill her desire to be the best dressed co-ed on the campus. The show was broken down into categories to cover all occasions, from campus separates to town date dresses.

Hitherto rare metals of limited use because of hardness and brittleness may, as a result of atomic energy experiments, soon be widely employed, a symposium on the physics of powder metallurgy heard yesterday.

RYE, N. Y., Aug. 24 -- Scoring a 69 and a 73 for his two rounds over his home course today, Jack Patroni of Apawamis brought his 54 hole aggregate to 213 and won the Westchester open golf title by a four-stroke margin.

PORT JERVIS, N. Y., Aug. 24 -- It's Christmas Eve at Camp Minisink. Yes, the 264 guests from 6 to 16 can hear the thermometer screaming "summer," so they know Santa Claus will arrive soon in a rowboat, because that's how he came here last Aug. 24 at midnight.
Your editorial on "The Over-Age Worker" fails to mention the principal reason for the barring of older workers from employment.

LONDON, Aug. 24 -- Although the new account in the stock markets here opened today, it failed to produce any increase in business. Even gold-mining shares, which have started recent accounts with speculative buying, were quiet and even lower for choice issues.

CHICAGO, Aug. 24 (AP) -- Dick Fowler, the Athletics' veteran right-handed pitcher, scored his fourth 1949 shut-out today. He pitched the Athletics to a 5-0 vic tory over the White Sox before 4,789 persons.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 -- Dean Acheson, Secretary of State, declared with a note of finality today that there was "not an iota of truth" in charges and insinuations that the State Department had deliberately omitted important documens from its White Paper on United States-Chinese relations.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 24 -- The Boston Tea Party has a modern parallel here in the case of George Ross, a 50-year-old pipefitter at the naval base shipyard.

Jaroslav Drobny and Vladimir Cernik, Czech tennis players who decided in Berne that they would not return to Czechoslovakia as long as the country is Communist-dominated, arrived at Idlewild Airport yesterday by a Pan American World Airways plane from London.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 -- The alliance of Western Europe and North America became effective today with the unanimous ratification of the North Atlantic treaty. President Truman declared no nation need fear the array of twelve nations that were rededicating themselves to peace.

Rubber futures were mixed on the Commodity Exchange yesterday, with near-by deliveries closing 1 to 4 points higher, while distant deliveries declined 4 to 10 points. The December delivery was the center of trading interest and closed 1 point net lower.

George T. Campbell, chief clerk, announced yesterday that the Appellate Division, First Department, would meet Tuesday at 10:30 A. M. to review decisions made by the Supreme Court and Board of Elections on the candidacies of various designees for Primary Day nominations.

TAIPEI, Formosa, Aug. 24 -- A limited Economic Cooperation Administration program for Formosa has been an important factor in keeping this island afloat economically during the last year. Approximately $8,000,000 has been spent for aid projects of various kinds.

The four officers of the Chilean Army jumping team, scheduled to compete in the nightly international military jumping contests at the sixty-first National Horse Show at Madison Square Garden, Nov. 1 to 8, reached New York yesterday aboard the Copiapo of the Chilean Line.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 24 (AP) -- The four top-seeded Americans advanced to the quarter-final round of the thirty-second girls' lawn tennis singles championship today with straight set triumphs.

THE TIMES is to be congratulated on its editorial "The War Against Hunger" in the Aug. 17 issue. On Page 25 of the same date is a little article, "20,000 Look On As Machines Transform a Farm," which supports THE TIMES' thesis that science will continue to solve the problem of finding food to feed the world's increasing population for a long time to come.

A 27-year-old hit-and-run driver, who had pleaded guilty to six different traffic violations in an automobile accident that resulted in a boy being seriously injured, was fined $750, with the alternative of 410 days in jail, in Auto Accident Court yesterday.
OTTAWA, Aug. 24 -- Marking the entry into force of the North Atlantic treaty, Prime Minister Louis St. Laurent in a statement tonight declared proof of its value already had been given.

MINEOLA, L.I., Aug. 24 -- Ferdinand A. Gehrhardt, 58 years old, the Freeport auto executive who has figured prominently in the wire-tap trial in New York, must stand trial Sept. 6 in First District Court here on a charge of driving while intoxicated.

Clarifying the recent opinion of Nathaniel L. Goldstein, State Attorney General, in connection with television service contracts, the State Department of Insurance issued yesterday a list of rules that will be applied in passing upon such contracts.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 24 -- The Yugoslav Government issued a communique tonight accusing the Albanian Government of acting as a screen for the Communist Information Bureau's ambition to divide Yugoslavia.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (AP) -- The states renewed their plea to Congress today for legislation to give them management of coastal submerged lands.

The nation's gasoline stocks last week declined 562,000 barrels to 107,612,000 at the week-end, according to the American Petroleum Institute. This compares with 108, 174,000 barrels a week earlier and 95,132,000 a year ago.
CAPE HATTERAS, N. C., Aug. 24 (AP) -- One hurricane headed into the open Atlantic tonight after sweeping this part of the North Carolina coast.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 -- Cedric R. Worth, special assistant to the Under-Secretary of the Navy, today admitted authorship of the anonymous letter that provoked a House investigation of the B-36 long-range bomber program. Mr. Worth was suspended from his $8,500 post a few hours later.

DETROIT, Aug. 24 -- With Joe DiMaggio still on the sidelines nursing a sprained left shoulder, Casey Stengel today crowded all the power he could into the Yankee line-up, including his newly acquired Johnny Mize. In fact, he had no fewer than five lefthanded sluggers in a row coming to the plate to oppose Art Houtteman.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 24 -- Marlon Brando, Broadway star of "A Streetcar Named Desire," will make his screen debut in Stanley Kramer's United Artists production, "The Men." which Fred Zinnemann will direct, Kramer announced today.

Though abandoned by his wartime allies and without any official government position save that of President in retirement, Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek is again emerging as the leading figure in the attempt to rally the Chinese National forces for last-ditch resistance against Communist subjugation.

More than 2,000 appeals by landlords and tenants from Federal rent rulings were dismissed yesterday by regional rent officials here. As part of the Housing Expediter's "economy" program, the action was not concerned with the merits of the cases, and will not prevent the persons involved from bringing new appeals for consideration by the housing expediter's staff at Washington.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 -- General Mark W. Clark, commanding general of the Sixth Army, was chosen by the Department of the Army today to be Chief of the Army Field Forces, succeeding General Jacob L. Devers.

Murray Latimer, insurance consultant for the United Steelworkers of America, CIO, sought to assure the steel industry yesterday that the union would not saddle it with social insurance duplicating protection that may be provided in the future under the Social Security program.

SANDS POINT, L. I., Aug. 24 -- Mrs. William R. Kirkland Jr. of Piping Rock equaled par with a 39, 35 -- 74 to win first low gross prize in the women's Long Island Golf Association's one day tournament held on the Sands Point Golf Club course today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 -- Some influential Administration Democrats in the Senate are now prepared to see included in the military aid program a carefully circumscribed and contingent $100,000,000 authorization for the "Far East."
CHICAGO, Aug. 24 (AP) -- Favorites advanced to the quarterfinals of the Women's Western Amateur golf tourney today with the exception of 15-year-old Miss Marlene Bauer.
CLEVELAND, Aug. 24 (AP) -- For the second straight night the Indians suffered a blow to their pennant aspirations by stumbling before the seventh-place Senators. The score was 3 to 2.

A seasonal increase in demand for steel products is due after Labor Day and current orders indicate it will arrive on schedule, W. K. Underhill, sales manager of the New York division of Joseph T. Ryerson Son, Inc., Jersey City, N. J., declared here yesterday.

BONNEVILLE SALT FLATS, Utah, Aug. 24 (AP) -- Alex Xydias of Burbank, Calif., today drove to a new world's record of 153 miles per hour in a trial run in the first annual Bonneville speed meet for American stock powered motor cars.

A better feeling exists in the raw fur market, with leading dealers here expressing the belief yesterday that the low point of prices on domestic furs has been passed. Price resistance is still evident on some furs, but the market has moved up 5 to 12 per cent over recent lows.

BOSTON, Aug. 24 (AP) -- The third-place Braves continued to enjoy their current home stand today by defeating the Pirates, 6 -- 5, for their fifth consecutive victory and their seventh in their last nine games at Braves Field.

Yesterday, after ten of the twelve signatory Governments had deposited instruments of ratification, President Truman solemnly proclaimed the North Atlantic Pact in force. The ceremony in the White House was brief and simple, but none of the foreign Ambassadors or the American officials present missed the historic significance of the occasion.
Honolulu, Hawaii, announced yesterday that it would receive bids on Sept. 1 on $1,500,000 of tax-exempt sewer bonds due on Sept. 1, 1954 to 1979.

A strike in any branch of the city's vast transportation system is always of serious concern and inconvenience to the public. The tie-up on the Triboro Coach Company's lines in Queens, affecting over 300 workers and 150,000 daily riders, is no exception.

LONDON, Aug. 24 -- Deputies of the Big Four foreign ministers who are trying to finish drafting an Austrian peace treaty before Sept. 1 agreed here today on legislation to protect the rights of the Slovene and Croat minorities in Austria.
DOVER, England, Aug. 24 (AP) -- Eighteen-year-old Philip Mickman was the toast of Britain tonight for his dogged battle in becoming the youngest swimmer ever to conquer the English Channel.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Aug. 24 -- The return of some of the Cabinet Ministers who had been vacationing in Russia and Communist press assertions that harversting of bumper crops had been successfully completed in spite of Roman Catholic Church attempts at sabotage, indicated today that the summer doldrums are over and that the Government is about to renew its campaign to control the Roman Catholic Church in Czechoslovakia.

MILWAUKEE, Aug. 24 -- The American Federation of Teachers, now holding its thirty-second annual convention here, today sent a telegram to the House Committee on Labor and Education urging passage of the Burke bill for Federal aid to education.

CANTON, Aug. 24 (UP) -- The closing of the United States Consulate in Canton was completed today after sixty-three years of operation and United States interests in the area were handed over to the British.

NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 24 -- Rashtriya Swayam Sevak Sangh (National Volunteer Corps), Hindu militant organization, has started a country-wide movement for the revival of Hindu culture. With the lifting of the ban on this organization last July and the release of its leader, M. S. Golwalkar, the new movement is becoming popular, especially among young Hindus.
