Beginning at 6 o'clock this morning, forty city buses, manned by city employes, are to operate in the area served by the strikebound lines of the Triboro Coach Company in Queens, Mayor O'Dwyer announced yesterday.

The ban of the Federal Communications Commission on the radio giveaway programs is a mixed blessing. While most thoughtful listeners will welcome a respite from the prize contests, the FCC's course of action is open to serious question.

The Department of State stepped into the case of the multi-million dollar international cocaine smuggling ring yesterday at a Federal Court arraignment in which the alleged "master mind," Eduardo Balarezo of North Great River, L. I., pleaded innocent to a charge of conspiracy to possess drugs.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 -- A program to free the national economy from "undue union concentration of power in the hands of a comparatively few labor leaders" was advocated today by Admiral Ben Moreell, U.S.N., retired. He is president and board chairman of Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 -- The North American Company of New York received permission today from the Securities and Exchange Commission to sell to nine individuals, for $2,189,160 cash, without competitive bidding, 109,458 shares of the $100 par value capital stock of the Capital Transit Company, Washington, D. C., which provides transit in the District of Columbia.

Arrangements have been made by the newly formed Northeastern Gas Transmission Company to obtain a supply of natural gas for New England from two of the country's major natural gas pipeline systems, Alexander Macomber, chairman of Northeastern Gas Transmission, announced yesterday.

WARSAW, Aug. 23 -- The Polish Government is planning a broad liberalization of its policy governing the emigration of Jews to Israel. It is expected that within a month a program will be inaugurated whereby any Polish Jew willing to renounce his Polish citizenship will be permitted to leave the country for Israel.
The Matson Navigation Company at San Francisco is filing charges of a secondary boycott with the National Labor Relations Board, it was announced here last night by the line's local office.

SHANGHAI, Aug. 24 -- The worsening relations between Russia and Yugoslavia when juxtaposed against developments here provide a striking contrast of Communist trends in countries whose revolutions contain high national content and whose economies are still dependent on aid from outside.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 -- As a result of the "five percenter" inquiry, the Commerce Department will use part of its funds for small business activities to expand its procurement assistance services and help the "little fellows," Charles Sawyer, Secretary of Commerce, said today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 -- Dean Acheson, Secretary of State, indicated today that he did not envy the position of the world-wide Communist parties that would have to explain the hostility of the Soviet Union toward Yugoslavia in terms of what has been called a Russian peace offensive.

MIAMI, Aug. 24 -- Philip C. Jessup, United States Ambassador-at-Large, said today that world peace was not "safe and secure" and that we were now "fighting for a just and permanent peace on the Atlantic and Pacific fronts just as much as we were in the war years."

August furniture dollar volume is running between 10 and 20 per cent behind last year in department stores and large home furnishings chains, buyers reported yesterday. Some said this indicated that August sales were generally successful because furniture volume stood at record levels in 1948 until the middle of September.
Sheldon Jones and Wes Westrum, a high voltage battery yesterday, powered the Giants to a 5-3 triumph over the Cubs at the Polo Grounds.

Prices of iron and steel scrap metal, which reversed the yearlong trend early this month and started to climb, are still on the rise. An increase of 50 cents a ton for top grade material was listed yesterday by a New York dealer. In some markets the price has jumped between $3 and $4 a ton this month, despite a small amount of sales.

SEABRIGHT, N. J., Aug. 24 (AP) -- Seeded players advanced without loss of a set today at the sixty-first annual Seabright Lawn Tennis and Cricket Club tournament. None of the seeded stars, domestic or foreign, had any trouble.

Reports that Washington would permit resumption of a free market in tin within the coming week were widespread in the metal markets here yesterday. According to the reports, which received full credence from major traders here, the Government had at long last agreed with domestic consumers that tin under Government control since before the war, should have the same freedom of sale as that accorded some time ago to copper, lead and zinc.

Though export restrictions on Switzerland Swiss cheese were discontinued last May, this country still imports only half as much as it did before the war. Americans, it seems, need to become reacquainted with this product that the Swiss make to such perfection.

CHICAGO, Aug. 24 (AP) -- Lowell North, 19-year-old San Diego, Calif., skipper, drove his North Star II across the finish line off Belmont Harbor in 2:50:51 today to win his third consecutive race in the Star Class world yachting championships.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (AP) -- Plenty of cranberries, to go with a near-record turkey crop, were predicted today by the Department of Agriculture.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 -- Friends of Tom C. Clark, the erstwhile Attorney General, swarmed into the White House rose garden this afternoon to see him sworn in as an associate justice of the United States Supreme Court. Later Senator J. Howard McGrath of Rhode Island was sworn in to succeed Mr. Clark as Attorney General.

Benedict Ginsberg's letter concerning Controller General Lindsay Warren may, to the casual reader, truly indicate that the Controller General's statements amount to a "molehill -- blown up to a headline."
What a difference one day can make!

A fashion philosophy stressing the importance of casual clothes was expounded yesterday by Adam Gimbel, president of Saks Fifth Avenue, at the opening of the store's enlarged sportswear shops, which cover almost the entire third floor.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 -- The Senate refused by a vote of 58 to 25 today to approve a twenty-six day recess of the House. Its action was on a resolution which had just gone through the House on a voice vote, with only a few scattered dissents. The House proposed to take the recess while the Senate stayed on to catch up on appropriations and other legislation.

HELSINKI, Finland, Aug. 24 -- The Finnish Federation of Labor was split wide open by the decision taken by its executive committee today to expel four striking trade unions for their refusal to obey the committee's order to return to work by today.

McKesson Robbins, Inc., in addition to reporting larger sales in its preliminary annual statement of earnings, announced yesterday the declaration of an extra dividend to common stockholders, the first in many years.

PARIS, Aug. 24 -- Although closely watched and fought by civilian and military fire fighters, including members of the Paris fire department, flames continued to exact their tribute of woodlands in the Gironde region today and again lashed out at the villages of Saucats, La Brede and Leognan.
A new chapter in the story of the "dream house" that has been sitting on a parking lot at the northeast corner of Fifty-second Street and the Avenue of the Americas started yesterday.
Peter Bondi's fall millinery collection, shown yesterday at his salon at 36 West Fifty-eighth Street, was inspired both by the era of 1918 and by the Orient.

VANDALIA, Ohio, Aug. 24 (AP) -- Joe Hiestand, 42-year-old Hillsboro, Ohio, farmer, continued to dominate the fiftieth Grand American trapshoot today as he captured the Class AA championship with a perfect 200 score at 16 yards.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 -- Louis Johnson, Secretary of Defense, today ordered for the sake of economy the dismissal of 135,000 civilian workers in the military forces and the release of 12,073 reserve officers from active duty.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Aug. 24 (AP) -- Bobanet Stable's King Midas, seeking his first victory since the Florida season, drove through along the inside to score by a length today in the featured Marmora Purse.

" Madame Bovary," starring Jennifer Jones in the Metro adaptation of the Gustave Flaubert novel, will open an engagement this morning at the Capitol. James Mason of Great Britain, Van Heflin of Hollywood. Louis Jourdan of France and Christopher Kent of Sweden comprise the lady's galaxy of lovers.

Carson McCullers' first play, a dramatization of her own novel, "The Member of the Wedding," will be presented this winter by Robert Whitehead and Oliver Rea, who have deferred several other projects to give the McCullers play top priority on their agenda.

John G. Broady, private investigator being tried for grand larceny, and illegal wiretapping admitted yesterday in General Sessions that shortly after the District Attorney began to investigate him he hired a woman who later became a prosecution witness.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Aug. 24 -- The United States is expected to have a decisive voice on at least one of the most important questions to be decided at the round-table conference on Indonesia -- the future of the Dutch naval base at Surabaya.

A description of four top events in the annual National Air Races at Cleveland, including the Thompson Trophy race, will be broadcast by the Columbia Broadcasting System radio network over the Labor Day week-end. Newsmen assigned to cover the races are Douglas Edwards, John Daly and Ted Hanna.

An account of changes in present-day England by Virginia Cowles, American journalist and wife of a member of Parliament, will be issued in October by Harper. "No Cause for Alarm" presents an outline of the historical events that have shaped the British system, portraits of the leaders of the Labor and Conservative parties and a discussion of the influence of the Crown in shaping public opinion.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 -- Cedric R. Worth, 49-year-old author of the mysterious letter that touched off the House investigation of B-36 bomber procurement, has worked as a New York newspaper man, a Hollywood scenario writer and more recently as an $8,500 special assistant in the Navy Department.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 -- President Truman invited States Righters and other dissidents tonight to come back into the party ranks as "loyal Democrats." He did it only a few hours after the Democratic National Committee had purged five States Righter members.

Sharp criticism of Mayor O'Dwyer's proposed plan for a survey on reclassification and wage adjustments for city employes was voiced yesterday by Jack Bigel, president of the New York District of the United Public Workers of America, CIO.

Two United States merchant seamen, who were returned here by air from France, were arraigned yesterday before United States Commissioner Edward E. Fay in Federal Court, Brooklyn, on a charge of cutting the mooring lines of their vessel.

LAKE SUCCESS, Aug. 24 -- In this century, for the first time, man is free of dependence upon his old natural environment for the food, clothing and shelter necessary for survival, according to experts who spoke today at the United Nations Scientific Conference on the Conservation and Utilization of Resources.

MOSCOW, Aug. 24 -- The Soviet press published today a vitriolic speech of Marshal Klementy Voroshilov, Deputy Premier and one of the Soviet Union's stanchest patriots and a close associate of Premier Stalin. He said "the camp of peace and democracy, with the Soviet Union at its head," will defend all peoples, including those of Yugoslavia, against "aggressive imperialistic forces."
Whatever middleweight championship dreams stout - hearted Steve Belloise entertained were hammered out of him last night at the Yankee Stadium.

LAKE SUCCESS, Aug. 24 -- New methods of conserving the world's limited supplies of irreplaceable natural resources as practiced in forty-four nations were discussed this morning during sectional meetings of the United Nations Scientific Conference on the Conservation and Utilization of Resources.

LAKE SUCCESS, Aug. 24 -- Malaria, once a feared killer in more than half of the villages of Greece, has been reduced to a "small" factor in the country's national health problem, the World Health Organization reported today.
The defense at the Communist trial yesterday charged anti-Communist bias on the part of Juror Russell Janney, theatrical producer and author of "The Miracle of the Bells," and asked for a mistrial.

LAUSANNE, Switzerland, Aug. 24 -- The United Nations Palestine Conciliation Commission decided today to send an economic survey mission to the Middle East "to study the economic situation in the countries affected by the recent hostilities."

CHICAGO, Aug. 24 (AP) -- Repeating his recent Washington Park Futurity victory, Mrs. Emil Denemark's slick bay colt, Curtice scored a three-quarters of a length triumph in the $28,550 Prairie State Stakes at Washington Park today.

BERLIN, Aug. 24 -- With the abolition of newspaper licensing in Bavaria, eighty or more frankly pro-Nazi newspapers will be founded in that state, long the most reactionary and anti-American in the United States zone, according to an official United States Military Government source.

There is something particularly satisfying in young Philip Mickman's success in entering the ranks of the swimming immortals by conquering the English Channel. For more than half of his eighteen years his country has either been in the front line of a desperate war or suffering the bitter hardships and privations that have resulted from that war.

Senator Warren G. Magnuson of Washington announced yesterday that a bipartisan group of twenty-four Senators had agreed to be sponsors with him of legislation authorizing $25,000,000 to give high quality repairs to a special emergency fleet of surplus ships.

Representatives of seafarer and longshoreman unions affiliated with the International Transport Workers Federation will meet in Rotterdam tommorow to discuss three issues now plaguing world maritime labor.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (UP) -- Federal tax collections in fiscal 1949 fell $1,401,417,277 short of the amount received the previous year, official figures showed tonight. Total income from taxes in the year ended last June 30 was $40,463,125,018, compared with $41,864,542,295 in fiscal 1948.

ROME, Aug. 24 -- Italian foreign policy is perhaps more directly linked with the fate of the new European Council at Strasbourg than is that of any other member state. The reason for this is that the Foreign Office has deliberately revised the fundamental philosophy of this country's role in the world.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 -- J. A. Krug, Secretary of the Interior, has designated Carlton Skinner, director of information in the Interior Department, as the first civilian governor of Guam, it was made known today.

This city will get an initial share of 20,300 dwelling units in eighteen projects for low-income families under the newly enacted Federal Housing Act, it was indicated yesterday. The Public Housing Administration in Washington announced it had signed "program reservations" of that amount for the city.
Residential properties constituted the sales reported yesterday in Queens and other sections of Long Island.

State-chartered banks in the United States and Hawaii added $201,618,000 to capital, surplus, undivided profits and capital reserves during the first half of this year, A. A. Rogers, president of the National Association of Supervisors of State Banks, reported yesterday.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 24 -- The Yugoslav Government is awaiting in a confident spirit Moscow's next move in the propaganda war. A physical reaction by the Soviet Government is discounted. It is believed the reaction may come in the form of a violent note or diplomatic maneuver.

CANTON, China, Thursday, Aug. 25 (AP) -- Chiang Kai-shek today blamed the "Communist International" for Nationalist China's woes and said Chungking "will again become the center for the fight against aggression."
STRASBOURG, France, Aug. 24 (UP) -- A powerful bloc of European Consultative Assembly members proposed today that a permanent European economic union be set up to prevent Europe's economic collapse.

HAMBURG, Germany, Aug. 24 (U.P.) -- Field Marshal Gen. Fritz Erich von Mannstein's defense attorney accused Russia today of having committed one of the seventeen war crimes for which the ailing Nazi was on trial -- using forced labor.

JERUSALEM, Aug. 24 -- The first archaeological discovery of modern times concerning the Samaritans was made known today by Prof. E. L. Sukenik of Hebrew University. Considered one of the most important finds in the Holy Land, it sheds new light on this strange cult about which little is known.
PINE CAMP, N. Y., Aug. 24 -- Metropolitan troops in training here heard praise today from Lieut. Gen. Walter Bedell Smith, Commander of the First Army, who watched the exercises.

With dress production lagging as a result of prolonged vacations, manufacturers are having difficulty in meeting the fall reorder demand, it was learned yesterday. A tight situation has developed also on many types of popular-price dresses, manufacturers said, where fabric supplies are not equal to the demand.

For construction of additional facilities at Queens General Hospital, a municipal institution, Federal funds of $1,341,667 -- one-third of the cost -- have been allocated, it was announced yesterday by the Hospital Council of Greater New York.

The Society to Encourage the Use of Blueberries in Blueberry Pie has just held its annual meeting. As always, the members approved unanimously the following: Resolved, That nothing tastes quite as good in blueberry pie as blueberries.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 -- An employe of the War Assets Administration, who said that Maj. Gen. Harry H. Vaughan, President Truman's military aide, got him his job, testified today at the "five percenter" inquiry that he made appointments for businessmen with James V. Hunt, Washington management counselor.
WINDSOR, Vt., Aug. 24 -- A murderer who owes his life to the pleading of Clarence Darrow, the attorney, twenty years ago, walked out of State Prison today on parole.

In your issue of Aug. 23 my name is mentioned by Edward A. Kracke, president of the New York State Society of Certified Public Accountants, in the midst of what appears to be a newspaper controversy in which he assumes to debate the law of the Bercu case with the distinguished lawyer, Julius Henry Cohen.

Bronzed and happy after vacations at Children's Aid Society camps, 118 boys and girls returned yesterday to the city and the fast approaching school year. Leaving their buses at the West Side Center, 419 West Thirty-eighth Street, the children proudly displayed the prizes, awards and strange pets they had garnered during their two weeks or more in up-state New York.

HONOLULU, Aug. 24 -- Prompt settlement of Hawaii's 116-day longshore strike was urged upon both the union and employers today by Federal Mediation Director Cyrus S. Ching as Harry Bridges, president of striking International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union, CIO, again canceled reservations for his return flight from San Francisco to Honolulu.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leadng cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, the following principal changes for the week ended Aug. 17:

More than half of the 600 families facing eviction on the lower East Side to make room for the Alfred E. Smith housing project will get apartments in the project as "site tenants," a committee of tenants was assured yesterday by the New York City Housing Authority.

MONTREAL, Aug. 24 (Canadian Press) -- The International Air Transport Association tomorrow will celebrate its thirtieth birthday, an anniversary described by Sir William P. Hildred, director general, as one of "international cooperation in air transport."
One man was killed and at least four other Californians were injured as forest fires blazed out of control last night in four states, Idaho. Montana, South Dakota and California.

ALBANY, Aug. 24 -- Reginald W. Case, 47 years old, president of the Central Businessmen's Association of Kingston, was arraigned in Albany Supreme Court today on charges of defrauding the state retirement fund of $6,093.

Manufacturers who sell to Army procurement offices reported here yesterday that there had been a sharp slowing down in the rate of new contract authorizations by district procurement officers in many branches.

CHICAGO, Aug. 25 -- Grains closed irregular on the Board of Trade today. Soybeans showed independent weakness, closing 3 1/4 to 4 cents a bushel lower than yesterday. Corn was unchanged to 7/8 cent higher; wheat 1/4 cent higher to 1 1/8 cents lower; oats, 1/4 to 1/2 cent lower, and rye, 1/4 to 3/4 cent lower. Lard declined 20 to 30 cents a 100 pounds.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange had a quiet session yesterday and final prices were unchanged to 11 points lower.

As a result of one bad tip on the horses five months ago, Carl Restivo, 31-year-old letter carrier and wounded veteran of Pacific fighting, is facing the possibility of a five-year jail sentence on a charge of stealing from the mails.
HAMBURG, Germany, Aug. 25 (UP) -- The chief prosecutor branded former Field Marshal Gen. Fritz Erich von Mannstein today as a ruthless criminal who had used Soviet war prisoners to clear mine fields.
The City of Denver, Col., announced yesterday that it will take bids Sept. 22 on $10,000,000 of general obligation water bonds.

LONDON, Aug. 25 -- Foreign Minister UE Maung of Burma, who conferred with Foreign Secretary Ernest Bevin on Monday and recently visited Washington, disclosed today that the United States, British and Burmese Governments had agreed to maintain close consultation on the advance of communism in southeast Asia.

The Lincoln Rug Company, through its subsidiary, the Springdale Realty Corporation, has acquired the one and two story building at Springdale Avenue and North Thirteenth Street in Newark and East Orange, N.J., formerly owned by Walter Kidde Co., and an adjoining half acre of land which it purchased by the Crocker Wheeler division of the Joshua Hendy Corporation. Emanuel L. Kamm was the broker.

Two University of Pennsylvania students who disappeared three weeks ago while cycling in Germany are being held as "hostages" by Soviet authorities for the return of three Russian Army deserters, it was disclosed yesterday.
LONDON, Aug. 25 (Reuters) -- Needing a victory to make sure of at least sharing the county cricket championship, Middlesex was held to 139 today, giving Derbyshire a first innings lead of 89.

The Maritime Commission will send its own technical experts abroad in the future to gather first-hand information on foreign shipbuilding costs on which American construction subsidies are based, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- The Administration retreated today, though more on form than on substance, before the Congressional forces trying to put help for Nationalist China into the predominantly European military aid program.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- The House, stung by the Senate's refusal to let it take a twenty-six day adjournment starting tomorrow, voted itself a holiday of that precise duration today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (AP) -- A House judiciary subcommittee today gave the Federal Government the chance to have the last spoken word at a hearing on who should control mineral wealth in submerged coastal lands.
BOSTON, Aug. 25 (AP) -- Lefty Ken Raffensberger's double and Lloyd Merriman's three-base drive to right center field in the tenth inning tonight gave the Reds a 4-3 victory over the Braves.

It is impossible for the average citizen to grasp all the intricate details of defense planning and defense spending. At some point he must repose his confidence in the judgment of specialists. But the citizen is vitally interested in two aspects of the problem. He wants to know that his defense is adequate and that it represents a dollar's worth of value for each dollar spent.
BUFFALO, N. Y., Aug. 25 (AP) -- A state mediator said today the issues involved in the ten-week-old Bell aircraft strike "do not seem insurmountable."

A pair of armed thieves dressed as delivery men entered the Bronx apartment of a jewelry merchant yesterday morning, but fled without any loot after a scuffle in which they fractured the skull of the merchant's wife.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Aug. 25 (AP) -- Favorite players in a crowd of 15,064 and the welfare fund of the Jockeys Guild were the gainers today when Silas A. Mason 2d's Westhampton coasted home to victory.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 25 (AP) -- Behind the eight-hit pitching of Robin Roberts, the Phillies defeated the Pirates, 4 -- 2, under the lights tonight after the Bucs won the afternoon game, 5 -- 1, with all their runs coming in the fifth inning.

Poliomyelitis cases here were up again yesterday for the fourth straight day, as fifty-seven new ones brought the year's total to 1,321 compared with 203 in 1948. The list of fatalities rose to 111 for the year with the addition of six deaths attributed to the disease.

Councilman Joseph T. Sharkey's latest rent control bill took a tongue-lashing yesterday at a public hearing at City Hall before the City Council's committee on general welfare. It was assailed by landlord and real estate groups as unconstitutional, unnecessary, "vicious'' and "political."

The New Haven Railroad went to some pains yesterday to point out that the Red Cap porter who eases your back strain by relieving you of your luggage doesn't in the slightest ease the figures in the railroad's deficit columns.
SEABRIGHT, N.J., Aug. 25 (AP) -- Two seeded players fell by the wayside today as the sixty-first Seabright Lawn Tennis and Cricket Club tourney moved into the quarter-final round.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 25 -- It's no longer cricket to refer to Greentree Stable's Doubtless II as "the 400,000-peso flop." For today, in the sixty-ninth running of the mile-and-six-furlong Saratoga Cup race, the Argentine Derby winner of 1947 led all the way to mark up his first victory north of the equator and shake loose from that unflattering tag.

THIS has been a remarkable week in the book world. After a summer in which good books were few indeed, more outstandingly good ones were published within a few days of each other than could be noticed in this space. Several, which may be just as good as those already discussed here, have been elbowed aside in the rush and will be considered next week.

The blue ambulance flashed out of the garage of the Manhattan Shelter of the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals. Minutes later Driver Peter Alvich stood on top of the ambulance under the girders of the El structure at Chatham Square.

"Soviet Gold: An Eyewitness Account by a Slave Laborer in the Siberian Mines," by Vladimir Petrov, will be published on Oct. 24 by Farrar, Straus. The author, an engineering student, recounts the story of his arrest, sentence to penal labor and life in the gold fields of Siberia.

LONDON, Aug. 25 -- President Truman's Point Four program to develop the world's backward areas may receive a major boost here tomorrow if current negotiations between Eugene Black, president of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development, and Lord Trefgarne, chairman of Britain's Colonial Development Corporation, are successfully concluded.

Prospects for passage of H.R. 4567, the bill to liberalize our present restrictive D.P. legislation, have brightened Although many pitfalls may still lie ahead, the action this week of the Majority Leader in moving to discharge the bill from the Judiciary Committee is as heartening as it is unusual.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- A pretty high school girl from a small town in South Dakota asked President Truman today whether she could have a job as Ambassador about five years hence. Her question succeeded in setting the Capital agog over the question whether Mr. Truman would run for another term in 1952.

I am altogether in accord with you that the Caribbean soldiers of fortune described by Harold B. Hinton should join the buccaneers of the romantic past evoked in your editorial "Ghosts Over the Caribbean" of Aug. 21. There most certainly should be no place for such mercenaries in today's world.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- President Truman made it plain today that the large-scale armed service employment cuts ordered yesterday by Louis Johnson, Secretary of Defense, were national policy, authorized by the White House.

Coat and suit designs of Elsa Schiaparelli, Parisian designer, will be manufactured in New York by a new concern called Schiaparelli Tailleurs, Inc., it was announced yesterday. Henry Mandelbaum, a New York manufacturer long known in the women's wear trade, will be associated with Mme. Schiaparelli in the enterprise which will have its showrooms and workshop at 498 Seventh Avenue.

Musical pageantry and folk dancing advocating friendship among the peoples of the world were the themes yesterday as 200 children presented a "One World Festival" at the Board of Education Center at Public School 101, 111th Street and Lexington Avenue.

BOSTON, Aug. 25 -- The minority recommendation of the Commission on Organization of the Executive Branch of the Government calling for abolition of the interior Department and creation of a Department of Natural Resources was endorsed tonight by Samuel J. Dana, dean of the University of Michigan's School of Forestry and Conservation.

BOWLING GREEN, Ohio, Aug. 25 -- Two hundred Christian students from twenty-eight countries considered today the possibility that neither Russia nor the United States has the answer in the struggle for world power.

Prices of brass ingots have been increased 1/2 cent a pound for all grades, custom smelters announced here yesterday. The price rise was attributed to a "correction of price levels" to reflect recent increases in scrap prices. Orders have been slow, refiners said, and no large increases in future business can be foreseen at this time, they added.
ALBANY, Aug. 25 -- Governor Dewey was requested today to order a state investigation of law enforcement in Republican-controlled Saratoga County.
CINCINNATI, Aug. 25 (AP) -Normal mail deliveries were being received at St. Mary's Hospital today, but not mall described by Federal postal authorities as involving a raffle.

Buying at the summer New York Gift Show, which entered its closing stages yesterday in the New Yorker and Statler Hotels, has been extremely brisk, both exhibitors and retailers say. Several exhibitors declared that orders received so far make the show a complete success for them whether or not more business is written up to 1 P.M. today when the event closes.

Oren Root, Republican-Fusion candidate for Borough President of Manhattan, announced yesterday that Robert P. Patterson, former Secretary of War, had consented to act as chairman of his campaign committee. Mr. Patterson, a former Federal judge, as president of the Bar Association of the City of New York and of Freedom House.

The two-story building at 109-03 Union Hall Street, Jamaica, Queens, containing a store and two apartments, has been purchased by Etta A. McClure from Isadore Rabinowitz. Rosetta B. Barker was the broker. Title was insured by the Title Guarantee and Trust Company.

MADISON, Wis., Aug. 25 -- Only "a very foolhardy program of the Government or Injudicious labor leadership" could lengthen the present period of economic readjustment and plunge the country into a serious depression, Henry H. Heimann, executive manager of the National Association of Credit Men, declared tonight.

The mystery of $111,000 worth of Dutch guilders that disappeared from a Hudson River pier in July, 1944, was partly solved last night with the arrest of a New Yorker who was trying to peddle some of the Dutch currency for one-tenth its face value.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- Department store sales in the week ended Aug. 20 were 7 per cent below sales in the corresponding week of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported tonight. The following lists percentage changes from like periods of 1948:

The issue of whether the state should provide financial aid to public libraries is so basic to the whole matter of the responsibility of local government that should like to comment on your Aug. 22 editorial on the subject, which was prompted by our recent editorial suggestion.

MILWAUKEE, Aug. 25 -- The question of Federal aid for the transportation of non-public school pupils exploded into bitter debate here today among the 500 delegates attending the American Federation of Teachers annual convention.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- During the week ended Aug. 24, member bank reserve balances decreased $587,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board announced today.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Aug. 25 -- The results of roundtable conference on Indonesia will determine the strength of the Communist party in the strategically located archipelago between the Indian and Pacific Oceans, two leaders of the Indonesian delegates to the conference declared today.

The urgent need for more modern facilities in marketing and distribution of agricultural produce will be a major problem to be studied at the annual convention of the National Association of Marketing Officers, it was announced yesterday following an organizational committee meeting in the New Yorker Hotel.

LAKE SUCCESS, Aug. 25 -- The United Nations Special Committee on the Balkans reported today that while Albania and Bulgaria had continued to supply arms and other assistance to the Greek guerrillas, aid from Yugoslavia "has diminished and may have ceased."

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 25 -- Mayor George E. Brunner of Camden, N.J., persuaded Philadelphia authorities today to release a constituent who had been in jail ten days for defiance of this city's 1 per cent wage tax.

While a Municipal Term Court antechamber took on the appearance of a circus yesterday, what with a host of photographers, reporters, witnesses and just curious bystanders watching the antics of two monkeys, the question of whether the animals were wild remained unsolved.

Directors of the Anaconda Copper Mining Company voted a 50-cent dividend yesterday for payment Sept. 29. This is 25 cents less than the payments made in March and June this year, bringing 1949 declarations to $2. In 1948 the company distributed a total of $3.50.
The $100,000,000 dollar-bond refunding operation which the Government of Canada timed to the easiest money market here in two years passed successfully through the marketing stage yesterday.

Stocks improved selectively in yesterday's trading and final prices were irregularly higher. Gains generally were small, with only a few running to a point or more. Reflecting heavy trading in the low-priced issues, sales expanded to 730,000 shares, compared with 720,000 on Wednesday.

GREENWICH, Conn. Aug. 25 -- Mrs. Donald C. O'Brien of Winged Foot scored her second victory of the season in women's Westchester-Fairfield Golf Association one-day competition by heading a field of fifty-eight at the Round Hill Club today with 40, 38 -- 78.
Negotiations that had been expected to go a long way toward settlement of the strike against the Triboro Coach Company in Queens broke down last night at 9:30 o'clock.

GARUT, Java, Aug. 25 -- Except for the area southeast of Bandung the situation in Western Java has improved considerably since the cease-fire order became effective on Aug. 10. The trouble areas around Tjikampek and Sukabumi are now quiet and all over Western Java the cease-fire order has been well observed.
The First Army honored yesterday the two "best" soldiers of the First Division, an occupation unit stationed in Germany.

Ray Robinson is in no hurry to surrender his world welterweight championship. This was revealed yesterday as the marvelous Harlem boxer discussed his ambition to emulate Mickey Walker and step as champion from the 147-pound to the 160-pound division.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Aug. 25 -- Elizabeth city officials and Union County authorities, including Prosecutor Edward Cohn, still believed low flying to be a problem requiring more study for eventual solution after they were taken aloft today on an observation flight sponsored by the Air Transport Association.

In a letter published on this page today George L. Nichols, representing a taxpayer organization, states the case against state aid to public libraries. "There are entirely too many small libraries," he says. There are about six hundred public libraries in New York State, which means one library for about 23,000 inhabitants, which does not seem excessive,
WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- A delay until next year was foreseen today on a bill to give New York State title to fifty-two acres at Manhattan Beach, Brooklyn, part of which would be made into a city park.

John J. Broderick, retired police detective, strengthened his chances yesterday in his fight to become the Tammany leader of the Times Square area. Through his attorney, Emil K. Ellis, Mr. Broderick was permitted to add the names of forty of his supporters to the Democratic County Committee slates for the Primary Day Election, Sept. 6.
Eagle-Lion now is in a position to make primary financing available to independent producers who will release their product through the company, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- President Truman undertook today to dispel the appearances of friction between the British and United States Governments prior to the monetary discussions to be held here, with Canadian participation, in two weeks.
CIUDAD TRUJILLO, Dominican Republic, Aug. 25 (AP) -- President Rafael L. Trujillo Molina's Government reported today that a state munitions plant had been set up in the Dominican Republic.

MOSCOW, Aug. 25 -- The Very Rev. Hewlett Johnson, Britain's Dean of Canterbury, told the cheering conference that he had been told by Premier Stalin that the greatest threat to the peace of the world might become the capitalist press.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (AP) -- Federal Judge Edward M. Curran heard arguments today on a petition by Colonial Airlines to forbid a Civil Aeronautics Board hearing on the application of Trans-Canada Air Lines for a permit to fly between New York and Montreal.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Aug. 25 (AP) -- Czechoslovak Communists accused the United States and Britain today of having tried to keep the Russian Army out of Western Europe by sabotaging the 1944 Slovak uprising against the Germans.

As definite as anything in the theatre can be is the premiere of "I Knox My Love," starring the Lunts, at the Shubert. The delayed Theatre Guild presentation of S. N. Behrman's variation from the French is now scheduled to arrive there Thursday night, Nov. 2. Stage favorites of long standing, the Lunts will be greeted in Boston the week of Oct. 10.
PORT JERVIS, N.Y., Aug. 25 -- Pine trees bloomed balloons at Camp Minisink today where Christmas has been celebrated in August for tile last fifteen years.

Responsive to firmer markets in London and Singapore, rubber futures were in active demand on the Commodity Exchange yesterday. Prices advanced 14 to 21 points. The market turned easier in late trading, and closing prices were at the lowest levels of the day.

WEST ORANGE, N.J., Aug. 25 -- Mrs. R.M. Torgerson of Cherry Valley, the Metropolitan and New York State champion, added another title today when she played alternate shots with her father, Judge Frank Adel of Oakland, to win the father-and-daughter championship over the Essex Fells Country Club course.

Your powerful editorial "State Aid to Libraries" in your issue for Aug. 22 is a crushing reply to the propaganda sent out by the organization in Albany which seeks to defeat in advance our efforts to secure adequate state for all the public libraries of New York. Your arguments are cogent and with editorial detachment you even under-state the case.
Harry Wennerholm has been appointed director of sales of the American Food Products Corporation, makers of Pref and Milko, powdered milks, and Maltina, chocolate malted milk powder.

PARIS, Aug. 25 -- In a note transmitted today to the eleven other signatories of the North Atlantic Defense Treaty, the French Government drew attention to the desire of the French Parliament and people that their Government should be represented on any defense boards created under Article 9 of the pact and that the United States should supply arms and equipment to enable the French Army to play its allotted role under the treaty.

LAKE SUCCESS, Aug. 25 -- Benjamin Gerig, United States representative, was elected chairman today of a special committee set up by the General Assembly to examine reports on conditions on sixty non-self-governing territories administered by United Nations members.

The nation's larger banks will be required to provide the United States Treasury with nearly $360,000,000 under a call on war loan accounts issued yesterday. The call, for 14 per cent of such deposits at the close of business on Aug. 24, is payable in two parts, half on Aug. 30 and half on Sept. 1.

RYE, N.Y., Aug. 25 -- The Winged Foot golf team followed a trend set in the past five years by winning the Hoffhine tournament at the Westchester Country Club course today for the sixth time. The aggregate score for the ten-man team, consisting of nine amateurs and the club pro. Claude Harmon, was 770.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (AP) -- The Government today removed a ban on private importing of tin Business concerns will be able to buy that metal outside the United States for the first time since Dec. 17, 1941 -- ten days after Pearl Harbor.

Extensive off-shore, oil drilling operations in the Gulf of Mexico have meant reprieve from the scrapyard for scores of former tank landing ships, according to a brochure issued yesterday by Langham, Langston Burnett, insurance counselors of Houston, Tex.

Although former Gov. Herbert H. Lehman, on vacation at Lake Placid, denied yesterday a published report that he had decided definitely to run for United States Senator at the November election, the impression prevailed in political circles that Mr. Lehman ultimately will decide to accept nomination by the Democratic and Liberal parties.

HELSINKI, Finland, Aug. 25 -- The next Communist strike move is expected to be a laydown order to metal workers, Finland's Labor Premier, Karl August Fagerholm, said at a press conference this afternoon. This would be a blow to the country's reparations deliveries to the Soviet Union and Finnish Communists hope in this way to cause trouble for the Government with Moscow, the Premier added.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- House investigators virtually ended a two-weeks' inquiry into the B-36 long-range bomber procurement program today with the unanimous finding that no evidence of corruption or political influence had been uncovered.
LAKE SUCCESS, Aug. 25 -- Dr. Ira N. Gabrielson, president of the Wildlife Management Institute, today attacked the Government's proposed program for development of the Columbia River area.

DETROIT, Aug. 25 (AP) -- Pitcher Virgil Trucks of the Detroit Tigers won his own ball game tonight when he singled home the winning run in the last of the ninth to top the Washington Senators, 2 to 1.
ALBANY, N.Y., Aug. 25 (AP) -- State and Federal representatives will examine "a lot" of welfare case records in New York City, a state official said today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- It is hard to distinguish "which twin has the Toni?" according to the Federa Trade Commission because the advertisements of the Toni Company of Chicago fail to disclose in their pictorial comparisons the fact that the coiffures of both twins were styled by a professional hair stylist.

Borough President John Cashmore of Brooklyn foresaw yesterday the time when edible oysters would flourish again in Jamaica Bay. Mr. Cashmore spoke before 250 persons gathered at Hendrix Street and Jamaica Bay, Brooklyn, for the laying of the cornerstone of the Twenty-Sixth Ward Sewage Treatment Works.

GREAT NECK, L.I., Aug. 25 -- Mrs. Clarissa Alden of 7 Highland Avenue, Thomaston, has sent a petition to the State Commissioner of Education demanding a recount of votes cast on July 26 at a special school district election that authorized the Board of Education of District 7 to spend $100,000 to convert the Henry Phipps Mansion into administrative offices for the school system.
CLINTON, N.Y., Aug. 25 (AP) -A member of Governor Dewey's Cabinet said today that the National Republican party was sick, malformed and freakish.
Two court attendants wheeled 20-year-old George Dei Toro into a court room in Kings County Court yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- Twice today President Truman clearly suggested that he would not be a Presidential candidate in 1952, but he implied with equal plainness that circumstances might cause him to alter this resolution.
CHICAGO, Aug. 25 (AP) -- The Chicago White Sox pushed the second place Boston Red Sox three full games behind New York's Yankees with an 8-3 victory before 24,018 persons tonight.

PARIS, Aug. 25 -- France will be represented at the Washington financial talks by Foreign Minister Robert Schuman, Finance Minister Maurice Petsche, Wilfrid Baumgartner, Governor of the Bank of France, and experts, who will include Guillaume Guindey of the Ministry of Finance and Herve Alphand of the Foreign Office.

HONOLULU, Aug. 25 -- More than 650 territorial Government stevedores worked on freighters in Hawaiian ports today as the territorial Attorney General's office defended Hawaii's new dock seizure and operation law in Federal Court.

CANTON, China, Aug. 25 (AP) -- The Communists were reported threatening points within 140 miles northeast of Canton tonight, but a Chinese Nationalist spokesman said they would not dare to go far because of Government gains on the western flank.

Metal traders and refiners here said yesterday that the easing of tin restrictions would insure improvement of the quality of soft metal compositions such as solders and tin-content babbitts, in which less than normal tin content has been used.

TRIESTE, Aug. 25 -- A survey of United States Army post exchanges in Europe indicates that while they certainly are more than adequately taking care of military and civilian personnel stationed abroad by the Government they also are providing considerable leakage of goods to black markets, are stocked with curiously useless articles and frequently are underselling local merchants in unfair competition.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (AP) -- Dr. Karl T. Compton said tonight that the United States is developing an "exceedingly important" guided missile which the B-36 can use to protect itself against speedy jet fighters.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Aug. 20, were 731,215 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 3,186 cars, or 0.4 per cent, more than for the preceding week, but 169,448 cars, or 18.8 per cent, fewer than for the corresponding week last year and 169,680 cars, or 18.8 per cent, fewer than for the corresponding week two years ago.

WESTBURY, L.I., Aug. 25 -- Proximity, the 7 year-old daughter of Protector who, many harness racing devotees claim is the greatest trotting mare of modern times, disappointed a huge legion of followers tonight when she finished second to Demon Hanover in the $50,000 Roosevelt two-mile trot at Roosevelt Raceway.

LONDON, Aug. 25 -- Britain's Treasury began today a campaign to effect economies in all Government departments. Meanwhile Harold Wilson, president of the Board of Trade, announced he had signed an order cutting the retail price of utility clothing, footwear and household textiles by 5 per cent as part of the campaign to reduce prices.

Walter L. Rothschild has purchased the seven-story building at 571 East 170th Street, northeast corner of Fulton Avenue, the Bronx, from Crotona Park Estates, Inc. The property, assessed at $205,000, contains seven stores and forty-seven apartments.

Frank Sedgman and Billy Sidwell, the choice instead of the veteran, John Bromwich, were named to play the singles for Australia as the draw was made yesterday for the Davis Cup challenge round, which starts today in the Forest Hills Stadium of the West Side Tennis Club.

"I Was a Male War Bride," a farce-comedy treatment of the true story of a French Army captain who married an American Wac lieutenant, will open today at the Roxy. Cary Grant and Ann Sheridan are co-starred in this Twentieth Century-Fox production, much of which was filmed in the American zone in occupied Germany. Howard Hawks directed.

Otis Brubaker, research director of the United Steelworkers of America, CIO, charged yesterday that the steel industry had presented an overly gloomy picture of profit prospects to the Presidential fact-finding board.

Prof. A.I. Lavorsen of Stanford, a geologist who has played his part in making petroleum surveys for the Government, imparted at Lake Success this week the cheerful news that though known world oil reserves amount to only 70 billion barrels -- hardly enough for more than twenty years at the present rate of consumption -- there is an undiscovered 500-year supply.

The case of James Montgomery, who, as reported in the press, was convicted of a crime he did not commit, and served twenty-six years in prison before his innocence was judicially declared, is not only shocking but actually terrifying. The question to enter the mind of the thoughtful person is, If such can happen, who is safe ?

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 25 -- In a front-page editorial today, Borba, official newspaper of the Yugoslav Communist party, declared that the Soviet Government was seeking pretexts to envenom the quarrel with Yugoslavia and was basing its campaign on a calculation that the isolated leaders of this country would not receive support from the outside in their hour of trial.

Sister Elizabeth Kenny, originator of a method of treating poliomyelitis, declared yesterday that if a true knowledge of her method were available to the medical world, recoveries from the disease would be increased at least 10 per cent.

WITH THE GREEK ARMY in the Grammos Area, Aug. 25 -- A new battle for the Grammos Mountain area, major fastness of the Communist-led rebels, was in full swing today. Five National Army divisions are in the offensive and most of them were already engaged.

Secretary of Labor Maurice J. Tobin paid tribute last night to Harry C. Bates, president of the Bricklayers, Masons and Plasterers Union, AFL, as "the modern sparkplug of housing," and declared that "Mr. Bates and the American Federation of Labor are making it possible for the average American to own his own home."

MONTAUK, L.I., Aug. 25 -- Although the off-shore fishing here is usually productive, the surf-casters are not too happy at the striped bass situation and many are waiting until next month when the run of big bass is scheduled to make an appearance.

ANNECY, France, Aug. 25 -- Completion of the United States tariff negotiations with Italy today virtually ended the work of the thirty-four-nation tariff conference that has been sitting here since early April.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Aug. 25 -- Provisions of a bill to be introduced to the State Legislature at a special session in the fall to ease gambling laws to permit games of chance at bazaars and carnivals for the benefit of fraternal, benevolent and church groups were outlined today by State Senator Milton J. Herman, who is drafting the measure.

LONDON, Aug. 25 (Reuters) -- Peter Brooke, 24-year-old production director of London's Covent Garden Opera House, said on his arrival here by air last night that he had been robbed by "armed anarchists" on a desolate road along the Spanish coast on Tuesday.

A new system of transmitting television in full color, eliminating virtually all of the major technical and economic problems that have delayed a change-over from the present black-and-white pictures, was announced yesterday by the Radio Corporation of America.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 25 -- Borden Chase is writing a photo-play about the Philippine Islands under the title "Far Island," as a vehicle for James Cagney, to be produced by William Cagney this fall for United Artists release, it was learned today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (AP) -- Legislation allowing a large expansion of the Government's experimental crop-insurance program was signed today by President Truman.

Jay Thorpe's selection of French millinery, which was shown to the press yesterday afternoon in the store's hat salon, wividly crystallized the style characteristics of the designers represented. In style the hats were practically all small and head-hugging.

LANSING, Mich., Aug. 25 (AP) -- The suicide of a former state employe led today to a disclosure that state auditors were checking the "improper" sale of Federal surplus property through a state agency.

With all tenants now safely removed from a deteriorating four-and-a-half-story brick building that almost collapsed two weeks ago, demolition of the Washington Square South block owned by New York University will be resumed Monday morning, it was learned yesterday.

STRASBOURG, France, Aug. 25 (U.P.) -- Paul-Henri Spaak of Belgium suggested today that one way of achieving European unity would be to quit criticizing the British Labor Government's economic policies.

DON'T look now, but the football season begins tonight. The Buffalo Bills and the Chicago Hornets formally will open the campaign in the All-America Conference which had virtually agreed to absorption by the National Football League last December and then backed away with surprising celerity at the last moment. So the pro war continues for another year and it's quite customary to add that this will positively be the last year.
MOSCOW, Aug. 25 (UP) -- An all-Russian "Conference of Peace Partisans" opened today to the accompaniment of explosive press attacks on the United States and individual Americans.

If Britain devalues sterling, South Africa will follow suit and will benefit by obtaining more pounds in the sale of its gold to the United States Treasury, according to views expressed yesterday by Richard Kulze, international lawyer and counsel of the international trade committee of the New York Board of Trade.

The Cardinals and the Giants each made four hits last night, but an important difference in the quality of their blows gave the Redbirds a 5-2 triumph before a Polo Grounds crowd of 26,375 that stretched their first-place lead over the Dodgers to one and a half games.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- Maj. Gen. Harry H. Vaughan, President Truman's military aide, obtained permission for his friend, John Maragon, to visit restricted areas in Europe a few months after "V-E" Day in 1945 by telling the State Department that the President was "personally interested" in the trip, it was disclosed today at the "five percenter" inquiry.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- The Senate Banking and Currency Committee will consider extending its hearings on alleged union labor monopoly, it was announced today by Senator A. Willis Robertson Democrat, of Virginia.

FRANKFORT, Aug. 25 (AP) -- Bizonal Germany's imports and exports climbed to a new post-war high in July. Joint Export-Import Agency (JEIA) officials said today that imports totaled $240,000,000, an increase of more than 45 per cent over June.

LONDON, Au. 25 -- Fresh gains in British Government funds and in industrial shares gave the stock markets a brighter appearance here today. Small but persistent buying of gilt-edge issues lifted these stocks by as much as 7/8 point all around.
HONG KONG, Aug. 25 -- A pilot of a Chinese Nationalist airline stole a plane from under the noses of Canton airfield personnel this morning and flew off, presumably to Communist Shanghai.

Six foreign syphilologists who are making a six-week tour of venereal disease clinics in the United States for the World Health Organization visited the rapid treatment center at Bellevue Hospital yesterday afternoon.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (UP) -- Representative Emanuel Celler, Democrat, of New York, revealed today that military intelligence chiefs had requested a provision in the displaced persons bill to admit 15,000 refugees farm Iron Curtain nations to the United States.

Fourteen of the thirty-three meat cuts checked yesterday by the consumers' service division of the City Department of Markets showed price increases over last week-end. They ranged from 2 to 7 cents a pound.
LARCHMONT, N.Y., Aug. 25 -- A dish of real rhubarb prevented today's conclusion of the Snipe Class international event at the Larchmont Yacht Club.

Opposing the scrap trade's effort to have export quotas on scrap removed, the steel industry's authority on the material, Robert W. Wolcott, president of the Lukens Steel Company, asserted yesterday that "there is no surplus of scrap existing in the United States which we can dissipate throughout the world."

LAKE SUCCESS, Aug. 25 -- Federal agencies now charting an expenditure of five billion dollars for the development of the Missouri River Basin have based their plans on not more than one-tenth of the "fundamentally needed basic data," a United States official told the United Nations Scientific Conference on the Conservation and Utilization of Resources here today.
TOKYO, Aug. 25 -- Almost revolutionary changes in Japan's tax system have been recommended by the mission headed by Dr. Carl S. Shoup of Columbia University.

CHICAGO, Aug. 25 -- The Essaness Theatres Corporation and nine subsidiaries, the 32 Randolph Corporation and two individuals today filed suit in Federal District Court charging twelve motion-picture producing, distributing and theatre companies and two individuals with monopolistic practices and asking $25,867,000 damages.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Aug. 25 -- The eleven Ministers-President of Western Germany, meeting in the French zone city of Coblenz today, formally decided to convene the new Federal Republic's first parliamentary bodies Sept. 7.

Reflecting a decline in its sales, the net profit reported yesterday by the International Paper Company and its subsidiaries for the first six months of this year declined to $24,649,329 from $28,556,437 earned in the initial half of 1948.

Eleven warships of a "hunter-killer" group, accompanied by three submarines that have been participating with them in training maneuvers, will enter New York harbor this morning for a three-day liberty stay.
Two boyhood friends left La Guardia Airport yesterday on a Trans World Airlines plane, bound for a photographic safari in the Belgian Congo, Kenya, Tanganyika and Uganda.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 25 -- The parents of Peter H. Sellers expressed themselves tonight as "very much relieved" to receive word that their 18-year-old son had been located after a two-week search.

The achievements of the European Recovery Program during its first year, and the problems that must still be solved before the goals of that Program are attained, are presented to the nation and the world in a sober report issued by the Economic Cooperation Administration.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (UP) -- Senator Brien McMahon, Democrat of Connecticut, chairman of the Congressional Atomic Energy Committee, tonight formally closed the three-month-old investigation of charges of "incredible mismanagement'' by the Atomic Energy Commission.

MIAMI, Fla., Aug. 25 -- Three veterans of World War II were elected unanimously today to the leading offices of the Veterans of Foreign Wars, thereby placing direction of the fifty-year-old organization in the hands of its youngest soldier group.

The American Natural Gas Company, which serves large sections of Michigan and Wisconsin with natural gas, reported yesterday that consolidated net income for the twelve months to June 30 amounted to $4,839,573, equal to $1.63 on each of the 2,767,581 common shares, compared with $2,185,862, or 50 cents a share, in the preceding twelve-month period.

SHANGHAI, Aug. 24 -- Under the heading "Private Life of Employes Comes Under Control," the newspaper Ta Kung Pao today told of the code of austerity regulations governing employes in the state-owned Central Electrical Equipment Factory here.

Federated Department Stores, Inc., in the year ended on July 30, set a dollar sales volume record for a single year, Fred Lazarus Jr., president, reported today. Net sales of $358,574,741 compared with $321,965,225 for the previous year.

The luxurious comforts of a bloated overstuffed sofa have been surprisingly combined with well-groomed, neat, almost delicate lines in a group of tailored upholstered pieces designed by Harold Bartos for the Lehigh Furniture Corporation.

Directors of the Shell Union Oil Corporation approved yesterday a plan for simplification of capital through which all assets of the Shell Oil Company, Inc., a wholly owned operating subsidiary, would be acquired as of Sept. 30.

The testimony submitted to the Presidential Fact-Finding Board regarding the wage and other demands of labor against the United States Steel Corporation is pretty nearly all in. A mass of arguments and data has been presented on the broader aspects of the situation.

Business loans made by banks in this area declined $7,000,000 during the week ended on Wednesday, breaking the upward trend of the two previous weeks. Total business borrowings from the twenty-five reporting New York City member banks now stand at $4,540,000,000, according to the data issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

Approximately $36,000,000 has been contributed to date by New Yorkers toward the 1949 drive of the United Jewish Appeal, it was reported yesterday at a luncheon meeting of 500 community leaders at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
MIAMI, Fla., Aug. 25 (AP) -- Hurricane warnings were hoisted at midnight for South Florida from Vero Beach to include the Greater Miami area.

Subway riders' ardent expectancy for improved comfort with the addition of new subway cars has not materialized. The new cars on the Independent System run smoother, it is true, but they have a much larger "squeeze-in" capacity without increased seating facilities.

The NBC radio network plans a full-scale "Night of Music" each Monday evening this fall after an announcement yesterday that "The Railroad Hour," which features operettas and musical comedies, will switch from ABC on Oct. 3. The program, starring Gordon MacRae and guest singers, will be heard from 8 to 8:30 P.M.

The Grand Army of the Republic will relight its campfires next week. It will relight them, but there will be a difference. This is to be the last encampment. The years have played their mischief. The ranks have thinned away.
After Johnny Schmitz had whitewashed them, 4-0, in the opener, the Dodgers were happy to settle for a split in their twin bill with the Cubs at Ebbets Field yesterday.
CLEVELAND, Aug. 25 -- Big Jawn Mize injected his broad back into the American League flag race tonight.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 25 -- The historic Hollywood Hotel, at Highland Avenue and Hollywood Boulevard, will fall to the wrecking crew soon after catering to famous stars of stage and screen for more than a quarter century.
John G. Broady, private investigator, ended yesterday in General Sessions three days of testimony in his own defense against charges of grand larceny and illegal wiretapping.
EAST ORANGE, N. J., Aug. 25 -- The United States Department of Agriculture counted itself the victor today in another summer's battle against the Japanese beetle.
LONDON, Aug. 25 (Reuters) -- British European Airways has opened negotiations for the purchase of a number of Vickers Viscount propeller-jet airliners.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- A trial examiner of the National Labor Relations Board ruled today for the first time that unions with observers following vehicles of an employer listed as "unfair" were violating the Taft-Hartley Law.
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 25 (AP) -- The Athletics hit the jackpot in two big innings to score a 9-to-5 victory over the last-place Browns in a slow, loosely played game tonight.

VANDALIA, Ohio, Aug. 25 (AP) -- Ohmer Webb, 41-year-old trucking contractor of Washington, D.C., today won the preliminary handicap at the Golden Grand American Trapshoot with a perfect score of 100 from nineteen yards.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (UP) -- The Government today added twenty-two critical employment areas to the ten named last month, but said it did not mean necessarily that unemployment was worse.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- A trial examiner of the National Labor Relations Board ruled today for the first time that unions with observers following vehicles of an employer listed as "unfair" were violating the Taft-Hartley Law.
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 25 (AP) -- The Athletics hit the jackpot in two big innings to score a 9-to-5 victory over the last-place Browns in a slow, loosely played game tonight.

VANDALIA, Ohio, Aug. 25 (AP) -- Ohmer Webb, 41-year-old trucking contractor of Washington, D.C., today won the preliminary handicap at the Golden Grand American Trapshoot with a perfect score of 100 from nineteen yards.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (UP) -- The Government today added twenty-two critical employment areas to the ten named last month, but said it did not mean necessarily that unemployment was worse.

After denying defense motions for a mistrial and disqualification of a juror accused of bias in the Communist trial, Federal Judge Harold R. Medina took steps yesterday that revealed an investigation has begun into the possibility of jury-tampering. He impounded part of the defense motion papers in the bias action, and directed that none of the papers be removed from the files without his order.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Aug. 25 -- The relief organizations caring for Palestine Arab refugees appear to have been informed that they can expect a Middle Eastern resettlement and development organization under United Nations auspices to take over by next April 1.

A score of men last night tilted a forty-two-ton subway car several inches, permitting the liberation of a 21-year-old girl whose leg had been pinned between the car and the southbound platform of the 161st Street-River Avenue Station of the Lexington-Woodlawn route of the IRT in the Bronx, police of the Sedgwick Avenue Station reported.

VERSAILLES, France, Aug. 26 -- The military reservation of Satory on the outskirts of suburban Versailles, once the parade ground for the cadets of Saint Cyr, is being turned into France's major center for the development of tanks and armored vehicles by the Armaments Command of the French Army.

These have been disturbing days, over which we shall probably be heartily ashamed before we have gone much farther on our way. In some areas there has been sought the exaction of oaths from teachers in our schools, and particularly from those engaged in instruction in our institutions of higher education -- oaths disclaiming belief in communism, or avowing loyalty to our country and its way of life.

Philip Murray, president of the United Steelworkers, CIO, made an impassioned plea for pensions yesterday before the Presidential fact-finding board in the United States Court House and declared that neither he nor the union would rest until the steel industry acknowledged its "just debt to those who have spent their lives in its service.''

BOSTON, Aug. 26 (AP) --Al Dark's two-out single in the ninth drove in a pair of runs that gave the Boston Braves a 3-2 victory over the Cincinnati Reds tonight before 12,426 fans. That frame was the only troublesome spot Johnny Vander Meer, the Reds veteran left hander, encountered while totaling eight strikeouts and giving up as many hits.

Burton and Mae Sloane won a sixty-mile-an-hour race with the stork early yesterday, but they couldn't best a couple of New York's Finest. The policemen, after leading them safely on the last lap -- at fifty miles an hour -- gave Mr. Sloane a ticket for speeding.

HONOLULU, Aug. 26 -- Another effort to settle the wage dispute in Hawaii's 118-day longshore strike appeared in the offing today as Harry Bridges, president of the striking International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union, CIO, left San Francisco by plane to return to Honolulu.

It was in 1904. The trustee of the Educational Alliance in the Lower East Side, the country's largest settlement house, looked down his nose at the young redhead with the eager blue eyes. She was applying for the position of director of women's and children's activities there.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- The cost of living dropped 0.6 per cent last month and a business survey indicates an optimistic prospect for the national economy. The Cabinet was informed of these developments today at its regular Friday morning conference with President Truman.

Buying of motors and some selected issues in the last hour kept the stock market yesterday on a fairly stable basis. Price movements, however, were mostly small and only a relatively few stocks fluctuated as much as a point either way. Final price changes were mixed.

CHICAGO, Aug. 27 -- A drastic decline in the price of old-crop soybeans started liquidation by holders of futures on the Board of Trade today and at one time the November position was off 7 3/4 cents a bushel, showing 15 cents under the high on Monday, which wiped out all of the advance made in the previous week.

PINE CAMP, N. Y., Aug. 26 -Two weeks of intensive exercises ended here today for the Seventy-seventh Infantry Division, Maj. Gen. Julius Ochs Adler commanding, while Gen. B. A. Burns' Forty-second Infantry Division, New York National Guard, held a division review.

Hardly had images appeared on the television screen in black and white than we began to wonder when we would behold them in color. The wondering was accompanied by some misgivings. Would we have to discard our old black-and-white sets for new and more expensive ones that would keep us abreast of the polychromatic times?
WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- The Administration forces in the Senate began an urgent effort today to save the $1,450,000,000 foreign military aid program from any cut at all.

A lightweight portable sewing machine now being made in the United States is capable of darning socks, sewing on tubular jersey, making buttonholes and doing embroidery. It lifts out of a small case just as a typewriter does and when closed looks like an ordinary leatherette overnight bag.

PARIS, Aug. 26 -- Premier Marshal Tito's conflict with Moscow and the Communist Information Bureau is fast developing into Europe's foremost problem in the opinion of Mrs. Ruth Fischer, who is in Paris bound for New York.

Four armed men invaued the office of American Stevedores, Inc., 73 Carroll Street, Brooklyn, shortly before 1 P. M. yesterday and escaped with two canvas bags and a steel cashbox containing between $6,100 and $9,000.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N. Y., Aug. 26 -- Jim Dieckelman, a 5-foot-10-inch 197-pound end from Holy Cross, continued today to be one of the outstanding players on the Eastern College All-Star squad practicing for the eleventh annual Fresh Air Fund game.

The property at 441 to 451 West Thirty-third Street with an outlet abutting on the south side of Thirty-fourth Street, near Tenth Avenue, passed from the control of Leo Kossove and another yesterday, when title was taken by the Dobb Realty Corporation of 342 Madison Avenue.

James Imbrie, Progressive party candidate for Governor of New Jersey, resigned yesterday from the "National Non-Partisan Committee for the Defense of the Rights of the Twelve Communists" in protest against organized attempts to influence Federal Judge Harold R. Medina in his rulings.

Leonard B. Steven has purchased the one-family dwelling at 13 Watson Avenue, Ossining, N. Y., from Family Homes, Inc., for cash above a mortgage of $9,400 held by the Industrial Bank of Commerce. Inter-County Title Guaranty and Mortgage Company insured the title for the bank.

MILWAUKEE, Aug. 26 -- After two hours of heated debate delegates representing the 60,000 members of the American Federation of Teachers, AFL, voted here today that membership in the Communist party was not sufficient reason to discharge a teacher.

New processes in creating fabrics have put weavers into the fashion spotlight this year. Texture, taking on pattern and design, has emphasized the handsome heavy silks and silk types which were popular in the Twenties. Women who shop for ready-to-wear fashions, as well as those who make their own, will find ribbed fabrics like ottomans, brocades and modern tweed-like weaves.

TOKYO, Aug. 20 -- The Japanese are up in arms over the latest of a series of railroad accidents that have cost a score of lives in the last few months and which, investigations have shown, have generally been caused by sabotage along the tracks.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Aug. 26 -- President Klement Gottwald and his wife, Marta, accompanied by important members of the Government, moved to Slovakia by special train today for the two-day observance of the fifth anniversary of the Slovak uprising against the Nazis.

MADISON, Wis., Aug. 26 -- Senator Clinton P. Anderson, Democrat, of New Mexico, warned American farmers today that they could not postpone a day of reckoning under a system of high, rigid Federal support prices for farm products in the face of mounting surpluses.

Stressing the importance of United States citizenship to the inhabitants of Guam, B. J. Bordallo, president of the Council of Guam, hailed yesterday as a good omen the recent appointment of Carleton Skinner as first civilian governor of the Pacific protectorate.

Some fabulous tales of bass, pike and muskie fishing have been emerging from the backwoods of Ontario this season, but as neither ice nor a reliable set of scales are available in many of these places, some of the weight estimates run on the optimistic side.

CHICAGO, Aug. 26 (AP) -- Robert Lippincott of West Jersey, N. J., turned in a brilliant job of sailing against strong Lake Michigan winds today to win the fourth race of the twenty-seventh international Star Class yachting championship series.

RANGOON, Burma, Aug. 26 (AP) -- Embassy officials of five nations set out today on a flying diplomatic mission intended to rescue 12,000 foreigners trapped by civil war battles in rebel-held Taunggyi.
TITUSVILLE, Pa., Aug. 26 (AP) -- The country's first oil well is ready to spout "black gold" again, but this time the flow will be "borrowed" petroleum.
By air and sea, the Coast Guard rushed a specialist and heavy equipment yesterday from New York to save the life of a youth seriously ill of poliomyelitis aboard the Cunard liner's Parthia.

With considerably less hullabaloo than attended their initiation two Congressional investigations have been closed. The House Armed Services Committee has unanimously reported that there is no evidence whatever of corruption or the use of political influence in the B-36 bomber procurement program.

The recent coup in Syria is a murder mystery that reverses the standard plot. The reader knows "whodunit" but nothing of the motives behind the crime. Not a word has come out of Damascus or the neighboring capitals that tells why Colonel Husni Zayim was suddenly liquidated or who engineered the plot against him.

LONDON, Aug. 26 -- Eugene R. Black, president of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development, said here today that he favored granting a $10,000,000 loan to Britain for colonial development in line with President Truman's Point Four program to assist the world's backward areas.

With a golden opportunity to move within a half-game of the league-leading Cardinals merely by beating the cellar-dwelling Cubs before 22,711 fans under the Ebbets Field lights last night, the Dodgers dismally blew the Duke by a 4-2 score and remained where they were yesterday morning -- a game and a half off the pace, with two games in the important loss column.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- John F. Maragon, personal friend of Maj. Gen. Harry H. Vaughan, President Truman's military aide, claimed constitutional rights and refused to answer some questions at the "five percenter" inquiry today on the ground that his answers "might tend to incriminate" him.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Aug. 26 (AP) -- Two pilots were killed yesterday when their planes collided in the air near Mayport during carrier practice landings. They were Lieut. (jg) Richard Spaulding Hodson of Jacksonville and Lieut. (jg) John Joseph Glynn Jr. of 400 East Fifty-seventh Street, New York City.
OTTAWA, Aug. 26 -- Canada had a favorable trade balance of $29,100,000 with all countries in the first six months of 1949, the Federal Statistics Bureau reported today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 (AP) -- The petroleum industry went hunting today for statistics on the effect which oil imports might be having on the domestic economy. It did so at the request of Secretary of the Interior Julius A. Krug. Mr. Krug also has asked the industry's opinion as to the amount of domestic productive capacity that should be kept in reserve for an emergency.

In October, Crown will publish a reference book for writers, teachers, librarians, students and ordinary readers. "Thesaurus of Book Digests" will contain synopses of 2,000 of the world's permanent and classic writings of all time and of all languages, from the "Code of Hammurabi" to "The Death of a Salesman."

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 26 -- The RKO Studio here confirmed reports emanating from Rome today of a dispute between the company and Roberto Rossellini, who has just completed direction of "Stromboli" for RKO in Italy with Ingrid Bergman as the star.
TRENTON, N. J., Aug. 26 (AP) -New Jersey projects, particularly the Newark Airport, will be rushed by the Port of New York Authority.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- Tighe E. Woods, Federal Housing Expediter, said today that a critical housing situation still exists in the New York metropolitan area and that no consideration for lifting the present rent control ceilings there is contemplated by the housing office.

SEOUL, Korea, Aug. 26 -- Real progress toward union of North and South Korea along the lines envisaged by the United Nations is impossible unless the United States and Russia attempt to settle their differences, according to the United Nations Commission on Korea.
CHICAGO, Aug. 26 -- The Billiard Congress of America today officially approved changing the standard size pocket billiard table from 5 by 10 feet to 4 1/2 by 9 feet.

Manufacturers here yesterday welcomed the action of the Department of Commerce releasing tin for use in the manufacture of costume jewelry. Use of the metal in this industry has been banned following the entrance of the United States into the war in 1941.

SEABRIGHT, N. J., Aug. 26 (AP) -- Cornell's Dick Savitt came from behind to upset Tulane's Jack Tuero today in the quarter-final round of the sixty-first annual Sea-bright Lawn Tennis and Cricket Club tournament 3 -- 6, 6 -- 3, 6 -- 0.

Election of Stephen A. McDonald as president and a director of the Joseph P. Day Florida Realty Corporation, with main offices in Miami, was announced yesterday by Bernard P. Day, president of Joseph P. Day, Inc.

The ice cream vendor on the wharf at New Dock Street in Brooklyn "had a feeling something was wrong" yesterday afternoon.
