One thousand children with their mothers were passing up his wares after a day's harbor cruise. They had just come off the Lloyd I. Seaman, floating hospital ship of the St. John's Guild, 1 East Forty-second Street, Manhattan.

Emergency service provided by the city on the strikebound lines of the Triboro Coach Company in Queens was sharply curtailed yesterday as the walkout passed its third stalemated day. There were no negotiations yesterday and none scheduled for the week-end.
STOCKHOLM, Aug. 26 (AP) -- Fortune Gordien, University of Minnesota star, uncorked another great discus throw today in international competition, this time for 184 feet 1 31/64 inches.

REHOVOTH, Israel, Aug. 26 -- A city of science, with the Weizmann Institute as its nucleus, is being planned here among the fertile hillocks of Rehovoth, where scientific history has been made during the past five years. The institute will officially be dedicated Nov. 2 while, at the same time, a $15,000,000 endowment fund campaign will be launched.
ROME, Aug. 26 -- The persistent drought has forced authorities in Northern Italy to ban the use of electricity three days a week beginning Sept. 5.

Fall advertising of Oakite Products, Inc., with the bulk of the campaign scheduled for 305 newspapers, will emphasize more direct explanatory copy on the many household uses for the cleansing product, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- President Truman indicated today that this country would back up any United Nations program for the rehabilitation of the Middle East with the contemplated Point Four plan to help undeveloped countries. He hailed Gordon R. Clapp as a "distinguished American," who would carry out the United Nations Near East survey in "a comparatively short time."

The Ingersoll - Rand Company had a net income of $4,783,528 in the quarter ended on June 30, according to a preliminary report issued yesterday. This is equivalent to $2.36 a share on the outstanding common stock and compares with a net income of $4,305,132, or $2.12 a share, in the corresponding period of last year.

CAMDEN, N. J., Aug. 26 -- A 23-year-old Portuguese stowaway, Alberto Lopes of Oporto, told United States District Judge Thomas M. Madden today he would sooner die than be deported. Lopes collapsed when he was arraigned in Federal Court on a charge of illegal entry.

CHICAGO, Aug. 26 (AP) -- The renovated Chicago Hornets defeated the Buffalo Bills, 17 -- 14, on Jim McCarthy's 21-yard field goal in the closing minutes of an All-America Conference season opener before 23,800 at Soldier Field tonight.

Florists' shops have been displaying dahlias for more than a month but these late summer flowers are just starting to open in gardens. Dahlias reach their peak in this area in September and so will be more plentiful as cut flowers during the next five weeks.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- Average primary market prices remained unchanged in the week ending Aug. 23, according to the United States Department of Labor's Bureau of Labor Statistics.

Cooler weather continued to aid retail trade here last week. Better interest shown in back-to-school apparel and accessories, home furnishings and furs. Department store sales were estimated at about 10 per cent below the corresponding week a year ago.

This week marked the thirtieth anniversary of international cooperation in air transport. Since the first International Air Transport Association meeting was held at The Hague on Aug. 25, 1919, progress of incredible proportions has been made in the aviation world.
MIAMI, Fla., Aug. 26 -- A great hurricane pounded the heart of Florida tonight after smashing the southeast "Gold Coast" with 150-mile-an-hour winds.
CHICAGO, Aug. 26 (AP) -- The Boston Red Sox powered thirty-three hits, nine for extra bases, to sweep a double-header from the Chicago White Sox, 11 -- 4 and 10 -- 7, before 19,647 fans today.

Hide futures prices went into a slump in trading on the Commodity Exchange yesterday. The market closed 27 to 44 points off from Thursday's final quotations. Prices held fairly firm, slightly up until the middle of the day, when they started sliding under the pressure of commission-house and trade selling.

TOKYO, Aug. 26 -- A demand that the Government press the occupation to permit Japanese to play a greater role in their own foreign trade has been presented by the Business Managers Association of Japan. The body declared that trade was being throttled by rules and restrictions that prevent normal competition.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- The Senate speeded its operations today to clean up the long pending appropriations bills on its calendar, cutting in the process the House provision for the Air Force by $222,000,000 in cash and $578,000,000 in authorizations.

The Government of Panama has named two special emissaries to go to Rotterdam to discuss the threatened maritime labor boycott with leaders of the International Transport Workers Federation, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 (AP) -President Frank Stanton of Columbia Broadcasting System today estimated that the cost of a color converter for a black-and-white television set would be $75 "on a mass production basis."

The slight rise in coffee prices expected Monday continues a trend apparent for some time. A year ago, according to a leading chain, a pound averaged 42.6 cents and six months ago 43.2 cents. Today it's about 44.2 cents.
LARCHMONT, N. Y., Aug. 26 -- World champion skipper of the Snipe Internationals is Ted Wells of Wichita, Kan., whose home port is a thirst-quenching dam for Santa Fe Railroad locomotives.

ALBANY, Aug. 26 -- The State Banking Department announced today that the Corn Exchange Bank Trust Company, 13 William Street, New York, has been authorized to open a branch office at 1242 Second Avenue. The Corn Exchange Safe Deposit Company was authorized similarly to open a branch office there.

In equatorial Liberia today an expedition of American scientists is probing into the life, habits and idiosyncrasies of the Strophanthus sarmentosus. This expedition has special significance for the 7,000,000 Americans who suffer from arthritis. High have been their hopes for ultimate relief or cure since the discovery of Compound E by Drs. Hench and Kendall of the Mayo Clinic was first reported in this newspaper on April 20, 1949, by Mr. W. L. Laurence.

EASTVIEW, N. Y., Aug. 26 -Hector L. Villoria, 40 years old, of 3103 Fairview Avenue, the Bronx, was held in Westchester County jail here today in default of $7,500 bail. He was accused of stealing more than $10,000 from Burroughs Wellcome Co., Inc., Scarsdale Road, Tuckahoe, manufacturing chemists, of which he was traffic manager at $100 a week.

MASERU, Basutoland, Aug. 26 -- In a high court here today one death sentence, five sentences of two years at hard labor and ten acquittals closed what the presiding judge described as the "most astounding case heard in a civilized court in this twentieth century."

July cancellations of dealer furniture orders amounted to only 3 per cent of new business booked by manufacturers, according to the monthly report issued yesterday by Seidman Seidman, accountants for many leading furniture factories.

SHANGHAI, Aug. 26 -- Communist China is building a "people's navy" and a "people's air force" with which to attack Formosa. The capture or neutralization of that island is essential to the effective breaking of the air and sea blockade of China's coast.

LAKE SUCCESS, Aug. 26 -- The world stands on the threshold of a bountiful new era based upon the wisdom of the ages, the skills of the present and the science of the future, it was empha sized here today at the United Nations Scientific Conference on the Conservation and Utilization Resources.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 (UP) -- Almost $100,000 has been laid out to date in the House investigation of now discredited charges against the Air Force and B-36 bomber program, it was revealed today.

Minneapolis, Minn., announced yesterday that it would receive bids Sept. 8 on issues totaling $4,600,000, including $2,200,000 of school and library certificates, $1,500,000 of refunding bonds and $900,000 of relief obligations. The indebtedness will come due Oct. 1, from 1950 to 1969.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange fluctuated within a narrow range yesterday and closed 1 to 8 points lower than the day before.
NORTHEAST, Md., Aug. 26 (AP) Twenty cars of a long, fast freight train of the Pennsylvania Railroad piled up early today, shooting blazing oil down the main street of a residential district.

GLENS FALLS, N. Y., Aug. 26 -- Several new officers of the Glens Falls Insurance Company, the Glens Falls Indemnity Company, the Commerce Insurance Company and the Glens Falls Corporation were elected today at the quarterly meeting of the boards of directors of the "Glens Falls group" at the home offices, in this city.

At least fifty small burglaries in mid-Manhattan and Bronx rooming houses was solved last night with the arrests of two young men and a 20-year-old girl, police of the West Fifty-fourth Street station said.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- Ezra Van Horn, operators' trustee on the United Mine Workers Welfare and Retirement Fund, told a Senate Banking subcommittee today that the facts about the fund he needed to carry on his duties were refused him.
Senator Antonio Bermudez, Mexico's negotiator for an official $203,000,000 oil development loan, believes that United States oil interests blocked it, Dr. Samuel Guy Inman asserted yesterday.

The Paris Theatre has been forced, due to the success of its current attraction, the French "Devil in the Flesh," to relinquish its booking commitment on the Rossellini film, "Germany Year Zero." The Paris management signed a contract last December with Superfilm Distributing Corporation to show the picture by Oct. 1.
LONDON, Aug. 26 (Reuters) -- Middlesex gained a three-wicket victory over Derbyshire on its famed Lords ground today, clinching at least a share in the county cricket championship this year.

LAKE SUCCESS, Aug. 26 -- Colorado is down to its last twenty-six bears, England's deer are having a tough time of it, and some of Sweden's foxes are running around with practically no fur on their backs.

I am no financier. In spite of a college course in elementary economics, what I don't know about international high finance would fill the Sunday edition of THE NEW YORK TIMES. However, I do believe that sometimes a common sense approach by a layman to this or any other complicated problem proves useful; at any rate, it furnishes a basis for general discussion.
Immediately following the Spanish-American War, under the guidance of Senator Elihu Root the Cuban people were given their independence, under the name of the "Cuban Republic."

LAKE SUCCESS, Aug. 26 -- Secretary General Trygve Lie today appointed Gordon R. Clapp, chairman of the board of directors of the Tennessee Valley Authority, to head a United Nations survey of the economic problems involved in finding homes for Palestine Arab refugees.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- The Federal Trade Commission in a complaint issued today charged the Dolcin Corporation of New York with false and misleading advertising of their medicinal preparation, designated Dolcin, sales of which totaled more than $1,000,000 in 1948.

A refreshing point of view on the parking problem in cities is presented in a newly published booklet by the Chamber of Commerce. The chamber's special committee on urban transportation proceeded on the premise that "solution to the downtown off-street parking problem rested with business men and property owners involved because they have the most to gain or lose by what is done to keep customers coming to their stores and buildings."

ALBANY, Aug. 26 -- (AP) -- Six retired Utica city employes today denied cheating the state of about $17,000 in disability pensions. Three former firemen, including a deputy chief, and three pensioned policemen pleaded innocent to charges of grand larceny and fraud.

MIAMI, Fla., Aug. 26 -- The Veterans of Foreign Wars approved today a resolution "endorsing the principle" of military aid to member-nations of the North Atlantic pact to help "resist attack from any countries unfriendly to them and the principles they have promised to defend."

Beset by financial difficulties that may curtail activities for the coming season, New Stages, Inc., the downtown producing group which successfully brought "The Respectful Prostitute" to Broadway, will hold a meeting of its board members on Sept. 7 to consider ways of overcoming the various problems.

The second annual assembly of the National Jewish Youth Conference, organized last autumn at Camp Wel-Met, Narrowsburg, N. Y., will be held there from next Friday morning through the following Friday afternoon. A dinner win be held at 7 P. M. on the opening day.

The first presentation of the new $1,000 Precision Scientific Company Award in Petroleum Chemistry will be made on Sept. 19 to Dr. Bruce H. Sage, Professor of Chemical Engineering at the California Institute of Technology, at the national meeting of the American Chemical Society in Atlantic City, N. J., it was announced yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 26 -- The American Legion is to be headed for the first time by a World War II veteran, it was indicated today as delegates gathered here for the organization's thirty-first annual convention.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- Twelve men were hurled into the lashing frigid water, but six of them were picked up, officials revealed as the first bare details of the disaster began to arrive this afternoon.

Sales of copper, tin and lead have been affected adversely by three aspects of national affairs, metal industry spokesmen declared here yesterday. Users are worried about possibilities of strikes cutting back coal, steel and copper production.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 26 (AP) -- Raul Machado, chief statistician of the National Coffee Bureau, reported today that Brazil's exportable coffee crop this year would be about 14 per cent under that of 1948.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- The Air Force today cut back its strength by six aircraft groups, including one light bomber and three day fighter groups, to conform to the defense economy program set forth Wednesday by Louis Johnson. Secretary of Defense.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- United States representatives at the forthcoming monetary talks with British Government officials, due to start here Sept. 7, will be limited to the framework of existing national economic foreign policy.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- The Civil Aeronautics Board was restrained today from proceeding with the granting of a permit to Trans-Canada Airlines to fly the New York-Montreal route until litigation brought by Colonial Airlines is heard by a three-judge court here.

ARGOS, Greece, Aug. 26 (AP) -- Greek Army commandos captured three important heights in the Grammos offensive today. The heights taken are along the northeastern edge of the Communist-led guerrillas' last important stronghold in the mountains on the Albanian border.

PEEKSKILL, N. Y., Aug. 26 -- Protests that "inflamatory statements" in a Peekskill newspaper and a threatened demonstration by veterans might "inspire illegal action and violence against a peacefully conducted concert" by Paul Robeson here tomorrow night were telegraphed today to Westchester County Executive Herbert C. Gerlach and to the office of District Attorney George M. Fanelli, at White Plains.

From the crowded cities of Europe, from the brush country of Africa, from places like Sarawak, Gambia and Truk come the visiting students to this country. During the last college year there were 24,800. And they differ from the visiting business man, the refugee, the sightseer.

SEOUL, Korea, Aug. 26 -- President Syngman Rhee served notice today that the South Koreans were tiring rapidly of the "passive" role as a buffer between Communist totalitarianism and Western democracy.
TRENTON, N. J., Aug. 26 (AP) -- Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll decided today to turn over to New York three New Jersey men accused of participating in a $50,000,000 numbers ring swindle.

LAKE SUCCESS, Aug. 26 -- The Department of the Interior is studying the possibilities of using power from the sun and may ask Congress to supply funds for large-scale research, Secretary Julius A. Krug disclosed here today.
The defense for John G. Broady, private investigator charged with grand larceny and illegal wiretapping, ended presentation of its case in General Sessions yesterday.

The value of Strasbourg as a rallying point and organization center for the forces making for European unity is enhanced rather than diminished by the day-to-day discussions of the Consultative Assembly. These debates lack the dramatic flourish of the opening sessions of the first Council of Europe, but as the delegates settle down to business they are not afraid to tackle fundamental issues.

SEA CLIFF, L. I., Aug. 26 -- Joseph Allen Physioc, 83-year-old artist who, at the age of 27, designed the scenery for Bernard Shaw's "Arms and the Man" for Richard Mansfield at the old Herald Square Theatre, is staging a one-man art exhibit at the Sea Cliff Art Center.

Members of the tin committee of the Commodity Exchange yesterday were giving close study to the Government's modification of controls on trade in that metal. Hans A. Vogelstein, committee chairman, said the committee will have to give considerable attention to the Government order before deciding whether or not futures trading in tin will be possible.

LONDON, Aug. 26 -- Paul G. Hoffman, Economic Cooperation Administrator, left London by air tonight for the Washington conference on Britain's dwindling foreign exchange with a valedictory of advice to the British to cut costs and try harder to sell in the United States market.

Without the benefit of Leo Durocher's managing, Freddy Fitzsimmons' coaching, Wes Westrum's catching and Hank Behrman's jockeying from the dugout, the Giants turned the tables on the league-leading Cardinals yesterday at the Polo Grounds.
DETROIT, Aug. 26 (AP) -- The Tigers fattened up their batting averages today as they slammed out 18 hits while walloping the luckless Washington Senators, 11 -- 1.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Aug. 26 -Delegates from thirteen states and the District of Columbia attending a conference on alcoholism here today voted to establish a national organization of alcohol commission executives.

ROME, Aug. 26 -- The Foreign Ministry has instructed its diplomatic representatives in Belgrade and in the capitals of other powers that signed the Italian peace treaty to protest against what was described in Rome as a "wave of arrests and expulsions" of Italians in Zone B, or the Yugoslav zone of the Trieste Free Territory.

CHICAGO, Aug. 26 -- The moral qualities of post-war motion pictures have hit an all-time low on the basis of records compiled by the Legion of Decency, the Rev. Patrick J. Masterson, executive secretary of the Legion, reported today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- Representative John D. Dingell of Michigan, third-ranking Democratic member of the House Ways and Means Committee, moved today for consideration in November of the reduction of Federal wartime excise taxes on furs, jewelry, luggage, cosmetics and other items classed as luxuries by the tax laws.

ELIZABETH JANEWAY'S "The Question of Gregory"* is the second novel in the last few days to describe the plight of a promising Washington liberal and officeholder beset by misfortune. Merle Miller's befuddled, young bureaucrat in "The Sure Thing" was the other. Both Miss Janeway and Mr. Miller have some provocative things to say and suggest about Washington, "where the politics come from" (Miss Janeway's phrase).
The Federal Communications Commission's ban on give-away shows is to be the subject of two discussion programs on television next week.

An upswing in the dress business has encouraged manufacturers to resist the pressure of large buying combines for extra discounts, it was said yesterday. Some manufacturers, it was said, had considered giving an extra 2 per cent in addition to the regular 8 per cent off.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 26 -- Fighting grimly to buck a tide which in the past few weeks has been sweeping them away from their second successive pennant, Lou Boudreau's Indians tonight turned violently upon their arch foes, the front running Yankees.
BALTIMORE, Aug. 26 (AP) -- The first court test was begun here today on the "regional compact" arrangement to keep Negroes out of state universities in the South.

The City Planning Commission adopted yesterday a resolution calling for an amendment to the city's zoning regulations to control landing facilities of aircraft. It would regulate the heigh of buildings in and around public and private airports.

VANDALIA, Ohio, Aug. 26 (AP) -- In one of the most thrilling finishes the fifty-year-old classic has witnessed, Pete Donat, 31-year-old farmer from Antwerp, Ohio, today fired an ordinary field gun to victory in the Golden Grand American Handicap trapshoot.

The four-story building at 85-89 Seventh Avenue, corner of Union Street, Brooklyn, containing five stores and eighteen apartments, has been sold by McLaren Properties, Inc., to a customer of the John Pullman Real Estate Company, broker in the transaction.
Permit me to answer briefly the letter of Alfred Kohlberg which you published Aug. 19 and which he wrote in reply to my own letter of Aug. 10.
LAKE GEORGE, N. Y., Aug. 26 (AP) -- Mrs. Rose Weiss of Saratoga Springs lost the first round today in her court fight to close three alleged gambling places in Saratoga County.

LONDON, Aug. 26 -- Further improvement in British Government funds was the feature in otherwise quiet stock markets here today. A small volume of institutional buying of medium and short-dated stocks was reported, and further bear covering in long-dated issues also was seen.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Aug. 26 -- The Rev. Alfred Barrett, chairman of the Journalism Division of Fordham University, has been named executive secretary of the Catholic Press Association of the United States and editor of The Catholic Journalist, it was announced here by the Rev. Paul Bussard, editor of The Catholic Digest and president of the Catholic Press Association.
ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Aug. 26 (AP) -- Arthur J. Sackett's Gasparilla found the course here to his liking today and galloped home an easy winner of the featured Linwood Purse.

The revised settlement worked out in 1946 to swell the stake of holders of Mexican railroad bonds that went into default in 1914 still lacks effectiveness because less than the required 55 per cent of the bondholders have concurred, but the matter will not be left there, it was learned yesterday.

FREEHOLD, N. J., Aug. 26 -- Pupils of the Freehold Migrant School, held to be the only one of its type in the nation, put on a closing-day program today, including singing of the Twenty-Third Psalm. Most of the children, who range in age from 3 to 13, are from the South.

BAR HARBOR, Me., Aug. 26 -Dr. Leslie C. Dunn, head of the genetics department of Columbia University, has been named president of the new board of scientific directors of the Roscoe B. Jackson Memorial Laboratory here, it was announced today.

Eric Johnston, president of the Motion Picture Association of America, Inc., yesterday reiterated his personal determination to fight for freedom of speech on the screen in response to an appeal from Louis de Rochemont, producer of "Lost Boundaries," for industry support in fighting the banning of the picture in Memphis, Tenn., and Atlanta.

BERLIN, Aug. 26 -- Admissions that anti-Communist activity is widespread in the Soviet zone and that the economic position there is far behind that in Western Germany are the first results of a careful inventory that the Soviet Military Administration is making of its position in Germany.

The strongest opposition Australia has offered in a Davis Cup challenge round since the postwar revival of the international tennis matches in 1946 came to nought yesterday as the United States won the opening two singles in the Forest Hills Stadium.
MIAMI, Fla., Saturday, Aug. 27 (AP) -- Late reports of hurricane damage in Florida follow:

Isaac Evans, 68-year-old Cleveland industrialist who believes in the principle that action is more effective than words in cementing international good-will, came to town yesterday and accomplished another successful mission.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 26 -- The Belgrade radio tonight quoted the "Free Greek" rebel radio as saying, "Better to surrender to the monarcho-fascists (Athens) than to the Yugoslavs."
BELLE GLADE, Fla., Aug. 26 (AP) -- We have been through a real hurricane, and there isn't anyone in these parts who has any doubts about it.

Manhattan Borough President Hugo Rogers asked the City Planning Commission yesterday to approve an expenditure of $760,000 to repair extensive damage to the West Side Highway caused by the use of salt to remove snow.

TRIESTE, Aug. 26 -- Despite the increasing intensity of the nerve war between the Soviet Union and Yugoslavia, there has not been stirred up sufficient alarm about the possibility or actual open conflict to cause the taking of any special military dispositions or other security steps by United States and British troops in the neighboring Free Territory of Trieste.

RICHMOND, Va., Aug. 26 (AP) -Mrs. J. L. Blair Buck, president of the General Federation of Women's Clubs, said today that volunteer social welfare work is claiming the greatest energies of women around the world.
Dealer orders for bedding are increasing more than seasonally, manufacturers reported yesterday.

Construction of the Norwegian America Line's new flagship, the 16,500-ton Oslofjord, is entering its final stages at Amsterdam, Holland, Christian J. Mohn, vice president and general manager of the line in this country, reported yesterday. He returned with his family aboard the Stavangerfjord from a two-month visit to Norway.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 26 (AP) -Ralph Kiner's thirty-sixth homer of the season, a mighty blast on the roof of the left field stands in the third inning, gave the Pittsburgh Pirates a 3-2 victory over the Philadelphia Phillies tonight.

MOSCOW, Aug. 26 -- Metropolitan Nikolai, speaking in behalf of the Russian Orthodox Church, denounced Pope Pius XII before the all-Union peace conference tonight as an "anti-Christian" and "agent of American imperialism."

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 26 -- Robert W. Grant's front-running Sun Bath took his third successive stake of the meeting today when he won the $11,075 Saratoga Steeplechase by close to a sixteenth of a mile. There were four starters and three finishers, the third one jogging in for the $1,000 show award after having been remounted following a spill.

Some Southern bedroom and dining room furniture factories turning out low-end merchandise have notified their local wholesale representatives that they will accept no more retail orders at current prices until the minimum wage controversy is settled, it was learned yesterday.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 26 (AP) -- Two home runs by Stan Spence, good for five runs, helped the Browns beat the Athletics tonight, 11 to 3. The victory enabled the Browns to vacate the American League cellar in favor of the Senators, who lost to Detroit.

HAMMERSFEST, Norway, Saturday, Aug. 27 (UP) -- Commander Worthington said today that the rescue of the seventy-eight crew members from the Cochino was "one of the most dangerous jobs" in his naval experience. He said the Cochino had sunk in thirty minutes after a series of explosions gutted her battery room.
CANTON, China, Aug. 26 (AP) -- The Communist capture of positions within 140 miles northeast of Canton was acknowledged tonight by a Chinese Nationalist army spokesman.

HELSINKI, Finland, Aug. 26 -- A noisy crowd of striking longshoremen paraded through Helsinki's main avenues this afternoon brandishing red banners and singing the Internationale. However, it was a small group and no incidents took place.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 26 -- The United States Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals affirmed restoration of citizenship today to three Japanese-Americans who had renounced it during their incarceration in wartime evacuation centers.

While an official investigation continued into the possibility of jury-tampering and obstruction of justice at the Communist trial, Communists and sympathizers picketed the Federal Court House yesterday as the jurors left for the day.
OSLO, Norway, Aug. 26 -- The United States submarine Cochino exploded, burned and sank in Artic waters early today.

A dispute between shipping operators and Local 33 of the Marine Engineers Beneficial Association, CIO, over interpretations of a contract, is developing serious proportions even though the national office of the union has taken sides with the operators.

On the bright days of high summer, we live less in our houses than out of doors, where the roof is likely to be the kindly boughs of a shade tree. In garden or backyard, guarding the doorway or whispering outside the window, such a tree is a family friend. If it goes in a gale, or from great age, we feel the loss of a faithful companion.

An elderly astrologer, encountered one night last week behind the Public Library in Bryant Park nursing a rusty pair of binoculars, complained rather sadly that the stars of stage and screen greatly interfered with his business of studying the stars in the heavens.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 27 -- Retail business activity continued on the upsurge this week with sales for the entire district registering the smallest loss in recent weeks. The preliminary report of the Twelfth Federal Reserve District for July shows a 14 per cent slide under last year for department stores and a 12 per cent loss during the same period for apparel stores.

IN her first novel Maggy Gould has attacked an extremely interesting problem. She has written a horror story about a man with a curse upon him and set it against a modern, cushy background of the Riviera, London, New York and California. A neat trick is that the reader is invited to consider the case as either a psychopathic condition or a bona fide curse.

THE recently disclosed details of two developments in aviation that may result in the greatest advances in commercial air transportation since its inception have started endless discussion in flying circles. The developments are the flight characteristics of the DeHaviland Comet, the first commercial jet airliner, and the new technique for refueling aircraft at high altitudes where aerial "tankers" are expected to have little trouble making contact with airliners.

WITH THE GREEK ARMY, in the Grammos Area, Aug. 27 (AP) -- A bitter battle raged today for Flambouri heights, eleven miles west of Nestorion, where elements of two guerrilla regiments from Vitsi fought to keep open an escape route through the Baroukas River valley to Albania.

Two players who had been suing baseball and one who had been contemplating suit have decided to drop all legal action, it was announced yesterday. The three, Max Lanier and Fred Martin of the Cardinals, and Sal Maghe of the Giants, were among those who jumped to the Mexican League in 1946 and, earlier this year, were reinstated by Commissioner A. B. Chandler.

The Dodgers crushed the Cubs, 6 to 1, scoring all their runs in the sixth inning yesterday but slipped another half game out of first place as the Cards swept a twin bill with the Giants, 5 to 2 and 11 -- 2. The Cards now lead the National League by two lengths.

THE effect of sudden blindness upon a young man is the theme of this English novel. So convincingly does the author describe the situation that if the book jacket did not state otherwise, this reader would believe it to be a true and personal experience.

Columbia University's School of Business will move this fall alongside the Harvard Graduate School of Business Administration as one of the nation's leading centers of business research and education for management.
THE new buyer of a small home is faced with the problem of building a lawn this fall. All too often, it is a real problem, for in the process of building the house, the topsoil has disappeared.

SAGINAW, Mich., Aug. 27 -- "Chiseling" of welfare food by some of Saginaw's wealthiest citizens was charged today by Circuit Judge Herman Dehnke, one man-grand jury, as he issued warrants accusing two persons of embezzlement of public housing funds.
A special House of Representatives group that will study displaced persons problems with an eye to revising this government's legislation sailed yesterday aboard the Queen Mary for Europe.

Alarm bells have been ringing on both sides of the ocean as the Washington conference between the United States, Great Britain and Canada approaches. The "technical and fact- finding discussions" which began yesterday at the State Department may narrow the area of controversy.

THE relationship between Brett Halliday and his private detective, Michael Shayne, was probably best expressed recently by a somewhat baffled girl who had married into the mystery profession. "Brett," she said with awe, "is what Mike Shayne would like to be."

CHICAGO, Aug. 27 -- Scientists will beam rays from a 22,000,000volt machine into a 72-year-old cancer patient Monday in the first experiment with the high-powered instrument to fight deep-seated cancer.

FOR several years two of Margaret Millar's novels -- "Wall of Eyes" and "The Iron Gates" -- have stood high among suspense novels of the "psychological thriller" variety. Her new book, while similar to these two in many ways, gives wider scope to her talent for exploring the emotional lives of a group of characters than the thriller form permits.

TO the biographer, literary or pubUc figures are generally more inviting than composers. From the wealth of books, correspondence, articles and notes a comprehensive portrait of the writer can emerge. Since words are his raison d'etre, it is through them that the most intimate and subtle details of his personality are revealed.

BELGRADE, Aug. 27 -- There are certain inescapable factors in the physical and political structure of Yugoslavia and of the other "People's Democracies" which create almost insuperable obstacles to anyone seeking to reach what is called public opinion in the West.

"MIRACLE AT CARDENRIGG" is an extremely interesting attempt to blend two traditions, or perhaps one should say, to apply the technique of the realistic novel to religious fiction. is writing of a small Scottish mining town in the Twenties.

TOKYO, Aug. 17 -- The Chinese Communists are making extensive use of Japanese prisoners of war in North China and have adopted a policy of refusing them repatriation "until the revolution in China and Japan is complete," the Japanese home population is being informed by men who recently have escaped from the Communist area.

Unaided by safaris, native guides or Baedekers, a group of City College students here completed recently a survey of little-known peoples who for centuries have been tucked away in the remote comers of the world. And the students did not have to brave the jungle-locked fastnesses of Indonesia to find the Javanese or scale the mountains of Navarre to speak to the Basques.

The farmers of the country, we have long maintained, know far more about what is good for them than do those members of Congress who count as lost any session which doesn't produce some new kind of farm subsidy or some new formula for raising farm prices.

JERUSALEM, Aug. 27 -- A $100,000 archaeological expedition is being planned here to investigate the mass suicide that took place at Massada, on the Dead Sea, in 70 A.D. There, 960 Jews who had fled Jerusalem after the fall of the Temple killed themselves, rather than be captured by the Romans.

"THIS book," writes Mr. Coyle, "is mainly about the meaning and purpose of our destiny -- our adventure in freedoms." Again: "This book is an attempt to consolidate some of the knowledge we have thus far gained that seems to indicate the main lines of progress which will be most desirable for us to pursue."

BOOKS like these, uninviting as their subject must seem to the general reader, are rewarding and instructive to anyone who recognizes (and who does not?) that labor strife is a threat to society. Strikes, crises, picket-line violence, emergency decrees -- all the phenomena of labor warfare -- create the impression that we are unmitigatedly going from bad to worse.

IT is the good fortune of the harried citizens of our complex civilization that a talented echelon, ranging in membership from Boy Scouts to cancer specialists, always has been willing to lend a hand to the less gifted and the more confused.

ELIZABETH, N. J., Aug. 27 -- International Printing Ink's new plant, the largest building erected here in two decades, has begun production, Charles R. Rietz, manager, announced today. Full-scale operation is expected in October, Mr. Rietz said.

LONDON, Aug. 27 -- Some Progress has been made toward a compromise of the Anglo-United States dollar problem as a result of this week's frank and sometimes acid conversations between United States and British officials.

Scandinavian countries are hungry for American materials and their lack of dollars conversely matches the need for goods, Robert C. Lee, executive vice president of Moore-McCormack Lines, declared yesterday.

THE Kingdom team of the Border Baseball League was trailing the leader by the trifling margin of thirty-one games early this month. So the manager resigned "in the best interests of the club." The news item hardly would be worth noticing were it not for the fact that the manager happened to be a large and perfectly delightful character named Henry John Bonura, better known as Zeke.

Although the Federal Government so far has limited its price-support activities almost entirely to agricultural products there is a determined movement reportedly backed by the Administration to extend these to other fields. Last week the Senate Interior and Insular Affairs Committee unanimously approved a measure that among other things would set a minimum and maximum price the Government would pay for metals or minerals.

CHICAGO, Aug. 27 (AP) -- The Boston Red Sox combined the efforts of Ted Williams, Vern Stephens and Chuck Stobbs for a 7-2 victory over the Chicago White Sox today to remain a game and a half behind the pace-making New York Yankees.
The feud that the domestic steel industry conducted in the 1930's with one of its principal suppliers, the scrap-metal trade, over the latter's ambitious export program has just been renewed.

THE Master Sergeant strolled along the Tempelhof Airport ramp. The M.P. took a horrified look at him, swallowed hard and called out: "Hey, Sarge, just a minute." This was polite talk for an M.P., but then he was stopping a Master Sergeant.

SEABRIGHT, N.J., Aug. 27 (AP) -- Earl Cochell of San Francisco and Giovanni Cucelli of Italy, two fleet-footed, hard-hitting players, today gained the final round of the sixty-first Seabright Lawn Tennis and Cricket Club invitation tourney.

Typical of the trend among many large companies in the face of current increasingly competitive conditions, A. M. Karagheusian, Inc., manufacturer of Gulistan carpets, has set up a sales training program, with one of its oldest and most experienced salesmen in charge.

I have read with interest the article "Conservation of World's Resources" published in THE NEW YORK TIMES on Aug. 21. I should like to direct your attention to a topic not covered in this article but placed on the program of the meetings of the United Nations Scientific Conference on the Conservation and Utilization of Resources (UNSCCUR), namely, the corrosion and protection of metals.

In one of the gamest uphill fights that over electrified a tennis gathering. John Bromwich and Billy Sidwell did the seemingly impossible yesterday to defeat William Talbert and Gardner Mulloy and keep alive Australia's Davis Cup hopes in the challenge round at Forest Hills.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 -- The countries of the Near East have reacted very favorably to the United Nations' economic survey mission that will be headed by Gordon R. Clapp, a State Department official said today.

IN New York, during the past twenty years, not one single "legitimate" theatre has been built. One by one, the playhouses of the world's largest city vanish and are not replaced. Throughout the rest of the country, meantime, the number of modern buildings, public and private, adequately equipped and suitably constructed for theatrical performances, has grown yearly.

THE absence of television from the Ray Robinson-Steve Belloise bout in Yankee Stadium last Wednesday night renewed the question of whether or not boxing promoters will continue to bar video in the future.

LONDON, Aug. 27 -- Since the United States terminated Lend-lease soon after the conclusion of the war, Britain has received about $7 billion in grants and loans to help her restore her shattered economy. That is a vast amount of money, yet recovery is not in sight.

NEW YORKERS, who have already spent their accumulated vacation time for this summer but who are looking for one and two-day excursions to keep them happy while their friends are still on holiday, can find plenty of opportunities in the historic mountains that rise northwest of the city and stretch back into the middle of this state.

A new type of walk-in cooler made of Armorply, a thin sheet of metal adhesively bonded to plywood, was announced yesterday by the United States Plywood Corporation, with offices at 55 West Forty-fourth Street. A model of the new cooler will be on display at the company's offices this week, it was announced by J.J. Dunne, vice president.

TO see "A Night in Spain," formerly known as "Cabalgata," is to realize that art is a much finer medium of human expression than politics. For a number of years our political relations with Spain have been bitter and sullen.

Three years ago the first radioactive isotopes were shipped from the atomic "furnace" at Oak Ridge National Laboratory to researchers in the United States. On the third anniversary the Isotopes Division of the Atomic Energy Commission announces that up to Aug. 2 there were 7,613 shipments, plus 750 of separated nonradioactive stable isotopes.

PROVIDENCE, R.I. -- Petty thieves who have harvested as much as $30,000 in a year from fraternity houses and domitories at Brown University here, according to Dr. Henry M. Wriston, president, will find things harder in the future.

WASHINGTON. WHEN President Truman named Charles F. Brannan Secretary of Agriculture late in May, 1948, the most generous reaction was that Mr. Truman had given the Government career service another nice shot in the arm. A man who had served the department faithfully for thirteen years and who had climbed the ladder from a $3,700-a-year farm resettlement attorney in Denver, had earned a fitting reward in Washington.

There must have been many persons who read Gov. Chester Bowles' "A Governor's Job as Seen by a Governor" who believed that his word concerning the so-called "rotten borough" system in the Connecticut General Assembly was the final and correct one.

IN addition to their brilliant color and song, birds serve the more practical purpose of feeding on certain destructive insects in the garden. If only for this reason, they are worth luring with food and drink, as well as appropriate nesting sites.

FACING the darkened room from behind the grand piano, she might be a movie star faking a performance. Her level eyes inspect her circle of admirers, A faint smile hovers on her oval, smooth face. Her head is nearly motionless, but her shoulders move gently as she plays.

HAS history a meaning? If so, what is it? For centuries the question has been raised by the thoughtful and answered often and variously. Seldom, if ever, has the query been as insistent as in our day, and solutions of all sorts are offered.

WHILE many alpine plants may be grown from seed, some are slow to sprout. Such varieties usually benefit from fall planting and the action of winter freezing. At this time, too, cuttings may be made for the rock garden from plants like Phlox subulata which are reluctant to produce seed.
HONG KONG, Aug. 27 -- Nationalist resistance to the Communist conquest of China stiffened on two important fronts this week, in Central China and the Northwest.

THE convergence of Fred Zinnemann, director of "The Search," Stanley Kramer, producer of "Champion" and "Home of the Brave," and Marlon Brando, Broadway star of "A Streetcar Named Desire," for a new project, "The Men," may logically be viewed as an auspicious Hollywood event.

For three weeks a parade of witnesses before a Congressional committee -- Government officials, Army officers, business men -- has held the center of attention in Washington and in much of the nation. The witnesses have told stories of alleged misuse of influence in high places in Washington.

THIS summer has been hot and dry enough to burn up the best of lawns. But a lot of that grass is not dead even though it looks it. Then again, much of the grass is, and this is the time to do something about it.

THE present volume is unmistakably a Lincoln book, yet it is not a book about Lincoln. From start to finish it is actually what the title indicates -- a book about Lincoln's Vandalia, the town to which he went when first elected to the Illinois Legislature.
Oliver Roddey Jr., of Charlotte, N.C., was the first player to gain a place in the main draw of the National tennis championships in the preliminary rounds played at Forest Hills yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 -- Diplomatic warnings from American and other sources in the Far East indicated the possibility as early as 1933 that Japanese aggression and preparations for war were directed at the United States, the State Department revealed today.

There was no help for the Dodgers forthcoming yesterday from the Polo Grounds, where the Giants engaged the Cardinals twice before 28,878 fans. The runner-up Brooks doubtless were hoping for at least one victory by the Giants over the league leaders but Leo Durocher's men, much as they would like to help themselves, even more than the Dodgers, were no match for Eddie Dyer's Redbirds.

VIRTUOUS, hard-hitting and faintly smug D.A. Doug Selby, who proclaims in this book that he can use only two weapons -- brains and two-fisted honesty -- is the least appealing of Erle Stanley Gardner's multitudinous series characters.

FIELD workers among the Hopi Indians have long remarked, as Weston LaBarre, Ph.D., reminds us, that even very young Hopi children play together peacefully, without any of the squabbles and yells that are common among our own small fry when engaged in early social encounters.

Sidney Moody Jr., 21-year-old Williams College senior who was stricken with polio aboard the Cunard White Star liner Parthia in mid-Atlantic, was carried off the ship in a stretcher last night and taken to New York Hospital after the vessel docked at Pier 54, North River at Fourteenth Street.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 (UP) -- Secretary of Agriculture Charles F. Brannan has privately warned Congressional Democratic farm leaders that if Congress continues the price-support program in its present form the Government would be swamped with eggs next year.

AS the summer draws to a close, announcements of fall activities hint of a busy new season for the amateur photographer. Heading the list is the news that the George Eastman House in Rochester will be opened to the public on Nov. 7.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Aug. 27 (Reuters) -- Eight men and one woman received long prison terms for high treason, public violence, thefts and other criminal offenses at Melnik state court, the official Czech News Agency announced tonight.

THAT gust of air you may have felt last Tuesday was caused by a simultaneous exhalation of many breaths, and we will not Inquire whether from relief or sighs of resignation. It came on the heels of the announcement that Decca Records would produce long playing disks after the Columbia model, rather than the pint-sized, 45-r.p.m. doughnuts introduced by RCA Victor.

In his review of Mr. Upton Sinclair's most recent volume on the life and times of Lanny Budd, Mr. Perry Miller of this city goes out of his way to make slighting reference to a little-known and long-suffering branch of armed services.

FEW devices have produced greater controversy and confusion than psychological tests. Everybody, of course, wants to do well at his job, but not everybody, of course, is suited to every job. The measurement of variations in aptitude has presented great difficulty.

HELSINKI, Finland, Aug. 27 -- Finland's nine-day-old, Communist-inspired strike wave may spread as a result of meetings called for tomorrow of workers affilated with the Metal Trades Union. The union, with a membership of 50,000, is considered the strongest in the country.

LONDON. ANYONE trying to analyze the origins of a war knows that he must distinguish between "immediate" and "ultimate" causes. Even so, it is not always easy to determine the "immediate" cause in the sense of fixing upon one Government or person the responsibility for the actual outbreak of fighting.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Aug. 19 -- Prime Minister Joseph Benedict Chifley did some plain talking at his annual conference with the six State Premiers at Canberra this week about the urgency of resuming gasoline rationing.

THE give-away show cannot be counted out yet; in fact, it probably will continue to blight the kilocycles for some time to come. Far from assuring an early end to radio's handout of cash and merchandise at a rate of $4,000,000 a year, the Federal Communications Commission took perhaps the mildest step it could to initiate a court test of the legality of the give-aways under the Federal lottery statutes.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 -- President Truman today nominated three officials of the Department of Defense to be Assistant Secretaries of Defense as provided in the recently-enacted unification law.

BROCK PEMBERTON passes along the word that Frank Fay and Shirley Booth may be figuring in the producer's plans for the coming season. Mr. Fay, who originated the role of Elwood Dowd, the tender lush of "Harvey," might be resuming in the Mary Chase play at the City Center for a run of two to four weeks next month.

PRETORIA, South Africa, Aug. 19 -- As outward signs of "national mindedness" men are growing beards and women are sewing prim puritanical dresses in readiness for mid-December, when the Voortrekkers (Boer pioneers) are to be commemorated here with pomp and circumstance.
DETROIT, Aug. 27 (AP) -- The Detroit Tigers subdued the Washington Senators by a 7-6 margin today.

The new wave of business confidence will become just another "psychological palpitation" unless it is followed up by realistic measures for selling the reluctant buyer, marketing research officials declared last week.

Residents in the vicinity of Ebbets Field whose siesta was disturbed yesterday afternoon may have thought the tail end of that Florida hurricane had just hit Flatbush. But it was only the Dodgers, breaking out in the first six-run inning in nearly a month, by which they slapped down the Cubs, 6 -- 1.

TROMSOE, Norway, Aug. 27 (UP) -- The United States submarine Tusk, which rescued seventy-eight men from its sister ship Cochino, which sank after an explosion in Arctic seas yesterday, arrived here from Hammerfest at 10 P.M. (4 P.M., Eastern daylight time) today.
NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 21 -- Americans investing in India were given official assurance by Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru today that their profits could be taken out of India in dollars.

THE HAGUE. The Netherlands, Aug. 27 -- One of the important links in the chain of events which, it is hoped, will lead to an economically unified Western Europe before the expiration of the Marshall Plan in 1952 is being forged here at the seat of the Netherlands Government in the Indonesian round-table conference that opened Tuesday and is expected to continue six to eight weeks.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 27 -- Unpredictable Tommy Byrne reached out with his left arm to steady the boat for the Yankees today and the as the Bombers evacuated the shores of Lake Erie for the last time this year it can be reported their hold on first place in the American League race is still fairly secure.
SAIGON, Indo-China, Aug. 27 (Reuters) -- Former Emperor Bao Dai's six-week-old Viet Nam Cabinet, mandated to rule over war stricken Indo-China, is already facing a crisis.

SEPTEMBER brings the pickling season. It always will so long as gardens and orchards over much of the country choose summer's end to yield cauliflower, crabapples, tomatoes, cucumbers -- all the things that, spicy sweet or spicy sour, as the case may be, are such appetizing accents for meals.

SYRACUSE -- Presenting its first full-scale show in eight years, the New York State Fair -- the leading attraction in the up-state area when Labor Day week-end rolls around -- will open its gates here Sept. 5 and continue through Sept. 10 on the 267-acre permanent fair grounds in the northwest section of the city. According to present indications, this year's fair will be bigger, better and more fun than ever before.

MOSCOW, Aug. 27 -- A permanent Soviet peace organization was established tonight by the All-Union Peace Conference with the announced purpose of organizing and directing the efforts of the nearly 200,000,000 citizens of the Soviet Union in protecting the world from threat of a new war.
CHICAGO, Aug. 27 -- Gasoline began flowing more freely today from the pumps of an increasing number of filling stations in the Chicago area as schedules of supply trucks were smoothed out.

TOKYO, Aug. 27 -- Official figures have been published of the Japanese elections for the agricultural commission that will control the land redistribution program ordered by the Allies. They show that the Communists sustained an even harder defeat in the countryside than had originally been supposed.

ONE of the things that makes this book of reminiscences so refreshing is that it contains no post-mortem evaluations. Mr. Miller is describing his boyhood on the West Coast, his newspaper days on The San Diego Sun, the writing of his books, and some of the incidents in his later life.
THE last fluttering gasps of the civilization of the Old South may be faintly heard if one puts a sensitive ear to its heart here in this ante-bellum village in the Alabama Black Belt.
THE title of this first novel is from the spiritual: "The big wheel runs by faith, and the little wheel runs by the grace of God, a wheel in a wheel, way up in the middle of the air."

IN order to maintain an old lawn or develop a new one, feeding with the right kind of fertilizer is absolutely essential. This assumes a particular importance when we stop to consider that a lawn is expected to make about an inch of growth every week for five months of the year.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 27 -- Emil Mayer Jr., the College Point. L.I., regatta veteran who has been carrying home speed-boat prizes mugs and trophies for many years and even taught his wife, Dorothy, how to be a piloting daredevil, had the narrowest margin of his career today.

CHICAGO, Aug. 27.-Some 15,000 Morse telegraphers around the country received greetings today from President Truman, addressed to the Morse Telegraph Club of America, Inc., at the Chicago Railroad Fair, where 200 of the veterans also heard an extemporaneous dinner address delivered in dots and dashes from Baltlmore. It was Morse Telegraph Day at the fair.

CHICAGO, Aug. 27 -- Calumet Farm's Ponder today ran the fastest mile and a quarter ever raced by a 3-year-old steed to win the $88,450 American Derby at Washington Park and establish himself as the champion of the year in his class.

HONG KONG, Aug. 27 -- British action in forcing the Chinese-American China National Aviation Corporation to remove most of its maintenance installations from Hong Kong's only airfield has dealt a severe blow to one of the largest, oldest and most successful of Chinese-American joint enterprises.

ATLANTA, Ga., Aug. 27 -- The South continues to make headway in its fight against the Ku Klux Klan. Public opinion against the hooded order and actions of community organizations and law-enforcement agencies are reaching unprecedented levels.

CHICAGO, Aug. 27 -- The executive committee of the National Society for Crippled Children and Adults, Inc., today voted to urge support for a bill now before the House Education and Labor Committee that would provide grants-in-aid to the states for more extensive vocational rehabilitation for the handicapped.

THE deluge of stamps this year for the observance of the seventy-fifth anniversary of the Universal Postal Union is expected to set a precedent for postal commemoration of any one event of world-wide significance.

Production of advertising displays printed in natural colors on transparent acetate through a patented Swiss process is now being made available in this country through the Mercury Paper Company, Inc., of Manhattan, it was learned last week.

On or about Sept. 7 the steel industry fact-finding panel -- Dr. Carroll R. Daugherty, Samuel I. Rosenman and David L. Cole -- will submit to President Truman its recommendations for settling the dispute between the industry and the United Steelworkers, CIO, over a fourth-round wage increase.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 -- Senator Irving M. Ives, Republican, of New York, is considering introducing legislation to obtain a refund of about $10,000,000 for the New York State Unemployment Insurance trust fund, he said today.

AKRON, Ohio, Aug. 27 -- Attempts to settle an unexpected strike that has paralyzed the seven plants of the B.F. Goodrich Company, which has its headquarters and main plants here, were recessed this afternoon until Monday in Dayton, where the United Rubber Workers, in a dramatic move, took the lead in the 1949 national campaign for pensions by the Congress of Industrial Organizations.

ALTHOUGH the English language boasts a vocabulary of unexpected richness, it has not yet evolved a satisfactory term to express the full significance of what other nations describe as "il turismo" or "le tourisme.

FLOWERS to pick every day for six months, and intermittently the rest of the year is a true story, not a tall tale, about pansies. Continuous bloom of this sort results from sowing seed twice a year -- in summet and in April.

No individual probably ever received as careful a grooming to head one of America's giant corporations as the man now directing the destinies of the $10,000,000,000 American Telephone and Telegraph Company.
In a letter to THE TIMES printed on Aug. 14 Walter E. Spahr discusses a dispatch of your Geneva correspondent, Michael L. Hoffman, on the price of gold.

Five hundred persons paraded in Fifth Avenue yesterday afternoon in connection with the third annual convention of the Middle Atlantic States Command, Canadian Legion. The Canadian Legion is made up of persons who served with the Canadian Armed Forces in the first and second World Wars.
LAUSANNE, Switzerland, Aug. 27 -- The Arab states have decided to advise the United Nations Palestine Conciliation Commission of their territorial claims in Palestine, it was disclosed here today.

MILWAUKEE, Aug. 27 -- The American Federation of Teachers, holding its thirty-second annual convention here this week, concentrated much of its attention on the dual problem of eliminating Communists from the corps of America's teachers while protecting at the same time the academic right of "free inquiry." Communists were assailed for their "blind subservience" to "Communist party thought control."

BELGRADE, Aug. 27 (UP) -- A Russian warship, in "a deliberately provocative manner," steamed 200 miles up the Danube through Yugoslav territory and then back this month, Yugoslav officials said tonight.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N, Y., Aug. 27 -- The King Ranch's Middle-ground, running what Trainer Max Hirsch said would be his last ace as a 2-year-old, did the expected in the $55,250 Hopeful Stakes as the Saratoga Association's four-week meeting ended today.

EARLY in the year, in response to a reader's inquiry, this department's specialist in literary high mysteries set to work to discover whatever had become of Winston Churchill's "History of the English-Speaking Peoples."
BELGRADE, Aug. 27 -- Rumanian Communist party leaders were named today as participants in an alleged plot by the Communist Information Bureau to partition Yugoslavia.

Appointment of ten committees that will prepare the American reports and recommendations for the biennial meeting of the International Law Association at Copenhagen next August was announced yesterday by James W. Ryan, president of the American branch of the International Law Association, 111 Broadway.

ATLANTA, Aug. 27 (UP) -- S.W. Roper, 54-year-old former state official who once served on the Atlanta police force, today succeeded the late Dr. Samuel Green as imperial wizard of the Ku Klux Klan in Georgia.

HAVANA - A big land development across the bay from downtown Havana which will take in part of three municipalities and include a "tourist city," is the latest project contemplated by the Cuban Government. A special department has been created in the Ministry of Public Works to handle the development, and a group of engineers is now drawing up plans.

MOTOR tourists are warned by the Automobile Club of New York that Labor Day week-end traffic congestion is expected to set a new peak, and extra vigilance will be required to avoid accidents and unpleasant delays on the highways.
LA PAZ, Bolivia, Aug. 27 -- Rebel forces attempting to overthrow the Government were reported tonight to be holding one city in Bolivia's tin mining district and to be fighting at another.

HONG KONG, Aug. 27 (UP) -- The Communist regular army has driven into Kwangtung Province from Kiangsi and has forged on to Yungyun, just 100 miles northeast of Canton, a military spokesman acknowledged today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 -- Angry House members have put the Senate's refusal to honor a House courtesy request into their book of rules. They plan to turn it against the Senate the first chance they get.

THE third Sculpture International of the Fairmount Park Association is still current at the Philadelphia Museum. There on the broad terrace and crowding into the museum and up the balustrades of the grandiose staircase is a strange, frozen population of giants and lilliputians, of gesticulating generals and spindly reclining women, of angular or anguished personages and appealing little animals.

WHEN former President Hoover two weeks ago on his way east from California had a five-hour stop-over at Chicago, readers of the nation's press learned that he played cards with friends in the Drake Hotel, during that time, and was a winner.

An industrial "economy wave" which has been gradually gathering momentum now threatens to impose cut-backs of 15 to 20 per cent in the rate of expenditures of many of America's largest durable goods industries from now till the end of the year.

PARIS, Aug. 27 -- Premier Henri Queuille, returnin to Paris after a holiday, presided at a conference at the Hotel Matignon today to frame instructions to representatives of France in the Washington monetary and financial conversations.

CHICAGO, Aug. 27 -- Harry G. Nye Jr., 40-year-old Chicago tool manufacturer, won the twenty-seventh international Star Class yachting championship on Lake Michigan today without coming in first in any of the weeks five races.

Cooler weather stimulated consumer demand for early fall merchandise last week. Retail promotions were numerous and will be followed by strong selling campaigns after Labor Day. Department store sales for the week were estimated at about 10 per cent under a year ago.
THE Munitions Board of the United States Government is up to its shirtsleeves in semantics. Its experts are searching for the meanings of words, though the board has dictionaries full of them.

ALTHOUGH written for teachers in the church school, this sprightly, well-organized discussion of the how, why and what of teaching will have an interest for teachers in general. Parents, too, will find some helpful pointers on the learning process, on the reactions of children and, no less important, on the peculiarities of adults, whether parents or teachers.

THE dog days of August have seen a quieting down of the buying spurt in July. This holds for heavy goods but not for soft goods. In the latter category the buying was on the slow order during the usual buying season and now it has perked up.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Aug 27 -- Running evenly under the cool guidance of Mike Basile, Rampart stepped down the winner of the $10,000 added Absecon Island Handicap at the Atlantic City race track today. With seven others opposing her, including the odds-on Pilaster, the 7-year-old daughter of Trace Call scored handily in the mile and a furlong fixture, finishing a length and a quarter in front of High Trend.

SHANGHAI, Aug. 26 -- The burden of huge military expenditures which constituted 80 per cent of China's budgetary outlays under the Kuomintang and complicated its governing tasks, has now been listed by a top-ranking Communist official as an important factor also affecting the present Communist rule.

LATELY a new note has crept into the pages of publishers' catalogues, a note that will be heard more and more publicly in book reviews, advertisements and the stalls of book shops. This is the appearance of a specialized class of novel called generically "science-fiction."

Reduction of the rediscount rate as the "next step" in the current program of the monetary authorities is generally expected in financial circles. A cut could be announced by the Federal Reserve System at any time and, according to banking opinion, revision of the rate is likely at least before the end of September.

A new plant source for the synthetic adrenal hormone that has brought hope of relief to millions of arthritis victims was announced here yesterday. The plant, a tropical yam, is expected to yield in abundance the chemical Compound E, recently hailed as a medical landmark. Early production of the drug at a lower cost is promised.
DALLAS, Tex., Aug. 27 -- Texas took legal action this week on its Mexican problem, which for years has been a source of tension along the border.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 (UP) -- The House Committee on Un-American Activities has three witnesses to back a perjury charge against the mysterious "Scientist X," alleged wartime atomic spy, it was learned today.

Devaluation of the pound sterling, if and when it comes, will not be a "cure-all" and possibly would represent but one step in the development of sounder conditions of world trade, according to views in foreign trade circles here last week.

Ralph Thompson in his column "In and Out of Books" (July 17) deservedly described the "Books for Europe" program currently being launched by CARE and UNESCO. He pointed out that cash contributions are being earnestly requested by CARE for this worthy cause.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 -- With the Federal Government spending $46 billion a year, "influence peddling" has become a big business in the nation's capital. Practical by nature, it thrives chiefly on the inability of little business to get to "first base" with its Government- related problems.
BANSKA BYSTRICA, Czechoslovakia, Aug. 27 (AP) -- President Klement Gottwald charged today that foreign were reactionaries stirring up Slovak Roman Catholics against his Government.

The "campaign." of anonymous letters, in which women education students were urged not to enter the teaching profession lest they become "old maids," has been solved, the National Education Association reported last week. The Post Office Department has determined the source of the letters, the NEA said, and has "secured from this individual a promise to discontinue the practice of sending such letters."

GREAT RIVER, L. I., Aug. 27 -- The Suffolk County Republican organization's outing, which annually ushers in the election campaign, was attended today by 5,000 persons who picnicked at the clubhouse grounds and beach at Timber Point.

GLADIOLUS shows are staged from mid-June until mid-September and from California to Massachusetts. In August alone, forty-three shows were held. The question at all of them this year has been, "Where do the fine flower spikes come from ?"

ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L.I., Aug. 27 -- The favored combination of Johnny Humm and Dr. Raymond Bowles advanced to the final of the Rockville Country Club's annual member-guest best-ball golf tournament today. William Schmidt and Robert Johnke were victorious in the other semi-final match.

Financial implications of the international monetary conference soon to get under way in Washington are of absorbing interest to the investment world, but skepticism persists as to how near the coming talks will get to the fundamental cause of the so-called dollar shortage, especially that of Great Britain.

TITUSVILLE, Pa., Aug. 27 (AP) -- Western civilization faces its greatest challenge from "Godless, cynical, grasping, materialistic Marxist communism," Secretary of the Navy Francis P. Matthews declared today at the oil industry's ninetieth birthday celebration.

MAIMI, Fla., Aug. 27 -- The Veterans of Foreign Wars, for the first time in the organization's fifty-year history, has adopted a broad and detailed program in support of a strong merchant marine as a vital factor in promoting national security.

THE first of the major fall shows resume broadcasting this week after the usual summer layoff. From now until mid-October there will be a steady succession of premieres on the networks, with most of the comedy shows scheduled to debut during the first week of next month.

The Washington Conference is due in the first week of September. Prominent men and, worse still, prominent journals (not THE NEW YORK TIMES) and periodicals on both sides of the Atlantic are doing their best or worst to insure that the conference will be a failure.

ONE of the world's greatest men was born almost exactly 2,500 years ago (the precise date is unknown). He was K'ung Fu-tzu, whom the modern world calls Confucius. A teacher during his lifetime, he was also the creator of a philosophy which after his death shaped the whole history of China, spread to many other parts of the world and to this day is a living force.

COLORADO SPRINGS, Col. -- To most of the million-odd tourists who visit Colorado Springs during the summer and early fall, the town's main attractions are the Pikes Peak Highway, Seven Falls, the Broadmoor Hotel, the Cave of the Winds, Manitou Incline and one petrified Indian.
New interest in investments in Latin America became apparent here last week with word that that troubled area's dollar problems would soon be solved.

After nine weeks of advancing prices, the stock market had its first real correction last week. Although the profit-taking was healthy for the technical position of the market, it also reflected uncertainty on the outcome of the steel-wage discussions, Congressional action on new legislation and coming developments in the international monetary situation.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 27 -- Thomas D. O'Keefe of the United States Department of Commerce said he had approached Brazilian Treasury authorities regarding the liquidation of blocked dollars here for the account of United States exporters.

SOME day a sociologist may explain fully why painters flock to seaports, why for three summer months sketchers almost supplant the true owners, fishermen and sea gulls. Such migrations transcend national and continental boundaries.

THE tourist court has come fully into its own as a favorite stopping place for auto travelers. Today about 30,000 tourist courts cater to the traveling public in the United States. They have a total of 550,000 rental units and put up an aggregate of 350,000,000 guests a year.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 -- In a kind of dry, exhausted anger, and with a spotty record, the first session of the Eighty-first Congress comes now to the beginning of the end.

Formation of a new non-profit cooperative association which provides scientific job counseling service and placement facilities for its 115 members was announced last week. Aiding members already employed to obtain better positions in their companies is as important a function of the organization as finding jobs for unemployed members, according to the association's prospectus.

IT is often simpler and more successful to begin or rebuild a garden around one good plant. Whether this flower blooms in spring, summer or autumn, it serves as a starting point for additions and regrouping.
BOSTON, Aug. 27 -- New Englanders who think about foreign affairs at all are feeling a lively -- and somewhat irascible -- concern these days about Britain's economic plight.

TO date, the efforts of some of the most colorful and hard-fighting American combat divisions of World War II remain shrouded in anonymity. Here are the stories of three of these outfits whose exploits, though vital, were lost in wartime reports of the over-all picture.

Last week Mayor O'Dwyer of New York turned a valve, and gas from Texas flowed into mains of Staten Island. By October, 1950, Texas gas will be delivered to other boroughs of New York City, near-by areas of New Jersey, Pennsylvania and eventually to New England.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Aug. 27 -- A wage committee of the American Flint Glass Workers Union of North America, AFL, and representatives of the National Association of Pressed and Blown Glasswares ended today six weeks of contract negotiations covering 26,000 workers.

CURRAGH, County Kildare, Ireland, Aug. 27 -- Johnny Longden, veteran American jockey, stunned Irish bettors by guiding a 5-to-1 shot to victory today over their 3-year-old champion in his first race on this side of the ocean.
One of the questions that two-term Presidents of the U.S. have to answer, sooner or later, is this: Are you going to run for a third term? These are some of the answers that have been made.

ROME, Aug. 27 -- The Vatican radio denied today reports appearing in the press from time to time that relations with Yugoslavia had improved as a result of Premier Marshal Tito's break with the Communist Information Bureau.
CAMDEN, N.J., Aug. 27 -- Camden's "wage-tax martyr," George E. Ross, 50-year-old grandfather, today was becoming disillusioned by the disinterest of those for whom he believed he was battling.

THREE new works of distinction had their premieres in the second American Dance Festival which closed last week at Connecticut College in New London. They were Doris Humphrey's "Invention," Sophie Maslow's "Festival" and most particularly Jose Limon's "The Moor's Pavane."

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 27 -- With two days to go before the official opening of the American Legion's thirty-first national convention, delegates were pouring into Philadelphia today and making their presence known in traditional whoop-and-holler fashion.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 27 (AP) -- Capitalizing on five errors and Ralph Kiner's thirty-seventh homer of the season, the Pirates routed the Phillies, 8 -- 2, today in the final of a four-game series.

After a short trip to Indonesia, William R. Mathews, editor and publisher of The Arizona Star, in his letter to THE NEW YORK TIMES of Aug. 21 presented information which he believes "will formulate a successful diplomatic policy in the Orient." My own experience in Indonesia, four months of which were spent in the area of the Republic of Indonesia, compels me to comment upon his observations.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 27 -- The Pacific Coast is pretty far away from Great Britain, and it would not be unfair to say that most people here neither understand nor care much about the economic crisis over there. However, those who take an interest in world affairs -- and there is a growing number of these on the Pacific Coast -- are deeply concerned about England's plight.

MARGARET MITCHELL, who wrote the most popular book of our time, had been in four motor accidents before she was struck down by the car in Atlanta which took her life. The accident which resulted in her death fractured both her skull and her pelvis; in previous mishaps she suffered a fractured skull and splintered vertebrae.

The unhappy controversy that reached its climax when Cardinal Spellman on July 21 charged Mrs. Eleanor Roosevelt with acting through "misinformation, ignorance or prejudice" in her comments on federal aid to education, has now happily ended. These two eminent Americans have exchanged friendly letters and Cardinal Spellman has paid Mrs. Roosevelt a friendly visit.

TOKYO, Aug. 27 -- Prospects that business will benefit from much fairer taxation sent the Tokyo stock exchange into a strong upward movement late yesterday and today, with the normal turnover of about 800,000 shares tripling for each session. Late today the movement declined slightly, but the tone remained optimistic.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 27 -- The annual powwow of the Shinnecock Indians, one of the thirteen tribes that originally lived on Long Island, will be held on the Shinnecock reservation west of this village on Sept. 3, 4 and 5 at 2 P.M. each day.
PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Aug. 27 -- A free-for-all fight involving several hundred persons tonight broke up a scheduled open-air concert by Paul Robeson at Cortland on the outskirts of Peekskill.

PANAMA, Aug. 27 -- Informed observers here are not optimistic about results of the investigation by the Inter-American Peace Commission of the present unrest in the Caribbean Central - American region -- at least on the basis of progress to date.

JUST as card players are convinced that luck runs in streaks, they believe that unusual hands seldom come singly. An evening of bridge, they say, will produce a series of freaks or a boring succession of dull hands, but not an even mixture.

THERE weren't many aspects of Iowa frontier life that Tom Kenyon didn't see when he went West in 1856 to see his sister. Tom, as readers of "Buckeye Boy" will remember, had earned his printer's apprenticeship back in Ohio. Now he hoped to find a job on an Iowa newspaper.

After thirty years of outstanding work in the fields of bettering inter- group relations and service to new citizens, the Common Council for American Unity is seeking help to further its activities. The Council's experience can make a signal contribution at this time in strengthening our democracy by providing anti-discrimination and civil rights information and in assisting thousands of displaced persons and other newcomers to become Americans.

IT is no new thing for spies and secret service and "British Intelligence,'' and all that, to attract writers and readers of popular books. But the subject grows more interesting and more complex as the national state system disintegrates.
FRANKFORT, Germany, Aug. 27 (AP) -- A group of United States police chiefs reported here today that they found the German police "leaning over backward trying to use democratic methods."

PUTTLE, the dog, and Puttler, the cat, bear a striking pictorial resemblance to Margot Austin's previous much-loved creations. Trumpet and Gabriel Churchkitten. In a book for 4-to-7-year-olds, however, this similarity is not unwelcome -- especially since it would be difficult to top those familiar animals who live in Parson Pease-Porridge's church.
