LONDON, Aug. 27 -- With only four working days left in which to complete the drafting of an Austrian peace treaty before the Sept. 1 deadline, the deputies of the Big Four Foreign Ministers made minor headway today. On the key issue of defining German assets and war booty in the Soviet zone of occupation, however, the deputies were still as far apart as ever.

A group of 450 animal lovers from forty nations were taken on a special tour yesterday of Bronx Park's zoo. However, the spectators -- delegates to the United Nations Scientific Conference on Conservation and Utilization of Resources and of the International Union for the Protection of Nature -- seemed as much fascinated by the tractor trailers that took them about the park as they were by the animals.

Most dramatic of the many problems to be discussed at the twentieth annual meeting of the Aero Medical Association in New York this week will be potential rocket flights beyond the stratosphere. Formerly limited to the imagination of the "comic" strip cartoonists and pseudoscientific writings, the current rapid development of rocket propulsion indicates the possibility of flight beyond the stratosphere in the foreseeable future.

WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., Aug. 27 (AP) -- Sixteen big transport planes and twenty-four private aircraft were wrecked by the hurricane at International Airport here. A metal-and-concrete hangar fell into a twisted, forty-foot junk heap.

OTTAWA, Aug. 27 -- Canada's trade position on the eve of the Washington conference has confirmed once more that the whole interest and policy of this country will continue to be directed toward the re-establishment of multilateral trade with the concurrent condition of stability of exchanges.

MRS. COBLENTZ has taken a blue cat right out of an early New England carpet at the Metropolitan Museum in New York and rewoven him into a modern folk tale. It is a tale of the making of that carpet by Zeruah Guernsey and of what she learned from the blue cat who came singing the river's song.

SU WON is a girl of modern Korea and the best weaver at the village school. An apparent miracle came to the humble Kim household when Su Won discovered that her own silkworms were spinning threads of rich golden yellow.

SALT LAKE CITY -- Cross-country motor travel is now at its best, improved in every respect since the war. New construction has left highways between New York and the West generally good and work now in progress will soon make them excellent. Overnight accommodations are satisfactory although scarce in scenic centers.

Each year a number of American shooters, unable to await the signal for the opening gun here, check over their last bank statement and finding it satisfactory they head for the Scottish moors, where birds are plentiful and bag limits non-existent.

GLENWOOD SPRINGS, Col., Aug. 27 (AP) -- A Yale University student fell to his death, and a Washington, D.C., visitor was marooned over night on ill-starred hiking trips in the Western Colorado Rockies yesterday.

CHICAGO, Aug. 27 (AP) -- A renewed burst of selling in soybeans again caused a nervous undertone in other commodities on the Board of Trade today. Soybeans dropped nearly 5 cents a bushel below yesterday's close before meeting enough support to stage a fair-sized rally.

Now we begin to see belated effects of the June drought. It is bringing autumn to the woods a month earlier than usual. JANE AUSTEN is one of the few English writers who has became a cult. It is in general a faintly amusing but admiring cult. WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 -- The shakedown in the national economy during the last eight months, falling somewhat short of the dreary climax that some alarmists predicted, has left the average consumer sitting cozily on the top of the heap with a reasonable prospect of staying where he is through the remainder of the year.

WESTBURY, L.I., Aug. 27 -- Argentina's El Trebol quartet, a favored entry in the National Open Polo championship which starts tomorrow, battled to a 6-all tie with the Bostwick Field four on Whitney Field of the Meadow Brook Club today.

BELMONT, Mass., Aug. 27 -- The United States Ryder Cup forces, sweltering through a series of best-ball matches, piled up an 8 to 4 point margin over Byron Nelson's challenger team today as they started the final tune-up for their international golf play in England next month.

MISS TENSEN'S first book, "Come to the Zoo," was, with its excellent pictures, its carefully selected vocabulary, admirably suited to the needs of the child who is just beginning to read. "Come to the Farm" takes that child one step further from "pre-primer" to primer reading.

TOP industry executives and their advisers will gather in Chicago this week to ponder the state of the movies public relations and to draft a program designed to win more public favor. President Truman's campaign promise last fall of more public power in the West moved closer to reality on Thursday when the Senate rolled out a $595,262,257 appropriation to the Department of the Interior. While cutbacks may be made in conference with the House next month, the proponents of Federal spending for public power projects have little to fear.

PHOTOGRAPHS in photo sensitive glass, the Corning Glass Company development which was announced about a year ago, are now being made on a regular production basis by Perma-Picture, Inc., of Warren, Ohio.

BOSTON, Aug. 27 (AP) -- Braves' outfielder Jeff Heath never hit two more timely home runs than he did today. His first, in the ninth inning, pulled Boston into a 5-5 tie. His second gave the Tribe a ten inning 6-5 victory over the Cincinnati Reds.

PARIS, Aug. 27 -- Reporting on the first year of the Marshall Plan, the Economic Cooperation Administration in Washington said this week that during that period Europe's dollar earnings paid for only one-fifth of Europe's imports from the Western Hemisphere.

HELSINKI, Finland, Aug. 28 -- The Communist inspired strike wave, now in the middle of its second week, spread further today when the metal workers at Finland's biggest shipyard, the Crichton Vulcan Company in Turku, voted overwhelmingly to strike tomorrow.

LONDON, Aug. 28 -- The British Cabinet is meeting tomorrow to draft final instructions for Foreign Secretary Bevin and Sir Stafford Cripps, who are leaving for the Washington financial talks on the Mauretania Wednesday. It will be the first time the Cabinet has met since Parliament recessed a month ago.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Aug. 28 -- More than 300 delegates from twenty-two countries assembled here today for the third Congress of the World Movement for World Federal Government, which will convene in the Swedish Parliament building tomorrow.

A French delegation, including the Finance Minister and the Minister of Foreign Affairs, will be in Washington at the time of the monetary talks with the British and Canadians. The French statesmen are coming here for the meeting of the International Monetary Fund, the Assembly of the United Nations and the probable reunion of the Council of Foreign Ministers.

Neither the number thirteen nor slugging Ralph Kiner held any terrors for big Don Newcombe at Ebbets Field yesterday. Russell Janney, author of "The Miracle of the Bells," who received much publicity when he was accused of talking out of turn as a member of the jury in the trial of the Communist leaders here, will have a new book published in November unlike anything he has previously written.

The Committee to Draft Herbert H. Lehman for Nomination for United States Senator made public yesterday a telegram to the former Governor, urging him to run for Senator on the Democratic and Liberal party tickets. ALBANY, Aug. 28 -- The death rate in New York for the first six months of 1949 was the lowest yet recorded for the state, according to the State Health Department in a report issued today.

The Department of Justice, which killed a bill to give New York State title to part of the former Coast Guard training station at Manhattan Beach, will not oppose the land transfer when a new measure is offered in Congress soon after Jan. 1, Representative Emanuel Celler, Democrat, of Brooklyn, said yesterday.

The domestic cotton market was quiet last week, with prices again holding in a narrow range. Active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange closed 3 points up to 13 points down. The only net gain was recorded by the near-by October contract.

The "Voice of Firestone" will become a regular Monday evening television feature over the National Broadcasting Company on Sept. 5 at the same time that it is broadcast by radio from 8:30 to 9 o'clock. The program of classical, light classical and popular music has been on NBC since 1928.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 (AP) -- The Washington Star reports that President Truman appears about to shake up the membership of the Fine Arts Commission which opposed the controversial balcony he had installed on the White House.

DETROIT, Aug. 28 -- Protestant denominational colleges in Michigan are making a united move to tie in more closely the needs of higher education with corporations and foundations in the state, it was disclosed today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 (AP) -- Hearings on a bill to prevent unfair competition by buying out competitors will begin probably within the next few weeks, Senator O'Conor, Democrat, of Maryland, said today.

BELMONT, Mass., Aug. 28 (AP) -- Chicago's Lloyd Mangrum posted a four-under par 67 for a 4-up victory over Toney Penna of Cincinnati today while pacing the United States Ryder Cup golf team to a 25-11 point triumph over Byron Nelson's challengers at the Belmont Country Club.

BROOKVILLE, L. I., Aug. 28 -- Sixteen-year-old Miss Carol Werber of Great Neck enjoyed a banner day in both the hunter and horsemanship classes as the fourth annual Brookville Horse Show was held at J. T. Bragg's farm today. The event was conducted for the benefit of the Community Scholarship Fund.
CLEVELAND, Aug. 28 (AP) -- Boston's Red Sex dropped a 2-1 decision to the Indians today on an eleventh-inning bungle by Shortstop Vernon Stephens.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- A direct move by President Truman to and a dispute among his Democratic advisers on farm programs was disclosed today by Senator Elmer Thomas of Oklahoma.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- The Bureau of Employment Security said today that there appeared to be a steady slackening "in the rate of new industrial lay-offs."

BERLIN, Aug. 28 (UP) -- The deputy chief of United States occupation forces said today that the Russians had refused to allow American officers to visit two young American prisoners in Germany's Soviet zone.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 (UP) -- The Government revealed today that it has signed "phantom orders" for the emergency production of $20,150,000 worth of gauges needed for the mass production of war materials.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 28 -- Guy Lombardo got back into the winning ranks in speed boating this afternoon after a summer of discouraging setbacks, scoring in the feature 20-mile event of the Maryland Yacht Club's annual Star Spangled Banner regatta.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 28 -- Dr. Edgar Collins Bain, vice president in charge of research and technology at the Carnegie Illinois Steel Company, has been named for the John Price, Wetherill Medal of the Franklin Institute of the State of Pennsylvania.

Shipping operators whose vessels use the Panama Canal said yesterday they were gratified by President Truman's decision to postpone proposed increases in Panama Canal tolls pending a general study of the toll system and other aspects of canal operation, as requested by Congress.

A united front of former service men's organizations to combat growing "anti-veteran" activities in Washington and elsewhere was recommended yesterday by Clyde Lewis, newly elected commander of the Veterans of Foreign Wars.
Application blanks for insurance dividends will be available starting today for 16,000,000 men and women who served in the nation's armed forces between Oct. 8, 1940 and Jan. 1, 1948.

FORT TOTTEN, L. I., Aug. 28 -- Fifty Sea Scouts from the metropolitan area, living like soldiers but acting like sailors, completed today their first week-long "windjammer encampment" as guests of this military post.

ROME, Aug. 28 -- consistory for the creation of Cardinals will certainly be held in December, according to reports circulating in the Vatican. It pointed out that the Pope will, in any case, hold a consistory to appoint papal legates who will inaugurate the Holy Year at the basilicas of St. John Lateran and St. Paul Outside the Walls and it is thought he will certainly take the occasion to replenish the College of Cardinals.

The Chelsea Products Corporation, manufacturer of fans and blowers for home and industrial use, has purchased the industrial property of the Kearny Trecker Corporation at 639 South Avenue, corner of Berkman Street, Plainfield, N. J.

CARACAS, Aug. 27 (AP) -- By year's end a great iron mountain in the Venezuelan jungle will start yielding its millions of tons of ore for the steel mills of North America. For Venezuela, it means the promise of new wealth heaped on its oil riches.

Melville Morris has been appointed president of Optimus Equipment Company, Matawan, N. J., manufacturer of industrial equipment. Mr. Morris was formerly executive vice president of the company, which is a subsidiary of Hanson-Van Winkle-Munning Company, also of Matawan.

The entire one-story building at 33-22 Northern Boulevard, Long Island City, has been leased for a long term by Steiner Brothers to the Eureka-Williams Corporation, distributor of Eureka vacuum cleaners and other appliances, which will use the property for showrooms, offices and servicing.
PITTSBURGH, Aug. 28 -- The national steel-production rate surprised the trade again last week when it was raised 1 1/2 points to 85 per cent of theoretical capacity.

A series of resolutions critical of the Soviet Union and the left-wing minority in the Congress of Industrial Organizations is scheduled for adoption at the state CIO convention to be held in Saratoga Springs next week, it became known yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 (AP)-- Philip Murray, president of the United Steelworkers of America, CIO, said today that industry-wide bargaining in the steel industry was "industry's creature -- not the union's."

BOSTON, Aug. 28 (AP) -- The Cardinals increased their National League lead to two and one-half games today by twice defeating the Braves, using their power for a 9-7 opening victory and receiving classy three-hit pitching from Max Lanier for a 7-1 decision in the second contest.

SHANGHAI, Aug. 28 -- A new "People's Government for the Northeast" has been established by the Communists in Manchuria, China's richest industrial area, it was announced here today. At a six-day "People's Congress" convoked in Mukden, more than 300 representatives from all parts of Manchuria were reported to have elected a list of forty-one Government members headed by Kao Kang, secretary of the Chinese Communist Northeast Bureau.

CHICAGO, Aug. 28 -- Grain markets were unsettled on the Board of Trade last week. Wheat, rye and soybeans averaged lower, while corn and oats showed a firmer undertone. Most grains, however, held within narrow price limits, with trading largely professional.
ROANOKE, Va., Aug. 28 -- High, savage winds, remnants of Florida's furious hurricane, ripped into Virginia tonight out of the Carolinas.

Billy Rose threatened to arrange a "buy" for Ken Murray's "Black-outs," which opens at his Ziegfeld Theatre on Sept. 6, and he did with the full cognizance of David W. Siegel, sponsor of the show. But there will be a vast difference between Mr. Rose's "buy" and the modus operandi in vogue before 1938, when it was outlawed by the combined action of the League of New York Theatres and Actors Equity to protect theatregoers.

CHICAGO, Aug. 28 -- The Yankees picked up two valuable victories today, but at a cost that could well make the forthcoming stretch drive to the pennant more difficult than ever. For while in the process of toppling the White Sox by scores of 8 to 7 and 7 to 5 before 38,135 fans, the Bombers lost the services of Tommy Henrich and Johnny Mize.

GARY, Ind., Aug. 28 (UP) -- One hundred police armed with riot guns closed a public beach today when about fifty persons sought to stage a demonstration protesting alleged racial discrimination. Police Capt. Peter Billick said he believed the incident was "Communist inspired."

HONG KONG, Aug. 28 -- Ships arriving here from Tientsin through the Nationalist blockade within the last week have brought several Britons and Americans from Peiping who have been in the Communist "capital" since its capture late last year.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 (AP) -- Senator Kenneth S. Wherry, Republican, of Nebraska, said today a Republican Congress would be elected next year "to stop the biggest give-away show on earth."

The adventure of Christian fellowship belongs not only to gifted mystics but to ordinary people trudging everyday roads as well, the Rev. Dr. David A. MacLennan of the faculty of Yale University Divinity School, New Haven, Conn., declared yesterday.
Vasil (Steve) Stepanchuk, 35 years old, a Ukrainian, wants to become a citizen of the United States.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- Canadian and United States experts who have examined the British balance sheet on dollar exchange have found no major discrepancies with the data accumulated on this side of the Atlantic, so far as could be learned today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- Robert F. Jones, member of the Federal Communications Commission, criticized the Columbia Broadcasting System tonight for what he called its lack of cooperation in the development of color television.

BURLINGTON, Vt., Aug. 28 -- Despite widespread social evils in Brazil, Communism is making "no headway at all" in that country, Msgr. L. G. Ligutti, executive secretary of the National Catholic Rural Life Conference, said here today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- While British, Canadian and United States Government technicians have been engaged in setting forth the basic facts that will govern the three powers' monetary talks, their more politically minded colleagues have been exploring broader fields that they believe will be touched on.

At a time when everything humanly possible should be done to maintain employment at the highest level, Secretary of Defense Johnson announces that 135,000 employes of the War Department are to be thrown out of work. Such a move coming when the Government has began to express anxiety and dismay at the rise in unemployment is as discouraging as it is confusing.
LONDON, Aug. 28 (AP) -- Homesick war wives, with numerous offspring, flew in tonight on "operation grandchild showoff" with eighty persons aboard.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Aug. 28 -- After a three-day adjournment, the round table conference on Indonesia will resume work tomorrow and by mid-week the three participating parties are expected to have submitted their preliminary working papers on various problems.

GREAT BARRINGTON, Mass., Aug. 28 -- The annual fixture of the Great Barrington Kennel Club today wound up with proof that obedience dogs can go to town on show awards. Mrs. Allan A. Ryan selected as best in the largest show ever held here, an Irish setter, Ch. Red Star of Hollywood Hills, C.D.X., owned by Mr. and Mrs. John P. McAteer of Boston and handled by Mrs. McAteer.

LONDON, Aug. 28 -- A wealth of novel detail is evident in the fall collection of Bianca Mosca. She based her autumn models on straighter lines, shorter skirts, concealed fullness and rounded shoulders.

A double-header involving two teams that are going nowhere in the National League race resulted in a split as the Giants and Reds fought each other to a stand-off yesterday at the Polo Grounds. The visitors captured the first with ease, 10 -- 3, after which the Giants won the nightcap, 4 -- 2, with darkness dictating a halt after the Reds had failed to score in the top of the eighth.

ROCHESTER, N. Y., Aug. 28 -- Four New York City competitors shared the honors with the sole representative from Washington, D. C., in the championship of the New York Chess Association after twelve of the games in the second round had been decided tonight.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 28 -- Teresa Wright has been signed by Stanley Kramer to play opposite Marlon Brando in "The Men," a film about paraplegic veterans, which Kramer will produce for United Artists release in October.

The window of Abraham Sahadi's shop, 195 Washington Street, is arrayed with Syrian pastries and confections. At the door there's a sign reading, "Come in and browse around." It's an invitation well worth accepting, for this quiet little establishment, opposite the Washington Market, might have been transplanted with all its wares from somewhere in the Near East.

CHICAGO, Aug. 28 -- The International Federation of Catholic Alumnae ended its eighteenth convention here today by going on record as "disapproving the complete separation of religion from education as recently legalized by a decision of the Supreme Court."

LONDON, Aug. 28 -- Secretary of State Dean Acheson and British Foreign Secretary Ernest Bevin have agreed to follow the dollar talks in Washington with a detailed review of all urgent political questions facing the United States and Britain.

A total of 210,000 to 240,000 persons, including 30,000 Japanese troops, died in the first combat blast of an atomic bomb over Hiroshima on Aug. 6, 1945, the Mayor of that ill-fated city declared yesterday.

Winthrop W. Aldrich, banker, has been named chairman of a citizens committee to support the proposed state constitutional amendmend permitting this city to borrow $150,000,000 outside its debt limit to modernize the municipal hospital system, it was announced yesterday.

AMSTERDAM, Aug. 28 -- Prof. Gererd Weyer, manager of the Escompto Bank of Amsterdam, who helped to draw up the economic and financial statute that forms the basis for the Dutch delegation to the round-table conference on Indonesia, outlined the basis for the statute to American "Marshall group" students at Leiden recently.
New York was conspicuously missing yesterday from a list of seventeen states receiving awards for their scholastic driver training programs from the Association of Casualty and Surety Companies.
The thoroughbreds -- and those who bet pari-mutuelly on same -- will be back in action today at Aqueduct, where the Queens County Jockey Club will open its second meeting of the year.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Aug. 28 -- One out of five children in the Arab states dies before reaching the first birthday and a third of all children die before the age of 10, according to a report prepared by Dr. Wendell Cleland, director of Nea East research for the United State State Department.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- Two Senators insisted today that the "five percenter" investigation be held open until two much-discussed figures, James V. Hunt and David Bennett, both ill, can appear.

The violent outbreak at the Lakeland Acres picnic ground, near Peekskill, on Saturday night, which forced Paul Robeson to give up an intended outdoor concert, requires a thorough investigation. In some way a veterans' demonstration against Mr. Robeson and his sponsors -- intended, the leaders said, to be "a peaceable one" -- turned into a riot.

WATERTOWN, N. Y., Aug. 28 -- United States Senator John Foster Dulles, speaking here this morning from the pulpit of the First Presbyterian Church, which once was occupied by his father, the late Dr. Allen Macy Dulles, characterized reliance by the United States mainly on "material and military might," in the world struggle for peace, as "dangerous."

The National Maritime Union, CIO, has urged all of its members to send messages to Congress urging further consideration of legalized maritime hiring halls. Leaders of the sea union said yesterday that they had not given up the fight for an exemption under the Taft-Hartley Act as far as the maritime industry was concerned.

Many of us Americans fail to understand the nature of the church-state struggle in the Iron Curtain countries because we do not know that totalitarians give different meanings to words we use constantly such as "religious liberty" and because we have not yet realized that the church cannot be the church in a dictator state.

THE Communists act with satanic cleverness on occasion but, gosh, they also can be awfully dumb. Japan once was a proud nation, too proud, perhaps. Its historians had recounted that Nippon never had been vanquished by another country in the 2,600 years of its recorded existence. But for the past five years the Sons of the Rising Sun were spiritually and emotionally starved for something to cheer about in the old-fashioned banzai fashion.
The priliminary rounds of the men's National tennis championships came to an end at Forest Hills yesterday with eight players gaining places in the main draw of the tournament.

Five hundred persons, many of them of German descent, gathered before the statue of Johann Wolfgang von Goethe in Bryant Park yesterday to pay tribute to the poet, philosopher and statesman on the 200th anniversary of his birth.

AKRON, Ohio, Aug. 28 -- Striking workers of the B. F. Goodrich Company were warned today by their leaders to gird for a "long and bitter" walkout if they expected to win their pension and pay-increase demands in a new contract.
ALBANY, Aug. 28 -- Governor Dewey declared today that employment conditions in New York State "appear definitely to be on the mend."
DOGUBAYAZIDI, Turkey, Aug. 28 -- Five Americans started up Mount Ararat at dawn today to determine finally whether Noah's Ark was there.

Fall buying in the wholesale apparel market here last week was considerably stimulated by cool weather, according to reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES. Buying of fall ready-to wear centered on fur trimmed and zip-out lining coats, medium and popular priced dresses and corduroy and wool jersey sportswear.

Followers of Jesus Christ cannot be "anti-anyone," because there is no such word in the Christian creed where people are concerned, the Rev. Daniel P. Byrne, member of the New York Apostolate of the Roman Catholic Archdiocesan Mission Band, declared yesterday morning at solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral.
Twenty-three new cases of poliomyelitis, but no deaths, were reported yesterday by the Department of Health for the twenty-four-hour period ended at 9 A. M.

CHICAGO, Aug. 28 -- The Government will provide storage for 250,000,000 bushels of grain this year, largely corn. Contracts have been let for space to store 190,000,000 bushels, with some construction scheduled to be completed within thirty days in one county in central Illinois.
Washington, Aug. 28 (AP) -- Publicly reported cash dividend payments totaled $493,600,000 in July, slightly less than the $496,100,000 paid out in July, 1948.

TOKYO, Aug. 22 -- With the projected special session of the Diet about two months off, the major Japanese political parties again are busily engaged on plans for mergers that, if successful, would reduce the post-war multiple-party system to three main groupings of Right, Left and Center.
HAVANA, Aug. 28 -- The start of operations of Cuba's new National Bank of Issue has been tentatively fixed for Nov. 15, according to Dr. Felipe Pazos, president of the institution.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- Senator Brien McMahon, Democrat, of Connecticut, chairman of the Joint Congressional Committee on Atomic Energy, has warned the American Legion that any change from civilian to military control over the development of atomic energy would "inflict a powerful blow upon our national security," it was learned today.

WESTBURY, L. I., Aug. 28 -- Laddie Sanford's Hurricanes began the defense of their National Open polo championship today in powerful style. With most of their strength in the middle of the lineup, the Hurricanes crushed the out-mounted Detroit-Templeton side, 15 to 4, in the inaugural match in the thirty-third Open tournament on International Field of the Meadow Brook Club.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- The votes of the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on important roll-calls during the period Aug. 20 to 26 are given in the appended tabulation:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 (UP) -- Senator Allen J. Ellender, Democrat, of Louisianna, revealed today as Senate debate neared on the Administration's disputed minimum wage bill that he would try to fix the wage at 65 cents an hour and tie it to future changes in the cost of living.

Some 38,000 families on Staten Island are the first in these parts to burn natural gas. And the gas comes all the way from Texas. By autumn of next year scores of communities all along the line to New York, Pennsylvania, New Jersey and New England will also buy natural gas that has been forced by powerful compressors half across the North American Continent.

BAD GODESBERG, Germany, Aug. 28 -- A group of Germans led by Rudolf Nadolny, former German Ambassador to Moscow, and Andreas Hermes, former German Reichsminister, announced today the establishment of a formal organization for the revival of Germany's national unity.

WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., Aug. 28 -- Virtually normal living conditions were resumed tonight in this resort city of 50,000 persons just forty-eight hours after it had borne the fury of a 150-mile-an-hour hurricane that tore into the mainland along its palm-fringed beaches.

GREENOCK, Scotland, Aug. 28 (AP) -- Hector McNeil, British Minister of State, accused Soviet Russia tonight of warmongering and threatening world peace in her campaign against Yugoslavia's Marshal Tito.

GENEVA, Aug. 28 -- Europe faces the coming winter with coal stocks higher than in any year since World War II, according to figures released today by the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe.

WITH THE GREEK ARMY, in the Grammos Area, Aug. 28 -- The Ninth Division captured 8,000-foot Mount Grammos this morning. The peak commands the whole mountainous area bearing its name, which has been, for the last three days, the scene of the heaviest fighting in Greece's supreme effort to crush the Communist-inspired rebellion.

The liner Atlantic, with 872 passengers from the Mediterranean, arrived here yesterday nearly seven hours late after weathering the hurricane that threatened the coast of Florida early last week and then moved out to sea. The vessel, with only minor damage as the result of her experience, docked shortly before 3 P. M. at Pier 54, North River.
Nine new pictures will be presented by local theatres during the week. The schedule follows:

Mrs. Margaret Osborne du Pont of Wilmington, Del., defending women's titleholder, will play the opening match in the stadium today in the combined men's, women's and veterans' national tennis championships at Forest Hills.

The John Simon Guggenheim Memorial Foundation announced yesterday the award of fellowships amounting to $70,000 to twenty-two Latin-American scholars and artists for research and creative work in the United States.

ZURICH, Aug. 28 -- According to Swiss banking experts, Switzerland's main interest in the forthcoming monetary conferences in Washington centers in the question of the official gold price. They say that the decisive significance of popular psychological forces, which often act to offset logic, should not be underestimated.

The high school girl has her own styles these days. In her way, she is as sophisticated as her college sister. The clothes she likes are planned to do something for the teen-age figure. We show here some good-looking costumes designed especially for her, which she can make for herself.
LA PAZ, Bolivia, Aug. 28 (AP) -- Government troops issued an ultimatum tonight to revolutionists entrenched at Cochabamba, 130 miles southeast of the capital, to surrender or be annihilated.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 28 -- Two committees of refugees from Premier Enver Hoxha's Albanian "people's republic" have been formed in Yugoslavia with the avowed purpose of overthrowing eventually the Tirana regime and returning to their homeland.
Bosco Company, Inc., to Robert W. Orr Associates for Bosco, a flavoring for milk. Joseph R. Joyce is account executive.

PELHAM, N. Y., Aug. 28 -- About the best sailing southerly of the summer regattas greeted the annual championship of the yachting department of the New York Athletic Club which was held out on Long Island Sound today. It came at twelve knots and rose to sixteen, with a splash of water.

MOSCOW, Aug. 28 (AP) -- Dmitri Shostakovich has put music to a poem singing praises of Joseph Stalin's forestry program. His song of forests, an oratorio, was hailed in the newspaper Soviet Art today as a major composition by Russia's best known composer.

SHANGHAI, Aug. 28 -- Lanchow, fortress city at the northwest frontie of China proper in ancient times and in modern days the administrative center of the four Northwest Provinces, was taken yesterday by the Chinese Communist Army, the Peiping radio announced tonight.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 28 (AP) -- San Francisco's Forty - niners opened their bid for the All-America Conference pro football championship with a 31 to 17 victory over the Baltimore Colts today before 29,095.

There is no doubt that shoes are a definite necessity to mankind, yet it is also indisputable that there are no shoes quite as comfortable as no shoes at all. Bare feet generate a feeling of freedom into soul and body that is unobtainable by a cold shower, a cool drink or a pipeful of tobacco.

LONDON, Aug. 28 -- Although the recovery in the stock markets here in the past week can scarcely be described as impressive and the turnover there has dwindled to negligible proportions, it appears that, barring quite unexpected happenings, the markets have for the time being done with the violent movements that characterized them for almost a month.
ROCHESTER, N. Y., Aug. 28 -- Eighty-two matches will inaugurate the forty-ninth amateur championship of the United States Golf Association over the Oak Hill Country Club's East course tomorrow.

A plan to sign on crewmen with radio operator licenses and pay them $25 a month extra for assuming the functions of radio officer aboard ship has been disclosed and condemned in the current issue of the monthly magazine of the Radio Officers Union, AFL.

Serge Prokofieff's fairy - tale opera, "The Love of the Three Oranges," which has not been heard here in twenty-seven years, will be the chief novelty of the New York City Opera Company's fall season, it was announced yesterday by Laszlo Halasz, artistic and music director, who founded the company five years ago. The work will be given in English.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Aug. 28 -- Resisting suggestions that they meet hereafter with surviving Confederate veterans, six of the remaining sixteen members of the Grand Army of the Republic began their eighty-third and final encampment here today.

Conflicting accounts were given yesterday of the immediate cause and the number of persons injured in the melee near Peekskill Saturday night that prevented a concert by Paul Robeson, baritone and left-wing political storm center.

The difference between Christianity and any other religion is personal loyalty and faith in Christ, the Rev. Dr. Russell H. Stafford, president of the Hartford Seminary Foundation, declared yesterday at morning services at the Broadway Tabernacle, Broadway and Fifty-sixth Street.

If modern man is to direct his new scientific forces for good instead of evil he must develop a greater strength of character than he now possesses, the Rev. George H. Taylor, chairman of the Methodist Conference of Liverpool, England, declared in a sermon yesterday.
ANN ARBOR, Mich., Aug. 28 -- There is no "Solid South" except on one subject -- the racial issue, a group of political scientists meeting at the University of Michigan were informed today.

Decorators of contemporary room settings appear to have a great urge to get furniture off the floor. Some of them achieve this by putting cabinets and chests on trestles, stretchers, slim legs, or similar devices. Others go further and actually hang furniture, like pictures, on the wall, to provide more floor space.
JERSEY CITY, N. J., Aug. 28 (AP) -- The Jerseys were back in the first division of the International League after splitting a doubleheader with Syracuse today before 3,240 fans.

PARIS, Aug. 28 -- In Paris and London during the last few days, Paul G. Hoffman, Economic Cooperation Administrator, has argued that the United States tariff level was now at about the same level that prevailed in 1914 and hence was not a major bar to the tripling of Europe's exports to the United States to overcome a dollar shortage.

HAMILTON, Ohio, Aug. 28 (AP) -- Senator Clinton P. Anderson, Democrat, of New Mexico, today ridiculed Republican charges of "welfare state" and "statism" by the Truman Administration. He opened a Democratic drive to defeat Senator Robert A: Taft, Republican, of Ohio, in the 1950 elections.

Another Australian quest for the Davis Cup ended unsuccessfully yesterday as the United States won the final two challenge round singles matches in the Forest Hills stadium for a 4 -- 1 decision in the series.
DETROIT, Aug. 28 (AP) -- The Detroit Tigers ran their winning streak to seven games today as they beat the Philadelphia Athletics, 6 to 4, behind the eight-hit pitching of Art Houtteman.

Municipal appropriations for public library purposes have increased progressively since Mayor O'Dwyer took office on Jan. 1, 1946, he reported yesterday, with the 1949-50 budget allotment 66 per cent greater than the amount fixed in the 1945-46 budget.

The serious world situation today increases the importance of the work of the Woodrow Wilson Foundation, 45 East Sixty-fifth Street, to promote the Wilsonian concept of "the reign of law, based upon the consent of the governed and sustained by the organized opinion of mankind," Mrs. Julie d'Estournelles, executive director of the foundation, said in the annual report yesterday.

PATERSON, N. J., Aug. 28 -- A movement to do away with sectarianism in Jewish religious life in favor of a "universal synagogue" has begun here with the establishment of a new Jewish congregation to be known as the Congregation Beth-El, which is being sponsored by a founding committee of ten Paterson residents.
If it were not the subject of constant discussion in top economic and international banking and political quarters the redundancy of the devaluation of pound sterling as an item would be wearisome.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 28 (AP) -- Russ Meyer pitched four-hit ball and Catcher Stan Lopata smashed out a three-run homer to give the Phillies an 8-to-2 victory over the Cubs in the second game of a double-header today.

One million employes of the nation's railroads will shift on Thursday from a forty-eight-hour to a forty-hour, five-day work week and at the same time will receive a wage increase of seven cents an hour. The new work schedule that has been evolved will be accompanied by significant internal changes in the rail industry affecting particularly its finances and to some degree its service.
A combination of above normal temperatures and relatively high humidity gave the metropolitan area an uncomfortable day yesterday.

LONDON, Aug. 28 -- There was published here today as a booklet the record of a public debate on Britain's economic ailments that was remarkable for its thoroughness, for the number and variety of experts who participated in it and for the forum in which it took place -- the editorial page of The Times of London.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 28 (AP) -- The St. Louis Browns nosed out the Washington Senators, 4 to 3, in the second half of a double-header today after taking a 13-to-2 trouncing in the opener.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 28 -- The reported arrival of three Soviet mechanized divisions in southern Hungary has created the impression in Belgrade that, after fourteen months of fruitless efforts to overthrow the Tito regime by subversive methods, the Soviet Government finally appears to have committed itself to some form of direct action.

The American Smelting and Refining Company reported yesterday for the first six months of 1949 a consolidated net income of $10,375,859 after charges and taxes. This is equivalent, after preferred dividend requirements, to $3.28 each on 2,630,000 common shares outstanding.

Hoffman, Economic Co-operation Administrator, deserves high commendation for the frankness and realism with which he spoke at his valedictory press conference in London on Friday before leaving for home. Auxiliary Bishop Joseph P. Donahue, vicar-general of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York, broke ground yesterday afternoon at Avenue D, between Twelfth and Thirteenth Streets, for a combined parish hall and chapel in the newly founded parish of St. Emeric.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- Showdowns in the field of national defense and security were expected today to mark the Senate's struggle this week to clear up its heavy backlog of pending legislation.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 29 -- The Chiefs of Staff of the armies of the countries belonging to the Communist Information Bureau conferred in Sofia over the week-end, it was reported on good authority today.

General Sessions Judge Jacob Gould Schurman yesterday set an additional $15,000 bail on each of three New Jersey defendants under indictment here on conspiracy and lottery charges in the $50,000,000 rigged policy ring investigation.

On invitation from the Federazione Italiana Motonautica, the national ruling body of Italian speed boat racing, three American pilots are sailing this morning from Pier 54 on the S. S. Atlantic to participate in three northern Italian regattas.
HELSINKI, Finland, Aug. 29 -- The Finnish strike situation looked blacker today as metal workers staged a mass walkout to close thirty-one plants and four shipyards.

ROCHESTER, N. Y., Aug. 29 -- Setting back Hans Berliner of Washington, D. C., who essayed a risky variation of the Kings Gambit, Max Pavey of Brooklyn, National speed champion of 1947, went out in front today, 3 -- 0, in the third round of the New York State Chess Association tournament.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 --Copies of all testimony received in the "five percenter" inquiry have been delivered to the Justice Department and the Treasury Department's Bureau of Internal Revenue for "possible action," William P. Rogers, chief counsel of the Senate investigations subcommittee, disclosed today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- Administration supporters today abandoned attempts to broaden coverage of the Wage-Hour Law and agreed to a bill in the Senate built around the proposal to raise minimum wages from the present 40 cents to 75 cents an hour.

CONCORD, N. H., Aug. 29 (AP) -- Governor Sherman Adams said tonight the court case in the dormitory death of a Dartmouth College honor student last March might be re-opened when the grand jury convened on Sept. 14.

THE great delusion of the Salem witch frenzy seems to exert a perennial sway on the imagination of American writers. Two novels about it have already appeared this year and now an excellent history is published, "The Devil in Massachusetts,"* by Marion L. Starkey. Miss Starkey is an English professor, a historian, an uncommonly assiduous researcher and a competent writer.

Title was closed yesterday in the conveyance of the land under Russeks Fifth Avenue, Inc., at the southwest corner of Fifth Avenue and Thirty-sixth Street, which had been a holding of the William Waldorf Astor estate for more than half a century.
LAUSANNE, Switzerland, Aug. 29 -- Paul A. Porter, United States member of the United Nations' Palestine Conciliation Commission, left Lausanne today for the United States.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 29 (AP) -- The pennant dreams of the Boston Red Sox took a nightmarish turn today and they dropped a double-header to the Cleveland Indians, 5 to 2 and 5 to 4. With three losses in a row to Cleveland, they fell to four games behind the league-leading Yankees.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Aug. 29 (AP) -- Jockey Jimmy Stout of Lakewood, N. J., scored with five mounts on today's card here when he piloted Mrs. J. B. Bond's Turnabout to a head victory over Mrs. C. O. Ferguson's Crowflight, with Cape Hatteras third, in the seventh event.

A walkout of 175 members of Local 824 of the International Longshoremen's Association, AFL, at 1 P. M. yesterday prevented the unloading of two French Line freighters at Pier 88, West Forty-eighth Street.

The phenomenal growth of the juvenile theatre movement was clearly apparent from the attendance of more than 300 representatives, mostly women, at yesterday's first session of the fourth annual Children's Theatre Conference of the American Educational Theatre Association held at the Hotel Belmont-Plaza.

New prohibitionist efforts to "black out" all alcoholic liquor advertising with a proposed Federal law will meet the strongest opposition yet raised to such a measure by liquor industry, publishing and advertising groups, it was learned yesterday.

RANGOON, Burma, Aug. 29 (AP) -- Eighteen Americans trapped by civil war in Taunggyi were reported safe but efforts to remove them were complicated today by the rebel capture of Lashio, capital of the Northern Shan State and one-time railhead starting point of the old Burma Road to China.

MOSCOW, Aug. 29 -- An eight-line announcement by the Tass News Agency in Pravda revealed today that the Council for Economic Mutual Assistance, made up of the Soviet Union and six Eastern European states, had just concluded a meeting in Sofia, Bulgaria.

BERLIN, Aug. 29 -- Notification was given this evening to Mayor Ernst Reuter that the three Western Military Governors had designated their respective economic and financial advisers as a committee that would survey the needs of Berlin and make recommendations designed to improve its economic situation.

ARCATA, Calif., Aug. 29 (UP) -- The airport that boasts the "worst flying weather in the country" today ended a demonstration of the aircraft industry's newest weapons in the fight against "zero-zero" weather.

A Fordham squad, numbering fifty-six, which Coach Ed Danowski compared to pre-war elevens as far as size is concerned began five weeks of football praactice with a morning and afternoon session yesterday.
TOKYO, Aug. 29 -- Defeated on every front, Japan's Communist party is on the run for cyclone cellars. The Labor Division reports that never since the surrender has the labor situation been so quiet.

Thirty-five candidates for the City College football team opened their pre-season training schedule yesterday in Lewisohn Stadium with two-hour workouts in the morning and afternoon. Ten major lettermen were among the group that reported to Coach Frank Tubridy for fundamentals drills and blackboard work.

NEWBURGH, N. Y., Aug. 29 -- Mrs. Mary Imbrie Millard, widow of Charles Ramsdell Millard of this city, said here today that she had received word of his death from the Red Cross, which said a military investigation was under way.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- Officials of the Federal Housing Authority expressed the hope today that President Truman would act by Wednesday to release $115,000,000 in FHA insurance on loans for home improvements and repairs.

CHICAGO, Aug. 29 -- Grain markets developed a stronger undertone on the Board of Trade today. At no time was there any material pressure except on soybeans, which broke sharply at one time on scattered liquidation. All grains rallied late in the session, wheat gaining 3/4 to 1 1/2 cents on the day.
The screams of a woman merchant held up by two men at 1 A. M. yesterday attracted the police and resulted in the capture of a suspect in front of her grocery store at 3832 Broadway.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- Greater productivity and a trebling of exports to the dollar areas by reduced manufacturing costs and vigorous merchandising were prescribed today by Paul G. Hoffman, Economic Cooperation Administrator, as the only lasting solution to Britain's dollar crisis.

Dissension among the members and directors of Save Austria's Children, Inc., a philanthropic organization of 10 East Forty-third Street, was disclosed yesterday when Supreme Court Justice Henry Clay Greenberg denied a motion for a temporary injunction brought in the name of the corporation's president, Mrs. Emmerich Kalman.
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 29 -- Gov. Earl Warren observed today that California had more unemployment "than we can view with equanimity" and that still more was in prospect next winter.

WASHINGTON, Aug 29 -- The Transamerica Corporation, San Francisco, appealed today a ruling of the Federal Reserve Board which denied the company's motion that the board's charge of "tendence toward monopoly" be dismissed.

DOWN in St. Petersburg last spring the New York Yankees looked to be a bad ball club. So, for that matter, did their neighbors, the St. Louis Cardinals. Each was an over-age team with no new talent in sight. Each looked to be lucky to attain a ranking as high as the bottom of the second division -- which should show you how discerning the experts can be.

PARIS, Aug. 29 -- In a revised division of Marshall Plan dollars submitted today, Britain was asked to accept as her share for the current year $960,000,000 in place of the $840,000,000 that she had rejected as inadequate and unfair.

Repairs to the eastbound tube of the Holland Tunnel, which was damaged May 13 by an explosion and fire, have been all but completed and full service will be restored for the expected Labor Day week-end rush, it was made known yesterday.

It is usually daughters who try to look like their mothers, but the aspiration works both ways, according to Lane Bryant. A collection of casually styled clothes for sizes 18 to 52, including some half sizes, were shown to the press yesterday morning.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 29 (AP) -- Another defense witness testified today he heard the name Tokyo Rose long before Iva Toguri d'Aquino began broadcasting over Radio Tokyo.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Aug. 29 -- A German-Swiss trade agreement announced today was described by Allied Military Government officials as a significant milestone toward reassumption of long-neglected principles of free trade in Western Europe.

Despite a pronounced sales slump throughout the entire liquor industry during July and August, the last four months of the year will exceed the corresponding months during 1948, Harry Herrfeldt, vice president in charge of sales for Park Tilford Distillers, Inc., predicted yesterday at the company's annual sales meeting in the Commodore Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- The Senate broke a precedent today by approving a defense money bill that left the armed forces free to decide whether they wanted to use oleomargarine as a substitute for butter.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 29 -- "La Duchesse de Langeais," the vehicle for Greta Garbo's return to the screen after eight years of inactivity, will be distributed by RKO under a deal concluded by Walter Wanger and Eugene Frenke, producers of the film, their Hollywood representative announced today.

ROXBURY, Conn., Aug. 29 -- With the increasing interest being shown by American sportsmen in the Weimaraner, we decided it would be worth the journey to this rural community to look over Chet Cummings' kennels and watch him work these dogs on pheasants.
ROCHESTER, N. Y., Aug. 29 -- An unusual day in the annals of the United States amateur golf championship ended officially at 8 o'clock this evening when darkness forced officials to call a halt.

A new novel by Josephina Niggli, "Farewell, Mama Carlotta," will be brought out in January by Rinehart. Set in Mexico at the turn of the century, the story deals with two brothers and the legend of Mama Carlotta, symbol of Imperial Mexico kept alive by the upper 5 per cent of the Mexican people so that the 95 per cent might be held in subjection.

WITH THE GREEK ARMY, in the Grammos area, Aug. 29 -- A message received today at Greek Army headquarters said that the commander of the rebel Ninth Division and his entire staff, numbering about thirty persons, had been killed in fighting around Flamboura, in the northern sector of the Grammos area, where the army is engaged in mopping-up operations.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores increased 6 per cent last week over the corresponding period last year, according to the "flash" report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The decline for the four weeks ended last Saturday was 10 per cent.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 (UP) -- President Truman today signed into law a bill giving the Department of Agriculture sweeping new powers to cut down on cotton planting next year and thereafter.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- Rayon broad woven goods production amounted to 434,000,000 linear yards during the second quarter of 1949, the Bureau of Census, Department of Commerce, announced today. This is the lowest quarterly production reported since the fourth quarter of 1946, when 430,000,000 yards were produced. Second quarter production this year was 15 per cent less than in the first quarter and 22 per cent less than the same quarter of 1948.

A fifteen-horse scrimmage, the $18,300 Bay Shore Handicap, marked the return of the thoroughbreds to Aqueduct yesterday after the four-week session at Saratoga Springs. When the fifteen had unscrambled themselves, 19-to-1 shots had their numbers on the board in the top two spots.
PRETORIA, South Africa, Aug. 29 (AP) -- Field Marshal Jan Christiaan Smuts said today an ultra-nationalist state was developing in the Union of South Africa.

They didn't gain ground on the league-leading Cardinals, but the Dodgers didn't lose any, either, by beating the Pirates, 5 -- 1, before 24,031 fans at Ebbets Field last night. Keeping pace with the high-flying Redbirds, who were victorious at Boston, the Brooks remained two and a half lengths behind the St. Louis outfit.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- Cedric R. Worth, suspended Navy Department special assistant to the Under Secretary, and author of the nine-page document which touched off a House inquiry on B-36 bomber procurement, was designated an "interested party" today in proceedings of the Navy's court of inquiry that is to investigate the matter.

CHICAGO, Aug. 29 -- A deaf child, like one who can hear, learns most from his mother during the first two or three years of life, according to Dr. Alexander W. G. Ewing and his wife, Dr. Irene Ewing, internationally noted educators of deaf.

CHICAGO, Aug. 29 -- Casey Stengel, already weighed down with such worries as the loss of Tommy Henrich for the balance of the season, not to mention sundry other aches and ills that have scattered his Yankees all over the countryside, has a fresh woe awaiting him when he arrives in St. Louis tomorrow morning from the club's one-day junket tour to Kansas City.

BERLIN, Aug. 29 (AP) -- Five Soviet zone German policemen entered the United States zone today and reported they had fled to escape service with Communist guerrillas in Greece, a Military Government announcement said.

Trading in rubber futures on the Commodity Exchange showed a mixed price movement yesterday. The market closed 1 point up to 5 points off. Prices on September contracts were depressed by liquidation. Prices on December deliveries were firm.
NEWARK, N. J., Aug. 29 -- The city of Newark finished the last year with a surplus of $7,976,283, the municipal auditors reported today.

LONDON, Aug. 29 -- After a session of more than four hours today, the British Cabinet adopted a 15,000-word outline of policy to be followed by the British delegation to next month's talks in Washington on the sterling area's dollar deficit.

David E. Beards, 37-year-old Briton crippled by multiple sclerosis, left the New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, yesterday by plane for London. He said his treatment in this country had been curtailed by lack of funds.

Certificates of reasonable doubt were granted yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Francis X. Giaccone in Brooklyn to four defendants charged with fraudulent practices in the letting of plastering contracts in Brooklyn. All were admitted to bail pending the outcome of appeals to the Appellate Division, Second Department.

Although a slight rise in the number of new cases of polio and deaths in New York was reported over the week-end, the Department of Health announced yesterday that the current mild epidemic of infantile paralysis would not interfere with the opening of the schools here on Sept. 12.

The American Medical Association's top officials brought their traveling press conference yesterday to New York, second stop in a tour to place their arguments against President Truman's health insurance program before editors, writers and radio commentators.

CHICAGO, Aug. 29 -- The new midwest stock exchange announced today that it will be called officially the Midwest Stock Exchange. Votes on a name for the new organization were cast by members of four participating exchanges, those in Chicago, St. Louis, Cleveland and Minneapolis-St. Paul.

INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 29 -- The oldest of the six veterans attending the eighty-third annual encampment of the Grand Army of the Republic is leading a campaign to induce the youngest delegate to change his mind about this being the final meeting of the Boys in Blue.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 29 -- President Truman declared this afternoon that the United States would consider the economic plight of Great Britain, like the problems of any democratic country resisting the sweep of communism, "in a spirit of friendliness and helpfulness."
WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 (AP) -- The Air Force announced today it would make Barksdale Air Force Base at Shreveport, La., its strategic reconnaissance headquarters.
William Faulkner is rated abroad as this country's finest author, speakers asserted yesterday at the opening of the Institute of International Education's two-day conference at International House.
LONDON, Aug. 29 -- Gilt-edge stocks showed a marked downward trend in the stock market here today, with losses of 5 to 15 shillings. However, they rallied from their lowest levels before the close.

LONDON, Aug. 29 -- Yehudi Menuhin, who arrived in London recently for a European concert tour, has unwittingly become involved in a controversy with a powerful British trades organization. The issue is whether the violinist must keep an engagement to play on Yom Kippur, the most sacred day in the Jewish calendar.

BERLIN, Aug. 29 (AP) -- The United States Military Government said tonight that Russian officers had so far ignored its newest demand for release of two American bicycle tourists held in the Soviet zone of Germany.

Former Gov. Herbert H. Lehman will confer with Democratic State Chairman Paul E. Fitzpatrick and National Committeeman Edward J. Flynn here tomorrow on Mr. Lehman's possible candidacy for the United States Senate. The two Democratic party chieftains, and leaders of the Liberal party as well, invited Mr. Lehman, more than a month ago, to run for United States Senator on their tickets, and Mr. Lehman reserved decision.

More than 1,000,000 applications for shares in the national $2,800,000,000 rebate on service life insurance premiums were distributed yesterday in New York as World War II veterans queued up at Federal buildings, postoffices and offices of veterans' organizations.

The appointment of Edward A. Stiles as executive director of the New York State Association for Crippled Children was announced yesterday by the association at its headquarters, 257 Fourth Avenue. Mr. Stiles resigned recently as executive director of the New Jersey Society for Crippled Children.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- The long and bitter economy fight in the Senate to direct President Truman to cut appropriations made by Congress to a level 5 to 10 per cent below his budget estimates failed today, although a bipartisan majority of the full membership voted for such an order.

John Hermance has been appointed treasurer and controller of the Sherry-Netherland Hotel and executive assistant to Colonel Serge Obolensky, its president, effective on Sept. 1. He had been with the Roosevelt Hotel twenty-two years.

The ducks fly fast in the Adirondacks these days, but that may only mean that the feed is tastier in some other lake. A better sign of summer's end than south-bound ducks is the departure of the camping trailers from the Adirondacks, the homes on wheels that have been parked by lakesides all summer.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- New York leads the country in state taxes collected during the fiscal year of 1949 with a total of $893,000,000, the Census Bureau reported today.

Further restraint was exhibited yesterday by the stock market as prices backed away in a repetition of last week's performance. A slow decline which got under way at the opening went unchecked until the final hour, but even then the resistance failed to alter materially the action of prices.

The Presidential fact-finding board in the steel industry dispute with the United Steelworkers, CIO, over a fourth-round wage increase disclosed yesterday that it had offered its services to the disputants as mediators.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 29 (AP) -- The convention of the American Legion Women's Auxiliary got under way today with a plea that the women of the United States "do something about the future of our country."
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 29 (AP) -- Eighth-inning homers by Stan Lopata and Andy Seminick drove across three runs and gave the Philadelphia Phillies a 6-5 victory over the Chicago Cubs here tonight.

One of the aviation industry's most complex training devices -- the "land-based" cockpit of a large airliner that accurately simulates all the sounds, sensations and contingencies faced by commercial air crews -- has proved so successful in providing practical and economical training for pilot and flight engineer alike that it is now being used by two other transatlantic airlines in addition to its owner, Pan American Airways.
Following is the text of President Truman's address yesterday at the Thirty-first Annual Convention of the American Legion in Philadelphia, as recorded and transcribed by THE NEW YORK TIMES:

CHICAGO, Aug. 29 (AP) -- Meat supplies will continue short in relation to expected consumer demand for the next year, H. M. Conway, writing his monthly review for the National Live Stock Producers Association, said today.

Increased prices on meats, eggs and coffee have been reported in this column in the last few days. They're far from cheerful news to the housewife on a budget. Now, from the United States Department of Agriculture, comes its list of plentiful foods for September, information that should provide considerable help to those with only a limited amount of money to spend for food.

Although total public savings are declining in Britain, thrift funds have been accumulating since the end of the war at an accelerated rate in Scandinavia, the Netherlands and Belgium, despite current political and economic unsettlements, according to Henry S. Kingman, president of the National Association of Mutual Savings Banks.

The Army's Corps of Engineers is the nation's No. 1 flood control and navigation agency. The Bureau of Reclamation is primarily concerned with Western irrigation projects. Between them, the two agencies are responsible for many hundreds of millions of dollars' worth of past and projected dams and levees and other works that are changing the face of the nation.

The fight between Eugene P. Connolly, secretary of the New York County American Labor party, and Representative Vito Marcantonio, county and state ALP chairman, had its repercussions in lower Manhattan Magistrates court yesterday.

A survey of home building activity in the New York metropolitan area is now under way by the United States Department of Labor's Bureau of Labor Statistics, Robert R. Behlow, regional director, announced yesterday. The survey was started last month and the first results are expected to be available early in the fall.
Fears caused by the near-collapse several weeks ago of a building at 136 Macdougal Street were revived yesterday as demolition was resumed in another section of Washington Square South.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- The first effort to cut the Administration's $1,450,000,000 foreign military aid bill was defeated today, 11 to 9, in the Senate Foreign Relations and Armed Services Committees.

Just what the nation most needs to slow down whirring gears and smooth out frothy rapids of current events is a matter of opinion. One friend of ours misses the cracker barrel in the general store. He also feels that we will not have the right kind of gingerbread until we get some of the old-fashioned tangy molasses that came in barrels.

Public Service Commissioner George A. Arkwright finished yesterday the taking of testimony on the petition of the trustees of the Long Island Rail Road for a 16 2/3 per cent increase in its basic one-way passenger fares. There was no indication as to when the full commission would make known its decision.

HONG KONG, Aug. 29 (UP) -- The main Communist armies out-flanked the Government's South China defense line at the Kiangsi-Kwangtung border today and sent two columns toward Canton. Simultaneously, Communist guerrillas opened a new and greater threat to the emergency capital.
A 7-year-old boy spiritedly maneuvered his wheel chair yesterday in a sun-filled ward of the Willard Parker Hospital for Communicable Diseases, at the foot of East Fifteenth Street.

The Federal Trade Commission's recent report on concentration of economic power in twenty-six industries definitely overstates the degree of concentration in the shoe industry, it was charged yesterday by the National Shoe Manufacturers Association.

A new low price of $12.95 on RCA Victor's automatic 45-RPM record-playing attachment will be promoted with a heavy advertising and sales drive beginning on Sept. 20, it was announced yesterday. Price of the attachment is said to be the lowest for such an instrument ever marketed.

His friends and neighbors from New Jersey swamped Will Marshall with gifts last night at the Polo Grounds and, following the theme generated by this manifestation of generosity, the Giants proceeded to give Larry Jansen his fifteenth victory as they clubbed Bucky Walters' Reds into submission before a scant 7,804.

While sales of the City Stores Company for the three, six and twelve months ended with July were larger than those of the same periods of the previous year, earnings for the quarter and six months were lower, the report disclosed today, although they gained for the year.

Running for trains will be as old-fashioned as a minuet when October rolls into Grand Central Terminal. For train announcers will double as disk jockeys and tell travelers where to shuffle off to Buffalo, begin the boogie beat to Back Bay or chug-a-lug to the Chattanooga choo-choo.

Secretary of Defense Louis Johnson's recent order reducing civilian personnel in the national military establishment "merits the commendation of every American citizen," Earl Bunting, managing director of the National Association of Manufacturers, yesterday wrote Mr. Johnson.
BOSTON, Aug. 29 (AP) -- Taking full advantage of every opportunity, the St. Louis Cardinals scored seven times in the seventh inning tonight in trouncing the Boston Braves, 8 -- 2.

TULSA, Okla., Aug. 29 (AP) -- The Independent Petroleum Association of America predicted today that imports of crude oil would increase rather than decline in the final quarter of this year. It based its forecast on information it said was obtained from the Texas Railroad Commission.

The abolition of newspaper licensing in Bavaria, last of the American-occupied states, as reported by your correspondent Drew Middleton, places the whole responsibility for newspaper publishing into the hands of the German people. With this bestowal of practically unlimited liberty upon the German press, the United States omits an obligation to the American people, to the Allied nations, and to the German people.

CHICAGO, Aug. 29 -- In a move apparently aimed against bookmakers, the Illinois Bell Telephone Company today asked the Illinois Commerce Commission in Springfield for approval of a rule to withhold or withdraw its service from any unlawful use.

Camille Cianfarra's article on the discoveries beneath the basilica of St. Peter's in Rome, while treating of historical data at once most interesting and important, contains a number of misleading observations that should not be allowed to pass unchallenged. He refers first of all to the whole body of excavations as if they were a closely guarded secret.
STRASBOURG, France, Aug. 29 (UP) -- The European Assembly today prepared plans to set itself up as a permanent parliament for Western Europe.

SHANGHAI, Aug. 29 -- The United States and British information services in all areas of Communist China were ordered to close to prevent their "poisoning the souls of the Chinese people," the official New China News Agency said tonight.

Councilman Ira J. Palestin, Liberal, of the Bronx, announced yesterday that he would introduce a resolution in City Council this afternoon calling on the Federal Housing Expediter to stabilize residential rents here at levels not exceeding those of March 1.
To a Canadian reader the letter on aid to Britain from Elizur Yale Smith which you published in your issue of Aug. 23 is grotesquely misleading.
Michael J. Quill, president of the Transport Workers Union, CIO, predicted last night that the strike of 300 employes of the Triboro Coach Company in Queens would end within twenty-four hours.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- Yugoslavia, now looming so importantly in the European scene, has formally asked the Export-Import Bank for a loan of approximately $25,000,000, it was officially stated today.

The pity about the speech that President Truman made to the American Legion in Philadelphia is that it may seem dull to many readers. The Marxists, especially the contemporary Communists, have always had the luxury of being able to dramatize economics for popular consumption.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Aug. 29 (AP) -- Three Czechoslovak planes and a small troop detachment wandered over the frontier into the United States zone of Germany last weekend, but American officials discounted the incidents today as accidental.

Despite the rain and the threat of a violent storm, with a heavy wind blowing and the skies darkening, the national tennis championships started at Forest Hills yesterday and the entire program as scheduled was carried out with hardly an exception.

HONOLULU, Aug. 29 -- Hawaii's hotly contested dock-seizure laws survived an initial court test today when a two-judge ruling in Federal District Court denied a petition by the striking International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union for a temporary restraining order barring the Territorial Government from further operation of Hawaii's docks.
WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Aug. 29 (AP) -- The real crisis in the world today is one of production rather than one of fiscal proportions, business consultant Milo Perkins said here today.

ZVOLEN, Czechoslovakia, Aug. -- 29 -- Neither the Roman Catholic Church nor anyone else will be permitted to stand in the way of Czechoslovakia's socialist development, President Klement Gottwald declared today before a crowd of 100,000.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- July sales of all manufacturing companies dropped 6 per cent to $15,000,000,000, against $16,500,000,000 in June, the United States Department of Commerce estimated today.

Following testimony of two prosecution witnesses at yesterday's session in the year-long Coast Guard case of charges against Capt. Frederic Sundlof, former master of the American tanker Chrysanthystar, the hearing, which took place at Coast Guard district headquarters, 80 Lafayette Street, was adjourned until 10 A. M. Sept. 8.

LONDON, Aug. 29 -- Leaders of Britain's shipping industry who have recently warned against rising construction costs here are carefully following the Congressional investigation in Washington into American shipping subsidies.
The State of North Carolina will receive bids on Sept. 28 on its proposed offering of $50,000,000 of road bonds, Brandon P. Hodges, State Treasurer, announced yesterday.
DETROIT, Aug. 29 -- The United Automobile Workers, CIO, has until midnight Friday to make known its intentions in its dispute with the Ford Motor Company, it was learned today.

LAKE SUCCESS, Aug. 29 -- The most recent census of the big game population of the United States shows that there are about 7,750,000 animals in the country and the upward trend appears to be continuing, Albert M. Day, director of the Fish and Wildlife Service, said today.

Mayor O'Dwyer reminisced for a few moments yesterday about his days on New York's police force thirty-two years ago, in his address of welcome to the fifteenth annual conference of the Associated Police Communications Officers.
The Maritime Commission will embark on an intensive program to clear out a backlog of claims involving millions of dollars, it was announced yesterday.

The "subdued remains" of the Florida hurricane struck the city and suburbs early yesterday morning. While little serious damage resulted, high winds toppled power lines and deprived 50,000 customers of electric service.

Tourists returning from Europe should prepare themselves this year for more than the usual annoyance on the piers occasioned by customs inspection. A news story recently published in THE TIMES indicated that, under the present law, in calculating the amount of duty payable on merchandise purchased abroad, the hard-pressed inspectors are required to apply an exchange rate which has little basis of reality.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 29 -- Legionnaire Harry S. Truman took time out today from his job as President to steal the show at the opening here of the American Legion's thirty-first national convention.

The privately owned electric utilities in the United States had a net income of $385,309,000 in the first half of this year, a rise of 14 per cent over the $338,084,000 reported in the same period of 1948, according to a report by the Federal Power Commission.

Floyd B. Odlum, president of the Atlas Corporation, in his semi-annual report to stockholders yesterday, announced that the Atlas Corporation's common stock had an asset value of $26.27 a share on last June 30, and of $28.10 on last Thursday, Aug. 25. The asset value was $27.18 a share on Dec. 31, 1948.

There is a "remote possibility" that color television receivers will be available to the consumer by 1953 at the earliest, Benjamin Abrams, president, Emerson Radio Phonograph Corporation, said yesterday during a press conference.

Competition for rayon goods finishing contracts has kept dyeing and printing costs at a low figure despite the recent increase in gray goods prices, it was pointed out yesterday. Finishers find themselves in a squeeze, they said, between converters who are paying more for cloth and cutters and retailers who are not yet willing to recognize the need for higher finished goods prices.

MOUNT KISCO, N. Y., Aug. 29 -- Heavy morning rain and wind cut the field in the one-day tournament of the Westchester P. G. A. to only thirty pro-amateur teams at the Mount Kisco Country Club today and scores generally soared with the breezes.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 (AP) -- Administration spokesmen offered Congress wide leeway today to divide the revenue from oil-rich tidelands, but renewed objections to any outright transfer of the land to the states.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was moderately active yesterday and final prices were 3 to 10 points net lower than last week's closing levels.

DAYTON, Ohio, Aug. 29 -- Still in disagreement on at least eight major points, negotiators for the striking United Rubber Workers, CIO, and the B. F. Goodrich Company met here today for six hours in an atmosphere that was civil, but unproductive.

R. H. Macy Co. won the right to sell Du Mont television sets at cut rate prices yesterday when Supreme Court Justice Henry Clay Greenberg denied a motion brought by Allen B. Du Mont Laboratories, Inc., seeking to restrain the department store from advertising and selling Du Mont sets at reduced prices.

LAKE SUCCESS, Aug. 29 -- Construction of a canal to link two of South America's great rivers was suggested here today to navigation experts as a means of opening up the continent's land-locked interior to trade and economic development.

A four-man Arctic shelter, designed to enable airmen to survive in relative comfort even when forced down near the Poles, was shown for the first time here yesterday at the twentieth meeting of the Aero Medical Association at the Statler Hotel.

Despite the fact that business actively has receded rather substantially from its post-war flood tide of late 1948, current statistics indicate that the economic status of the wage-earner has been comparatively well maintained, in terms of past experience.

A home club team consisting of Patrick McGee and Stanley Remsen won the Long Island P. G. A. amateur-pro best-ball tournament yesterday over the North Hills course at Douglaston with a 9 under par 32, 31 -- 63.

State and city officials got first-hand evidence yesterday that the metropolitan housing shortage was still critical when the opening of applications for two large-scale projects attracted more than 3,000 home-seekers.

CONCORD, N. H., Aug. 29 (AP) -- Senator Styles Bridges, Republican, of New Hampshire, tonight accused Ezra van Horn, a trustee of the United Mine Workers Welfare Fund, of "obstructionism" and attempting to "hamstring" the fund.

BURLINGTON, Vt., Aug. 29 -- Roman Catholic parishes in large metropolitan centers are little more than "efficiently-run sacramental filling stations," Msgr. L. G. Ligutti, executive secretary of the National Catholic Rural Life Conference, said here today.
FAIRBANKS, Alaska, Aug. 29 (AP) -- The discovery of two unmapped and unclimbed peaks in the Mount McKinley area has been reported by a Boston scientist.

A new type of picture tube which is said to reduce eyestrain for television viewers by improving sharpness and contrast featured the introduction yesterday in the Pierre Hotel of the new television and radio-phonograph combination line of Capehart-Farnsworth Corporation, an associate of International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation.

Beatrice Kay, the singer with the tremulous voice who chants those nostalgic numbers of the Mauve Decade, signed contracts yesterday to undertake the leading feminine role in the forthcoming musical "And So to Wed." This is the production that has a book by Eddie Davis and Harold Liss and score by Bob Stanton and Marty Clark, which is being brought to Broadway by Aline Hudson, a Hollywood agent.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, Aug. 29 (UP) -- The Bolivian Government ordered a general mobilization tonight of all able-bodied citizens between the ages of 19 and 50 as rebel forces held out for the third day against Government ground and air attacks.

Two persons may or may not be able to live as cheaply as one today, but Charles E. Summers and his family demonstrated on their arrival yesterday at La Guardia Airport, Queens, from Doylestown, Ohio, that eight can fly as cheaply as two and a half.

Telecasts of fifteen professional gridiron games to be played in the National Football League will be carried this fall by the American Broadcasting Company.
