They will be seen in twelve non-league cities and also in certain NFL cities, provided no local league game is being played at the same time.

Governor Dewey ordered yesterday a complete report from Westchester County's two top law enforcement officials on Saturday night's outbreak of violence near Peekskill that prevented a scheduled concert by Paul Robeson, baritone and leader in left wing political movements.
Two sets of young twins born of a wartime romance faced last night the prospect of being brought up by their father and grandfather as an aftermath of this year's polio outbreak.
A former Army Quartermaster Corps industrial consultant who had been mentioned in the "5 per cent" inquiry in Washington was being sought last night by the New York police as a hotel beat.
Residential properties dominated the transactions in various sections of Long Island reported yesterday by brokers and title companies.

LAKE SUCCESS, Aug. 29 -- A warning that the economically backward nations can only hinder their own development by misplanned industrial expansion was voiced at the plenary meeting of the United Nations Scientific Conference on the Conservation and Utilization of Resources here today.

The Sinclair Oil Corporation has made arrangements with an insurance company for a twenty-five-year, 3 per cent loan of $50,000,000 to be available for expansion of crude oil production, P. C. Spencer, president, announced yesterday. Only $5,000,000 of the loan is to be taken down this year. Repayments of principal are not to commence until the twenty-first year of the loan.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 (AP) -- The Secretary of the Interior, Julius A. Krug, presented to Congress today a $2,000,000,000 program for water resource development of California's Central Valley basin.
RANGOON, Burma, Aug. 30 (AP) -- A Burmese Army spokesman said today a pact between Karen rebels and Kachin tribesmen had been dissolved.

E. M. Helwig will retire as director of purchases of Burroughs Adding Machine Company, Detroit, effective tomorrow. Mr. Helwig, who has been with the Burroughs company for the last forty years, will continue to be available to the Burroughs contract division for counsel.

A dispute involving contract interpretation between the Isbrandtsen Company, Inc., and the Marine Engineers Beneficial Association, CIO, which has been going on since Aug. 16, culminated yesterday afternoon in a work stoppage aboard the company's cargo vessel Sir John Franklin.

Gil Hodges came gallantly to the rescue with a two-run homer in the ninth inning yesterday, just when it appeared that the Dodgers were about to muff a beckoning opportunity to close in on the pace-setting Cardinals.

For the first time in its history the New York City Federation of l Women's Clubs, which represents 200,000 members, will have a welfare and mental health department, it was announced yesterday by Mrs. Claire M. Senie, the federation's new president.

A Texan, who the police charge concealed a pistol by strapping it to his leg, was remanded with an alleged companion to the City Prison yesterday to await possible confirmation from Port Arthur, Tex., that they were wanted there for the kidnapping and robbery of a married couple.

LONDON, Aug. 30 -- Flight refueling in the air, the possibilities of which were dramatized recently by the round-the-world non-stop flight of the United States bomber Lucky Lady, may become standard commercial procedure here in a few months if the plans of the Ministry of Civil Aviation materialize.
The week-old strike of 300 employes of the Triboro Coach Company in Queens ended yesterday on the terms the men had rejected before the tie-up began.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- Democratic and Republican foreign policy leaders in Congress reached a reconciliation, in principle, today on the Administration's foreign military aid bill.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 30 -- The surprising Browns, who have been enjoying a deal of fun of late tripping various contenders, took it out on the front runners tonight as they flattened the harried Yankees, 6 to 2, in the opener of a three-game series.

On June 13, last, the Senate Committee on Expenditures in the Executive Departments approved a resolution which, if supported on the floor of the Chamber, would have directed the President to introduce a general cut in appropriations for the Executive branch for fiscal 1949-50.
The Yugoslav Government freighter Gorica, docked in the East River near Bush Terminal, at Twentieth Street, Brooklyn, began unloading yesterday 7,700 tons of metal worth more than $1,800,000.

The ninety-sixth annual report of Mount Sinai Hospital opens with a chronology that its author must have enjoyed writing. What began in 1852 as a haven for the sick, incorporated for "benevolent, charitable and scientific purposes," has become a hospital of national importance.

Kings County Judge Samuel S. Leibowitz, Alberto Tarchiani, Italian Ambassador to the United States, and Dr. Luigi Crocco, a jet propulsion expert, were among the 1,497 passengers who arrived here yesterday on the Italian liner Saturnia.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- Maj. Gen. Harry H. Vaughan, President Truman's military aide, told the Senate "five percenter" inquiry today that he had received approximately $5,000 for the Democratic Congressional campaign in 1946 from John F. Maragon, a central figure in the investigation, and William Helis, owner of a large stable of race horses.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were steady yesterday and closed unchanged to 13 points net higher on the day.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 (AP) -- the United States Treasury today made its first offering of one-year Government securities at the recently announced cut-rate of interest: 1 1/8% per cent. Since last October the Government has paid 1 1/4% per cent on money borrowed for one year.

An arthritic man with a name found on many police blotters told a judge in Camden, N. J. yesterday that his brother, "Count" Victor Lustig, one of the most notorious counterfeiters and international confidence men of this century, was dead.
It's Hennessey Place again and the Bronx rejoices.

BERLIN, Aug. 30 -- The German trade fair in Leipzig, which has been held in spring and fall since the Middle Ages, opened today. The goods Eastern Germany could offer on the world markets were scarce and of poor quality, but the propaganda offered to visitors was plentiful.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- Maj. Gen. Harry H. Vaughan, who told a Senate investigations subcommittee today that his friendship with President Truman spanned thirty years, has held his present rank since May 31, 1946, when the President pinned the second star on his shoulders.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- One of the most elusive targets ever confronting an anti-aircraft gunner, a pilotless, radio-controlled, ram-jet powered drone that streaks across the skies almost as fast as the speed of sound, will soon be put into practice by the Navy.

Changes involving the occupancy of seven Brooklyn piers were announced yesterday by the De La Rama Steamship Company, Inc., and the Transportadora Grancolombiana, Ltda., the two lines involved in the moves.

Pointing to moves being made in and out of Congress to halt current economic readjustment by "injections of the inflationary virus," the Guaranty Trust Company asked yesterday whether or not an orderly economic readjustment in the United States has become impossible.
Left-wing affiliates of the Congress of Industrial Organizations announced for the first time last night that they intended to remain in the CIO and fight all efforts to dislodge them.

AVALON, N. J., Aug. 30 -- Robert McGill, 7-year-old son of Mr. and Mrs. J. F. McGill of Roxborough, Pa., vacationers here, was injured critically today in a fall from a fifty-five-foot Coast Guard tower.

The Russian airmen, Lieut. Piotr Pirogov and Lieut. Anatoli P. Barsov, took off from the Ukraine last Oct. 9 in a two-engined Russian bomber, crash-landed at Hoersching air base near Linz. Austria, ten miles inside the American zone, and refused to return to the Soviet Union.

Twenty pounds of green marijuana, said by Custom House officials to be the largest shipment detected in many months, were uncovered yesterday in a routine search of the Atlantic, Gulf West Indies Lines freighter Agwi-princess soon after the vessel arrived from Tampico, Mexico.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Aug. 30 -- An attempt to overthrow Czechoslovakia's Communist Government was launched but suppressed almost before it got started last spring, the official Government news agency reported today.

CHICAGO, Aug. 30 -- Representatives of all phases of the motion-picture industry gathered here today to discuss their box-office and legal troubles and seek a comprehensive public relations program. The meeting will close tomorrow night.
With the withdrawal of offerings of tin yesterday by the Ministry of Supply in London, trading in Straits tin for forward delivery came to a standstill here yesterday.

A more lasting solution to the British Commonwealth's export-sterling problems, beyond anticipated financial and tariff adjustments, lies in greatly expanded advertising in this country of basic raw materials, it was declared yesterday by advertising officials directing current promotion of British products here.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- President Truman today urged more than 300 members of his committee to aid the physically handicapped to devote another year to their cause and proclaimed National Employ the Physically Handicapped Week, which opens Oct. 2.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- Louis Johnson, Secretary of Defense, ordered today all possible assistance in getting new jobs for the 135,000 civilian employes who are to be dismissed as the start of an economy drive. He directed cooperation with the United States Employment Service and the Civil Service Commission.

MOSCOW, Aug. 30 -- The latest weapon in the hands of American forces seeking "to Marshallize" Europe has been incendiary forest fires, designed not only to ruin the French turpentine industry but to pave the way for the establishment of a military Fascist dictatorship in France, according to a Soviet commentator.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- President Truman has moved to halt the spread of communism in Asia by appealing to India and Pakistan to settle their bitter dispute over the rich Kashmir state, it was disclosed tonight.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- The State Department disclosed tonight that a Soviet Air Force deserter who had sought political asylum here, and then apparently changed his mind, was back in Austria under United States jurisdiction with the freedom to return to the Soviet Union if he wished.

With the emergence of investment trust shares as a major segment of the securities industry -- more than $1,500,000,000 has been entrusted to investment companies -- public interest in them was further emphasized yesterday in a survey which showed ownership of such shares in every state of the Union.

A showcase for new talent will be unveiled by WOR-Mutual on Oct. 1 when it presents the "Gabriel Heatter Opportunity Show" as a regular Saturday evening radio feature from 8:30 to 9 o'clock. The commentator will introduce four entertainers each week and tell the stories behind their bids for fame.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- The Canam Mining Corporation, Ltd., Vancouver, B. C., Canada, filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering 1,000,000 shares of non-par value common stock that it proposes to offer only in the United States.

ROCHESTER, N. Y., Aug. 30 -- With a clever victory over Erich W. Marchand of Rochester in the fourth round today, Larry Evans of New York, defending titleholder, moved into a triple tie for first place with Max Pavey of Brooklyn and Jack Soudakoff of the Bronx in the championship tournament of the New York State Chess Association.

The stock market remained virtually stalemated yesterday with irregular price movements throughout the day and closing slightly higher. The volume was so small as to make price changes meaningless, as business on the Stock Exchange fell to a two-month low of 590,000 shares, against 640,000 shares on Monday.

" Broadway Johnny" Broderick, who had a twenty-five-year reputation as a "tough cop" who roughed up gangsters, was disclosed yesterday to have been forced to retire from the Police Department because of intimate association with gangsters.

Charles E. Wilson, president of the General Electric Company, said yesterday that this country was capable of expanding its national income to President Truman's $300,000,000,000 estimate with consequent higher living standards for all segments of the population.

NORWALK, Conn., Aug. 30 -- The State Department's assertion that Barsov was sent to Austria to enable him freely to determine his own course is proof that Barsov was not able to make a free decision when he was in the United States, according to Isaac Don Levine, anti-Communist editor of Plain Talk magazine.

The Borden Company estimates its net income for the first six months of 1949 at $10,200,000, equal to $2.37 a common share, according to the report of Theodore G. Montague, president, mailed to stockholders yesterday. In the same period a year ago the company earned $9,000,000, or $2.10 a share.

A Brooklyn landlord was indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury on a charge of submitting to the Office of the Housing Expediter false invoices in support of an application for a rent increase. The case was described as the first in the New York area in which the agency is seeking criminal prosecution of an alleged offender of the Rent Control Law.

LONDON, Aug. 30 -- The Soviet Union renewed its bitterly abusive attack on Yugoslavia tonight, calling her leaders deserters and "wild Fascists" and saying Moscow was no longer defending Belgrade's claims on Austria because Yugoslavia herself had renounced her claims on Slovene Carinthia.

The Union Settlement will take over on the night of Nov. 3 the performance of "Double Bill," comprising two plays by Terence Rattigan, with Maurice Evans and Edna Best in the leading roles, at the Coronet Theatre. Proceeds will further the work of the Settlement, 237 East 104th Street, which carries on varied recreational and educational enterprises.

An air cargo agreement, by which shipments between the United States and almost any point in the world can be made on one airway bill, has been arranged between Slick Airways and Pan American Airways, it was announced yesterday.
CARATUNK, Me., Aug. 30 (AP) -- A weary and footsore Boston University professor, Carl E. Purinton, lost four days in the rugged Dimmick Mountain wilderness, was found today by Maine guides.

The American motion-picture industry should, as a matter of business expediency, if nothing else, do all it can to help film production in England and other countries, Spyros Skouras, president of Twentieth Century-Fox, asserted yesterday.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., Aug. 30 -- Government action to maintain high purchasing power for farmers and labor is necessary to avoid an economic depression in the United States, a conference of farm and labor union leaders was told today by the Secretary of Agriculture, Charles F. Brannan and by Maurice J. Tobin, Secretary of Labor.

Governor Dewey was urged yesterday by the City Council to call an immediate emergency session of the State Legislature to enact "proper curbs upon rent increases" granted under the Federal net operating income formula.

INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 30 -- Six centenarians of the Grand Army of the Republic, here for their eighty-third -- and last -- encampment, were smothered today in the embraces of the G. A. R. ladies auxiliaries.

Producers of paint, lacquer and varnish expressed confidence yesterday at the Statler Hotel that their products are facing a steadily increasing long-term demand from both consumers and manufacturers. At a meeting of representatives of the National Paint, Varnish and Lacquer Association, a group with approximately 2,000 members from all trade levels, it was emphasized that the industry is strongly optimistic.

BOSTON, Aug. 30 (AP) -- For most of the season the Braves had been "cousins" to the Cardinals, losing fifteen of nineteen previous games, but today Boston turned on the National League leaders, walloping them, 12 to 4.

Higher and higher go the newest-looking necklines for fall, tipping the ears and buttoning under the chin. The fashionable woman no longer needs to turn up her collar for a chic effect -- now it is cut with a high and handsome air.

Two hundred persons, mostly women and children, held up traffic for half an hour yesterday morning at two intersections of Hopkinson Avenue in the Brownsville section of Brooklyn, in protest against the absence of traffic lights at those points.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 30 -- It was learned tonight that the British Government had officially asked the Yugoslav Government what its attitude would be if the current Balkan crisis were to be openly presented to the United Nations Security Council. There has not been any official reply on behalf of the Belgrade regime.
The Presidential fact-finding board in the dispute over a fourth wage round between the steel industry and the United Steelworkers, CIO, withdrew yesterday its offer to serve as mediator.

More than 300 representatives of children's theatres throughout the nation attended yesterday morning the second session of the Children's Theatre Conference under the auspices of the American National Theatre and Academy, at Hunter College.
HONG KONG, Wednesday, Aug. 31 (UP) -- The Chinese Government today announced the appointment of American-trained Gen. Sun Lijen to conduct the defense of Formosa, the Nationalists last-ditch bastion.
KASTORIA, Greece, Aug. 30 -- The last escape routes permitting orderly withdrawal of rebel military formations into Albania had been closed by sunrise today.

Early Heath got up late in the Exile at Aqueduct, but she got up just late enough to beat Ceara in a thrilling finish of the five-and-a-half furlong feature race yesterday. Under a sparkling ride by Sebastian Perez, Early Heath slipped into the photo at the wire, and developments revealed that she earned the victory over her pace-setting rival.
LONDON, Aug. 30 -- If his work permits, Foreign Secretary Ernest Bevin wishes to visit Canada while he is in North America for the Washington financial talks and other conferences.
A round behind the field, Richard (Pancho) Gonzales of Los Angeles made his first appearance in defense of his title yesterday in the national tennis championships at Forest Hills.
LA PAZ, Bolivia, Aug. 30 (AP) -- Bolivia's General Staff announced a victory at Cochabamba tonight in the Army's first major battle with rebels trying to overthrow the Government.

RENO, Nev., Aug. 30 -- Mrs. Carolin Bunmiller Wharton was divorced here today from John F. Wharton, New York lawyer and president and one of the founders of The Playwrights Company, a Broadway theatrical organization. The divorce was granted on grounds of cruelty.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- The Military Procurement Information Center, started by the Department of Defense two weeks ago in the hope of rendering "five percenters" obsolete, is one of the busiest establishments in the Pentagon. It has set itself up in room 3-D-760, only a few steps from the office of Louis Johnson, Secretary of Defense.

I have read with interest both Robert S. Fougner's letter appearing previously on your editorial page, and Sidney S. Bobbe's letter appearing Aug. 25, both of which concern Councilman Sharkey's proposal to amend the New York City Local Rent Law.

BERLIN, Aug. 30 -- A distinct though indirect warning was issued today to the Soviet by Gen. Sir Brian Robertson that removal of the main British Military Government headquarters in October to the vicinity of the capital of the new Western German state would not imply any relaxation of interest in Berlin.

Former Governor Herbert H. Lehman returned to the city yesterday, after a vacation at Lake Placid, and held the first of a series of conferences that will determine whether he will accept the Democratic and Liberal party nomination for the United States Senate.

DETROIT, Aug. 30 (AP) -- Two home runs and a walk with the bases loaded enabled the Red Sox to snap eight-game winning streaks today for both the Tigers and Pitcher Freddie Hutchinson. The score was 3 to 0.

HONOLULU, Aug. 30 -- Negotiations were resumed late today in another effort to end Hawaii's 112-day dock strike. But there was little hope that any agreement could be reached on a new wage figure for the 2,000 or so striking Hawaii longshoremen.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 (AP) -- Prices of spot cotton during the 1948-49 season were approximately 2 1/2 cents a pound lower than last season, the Department of Agriculture said day. The season's average price for middling fifteen-sixteenth inch cotton was 32:15 cents, compared with 34.58 cents last season.

The arrival of canned clams in the shell, a product that's being introduced at Macy's, is opportunely timed. The Fishery Council reports that the fresh variety, especially the soft shell ones, are scarce and expensive now. The tinned specimens, which are packed by the House of Stevens in Braintree, Mass., are delectable enough to provide a satisfactory substitute.

Traffic through the Suez Canal during the first six months of this year reached a record high despite the fact that activities dropped sharply in June, according to the latest bulletin of the Suez Canal Company (Compagnie Universelle de Canal Maritime de Suez).

TOKYO, Aug. 30 -- The Japanese Government acted swiftly today to enact the recommendations of Dr. Carl S. Shoup of Columbia, chief of the United States tax mission, for a sweeping revision of the Japanese tax system.

The testimony of Maj. Gen. Harry H. Vaughan yesterday before the Senate subcommittee investigating "five percenters" brought this phase of the hearings to something of a climax. It is a good point at which to step back and try to view the bizarre picture in some perspective.

Mary L. Jobe Akeley, who with her husband, Carl Akeley, helped establish a chain of wild game sanctuaries in the Congo, has just completed the manuscript of a new book about her experiences there. She was recently commissioned by the Belgian Government to return to Africa and describe the wonders of all the Congo wild life preserves.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 (AP) -- Housing officials said today that Tighe E. Woods, housing expediter, would begin studying broad surveys next week to determine how far his agency would go in a cut-back of rent controls.

BURLINGTON, Vt., Aug. 30 -- A "Liturgical Cook Book," designed to integrate religious teachings with the practical day-to-day business of preparing a meal, will be published next month by the National Catholic Rural Life Conference, it was learned here today. The book will be divided into six sections according to the Liturgical seasons.

CHICAGO, Aug. 30 -- In one of the most daring crimes in Chicago police history, two gunmen late last night raided the City Hall office of Joseph L. Gill, Chief Clerk of the Municipal Court, who is also secretary-treasurer of the Cook County Democratic Organization.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 (UP) -- Representative Michael J. Kirwan, Democrat, of Ohio, chairman of the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee, announced today that he would make a district-by-district survey of eleven Western states with an eye to increasing Democratic representation in the Eighty-second Congress.
In a matter of some importance in the history of art, may I ask that you correct a misstatement which appeared in the Aug. 10 issue of THE NEW YORK TIMES.

ROCHESTER, N. Y., Aug. 30 -- The initial appearance of the defending champion, Willie Turnesa of Elmsford, N. Y., who scored a 1-up triumph by playing at a 69 clip, and the elimination of three British Walker Cup stars, including the British titleholder, Max McCready, marked the second round of the United States amateur golf tournament at the Oak Hill Country Club today.

Out of town buyers registered in the market for the week ended yesterday numbered 1,409 compared with 1,862 last week and 1,341 in the similar week a year ago, according to the listings appearing in THE NEW YORK TIMES.

The New York Football Giants staged a two-hour drill on Fordham Field yesterday morning with emphasis on their offensive formations. The first hour was given over to running through attack plays, with Charlie Conerly calling the signals from the newly-in-stalled "T" formation.

Dollar volume of initial orders from distributors for the Motorola, Inc., 1950 television and radio receiver line exceeds the amount for first orders taken for the 1949 line by 103 per cent, Paul Galvin, president, revealed in an interview yesterday. The new line was first shown to the company's distributors in Chicago three weeks ago.

NEWARK, N. J., Aug. 30 -- A turning point in the 10-year struggle of the Central Railroad of New Jersey to reorganize under the Federal Bankruptcy Act was reached in Federal court here today when Judge Guy L. Fake approved an order returning all company property to the railroad as of 12:01 A. M. Oct. 1.
LAUSANNE, Switzerland, Aug. 30 -- The United Nations Palestine Conciliation Commission is beginning to feel the need of new terms of reference as a basis for its work.

Virtually every World War 11 veteran in New York had his application form for a rebate on his service life insurance premiums yesterday, only the second day of the national distribution of the blanks.

A 16-year-old boy, who was accidentally shot in the left eye by a friend who was showing him a revolver from his collection of firearms Monday evening, died at 5:23 A. M. yesterday at Methodist Hospital, Brooklyn. The owner of the revolver is Thomas Adesso, 21, an ice man, of 135 Twenty-third Street, Brooklyn.

The young lad Richard Rodgers and Oscar Hammerstein 2d have in mind for the central role in "The Happy Time" is Johnny Stewart, who celebrated his thirteenth birthday on May 21. Quite a search had been conducted by the noted producers to find a capable youngster for the major assignment in Samuel A. Taylor's dramatization of the Robert Fontaine book.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 30 -- The American Legion gave Philadelphia the city's biggest parade today -- a twelve-hour spectacle as only the Legion knows how to stage.

The police of the Astoria precinct in Queens spent six hours early yesterday in a vain effort to figure out who did what to whom in a mystery that involved three shots, an automobile crash, a vanished truck loaded with candy from a strikebound plant, a man with a possibly fractured skull, a mobile arsenal and a union president.
Miss Kathlene Murtha is retiring at the end of next week after forty-nine years of making change for Brooklyn rapid transit riders.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 30 -- The latest Soviet note to the Yugoslav Government was considered tonight in Belgrade as forming another backdrop of psychological "frightfulness" for new maneuvers by the Moscow Government to overthrow the Tito regime.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Aug. 30 (AP) -- Manchac, a candidate for the $25,000 added Atlantic City Turf Handicap on Labor Day, received his final tune-up for the country's richest grass race by winning the Avalon Purse today.

CHICAGO, Aug. 30 -- Scientists at the Argonne National Laboratory for atomic energy research announced today that they had perfected a chemical treatment for protecting rats and mice against death from exposure to more than double the amount of lethal radiations needed to kill a human being.

Tomorrow opens the season for the eating of the oyster, one of the most prolific of the bivalves, and both oyster eaters and oyster growers are pretty much excited about it. They're particularly excited because, according to the growers and the Oyster Institute Information Bureau, at 20 East Thirty-fifth Street, the indications are this will be the best oyster season in ten years.
The National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis said yesterday that country-wide statistics that should be available today might indicate whether the peak of the epidemic had been passed.

With demand for nylon fabrics outstripping supply, fabric converters and weavers will find themselves unable to fill their commitments for delivery of the cloth, it was predicted yesterday in the trade. Garment cutters who have spearheaded promotional campaigns with nylon dresses, underwear and outerwear, it was said, are facing substantial losses in volume because of a lack of nylon material.

PALO ALTO, Calif., Aug. 30 (Science Service) -- How tall a growing child will be when he is grown up is now being predicted to within a quarter of an inch by scientists at the Leland Stanford University here.

LONDON, Aug. 30 -- The Soviet announcement "withdrawing" support of Yugoslav claims to territory in Slovene Carinthia, in Austria, will have little if any effect on the deadlocked Austrian treaty talks here, informed observers say.

ENGLEWOOD, N. J., Aug. 30 -- Just on the outskirts of this town in a setting of woodland, flower gardens and vegetable patches stands a three-story white rambling house. It rests on the rolling hill of a seven-acre site blanketed by elm, maple and ailanthus trees and bordered on all sides by trim hedgegrows.

A banking syndicate headed by Blyth Co., Inc., bought at competitive sale yesterday an issue of $4,000,000 of tax-exempt serial sewer revenue bonds of the Metropolitan Sewer District of Louisville and Jefferson County, Ky. The price was 100.051 for a combination of rates representing a net interest cost of 1.8644 per cent to the borrower.

After swearing to tell the truth, the whole truth and nothing but the truth as a defense witness at the Communist trial, Max Weiss, the Communist party's Midwest regional coordinator, was confronted with documents on cross-examination yesterday that made him admit:

In the constantly growing daily grist of news concerning aviation; first flights of new planes, new and seemingly bizarre uses for fixed wing aircraft and heliocopters, speed records and the like, it is easy to lose sight of the steadily mounting accumulation of accomplishments which does not make the headlines but which bears witness to the solid growth of commercial flying.

A large fan, strange as it may seem, when combined with an electric heater, can increase heating efficiency. This is the idea incorporated in a highly effective portable heater just introduced by the General Electric Company.
LONDON, Aug. 30 (AP) -- Following is the text of a Soviet note to Yugoslavia as broadcast by the Moscow radio and recorded here by the Soviet Monitor, an affiliate of the Soviet Tass agency:
HELSINKI, Finland, Aug. 30 (AP) -- There were indications tonight that the Communists would stand alone in an expected fight against Finland's Government when Parliament opened Thursday.

BELMAR, N. J., Aug. 30 -- Fate and the weather man conspired to wipe out the tuna score of the eighty boats that alternately chummed and trolled the waters of the mudhole today in the opening of the United States Atlantic Tuna Tournament.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 30 (AP) -- This city's largest fire in years today swept through a grocery warehouse of the Safeway Stores, Inc. Upwards of thirty-five firemen were injured. Damage was estimated at $4,500,000.

SANDS POINT, L. I., Aug. 30 -- Mrs. Mortimer May of Willow Brook, former Metropolitan and New York State champion, led a field of twenty contestants in the first eighteen holes of the New York District sectional qualifying round for the Women's National amateur championship today.

UMPIRES are human, contrary to popular belief. Most of them also are very nice guys. But there is none nicer than Bill Klem, the self-styled Old Arbitrator, who served as a National League umpire for thirty-six years and then acted as chief of staff -- he made up the title himself -- for the senior circuit's Boys in Blue for the next eight years.
CAMDEN, N. J., Aug. 30 -- Emil Lustig, 57-year-old confidence man, was permitted to sign his own bail bond today, pending a new trial on a charge of counterfeiting.

STRASBOURG, France, Aug. 30 (AP) -- The European Consultative Assembly's general affairs (political) committee unanimously adopted today proposals for a permanent year-round executive body within the assembly.

DETROIT, Aug. 30 -- Walter P. Reuther, president of the United Automobile Workers, CIO, returned to the bargaining table today in the union's negotiations with the Ford Motor Company and the talks shifted from non-economic issues to pensions, medical care and a fourth-round wage increase.

Rubber futures gained 13 to 23 points in active trading on the Commodity Exchange yesterday. The upturn in quotations following the previous session's mixed prices, reflected a stronger tone in the London market where prices were up 1/8d.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 (UP) -- Voluntary health insurance plans under the auspices of the American Medical Association "offer no adequate substitute" for national health insurance measures, the Congress of Industrial Organizations stated today in its monthly publication, The Outlook.

ROTTERDAM, the Netherlands, Aug. 30 -- A threatened world-wide boycott of Panama-registered shipping was averted today by an agreement providing that the Panamanian Government will sponsor a conference between ship owners and union leaders to regulate working conditions on ships flying Panama's flag.

SHANGHAI, Aug. 31 -- The British-owned North China Daily News, last of four English language newspapers that formerly were published here, was threatened with extinction today as the Shanghai Military Control Commission promulgated an order banning the distribution of news by foreign news agencies.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 30 -- "Martinique," a story by Everett Freeman about the eruption of Mount Pelee in 1902, has been scheduled for production by Warner Brothers by Freeman, the studio announced today. George Tabori has been engaged to work with Freeman on the development of the scenario, which will deal with the destruction of the village of St. Pierre on the Island of Martinique during the volcanic upheaval.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- Robert F. Jones, member of the Federal Communications Commission, was preparing a dissenting opinion on the recent commission ruling against the broadcasting of radio and television give-away programs but was prevented from presenting it by illness, it was learned today.

The Chicago Corporation, in its semi-annual statement yesterday, reported net income of $1,731,739 before profits from the sale of securities for the six months ended on last June 30. The earnings are equivalent to 48 cents a share on the common stock after allowance for dividends on the preference stock, comparing with 55 cents a share on earnings of $1,975,121 in the corresponding period of last year.

Directors of the Superior Steel Corporation took no action on a dividend at their meeting on Monday in Pittsburgh. The company, which has been paying 25 cents quarterly, with occasional year-end extras, made it last distribution on July 1. Explaining the omission of the dividend due at this time, a spokesman for the company said:

Three thousand applications for apartments in Gov. Alfred E. Smith Houses on Manhattan's lower East Side were distributed yesterday by the New York City Housing Authority. A like number had been given out on Monday when distribution of the blanks began.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 (AP) -- The Bureau of the Census reported today that state tax collections in the last year amounted to $8,300,000,000, a rise of 7.1 per cent over the previous twelve months.

LAKE SUCCESS, Aug. 30 -- Man's age-old struggle to wrest a living from his environment in the face of an increasing world demand on the earth's limited reserves of raw material was viewed with optimism here today by delegates to the United Nations Scientific Conference on the Conservation and Utilization of Resources.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., Aug. 30 -- With first and second places, the crew of the Women's North Shore Yacht Racing Association from the Corinthian Club of Marblehead jumped to a clear lead today in the series for the national women's sailing championship, being held by the Larchmont Yacht Club.

This country needs a Bureau of Fine Arts to subsidize artists, twenty-two foreign art delegates decided yesterday at the final session of the Institute of International Education conference at International House.

Federal authorities indicated yesterday that they were an important step nearer to closing the circuit on a nation-wide money and stamp counterfeiting ring as they issued warrants for the arrest of two men charged with being "top figures" in the stamp department of the ring.

LAKE SUCCESS, Aug. 30 -- The Soviet Union assailed the colonial powers today, charging that these European nations were systematically exploiting the native inhabitants of territories under their jurisdiction.

The Paramount this morning will open the new Bing Crosby film, "Top O' the Morning," co-starring Barry Fitzgerald. The story is set in Ireland and lets Crosby do some singing and romancing as an American insurance investigator on the trail of the missing Blarney stone.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 (AP) -- The text of Maj. Gen. Harry H. Vaughan's statement prepared for the Senate's five per center investigation today:

DONCASTER, England, Aug. 30 (AP) -- The on-again off-again battle between Lee Savold of the United States and the British heavyweight champion, Bruce Woodcock -- billed as a world title bout -- was reset today for London in the Spring.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- Representative Adolph J. Sabath, Democrat of Illinois, announced after a White House visit today that President Truman had requested that a bill to create a permanent Federal Fair Employment Practices Commission be placed on the list of "must legislation" for this session of Congress.

CHICAGO, Aug. 30 (AP) -- Bill Wight's throwing error and Sam Dente's tenth inning fly enabled Eddie Yost to score the winning run tonight as the Senators defeated the White Sox, 1 -- 0, before 11,974 fans. Lloyd Hittle allowed only three singles as he scored his second straight shut-out over Chicago for his fourth victory.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- Administrative opponents in the Senate tonight breached a substantial hole in the Fair Labor Standards Act by adopting an amendment exempting a considerable number of employes in retail and service establishments.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 (AP) -- The Department of State announced today that 152 American graduate students had received awards under the Fulbright Act to study in the United Kingdom, Belgium and Greece during the next academic year.

Ten years ago tomorrow the German armies lunged into Poland and started a war which has been going on ever since. The last two weeks of August, 1939, were marked by a crescendo of accusations against Poland that bear a striking resemblance to the series of notes addressed to Yugoslavia from Moscow in the last two weeks of August, 1949.

CHICAGO, Aug. 30 -- Grain markets developed an easy undertone in the late trading today on the Board of Trade after showing fair strength early. When early buyers tried to sell out, however, they disclosed a lack of aggressive support.

Over the week-end the radio and newspapers were busy regaling the public with what was scheduled to happen, what was happening, and what were the after-effects when Peekskill war veterans and others set out to prevent or to break up a picnic of Harlem Negroes related to the left wing Civil Rights Congress, at which Paul Robeson was expected to be present and to sing.

ALBANY, Aug. 30 -- Mayors of cities and the chairmen of county boards of supervisors in the state were notified today that the Board of Trustees of the State University would conduct a two-day public hearing here on Sept. 20 and 21, on the need for higher educational facilities in New York.

ATHENS, Aug. 30 -- According to the most reliable information, the Italian-Greek peace treaty scheduled to be signed in Rome tomorrow will include a provision that Italy will pay Greece $105,000,000 in five-year installments.

National advertising in newspapers during July increased 13 per cent over the same month last year, according to a pre-publication report on the Printers' Ink national advertising index issued yesterday. Newspapers were the only medium to carry more national advertising during the period covered, it was noted.

The District Attorney and Sheriff of Westchester County started yesterday questioning witnesses in an inquiry ordered by Governor Dewey into the violence at Cortland on Saturday night which prevented a concert at which Paul Robeson was to have sung.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 (AP) -- Senator John Foster Dulles of New York said tonight he would decide by next week whether he would seek the Republican nomination to retain his Senate place.
LONDON, Aug. 30 -- The cautious policy adopted by investors and dealers in recent weeks was still more marked in the stock markets here today. Nearly all sections were stagnant.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- With an adjournment rash breaking out in the Senate, Senator Scott W. Lucas, the majority leader, said today, after a meeting of the Democratic Policy Committee, that he might talk over with the Republican minority next week plans to end the present Congressional session.
I belong to the ordinary working class of Great Britain and I am writing to express my disgust at the letter F. Tennyson Jesse recently wrote to THE NEW YORK TIMES.

The foreign-exchange market here made a quick and favorable response to President Truman's Philadelphia address on Monday on the economic plight of Britain. A general wave of buying of pound sterling lifted the spot rate to $4.03 1/4, while the discounts on forwards were narrowed by 1 to 2 cents from those of the preceding day.
The Air Force reported yesterday on its efforts to solve the problem of airsickness. It has not succeeded, but is encouraged by its experiments with several drugs, and with one in particular.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission approved today a new contract between the Pullman Company and its railroad proprietors covering the pooling of sleeping-car earnings. The company was bought by fifty-nine roads for $75,000,000 three years ago.
LAKE SUCCESS, Aug. 30 -- Women have won full political freedoms in fifty countries, the United Nations reported today in a new world-wide survey.

The protests that have arisen since a demonstration prevented Paul Robeson from giving a concert in Peekskill last Saturday represents a historic turning point in the anti-Fascist struggle in America, the singer told 3,000 cheering persons last night at a mass meeting of protest in Harlem.

HAMBURG, Germany, Aug. 30 (AP) -- An alleged secret Hitler order for waging brutal war on Poland was introduced in evidence today at the British war crimes trial of former German Field Marshal Gen. Fritz Erich von Mannstein.

The Appellate Division, First Division, agreed unanimously yesterday that Councilman Edward Rager had no legal right on the Primary Day ballot as an opponent of Councilman Stanley M. Isaacs for the Republican councilman nomination in the Twentieth Senatorial (Silk Stocking) District.

Hezekiah Cobb, confirmed Virginia countryman and unterrified foxhunter, in spite of his eighty years, says that a countryman's life today is not what it used to be. Only a couple of decades ago the people you met in his neighborhood were people who had always lived there -and mostly had never been anywhere else.

NINE days out of Baltimore the ship on which A. Clarence Shandon was a cynical, unhappy and morose passenger went down in a storm with all hands. Only Shandon, a husky young man with no beliefs and few morals, survived by reason of clinging to a mast. Also clinging to it was one Golias, who had not been on board Shandon's ship at all.

A five-story building containing ten apartments and occupying a lot 20 by 100 feet at 33 East Sixty-third Street, between Park and Madison Avenues, was sold by Thomas Weatherley Jr. to William Rohe for investment in a transaction reported yesterday by Douglas L. Elliman Co., the brokers in the deal.

ROME, Aug. 31 -- Foreign Minister Count Carlo Sforza today instructed the Italian Minister to Belgrade, Enrico Martino, on his return to his post to renew Italy's portests against alleged treaty violations by Yugoslavs in Zone B of the Trieste Free Territory.

A vacant irregular plot of land about 67 by 220 feet on the north side of Eighty-fifth Road, east of 188th Street, in Holliswood, Queens, has been purchased by Arthur and Bessie Broderick from Anna S. Peterson and others. Harry B. Lader was attorney for the buyers and Vincent A. Raber acted for the sellers.

A few days ago there was a breeze. That event should have been without great significance, since there have been breezes before. This one happened to come, however, at the end of an extended heat wave and, in addition, it was quite a cool breeze, almost chilly.
CHICAGO, Aug. 31 (AP) -- The White Sox blended nine hits with Billy Pierce's eight-hit pitching to snap their six-game losing streak in defeating Washington, 4 -- 2, before 3,070 persons today.

MADISON, Wis., Aug. 31 -- M. S. Szymczak, member of the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System, declared here today that recent actions by the Federal Reserve Board to increase available credit "have had some influence in making the current economic situation somewhat more favorable than in general it promised to be a few months ago."

LAKE SUCCESS, Aug. 31 -- Top efficiency in the animal kingdom for the production of usable human food from inedible plant sources goes to the dairy cow, according to experts here this morning at the United Nations Scientific Conference on the Conservation and Utilization of Resources.

Directors of Servel, Inc., have elevated Louis Ruthenburg, president since 1934, to the new post of chairman of the board and chief executive officer, it was announced yesterday. W. Paul Jones was elected president, general manager and a director.

Sweltering New Yorkers who have felt that August was an exceptionally hot month were right. The Weather Bureau yesterday released figures giving the detailed record of the thirty-one day period of discomfort.
NANKING, China, Aug. 31 (AP) -- Many foreign diplomats, an authoritative source said today, have been ordered home by governments tired of trying to do business with the Chinese Communists.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (AP) -Americans chewed less tobacco last year, but Australians, Filipinos and Newfoundlanders chewed more. American chewing tobacco, that is.
The Dickard Co, printers, 12,500 square feet of space in 52 E 19th St -- Farber-Wittman Inc and Brett, Wyckoff, Potter, Hamilton Inc, brokers.

ROCHESTER, N. Y., Aug. 31 -- Still undefeated after five rounds, and following up his draw against Max Pavey of Brooklyn in the fourth round with a well-earned victory over Jeremiah Donovan of Brooklyn in the fifth, Jack Soudakoff of the Bronx today took the lead in the championship tournament of the New York State Chess Association, with a score of 4 1/2 -- 1/2.

A dull and dripping afternoon at the Polo Grounds yesterday was brightened by the lustiest display of slugging the Giants have put on in many a moon. The free-swing-ling New Yorkers belted five home runs into the sparsely populated stands in the course of leveling the Pirates, 12 to 5, under an eighteen-hit barrage.

Traders in "restricted" and locked" sterling balances deriving from international trade and the non-British exchange of British securities are taking note of a new wrinkle with which the British foreign-exchange authorities are now experimenting.

Blue Kay survived some awkward going in the early stages to race to victory in the Astarita Stakes, $10,000 added feature for 2-year-old fillies at Aqueduct yesterday. Ridden confidently by Teddy Atkinson, the daughter of Blue Swords scored by two lengths over top-weighted High Frequency, with Sweetlucybell third.

LAKE SUCCESS, Aug. 31 -- The construction of giant windmills to produce cheap electric power was urged at the United Nations Scientific Conference on the Conservation and Utilization of Resources here today.

The American Broadcasting Company filed an action in Federal Court yesterday to enjoin the Federal Communications Commission from enforcing its order of Aug. 18, which would ban all broadcasting of give-away programs after Oct. 1.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- The Senate went off this evening on a six-day vacation, twenty days less than that the House is taking, and with the Congressional drive for early final adjournment badly shaken.

I must line up with Arthur Krock and against McAllister Coleman in Mr. Krock's contention that propaganda for the left is more pervasive than that for the right. It is more vocal, more convinced, and more spirited as well.

Passengers on the Long Island Rail Road who are accustomed in the summer months to wait in line to buy single trip tickets, began yesterday to buy such tickets through an automatic ticket-vending machine that railroad offficials had placed on trial for a six-week period.

LONDON, Thursday, Sept. 1 -Most of the kind words today's London newspapers had for "Fading Mansion," which opened at the Duchess Theatre last night, were reserved for the cast and the producer. The play, which is presented by Sir Laurence Olivier, is Donagh MacDonagh's adaptation of the French "Romeo and Jeanette" by Jean Anouilh.

EVEN those who don't always see eye to eye with John L. Lewis will agree that coal mining is a rugged occupation. If that is true in this country today, it was even more so in Scotland between the two World Wars. Any dissenters are invited to read "Miracle at Cardenrigg,"* by Tom Hanlin. This is Mr. Hanlin's second novel of life in a Scottish mining town,

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Aug. 31 -- An economic survey group of the United Nations Conciliation Commission -- headed by Gordon R. Clapp -- is going to be faced with the necessity of providing a way out of an impasse for Israel's four neighbor Arab states. The extent of the impasse is only evident on the spot.

BELMAR, N. J., Aug. 31 -- A tuna tournament without fish has all of the sparkle of a firecracker without a fuse and tonight the majority of the anglers competing in the seventh United States Atlantic tuna tournament were as discouraged a group of piscatorial adventurers as ever gathered in one place.

The 540 Girl Scouts who came home yesterday after vacations of two to four weeks at four camps operated by the Girl Scout Council of Greater New York had a "wonderful" time. But they had one regret -- "school starts in only eleven more days."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (UP) -- Judge Edward M. Curran granted in Federal court today a request of the Department of Justice that he dismiss an indictment charging two state agriculture commissioners, two commodity brokers and two farm organizations with conspiring to evade the lobbyist registration law.

LONDON, Aug. 31 -- Arm in arm and beaming, Foreign Secretary Ernest Bevin and Sir Stafford Cripps, Chancellor of the Exchequer, left England today on a journey that Mr. Bevin described as "probably one of the most important missions in history."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, the following principal changes for the week ended Aug. 24:
VIENNA, Aug. 31 (UP) -- Barsov entered Russian territory at Urfahr at 7 A. M. today of his own free will. He was whisked away by armed Soviet officers in a black sedan.
Former Gov. Herbert H. Lehman announced yesterday that he would run for United States Senator on the Democratic and Liberal party tickets.

Adoption by the Senate of a new displaced persons bill already approved by the House was urged yesterday by the National Catholic Resettlement Council. Sixty members of the group met at the Roosevelt Hotel under the leadership of Msgr. Edward E. Swanstrom, executive director.

CHICAGO, Aug. 31 -- Grains turned upward in the late trading on the Board of Trade today under the leadership of soybeans, the latter, rallying as much as 6 3/4 cents a bushel from the low after the November position, had declined to a point where it was 21 cents under the high of Aug. 22.

Two plump American youngsters romped happily about the sun deck of the arriving United States liner America yesterday chatting animatedly in a language that startled bystanders and, as it developed, has proved a problem for their mother.

Feeble attempts were made yesterday to force the stock market out of its narrow channel, with only scant success. The list again was slightly on the higher side at the close after a series of irregular movements, the composite rate advancing 0.04 point.
LONG BRANCH, N. J., Aug. 31 -- William D. Martin, United States weather observer here, is observing this week his twenty-fifth anniversary as a partner with the sea.

HONOLULU, Aug. 31 -- Hawaii's new dock seizure laws were attacked in court today by Harry Bridges. The president of International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union, CIO, told Federal Court here that territorial legislation had "wiped out our bargaining strength and all the position we had gained in 100 days of strike.

Enthusiastic herb "farmers," Mr. and Mrs. Sherman K. Hardy of Lexington, Mass., might be said to practice what they preach. They urge their customers to use the aromatic plants discreetly but with an imaginative flair; they do this themselves in the products they prepare for distribution through mail orders.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Aug. 31 -Government administrators can make good use of public opinion studies but should not be expected to run their offices by any such guide, Dr. Angus Campbell, director of the survey research center of the University of Michigan, said today.

BOSTON, Aug. 31 -- The cigarette tax goes up a cent a package in Massachusetts tomorrow, and Tax Commissioner Henry F. Long, of Massachusetts, took steps today to prevent residents from bringing in cheaper smokes from Rhode Island and New Hampshire.

DEARBORN, Mich., Aug. 31 -More than $100,000 worth of awards will be given in a countrywide automobile safety essay competition announced today by the Ford Motor Company. The event opens tomorrow for all motorists who have their vehicles checked by 6,400 Ford dealers during September and October.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission today notified the West Penn Electric Company of New York that the company's proposed sale of 856,895 shares of common stock was exempted from the competitive bidding regulation administered by the SEC.

Reporting on operations of the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation for the first half of this year, Robert E. Gross, president, informed shareholders yesterday of a substantial increase in the backlog of commercial orders, indicating the reversal of a trend toward greater dependence on military business.

NORWALK, Conn., Aug. 31 -Isaac Don Levine, editor of the magazine Plain Talk, said tonight he had incontrovertible information that Mr. Pirogov was severely clubbed by Soviet agents in an attempt to kidnap him when he kept his rendezvous at a Washington restaurant with Barsov earlier this month.

CHICAGO, Aug. 31 (AP) -- Live hogs generally recovered another 25c a hundred pounds today, while cattle and sheep were mixed. Three loads of choice butcher hogs sold at $21.75. Cattle were mostly steady to 75c higher, the biggest share of the rise appearing in steers. A load of choice-to-prime steers matched the seven-month high of $31, followed by several loads grading high-choice at S30.25 to $30.50.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (UP) -- The Government today allocated new low-rent public housing projects to eight cities.

With eighteen students slated for graduation today, the Ballard School of the Central Branch of the Y. W. C. A., Lexington Avenue and Fifty-third Street, announced yesterday it would discontinue its course in practical nursing on Dec. 1.
Mrs. Caroline S. O'Neil Ryan, widow of Clendenin J. Ryan Sr., left a net estate of $1,250,693 when she died in 1946, an estate tax appraisal filed yesterday with the state showed.

DETROIT, Mich., Aug. 31 -- The top policy committee of the United Automobile Workers, CIO, met today in an extraordinary session and speculation immediately developed that the union was considering canceling its contract with the Ford Motor Company to clear the way for a walkout of 116,000 workers by Sept. 13.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 31 (AP) -- The Indians split a twilight - night double-header with the Athletics tonight, dropping the second game. 2 -- 1, after outlasting Philadelphia in the fourteen - inning opener, 7 -- 6.

LONDON, Aug. 31 -- Complete lack of interest characterized almost all sections of the stock markets here today and resulted in slightly lower prices in some cases. After showing gains early, a weaker trend developed in gilt-edge stocks, the long-dated issues losing one-eighth to one-half point.

PRETORIA, South Africa, Aug. 31 -- The Farrell Lines' new luxury liner African Enterprise arrived in Capetown today from Durban, thus completing the voyage of the first post-war passenger ship to operate between the United States and South Africa. The Enterprise, which made calls at East London and Port Elizabeth, is now returning to New York.

WARRENSBURG, N. Y., Aug. 31 -- Forestry methods of the United States are being studied here by a group of conservationists, including fourteen United Nations delegates, who visited state and privately owned woodlands at Saratoga Springs and Warrensburg.
Niagara Falls, N. Y., announced yesterday that it would receive bids Sept. 14 on $2,060,000 of school district bonds dated Aug. 1, 1949, and due on Aug. 1, 1950 to 1969.

WARSAW, Aug. 30 -- Absenteeism in the Silesian coal mines has reached such dangerous proportions that the Polish press today called for initiation of "drastic" steps to combat this threat to fulfillment of the nation's three-year production plan.
CLEVELAND, Aug. 31 (AP) -- Bill Odom, who made his fame using the globe for a speed course, showed he was not bad around the pylons of a closed course today with an average of 405.5 miles an hour.

WILMINGTON, Del., Aug. 31 (AP) -- A chemical which makes cotton and rayon flame-resistant, durable to weather and laundering, :and which does not change the "feel" of the materials was aninounced today by E I. du Pont de , Nemours Co., Inc.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- Albert B. Hermann of Milltown, N. J., resigned today as administrative assistant to Senator H. Alexander Smith, Republican, of New Jersey, to become executive director of the Republican National Committee. His salary, it was reported, would be $20,000 a year.

Mayor O'Dwyer gathered representatives of the various branches of the theatre industry around him yesterday afternoon to lay plans to improve conditions along Broadway, particularly as they relate to the sale of theatre tickets.

An 18-year-old youth, who said he was unemployed and had not eaten in several days, held up the cashier of the Melba Theatre at 300 Livingston Street, in the downtown section of Brooklyn, at 7:30 o'clock last night. He used a black plastic toy pistol partly concealed in a paper bag and took $84.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Aug. 31 (AP) -- Rarco Stable's Tight Squeeze, a candidate for Saturday's $10,000 added Boardwalk Handicap, took the measure of seven other sprinters in the featured American Legion event today.
With little fanfare and lots of tears, the Board of Education's summer recreation program ended yesterday, another harbinger of the opening of schools on Sept. 12.

LONDON, Aug. 28 -- Every politician in the House of Commons and every writer of a letter to The Times of London seems to have a different solution for the British dollar crisis; but at least there is general agreement about the essential facts in the case.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- The vote by which the Senate today rejected the Ellender amendment that would have limited the minimum wage bill to a 65-cent minimum and tied it to the cost of living was as follows:

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 31 -- The United States Government was understood tonight to have suggested to London that Yugoslavia herself must decide if and when the present Balkan crisis should be raised before the United Nations as a threat to world peace.

BOSTON, Aug. 31 (AP) -- Tommy Holmes drove a single over third base with two out to score Sibby Sisti with the tenth inning run that gave the Braves a 4-3 victory over the Cubs tonight before a crowd of 11,670. Elbie Fletcher celebrated his "night" by hitting a home run with a Tribesman aboard in the seventh.

In contrast to the marked slump in off-shore shipping activities in the last year, intercoastal operators report a slight upward trend in cargo volume in recent months. which has led to a feeling of caucautious optimism within the industry.

TOKYO, Aug. 31 -- Business men are watching with pleasure and amusement the Cabinet's reaction toward the tax reform plan proposed for Japan by Dr. Carl S. Shoup of Columbia. The most notable result has been a stampede of officials to promise that they would slash appropriations far more severely than the occupation authorities had dared ask.

A building loan of $2,358,000, insured by the Federal Housing Administration, has been obtained by the Kingsway Gardens, Inc., Jack Carner, president, from the Williamsburgh Savings Bank of Brooklyn on the seven six-story garden apartment houses under construction on the north side of Kings Highway, between East Twenty-sixth and East Twenty-ninth Streets, in Brooklyn.

A decline last week of 1,332,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end they were 106,280,000 barrels, compared with 107,612,000 a week earlier and 95,504,000 on Aug. 28, 1948.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 31 -- The rambunctious Browns were still at it tonight to give our harried Yankees no peace. In fact, they gave the battered Bombers another sound thrashing to make it two in a row in this three-game series.

ZURICH, Switzerland, Aug. 31 -- One of the worst sores in Europe's not too healthy economy has been reopened, it was learned here today. The Netherlands Government has filed a formal protest with United States authorities in Germany charging violations of an agreement of Sept. 19, 1948, providing for nondiscriminatory utilization of great ports linking the Rhine with the ocean.

LAKE SUCCESS, Aug. 31 -Fleet Admiral Chester W. Nimitz, who was named last March to administer a plebiscite in Kashmir, said today that he hoped that President Truman's appeal to India and Pakistan to settle their differences would expedite the long-delayed truce agreement.

Key executives in banking, government finance and the European Recovery Administration are scheduled to speak at the annual convention of the American Bankers Association to be held in San Francisco from Oct. 30 to Nov. 2, Evans Woolen Jr., president of the association, announced yesterday.

The blockfront property on the west side of Ninth Avenue between Thirty-fourth and Thirty-fifth Streets has been leased from St. Mary's Hospital for Children by Triboro Parking, Inc., of which Samuel Wolf is president, for improvement with a taxpayer and parking deck.

Indianapolis and Philadelphia are 650 miles apart. This week they have been set eighty years apart in time. At Philadelphia the veterans of the two recent world wars are holding their usual lusty American Legion convention. At Indianapolis six old men, a proud remnant of those who fought the Civil War, have lit the campfires of the last encampment of the Grand Army of the Republic.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 31 -- Borba, official newspaper of the Yugoslav Communist party, will publish tomorrow morning a reply to the Soviet Government's note of Aug. 29. In a sharp retort Borba ridicules the Soviet Government for displaying the "heroism" of a big bully toward Yugoslavia.

The Collegiate Reformed Church of St. Nicholas, waiting at Fifth Avenue and Forty-eighth Street to be torn down and replaced by an insurance company skyscraper, added another and unusual farewell to its collection yesterday.
MOSCOW, Aug. 31 (AP) -- Russia's latest verbal blast at Marshal Tito was regarded by foreign diplomats here today as of major import.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., Aug. 31 -- Three more races of the women's national sailing championship were held today at the Larchmont Yacht Club and the crew of the Maine Yacht Racing Association from Portland now leads by a series score of 22 points, one-quarter of a point more than the sailors of Eastern Connecticut from Pine Orchard.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- President Truman formally announced plans today for a Mid-Century White House Conference on children and youth to be held late in 1950 and called on the Governors of all states and territories to appoint participating committees.

John J. Broderick, the former Broadway detective now running for the Tammany leadership of the White Light district, issued a blanket denial yesterday of charges made by Gerard V. Murphy, one of the present leaders of the area, that Broderick was forced to retire from the Police Department because of proved association with gangsters.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Aug. 31 -An efficient national development program cannot be carried out without the participation of local and international private capital, Edward G. Miller, Assistant Secretary of State for American Affairs, declared at a dinner given by the Foreign Office in his honor last night.

LAKE SUCCESS, Aug. 31 -- The United Nations Palestine Conciliation Commission has decided to suspend its efforts in Lausanne to bring about a permanent peace settlement between Israel and the Arab states. The commission will come to Lake Success next week to start drafting its report to the General Assembly.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- Although most of them are convinced that anything less than sterling devaluation will fall short of a realistic approach to the British "dollar crisis," negotiators for the United States Government in the three-nation discussions are under orders to avoid the subject unless it is broached by the British.

A new era of management progress, with emphasis on the development of physical resources broadened to include all aspects of management science, was seen here yesterday by Lawrence A. Appley, president of the American Management Association.

LONDON, Aug. 31 -- With great force and earnestness the General Council of the Trades Union Congress recommended to British workers today that they continue to show "moderation and restraint" in their wage demands.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (AP) -The Reconstruction Finance Corporation has informed Congress that the RFC may have to put all of its prefabricated housing eggs in one basket.

LAKE SUCCESS, Aug. 31 -- The American Committee of Jewish Writers, Artists and Scientists today labeled as "fantastic" a memorandum submitted to the United Nations last month by the Jewish League against Communism. The latter charged that 400,000 Jews had been uprooted from their homes by the Soviet Government and exiled to Siberia.

The Nationalist blockade of Shanghai and the Hawaii dock strike have hurt Pacific shipping but some of the loss has been made up by increased business with the Philippines and Japan, Giles C. Stedman, vice president of the United States Lines Pacific services, said yesterday.

United States tourists, pondering What gifts to bring home with them after a trip to Europe, do not seem to have any more imagination than those of a generation ago. At least, they're bringing back just about the same things as their fathers and mothers did -only a little more of them.

Nubby textures that contrast with smoothly woven backgrounds to form interesting raised patterns were outstanding among an extensive collection of drapery and upholstery goods introduced at the Oken Fabrics showroom yesterday. Simple large-scale geometric designs and stripes in varying widths were featured, making the fabrics suitable for either contemporary or traditional rooms.
A solemn little girl who was 15 years old only a few weeks ago was freed yesterday in Bronx Children's Court of a charge of collecting policy slips.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 31 -"Five percenters" in Washington and lobbyists in the State Legislature were attacked today by Gov. Earl Warren at the opening of the California state bar convention as harmful to constitutional government.

" Hopeless poverty and slum squalor" have resulted in broken families and increasing delinquency among the remnants of four once great Indian tribes in the Midwest, the Association on American Indian Affairs, 48 East Eighty-sixth Street, declared yesterday.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were quiet yesterday, and final prices were 11 points higher to 1 point lower. The only decline was in the December, 1950, position.

Earlier than usual, football will bow in here tonight with the presentation of the eleventh Fresh Air Fund game at the Polo Grounds. With the professional New York Giants engaging the Eastern College All-Stars. good weather is expected to bring out some 35,000 fans, with underprivileged youngsters benefiting the most.
Blue ribbon jurors received yesterday the case of John M. Broady, private investigator charged with grand larceny, illegal wiretapping and conspiracy. Broady's co-defendant is Edward M. Jones.

When President Truman addressed the Governments of India and Pakistan urging an early settlement of the Kashmir dispute his action was interpreted in some quarters as a first step in building up an anti-Communist Far Eastern policy. Secretary Acheson rightly corrected this misapprehension yesterday at his press conference.

For the first time in its eleven years, the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis will be forced this fall to go to the public with an appeal for special epidemic funds in advance of the regular January March of Dimes campaign, it was announced yesterday.

The Power Memorial High School of the Christian Brothers Institute, Inc., at the northeast corner of Amsterdam Avenue and Sixty-first Street is to have a new gymnasium, for which Kelly Gruzen, architects and engineers, have been commissioned to prepare plans.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- Maj. Gen. Harry H. Vaughan, President Truman's Military Aide, acknowledged today at the "five percenter" inquiry that the Federal Bureau of Investigation had inquired into a charge that he had accepted a bribe for "fixing" an income tax case.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Aug. 31 -- A class of political and economic outcasts has been created in Western Germany in a situation that has ugly overtones of retaliation against "collaborators" with the Western Allied powers.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (AP) -The Economic Cooperation Administration granted today $17,000,000 to France and Italy for the purchase of United States cotton. The action was included in new Marshall Plan aid grants to six European countries, Western Germany and Trieste.

The Isbrandtsen Company's freighter Sir John Franklin remained tied up at Pier 8, Tompkinsville, S. I., yesterday. The company still asserted it had had no official notice from the Marine Engineers Beneficial Association, CIO, as to the reason for a work stoppage.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Aug. 31 -- Miss Patricia O'Sullivan, 22-year-old Connecticut State champion from Race Brook Country Club, Orange, Conn., captured top honors in the New York sectional qualifying play for the Women's National amateur golf tourney at the Sands Point course today.

The story of Charles Edward Wilson is a Horatio Alger tale come to life. Starting work at the age of 12 as a $3-a-week office boy, he rose in forty years to the presidency of one of the nation's greatest corporations, the General Electric Company. A production genius, he has fairly earned for himself a place among America's industrial immortals.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 31 -- Secretary of Defense Louis Johnson pledged to the American Legion today that he would "not be distracted by name-calling" or by critics who described him as "ruthess" but would stay on the job of unifying the armed forces.

CHICAGO, Aug. 31 -- Malnutrition is a national problem in this country, despite an abundance of food, a great outlay of money and an increase in the knowledge of nutrition, Dr. Ouida Davis Abbott, head of the Department of Home Economics at the University of Florida, said here today.

Marshall Rawle will become a general partner today in the stock brokerage firm of Payson Trask, according to Mrs. Joan W. Payson and Frederick K. Trask Jr., present partners. Mr. Rawle resigned recently as vice president and a director of Textron Incorporated.

MADISON, N. J., Aug. 31 -- Two youths were killed today at 7:40 A. M. in a plane crash on the fog-shrouded Giralda Farm of Mr. and Mrs. Marcellus Hartly Dodge here. They were identified by Madison police as John Goumas, 19 years old, of 99 Main Street, and Robert McLaughlin, 20, of 5 Alexander Avenue.

ROME, Aug. 31 -- Italy and Greece signed today an agreement of economic collaboration, which at the same time regulates all economic questions between the two countries arising from application of the Italian Peace Treaty of 1947.
The National City Bank's September Letter, out today, discusses dilemmas posed by Britain's continuing dollar-shortage crisis before both the British and American people.

A new department of the Railway Express Agency has been established to combine personnel and public relations under the direction of Albert M. Hartung, it was announced yesterday by A. L. Hammell, president of the agency. Mr. Hartung has been appointed vice president, department of personnel and public relations.

SHANGHAI, Aug. 31 -- Just four weeks after celebrating its ninety-ninth birthday, Shanghai's British-owned North China Daily News decided tonight to ask the Communist authorities for permission to go out of business as a result of the ban on news distribution by the foreign press associations.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (AP) -Retail trade was down 7 per cent in July from a year ago, the Census Bureau reported today. Dealers in lumber and building materials suffered a 26 per cent decline.

Casual fashions have come into their own in recent years. Their popularity has helped to bring about the style importance of separates -- skirts, blouses and jackets that, when worn together, form a unit.

The week-long bus strike on lines of the Triboro Coach Company in Queens provides a lesson in futility. It cost the public serious inconvenience; it cost the men a week's pay; it cost the company a week's receipts. It availed nothing, because the terms which the men accepted Tuesday (by secret ballot) were precisely those which they rejected (in open voting) at the outset.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- President Truman said today that labor must be a "full partner" in all the nation's undertakings, domestic and foreign. In a Labor Day statement, Mr. Truman said that labor "statesmen" are alert to their responsibility.
LAKE SUCCESS, Aug. 31 -- The Soviet Union was defeated today in its attempt to have a special United Nations committee drop debate on a Netherlands Government report covering conditions in Indonesia.

PARIS, Aug. 31 -- The prolonged deadlock among the European Governments over the division of this year's dollar aid was broken late tonight when the Marshall Plan Council reached a reluctant and belated agreement.

The Greeks had a word for the process exemplified by the angry exchange of notes between Moscow and Belgrade -- "logomachia," a war of words. Marshal Tito could well say in response to the latest blast from the Kremlin that "sticks and stones will break my bones, but names will never hurt me."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- Democratic Senate foreign policy leaders agreed today to withhold all but $100,000,000 of this country's proposed military aid to Western Europe until the North Atlantic treaty's common defensive council became a functioning reality.
BERLIN, Aug. 31 -- Brig. Gen Frank L. Howley ended his fouryear tenure in the Berlin Military Government today with an attack on Soviet officials in Berlin.

The present city rent control laws, adopted in 1947-48, do not set their own rent ceilings, but are limited to the enforcement of rents fixed by federal regulation. The proposed Sharkey bill would amend these local laws by adding provisions setting the ceiling on the basis of rents prevailing on March 1, 1949, and authorizing the City Rent Commission to make limited adjustments upward and downward.

Unrefined gold, packaged in small lucite bottles, will be available for gift shoppers this Christmas, it was learned yesterday. The gift package containing 2 1/4 ounces of gold of 850 fineness will sell for $100. An assay certificate attesting to the quality and weight will accompany each sealed bottle.

BURLINGTON, Vt., Aug. 31 -- In an effort to bring the church closer to the people it serves, the National Catholic Rural Life Conference has petitioned the Holy See in Rome for permission to translate certain rural blessings into English, the Rev. William Schimek of Rose Creek, Minn., disclosed here today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- Following President Truman's action in extending to Nov. 1 the authorization for the Federal Housing Administration to insure loans for home repair and modernization, all banks and private lending institutions will be notified this week of applicable amendments to Title I of the National Housing Act.

TOKYO, Thursday, Sept. 1 (AP) -- Japan's worst typhoon in eleven years lashed the crowded Tokyo-Yokohama metropolitan area last night, killing at least twelve Japanese and injuring more than 100. Floods threatened today to add to the devastation.

CINCINNATI, Aug 31 (AP) -Robert Gould, the ex-convict mentioned in today's "five percenter" hearing in Washington, said tonight he had no knowledge of political campaign contributions by his attorney, William H. Neblett.

" The House Across the Street," a Warner Brothers melodrama with Wayne Morris, Janis Paige and Bruce Bennett, which opens at the Palace, is this morning's lone film newcomer. Richard Bare directed and Saul Elkins produced from a screen play by Russell Hughes and a story by Roy Chanslor.

New reference files, entitled "Performance Data on Furniture Stores," have been set up by the Bureau of Advertising, American Newspaper Publishers Association, it was announced yesterday by John Giesen, director of the retail division. The reference source is the second in a series designed to broaden newspapers' services to the nation's estimated 1,705,000 retail stores.
CHAMPAIGN, Ill., Aug. 31 (AP) -The National Student Association urged today that colleges ban new student groups that would discriminate on racial, religious or political grounds.

LONDON, Aug. 31 -- The British Government is expected to propose a substantial investment of United States capital in Southeast Asia and specifically in Malaya during the coming review of Far Eastern policy in Washington.

Patrolman John E. Carton, newly elected president of the Police Conference of the State of New York, was sworn into office yesterday by Mayor O'Dwyer at a City Hall ceremony. Patrolman Carton is also president of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association of the City of New York.
