LONDON, Thursday, Sept. 1 -- The deadline for completing the draft of an Austrian treaty of independence was reached here last midnight with the depuities of the Big Four foreign ministers still hopelessly deadlocked on the basic treaty issues.

James M. Faust, 65 years old, former real estate broker, was found dead of gas poisoning in the kitchen of his apartment at 310 East Fifty-fifth Street yesterday morning. The police said the death evidently was a suicide. No notes were found.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif. Aug. 31 -Marta Toren has been named by Universal-International for the leading feminine role in "Deported," which Robert Buckner will produce for the company in Italy. The studio also revealed that Sara Allgood and Erskine Sanford has been engaged for character roles in "Sierra."
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (U.P.) -The Senate today confirmed the nominations of American diplomatic representatives to two Soviet satellite states after a delay of more than two months.

Designers of today's high-altitude commercial airliners did not explore thoroughly the danger of carbon dioxide gas to passengers and crews when they installed the standard method of fighting fires in aircraft, an aviation medical specialist charged yesterday.
SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Aug. 31 (AP) -- The widow of Vachel Lindsay, poet, said today an examination of his stored papers had revealed them as "the core of Lindsayana."
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- The course of Soviet Russia in holding two American students in eastern Germany was arraigned as outrageous, illegal and improper by Secretary of State Acheson today.

Directing attention to the lack of suitable plays for children, Mrs. Charlotte B. Chorpenning, considered the dean of playwrights in the particular field and director of the juvenile department of Chicago's Goodman Theatre, laid down six principles to guide authors at yesterday afternoon's session of the fourth annual Children's Theatre Conference.
LA PAZ, Bolivia, Aug. 31 (AP) -The Government announced tonight the fall of two more cities to the rebels, who earlier had been forced to surrender their stronghold at Cochabamba.

A syndicate of investors represented by George Nodelman, attorney, has purchased the five-story office building and three apartment houses at the northeast corner of East 149th Street and Courtlandt Avenue in "the Hub" section of the Bronx from the Dollar Savings Bank in the City of New York.

In the most active session of the week, rubber futures prices continued yesterday to advance on the Commodity Exchange and closed with net gains of 11 to 34 points. Buying support was furnished by trade interests in the December position and by the trade and commission-house short-covering in the September position.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission today permitted Eastern railroads to charge shippers for pick-up and delivery service that hitherto has been rendered by the carriers free of charge.
BUFFALO, N. Y., Aug. 31 (AP) -The State Board of Mediation gave its findings in the Bell aircraft strike to both disputing parties late today.

LONDON, Aug. 31 (UP) -- In London they were singing "Roll Out the Barrel" and in Austria the opening lyrics of the hit tune of the day were "The hollow bones of the world are rattling but the Fuehrer will set them straight again."

New bond financing in August was slightly less than in the preceding month, but larger than in the corresponding month of 1948. The volume of offerings was sustained, in part, by increased flotations of foreign and Federal Home Loan Bank bonds, which greatly offset a drop in corporate and local Government bonds.

The Coast Guard hearing into charges resulting from the collision in June, 1948, between the American tanker Chrysanthystar and the British trawler Energetic took a new turn yesterday when Examiner Francis X. J. Coughlin offered to aid the defendant.

A modernization program designed to demonstrate how electricity can be put to greater use in the textile industry has been completed by the General Electric Company, it was announced yesterday. The program includes a sound-color motion picture and a 104-page manual that will be made available to textile mills, machinery manufacturers and others associated with the industry.

PEARL RIVER, N. Y., Aug. 31 -- A Canadian woman missionary was cured of a tropical eye disease and had her sight restored in what was believed to be the first such use of a new drug in the United States, it was reported here today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (UP) -- Senator Dennis Chavez, Democrat of New Mexico, today asked President Truman to revive negotiations on the $203,000,000 Mexican oil loan before the communist-supported International Peace Congress meets in Mexico City on Sept. 4.

INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 31 -- The Grand Army of the Republic held its last official meeting today in the city where it first met eighty-three years ago. Tonight, as dusk darkened Indianapolis, the six delegates who attended the last G. A. R. encampment rode in the last G. A. R. parade.

NEWCASTLE, England, Aug. 31 -The world will not starve because of inadequate food production if population increases as it does in Western countries, Sir John Russell, leading agricultural expert and director of the famed Rothamsted experimental station, told the British Association for the Advancement of Science in his presidential address tonight.

Underlying conditions in the men's clothing industry now show considerable improvement, it was reported here yesterday. This was said to be evident, not so much in a current spurt in retail sales but in the fact that the decrease in production thus far this year has been considerably greater than the decrease in retail volume.
Grocery manufacturers share optimism for a good September volume and a general business upturn, Paul S. Willis, president of the Grocery Manufacturers of America, disclosed in an interview yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- President Truman's request for an increase of the minimum wage from 40 cents to 75 cents an hour was approved today by the Senate, but his proposal to expand the coverage of the Fair Labor Standards (Wage-Hour) Act was ignored.
CHICAGO, Aug. 31 -- The American motion-picture industry today repledged itself to safeguard the freedom and accept the responsibility of the film in the interests of the free peoples of the world.

Carl Winter, Michigan chairman of the Communist party, took the witness stand yesterday as the fifth defendant and the thirty-first witness to testify at the eight-month Communist trial. Mr. Winter denied testimony by Government witnesses that the 1945 reorganization of the party was forced upon the membership by totalitarian methods without free discussion.
Petty racketeering in door-to-door selling, which cost its victims millions of dollars, has been virtually wiped out in New York, it was reported yesterday.
CANTON, China, Aug. 31 (AP) -- Chungking, capital of wartime China, already has become the Government's administrative center, an official spokesman said today.

A plan to solve the world monetary crisis by creating an international bank modeled after the Federal Reserve System and capitalized at $8,000,000,000 was proposed last night to the foreign affairs committee of the New York Republican Club at a meeting in its headquarters, 54 West Fortieth Street.

District Attorney George M. Fanelli of Westchester County became secretive yesterday about most aspects of his inquiry into last Saturday's fighting near Peeks kill as demands increased for the appointment by Governor Dewey of a special prosecutor.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Aug. 31 -- Approval of Israel's first annual budget appeared certain tonight as the Assembly began its examination of Finance Minister Eliezer Kaplan's estimates. The coalition majority supported item after item in the financial provisions.

Trading on the New York Stock Exchange last month was the heaviest of the year, due to heavy turnover in low price utilities. The volume for August also was the greatest for a corresponding month in 13 years or since 1936. Sales crossed the million-share mark in eight sessions, the largest of which was on Aug. 8, when 1,656,600 shares were handled, the best volume since March.

James C. Petrillo, president of the American Federation of Musicians, AFL, threatened yesterday to pull orchestras out of New York night clubs, vaudeville theatres, hotels and taverns unless the American Guild of Variety Artists stopped "raiding" his union.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 31 -Her eyes filled with tears, Mrs. George Herman Ruth today accepted the American Legion's Distinguished Service Medal on behalf of her late husband, baseball's immortal "Babe."
CANNES, France, Aug. 31 (AP) -Count Giorgio Cini was killed today as his private plane crashed in circling back low after a takeoff so he could wave good-by to actress Merle Oberon.
SPRING GREEN, Wis., Aug. 31 (AP) -- Miss Maurice Cavanaugh denied tonight she had black marketed an Oldsmobile purchased for her by General Vaughan.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- An unusual aerial photograph of Washington, which had been suppressed by defense officials, was found today displayed on the wall of a cocktail lounge one block from the White House.

STRASBOURG, France, Aug. 31 (AP) -- The Economic Committee of the European Consultative Assembly called today for lower United States tariffs to help Europe unite its economies and avoid economic disaster.
Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, as a trustee of Howard University, went aboard the Norwegian America liner Stavangerfjord yesterday to bid bon voyage to the Howard University Players.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- President Truman has asked India and Pakistan to accept a new proposal by a United Nations commission for a truce in their bitter clash over the possession of Kashmir, the State Department officially announced today.

Why all the voluble protest against the requirement of an oath of allegiance to the United States Government on the part of teachers? Wherein is there an implied insult to the teacher required to take such oath any more than to the judges, Government officials and innumerable other public servants who regularly take such oaths without a question?

LONDON, Aug. 31 (AP) -- The World Jewish Congress, meeting in Paris this week, has decided to keep a neutral position in the conflict between communism and the West, a member of the executive council said today.

DETROIT, Aug. 31 (AP) -- Home runs by Bobby Doerr and Ted Williams, each good for two runs, provided the margin tonight as the Red Sex defeated the Tigers, 7 to 4. The victory lifted the second-place Red Sox to within two games of the league-leading Yankees.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 31 -- Despite the charges yesterday in New York that John Broderick was forced to resign from the Police Department because of intimate association with gangsters, RKO-Radio Pictures, which has invested $75,000 in the screen rights to his life story, will produce the picture, the company said today.

HONG KONG, Aug. 31 -- The top British commander in Hong Kong said today any aggression from the China mainland would be met by much stiffer opposition than this British Crown Colony offered the Japanese in December, 1941.

Morton Gould, pianist, conductor and composer, seems to have the inside track on the assignment to provide the music for the forthcoming Theatre Guild presentation of "The Pursuit of Happiness." No contracts have been signed yet, but indications are that they might be within forty-eight hours.

Richard (Pancho) Gonzales, the defending titleholder from Los Angeles; Jaroslav Drobny, formerly of Czechoslovakia; John Bromwich of Australia, and Earl Cochell of San Francisco advanced to the third round of the national championships yesterday before rain cut short the program at the West Side Tennis Club in Forest Hills.

PRAGUE, Aug. 31 -- Like two others installed at Trnava seventeen days ago, another new Roman Catholic Bishop appointed by the Vatican as Bishop "in partibus infidelium" ("in the land of the faithless") will be consecrated without Government permission, church sources said today.

Exceptionally heavy travel by railroad, bus and airline was predicted yesterday by transportation company officials for the Labor Day week-end. The worst of the rush is expected on Monday and Tuesday, when incoming lines will be jammed with a mixture of week-enders and returning vacationists.

With traffic conditions in the garment area "tragic" and all remedies having failed because of the apathy of the industry, the Traffic Commission indicated yesterday that any future plans would be aimed at containing the paralysis within the snarled zone.

Trading here in Straits tin continued quiescent yesterday, pending reinstatement of offerings by the British Ministry of Supply. Importers here in contact with London yesterday were still speculating on the actual reasons for the withdrawal of offerings on Tuesday, but expected them to be renewed shortly.

There was no cooperation from the weather last night, so today the Dodgers will stage another night-and-day special -- an after noon game with the Reds starting at 1:30 and another tonight at 8:30 P. M.

Charles D. Hilles lived beyond his era, but up to his death last week he was a constant reminder of some of its more attractive aspects. He was a courtly gentleman, who did not give his word lightly, but kept every political commitment he ever made.

Three thousand clerks employed in 400 New York shoe stores won a basic forty-hour week under a new two-year agreement announced yesterday by two locals of the Retail. Wholesale and Department Store Union, CIO. Union officials said the workers would work five days a week, except in eight busy weeks when they will work six.
Harry W. Porte has been appointed vice president in charge of sales of the Mergenthaler Linotype Company. He was formerly manager of the company's Pacific Coast agency.

ROCHESTER, N. Y., Aug. 31 -Two decisive victories carried Willie Turnesa of Elmsford, N. Y., defending titleholder, into the fifth round of the United States amateur golf championship today as the last of the British Walker Cup players went down to defeat.

Allied Mills, Inc., and its wholly owned subsidiaries reported yesterday for the fiscal year ended with last June, a net profit of $2,369,814, equal to $2.96 a share. In the preceding fiscal year the company, which is a processor of grains, had a net profit of $3,110,672 or $3.89 a share, after setting aside $200,000 inventory reserve.

VIENNA, Aug. 31 -- A Russian Air Force officer who deserted last year and offered to fight for the United States was handed back to Soviet authorities here today. He is Lieut. Anatoli P. Barsov, who chose the role of a political refugee and then repented his action.

A. L. Hammell, president of Railway Express Agency, announced yesterday the creation of a new department to embrace both personnel and public relations under the direction of Albert M. Hartung, who has been elected a vice president.

LAUSANNE, Switzerland, Sept. 1 (UP) -- Israel notified the United Nations Palestine Commission today that she would make no territorial concessions to her Arab neighbors beyond the existing armistice lines.

With this anniversary of the signing of the Japanese surrender on the battleship Missouri, Gen. Douglas MacArthur has released for publication his review of our four years of occupation of Japan. In it he points out the gains in the political consciousness of the Japanese people, the recovery in productivity, the high degree of public order and the beginning of the emergence of Japan into normal and peaceful international life.

After beating the Reds, 11 -- 8, yesterday afternoon in a feverish game that resulted in Barney Shotton's first banishment as a Major League manager, the second-place Dodgers blew a 4-3 decision last night and dropped two games behind the league-leading Cardinals.

The jurisdictional dispute between the American Federation of Musicians and the American Guild of Variety Artists continued yesterday as guild officials asserted that they had made repeated attempts to meet with James C. Petrillo, president of the musicians' union, in an effort to reach a settlement.
CANTON, China, Sept. 1 (AP) -The Communists were smashing hard today toward Chenhsien, railway town 180 miles north of Canton.

What went on in the tortured, Slavic mind of Lieut. Anatoli Porfirievich Barsov before he succumbed and decided to go back to the Soviet Union, and possibly to his death? It would take another Dostoievsky to do the subject justice -- after which this contemporary Dostoievsky would be arrested, sent to Siberia and his manuscript destroyed.

KEARNY, N. J., Sept. 1 -- A spectacular fire whose flames reached 200 feet in the air and were visible from many points in the metropolitan area caused an estimated $300,000 damage to three plants in the north Kearny meadows today.

CHICAGO, Sept. 1 -- Gasoline trucks rolled through the streets of Chicago and suburbs today filling the tanks of stations emptied by the twenty-one-day strike of truck drivers that ended early this morning.
A "tentative agreement" for the sale of the Bank of Yorktown to the Marine Midland Trust Company of New York has been made, it was learned officially yesterday.

In a repurchase for investment, Charles F. Noyes has acquired the six-story building on a plot 50 by 100 feet at 424-26 Broadway, near Canal Street, from the Plymouth Curtain Corporation representing tenants occupying three upper floors in the structure.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 1 (AP) -- The Cleveland Indians won their seventeenth straight extra-inning contest tonight, defeating the Philadelphia Athletics, 2 to 1, on Larry Doby's single to left in the eleventh inning. His hit off Carl Scheib scored Thurman Tucker from second.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- President Truman expressed supreme confidence today that his Fair Deal program would be enacted in its entirety.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 1 -- William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, said today that present unemployment "does not herald a depression and we'll come out of it in a reasonable amount of time."

ROCHESTER, N. Y., Sept. 1 -Two decisions given today by the referees' committee at the conclusion of the fifth round of the New York State Chess Association championship affected several of the leaders.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 1 (AP) -Howie Pollet shut out the Philadelphia. Phillies with five hits tonight as the St. Louis Cardinals won, 4 -- 0, and boosted their National League lead to two games as the Dodgers split with the Reds.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (UP) -The seizing and whisking away to Austria of the "repentant" Russian deserter, Anatoli P. Barsov, was pictured today as a cloak-and-dagger episode in which United States operatives trapped the man in a restaurant moments before Russian agents pounded onto the scene.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 1 -Joan Evans, 15-year-old actress who made her screen debut recently in Samuel Goldwyn's "Roseanna McCoy," has been named by Goldwyn for the leading feminine role in his projected production, "Edge of Doom."

Your recent editorial, "City Hospitals, 1946-49," clearly points up the grave need of a sound progressive program to deal with this problem. A valuable contribution is made if this editorial is studied with your previous one in which a plea was made to intimately tie up fundamental research with medical practice.

Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick, pastor emeritus of the Riverside Church in New York, has a new book listed for Sept. 21 publication by Harper. "The Man From Nazareth" is a story of Christ as the people of His time saw Him, based on a study of Christian and Jewish literature.
TORONTO, Sept. 1 (AP) -- A gale that lashed across Ontario and into Quebec today snarled communications and shipping along the Great Lakes waterways and caused untold crop damage and power blackouts.

DUESSELDORF, Germany, Sept. 1 (UP) -- Three hundred British troops made a brief show of force today at a synthetic oil plant where workers had manhandled a British officer yesterday who came to see that dismantling orders were carried out.

Aggregate net profits of the larger member banks in this district showed substantial gains in the first half of this year, compared with the first six months of 1948, while the smaller banks, which held deposits of less than $5,000,000, had only nominal gains, or even showed declines, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.
BOSTON, Sept. 1 -- Mayor James M. Curley announced today that a $50,000,000 housing program of 4,000 low-rent units for Boston had been approved by Federal housing officials.

LAKE SUCCESS, Sept. 1 -- For the first time, after two weeks of discussion devoted to a quiet and unspectacular exchange of technical information, delegates to the United Nations Scientific Conference on the Conservation and Utilization of Resources here had an unscientific spat today.

A serious threat to waterfront operations in New York and other Atlantic ports was posed yesterday as employer representatives asked a negotiating committee of the International Longshoremen's Association, AFL, to accept a thirteen-cent reduction in hourly pay rates.
Wanted: 40,000 veterans of the Women's Army Corps who served during the war from New York State to join the Organized Reserve Corps.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N. Y., Sept. 1 (AP) -- A company and two individuals filed claims totalling $17,105 today for work they said they had done on Elliott Roosevelt's real estate developments in the Hyde Park area.
A tour of even American cities will begin for fifty European publishers, editors and writers when they arrive here on Tuesday for a two-week flying visit to the United States.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (AP) -Logging and sawmills made noteworthy declines in the frequency of injuries last year but remained at the highest among manufacturing industries, the Bureau of Labor Statistics said today.

The grip that the Marine Engineers Beneficial Association, CIO, has held on the Isbrandtsen cargo ship Sir John Franklin for three days was weakened considerably yesterday afternoon as the company resumed unloading the vessel.
ELIZABETH, N. J., Sept. 1 -Stealing company time was the basis for a larceny charge filed here by the Phelps Dodge Copper Products Corporation.

The champion money-winning steeplechaser of 1948 made his second start and scored his first victory of 1949 at Aqueduct yesterday. American Way, 7-year-old gelding bred and owned by Paul Mellon's Rokeby Stables, won the thirty-third Harbor Hill Steeplechase by two lengths.

Parallel developments will take place at WNBC and WCBS next week when both stations will drop fifteen-minute news shows and tack the time on other programs that offer participating sponsorship to advertisers.

LONDON, Aug. 29 -- The economic changes in the British Commonwealth and Empire will be one of the main topics of conversation in next week's dollar conference in Washington, for these changes are in some ways more revolutionary than the changes that have taken place in Britain itself.

Aviation medicine specialists yesterday took steps to assure military and civil aviation of a flow of qualified doctors into a field growing daily more complex with the development of jets, rockets and faster and higher-flying commercial aircraft.

Unit sales of work clothing in the last six months of 1949 will exceed those of the corresponding period last year, according to study made by Dun Bradstreet for the Association of Cotton Textile Merchants of New York. Dollar volume, it was said, will equal or fall a shade below a year ago, as a result of the general decline in prices.

URBANA, Ill., Sept. 1 -- Delegates to the National Student Association Congress came out strongly today for legislation to eliminate discrimination in schools because of race, religion, sex, national origin, political beliefs or economic circumstances.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., Sept. 1 -- Gaining a second place in the sixth and final race for the national women's sailing championship, the crew from the Portland Yacht Club, representing the Maine Yacht Racing Association, today won the honor and prize, the latter a beer mug, the Mrs. Charles Francis Adams Trophy.

City officials and representatives of the Bethlehem Steel Company's shipbuilding division signed a contract in City Hall yesterday calling for the construction of three new express ferry boats to run between South Ferry and Staten Island.

The stock market yesterday unexpectedly snapped out of a corrective reaction that had lasted two weeks. Selective improvement occurred after a hestitant start and left the composite rate higher by 0.71 point at the close for the best gain in two weeks.

Lewis W. Douglas, United States Ambassador to Britain, said yesterday that he was "sure" the conference in Washington next week involving this country, Britain and Canada would be a success because "friendly countries will be reviewing a very important situation in an atmosphere of amity and sympathy."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- Department store sales in the week ended Aug. 27 were 1 per cent below sales in the corresponding week last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. The following lists percentage changes from like periods of 1948:

Representatives of Great Britain's building industry who have spent six weeks studying methods of construction in several cities here reported yesterday that they were impressed by the pre-planning and efficiency in this country. The seventeen members of the group, whose visit here was sponsored by the Anglo - American Council on Productivity and the Economic Cooperation Administration, will leave for Great Britain tomorrow night on the Queen Elizabeth.

CHICAGO, Sept. 1 (AP) -- Dick Weik, rookie Washington right-hander, walked thirteen batters in seven innings tonight as the Chicago White Sox defeated the Senators, 3 -- 0, before 4,219 fans. Randy Gumpert pitched the distance for the sixteenth time in twenty-seven starts on a yield of four singles for his eleventh victory.

Bond Stores, Inc., which operates sixty-nine stores in fifty-six cities and features men's and women's ready-to-wear clothing, showed an increase in sales for the six months ended with last June over the corresponding period of 1948, but earnings were lower, it was revealed yesterday.

The city of Waterbury, Conn., sold yesterday a new issue of $3,269,000 of tax-exempt improvement bonds due on Sept. 1, 1952 to 1971, to a banking syndicate headed by the Chase National Bank at a bid of 100.149 for interest of 1.80 per cent.

You published a letter from Frank P. Biggs, in which he suggests that the United States of America should seek to become a member of any European union that might develop out of the Council of Europe, the Assembly of which is meeting now in Strasbourg.

Representative Vito Marcantonio, the American Labor party candidate for Mayor, gave a preview last night of his tactics in the coming campaign. Turning his satire directly on his two major party opponents, he referred repeatedly to Mayor O'Dwyer as "Whirling Willie" and to Newbold Morris as one who "lost his scoutmaster when La Guardia died."

LONDON, Sept. 1 -- The United States proposed here today that deadlocked four-power negotiations on an Austrian peace treaty be temporarily adjourned and resumed again in New York Sept. 22. The proposal was made by United States Deputy Samuel Reber with the knowledge and approval of the British.

Britain's trade with Brazil is now growing and under the new trade agreement between the two countries the volume may rise to 35 per cent of the total of United States exports to Brazil, according to analysis yesterday by the Brazilian Government Trade Bureau.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- Testimony that 40 per cent of displaced persons' applications for admission to the United States from Germany were based upon false documents in 1947 was received today by a Senate Judiciary subcommittee considering new DP legislation.
John Bromwich, captain of the Australian Davis Cup team, met his master in a 24-year-old American war veteran yesterday in the national tennis championships at Forest Hills.

BELMAR, N. J., Sept. 1 -- The jinx that has been hovering over the United States Atlantic tuna tournament was banished on the strong southwest wind that ruffled the water today, and two eligible tuna plus a scattering of other non-eligible fish were weighed in at the tournament dock.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 1 (AP) -Francis P. Matthews, Secretary of the Navy, and a party of officials landed at Moffett Field near here early today after being forced back from a flight to Honolulu by engine trouble.

A group of 100 children tied up traffic yesterday for two hours and damaged an automobile parked in Thirty-fourth Street between Third and Fourth Avenues, Brooklyn, in a demonstration protesting the death on Wednesday of a 5-year-old boy.

An unemployed seaman's three-month effort to collect his state unemployment insurance payments seemed on the verge of success last night after he had exhausted his savings, sold his marine tools and pawned his two civilian suits.

The magnitude of this state's pollution and sewage control problem is brought out forcibly in the 1949 report to the Legislature, recently published, by the special legislative Committee on Pollution Abatement. This report deserves the serious consideration of all our citizens, for the problem of adequate sewage disposal and waste control affects each of us more and more every year as our population increases and our industries expand.
How to buy pots and pans and influence a husband by wise choice of his shirts are the themes of two pamphlets just issued by the National Consumer - Retailer Council at 1860 Broadway.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange continued quiet yesterday and closed 2 points lower to 5 points higher.

Brisk trading in rubber, hides and zinc futures marked activities on the Commodity Exchange here yesterday. Rubber futures were particularly active and closed the day 15 to 24 points higher than Wednesday's closing quotations. Trade short covering commission-house buying and lifting of hedges accounted for the strong demand, particularly for December and for March, 1950, deliveries.
Mayor O'Dwyer promised yesterday the cooperation of every city agency with the new theatrical committee organized to improve conditions along Broadway.

William Helis Jr., Louisiana oil man and friend of Maj. Gen. Harry H. Vaughan, President Truman's military aide, charged yesterday that he and his father had been made victims of "character assassination" in references and innuendoes in the Senate's 5 percenter inquiry.

PARIS, Sept. 1 -- Amid suggestions that the Marshall Plan was in danger of being compromised, two top officials of the European Council of the plan issued today a statement that was regarded as a supreme appeal to the United States for more extended dollar aid.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- President Truman disclosed today that negotiations for a $203,000,000 oil development loan to Mexico would be resumed and that he was confident they would be successful.

Increased attention by American churches to group responsibility, action and morality in our economic life is called for in the annual Labor Sunday message of the Federal Council of the Churches of Christ in America. The message is to be read Sunday from the pulpits of the council's affiliates.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- The Administration's policy for recruiting business and industrial specialists, especially in the Department of Defense, may be affected by the coming Senate consideration of the nomination of Carl A. Ilgenfritz, vice president of the United States Steel Corporation, for chairman of the Munitions Board, according to indications today.
Arduilio Susi, secretary-treasurer of Local 89 of the Chefs and Cooks Union, AFL, yesterday won a five-year battle for United States citizenship.
A small group of French imports was included in the custom collection of millinery presented yesterday morning at Milgrim's. Little head-hugging shapes, draped to the side, featured the collection.

Since recommendations by home economists constantly emphasize the advantages of sitting down at one's job, the most desirable chair for the kitchen would appear to be one that offered unique inducements to the homemaker to relax at her chores.

WASHINGTON, Sept 1 -- President Truman expressed the hope today that the deep conflict between the democratic nations and Russia and her satellites would end in the surrender of the Communist bloc and lead to generations of peace.

HONOLULU, Sept. 1 -- A wrangle over union records today delayed the International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union, injunction suit in Federal Court against the Hawaiian Government's dock seizure laws and operations.

Shrill cries of excitement echoed long 129th Street between Fifth and Lenox Avenues yesterday as 13-year-old James McCrae roller-skated across the chalked finish line in first place and earned a book on Babe Ruth as his prize.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed a decline of 5.5 per cent in August compared with the corresponding month last year, according to the survey made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES.

Former Governor Herbert H. Lehman will address the convention of the New York State Congress of Industrial Organizations at Saratoga Springs on Sept. 10, Louis Hollander, its president, announced yesterday.

In your issue of Aug. 22 a letter from F. P. Biggs on "Broadening European Union" suggests that America associate herself with the "Council of Europe" in Strasbourg. Perhaps your correspondent is not yet familiar with the work of the "Atlantic Union Committee" in New York City, which is advocating a federal union of the signatories of the Atlantic Pact, including of course the United States.

An export racket in which the name of a relief organization was used illegally as a front was brought to light yesterday when a Federal grand jury indicted thirteen men on charges of fraudulently exporting $500,000 of commodities to Italian and South American black market outlets.

LONDON, Sept. 1 -- Hesitancy and dullness prevailed in most sections of the stock markets here today. European political events and speculation about the outcome of Washington financial talks provided the occasion for a continued disinclination to undertake fresh commitments.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- In a move interpreted in Congress as a final and drastic attempt to force a Federal-aid-to-education bill to the House floor for a voting showdown, Representative John Lesinski, Democrat, of Michigan, chairman of the Committee on Education and Labor, suddenly "dissolved" today all four of that body's special subcommittees.
The American Cancer Society will not join any united fund-raising efforts anywhere in the United States, it was announced yesterday by the ranking executives of the organization.
Paul Robeson and his political supporters are going back to Peekskill Sunday, "twenty thousand strong," and are prepared to "defend themselves," it was announced last night.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (AP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board today completed a four-day public hearing on Trans-Canada Airlines' request for a permit to fly non-stop between Montreal and New York.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Sept. 1 -- The recently crowned Westchester and Fairfield champion, Mrs. John H. Bartol of Greenwich, won low gross honors in the one-day Westchester and Fairfield tourney with a 4-over-par 41, 38 -- 79 over the Westchester Hills Golf Club course today.

By automobile, bus, train and airplane the Labor Day week-end trek from the metropolitan area will get under way today, with outgoing travel reaching a peak probably around 6 P. M. Airlines alone predicted record traffic.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- Large numbers of workmen have not yet "acted on their obligation to join unions" as the surest guarantee of their own welfare, the National Catholic Welfare Council said in a Labor Day statement today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- The Tennessee Gas Transmission Company, Houston. Texas, filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering 100,000 shares of $100 par value, cumulative preferred stock and 400,000 shares of $5 par value common stock.

THE pennant hopes of three teams will take an abrupt turn for the better today. The worst is now behind them. The St. Louis Cardinals have headed West, there to remain, with the majority of their games scheduled for the friendly confines of their own home park. The New York Yankees and the Boston Red Sox are returning to the East with nothing but a few easy side trips confronting them.

Charge accounts have been mad available to patrons of the Wood bridge Drive-In Theatre in Wood bridge, N. J., it was announced yesterday by Walter Reade, head of the Walter Reade Theatres operators of the house. According to the announcement, this mark the first time that movie patron will be able to run up charge accounts.

Two of Manhattan's busiest thoroughfares will be selected next week as a testing ground for a new rubber compound to make road surfaces more durable, provide a safer driving Surface and reduce street maintenance costs, it was learned yesterday.

A motion-picture technique for informing securities dealers on a nation-wide scale about an imminent offering of new securities and about the business of the issuing company was demonstrated for the press yesterday in the First Boston Corporation's offices at 100 Broadway, here.

To diversify operations of its network of plants in thirteen New England, Southern and Midwestern States, the Atlas Plywood Corporation is going into mass production of hardwood plywoods in grades being utilized in the construction, wood - working and related industries, Elmore I. MacPhie, president, declared in his annual report to be mailed to stockholders today.

LAKEHURST, N. J., Sept. 1 -Twenty-five years ago, on Sept. 1, 1924, two chief petty officers, using an old warehouse, a sewing machine and a packing table, started the Parachute Materiel School at the Naval Air Station here.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- President Truman will combine an overnight visit to his home in Independence, Mo., with his marathon air speaking tour on Labor Day when he will make two major speeches.

Lest your Paris reporter, Harold Callender, begin to believe some of the European experts' statements he has so admirably reported in his dispatch of Aug. 28, here is one of the facts versus the story told him.

LAKE SUCCESS, Sept. 1 -- Yugoslavia does not plan to bring her troubles with the Soviet Union before the United Nations now, according to informed sources at the headquarters of the world organization.
LONDON, Sept. 1 -- Plans of the new Atlantic pact defense organization are being hurried to completion in time for the meeting of the Atlantic pact foreign ministers in Washington on Sept. 17.

The six-story building containing a store and fifteen apartments on a lot 25 by 100 feet at 426 East 170th Street, the Bronx, has been sold by the 470 East 170th Street, Inc., to Seymour M. Tannenbaum in a deal negotiated by Elmer Von Dickersohn, broker.

The defense will rest in the eight-month Communist trial in "a matter of days," defense counsel told Federal Judge Harold R. Medina yesterday. They have given Government counsel the impression that after Carl Winter, their present witness, leaves the stand they will read a deposition of William Z. Foster to the jury, and then close their case with Henry Winston, who will be the thirty-second defense witness.

In a unique effort to protect the jobs and wage standards of union members by keeping store sales high, a union representing 2,400 Wanamaker employes in this city decided yesterday to place newspaper advertisements, sponsor an essay contest and mail out 10,000 letters, all with a view to urging more persons to buy at Wanamaker's.

When a genial 73-year-old Indian Prince stepped from a transatlantic airliner at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, yesterday he knew well what questions would be put to him by the reporters who approached him as soon as he left customs.

The Giants, hitting that long ball again, rapped out three home runs in beating the Pirates, 9 to 5, for the second day in a row at the Polo Grounds yesterday. It was the fourth straight victory for the New Yorkers, who are coming on with renewed vigor in a stretch bid to capture third place.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Sept. 1 -- A picture of the imprisoned Hungarian Primate, Joseph Cardinal Mindszenty -- one among 200 in the window of the United States Information Service library here -has been removed at the request of a Czechoslovak Foreign Office official.

An outstanding example of modern architecture and equipment in a town house designed largely to accommodate visiting members of the family is nearing completion in the Beekman Place section of Manhattan for John D. Rockefeller 3d and his wife, the former Blanchette Hooker.

NEWCASTLE, England, Sept. 1 -- Accepting the evidence of telepathy, Prof A. C. Hardy of Oxford, president of the zoological section, told the British Association for the Advancement of Science today that existing ideas of evolution might have to be altered.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 1 -- The Yankees got the Browns out into broad day light today, but even this shift failed to curb the ferocity with which Zach Taylor's St. Louisians have been tearing into the American League's first division clubs of late.

LONDON, Sept. 1 (UP) -- Iron Curtain countries marked the tenth anniversary of the start of the second World War today by at tacking President Truman, Pope Pius XII, Premier Marshal Tito of Yugoslavia and other leaders who have come into disfavor with the Communists.

Raising the curtain on the 1949 gridiron campaign with a rousing struggle in which the losers had three touchdowns recalled, the Eastern College All-Stars smashed their way to a 28-13 upset victory over the New York Giants last night at the Polo Grounds.

HELSINKI, Finland, Sept. 1 -While the Communist-inspired strike wave entered its third week with bricklayers walking out and longshoremen resuming work, the Finnish Parliament began its autumn session calmly today.

HONG KONG, Sept. 1 -- One of the greatest accumulations of merchandise from Britain, the United States and other countries in a century of Hong Kong commerce now is stored up here awaiting the day when trade with China will reopen again on a large scale. Warehousing space is at a premium and in some cases office and residential quarters are being used for storage.

LONDON, Sept. 1 -- Half an hour before the release tonight of a prepared statement announcing the breakdown of economic talks between the governments of Britain and Malta, Dr. Paul Boffa, Prime Minister of Malta, telephoned the Colonial Office to say that he wished the discussions to continue.

Encouraged by substantial factory unit sales increases in small appliances during the last seven Weeks, Landers, Frary and Clark will spend 65 per cent of its entire 1949 advertising and promotional budget for these items from now until the end of the year, Robert M. Oliver, general merchandise manager, portable electric appliance division, disclosed yesterday.

ROCHESTER, N. Y., Sept. 1 -- With a brilliant putting touch, Willie Turnesa of Elmsford, N. Y., defending champion, rallied after being 2 down to defeat Frank Strafaci of Flushing, the Long Island titleholder, by 3 and 2 and gain the semi-finals of the United States amateur golf tournament at the Oak Hill Country Club today.

A somewhat better feeling has developed in the men's furnishings field, with indications pointing to more active covering of fall and holiday lines starting after the holiday next week. Open-to-buy percentages of retailers are still high, ranging to 50 per cent in some instances.

LONDON, Sept. 1 -- A puppet, representing George Bernard Shaw, knocked out William Shakespeare in a play published today which the 93-year-old playwright said was "in all actuarial probability, my last play, and the climax of my eminence."

There are fifty-five new "Wise Old Owls" in Manhattan today. Degrees were presented yesterday to the youngsters at the closing rooftop jamboree of the Madison Square Boy's Club, 301 East Twenty-ninth Street.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- During the week ended Aug. 31 member bank reserve balances increased $3,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board announced today.

CHICAGO, Sept. 1 -- Deliveries of 1,461,000 bushels of cash wheat on September contracts and tenders of an additional 755,000 bushels today failed to affect the price of that contract on the Board of Trade today. Instead of the liquidation expected by some operators there was aggressive buying of September against sales of December, attributed to cash interests changing over hedges into the distant month.

GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 1 -Alex Watson, the veteran who teaches at the Leewood Golf Club in Tuckahoe, teamed with one of his club amateurs, Harry Denmead, for a best-ball of 33, 34 -- 67, four under par, at Tamarack this afternoon to win the weekly one-day pro-amateur tournament conducted by the Westchester Golf Association.

The Strand this morning will return to a combined stage and screen policy with the premiere of the James Cagney vehicle, "White Heat," and a stage show headed by Xavier Cugat and his orchestra. Cagney also is returning to his gangster characterization in "White Heat," a Warner Brothers melodrama featuring Virginia Mayo, Margaret Wycherly, Edmond O'Brien, Wally Cassell and Fred Clark,

As the long week-end of Labor Day approaches, all who are concerned with greater safety on the roads and streets must feel a sense of apprehension. The holiday seems to impart a sort of last-fling recklessness to drivers. Last year the Labor Day week-end was more deadly in New York City than the equally long Fourth of July holiday period.

In making recommendations for contestants in the primary election next Tuesday, the Citizens Union yesterday expressed a preference for Shad Polier, candidate of the Fair Deal Democrats for the Democratic nomination for City Council in the Twentieth Senatorial District over Donald F. Monagh, the Tammany designee.

Mayor O'Dwyer received yesterday from Acting Budget Director Abraham D. Beame a report showing that the city appropriated $654,749,000 between Jan. 1, 1946, and Sept. 1, 1949, for construction of public works under its capital budget program.

BERLIN, Sept. 1 -- Symbolized by an outsize wooden dove, surmounting a tall column in August Bebel Platz, the Soviet-sponsored "Peace Day Demonstration" in this city's Russian sector this afternoon was interspersed with belligerent proclamations.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended Aug. 27 were 746,912 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 15,697 cars, or 2.1 per cent, more than for the preceding week, 144,754 cars, or 16.2 per cent, fewer than for the corresponding week of last year; and 178,800 cars, or 19.3 per cent, fewer than during the corresponding week of two years ago.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- Applications for public hearings on a proposed increase of 44 cents per hundredweight in the minimum price of Class 1-A milk in New York and New England were turned down today by the Department of Agriculture.

SHANGHAI, Sept. 1 -- By the end of 1950 the Communists in Manchuria hope to restore heavy industrial production to 40 per cent of the level attained by the Japanese during the days of the puppet Manchukuo regime according to an official report published here.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 1 -- A new generation took over control of the American Legion today when delegates to the thirty-first national convention here chose a 40-year-old veteran of World War II as their national commander.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- For the first time in many years the Washington Publishers Association has served notice on Columbia Typographical Union No. 101 proposing terms of a new agreement, it was learned today. Usually the union serves its demands as preliminary to joint collective bargaining conferences.

BOSTON, Sept. 1 -- The Vatican tonight ordered a Jesuit priest, four discharged Boston College professors and their followers to drop their charges of "heresy" and return immediately to the Catholic Church at the "peril of their souls."
SUPERIOR, Wis., Sept. 1 (AP) -The Superior Evening Telegram said today that Superior will be the terminal of a $100,000,000 pipeline from the oil fields discovered in Alberta, Canada, two years ago.

American importers of textiles have placed sizable orders in Great Britain subject to devaluation of the pound, according to Herman L. Bates, president of H. Bates Co., Inc. Many of the orders, he said, have been made up and are waiting on British docks for the outcome of forthcoming currency discussions in Washington which are expected to peg the pound at a lower figure in relation to American dollars.

LONDON, Sept. 1 -- Sir Norman Kipping, director general of the Federation of British Industries, said today that United States manufacturers should not be frightened by the increase in British exports that would be needed to erase this country's dollar deficit.

Something resembling a price war has developed on the Pacific Coast in an effort to dispose of the excess stocks of heavy fuel oil there. Recently, the Union Oil Company of California sold 2,800,000 barrels of that product to East Coast operators at a discount of 15 cents a barrel below the going cargo price here at the time of delivery.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (AP) -Testimony that two former United States Navy men were "shanghaied" into the French Foreign Legion in 1947 and 1948 was recorded at a Naval court-martial today.

FORT MONMOUTH, N. J., Sept. 1 -- Capt. Henry E. Bernstein, naval adviser to Maj. Gen. Francis H. Lanahan, commanding general of Fort Monmouth, became the director of the Armed Services Electro Standards Agency here today, through a joint agreement of the Army, Navy and Air Force.
Prices of scrap metal are continuing to advance in all major markets throughout the country simultaneously with the sharp upturn in steel industry operations.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- Two exercises to test the defenses of the northern approaches to the United States were announced at the Department of Defense today. Both are scheduled to be staged on a relatively small scale.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 1 -- The Hungarian villages of Kacmar and Gara, on the Yugoslav border, west of Subotica, have been evacuated of their civilian population in order to billet Soviet troops maneuvering in the frontier region.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Sept. 1 -- A large-scale afforestation project designed to revitalize the barren parts of Israel, especially in the Galilee district, will be launched within a few days by the Jewish National Fund under the auspices of the Jewish Agency for Palestine.

CHICAGO, Sept. 1 -- Ralph Budd, retired president of the Chicago, Burlington and Quincy Railroad, today opened his new office as Chairman of the Chicago Transit Authority, a job that pays him $15,000 a year as a member and $20,000 as chairman.
TOKYO, Friday, Sept. 2 -- Following is the text of General MacArthur's statement on he fourth anniversary of the Japanese surrender:

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 1 -Yale began its seventy-seventh football campaign today when a squad of sixty-eight candidates reported to Coach Herman Hickman, starting his second season at the Eli gridiron helm. After physical examinations were conducted, Coach Hickman sent the squad through a brief session of calisthenics.
Mayor O'Dwyer personally ordered the dismissal of John J. Broderick from the Police Department, according to District Attorney Frank S. Hogan.

An effort at "grass roots" reporting on marketing conditions by key areas' business men and retailers in order to obtain more current data is being planned as a feature of the Association of National Advertisers' annual meeting, Oct. 10-12, in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, it was learned yesterday.

BURLINGTON, Vt., Sept. 1 -Ninety per cent of the nearly 72,000 displaced persons who have been resettled in this country have made satisfactory adjustments to their new life, the Rev. William J. Gibbons, a member of the executive committee of the National Catholic Rural Life Conference and a former associate editor of the magazine America, said here today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- President Truman said today at his regular press conference that he contemplated no change in the status of his Military Aide, Maj. Gen. Harry H. Vaughan, as a result of the "five percenter" inquiry being conducted by a Senate investigations subcommittee.
Daniel Platt, 52 years old, of 1166 Grand Concourse, The Bronx, was indicted yesterday by the Federal grand jury on twenty-nine counts charging mail fraud in the sale of an alleged water heater.
URBANA, Ill., Sept. 1 (AP) -- The National Student Association voted today not to affiliate with the International Union of Students.

DETROIT, Sept. 1 -- With a warning that set no deadline, Walter P. Reuther, president of the United Automobile Workers, CIO, told the Ford Motor Company today that the union's patience could not last much longer without evidence that a "fair solution" to contract problems was being negotiated.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Sept. 1 (AP) -- Richard A. Johnson's Black and Blue, 3-year-old colt that had won his last start under a $2,500 claiming tag, triumphed in $6,000 company in the Montclair Purse before 13,106 racegoers today. The son of Kings Blue beat Floco by three lengths with the favored Dream Spinner third in the six-furlong race.

A sophomore-laden squad of sixty-one Columbia football candidates ran through brisk light contact drills at Baker Field yesterday as the Lions opened training for their 1949 season. Coach Lou Little, now in his twentieth year at Columbia, put the squad through its two-a-day practice routine which will continue until the Lions meet Amherst in their opener on Sept. 24.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (UP) -- A serious decline in Russia's grain crops was reported today by the Department of Agriculture.
Northwest Airlines, which is the first carrier to put large Boeing Stratocruisers into regular service on domestic air routes, began nine-hour transcontinental commercial flights yesterday.

Studies of alternate routes in the metropolitan area were suggested for motorists yesterday by the Automobile Club of New York as a factor in reducing Labor Day week-end congestion. A recent survey indicated that a more extensive knowledge of highways that virtually parallel popular thoroughfares would benefit many who now follow "beaten path" procedures.

The United Brewery Workers, CIO, won a major defense yesterday against threats by the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, AFL, to try to take over control of beer drivers and other brewery workers in this city.

MEXICO CITY, Sept. 1 -- Devaluation of the peso has been Mexico's economic salvation but inflation can be avoided and the development of the nationalized oil industry will not depend on foreign loans, President Miguel Aleman said today.

MOSCOW, Sept. 1 -- Culture and Life, important organ of the Propaganda and Agitation Department of the Central Committee of the Communist party, calls for improvement in the work of the Institute of Economics of the Academy of Sciences so that it shall "decisively overcome serious shortcomings and mistakes existing in its work."

John M. Broady, private investigator, was cleared of illegal wiretapping yesterday by a blue ribbon jury that deliberated more than seventeen hours. Also acquitted of this charge was Edward M. Jones, an employe of Broady's.

ROME, Sept. 1 -- The membership of the Italian Communist party has decreased by more than 20 per cent in the last year, according to the best figures available in Rome. The total dropped from a maximum of 2,272,000 on May 31 of last year to 1,780,000 on June 30 this year.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 1 -- Reliable sources said tonight that they believed the Soviet Government was entertaining a plan calling for severance of diplomatic relations between the Cominform states and Marshal Tito's regime.

TRENTON, N. J., Sept. 1 (AP) -The difference between one-14,175th and one-283,500th part of an ounce won a new trial today for a Plainfield man who lost his motor vehicle license on a drunken driving charge. A new trial was ordered by the Appellate Division of the New Jersey Superior Court for Clayton L. Hunter, convicted in Plainfield City Court after a "drunkometer" test.

TOKYO, Friday, Sept. 2 -- Japan, after four years of Allied occupation, merited the right to a peace treaty with her conquerors, Gen. Douglas MacArthur said today on the fourth anniversary of the surrender aboard the battleship Missouri.
FRANKFORT, Germany, Sept. 1 (AP) -- West German newspapers noted the tenth anniversary of the outbreak of World War II today with a chorus of "We don't want another."
WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (AP) -Bean price support levels somewhat below last year's were announced today by the Department of Agriculture. The basic support prices for the 1949 crop follow:

A committee headed by Robert Moses acknowledged yesterday that it had erred when it charged last month that the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company had violated an agreement with the city by failing to provide adequate parking facilities at Stuyvesant Town and Peter Cooper Village.

STOCKHOLM, Sept. 1 -- Sweden can obtain a more profitable and a larger share of American business by concentrating on America's number one market area, Dr. Eric W. Stoetzner, director of foreign business promotion of THE NEW YORK TIMES, declared in a speech here tonight.
NEWARK, Sept. 2 (AP) -- Newark came up with two peerless pitching performances tonight to sweep both ends of a double-header from Syracuse by the identical 1-0 score.

A year ago President Truman asked for a three-year extension of the Hull Reciprocal Trade Agreements Act, which up to that time had been renewed regularly at every expiration date since 1934. Instead, the then Republican Congress voted to continue the program for only one year and rewrote the legislation in such a way as to curtail substantially the President's freedom of action in tariff negotiations.
Loans to business made by banks in this area resumed their climb, advancing $20,000,000 during the week ended on Wednesday after faltering in the previous week.

We are indebted to a restaurateur hereabouts for an odd bit of information anent the recent cool snap. His sales of apple pie portions, far below normal during the stupefying heat, climbed sharply as soon as the temperature dropped.

After their high shenanigans of a week ago, prices of meats and fancy eggs steadied this week. Homemakers stocking up for the long week-end will find meat costs, though no lower than last Friday when porterhouse hit $1.05 a pound, at least no higher.

Charles Dewey Hilles belonged to that group who from the beginning of the Republic have helped to bring it to pass that popular government has worked better here than anywhere else in the world. Patriotic, possessed of patience, tact and an understanding of the science of human nature as it expresses itself in elections, Mr. Hilles' judgment in political matters was unusually sound and hence he was an outstanding figure among politicians.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Sept. 1 -- Guy J. Swope, former Congressman of Harrisburg, Pa., arrived here today to serve in the office of the United States Military Government in Bavaria, according to an announcement by the office of John J. McCloy, High Commissioner-designate.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 1 -- Dismissal of perjury and conspiracy indictments against Harry R. Bridges, West Coast longshore leader, and two of his colleagues, was sought today in thirteen motions filed with Chief Judge Michael J. Roche in Federal District Court here.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- About 435,000 veterans of World War I who hold Government life insurance on a permanent basis are receiving special dividend checks this month.

The Masonic lodge building at 91 Middle Neck Road, corner of Maple Drive, in Great Neck, L, I., has been sold by Paumonok Lodge to the 91 Middle Neck Road Corporation, which plans to develop the site for business use. The lodge structure, on an irregular plot about 89 by 105 feet, was erected more than forty years ago.

BOSTON, Sept. 1 (AP) -- Supported by a 13-hit attack, Lefty Warren Spahn became the National League's first 17-game winner today as the Boston Braves swept a two-game series with the last-place Chicago Cubs with an 8-4 victory.

Forty new cases of poliomyelitis and two more deaths from the disease were reported yesterday by the city's Department of Health. In its daily polio summary covering the twenty-four hours up to 9 A. M., yesterday, the department said the total number of cases for the year thus far had reached 1,549, compared with 228 on the same date a year ago.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Sept. 1 -- John J. McCloy, United States High Commissioner-designate, and Gen. Sir Brian Robertson, Military Governor of the British zone, have sternly advised the eight German Ministers-President of the United States and British zones of Western Allied concern over signs of renascent nazism in the German press.

ONE of the most popular and admired of living European novelists is a Hungarian author absolutely unknown in this country. He is Ferenc Kormendi, whose most important novel, "The Happy Generation,"* is finally published here fifteen years after its original appearance in Hungary.

Captain Frederic Sundlof, former master of the American tanker Chrysanthystar, emphatically denied yesterday charges brought against him by the Coast Guard as the result of the collision in July, 1948, between his ship and the British trawler Energetic.

DETROIT, Sept. 1 (AP) -- The Tigers finally broke the spell Mel Parnell had cast over them throughout his big league career and beat him, 7 to 0, in the Red Sox' final 1949 appearance at Briggs Stadium today.

In asserting that "Congress is abundantly right in speeding legislation to outlaw the picketing of United States courts," your editorial of Aug. 28 endorses a bill which, if enacted, would severely curtail the right of free speech. The right to express opinions by carrying placards has been recognized by the Supreme Court as a part of the right of free speech.

One of the plays Lee Shubert didn't care to announce on his recent arrival from Europe presumably was "The Chiltern Hundreds," written by W. Douglas-Home, who is otherwise known as Lord William. According to London advices, contracts are being drawn to bring it here under the supervision of John Krimsky and Mr. Shubert, for a late September opening.

Sophie, ace designer for Saks Fifth Avenue's Salon Moderne, has a happy faculty for making her audience leave her show room in a thoroughly contented mood. Her collections always end on a dramatic note. In quick succession glamorous evening gowns float into the room and the manikins take their places on the floor, occasionally in front of a mirror, where their gowns show off to the best advantage.

Prices of real estate bonds were strong in August for the second successive month, with fractional gains wiping out the decreases sustained during the early part of the year. The price averages are based on an index of forty issues compiled by Amott, Baker Co.
In line with a suggestion advanced originally by Mayor O'Dwyer, the Traffic Commission proposed formally yesterday that the city initiate legislation to set up a parking authority.

ALLENTOWN, Pa., Sept. 2 (AP) -- The Chicago Cardinals scored in the last ten seconds tonight on a pass from Paul Christman to Boris DiMancheff to edge out the New York Bulldogs, 24 to 21, in an exhibition game between the two National Football League teams.
PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Aug. 26 -- An archaeological excavation in southern Moravia has brought to light what is regarded as the oldest example of stone architecture north of the Danube.

The long holiday week-end exodus began early yesterday, slackened off during midday, then picked up again in the late afternoon. Between 5 and 6 P. M. the travel peak was reached, with millions of persons leaving the city by automobile, bus, train and plane to enjoy the last holiday of summer at beach and mountain resort.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 2 -- New world speed records for closed-course flying were foreshadowed here today when three United States Air Force jet fighters posted an average speed of 605 miles an hour while making a trial run over the new National Air Races Course.

The appointment of Gordon R. Clapp, chairman of the TVA, to head a mission to the Near East, marks a significant turn of policy in the efforts of the United Nations and the United States to bring permanent peace to that troubled area.
A sharp increase of tax paid withdrawals of whisky during July gives indication that distillers are looking forward to good fall and winter sales, industry leaders declared here yesterday.!

John David Provoo, 33 years old, of Sausalito, Calif., who was separated from the United States Army as a sergeant yesterday afternoon at Governors Island, was immediately arrested by Federal Bureau of Investigation agents and an hour later was arraigned here before United States Commissioner Edward W. McDonald on a charge of treasonably dealing with Japanese in time of war.

The contracts still remain to be signed, but the necessary arrangements have been made whereby the Music Box definitely will house the forthcoming Maxwell Anderson-Kurt Weill play with music, "Lost in the Stars."

The one-story taxpayer building at the northwest corner of Eliot Avenue and Eightieth Street in Elmhurst, Queens, containing an A. P. super market and five other stores, has been sold by B. F. Moss and associates to Jack Kliger and Max Schneider for cash above a mortgage of $45,000.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Sept. 2 -- An American student returning from the Budapest Youth Festival, charged here today that pro-Communist leaders of the United States delegation tried to prevent delegates from getting in touch with the United State legation and had expelled a girl delegate for "spreading false rumors."

LAKE SUCCESS, Sept. 2 -- Dr. Howard A. Rusk, chief of the Army Air Force's rehabilitation program during World War II, will go to Europe next week to look into the possibilities of setting up an international center to aid the millions of people left crippled by the war.
After a long period of litigation, Canio Lagala, who had been a candidate for Tammany leader of the Sixteenth Assembly District, North, against Frank Rosetti, the incumbent, withdrew last night.

Mayor O'Dwyer told a group of Anglican bishops and clergymen at City Hall yesterday that nearly every known religion was represented in the city's population and that all the sects were living at peace with one another. He said that if the sects did not respect each other's freedom of worship there would be danger that all religious freedom would be destroyed.

HONOLULU, Sept. 2 -- The United States' new National Memorial Cemetery of the Pacific was dedicated here today on a note of solemn prophecy by Secretary of the Navy Francis P. Matthews. He declared that the fate of the war dead who are buried there was a final warning that America's future was at stake in the conflict of ideologies raging in the world today.

NARROWSBURG, N. Y., Sept. 2 -- A three-point program to strengthen the Jewish community in Europe, Israel and America was urged by Arnulf M. Pins of Paterson, N. J., chairman at tonight's opening of the second annual assembly of the National Jewish Youth Conference at Camp Wel-Met.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 2 -"Elmer the Great," Ring Lardner's comedy about baseball which was staged on Broadway in 1928 and filmed by First National in 1933, with Joe E. Brown, will be remade by Warner Brothers (which has absorbed First National) this year with Jack Carson in the title role.

NEW LONDON, Conn., Sept. 2 -- Some advances in knowledge concerning the formation of twins were reported today by Dr. S. Gluecksohn Schoenheimer at a meeting here of the Society for Growth and Development. Dr. Schoenheimer, an associate in genetics in the zoology department of Columbia University, read a paper on her researches in mouse embryos.
STRASBOURG, France, Sept. 2 (Reuters) -- Europe's twelve-nation consultative assembly today rejected a call for a review of European exchange rates in relation to the dollar.
A drive to unite all of the anti-leftists in the city's Welfare Department under a new union has been quietly started, it was learned yesterday.
The report of the Celotex Corporation issued yesterday for the nine months ended on July 31, last, disclosed a net profit of $887,921 after taxes and all charges.
An official threat to call out every longshoreman in ports from Maine to Virginia was issued yesterday by Joseph P. Ryan, president of the International Longshoremen's Association, AFL.

ALBANY, Sept. 2 -- Republican State Chairman William L. Pfeiffer announced today that he had requested President Truman to dismiss his military aide, Maj. Gen. Harry H. Vaughan, "for conduct unbecoming an officer and gentleman of the United States Army."

"Candid Camera," the Allen Funt show which employs a concealed camera to catch persons in unrehearsed situations, will be added to the CBS video schedule at 9 P. M. on Monday, Sept. 12. The program, previously seen on ABC and NBC television, will be sponsored by Philip Morris cigarettes.

LAKE SUCCESS, Sept. 2 -- The earth's most valuable natural resource is the productivity of a working man, and this asset never has been fully realized because of the ravages of disease and malnutrition, speakers at the United Nations Scientific Conference on the Conservation and Utilization of Resources declared here today.

CHICAGO, Sept. 2 (AP) -- The newspapers' biggest retail advertiser, Sears, Roebuck Co., spent a record-breaking total for newspaper ads last year, Editor and Publisher, newspaper trade publication, announced today.

PARIS, Sept. 2 -- Marshal Tito has told a group of Americans that his differences with Premier Joseph Stalin go back at least five years, but that he does not think they will lead to war, it was disclosed tonight. The Yugoslav eader said that Premier Stalin regarded him as "small fry" and wanted him to "knuckle under," the Americans reported.

Michael G. Phipps, eight-goal internationalist, whose name long has been associated with high-goal polo, will replace the injured George Oliver for Chicago when that team faces Argentina's El Trebol side in a first-round match in the national open polo championship on International Field of the Meadow Brook Club tomorrow.

The hosiery picture for this fall is one of exciting color interest and style. Stocking houses are featuring shades keyed to new fashion colors. New styles are in keeping with the shorter-length street and evening dresses and the low and open shoes.

As twenty-five families faced resolutely a legal deadline yesterday for the evacuation of a Washington Square block projected for New York University's $3,000,000 Law Center, demolition work on the south side was halted to insure the safety of occupants of No. 41.

Steps to obtain damages for breach of contract were taken yesterday by the Isbrandtsen Company, Inc. against the Marine Engineers Beneficial Association, CIO, which has tied up the company's freighter Sir John Franklin since Tuesday afternoon.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission today approved the sale of the controlling interest in the Capital Transit Company, owner of Washington's street railway and bus lines, to a syndicate of Jacksonville, Fla., investors for $2,189,160.

NO MANS LAND ISLAND, Mass., Sept. 2 -- The three-man crew of a fishing boat said today that a fighter plane, skimming the water, had strafed them as they were docked here. They showed more than a score of bullet holes to back up their story.
Louis Hollander, president of the State Congress of Industrial Organizations, recommended yesterday in a Labor Day statement that the labor movement inventory its strength and organize politically.

Two graduate courses in religious journalism for the training of young men and women for work overseas on Evangelical Christian magazines, books and pamphlets have been announced by the Syracuse University School of Journalism.

A new, fast passenger service to Greece and Israel to begin with the sailing of the 18,000-ton liner LaGuardia on Oct. 13, was announced yesterday by George C. Gaede, passenger traffic manager of the American Export Lines.

Warning that some of the contests in this Tuesday's coming primary elections may be "hot," Police Commissioner William P. O'Brien instructed 250 officers of the rank of captain or above yesterday to concentrate their men in possible trouble areas.

The publishers of dictionaries are given to boasting how many words their compilations contain It makes no difference if a word is obsolete or if it is a curiosity, like "succussion," "smeddum," or "succedaneum." In it goes. It is sad to record that the scientists have contributed more than a mite to the verbal Mount Everest.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- The United States Congress will be represented by nine of its members at the thirty-eighth regular conference of the Interparliamentary Union beginning Sept. 6 at Stockholm, the State Department announced today.

BELMAR, N. J., Sept. 2 -- Fred Schock of Spring Lake won the United States Atlantic Tuna tournament for his team, the Brielle Marlin and Tuna Club, by bringing in the largest fish two days in succession. Schock's fish scaled 367 pounds, and with the penalty deducted for the use of 39-thread line, the tournament weight was brought down to 275 1/4 pounds.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 2 (UP) -- A deposition supporting the defense contention that Iva (Tokyo Rose) D'Aquino frequently predicted Japan's defeat was introduced in evidence today at the treason trial of the Los Angeles-born Nisei, 33 years old.

PARIS, Sept. 2 -- The insistence in naval circles here that the French Navy, which is at present in a serious decline, be saved from further decay, is heard increasingly with the approach of what is expected to be an all-out debate on national defense, after Parliament reconvenes next month.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 (AP) -Senator Millikin, RepubLican, of Colorado, promised today a "furious debate" if the Administration tries to lower tariff barriers for Britain without heeding Republican demands to protect domestic industry.

Editorial nostalgia for penny candy as expressed in your issue of Aug. 30 took me back to my early childhood in a small Massachusetts town. It was just around the corner at Miss Hatty's store, where the young penny consumer and the here's-a-penny shopper-for-mother went through the hard exercise of multiple choice as they eyed the varieties in the prominently set glass case.

The members of the National PT Veterans' Association -- the men who manned the PT boats during the last war -- came to New York yesterday from all parts of the country for their fourth annual convention.

PRETORIA, South Africa, Sept. 2 -- Another strand binding the Union of South Africa to the British Commonwealth was severed today when the government Gazette promulgated the South African Citizenship Act enacted by Parliament last June.

Westchester County war veterans' organizations, with reinforcements from other areas, arranged yesterday for a second anti-Communist demonstration to be staged tomorrow in conjunction with the scheduled appearance near Peekskill of Paul Robeson, baritone and left-wing political storm center, for an adjourned concert.

All Germans should have learned by this time what a wicked and destructive thing nazism was. They can see its physical effects in their own divided and occupied country, in the ruins of their cities, in their own war dead and crippled. They can feel its moral effects in the ghastly burden of guilt which hangs over all who were in any way responsible for the Hitler regime.
OTTAWA, Ont., Sept. 2 (AP) -- A sharp drop in exports to the United States during July resulted in a 4 per cent decrease in Canada's domestic shipments abroad compared with a year ago.
The futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange had a steady tone yesterday and final prices were 1 point higher to 5 points lower.
Certain materials, such as rattan, wicker and wrought iron, were at one time exclusively restricted to use in outdoor furniture planned for garden, terrace or porch.

LONDON, Sept. 2 (Reuters) -Brian Close, 18-year-old Yorkshire all-rounder, today became the youngest player in history to complete the coveted double of 1,000 runs and 100 wickets in an English cricket season when he had scored nineteen runs in Yorkshire's second innings against the Marytone C. C. at Scarborough.
The Territory of Hawaii announced yesterday that it would receive bids Sept. 28 on $8,000,000 of public improvement bonds dated Oct. 1, 1949, and due on Oct. 1, 1952 to 1969.

An agreement in principle for the merger of the Ogden Corporation into the Barnsdall Oil Company has been reached, Floyd B. Odlum, chairman of Barnsdall and president of the Atlas Corporation, of which Ogden is a subsidiary, announced yesterday.

STAMFORD, Conn., Sept. 2 -Twenty-nine sail boats ranging in size from 30 to 75 feet started tonight from the Stamford Yacht Club in the 233-mile race to the Vineyard Lightship and back. Class A boats, over 35 feet in overall length, started at 6, and Class B boats, under 35 feet, left ten minutes later.
BURLINGTON, Vt., Sept. 2 -Four "lay apostles" of the Roman Catholic Church described here today their efforts to "translate" the precepts of Christ into action.
SEOUL, Korea, Sept. 2 (AP) -- A gigantic sea turtle, possibly the largest ever caught, gave this Communist-menaced republic an upsurge of spirits today.

TORONTO, Sept. 2 (AP) -- Dr. G. F. Laing of Windsor, Ont., today won the United States Seniors Cup, emblematic of the international championship for golfers over 55 years, by firing a 74 over the par-71 Toronto club course.
LONDON, Sept. 2 (UP) -- Nat Fleischer, editor of Ring magazine, arrived in London today to study the effects of the war on European boxing.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican, of Wisconsin, said today that he would ask that Frank Costello, whom he described as "a big-time gambler and slot machine king" of New York, be called as a witness before the "five-percenter" inquiry.
MADISON, Wis., Sept. 2 (AP) -- The National Phi Beta Kappa Council today voted the University of Texas an academic clean bill of health.

Appointment of a European film attache by the Department of Commerce to advise American Embassies on motion-picture matters will be recommended by Nathan D. Golden, chief of the motion-picture photographic branch of the Department of Commerce.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- Air Force fliers have been forced to acknowledge that they took an operational beating from Navy airmen in carrying supplies in the Berlin airlift, it was disclosed today.

CHICAGO, Sept. 2 (AP) -- Sandy Saddler of New York, former world featherweight champion, tonight administered a ten-round beating to Harold Dade of Chicago, former bantamweight titleholder, in a boxing show for Negro Charities in the Chicago Stadium.
