ESTES PARK, Col., Sept. 2 (AP) -- The economic advisory committee of the Interstate Oil Compact Commission said today that 1949 domestic crude oil production had declined an average of 414,000 barrels daily, while foreign crude imports increased 117,000.

Lumber production for the week ended Aug. 27 was 5 per cent below the comparable week a year ago according to reports wired yesterday to THE NEW YORK TIMES by trade associations. Shipments were 0.5 per cent above last year and orders were up 22.4 per cent.

CHICAGO, Sept. 2 -- The whole system of "fair trade" pricing may collapse unless manufacturers do a better job of policing, Joseph T. Meek, executive secretary of the Illinois Federation of Retail Associations, warned today as association members became restless over the activities of discount houses and other means of sidestepping the regulations of the "fair trade" pricing system.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- A delegation of five members headed by George V. Allen, Assistant Secretary of State for Public Affairs, was named by President Truman today to represent the United States at the meeting of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization to be held in Paris from Sept. 19 to Oct. 5.

Customs and immigration personnel here, who were "spread thin" to process the unusual number of passenger arrivals in the last week, will face an even busier week-end, Government officials said yesterday.

Lack of a soundly conceived and well directed merchandising approach by foreign producers of consumer goods to meet the price and delivery requirements of the American market is the major obstacle to increasing imports into the United States.

The rose family of some 1,200 species and seventy-five genera covers an extensive area of our planet. It includes herbs, shrubs and trees. Steeplebush, or hardback, is one of the humbler species; but as the wave of summer flowers recedes, the slender spikes of rose-purple blooms around the edges of swamps, along the roadsides, fringing upland mowing fields and dotting windswept mountain pastures tell us how the season is drawing on.

An advertising campaign believed to be the largest and most extensive in the frozen food industry will be started this month by the Birds Eye-Snider Division of the General Foods Corporation, it was announced yesterday by Howard F. Lochrie, director of marketing.

Industrial mobilization planning for completing the manufacturing blueprint in the event of another war will be speeded up by electrical accounting machine methods, it was learned yesterday. At the New York Quartermaster Purchasing Office, headquarters for the planning division on textiles, clothing and equippage, business machine methods currently used for inventory and accounting will be projected into mobilization surveys by the end of the year.

Mollie Fleishman sold the fifteen-family apartment house at 506 East 163d Street, the Bronx, to the Del-Rose Realty Corporation. The property, on a plot 25 by 100 feet, is assessed at $33,000. It was conveyed subject to a mortgage of $20,500.

Deliveries of many types of lamps are running from four to eight weeks instead of the four-week maximum normal for the first week in September, producers reported yesterday. They attributed the tight delivery situation primarily to unexpectedly heavy orders in the last ten days to two weeks.

ROCHESTER, N. Y., Sept. 2 -The seventh round of the New York State Chess Association championship today brought together the two young titleholders of the Manhattan and Marshall chess clubs of New York -- Arthur B. Bisguier, with a score of 4 1/2 -1 1/2, and Larry Evans, with 5 1/2 -1/2.

BERLIN, Sept. 2 -- Maj. Gen. Maxwell D. Taylor, who yesterday assumed office as United States commander in Berlin, confirmed this morning at his initial press conference that the policies observed by his predecessor, Brig. Gen. Frank L. Howley, in negotiations with the Soviet would be continued.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- Dr. Michael Novikov, 73-year-old great-grandfather, heads a four-generation group of his family arriving in New York on Sunday aboard the Army transport General Stewart, the International Refugee Organization announced today.

CAMDEN, N. J., Sept. 2 -- Mayor George E. Brunner of Camden and Abraham Wernick, Assistant City Solicitor of Philadelphia, tossed insults and challenges to battle back and forth across the Delaware River today.

It was good news for those who drive regularly in Brooklyn that Borough President Cashmore and the Board of Transportation are planning the widening and partial repaving of Fourth Avenue in that borough to speed up traffic upon it. Like many other avenues and street, Fourth Avenue has become inadequate to meet the demands of present-day travel.
Financial. and commodity exchanges throughout the United States and Canada will be closed on Ylonday in observance of Labor Day. IVarkets in Great lrltain will operate as usual.

TORONTO, Sept. 2 (AP) -- Cliff Lumsden, 18-year-old Toronto truck driver, tonight became the youngest swimmer to win the fifteen-mile Canadian National Exhibition's annual marathon. Only three of the forty-seven entrants from Canada and the United States finished the grind in the 62-degree Lake Ontario waters.

The Western Union Telegraph Company reported yesterday that operations in the seven months to July 31 resulted in a deficit of $5,091,795, compared with a loss of $1,192,500 in the same period in 1948.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 (UP) -The Bureau of Internal Revenue ruled today that all railroad, airplane and boat tickets bought by Americans outside the country for travel within the United States are subject to the 15 per cent Federal transportation tax.
LONDON, Sept. 2 (AP) -- British-Russian trade pact talks were reported near a breakdown today. The business involved under the proposed one - year agreement would amount to nearly $400,000,000.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- Average primary market prices advanced 0.3 per cent in the week ended Aug. 30, according to the Department of Labor's Bureau of Labor Statistics. The index was 152.4 per cent of the 1926 average, 0.1 per cent below four weeks ago and 9.8 per cent below the comparable week in 1948.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- British, Canadian and United States conferees on Britain's financial plight agreed today on a broad agenda for next week's meeting of Cabinet ministers that left the way open for consideration of sterling devaluation and support from the International Monetary Fund.
The discussion of the British currency crisis has wandered into so many by-ways that it may be useful to set out a few fundamental propositions:

Retail sales declined slightly during the week, with some of the stores here showing small increases. Department store sales were estimated to be about 3 per cent below the corresponding week last year. Sales last week were 7 per cent above last year.

Five women who had admitted possessing 1,260,800 policy slips stood calmly yesterday before Magistrate Hyman Bushel in Bronx Magistrates Court. After receiving fines and sentences that probably set a record for severity in such a case, they heard themselves denounced as "a gang of cancerous parasites."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- Louis Johnson, Secretary of Defense, turned his economy drive on Congress today, delicately suggesting that Senators planning an around-the-world trip take a commercial plane instead of a special Air Force transport.

PARIS, Sept. 2 -- Three hundred delegates and observers are expected to converge on Paris in the days ahead for the fourth general conference of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization at UNESCO House here.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Sept. 2 -- The three high commissioners-designate for Western Germany discussed today a standardization of the billing for occupation costs. It is recognized that this will prove to be one of the major problems of the new western German Federal Republic.

Winners of the six prizes awarded in the seventh annual Young Composers Contest of the National Federation of Music Clubs were announced yesterday. In this competition, Lochrem Johnson of Seattle won the first prize of $100 in Class 1 for a chamber music composition, his Sonata Breve, and also captured the first prize of $50 in Class 2 for a keyboard work, with his Chaconne for piano.

PARIS, Sept. 2 -- Paul G. Hoffman's veto of the use of the emergency Marshall Plan dollar pool to increase aid allotments to European countries was discussed today in the European Marshall Plan Council, which decided not to revise its figures for the present but to await the appropriations by Congress before making up the final sheet.

The first of the month seems as good a time as any to review recent reader inquiries. August was sizzling, but apparently many did not consider it "too hot to eat" -or at least, to consider questions relating to that activity. One gentleman wanted to know how to smoke a forty-pound white marlin he had caught; another how to flambe a baked Alaska.

It is possible that this summer's heat has melted even the most starchy of correspondents, or it may be that a trend toward informality in business letter composition is just now engaging this corner's attention; at any rate, there are evidences that some of the stuffiness that often surrounds written communications is being sloughed off these days at an encouraging clip.
HONG KONG, Sept. 2 -- The guerrilla menace to the Nationalist refugee capital of Canton is more immediate now than the danger from regular Communist armies.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 2 -- The outlook for the success of the United Nations economic mission coming to the Middle East, under the direction of Gordon R. Clapp, has turned darker. Increasingly strong elements in Syria, which is vital to the success of any plan based on the combined resettlement of Palestine refugees and internationally supported development of backward areas, are showing hostility to the mission's objectives.
Greentree Stable's One Hitter, bet down to 1 to 2, made the grade with a length to spare in the race for 3-year-olds that headed Aqueduct's program yesterday.

Hassoldt Davis, author and explorer, who with his wife spent seven months in the back country of French Guiana and Brazil during 1947-48, has written an account of his experiences that Prentice-Hall will bring out in the spring. His book will be illustrated with photographs taken on the trip.

May I be allowed to congratulate your London correspondent for the lucid articles in THE NEW YORK TIMES regarding the dollar crisis, which all the Tory press tries very hard to misrepresent in your country and mine.

Radio will play a vital auxiliary role in the education of children in New York City's public schools in the coming school year, it was made known yesterday by Seymour N. Siegel, director of Radio Communications of the Municipal Broadcasting System, and Dr. William Jansen, Superintendent of Schools.

Potential wealth locked in the mysteries of the sea, in the chemistry of its waters and the physics of its tides and currents, is being explored more intensively than ever before by six "floating laboratories" based at the Wood's Hole Oceanographic Institution in Massachusetts.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- The Pacific Telephone and Telegraph Company, San Francisco, filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering 828,920 shares of its $100-par value common stock that it proposes to sell at $100 a share.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept. 2 (AP) -A wave of upsets swirled over the fourth national caddie golf championship today as youngsters from Ohio, Michigan, Missouri and Massachusetts won semi-final berths.
LONDON, Sept. 2 -- Apart from special items, the stock markets in general showed little change today from recent quiet conditions.

CHICAGO, Sept. 2 (AP) -- The pilot of a chartered airliner saved his twenty-eight passengers from possible injury at the Municipal Airport here today after the brakes on his twin-engined DC-3 had failed.
MIAMI, Fla., Sept. 2 (AP) -- The man who forecast Florida's recent hurricane made a preliminary estimate today that the big blow had caused $40,000,000 to $45,000,000 damage in the state.

SIMON BRACKENWOOD slept in a four-poster bed "that had once been occupied by Zachary Taylor and on two occasions by Henry Clay." He lived in an eighteenth-century house in which four Presidents had slept, built on part of the 6,500-acre grant of an ancestor who had come into Kentucky with Daniel Boone. The four-poster bed sagged in the middle.
ROSAMOND DRY LAKE, Calif., Sept. 2 -- Six planes were poised here tonight for a dawn take-off in the annual Bendix Race to a finish line at the National Air Races in Cleveland, Ohio.
The letter of Alexander Cumming published Aug. 27 prompts this answers as it appears to me to be an expression of undemocratic sentiments.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- Peace and prosperity in the Western Hemisphere canot be maintained without extinguishing the smoldering international tensions in the Caribbean area, the United States informed the Inter-American Peace Commission in a formal memorandum made public today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 (AP) -- A diary purportedly written by Anatole Barsov, Soviet Army flier who twice switched sides in the "cold war," was scanned by State Department officials today for possible solution of a mystery.

NEWARK, N. J., Sept. 2 -Local taxicab drivers, who became an extension of the long arm of the law on July 23, received their first assignment today. It was to find two "wanted" men and deliver them to the nearest police station.

Hides futures continued upward on the Commodity Exchange yesterday and transactions reached 3,800,000 pounds, the highest level in two weeks. The market closed 5 to 23 points above Thursday's closing levels. There was considerable interest in December deliveries and these contracts reached a price of 20 1/2c a pound, establishing an advance of 1 cent a pound in the last four days.

HONOLULU, Sept. 2 -- Harry Bridges, president of the International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union, CIO, took the witness stand in Federal Court here today to testify that Hawaii's 125-day dock strike "might a good thing for the new Maritime Federation of the World to cut its teeth on."

DETROIT, Sept. 2 -- Moving against a second member of the "Big Three" among automobile manufacturers, the United Automobile Workers, CIO, asked today that a state-supervised strike election be held for its more than 80,000 Chrysler Corporation employes in Michigan.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 2 (AP) -- Jersey City took both ends of tonight's double-header from the Baltimore Orioles, 2 to 1 and 6 to 2. Ford Smith pitched a five-hitter to win the opener, the Little Giants securing seven hits off John Maldovan.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- Back East after a final Western trip which, even though it didn't yield anything more profitable than an even break in ten games, nevertheless left them a reasonably firm hold on first place, the Yankees tonight were looking toward squeezing as much additional profit as possible out of their four remaining road games before moving into their home stadium.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 2 -- The Yugoslav Government announced tonight the dissolution by mutual consent of the Soviet-Yugoslav Danube River Navigation Company and a joint civil aviation company.
It's becoming increasingly apparent that Branch Rickey was not so far off the beam when he hung a $1,000,000 price tag on Don Newcombe when the purchasing Pirates were pitcher-shopping last winter.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Sept. 2 (AP) -- D. T. Swidler's acquisition of Abstract for $7,500 earlier in the meeting paid dividends today when the bay colt took the $4,000 Vineland purse. Scoring by one length and a half the son of Isolator turned back several of the best 3-year-olds on the grounds before 13,065 racegoers.

OTTAWA, Sept. 2 (AP) -- Canada's Air Transport Board announced today that it would hold a public conference next Thursday to talk over applications by six United States airlines for the renewal and extension of rights to do business in Canada.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- Job reinstatement with back pay up to a total of $205,000 was directed today by the National Labor Relations Board for 1,328 California cannery workers on a finding that the employes had been illegally discharged in 1946.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- A story of being "shanghaied" into the French Foreign Legion and tortured failed to win acquittal today for Patrick James Ryan, 24-year-old United States sailor accused of deserting his ship.

Last Wednesday 19-year-old Francis X. Lonie walked into Kormann's Bakery shop at 64-10 Fresh Pond Road, Ridgewood, Queens, and ordered a wedding cake for $31. He paid for it with a $75 United States Treasury check and received $44 in cash as change.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- The State Department sharply accused the Soviet Union today of intransigence and backtracking in the four-power talks in London on an Austrian treaty.

After an unbroken ownership of 120 years, the six-story building at the southeast corner of Park Row and Beekman Street in the heart of old Newspaper Row of former days, is under contract of sale to two merchants.

The Yugoslavs are expert rebels. The towns along the East Adriatic coast are Roman, or Venetian, part of the historic fabric of Europe, but behind the high, forbidding wall of the Dinaric Alps is another world altogether, inhabited by people whose proudest boast, before the war, was that they had been in a state of rebellion for more than a century.

The trend in the poliomyelitis epidemic in New York continued downward as the Health Department reported thirty new cases and five deaths for the twenty-four hours ended at 9 o'clock yesterday morning. A week ago fifty-two new cases and two deaths were reported.

The New York Football Giants received no chance to brood over Thursday night's defeat at the hands of Herman Hickman's 1949 Eastern College All-Stars for Coach Steve Owen hustled them right out to Fordham Field for a workout yesterday.
DETROIT, Sept. 2 (AP) -- Virgil Trucks, top winner this year for the Detroit Tigers, breezed to his sixteenth victory of the season today, shutting out the Chicago White Sox, 8 to 0.

Bishop Hans Fuglsang-Damgaard, Primate of the Church of Denmark (Lutheran), will be luncheon guest of the National Lutheran Council at the Uptown Club, 60 East Forty-second Street, next Thursday at 1 P. M. Among the guests will be officials of the World Council of Churches, the Federal Council of the Churches of Christ in America and the Danish legation.

The story of how Johnny Breitenbruck, 21-year-old welterweight professional boxer who won his eight-round main event bout Thursday evening by a knockout, lost another, more serious fight to save the life of a 10-year-old boy was reported yesterday by Brooklyn police.

LONDON, Sept. 2 -- Dollar bankruptcy faces Britain within a matter of months unless the Labor Government changes its policy or dollar relief is obtained from the Washington financial talks beginning next week, in the opinion of commentators writing in the British week-end reviews today.

ROCHESTER, N. Y., Sept. 2 -- A thirty-three-year-old Texan, Rufus King of Wichita Falls, who describes himself as a "week-end golfer," eliminated the defending champion, Willie Turnesa of Elmsford, N. Y., by 2 and 1 in a 36-hole semi-final match of the United States amateur golf championship at the Oak Hill Country Club today.

BOSTON, Sept. 2 (AP) -- With Al Zarilla lashing an inside-the-park homer with two on, the Boston Red Sex trounced the Philadelphia Athletics, 8 -- 4, tonight before 33,807 fans. The victory enabled the Red Sox to cut the idle New York Yankees' top-place lead to two and a half games.
TEL AVIV, Israel, Sept. 2 -Planning of the preliminary phases of Israel's counterpart of the Tennessee Valley Authority is nearing completion.
ALEXANDRIA, Va., Sept. 2 -- United States District Judge Albert V. Bryan has ruled that race segregation does not violate the Constitution or acts of Congress.

Joseph E. Rivere, 43 years old, of 15 Second Street, Lynbrook, L. I., who had been mentioned in the "5 per cent" inquiry in Washington, was held in $1,000 bail for a hearing Thursday when he was arraigned yesterday before Magistrate Phillip B. Thurston in Felony Court on a forgery charge.

HONG KONG, Sept. 2 (U.P.) -- Nationalist China rushed reinforcements to the "invasion coast" today as the Communists sought to forge the last links of an iron ring around the ports of Amoy and Swatow.
Four new pictures, including contributions from England and Russia, will have local premieres today.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 2 (AP) -A home run by Bill Nicholson and a two-run single by Willie Jones were the pay-off blows tonight as the Philadelphia Phillies defeated the Boston Braves, 6 -- 3, and regained fourth place in the National League pennant race.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept. 2 (AP) -All week long Emerson C. Burkhart's painting hung upright in an Ohio State Fair exhibit. Art-loving fairgoers admired it.

To aid war-maimed Italian children, Columbia University has given a five-month resident scholarship worth $6,100 to Dr. Attilio Rampoldi, a specialist in physical medicine at the University of Rome, so that he may study and obtain medical equipment in this country, it was announced yesterday at the university.

MONTREAL, Sept. 2 (AP) -- The Aluminum Company of Canada, Ltd., in a statement today said continuing unsettled world economic conditions are forcing the company to reduce rate of operations at the Arivda and Shawinigan Falls smelters.
Eric Sturgess of South Africa, runner-up to Richard Gonzales a year ago, was eliminated from the national tennis championship yesterday in the Forest Hills Stadium.

NEWARK, N. J., Sept. 2 (AP) -Syracuse pitcher Ed Blake hurled a four-hitter and won his own ball game with a three-run homer, 5 -- 2, against Newark tonight. The Chiefs also won the second game of the double-header, 11 -- 3, behind Bud Byerly.
PREAKNESS HILLS, N. J., Sept. 2 -- In a Women's Golf Association New Jersey one-day event at the North Jersey Country Club course, thirty-nine players teed off in a match against par today.

TORONTO, Dept. 2 (AP) -- A spokesman for the Imperial Oil Company here said today application had been made for an extension eastward the Great Lakes of the company's 450-mile Edmonton-Regina pipeline from new oilfields in Alberta.

TOKYO, Sept. 2 -- Premier Shigeru Yoshida, in a nationwide broadcast tonight on the fourth anniversary of the surrender, urged Japan to adopt as a goal the eventual repayment of all relief and rehabilitation funds poured into the country by the United States since the war.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- Initial claims for unemployment insurance reached the year's low of 251,000 during the week ended on Aug. 27, the Department of Labor reported today. Initial claims based on new unemployment fell 15,700.

CHICAGO, Sept. 2 -- Grain markets closed irregular on the Board of Trade here today. Wheat was 1/4 cent higher to 3/4 cent lower than yesterday; corn, 1 cent lower to 3/8 cent higher; oats, 1/2 cent higher to 3/8 cent lower; rye, 3/4 cent lower to 3/4 cent higher, and soybeans, 3/8 to 1 1/2 cents lower.
PARIS, Sept. 1 (UP) -- Reporters from the American Fashion magazine Vogue will be barred from future Paris fashion showings, the Chambre Syndicale de la Couture announced today.
LA PAZ, Bolivia, Sept. 2 (UP) -- Loyalist forces recaptured four towns from the rebels in scattered sections of Bolivia, the Government announced today.

LONDON, Sept. 2 -- In the United States "there is growing up -- and growing fast -- a quantity market for quality goods," of the type that Britain makes best, J. W. Taylor, British Minister for Commercial Affairs in Washington, reported today in the official Board of Trade Journal.

KAMENIK, Greece, Sept. 2 -- Units of the Greek National Army now hold all important heights from the Sarantaporos River to the Yugoslav frontier, according to information today at headquarters in this village near the Albanian border on the southwestern Grammos front

Mayor O'Dwyer witnessed yesterday at City Hall the signing of a new contract between the American Machine and Foundry Company, of 5502 Second Avenue, Brooklyn, and Local 116, United Automobile Workers of America, CIO, formally ending an 18-week strike of 1,400 production employes.

Mayor O'Dwyer announced yesterday the appointment of Sidney Sugerman, former chairman of the National Wage Stabilization Board for New York and Northern New Jersey, as the arbitrator in contract negotiation disputes between the Transport Workers Union, CIO, and four privately operated bus companies.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Sept. 2 (AP) -- Carleton Smith, director of the National Arts Foundation of New York, headed today for Berlin in a search for scores by Beethoven, Mozart and Wagner missing since the war.

LONDON, Aug. 30 -- Sir Stafford Cripps, Chancellor of the Exchequer, and Ernest Bevin, Foreign Secretary, are taking with them to the Washington dollar talks a detailed memorandum on Britain's current war debts and while this is not the most popular topic of conversation in the United States, the chances are it will be seriously discussed with John W. Snyder, Secretary of the Treasury, and Dean Acheson, Secretary of State.

BOSTON, Sept. 2 -- The Rev. Leonard J. Feeney, S. J., founder of St. Benedict's Center in Cambridge, today called for release of the "whole letter" from the Supreme Sacred Congregation of the Holy Office in Rome, in which he was censured for insisting that there is no salvation outside the Catholic church.

Belief in the same free enterprise system as that of this country has enabled Belgium to make a rapid recovery from a debtor to a creditor nation, John Haynes, Economic Cooperation Administration program review officer for Belgium, said yesterday on his return aboard the United States liner Washington.

Prices of shames on the New York Stock Exchange drifted aimlessly yesterday and finished with irregular changes. Pre-holiday influences caused a contraction in trading. The composite rate showed a loss of 0.01 point on the day. However, the market ended the week on a higher plane after earlier setbacks.
Bob Morgan, slugging Montreal shortstop, was named yesterday the International League's most valuable player of 1949.

The tiny snub-nosed units of the seven - ship Canadian - flag fleet that slip unobtrusively into port through New York's back door three times a week not only provide serious competition for trucking concerns and railroads by hauling 10,000 tons of cargo a month between Montreal and New York, but are also part of the smallest foreign-flag service sailing from this city.

The petition of the trustees of the Long Island Rail Road pending in United States District Court, Brooklyn, for permission to spend up to $25,000 for outside engineering advice is intended to obtain independent investigation of controversial engineering questions, a spokesman for the railroad explained yesterday.

NEWCASTLE, England, Sept. 2 -- The suggestion that a wave of gangsterism in the United States had been due to an epidemic of encephalitis or sleeping sickness was made at the annual meeting of the British Association for Advancement of Science today by Prof. Alexander Kennedy, professor of psychiatry at Newcastle University.

There are two distinct phases in the current news from China and they are equally disturbing. Far in the north the final steps are being taken to enclose Manchuria firmly within the grasp of the Soviet Union. Down in the south the Chinese Communists are closing in on Canton, and some observers predict the fall of the temporary capital of China within two weeks.

It remained for Theron Bamberger in "Confessions of a Barnyard Belasco" to clarify the chief reason for the ineptness of so many straw hat performances. Stars, he informs us, "are in such demand that a condition of their contract is that they are not compelled to rehearse but are permitted to arrive one day before the opening."
PARIS, Sept. 3 -- Amid uncertainties greater than at any time since its inception in April, 1947, the European Marshall Plan Council recessed today for the period of the Washington negotiations.

THE probable comparative status of commercial aviation in the United States and Great Britain in the next few years has been studied by Delos W. Rentzel, Administrator of Civil Aeronautics in the United States, and he declares it to be an "unvarnished fact" that in the near future aircraft powered by reciprocating engines will inevitably be superseded by turboprop airliners and commercial jets.

IN this third volume of his massive study of the religious content of English poetry, Professor Fairchild returns to the subject with which he began his scholarly career, the romantic movement in England. And as always when he deals with romanticism, Professor Fairchild is polemical.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Sept. 3 -- Finance Minister Guilherme da Silveira, appearing before the Finance Committee of the Chamber of Deputies, said this week that Brazil's economic situation was "alarming."
DETROIT, Sept. 3 (AP) -- The Detroit Tigers won their eleventh game in their last thirteen starts today, beating Chicago's White Sox, 5 to 3.

THE new season will open officially when the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo begins an engagement of twenty performances at the Metropolitan Opera House on Sept. 16. There are a good many changes in personnel this year, and five additions to the repertoire.

WASHINGTON -- Thousands of Americans homeward bound from summer vacations abroad are facing a new kind of customs bugaboo. This revolves the possibility of unanticipated payment of duty on merchandise they wish to bring into the country.

MR. FISCHER'S latest murder story has a new kind of new twist. Not only does the plot proceed ingeniously, but the unwary reader will find, as he goes along, that his reactions and expectations are being manipulated as much as are the actions of the characters.

PLANS for a comprehensive public relations program were unanimously endorsed by seventy delegates, representing practically all aspects of the motion picture industry, at the plenary sessions of the All-Industry Public Relations Conference held last week in Chicago.

ALBANY, Sept. 3 -- Bitterly contested fights for Democratic and Republican nominations for municipal offices in Buffalo are likely to furnish the highlights of Tuesday's primary voting up-state. The only other contests of importance are confined to the Republican ranks in Utica and Binghamton.

If Mr. Browne can define what a distinctly Negro culture is. I should very much like to hear that definition. In my opinion the Negroes in America are part of American culture and in the larger sense belong to the culture ou the Western World.

Representative W. Kingsland Macy of Suffolk County, who wrote last month to all Republican county chairmen and members of the Republican State Committee urging the nomination of Governor Dewey for United Senates Senator, repeated his demand yesterday.

AS this holiday week-end marks the close of the vacation season and the business summer, some trade and industrial results are backing up the recent gain in sentiment. Retail sales have drawn closer to last year's levels and producers find new orders gaining.

A DOZEN technical papers on the subject of DDT and other new insecticides were presented to the International Technical Conference on the Protection of Nature, which wound up a ten-day session at United Nations headquarters at Lake Success last week.

WRITTEN at the request of Arkansas country children, this book is a revealing account of life among the sharecroppers, tenants and farm owners of the Cotton Belt. While gathering material for the story Miss Lenski lived among the farm families, picking cotton with the children, listening to their stories, and making on-the-spot sketches of characteristic scenes.

SALEM, N. H., Sept. 3 (AP) -- Well handled by Gigi Moore, the Dickey Stable's Growing Up flashed under the wire first by a neck today in the $7,500 Petee-Wrack Purse before 19,900 racegoers at Rockingham Park.

TUESDAY night Ken Murray's "Blackouts," the eight-year wonder variety show of the Pacific Coast, opens at the Ziegfeld, and another theatre season will be under way. To be sure, "Miss Liberty" and "A Night in Spain," having bowed in July, will find themselves in the 1949-50 record books, but tradition still regards September as the beginning.

TEN years ago Thursday the Nazi legions marched, their tank tracks clanged and Polish horsemen died in brave and futile defiance. Ten years ago yesterday New York's summer heat was slowly fading and the airborne voice of England's King was heard solemnly rallying his people for the dark days ahead, for a war no longer confined to the battlefield.

THERE have been many stories written about the land-poor gentry, and many other stories written about their big, ramshackle houses. The creator of that famous man, Mr. Belvedere, has put the two together in a sturdy, honest novel that contains ghoulies and ghosties, Kentucky thoroughbreds and prized antiques, the scent of Blue Grass and a couple of millionaires.
Forest fires have been in recent weeks the subject of news.

The possibility of the title leaving this country was removed in the men's national tennis championship yesterday as the four top ranking players of the nation occupied the semi-final brackets at Forest Hills.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 3 -- The United Nations Arab Social Welfare Assembly closed here this week-end with an effort by Sir Raphael Cilento, high United Nations official who presided, and Glen Leet, the American United Nations adviser to the Greek Government, to demonstrate the probable necessity of Palestine refugee resettlement, or at least employment projects, in the Arab states.

THAT summer when Sudy and Prill met and became best friends was an important one for both girls. To Sudy, an only child, new to the little New England coast town, Prill's big, musical, very merry family was the complete realization of a lonesome girl's dreams.
The controversy between the Navy and the Air Force over such matters as carrier aviation and B-36 bombers has affected even Hollywood, it became known yesterday.
DETROIT, Mich., Sept. 3 -- A new operation that "runs the blood stream in reverse" was announced today by Wayne University physicians seeking a better treatment for gangrene of the leg.
LONDON, Sept. 3 (AP) -- Diplomatic officials said today that the United States was in disagreement with Britain and France over the size and shape of a future West German merchant Navy.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 3 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower is more optimistic today over the prospects of winning the peace and the world situation in general than he has been for two years.

Three Venezuelan baseball players arrived here yesterday to study the customs of Americans on or near baseball diamonds. While they were waiting for their first lesson at the Polo Grounds the visitors briefly described their own customs.

LONDON, Sept. 3 (Reuters) -- The Wolverhampton Wanderers held their one-point margin in the English Football League today with a 2-1 victory at Blackpool as Manchester United triumphed by 2 -- 1 against Manchester City at Old Trafford, Lancashire. Wolverhampton's triumph was its fifth straight.

NO one is angrily denouncing Sean O'Casey's "The Silver Tassie" today. The young people who dub themselves the Interplayers have been acting it for seven weeks in their air-cooled theatre at Carnegie Hall; and most people recognize it as a vigorous and biting drama about the horrors of war by a fiery and gifted dramatist.

WESTBURY, L. I., Sept. 3 -- A Westbury side led by Pete Bostwick and Emilio Tagle rode to a 9-6 triumph over Alan Corey's Roslyn quartet in a seven-period tune-up match today on Cochrane Field of the Meadow Brook Club.

Sympathy for Paul Robeson and his followers, after their interrupted concert near Peekskill last Sunday, was not increased by their threat to mobilize "20,000 strong" this Sunday and their protest against a permit for the anti-Communist veterans to stage another parade.
DETROIT, Sept 3 -- Horace E. Dodge's My Sweetie ran away with the first heat of the Silver Cup speed-boat trophy race today.

ST. LOUIS, Sunday, Sept. 4 -- The Cincinnati Reds and the St. Louis Cardinals battled to a fifteen-inning 9-9 tie in a game ending early this morning. The contest was called on account of a National League rule prohibiting any inning of a night game starting after 12:50 A. M. A double-header will be played this afternoon.

I am sure that "Negroes everywhere are thrilled" by the invitation the Norwegian Government extended to the Howard University Players to stage Ibsen in the count tries of Norway, Sweden and Denmark. I am equally as sure that Mr. Browne is that "one Negro in a hundred thousand who is not thrilled."
WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 (UP) -- The nation's post-inflation hangover appears to be cured and better days are ahead, three experts agreed today.
TAVARES, Fla., Sept. 3 (AP) -- Three Negroes were convicted tonight of a rape that ignited race demonstrations by white mobs in this central Florida area last July.

" THE Age of Constantine" is one of the best known works of the distinguished Swiss historian, Jacob Burkhardt. Written in the nineteenth century, it is now offered in English for the first time in an admirable translation by Moses Hadas.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 (AP) -- Secretary of Agriculture Charles F. Brannan told Congress today that he planned to remove Government price supports from Irish potatoes in areas where farmers rejected marketing and production controls.

The mummy of a pre-Inca high priest, believed to be 3,000 years old, is on its way here from Peru aboard the Grace Line's Santa Isabel and is due to arrive Sept. 12. It is the first such archaeological specimen ever to leave Peru.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- Whatever else may be their shortcomings it can never be said that Joe Kuhel and his Senators do not know how to play the perfect host when a visitor comes to the nation's capital.

MADISON, Wis., Sept. 3 -- The most important factor in American commerce is the credit accepted by manufacturers, wholesalers and jobbers, as reflected by their accounts receivables, Henry H. Heimann, executive manager of the National Association of Credit Men, declared here today.

LONDON (By wireless). EVEN if all the charges of British indolence and inefficiency were assumed to be correct, the consequences of a British collapse would still have to be calculated and the United States would have to strike a balance between the cost of helping Britain and the cost of not helping her.
WESTBURY, L. I., Sept. 3 (AP) -- Proximity broke the Roosevelt Raceway track record for the mile tonight in winning the featured Rochester trot.

It is becoming more widely recognized that our Federal tax system and the extremely high rates of taxes now being imposed are restricting seriously the supply of risk capital; that unless something is done to remedy this tendency, production will be further curtailed, bringing about more unemployment.

The financial community, along with political and business interests, will have its attention centered this week on Washington, where the Anglo-American-Canadian discussions of Britain's economic crisis are scheduled.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 3 -- Senator Robert A. Taft will return to Ohio tomorrow to tee off in its labor-conscious largest city on a thorough three-month "non-political" tour that will criss cross all of the eighty-eight counties, and cast a shadow all the way to both ends of Pennsylvania Avenue in the National Capital.

CHICAGO, Sept. 3 -- The populace generally in this part of the country, while devoting public discussion chiefly to the startling disclosures brought out in the Senate investigations subcommittee's inquiry into "influence peddling" by so-called "five percenters" in Washington, is apparently disposed to withhold judgment until all the evidence is in.

THE machinery already has been put in motion for the repeal of baseball's bonus rule, one that was as lofty in its idealistic motives as prohibition and, like it, just as impractical in application. Organized ball bore up under it with ill-conceived impatience for almost three years and now is about to toss it into the ashcan without a tear being shed.

Dodger followers, whose reference to their favorites as "Bums" is a widely accepted term of endearment, were all for changing the spelling to a lower-case "b" yesterday. Drastic as such a move might be, the disillusioned faithful had a strong point after watching the Brooks drop a 6-3 decision to the Giants at the Polo Grounds.

As retail trade swings into the fall season growing optimism is becoming evident among store executives here. During the past two weeks sales comparisons with last year have shown a marked improvement and it is now the popular belief among merchants that fall and winter sales will put a definite end to the downward trend established late last year.

Henry Morgenthau Jr., general chairman of the United Jewish Appeal campaign for $250,000,000, in a survey of the appeal's wartime and post-war relief for 2,000,000 Jews here and abroad, declared yesterday that the resettlement of 600,000 refugee Jews was an outstanding accomplishment of the appeal's agencies.

Drs. Julian Johnson and Charles K. Kirby, surgeons on the staff of the University of Pennsylvania's Medical Center, have succeeded in transferring lengths of vein from one part of the human body to bridge gaps between arteries in another part. As might be inferred, the purpose is to restore free and normal flow of the blood in a defective arterial system.

HONOLULU -- Hawaii's tourist entrepreneurs are hanging out the "Business as Usual" sign for the fall and winter season despite the widespread effects of the longshoremen's strike, which has cost this year-round vacation center well over $5,000,000 in tourist trade. They are promising swift and adequate travel facilities, a wide variety of accommodations and a full calendar of Polynesian ceremonies for sight-seers, including the third annual Aloha Week in Honolulu, which will begin Oct. 30.
ALBUQUERQUE, N. M., Sept. 3 -- Mounting agitation about freight rates was the chief topic of conversation in the Southwest this week.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- Senator Elmer Thomas, Democrat, of Oklahoma, today indignantly turned a Department of Defense request for economy in the use of military aircraft by Congressmen into an inquiry of such trips by Government officials from the President down.

MINEOLA, L. I., Sept. 3 -- A complicated political squabble that found itself finally before the Court of Appeals will be settled in Long Beach at next Tuesday's primary election. It is the most important political battle in this predominantly Republican county.

TELEVISION in full color, which for a decade has been perhaps the most controversial subject in the field of video, has returned to the limelight with the announcement by the Radio Corporation of America of a new system for transmitting images in natural tones.

This Wednesday in Washington the chief economic and diplomatic Ministers of the United States, Britain and Canada gather for the most important Anglo-American conference since the end of World War II. Their purpose is to explore the means of keeping Great Britain a going concern in the economy of the world.

Kid Gavilan, Cuban welterweight battler, will help reopen Madison Square Garden to boxing on Friday night. He will oppose Rocky Castellani, middleweight boxer from Wilkes-Barre, Pa., in a ten-round bout that will serve as the feature attraction on the program.

MIAMI -- Barring any repeat performances of the destructive Aug. 26 hurricane which ripped through Florida Gold Coast, there will be no major scars remaining when the early winter tourists begin to arrive in November.
DURING the rest of this sunshiny month the nimble citizens of Los Angeles will be busy celebrating, in various flamboyant ways, the 168th birthday of their town.

PARIS, Sept. 3 -- Walter Schevenels, former Belgian labor leader and liaison officer for the European Recovery Program's Trade Union Advisory Committee, declared today that it was estimated the Marshall Plan had cut Europe's unemployment total by between 6,000,000 and 12,000,000.
Die-hard advocates of the status quo at the Stock Exchange last week comprised the majority opposed to a reduction in commission charges for the short-term trader.
Lou Little will face three of the most trying weeks in his two decades as head football coach at Columbia before the Lions open their season at Baker Field against Amherst on Sept. 24.

LAST summer the premiere of Eve Arden as "Our Miss Brooks" on CBS was delayed one week by the Democratic National Convention in Philadelphia. Since then the radio series has enjoyed a harmonious run which even the Democratic party might envy, and the star of the show, a former movie gun moll turned radio schoolteacher, is happy that she took a role which she did not really want.
FORT SHERIDAN, Ill., Sept 3 (AP) -- Tech. Sgt. Huelet Benner of Fort Knox, Ky., took a 17-point lead, virtually clinching the championship, in today's second round of the national pistol meet.

Current increases in the volume of national advertising in newspapers were seen last week as evidence that more advertisers are turning to a new market-by-market technique for promoting their products.

THE reshuffling of radio's program schedules continues, lending further weight to a recent observation that the listener this season is going to have quite a problem finding his favorite program. The latest changes include the following:

DESPITE the season, a traditionally slow one for the record business, there are a few releases of exceptional interest on the market today. The first work is an old warhorse, Franck's D minor Symphony, but the performance is an exciting one by the Concertgebouw Orchestra of Amsterdam under Willem Mengelberg (Capitol-Telefunken, five twelve-inch disks).

THE first general book on the twin-lens reflex, the favorite post-war camera type among amateurs and professionals alike, has just been published. It is "The Twin-Lens Camera Companion" (New York: Focal Press, Inc., and Pitman Publishing Corporation. $3.75) by H. S. Newcombe, outstanding English authority on modern small-camera technique, and it is supplemented with chapters by ten American photographers on their methods with the camera.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Sept. 3 -- Under the auspices of the International Refugee Organization, 227 Bulgarians, who escaped across the frontier in Thrace to Turkey in recent months, will sail to Naples tomorrow on the Turkish steamship Adana.
Anthony Leviero in "Press and President: No Holds Barred" calls the Presidential press conference "a great institution" and "a factor in our checks and balance system of government."

GARDEN CITY, L. I., Sept. 3 -- Unseeded Mrs. Shelby Torrance, home club player, who last month eliminated the tourney's No. 2 and 6 performers in the singles of the Women's New York state clay court championships, was not able to hurdle the most important obstacle of all today as the belated final was held at the Cherry Valley Club.

FOLLOWING the bitter controversy over the award of the $1,000 Bollingen Prize in Poetry to Ezra Pound by the Fellows of American Letters of the Library of Congress, the Library has announced the cancellation of all its prizes in literature, music and art.

The West Side slums of Manhattan produced a lad near the end of the last century who has become one of America's industrial statesmen -- a sort of Bernard Baruch, Owen D. Young and Paul G. Hoffman rolled into one.

ERNEST B. MILLER, a former colonel who commanded the 194th Tank Battalion in the Philippines, has written "Bataan Uncensored," apparently to search out those who, he believes, were responsible for the disaster that led to the infamous Death March and for its survivors, years of indignity.

The speedboat regatta that is uniquely "New York's own" and when uncounted thousands of apartment dwellers can look down out of their windows to see mile-a-minute daredevils tear down the Hudson, up the East River and through the ship canal that is known as the Harlem River comes to town next Sunday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- The House and Senate made divergent moves this week to tackle the same, admittedly complex problem -- the problem of putting together for the first time a clear picture of all of the United States Government's overseas programs and operations.

BERLIN, Sept. 3 -- A flood of stories in the Western-licensed German press here recently has reflected the conviction that anti-clerical measures in the Soviet zone are biulding up to an overt drive against oranized religion. Today's editions of various publications report for the first time in this connection that church buildings in several communities that were left intact during the war have been razed.
The first faint nip of fall cut sharply into last-minute holiday travel yesterday. Rail, bus and motor traffic was reported well below last year, but airlines operated at near maximum capacity.

While business men engaged in world trade continue to be harassed by the problem of transferability of currencies, thirty-seven international airlines find currency convertibility no difficulty at all.

THE bridge books, after advising the bridge player to play third hand high, go on to say, "There is an obvious exception when you hold a tenace over dummy. For example, if dummy plays low from J-x and you have Q-10, you play the ten, not the queen."

AROUND this season, twenty-one years ago, the first full-length talking film was shown in England. This writer was relieved to find, on checking up with the contemporary records, that she endorsed the novelty, but a little startled to discover that she also prophesied that talkies would supersede the silent films "as surely as television will in time supersede the talkies."

In a few days the preliminaries of the conference on Britain's dollar crisis will have ended and the decisive negotiations will begin. The issues in their broader aspects are now clear; the squalls of mutual criticism have blown away. All is now relatively quiet, and if it be the lull before a storm, neither we nor the British were ever afraid of a fair fight with the knowledge that we would shake hands afterward.

IN 1918 there arrived in Iran, with an invading Soviet Army, a 30-year-old Iranian revolutionary who called himself Seyyid Ja'afar Badku Bayi. Within two years he was installed as Minister of the Interior of a "revolutionary republic," established by the Reds in the Northern Iranian province of Gilan.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 3 (AP) -- The Phils hit three home runs, including a grand slam homer by Andy Seminick, today to trounce the Braves, 10 to 4.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- John Maragon, a central target in the Senate "five percenter" investigation, said today that he helped organize an election party for Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican, of Wisconsin, one of his chief critics on the investigating committee.
A lively battle looms for inclusion of "peril points" as an amendment to HR 1211 when the measure for renewal of the Reciprocal Trade Agreements Act comes to the floor of the Senate on Wednesday.
BOSTON, Sept. 3 -- The Federal cut in the Housing Expediter's payroll this week caused thousands of New England apartment renters to wonder uneasily how it would affect rent control.

Mr. Browne's challenge of the right of a college drama group to appear in these plays because the members of the group are Negroes and therefore "out of place" in "white" plays is the most provin cial statement about the theatre to be recorded in the public priny since 1821, when critics sneered at the African Company because it was producing Shakespeare.

While conducting refresher courses for 310 displaced physicians, dentists and pharmacists in Germany in July, a sixteen-member medical mission made plans for a blood bank in Munich, Dr. Benjamin Kramer, chairman of the mission, announced yesterday.

The business curve has reached bottom and is turning upward, according to the August survey reports of purchasing executives compiled by the National Association of Purchasing Agents. Production and new orders both have increased, overbalancing those reporting declines by three to one.

Many grocery store operators here are closely watching sales of non-grocery items in food stores, with the intention of increasing these departments, it was learned here yesterday. While some of the local chains now stock limited lines of household hardware and other items, it is believed that more and more independents will also adopt this operational policy.

MOSCOW, Sept. 3 -- To the Soviet public, which has watched month by month the progress of the New York trial of American Communist party leaders, the United States Government's prosecution appears to be part of a calculated offensive designed to suppress civil rights and stifle human liberties. It is presented as the plan of warmongers to turn America into a fascist state and launch a war against the Soviet Union.

NORTHAMPTON, Mass., Sept. 3 -- Smith College announced today the names of twelve distinguished women from this and other countries who, in recognition of their accomplishments, would receive honorary degrees Oct. 20 at the convocation celebrating the seventy-fifth anniversary of the opening of Smith College.

ZURICH, Sept. 3 -- After four years of honest effort to get control of its own economic destinies, Europe's problems are back where they were -- in the lap of a sympathetic but nevertheless distant and foreign Government responsible to people who do not have to live in Europe.

Comparatively few contests for party nominations are scheduled for the primary election in the city next Tuesday. There are no contests in the Republican primary, but there are eight in the Democratic primary, three in the American Labor primary and one in the Liberal primary.

BERNARD SHAW'S duel with William Shakespeare, which has gone on more than half a century despite the latter's unavoidable absence, has now risen to the heights of Punch and Judy and been presented at the Malvern Festival as a puppet show. As usual in this epic conflict, Shaw makes a splendid showing by the simple expedient of delivering not only his own thrusts but also the ripostes for his rival.

Without entering into a discussion about the basic idea of Isaac Deutscher's "Strange World of Russian 'Non-Returners'" I merely wish to establish the truth as it deals with the Russian "Solidarist" (N.T.S.) movement, of which I am the head.
BURLINGTON, Vt., Sept. 3 -- One of America's most remarkable, as well as controversial, Roman Catholic churches stands in a grove of birch and pine on the outskirts of this Vermont city.
SEOUL, Korea, Sept. 3 (AP) -- They'd better get that big sea turtle up here from South Korea quick before it shrinks to terrapin size.

WE have learned, with God knows what feelings of exaltation, of Ernest Newman's discovery of the music of perhaps the greatest composer of centuries: Krzsmaly, who unluckily died unpublished, or, in the strict sense of the word, unperformed, a few months ago.
BOSTON, Sept. 3 -- Commenting on a report that he faces possible excommunication, the Rev. Leonard J. Feeney said today that he would appeal any such action to the Pope in person.

Officers and directors of the National Sales Executives, Inc., and representatives of each of its ninety affiliated clubs throughout the country will meet in Washington on Sept. 8 and 9 to confer with Secretary of Commerce Sawyer and other Government officials on "the salesman's status in American economy."

In 1928 Al Smith, then seeking the Presidency, called on his "good friends" Franklin Delano Roosevelt and Herbert Henry Lehman to strengthen the Democratic ticket in New York and thus help him win the state, Mr. Roosevelt ran for Governor, Mr. Lehman for Lieutenant Governor. That was how Mr. Lehman -- until then an investment banker -- got into politics.
ESSEX JUNCTION, Vt., Sept. 3 -- Nibble Hanover, one of the world's top trotters -- now retired to stud -- was purchased for $100,000 today by L. B. Sheppard, owner of Hanover (Pa.) Shoe Farms.

LONDON, Sept. 3 -- Fernand Dumoulin, thirty - four - year - old crippled hero of the Belgian resistance, completed swimming the English Channel at 7:57 tonight (2:17 P. M., E. D. T.). He was in the choppy seas twenty-two hours and one minute.

ELIZABETH, N. J., Sept. 3 -- The strike called at the Singer Manufacturing Company plant here May 1 by Local 401, United Electrical Workers, CIO, over disputed provisions of a new contract, has cost the employes of the sewing machine factory, the city's major industry, some $9,000,000 in wages.

This fall there will be 32,671,500 students enrolled in the nation's educational institutions, ranging from elementary schools through the university level, according to estimates of the United States Office of Education. Last year's grand total was 31,880,000.

IN the relatively stable world of best-sellerdom a change is a mighty welcome and exciting thing. Since the analysis of the chart to the right was last made, a month ago, something new has been added. To be exact, four titles in fiction, three in general.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Aug. 29 -- In an address to the Economic Society, Prof. Douglas Berry Copland, vice chancellor of the National University at Canberra controller of prices in wartime and an eminent economist, urged the British Dominions to cooperate in a great developmental plan, backed by United States capital, provided it were obtainable on reasonable, terms.

One who has lived with a garden all summer comes now to the time when a sense of immediacy begins to close in. Days shorten. Growth slackens. The garden is still full and overflowing with plenty, but one knows that it may be the last full crop. The season grows late.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- President Truman sought today to minimize the hardship of unemployment resulting from the defense economy ordered recently by Louis Johnson, Secretary of Defense.

MIAMI, Fla., Sept. 3 (AP) -- Dick Bertram, defending champion, of Miami Beach, pulled up from thirteenth position today to win the second race in the International Lightning championships being held on Biscayne Bay.

Only one-fourth of the nation's adult population reads one or more books a month and among the five major media of communications -- books, magazines, newspapers, movies and the radio -- books attract the smallest audience. This was reported by Bernard Berelson, dean of the University of Chicago's graduate library school, at a recent librarians' conference on the campus.

With a new round of aid to Britain being promoted under the heading of "investments" rather than new Government loans or gratuities, the stand is being taken in financial circles that some easing of the inequities and inflexibilities now attending American private investment in Britain is in order before any rush to expand such investment can reasonably be expected.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 3 -- A new speed record for the piston-engine division of the $25,000 Bendix Trophy Race was set today when Joseph De Bona, Hollywood real estate man, flew a modified F-51 Mustang from California to Cleveland at an average speed of 470 miles an hour.

Engineers and highly placed representatives of governments have been discussing sources of energy at the United Nations Scientific Conference on Conservation and Utilization of Resources, even though there is soft coal enough in the world for two thousand years and unproved oil resources for at least two centuries and possibly five.
THE cost of producing studio television programs has increased "at least 10 per cent" since a year ago, according to a survey by Ross Reports on Television Programming, published by Wallace A. Ross.

There is a hint of gentle sniping on the economy front in Secretary Johnson's delicate suggestion that round-the-world Congressional tourists would do well to use commercial planes rather than special Air Force transport. Senator Thomas remarks with suave understatement that "Senators will not be pleased."

South Africa offers one of the best foreign markets for automobiles and automotive replacement parts, it was reported last week by Miss Dorothy Lewes, export manager of Standard Motor Products, Inc., following an eleven-week field trip in nine countries in Europe, the Near East and Africa.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- The case of the harassed general -- Maj. Gen. Harry H. Vaughan, the President's military aide and old Field Artillery comrade -- has set a great many political seers off upon strange and largely intuitive calculations.

THE criminous short story has been badly neglected by book publishers this year. All that's appeared so far has been one volume by William Irish, and that only partly devoted to crime and detection. But the aficionado of short, if hardly simple, annals knows that he is guaranteed at least two yearly delights: "The Queen's Awards" (which will appear later this fall) and David C. Cooke's "Best Detective Stories of the Year."
The seventeen outdoor swimming pools of the Department of Parks will close tomorrow night, it was announced yesterday.

NO official announcement has been made as yet, but the dates are up on the billboards of the opera house. The Metropolitan's new season will run for eighteen weeks, opening Nov. 21 and closing March 25. Thus the customers will get two more weeks than they did last season when the subscription period ran from Nov. 29 to March 19.

Greentree Stable's Wine List, named for his dam, Fizz II, won the roughly-run Aqueduct Handicap at the Queens County Jockey Club's home base yesterday. A 12-to-1 shot, he accounted for one of the several sets of fancy prices that went up on the result board during the sunny afternoon.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- George Washington University today announced appointment of William J. Reinhart, athletic director at Kings Point, L. I.) Merchant Marine Academy, as head coach of basketball and baseball.

WASHINGTON AND LEE -Changes Sweeping changes in curriculum requirements, a $100 tuition increase accompanied by expanded scholarship aid and the introduction of the South's first courses in American studies will highlight the beginning this fall of Washington and Lee University's third century of service.

LONDON, Sept. 3 -- The belief that Britain's economic and financial crisis would force the Labor Government into an early election was voiced publicly today by Brendan Bracken, wartime Minister of Information and a member of Winston Churchill's "kitchen cabinet."

General Electric physicists have developed for the Navy an instrument which indicates the thickness, height and density of clouds. This "cloud analyzer" is carried by a weather balloon into the upper atmosphere. It radios weather data to a ground receiver at the rate of 120 times per minute.

WITH another New York music season about to open, this is perhaps an appropriate time for a few words on the subject of emotion. Past seasons have shown that too often recitalists have given too little thought to just what role it should play in their efforts.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- There were indications today that the Anglo - Canadian - United States talks, scheduled to start next Wednesday morning, would be extended beyond the four or five days originally set aside for them.

REDUCTIONS in the prices of flash lamps are announced by General Electric Company's Lamp Department. The principal item on the list is the popular No. 5 midget lamp, which drops in price from 14 to 12 cents each.

From 1928 until 1941 the name of Mal Stevens figured importantly in intercollegiate football. A graduate of Yale in 1925, he divided his time for the next three years as assistant coach at the university and to his studies at Yale Medical School.
Adolph Held, chairman of the Jewish Labor Committee, announced yesterday receipt of Labor Day greetings from many European and Canadian labor leaders.

The decline in retail housewares dollar volume, which worried dealers up to the end of the first week in August, definitely has been arrested and sales in the last three weeks have pushed ahead of the comparable period last year by a substantial margin, buyers reported yesterday.

OMAHA, Sept. 3 -- New Yorkers, who consume nearly three-fourths of the entire spring lamb crop, will be interested in knowing that the low state of the sheep industry was a matter of concern and widespread speculation in the Midwest this week.

DETROIT, Sept. 3 -- Noel P. Fox, chairman of the State Labor Mediation Board, said today that his board would meet with the Ford Motor Company and the United Automobile Workers, CIO, next week to examine the board rule that strike authorization under state-conducted elections are valid for only thirty days.
SEPTEMBER may be only the tag end of summer to adults; to youngsters it means just one thing: back to school. Two to three months out of doors have left them brown and healthy. How to keep them well?

ANY number of writers have argued that discrimination on racial or religious grounds is a bad thing. Dr. Fineberg agrees, but mere agreement would not justify another book. What does justify his book is his successful attempt to establish a technique for fighting discrimination. Good intentions are not enough and enthusiasm is not enough.

SOME people collect stamps, others collect buttons. But perhaps one of the most enthusiastic groups, if less well known, are the "pelargoniumites." They devote themselves to a search among the seemingly endless variety of geraniums, growing plants in one or all of the six classifications.

The Navy's Atlantic Fleet Task Force 51 thought it had a rescue operation on its hands Friday when it sighted a small ketch about 200 miles east of New York, but despite winds of forty knots and heavy seas its assistance was declined by the small craft, according to reports reaching here yesterday.

AN intensive campaign to curb highway accidents by the practical application of data obtained through nation-wide research will be the fundamental aim of the Yale Institute for Traffic which opens Tuesday at Yale University. The Institute, whose enrollment will include city, county and state police and highway-patrol officers in active service, will extend through Sept. 16 and will be conducted in cooperation with the National Committee for Traffic Training.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Sept. 3 -- The fifth national convention of the American Veterans of World War II (AMVETS) is unlikely to approve a merger with the American Veterans Committee (AVC), if sentiments expressed today by delegates and the leading candidates for the AMVET's national commandership remain unchanged.

From the businessman's standpoint, the present tax situation is too dangerous to be sloughed off without further discussion, even by so eminent a tax man as Chairman Doughton of the House Ways and Means Committee. (TIMES editorial, "Mr. Doughton on Taxes," Aug. 24.)

LONDON, Sept. 3 -- Anyone who expects Ernest Bevin and Sir Stafford Cripps to appear in the United States next week abjectly penitent and apologetic will be disappointed. Although Britain is again nearly broke, the Foreign Secretary and the Chancellor of the Exchequer will not arrive at the Washington financial talks with their caps in their hands and palms outstretched.

JOHN LAW, the same "Jessamy John" who starred in Phil Stong's historical novel of that name two years ago, plays a return engagement in Rafael Sabatini's "The Gamester." Both titles refer to the fabulous Scottish gambler - financier who seized France's economic reins after Louis XIV died and made himself virtual master of the nation.

EDWARD DMYTRYK, film director and one of the ten Hollywood figures who have been barred from employment in the industry here for refusing in 1947 to tell a Congressional committee whether or not they were Communists, returned to town last week after spending a year in England, where he directed two pictures.

ROCHESTER, N. Y., Sept. 3 -- For the first time in the forty-nine-year history of the championship, a player from the Southwest today captured the famed United States amateur golf trophy as 25-year-old Charlie Coe of Oklahoma City won the title by beating Rufus King of Wichita Falls, Tex., 11 and 10, at the Oak Hill Country Club.

THE Garden Club of New Jersey will hold its Annual President's Day Meeting Wednesday, Sept. 7, at the Upper Montclair Country Club. Over ninety clubs are expected to participate in this all-day session, which is scheduled to start at 10:30 A. M.

EDINBURGH, Scotland, Sept. 3 -- The only major novelty of the Edinburgh Festival, Ernest Bloch's new Piano Concerto, was performed for the first time at a concert given tonight by BBC Scottish Orchestra, with Corinne Lacomble as soloist.

In "Russia Is Still Remote from Communism" Isaac Deutscher conjectured as to how long it would take the Soviet Union to achieve the living standards of the Western World. I have a direct answer. As Secretary of Information of the Catalan Autonomous Government during the Spanish civil war, I had occasion to meet the most varied personalities, among them the Soviet journalist Ilya Ehrenburg.

ATLANTA, Ga., Sept. 3 -- The Senate subcommittee "five-per centers" inquiry was discussed on all sides. The majority opinion seemed to be that Maj. Gen. Harry Vaughan's usefulness as a White House aide is clearly at an end.
SEA GIRT, N. J., Sept. 3 (AP) -- Rutgers and Rider football teams scrimmaged today in the first intercollegiate clash of the season for both teams.

DUBLIN, Sept. 3 (UP) -- Andy Stanfield of Seton Hall and Willie Slykhuis of the Netherlands each broke an Irish record today as America's touring track and field squad won six events in an international meet at College Park.

CHARLES R. KNIGHT is best known for his paintings of the prehistoric men and animals that adorn the walls of our leading museums. As his admirers will testify, Mr. Knight does not invent creatures of pure fantasy or transcribe his nightmares.
LA PAZ, Bolivia, Sept. 3 (AP) -- The General Staff said today that it had received a report to the effect that the rebel stronghold, Potosi, had fallen to Government troops.
CHICAGO, Sept. 3 (AP) -- The Cubs slammed across nine runs in the eighth inning, fashioned on nine hits and two walks, for an 11-to-7 triumph over the Pirates before 13,289 at Wrigley Field today.
LONDON, Aug. 31 -- At the end of the first World War somebody in England wrote a malicious little rhyme about the British people during a period of national crisis. It went roughly like this:

THE newest look in upholstery fabrics this fall is the hand-loomed look, which is about the best evidence there is that the individual hand-weaver is no arts-and-craftsy eccentric, but an important contributor to the march of industry.

If industry is ever to apply atomic energy for commercial purposes it must receive considerable guidance from the physicists and engineers who developed "furnaces," "piles," or "reactors," as the chambers are called in which uranium 238 is transmuted into plutonium. There is no good reason why the Atomic Energy Commission should not release much of the information which engineers need and which it has accumulated at Oak Ridge and Hanford.

Fast retail turnover of many items of women's and children's apparel has brought a flood of reorders to New York manufacturers, it was learned last week. Retailers everywhere are finding themselves short of fall merchandise, which was ordered sparingly in June and July.

DWELLING thus upon the dunes, I lived in the midst of an abundance of natural life which manifested itself every hour of the day, and from being thus surrounded, thus enclosed within a great whirl of what one may call the life force, I felt that I drew a secret and sustaining energy.
MIAMI, Sept. 3 (AP) -- A growing tropical hurricane with winds already up to 90 miles an hour showed a tendency tonight toward a northerly course which would carry it away from the mainland.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 3 -- The chief justices of forty-five states opened a three-day conference here today for the exchange of ideas and information on the American judiciary system in all sections and to organize a permanent Conference of Chief Justices.

IN approximately twenty pages each, the author appraises ten of our great cities: Boston, Philadelphia, Brooklyn, St. Louis, New Orleans, San Francisco, Salt Lake City, Seattle, Dallas and Chicago. The pattern is the same for each chapter -- brief introduction, usually a smattering of both past and present; then the story of some major historical episode connected with the city; finally, a brief account of the more recent past, with some description of the present.

In promotions here last week retailers stressed wool piece goods silverplated flatware, "Howdy Doody" watches, umbrellas and corduroy separates, according to a survey made especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by the Retail News Bureau, Inc.

WASHINGTON. THE observer who has watched a wearying Congress struggle on, week after week, month after month, toward autumn is conscious of how much that has occurred in its air-cooled but cramped quarters has to do with something that is to happen next year -- the Congressional elections of 1950 -- and, beyond that, with something that is to happen two years later -- the Presidential election of 1952.
CLEVELAND, Sept. 3 -- With manager Lou Boudreau on the bench wearing a slipper on his injured foot, the Browns again showed their contempt for pennant contenders today and beat his Indians, 4 to 3.

Governor Dewey directed yesterday that all state police "who can be made available" assist local authorities in preserving order at the Paul Robeson concert scheduled for 2 P. M. today near Peekskill.

For the fourth week in a row, last Thursday the hottest topic at the President's press conference was Maj. Gen. Harry H. Vaughan, the President's military aide. General Vaughan -- who had spent the preceding two days testifying before the Senate investigations subcommittee on "five per centism" -- was at his usual post, directly behind the President. A reporter put the big question:

SALT LAKE CITY, Sept. 3 -- Utah's Gov. J. Bracken Lee, Republican, is gaining a reputation as the mountain region's major spokesman for groups seeking to check Government costs. This week he told city officials that they were being lured into excessive spending by the Federal policy of appropriating matching funds for airports, highways and similar improvements.

Coastwise steamship service between Norfolk, New York and Boston will be reestablished for the first time since the start of World War II if plans now on file with the Interstate Commerce Commission are approved.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- President Truman today named Carlton Skinner of Milford, Conn., to be the first civilian governor of Guam.

AT long last, success, by Hollywood standards, has come to Mel Ferrer, who was 32 on Aug. 25. Three different press agents are strewing his path with acclaim these days and competing to see which one can get the largest number of superlative adjectives about him into the public prints.

A slight decline in the incidence of the polio epidemic in the New York area was indicated in the report of Health Department officials of twenty-nine new cases and two deaths for the twenty-four hours ended at 9 o'clock yesterday morning. This brought the total number of cases for the year to 1,580 with 137 deaths.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- The looms of two textile firms down in Knoxville, Tenn., are now weaving something they had never produced before "disinflation" set in -- $2,000,000 worth of mailbags.
BALTIMORE, Sept. 3 (AP) -- Baltimore won a 4-3 game from Jersey City tonight. Ernie Bickhaus pitched a seven-hit contest to score his fourth victory of the season.

DALLAS, Sept. 3 -- Department store sales in the Eleventh Federal Reserve District last week were still sharply below sales for the corresponding period of 1948, but again showed improvement over the preceding week of this year. Fall promotions continued to stimulate demand.

In 1938 the Democratic party leaders drafted Herbert H. Lehman, reluctant to spend any more years in Albany, to run for a fourth term as Governor. They did so in the belief that he was the strongest candidate, the party's best state vote-getter. Now, eleven years later, by unanimous request, he is making the run for United States Senator, because of the same belief held by the party leaders.

Preceding an influx of buyers expected next week in the wholesale garment market, mail orders to resident buying offices here last week were quite heavy, according to a report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell Company, resident buying office.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- That elaborate photograph gallery on the walls of Col. James V. Hunt's office is no novelty in the National Capital. The collection of signed and unsigned portraits assembled by the central figure in the "five per center" investigation is duplicated in many instances.
FOR many week-end gardeners, Labor Day brings the season to an end. There remains only the job of putting the garden in ship-shape condition for the months that it will stand unattended.

ACCORDING to this book, the "triumph of music" in the seventeenth and eighteenth centuries in Italy was a new manifestation of that Italian intellectual vitality which had produced the Renaissance during the three previous centuries. That triumph came about after the Counter-Reformation had suffocated all freedom of religious, philosophical and scientific thought, and the artistic expressions of that freedom. Italian intellectual vitality, finding these outlets blocked, overflowed into music.

This month, as some two and one-half million other children start back to school, there is a ten-year-old boy in one of the Western states to whom the public school doors are closed. A handsome and affectionate child, Tim is one of the nearly a half million children in the United States who are mentally deficient.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Sept. 3 -- The first anniversary of the death of President Eduard Benes passed almost without official notice today. The Czechoslovak press did not mention the anniversary. Only the official, news agency at 2.30 P. M. briefly announced that official wreaths from the President, the Government, the City of Prague and the Army had been laid on the grave of M. Benes.
SOUTH BEND, Ind., Sept. 3 (AP) -- Three injury reports did not brighten the football picture today as Coach Frank Leahy put his squad through the first scrimmage of the season.

Maintenance of satisfactory volume in apparel and other merchandise not usually found in a home furnishings store enabled Ludwig Baumann to finish the first six months of the current year only slightly behind the like period of 1948, Manfred I. Behrens Jr., vice president and general manager, disclosed in an interview last week.

MOSCOW, Sept. 3 -- Dispatches from abroad published by the Soviet press today said that the task of ridding Yugoslavia of the Tito clique was one of which democratic Yugoslav forces were fully capable with the support of the people's democratic camp headed by the Soviet Union.
