Wilson Wright has been appointed manager of the economic research department of Procter Gamble Company, Cincinnati, to succeed N. R. Whitney, who after twenty-seven years will continue in a consulting and advisory capacity.

" IN THE GREEN TREE" brings together six of Alun Lewis' stories which have hitherto appeared only in periodicals. To readers who know his earlier volume, "The Last Inspection" (1942), that will be enough to recommend this book.

Mexico has been assured that it will receive from the United States the loan sought for expansion of its oil industry, Representative Robert Crosser, Democrat of Ohio, and chairman of the House Interstate and Foreign Commerce Committee, disclosed yesterday.

Another two weeks will find the scoter season opening beyond the outer harbor lines of several coastal states, and although some refer to this as the "poor man's" duck hunting, it can provide real sport and excellent fare.

FOLKESTONE, England, Sept. 3 (AP) -- America's ace jockey, Johnny Longden, will ride for the Aga Khan m the famous St. Leger race for three-year-olds arid he tuned up for it today by booting home a winner in his first day of racing on an English track.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- American exports of domestic and foreign goods dropped 18 per cent in July below the level established in the first six months of 1949, the Department of Commerce reported today through its Bureau of the Census.

STAMFORD, Conn., Sept. 3 -- Clear weather and an east-southeast wind of ten males an hour made for good sailing conditions as J. N. Brown's 73-foot yawl, Bolero, rounded the Vineyard Lightship today to lead twenty-eight other yachts in the homeward leg of the 233-mile race from the Stamford Yacht Club and back.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- Secretary of Labor Maurice J. Tobin in a Labor Day message today, noted labor's "great progress," but insisted still further gains were necessary to guarantee a good standard of living for all.

After a two-mile chase punctuated by a furious exchange of pistol fire, the police arrested yesterday morning four thugs identified in the hold-up of two Bronx taverns. Two of the bandits were wounded by police fire, while a third was beaten in his attempt to escape.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept. 3 (AP) -- Frank (Barrel) Guarasci of Columbus, Ohio, and Don (String) Guariglia of St. Louis, Mo., today shot their way into the 36-hole final of the fourth National caddie golf championship.
BOSTON, Sept. 3 -- Supported by a lusty 16-hit attack, Ellis Kinder today pitched his eighteenth victory as the Red Sox walloped the Philadelphia Athletics, 10 -- 3, before 21,269 Fenway Park fans.

The Isbrandtsen Company, Inc., rejected an offer yesterday afternoon by the Marine Engineers Beneficial Association, CIO, the terms of which, it said, exceeded the union's East and West Coast agreements.

TOKYO, Sept. 3 -- The Japanese today received a rude shock with the publication here of a statement attributed to Australian Premier Joseph B. Chifley that Japan was "wasting her time and ours" in seeking to have consular representatives admitted to the Commonwealth.

MOST five-and-a-half and six - year - olds know and can promptly give their full names and tell where they live. If parents have been briefed by some of the printed material we've seen lately, the child beginning first grade also knows his father's and mother's full names, and can give the family telephone number.

The alarming aspect of the impending United States-British talks in Washington is that so much emphasis has been placed upon them. Actually, even if action is taken on all the proposals now on the fire -- devaluation, lower tariffs, price props for sterling area commodities, higher gold price, etc. -- British exports to this country still won't begin to play their proper role in putting Britain back on a self-supporting basis.
CHICAGO, Sept. 3 -- Dixiana Stable's Here's Hoping today joined the ranks of claimants to the 1949 juvenile filly championship by winning the $54,425 Princess Pat Stakes at Washington Park.

Two radio patrolmen raced in the early morning hours yesterday with sirens screaming over city streets and parkways from their Grand Central Parkway Precinct to the Bronx Zoo then on to Kings County Hospital -- an over-all distance of about forty-five miles -- to deliver an anti-toxin serum.

ATLANTA, Sept. 3 -- Heavy special sales by two of Atlanta's largest stores sent the week's trade here above last year's levels for the first time in many weeks. The increase was 8 per cent but there still was a net decline of 8 per cent in the four weeks period and a loss of 4 per cent in dollar volume for the year to date.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 3 -- Retail business activity in the Twelfth District suffered a general slump last week. Business loans declined $1,000,000. Loans to business, agriculture and industry went against the national totals during the week ending Aug. 24. Business loans now total $1,919,000,000, some $196,000,000 below the level at the same time last year.

There is a valid reason "why Negroes should be doing Ibsen, or any 'white' play." The fact that Negroes can do Ibsen is a tribute not only to the interpretative powers of the student drama group but also to the genius of Ibsen.

IN reply to Theodore Browne's recent letter, we should like to remind him that the Howard University Players is not a commercial theatre organization, but it is part of a college educational program whose responsibility is to acquaint theatre students and the college community with the theatre at large, which includes world classics, recent experiments as well as folk theatre.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- The Senate set a record for speed today by meeting and recessing in about fifteen seconds.

MINEOLA, N. Y. -- Long Island's County of Nassau, which on occasion calls itself "Playground of the East," "Cradle of Aviation" and "Historical Nassau," will roll all of these distinctions together during the celebration of its golden jubilee this month and next.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 (AP) -- Sinclair Weeks, former Senator from Massachusetts, was named today to head the Republican fund raising to pay for the fateful 1950 Congressional campaign.
HONOLULU, Sept. 3 (AP) -- Harry Bridges charged today that President Truman knew Gov. Ingram M. Stainback of Hawaii was "strike-breaking."

EVER since a radio voice first droned, "The count is now three and two" into a kitchen, the number of "lady sports fans" has been increasing. But since the first television set dumped brawny wrestlers into the housewife's lap in her own living room, the increase has accelerated so much that a phenomenon has become an invasion.
WASHINGTON. ALBEN W. BARKLEY comes from Paducah, Ky., the home town also of Irvin S. Cobb, and he represents one of those cases where nature (Mr. Barkley's) improves upon art (Mr. Cobb's).

" THIS philosopher's testament" -- a "compact, minimum prospectus" of the Humanist philosophy of life as Dr. Lamont sees it -- concludes that "humanism assigns to man nothing less than the task of being his own savior and redeemer."

Of Princess Margaret ("'She Could Charm the Pearl Out of an Oyster'") Gilbert Bailey writes, "Not since the end of the Georgian period, when Victoria led a rather gay private life, has a British princess set an example for exuberant living.

HOBOKEN, N. J., Sept. 3 -- Ending two and one-half years as United States Ambassador to the Netherlands, Dr. Herman B. Baruch was one of the 1,230 passengers on the Nieuw Amsterdam of the Holland-American Line, which docked at the company's Fifth Street pier, here, early today.

RANGER is a big Labrador retriever who joins the United States Forest Service with his owner, young Buzz Hampdon, and plunges immediately into action. Together, man and dog perform a rescue in a flood, capture some burglars and hurry on to rout a marauding bear.

ROCHESTER, N. Y., Sept. 3 -- Larry Evans of New York, the defending titleholder, was defeated for the first time today in the New York State Chess Association tournament, losing his seventh-round game to Arthur B. Bisguier, champion of the Manhattan Chess Club.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Sept. 3 -- Westchester voters will have a chance to go to the polls on primary day next Tuesday, but there is just passing interest in the nominations of candidates. There are no major issues to be settled. In some of the communities there are a few contests, based mostly on neighborhood rivalries.

During the recent celebration of the fifth anniversary of the Slovak rising against the Nazi occupation forces the claim has been made by the representatives of the Communist Government of Czechoslovakia that that gallant attempt to aid the Allies was Communist-led and that its failure was due to lack of support from the United States and Britain and with them the Czechoslovak Government in exile.

JEANNE BENDICK, the girl whose many books give evidence that she knows all about everything, is now explaining television. For co-author this time she has her husband, Robert Bendick. It's a brave and on the whole very successful attempt to show how Milton Berle and "Howdy Doody" turn into electrons and back again, but it's definitely for older boys -- television is a complicated business.

CHICAGO, Sept. 3 (AP) -- Grains moved over a narrow price range in quiet dealings on the Board of Trade today. The market did not have much of a trend, but relative weakness in the September corn contract was apparent. It fell more than a cent a bushel at one time.

SPRINGFIELD, Mo., Sept. 3 (AP) -- Fred Hawkins of Antioch, Ill., hit his approaches with deadly precision and carded a 65, eight under par, to lead the field in the first eighteen holes of the third annual Ozarks open golf tournament today.

FROM its novelty state of just a few years ago the drive-in theatre has mushroomed into a multi-million dollar outlet for the exhibition of motion pictures. From Maine to California increasing numbers of Americans are taking in the movies with nary a thought about bus schedules or "where are we going to park the car?"
WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 (AP) -- The Treasury called today for new public hearings on Oct. 3 to seek a compromise in the dispute over labeling of the aging of bourbon and rye whisky.

In Gertrude Samuels' "From Munich to Haifa," which I read with mixed feelings of sorrow and joy and for which I thank you and the author, mention is made of the fact that Israel-bound emigrants call their future homeland "Eretz."

" Decoration Day, Fourth of July, Labor Day, and the summer is gone" said the lady, following with a sad "heigh-ho," which seemed to say that she had seen too many summers. Custom is thus strong with us. We think of Labor Day as the end of summer, whereas summer, by all the almanacs, has still nearly three weeks to go.

The Little Orchestra Society, Inc., under Thomas K. Scherman, will open its third annual series of "Eight Evenings of Music" on Oct. 24 in Town Hall, when Pierre Luboshutz and Genia Nemenoff, duo-pianists, will be the soloists.

OYSTER BAY, L. I., Sept. 3 -- Swelled to 130 craft, the Long Island Sound championship racing moved out here today. It also was the seventy-eighth annual fall regatta of the Seawanhaka-Corinthian Yacht Club.

Military men do not doubt that the Russian army's steamroller could crush Yugoslavia's army if Stalin made an all-out attack on Marshal Tito. Moscow has made a tremendous propaganda build-up against the Belgrade leader. He has been called a traitor and many other things. There are reports of the movements of Red troops on the Hungarian-Yugoslav border. There have been threats against Tito from Rumania, Hungary, Bulgaria and even inconsequential Albania.

JANE AMANDA EDWARDS, a middle-aged lady detective (no official status, just helps out the police) comes for tea at the commandant's house on a Midwestern Army reservation, stays for several days, encounters a couple of murders and eventually solves them.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- The position of the United States Government on the eve of the Anglo-American finance talks in Washington is that it is extremely anxious to do whatever it can to help tide Britain over its current difficulties.

The so-called "uniform reserve requirements plan," a proposal that would revise the bases for establishing the reserve requirements of commercial banks, was spotlighted publicly last week by a member of the Federal Reserve Board.
STRASBOURG, France, Sept. 3 -- Europe's Consultative Assembly called for a European economic union today and made plans to seek United States aid for it.

IN three previous novels Mr. Myers has investigated the fictional possibilities of the middle ages, Elizabethan England and the ante-bellum South. In this new volume he has let his hero course through literature from Homer to Mark Twain meeting on the way a host of people already famous in previous books, and others, of Mr. Myers' creation, for whom he has modest hopes.
BELGRADE, Sept. 3 -- Military demonstrations along Yugoslavia's borders are regarded here as a confession of failure of the Soviet Union's policy of economic sanctions against Marshal Tito's regime.

AS has been said before, John O'Hara (whose new book "A Rage to Live" has been stirring up the literary and psychiatric factions) was a jack of all trades and a master of some -- being at various times a steel-mill roughneck, a soda-jerk, secretary to Heywood Broun and guard in an amusement park.
CHICAGO, Sept. 3 (AP) -- Today's report of the markets in the Union Stockyards by the United States Department of Agriculture follows:

The Maritime War Emergency Board, scheduled to sit this fall on the important question of bonus payments to seamen, will convene on Nov. 1, the Maritime Commission announced yesterday. The meeting had been scheduled for Sept. 28 but was postponed on the request of some witnesses, according to Francis B. Goertner, the commission's general counsel and secretary of the board.

On Thursday President Truman told his press conference that the tension in the current war of nerves between the Western nations and the Moscow-line nations had decidedly slackened. On Friday the State Department indicated in a frank and bitter statement that the tension stirred up by the attempt to make an Austrian treaty had increased rather than diminished.

The number of students seeking admission to the nation's medical schools increased slightly in 1949, but the ratio of applications to openings at dental, veterinary and other professional schools decreased. Even with this slight improvement in the admissions picture, the number of students seeking enrollment is way out of proportion to the total of freshman openings, and many qualified students this year, and apparently for some time to come, will be unable to gain admission.

Financial markets crept along cautiously last week as the crucial month of September opened. Many problems which will have a bearing on the future economic health of the nation are expected to come to fruition before the autumnal equinox has ended. The behavior of stock prices gave an indication of the watchful, waiting attitude which has been adopted.

AT one point in Mr. Wynd's breezy, decade-hurtling romance -- it begins with the Yokohama earthquake of 1923 and ends on the high seas in 1946 -- the heroine, a lass named Irma, remarks: "I suppose American women believe more in their right to have one man to themselves than women in other countries.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 (UP) -- The Veterans Administration acted today to assure "fair and reasonable" tuition charges for veterans going to school.

NEITHER drought nor rain nor heat of day seem seriously to affect the rugged character and dependability of certain annuals. And, particularly to the flower arranger, it is gratifying to know that there are several that can be relied upon when growing conditions are most unfavorable. Heading this list are marigolds, zinnias and cockscomb in late summer.

Seventy-five students from Western Germany who will attend universities in this country under the Army's re-education program arrived yesterday aboard the Army transport Gen. R. E. Callan. The ship docked yesterday morning at the Staten Island Army Base with 1,572 passengers, mostly military personnel.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Sept. 3 -- Every major original music manuscript of Richard Wagner, except those which fell into the hands of Adolf Hitler, has been recovered, Carleton J. Smith, director of the National Arts Foundation of the United States, reported today as he continued on his two-month musicology tour of Austria, Czechoslovakia and Germany.

AS a usual thing, this reviewer takes a rather dim view of films in which the actors are called upon to give forth in heavy and studied dialects. Nothing is quite so frustrating as to hear the performers speak in language which is supposed to be English but which is almost impossible to understand.

One of the most elaborate books of the year will soon be published by Oxford, "In Our Image: Character Studies from the Old Testament." This book consists of twenty-six Old Testament stories selected by Houston Harte with the advice of a board of six clergymen and of thirty-two full page color paintings by Guy Rowe.

The first community self-audit of civil rights is under way in New York, in the area west of Central Park from Fifty-ninth Street to 138th Street. This survey at present is inquiring into the medical care available to residents in the area and later it will investigate housing, education, employment and access to public facilities.

GLEN RIDGE, N. J., Sept. 4 -- For the first time in the eight-year history of the event, New Jersey amateurs today defeated teams of professionals and women in the New Jersey State Golf Association's triangular matches for the association's caddie scholarship fund.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 4 (AP) -The Phillies took a double-header from the Braves today, 9 -- 8 and 8 -- 7, to move into undisputed possession of third place in the National League. Eight homers marked the twin bill. Willie Jones' ninth inning four-bagger gave the Phils the opener while Dick Sisler's homer with one on clinched the nightcap.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 4 -- Farmers of the Midwest appear to hold today a calmer view of the general economic picture and of their own price situation than they did six months ago. This could mean good news for the Democrats.

LONDON, Sept. 4 -- Aneurin Bevan, Minister of Health, is expected to ask additional funds for Britain's nation-wide health service before the end of the current fiscal year. Despite the Labor Government's efforts to cut Government spending, a Conservative member of the House of Commons predicted today that another 25,000,000 ($100,750,000) would be needed.

The nine-family apartment house occupying a lot 17 by 101 feet at 149 West Eighty-eighth Street has been sold by Francis Nagy to Frank and Sophie Schiffman in a transaction negotiated by Jack Ganzberg, broker. It is assessed for $15,000 and was sold subject to mortgages amounting to $11,690. Title was insured by the Inter-County Title Guaranty and Mortgage Company.

SAN JOSE, Calif., Sept. 4 -The University of California's 120inch telescope project at Lick Observatory, near here, has been advanced two years ahead of schedule as the result of acquisition of a mirror of that diameter from the California Institute of Technology, Dr. C. D. Shane, the observatory's director, revealed last week.

A doctor's strong fingers kept a young polio victim breathing yesterday after the motor of an iron lung failed while he was being transferred by ambulance from St. Luke's Hospital, Newburgh, N. Y., to New York Hospital here.

The decline in relations between the Soviet Government and the United States in recent years has been reflected in the market for old Imperial Russian Government bonds here. In contrast with 1945, when a miniature "bull market" occurred in the issues, prices and trading now are well below former levels.

While quite a few horses are used on farms, it is safe to say that we can place the equine, at least as an urban guidepost, among the "vanished" necessities of yesteryear. Yet, as people are prone to do, they will live upon nostalgic memories of the past. The farm still depends on "horsepower," in which old Dobbin plays a posthumous part.
PEEKSKILL, N. Y., Sept. 4 -- At least 1,000 followers of Paul Robeson were stranded here several hours today when bus drivers hired to carry the travelers from and to New York deserted the vehicles.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Sept. 4 -- The difficulty John J. McCloy, High Commissioner-designate for United States Occupied Germany, has been having in recruiting top-flight personnel to aid him in tasks of the occupation was indicated today in the announcement of the establishment of a Provisional Office of Economic Affairs and of appointments to three-power committees.

WASHINGTON, Sept, 4 (UP) -- Most of the difficulty encountered by Government officials in forming the military policy of the United States lies in "continuing mutual mistrust" of the Navy and Air Force, the Foreign Policy Association said today.

CHICAGO, Sept. 4 -- Grain markets were decidedly unsettled on the Board of Trade last week. Wheat advanced and corn declined, while September oats soared nearly 2 cents a bushel and sold at the highest price since late last January.

Direct obligations of the United states Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months amount to $53,374,847,214. They consist of Treasury bonds, certificates of indebtedness, bills and notes as follows:

TRENTON, N. J., Sept. 4 (AP) -- Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll wants a state park and bathing beach at Sandy Hook. The Army controls the peninsula and has refused to release the area, citing defense reasons.

The champion of the United States will play the monarch of Wimbledon in the tennis match of the year today and Forest Hills may see an outpouring of fans to put standing room in the Stadium at a premium.

Smoke abatement programs costing millions of dollars have been undertaken by public utilities and the Board of Transportation in an effort to rid the city of one of its worst nuisances, William H. Byrne, Director of the Bureau of Smoke Control, disclosed yesterday.

The new Permanent Disputes Board that was set up in the latest working agreement between Atlantic shipping operators and the National Maritime Union, CIO, has completed its first case, with a defeat for the union, it became known yesterday.

PARIS, Sept. 4 -- The exchange of recriminations across the English Channel that followed the assassination of Marshal Husni Zayim of Syria, whose regime had been friendly to France, is cited by observers here as proof that the ghost of anglo-French rivalry in the Arab world has yet to be laid.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 -- With only a fraction of President Truman's program enacted, the vacationing Eighty-first Congress faced today the choice of a whirlwind finish to its first session or another protracted session next year to make a good showing for the Fair Deal.

It was only yesterday that after shifting his knapsack from left hand to right, he waved good-bye as he went through the gates to the train, a train that obviously on this day was obtaining most of its revenue from small people with crew haircuts and large bundles.
HONOLULU, Sept. 4 (AP) -- Chief negotiators for the striking Hawaiian dock workers and employers left aboard separate planes today for conferences scheduled to open in New York Sept. 7.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 4 -- The speed record for the Tinnerman Trophy Race was pushed up almost twenty-five miles an hour today when B. W. McKillen of Willoughby, Ohio, flew his Vought Corsair fighter plane around the National Air Race course at a speed of 386,069 miles an hour.

It is easy to understand how the Japanese would get something of a shock from the reported declaration of Australian Premier Chifley that they were wasting time in any efforts to obtain consular representation in Australia before the signing of the peace treaty.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Sept. 4 -- Because of its location between New York and Philadelphia, the State of New Jersey is disunited economically, politically, culturally and geographically and lacks state spirit and state pride.

MOSCOW, Sept. 4 -- A new Moscow dramatic season is opening, after a summer respite, with emphasis being placed on a repertoire of new plays dealing with contemporary themes, particularly "Anglo-American imperialist plotters" and the defense of peace by the Soviet Union and the people's democracies.

WESTBURY, L. I., Sept. 4 -- Although they were outscored and outplayed in the second half, Argentina's El Trebol team moved into the semi-final round of the National Open polo championship tournament today by topping a game Chicago quartet, 7 to 5, on International Field of the Meadow Brook Club.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 -- The Yankees came an inelegant cropper today as they tripped right over the lowly Senators and landed all sprawled out beneath a 3-to-2 setback.

ROCHESTER, N. Y., Sept. 4 -- Larry Evans, holder of the title, and Max Pavey, former national speed champion, triumphed in the eighth round of the annual tournament of the New York State Chess Association today to tie for first place at 6 1/2 --1 1/2.
LONDON, Sept. 4 -- The Brabazon I, the world's largest civil landplane, flew today for the first time and landed safely after twenty-seven minutes in air.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 -- The National Labor Relations Board has found two Los Angeles labor organizations guilty of engaging in jurisdictional strikes in violation of the Taft-Hartley Labor Law.

LONG BRANCH, N. J., Sept. 4 -- The work of transforming weed-ridden, debris-laden areas into small parks and playgrounds is well under way in Long Branch under a three-year improvement program sponsored by the Department of Parks and Public Property.
This is a season of paradoxes. Some dress designers have selected coat-weight tweeds for dresses. Others have demanded tissue-sheer wools and worsteds for their clothes.
LINCOLN, R. I., Sept 4 (AP) -Gov. John O. Pastore said today that industrialists who moved their plants to Puerto Rico to take advantage of lower wages were "unworthy of being called Americans."

Another breakdown in the three-year effort to draft a peace treaty for Austria is a minor affair compared to the Tito-Stalin quarrel or the British dollar crisis. The latter events are of capital importance because one involves a rift in the Communist front and the other contains the danger of division in the Western world.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 4 (AP) -- Mike Garcia pitched four-hit ball and struck out nine today as the Cleveland Indians blanked the St. Louis Browns, 5 -- 0, before 35,759 fans. Ned Garver, who allowed the Indians one earned run and three hits in seven innings, was the loser.

CORPUS CHRISTI, Tex., Sept. 4 -- Plans have been announced here for construction of the new Driscoll Foundation Hospital for Children in this city at an estimated cost of $2,500,000. The institution will serve children up to 16 years of age.

THE mental image of Ray Robinson in action has been lingering for the better part of a fortnight and it just won't go away. One doesn't have to admire Sugar Ray as a man to admire him as a fighter. But the fact remains that he was the best ring artist these eyes ever have seen when he flattened Steve Belloise a little more than a week ago.

Arbitration of the annual dispute between the International Longshoremen's Association, AFL, and the stevedoring employers of the Atlantic Coast probably will be rejected by both sides, it was indicated yesterday.

SCARSDALE, N. Y., Sept. 4 -- Rehabilitation of persons disabled either by illness, injury or psychological ailments has become a major medical problem throughout the world, Dr. Howard A. Rusk, who is to lecture on the subject in Europe with United Nations cooperation, said in an interview at his home here today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 (UP) -- John M. Redding, publicity director of the Democratic National Committee, said today that the eleven-state Democratic conference to be held in San Francisco Sept. 18 and 19 would be followed by a similar meeting in New England in November.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, Sept. 4 (UP) -- Government forces captured Sucre and Potosi, two of the five cities still held by rebel forces, in savage fighting today. It was indicated that the revolt was starting to crumble.

AMSTERDAM, Sept. 4 -- It is understood that the Dutch Government's objections to restoration of free trade in certificates of American securities on the Amsterdam Stock Exchange has been largely smoothed over, so that there is a possibility of resumption of purchases here.

In many families the acquisition of a television set has merely intensified the family problem of where to seat guests. Homemakers who don't like to clutter up living space with extra chairs that are unneeded except for special events many find two solutions to their problems -- hassocks that may be stowed away or stools that will fit in a closet.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 -- The two great relief specialists who fought it out in the 1947 Yankee-Dodger world series, which still may be recalled as the "battle of the bullpens," have finally been reunited.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 -- Leaders of the country's two largest labor organizations keynoted Labor Day messages today with calls for greater activity on labor's political front in the coming year.

CANTON, China, Sept. 4 -- An eighteen-hour fire swept central Chungking over the week-end, killing at least 1,000 people and leaving 100,000 homeless, the Nationalist Central News Agency reported today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 (AP) -- The United States Treasury, largest money handler of all time, was established 160 years ago this week-end.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Sept. 4 -- In a sermon read today in many churches of the Archdiocese of Prague, Roman Catholic Archbishop Josef Beran denied the Communist allegation that he was a traitor to his nation, compared the Communists with Satan and predicted the final victory of the forces of love.

Action against the Roman Catholic church is expected in the Soviet zone in Berlin, the Rev. Walter C. Daib, field secretary of the Board for Missions in Europe of the Lutheran Church - Missouri Synod, reported on arriving yesterday at La Guardia Airport, Queens, from a three-month visit in Europe.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 4 -- Last week the steel industry raised its national operating rate again when the mills stepped up operations 1 1/2 points to 86.5 per cent of rated capacity. It was believed here that the increase was due partly to an attempt to make up for shutdowns due tomorrow, Labor Day.

NEWARK, N. J., Sept. 4 -- A fight to liberalize the policy concerning admission of Negroes to the American Bar Association will be waged at the group's convention, which opens in St. Louis tomorrow. The leader of the movement will be Adrian M. Unger, a lawyer of this city.

In an attempt to mobilize the nation's intellectual and spiritual power for the defense of democracy, eighty scholars representing virtually every branch of learning will seek to arrive at a meeting of minds at the tenth annual Conference on Science, Philosophy and
With none of the city-wide candidates for party nominations facing opposition in tomorrow's primary election, the city campaign is scheduled to start immediately afterward.

DETROIT, Sept. 4 (AP) -- Hoot Evers' homer in the eighth inning with one on base gave the Tigers a 5-to-4 decision over the Chicago White Sox before a crowd of 18,885 today. It was the twelfth victory for the Tigers in fourteen games.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 (UP) -- Representative E. E. Cox, Democrat, of Georgia, who has been one of President Truman's sharpest critics, said today that the Northern and Southern wings of the Democratic party could be united on a "give-and-take" basis.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Sept. 4 -- United States Army, Navy and Air Force units in Germany will begin Tuesday ten days of joint military maneuvers described as the greatest ever held by the United States at home or abroad in which every participating outfit was fully equipped.

Prayer is essential for "the integral, well-balanced, whole individual" and the facing of reality, the Rev. Thomas A. Donnellan, member of the staff of St. Patrick's Cathedral and a Pro-Synodal judge of the matrimonial court of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese, declared yesterday at the cathedral's solemn mass.
HONG KONG, Sept. 4 -- The big southwest China province of Yunnan may be lost by the Nationalists as a result of week-end developments there reported in uncertain, fragmentary form here today.

ZURICH, Sept. 4 -- "We acted in the interests of all of Europe" exclaimed one of the Swiss experts who took part in negotiation at Berne last week when at record speed a new trade and payments agreement between Western Germany and Switzerland was drawn up and signed.

Manufacturers and retailers who held out on making rayon goods purchases in July in the hope of still lower prices have begun to buy substantial quantities of fabrics, it was reported last week. Their activity, suppliers said, has heightened market tempo and prices continued to edge upward.

HUNTINGTON, L. I., Sept. 4 -- Mr. and Mrs. George H. Bostwick's Queen's Flight won the conformation hunter championship in the Rice Farms horse show at the Squadron C farm today. Vivienne Mitchell's Pitchblend was named reserve.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 4 -- In a letter sent this week-end to 8,000 shippers throughout the country, the Matson Navigation Company gave notice it would "continue to make every effort within the law to get Matson's ships sailing to and from Hawaii again."
WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 -There will be 43,298,000 automobiles, trucks and buses on the road by the end of this year, more than at any time in history, the Bureau of Public Roads estimated today.

Manufacturers must speed up production or face a loss of sales through dangerously low retail stocks, it was declared last week by Dr. Vergil D. Reed, associate director of research for the J. Walter Thompson Company.

The health needs of the American people should be met by giving everyone the medical care he requires, regardless of whether he is able to afford it, the Rev. Cameron P. Hall, executive secretary of the Department of the Church and Economic Life of the Federal

NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 4 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru told a public meeting in Allahabad tonight he was "surprised at the intervention of President Truman and Prime Minister. Attlee in the Kashmir dispute." -- The United States and British leaders have urged acceptance by India and Pakistan of the latest proposals of the United Nations Kashmir Commission for a truce in Kashmir.

CHICAGO, Sept. 4 -- Trade in lard futures fell off considerably on the Board of Trade last week, and prices fluctuated slowly within a moderate range despite the entrance of the Army into the market for 7,000,000 pounds of refined lard and a sharp reduction in local stocks.

PEEKSKILL, N. Y., Sept. 4 -- The spirit of violence was abroad this afternoon and tonight in upper Westchester County. Men and women who looked normally like law-abiding citizens shouted imprecations at the cars bearing visitors to the Robeson concert.

Making his twenty-seventh assist in arrests, Edgar Rustad, 52 years old, superintendent of an apartment house at 135 West Fifty-eight Street, chased an intruder from his apartment and along the street yesterday at 11 A. M. The chase ended when a passing patrolman captured the fugitive.

It is natural that the tenth anniversary of the commencement of the Second World War should have turned our thoughts toward the wicked genius who unleashed the dogs of war -- Adolf Hitler. H. R. Trevor-Roper, in his interesting article in yesterday's issue of THE NEW YORK TIMES, assures us that the Hitlerite gospel will not survive.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 (AP) -- A cessation of the use of military planes for other than strictly military business might put a stop to most of the official trips Congress member take abroad each year on expense accounts, one House member said today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 (AP) -- Washington printers voted unanimously today to seek a wage increase rather than accede to a request from four local newspapers that they accept a "substantial reduction."

Weaknesses and errors in contemporary concepts of labor were denounced yesterday as "sub-Christian" by the Rev. Dr. Russell Frank Auman, minister of St. Peter's Lutheran Church, Lexington Avenue and Fifty-fourth Street.

Twenty-eight patrons of Fitzgerald's Bar and Grill, 690 Trinity Avenue, the Bronx, who had come up to the Peekskill area on a clambake and outing, were surprised to be the object of a barrage of stones last night when their chartered bus blundered through that city.
The Coast Guard has immediate openings for a limited number of naval architects to become commissioned officers, according to an announcement by Admiral Joseph F. Farley, the commandant.

Here's a new booklet with appetite appeal for a city that produces and enthusiastically consumes more soft cheeses than any other area in the country. It's "Serve Cottage Cheese," a group of forty-five recipes, many illustrated and all worked out by the Sealtest Kitchen.
DES MOINES, Sept. 4 -- The American Veterans of World War II went on record tonight in favor of a Federal bonus for World War II veterans. The roll-call vote was 193 to 152.
SHANGHAI, Sept. 4 -- During the past six months 115 workers have been made factory directors and managers in the Port Arthur-Dairen area, the official New China News Agency reported today.

ROME, Sept. 4 -- Pope Pius XII urged German workers today to strive for the advent of the day when labor unions, to which he referred as "organizations of self-defense," will cease to have any reason for existence.
PARIS, Sept. 4 -- A decision just announced by the French Government with regard to foreign investments in the French franc zone is considered here to be one of capital importance.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 (UP) -- Louis Johnson, the Secretary of Defense, has no intention of stopping free air travel for members of Congress, Defense Department sources said today.

MIAMI, Sept. 4 (UP) -- A hurricane having winds of ninety-five miles an hour moved slowly northward far out in the Atlantic between the Bahamas and Bermuda tonight in the direction of the New England coast.
CASTEL GANDOLFO, Italy, Sept. 4 (AP) -- An unofficial translation of the Pope's radio broadcast today to German Roman Catholics at Bochum follows:

BOSTON, Sept. 4 (AP) -- With Lefty Chuck Stobbs superb in the pinches, the Boston Red Sox defeated the Philadelphia Athletics, 4 -- 2, today for a clean sweep of the eleven games those clubs have played at Fenway Park this season.

At the end of the war, in 1945, the so-called "frozen" sterling balances in London amounted to approximately $13,500,000,000, of which roughly $4,500,000,000 were held by India. When the question of an American loan to Britain came up later that year these balances were admittedly a major cause of concern to the American negotiators.

The Texas Line of the Newtex Steamship Corporation last week modified its seventeen-month embargo on less than carload traffic destined to points in Texas, Western Louisiana, and the Southwest, and henceforth such cargoes will be accepted subject to certain new conditions.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 (AP) -- The Farmers Home Administration expressed belief today that farm home loans under the new Housing Law will average only about five or six to a county during the first year of operation if Congress provides authorized funds. The loans, agency officials estimated, would average $2,200.

Eleven persons were reported last night to have been attended at hospitals in this city for injuries they said they had received while returning here from the Paul Robeson concert near Peekskill. Included were a union official and four persons from Massachusetts who declared that their automobile had been overturned in Cortland, N. Y.
Almost any resident of the New York suburbs, from the rolling hills of Westchester and southern Connecticut to the wooded stretches on Long Island, will tell you happily that 1949 is a "bird year."
BOULDER CITY, Nev., Sept. 4 -- The United States Government is hunting an expert to help it convert this, Nevada's third largest city, from a Federal "enclave" into a regular community.

Percentage probably is the greatest factor in determining the outcome of baseball games and pennant races. Here and there a manager defies it, resorts to the unorthodox and sometimes gets by. More often, though, the pilot's strategy is dictated by the "book" and more than a century of diamond activities have proved the soundness of playing percentage.

STAMFORD, Conn., Sept. 4 -This city's Exposition of Progress, the first trade show and fair here in a quarter of a century, will open at Woodside Park Saturday for a nine-day run. A special legislative bill signed by Gov. Chester Bowles will allow the exposition to run during the afternoon and evenings of both Sundays during the period.

It has been reported that at the close of the financial discussions between the representatives of Great Britain and ourselves, the British Foreign Minister, Mr. Bevin, and our Secretary of State, Mr. Acheson, will proceed to explore the political situation in the world, with special reference to areas of tension.

DETROIT, Sept. 4 (AP) -- Cracks are appearing in the once-solid wall of automobile dealers against the relaxing of wartime credit controls. Increasingly stiff competition among new and used car dealers is forcing some to accept less than the formerly required one-third down and 18 months to pay.
Four new films, including a pair of imports from England, are slated to open in first-run theatres this week. The programs follow:
OAKLAND, Calif., Sept. 4 (AP) -- Rudy Vallee took his fourth wife last night and minutes after the ceremony saved her from possible serious injury by fire.

BRIDLINGTON, Yorkshire, England, Sept. 4 -- Although Britain is on the verge of dollar bankruptcy, there was no apparent atmosphere of crisis tonight in this Yorkshire seaside town teeming with Sunday visitors.

As buses and private cars carrying persons who had attended the Robeson concert began arriving in this city early last night, the damaged condition of the vehicles and the nervous appearance of the passengers testified to their ordeal on the trip back.

NEWARK, N. J., Sept. 4 (AP) -- The Bears won their fourth shut-out victory in seven games against the Chiefs today when Bill Woop twirled a four-hit, 3-0 triumph in the first game of a double-header. Newark also won the second contest with a run in the seventh, 4 -- 3.
Dr. Michael Novikov, once a member of the faculty of the University of Moscow, arrived here from Germany yesterday to start life anew at the age of 73.

W. C. Rowland has been appointed manager of the manufacturing and repair division of the Westinghouse Electric Corporation of Pittsburgh, which operates thirty-eight Westinghouse plants in twenty-five states. He succeeds H. F. Bee, vice president, who has headed the division since 1938.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 4 -- The Yugoslav people were warned today of the jeopardy into which they had been placed by the Soviet Government. For the first time since the Belgrade-Moscow crisis, the people were told of a concentration of Soviet troops on the Yugoslav borders and that there was a possible threat of war.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 4 -- President Stephen Penrose of the American University in Beirut announced today he had protested to the State Department against reports that the United States had warned that unless Israel and the Arab nations got together it could not continue to underwrite aid for Palestine Arab refugees.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 4 -- Considering that the dispute between Marshal Tito's Yugoslav Communist party on the one hand and Generalissimo Stalin's Bolshevik party and its satellites on the other has been sharpened for considerably more than a year, it is astonishing how small a defection to the Communist Information Bureau there has been in this country.

YONKERS, N. Y., Sept. 4 -- The pure white standard poodle, Ch. Blakeen Perfection II, took the top award today in the second show of the Yonkers Kennel Club, one that brought all-breed competition back to the metropolitan area for the fall season.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 (UP) -- The National Lawyers Guild demanded today that the Department of Justice take "vigorous action" in the Aug. 27 disturbance near Peekskill, N. Y.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 4 -- State Chief Justices formally organized today the first Conference of Chief Justices and immediately directed a five-man council to investigate suggested simplification of appellate court procedure.

Representative Vito Marcantonio, American Labor party candidate for Mayor, announced yesterday that he had seventy-four signatures to a petition to force repeal of the Taft-Hartley Act at this session of Congress, with 218 signatures needed to bring about action by the House of Representatives at this session of Congress.

The four-month-old strike of 1,440 workers at the Brooklyn plant of the American Machine and Foundry Company ended officially yesterday when members of Local 116 of the United Automobile Workers, CIO, voted to ratify an agreement reached last Friday in Mayor O'Dwyer's office at City Hall.

The Waltham Watch Company of Waltham, Mass., has applied to the Securities and Exchange Commission for registration of up to 1,300,000 shares of common stock of $1 par value, it was disclosed by the company yesterday. The application is in pursuance of a plan of reorganization which is nearing completion.

CHICAGO, Sept. 4 (AP) -- The Chicago Cubs defeated the Pittsburgh Pirates, 11 to 7, in a slugfest that was called on account of rain after six and a half innings today. The Cubs came up with an eight-run explosion that routed Bob Chesnes. Wayne Terwilliger hit a three-run homer and Andy Pafko socked one with the bases loaded in the big inning.

"The O'Neills," a former daytime radio serial which went into retirement after a run of fourteen years, will be revived by WABD and the DuMont television network tomorrow evening as a regular Tuesday feature from 9 to 9:30 o'clock.

WORCESTER, Mass., Sept. 4 -A young Montclair, N. J., engineer and manufacturer, Don Whitfield, whose hobby is speed-boating and whose habit is winning, combined the two as usual on Lake Quinsigamond today. While others were losing their titles, Whitfield, in Class M, was the only holdover to retain his Eastern divisional outboard hydroplane championship.

KINGSTON, N. Y., Sept. 4 -- "The Bible proved to be the most valuable book of the Israeli Army during the recent war and is today the most valuable book for the Israeli Foreign Office in shaping peace time policy," Yehuda Hellman, Israeli journalist and lecturer, told the annual National Hillel Summer Institute at Camp High Point, Shokan, N. Y., today.

An air-conditioning system, complete with 4,000 individual hand control, is being installed in the Manhattan headquarters of the United Nations to make conditions "climatically perfect" for delegates and staff workers.

Following the pattern of recent weeks, cotton futures prices in the domestic market held within a narrow range last week. At the close of trading on Friday, active futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were 2 points lower to 9 points higher than the final levels of the preceding week, when the market had closed 3 points higher to 13 points lower than at the start of that period.

LONDON, Sept. 4 -- Pending the coming British-American financial talks in Washington, the stock markets here have fallen into a state bordering upon noma. Although there has been no follow-through from the preceding week's recovery, the City is allowing itself to be mildly optimistic concerning the outcome of the conference.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 (AP) -- Senate "5 per center" investigators are badly split over the future course of the inquiry. The breach, it was apparent today, is widening instead of healing. It is extending into the question of what witnesses to call when hearings resume.

Impishness and anthropology were combined over the week-end at the American Museum of Natural History in the hope that a convention of anthropologists would be roused to controversy over the early history of the American Indian.

Strike threats involving 3,000,000 workers in steel, coal, automobiles, electrical manufacturing, rubber, shipbuilding and other key industries are hanging fire today as the nation marks the sixty-seventh anniversary of Labor Day.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 4 (AP) -- Crushing the Chicago Hornets with a terrific ground attack coupled with a deceptive aerial game, the San Francisco Forty-niners won their second straight All-America Conference football game today, 42 to 7.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Sept. 4 -- Back in the Western part of Long Island Sound for the rest of the season, the Yacht Racing Association fleet participated today in the regatta of the Port Washington Club.

CHICAGO, Sept. 4 -- Meat production in the United States this year will exceed the 1948 supply by a wider margin than the industry had expected, according to predictions at the Chicago stockyards. Private estimates placed the probable rise over last year at about 700,000,000 pounds, or more than 3 per cent.
Joseph Clark, city editor of The Daily Worker, charged last night that there had been connivance between state and local police and "hoodlums" at the Raul Robeson concert near Peekskill yesterday.

BERLIN, Sept. 4 -- In a dispatch datelined Madgeburg (in the Soviet zone) the United States Military Government newspaper Neue Zeitung today asserts that units of the East Zone People's Police are being trained on Russian aircraft. Complete and permanent abolition of Germany's air force as well as her naval and ground forces was decreed at Potsdam.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 4-- Universal-International has purchased three new screen stories for production this year, it was disclosed in a week-end announcement from the studio.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 4 (AP) -- A pair of returned Mexican League jumpers -- Max Lanier and Fred Martin -- backed by the rest of the heavy-hitting Cardinals, hurled the St. Louis club to a twin victory over the Cincinnati Reds today, 6 to 4 and 11 to 2.

MARK ALDANOV, often called the finest living Russian novelist, although he hasn't lived in Russia for thirty years, can be an exasperating as well as a fascinating writer. A barber in the little mining and ranching town of Salida in the Colorado Rockies has written a manual to teach parents how to cut Junior's hair without putting a bowl on his head. He has got it published in New York, too.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 4 -- When Great Britain embraced socialism in her government she lost "half the battle against the Communist philosophy," Senator Robert A. Taft charged today as he opened a 100-day report to his constituents as a "nonpolitical" prelude to his battle for re-election next year.

SHANGHAI, Sept. 4 -- The vast frontier Province of Sinkiang, whose northwest corner is now controlled by the pro-Soviet "East Turkestan Republic," is scheduled for "liberation" by the Chinese Communists, it was disclosed today.

MARTINSBURG, W. Va., Sept. 4 -- Experiments being conducted during the peach harvest now practically at its close may almost completely revolutionize the shipping by freight of peaches and other highly perishable foods, according to growers and others interested.

PEEKSKILL, N. Y., Sept. 4 -The crowd that came to hear Paul Robeson sing or at least make sure that he was allowed to sing, was larger and tougher than the crowd that tried to stop him. It appeared to contain many veterans of World War II.

NEWPORT, R. I., Sept. 4 -- Newport turned back the years today as several hundred persons in costumes walked, rode horses tandem and traveled on high-wheel bicycles or in twenty-eight automobiles of the past. Together with floats and bands they paraded for the fourth annual Gay Nineties celebration, witnessed here by 30,000 persons.
To the astonishment of thousands of Americans, the San Francisco Conference was opened without invoking God's blessing on the sessions. Since then, world conditions have grown steadily worse.

LONDON, Sept. 1 -- Britain's ability to earn dollars is handicapped not only by revolutionary economic and political changes within the whole British Commonwealth and Empire but by a profound lack of confidence here in the dependability of the United States competitive system.

ALBANY, Sept. 4 -- Incomes of $5,000 and above were reported by 639,421 taxpayers in New York State, according to an analysis of personal-income-tax returns reported by Chester B. Pond, director of research of the State Department of Taxation and Finance.

The Most Rev. John C. H. How, Primus of Scotland, issued yesterday a call to all Protestant Episcopal churchmen to use their commemoration of the 400th anniversary of the compilation of the Book of Common Prayer as an occasion for personal rededication to "Prayer-Book" Christianity.

PEEKSKILL, N. Y., Sept. 4 -The heaviest concentration of police ever massed in this area kept a hostile demonstration by war veterans from flaring into violence while Paul Robeson sang here this afternoon, but buses were stoned and private cars overturned as the 15,000 concertgoers started home.

Charlie Hammer, a 31-year-old former coal miner in a small western Pennsylvania town, raises himself on powerful arms when he turns to talk. He looks on his bed at first glance like a football player who has just thrown himself down on a table for a rubdown between halves.

Those who have been waiting for Gertrude Lawrence's return to the local stage are advised to be patient. Since she was seen here early last year in a brief revival of "Tonight at 8:30," the star enjoyed a successful London engagement in a weak play by Daphne du Maurier, "September Tide."

The Rev. Berthold von Schenk, pastor of the Lutheran Church of Our Saviour, 1734 Williamsbridge Road, the Bronx, urged laymen in his morning sermon yesterday to carry out in their business and profession the spiritual principles of Lutheran liturgy.

STAMFORD, Conn., Sept. 4 -De Coursey Fales' schooner, Nina, was first tonight in the fifteenth annual Stamford-Vineyard race of the Stamford Yacht Club. The Nina crossed the finish line at 8:13:04. She was 3 minutes and 5 seconds ahead of the yawl Bolero, owned by J. N. Brown.

THE NEW YORK TIMES deserves commendation for its strong support of state aid to public libraries. Your powerful editorial on Aug. 22 and the strong follow-up editorial on Aug. 26 in answer to the letter by George L. Nichols, editor of The New York State Taxpayer, will receive support from community-minded organizations and individuals.

From Hollywood, where it rolled up a record-breaking run of more than seven years, comes Ken Murray's "Blackouts" to the Ziegfield Theatre tonight, the curtain rising at 8:30. Starring the cigartoting Mr. Murray, the revue's company also includes Nick Lucas, Pat Williams, George Burton, Owen McGiveney, D'Vaughn Pershing, Jack Mulhall, Harris and Shore, Les Zoris, Peg Leg Bates, Shelton Brooks, Charles Nelson and Alphonse Berge.
DALLAS, Tex., Sept. 5 -- Two French and two American designers received Neiman-Marcus awards here tonight "for distinguished service in the field of fashion."

NEWARK, N. J., Sept. 5 (AP)--With Roger Bowman twirling a brilliant two-hitter, Jersey City blanked the Bears, 4--0, in the first half of a Labor Day twin bill. The Bears took the nightcap, 7--2, behind Lee Dodson.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 5 -- America's future in the industrialized economy of the twentieth century "lies down the middle of the road between concentrated wealth on one flank, and the unbridled power of statism on the other," Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower said today.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., Sept. 5 (AP) -Edward Corsi, industrial commissioner of the New York State Department of Labor, said today American labor believes in being largely self-sufficient and does not want to depend on government aid.

Following successful negotiation of a new union contract, diamond cutting shops here will resume full activity today, according to a statement by Louis Frankel, executive director of the Diamond Manufacturers and Importers Association.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Sept. 5 (AP) -- A record breaking crowd of 26,210 was on hand today to see George H. (Pete) Bostwick's Stunts race to an easy triumph in the $25,000 added Atlantic City turf handicap, richest grass race in the country.

CHICAGO, Sept. 5 (AP) -- The Cincinnati Reds and the Chicago Cubs divided their holiday twin-bill today before 28,553 fans. The Reds rallied for four runs in the ninth inning to win the opener, 7 to 3, and the Cubs captured the nightcap, 7 to 2.

PROVINCETOWN, Mass., Sept. 5 -- The late lamented tuna derby should have been held in these waters, for while they have not been producing really big tuna, there is no scarcity of fish running in the 125-pound class.

A new pmphlet designed to aid those seeking to do business with the Quartermaster Corps has been made available to manufacturers, dealers and distributors, it was announced last week. Entitled "How to Do Business With the Quartermaster Corps," it outlines Quartermaster procedures and the products which are bought.

Forty-five per cent of the world's merchant vessels of 1,000 or more gross tons on order or under construction in the thirteen major maritime countries at the end of the second quarter of 1949 were contracted for by British shipyards, it was announced here yesterday by the Shipbuilders Council of America.

W. Noel Hudson, executive vice president of the Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies, appealed yesterday for foster boarding homes for dependent and neglected Protestant children. He said that more than 500 Protestant children of all ages were awaiting foster care in New York.
Robert J. Kleberg's King Ranch, winner of the Discovery Handicap with Better Self a year ago, won it with his half-brother at Aqueduct yesterday.

LONDON, Sept. 5 -- A jet fighter aircraft with an engine 66 per cent more powerful than that of the Vampire -- until now Britain's fastest fighter -- was one of two De Havilland aircraft taken off the secret list tonight. The other is Britain's first jet night fighter.

Norman Bel Geddes declared yesterday that he and Eddie Dow ling have decided against forming a partnership for the production of new plays. However, Mr. Geddes expects to sponsor on Broadway this season at least one play. The designer said that he is continuing the program he began nine months ago for the establishment of a "flexible" theatre not handicapped by the limitations of a proscenium.
PITTSBURGH, Sept. 5 -- The man who got the loudest applause today at the Allegheny County Fair Grounds was not President Truman but his currently prominent military aide, Maj. Gen. Harry H. Vaughan.
Initiating fall millinery sales in local stores, a millinery fashion show will be held on the steps of City Hall at noon next Monday, it was announced yesterday.

Two men were burned seriously and four other persons endangered when their motorboat exploded and sank yesterday morning in the ocean one mile off Manhattan Beach, Brooklyn. All six were rescued from the water by the crew of a fishing boat nearby and landed at Sheepshead Bay.

ROME, Sept. 5 -- The Communist campaign of agitation and violence was resumed in Milan today after an interruption for most of the summer. Several clashes occurred between the police and demonstrators who on more than one occasion were reported to have made use of firearms.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 5 -- The Yankees, with re-enforcements pouring in from all sides, wound up their six-city tour on a triumphant note today as they shot down the Athletics in both ends of the holiday twin bill before a gathering of 32,844.

There is a theory, widely held, that a vacation creates energy. According to this belief, the vacationer, home again, will sell more shoes, or dig more coal, or win more legal cases than he did before going away. Naturally, no one cares to dispute any theory tending to advocate a longer vacation; but if it can be spoken quietly and off the record, something is a little wrong with this one.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 (AP) -- Business is getting better for the men who build houses and those who sell them.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Sept. 5 (AP) -- The Middle Atlantic States accounting conferfence was told here today that failure to balance the Federal budget with present tax yields may lead to inflation in the future.

NEWCASTLE, England, Sept. 5 -- Radio-astronomy, a new science that has developed since the war, largely out of the experience of radar, was one of the main subjects at today's conference here of the British Association for the Advancement of Science.

The defection of the provincial government of Yunnan, in Southwest China, is a blow not merely to free China but to peace and stability in Southeast Asia. Yunnan was a possible barrier to Communist advance. But it can be a bridge for the Communists to other sensitive areas in the Far East.

Today is the day of the primary election, wherein the city's voters are supposed to choose the nominees of the four legal parties, and the officers of those parties as well. There are many parts of the city where the candidates selected in advance by the party organizations are unopposed and it would be rather foolish to urge an outpouring of the electorate in those areas.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 5 (AP) -- The Pittsburgh Pirates rallied for a ten-inning 5-to-4 victory over the league-leading St. Louis Cardinals today after dropping a 9-to-1 decision before 32,000 fans. The split cut the Redbirds' margin over the runner-up Brooklyn Dodgers to one and a half games.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 5 -- Philip Murray, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations and the United Steelworkers, CIO, today prescribed wage increases as the medicine which would banish unemployment and insecurity and replenish buying power.

One-button model men's suits in tropical weight fabrics are suggested for promotion by retailers for next summer, it was announced yesterday by the National Association of Retail Clothiers and Furnishers, in cooperation with groups of men's wear manufacturers.

Organizations and individuals desiring speaking time at the rent hearing to be held Sept. 14 in Manhattan Center, 311 West Thirty-fourth Street, were reminded yesterday by Joseph D. McGoldrick, chairman of the New York City Rent Advisory Board, that requests for time to testify must be presented in writing not later than 5 P. M. Friday.

An appeal for liberalization of the Displaced Persons Act was made yesterday to the United States Senate by leaders of religious groups concerned with the relief and rehabilitation of displaced persons.

Ricardo Guillermo Staudt, German-born Argentine business man who was one of the most important and controversial figures in the State Department's Blue Book of February, 1946, arrived here yesterday on the liner Brazil on his first trip to the United States in twenty-two years.

The fall safe-driving newspaper campaign of the Advertising Council opens today with the release of 1,000, 600 and 100 line ads to daily and weekly newspapers throughout the country. The Chicago office of Young Rubicam, Inc., prepared the ads under the direction of Robert Burton, vice president.

LONDON, Sept. 5 -- Internal inflation lies at the root of Britain's foreign exchange crisis, two noted financial experts declared today in addresses to Institute of Bankers' international summer school at Oxford. The session is being attended by some 200 bankers from thirty-five countries.

Since ancient days dew has been an accepted symbol of dawn and morning freshness. In poetry and prose one reads of dew "falling"; this is permissible literary license, but not scientifically correct. The tiny drops of water that gather on leaves, blades of grass and threads of spiders' webs are condensed from water vapor.

TOKYO, Sept. 5 -- Malcolm MacDonald, the United Kingdom's Commissioner General for Southeast Asia, said today that concern over Asia necessitated close liaison between Britain and the United States in the face of the Communist drive there.

The number of verified casualties in the wave of violence that swept upper Westchester on Sunday mounted yesterday to 145. Paul Robeson, political storm center, blamed the state and local police for the situation that resulted in the stoning of buses and automobiles filled with persons who had heard him sing near Peekskill.

MUNICH, Germany, Sept. 5 -Three former interrogators of German prisoners of the United States Army told a Senate subcommittee meeting here today that no violence had been used to get confessions from Germans charged with killing United States soldiers in cold blood during the Battle of the Bulge.

Experiments with nuclear energy have accidentally uncovered a method of determining with relative accuracy the age of earth's materials by measuring their radiocarbon content, an associate of the Institute of Nuclear Studies, University of Chicago, reported yesterday.

PARIS, Sept. 5 -- Two important steps toward liberalization of French trade announced within the last two days are aimed to improve the reception that Finance Minister Maurice Petche will get when he arrives in Washington.

A hold-up in which the victims were players or spectators at an outdoor dice game at 182 and 184 West End Avenue resulted in the shooting of two men at 7:15 P. M. yesterday, and in the arrest of a suspect after a police chase through the neighborhood.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 (AP) -- The Export-Import Bank today approved a $250,000 loan to the Dahican Lumber Company in the Philippines for development and production of Philippine mahogany and other hardwood.

SEOUL, Korea, Sept. 5 -- To meet stepped-up Communist guerrilla attacks growing out of the so-called September offensive ordered by Communist-controlled North Korea, the national police today began establishing supervisory teams.

PRETORIA, South Africa, Sept. 5 -That the Nationalist party in Transvaal supports the Government's policies of racial segregation seems indicated by the agenda of the annual provincial congress, which opened today in Johannesburg.

The Consultative Assembly of the Council of Europe is approaching the end of its first session in fine style. It has tackled administrative, economic and now political problems with boldness and vision, and in so doing it has defied its superior Committee of Ministers, apparently with impunity.

FREEPORT, L. I., Sept. 5 -- Clarence Amberman, captain of, the charter fishing boat Ah,kom-[ on, died 'this morning in Isieadow-] brook Hospital; East Meadow, of! burns suffered when one of the! craft's two gasoline tanks expl0d-i ed Shortly after being filled last Aug. 28. His age was 58.

BERLIN, Sept. 5 -- In his initial session today with members of the Western Berlin Magistrat, Andre Francois-Poncet, who has been named French High Commissioner for Germany, dampened hopes that the city's Western sectors could be included as the twelfth state of the German Federal Republic.
The S. S. Brazil of the Moore-McCormack Line arrived yesterday morning at Pier 32, North River, from South American ports with 365 passengers.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Sept. 5 -- Maj. Gen. Harry H. Vaughan, President Truman's military aide, released tonight a telegram from Federal District Judge James P. McGranery of the Eastern District of Pennsylvania denying that General Vaughan had tried to influence him in an alleged jury-tampering case.

BUFFALO, N. Y., Sept. 5 (AP) -The champion Cleveland Browns came roaring from behind with 21 points in the last quarter today to tie the Buffalo Bills, 28 -- 28, in the local All-America Conference football season opened before 31,839 in Civic Stadium.

The last writings of the late Max Planck, physicist and originator of the quantum theory, will be published by the Philosophical Library on Oct, 17: The book will be called "Scientific Autobiography and Other Papers."

HELSINKI, Finland, Sept. 5 (AP) -Finland's Trade Union Federation today considered a break with the World Federation of Trade Unions as a result of the country's seventeen-day Communist strike offensive.

BRIDLINGTON, England, Sept. 5 -- Spokesmen of the British Labor movement lashed out left and right today, attacking both those who would sabotage the Labor Government's recovery program and those who would sacrifice labor's social gains in an effort to restore Britain's balance of trade.

WESTBURY, L. I., Sept. 5 -- Never letting the opposition get set, Laddie Sanford's Hurricanes rode into the final round of the National Open polo championship tournament today by routing Pete Bostwick's Bostwick Field four, 12 to 6, on International Field of the Meadow Brook Club.

BERLIN, Sept. 5 (Reuters) -- Carleton Smith, head of an American commission searching for missing music manuscripts, tonight wrote to Premier Stalin and Premier Cyrankiewicz of Poland asking for their help in tracing original manuscripts of Beethoven, Mozart and Wagner.
HONG KONG, Sept. 5 -- British warships now are escorting British merchant vessels trading with the Communist-held North China port of Tientsin.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Sept. 5 -- Dr. J. H. Van Maarseveen, Minister of Overseas Territories, said today that Dutch delegates to the Indonesian round table conference were now united on proposals to transfer sovereignty over the East Indies to the Indonesians.
Capt. "Bill" Odom came into prominence in April, 1947, when he made a fast 'round-the-world flight that broke a record set nine years earlier by Howard Hughes.

Spurred by the introduction of the forty-hour week on the nation's railroads, Michael J. Quill's Transport Workers Union, CIO, intends to "put the heat" on Mayor O'Dwyer and the Board of Transportation to obtain a forty-hour schedule for 40,000 workers on the municipal subway, elevated and bus lines, it became known yesterday.

Following is the text of the address of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, president of Columbia University, before the American Bar Association in St. Louis yesterday, as recorded and transcribe by THE NEW YORK TIMES:

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 5 -- Vowing a knockout fight against "selfish interests," President Truman today extolled the Eighty-first Congress for arresting the "destruction" of the Eightieth Congress and advancing his Fair Deal program.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 5 -- A proposal designed to make it easier for Negroes to become members of the American Bar Association was turned down today by the association's house of delegates.

DETROIT, Sept. 5 (AP) -- Freddy Hutchinson and Art Houtteman each won his fourteenth game of the season today as the Detroit Tigers took a double-header from the St. Louis Browns, 4 -- 0 and 2 -- 1. Hutchinson pitched a four-hitter in the opener while Houtteman gave up six hits in the nightcap.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 -- With the critical top-level talks among United States, British and Canadian officials on the dollar crisis two days off, no break in the gloomy overcast appeared today. The dour prospect remains that there is little chance for finding an immediate and easy formula for reversing Britain's unfavorable economic tide.

Little change in the relationship of wage rates of unskilled workers to those of skilled employes has occurred since 1920, according to an analysis of wage differentials by skill released over the weekend by the National Industrial Conference Board. From 1920 to 1948 average earnings of the skilled and unskilled in twenty-five manufacturing industries have tended "to move up together," the board said.

LAKE SUCCESS, Sept. 5 -- Although billions of dollars are being spent in the development of the world's great river basins, little attention is being paid to national planning and to the international rights involved, speakers asserted today at the United Nations Scientific Conference on the Conservation and Utilization of Resources.
OMAHA., Sept. 5 (AP) -- Ten persons, including an Omaha Communist, were arrested today as an aftermath of fist fights at a Labor Day parade here.

After a big surge of business on Sunday the Broadway movie theatres noted a slackened attendance yesterday, but enough people were on hand to enable most of the first-run houses to play to capacity and near-capacity audiences. Standing room only was the order at several theatres for intervals before shows "broke" during the afternoon, but the street lines were not a steady fixture throughout the day.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 5 -- Senator Robert A. Taft observed Labor Day at the National Air Races today while the political leader of the American Federation of Labor was promising the rank and file of Cleveland that the Cincinnati Republican would be ousted from the United States Senate next year.

Permit me to disagree with your editorial statement that"* * * Traffic on the West Side will be well taken care of by the West Side Highway, which will have direct access to the Brooklyn-Battery Tunnel. * * *"

ATHENS, Sept. 5 -- Forest fires tonight were spreading over the island of Euboea, north of Athens. Several thousands of acres of pine woods have already been damaged, according to reports reaching here.

STRASBOURG, France, Sept. 5 -- The Council of Europe's Consultative Assembly called today for the creation of a union of European countries with real power in a limited range over the Governments of member nations.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 -- The three major generals involved in the "five per cent" inquiry should receive equal treatment, Senator Karl E. Mundt, Republican, of South Dakota, a member of the investigating committee, maintained today.

The infantile paralysis epidemic here continued to decline, as only fifteen new cases were reported by the City Health Department for the twenty-four-hour period ending at 9 A. M. yesterday. This is the lowest twenty-four-hour case total since early last July.
CHICAGO, Sept. 5 (AP) -- A 5 to 1 vote in favor of strike action against the Phelps-Dodge Corporation by its CIO union employes was announced today.

PAWLING, N. Y., Sept. 5 -- Champion Twin Ponds Belle, the Welsh terrier that is already loaded down with ring honors, tacked one more to her string today in the seventh annual Mid-Hudson Kennel Club fixture high on breezy Quaker Hill.

On the roads near Peekskill Sunday afternoon there occurred a series of incidents that were a disgrace to the community and a reminder that as great violence can be done to democracy by a gang of hoodlums in Westchester County as by a lynch-mob in darkest Georgia.

Activity in the wholesale garment market last week sharply increased and reorders for fall apparel were heavy, according to reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices. Many buyers are expected in the market this week to complete fall purchases and place commitments for the holidays.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Sept. 5 -- United States Constabulary forces and assailants hidden in the woods exchanged more than 600 shots in an apparently bloodless skirmish on the Czechoslovak border, it was disclosed today.

JONES POINT, N. Y., Sept. 5--As night touches Dunderberg Mountain in the Hudson Highlands, a Diesel-powered patrol boat prowls softly through a jungle of ghostly ships. Each hour until dawn the lonely tour encompasses a cross-stitch silhouette of stacks, masts, bridges and crows' nests.

SAN DIEGO, Calif., Sept. 5 -- William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, in his Labor Day address mentioned the possibility of an ultimate re conciliation between the AFL and the Congress of Industrial Organizations.

GLASGOW, Scotland, Sept. 5 -- A stellar attraction at the Scottish Industries Exhibition, which opened today in Glasgow's huge Kelvin Hall, is a mechanized toy -- the familiar old game of "tick-tack-toe" done in modern style.

The final contracts in the $120,000,000 school construction and modernization program begun soon after Jan. 1, 1946, will be let by July 1, 1950, Mayor O'Dwyer announced yesterday in a comprehensive report on the handling of the school problem by his administration.

BRANCH RICKEY, a salesman of expensive ivories, will soon have a new product on the market. The chap who once sold a sore-armed Dizzy Dean to the Cubs for a mere $185,000 and who once asked $300,000 -- or was it a half million? -- for Don Newcombe will shortly be putting a fancy price tag on a mercury-footed outfielder he now has parked in Montreal, a certain Sam Jethroe.
It may be too late, but the Dodgers yesterday decided to cease being doormats for the Boston Braves, whom they trounced twice at Ebbets Field, 7 -- 2 in the morning and 13 -- 2 in the afternoon.

I was disappointed at the superficial treatment which your editorial page of Aug. 13 gave the price support recommendations of Secretary of Agriculture Charles F. Brannan. I know it is tempting for a metropolitan editor to have academic fun with farm programs, but I had come to think that THE TIMES was intelligent enough to realize the true relationship between urban and rural people.

Lyle C. Roll has been appointed assistant to Watson H. Vanderploeg, president of the Kellogg Company, Battle Creek, Mich. Mr. Roll was formerly director and assistant general manager of Kellogg Company of Canada.

The Columbia Broadcasting System has notified the Federal Communications Commission that the network has completed arrangements to begin a series of color television tests in Washington on or about Sept. 26, the date on which the FCC opens hearings on color video.

Guarantees of washability and color-fastness which are being made indiscriminately on spun-ray-on fabrics will cause widespread consumer reaction, it was predicted last week by textile chemists. Good results have been obtained in dyeing and finishing these fabrics, the chemists said, but only a relatively few manufacturers have been willing to pay the extra cost involved.
DES MOINES, Sept. 5 -- President Truman in two campaign-style speeches set out today to build a farm-labor vote to swing the 1950 Congressional elections.

HONOLULU, Sept. 5 (AP) -- "Hawaii and the Philippines are the last barriers against the further spread of communism from Asia into the Western World," Gov. Ingram M. Stainback declared today in a Labor Day address.

INDEPENDENCE, Mo., Sept. 5 -- President Truman wound up an 1,100-mile speaking tour tonight only to be stopped by a traffic policeman who was letting "some very important people" through a busy intersection in Kansas City. The important people were newsmen who had made good use of a motorcycle police escort, with screaming sirens, that Mr. Truman had eschewed.

WORCESTER, Mass., Sept. 5 -In a wild and woolly succession of mishaps and accidents that saw ex-champions capsize and near-champions come to other forms of grief, George Shevlin of Middle Village, L. I., emerged a rather surprising Class C Eastern divisional outboard hydroplane champion today on a roughened and wind-blown Quinsigamond River.
Today's primary election will be held for all parties between 3 and 10 P. M.

DENVER, Sept. 5 -- A new concept of intelligence that includes not only a person's intellectual ability but also his personality as a whole and his ability to adjust to his environment was called for by Dr. David Wechsler, president of the Division of Clinical and Abnormal Psychology of the American Psychological Association.
