NASHVILLE, Tenn., Sept. 5 -- A five-year $20,000,000 program for general improvements to this capital city and the redevelopment of its hostoric Capitol area has received the endorsement of Federal, state and municipal officials.
Mrs. Helen Tvedt is one in a million, according to unofficial statistics. For the record, however, the pert redhead is one of a small handful of women in the ranks of the city's 6,000 bus drivers.

Backfire from an automobile caused a horse to bolt in Prospect Park at 6 P. M. yesterday. The animal threw its rider, a mounted policeman, and then ran into a woman who was crossing the bridle-path 100 feet from the accident.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 5 -- Presentation next year of the annual awards of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences will be made at the RKO Pantages Theatre here, Charles Brackett, president of the academy, announced yesterday.
MIAMI, Fla., Sept. 5 (AP) -- A severe Atlantic hurricane, with winds of 120 miles per hour or more, pushed toward Bermuda tonight.
Mrs. Madeleine B. Gerrish has sold the residence at 25 Seneca Street in the Apawamis section of Rye, N. Y., to Robert L. Cammann. Edward V. Siedle was the broker in the transaction.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 (UP) -- Louis Johnson, the Secretary of Defense, will visit a Navy carrier at sea this month, it was disclosed today.

The New Zealand wool bureau has recommended that a permanent joint organization for wool disposals be established and has asked for a meeting of United Kingdom and Dominion wool growers to be held early in 1950, according to a statement issued for publication today by the Wool Bureau, Inc., 16 West Forty-sixth Street.
The refusal of steamship operators to employ qualified Negro deck and engineer officers is causing discontent and unrest among the men, one of their representatives reports.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 -- The Navy said today it had a new nylon parachute with an "extended skirt" for use in bailing out of jet planes at high speeds.

Following are the texts of President Truman's Labor Day addresses yesterday at the Allegheny County Fair, Pittsburgh, and the convention of the American Veterans of World War II, Des Moines, as recorded and transcribed by THE NEW YORK TIMES:

The list of left-wing unions holding out against the non-Communist affidavit provisions of the Taft-Hartley Act shrank further yesterday when it becameknown that the international executive board of the American Communications Association, CIO, had voted unanimously to comply with the law.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 5 (AP) -- Cleveland's Indians held to the pace in the pennant race today by twice defeating the Chicago White Sox, 5 to 3 and 6 to 4. Bob Lemon limited the Sox to four hits in the second game for his eighteenth victory.

This fall's handbags and gloves have been designed in keeping with the latest fashion silhouettes; interpreting such trends as the abstract or oblique line, winged effects, slim lines and soft drapings. Designers have kept in step with the "Twenties" look by reviving the clutch bag.

Oren Root, Republican candidate for Borough President of Manhattan, issued a statement yesterday attacking the O'Dwyer administration for "wasting" the taxpayers' money by issuing reports on city affairs that are "unnecessarily extravagant vehicles of self-glorification."

On the eve of the vital Anglo-American financial talks about to take place in Washington, certain of my fellow-countrymen have seen fit to ignore the many manifestations, both national and individual, of the generosity and kindliness of the American people and to add unforgivable abuse to undeserved criticism.
LONDON, Sept. 5 -- Featuring an otherwise quiet stock market here today were the speculative buying of Japanese bonds, which showed fresh gains, and a rally in gilt-edge stocks.
CHICAGO, Sept. 5 (AP) -- Calumet Farm's cannonball, the amazing Coaltown, today registered his twelfth victory in thirteen starts this season by easily winning the $52,900 Washington Park Handicap.
TOKYO, Sept. 4 -- Controls and other artificial influences in the Japanese business world are being removed at a constantly accelerating pace.

MEXICO CITY, Sept. 5 -- With 186 delegates or observers from the United States virtually sharing leadership with 600 Mexican organizers and hosts, the Continental Congress for Peace opened here today.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 5 -- William P. Odom, round-the-world flier, was killed today when his F-51 Mustang crashed into a house a few minutes after he took off in the Thompson Trophy Race. A woman and a boy in the house were burned to death and a man was seriously injured.
ALBANY, Sept. 5 (AP) -- Intra-party battles for mayoral nominations in Buffalo, Utica and Binghamton will highlight tomorrow's off-year primary elections in New York State.

Eggplant for a dime a pound is one of the most attractively priced vegetables in the market now. Plentiful supplies from New Jersey will be augmented within a week by shipments from Long Island, indicating that September and October are the time to present some of the many delectable dishes that may be prepared from this vegetable.
LONDON, Sept. 5 -- Yugoslavia's leaders do not expect their differences with the Soviet Union to reach the point of war, Konni Zilliacus, British leftist member of Parliament, said today.
SYRACUSE, N. Y., Sept. 5 -- An estimated 100,000 persons pushed and crowded their way through the gates of the New York State Fair Grounds today for the opening of the 103d exhibition.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 5 -- Emir Fawaz Shaalam, paramount chief of the Ruwalla tribes, largest and most powerful tribal federation in Syria and the northern desert, came out today against the resettlement of Palestinian Arabs in newly developed lands, particularly lands that might be brought under irrigation.

The discussions of state aid for our libraries overlook the possibility of considerable financial self-help for the larger libraries and the specialized departments of many libraries. We should insist on this self-help by the libraries before agreeing to state aid.

Seventy-four graduate students in engineering and science from twenty-two foreign countries, including some with Socialist and Communist leanings, will see American free enterprise in action during a ten-day, 2,200 tour sponsored by the National Association of Manufacturers.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 -- An extraordinary star, apparently the sun's second closest neighbor in space, has just been reported. Located as a little way south of the celestial equator, its distance is calculated at between 50,000,000,000,000 and 120,000,000,000,000 miles from the solar system.

Five winter cruises to the West Indies and South America aboard the luxury liners Caronia and Mauretania have been scheduled for the 1949-50 season, it was announced yesterday by Cunard White Star Line, operators of the vessels.
DENVER, Sept. 5 -- Details of a new Federal effort to expand job opportunities for Negroes were disclosed here today.

Union members were urged yesterday to keep alive their sense of individual responsibility for the determination of union policies. The advice was given by Msgr. John M. A. Fearns, rector of St. Joseph's Seminary, Yonkers, in his sermon to 1,200 persons attending the sixth annual Labor Day mass at St. Patrick's Cathedral.

The annual ice patrol report for this year will not be made for several months, but Coast Guard officers said yesterday that it would record a rare and gratifying absence of ice danger in the steamer lanes last spring.

Mild temperatures, although a bit above those at the start of the long Labor Day week-end, sent good-sized crowds to metropolitan beaches yesterday as returning week-enders and vacationists taxed the city's bus, railroad and air terminal facilities.

A FEW days ago in this space tribute was paid to the remarkable number of good books which were published in the week beginning Aug. 22. Whether so many fine books have ever been published in one week before I do not know; but surely such an outburst of literature never occurred before in August. Several good books had to be neglected here at the time and were discussed last week.

BOSTON, Sept. 5 (AP) -- The Boston Red Sox pennant hopes flared high as they swept a double-header from the Washington Senators, 5 -- 2 and 12 -- 2, before 35,808 today. Lefty Mel Parnell gained his twenty-first pitching decision in the opener.
LARCHMONT, N. Y., Sept. 5 -It blew and blew today out on Long Island Sound for the Larchmont Yacht Club's last championship regatta of the year, its annual fall one.

Late last month Lee Shubert, after returning from a visit to England and France, announced that by special arrangement with Sir Laurence Olivier he and his brother, J. J. Shubert, would import Sir Laurence's production of "Daphne Laureola," the James Bridie play starring Edith Evans, which is standing them up at London's Wyndham Theatre.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Sept. 5 -- The American Veterans of World War II today elected Harold J. Russell of Watertown, Mass., as national commander. The election was decided on the second ballot in a four-way race.
HONG KONG, Sept. 5--No violence has so far occurred in the reported Yunnan opposition movement against the National Government, information to a number of sources here indicated today.

BOSTON, Sept. 5 -- Maurice J. Tobin, Secretary of Labor hailed an upswing in economic activity in his Labor Day speech here today, but told of having received reports of "shocking" working conditions in some industries.

NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 5 -The Constitutent Assembly today adopted provisions in the new Indian Constitution insuring a certain measure of local autonomy to almost 30,000,000 aboriginal tribesmen. For the first time in the history of the Adibasis, original settlers, they win manage their own affairs constitutionally through tribes elected to the advisory councils.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 5 -- It was learned today that the Export-Import Bank was giving favorable consideration to a loan of approximately $25,000,000 requested by the Yugoslav Government. An announcement to the effect that the loan has been granted is said to be not far off.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 -- The first issue of a new publication, British News, will appear tomorrow, marking another step by British manufacturers to build up exports to the United States and Canada.
The patients of Veterans Administration Hospital No. 81 had a carnival, field day, and barbecue yesterday afternoon on the grounds at Kingsbridge Road and Sedgwick Avenue, the Bronx.

The one-story taxpayer at 417 Central Avenue in Cedarhurst, L.I., has been sold by Samuel Kann to Theodore Sakelariadis. The building, 20 by 80 feet, is occupied by Bunnyland, Inc. Sale was subject to a mortgage of $5,659.

CHICAGO, Sept. 5 -- Secretary of Agriculture Charles F. Brannan, author of the proposed farm price support plan bearing his name, tonight assailed "standpatters" who have "painted a terrifying picture" of the cost of the program.

MINEOLA, L. I., Sept. 5 -- Nassau County's Golden Jubilee, commemorating the fiftieth anniversary of the establishment of the county, will start here next Saturday with ceremonies and a historical cavalcade from the Old County Court House.

Frank Cakouros bought the six-story tenement building with one-story extension, containing three stores and twenty-eight apartments, at 276 East 137th Street and 192-94 Lincoln Avenue, the Bronx, from Joseph R. Nayvin. Adolph Bretz was the broker.
The Women's Law Class of New York University will begin its sixtieth anniversary year when the course opens for the fall semester on Sept. 26.

Richard (Pancho) Gonzales' reign as national amateur tennis champion was extended for a second year yesterday and no holder of the crown has shown more perseverance in enduring and surmounting the barbs of adversity than did the 21-year-old six-footer from Los Angeles to defeat Frederick R. (Ted) Schroeder of La Crescents, Calif., in the Forest Hills stadium yesterday.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 5--Marshal Tito said today that the economic blockade of this country by Communist Information Bureau countries no longer represented a threat to Yugoslavia.

ROCHESTER, N. Y., Sept. 5 -- In an exceptionally close finish Max Pavey of Brooklyn, prominent member of the Manhattan Chess Club and at one time champion of Scotland, today gained the title in the New York State Chess Association tourney, sponsored by the Kodak Park Athletic Association.
DETROIT, Sept. 5 (AP) -- Wild Bill Cantrell smashed two more speed-boat records with My Sweetie today to win the Silver Cup with virtually no competition.

EL PASO, Tex., Sept. 5 (AP) -- An Army private gave himself up today in the death of Second Lieut. Edward L. Helmstetter, who was found dead from a terrific beating yesterday in the driveway of an El Paso home.

The probability that in the first half of the next decade the airlines of the United States, equipped with piston-driven planes cruising at 300 miles an hour or less, will be competing with foreign lines flying fast, vibrationless jet-propelled and turboprop-powered airliners appears stronger with an announcement that British European Airways has opened negotiations for purchase of Vickers Viscounts.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 5 -- A demand that this country withdraw its diplomatic recognition of "the Polish regime which has perpetuated itself upon the basis of fraudulent elections" was made today by delegates to the annual convention of the California division, Polish American Congress.

The Electric Bond and Share Company has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission an amended Plan No. 3 in which it applies for exemption from the provisions of the Public Utility Holding Company Act of 1935, it was announced yesterday.

With Labor Day come and gone, it is time to take under consideration the question of fall and winter fashion needs. Three costumes can fill the basic requirements of a smart woman's wardrobe -- a dress, a suit and a coat.

In a hot, congested room filled with the white glare of photographers' lights, Paul Robeson led a succession of fifteen witnesses, some of them bandaged, who told yesterday afternoon of attacks by state and local police on peaceful patrons at a concert near Peekskill on Sunday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 (UP) -- A troop of fifteen Sea Scouts, reported two days overdue on a cruise to Annapolis, Md., has been found safe aboard its 38-foot picket boat in a cove near Colonial Beach, Va., Virginia State Police reported tonight.
DETROIT, Sept. 5 (AP) -- General Motors' five-car divisions have built more than a million and a half passenger vehicles since Jan. 1.

MOSCOW, Sept. 5 -- The creation of a completely new Yugoslav Communist party for the purpose of leading Yugoslavia to freedom and accomplishing the defeat of the Tito regime was forecast by a Pravda article today.

Four vessels of Task Force 87, which arrived in New York on Saturday morning, attracted 8,300 visitors yesterday at the Navy Pier at Beach Street and the North River. The ships will depart today at 11 A. M. for training maneuvers in the Atlantic.

Broadway's stage attractions that gave holiday matinees yesterday fared rather well. More than half played before standees, while business for the rest ranged from three-quarters capacity to sold-out houses. Enjoying standee trade (the parenthetical figure denotes the number) were: "Mister Roberts" (50), "Miss Liberty" (49), "Lend an Ear" (40), "Where's Charley?" (30), "A Streetcar Named Desire" (30) and "Detective Story" (20).
WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 (AP) -- Senator Joseph C. O'Mahoney, Democrat, of Wyoming, said today that a survey showed thirty-four states needed $20,000,000,000 worth of work done on their roads.

Florida's electric power industry, hit hard by damages to transmission lines during the recent hurricane, made a fast recovery in restoration of essential service, it was reported yesterday in a survey of the area by the Edison Electric Institute.
New advances in use of color on packaging will be made this fall in hitherto neglected fields, it was declared last week by an official of International Printing Ink.

After the Giants had succumbed to the Phillies in the first game of yesterday's double header at the Polo Grounds, 9 to 7, the disc jockey spun "You Can't Buy Happiness," "Dancing with Tears in My Eyes" and "I'm Alone Because I Love You."
Private interests are providing much-needed parking space in the growing shopping center of Glen Cove, L. I., following failure of the municipal officials there to create a public parking area.
Vaudeville continues to flourish in this town and is beginning to reach into the deep hinterland, where it has not been on view since its halcyon days of the early Thirties.

The first two volumes of a four-volume military history of the Civil War by Kenneth P. Williams, Professor of Mathematics at Indiana University, has been scheduled for Nov. 1 publication by Macmillan. The two books of "Lincoln Finds a General" describe the first three years of the war in which Lincoln searched for a general to pit against Lee and Jackson.
LONDON, Sept. 6 -- The stock markets here made a bright showing today on the eve of the Washington talks. This was the last day of the account and "bears" were buying to square their books.

A popular misconception of which veterans' minds ought to be disabused is the prevailing idea that they constitute a super-patriotic group. In consequence of this pattern of thought, many veterans are impelled to take unilateral action in suppressing what they consider to be acts which jeopardize the security and stability of the nation.

TRENTON, N. J., Sept. 6 -- The possibility of White House intervention to bring peace between the pro-Hague and anti-Hague factions within the New Jersey Democratic organization was discussed here today.

KENTON, Ohio, Sept. 6 (AP) -John's Gift, owned by George Leffel of Springfield, Ohio, won the North American coondog championship today at the twenty-second annual National Leafy Oak coonhound field trials.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 6 -- A group of more than thirty policemen from twelve states went back to school today in classroom sessions of the Yale Institute for Traffic Training held in Strathcona Hall of Yale University.

BERLIN, Sept. 6 -- The deconcentration and sale to private individuals and enterprises of the former Reich-owned film monopoly UFA, to be completed in the next eighteen months, were ordered today by the military governors of the United States and British zones.

MEXICO CITY, Sept. 6 -- More speeches condemning the United States as a nation bent on war to save capitalism and glorifying Russia for being dedicated to world peace, "even if she has to fight for it," occupied the second day of the Continental Congress for Peace.

The contract dispute between East Coast longshoremen and their employers was complicated further yesterday when the International Longshoremen's Association made additional demands on the company committee.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 -- A distinguished Navy pilot testified today that he relayed to Cedric R. Worth some of the reports that led to the Congressional inquiry on the B-36 superbomber. But the witness agreed that they were "rank gossip."

The city's bus riders got a new strike threat to worry about yesterday. Michael J. Quill, international president of the Transport Workers Union, CIO, warned that service for 1,800,000 persons on routes of the Third Avenue Transit Corporation in Manhattan, the Bronx and lower Westchester would be cut off early Monday morning unless the lines were included in an arbitration pact accepted by other private bus companies.

An encouraging subscription has been reported for the American premiere of the J. Arthur Rank Technicolor film, "Christopher Columbus," with Fredric March in the leading role, on the night of Oct. 11 at the Victoria Theatre for the benefit of the Seamen's Church Institute of New York.
ALBANY. Sept. 7 (AP) -- Insurgents won the Democratic nomination for Mayor of Buffalo and the Republican nomination for Mayor of Binghamton in today's primary elections.

Tele-tone Radio Corporation stands ready to go into immediate mass production of a color television converter to retail for less than $100 if the Federal Communications Commission approves the Columbia Broadcasting System's color transmission system, S. W. Gross, Tele-tone president, revealed yesterday.

With the approach of fall, activities on the summer theatre circuit have slackened considerably. A survey made yesterday revealed that almost half of the more than 100 rustic playhouses that began operations at the start of the season have called it quits .

Eighty-five graduate students who are the first of a contingent of 125 to win study awards in Great Britain under the Fulbright Act heard themselves described yesterday by Sir Francis Evans, British Consul General in New York, as pilgrims retracing the steps of their ancestors.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores declined 6 per cent last week below the corresponding period last year, according to the "flash" report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The decline for the four weeks ended last Saturday was 8 per cent.

The first Negro family to live in restricted Stuyvesant Town was still occupying an apartment there yesterday although it had been scheduled to depart on Labor Day. However, the community seemed as unconcerned as it had been for the last month.

A new lecture hall that has been under construction in the Brooklyn Museum for the last two months will be opened today for the third meeting in the eight-day conference of the International Congress of Americanists.

PAWTUCKET, R. I., Sept. 6 (AP) -- Mrs. Robert Cramer's Divot Digger today captured the featured sixth race at Narragansett Park by three-quatrers of a length over S. S. Barrett's Auntie by running the six furlongs in 1:10.1. I. J. Collins' Garrett C. was third.

A good many essays have been written about the joys to be found in getting up at 4 o'clock in the morning. This does not mean getting up from a comfortable chair and bidding the evening's host good-night, but getting up from bed at the end of sleep.

FARNBOROUGH, England, Sept. 6 (AP) -- United States aviation executives, who brought along their checkbooks, were among the most interested spectators today as British designers unveiled their latest aircraft.

The battered but still defiant Yankees were all but digging trenches in the Stadium outfield yesterday in preparation for the invasion of Boston's surging Red Sox tonight for the first game of a three-game series.

The foreign-exchange market yesterday adopted a stand-off attitude so far as trading in pounds sterling was concerned. This quiet was viewed as an implied desire on the part of bankers and dealers to mark time until the outcome of the conference this week in Washington by representatives of the American, British and Canadian Governments is known.
LAKE SUCCESS, Sept. 6 -- The United Nations Security Council will begin a round of controversial meetings tomorrow that is expected to bring from two to ten Soviet vetoes.

Plans were made yesterday for another meeting Sunday in the grove near Peekskill, N. Y., where a concert last Sunday by Paul Robeson and an anti-Communist demonstration organized by war veterans were followed by widespread violence.

GREENWICH, Conn. Sept. 6 -It took just fifteen minutes here today for the Government to auction off a list of gilt-edge securities -with a par value of $92,000 -that it had seized to satisfy a tax judgment against the Puritan Church Building Fund of La Grange, Ill.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 (UP) -- Defense officials are working on a $13,700,000,000 military budget for the next fiscal year, about $3,600,000,000 less than the current budget and just about the figure set by President Truman.
MATTOON, Ill., Sept. 6 (AP) -- A physician, 34 years old, announced today the invention of an electronic apparatus to make speedy, accurate red and white blood-cell counts.

In its first change of ownership in forty years the four-story brick building containing two stores and eight apartments at 1686 Webster Avenue, the Bronx, was sold by James J. Kolbeck to Mollie Fleck for investment in a deal negotiated by Elroy-Clark Co., brokers.

Ricardo W. Staudt of Buenos Aires, head of the Staudt group of South American companies, and George E. Allen of the Eastall Corporation, 120 Broadway, began a review yesterday of the commercial alliance under which the Staudt group and Eastall collaborate in foreign trade and investment abroad.
CHICAGO, Sept. 6 (AP) -- A battered, drifting sailboat -- with a young bride's body lashed to the rigging -- unfolded today the story of a sudden squall that brought death to four holiday sailors.
After bowing in ten innings, 4 to 2, the Giants snapped the seven-game winning streak of the Phillies, 4 to 1, before 4,150 spectators at the Polo Grounds yesterday.

The Edison Electric Institute issued yesterday an analysis of Government-released information to show that the Rural Electrification Administration, a division of the Department of Agriculture, was becoming "an increasingly expensive proposition," because of rising costs of construction.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 6 -- Hearings on defense motions to force the Government to disclose evidence in its civil suit against Harry R. Bridges, the West Coast longshore leader, were delayed today until Sept. 22 by Federal Judge George B. Harris.

The New York State Insurance Department announced yesterday that it had approved the "Escott Plan" for rating of fire insurance on multiple location contents risks. The filing was made on Aug. 31 by the New York Fire Insurance Rating Organization and the State Department's decision was made effective from Sept. 1.

The passing of Labor Day produced no appreciable change yesterday in the pattern of trading on the Stock Exchange. Traders and investors, alike, were still concerned with the domestic economic outlook as exemplified by the steel wage arguments and the pending discussions of the financial troubles of Great Britain.

The deportation hearing on Alexander Bittelman, an important member of the Communist party leadership in this country, was ended yesterday morning by the Government after going on intermittently for nearly a year.

LAUSANNE, Switzerland, Sept. 6 -- The United Nations Palestine Conciliation Commission announced today that its Jerusalem committee had asked the Israeli Government to clarify its attitude toward Jerusalem.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 6 -- A charge that the Defense Department's policy on the transfer of industry from "too vulnerable" areas was threatening the economic security of the Far West was made here today by Christy Thomas, Washington representative of the Seattle Chamber of Commerce.

SHE was not yet seventeen, a prim, solemn, scholarly girl. A serious and able student of Latin, Greek and Hebrew, a zealous -some said bigoted -- follower of the new religion, she was pretty and not without courage. She did not want to get married, but she had to. Were young minxes to set themselves up as superior in judgment to their parents?

SHANGHAI, Sept. 6 -- The United States Educational Foundation in China, which has been promoting a cultural exchange of Chinese and American students under the Fulbright Act, is making arrangements to suspend its activities because of the lack of funds.

Charging that the amount of red tape at the operating level of the Economic Cooperative Administration in Europe is "unwarranted and wasteful," Nathan Cummings, chairman of the board of Consolidated Grocers, largest food wholesalers in the country, suggested yesterday that an "economic stablilization committee" of business men be formed.

BUFFALO, N. Y., Sept. 6 (AP) -- The Bell Aircraft Corporation reported today a net profit of $133,332 for the six months ended on June 30. This was about 30 1/2 cents a common share. It contrasted with a net loss of $205,696 for the corresponding period in 1948 and one of $210,394 for the same period in 1947.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 6 -- Aroused by the tragic Bill Odom plane crash that resulted in the deaths of the world-famous flier, a young Berea mother and her baby son, the Progressive Citizens League of the Ohio city was circulating petitions tonight demanding a halt to closed-course races over heavily populated areas.

The death toll in the nation from the holiday week-end rose yesterday to a total of 550, The Associated Press reported, the largest ever for a Labor Day holiday. The new and unenviable record showed a startling increase over the previous high mark of 428 deaths recorded over the 1937 Labor Day week-end.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 -- Presdent Truman returned today from his Labor Day speaking tour, in which he covered more than 2,000 miles by air. He arrived at National Airport in the Presidential plane, the Independence, at 4:17 P. M., making the trip from his home in Independence, Mo., in 3 hours and 17 minutes.

The Republic of Poland filed suit in Federal court here yesterday for recovery from two New York corporations of $226,680 that it held it had overpaid on marine, war risk and storage insurance for railroad and mining equipment purchased with a $40,000,000 Export-Import Bank loan in 1946.

NEWCASTLE, England, Sept. 6 -- Tilting at the "muck and mystery" school that, as one speaker said, had the mystical belief that nothing must be used in agriculture that was not supplied by nature, chemists at the British Association today produced their answers to the problem of feeding the world's swarming millions.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Sept. 6 (AP) -- The need of an informal agency to settle disputes between taxpayers and the Bureau of Internal Revenue was recommended by accountants in convention here today.

The brown shopping bag delivered to the food news department yesterday looked as if someone had been buying out a bakery. It was bulging with bread, muffins, buns. A note announced that these were new products in the 300 Bohack stores, to be introduced next Monday.

Britain hopes to get out of the tripartite conferences that open in Washington today an economic "one world" to match the democratic nations' advances toward its political counterpart, British Foreign Secretary Ernest Bevin said last night on his arrival here.

CAMDEN, N. J., Sept. 6 -- Howard B. Unruh, who killed twelve persons and wounded four in his home block here today, was in several major engagements with an armored artillery unit in the European theatre of war from 1942 to 1945.
DENVER, Sept. 6 -- Private builders in cities throughout the country have started this year to show some interest in putting up homes for Negroes, it was reported here today.

For the fifth consecutive day rubber futures showed a rising trend on the Commodity Exchange yesterday and closed 29 to 31 points above Friday's closing levels. Yesterday's closing quotations were near the highs for the day. There was considerable activity in December deliveries.

NEWARK, N. J., Sept. 6 (AP) -- Jersey City strengthened its hold on fourth place in the red-hot battle for International League play-off berths by sweeping a double - header from the Newark Bears, 8 -- 5 and 8 -- 2, tonight. With Toronto dividing a doubleheader with second-place Rochester, Jersey City now holds a game and a half lead over the fifth-place Leafs.

After rehearsing in Hollywood for nearly eight years, Ken Murray has brought his "Blackouts" to New York, where it opened at the Ziegfeld last evening. Mr. Murray is a tall gentleman with what used to be known as a pompadour and what is still known as a cigar and an amiable personality.

" Under the Sun of Rome," an Italian-made feature film dealing with the effect of the second World War on Italian adolescents in Rome, will have its premiere here at the Avenue Playhouse next month, it was announced by United Artists.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 6 (UP) -- Ford Frick, president of the National League, today fined Outfielder Dixie Walker of the Pirates $100 and suspended him for three days for an altercation with Umpire Larry Goetz in yesterday's game against the Cardinals.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 -- Chairman Elmer Thomas of the Senate Agriculture Committee today sent two egg-control bills to Senator Clinton P. Anderson, chairman of a subcommittee, with a recommendation that in holding hearings on them he also investigate "egg-price manipulation" under the support program.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 (AP) -- Both Democratic and Republican leaders appeared to be taking a "no compromise" attitude today on the eve of a hard Senate fight over legislation to extend the reciprocal trade treaty program.

BONN, Germany, Sept. 6 -- Political party leaders completed their last-minute chores today as most of the representatives to the Parliament of the new Federal Republic of Germany (West German State) arrived for tomorrow's historic initial session.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 6 -- The adoption by the voters of Ohio of a constitutional referendum abolishing straight-ticket voting would swing at least 100,000 votes to Senator Robert A. Taft, Republican, in the general election next year, it was estimated today by the principal proponent of the move.

Scenes from the Revolutionary War battle of White Plains are the subject of a series of six wall panels that went on display yesterday at the Nancy McClelland showroom, 15 East Fifty-seventh Street. The papers, which were hand-painted by a young French artist and decorator, Comte Bernard de Perthuis, for the dining room of a home in Mamaroneck, will remain on view through Friday.

In a Labor Day address at Pittsburgh, Philip Murray, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, called for wage increases as "the quickest and easiest way * * * to replenish the buying power of our people." At about the same time, in Boston, Maurice J. Tobin, Secretary of Labor, was paying his respects to this same economic theory.

Forty-two years after he joined the Department of Parks as a tree trimmer, David Schweizer is still at it. But today, as the department's chief of horticulture, his work is of a more extensive and satisfying kind -- decorating the city streets with a green garland of shade trees.

BRISBANE, Sept. 6 (AP) -- Competition widened today at the Brisbane wool sales with prices holding firm. The United Kingdom was the principal buyer and there was additional support from Continental purchasers. On the second day of the sales top prices for greasy wools hit 80 pence ($1.60) a pound and the highest price on

Millinery week which opens in New York and fifty other cities beginning on Monday will be backed by 600 New York manufacturers and the Millinery Workers Union, according to Sam Finkelstein, executive director of the Millinery Stabilization Commission.

MOSCOW, Sept. 6 -- The Broadway stage is characterized as "a monstrous delirium of the reactionary propaganda of fascism" by which ordinary Americans are being turned into mutes, "deprived of thoughts and normal feelings" in the interests of mongers of a new war in a story today in Pravda.

Fifty publishers, editors and writers representing fourteen western European countries who will make a two-week tour of the United States as guests of American Overseas Airlines arrived early yesterday at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens.

ATLANTIC CITY N. J., Sept. 6 (AP) -- Jacob Sher's Excitable Mary was given a cool ride by Jack Richard here today in the Seabrook, feature event on the off-day program, to win by a nose in the six-furlong dash.

WARSAW, Sept. 6 -- The entire Polish press violently attacked Pope Pius XII today as a schemer fomenting dissension in Poland for political reasons through his letter to the Polish Bishops on the tenth anniversary of the war's outbreak. Answering the Pope's letter point by point, virtually every newspaper challenged the Roman Catholic Episcopate "to correct the obvious and harmful lies" by issuing a statement denying the veracity of the Pope's charges of religious persecution.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 6 (AP) -- The Reds exploded for four runs in the top of the tenth tonight to take a 3-3 decision from the hapless Pirates. Ralph Kiner, slugging Pittsburgh outfielder, blasted his forty-third homer of the season in the fourth with no one aboard.
MIAMI, Fla., Sept. 6 (AP) -- A huge hurricane with winds up to 130 miles per hour drifted slowly northeastward in the Atlantic tonight, moving away from Bermuda and the United States mainland.

Opposition to the New York Central Railroad's application before the Public Service Commission for fare increases and service curtailment on the Putnam Division will be opened tomorrow night when the Putnam Commuters Association holds its first meeting.

Jobs are plentiful in rural electrification and related work, according to the Rural Electrification Administration. The REA says the labor shortage is particularly acute for electric cooperatives in the Plains States, where progress in rural electrification is just beginning.

CHICAGO, Sept. 6 -- Grain markets staged a strong rally in the late trading on the Board of Trade today, shorts covering freely after a small dip early. There was little pressure on the way up, and it took but little buying to start prices rising.

ROME, Sept. 6 -- Foreign Minister Count Carlo Sforza left by train this morning for Cherbourg, where he will embark tomorrow on the Queen Mary for New York to attend a meeting in Washington of the Foreign Ministers of the North Atlantic powers.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Sept. 6 -- The Czechoslovak Foreign Office protested "most sharply" to the United States Embassy today against what it said was a "pronounced intentional and gross violation of Czechoslovak sovereignty" by American troops.

The work of the Hoover Commission is criticized as faltering in some of the most important matters by Dr. Herman Finer, professor of political science at the University of Chicago and author of "The Road to Reaction." His article appears in the September issue of the Political Science Quarterly, a publication edited by Columbia University's Faculty of Political Science for the Academy of Political Science.

Whisky John Mustache ran around the reservation handing out tobacco in invitation to the bear feast. He was spreading the news that George James had killed a bear and its cub feeding on acorns on the Lac Court Oreilles Reservation in Northern Wisconsin. Mr. James, as a true Ojibwa Indian, felt he had to do something about it.

Business, government groups, educators and writers of textbooks were urged yesterday to see that the processes of distribution get "full and favorable public understanding." The recommendation was the subject of a resolution adopted by the American Association of Advertising Agencies' operations committee, which warned that lack of such understanding now makes likely development of "a lop-sided view of our economy."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 -- The controversy over the use of military airplanes by members of Congress apparently ended today as the result of a compromise between Senator Elmer Thomas, Democrat, of Oklahoma, and Louis Johnson, Secretary of Defense.

The need for strengthening everyday human relations in American society and the opportunity for psychologists to contribute to international understanding were two of the subjects discussed last night by scholars who opened the tenth annual Conference on Science, Philosophy and Religion.

Next Sunday afternoon seventy-four graduate students from twenty-two foreign countries will start on a enday, 2,200-mile tour in order to see samples of American industry in operation. Four members of the party are from Yugoslavia. If there are none from Russia, or from any country whose Government faithfully follows the Moscow line, this is not the fault of the National Association of Manufacturers, which is sponsoring the tour.
EL PASO, Tex., Sept. 6 (AP) -- An Army private, who admits he slugged a young officer found dead here Sunday, was paroled to Fort Bliss authorities today.

HOLLAND, Mich., Sept. 6 (UP) -- David A. Bennett, scheduled to testify soon before the Senate "five percenter" inquiry, said today Maj. Gen. Harry H. Vaughan "helped me see the right people" so I wouldn't be "pushed around by clerks."
HASTINGS, England, Sept. 6 -(Reuters) -- The New Zealand cricket team scored an easy victory over the South of England in the first match of the Hastings Festival today by an innings and three runs.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 6 (AP) -- Ginger Rogers told the divorce court today that her husband, Jack Briggs, did not come to dinner even on their wedding anniversary when she prepared the meal herself.

Gustav H. Jensen, 83 years old, "too young to have known the Taylors but old enough to have known the Lords," celebrated yesterday his seventieth anniversary with Lord Taylor. The store, founded in 1826 and reputed to be the oldest in the country, "turned itself inside out" to pay tribute to its oldest employe in terms of service.

Federal Judge Harold R. Medina yesterday put off the Communist trial until tomorrow after Harry Sacher, attorney for Irving Potash, one of the defendants, asked for the delay. Mr. Sacher said his client needed the time to recover from an injury he received last Sunday on the way home from Paul Robeson's concert near Peekskill.
HONOLULU, Sept. 6 -- The Navy's Philippine Mars settled to a safe landing today three hours after an engine fell off and set fire to the wing of the giant flying boat 440 miles out in the Pacific.
Forstmann Woolen Company has established an Australian subsidiary to buy its wool requirements in that country, it was announced yesterday by Curt E. Forstmann, president and chairman of the board.

The Braves were no match for Don Newcombe and the Dodgers last night at Ebbets Field, where the question before the house was not "Will the Braves win?" but "Will they score?" Newcombe started the game with three straight shut-outs and thirty and one-third consecutive scoreless innings behind him and was in a position to tie the all-time National League record via another whitewash.
CAMDEN, N. J., Sept. 6 -- The twelve killed and four wounded today by Howard B. Unruh were:

Twenty-one years ago Mae West first unveiled her portrait of a Bowery coquette with a heart of gold in "Diamond Lil," at Forty-fifth Street's Royale Theatre. Tonight, at the Plymouth, which is adjacent to the Royale, the author-star will reopen in her play, the run of which had to be interrupted last winter at the Coronet because she suffered a triple fracture of her left ankle.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 (AP) -- A former aide to Senator McCarthy, Republican, of Wisconsin, denied today that John Maragon had any official connection with a party given for Senator McCarthy when he took office in 1947.
STRASBOURG, France, Sept. 6 (AP) -- The European Consultative Assembly decided today to consider establishment of a European university at its next session in 1950.
NUREMBERG, Germany, Sept. 6 (AP) -- Defense forces took a theoretical beating today in the first United States maneuvers in Europe under a joint command.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 (AP) -- Robert M. Hanes, now chief of the Marshall Plan mission to Belgium, today was designated Director of Economic Affairs for Germany and chief of the Economic Cooperation Administration mission at Frankfort.

BERLIN, Sept. 6 -- In response to an announcement from United States headquarters that two United States nationals held by the Soviet since July 30 would be released today, Allied and German correspondents from Berlin and a motorcade of Military Police from Brunswick burned up the Autobahn to Helmstedt and spent several hours in a futile wait.

NEWARK, N. J., Sept. 6 -- The Rev. James Raile, 56-year-old German instructor in the high school at Boston College, was killed this morning when a car in which he was a passenger crashed into the rear of a trailer on Route 25, near the airport here.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 -- The York County Gas Company, York, Pa., received permission today from the Securities and Exchange Commission to sell $400,000 of first mortgage bonds, 3 3/8 per cent series, due in 1979, to the Travelers Insurance Company and to sell an additional 6,000 common shares of stock, $20 par value, at $50 a share.

Getting the lead a few strides away from the starting gate and holding it, Burton D. Chait's Sky Miracle captured the Stony Brook Handicap at Aqueduct yesterday. With Hedley J. Woodhouse rating the 3-year-old son of Teddy's Comet astutely, Sky Miracle crossed the finish line a full length ahead of Mrs. Ethel D. Jacobs' Our John Win.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 6 -- Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer has signed Richard Carlson for one of the leading male roles in "King Solomon's Mines," with Deborah Kerr and Stewart Granger, the studio announced today. The picture will be produced in Africa, with Compton Bennett directing, starting next month.
SYRACUSE, N. Y., Sept. 6 (AP) -- Cooler weather, and visions of another traffic jam, cut the attendance at the State Fair today to a fraction of yesterday's record invasion.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Sept. 6 -- To make room for Czechoslovakia's growing prison population, Roman Catholic Church sources charged today, Communist authorities are threatening to confiscate the buildings and lands of one order of nuns and have demanded, on twenty-four hours' notice, a five-year lease on the property of another order of nuns in Prague.

Major party candidates for county offices in the New York suburban area were nominated in primaries yesterday without opposition. There were a few contests for city offices in Yonkers and New Rochelle in Westchester County, and at Long Beach in Nassau County. Local rivalries for places on county committees in Westchester and Suffolk Counties provided the only other contests.

HELSINKI, Finland, Sept. 6 (AP) -- A delegates' meeting of the 330,000-man Trade Union Federation ordered its executive committee to examine relations with the World Federation of Trade Unions and report on whether the Finnish group was justified in remaining in that Communist-led world organization.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange became more active yesterday and closed firm, with gains of 12 to 26 points.

Veteran players dominated every major department of action in the first two weeks of the All-America Football Conference season, according to official figures announced yesterday. Otto Graham, Cleveland Browns, who tied for the forward passing title in 1946 and won it outright the next two years, got off to a record - matching twenty-seven completions in forty attempts and a record-equaling showing of four touchdown aerials.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, chairman of the United Nations Commission on Human Rights, warned last night that the "United States can't take as much time as many people thought we once might regarding our domestic problems." She included in this category race issues.
BUFFALO, Sept. 6 (AP) -- Norman Thomas said today that America now was geared to a war economy.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 6 -- It is evident from an analysis of Marshal Tito's remarks to this correspondent yesterday, from discussions with other Yugoslav leaders and from study of recent ideological journalism here that Yugoslavia's break with the Communist Information Bureau states has reached the ideological core of socialism.

Warren Lee Pierson, chairman of the board of Transcontinental and Western Air, Inc., announced from Rome yesterday that TWA would sign a memorandum of agreement with the Port of New York Authority to work out leases for the use of New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens.
The E. H. Harriman Memorial Gold Medal for the best safety record in 1948 of the Class A carriers has been awarded to the Chicago, Burlington Quincy Railroad Company, it was announced here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 -- The Administration's Senate forces intend to bring the foreign military aid bill out of committee by the middle of next week, and will oppose any further basic compromise anywhere.

LONDON, Sept. 6 -- A slight relaxation of Britain's rigid import restrictions to stimulate trade among the countries sharing Marshall Plan aid may be expected to follow the Washington talks on the sterling area's dollar shortage.

BANGOR, Me., Sept. 6 (AP) -- Directors have approved a refinancing plan for $12,265,000 in bonds of the Bangor Aroostook Railroad, Curtis M. Hutchins, president of the road, said today. Involved were $8,665,000 in the road's consolidated refunding mortgage bonds and $3,600,000 in its issue of collateral trust bonds.

ITHACA, N. Y., Sept. 6 (AP) -Cornell University has a remarkable new school of nutrition. It analyzes the blood of entire communities to learn what food does for their health. It goes into homes to find out what quickfreeze units do for dinner tables, pocketbooks and social life.

One curious feature of the dollar talks beginning today in Washington is that the British public, according to all reports, is not greatly interested in them. Britain is represented as facing bankruptcy unless these talks produce quick results in easing the dollar shortage. British living standards will sink to a new low, it is predicted, if the drain cannot be stopped at once.

CAMDEN, N. J., Sept. 6 -- Howard B. Unruh, 28 years old, a mild, soft-spoken veteran of many armored artillery battles in Italy, France, Austria, Belgium and Germany, killed twelve persons with a war souvenir Luger pistol in his home block in East Camden this morning.
PIRAEUS, Greece, Sept. 6 (AP) -- A court-martial tonight sentenced ten wealthy Piraeus importers to death on charges of financing the Communist organization in Piraeus -- the port for Athens.
LA PAZ, Bolivia, Sept. 6 (AP) -- The rebel radio at Santa Cruz announced today that a rebel government headed by Victor Paz Estenssoro as President had been appointed.

CORUNNA, Spain, Sept 6 (UP) -- Spanish and Arabian quarters are annoyed because British authorities let King Abdullah of Jordan come on his visit to Spain in an ordinary passenger-freight steamship instead of sending him on a warship, it was understood tonight. The resentment was disclosed today at a luncheon that Premier Francisco Franco gave Abdullah.

LAKE SUCCESS, Sept. 6 -- Two weeks of discussion on a dispassionate level rarely attained in an international parley ended here today with a new emphasis on the precarious relationship between man and his environment stated by experts at the United Nations Scientific Conference on the Conservation and Utilization of Resources.
An additional justice is needed in the Domestic Relations Court because of a sharp rise in the number of new cases, Mayor O'Dwyer has been informed by a majority of its seventeen justices.
CHICAGO, Sept. 6 (AP) -- Star Reward, owned by Charles T. Fisher of Detroit, set a new track mark today in winning the $12,000 Inaugural Handicap on opening day at Hawthorne.

The Hattie Carnegie collection for fall and winter has contrived to establish a silhouette of elegance in which a dress of sheathlike slimness at the front has controlled fullness at the back. The flattery of this line was evident in the custom-made collection shown in the Carnegie salon at 42 East Fortyninth Street yesterday afternoon.

A closer integration of the campaigns of Mayor O'Dwyer and former Governor Herbert H. Lehman was indicated last night as the Mayor conferred with Mr. Lehman at the latter's apartment at 820 Park Avenue.

NEWARK, N. J., Sept. 6 -- The women tenants in more than a score of houses owned by the late Wilbur B. Drivers wealthy wire manufacturer of East Orange who died last Aug. 23, will inherit title to the properties under terms of Mr. Driver's will, which was probated this morning in the office of the Essex County Surrogate.

Mrs. Mack A. Schwartzberg of 1168 East Twenty-first Street, Brooklyn, was robbed yesterday of a five-carat diamond ring valued at $5,000 and $100 in money by a lone bandit who forced his way into her car as it was halted for a red light at Ocean Avenue and Avenue K.

Montauk is continuing to produce surprises for the anglers, and word was received yesterday that a 124 3/4 - pound white marlin, a new women's record, was brought in by Mrs. George Fechtman of New York.
HONG KONG, Sept. 6 -- Gen. Lu Han, Governor of Yunnan, has decided to talk over his differences with the National Government.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 6 -- Federal Judge George B. Harris granted today a temporary order restraining the International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union, CIO, from interfering with the loading and sailing of Hawaii-bound ships of the Matson Navigation Company.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 -- On the eve of the Tripartite Ministers Conference the United States Government was hopefully determined today to promote a solution of Britain's external financial crisis, but had neither a plan nor program for easing the emergency dollar shortage in the sterling area.

The two-story taxpayer building at 2220-26 Broadway, northeast corner of West Seventy - ninth Street, which is under net lease to the F. W. Woolworth Company for twenty-one years at an aggregate rental of about $900,000, has been sold by a client of the A. F. Roe Company of Jersey City, N. J., to Frederick Brown, the operator, it was announced yesterday.
DOVER, England, Sept. 6 -- Exhausted and hysterical, Shirley May France was hauled from the water six miles from her Dover goal today, ending a plucky but vain attempt to swim the English Channel.
BRONXVILLE, N. Y., Sept. 6 -A good deal of the honors in the Westchester P.G.A. pro-amateur tournament today at the Siwanoy Country Club went to representatives of the Fenway Golf Club.

In the financial section of your paper of Aug. 29 Edward H. Collins, writing on Britain's dollar export gaps, ends up his article with the quotation: "England's history is rich with episodes of improvidence, but this crowns them all," the reference being to the recently concluded Indo-British sterling agreement.
Bogus travelers checks with a face value of $125,000 have been passed by counterfeiters within the last two weeks, the American Express Company disclosed yesterday.

PARIS, Sept. 6 -- Despite denials made in New York by Maurice Petsche, Finance Minister, and in official quarters here of any loan of private capital to France, informed circles here tonight expressed belief that there was a move afoot for French-American cooperation in developing France's African colonies.
The city of Waterloo, Iowa, announced yesterday that bids will be received on Sept. 20 on an issue of $5,000,000 of independent school district bonds due from May 1, 1951 to 1969.

UTRECHT, the Netherlands, Sept. 6 -- The Netherland Government launched today a new export drive by which it hopes to treble the country's present earnings of $30,000,000 annually by the time Marshall Plan aid ends in 1952.

A "dead ship" -- the Sir John Franklin -- is the result of the controversy between the Marine Engineers Beneficial Association, CIO, and the Isbrandtsen Company, Inc., as the latter yesterday completed paying off the crew. The vessel is now idle at her Staten Island pier with only a watchman aboard.

Retailers throughout the country are in an open-to-buy position for 75 per cent of their towel requirements for the balance of the year, according to the textile survey made by Dun Bradstreet for the Association of Cotton Textile Merchants of New York.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Sept. 6 -- Fifty-two youthful contestants for the 1949 Miss America beauty crown made their public debut in a colorful parade on this resort's famous Boardwalk this afternoon before a nestimated 250,000 spectators.

The fateful Washington conference on Britain's dollar gap is to begin today. There has been much ill-natured, ill-advised and ill-informed criticism of the Labor Government which has been in power since the end of the war, and it is well for both sides that the worst of the storm has blown over.

BRIDLINGTON, England, Sept. 6 -- A notable weakening of Communist influence in the British Trades Union Congress was recorded here today. By 6,746,000 votes to 760,000, the eighty-first annual meeting of the congress endorsed the TUC General Council's campaign against Communist interference in the affairs of its affiliated trade unions.

Brooklyn College and the National Broadcasting Company will cooperate during the academic year in presenting a series of radio-assisted home study courses in literature for a nation-wide audience. The first course, "Reading For Pleasure," beginning Oct. 2, will be based on the "NBC University Theatre" broadcast Sunday afternoons from 2 to 3 o'clock.

The Long Island Rail Road's "Main Line" stations presented a quiet, undisturbed scene, yesterday morning. It was Tuesday, again, and again the 7:52 A. M., out of Greenport by way of Southold, Peconic, Cutchogue, Mattituck, Yaphank and other stops, was late.

The fight between Vito Marcantonio and Eugene P. Connolly for control of the American Labor party in Manhattan was resolved in Representative Marcantonio's favor in yesterday's primary election. Mr. Marcantonio's candidate for Borough President of Manhattan, Ewart Guinier, easily defeated Mr. Connolly, seeking the party's nomination for the post.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 -- Maj. Gen. Alfred M. Gruenther is soon to be appointed Deputy Chief of Staff for Plans and Combat Operations, one of the Army's half-dozen most important positions, it was learned today.
The Buffalo Bisons, who last night clinched the International League pennant, placed only one man on the circuit's 1949 all-star team, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 -- About 44 per cent of the veterans of World War II, approximately 6,600,000, have taken some form of educational courses under the Government benefit program, the Veterans Administration announced today in a compilation covering the period to last June 30.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 -- The Brookings Institution has launched an all-inclusive medical service survey that will require at least two years.

LAKE SUCCESS, Sept. 6 -- One of the most important functions of the United Nations in the future will be to further the spread of technical information to undeveloped regions of the world, according to speakers at the closing sessions of the United Nations Scientific Conference on the Conservation and Utilization of Resources here today.

The most amazing letter appeared in your columns, written by John F. Victory, in which he compares traffic control in New York with that in Washington, to the former's disparagement. As one who drove around New York City for ten years, and am now bucking Washington's traffic, it is inconceivable how any person can make such statements.

A record of low-damage claims on air-freight shipments, despite a minimum of packaging, was disclosed yesterday by Seaboard and Western Airlines, Inc. Seaboard officials said the low-claims rate was an index to the practicability of this country's infant "merchant marine of the air" as a general freight-carrier service, rather than an emergency, or express operation.
Two additional deaths from polio in Brooklyn have raised the total to 143 in the city so far this year, as compared with twenty-seven for all of last year, the Health Department announced yesterday.
Eighteen baseball players from Boys' Town, Neb., who call themselves the "Dodgers," arrived by plane yesterday to play against a team of New York orphans.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 6 -- The complicated and often tangled fields of human rights and international crime in a post-war world and the best methods of achieving a permanent peace were discussed today at the annual meeting of the American Bar Association.

ROME, Sept. 6 -- The Cabinet, in its first meeting today after the summer holidays, decided to pay an "active service bonus" to officers and men participating in the campaign against the Sicilian bandit, Salvatore Giuliano and his gang.

The open letter written to Mayor O'Dwyer and Newbold Morris by Paul Windels, lawyer, former city Corporation Counsel, and perpetual gadfly on transit deficiencies, asks some searching questions that demand frank answers from the candidates for Mayor. Mr. Windels wants to know what transit plans the candidates have for the future.

The ninetieth birthday of Dr. John Dewey, philosopher and Professor Emeritus of Philosophy at Columbia University, on Oct. 20 will be celebrated by a series of dinners and conferences and by the issuance of several anniversary publications, it was announced yesterday.

In a sharp reversal of August trends, durable goods purchasing by large industrial interests has increased, according to purchasing agents for New York companies yesterday. Increased inquiries were noted for machine tools, industrial construction and steel products.

Transcontinental Western Air, Inc., and Eastern Air Lines, Inc., which have occupied space in the Airlines Terminal Building at Park Avenue and East Forty-second Street since 1940, yesterday leased different space in the same structure from Webb Knapp, Inc.

DENVER, Sept. 6 -- Thousands of teachers, by creating tension in their classrooms, are increasing maladjustment in children, it was charged today by Dr. D. S. Arbuckle, Boston University psychologist.
INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 6 (AP) -- Lusty Song, owned by Hayes Fair Acres Stables, DuQuoin, Ill., today set a new 2-year-old trotters' world race record at 2:02 1/5.

Unification of the public information services of the Armed Forces in the New York area became a physical reality yesterday when the Third Naval District Public Information office moved furniture into space allotted to it at the First Army Public Information section at 90 Church Street.

The Socony-Vacuum Oil Company, Inc., announced yesterday an advance in the price of home heating oil and kerosene throughout New York and New England, effective today. The advance, the second in two weeks, ranges from one-tenth to eight-tenths of a cent a gallon in home heating oil and from one-tenth to six-tenths of a cent in kerosene.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 (AP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board today announced the rules under which it would permit scheduled air lines to continue low-cost "air coach" services.

A MANIFESTO-HAUNTED generation or so has passed the what-must-we-do-to-be-saved reviewing stand since young John Strachey wrote "The Coming Struggle for Power" and young John Chamberlain wrote "A Farewell to Reform," but the lavish fields for desirable reform still spread, and the struggle for power goes on.

Advertising in the eight major New York newspapers during the first eight months of 1949 totaled 97,510,200 lines, a gain of 3.84 per cent over a year ago, analysis of media records showed yesterday. Categories recording gains were: Automotive, 46.47 per cent; general, 4.70 per cent, and retail, 4.29 per cent.

UTRECHT, The Netherlands, Sept. 7 -- An impressive recovery of the Netherland agricultural industry, with almost all branches having surpassed pre-war levels of production, was reported today during ceremonies acknowledging that Marshall Plan aid had made the recovery possible.

TRIESTE, Sept. 7 -- Although Yugoslavia's foreign policy has shifted markedly during the past year as a result of the Soviet Union's and its satellites' attitude, the full extent of this new orientation cannot be gauged until Moscow replies to Belgrade's diplomatic note of Aug. 23.
LONDON, Sept. 7 -- Yehudi Menuhin has been spared the embarrassment of breaking a contract to play on Yom Kippur, the Day of Atonement, most sacred day in the Jewish calendar.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 7 (UP) -- Mrs. Iva Toguri D'Aquino, Japan's wartime Tokyo Rose, testified at her treason trial today that she missed the last boat out of Japan before the sneak attack on Pearl Harbor because the United States consul failed to have her passport ready.

CANBERRA, Australia, Sept. -- Prime Minister Joseph B. Chiefley, presenting the budget in the House of Representatives today, announced that in view of the further contribution that Britain would make to European revival this year, "and to assist her in her own great effort," the Australian Government would make a further gift of 10,000,000 Australian pounds [about $32,240,000] to the British Government.

Two issues in addition to that of wages were presented yesterday by the International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union, CIO, as matters that must be settled to end the 130-day-old Hawaiian longshoremn's strike.
TRENTON, N. J., Sept. 7 (AP) -- A test of the validity of the New Jersey Turnpike Authority act came before Superior Court Judge Ralph J. Smalley today. The judge reserved decision.

BONN, Germany, Sept. 7 -- The two houses of the Federal Republic of Germany were constituted officially today as the parliamentary successor to the German republic snuffed out by Hitler sixteen years ago. The ceremonies were meant to be mere formalities but the Germans immediately disclosed their unremitting opposition to the Allied reparations policy, which calls for dismantling their war industries and the stabilization of their economic potential with that of the rest of Europe.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 -- Two admirals today flatly contradicted the sworn testimony of Dan A. Kimball, Under-Secretary of the Navy, that he took steps to investigate a "smear" campaign against the Air Force.

The first annual convention of the Paralyzed Veterans of America to be held outside a Veterans Administration hospital opened yesterday at the New Yorker Hotel with fourteen paraplegic delegates representing 1,600 members from all sections of the country.
WARM SPRINGS, Ga., Sept. 7 -- (AP) Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt spent an hour in the "Little White House" today where her husband died here on April 12, 1945.

ROME, Sept. 7 -- The cabinet council today noted with satisfaction the favorable development of the Italian unemployment situation. From a post-war maximum of 2,421,973 on May 31, 1948, unemployed dropped in fourteen months to 1,787,321 on July 31, 1949.

HONG KONG, Sept. 7 -- A United States Army officer has been named for liaison duty at headquarters of British defense forces here. He is Maj. William Saunders and he will serve virtually as a member of the staff of Lieut. Gen. F. W. Festing, British Commander in Chief.

NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 7 -- With the return of Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru from Bombay yesterday after conferring with Sardar Vallabhbhai Patel, Deputy Prime Minister, the Indian Cabinet is understood to be considering a draft reply to President Truman and Prime Minister Attlee on the Kashmir dispute.

The two-week flying visit to the United States by fifty leading publishers, editors and writers from fourteen countries will give our European colleagues an opportunity to freshen and strengthen their understanding of our country and its people. As they stop in several American cities and talk with government officials, business men and our newspaper men they will also be bearers of better understanding of the problems in their own countries.

Although the summer season on the citronella circuit is supposed to be only a memory at this date, a number of houses will continue to operate a while longer. Bills announced for next week, in addition to those reported yesterday, follow:

In tune with the autumnal chill yesterday, the Tailored Woman offered a collection of fall costumes for town, country and after dark. Tweeds and jerseys for casual wear opened the show at the St. Regis Hotel's roof garden.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 7 (AP) -- Miss Doris Hart, No. 2 player on the United States team from Miami, Fla., and Mrs. Jean Walker-Smith, Great Britain's second ranking star, will open play in the Wightman Cup tennis series Friday.

Cash reserves held by American farmers are sufficient to retire all farm debt, despite the millions of dollars spent for improvements, soil conservation and new equipment since the war's end, the American Bankers Association reported yesterday.

PAWTUCKET, R. I., Sept. 7 (AP) -- Mrs. Sam Orr's U. S. Bound, ridden by Darrell Madden, scored his second straight victory by capturing the featured six-furlong event today from Lady Carrie before 9,424 at Narragansett Park. The victor was timed in 1:12 2/5.
LAKE SUCCESS, Sept. 7 -- In the shortest United Nations ceremony on record, the United States today deposited a copy of the North Atlantic Treaty with the world organization.

Recent testimony before the House Judiciary subcommittee, which is presently conducting investigations on monopoly practices, reveals the mature concern of those familiar with the problem about the question of "bigness." The question that seeks resolution is: "Is bigness per se undesirable in the economic, political and social sense?"

BOSTON, Sept. 7 (UP) -- A Dallas debutante was killed and her escort was critically injured when they fell backward to the promenade deck of the Excalibur while climbing a stairway at 4:30 A. M. Saturday, Capt. Samuel Norman Groves reported tonight.

BUFFALO, N. Y., Sept. 7 (AP) -- In another outbreak of violence in the thirteen-week-old Bell Aircraft strike today, six persons, among them five employes reporting for work, were injured at the plant, in near-by Wheatfield.

Dr. Nahum Goldman, chairman of the American section of the Jewish Agency for Palestine, and Dr. Israel Goldstein, former treasurer, said yesterday that Israel is in imperative need of American "know-how" to develop its economic potentialities.

CHICAGO, Sept. 7 -- Wheat turned reactionary in the late trading on the Board of Trade today while corn continued to show a strong undertone. December wheat sold at a new high since late last July at one time, while the July future, representing the 1950 crop, went to a new seasonal low.

SHRUB OAK, N. Y., Sept. 7 -- City College's football team opened ten days of intensive pre-season training today when a forty-one-man contingent of coaches and players arrived from New York and immediately engaged in a two-hour fundamentals drill.

LONDON, Sept. 7 -- Conditions were quiet in the stock markets here today for the opening of the new account. Buyers were waiting cautiously for some trend to emerge from the American-British-Canadian financial talks in Washington.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Aug. 31, the Federal Reserve Board reported today:

The number of workers seeking unemployment benefits in this state has dropped nearly 20 per cent since mid-July, according to figures made public yesterday by Edward Corsi, State Industrial Commissioner. He reported that 471,659 persons had filed applications for unemployment insurance and veterans' readjustment allowances last week, a decline of 113,039 from the record total of 584,689 in the week ended July 15.

BRIDLINGTON, England, Sept. 7 -- Speaking on the opening day of the Anglo-American-Canadian financial talks in Washington, Prime Minister Atltee declared today that while the disbalance of trade between the sterling and dollar areas was an international problem, the British people would do their utmost to make the fullest contribution to its solution.

The Coast Guard suspended for one year yesterday the master's license of Capt. Frederic Sundlof, who commanded the American tanker Chrysanthystar when it collided with and sank the British trawler Energetic off the English coast in June, 1948.

PARIS, Sept. 7 -- Innovations intended to expand trade and encourage competition among European nations are contained in the intra-European payments agreement signed by the Marshall Plan countries here today. The accord provides for European creditor countries to offer facilities to their debtors in return for greater dollar aid.
Following is the text of the speech of Newbold Morris, Republican-Liberal-Fusion candidate for Mayor, opening his campaign last night:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 -- Senator John Foster Dulles announced today that he would "gladly" run for election to the Senate seat he now holds by appointment, if the New York State Republican organization, "knowing my views," should nominate him.

After ten years of puzzling over each other's thoughts and special language, a group of scientists, theologians and philosophers agreed yesterday that they understood one another sufficiently to tackle together a problem common to all. They chose to apply themselves constructively to the founding of a world organization.

WELLINGTON, New Zealand, Sept. 6 (Reuters) -- The national executive committee of the New Zealand Waterside Workers Union today lifted its "black ban" on the 7,132-ton Canadian ship Tridale, tied up here since April 18, and on the 7,164-ton Ottawa Valley, anchored in Auckland for the last eight weeks.

District Attorney George M. Fanelli of Westchester County, who headed the law enforcement agencies at last Sunday's affray outside of Peekskill, following a concert by Paul Robeson, contended yesterday in a formal report to Governor Dewey that the police and others concerned with law and order should be commended rather than censured for their part in the affair.

Gen. Lucius D. Clay, former United States Military Governor in Germany, yesterday expressed utmost confidence in the soundness of American business following his first attendance at a meeting of the directors of the Marine Midland Trust Company of New York.

CHICAGO, Sept. 7 -- Wage increases that will cost the publicly owned Chicago Transit Authority about $4,500,000 during the current contract year were agreed on today for more than 22,000 CTA employes, and Ralph Budd, CTA board chairman, forecast a fare increase to cover the wage rise and other increased operating costs.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 7 (AP) -- A burning building erupted in downtown Philadelphia today, hurling bricks and chunks of flaming wood for three blocks and setting off fifteen different fires.
Women in Israel do not possess equal status with men, Mrs. Israel Goldstein, president of Pioneer Women, the Women's Labor Organization of America, said here yesterday.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Sept. 7 -- United States Ambassador Joseph E. Jacobs today accused the Czechoslovak Government of taking "undue advantage" of the frontier incident in which twenty-two Czechoslovak soldiers and a boy were apprehended by the United States Constabulary in order to publicize a "note in which the facts and importance of the incident have been exaggerated for distorted propaganda purposes."

Consideration of the resumption of futures trading in tin was deferred indefinitely by the Metals Group of the Commodity Exchange at a meeting here yesterday. Discussion of tin trading at the committee's meeting was informal and followed the disposal of regular business.

Formation of a new investment business to deal primarily in United States Government, state and municipal securities, and to be capitalized initially with $1,400,000 was announced yesterday by Aubrey G. Lanston, money market specialist who until recently was associated with First Boston Corporation as a director and executive officer.

Election of John F. Gehan as executive vice president of American Export Lines, Inc., and promotion of seven other veteran officials of the steamship company was announced yesterday by John E. Slater, the president. Mr. Slater was executive vice president when W. H. Coverdale, the former president, died last month.

A cornerstone-laying ceremony for the new Community and School House of Temple Beth-el of Rockaway Park will be held at Beach 135th Street and Cronston Avenue, Rockaway Park, Queens, at 10 A. M. Sunday.

Members of the Foreign Credit Interchange Bureau approved a resolution yesterday calling on the Economic Cooperation Administration to change its system of disclosing private information on foreign traders. The action was transactions handled by American foreign traders. The action was taken at a round-table discussion attended by banking and trade executives in the Statler Hotel.

LAKE SUCCESS, Sept 7 -- Latin-American countries north of the Panama Canal still can be considered virgin territory for industrialization, Dr. Robert S. Aries, consulting chemical engineer and a delegate to the United Nations Scientific Conference on the Conservation and Utilization of Resources, said here today.

The American heritage is a thing of the spirit, but it has its material symbols: sites where battles were fought or men gathered in the name of liberty, or westward-bound travelers paused before plunging into the wilderness; houses where renowned figures in our history were born or lived, buildings made memorable by those who met within their walls.

The Jewish Statistical Bureau announced yesterday that it had mailed questionnaries to 4,500 rabbis in the United States and Canada for the collection of statistics for the first complete Jewish Directory.

Fifty-one Army, Navy and Air Force stations all over the country and overseas will begin to close down next week in the first of a series of measures which, it is hoped, will reduce defense costs by a billion or more over the course of the next year or so.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 -- Following are the texts of statements made today by Joan W. Snyder, United States Secretary of the Treasury; Sir Stafford Cripps, British Chancellor of the Exchequer, and Douglas C. Abbott, Canadian Finance Minister, as they opened their conference on Britain's economic crisis:

A rally was negotiated yesterday morning by the stock market and the advance left the composite rate higher by 0.68 point. Although the forward movement halted in the afternoon when buying diminished, most quotations held at the best marks of the session.

Re-examination of costs involving premium payment for fabric and overtime labor is necessary for coat and suit manufacturers, according to the Merchants Ladies Garment Association, Inc. In a bulletin to members, Joseph L. Dubow, executive director, pointed out that the retailers' demand for quick delivery following a period during the summer when thy were inclined to underbuy has changed the picture in regard to calculating cost of manufacturing and margin of profit.

ALBANY, Sept. 7 -- Governor Dewey, commenting upon the decision of Senator John Foster Dulles to accept the Republican nomination for United States Senator, said today that his election would advance the cause of world peace.

JERSEY CITY, Sept. 7 -- Joe DiMaggio, Yankee center-fielder, sold football tickets from a stand in Journal Square, Jersey City, for half an hour today to help raise $10,000 for the Polio Clinic of the Sister Kenny Foundation in the Medical Center, Jersey City.

MUNICH, Germany, Sept. 7 -- Hundreds of ill, crippled and curious Germans have been keeping a day and night vigil in front of a Munich restaurant waiting for the arrival of Bruno Groening, the "miracle healer" of Bavaria. Herr Groening, number one subject in the Bavarian press, has been credited with numerous "miracle cures," including that of a United States Military Government official.

LONDON, Sept. 7 -- Sir Stafford Cripps, Chancellor of the Exchequer, went to Washington it was learned today, armed with evidence to challenge the American contention that British prices are too high.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 -- President Truman received a gift of forty-eight neckties today -- one for every occasion, according to the donors -- but it is safe to say that he will never wear some of them.
