More than $400,000 has been spent for American machinery for use in a tropical fruit-canning factory with a capacity of more than 20,000 pounds of products a day in Ciudad Trujillo, the capital of the Dominican Republic, it was announced here yesterday.

The Cuban Atlantic Sugar Company declared yesterday an extra dividend of 25 cents in addition to the regular quarterly of 50 cents payable to common stockholders on Oct. 1. This brings the total for the fiscal year ending Sept. 30 to $2.25, compared with $3 distributed in the previous year.

Mayor O'Dwyer declared yesterday that he was opposed to any zoning change that would permit the construction of a commercial building in the Yellowstone Oval area in Forest Hills, Queens, where the Bulova Watch Company planned to erect a modern watch factory.
ALBANY, Sept. 7 -- The text of District Attorney George M. Fanelli's report to Governor Dewey follows:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 -- In an atmosphere of economic and political realism, the Tripartite Conference of Ministers for the United States, Great Britain and Canada was opened by Secretary of the Treasury John W. Snyder today with a pledge of this Government's every effort to solve Britain's financial troubles "within the framework of our existing foreign economic policy."

About 1,000 securities dealers all over the nation will take time out today and tomorrow to see the same moving picture -- a forty-minute sound and color film signalizing the offering of 835,000 common shares of the Rochester Gas and Electric Company to stockholders of the General Public Utilities Corporation, which is divesting itself of the stock.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 -- Closely associating the United States trade program with Great Britain's economic crisis, Senator Walter F. George, Democrat, of Georgia, warned the Senate today as it began debate of the controversial reciprocal trade agreements bill that "if Britain goes down, we'll go down, too, in a matter of months."

LONDON, Sept. 7 (UP) -- Moscow broadcast alleged tonight that Greece and Yugoslavia, by a coordinated campaign of border violations, threatened the independence of Albania and demanded that the United Nations take action.

EAST ORANGE, N. J., Sept. 7 -- Mayor Charles H. Martens cut a tape at 10 A. M. today to open the expanded Oppenheim Collins store here at 538 Central Avenue. Northern New Jersey suburban shoppers filled the modernized women's and children's wear store throughout the day.
JERSEY CITY, N. J., Sept. (AP) -- Jersey City captured both ends of its double-header with Newark's Bears tonight, taking the opener by 2 -- 0 and the nightcap by 3 -- 0 before 2,000.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 (AP) -- The Air Force today announced the retirement of Maj. Gen. Albert F. Hegenberger, expert on atomic energy and chief of the Air Force's special-weapons group.

James J. Murphy, Democratic Representative from Staten Island and member of the House Merchant Marine and Fisheries Committee, sailed on the French liner Ile de France yesterday to survey, with other members of Congress who will depart later, European shipbuilding and repair facilities and their possible aid to this country in the event of another war.

Sir Stafford Cripps, asked on his arrival here about the prospects for devaluation of the pound sterling, told newsmen that he would stand on his recent statement in the House of Commons. At that time he declared his firm opposition to such a course. Meanwhile, American fiscal officials are reported to hold the view that devaluation is a necessary prerequisite to any constructive action by this country.

Charging that the Borough of Brooklyn is controlled by a political machine more powerful, arrogant and corruptible than Tammany Hall at its worst, Abe Stark, Republican and Liberal party candidate for Borough President, last night again called upon his opponent, Borough President John Cashmore, to resign as Democratic leader of Kings County.

An increase in attendance of about 10 per cent over last year marked the opening yesterday, at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, of the largest national leather show ever staged by the industry. Eighty-seven members of the Tanners Council of America, Inc., participated with exhibits.

The international executive board of the Transport Workers Union, CIO, cracked down yesterday on an insurgent local representing 2,000 employes of Pan-American Airways in Miami but even as the board was acting a new revolt broke out in a sister local here.

Two new films will open in midtown theatres this morning. At the Radio City Music Hall the attraction is "Under Capricorn," starring Ingrid Bergman, Joseph Cotten and Michael Wilding. Filmed in England, the Transatlantic Pictures production was directed by Alfred Hitchcock for Warner Brothers release.

It became official yesterday that Maurice Evans will manage the artistic affairs of the New York City Center of Music and Drama for the forthcoming season. He will serve as the civic playhouse's managing director, a post which has been held by Jose Ferrer since Jan. 8, 1948.
Investment buying of residential properties over a wide area featured realty activity in Manhattan yesterday.

MONTREAL, Sept. 7 (UP) -- A chemical discovery that may reduce North America's dependence on imports of manganese, the mineral used to strengthen and toughen iron and steel, was reported today. Richard D. Hoak, senior fellow of Mellon Institute, Pittsburgh, told the regional conference of the American Institute of Chemical Engineers that manganese can be economically recovered from low-grade ores.

In a significant step designed to reach a vast untapped market for low-priced homes, the United States Steel Corporation announced yesterday that it would enter the mass housing field on a nationwide basis.

The National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis and other groups, as well as family physicians, have advised parents to keep their children out of crowds and away from new acquaintances during the present polio epidemic.

A few minutes afeer a young angler had left, complaining that he had fished the surf for two seasons without getting so much as a look at a striped bass, a call was received from Sandy Hook reporting that one caster had hooked twenty-nine bass yesterday, losing all but four.
LAKE SUCCESS, Sept. 7 -- An "action program" to meet problems in world economic affairs was submitted today by the International Chamber of Commerce to the United Nations.

Five tenants of 41 Washington Square South filed suit in Supreme Court yesterday to halt further demolition of the adjacent building at No. 40, contending that its piecemeal removal constituted a threat to their safety. The buildings are being razed to make way for New York University's proposed $3,000,000 law center.

An experimental asphalt, containing a new rubber compound to make road surfaces more durable, provide a safer driving surface and reduce street maintenance costs, will be laid today in various busy thoroughfares in Manhattan. In case of rain the paving will be laid tomorrow.

TEANECK, N. J., Sept. 7 -- Warren Westphal, a veteran, considered himself lucky when this township provided him and his family with an apartment recently in the veterans' temporary housing development at 21 State Street here. But today he's questioning his luck.

When Paul Robeson scheduled a concert that was not a concert, and when certain citizens of a Westchester community set up a parade that was not a parade, the American people were left holding the bag. That is the lesson of the Peekskill riots.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 (AP) -- Following is the text of Senator John Foster Dulles' statement today announcing he would accept a New York State Republican nomination for a further term in the Senate:

A suit challenging the constitutionality of the Feinberg Law, which bars subversive persons from public school jobs in the state, will be filed here this week in the State Supreme Court by the New York Teachers Union, CIO, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 (AP) -- The United Gas Corporation, Shreveport, La., asked the Securities and Exchange Commission today to approve its purchase of securities of Carthage Hydrocol, Inc., which is building a plant near Brownsville, Tex., to produce gasoline from natural gas.

With John Foster Dulles as the Republican candidate and Herbert H. Lehman as the Democratic and Liberal candidate New York State is assured of first-class representation in the United States Senate for the balance of the unexpired Wagner term. We welcome Mr. Dulles' announcement yesterday that he will "gladly accept" the nomination if offered.

NEWCASTLE, England, Sept. 7 -- The meeting of the British Association for the Advancement of Science, that closed here today has proved to be one of the most successful in the 180 years of the association's history. As the president, Sir John Russell, said, any Briton who was feeling pessimistic about the vitality of the future of the country ought to be reassured by the performance of the scientists.

Maria Reining, Austrian soprano, will head a list of five foreign-born and eight American singers who are joining this season for the first time the New York City Opera Company. The announcement, made yesterday by Laszlo Halasz, artistic and music director, added the names of six former leading singers who return to the company after varying periods of absence.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 (AP) -- The Congress of Industrial Organizations today asked quick Senate action on a House-approved bill designed to prevent monopoly mergers of corporations.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Sept. 7 (AP) -- Brown Hotel Stable's Miss Highbrow qualified in good fashion for her impending engagement in the $10,000 added seashore Stakes on Sept. 17 when the Heliopolis filly romped to an easy two and one-half length victory in the featured Bridgeton Kiwanis Purse.

TRENTON, N. J., Sept. 7 -- Simon Cherivtch has admitted he stole sixteen chickens in 1935 and now is appealing a Federal income tax evasion conviction, but the New Jersey Superior Court ruled today he was still eligible to serve as a Millville City Commissioner.

Saying that he wanted very much to be Mayor, Newbold Morris, Republican-Liberal-Fusion candidate, opened his campaign last night by charging that William O'Dwyer, his Democratic opponent, had not been and could not be a good Mayor because of his peculiar mental and emotional make-up.

The advance of 1 3/4 cents an ounce in the price of silver over the past two weeks is attracting some attention in the trade. Until Aug. 23 the price of the metal had held unchanged at 71 3/4 cents an ounce since mid-February. The change in the trend has resulted largely from increased buying by the silverware industry, which is getting ready for the fall and Christmas buying.

FARNBOROUGH, England, Sept. 7 -- Britain went all out here today in a demonstration of her aircraft of every category, aircraft of today and tomorrow. The first conclusion that must be drawn is that the tight little isle is better prepared to fight another "Battle of Britain" if Russia should move than she was when Adolf Hitler struck.

So many of your correspondents' letters pertain to the depressing news of the day that it might be a relief to mention something a little less cheerless than communism, DP's, income taxes, labor unrest, poliomyelitis and Mr. Maragon.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Sept. 7 -- The opening day of the seventeenth annual five-day fall race week of the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club attracted 241 competitive craft today out in Old Cow Bay, the name of the old Long Island Sound filler that the charts record.

Germany made a fresh start yesterday with the opening of the Parliament of the Federal Republic. The Pedagogical Institute, one of the few whole buildings left of the shattered University of Bonn, was enlarged almost overnight to serve as the capitol of a people's government that comes to life again after sixteen years of dictatorship, war and military occupation.

The steel fact-finding report, which is expected to have a decisive effect on labor's campaign for a fourth-round wage increase, will be outlined informally to President Truman at the White House tomorrow by the three-man board the President named to head off a national steel strike.

MEXICO CITY, Sept. 7 -- Vicente Lombardo Toledano, head of the Latin-American Labor Federation, denied today that his purpose in assuming responsibility for organizing the Continental Congress for Peace, now in session, here, was to revive the Communist International in the Western Hemisphere.

As we remember it, Alice in Wonderland could see little point in a book without pictures. She would have approved, we think, of a new leaflet to come to us from Swift Co. It is "Your Guide to Meat Buying," with twenty-two pages containing no less than sixty photographs.

Sylvania Electric Products, Inc., yesterday entered the television receiver manufacturing field with the introduction of nine units to retail from $199.95 to $499.95. At the same time, Tele-tone Radio Corporation announced what it claims are record low prices for quality receivers when it offered a 10-inch table model for $149.95 and a 12 1/2-inch tube set for $199.95.
CLEVELAND, Sept. 7 -- Instructions to strike the Missouri Pacific Railroad at 2 P. M. tomorrow were being sent out from the headquarters of three operating railroad brotherhoods here tonight.
The tall, hatless man in the clerical collar and black suit seemed so much at home, as he strode swiftly along, that he unwittingly beguiled at least one of the East Sixth Street children.

Five hundred and thirty-five modern Prosperos from forty-nine nations have been meditating at Lake Success as members of the U. N. Scientific Conference on Conservation and Utilization of Resources. Their field of debate, like Prospero's, is nothing less than the planet.

Trustees of the Long Island Rail Road filed yesterday in the Federal Court, Brooklyn, a petition requesting permission to purchase eight new 2,000-horsepower Diesel-electric locomotives for use in passenger service on steam-operated lines. A hearing on the request will be held this morning before Judge Harold M. Kennedy.

PALO ALTO, Calif., Sept. 7 -- So-called "life adjustment education" was attacked today as "educational flapdoodle" by Dr. Henry G. Doyle of George Washington University in a report read at the annual meeting of the Modern Language Association of America.

LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., Sept. 7 -- Mrs. Harold M. Hunter and her son, Dick Hunter, of the North Hempstead Club, teamed to score a one-over-par 36, 36 -- 72, in the Women's Long Island Golf Association's family-string tournament at the Creek golf course, today.
LAKE SUCCESS, Sept. 7 -- The Himalayan Kingdom of Nepal was kept out of the United Nations today by the thirty-first veto registered by the Soviet Union.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Sept. 7 -- The executive board of the State Congress of Industrial Organizations laid the groundwork here today for its strategically important tenth annual convention by adopting a resolution of full support for all aspects of the Administration's foreign policy.

Automobile manufacturers should concentrate on improved steering mechanism rather than on showy design or minor luxury features, in the opinion of A. E. Ulmann, vice president of the Sports Car Club of America.

An increase in the 15-cent quarterly dividend of the Southern Company was indicated yesterday by E. A. Yates, president, during a luncheon meeting of the utility section of the New York Society of Security Analysts at Schwartz's Restaurant, 54 Broad Street.
Emerson D. Ogle, associated with SKF Industries, Inc., since 1937, has been appointed industrial sales department manager, succeeding C. D. Cummings, who recently resigned.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 7 -- Reports published here today said that delegations of Arab Palestine refugees had approached the Lebanese Premier asking that the Arab Governments boycott the United Nations Economic Survey Mission under Mr. Clapp on the ground that its real purpose was to arrange for refugee resettlement outside Palestine.
DENVER, Sept. 7 -- If another major depression occurs and America's free enterprise system falls, one of the main reasons will be industry's failure to solve its "acute" problems in human relations.

HONG KONG, Sept. 7 (UP) -- Reports reaching Hong Kong said today that South China guerrillas had split with regular Communist forces over inability of the irregulars to carry out orders and that as a result the Nationalists had won several important victories.

Crowned with delightful hats, when the costumes called for them, sparkling with the required jewelry and carrying smart bags, Bergdof Goodman's sleek models took their place in the fashion presentation of custom-made clothes exhibited, yesterday afternoon, in the newly decorated and arranged fourth floor salons.

CHICAGO, Sept. 7 (UP) -- Big Ten members who have agreed to televise their 1949 football games reported no drop in ticket sales thus far, but two were holding up final television agreements pending satisfactory ticket sales or higher bids for TV rights.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 7 -- The Belgrade District Court issued a ruling yesterday forbidding the sale and distribution of the current issue of the Yugoslav weekly Literary Gazette on the grounds that it had misinterpreted Yugoslav foreign policy.

DENVER, Sept. 7 -- More and more white Southerners are showing sympathy toward programs for improving the status of Negroes, Nelson C. Jackson, director of the Southern Field Division of the National Urban League, said here today at the league's annual convention.

The labor record of the Democratic-controlled Eighty-first Congress and the personal labor record of Mayor O'Dwyer were attacked last night by Representative Vito Marcantonio, American Labor party candidate for Mayor, in the first of a series of weekly campaign radio talks over WMCA.

A hand-screened print that combines the feeling of a medieval tapestry with the sketchy technique of contemporary fabric design is the highlight of the new collection designed by Harold Schwartz for Decorative Fabrics, Inc.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 7 (AP) -- Four sharp singles in the last of the ninth brought the Cardinals from behind to give them the necessary two runs for a 3-to-2 victory over the Cubs tonight.
PITTSBURGH, Sept. 7 (AP) -- The Reds made it two straight over the Pirates by pounding out a 5-2 victory tonight before a crowd of 12,367.

Luggage, handbags, traveling bags and personal leather goods were taxed as a war conservation measure and not for the purpose of raising revenue. They were taxed along with other articles whose component parts consisted of vital war materials. Leather goods were never considered a luxury by Congress and were, therefore, placed in a separate section apart from the acknowledged luxury articles.

MINEOLA, L. I., Sept. 7 -- A two-man team of skilled artisans devoted to research in aviation have reverted to a childhood hobby -- building model airplanes -- and their miniature fighters and bombers are being used in a test program that saves many costly hours of actual flight.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 7 -- Irving Allen, independent producer, has announced plans for a screen version of "The Man Who Watched the Trains Go By," a novel by George Simenon. According to the announcement, Claude Rains will play the leading role and it is probable that Sir Cedric Hardwicke will direct.

Princess Doris Farid es Sultaneh, who started life as Doris Mercer, daughter of a Pittsburgh police captain, will put up for auction the furniture and furnishings of Glen Alpine, her sixteen-room house at Morristown, N. J. The articles are valued at $75,000.
CHICAGO, Sept. 7 (AP) -- Today's report of the markets in the Union Stockyards by the United States Department of Agriculture follows:

Hill Prince lived up to expectations at Aqueduct yesterday. The son of Princequillo and Hildene, running in the colors of Christopher T. Chenery, was made the 19-20 choice in the $10,000 added Babylon Handicap against ten other 2-year-olds and responded admirably, to the delight of many of the 17,517 fans on hand.

Formal announcement was made yesterday that bond issues of Long Beach Unified School District, Los Angeles County, Calif., totaling $14,900,000 would be offered for sale next Tuesday. The total is made up of $7,125,000 of elementary school obligations, $5,480,000 of high school bonds, and $2,295,000 of college bonds.

DETROIT, Sept. 7 -- Today had been announced as the deadline for the United Automobile Workers, CIO, to give the required notice of canceling its contract with the Ford Motor Company and still take advantage of the state's authorization to strike by Sept. 13.

In advertisements published in New York newspapers, the Missouri Pacific Railroad announced today that it would cease operating tomorrow afternoon "because engine and train service employes will quit their jobs rather than arbitrate their differences."

Peter Loftus, chief of the New York Fire Department, was back in his Flushing home yesterday preparing a report on the conditions he found in the fire departments of the major cities in the British Isles.

The annual school traffic-safety campaign sponsored by the Automobile Club of New York was started at City Hall yesterday when Mayor O'Dwyer received from 5-year-old Leonore Kerz the first of 6,500 placards to be posted in the city.

WIESBADEN, Germany, Sept. 7 (UP) -- Four American soldiers will be charged formally with man-slaughter and assault and battery for allegedly killing a German and injuring two others during a wild spree at Mainz Tuesday, American military police announced tonight.

A loan of $12,000,000 has been obtained by Transcontinental and Western Air, Inc., from a syndicate of seven banks to aid its purchase of twenty new aircraft, A. V. Leslie, vice president and treasurer of TWA, announced yesterday.

STRASBOURG, France, Sept. 7 (AP) -- The European Consultative Assembly was asked today to approve a human rights program to prevent any other peoples from being sent "on the road to Dachau or Buchenwald."

It is a safe bet that the concentration of orchid-bedecked women at McCreery's yesterday was higher than that anyplace else in town. The combination of cool, good-for-shopping weather, advertised bargains and the lure of a Princess Aloha orchid, complete with plastic lapel vase, was more than some of them could resist.

The Rev. Dr. F. Ernest Johnson, executive secretary of the Federal Council of the Churches of Christ in America, called attention yesterday to a possible approach to a solution of the Protestant-Catholic controversy on Federal aid to education.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 7 -- The American Bar Association ordered today an inquiry "into the propriety" of judges testifying in civil and criminal law cases.

A bolt from the blue in the form of a two-run homer by Eddie Miksis, a late and unscheduled entry into a game enlivened by fisticuffs, powered the Dodgers to a 5-4 triumph over the Braves at Ebbets Field last night.

Members of the baseball squad from Boys Town, Neb., who are scheduled to meet a team of New York Orphan All-Stars at the Polo Grounds this afternoon were welcomed yesterday during the noon hour by Mayor O'Dwyer at City Hall.

ALBANY, Sept. 7 -- Governor Dewey issued a statement today urging the people of the state to contribute generously in the polio emergency drive being conducted by the National Foundation for Infantile paralysis.

Coffee futures were strong in moderately active trading on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange yesterday. Short covering and trade demand for the near-by delivery positions, along with scattered new buying of the distant positions, advanced prices in Contract S 18 to 34 points above Tuesday's levels.

HONG KONG, Sept. 7 -- Chung-king discussions between Gen. Lu Han and Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek over the fate of Yunnan broadened today. The Nationalist Government Premier, Gen. Yen Hsi-shan, flew to join the conferences along with Gen. Huang Chieh, governor of Hunan.

John J. Broderick, former Broadway detective, claimed yesterday a seat on the Tammany executive committee as a result of Tuesday's primary election, but it is doubtful that his claim will be recognized.

LONG BEACH, L. I., Sept. 7 -- In a record primary vote of 3,600, the regular Democratic slate won a two-to-one victory over a Good-Government-Fusion group in the balloting yesterday for six contested offices here.
A most quotable author of the early Nineteen Hundreds has one of his characters say:

Two separate discoveries indicating that an ancient people inhabited northern Alaska long before the earliest Eskimos -- the Ipiutaks -- were reported yesterday at the twenty-ninth International Congress of Americanists in the American Museum of Natural History.

Export markets for United States chemicals and pharmaceuticals have been shifting from South America to Europe and the Near and Far East in recent months, Frederick W. Richmond, president of the United States Foreign Corporation, declared here yesterday.
Broadway's first major edifice designed for the video era will be a twenty-story structure of unusual style to occupy a site north of Times Square, it became known last night.

ALBANY, Sept. 7 -- Governor Dewey ordered Sheriff Henry E. Becker of Niagara County today to deputize police reinforcements from neighboring communities to deal with what he described as an "outbreak of lawlessness" at the strike-bound plant of the Bell Aircraft Corporation near Niagara Falls.

GENEVA, Sept. 7 -- European difficulties in exporting to dollar markets probably are caused more by high-cost raw materials and high profits on exports to soft-currency areas than by high labor costs, the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe reported today.

In a blunt telegram to Mayor O'Dwyer, the Third Avenue Transit Corporation charged last night that the latest strike threat by Michael J. Quill's Transport Workers Union, CIO, represented a union effort to dominate the city's transportation system "through hysteria and pressure founded on misstatements, distortions and threats."

There may be any number of good and sufficient reasons why Boston's battering Red Sex should be trampling all over New York's battered Bombers. But last night, in the presence of 66,875 roaring fans at the Stadium, Joe McCarthy's hale and hearty Red Sox couldn't come up with a single one of them.

CHICAGO, Sept. 7 (AP) -- Bill Wight, Chicago left - hander, stopped St. Louis on five hits tonight as the White Sox defeated the Browns, 7 -- 1. Wight gained his twelfth victory before the smallest crowd of the White Sox home season, only 2,210 paid.

Two things turned yesterday into a holiday for Doris Charlotte Newman, who was born in Shanghai six years ago. She put on a new pair of shoes. Then her father, Peter, a refugee from Austria in 1938 and from China ten years later, registered her for the first grade at Public School 121.
CLEVELAND, Sept. 7 (AP) -- The Hupp Corporation today reported a net loss of $197,297 in the three months ended June 30, compared with a net profit of $41,584 in the similar quarter of 1948.

SHANGHAI, Sept. 7 -- In an editorial undertaking to "discuss openly" the question of the "Soviet Union and the northeast," the pro-Communist newspaper Ta Kung Pao declared today that the 1945 Sino-Soviet treaty of friendship and alliance had been of inestimable value in aiding the Comunist cause in China.

Seven months ago, almost to the day, the House of Representatives approved by an overwhelming majority a bill restoring to the President the full powers of negotiation which he had enjoyed under the original reciprocal trade agreements act sponsored by Secretary Cordell Hull. Now, after many interruptions and postponements, the Senate is at last getting around to a discussion of this measure.

I have just noticed an article stating that starting in October the Grand Central Terminal in New York will broadcast on a public address system train service reports, baseball scores, boogie-woogie, weather reports and music (whatever that is).
An enormous hurricane was headed for Bermuda, while another storm raged off Lower California, The Associated Press reported last night.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., Sept. 7 -- Farming must be made more attractive to young people if it is to compete with industry and commerce for the more aggressive and capable youngsters who are growing up today, Governor Dewey warned tonight.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was moderately active yesterday and final prices were 2 to 8 points net higher.

CBS television finally has decided on the show that will compete with Milton Berle's program on NBC on Tuesday evenings at 8 o'clock. It will be an all-Negro variety program with Louis Armstrong as the featured headliner at the premiere on Sept. 13.

CAMDEN, N. J., Sept. 7 -- Howard B. Unruh, who killed thirteen neighbors and strangers yesterday in a wild twenty minutes of deadly accurate shooting, was taken to the New Jersey State Hospital at Trenton late today. His thirteenth victim, John Wilson, 9 years old, died this morning.

WARSAW, Sept. 7 -- Wladyslaw Gomulka, former Communist Deputy Premier, who was demoted early this year for having deviated from the Cominform line, announced today his complete hostility to the present Yugoslav Government and attacked Premier Tito's aides, who had described him as being in sympathy with their aims and actions.

The first major price cut in bonded whiskies since the war was announced here yesterday. Kentucky Tavern, which now sells here for $6.94 for a fifth of a gallon, will be reduced "approximately one dollar" or 15 per cent on deliveries from the distillery after Oct. 1, according to Joseph A. Engelhard, president of Glenmore Distilleries Company.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 -- Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek was accused today in the Senate of having "absconded" to Formosa with $138,000,000 in gold after "deserting" the Chinese people.
CLEVELAND, Sept. 7 -- Senator Robert A. Taft accepted today the challenge of organized labor to do battle on the Taft-Hartley Law in his compaign for re-election in 1950.

Patent - sharing arrangements among major drug companies working on the chemical problem of increasing the supply of the new drug cortisone, are being worked out, it was reported yesterday at the end of a day-long conference.

MUNICH, Germany, Sept. 7 -- German workmen today started digging up the graves of thousands who died in the Dachau concentration camp. Officials said that the earth was to be used for commercial purposes, presumably for pottery manufacture because of the high clay content.

The administration of the Department of Licenses has been greatly improved and expanded since Jan. 1, 1946, and its operating staff substantially enlarged, Mayor O'Dwyer declared yesterday in a report made public at City Hall.

HAVANA, Sept. 7 -- The United States delegation to the second congress of the Inter-American Labor Confederation tonight called upon the delegates to defend democracy in Latin America against mounting threats "from the totalitarianism of communism and of neo-fascism."

HOBOKEN, N. J., Sept. 7 -- Sinclair Lewis, novelist and Nobel Prize winner, and his brother, Dr. C. B. Lewis of St. Cloud, Minn., physician, were among the 842 passengers aboard the Holland American Line's flagship Niew Amsterdam, which sailed this afternoon from the Fifth Street Pier here for Southampton, Le Havre and Rotterdam.

HOBOKEN, N. J., Sept. 7 -- Sinclair Lewis, novelist and Nobel Prize winner, and his brother, Dr. C. B. Lewis of St. Cloud, Minn., physician, were among the 842 passengers aboard the Holland American Line's flagship Niew Amsterdam, which sailed this afternoon from the Fifth Street Pier here for Southampton, Le Havre and Rotterdam.

The home at 83 Michael Lane, in Lakeville Estates, near New Hyde Park, L. I., was sold by John J. Egbert to Stephen Chwat, who insured title with the Title Guarantee and Trust Company, also the insurer of title in the sale of the two-family dwelling on lot 19 by 100 feet at 39-47 Fifty-ninth Street, Woodside, by Catherine McDonnell to Philip C. Reilly through Wagner Kelly, brokers.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 (UP) -- The full five-man National Labor Relations Board ruled today that an employer must bargain on pensions in "the absence of a specific waiver of the union's right to bargain."

MUNICH, Germany, Sept. 7 -- Col. A. H. Rosenfeld Jr. of Mount Holly, N. J., law member of the Court Martial that in 1946 sentenced six Germans to death for the massacre of 700 United States soldiers whom the Germans had captured during the Battle of the Bulge, said here today that he doubted the veracity of testimony of Lieut. Col. Harold D. McGown.
Classroom facilities at New York University this fall will include several buses. Their use is not occasioned by a shortage of more conventional structures, but by a need for mobility.

SPRING LAKE, N. J., Sept. 8 -- Manufacturers of pest poisons for farm use were warned here today to set up an organization for testing new products prior to public marketing before the Government steps in and enacts "hastily conceived laws and regulations."

CANTON, China, Sept. 8 (AP) -- An American explorer who may have found the world's highest mountain was wounded critically today in an unexplained shooting in which another American was injured seriously and a British businessman was slain.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture today predicted that this year's cotton crop would be the fifth largest of record, totaling 14,943,000 bales or 138,000 bales more than was forecast a month ago. Production was 14,868,000 bales last year and the ten-year (1938-47) average was 11,306,000 bales.
BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Sept. 8 -- President Juan Peron asked Congress today to drop gold as the backing for the Argentine peso in a move to solve the nation's financial problems.
CHICAGO, Sept. 8 (AP) -- Bob Kuzava allowed only five hits today to score his ninth victory against four losses as the Chicago White Sox defeated the St. Louis Browns, 3 -- 1.

The S. S. Goldwater Fellowship in Hospital Administration at Mount Sinai Hospital has been awarded for the year beginning next Thursday to William L. Agress, assistant director of the Brooklyn Tuberculosis and Health Association, it was announced yesterday.

NORWALK, Conn., Sept. 8 -- Local 283, United Rubber Workers, CIO, announced today that its members late Wednesday had voted 124 to 45 to accept a decrease in piece-work rates, averaging 11 cents an hour, from the Norwalk Tire and Rubber Company, thereby averting a strike that had been called by the union effective Sept. 30.
A number of interesting reports have come in on the opening of the rail season, both from Connecticut and New Jersey, and the birds seem more plentiful than they have been in several years.

A majority of the outstanding common stock in Franklin Simon Co., Inc., oldest specialty store in the country, was purchased yesterday by City Stores Company, operator of department and specialty stores in the eastern, northeastern and southern states.

Kid Gavilan, the Cuban battler who holds the welterweight championship of his homeland, will help inaugurate the indoor boxing season at Madison Square Garden tonight. He will oppose Rocky Castellani, nimble battler from Luzerne, Pa., in the feature bout of ten rounds.

Two international good-will projects and one local community service program will be expanded during the 1949-50 academic year by the Junior Red Cross in its activities in 900 New York public, private and religious schools.

SUFFERN, N. Y., Sept. 8 -- A mentally disturbed war veteran, who wrecked a lunchroom and injured four persons after being refused an after-hours bottle of beer was shot dead early today by a police lieutenant whose skull he had fractured with a metal chair.
New York State, in an endeavor to attract new industries and prevent old ones from leaving, is quietly building up a reservoir of skilled craftsmen.
The National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis began yesterday a one-week emergency drive to raise $14,500,000 for the medical care of recent polio epidemic victims.

Rubber futures firmed yesterday on the Commodity Exchange following Wednesday's moderate decline, and closing prices were 7 to 17 points net higher. The market opened lower. London cables showed that market 1/8d off and word from Singapore was that prices there were down 1/4d.

HAVANA, Sept. 8 -- Bernardo Ibanez, president of the Inter-American Labor Federation, today called on the delegates to the organization's second congress to endorse fully the efforts of the free democratic trade unions to form a new global organization opposed to the Communist-dominated World Federation of Trade Unions.

Spurred by increased competition, retail stores made additional use of newspaper advertising in an effort to sustain sales volume during fiscal 1948, according to the 1949 edition of the Analysis of Publicity Expense issued yesterday by the National Retail Dry Goods Association.

Business loans made by banks in this area have maintained their upward trend for the second successive week, advancing $38,000,000 during the period ended on last Wednesday, it was disclosed yesterday. According to the data issued by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, covering the reporting New York City member banks, the rise reflects increased borrowings by tobacco, oil and miscellaneous companies, and marks the fifth gain in seven weeks.

A showing of afternoon and evening gowns, furs and custom millinery comprised the three-fold presentation offered yesterday at Jay Thorpe. The first group numbered soft afternoon frocks of taffeta-accented crepe and baghera jersey, chic satin dinner suits, short evening dresses and flowing ball gowns in the grand manner created by well-known designers exclusively for this shop.

Representatives of the steamship industry, dock labor and the armed services were guests of the Army Port of Embarkation yesterday at a demonstration of a new development in the handling of cargo -- the rolling wing deck -- which its inventor says will reduce cargo stowage time and costs by at least 50 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- President Truman sent to the Senate today the nomination of Robert D. Murphy, veteran diplomat, as Ambassador to Belgium. Later he disclosed he would appoint Stanton Griffis of New York, former Ambassador to Poland and more recently to Egypt, as Ambassador to Argentina.

With a Monday strike deadline still hanging over the bus and trolley routes of the Third Avenue Transit Corporation, city officials indicated last night that Mayor O'Dwyer would resolve the impasse between union and management representatives over choice of an arbitrator by naming one himself if the parties failed to agree by tomorrow morning.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- The United States extended a loan of $20,000,000 today to the Government of Yugoslavia, closing a deal described in many quarters here as "a good proposition" on both diplomatic and economic grounds.

The figures for the Labor Day weekend this year show that new high records of death and destruction were made. Many more persons are now in hospitals, some of them crippled for life, than was the case before the holiday started. And most of that can be laid to carelessness.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- The hoofers struggling to assure the nation-wide revival of vaudeville got a great "plug" today from an old show fan, President Truman.

HELSINKI, Finland, Sept. 8 (AP) -- Premier Karl A. Fagerholm said today the Communist strike offensive against Finland's Social Democratic Government had been converted into "a complete and first-class failure."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- The State Department strongly protested to the Communist authorities in Shanghai today against their failure to protect the American consul general there from siege and attack about five weeks ago by former Chinese employes of the United States Navy.
MIAMI, FLA., Sept 8 (AP) -- The weaker side of a huge Atlantic hurricane lashed lightly at British-owned Bermuda today as the center swirled off into the open sea.

The Boragine Realty Corporation has purchased the property at 632 Gates Avenue, Brooklyn, from Berke Bakeries, Inc., through the Kalmon Dolgin Company, broker. The property, consisting of two one-story buildings and a three-story structure containing a total of 15,000 square feet, will be used by the Venezian Lamp Company for the manufacture of lamps.

The O'Dwyer administration got a major victory in its inquiry into ticket scalping yesterday when the Manhattan Theatre Ticket Service, 264 West Forty-seventh Street, promised to surrender its broker's license just before a hearing on the subject of its revocation.
HAVERFORD, Pa., Sept. 8 -- England and the United States will meet here tomorrow for the twenty-first time since 1923 in the annual international women's team matches for the Wightman Cup.

Neither the might of the power-laden Red Sox nor the spirit of tenacity which has enabled the shell-ridden Yankees to cling to the top these many weeks could do a thing about a third element which injected itself into the seething American League pennant race yesterday.
AUGUSTA, Me., Sept. 8 (AP) -- New hope for a review of his conviction of murder was offered to Francis M. Carroll today after eleven years of imprisonment.

Prices of meats and fancy eggs remain at the high levels reached a fortnight ago, the consumers' service division of the City Department of Markets discovered yesterday in its regular weekly check of retail food stores. Costs are unchanged, too, for such other perishables as fish, butter and margarine. In produce, certain items have seesawed up and down, but the increases or decreases have been negligible for the most part.

SAN JUAN, P. R., Sept. 8 (UP) -- The Insular Narcotics Bureau announced today that it had confiscated more than $36,000 worth of heroin smuggled from New York. Officials said the smuggling apparently was done by a group connected with the world-wide ring alleged to be headed by Eduardo Balaresco, arrested recently in New York.

TORONTO, Sept. 8 (Canadian Press) -- Plans to raise the $90,000,000 required to build its proposed 1,150-mile pipeline from Edmonton, Alberta, to Superior, Wis., were announced today by the Interprovincial Pipe Line Company.

Temple University has announced that this year it is inaugurating a three-day orientation course, in advance of the fall college term, for a limited number of incoming freshmen. Temple thus joins several other universities -- such as Washington and Lee, a pioneer in the development of the "freshman camp" plan -- which have found that the briefing of freshmen on how to behave like freshmen is well worth the effort involved.

STRASBOURG, France, Friday, Sept. 9 -- The Council of Europe's Consultative Assembly called early today for an international supreme court to uphold human rights and then ended its first month-long session.

The Port of New York Authority intends to borrow this fall $30,000,000 on tax-exempt bonds maturing over thirty years in furtherance of the financing of development at the La Guardia and New York International Airports here and the Teterboro and Newark Airports in New Jersey.

In a press conference at his campaign headquarters in the Astor Hotel, Newbold Morris, Republican-Liberal-Fusion candidate for Mayor expressed resentment yesterday at a recent charge by Mayor O'Dwyer that the city in acquiring the IRT and BMT rapid transit lines had "bought a lot of junk."

Paul Makushak, 32-year-old self-imprisoned Brooklyn "hermit" who was rescued by the police on April 26 from a walled-in closet he had occupied for ten years, was released on Aug. 28 from Pilgrim State Hospital, Brentwood, L. I., to which he had been confined under court order, it was learned yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- Glenn L. Martin, the veteran airplane manufacturer, denied under oath before a Navy court of inquiry today that he had contributed to or assisted in writing the celebrated anonymous memorandum that precipitated the investigation of the B-36 bomber program of the Air Force.
TAVARES, Fla., Sept. 8 (AP) -- Two Negroes were sentenced today to die in the electric chair for the rape that brought mob terrorism to this section of central Florida two months ago.

The report of District Attorney George M. Fanelli of Westchester on the disturbance after the Paul Robeson concert near Peekskill last Sunday produced a new series of protests yesterday. Mr. Fanelli's report, asking for commendation of the police work, and laying the disorders to teen-agers out of control, was released by Governor Dewey without comment on Wednesday.

The three-way battle for control of the Segal Lock and Hardware Company, Inc., of New York, was settled yesterday when final tabulation of proxies placed representatives of the three factions on the five-member board of directors. None of the groups, however, gained majority representation.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 8 -- The Yugoslavs broadened their attack today on the Communist Information Bureau by denouncing the Communist parties of the Western countries as instruments of Soviet national policy.
HALIFAX, N. S., Sept. 8 (Canadian Press) -- They are all but gone now, the three-masted sailing ships which once carried Nova Scotia's flag and merchandise across the seas.

Convinced that the incoming social season will call for elegance, the fashion authorities at Henri Bendel's put their best efforts into the production of a custom-made collection. It was presented to the press yesterday morning.
DETROIT, Sept. 8 (AP) -- The Ford Motor Company and the United Automobile Workers, CIO, tried again today without success to settle their pension dispute and avert a threatened strike.

LAKE SUCCESS, Sept. 8 -- The Republic of Korea and the Soviet-sponsored opposition government in the northern part of the country came in for some pointed criticism today in a United Nations report that warned of the danger of "barbarous civil war."

ST. LOUIS, Friday, Sept. 9 -- Missouri-Pacific Railroad trains rolled toward a final stop early today in preparation for a strike of four operating brotherhoods this afternoon. All traffic was at a standstill except two inbound and two outbound trains. They will continue to their destinations before ceasing operation on one of the country's major rail lines.

Mayor O'Dwyer's leadership in providing public housing for scores of thousands of persons was praised yesterday by city officials at ground-breaking ceremonies for one public and one cooperative housing development. The Mayor attended both exercises, at Farragut Houses in Brooklyn, and Queensview, in Long Island City, Queens.

Six table settings that illustrate the fact that even the simplest type of cloth, when handled with dignity, may be used to give a surprisingly formal effect, were exhibited on the second floor of Bloomingdale's yesterday.

Effectiveness of increased newspaper advertising to sell the buyer's market during 1948 and early 1949 was reported in detail yesterday by the Bureau of Advertising, American Newspaper Publishers Association. The account was in the form of the bureau's eleventh annual Blue Book of Newspaper Advertising.

Federal Judge Harold R. Medina at the Communist trial denied a defense motion yesterday for a mistrial because of the Peekskill affair in which Irving Potash, one of the defendants, says he was injured. Judge Medina also denied a defense motion for investigations of the affair by the judge and by United States Attorney John F. X. McGohey.

LONDON, Sept. 8 -- The Royal Commission inquiring into murderers and what to do with them today considered the views of chiefs of police and rank-and-file policemen. All grades expressed a strong belief that fear of the death penalty was a strong deterrent to acts of violence by potential criminals and argued that it should be retained.
ROME, Sept. 8 -- A new agitation among the seamen in Genoa caused the liner Ameriga Vespucci to cancel her scheduled sailing from that port for Valparaiso, Chile today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept 8 -- Evelyn Keyes was named today by Columbia for the leading feminine role in "The Killer That Stalked New York," a melodrama by Harry Essex about smallpox which Robert Cohn will produce early next month. The plot deals largely with the search for the carrier of an epidemic infection, with most of the film being photographed in New York.

BRIDLINGTON, England, Sept. 8 -- As had been fully expected, the delegates to the annual convention of the British Trades Union Congress overwhelmingly reaffirmed today their policy of restraint and moderation in wage demands.

DETROIT, Sept. 8 (AP) -- The hustling Detroit Tigers jolted the Cleveland Indians twice today, 10 -- 0 and 4 -- 1, behind the effective lefthand pitching of Hal Newhouser and Ted Gray. Newhouser pitched a one-hit shutout in the afternoon game while Gray gave up only four hits in the second game tonight.
PRAGUE, Sept. 8 (AP) -- The text of a statement by Czechoslovak Roman Catholic priests opposing a Government-sponsored church control bill:

Immediate re-establishment of a gold coin standard, with United States currency freely convertible into gold at $35 an ounce, was urged yesterday by speakers at a conference on the subject sponsored by the Economists' National Committee on Monetary Policy.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- President Truman asserted today that he would begin identifying "selfish interests," including individuals, in the 1950 election campaign for control of Congress.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Sept. 8 -- Louis Hollander, president of the State Congress of Industrial Organizations, opened the convention of that group here today by warning Left-wing delegates that he would bar them if they pursued disorderly tactics.
BOSTON, Sept. 8 (AP) -- The death of a Texas debutante in a stairway fall aboard the liner Excalibur in mid-Atlantic was ruled accidental tonight after investigation by a Boston medical examiner.
GROTON, Conn., Sept. 8 (AP) -- The crew of the submarine Cochino, sunk in the Arctic, came back to the submarine base here today by water and plane to the greetings of wives and friends.

TOKYO, Sept. 8 -- The Japanese Government today ordered dissolution of the leftist League of Koreans Resident in Japan and three minor Korean organizations. The Government charged that they were "anti-democratic and terrorist" associations that resisted orders of the Allied Occupation.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 (UP) -- President Truman said today he might ask for an extension of the steel strike truce to prevent a walkout by 1,000,000 steel workers scheduled for midnight next Wednesday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- A willingness to put into the predominantly European military-aid program a token sum of $75,000,000 for possible, but not mandatory, use in China was indicated today by Senate spokesmen for the Administration.
The city's Department of Traffic Engineering held out hope yesterday for relief of the apparently hopeless traffic snarl in New York's congested garment center.

BUFFALO, Sept. 8 -- For the second consecutive day violence flared this morning in the thirteen-week-old Bell Aircraft strike. At least fifteen persons were injured in altercations between non-strikers and "flying squads" of strike sympathizers.

BOSTON, Sept. 8 (AP) -- Righthander Russ Meyer limited the Braves to one hit tonight and Boston lost its ninth straight game. The Phillies won, 3 -- 1. Meyer clinched his twelfth victory of the season by setting down the last sixteen Tribesmen to face him.

The Dodgers walloped the Giants, 12 -- 7, last night at Ebbets Field and the tip-off on the one-sidedness of this affair came early. Before the game was four innings old quite a few fans left the park. Those who departed before it was official showed good sense because it developed into one of the longest, dullest and sorriest ball games of the season.
A ten-point program intended to promote the success of the Anglo-American-Canadian economic talks was sent to the conferees in Washington yesterday by the American Federation of Labor.

DENVER, Sept. 8 -- Stepping out of the field of social welfare, leaders of the National Urban League have prepared a resolution condemning exploitation of the race issue by "totalitarian forces of whatever persuasion."

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Sept. 8 (AP) -- W. M. Wickham's Woodford Sir and Shamrock Stable's Little Harp raced to a dead heat in the six-furlong feature today. Little Harp drew even with Woodford Sir in the last stride.

THE HAGUE, The Netherlands, Sept. 8 -- A $300,000,000 trade agreement between The Netherlands and Western Germany was signed today, initiating an important shift in United States economic policy designed to increase intra-European trade by cutting the Deutsche mark's ties to the dollar.

James A. Lundy, Republican candidate for Borough President of Queens, opened his campaign last night at a dinner meeting of the Queens County Republican Executive committee by charging that the present Democratic administration of the borough was guilty of "neglect and failure."
WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- Some of the country's prime economic indicators pointed upward today after a summertime slump.

The Council of Europe emerges from four weeks of debate a stronger and more important body than when it started. It adjourns to meet again, and has established committees to remain at work between the general sessions. Already, and unexpectedly to skeptics who regarded it as the projection of a dream, it takes on the features of a permanent institution.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- The United States has rejected a British proposal to waive Article 9 of the Anglo-American Loan Agreement prohibiting discrimination against this country's exports for the benefit of those from the Commonwealth or Western Europe.
Something dark and nameless spread over this city yesterday afternoon. The gloom and mystery remained for about half an hour.

The situation which has produced the Washington economic talks is dramatic enough, but the talks themselves are not. There were no surprises on the opening day. All the facts stated by the Finance Ministers of Britain, Canada and the United States were already well known.

Assembled philosophers, scientists and theologians were told last night that no matter what high-purpose programs they evolved in concert for the common good they had better also reckon with a workaday problem known as administration.

A recent news story gave me a jolt. A once-proud race of men may be on the road to serfdom. Private rights are being attacked on all sides. A change in men's styles every five years has been proposed!

The second day of the thirty-fifth official opening of American Leathers at the industry exposition at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, was marked by a new high for attendance in the two-day period, according to Irving R. Glass, executive vice president, the Tanners' Council of America.

LONDON, Friday, Sept. 9 -- The warmth of the reception for J. B. Priestley's "Summer Day's Dream," which opened at the St. Martin's Theatre last night, was echoed today by reviewers in London newspapers.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Sept. 8 -- The vicars of the Roman Catholic Church in Czechoslovakia are now challenging the core of the Government's church program by sending statements to the Central Action Committee of the National Front rejecting the new church law that is to be submitted to Parliament within the next few weeks.

LONDON, Sept. 8 -- Despite obstacles, a few British industries have succeeded in lowering costs and increasing productivity. Their achievement is recorded in the official government dossier that Sir Stafford Cripps, Chancellor of the Exchequer, and Foreign Secretary Bevin took with them to Washington.

The New York Stock Exchange made a further bid for public interest yesterday when the board of governors decided again to submit to the membership a plan to allow the current partnership arrangement to be changed into an incorporated company basis.

A group of new tables planned to go with special types of sofas was introduced yesterday by the designers, Kim Hoffman and Stephen Heidrich, at the Pelican Upholstery Company showroom, 220 East Fifty-first Street.
Operations of the International Harvester Company for the nine months ended on July 31 resulted in a net income of $48,910,000 after taxes and all charges, according to the report issued last night.

STONY BROOK, L. I., Sept. 8 -- Llangollen Farms Adventure, champion conformation hunter of last November's national horse show in Madison Square Garden, scored two important triumphs today in the opening session of the three-day north shore fixture at the Old Field Club.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 8 (AP) -- The Athletics left-handed the Senators to a double defeat tonight as Lou Brissie recorded his fourteenth Triumph, 8 -- 4, in the second game under the lights after rookie Alex Kellner had picked up his seventeenth, 9 -- 1, in the twilight contest.

The nation's gasoline stocks fell 1,646,000 barrels last week, according to the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end they amounted to 104,634,000 barrels, compared with 106,280,000 a week earlier and 94,893,000 a year before.

MITCHELL AIR FORCE BASE, L. I., Sept. 8 -- Operation of the first jet aircraft training for pilots in the Air Force corollary program was announced here today by Headquarters, Continental Air Command. High speed F-84 Thunderjets have been assigned to reservists of the Fifty-second Fighter Squadron, Jet, at Hamilton Air Force Base, Calif.

Your international air edition has turned out to be a Godsend to me. Over here I find that I must be kept informed on the official attitude of my Government toward the world and other Governments at all times. In these months of crisis I find this particularly so.

OTTAWA, Sept. 8 (AP) -- United States Airlines seeking traffic rights in Canada under the recent Canada-United States air agreement will have to wait until Washington has taken further action to clarify the status of the agreement, the Air Transport Board indicated today.

DENVER, Sept, 8 -- Persons who undergo brain surgery for mental illness lose their emotional tensions but also lose a feeling of "self-continuity" and do not seem to care very much what happens to themselves or to other people, it was revealed today by Dr. Walter Freeman and Dr. James W. Watts, the two surgeons who have pioneered in America in psychosurgery.

WEST NYACK, N. Y., Sept. 8 -- Chris Olsen has cleared the last of his 18,000 bugs out of the house. He did the job reluctantly, but as a man now in his seventieth year he has decided that from now on the American Museum of Natural History ought to take care of the creatures.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- George S. Jones Jr., vice president and assistant to the president of Servel, Inc., Evansville, Ind., was named chairman of the National Distribution Council in an announcement made today by Secretary of Commerce Charles Sawyer at a joint luncheon meeting of the Council and National Sales Executives, Inc., at the Statler Hotel.
The Presidential Fact Finding Board will shortly make its recommendations for the settlement of the steel labor controversy.

BONN, Germany, Sept. 8 -- In a major address on behalf of his Government, Gen. Sir Brian Robertson, British High Commissioner-designate for Germany, took note today of German bitterness against Britain and "appealed for friendship and cooperation between the people of the two countries."

Richard F. Behrendt, Professor of International Affairs at Colgate University and an expert on Latin America, declared yesterday that all governments of Bolivia, except two that he did not name, have been "the instruments of the large mining interests."

Barbara Gibson, a 20-year-old coloratura soprano, who never has sung professionally, will be heard on the NBC radio network at 9 P M. next Monday as guest soloist on "The Telephone Hour." She is a graduate of the Port Richmond High School on Staten Island, where her only public singing was in Red Cross entertainments at Halloran General Hospital.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Sept. 8 -- Senator Robert A. Taft spent his sixtieth birthday today touring neighboring Lake and Geauga Counties to tell his constituents that, with the future of our own economy at stake, we could not increase the public debt further either for the benefit of the nation or for the sake of Great Britain.
ARDSLEY-ON-HUDSON, Sept. 8 -- Mr. and Mrs. Donald O'Brien of Winged Foot won the Westchester Golf Association's husband-and-wife championship today for the fourth time.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., Sept. 8 -- In two addresses during a Governor's Day appearance at the New York State Fair here today, Governor Dewey assailed what he described as a growing trend toward government control over the lives of its citizens.
HONG KONG, Sept. 8 -- The slow progress of the Communist drive into South China has confounded almost every student of Chinese affairs in this part of the world.
The Port of New York Authority devoted most of its monthly meeting yesterday to advancing projects for the improvement of airport facilities in the metropolitan area.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 8 -- An important distinction is already being made in this region, where the United Nations economic survey mission under Gordon R. Clapp is scheduled to start work next week, between the program of Palestine refugee employment and resettlement.

The thousands of American soldiers who visited Dachau just after its liberation in those crisp spring days of 1945 will surely never forget what they saw there. They will never forget the scores of shriveled bodies lying where they were starved and smothered to death in a train of box cars.

HONG KONG, Sept. 8 -- Great significance was attached here to the Communist appointment of Lieut. Gen. Yeh Chien-ying to the post of first secretary of the South China Bureau of the Communist party, which was announced tonight over the Communist radio.

ALBANY, N. Y., Sept. 8 -- Governor Dewey, in a move to put an end to the violence accompanying the Bell Aircraft strike, tonight asked officials of the United Auto Workers Union, CIO, and the Sheriffs and District Attorneys of Niagara and Erie Counties to meet him in his office tomorrow.
Earl T. Moore of Westfield, N. J., chief executive officer of the Central Railroad of New Jersey, was elected president of the railroad yesterday.

Montgomery Clift was voted Number One Star of Tomorrow in the ninth annual poll of the nation's film exhibitors conducted by the trade weekly, The Motion Picture Herald. Runners-up in the canvass, in the order they finished, were Kirk Douglas, Betty Garrett, Paul Douglas, Howard Duff, Pedro Armendariz, the child actor; Dean Stockwell, Wanda Hendrix, Wendell Corey and Barbara Bel Geddes.

BRIDLINGTON, England, Sept. 18 (Reuters) -- Officials of two film workers' unions warned the Trades Union Congress here today that Hollywood pressure and declining British production might soon make British movie theatres dumping grounds for American films.

New York, which last week played host to several thousand sailors from nineteen visiting warships of Task Force 87, will stage a repeat performance this weekend with the arrival, of eleven vessels of the Atlantic Fleet led by the 45,000-ton aircraft carrier Franklin D. Roosevelt.

Background of the Hawaiian longshoremen's 131-days-old strike was reviewed yesterday by representatives of the employers and the International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union, CIO, in separate meetings with Cyrus S. Ching, director of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service.

PROBABLY the most famous sentence Jane Austen ever wrote is the opening one from "Pride and Prejudice": "It is a truth universally acknowledged, that a single man in possession of a good fortune must be in want of a wife."

LONDON, Sept. 8 (Reuters) -- The Warsaw radio broadcast tonight the text of a Polish Foreign Ministry note handed to the Yugoslav Embassy in Warsaw today, declaring that the Tito Government had "trodden down and destroyed" the pact of friendship and mutual assistance signed on March 18, 1946.

CAMDEN, N. J., Sept. 8 -- The fate of Howard B. Unruh, the ex-GI sharpshooter who shot to death thirteen men, women and children on Tuesday, hinged tonight on the outcome of an extensive psychiatric examination that may last two months.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Sept. 8 -- Representative Gustavo Jimenez was killed in a gun fight in the Colombian House of Representatives today, in which three other Congressmen were wounded. The trouble started after a three-minute recess at midnight when, according to the Conservative newspaper Siglo, fifty shots were fired on the floor of the Lower House.

Newbold Morris' opening speech as a candidate for Mayor offers a blueprint of the terrain on which he will do battle. It is described as a "keynote" address; it seeks to set the tone of what is to come. A considerable amount of attention is paid to Mayor O'Dwyer's personality and character, his political loyalties and his frequent changes of mind, particularly as to his willingness to stand for another term.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt's account of her years in the White House as First Lady and as a world figure will be published by Harper on Nov. 9, entitled "This I Remember." The Book-of-the-Month Club has chosen it for November distribution.

A serious jurisdictional dispute between the nation's actors and musicians appeared nearer last night after the parent body of all performer groups, the Associated Actors and Artistes of America, voted "unanimous defiance" of James C. Petrillo, president of the American Federation of Musicians.

LONDON, Sept. 8 -- Such private organizations as the British Bird Watchers Society are preventing the installation in this country of an omnidirectional range system, an aviation aid. This American device, now being installed throughout the United States, is here in packing cases but must be cleared through the bird watchers' and similar societies before erection.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- The State Department spoke out officially for the first time today against the revolutionary forces in Bolivia.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- During the week ended Sept. 7, member bank reserve balances decreased $517,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

The Liberal party urged last night that the independence of the City Planning Commission be restored and the powers of City Construction Co-ordinator Robert Moses and the Board of Estimate be restricted on planning matters. Mr. Moses is a non-salaried member of the seven-member planning commission.

Department store profits during the six months' period this year between Feb. 1 and July 31 fell 58 per cent below the corresponding period last year, according to a study disclosed yesterday by the National Retail Dry Goods Association.

MUNICH, Germany, Sept. 8 (UP) -- Two former Nazi Storm Troopers today told a representative of the Senate subcommittee investigating the Malmedy massacre that they and others were forced by beatings and "mental pressure" to confess to slaying 700 American prisoners of war.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- President Truman today opened an organization meeting for the 1950 mid-century White House Conference on Children and Youth with reiterated pleas for his health and Federal aid to education programs.

The Peron Government moved swiftly yesterday to improve commercial relations with American enterprises operating in Argentina when it guaranteed dollar payment on a $20,000,000 telephone equipment deal with the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation. Reliable sources in foreign utility circles said it was the first such guarantee made by the Central Bank of the Argentine Republic in more than a decade, and characterized the action as preliminary to unfreezing American funds tied up in Argentina.

CHICAGO, Sept. 8 -- The decline in business, which gathered speed during the first half of the year, appears to have lost its impetus and is now in the leveling-off stage, the August report of the Business Survey Committee of the Continued on Page 39, Column 8 Purchasing Agents Association of Chicago revealed today.

Procedures for enforcing the state's new Feinberg law, barring subversive persons from public school jobs, will be announced before next Thursday's special meeting of the Board of Education, it was made known yesterday.

ATLANTA, Sept. 8 -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, speaking to an audience in the South for the first time since 1944, asserted today that instances of "democratic failures" in the South could be paraleled in every other section of the country.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 8 (AP) -- The fast-flying Cardinals, behind three-hit pitching by Southpaw Harry Brecheen, steam-rollered the last-place Cubs tonight, 8 to 0.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- Department store sales in the week ended Sept. 3 were 4 per cent lower than in the corresponding week of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. The following lists percentage changes from like periods of 1948:

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Sept. 8 -- It was out of Old Cow Bay and back again today in the second session of the fall series at the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club. There was a fleet of 207 craft and as they came on to the finish line past Plum Point it looked like an invasion of great white-winged birds.

Six longshoremen got jail terms of thirty to sixty days yesterday in Municipal Term Court for collecting state unemployment insurance checks to which they were not entitled. One cleaning woman, who admitted doing the same thing, received a three-month suspended sentence and four others had their cases adjourned for sentencing on Sept. 15.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- The Navy Department will henceforth permit its civilian employe supervisors to join unions and take part in their business meetings, it was announced today. The new policy was approved by Dan A. Kimball, Under Secretary of the Navy.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 (AP) -- The American General Corporation and the Equity Corporation, New York investment companies, proposed today to the Securities and Exchange Commission further stock offerings as another "step in the simplification of their capital structures."

FRANKFORT, Germany, Sept. 8 (UP) -- Former Berlin airlift planes carried an entire combat command of 2,400 soldiers 300 miles by air today to fight a mythical enemy invading Western Europe from the east in the United States Army war games.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- Over the bitter protests of Australia and the Philippines the United States today informed the eleven-nation Far Eastern Commission that it intends to turn over $80,000,000 in Japanese gold to Thailand and Indo-China.

LATROBE, Pa., Sept. 8 -- In an election attended by 186 Benedictine monks from all parts of the country, the Rev. Denis Omer Strittmatter was chosen tonight as Coadjutor Archabbot of St. Vincent Archabbey here. The Arch abbey has fifty outposts in sixteen dioceses in the United States which are affiliated with the American-Casinese Congregation of the Benedictine Order.

TRIESTE, Sept. 8 -- International communism will seek to overthrow Premier Marshal Tito's Government in Yugoslavia by "every legal and illegal means" within that country and also by "partisan war" but not by invasion or formal war, Vittorio Vidali, Trieste Communist leader, declared today.

MUNICH, Germany, Sept. 8 -- The United States Military Government for Bavaria today placed the blame for desecration of a mass grave near the Dachau concentration camp squarely on the Bavarian Government. A Military Government spokesman added that the grave opened yesterday by German workmen already had been closed again on a Military Government order.

Portugal's action in setting sixty-day limit on validity of import licenses was condemned as "completely impractical" at meeting of the Overseas Automotive Club yesterday in the Shelton Hotel. Filing of protests with the State Department and the Portuguese Government was approved.
PITTSBURGH, Sept. 8 (AP) -- The Cincinnati Reds came through with two big rallies today to dump the Pittsburgh Pirates, 9 -- 7, and sweep their three-game series here.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 8 -- Mrs. Iva Toguri D'Aquino, accused by the Government of broadcasting treasonable "Tokyo Rose" programs to Allied fighting men in the South Pacific, testified today that she had taken an announcer's job at Radio Tokyo out of fear to refuse.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- The inclusion of a "peril point" clause in the proposed reciprocal trade agreements bill would hang out a "red lantern" against injury to American producers, Senator Eugene D. Millikin, Republican, of Colorado, told the Senate today.

Five of the six contestants in the $11,300 Bushwick Hurdle Handicap at Aqueduct yesterday had the lead at various points along the line. Persepolis, owned and trained by Arthur Preece and a carrier of his Clynmalyra Stud silks, had it at the right time -- in the pay-off run through the homestretch.
LONDON, Sept. 8 -- The chief interest in the somewhat uncertain stock markets today centered on commodity shares. Oils and coppers were prominent in this movement.

BOSTON, Sept. 8 -- Frankie Brimsek, goalie for the Boston Bruins of the National Hockey League, was sold to the Chicago Black Hawks today. Brimsek has been a mainstay on the Bruins, excepting for war service, since he succeeded Tiny Thompson early in the 1938-39 season.

Capt. John George Stahley, who retired this week as assistant boatmaster of the Pennsylvania Railroad in New York Harbor, was guest of honor at a dinner given last night by 200 shipmates and railroad associates at the Plaza Hotel, in Jersey City.

PARIS, Sept. 8 -- Premier Henri Queuille said today in an interview to be published this weekend, that the orders of the Communist party were now less influential and that France had "freed herself from the fear that last year weighed upon her."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- The Wage and Hour Administrator announced today the probable new rules for exempting certain "white collar" employes from the overtime pay requirements of the Fair Labor Standards Act.

MEXICO CITY, Sept. 8 -- After the United States Embassy here had denied an assertion that American citizens had been prevented from coming to Mexico City to attend the Continental Congress for Peace, two officials of the embassy staff were barred from today's session.

A part of the "short interest" in September rubber futures on the Commodity Exchange was "run in," as the saying goes, yesterday. The price on the near-by delivery was 18.30 cents a pound, highest since last March and 90 points above the December delivery, as the shorts bid aggressively to liquidate their open interest.

MITCHEL AIR FORCE BASE, L. I., Sept. 8 -- Beginning at 8 A. M. on Saturday New York and nine other Eastern states will be subjected to a week-long air "attack" by bombers and fighter planes coming in from all directions.

The death of Richard Strauss severs one of our important artistic links to the past. In his long career he represented in an unusual way the evolution and transition in the musical thinking of the Western World. Since he was an iconoclast and an innovator it was natural that he should have been reviled by his early contemporaries.
The United States Maritime Commission has asked the Arnold Bernstein Lines, Inc., for additional information on its capital structure and resources, a spokesman for the agency reported yesterday.

Is the fate of the City Center in the balance? Since December of 1943 the municipally owned house has been purveying high-grade entertainment, such as opera, dance, concerts and shows, within the reach of anyone's purse. Now the musicians' union, Local 802, wants to buy the City Center and has submitted a bid of $850,000. accompanied by a deposit of $10,000. to the City Controller.

Dollar volume of home furnishings stores throughout the country in the first six months of the current year declined 11.1 per cent compared with the corresponding period last year, according to a semi-annual report of store operating experience released yesterday by the National Retail Furniture Association.

A detective and a woman were killed and another detective suffered serious injuries when the police car in which they were driving crashed into a parked truck in front of 213 Throop Avenue, near Stockton Street, Brooklyn, at 1:40 A. M. yesterday.

Back-to-School Week highlights once again the sorry plight of the nation's schools. Public educators meeting earlier this summer announced a present shortage of 260,000 qualified teachers and reiterated that, in the next ten years, a million new teachers will need to be recruited and developed.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 8 -- The American Bar Association condemned today the mass killing of innocent peoples, but rejected the United Nations' genocide convention in its present form. After three hours of hot debate, the association's House of Delegates adopted a "compromise" resolution which disapproved the treaty because it involved vital constitutional questions.

A few Southern bedroom furniture manufacturers have increased prices between 2 and 8 per cent because of increased expenses resulting from the recent change in minimum wage legislation, manufacturers' representatives reported yesterday.

Hemphill, Noyes Co., investment bankers and members of the New York Stock Exchange, announced yesterday plans to acquire the business of the New York Stock Exchange firm of Graham, Parsons Co. With completion of the transaction, the name of the investment firm will be Hemphill, Noyes, Graham, Parsons Co.

Thousands of subway travelers were stranded in Manhattan and Brooklyn yesterday when a southbound express train was derailed in the Atlantic Avenue station, cutting off transportation between the two boroughs on the IRT system for five hours.
TEL AVIV, Sept. 8 -- The Knesset (Assembly) unanimously approved tonight a bill providing for conscription of men between 18 and 49 and national service for women between 18 and 34.

LOBATSI, Bechuanaland, Sept. 8 -- Should Ruth Khama, the former Ruth Williams, London stenographer, ever realize her ambition of becoming the "white queen" of an African tribe she may at the same time discover that she is a pauper.
The Cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was fairly active yesterday and final prices were 16 to 31 points, or 80 cents to $1.55 a bale, net lower.
Edward A. Norman, in a letter published in THE NEW YORK TIMES on Sept. 2, makes three misleading statements about the relationship of the United States to a European union.
AUSTIN, Tex., Sept. 8 (AP) -- The Western Union Telegraph Company was barred today from furnishing racing information service which the state of Texas charged had been going to "bookie" shops.

The stock market encountered some resistance yesterday in its attempt to return to the high mark set in mid-August, but still closed with an advance. Extreme gains for the day were shaded in the final hour, when buying diminished and most stocks were left to seek their own levels.

In your editorial of Sept. 3 on "Aftermath of Nazism," you refer to the reports of your correspondents which brought to light a systematic boycott by the local German governments of persons who had worked for or assisted the occupation authorities. Anti-Nazis are excluded from the civil service of the new government because the officials are in the main former Nazis or their sympathizers.
