Once more the Soviet Union has prevented the entry of a candidate into the United Nations. The Himalayan kingdom of Nepal was first subject to scrutiny to see if it complied with the terms of the Charter. That consumed many months. Apparently it did so conform, since the Soviet Union took no occasion, this time, to attack the state or its rulers.

TED WILLIAMS was sitting in front of his locker at the Yankee Stadium yesterday. It never is difficult to get him talking. The difficulty usually is that the restless Red Sox slugger rarely remains stationary long enough to get any conversation out of him. He was discovered giving himself and his locker-room neighbors, Bobby Doerr and Dom DiMaggio, a pep talk.

The mythical family that has been occupying Sloane's "House of Years" for some seasons past has now terminated its lease and is about to be replaced by another, judging by the redecorating which has been going on there for the last six weeks. The house will be reopened to the public on Monday.

Preacher Roe requested the starting assignment against the Giants yesterday at Ebbets Field and Burt Shotton granted it. Along about the seventh inning, Roe, Shotton and all the Dodgers had cause to regret the switch from Ralph Branca to the veteran southpaw, who was shelled from the box in the seventh.

Chile and Ireland will compete this year in the National Horse Show at Madison Square Garden, Nov. 1-8, according to the prize lists sent yesterday to exhibitors throughout the country. The South Americans, now training at Harrisburg, Pa., will be here for the first time in ten years, while the Irish last were seen at the 1947 show.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 (AP) -- Still further improvements in the job picture were reported today by the Bureau of Employment Security.

George I. Marcus and Theodore J. Vogel, through their Mount Prospect Gardens, Inc., have obtained two building loans totaling $1,414,000 on garden apartments in progress in Newark and Bloomfield, N. J. Both loans, insured by the Federal Housing Administration, were obtained from the County Trust Company of White Plains, N. Y. The Stalford Mortgage Company was the broker in both transactions.
ATHENS, Sept. 9 -- The Communist party of Greece will not be permitted to reinstate itself as a legal party "for some time to come," a Government source said today.

ST. CERGUE, Switzerland, Sept. 9 -- Dr. Chisholm compared mankind's position to that of the brontosaurus, a pre-historic monster that became extinct because it could no longer adapt itself to the present.

SPRINGDALE, Conn., Sept. 9 -- Walter S. Hoyt and Duncan Edwards of the Greenwich Country Club, who won the qualifying medal, led the way through the first round as match play began today in Woodway Country Club's eighth member-guest golf tournament.
The Central Committee of the Soviet Communist party has shaken up its group of theoreticians, discharging eight of them, including two well-known Soviet economists, it became known yesterday.

GENEVA, Sept. 9 -- Known forms of biological warfare have made the atomic bomb and all other forms of armament obsoluete, Dr. Brock Chisholm, Director General of the World Health Organization said today.
The Transcontinental Gas Pipe Line Corporation plans to extend its delivery of natural gas from Texas into Westchester County and to the New York-Connecticut state line, it was announced yesterday.

CANBERRA, Sept. 9 (Reuters) -- Prime Minister J. B. Chifiey told a press conference today that Australia would welcome investment in Australia by United States companies prepared to use dollars to establish industries.

HARTFORD, Sept. 9 -- Mrs. Winifred McDonald, Secretary of State, today urged town and city officials in Connecticut to extend voting hours in local elections on Oct. 3 so Jewish voters could go to the polls after sunset, the end of their Yom Kippur observance.

Retail sales increased slightly during the week as more seasonal weather and a general stimulation of public interest arrived. Department store sales were estimated to be about 2 per cent above the corresponding week last year. Sales last week were 6 per cent below last year.

WILDWOOD, N. J., Sept. 9 -- Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll, speaking today before the opening session of the thirty-first annual convention of the American Legion, Department of New Jersey, pledged a "strengthening and carrying forward" of the state government's veterans' program.
WESTFIELD, N. J. -- A team of Philadelphia girls defeated a squad representing the New York metropolitan district today in the renewal of a links competition which had been suspended since 1941.

Thirty-three Austrian students, who were selected for study at American colleges under a program administered by the Army's Institute of International Education, were among the 534 passengers who arrived here yesterday on the United States Lines Marine Tiger.
Here's consolation at a time when a dollar bill disappears into the cash register in return for a dozen eggs or a pound of steak:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -- Headed by Henry Morgenthau Jr., more than 800 Jewish leaders from thirty-four states will meet at the Hotel Statler here tomorrow for the opening of the emergency national conference of the United Jewish Appeal.

Reports from several sections of Maine, New Brunswick and Quebec indicate that this has been an excellent rearing and nesting year for the ruffed grouse, and an interesting shooting season is assured in these areas.
KING CITY, Calif., Sept. 9 (AP) -- Brisk winds hampered efforts of nearly 300 firefighters today to control flames sweeping through Los Padres National Forest near the central California coast.
RYE, N. Y., Sept. 9 -- Forty-six debutantes made their bows to society tonight at the tenth Westchester cotillion held here at the Shenrock Shore Club.

FORT DIX, N. J., Sept. 9 -- While two airmen bailed out of a burning "flying boxcar" over Camden this morning, four other crew members stayed with the ship, extinguished the fire and landed safely at McGuire air force base here two hours later.

BRIDLINGTON, England, Sept. 9 -- Beginning Oct. 1, the British Actors Equity Association means to carry out its intention of collecting a 5 per cent subscription from the salaries of all American theatrical performers appearing in Britain, John Keet, assistant general secretary of the association, said today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -- The reciprocal trade agreements bill now being debated in the Senate would give President Truman "the power to destroy any American industry," Senator Robert A. Taft said today.
SOUTHAMPTON, Eng., Sept. 9 (AP) -- America's Ryder Cup team with its chuck wagon of 600 steaks, half a dozen hams, four boxes of bacon and twelve sides of beef arrived on the Queen Elizabeth today.
Efforts are being made to salvage the fortune left by Jonce I. McGurk, noted collector and authority on early American art, it was learned yesterday from friends.

LONDON, Sept. 9 -- The establishment of committees at the Washington dollar conference of Britain, the United States and Canada, to consider the possibility of increasing commodity stockpiling and revising United States import duties downward for British goods has encouraged the hope here that some good will come out of the conference.

As the site for an impressive cathedral and cultural center, the Armenian Church in America has assembled a plot of about 16,000 square feet facing St. Gabriel's Park and playground at Second Avenue and Thirty-fifth Street.

HAVANA, Sept. 9 -- The United States delegation at the Congress of the Inter-American Confederation of Workers today proposed a comprehensive long-range program for economic development of Latin America.

A hearing for John David Provoo, charged with treason, was postponed until Sept. 30 when the 33-year-old former sergeant appeared yesterday before Federal Commissioner Edward W. McDonald. The postponement was granted at the request of both Provoo and of the Government.

HONG KONG, Sept. 9 -- A few days ago a box containing an ornate new Mongol saddle was dumped unceremoniously into the room of Donald Gilpatric at the Gloucester Hotel here. With the saddle came the information that it was the property of President Truman and should be forwarded to him.

The Federal Communications Commission has rejected a proposal by the ABC, CBS and NBC networks that it issue a general stay of its ban on give-away programs pending a decision in the court actions brought by the chains.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -- Average primary market prices advanced 0.2 per cent in the week ended on Sept. 6, according to the United States Department of Labor's Bureau of Labor Statistics. The index was 152.7 per cent of the 1926 average, the same as four weeks ago and 9.3 per cent below the comparable week in 1948.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 9 -- Operations in the Missouri Pacific Railroad's 7,200-mile system came to a standstill tonight as 5,200 trainmen went on strike. More than 20,000 other employes were laid off for the duration of the walkout.

PORT ARTHUR, Ont., Sept. 9 (Canadian Press) -- The lakehead cities of Port Arthur and Fort William protested today a proposal by Imperial Oil; Ltd., to build part of its $90,000,000 Alberta-to-Ontario oil pipeline through the United States.

E. Tappan Stannard, who had been president of the Kennecott Corporation since May, 1933, was born Dec. 9, 1882, in Chittenango, N. Y. He attended the Phillips-Andover Academy and was graduated in 1905 from the Sheffield Scientific School of Yale University.

BOONTON, N. J., Sept. 9 -- Mrs. Joseph J. Mason of Ridgewood set a competitive course record of 75 at The Knoll Country Club today to top a field of eighty in a one-day tournament of the Women's New Jersey Golf Association. She carded 38, 37 -- 75 against a women's par of 37, 39 -- 76.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 9 -- The British motorship Pacific Enterprise, with a crew of fifty-four and five passengers ran aground in thick fog this morning near Point Area Lighthouse, 100 miles north of San Francisco.

HARTFORD, Conn., Sept. 9 (AP) -- Connecticut's Adjutant General said today that Capt. Tee Broderick of New Bedford, Mass., had only himself to blame for the strafing of his fishing boat by one of a group of National Guard planes at No Man's Island on Sept. 2.

CAUX SUR MONTREUX, Switzerland, Sept. 9 -- Two Germans who had been Communists for twenty-five years told an audience that included many of Europe's leading industrialists today how to convert people away from Marxism.

In a deal for cash over a mortgage of $50,000, the six-story limestone apartment building on a lot 25 by 102 feet at 16 East Eightieth Street, near Fifth Avenue, has been sold by Miss Eva Gabor, motion-picture actress, to an investor through Samuel J. Landau, broker.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -- A $1,314,010,000 foreign military aid program, embodying nearly all that the Administration had asked, was provisionally approved today by the Senate Foreign Relations and Armed Services Committees.

ALBANY, Sept. 9 -- The State Board of Law Examiners announced today the results of the state bar examinations conducted on June 23 and 24, in which 716 of the 1,488 applicants examined achieved passing marks. Of the total passing, 561 live in the Greater New York area.

A 25 per cent price cut on men's worsted suits will feature its fortieth anniversary sale to be held next week by Bond Stores, Inc., officials of the manufacturing clothing chain announced here yesterday. The offering was described as "the greatest sale of suits in Bond history," with every suit in stock except gabardines and formal wear subject to the reduction.

The story of an ice skater who was forced to join the musicians union because he played three random notes on a clarinet came to light yesterday in the jurisdictional dispute between James C. Petrillo's American Federation of Musicians and the Associated Actors and Artistes of America, parent body of all performer groups.

LONDON, Sept. 9 (UP) -- The London Times diplomatic correspondent reported today that Royal Air Force bombers destroyed a fort erected by an armed force from Yemen inside British territory of the Western Aden Protectorate.

MEXICO CITY, Sept. 9 -- After having been bypassed for three days on various pretexts, O. John Rogge, former Assistant United States Attorney General, finally was allowed to speak today to the Continental Congress for Peace.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 9 -- Reliable reports indicate that Yugoslav leaders have been greatly encouraged by the Export-Import Bank's loan of $20,000,000.
John Lawrence pitched a two-hitter to lead the New York Orphan All-Stars to a 10-3 triumph over the Boys Town baseball team at the Polo Grounds yesterday before 3,500 fans.

MOSCOW, Sept. 9 -- Pravda said today that President Truman was talking "through his hat" in speaking of a Soviet surrender in the "cold war" and called on the United States to end "its protracted hysterics" because "everybody is fed up with talk of the cold war."

CHICAGO, Sept. 9 -- The Government's estimates of this year's crops of corn, oats and soybeans were about in line with the trade's expectations. Corn and oats did not show as low as recent private returns, while the figures of soybeans were slightly smaller.

DENVER, Sept. 9 -- The question that is of great concern today to the general public, the medical profession and psychologists -- should psychologists practice psychotherapy? -- was answered tonight by Dr. William C. Menninger, a world leader in psychiatry.
TRENTON, N. J., Sept. 9 (AP) -- The state police said an eleven-state alert was sounded tonight for a 5-year-old girl kidnapped from a Trenton street.

Newbold Morris, Republican-Liberal - Fusion candidate, declared last night that, when elected Mayor of New York, he would use the tremendous prestige of that office to call upon President Truman to appoint a commission with broader powers than the Hoover Commission to study the tax system and would then call upon Congress to enact legislation for a complete revision of the tax structure, state and national, to end duplication.

Dr. William Jansen, Superintendent of Schools, warned 1,800 newly appointed teachers yesterday that they must be concerned with the effects upon their pupils of the tensions and fears that now grip the world.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -- President Truman's board of inquiry in the steel dispute will recommend pensions and social insurance, with important qualifications, but no general wage increase, it was reported tonight.

An old friend returns to racing today. Mrs. Ethel D. Jacobs' Stymie, out of action since July of last year, is among the ten entered in the thirtieth running of the $20,000 added Edgemere Handicap at Aqueduct. Stymie won it in 1946 and was runner-up in the nine-furlong run in 1947.

HONG KONG, Sept. 9 (UP) -- The Chinese Communists concentrated most of their South China strength today in an area about 160 miles north of Canton in what appeared to be the start of their "big push" south.

The five-story remodeled apartment building at 63 Eighth Avenue, Brooklyn, accommodating twelve families, has been sold by the Sterling Investing Corporation to Eva Porcaro. The seller took back a purchase money first mortgage of $24,000.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -- Sir Stafford Cripps, British Chancellor of the Exchequer, told a National Press Club audience today that nothing less than the collective security of the Western world was at stake in the successful outcome of the conference of Ministers of the United States, Britain and Canada.
The futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was quiet yesterday and fluctuations were within a narrow range. Final prices were 2 points higher to 5 points lower.

NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 9 (AP) -- Britain's long hold on the Indian market is being broken by lower priced goods from other countries, including the United States, Government and private import figures revealed today.
SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Sept. 9 -- Mayor O'Dwyer unofficially opened his campaign for re-election here today with an outspoken attack on the Eighty-first Congress.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Sept. 9 (AP) -- Arthur B. Hancock Jr. made a good buy when he acquired the 4-year-old filly Shimmer at Saratoga for $6,500. In her first start for Hancock, she breezed home in the Morris County Purse before 10,500 racegoers today.

The report of Abraham and Straus, Inc., for the fifty-two weeks ended on July 30, shows net sales of $66,692,044, and a net profit of $2,795,212. For the fifty-two weeks to July 31, 1948, net sales were $66,160,180, and the net profit was $2,214,474.

Of all the celebrations and parades in and around Labor Day, there are none more significant than the tournaments of local volunteer fire departments. These annual high jinks are days of public recognition for a job well done the year long. They are undeniably festive.

A proposal to increase the corporation's authorized capital stock by 600,000 shares so that stock can be sold to two corporations holding purchase options will be voted upon by stockholders of National Airlines, Inc., at their annual meeting on Sept. 29 in Miami, Fla., G. T. Baker, president, announced yesterday.

SHAWNEE - ON - DELAWARE, Pa., Sept. 9 (AP) -- Three former national amateur golf champions came through successfully today in opening matches of the fourth Waite Memorial best-ball tournament at the Shawnee Inn course.

FARNBOROUGH, England, Sept. 9 -- The father of the jet engines, Sir Frank Whittle and Prime Minister Attlee and his Cabinet members saw Britain's all out air show today. They united in saying that developments of the jet and turbo-prop airliners promised within five years to place Britain at the top of commercial aviation.
PITTSBURGH, Sept. 9 (AP) -- Andy Pafko's grand slam homer capped a seven-run fifth inning tonight as the Cubs crushed the Pirates, 8 -- 1, behind the three-hit pitching of Walt Dubiel.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 9 -- The "Tokyo Rose" who chided Allied troops as "boneheads" and bade them leave their "stinking, mosquito-infested islands" for home before all their ships were sunk was not Mrs. Iva Toguri D'Aquino, the Los Angeles-born Nisei insisted today at her treason trial.

BUFFALO, Sept. 9 -- Police of both Niagara and Erie Counties tonight were still looking for CIO union leaders who are accused in warrants bearing their names of inciting two days of rioting and bloodshed outside the struck Bell Aircraft Corporation plant on Niagara Falls Boulevard.

Among the many union alarms and excursions, against the Third Avenue lines one claim that appeals strongly to the public's sense of fairness is the demand of the men that they receive their $1,100,000 in retroactive pay. The work that this pay represents was done as long ago as late 1947 and early 1948.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -- A national committee of fifty-two, meeting in the East Wing of the White House, today set the week of Dec. 3, 1950, for the Mid-Century White House Conference on Children and Youth.

The polio epidemic in this city is "definitely" on the wane, Dr. Harry S. Mustard, Health Commissioner, declared yesterday in releasing statistics showing that the number of cases recorded by his department had declined for the third successive week.
The picketing of the British delegation at present in this country by a group of minor American politicians, in the name of Ireland, deserves immediate attention.

After a slight slump this week due to the Labor Day holiday, steel operations are expected to increase next week unless an industry strike should materialize after the fact-finding board makes its report today in the wage dispute. The Youngstown, Ohio, area is particularly experiencing the pressure of demand for steel products.

KANSAS CITY, Sept. 9 (AP) -- Dick Metz, the gentleman farmer from Arkansas City, Kan., posted a 36-hole score of 137, seven under par, to take the half-way lead in the $5,000 Kansas City open golf tournament today.

Two important measures affecting immigration and naturalization have been adopted in the House of Representatives, but are still languishing in the Senate's Judiciary Committee. On March 1 the House adopted the Judd bill providing for limited immigration (quotas of 100 a year) from Asiatic countries not covered by previous legislation.

Foreign buyers of American textiles are holding up orders awaiting the outcome of current Anglo-American currency talks, according to New York exporters. A perceptible decline in business, they said, has been felt in the last few weeks even though the rising market here would ordinarily tend to stimulate trade.

Warren R. Smith has been appointed assistant to the president and director of public relations of Fairchild Engine and Airplane Corporation. All corporate public relations functions of the company have been transferred to Hagerstown, Md.

The St. John's Guild Floating Hospital for Children broke a precedent yesterday for the first time since its inception in 1875. Its cargo was 625 oldsters and twenty-five social workers, cruising down the bay from Pier 70 at East Twenty-second Street to Sandy Hook and back.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Sept. 3, were 703,930 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 42,982 cars, or 5.8 per cent, fewer than for the preceding week, 191,201 cars, or 21.4 per cent, fewer than for the corresponding week last year and 105,009 cars, or 13.0 per cent, fewer than for the corresponding week two years ago.

Coffee futures were strong and very active with all delivery positions in both contracts advancing to new highs on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange yesterday. Buying by trade interests and short covering of the nearby delivery positions along with strong demand from producer interests and local trade houses for the more distant months advanced prices in Contract "S" by 28 to 64 points above the levels of the previous close.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 9 -- The strike that started today against the Missouri Pacific Railroad was caused by the same kind of contractual disagreements that provoked the week-long walkout against the Wabash Railroad Company last March, a spokesman for one of the participating brotherhoods explained at its general headquarters.

BOSTON, Sept. 9 -- Czechoslovakia moved its international trade fair into Boston today, placing $1,000,000 worth of its manufacture products on dispulay in a two-week bid to attract more American dollars.

ROME, Sept. 9 -- Passenger traffic in the port of Genoa was paralyzed today when the seamen's strike spread to the liner Atlantic. The Atlantic arrived from New York yesterday afternoon, and although she is of Panamanian registry, her all-Italian crew was immediately called out on strike.

Lack of financial support from the public threatens to disband the Motor Transport Unit of the American Women's Voluntary Services, Mrs. Lester K. Thorman, corps chairman, said yesterday. Two more cars were sold this week to shrink the unit from a war peak of thirty-four vehicles to nine station wagons to shuttle disabled veterans and civilians between hospitals and homes.

BOSTON, Sept. 9 (AP) -- Federal Judge William T. McCarthy upheld today a Securities and Exchange Commission complaint charging that Trusteed Funds, Inc., of State Street, sold more than $43,000,000 of securities to New Englanders by "making untrue statements of material facts."

BERLIN, Sept. 9 -- Political and other prisoners now held in Soviet zone concentration camps total 47,280, according to the United States-licensed newspaper Abend. As authority for this report the paper cited individuals working closely with Soviet security agencies.

ATLANTA, Sept. 9 -- A program calling upon the white churchwomen of the South to accompany their Negro employes to voters' registration centers to insure "equal" treatment in enrollment, was approved today at a conference of regional church workers.

Sixty scholars in the fields of philosophy, science and religion closed a four-day meeting yesterday at Columbia University on a common theme. Spokesmen for the three areas of a conference devoted to "integration" agreed that obfuscation had come first.

Somewhere in the broad Atlantic John Gau, a 47-year-old mariner, is heading for these shores in his tiny ketch of undetermined length and tonnage. Nobody would venture a guess as to the time of his arrival.

HAVERFORD, Pa., Sept. 9 -- The United States won the first three matches without the loss of a set in defense of the Wightman Cup against the British at the Merion Cricket Club today and an American victory in the series may be accepted as inevitably in store tomorrow.

CHICAGO, Sept. 9 -- Three more high ranking officials have resigned from the merchandising staff of Montgomery Ward Co., it was learned today. Two who quit in the last few days were A. Fred Greenwood, in charge of all nondirect mail order business, and V. F. Peterson, an executive in the major appliance division.

"Saints and Sinners," a British-made comedy-drama of life in an Irish village, will open today at the Little Carnegie. Kieron Moore, Michael Dolan, Sheila Manahan and Maire O'Neill have the principal roles in this folk tale, which was written originally for the screen by Paul Vincent Carroll.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -- Intended as a move for economy, the first merger of Government agencies has actually resulted in the employment of 140 new persons, the Joint Committee on Reduction of Nonessential Federal Expenditures stated today.

Kid Gavilan had a much rougher time than he expected with Rocky Castellani, courageous middle-weight from Luzerne, Pa., in the ten-round bout that featured the return of boxing to Madison Square Garden last night.

GENEVA, Sept. 9 -- The formation of a corporation representing Italian, United States and Latin-American interests to undertake large-scale economic development of Peru, Bolivia, Ecuador, Colombia, Venezuela and the northern part of Brazil has reached the stage of advanced planning, it was learned here today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 (AP) -- The Government estimated this year's corn crop today at 3,525,741,000 bushels, a figure that virtually assures Federal controls next year to hold down production. A crop of this size would add to the big surplus of livestock feed grain resulting from last year's record of 3,650,000,000 bushels.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -- The special Navy court of inquiry established to determine full responsibility for an anonymous attack on the Air Force that prompted the Congressional inquiry into the B-36 bomber program recessed today until Sept. 21 to give its counsel time for further investigations.

Michael Todd's variety offering, "Two-A-Day," will make its local debut at the Winter Garden on Saturday evening, Sept. 24, it was learned yesterday. Asked to confirm the booking, the producer said last night that for the time being he preferred not to comment on the arrangement.

ALTHOUGH we are having some sort of an Italian literary renaissance born of the war ("A Bell For Adano," "The Gallery," "The Girl on the Via Flaminia" and, perhaps appropriately enough, after all, numerous books by Italian writers) the recent stories in that field seem to be studiously overlooking that leading modern creation of Italian fiction, a character called, if memory serves, Benito Mussolini.

The forces for the recovery on the stock market took to the sidelines yesterday and, as a result, prices drifted narrowly throughout the session and finished irregularly lower. Fractional alterations predominated with the composite rate lowered 0.34 point on the day.

The mercury dropped 11 degrees below normal for Sept. 9, the Weather Bureau reported yesterday. The low of the day came at 7 A. M. when the temperature was 53 degrees. By 5 P. M. it had climbed to 64. A spokesman for the bureau said the normal temperature for a Sept. 9 was 69 degrees.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Sept. 9 -- A pledge of loyalty to the Czechoslovak Republic that the Vatican has authorized the hierarchy and 6,000 Roman Catholic priests of this country to take was made public by church sources today.

NARROWSBURG, N. Y., Sept. 9 -- Congress was urged to liberalize the Displaced Persons Act of 1948 and the Senate was asked to establish quickly its proposed committee on investigation of a resurgence of nazism in Germany in resolutions adopted at today's closing session of the National Jewish Youth Conference at Camp Wel-Met.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 9 -- Fernando Lamas, Argentine actor, singer and Olympic swimmer, has been signed to a term contract by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer and will probably make his American screen debut in the studio's forthcoming musical potpourri "Summer Stock," it was learned today.
CHICAGO, Sept. 9 (Science Service) -- Allergy plays an important role in the susceptibility to colds, an editorial in the Journal of the American Medical Association asserted today.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 9 (AP) -- Led by Dale Mitchell, who pounded out a home run and a triple, the Claveland Indians got back on the victory trail tonight as they handed the St. Louis Browns their sixth straight defeat, 5 to 2. Home runs by Jack Graham and Stan Spence accounted for the only runs given up by Mike Garcia.

The Advance Pattern Company presented a fashion show yesterday afternoon in the Roosevelt Hotel to home economists who have been attending a clothing seminar at Syracuse University. Speakers were Miss Virginia Pope, fashion editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES, and Margaret George de Mille, merchandise editor of Mademoiselle Magazine.

A retail merchandising and advertising manual for November, showing that month to be the second best for selling Christmas and winter items, has been prepared by the Retail Division of the Bureau of Advertising of the American Newspapers Publishers Association, it was announced yesterday.

A report by Sheriff Fred W. Ruscoe of Westchester County on last Sunday's disturbances incidental to a concert near Peekskill by Paul Robeson, baritone and left wing political figure, was released yesterday without comment by Governor Dewey.

PARIS, Sept. 9 -- Mention of the name of Mme. Helene Lupescu, wife of former King Carol of Rumania, during high mass was said today to have been responsible for violent scenes in the Rumanian Orthodox Church here. The officiating priest was said to have been dragged from the church and ejected from his position by the parishioners.
Dr. Frantisek Kase in his letter published Aug. 16 employs an unfair method of criticizing a lengthy series of articles on Czechoslovakia by selecting a few passages out of context from one dispatch.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 9 (AP) -- The Philadelphia Athletics made a clean sweep of their three-game set with Washington by taking the series final, 5 -- 2, tonight before 1,518 fans, the smallest floodlight crowd of the local major league season.

You are to be commended for correctly pointing out in THE TIMES of Sept. 5 that the motives which prompted the Soviet flier Barsov to return to the Soviet Union are not yet known. By comparison your editorial in the Sept. 2 issue on "The Slavic Soul" in most deplorable.

Four ships of the United States Navy have just paid a courtesy call at a Spanish port, the first since the republic fell to the forces of France and Mussolini. In the course of this official visit the commander of the United States naval forces in the Mediterranean and the Eastern Atlantic spent an hour in conference with the Generalissimo himself.
TORONTO, Sept. 9 (Canadian Press) -- The Ontario Securities Commission has resumed jurisdiction over the extent of offerings of securities made in the United States and other points outside Ontario.

A strong fight against imposition of any new taxes on tobacco products was promised in a resolution adopted last night by the Retail Tobacco Dealers of America, Inc., at the annual meeting at the Hotel Astor.
The nineteenth annual observance of Religious Education Week will be held from Sept. 25 to Oct. 2.
NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 9 (AP) -- An American syndicate that has recently purchased a Pakistani newspaper is now seeking to buy papers in principal Indian cities, its representative said today.

Winners in the eighth annual scholarship awards of the Men's League in Aid of Crippled Children were announced yesterday by C. Clarence Kaskel, president of the league. The scholarships will be presented next Friday to fifteen boys and girls between the ages of 16 and 21 years "who have demonstrated by their ability that they are capable of defeating their own physical handicaps."

Most homemakers admit the advantages of venetian blinds and admire their flexibility in controlling light and sun, but are loathe to have this type of window covering because of the great amount of work they believe is entailed in keeping them clean and in good repair.

ALBANY, Sept. 9 -- Governor Dewey disclosed tonight that he was prepared to order local police forces in Western New York to come to the assistance of Sheriff Henry E. Becker of Niagara County if necessary to prevent further violence in connection with the thirteen-week-old Bell Aircraft strike.
PORT WASHINGTON, N. Y., Sept. 9 -- It really blew for the third regatta of the Manhasset Bay fall race series, which was mostly blown away today.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Sept. 9 -- The Dutch Government has drawn up a detailed draft of the statute of union between the Netherlands and Indonesia to replace the 300 years of Dutch colonial rule over the rich Pacific archipelago.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -- A Senate Judiciary subcommittee moved today toward broadening the base of admission of displaced persons. Testimony of witnesses urging that 10,000 Arab refugees be included in pending amendments to the Displaced Persons Act was taken.

PEEKSKILL, N. Y., Sept. 9 -- In a re-examination of the violence that marked recent demonstrations against Paul Robeson and his leftwing followers, persons in this politically conservative city of 18,600 were wondering today whether they could best oppose communism by continuing open battle or by learning to turn their backs on the controversy.

Officials at the United Cigar-Whelan Stores Corporation's thirty-fifth annual showing of fall and winter merchandise yesterday in the New Yorker Hotel reported an all-time high of purchasing at the show.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -- The United States, charging a breakdown of normal "international intercourse," today sharply reduced its diplomatic representation in Communist-held China.
JERSEY CITY, N. J., Sept. 9 -- It appeared today that this city will have its first new public school building in twenty years.

The $20,000,000 loan which this country has just made to Yugoslavia, through the Export-Import Bank, represents less than fifteen cents for each inhabitant of the United States. In practical terms it will enable Marshal Tito to fix up his mining machinery and other key apparatus.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -- The political talks that will occupy Secretary of State Dean Acheson and British Foreign Secretary Ernest Bevin after the dollar discussions end early next week will find the foreign policies of the United States and Britain in harmonious agreement on most of the world's tormented areas, it was indicated today.

HONG KONG, Sept. 9 -- A stronger anti-Communist stand by Gen. Lu Han in return for his greater freedom in managing the financial, political and military affairs of Yunnan Province was reported here tonight to have been the basis for settlement of differences between General Lu, governor of the province, and Nationalist Government leaders.

It was brought out at the Communist trial yesterday that the party quit the Communist International in 1940 and changed its constitution in 1945 so that its leaders would not have to register as foreign agents.
VIENNA, Sept. 9 -- A carefree Brooklyn youth told today how he had pedaled blithely through the Russian zone of Austria with an American flag flying on his bicycle.
WARSAW, Sept. 9 -- Angry editorials approving the Government's action accompanied the publication today of Poland's renunciation of the mutual-assistance treaty with Yugoslavia.

FAIRFIELD, Ill., Sept. 9 -- Another of the notorious Sheltons -- this time "Little Earl," 29-year-old ex-GI and nephew of the better-known brothers who terrorized central Illinois in the 1920's and have controlled gambling in this region ever since -- was ambushed and shot down shortly after midnight last night in front of his modest Fairfield home.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 9 (AP) -- A minority stockholder of the Eastern States Corporation today brought an injunction suit against the management of the investment company seeking to stop a stock trade involving the St. Regis Paper Company.
ST. JOACHIM, Que., Sept 9 -- A Quebec Airways plane crashed and burned on a barren mountainside near here today, killing all twenty - three persons aboard.

ENGLEWOOD, N. J., Sept. 9 -- A part of the New Jersey section of the Palisades Interstate Parkway, described by the New Jersey State Highway Department as "one of the future wonders of the world" because of the scenery that will be unfolded to motorists, is beginning to take shape atop the Palisades as engineers cut with extreme care through the woodland.

CAMDEN, N. J., Sept. 9 -- Moments before the wild shooting spree in which he killed thirteen persons, Howard B. Unruh, a strapping six-foot Army veteran, had suddenly swung around in the living room of his home and, with an upraised wrench, threatened his mother, a frail 50-year-old woman of less than 100 pounds.
DES MOINES, Sept. 9 (UP) -- F. G. Macomber, dean of the Drake University College of Education, said today that a modern child could hardly wait to get back to classes.
SYRACUSE, N. Y., Sept. 9 (AP) -- Scoring eight unearned runs in the tenth inning, Newark managed to swap shutouts with Syracuse tonight, winning, 8 to 0, after losing the opener, 2 to 0.

YONKERS, N. Y., Sept. 9 -- The work of electing a member of the Common Council and a new Mayor of this city on the basis of the 1947 balloting continued today with twenty-five canvassers recounting 13,000 proportional representation ballots at the state armory here.

A broken rail during the rush hour yesterday on the Lexington Avenue IRT subway tied up northbound local traffic between Forty-second and 125th Streets for nearly two hours and compelled hundreds of passengers in four stalled trains to walk through many cars to reach the street at the Seventy-seventh Street station.

The tripartite economic talks in Washington have not gone far enough to know what results -- or the lack of them -- we may expect. Yet the three days of discussion between Americans, Britons and Canadians have shown us enough to lift one great load of anxiety from the minds of those here and in Great Britain who were preparing for or thinking about this conference.

A rich shipment of Russian furs and skins valued at $1,000,000 is being unloaded from the Swedish freighter Kristina Thorden at pier B. Jersey City, N. J., it was announced yesterday. The shipment, one of several that have arrived here from Leningrad recently, consisted of hundreds of bales of different types of furs, including lamb, weasel, martin, sable, ermine and broadtail, according to Boise-Griffin, agents for the ship here.
SYDNEY, N. S., Sept. 9 (Canadian Press) -- Cmdr. Donald B. MacMillan came out of an Arctic gale today with a new map of the Labrador coast and a collection of fossils.
Because of the influx of Puerto Ricans here the Health Department has a language problem on its hands, it was learned yesterday.

The first step in eight years toward freeing imported supplies of tin for eventual open-market buying by American consumers was taken yesterday when the British Ministry of Supply announced a new consignment sales plan under which sub-agents here will have tin on hand to sell to American buyers.

Life in Manhattan never was simple, even in the old, old days. Making money involved a lot of toil and trouble. Wampum-producers had to be up on their periwinkles and clam shells, but they took a beating on breakage.

Pilot Radio Corporation has adopted a new merchandising policy which offers its 130 television receiver dealers in fifteen states exclusive territorial franchises and a mark-up "making profitable operation possible," Edward M. Gilmore, domestic sales manager, disclosed yesterday.

CHICAGO, Sept. 9 -- Vice President Albert W. Barkley said today that "we now have a situation where we have got to decide whether for the period of adjustment we will have deficit financing or taxes to balance the peacetime budget of $42,000,000,000 annually.
DENVER, Sept. 9 -- The National Urban League ended its annual convention today with the unanimous adoption of a resolution decrying totalitarian exploitation of the race issue.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 (UP) -- Business inventories in July were about $1,100,000 less than in June, and amounted to $50,400,000,000, the Department of Commerce reported today.

Mayor O'Dwyer eliminated the threat of a strike Monday morning against the Third Avenue Transit System yesterday when he named Dr. Emanuel Stein to arbitrate the company's differences with the Transport Workers Union, CIO.

LAKE SUCCESS, Sept. 9 -- The struggle between the Communist countries of Europe and the Roman Catholic Church was brought into a United Nations chamber today with a Soviet Ukrainian charge that the Vatican excommunication order amounted to "moral suicide."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -- President Truman told a group of visiting Bishops of the Church of England today that the teachings of the Sermon on the Mount could do more than anything else to prevent wars if they could find universal acceptance.

The Rev. Dr. Glora M. Wysner, first woman ordained a Methodist minister in North Africa, has been appointed as a full secretary of the International Missionary Council effective Oct. 1. She is also the first woman to hold the latter post.

BRIDLINGTON, England, Sept. 9 -- Britain's trade unionists, upon whom the success of the country's recovery effort so much depends, concluded their annual convention here today without having learned exactly what was expected of them in the coming critical year.

GLEN HEAD, L. I., Sept. 9 -- Mrs. A. I. Freeman of Fairview scored 46, 46 -- 92, to win low-gross prize of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association one-day Class B tournament at the North Shore Country Club today. Mrs. E. K. Smith of Hempstead was second low, with 44, 51 -- 95.

September is a month when flower arrangements may be made on a lavish scale, for all kinds of flowers are blooming generously in the garden before frost comes. And the selection of blossoms in the florist shop reflects those in the gardens to a great extent.

SPRINGFIELD, N. J., Sept. 9 -- This town, rich in Revolutionary War landmarks and folklore, was virtually turned over to forty Pace College students today who were bent on an intensive one-day survey that will equip them to formulate an integrated picture of "a typical small American town in transition."
Announcement was made yesterday that Davidson County, Tenn., would receive bids on Sept. 28 on an issue of $3,750,000 of school bonds dated July 1, 1949, and due from 1950 to 1974.
The third day of effort by Cyrus S. Ching, director of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service, to settle the 132-day strike of Hawaiian longshoremen ended fruitlessly last night.

STONY BROOK, L. I., Sept. 9 -- Miss Carol Gussenhoven rode Mr. and Mrs. A. M. Willcox's aged chestnut mare, Rose Parade, to three handsome triumphs in the working hunter division of the annual North Shore horse show's second session at the Old Field Club today.

TOKYO, Sept. 9 -- The Government's order dissolving the leftist League of Korean Residents in Japan as an "anti-democratic and terrorist" group is the opening step in a campaign to outlaw all leftist organizations known to have participated in the recent Communist-inspired acts of violence, Japanese circles reported today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -- Commandants of the twelve naval districts ended a three-day conference here today by hearing the "Philadelphia Plan" for the re-employment of civilian Navy workers who are soon to be laid off for economy reasons.
In connection with the dollar-sterling currency discussions your readers may be interested to know the opinions of an ordinary middle-class business man in this country.
BOSTON, Sept. 9 -- Five hundred twenty-five Bostonians, led by the Most Rev. Richard J. Cushing, Roman Catholic Archbishop, sailed on the liner Britannica today for a pilgrimage to Ireland.

Cargo movements between the United States and the Mediterranean are expected to decline for another year, but the trade route probably will set a new post-war record in passenger travel, according to officials of the American Export Lines, Inc., leading American shipping line in this field.
CONCORD, N. H., Sept. 9 (AP) -- Dartmouth College President John Sloan Dickey said today he never had condoned the "ignoble conduct" that led to the death last March 18 of a Dartmouth student.

Lumber production in the week ended Sept. 3 was 2.3 per cent above the comparable week last year, according to reports wired yesterday to THE NEW YORK TIMES by trade associations. Shipments were up 10.8 per cent in the week and orders were 37.2 per cent higher.

The Lightnings may be all over town this week-end. That is another way of saying that the Seventy-eighth (Lightning) Infantry Division is holding its reunion at Fort Dix, N. J., where it was first activated thirty-two years ago, and may be expected to spill over into the Great White Way and other New York concourses part of that time.

William Katz, lessee of the vacant property at 51 West Street through to 82 Washington Street which he operates as a parking lot has purchased the plot from the Robert Walton Goelet estate in the first change of ownership since 1857.
CONCORD, N. H., Sept 9 (AP) -- Puerto Rican wages may be raised as a result of a Senate probe of Textron, Inc., at Nashua last year.

There are times when Joe McCarthy's power-laden Red Sox do contrive to harness their offensive skills to an excellent piece of moundsmanship and the result invariably is a superlative performance such as a gathering of 53,548 witnessed at the Stadium yesterday with mingled dismay and admiration.
BOGUBAYAZIDI, Turkey, Sept. 9 (AP) -- An American expedition gave up the hunt for Noah's Ark today after twelve days of fruitless search on Mount Ararat.

LONDON, Sept. 9 -- Rejection of the railway workers' claims for wages by the Government board displaced the Washington dollar conference for the time being as the main topic in the stock markets today, but brokers who had expected the markets to weaken as a reflection of renewed uncertainty found prices remarkably steady.

Leopold Shwarzschild, anti-Nazi German writer, formerly a prominent economist, who was forced into political exile during the Hitler regime, was found unconscious just after 10 A. M. yesterday in his apartment at 225 East Fifty-seventh Street, after seemingly having taken an overdose of sleeping pills. He was taken to Bellevue Hospital where his condition was reported critical last night.

Thomas Merton, whose new book, "The Waters of Siloe," will be issued by Harcourt, Brace Thursday, recently received the annual Catholic Literary Award given by the Gallery of Living Catholic Authors. The presentation was made by the Rev. Harold C. Gardiner, literary editor of America.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 9 (AP) -- Sixteen-year-old Hamilton Richardson of Baton Rouge, La., scored the first major upset of the Pacific Southwest Tennis championships today when he beat Eustace Fannin of South Africa, 6 -- 3, 6 -- 3. The Louisiana youth is competing in both the junior and senior divisions.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Sept. 9 (AP) -- Two white farmers, accused of kidnapping an Arkansas Negro for forced labor on their Missouri cotton farm, were arrested today by Federal authorities.

DETROIT, Sept. 9 -- Likelihood of an immediate strike against the Ford Motor Company faded today when the State Labor Mediation Board waived its thirty-day strike vote rule to permit the disputants to extend the deadline on a day-to-day basis beyond Sept. 13.

Paul Murray is one aspiring author who can be reasonably sure that his writing is down-to-earth. For his only opportunity to devote himself to literary pursuits comes on his off-hours from his regular job as a steward for Pan American Airways on regular flights to Europe, India, and Africa.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Sept. 9 -- The newest tournament on the Westchester P. G. A. schedule was introduced today to the Fenway Golf Club in the form of a foursome championship with the teams consisting of a club professional and a woman player as his partner.

BOSTON -- New England's vacation resorts attracted more visitors and dollars this summer than last year, despite a growing tendency among customers to shop for vacation values.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 10 -- Philip Murray's United Steelworkers of America, CIO, are prepared to call off their threatened strike if the steel companies will accept the terms recommended by President Truman's fact-finding board, it was reported here tonight.

WARSAW, Sept. 10 -- Polish athletic teams will not be allowed to participate in contests held in capitalistic countries unless they have a good chance of winning or unless the trip will have positive propaganda results, Trybunu Ludu, organ of the United Workers (Communst) party stated today.

THE American motion-picture industry still is doing a thriving business in England and, in one way or another, has been able to use to advantage about $37,000,000 of its earnings in Great Britain during the last year despite the country's dollar shortage and attendant restrictions on the transfer of pounds into dollars.

Two amateur radio operators, a couple of GI's and the United States Army can take credit for a mission of mercy on which an American Airlines plane left La Guardia Airport at 9 o'clock last night with sixteen capsules of aureomycin for a sick German youth in Hanover.

The book has the resounding title "Europaeische Literatur und Lateinisches Mittelalter" and the author is Ernst Robert Curtius, literary historian.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 10 -- Democrats of the Far West, particularly of California, are counting on producing a bumper crop of "political hay" at a conference here on Sept. 18 and 19.

ROBERT MONTGOMERY will embark on the new role of a radio news commentator at 10:10 next Thursday evening over the ABC network and WJZ in New York. The urbane motion-picture star has accepted the assignment with characteristic equanimity, but he does not intend it to interfere with his film-making here in England.
Dr. H. G. Creel's extremely interesting article, "The Man Who Lighted the Way in China," suffers, in my opinion, from a grave error.

A significant experiment in the development of leaders for America's public school system begins this fall at Harvard University's Graduate School of Education. For the first time a select group of educators will gather at Cambridge to begin a year's study as Education Fellows.

Marking the fact, that in the twenty-five years of its existence no strikes or lockouts have occurred in the men's clothing industry, the New York Clothing Manufacturers Exchange, Inc., last night held a silver anniversary dinner dance and entertainment in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. More than 800 guests were present.
DONCASTER, England, Sept. 10 -- Ridgewood, 100-to-7 shot ridden by one of Britain's oldest jockeys, won the St. Leger Stakes today before a crowd estimated at 400,000.

THE climax of the annual search for wild flowers is hunting fringed gentian, which blooms this month. This year, as always, enthusiasts are beginning to wonder whether they will find this loveliest of the American native flowers. It is almost as rare as it is famous.

THE organizational set-up of broadcasting here is at variance with the system in Canada, which has both private and government-owned stations, but both methods presently have one thing in common -- financial worries.

BERLIN, Sept. 10 -- Up to this evening, according to an official release from the headquarters, John J. McCloy, United States High Commissioner-designate, has received no reply to a letter delivered Sept. 4 to Soviet headquarters concerning the detention of two young American bicyclists who ventured into the East zone.

On the basis of present reports Chiang Kai-shek seems to have won a considerable diplomatic victory in the matter of the position of Yunnan province in southwest China. The revolt of the province and its swing to the Communists would have been a military disaster of the first order.

OKLAHOMA CITY, Sept. 10 -- The "Sooner State," where a bootlegger's airplane was grounded for non-payment of a repair and gasoline bill rather than for the flying in of illegal liquor, votes Sept. 27 on repeal of its constitutional prohibition.

BOSTON, Sept. 10 -- Although Bureau of Labor statistics indicate a slight drop in living costs in New England, a survey of actual prices in stores shows the decrease to be confined chiefly to household goods and apparel, in which there are surpluses. Food remains on the upgrade and market men saw signs of further increases.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 10 -- The Yugoslav delegation to the United Nations General Assembly left Belgrade this morning for Lake Success.

EVER since the first images flickered through the air, the goal of the television industry has been to provide coast-to-coast service similar to the existing radio system. Predictions as to when the video networks would span the country have probably been made more often -- and changed more often -- than any other estimate about TV's future.

WASHINGTON. INFLUENCE is Washington's most treasured commodity. The next dearest is knowing, and having access to, people who have it. Politicians, bureaucrats, lobbyists, newspaper men and the inevitable "five percenters" spend their professional lifetimes cultivating influence or the influential, and their usefulness on the Washington scene is measured in precise -- and rewarding -- ratio to the success of that quest.

The "ABC" conference -- the monetary conference of American, British and Canadian Ministers -- has been going on in Washington for four days. There have been highly technical discussions of intricate matters of economics, which Carlyle called the "dismal science."

WITH fall flower shows in the offing, preparation of specimen material should get under way promptly. Dahlias, zinnias and marigolds are some of the popular candidates, and their grooming starts at once.

STONY BROOK, L. I., Sept. 10 -- Adding two blues and a fourth in today's events to previous accomplishments, Black Watch, 8-year-old black gelding owned by Mrs. Don J. Ferraro of New York and ridden by Miss Peggy Mills, captured the open jumping championship of the annual North Shore horse show.
ATLANTA, Ga., Sept. 10 -- The cost of living in this area is down about three per cent from last year's levels and some observers foresee a continuing dip through early fall.

ALTHOUGH American foreign policy today is confronted with problems and challenges unknown in the early days of the Monroe Doctrine, we have much to learn from the statesmen who developed that great concept in our foreign relations.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 10 -- Stan (The Man) Musial took personal charge today to protect the St. Louis Cardinals' one-game lead over Brooklyn in the tight National League pennant race. He blasted a home run into the right field bleachers with two on and two out in the first of the ninth to give the Cards a 6-to-5 victory over the Cincinnati Reds.

EXCESSIVE speeds, reckless driving and lack of patience were the principal reasons for the appalling death toll (more than 400 in traffic accidents) and injury toll on the highways over the Labor Day weekend, according to the National Safety Council and the Association of Casualty and Surety Companies.

FALMOUTH, Mass., Sept. 10 (AP) -- Three brothers were left of the family of the Rev. Hubert Allenby. They were Alfred, Gilbert, 18, with the Air Force in Germany, and Norman, 14, who did not go on the boat trip on which four of the family died.

FAIR HILL, Md., Sept. 10 -- Replica II, Richard K. Mellon's veteran campaigner who was making his first start since falling in the Grand National at Aintree, England, last March, came back today to the scene of his impressive triumph last year and captured the tenth running of the Foxcatcher National Cup Steeplechase.

Mr. McFadyen ("Letter to the Editor," Aug. 21) is not the only person who flinches from the lash of literary criticism. And if that criticism is either false or malicious, one cannot help but flinch with him.

ON Capitol Hill today many an honest and earnest legislator is a study in frustration. These men, though they have shown no lack of energy or intelligence, find themselves with an anthology of alibis rather than a satisfactory list of accomplishments. The program that these men set out to achieve was a simple one, and they had a fairly clear mandate from the people to put it into effect.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- Political fires have been kindled from one end of the country to the other, to glow with an ever-increasing intensity from now until a year from next November, when there will be an election for all members of the House and one-third of the members of the Senate.

JAMES M. CURLEY, the "Purple Shamrock" of this semi-official biography, is 74 and still Mayor of Boston. Half of his years have been spent in public office representing Boston and most of the rest have been influential in Boston politics.

LOREN RUDD had never seen the Hat ranch when she inherited it from her father but she had convinced herself that the bitter feud with other landholders in Long Valley resulted only from old Hamp Rudd's refusal to sell so much as an acre of his vast range or to permit any outsider to have a drop of the Hat's water.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- The American Institute of Architects commended today the public service records of Lieut. Gen. Raymond A. Wheeler, Maj. Gen. Philip B. Fleming and Maj. Gen. U. S. Grant 3d.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Sept. 10 -- Former Governor Herbert H. Lehman began his race for the United States Senate here today with an indirect but obvious attack on the political credo of his Republican opponent, Senator John Foster Dulles.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 10 -- Dean Donald K. David of the Harvard Business School called on American business men today to assume a major role in the "war of ideals against communism."

A new book discussion group on "Science: Its History and Philosophy" has been announced by the New York Public Library. Thirty members with a background of science or experience in a related field will form the group, which will meet on alternate Wednesday evenings at the St. Agnes Branch, 444 Amsterdam Avenue.

Last Wednesday the Research Corporation, a non-profit organization interested chiefly in physical research, called a meeting in New York of distinguished organic chemists, representatives of foundations and chemists connected with pharmaceutical research laboratories for the purpose of discussing what should be done to increase the supply of cortisone, the compound that has proved so dramatically successful in the treatment of arthritis in the Mayo Clinic.

IT is difficult to characterize these letters written from Europe and illustrated with pen-and-ink sketches by Booth Tarkington. They are full of high-hearted and boyish nonsense, fantastic and fanciful, but beneath the humor there is something more.

THE nation's orchestras, both large and small, will soon be opening their new seasons. The current mail is heavy with announcements of all their plans. The general impression is of continued expansion. The mushrooming is not as exuberant as it was a year or two ago, and some orchestras have been having a hard time raising money, but the picture is still an enlarging one.

With the "shooting" season in full swing, and the "hunting" season just beginning, this would seem the right time for a discussion on the .30-caliber match prospects for 1950, and these prospects seem much brighter than they have since the war.

HARRISBURG -- Pennsylvania resorts have had an "exceptional" vacation season, much better than had been antici pated, according to the State Department of Commerce. Reservations were slightly off from normal in June, but picked up in July and August when most resorts were crowded to capacity.

RIDGEFIELD PARK, N. J., Sept. 10 -- After fifteen years of planning, the Overpeck Valley trunk line sewer project was started at Teaneck Road and Bergen Pike here today in ceremonies attended by the mayors of the eleven Bergen County towns participating.

A men's toiletries producer long noted for "prestige" products in the higher price range will broaden a low-price line this fall in an intensive drive to increase its share of the market, it was learned last week.

Trading in cotton futures on Saturdays was resumed yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange, after having been dropped all summer, and final prices were 6 points higher to 6 points lower than on Friday.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 10 (AP) -- The Indians, refusing to be counted out of the American League pennant fight, squeezed out a 2 to 1 decision over the Browns tonight. The champions were limited to three hits, but one of them was a bases-loaded single by Mickey Vernon, which gave Bob Lemon his nineteenth victory.

UNLESS controlled in August when it reared its ugly head, crabgrass has overrun the lawn by now. The two species, Digitaria sanguinalis and D. schaemum are equally prevalent in lawns around the northeastern part of the country.

THIS year's Salzburg festival represented about as complete a return to the pre-1938 scheme of things as could be imagined without Toscanini. Even Bruno Walter was here, to make of "Das Lied von der Erde" one of the most moving achievements in four weeks of distinguished music making.

ALTHOUGH this is Jean Leslie's sixth mystery novel, one has the feeling that she has not yet determined precisely her own line of approach to the mystery field -- which is something of a relief in a business in which so many authors regularly produce pastiches of their own earlier work.

A CHIPPENDALE chair and a sumptuous silk brocade endlessly reflected in a pair of mirrors is the first sight to greet visitors to the exhibition, "For Modern Living," which opens today at the Detroit Museum of Arts. The inconsistency is meant to symbolize the futility of endless repetition of designs of the past.

DROUGHT is more certain than any other kind of weather at some time during the garden year. The usual casualties can be averted, however, by relying for the most part on plants that can survive extremely dry weather without artificial watering.

How telling the remarks of Ivor Brown in his article on London's reception to "Death of a Salem"! I sat in a New York audience soon after the opening and I, a minority, was amazed at the slobbering all around me.
LONDON, Sept. 10 (Reuters) -- Britain's soccer fans for the last few weeks have been mulling over the question, "What's wrong with Arsenal ?"

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 10 -- The application of the Iraq Petroleum Company to the Syrian Government for permission to build a cross line to Banyas on the Syrian coast from its two pipelines from Kirkuk to Tripoli, has started a rumor that Haifa is finished as a major oil outlet and a refining center.

THERE are people who prefer seed catalogues to all other reading. Droughts and bugs do not threaten the luxuriant beauty promised for the future in their brightly illustrated pages. Something of the same pleasure may be had from prolonged immersion in publishers' catalogues.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 10 -- Because of the Labor Day week-end, no definite figures were available which would indicate the trend of retail business activity in the Twelfth District during the last week. However, larger stores for the most part were enjoying a somewhat increased activity in buying for the year's last three-day vacation week-end.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- The quickly quashed feud between Louis Johnson, the Defense Secretary, and Senator Elmer Thomas of Oklahoma over "free" Congressional junketing in military planes raised a furor seemingly far out of proportion to the number of legislative overseas trips actually contemplated this year.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (AP) -- Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg, Republican, of Michigan, took the lead today in a move to resolve a growing Senate fight over arms aid to non-Communist China.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- If a mutually cooperative spirit and a determination to face unpleasant realities could assure the successful outcome of international negotiation, the so-called dollar conference here of the United States, Britain and Canada is already an overwhelming success.

THE study and appreciation of nature comes easier than that of art. The lowliest product of nature embodies the sphere of its perfection within itself, and to discover these relationships all I need is eyes to see. I am certain that within a small sphere a wholly true existence is confined.

In successive issues the Sunday edition of THE NEW YORK TIMES has printed two letters critical of American policy in Indonesia. In a letter on Aug. 21 William R. Matthews inveighs against this policy for being "defeatist" because it has temporized with the Indonesian Republicans.

WHEN Otis Barton recently made his record 4,500-foot dive off the California coast, one of the numerous motion-picture cameras trained on the event had the unlikely affiliation of the Moody Bible Institute of Chicago.

VALLETTA, Malta, Sept. 10 (AP) -- The Maltese Government is going ahead with its campaign to ask for United States aid in exchange for naval bases if Britain refuses to cut Malta in on Marshall Plan aid.

On July 15, with a strike of the nation's 1,000,000 steel workers imminently threatening on the issue of a "fourth round" wage increase, President Truman named a three-man fact-finding board to consider the dispute between labor and management and to propose a basis for settlement.

CHICAGO, Sept. 10 (AP) -- The Detroit Tigers continued a hot challenger for the American League pennant by handing the Chicago White Sox an 8-3 licking today for their ninth straight victory and No. 17 in the past nineteen games.

CHICAGO -- The 1949 summer vacation season in the Central States was one of the best on record. In Michigan, Wisconsin and Minnesota -- the leading resort states in the area -- there were more tourists than ever before, although most vacationists did not spend quite so much individually as they did in 1948 and were considerably less open-handed than they were in 1947 and 1946.
MR. FAST'S new collection of short stories (which includes, as well, a large percentage of sketches, moods, and notebook squiggles) ranges over much of the disputed area of the globe.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 10--Mr. Rogers was a former vice president and director of the American Newspaper Publishers Association and played an active role in the formation of the association's Mechanical Conference Division.

CHICAGO, Sept. 10 -- The home appliance industry has largely recovered from the slump which occurred in the second quarter, James J. Nance, president of Hotpoint, Inc., said today in a statement reviewing business conditions in the appliance field.

THE most interesting poet in France today is, in all probability, Henri Michaux -- whose first volume in English translation, "A Barbarian in Asia," has just been published in the United States. The translator was none other than James Joyce's friend and one-time publisher, Sylvia Beach, once of Princeton, N. J., now for many years a resident of Paris.

Government agencies have been puzzling over what to do with forty-five Hungarian political refugees on Ellis Island, where the majority have been detained nearly two months, it became known yesterday.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Sept. 10 -- Jim Ferrier of San Francisco blasted his third successive 69, three strokes under par, today, to take the fifty-four-hole lead in the $5,000 Kansas City seventy-two-hole open golf tournament with a 207.

Just 2 hours and 21 minutes after the Giants and Dodgers yesterday had begun the third game of their Ebbets Field series, Erv Palica topped a ball toward first base, Joe Lafata missed his grab for it and Bruce Edwards raced across the plate to give Brooklyn a 5-4 victory in the ninth inning with one out.

I HAVE written scores for eighty-two motion pictures, the most recent being "Open City," "Paisan," and "Germany, Year Zero" (which will open soon at the Ambassador). Twenty years of composing for symphony, ballet and theatre as well as films have convinced me that the cinema is as great as any of the arts and deserves the collaboration of serious musicians.

Cyrus S. Ching, director of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service, last night reported "no progress yet" on the fourth consecutive day of his effort to end the 133-day walkout of 2,000 dock workers in Hawaii. Both sides agreed that they were as far apart as ever.

DAVE GARROWAY, the erstwhile NBC page who for some years has labored in the comparative anonymity of Chicago radio, is receiving at the moment a strenuous build-up for the big time. Possibly with an eye to the fabulous revenues garnered by the labors of one Arthur Godfrey, the NBC planners have put their promising protege to work both on their TV network (10 P. M. Sundays) and on their radio chain (10:30 P. M. Mondays).
CHICAGO, Sept. 10 (AP) -- Prices of grains tumbled on the Board of Trade today in the wake of yesterday's Government forecast of another autumn of bumper harvests. Corn and soybeans led the downturn.

FOLLOWING this big, sprawling, crowded, leisurely written family chronicle by one of Hungary's foremost modern nov elists is almost like rereading Galsworthy's "The Forsyte Saga." Ferenc Kormendi's rambling semi-autobiographical novel appears a decade too late here.

SPRINGDALE, Conn., Sept. 10 -- Medalists Walter S. Hoyt and Duncan Edwards, his guest from the Greenwich Country Club, along with Ruppert Vernon of Woodway and James Healey of Race Brook, gained the final of the Woodway Country Club's eighth member-guest golf tournament today and will meet for the championship tomorrow.
ASIA today presents a baffling picture to the West. It is a study in contradictions. Amid the conflicts that divide it, we find at work a powerful impulse toward integration and unity.

NEW ORLEANS, La., Sept. 10 -- The last cost of living index of the Bureau of Labor Statistics for New Orleans was compiled as of May 15, and stood at 172.5. This represents a decline of 0.6 per cent from the Feb. 15 index of 173.6. The peak was reached in New Orleans Aug. 15, 1948, when the index stood at 179.8.

TOKYO, Sept. 10 -- The occupation administrators are becoming concerned over what appears to them to be a growing tendency in United States legislative circles to consider Japan as if she were a colony, a dumping ground for American surpluses and a handy piece of camouflage for subsidies to United States shipping.

Sentimentalists in the crowd of 30,093 at Aqueduct yesterday didn't have much fun during the running of the $22,900 Edgemere Handicap. For Stymie, returning to the racing wars after a fourteen-month absence, finished last, beaten fifteen lengths, and Assault, another old favorite who is in the midst of a comeback campaign, had to settle for third money.

Most people in the farm districts of the United States favor reorganization of the rural schools -- except when it involves their own communities, according to Prof. Shirley Cooper of the University of Wisconsin's School of Education, who has addressed sixty-five rural audiences during the last six months.

ABOARD THE ILE DE FRANCE AT SEA -- Last month in New York harbor, the tugboats, fireboats and harbor craft gave this old friend one of the tumultuous receptions usually reserved for ships on their maiden voyage. Her scars of war erased by a complete facelifting and refurbishing, the Ile de France, flagship of the French Line, like the thousands of troops she carried during the war, had become a civilian again.
