ROME, Sept. 10 -- Pope Pius has signed three "apostolic constitutions" regulating the acquisition of indulgence for their sins by the faithful during the Holy Year, which will be inaugurated on Christmas Eve with the ceremonial opening of the holy doors in Rome's four Patriarchal Basilicas.

The evolution of Federal income tax law is a slow and unpredictable process. In its development major changes sometimes occur without statutory amendments. When the courts hold Treasury regulations to be invalid, for instance, unless modified by new legislation, the effects can result in either narrowing or broadening the law's interpretation.

TEL AVIV -- Israel, too busy establishing itself as a new nation to provide the comforts and entertainment usually offered pleasure travelers, is nevertheless rapidly becoming one of the major tourist countries of the world.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- Gordon Gray, Secretary of the Army, accepted the retirement request of Maj. Gen. Alden H. Waitt today for the "best interests of the service," and restored Maj. Gen. Herman Feldman to duty with the firm assurance the general's "lapse of judgment" would not be repeated.

ILE D'YEU, France, Sept. 10 (AP) -- Madame Annie Petain today denied recently published reports that her 93-year-old husband -- imprisoned former Marshal of France -- was ailing and might not live through the winter.

CONTRARY to the popular belief that the country's airport development program has passed its climax and fewer projects are being undertaken, a survey reveals that at present more work than ever is being done on airfields of all types.

A new undergraduate curriculum in public administration, designed primarily for persons already in the field but open to any qualified man or woman, will be offered beginning with the fall semester by the College of Arts and Sciences of Saint Louis University. The four-year course leads to a Certificate in Public Administration.

FRANKIE MACHINE, born Majcinek, had a golden arm. He was the best dealer on Chicago's West Division Street, and he dealt the cards all night, every night when he wasn't in jail, upstairs in Zero Schwiefka's gambling room.

Though he disclaims any intention of fanning the flames of an old controversy, Dr. Gordon F. Edholm has arranged at the American Museum of Natural History for the benefit of the International Congress of American Scientists an interesting exhibit which will do just that.

World-wide military service by American Indians during the last war, with all its opportunities for broadening influence, had little effect on the traditional culture of many of them upon their return home, according to papers read by two anthropologists at yesterday's session of the twenty-ninth International Congress of Americanists.
PITTSBURGH, Sept. 10 (AP) -- The Pittsburgh Pirates lost their fifth straight game and the thirteenth of their last fourteen today by dropping a 9-5 decision to the Chicago Cubs before 5,376 fans.
WINDSOR, England, Sept. 10 -- Winston Churchill saw his race horse in action today for the first time -- and it won.
Public power broke through another barrier of the private utilities last week and took over, for $16,000,500, part of the properties of the Puget Sound Power and Light Company in the Northwest.
A critical shortage of elementary teachers and a desperate lack of classroom space confront the nation as schools reopen this week for their fall term.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 10 -- Final figures on retail trade in St. Louis for the week ended Sept. 3, disclosed the best relative showing against the preceding year since early this summer. Loss here was only 1 per cent, and the comparison was with a fairly brisk buying period last year.

WHEN Peter Pepperell III was 7 years old he began to grow down instead of up. This is a situation full of fascinating possibilities to children, who are inevitably fascinated by the miniature. In Peter's case it had happy and hilarious results.

IN bloom now, Artemisia lactiflora is a handsome perennial with tiny white, fluffy flowers. This is only one member of a very large family. Another is Artemisia albula, which is somewhat smaller-growing but equally attractive.
CHICAGO, Sept. 10 -- A strike threat has arisen at Chicago's stockyards.

A substantial increase in retail orders since the middle of August has partially lifted the domestic dinnerware manufacturing industry out of its long slump, Wilbert A. Betz, secretary-treasurer of the United States Potters Association, reported last week.

RECENT evidences that the business recession had leveled off as a result of inventory replenishment and seasonal influences were more or less officially confirmed during the week. Employment has gained in the last month, according to the Census Bureau figures.

PORTLAND, Ore. -- As the weather in the eastern United States ran up new records in heat and humidity this summer, travelers rushed to the perennial coolness of the Oregon and Washington seacoasts. A steady barometer, the ferry plying between the two states at the mouth of the Columbia River carried the greatest traffic in its history, 12 per cent above 1948.

FOR little Deborah, not quite old enough to go to school, a part of the fun of a white winter lay in making snowball ammunition so that she could join her friend Tommy in their ever-unequal battle with the older children coming home from school.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 10 -- Optimism in the face of many problems confronting the motion-picture industry was expressed today as 750 theatre owners began assembling for the four-day convention of the Theatre Owners of America, opening Monday.

Detectives William Cohen and Raymond Gill waited early yesterday while thirty-three cartons of books containing 1,400 volumes were being loaded on a truck from the Associated Book Service, 310 West Sixty-eighth Street.

IF you said that Elizabeth Janeway, author of the recently published "The Question of Gregory," was born in Brooklyn and now lives in the poorhouse, you would be nearly right. Mrs. Janeway lives in what once was the poorhouse, in the Connecticut town of Redding.
STAMFORD, Conn., Sept. 10 -- Gov. Chester Bowles used a typical New England clambake here today to give some advice on how New England, itself, could emerge from its present economic slump.

BONN, Germany, Sept. 10 -- The people of Western Germany now have a Constitution, a Parliament, a flag and a formal title as the Federal Republic of Germany. On Monday a President will be elected and a Chancellor called upon to form a Cabinet.

The National Conference of Commercial Receivable Companies, Inc., will hold its annual convention Oct. 23-25 at the Waldorf- Astoria Hotel, it was announced yesterday. Public sessions beginning Monday, Oct. 24, will feature a panel of speakers on legal decisions and fraudulent practices in the commercial finance industry, and a second panel on current problems, operation and internal management of commercial finance companies.

OMAHA, Sept. 10 -- Several facts of major political significance came into sharper focus this week on the heels of President Truman's Labor Day air dash to Des Moines and as Republicans completed plans for a big farm conference in Sioux City, Iowa, on Sept. 23-24.

The upper reaches and headwaters of the Amazon have long had a fascination for the not-too-well-informed imagination. There were vast jungles flooded annually by the mighty waters. There were strange trees hung with vines illumined by bright-colored birds. There were great snakes and little snakes and other weird forms of life.
Practical steps are being taken by other countries, notably Belgium and the Netherlands, to expand their exports to the United States.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 10 -- Independent inquiries among consumers here brought answers which tend to substantiate Bureau of Labor Statistics showing a decline in the cost of living.

SHANGHAI, Sept. 10 -- The editor and the Peiping correspondent of the pro-Communist newspaper Ta Kung Pao apologized today for the publication on Aug. 22 of an article allegedly misrepresenting statements made in a speech by Gen Chou En-lai, vice chairman of the Communist Revolutionary Council.

CHICAGO, Sept. 10 -- Cost of living for five Central Western cities has declined 3.1 per cent from a year earlier, and 3.6 per cent from the average of highs for the five communities, according to the Bureau of Labor's latest statistics. The cities are Chicago, Cincinnati Detroit, Indianapolis and Kansas City.

THE key to the summer tourist season in New York can be found in the traffic count made by state police who reported a 12 per cent increase in out-of-state automobiles on the highways, and increases of 40 to 50 per cent in the number of cars crowded into major resort areas.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 10 -- Russeks, operators of women's wear stores in New York, Brooklyn and Chicago, staged a preview today of its first Philadelphia store, a new and handsomely decorated building at 1212 Chestnut Street.

ON the musical side the Edinburgh Festival established itself at once as an event of major importance and international interest. On the dramatic side the problem of giving it equal significance can hardly be said to have been solved, though a tradition of quality is gradually coming into being.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- The conference of Ministers of the United States, Britain and Canada has agreed in principle on the formation of a permanent economic council to deal with problems bearing on the disequilibrium of the dollar and sterling trading areas.

Frequently the nation's high schools have been criticized as "unrealistic" institutions that do not train their six million students for "life" situations. That there is some validity in these charges is admitted by responsible educators. Indeed, the United States Office of Education appointed a committee a year ago to study ways to bring the high schools into line with everyday living.

LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., Sept. 10 -- Howell Van Gerbig, Meadow Brook, and Mrs. Joseph McFadden, Piping Rock, led the way into the semi-final round of the Piping Rock mixed foursomes tournament with a 3 and 2 victory over Mr. and Mrs. V. D. Crisp, Piping Rock, today.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 10 -- Business was upset this week by the Labor Day holiday. Shoppers went on a spree Tuesday, causing one of the greatest ordinary traffic jams in a long time. Police attributed the general tieup to shoppers trying to get home after a belated effort to outfit their children for school.

Capt. John A. Gaffney, Superintendent of State Police, laid the blame yesterday for the disorders that attended the Robeson concert meeting Lear Peekskill last Sunday, on both Paul Robeson and his leftist followers and the anti-Robeson demonstrators.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (AP) -- President Truman today approved a stop-gap bill providing for Federal aid to local school agencies for children on Federal reservations or in defense areas.

In Bonn, Germany, last Wednesday the black, red and gold flag of the Weimar Republic was raised. The Parliament of the Federal Republic of Germany, the new West German state which has adopted the Weimar flag, was holding its first session.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Sept. 10 -- Premier Antonin Zapotocky, in opening the fiftieth Prague autumn fair, today declared that regardless of political differences, Czechoslovakia was willing to do business with the whole world.

Mayor O'Dwyer made his first visit yesterday to his campaign headquarters on the eighth floor of the Commodore Hotel and conferred for four hours with a group of advisers on plans for his campaign for re-election.

The Isbrandtsen Company's freighter Sir John Franklin left this port early yesterday morning after being tied up for eleven days by a contract dispute between the company and the CIO-affiliated Marine Engineers Beneficial Association.

UTSUNOMIYA, Japan, Sept. 10 -- Gen. Douglas MacArthur's headquarters may be petitioned soon to reverse the decision wiping out military government in forty-five Japanese prefectures and to maintain some form of American supervision over local civil affairs, at least on a reduced scale.

JUDGING from those gayly illustrated catalogues which beguile even a book reviewer's weary eyes, this autumn season promises an abundance of books for younger readers. By Christmastime over 400 new books will have been published, nearly a hundred of which have already appeared.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Sept. 10 (AP) -- A bitter twenty-three hour filibuster ended the 1949 Alabama Legislature last midnight and spelled defeat to a substitute for the outlawed Boswell amendment, a voter-qualification law.

THE purport of today's pictures is this: A nine-pound pork loin furnishes three or four dinners for a four-person household. Purchasing such a big cut saves time rather than money in marketing; one trip to the butcher yields meat for half a week.

IT should be of interest to all friends of Jane Austen's Bennet family to know that Mr. and Mrs. Darcy have had a second son (named Grenville) and the Bingleys, although parents only of daughters, are still hoping. Although Elizabeth has, with her marriage, lost a good deal of her old sprightliness, Jane retains all her good-humored tolerance and is, indeed, more inclined than ever to think the best of everyone.

A RECENT issue of The Times Magazine had photographs by Fritz Henle of New York scenes which reminded him of Paris. A reader, Mme. Yvonne Haymoz. Musyl, protested that the Washington Arch, "even with a great stretch of the imagination," never reminded her of the Arch of Triumph, and that such pictures might dissuade Americans from visiting Paris, because "it's all here."

TEL AVIV, Sept. 10 -- As the years go by and commissions come and go, it becomes more apparent that a solution of the Palestine problem will come unilaterally. Israel can come to an agreement, and it has, with Egypt, Jordan, Syria and Lebanon, but it cannot reach a common agreement with all of them at one time.

WALTER HAGEN rarely prepared for anything. But recognizing the importance of the occasion, the insouciant Sir Walter really prepared for this one. The United States had just vanquished Great Britain in the Ryder Cup matches of 1937 at Southport, the first time either nation had scored a victory on foreign soil. The swashbuckling Haig realized better than most the importance the British placed on the presentation ceremonies.

FRIDAY will see the opening of the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo at the Metropolitan Opera House for a season of a little over two weeks. The first night's bill will include the premiere of "The Mute Wife" in the new version which Antonia Cobos has made for this company.

The keynote of the recent sessions held on opposite sides of the Atlantic by the United Nations Scientific Conference on the Conservation and Utilization of Resources and by the British Association for the Advancement of Science was material needs -- food, minerals, sources of energy, people.

WHITE PLAINS -- Because of the increasing use of Westchester County's park system, officials are now considering plans for expansion of public facilities in two of the county's principal northern recreation areas -- the Blue Mountain and the Ward Poundridge Reservations.

In promotions here last week retailers stressed boys' Western outfits, Chinese hand hooked rugs, corduroy and plaid separates and dress fabrics, according to a survey made especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by the Retail News Bureau, Inc.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (AP) -- Following is an official summary of a committee report adopted today by the three-power conference on British economic problems, calling for the encouragement of International Bank for Reconstruction and Development and Export-Import Bank financing in sterling area countries:

LONDON, Sept. 10 -- Financial experts can predict in general terms what will happen when currencies are devalued, but there are few who have the temerity to prophesy in exact terms because so much depends on political developments, temperament of peoples and possible effects on foreign relations.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Sept. 10 -- To protect the Dutch people's vast investments and vital economic position in Indonesia, the Netherlands Government has asked for broad veto powers over the future economic and financial life of the proposed new state so long as it remains in debt to the Netherlands.

TOKYO, Sept. 10 -- Tracy S. Voorhees, Under-Secretary of the Army, reiterated today that his purpose in coming here for conversations at Gen. Douglas MacArthur's headquarters was to improve liaison between the Supreme Commander and Washington.

The well-documented and well-balanced pair of articles on the U. S. S. R. by Isaac Deutscher ("Russia Is 'Still Remote From Communism'") and Alexander Dallin ("The Fateful Pact: Prelude to World War II") furnish a relief from the usual fare of saber-rattling and military self-aggrandizement.

YORK, Me., Sept. 10 -- Supreme Court Justice Wiley B. Rutledge, who had served on the nation's highest bench for six years, died at 9:05 o'clock tonight in York Hospital after a two-week illness. His age was 55. He was the second member of the court to die within two months.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (AP) -- Orlando S. Milano of Erie, Pa., received the annual "achievement award" of the Blinded Veterans Association at its national convention dinner tonight.

TRENTON, N. J., Sept. 10 -- Five-year-old Janie Franz, who was kidnapped late yesterday afternoon while playing with two friends near her home here, was back home this afternoon after being found in Philadelphia.
Pavlo D. Lysenko, a leading Ukrainian industrial chemist and brother of Academician Trofim D. Lysenko, top Soviet biological theorist, has found refuge in the United States.

Representative Vito Marcantonio, American Labor party candidate for Mayor, charged last night that the Truman Administration had made no fight for repeal of the Taft-Hartley Law but had made deals that would have "reincarnated" Taft-Hartley in another law had this not been stopped.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- Jewish leaders from thirty-four states met here today in an atmosphere of "crisis" resulting from the failure so far of the 1949 United Jewish Appeal to reach anything close to its goal of $250,000,000.

Seemingly overcome by excitement over being prevented from making a rescue attempt, Melville Philips, 55 years old, of 45 Gaynor Avenue, Manhasset, L. I., plant manager of the Queensboro Western Electric Company, collapsed and died at 6:30 o'clock last night on the 55-foot cabin cruiser Jojo while sailing off City Island.

The first in time was "Linden on the Saugus Branch," which described Mr. Paul's only slightly implausible, only occasionally Gargantuan childhood in Massachusetts.

REX HARRISON, now charming Broadway theatregoers in "Anne of the Thousand Days," will be returning to films once that Maxwell Anderson drama completes its road stand in Chicago on Dec. 31, Mr. Harrison revealed last week.
A STRONGLY felt theme developed against a background integrated with the author's own roots has produced this stirring junior novel about the Underground Railroad.

Settlement of Israel's "acute" economic and political problems in all likelihood will take precedence over any adjustment in the relationship there between religious authority and government, Dr. Israel Goldstein, rabbi of Congregation B'nai Jeshurun, 257 West Eighty-eighth Street, said yesterday.

PROFESSIONAL students of eighteenth-century literature have labored over the past generation-under the handicap of finding their material fallen out of fashion. As the metaphysical seventeenth century has risen in the esteem of poets and undergraduates, lecturing upon Dr. Johnson and neo-classical poetry has put a peculiar strain upon professors.

First regular stock orders for new inventories of hardware have been placed for meeting seasonal demands expected during the Christmas merchandising period, trade spokesmen revealed here yesterday. Dealers and distributors expect a volume of business as large as last year or larger, according to leading companies.

POSTMASTER GENERAL JESSE M. DONALDSON announced last week that the year's stamp-issuing program had been broadened to include a commemorative for the final national encampment of the United Confederate Veterans at Little Rock, Ark., on Sept. 27-29.

SAULT AU COCHON, Que., Sept. 10 -- Canadian Pacific Airlines officials said today "the possibility of an explosion in the luggage is not ruled out" as the cause of a crash near here yesterday of the passenger plane in which five industrialists and eighteen other persons were killed.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Sept. 10 -- Prophets Thumb continued to reveal the form that has made him one of the best 3-year-olds in the East in the $10,000 added Pageant Handicap today. The King Ranch color-bearer, a son of Bull Lea and Bee Mac, made his 2-to-5 favoritism stand up easily as he raced home ahead of eight others in the mile-and-a-furlong fixture.

PAWTUCKET, R. I., Sept. 10 (AP) -- Jockey Joe Renick won his third stakes race of the New England season when he guided William Goadby Loew's Petit Bleu to victory in today's twelfth running of the $7,500 added Jeanne d'Arc Stakes before 19,916 Narragansett Park racing fans.

BOSTON, Sept. 10 -- Department store sales in Boston for the week ended Sept. 3 were 7.1 per cent below the corresponding week of last year. According to figures prepared by the Massachusetts State Planning Board industrial activity in Massachusetts in July was 6 per cent less than a year ago.

DETROIT, Mich., Sept. 10 -- Another test of the political strength of the Americans for Democratic Action and the Political Action Committee of the Congress of Industrial Organizations will attract national interest in the outcome of the municipal primary election in Detroit on Tuesday.

NEARLY everybody knows that behind the rah-rah of amateur college athletics is the less disguised professionalism of the college itself. Scouts -- all loyal alumni are supposed to be in this category -- comb the high schools for scholarship players, not scholars.

CHICAGO, Sept. 10 -- Department store sales here for the six months ended July 30 were off 5.5 per cent compared with the same period in 1948. However, there was a slight divergence of trends in main store and basement totals, the Federal Reserve report showed.

WESTBURY, L. I., Sept. 10 -- The Hurricanes, who gained the final round of the National Open polo tournament last week, tuned up for their match with tomorrow's Mexico-Argentine winner, by topping Bostwick Field again, 11 -- 10, on Hitchcock Field at the Meadow Brook Club today.

NANTUCKET ISLAND, Mass., Sept. 10 -- Nine persons, including five women, perished and two men struggled against stormy seas all night to safety after the thirty-eight-foot cabin cruiser Constance was smashed to bits in a raging storm.

Retail trade here headed upward last week under the influence of cool weather. Back-to-school and seasonal merchandise was in demand. Department-store sales were estimated to show a 2 per cent advance over the comparative week of last year.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (AP) -- The text of that portion of the Steel Fact Finders' Report to President Truman headed "Findings and Recommendations; General Summary," follows:

American mass employment and production industries are vitally involved in the present international dollar crisis, William L. Batt, president, SKF Industries, Inc., Philadelphia, and formerly vice chairman of the War Production Board, emphasized here yesterday in his first statement following return from an extensive European survey.

In a short article in the science department of THE NEW YORK TIMES of Sept. 4 commenting on the appointment of a committee to advise the Atomic Energy Commission with regard to the dissemination of information useful in connection with metallurgy, the author expresses disappointment that the committee has so many members who are trade-journal editors rather than technologists learned in nuclear science.

The ionosphere is a series of electrified layers in the atmosphere 50 to 250 miles above tile earth. It reflects radio signals over long distances. Radio waves travel like light in straight lines through the lower atmosphere and, like light, they are bent away from the vertical as they penetrate the layers of the ionosphere at an oblique angle.
MORE than 200 prints submitted in a national competition for Chinese amateur photographers in America were judged here last week under the auspices of New York's China Photographic Society.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Sept. 10 -- The customary resort calm here was disturbed abruptly this morning when the Navy moved in and established a "beachhead." Demolition charges exploded, rocket shells burst in the air and speedy fighter planes "strafed" the invaders.

RUTLAND, Vt. -- Natives of New England insist that late summer and early fall offer the best vacation times, a fact that may be hard for a tourist to accept unless and until he has visited the Northeast in September. Now the summer crowds have gone home, and life is returning to normal.

FOR THIS WEEK: Sow spinach, lettuce and radish for late fall harvest. Start blanching celery to be picked at two-week intervals. . . . As flowers and vegetables finish their season, pull out plants, then turn over the earth and let it lie rough all winter. . . . Spray roses for black spot. . . . Take cuttings of begonias, fuchsias, lantana and other tender plants for the house. . . .
SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Sept. 10 -- The text of the address delivered by former Governor Herbert H. Lehman before the State CIO Convention follows:

HANS PFITZNER was a composer who outlived his epoch. A musical follower of Wagner and Schumann, he wrote and voiced his opposition to "modernistic" tendencies for many years before his death four months ago.

FROM early September until the ground begins to freeze is a favorable time to plant fruit trees and berries of all kinds. The soil is usually in better condition than in early spring, and the weather is propitious for outdoor activities.

A group of twelve American orthodox Jews arrived at the New York International Airport, Idle-wild, Queens, early yesterday morning, and because of a religious tenet which forbids traveling on the Sabbath, spent their entire day at the airport and in its vicinity.
PALERMO, Sicily, Sept. 10 -- Sicilian Nationalists today, in effect, "declared war" on Italy by announcing that they had allied themselves to Salvatore Giuliano, the island's bandit king.

IT is vintage time again, and in the nation's representative vineyard states -- California, New Jersey and New York -- pickers are beginning to move slowly down the head-high rows of grapevines. On the highways bordering the vineyards tourists pause to watch the workers, while from across the fields comes the rumble of crushing machines extracting juice.

In line with the lessening of the incidence in the polio epidemic here reported on Friday by Dr. Harry S. Mustard, Health Commissioner, the twenty-three new cases listed for the twenty-four hours ended at 9 A. M. yesterday marked a reduction from the thirty-seven of the previous day.

With an eye toward making New York City the world's trading center for metals, the Commodity Exchange tomorrow will introduce a new contract for copper futures. Because the British Government has refused to relinquish its war-time controls over metals and to permit the resumption of futures trading in London, that city has lost its traditional pre-eminence as the center of metal trading.

A three-alarm fire destroyed last night a one-story 200-foot wooden loading shed in the yards of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad at 132d Street between Lincoln and Alexander Avenues, the Bronx. Service on the Third Avenue "El" line, which crosses the yard, was suspended for fifteen minutes.

City officials and civic leaders, led by Vincent R. Impellitteri, president of the City Council, joined yesterday in opening an enlarged store at 22 Division Street as part of a new shopping center within the area of a master plan approved by the City Planning Commission foor the lower East Side.

TRADITIONALLY, the American book publishing year has had but two seasons, spring and fall, the first reaching into the lazy summer months, the second into the feverish Christmas-shopping weeks and beyond them to a new spring.

Hundreds of seedlings of the Dawn Redwood, the ancient cousin of the California Redwoods recently discovered in China, have been planted along the Pacific Coast from Alaska to Guatemala by Dr. Ralph W. Chaney, Professor of Paleontology at the University of California, who has just returned from a fossil-hunting expedition to Oregon and British Columbia.

FAR HILLS, N. J., Sept. 10 -- The big dog in the Somerset Hills Kennel Club show a year ago was the big dog again today when Champion Walsing Winning Trick of Edgerstoune, imported Scottish terrier belonging to Mrs. John G. Winant of New York, was chosen for the top award by John W. Cross Jr.

IN accordance with its now firmly established policy of presenting new productions annually, the New York City Opera Company will add four works to its repertoire this year, two in the forthcoming fall season, starting Sept. 29 at the City Center, and the other two next spring.
BUFFALO, N. Y., Sept. 10 (AP) -- Possible arbitration plans were being drafted today in an effort to settle the 13-week-old violence-ridden Bell Aircraft strike.

THE annual convention of the Photographic Society of America will be held Oct. 19-22 at the Jefferson Hotel in St. Louis. Features of the meeting will be the 1949 International Exhibition of Photography at the St. Louis City Art Museum; he New York Museum of Modern Art's "The Exact Instant" and "50 Photographs by 50 Photographers" and the Masters' Exhibit of the Photographers Association of America.

The African plant Strophanthus sarmentosus, the seed of which is a potentially unlimited source of raw material for cortisone, the rare chemical that promises new life for millions of sufferers from arthritis, rheumatic fever and some other crippling chronic ills, is growing in Hawaii, it was learned here yesterday.

THIS year lovers of contemporary music throughout the world will celebrate the seventy-fifth birthday of the composer Arnold Schoenberg on Sept. 13. Measured by box-office or Hooper-rating standards, Schoenberg has still a long way to go to equal the success of his friend and admirer, the late George Gershwin.

FORCED by an illness to retire from medical research in London and live in the country, Dr. Salaman tells us in the preface to this vastly engaging volume that he found the summers, when there was no hunting, dull.

DENVER, Sept. 10 -- Because "a serious amount of charlatanism" has developed in this country, it is essential that all groups concerned with the mental health movement start collaborative efforts to protect the public through legislation, it was held today by Dr. G. R. Wendt, chairman of the Psychology Department at the University of Rochester.

THE eventual return of Jimmy Cagney to a tough-guy gangster role -- to the realms of the cinematic hoodlums in which he made his first leap to fame -- was probably as inevitable as the striking of 12 o'clock.

WHERE were all the bones that Little-or-Nothing buried each morning under his circus-wagon home? This mystery is too much for the little dog and he suspects everyone of having robbed him: the other animals, Barkus, the dog-faced boy, and even Mrs. Spangler, with whom he lives.

CHICAGO, Sept. 10 (AP) -- Rookie George Blanda's second field goal in the closing minutes from a difficult angle gave the Chicago Bears a 20 to 17 exhibition triumph over the New York Giants before 32,560 at Wrigley Field today.

THE Botanical Gardens in Brooklyn and the Bronx are offering numerous courses this fall of particular interest to gardeners. Subjects that can be studied range from practical gardening to one on flower painting.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- Congress will shortly pack up and go home, apparently deaf to pleas of top Governmental officials that they do something about the worker hodgepodge which has blossomed under the guise of veteran job preference.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 10 (AP) -- Two seeded foreign stars, Eric Sturgess of South Africa and Felicisimo Ampon of the Philippines, reached the fourth round of the Pacific Southwest tennis tournament today.

ASUNCION, Paraguay, Sept. 10 (UP) -- President Felipe Molaz Lopez resigned tonight after the Directive Board of the Colorado (Government) party withdrew its support of his regime, it was officially announced.

SOMETHING new and exciting has happened to daffodils. During the past hundred years, thousands of new varieties have been introduced by amateur and professional hybridizers. But there has never been any great change in basic color. This year, a whole new group of pink daffodils is being introduced.

GANUS BAZEMORE and his sister Kathyanne have moved into Estherville from the country. Being light-skinned mulattoes who have had some education -- and have not acquired the defensive humility of city Negroes -- they learn about Negro life in a Southern town the hard way.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Sept. 10 -- Faced with dissension in his own Christian Democratic party, Dr. Konrad Adenauer, Chancellor-designate of the Federal Republic of Germany, met today with Dr. Kurt Schumacher, leader of the Socialist opposition, in an attempt to work out a stable start for the West German state.

TOO often, perhaps, this department has talked about the responsibility of writers in our time. This was, in part, at least, the subject of last Sunday's column, as it has been of numerous others. I have spoken of it often because it seems to me of extraordinary significance just now, weighted with more potentials, both good and evil, than at any time since man first concerned himself with the written word.

John Foster Dulles has been a United States Senator for sixty-six days -- since Governor Dewey appointed him to fill the vacancy caused by Senator Robert Wagner's resignation. In that time Mr. Dulles has built up an unusual record for a freshman Senator, largely as a result of his prestige as Republican foreign policy advisor.

PRESSURE of business that virtually excluded Mayor O'Dwyer from theatres in recent years has now projected him into theatre business. What began as a limited investigation of ticket scalping has widened into a fairly comprehensive study of show business by a committee that represents nearly every phase of the industry.

PARIS, Sept. 10 -- The fourth International Neurological Congress concluded its sessions here today with a ringing demand that neurology "be recognized in the field of medicine in all countries as a central independent dynamic specialty."

HAVERFORD, Pa., Sept. 10 -- The defense of the Wightman Cup was brought to a successful conclusion today as the United States defeated Great Britain for the thirteenth successive time in the international women's tennis matches.
I wish to convey to Mr. Russell Lynes my appreciation for the pleasure his brilliant article ("Intellectuals vs. Philistines," July 10) brought to me.

AFTER an initial season that has inspired considerable elation, Washington's outdoor summer theatre in Meridian Hill Park will dose tonight. The sponsors of the project, the Washington Theatre Festival, have been cheered by the appreciation shown by capital theatregoers for the first professional theatre to be operated here in more than a year.

JOHNSTOWN, Pa., Sept. 10 -- Leaders of the Democratic and republican organizations, both of which are waging topflight campaigns, perfected plans today for a final drive for votes in the Twenty-sixth district's special Congressional election on primary day, next Tuesday.
ROME, Sept. 10 -- The seamen's strike, which up to last night had been limited to three liners in the port of Genoa, spread today to Naples and Trieste.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- A Navy captain said today that the Navy's attack power was being wrecked in the Pentagon and that he was throwing away his thirty-year career by saying so publicly.

WRITING with affection, skill and detachment of his own offspring, John Mason Brown has turned out an engaging book of short pieces entitled "Morning Faces." Most of these chapters have appeared in his department, Seeing Things, in The Saturday Review of Literature.

Plans for a housing project for 400 low-income families in a congested district of Flushing were put into an advanced stage yesterday, when Herman T. Stichman, New York State Housing Commissioner, signed on behalf of the state a $5,300,000 loan and subsidy contract with the New York City Housing Authority.
LAUSANNE, Switzerland, Sept. 10 -- The United Nations economic mission for the Middle East left here for Beirut, Lebanon, tonight.
Following are the figures showing the school enrollment, teachers' salaries, and total school budget of thirty major cities for 1948-49 and 1949-50:

I read with keen interest Cabell Phillips' "Camden, Alabama: a Case History." Camden, Ala., is not only an excellent specimen of the "Old South" but also a study of the South's moral degradation, with its many smoldering conflicts and fears.
THE scene of this new novel by Elisabeth Ogilvie is, as before, the coast of Maine. Sky and ocean again come vividly to view, fog creeps in, and the cry of gulls is heard.

The decline in the nation's employment figures has already been anticipated by an increase in demand for work clothes fabrics, it was pointed out last week. Producers of denim used in overalls, dungarees and work jackets, who offered fourth quarter goods on Tuesday, said at the week-end that they were literally swamped with orders and that production for the October-December period has been taken up.

NEWARK, N. J., Sept. 10 -- Discussing the future of the nation in respect to internal security, Assistant United States Attorney General Alex Campbell told 160 delegates to a county American Federation of Labor political convention here today that "our greatest fight is to maintain a free democracy against totalitarian communism."

A SERIOUS novel about physicists, "Live With Lightning" is nervous and charged with excitement. Mitchell Wilson gives his researchers neither the hoorah of supermen nor the consecrated quiet of selfless workers in the temple of science.

COLORADO SPRINGS -- Tourist operators generally throughout the Rocky Mountain region are more than pleased with the results of the 1949 summer season and most of them expect at least three weeks more of brisk business.

RICHMOND, Sept. 10 -- Judging from the comments of housewives interviewed here, Bureau of Labor statistics indicating a drop in the cost of living are generally accurate and may possibly be on the conservative side. An exception to this view occurs on the rent index, which reports a 12 per cent increase. Thousands of post-war apartments and dwelling units are renting at higher levels, tenants report.

As one who spent more than twenty-five years with General Motors and the Durant interests, and who pioneered the automotive business literature of the industry, I may be qualified to write on the present situation and the mounting death and accident toll on highways and city streets.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 10 -- Coasting in after a 6-run outburst -- much of it tainted -- in the first, the Red Sox romped to a 9-1 victory over the Athletics today at Shibe Park. With Mel Parnell spinning a masterful 3-hitter for his twenty-second triumph of the campaign, the Bosox did not need nearly so many runs as they were handed at the outset.
CAMDEN, N. J., Sept. 10 -- Funeral services were held today for six of the thirteen persons killed by Howard B. Unruh in his wild shooting rampage in East Camden last Tuesday.
SHANGHAI, Sept. 10 (AP) -- The Chinese Communists, struggling with unemployment and inflation, called on Shanghai's millions today to "let three people's rice be shared by five."

"BOOK jackets, which were devised to keep dust off books, are now designed to throw dust in the eyes of book buyers." This indictment, uttered by a thoroughly experienced (and highly irritated) critic during a visit to the Book Review office, was leveled against the practice of printing on the covers of new books a series of laudatory quotations from literary notables.

PARIS, Sept. 10 -- After more than a month's discussions the Council of Europe's Consultative Assembly closed its first session this week at Strasbourg with a European federation a long way off, but amid almost general assertions by its members that the foundations for the unity of Western Europe had been laid.

LOS ANGELES -- The volume of vacation travel and resort business in California and the Southwest this summer held to about the same level as last year, with tourists showing an increasing interest in economy.

Delays over the adjournment of Congress mean more to many Senators and Representatives than loss of opportunity for political fence-building at home. A good many of them -- like other Americans -- have hobbies, and time away from the capital treadmill also means time for indulging them. Here are a few of these Congressional hobbies.

ENVELOPING the central drama of Christendom with the luminous haze of sensation is an oft-repeated adventure in popular fiction. It may be said at once that at the climax of this latest of such narratives every reasonable susceptibility is respected.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Sept. 10 -- The Labor Day holiday Monday interrupted a three-week rise in department store sales which last week attained the largest volume since Mother's Day. Last week's increase of 4 per cent was the first gain over 1948 since April.
SALEM, Ore., Sept. 10 (AP) -- Senator Wayne L. Morse, Republican, of Oregon, suffered a back injury tonight when he was thrown to the ground in a sulky race at the Oregon State Fair Arena.

The modest and reasonable hope that informed observers entertained for the tripartite economic conference in Washington was that it should take some preliminary steps and lay the groundwork for the arduous and complicated tasks ahead. Yesterday's announcement that the United States, Great Britain and Canada have agreed to encourage investment in the sterling area countries was just such a step.

LONDON, Sept. 10 -- Except for persons at the top level of the British Government, business and finance, this week's conferences on the "dollar crisis" in Washington might as well have been conducted on Mars.

The general improvement in retail activity last week resulted in some shortages in the soft goods line and retailers asked for quick delivery of fall merchandise, according to a report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co., Inc., resident buying office.

THIS is not, it must be said sadly, a refreshingly original novel. Mr. Warren has chosen to present yet another of the numberless case histories of that singular mental disease of our times, amnesia whodunitica; and he advances from this standard opening gambit through a series of highly colorful cliches to the equally standard finish of wild carnage in a fun-house.

YOU are soon in my library and soon out of it, for most of the books are contained in a single room. I keep some more of them in a bedroom and in a little sitting-room and in a bathroom cupboard, but most of them are in what we will politely term the library. This is commodious apartment -- 24 feet by 18 feet -- and a very pleasant one.

BOSTON, Sept. 10 (AP) -- Lefty Warren Spahn struck out eleven batters tonight in pitching the Braves to a 1-0 decision over the Phillies, snapping a Boston losing streak which had run through nine games. The victory enabled the Tribe to jump back into fourth place in the National League, a half game ahead of the New York Giants.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (AP) -- Seaman Patrick Ryan, who said he missed his ship and was shanghaied by the French Foreign Legion, has received a four-month sentence from a Navy court martial for "unauthorized absence from duty."

The owl has hooted in the evening darkness. The voice of autumn has echoed across the valley. There is no mistaking it now, for although the green world is still green it has the gleam of dogwood berries turned scarlet and the shine of goldenrod in the fence corners and the glow of little white asters on the meadow.

What are the trends in American literature this fall! It's a wise publisher who recognizes his own trends, of course, but no one else is in quite so advantageous a position to form an opinion on this question as the men who select books for publication.

THERE is as much excitement in this sober little book as in any war memoir or murder thriller. It is a straightforward account by the head of the world's largest spice and extract manufacturing house of the measures his company has taken to establish labor peace by giving each employe a direct sense of participation in the success of the business.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 10 -- The St. Louis Southwestern (Cotton Belt) Railroad resumed at about 9:30 tonight service in and out of this city which had been tied up for nearly twenty-four hours by the strike of 5,200 trainmen on the Missouri Pacific Railroad.

The monetary discussions in Washington will have at least the merit of having brought to the fore the over-all confusion that reigns regarding the most fundamental monetary notions. The world seems to be devoid of a comprehensive monetary philosophy, or at least it has forgotten the basic principles according to which our monetary systems have evolved.

Forecasts issued last week by the Department of Agriculture indicate the second largest yield of farm products in the nation's history. Coming on top of the record output of 1948, the large harvests are creating a price-support and storage problem that is giving much concern to the Administration.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Sept. 10 -- While steadfastly opposing complete internationalization of modern Jerusalem, Israel is prepared to consider a three-point compromise plan that she believes would meet many current objections to Israeli control of the city, it was learned tonight.
Columbia University's American Press Institute will offer six seminars for newspaper men during the 1949-50 academic year, Floyd Taylor, director, announced yesterday.

HAVANA, Sept. 10 -- The United States delegation to the Congress of the Inter-American Labor Confederation was placed on the defensive today when delegates from Latin American countries criticized the State Department's policies.

SINCE the madwoman of Chaillot has celestial knowledge of ultimate values, it was inevitable that she would take a vacation during the heated term. No doubt she knew that the summer would be more hellish than usual; and, believing only in gentleness and ease, took appropriate measures to escape it.
THIS week some 1,500 men and women will gather at the Waldorf-Astoria's main ballroom for a frolicsome dinner-dance in honor of a rather peculiar part of a man's wardrobe.
PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Sept. 10 -- Moved out into Long Island Sound for their fourth races,...

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 10 -- Department stores sales last week at this Federal Reserve District were 9 per cent under a year ago and sales reported by central Philadelphia department stores were off by the like percentage. In four weeks to Sept. 3, department stores in the district had 9 per cent less dollar-volume of sales and the decrease, compared with like 1948 weeks, was 11 per cent for the central-city stores.

IN the ageless struggle between the sexes Mrs. Pinkham became a subject of humor among men and the object of veneration among women. To reverse a once popular ditty, the sirens sang of her face while the men laughed at it. Miss Burton has soberly tried, and with considerable success, to set the record straight.

IN this series of studies Miss Freeman has effectively disposed of the fallacy that childhood is the happiest time of life. No child would agree with it. Children are frequently unhappy and afraid, and out of her own memories and her present acquaintance with other people's children she has reconstructed the confused, introspective torment they suffer and are not able to communicate to adults.

MR. KAFKA (an Austrian-born author whose all-American output is not to be confused with his Czech counterpart) turns in his new novel to a gay, sometimes witty and always amusing commedia dell' arte in the heart of Manhattan's East Side.

The customary post-Labor Day revival of interest in stock prices was missing last week. Uncertainty about the steel fact-finding board's decision and Britain's dollar crisis hung like the sword of Damocles over financial markets. Stocks moved in a narrow range and closed slightly higher after early softness.
THE disastrous results of a long period of drought on lettuce has been realized even by non-gardeners, who have shopped for this green during the summer. Lettuce is essentially a cool-weather crop.

Retailers accepted the mid-year profits report on department and specialty stores with little surprise last week. The report, which was prepared by the Controllers Congress of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, showed that profits in department stores were 58 per cent below the corresponding period last year.

With the report of the President's steel fact-finding board in, the question of a fourth-round increase in wages and welfare benefits becomes of immediate importance not only to all organized workers, but to the great mass of the United States labor force.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Sept. 10 -- Roman Catholic Archbishop Josef Beran has protested that the Government's "plenipotentiary," who has occupied the Archbishop's consistory the past three months, now "actually performs the duties of the Archbishop."

BERLIN, Sept. 10 -- The scope of reported Soviet preparations to resuscitate a German air force as a unit within the East Zone German police organization was indicated today in separate reports in two Western-licensed papers.

A survey among 400 retailers indicates that they have exhausted their large inventories of men's shirts and they are now actively engaged in replenishing stocks for the last quarter, according to Seymour J. Phillips, president of Phillips Jones Corporation.

THE current interest in American folk art is a healthy sign. It is all to the good to recognize the fact that in eighteenth and nineteenth century America there were many unknown craftsmen whose talents were never matured by education nor afflicted by the blight of academicism.
ATHENS, Sept. 10 -- The Balkan Peninsula earned its reputation for trouble-making through one basic and constant tradition: the desire to shake off foreign domination.

BUS travel is an ideal way to see America, according to a group of thirteen women and four men from Rio de Janeiro who last week completed a 9,000-mile two-month transcontinental bus tour. And, for visitors from a land where there are few highways and practically all major travel is by air, the expressways, parkways and rapid travel facilities here are among the most impressive aspects of life in the United States.

With all hands holding high hopes that a flukey wind at the outset would freshen considerably as the grind continued, twenty-five craft went across the line yesterday in the City Island Yacht Club's annual overnight races to Cornfield Lightship and Stratford Shoal Lighthouse.
COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Sept. 10 -- The probability of the dissolution of the Rigsdag and new elections looms large on Denmark's political horizon.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- The first recovery in national industrial production since October, 1948, was reported today by the President's Council of Economic Advisers. Other reported indices, however, presented a less favorable picture.

In his campaign last fall President Truman traveled 25,000 miles and made 250 speeches full of phrases like these: "do-nothing Eightieth Congress * * * union-busting * * * pitchfork in the farmer's back * * * special interests * * * brazen lobbies."

JUST as the public excitement generated by the association of Roberto Rossellini and Ingrid Bergman for the production of RKO's "Stromboli" in Italy was beginning to quiet down two weeks ago, Mr. Rossellini came to the aid of the RKO publicists with a new controversy, and the publicists, with the help of mysterious driblets of information from their boss, Howard Hughes, have managed to keep the controversy simmering ever since.
OTTAWA, Sept. 10 -- Canada's twenty-first Parliament, which was elected last June, will meet in its first session on Thursday.
Although the new auction season will not be in full swing until the latter part of the month, opportunities for bargain-hunters and collectors alike are improving as galleries resume activities.

IN "The Wolfshead" Jere Wheelwright continues the adventures of John Aumarle, the fictitious, sixteenth-century Earl of Bristol whose cloak-and-sword adventures during the reign of Queen Mary entertained a good many readers in "The Strong Room."

THERE have been many arguments for or against economic planning. This book is neither. It contains the essentials of the post-war plans of fourteen countries, ranging from the United States to Russia, with an analysis of their principal aims and devices.

MITCHEL AIR FORCE BASE, L. I., Sept. 10 -- Many persons learned today that mass formations of enemy war planes carrying bacterial, atomic or poison gas bombs could attack the eastern coastal area of the United States while the inhabitants of large areas involved were temporarily unaware of the devastation.

ROME, Sept. 10 -- The Pope has received in his summer residence of Castel Gandolfo a delegation representing the National Conference of Christians and Jews, a United States organization dedicated to promoting justice, amity, understanding and cooperation between Protestants, Catholics and Jews.

SEATTLE, Sept. 10 -- Bureau of Labor statistics indicate that Seattle living costs are down approximately two points from February, but the average citizen seems to think the decline is not visible to the naked eye.
Karl Krueger, conductor of the Detroit Symphony Orchestra since 1943, resigned yesterday and will become music director and conductor of the new American Arts Orchestra to be formed in New York.
STAFFORD SPRINGS, Conn., Sept. 10 (AP) -- A Greyhound bus rammed the rear of a truck early today on the Wilbur Cross highway in Ashford, tossing its thirty-eight passengers from their seats.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 10 -- Senator Robert A. Taft began this week to build up the case on which he will ask to be judged in next year's election. Fourteen months before the ballots are to be counted Mr. Taft started out on what he calls a "non-political report" to the folks back home -- a tour that will last well into December.

Osbert Lancaster, in "More Toured Against Than Touring," refers to the francophile snobbery of the early nineteenth century which substituted such words as "serviette" and "table-d'hote" for the Anglo-Saxon "napkin" and "ordinary."

"THE BEAST IN HIS HUNGER" is a book of poems by Harry Brown, author of "A Sound of Hunting," "A Walk in the Sun" and several collections of lyrics. The present volume is divided into three parts, of which the first is a group of four elegies, an eclogue, and an ode; the second ("Alarms and Excursions") has no recognizable principle of unity; and the third consists of six war poems.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, Sept 10 (AP) -- Hungary charged today that Marshal Tito's Yugoslav regime and the United States Office of Strategic Services had backed an abortive revolt plot aimed at the assassination of Hungarian Communist leaders and the overthrow of the Government.

WITH the 1949 summer vacation season now in its last few weeks, resort operators are adding up their scores and reporting, with some amazement, that this was a much better season than they had hoped for.

HOLLYWOOD, Sept. 10 (AP) -- A group of 382 writers, actors and other professional persons will file a brief with the United States Supreme Court charging that a plan of movie censorship was instigated by the House Un-American Activities Committee, their lawyers have announced.

MONTREUX, Switzerland, Sept. 10 -- Chen Li-fu, Minister Without Portfolio in the Canton Chinese Cabinet, proposed a three-point program for saving China from communism in a message received here, officials of the world Moral Rearmament Assembly said today.

MONTCLAIR, N. J., Sept. 10 -- With most of its neighbors struggling under a burdensome parking problem, this North Jersey community is easing the shopper's headache with a well-planned series of municipal parking areas. Five of the off-street sites located at strategic spots are providing space for 450 automobiles.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- President Truman's board of inquiry in the steel dispute urged today that the United Steelworkers of America, CIO, withdraw its "fourth-round" wage demands at this time and that the steel companies finance pension and social insurance programs for their employes.

CHICAGO, Sept. 10 (AP) -- Roman Bath, 18-1 shot owned by John Marsch of Chicago, surprised most of the 17,409 racegoers at Hawthorne today by defeating William M. Peavey's Wisconsin Boy in a photo finish of the $24,550 Juvenile Handicap.

The seventh biennial convention of the National Maritime Union, CIO, opening here tomorrow morning, is expected to be much more peaceful than past conventions -- especially the 1947 session which lasted a stormy twenty-four days and cost $300,000.
GENEVA, Sept. 10 -- The European timber market has been completely upset by the consequences of the recent devastating forest fires in France, according to timber specialists here.

Three fellow-townsmen of Freeport, L. I., dominated the Harwood Trophy race around Manhattan Island yesterday afternoon but it wasn't the speedboat veteran, Guy Lombardo, who led the pack home. His Tempo VI had to be satisfied with second place.

Sally Milgrim, in designing her fall custom order collection, looked to the future, not the past, for inspiration. The presentation, shown recently at the Milgrim shop, reflected this modern trend in its greater simplicity, its feeling for clean, sharp lines and asymmetry.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (UP) -The Federal Trade Commission moved today to wipe out an alleged "racket" by some automobile dealers involving finance and insurance overcharges.

SALEM, Ore., Sept. 11 (UP) -Senator Wayne Morse of Oregon suffered a back injury and a temporary concussion last night when he was thrown from his sulky at the Oregon State Fair horse show, hospital X-ray pictures disclosed today.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 11 -- The Missouri Pacific Railroad strike is expected to cause some delay in the arrival of mail in some isolated communities, but Post Office authorities here have promised at least one delivery a day to every town, village and city in the affected area.

Although many state and local governmental purchasing departments agree that it is not good public purchasing procedure to allow a price differential in favor of local bidders, in some cities and states "home-town" vendors enjoy an advantage of as much as a 10 per cent differential in their favor over out-of-state suppliers.

PORTSMOUTH, N. H., Sept. 11 (AP) -- Cancer experts today announced a five-point plan to find cancers early and save millions of people now destined to die of the disease. The program came at the end of the first Conference on Cancer Detection sponsored by the American Cancer Society, which brought together sixty experts who decided to:

ROME, Sept. 11 -- Dr. Enrico Fermi, Nobel prize winner in 1938 and a leading member of the team of scientists in the United States who developed the atomic bomb, spoke today at the opening of the International Congress of Physicists in Como. His speech was non-technical.

In November there will be a statewide political contest for United states Senator between two outstanding candidates. This should provide political campaigning of the highest order. The other important office for which voters throughout New York State will cast their ballots in November is a judicial one -- Judge of the Court of Appeals, our highest state court.
PORTLAND, Me., Sept 11 (AP) -- The Danish Evangelical Church "suffered during the occupation of the war but came out stronger than before," its primate said today.

For the past three years, Johnnie Lucas, a 14-year-old blond-haired boy of Glen Gardner, N. J., has spent all of his spare time building model trains and watching locomotives. His hobby was "one of the most important things in the world" to him.
CINCINNATI, Sept.11 (AP) -With Stan Musical hitting three homers, the Cardinals took both ends of a double-header from their "cousins," the Reds, 7 -- 5 and 7 -- 4, today before a crowd of 25,270.
Four new films will open in midtown theatres this week. The programs follow:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- The establishment of HELP -- Holyland Emergency Liaison Program -- aimed at keeping "the American public informed as to the needs, activities and accomplishments of the volunteer established agencies, and building of public understanding of the problems of the Near East," was announced here today.

National Airlines, Inc., will report today in its annual statement to stockholders for the fiscal year ending on last June 30, a profit of $38,963, compared with a loss of $2,309,000 in the preceding year.
PITTSBURGH, Sept. 11 (AP) -- Ralph Kiner smashed his forty-fifth and forty-sixth home runs of the season today, each with one aboard, to lead the Pirates to a 7-to-3 triumph over the Cubs.

WESTBURY, L. I., Sept. 11 -- Whittling away the loser's lead in the second half. Argentina's El Trebol quartet reached the final round of the thirty-third National Open polo championship tournament by topping Mexico's Gracida Brothers, 10 -- 9, on International Field of the Meadow Brook Club today.

The sixteen-story and penthouse apartment building for 132 families at 307-11 East Seventy-second Street was sold by 307 East Seventy-second Street Realty Corporation to an investing client of Murray Adler, broker in the transaction.

A distinct tone of firmness was evident in the market for pound sterling last week as this was linked to the opening sessions of the tripartite Ministers' conference in Washington, which is canvassing the dollar crisis of Great Britain.

ROME, Sept. 11 -- The Italian seamen's strike took another turn for the worse today when it spread to Venice, where it was complicated by a simultaneous longshoremen's strike. Almost all shipping was at a standstill in the ports of Genoa, Naples, Venice and Trieste.

ROME, Sept. 11 -- The temptation to misuse the power of labor unions is one the greatest dangers to modern society and the workers themselves, Pope Pius said today. He spoke at his summer residence of Castel Gandolfo to a pilgrimage of Belgian workers.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 11 (AP) -- The champion Cleveland Browns meshed a powerful passing and running attack today and defeated the Baltimore Colts, 21 -- 0, for their first 1949 All-America Football Conference victory.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (AP) -- Capt. S. B. D. Wood, Judge Advocate for the Navy court investigating the sources of an anonymous document, that touched off a Congressional investigation of the B-36 controversy, said today that Capt. John G. Crommelin would be called to testify when the court reconvened Sept. 21.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- Jewish leaders meeting in emergency conference here voted today to take extraordinary measures, including reduction of home expenditures, to meet "a critical situation" resulting from the lagging of the United Jewish Appeal's drive to aid the resettling of Jewish refugees in Israel and elsewhere.

MOSCOW, Sept. 11 -- The Soviet Union dedicated this day to the honor of its tank and armored forces, which were called upon to maintain constant vigilance to defend "at any time and under any conditions" the Soviet state's borders and to stand guard, in the words of Izvestia, for the defense of peace throughout the world.

Peter Goggi, vintner and winemaker a la francaise, has preserved an Old World custom for more than forty-five years in the face of modern, high-speed production methods. His winery at Stapleton, S. I., adheres to the classic method of making champagne and sparkling Burgundy by fermenting them in the bottle.

ARDMORE, Pa., Sept. 11 -- The forty-ninth women's United States golf championship will start tomorrow over the east course of the Merion Golf Club. It will be entirely on a match-play basis, an innovation this year.
Two youths who allegedly tried to steal a policeman's private automobile Saturday night while its owner was cruising by in a radio car were arraigned yesterday in Felony Court, Ridgewood, Queens.

American investments in foreign areas never will be stimulated until the conditions prevailing in the domestic field of equity financing are modified drastically, according to Andre Istel, investment banker and former French delegate at the Bretton Woods Monetary Conference.

The televising of the complete World Series on the screens of motion picture theatres will be done on a limited and experimental basis next month, it was disclosed yesterday. If the experiment works out successfully from an economic standpoint, it may be the forerunner of regular presentation of the annual baseball classic in theatres throughout the country.
PITTSBURGH, Sept. 11 -- Postponement of the national steel strike until Sept. 25 was virtually certain tonight.

BERLIN, Sept. 11 -- The four-year ban on direct transactions between Americans and Germans will be extensively modified as of tomorrow in recognition of altered conditions in the occupation zone, notably the establishment of the Federal German Republic.

BOMBAY, Sept. 11 (Reuters) -- India's Industry and Supply Minister, Dr. Shyamaprasad Mookherjee, today announced a twelve-point formula for the liquidation of accumulated cotton textiles and the reopening of mills which have closed down.

ATHENS, Sept. 11 -- The Soviet Union has accelerated and expanded its program of securing militarily the areas along its European and Near Eastern frontiers by deporting non-Slavic elements to the extreme north and to Asia.
Cool weather and successful back-to-school promotions will bring a horde of buyers into New York's garment market this week, according to resident offices.

MOUNT KISCO, N. Y., Sept. 11 -- The Hutchinson Farms 8-year-old chestnut gelding Forward Passer, a veteran competitor from Teddy Gussenhoven's Stables in New Rochelle, and the 7-year-old chestnut gelding Guard Hill from the Shannon Stables of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Hawkins at Bedford Village, shared hunter championship honors at the thirteenth Lawrence Farms horse show today.

The United States must insist that it advance money to Britain only as part of a firm plan by which British industry can be modernized and made more efficient so that British exports can compete in world trade, Jacob K. Javits, member of Congress from the Twenty-first District, New York, stated last week. He outlined recommendations for British recovery in a statement to THE NEW YORK TIMES.

Nearly a half century ago -- in 1904 -- Albert Goodsell Milbank was elected to membership on the board of trustees of the Association for Improving the Condition of the Poor, now the Community Service Society. It was a time in New York history when the city was beset with social and health problems of serious magnitude.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 11 (AP) -- Jack Graham and Paul Lehner slammed out home runs in the sixth to help the Browns beat the Indians, 15 to 4, today, St. Louis' only triumph in the three-game series with Cleveland.

Every year about this time, weeks before Indian summer has garbed the trees and trails with the variegated war paints of approaching winter, there bursts forth in renewed fury the annual warfare between the Redskin and the Paleface.

An antidote to this blue Monday is to consider a cheerful little restaurant on the East Side at 41 East Forty-ninth Street that proves once again, if doubt still exists, that the French are the finest cooks in the world.

Orders for women's apparel were heavy in the wholesale garment trade here last week, according to reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices. Many buyers are expected in the market this week to cover holiday lines and fill-in on fall apparel.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- For laymen -- and that term covers most of the Senators and Representatives -- it is difficult to see why economy comes so hard to the armed services. There are several principal reasons.

Marly of the evils confronting various parts of the world today "derive directly from man's service to Mammon," the Rev. William T. Green, commissioner of music for the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York and a member of the staff of St. Patrick's Cathedral, declared there yesterday at solemn mass. Cardinal Soellman presided.

Gerald Gonzalez, 23-year-old Cuban boxer known as Kid Gavilan, a prominent contender for the welterweight and middleweight titles, suffered superficial wounds in the back of his neck early yesterday morning in a Harlem street fight with three men.

A house of worship, formerly used by the Good Shepherd Lutheran Church in Laurelton, Queens, and recently moved to 131-72 223d Street, Queens, was dedicated yesterday afternoon as the Jewish Community House of Laurelton and Springfield.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (AP) -- The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation said today that its $1,065,000,000 surplus -- used to support banks which get into trouble -- is "by no means as adequate as was formerly thought."

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 11 -- A combination of factors has held steel-making operations at a relatively high level here ever since late July, and the past week was no exception. Last week there was little or no buying as a hedge against the threat of a steel strike, according to industry sources.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Sept. 11 -- With Socialist and conservative party leaders wrangling over the nomination and last-minute party caucuses scheduled for tomorrow morning, the final ceremonies were being prepared in Bonn tonight for the election tomorrow evening of a President for the Federal Republic of Germany.

HAVANA, Sept. 11 -- The creation of a Continental Agrarian Commission to make plans for assisting the farmers in all the Latin American nations was agreed upon today at the closing session of the Inter-American Confederation of Labor.
Although the Dodgers yesterday won another error-filled game from the Giants at Ebbets Field, 10 -- 5, their pennant chances suffered a severe blow.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (AP) -- The Air Force expects to have big jet bombers capable of striking targets thousands of miles from this continent in operation in its strategic warplane fleet by about 1954.

SEOUL, Korea, Sept. 11 -- South Korea's economy is being lifted to levels of survival, according to a joint report issued this week-end by the combined State Department and Economic Cooperation Administration missions in Korea. For this, the report credits Korean self-help along with the Marshall Plan.
A Jesuit brother who combines carpentry, plumbing and chemistry with his daily prayers will soon be en route to the Caroline and Marshall Islands in the Pacific to put his varied talents to work.
PARIS, Sept. 11 -- France's production has attained the level of 1927, the most prosperous year between the wars, Edgar Faure, Secretary of State for Finances, announced today.

By the use of the world's fastest robot brain, the gigantic calculating machine known as the selective sequence electronic calculator, astronomers are now able to trace the paths of the outer planets and pinpoint their positions for the navigator for the next hundred years, the International Business Machines Corporation announced yesterday.
Souvenir war weapons figured in the arrest over the week-end of two men on charges of robbery and violation of the Sullivan Law.

LAKE SUCCESS, Sept. 11 -- The International Labor Organization reported here today that Japan had made remarkable progress toward economic recovery but that the country's future hopes were pinned on its ability to find a place in the international trade picture.

Although specific "Days" and "Weeks" are becoming so frequent as to lose a good deal of their significance, the accomplishments which underlie the celebration today of Transit Progress Day are impressive. The weekday average of riders on public vehicles in 1948 is revealed by the American Transit Association to have been 65,000,000.

SHANGHAI, Sept. 11 -- The newspaper Wen Hui Pao published a lengthy article today contending that primary allegiance to the family is "completely incompatible" with the spirit of proletarian revolution. The writer, Li Lin, called for a clean break with China's "patriarchal" concept of the family.

Victor M. Ratner has been appointed vice president in charge of sales promotion, public relations and advertising for Macy's New York, effective Nov. 1, it was announced by Richard Weil, Jr., president. Since 1947 Mr. Ratner has been vice president in charge of advertising and sales promotion, for both radio and television, of the Columbia Broadcasting System.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Sept. 11 -- Any decision to devalue the British pound will be followed by a general adjustment of European currencies to meet the British step, but according to a considerable economic opinion in Europe devaluation may boomerang on its American proponents.

All 150 members of the current fifteen-week day and evening sales training course at the City College Midtown Business Center have job offers awaiting them after graduation on Sept. 20, J. S. Schiff, course supervisor, reported over the week-end.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- Leaders on both sides prepared today to press for a Senate decision this week on the controversial "peril point" amendment to the reciprocal trade agreements bill as agitation continued for early adjournment of Congress.
LOCKPORT, N. Y., Sept. 11 (AP) -- Dr. Walter A. Maier, Lutheran Hour speaker engaged in a controversy with Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, criticized her again today.

CHICAGO, Sept. 11 -- Prices of grains moved upward on the Board of Trade last week with December wheat and September oats selling at the highest levels since last January and September corn reaching the best mark in a month before reacting under profit-taking sales induced by the Government estimate showing a probable yield of 3,525,000,000 bushels of corn.

BURLINGTON, Vt., Sept. 11 -- The body of James P. Taylor, for twenty-five years secretary of the Vermont State Chamber of Commerce and founder of the Green Mountain Club, who had been missing five days, was found floating in Lake Champlain today.

WARSAW, Sept. 11--A "rank and file movement" of Roman Catholic priests has asked the Polish Government to help them carry out their duties "joyfully" in a people's Poland, the official Polish news agency reported today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 11 -- Twentieth Century-Fox has announced plans for a screen biography of Sigmund Freud, the Viennese founder of psychoanalysis, to be produced next year under the title, "Dr. Freud." Charles Kaufman is preparing the photoplay under the supervision of Julian Blaustein, who will produce the film.

Christians have only the "haziest notion" of what it means to serve God faithfully, the Rev. Bernard C. Newman, vicar of Trinity Protestant Episcopal Church, said yesterday in a sermon at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, Amsterdam Avenue and 110th Street.

AMSTERDAM, Sept. 11 -- The trade pact concluded on Wednesday between Holland and Western Germany, which is expected to lead to a reciprocal trade of nearly $150,000,000 annually, is considered here an important step in attempts to liberalize European trade.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- The question of devaluation of the pound sterling, barred from discussion in the United States-British-Canadian financial conference, will receive a thorough if secret airing this week in the meeting of the International Monetary Fund.
PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Sept. 11--In a real sailing breeze, a jump of water and hard canvas competition, the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club's fall race series ended today.

Professional traders on the New York Cotton Exchange underestimated the Government's second forecast of the current cotton crop last Thursday, with the result that on Saturday active futures contracts were seventeen points lower to five points higher than the closing levels on Friday, Sept. 2.

MEXICO CITY, Sept. 11 -- Mrs. Paul Robeson told the closing session today of the Continental Congress for Peace that "forces of violence and hate" were waging an undeclared civil war against any who disagreed with the Government in the United States.

A week-end lag in reporting by physicians and hospitals resulted in the listing of only twelve new cases of polio here for the twenty-four-hour period ended at 9 A. M. yesterday. In spite of the absence of complete figures, Health Department officials expressed the opinion that the recession in the epidemic was continuing.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- The death of Associate Justice Wiley B. Rutledge in Maine last night allows President Truman to fill a second Supreme Court vacancy within six weeks, and also to make his fourth appointment to the highest bench.

Opening this morning with the largest enrollment in seven years, the New York City school system will begin its new academic year in "excellent condition," with the morale of the teaching staff at its highest, Dr. William Jansen, Superintendent of Schools, declared yesterday.

In the untimely death of Wiley Blount Rutledge, the Supreme Court has lost an earnest humanitarian, a devoted champion of civil rights and one of the kindliest and most courteous of men. The last of the Roosevelt appointees, Justice Rutledge was unquestionably a member of the Court's "liberal bloc."

CHICAGO, Sept. 11 -- Standard Oil Company of Indiana announced today it was abandoning a basing-point price system known as the Group Three method. The system, which based prices on Tulsa, Okla., plus rail freight, never was rigidly applied and is outmoded, the company said. Prices now will be established for each bulk plant and other supply points on the basis of "local economic and competitive factors."

BOSTON, Sept. 11 (AP) -- The Phillies twice defeated the Braves today, 3 -- 1 and 6 -- 3, but the 1948 National League pennant winners remained in fourth place with a percentage of .4892 as compared to the Giants' .4891.

RYE, N. Y., Sept. 11 -- Darkness had fallen on the polo field of the Westchester Country Club this evening when the imported Scottish Terrior, Champion Walsing Winning Trick of Edgerstoune, rose to a new height by taking the top award in the thirty-second and greatest Westchester Kennel Club fixture.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Sept. 11 -- Roman Catholic dignitaries protested "most emphatically" today against what they termed interference in church rights as a result of a Government order to theology students to attend lectures on "social science." The lectures have beer scheduled for Sept. 15 to 23.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (UP) -- The newly created Airport Advisory Committee of the Civil Aeronautics Administration will hold its first meeting here tomorrow to consider problems affecting airport construction, management and operation.
