The Virgin Islands, only United States possession without a radio station, is to have its first broadcaster soon, according to word from the Federal Communications Commission. He will be William N. Greer, who proposes to erect a 250-watt station at a cost of less than $4,000.

The urgent task of every Christian is to stem the tide of "sense" culture that is driving spiritual forces into retreat and making the church in New York "seem like a voice crying in the wilderness," the Rev. Dr. Allen E. Claxton, pastor of the Broadway Temple-Washington Heights Methodist Church, Broadway and 174th Street, declared in his morning sermon yesterday.

PARIS, Sept. 11 -- Financial circles are expecting a renewal of activity on the Paris Bourse as a result of the facilities accorded to the investment of foreign capital here. These facilities consist chiefly in the possibility for investors to repatriate at will their funds in the currency of their origin.

AURIESVILLE, N. Y., Sept. 11 (AP) -- The Rev. Francis D. Burns, director of the Shrine of North American Martyrs, said today Catholics should vote for candidates whose records showed "they would give to the Catholic child the educational advantages he is entitled to under the Constitution."

BUFFALO, Sept. 11--With losses by innocent buyers of stolen and fraudulently acquired cars in this state estimated at more than $500,000 thus far this year, Governor Dewey and the Legislature were urged today to plug loopholes in the laws to curb the practice.

Separates are important in today's fashion news. Young and old enjoy this mix-and-match game, which permits them to assemble a costume of various parts. It is fun because it taxes one's style sense in putting together colors and fabrics; it is practical because the clever woman can provide herself with the means of developing costumes for all hours of the day.

Columbia University will offer five evening courses in advertising this fall, it was announced over the week-end. They will be given by the Department of Business for the School of General Studies. Under a new system of course classification, enrollees for business evening courses having few or no college credits will have their business experience considered as an equivalent in registering them for the most appropriate classes, it was noted.

The National Federation of American Shipping announced yesterday that it had suppported the request of British shipowners for a reduction of Suez Canal tolls that are costing American shipowners about $6,000,000 annually.

CHICAGO, Sept. 11 -- Vice President Alben W. Barkley, addressing an audience of 10,000 persons at an all-Cook County Democratic picnic, promised that before the Administration of President Truman expired "we will have written into law every pledge made in the last campaign."

The state committees of the four legal political parties, Republican, Democratic, American Labor and Liberal, will meet this week to name candidates for United States Senator to run for the unexpired part of the term of Robert F.Wagner and for Associate Judge Thomas D. Thacher.

Harry Bridges, president of the International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union, CIO, said yesterday that he had made five different proposals for a settlement of the Hawaiian longshoremen's strike in the current mediation talks with Cyrus S. Ching, head of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service.

KANSAS CITY, Sept. 11 (AP)--Jim Ferrier of San Francisco won the $5,000 Kansas City open golf tournament today with a 72-hole score-of 277, eleven strokes under par for the four rounds. He had a two-under-par 70 today.

Re-election of Mayor O'Dwyer was urged yesterday by City Construction Coordinator Robert Moses. He declared that a second term was needed to assure proper completion of a "first rate" public works program upon which the present city administration has made "excellent" progress despite many obstacles.

A merchant whose stock consisted of one pair of used shoes made a 100 per cent turnover yesterday on the Bowery in front of one of a half dozen diamond exchanges where, on six days of every seven, a maharajah's ransom in gems changes hands.

BUFFALO, N. Y., Sept. 11 (AP) -- The Brooklyn-New York Yankees surged from behind today to win their All-America Conference football opener with the Buffalo Bills, 17 -- 14. Harvey Johnson's 21-yard field goal did the trick with a minute and ten seconds to play. A crowd of 30,410 saw the game in Civic Stadium.
An eight-grade, one-story, ranch-type parochial school edifice was dedicated yesterday afternoon for St. John's Lutheran Church, Twenty-second Avenue and 123d Street, College Point, Queens.

Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months amount to $53,470,697,214. They consist of Treasury bonds, certificates of indebtedness, bills and notes as follows:

From time to time this summer a Senate Judiciary subcommittee has been conducting "hearings" on displaced persons legislation. The quotation marks are used advisedly, for it is apparent from the spasmodic timing of the subcommittee's sessions that no real effort is being made to report out any sort of DP bill this session.

The City Island Yacht Club's thrash to Cornfield Lightship and return for large auxiliary craft in the Class C Division was won by Herbert Ahrens' Pirouette, a cutter, yesterday. Pirouette annexed the honors in the 140-mile race by covering the distance in the corrected time of 21:25:28, while John Ryan's Baccarat, the runner-up, finished in 21:53:12.
Harold Taylor in a letter to the editor on Sept. 1 made a number of misstatements about UAW-CIO Ammunition, a publication of the union's Education Department, which I happen to edit.

HONG KONG, Sept. 11 -- Moving swiftly to implement agreements reached with Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek and other Nationalist leaders at Chungking, Gen. Lu Han, Governor of Yunnan Province, has begun a sweeping clean-up of pro-Communist elements in Kunming.

SYOSETT. L. I., Sept. 11 -- Mrs. Edward Robertson's Randle's Lad was adjudged the working hunters champion during the Helping Hand Horse Show on the estate of Mrs. M. B. Hewlett today. The show was staged for the benefit of the Community Church of Syosett.

A resolution calling for academic freedom from discrimination on ideological or racial grounds was adopted unanimously yesterday by the Twenty-ninth International Congress of Americanists, after attempts to introduce a stronger statement had failed.

The Rev. Dr. Albert J. Penner, new pastor of the Broadway Tabernacle Congregational Church at Fifty-sixth Street, expressed the hope yesterday that freedom of utterance in his church would not go beyond the bounds of freedom of the Gospel.

FRENCH LICK, Ind., Sept. 10 (AP) -- Competition and efficiency have so improved the general construction picture that an investor can get a dollar's value from each dollar spent for building, a nationwide survey of general contractors reports.

An article in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Aug. 28 has the caption "Arab States Seek Wide Israeli Area" and says that "one-justification for the large claims, in the Arabs' view, is that they will have to undertake the resettlement of the refugee populations and need territory on which to do it."

The latest change in the Presidency of Paraguay is of more than ordinary significance because it removes the one man whose close personal ties to Argentina were tending to orient his country toward the Peron regime, and thus upset the diplomatic balance of power between Argentina and Brazil.

A former instructor at City College announced yesterday that he had invited a Negro couple and their 5-year-old son to use his Stuyvesant Town apartment for the coming academic year while he is teaching at Pennsylvania State College.

A model airplane with a wing-spread of two to three feet almost rammed a transatlantic airliner carrying forty-three passengers yesterday as the big plane neared the New York International Airport at Idlewild, Queens. Capt. Gerard Bruens, pilot of the KLM Royal Dutch Airlines Constellation from Amsterdam, said that the model plane might have been "very embarrassing" to the incoming passenger craft.

With the lowly Senators the victims in a long and tumultuous afternoon, the Yankees yesterday took a double hitch on their first place hold in the American League flag race by grabbing two games at the Stadium to the roaring cheers of 41,800 onlookers, while disaster befell the pursuing Red Sox and Indians.

Mrs. Elsie Murphy, executive vice president of S. Stroock Co., has been appointed temporary chairman of an advisory committee to promote wool for women's wear, it was announced over the week-end by The Wool Bureau, Inc.

" Knowing and the Known," by John Dewey in collaboration with Arthur Bentley, will be published by the Beacon Press on Oct. 20, Mr. Dewey's ninetieth birthday. The book will contain the findings of the two philosophers in the specialized field of research called the science of meaning. The concern will also issue on Sept. 21 "The Wit and Wisdom of John Dewey," culled from his writings.

Fifty-seven men and three women -- graduate students in engineering and science from twenty foreign countries -- left New York in two chartered buses yesterday for a 2,200-mile "Industry-in-Action" tour, as guests of the National Association of Manufacturers.

TOKYO, Sept. 11 (UP) -- The "Flying Fish of Fujiyama," Hironoshin Furuhashi, splashed home first in the rain today with another world record-breaking performance in the, 800-meter freestyle during the Japanese intercollegiate championships.

WHITE SANDS PROVING GROUND, N. M., Sept. 6--(Delayed by the United States Navy)--The Navy's second attempt in a fortnight to shoot its new "Viking" rocket to an altitude of 100 miles failed today when the missile petered out inexplicably after reaching a height of only thirty-three miles.

Fifteen additional Swedish factories producing modern furniture have joined the export group represented in the United States by Swedish Modern, Inc., Arthur Schlossman, president, and Mrs. Alice M. Roberts, treasurer, announced jointly last week. They have just returned from a sixty-day stay in Sweden to work out contractual arrangements.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (UP) -- Chief Justice Fred A Vinson led his associates of the Supreme Court today in paying tribute to the late Associate Justice Wiley B. Rutledge.

Oren Root, Republican and City Fusion party candidate for Borough President of Manhattan, asked Mayor O'Dwyer yesterday if he intended to spend $495,000 of capital budget funds for the erection of statues of Generals Simon Bolivar and Jose de San Martin at each end of the Avenue of the Americas. Placing of the statues has been recommended by the City Planning Commission, of which Mr. Root's opponent, Robert F. Wagner Jr., is chairman.

The belief dies hard that when a country runs a chronic deficit in its international financial transactions it must be having currency trouble, and that the indicated remedy is to change its currency policy.

Mayor O'Dwyer announced yesterday that he would swear in at City Hall on Friday the members of an Advisory Committee on the Puerto Rican Problem. The committee's job will be "to formulate and activate a program for constructive and comprehensive improvement of New York's Puerto Rican community."

For most of us, perhaps, the emu is a bird that inhabits the insides of crossword puzzles. There, like the obi, the gnu and the yak, he browses on the succulent pods of the zaman tree and lives a life that might seem dull to a human being, yet which serves its purpose in the final pattern.
A recent decision by French courts involving the payment of quay dues in France on bulk cargoes of coal or grain is receiving considerable attention from American-flag steamship companies.

MONTREAL, Sept. 11 (Canadian Press) -- Formation of a committee of British and Canadian business men to study Anglo-Canadian economic problems and help in finding a solution to trade difficulties between the two countries was announced today. The committee will meet twice annually -- once in the United Kingdom and then in Canada.
ASUNCION, Paraguay, Sept. 11 (AP) -- Congress named Federico Chaves provisional President of Paraguay today. It was the sixth change of administration for Paraguay in seventeen months.

DETROIT, Sept. 11 -- Walter P. Reuther, president of the United Automobile Workers, CIO, arrived home from Pittsburgh this afternoon, but was silent on whether the recommendations of the President's fact-finding board in the steel dispute would influence his bargaining with the Ford Motor Company.
MONTREAL, Sept. 11 -- An inadequate twelve-mile Canadian canal is the main barrier to reviving a once thriving water-borne trade over Lake Champlain between New York City and the St. Lawrence River.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 11 -- Formation of a citizen's committee to bring together representatives of management and labor offered hope tonight for a resumption of negotiations in the Missouri Pacific Railroad strike.
JERUSALEM, Sept. 11 -- The City Council of Jewish Jerusalem declared tonight that it never would accept international control of the city.

LAKE SUCCESS, Sept. 11 -- The employes of the United Nations celebrate the staff's fourth birthday next month. The occasion will end four years that have seen the staff grow from a harassed pioneer group to the world's most ambitious experiment in international civil service.
The local art season gathers headway this week with thirteen attractions.

During the past few days some important conversations have been taking place in Tokyo. One visitor has been Malcolm MacDonald, Britain's High Commissioner in Southeast Asia. Another has been Tracy S. Voorhees, United States Under-Secretary of the Army.
SHANGHAI, Sept. 9 -- Plans for a radical administrative and geographical reorganization of China under Communist rule were outlined today in one of Shanghai's leading newspapers.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 11 -Just what the doctor, C. D. Stengel of New York, ordered, a double-dose of defeat was administered the Red Sox by the Athletics today at Shibe Park.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11-- Development of a master plan for economic expansion of the United States was proposed today, in a report issued by the National Planning Association, as a means of promoting world recovery and domestic well-being.

LONDON, Sept. 11 -- The stock markets here have developed a surprising degree of firmness and also activity despite a somewhat anxious period of waiting for results from the British-Canadian-American conference in Washington.
JERUSALEM, Sept. 11 -- The City Council of Jewish Jerusalem declared tonight that it never would accept international control of the city.

LAKE SUCCESS, Sept. 11 -- The employes of the United Nations celebrate the staff's fourth birthday next month. The occasion will end four years that have seen the staff grow from a harassed pioneer group to the world's most ambitious experiment in international civil service.

MARY PIERREPONT, whose father became first an earl and then a marquis and finally a duke, was a lady of quality with a mind of her own. She lived in the reign of Queen Anne and the reigns of the first two Georges. An aristocrat, a greatly gifted writer, sublimely egoistic and maliciously witty, she contrived to spend much of her life in controversy, scandal and extraordinary circumstances.

LONDON, Sept. 12 -- The communique issued in Washington today on the outcome of the talks on how to restore the balance between the sterling and the dollar areas left the City of London, the financial district, guessing on what would be the next step and who would take it.

Their long summer vacation over, more than one million children returned to New York's public and parochial schools yesterday. Here in our own city the 886,500 children in the public schools represent an increase of 22,000 in the last twelve-month period, making it the largest enrollment in seven years.

ARDMORE, Pa., Sept. 12 -- A few hours after the United States Golf Association's women's championship got under way on an all-match play basis over the Merion Golf Club's east course today, the defending titleholder, Miss Grace Lenczyk of Hartford, Conn., was eliminated.

Awards for research totaling $1,216,700 have just been made by the American Cancer Society to twenty-five hospitals, medical schools and scientific institutions, it was announced yesterday. This completes the society's research program for 1949-50, the sum of $3,194,857 having been contributed during the period.

Leon Kraemer, the last surviving member of the infamous Whittemore jewel gang of the roaring Twenties, will be released today from Clinton Prison at served Dannemore, N. Y. He has served twenty-three years of a forty-year term.
Bloomingdale Bros., Inc., and its wholly owned subsidiaries reported yesterday for the twenty-six weeks ended on July 30, net profit of $506,251, after taxes and all charges.

The stock market reflected optimism yesterday over the two problems that recently caused traders to exercise a high degree of caution. The day's developments indicated the possibility of a solution of the differences between steel management and labor, and sufficient American concessions to Great Britain to help her solve her dollar crisis.
CINCINNATI, Sept. 12 (AP) -President Truman said today that the nation's economic strength depended to a significant extent upon the way life insurance companies performed their responsibilities.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (UP) -Admiral Louis E. Denfeld, Chief of Naval Operations, and three other high United States naval officers were decorated today by the Peruvian Government. The medals were awarded in a ceremony commemorating the twentieth anniversary of the inauguration of Pan American-Grace Airways [Panagra] service between Peru and the United States.

Representatives of the International Longshoremen's Association, AFL, and the New York Shipping Association, an employer group, met in the latters offices, 80 Broad Street, for ninety, mintues yesterday but recessed until Thursday at 11 A. M. Efforts to negotiate a new contract were stalemated over the issue of wages.

BERLIN, Sept. 12 -- After more than eighteen months of disharmony on virtually every topic, the United States, British, French and Soviet commandants of Berlin reached agreement today on the minor matter of normalization of mail service in all four sectors.

There was no particular pressure on the cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday but hedge selling seemed to increase toward the close of the market, and prices fell 4 to 8 points net on the day.

JAMESTOWN, Va., Sept. 12 -The Robert Hunt Shrine on Jamestown Island, scene of the first English mass said on American soil, was visited today by eight Anglican and two Protestant Episcopal bishops commemorating the 400th anniversary of the first "Booke of Common Prayer After the Use of the Church of England."

The City of New York has borrowed $65,000,000 from twenty-five banks and trust companies on 1 1/8 per cent tax anticipation notes scheduled to mature as follows: Oct. 26, $20,000,000; Oct. 28, $20,000,000; Nov. 1, $25,000,000.
For the first time since the big pheasant decline in 1946, New York will have a state-wide pheasant season and a more liberal grouse season.

YONKERS, N. Y., Sept. 12 -- Mrs. Edith P. Welty, 61-year-old grandmother, became the first woman Mayor of Yonkers today, chosen to serve out the unexpired term of Curtiss E. Frank, who resigned Sept. 1.

BERLIN, Sept. 12 -- The joint directive issued yesterday by the military government and the European Command liberalizing regulations for transactions with Germans was clarified today. American personnel were surprised at the assurance that they may, if they wish, sell their private automobiles for Deutsche marks.

The threat of a walkout of the nation's steelworkers, seheduled for midnight tonight, has been definitely postponed as a result of the report of the President's board and of subsequent developments over the week-end, with a strong probability that it may have been removed altogether.
ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Sept. 12 (AP) -- Mom's Choice, owned and trained by Carl Hanford, was ridden to a neck victory by Hanford's brother Ira in a fifth-race dash for juvenile fillies here today.
Mediation efforts undertaken here by the Federal Government to end the 135-day-old Hawaiian longshoremen's strike broke down last night with the disputants as far apart as ever.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -- Senator George Aiken, Republican, of Vermont, today issued a statement outlining effects of his (the Aiken long-range flexible farm price support law will have if it automatically goes into operation on Jan. 1. He pointed out that chances seem slim for action this session on any basic agriculture program.

To commemorate the 100th anniversary of Chopin's death Macmillan will publish on Sept. 27 "Frederic Chopin, 1810-1849," edited by Stephen P. Mizwa, which will contain articles by European and American authors, an oration delivered by Ignace Jan Paderewski on the centennial of the composer's birth, and a collection of Chopin's correspondence that has never before appeared in print.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -- Fleet Admiral William F. Halsey took an unequivocal position today at the head of the ranks of Navy supporters of Capt. John Crommelin Jr., who protested on Saturday in a public statement that Navy power was being "nibbled to death" in the Pentagon.

A large number of visiting buyers crowded showrooms of New York garment manufacturers yesterday to complete their fall purchases of women's and children's apparel. Quick delivery is desired on a variety of items, buyers informed manufacturers, and fill-in orders were placed for coats, suits, sportswear and dresses.

While the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis warned yesterday that this year's epidemic was only half over and would surpass that of 1916, reports of new cases here continued to be comparatively few.

BELGRADE, Sept. 12 -- The political and operations chiefs of the Yugoslav Navy sent a message to Marshal Tito yesterday informing him that the Navy was in a state of readiness and was prepared to fight to the last man to defend this country's independence against any aggressor.

The Senate is scheduled to meet tonight in the first of several night sessions intended to speed up action on the Reciprocal Trade Agreements program. The question at issue here is whether to restore the full bargaining powers (in the negotiation of new agreements) which Presidents Truman and Roosevelt enjoyed under the original plan sponsored by Cordell Hull and subsequently approved five times by Congress.

HAVANA, Sept. 12 -- The International Transport Workers Federation today declared war on the maritime section of the Communist-dominated World Federation of Trade Unions. This section was formed recently in Marseille and Harry Bridges, president of the International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union, CIO, was named chairman.

HERSHEY, Pa., Sept. 12 -- The strong man of Pennsylvania football for three years, Chuck Bednarik, is now a legend and no longer the bulwark and anchor of the line, and no one could blame George Munger very much if he doesn't feel too happy about the season coming up.

Federal Judge Harold R. Medina jailed another defendant in the Communist trial yesterday for contempt of court. He sentenced Carl Winter, the party's Michigan chairman, to thirty days for disobeying an order of the court to answer questions under cross-examination.

NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 12 -- President Truman, in a letter read today to the delegates attending the thirty-first National Recreation Congress, endorsed the theory of Federal Government aid in the field of community recreation.

PRAGUE, Sept. 12 (UP) -- The Czechoslovak Bishop's memorandum called for peace, though it was anything but conciliatory. It outlined demands the Government could hardly accept without making a major retreat.

BUFFALO, Sept. 12 -- State and Federal mediators joined here today to urge the Bell Aircraft Corporation, strikebound since June 13, and Local 501, United Automobile Workers, CIO, to resume negotiations.

CAMDEN, N. J., Sept. 12 -- As the last of the thirteen victims Howard Unruh's murderous rampage last Tuesday were buried today, Treasury agents began a drive in this area to make useless souvenir war weapons such as the moody former 'soldier collected.

Henry A. Wallace charged last night that the Truman Administration had betrayed "that common man" and that its policies, which he said were dictated by corporate monopoly interests, were taking the country down a "valley of depression" into a third world war.
An underwriting syndicate headed by Putnam Co. will offer today 160,000 shares of new $50 par value 3.9 per cent cumulative preferred stock of the Hartford Electric Light Company at par.
HONG KONG, Sept. 12 (UP) -- British naval authorities said tonight that a "strong diplomatic protest" was being made over the seizure of the British vessel Leongbee by a Chinese Nationalist gunboat.

Some extremely smart fashions were presented by Macy's Fabric Center at a preview held yesterday morning for the press. The fabrics, mostly nylons by Mallinson and woolens by Milridge, were made up in pattern styles by McCall. The show is being held today and tomorrow in the department.

The American Broadcasting Company has decided for the time being not to accept programs that advertise liquor, it was announced yesterday by Robert E. Kintner, executive vice president. Among the four national chains, ABC reportedly had entertained the idea of liquor advertising far more seriously than the others after Schenley Distillers, Inc., put out exploratory feelers to networks and stations two months ago.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -- More than 3,000,000 workers -- probably a great deal more -- are covered by some type of health, welfare, or retirement plans in collective bargaining agreements such as the board of inquiry recommended in the steel dispute.

A storm that "has characteristics of the typical wintertime northeaster" is due to be felt in this city today, the Weather Bureau here said last night. Strong to gale, east to northeasterly winds were predicted for the New York area today and tonight, with wind velocities of thirty-five to forty-five miles an hour.
LAKE SUCCESS, Sept. 12 -- Every day for three years how there have been little cards tacked up on United Nations bulletin boards with hopeful messages that run something like this!

The New York City CIO Council approved last night a resolution supporting the Democratic candidacies of former Gov. Herbert H. Lehman for the Senate and Mayor O'Dwyer and his running mates on the party's city ticket.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores increased 1 per cent last week over the corresponding period last year, according to "flash" report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The decline for the four weeks ended last Saturday was 3 per cent.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (AP) -- The text of the joint communique issued today on the conclusion of the Anglo-American-Canadian financial talks:

MONTCLAIR, N. J., Sept. 12 -- Parents of fifty children who had been transferred to a new school as a result of a redistricting program instituted by the Montclair Board of Education announced today they would keep their children out of school in protest against the change. They charge the redistricting was motivated by reasons of racial discrimination.
A pre-Inca high priest who died perhaps 3,000 years ago arrived yesterday on the Grace liner Santa Isabel from Peru, designated on the ship's manifest merely as "Mummy No. 49."

HELENA, Mont., Sept 12 -- Snow continued falling in Montana today as the first sign of winter spread into Wyoming and the Dakotas. The storm hit Montana Saturday, spreading more than a foot of snow over some areas.
LONDON, Sept. 12 -- Consideration over the week-end of "progress reports" from Washington brought brokers to the City in a more cheerful state of mind today despite railroad wage uncertainties.

There was no disturbance of the natural laws of horse racing at Aqueduct yesterday when Burton D. Chait's Sky Miracle won the Little Neck Handicap. As a matter of fact, judging from the support accorded the 3-year-old son of Brown Comet and from his record on recent performance, it would have been a miracle if the Chait color-bearer had lost the mile and a quarter event.
Following is the text of the general circular to be issued by Superintendent of Schools William Jansen for putting the Feinberg Law into effect here:

SCARSDALE, N. Y., Sept. 12 -- The combination of Lloyd Wadkins and Roy Tilles of the home club fashioned a 67 to win the Westchester County Golf Association one - day pro - amateur best - ball competition today over the windswept Quaker Ridge course.
BUFFALO, Sept. 12 -- President Truman was likened today by Senator Irving M. Ives, Republican, to a reckless automobile driver speeding along the road to national bankruptcy.

Five Chicago Protestant ministers who attended yesterday the trial of eleven Communists before Federal Judge Harold R. Medina were unanimous in their disapproval of the trial but refused to release a press statement that had been prepared and mimeographed for them.
SCHENECTADY N. Y., Sept. 12 -- Charles M. Ripley, 69, retired lecturer for the General Electric Company, was found dead in his home tonight by his son, Charles C. Ripley.

From the director of the consumers' service and research division of the New York City Department of Markets, Mrs. Frances Foley Gannon, comes news that "heavy production of sweet potatoes is now under way in Virginia and Maryland."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -- The current search for economy by the Department of Defense offers no more complicated field than its medical services. After two years of investigation by various boards and committees, no clear-cut remedy for admitted over-extension has been devised.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 12 -- A conciliatory attitude shown by representatives of four striking brotherhoods and the Missouri Pacific Railroad was believed tonight to presage an early settlement of the walkout that has tied up the 7,200-mile system since Friday.
LONDON, Tuesday, Sept. 13 -- Britain's nationalized coal mines continued to show a profit in the second quarter of this year, but earnings declined in comparison with the first quarter.

NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 12 -The provincial Government of the United Provinces has launched an agrarian reform movement. Within three months it will eliminate 2,000,000 landlords, big and small, and transfer ownership of the land to about 11,000,000 cultivators.

TEL AVIV, Sept. 12 (AP) -- The chairman of the Parliamentary Foreign Affairs Committee declared today that "neither the Israeli Government nor the Israeli Parliament is contemplating a change in their declared policy regarding Jerusalem."
Trading in a new copper futures contract began on the Commodity Exchange here yesterday. A turnover of 125 tons, largest in recent weeks, was reported.
CHICAGO, Sept 12 -- John T. Jarecki, Collector of Internal Revenue, today filed a lien against Preston Tucker, president of the Tucker Corporation, for nonpayment of 1947 income taxes.

The statue of Simon Bolivar will remain where it-is in Central Park at Eighty-third Street, near Central Park West, but in a more elaborate setting than at present, while the statue of Gen. Jose de San Martin will occupy a site at the Avenue of the Americas and Fifty-ninth Street, under plans approved by the Art Commission yesterday.

THE HAGUE, The Netherlands, Sept. 12 -- The world's airline operators called today for a multilateral air-traffic agreement to replace the present system of bilateral pacts and for less government interference in commercial air transport.

Now more than ever before, new products, freshness and quality are essential to success in the candy industry, Stephen Klein president of Barton's Bonbonniere chain of retail candy stores in this area, declared yesterday at the opening of a new store at 126 West Fiftieth Street, Manhattan.
CLEVELAND, Sept. 12 (AP) -- This season's shipment of grains on the Great Lakes, up to Sept 1, was almost double that of last year, the Lake Carriers Association reported today.
PITTSBURGH, Sept. 12 -- The national steel strike, scheduled for midnight tomorrow, was officially postponed tonight until 12:01 A. M. Sept. 25.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -- The body of Associate Justice Wiley Blount Rutledge of the Supreme Court reached Washington today from York, Me., where the jurist died Saturday after a cerebral hemorrhage.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -- The Senate was ordered today into night sessions in an Administration drive to finish action this week on the trade agreements bill, and get on next week to the controversial foreign arms aid program, which this morning received committee approval.

Henry A. Wallace, former Vice President and candidate for President on the Progressive party ticket in 1948, refused flatly yesterday to be the American Labor party's nominee for United States Senator from New York in the coming election.

Esther Dorothy's fall collection of furs, viewed yesterday at 68 East Fifty-sixth Street, highlighted scarves without heads and tails, a new smock coat silhouette with fullness falling from the shoulder yoke, a rich dark shade of green for furs, a discreet use of buttons and pockets, the reappearance of fox, now clipped and dyed, a slim reversible coat of tweed and kidskin and her usual charming linings of bright colored silk and wool.

Declaring that they were forced to leave Hungary because of "political and economic persecution,'' the forty-five Hungarian refugees detained for nearly two months on Ellis Island for passport and visa investigation appealed yesterday to "the humanity and love of freedom of the American people" to enable them to remain in this country.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -- Gold pricing and possible revaluation of currencies as remedies for the world's financial ills will highlight discussions at the fourth annual meeting of the International Monetary Fund, which opens tomorrow.

BONN, Germany, Sept. 12 -- Theodor Heuss, 65-year-old liberal professor and journalist, was elected President of the Federal Republic of Germany today. He immediately took the oath of office and told the people of Western Germany their fate was tied with that of Berlin.

The method by which it is proposed to give loyalty tests to this city's 40,000 public school employes, as required throughout the state by the Feinberg Law, was made public yesterday by Dr. William Jansen, superintendent of schools.

UNIONDALE, L. I., Sept. 12 -- The mystery of a cross-burning incident on the lawn of a Negro resident here the night of Aug. 10 was cleared up today by the arrest of two men, who said they did it as a "drunken prank."

Mohawk Carpet Mills, Inc., is increasing production of Axminster carpeting because of a "decided improvement" in retail orders, Gerald I. Monahan, vice president in charge of sales, reported yesterday. Other leading mills also are stepping up Axminster output, according to production executives.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -- The first large scale nation-wide attack on heart disease under the National Heart Institute, a Federal aid program totaling $8,614,737, was announced today by the Public Health Service, an arm of the Federal Security Agency.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Sept. 12 -- The Republican majority of the Westchester County Board of Supervisors met in caucus here today for nearly two hours and decided "to add no more kindling" to the controversy that followed the Sept. 4 riot near Peekskill between left-wing followers of Paul Robeson and politically conservative residents of that area.
The seventh annual convention of the National Maritime Union, CIO, opened here yesterday at St. Nicholas Arena with most of the session devoted the formation of committees.

BONN, Sept. 12 -- Dr. Konrad Adenauer, Chancellor-apparent of the West German state, appealed to the Tripartite High Commission today for some concession on the issue of dismantling. Dr. Adenauer visited members of the commission this morning at their offices in Petersburg, atop a mountain across the Rhine.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (AP) -- Two competitors opposed today Capital Airlines' proposal that what it termed "restrictions" on its present route be removed.
GANTON, England, Sept. 12 (AP) -- Ben Hogan said today he is "sick and tired" of harping by the British press on the half-ton of meat brought to England by the American Ryder Cup golfers.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -- The United States, Great Britain and Canada agreed today to work together to put the sterling area on a basis of paying its way by 1952, and undertook a series of measures to ease the dollar crisis and end the drain on British gold and dollar reserves.

With all the trappings of a major league classic, the Air Force staged its own version of the world series at the Polo Grounds yesterday. Winner of the championship, after a week-long tournament, was the Bolling Flyers of Washington, D. C., who defeated the Lowry Field team from Denver, 3 -- 2, in the final game.

The election of Theodor Heuss as first President of the new German Federal Republic marks one of the final steps toward organization of the infant state as a fully functioning entity. Under the Constitution, powers of the President are severely limited; the Germans, we may hope, have had enough in recent years of a strong "leader" utterly independent of legislative controls.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Sept. 12 -- A British-Israeli rapprochement is developing, according to diplomatic sources here. Israel's unexpected acceptance of British membership in the economic survey group established by the United Nations Conciliation Commission is held to be one sign of the growing understanding.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -- Senator Pat McCarran, Democrat, of Nevada, chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee, will make his own investigation of displaced person camps, he told the Senate today. He will sail from New York Wednesday on the Queen Mary.
The captain of the launch that takes Bedloes Island employes to and from the city shouted across the boat yesterday to his two deck hands.

Trans World Airlines yesterday formally approved the master agreement between international airlines and the Port of New York Authority for use of New York International Airport at Idlewild, Queens, in a ceremony in Governor Dewey's suite at the Hotel Roosevelt.

How to furnish a four-and-a-half-room apartment by supplementing a minimum amount of money with a maximum investment of hard work, special skill and imagination may be seen in the model apartment at South Beach on Staten Island, which opens to the public today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (UP) -- The Economic Cooperation Administration today released $13,000,000 for construction of a new electric power plant in the Western occupation sectors of Berlin.
Newbold Morris, Republican-Liberal party nominee for Mayor, carried his campaign to Queens last night, addressing the County Committee of the Liberal party at the Forest Hills Inn.
CINCINNATI, Sept. 12 -- Members of the Cincinnati Stock Exchange voted, 11 to 8, today against a proposal to merge with the new Midwest Stock Exchange in Chicago.

TOKYO, Sept. 12 -- In four years, Japan's labor movement has grown from a membership of 5,000 to almost 7,000,000, Chester W. Hepler, chief of the Occupation's labor division, declared today in a farewell message. He has resigned to join the International Labor Organization staff at Geneva.

Steel operations this week are scheduled at 80.4 per cent of capacity, a decline of 3.8 points from last week's operating rate, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. The institute previously had reported a scheduled rate of 86.6 per cent, but lowered it as a result of the interplant railroad strike slated for this morning at plants of the United States Steel Corporation in the Pittsburgh district.
CLEVELAND, Sept. 12 (UP) -- The Republic Steel Corporation said tonight it was "ready and willing" to join with the United Steelworkers "in a study of the whole pension problem."

The Chinese Communists' announcements of new geographical divisions for China confirm some of the fears over the possible fragmentation of the Chinese state. Six "administrative areas" have been designated, but beyond them lies a new creation, the "Inner Mongolian Autonomous Region," lying on the borders of the Soviet Union.

The American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals is facing a financial crisis as a result of increased operating costs and the need to build a new animal hospital and shelter in Manhattan, John D. Seals Jr., its president, said yesterday.

BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 12 (AP) -- Leon Henderson, former Office of Price Administration administrator, is working on a private barter plan here whereby Argentina would get United States goods without spending dollars.
The New York Zoological Society will begin next week a course of lectures for public school teachers to "teach the teachers" how to use the facilities of the Bronx Zoo.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 12 -- The nation's leading motion-picture theatre operators opened their annual convention here today with an unscheduled protest against certain film distribution practices which have grown out of the Government's anti-trust action.
SARANAC INN, N. Y., Sept. 12 (AP) -- Norman H. Polhemus of Poughkeepsie today was elected president of the New York State Savings and Loan League to succeed Herman L. Reis of New York City.
John J. (Broadway Johnny), Broderick, former "tough cop" of the Great White Way, has lost out in his bid for all or part of the Tammany leadership in that area, it was learned last night.

Nassau County petitioned the Interstate Commerce. Commission yesterday for the appointment of a third trustee for the bankrupt Long Island Rail Road so that a majority of the trustees would be free of prior obligation to the Pennsylvania Railroad, the sole owner of the Long Island.

NUREMBERG, Germany, Sept. 12 (UP) -- A dispute between the United States Army and Air Force over Air Force claims to have wiped out an Army unit tonight marked the autumn war maneuvers, which began last Tuesday in what outwardly appeared to be complete inter-service amity.

To promote New York as the largest millinery center in the country, Mayor O'Dwyer gave official recognition to the millinery industry of the city yesterday, in a special program held on the steps of City Hall.
ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Sept. 12 (AP) -- Company-owned stores in coal, steel and textile centers are planning to compete with chain stores for outside business, an industrial store official said today.

Shirley Booth has signed to play one of four important roles in Brock Pemberton's forthcoming production of "The Time Is Yes," Doris Frankel's comedy, formerly known as "Rondo in a Flat." Miss Booth, known for her caustic comments and humor on the stage, will portray what has been described as "a dizzy actress."

The earnings of no one industry will solve Britain's financial crisis, but if she manages to bridge the immediate nonetary problem British-built airliners may be a noteworthy source of American dollars. Jet airliners designed and built in England are now in the air while their American counterparts are reaching the drawing board stage.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 12 -RKO today announced castings for the leading roles in two films, "Carriage Entrance" and "The Blind Spot." Ava Gardner, Robert Mitchum, Melvyn Douglas and Gloria Graham will be seen in "Entrance," and Claudette Colbert and Robert Ryan will appear in "Blind Spot," the studio disclosed.

Count Carlo Sforza, Italian Foreign Minister, declared here yesterday as he arrived on the Queen Mary that Italy would not seek to further any special national aims at the meeting of the Council of Foreign Ministers of Atlantic Pact nations that opens in Washington on Saturday.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Sept. 12 (AP) -- Sherman H. Bowles, president of the Atlas Tack Corporation, said in a statement today that financial reports to the New York Stock Exchange and stockholders were delayed because the company was seeking to complete transactions with the liquidated Phoenix Apollo Steel Company.

CHICAGO, Sept. 12 -- The first official act of the forty-fifth convention of the Mine, Mill and Smelter Workers Union, a left-wing affiliate of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, today was to call on Philip Murray, CIO president, and the United Steelworkers of America, which he also heads, to reject the Presidential fact-finding board's pension and health proposal.

In a day of strong and active trading, coffee futures advanced the permissible trading limit yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. Final levels in Contract "S" were 116 to 145 points above the previous close and in Contract "D" were up 148 to 150 points compared with Friday's close.

HONG KONG, Sept. 12 -- The necessity for an early decision in Washington on the use of unexpended Marshall Plan funds in China may prompt an examination of the United States policy toward Formosa, informed sources here believe.
GENEVA, Sept. 12 -- A conference of the International Union of Cities and Local Authorities opened here today for a week-long meeting devoted to local government problems.

The Federal Government and the $80,000,000 Idaho Power Company will begin tomorrow a court battle that promises to decide whether the electric power needs in a large area of the northwest will be met by the Department of the Interior or the private utility.

ROME, Sept. 12 -- Negotiations to end the seamen's strike were begun today by the Minister of Merchant Marine, Giuseppe Saragat, and the Communist Secretary General of the Italian Labor Confederation, Giuseppe di Vittorio.

NEWARK, N. J., Sept. 12 -- The new third-floor fashion center at the L. Bamberger Co. store here, which will be formally opened to the public tomorrow, will enable the customer, if she so desires, to assemble a new costume, complete from head to foot, without leaving the floor.
WARSAW, Sept. 12 -- President Boleslaw Bierut said today that the economies of capitalist countries were "pitilessly caught" in an economic depression that could only grow worse.

MINEOLA, L. I., Sept. 12 -- Opening day ceremonies of the 107th annual Mineola Fair tomorrow will be clouded momentarily as more than 1,000 pigeons are released simultaneously in front of the grandstand at the fair grounds.

READING, Pa., Sept. 12 (AP) -- Arden Homestead Stables' Florican captured his third straight rich Grand Circuit stake today by winning the $11,141 Reading Fair Futurity for 2-year-old trotters at the Reading Fair.

DETROIT, Sept. 12 -- Both sides withheld formal comment tonight in the contract dispute between the Ford Motor Company and the United Automobile Workers, CIO, while their leaders studied the steel "formula" accepted by the United Steelworkers.

Back in 1869 the first American intercollegiate football game was played between Rutgers and Princeton at College Field, New Brunswick, N. J. Yesterday Rutgers University was honored by being chosen as the site of the National Football Hall of Fame.

The Forma Corporation, a realty holding company for the Ruppert interests, has been acquired by the Perma Realty Corporation, headed by Elias A. Cohen, through the purchase of stock. The holding company owns about eleven real estate parcels assessed at a total of $6,500,000, and cash and bonds valued at about $1,250,000.
The city's streets were so quiet yesterday morning you could hear a pencil drop after more than 1,000,000 youngsters trudged off to school to start the fall term.

Communism has "lost ground" in Belgium, one of the first European countries to recover from the immediate effects of World War II, Paul van Zeeland, Belgian Minister of Foreign Affairs, said yesterday upon his arrival from Brussels at the New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens.
Some time ago I read in THE NEW YORK TIMES an editorial which said that extensive highway damage by heavy trucks was "bad news for motorists."

The Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, owner of Stuyvesant Town, has refused to accept the September rent of Jesse Kessler, who allowed a Negro family to use his apartment in the housing project while he was on vacation, it was learned yesterday.

PARIS, Sept. 12 -- Because the Washington communique of the three powers [the United States, Britain and Canada] leaves out reference to specific monetary plans, it is thought tonight that France will make no move on behalf of the convertibility of currencies.

The schedule of college basketball games to be played at Madison Square Garden during the forthcoming season, listing twenty-six double-headers and two single attractions, was announced yesterday. It calls for the campaign, the sixteenth consecutive one at the Eighth Avenue arena, to be launched on Thursday night. Dec. 1.

Senator Tom Connally's statement an reported in THE NEW YORK TIMES on Sept. 8 that "Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek absconded to Formosa with $138,000,000 in gold after deserting the Chinese people" is a serious accusation and should be carefully scrutinized by the American public.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Sept. 12 -- The Roman Catholic Bishops of Czechoslovakia made public today a demand that the Government revoke all forms of persecution of the church, including restrictions on the freedom of Archbishop Josef Beran, as a condition for the resumption of negotiations with the Government.

ATHENS, Sept. 12 -- King Paul warned today that the Greek Army could not be demobilized and returned to the processes of civilian economic recovery unless this country's northern provinces were safeguarded to prevent a recurrence of the insurrection aided from abroad.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -- A $1,314,010,000 program to help arm much of the non-Communist world was approved formally today, 20 to 3, in an atmosphere of restored bipartisanship, by the Senate Foreign Relations and Armed Services committees.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (AP) -- The Federal Circuit Court of Appeals upheld today the Civil Aeronautics Board in granting Braniff Airways the right to operate south of the Panama Canal.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -- The White House, doubtless reflecting the President's attitude, believes that the report of the board which Mr. Truman appointed to evaluate the economic facts in the steel industry justified the procedure he employed and demonstrates the integrity of the board and the President's good faith.

Textron Incorporated and its subsidiaries, sustained a net loss of $3,339,808 in the six months ended on July 2, which contrasted with a profit of $3,805,000 or $3.20 a common share a year earlier, according to the report issued yesterday by Royal Little, president.

Foreign exchange arbitrageurs complain that the basic economic problem symptomed by Britain's dollar shortage is bad enough without it being compounded by the dead hand of language. A current example is "devaluation" of "sterling" -- terms which are used today in much the same way that they were in the days of the gold standard and uncontrolled foreign exchange.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 12 -The United Nations economic survey mission for the Middle East released for the Arab countries today a statement concerning its terms of reference. It said the mission's tasks were as follows:

Marquis Productions, a company of which Jose M. Carles Tolra, Marques of Castelar, is president, has announced plans for two new productions in Mexico next year, one starring Ramon Novarro, the other starring Gilbert Roland.
PITTSBURGH, Sept. 12 -- Following is the text of the telegram sent today by Philip Murray, president of the United Steelworkers of America, CIO, to President Truman:

The super-cautious and alarmist approach Moses A. Monroe evidenced in his letter of Sept. 7, wherein he advised fellow-veterans not to condition their minds to think of themselves as superpatriots, presents an interesting aspect to one in sharp disagreement with him concerning the Peekskill riots.
The Los Angeles Dons have averaged a gain of 414 yards in their first two starts to take the early lead in total offense in the all-America football conference, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -- Fifty Senators have signed or are about to sign a letter to Vinton Freedley, president of the American National Theatre and Academy, which may clear the way for ANTA to lease from the Government Washington's long-closed Belasco Theatre.

Peg Newton, who specializes in clothes for the girl 5 feet 7 inches or more tall, presented her fall fashions at a luncheon showing yesterday at the St. Regis Roof. Styles that glamorize as well as fit the longer torso were modeled for college, business, country and city wear.

A 5 per cent wage increase, a union shop and union hiring hall headed a list of demands by the National Organization of Masters, Mates and Pilots of America as the union opened negotiations yesterday for a new contract with the Committee for the Companies and Agents, Atlantic and Gulf Coasts.

When the Dodgers headed for Cincinnati last night Peewee Reese, captain and shortstop of the contending Brooks, was aboard the train. The mere presence of their key defense-man buoyed the spirit of the Flatbush forces as they departed on this final, make-or-break trip to the hinterlands.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Sept. 12 -- The Army's Continental Air Command reported here this afternoon that its new air-raid detection system had been 100 per cent effective in three days of test. Twenty-five thousand civilian spotters supplemented new radar equipment so effectively that every "enemy" plane was intercepted by Army fighters and Navy jets.

PARIS, Sept. 12 -- Responding to a call from the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization, specialists from seventeen nations met today at UNESCO house in Paris to discuss the formation of an International Association for Political Science.

CHICAGO, Sept. 12 -- Heavy and unwanted rains in the main corn and soy bean-producing areas started short covering in both grains on the Board of Trade today and carried wheat and oats up with them. An early dip on scattered liquidation was quickly recovered.
All was smiles at 90 Church Street yesterday as public relations officers of the Army, Navy, Air Force and Marines spent their first day in the same office with the same telephone number.

Architects' plans for a modernistic eleven-floor aluminum- and-glass-fronted hospital building were accepted yesterday by the planning committee of the New York Infirmary Building Fund at a meeting in its offices at 535 Fifth Avenue.

Mainbocher has turned the trick again. Somehow, while always running true to form he has managed to give a fresh excitement to his fall and winter collection, which was presented yesterday morning in his salon, at 4 East Fifty-seventh Street.

PAWTUCKET, R. I., Sept. 12 (AP) -- Mrs. H. Gordon's Wisenheimer, beaten 17 lengths in his last race after winning a previous start, came back to another victory in the featured sixth at Narragansett Park today, $5,000 claiming event that attracted a field of eight 3-year-olds for a $2,500 purse.
ROME, Sept. 12 (AP) -- Italian customs officials threatened today to eliminate a United States entry in the International Outboard Motor-Boat races opening Saturday at Trieste.

After a two-and-a-half-month American study tour, thirty-seven European students -- twenty-seven boys and ten girls -- departed on the Holland-America liner Volendam yesterday wishing they had had more time to spend in New York and hoping to visit the country again.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Sept. 12 -- The news that Rutgers University's College Field today had been selected as the site of football's Hall of Fame met with unanimous approval from city and college officials.

It's All Over Well, it's over now. The schools have reopened, and that is that. All of the desks in the office are filled up again by lifeless figures gloomily awaiting Saturday noon. That is that. The milkman on his rounds, and the boy who brings the paper, whistle as they regain their old subscribers. Suburban buses are filled, suburban trains are filled, and the stores are filled with those of college years, still growing.

Industrial purchasing policies are being tightened up in the expectation of long-term increases of competitive pricing in sales of materials and equipment, it was disclosed here yesterday in a canvass of purchasing agents.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 12 (Reuters) -- Marshal Tito accused Russia today of trying to maintain Yugoslavia as an agricultural and raw-material-producing country.

ALBANY, Sept. 12 -- The Public Service Commission, resuming hearings on the application of the New York Telephone Company for a permanent 15 per cent rate increase, was told today that expansion of company telephone facilities up-state would require gross expenditures of about $462,000,000 from 1949 to 1951, inclusive.

Demand for boys' and children's wear has picked up sharply since Labor Day, with indications in merchandising quarters that retail trade in these lines will continue good until the end of the year, it was reported here yesterday.

The cost of full-page four-color advertising in Coronet Magazine will be refunded to advertisers who do not obtain more inquiries or direct mail sales per dollar of cost than from similar page ads in Life, Look, Saturday Evening Post or Collier's, it was announced yesterday by David A. Smart, publisher.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -- The Lawyers Title Insurance Corporation, Richmond, Va., filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering 55,000 shares of $10 par value common stock to be offered on a pro rata basis to common stockholders at par.

The first members of the Chilean police team that will compete at the National Horse Show in Madison Square Garden, Nov. 1 to 8, arrived by air from Chile yesterday. They were Capt. Oscar Cristi and Lieut. Cesar Mendoza. They are Carabineros, the military police of Chile, comparable to the Mounties of Canada.

Suspended for nine weeks because of Bobby Clark's illness, Michael Todd's production of "As the Girls Go" reopens for business tonight at the Broadway instead of the Winter Garden, where the William Roos-Jimmy McHugh-Harold Adamson musical was first presented for 279 performances.
In the present controversy over pensions for industrial workers it seems to me that inadequate attention has been given to their possible effect on the mobility of the labor market.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 -- Capt. John Crommelin Jr., Navy pilot, who blasted the Pentagon high command on Saturday for alleged maltreatment of the Navy, was within his "constitutional right" in making his statement, the Under-Secretary of the Navy, Dan A. Kimball, said today.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Sept. 13 -- The Palestine Conciliation Commission's draft recommending the internationalization of the Jerusalem area, including Bethlehem, was received here frigidly. Israel remains adamant in her insistence that Jewish Jerusalem should be part of her sovereign state.

LONDON, Sept. 13 -- Fairly heavy speculative buying of shares of companies producing rubber and tin was seen in the stock markets here today, following news of plans in Washington for expanding United States and Canadian purchases of these commodities.

GENEVA, Sept. 13 -- In the view of competent European observers the most important thing in the communique issued at the end of the tripartite - financial talks in Washington is the statement that "high tariffs are clearly inconsistent with the position of creditor countries."

The transfer of Army-owned sea transport to the Navy as directed by the Secretary of Defense may be more complete than at first indicated, according to an announcement from the Third Naval District yesterday.

BOSTON, Sept. 13 -- The skipper of the thirty - eight - foot cabin cruiser Constance testified today that an attempt to go to the rescue of a small sailing vessel in Nantucket Sound last Friday in a squall led to the tragedy that cost the lives of nine of the eleven persons aboard the cruiser.

Mayor O'Dwyer assured a group of employes of the New York Naval Shipyard in Brooklyn who visited him at City Hall yesterday that he would assist them in their efforts to prevent further lay-offs at the yard.

The Department of Welfare is planning to extend its old-age services to Brooklyn to provide medical, foster and day care facilities for 300,000 persons more than 60 years old, it was learned yesterday.
PITTSBURGH, Sept. 13 (AP) -- Ralph Kiner, Pittsburgh outfielder, tied a major league record of four grand slam home runs in one season tonight as the Pirates beat the Phillies, 11 -- 6.

The Aspinook Corporation, printers, dyer and finisher of fabrics for converters, reported yesterday in its statement covering the six and a half months ended on June 30, a net income of $1,484,347, equal to $1.54 a share on 966,260 common shares outstanding, on net sales of $13,236,595.

Debutantes of this season are serving with Miss Marguerite Stehli in behalf of the dinner dance to be given for the benefit of the Travelers Aid Society of New York at the formal autumn opening on Sept. 22 of the Persian Room of the Plaza.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 13 -- Fifty-five law enforcement officer and traffic specialists are studying the details of traffic control in intensive courses given by the Yale Institute for Traffic Training, a survey disclosed today.

The designation of Cedric V. Kellway, Australian Consul General in New York, who was notified yesterday by his government that he had been named Australia's first Minister to Italy, completes an agreement between the two countries for an exchange of diplomatic representatives.

ATHENS, Sept. 13 (AP) -- Greece plans to tell the United Nations she will invade Albania "in self-defense" if Communist-led guerrillas launch new aggressions from Albanian soil, a high Greek source said today.

Richard Strauss' "Ariadne" will be the first presentation of the New York City Opera Company at the City Center on Sept. 29, it was announced yesterday. The work will be revived after an absence of a year and a half.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 13 -- Mosha Piyade of the Yugoslav Politburo and director of the struggle against the Communist Information Bureau today challenged the Soviet Government to make good its threats, published in Moscow's weekly New Times, to throw the Albanian question into the United Nations for adjudication.

BUFFALO, Sept. 13 -- Acceleration of the lagging construction program for the proposed state East-West Thruway was urged today by the New York State Automobile Dealers for unemployment relief. Reports offered at the closing session of the annual convention of the organization here indicated that only about forty-eight miles of the projected 385-mile route had been built, although the highway is scheduled for completion in 1951.

Ten paintings, four sculptures and drawings and prints by modern Italian artists have been purchased by the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West Fifty-third Street, it was announced yesterday. The collection, part of a large display of twentieth century Italian art that has been on view in the museum for several weeks and that will end its run on Sunday, contains several of the most renowned pictures of the "futurist" movement.

The chief pilot of a Transocean Air Lines plane blamed his navigator yesterday for making it necessary to "ditch" his plane into the sea off Galway, Ireland, last Aug. 15. Seven passengers and a crew member drowned after the crash.

TOKYO, Sept. 13 -- Japanese and foreign observers here today were closely scanning reports from Washington of the forthcoming conference of Foreign Ministers of the big three Western powers. There was considerable expectation that a sharp turn in the policy toward Japan might be finally in the making.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 -- President Truman said today there was nothing that would contribute more to the peace of the world than a stable international economy, and he urged the financial leaders of forty-eight countries assembled here to "do away with obstacles to international trade."

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 13 -- Barak T. Mattingly announced today that he had submitted his resignation as counsel for the Republican National Committee. In a letter to Guy Gabrielson, the national chairman, he said the new party leader should have "a free hand to select your own counsel just as any client would."

From 1941 to V-J Day the New York Chapter of the Red Cross collected 1,250,000 pints of blood from 610,534 donors. No other chapter made such a record, which is said not in disparagement of what was done throughout the country but in praise of Lieut. Col. Earle Boothe, who died yesterday morning and who directed the New York Chapter's campaign and made it a model.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 13 -- Employment of screen writers in Hollywood has increased 10 per cent since the three-year low of 425 writers working Aug. 15, the Screen Writers Guild disclosed today.

CHICAGO, Sept. 13 -- A Senate bill that would subsidize marginal non-ferrous metal mines was endorsed today by the forty-fifth convention of the Mine, Mill and Smelter Workers, CIO. The proposed measure, which, in effect, would prevent loss of jobs held by nearly 20,000 of the union's 110,000 members, is sponsored by Senators Joseph C. O'Mahoney, Democrat, of Wyoming; George W. Malone, Republican, of Nevada, and Carl Hayden and Ernest W. McFarland, Democrats, of Arizona.

CHICAGO, Sept. 13 -- Leaders of the American Legion and Veterans of Foreign Wars joined today in urging their members to ignore the Chicago concerts scheduled for Paul Robeson by the Civil Rights Congress of Illinois, labeled a "subversive" organization by former United States Attorney General Tom C. Clark.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (UP) -- Senator Harry F. Byrd, Democrat, of Virginia, today opposed the appointment of Carl A. Ilgenfritz as chairman of the Munitions Board because he plans to accept a private salary in addition to Government pay.

LONDON, Sept. 13 -- Revaluation of the European currencies including the pound sterling in relation to the dollar is being predicted in informed financial circles here. Some prophets even go so far as to say that the pound, which now is pegged at $4.03, will be devalued to $3.20 and that the announcement will be made by the International Monetary Fund this coming week-end.

Planned inventories for the end of the current fiscal year will be lower than the previous year in about 80 per cent of the smaller department stores in the nation, it was predicted last night. The forecast was made at a dinner of the smaller stores division of the National Retail Dry Goods Association in the Statler Hotel. The declines will be as much as 30 per cent in some cases, it was said.

YONKERS, N. Y., Sept. 13 -- Ms. Edith P. Welty, first woman Mayor of Yonkers, put in a busy first day in office yesterday. It was not so much the Mayor's duties -- as a ten-year member of the City Council Mrs. Welty was thoroughly familiar with the details of the job.

A fashion review ushered in the fall season at Martin's in Brooklyn yesterday afternoon. Every size range and age group from the large matron to the junior miss was represented in smart town and evening costumes.

Newbold Morris, the Republican-Liberal party nominee for Mayor, said yesterday he regarded it as his "duty" to concentrate on local issues in the Mayoralty campaign. He thus appeared to rule out his active participation in the Republican campaign to elect John Foster Dulles as United States Senator, though Mr. Morris is expected to endorse Mr. Dulles on Friday.

New lows for the Long Island racing season went into the records at Aqueduct yesterday. On a gray, windy, rainy afternoon more suitable for movie-going or curling up with a good book, only 11,229 customers checked in at the home base of the Queens County Jockey Club.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 -- Forty-five Hungarians detained at Ellis Island will presumably receive help through a Government order within the next few days, according to strong indications tonight.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 -- President Truman has asked Charles Sawyer, Secretary of Commerce, to survey Federal policies relating to transportation, with a view to unifying them, and to report by Dec. 1.

Shirley May France, 17-year-old unsuccessful English Channel swimmer, returned to the United States yesterday firm in her resolve to conquer the France-to-England swim in another attempt next year. Miss France arrived early yesterday morning at LaGuardia Airport on an American Overseas Airline plane from London.
A taste of chill weather was forecast for the city last night in the wake of a "northeaster" that turned out to be less severe than expected.

Opera has its off-Broadway groups, too. One of the most ambitious of them, the Amato Opera Theatre, last night opened its second year by presenting Verdi's "Aida," the most elaborate of the twelve productions it gave during its first season under Anthony Amato, its founder-conductor.

NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 13 -- An eleven-member committee appointed by the National Recreation Association to recommend personnel standards in recreation leadership and how to apply them has completed its report.

The completion of preliminary plans for the new Supreme Court building in Brooklyn, designed as an integral part of the gradually developing downtown civic center for that borough, was announced yesterday by Frederick H. Zurmuhlen, Commissioner of Public Works.

MORRISTOWN, N. J., Sept. 13 -- Furniture, silverware, rugs, paintings and numerous objets d'art, put up for auction by Princess Doris Farid-es-Sultaneh, who said the articles were valued at $75,000, brought a total of $39,600 at a two-day sale that ended today in her sixteen-room mansion on her estate, Glen Alpine.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 -- Secretary of State Dean Acheson and British Foreign Secretary Ernest Bevin were able to arrive this afternoon, in the first of a series of exploratory talks on the troubled world, at a "community of views" on most of the issues and a "similarity of opinion toward objectives" even when their Governments differed.

The 20-to-3 vote by which the Foreign Military Aid Bill has finally been reported from committee to the Senate seems clearly to foreshadow both strong bipartisan support and prompt action when the measure comes up for debate next week. It is reassuring to note that after all the delays and disagreements the bill has reached the Senate substantially in the form in which it was originally recommended by the Administration.
INWOOD, L. I., Sept. 13 -- Despite rain and heavy winds, fifty players competed today in the Metropolitan Golf Association's one-day handicap tournament at the Inwood Country Club course.

TWENTY-SIX years ago tonight Jack Dempsey knocked out Luis Angel Firpo in what was undoubtedly the most spectacular brawl in the history of pugilism. Three years ago Tony Zale knocked out Rocky Graziano in another epic battle of unbridled ferocity. Neither of those examples necessarily means that tonight's beak-busting party at the Polo Grounds between Graziano and Charlie Fusari belongs in the same general category.

CHICAGO, Sept. 13 -- Judge Michael L. Igoe of the Federal District Court issued an order today restraining the Federal Communications Commission from putting into effect its ban on radio give-away shows until a three-man Federal court could rule on the ban's legality.

Adrian, sometimes called the dramatist of American fashion, brought his fabulous fall and winter collection to New York to coincide with the opening of the new Gunther Jaeckel store, at 10 East Fifty-seventh Street. The press had a preview in the morning, a formal reception for 1,000 guests was held at night.

Unification sank to a new low this week, with the Army and the Air Force squabbling in Germany; with an Air Force officer openly criticizing his former Army superior in Greece, and with naval aviation virtually in open revolt against current defense policies.

The National Broadcasting Company has reached a tentative agreement with the American Broadcasting Company which would allow WJZ-TV, owned by the latter, to place its antenna atop the Empire State Building alongside that of WNBT on a share-the-lease basis, it was learned yesterday.

Decrying the "gloomy boys" who look on present-day Germany with despair, Dr. Hans Simons, dean of the School of Politics of the New School for Social Research, said yesterday that the accomplishments of post-war Germany had been "amazing."

Concededly, it is the prerogative of a newspaper to incorporate into its editorials any matter that in the judgment of its editor is proper. Similarly, it is the prerogative of the reader to subject such editorials to critical review. In this connection, I should like to exercise my prerogative with respect to your editorial "A New Bonus Plan."

" The Peddler and the Lady," an Italian-made feature film starring Anna Magnani and Aldo Fabrizi, has been booked by the Little Cine Met, where it will have its American premiere on Thursday, Sept. 29, it was announced by the management.

ALBANY, Sept. 13 -- Governor Dewey will confer at the capitol tomorrow afternoon with District Attorney George M. Fanelli and Sheriff Fred W. Ruscoe of Westchester County and Superintendent of State Police John A. Gaffney on their reports of the Paul Robeson meeting near Peekskill Sept. 4, and the disorders that followed it.

A Frenchman who knows how to design for American women is Jacques Fath. His second collection created in this country for Joseph Halpert and shown yesterday at Lord Taylor combined a matchless blend of French dash and chic with the wearable simplicity this country loves.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 13 -- King Abdullah of Jordan has a chance of finding himself the principal, or perhaps the sole, Arab beneficiary of United Nations projects for Middle East development and Palestine refugee settlement.

NEWARK, N. J., Sept. 13 -- With the aid of photographs taken from a Coast Guard helicopter, ten agents of the Alcohol Tax Unit of the Treasury Department raided an illicit still this morning in a heavily wooded area a half mile off the main road in Raritan Township. Four men were arrested.

Public Service Commissioner George A. Arkwright, who has heard all kinds of arguments why railroads should increase their passenger rates, smiled yesterday when a Delaware Hudson official said his railroad's revenues had jumped 20 per cent after the PSC granted a 10 per cent interim rise in commutation rates on Feb. 1, 1948.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 13 -- In a joint letter, seventy-five Americans of prominence in widely varied fields today urged President Truman to grant immediate freedom to imprisoned conscientious objectors.

The headline's message had a familiar ring. It said: "High Schools Urged to Teach 'Life Adjustment.'" It seems that Galen Jones, director, division of secondary education of the United States Office of Education, told a group of Wisconsin school authorities the other day that American high schools are failing to "prepare their pupils for life."

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 13 -- Operations of a fleet of ships and barges that has been carrying supplies from West Coast ports to Hawaii during the territorial long-shore strike came under the scrutiny of the Maritime Commission at a "cease and desist" hearing that opened here today.

Directors of Pan American Airways and American Overseas Airlines yesterday revised the agreement entered into last December for the sale of Overseas Airlines' assets to Pan American. The changes involved a six-month extension of the deadline for completion of the transaction and a provision that the ultimate sale be for $17,450,000 and assumption by Pan American of AOA's liabilities, instead of for Pan American common stock.

ARDMORE, Pa., Sept. 13 -- A 15-year-old Los Angeles girl, Miss Marlene Bauer, gained golfing distinction over the rain-soaked Merion Golf Club course today by defeating Mrs. Glenna Collett Vare, six-time titleholder, in the second round of the women's United States championship.

Theatre-On-Tour, the recently organized producing group of Equity players that will take the theatre to small towns with populations of not more than 3,000, will get under way on Sept. 30, when John Patrick's "The Hasty Heart" will be given at the University of Minnesota.

SEOUL, Korea, Sept. 13 -- Unemployment in South Korea during the first half of 1949 is estimated at between 889,169 and 1,500,000, according to a report made public here by the Joint State Department and Economic Cooperation Administration mission

The Frigidaire division of General Motors Corporation cannot meet the demand for home and farm food freezers, C. E. Quigley, special markets department manager of the division, said yesterday. He attributed the short supply situation to underestimation of demand in drawing up production schedules early in the year.

ALBANY, Sept. 13 -- Top Republican leaders, including Governor Dewey and Senator Irving M. Ives, will join Senator John Foster Dulles Thursday night in formally starting the latter's candidacy for the United States Senate.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 -- The tripartite monetary talks are described by one participant as having set a record for frankness and realism. They were more like an exchange of views between the departments of one government than an international conference. Sir Stafford Cripps is said to have been more flexible than he was in discussing the same problems in London in July and Secretary Snyder, as presiding officer, more actively helpful.

Seven hundred persons attended yesterday a "housewarming" ceremony to mark the formal opening of the Federal Building at the New York International Airport at Idlewild, Queens. The structure, the first permanent one at the field, houses offices of the Civil Aeronautics Administration, the Civil Aeronautics Board and the Weather Bureau.

Increased enrollment in nineteen schools of nursing in Manhattan, the Bronx and Richmond and twenty-two in Brooklyn and Queens was reported yesterday. Although the total figures are not complete, most classes for the fall term have been filled.

MARTINSBURG, W. Va., Sept. 13 -- An intensive advertising campaign in fifty-eight cities of the East and Southwest to move maturing apples from the Appalachian belt was started here today under the direction of the Appalachian Apple Service, Inc.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 13 -- Direct negotiations will be renewed tomorrow between representatives of four striking brotherhoods and the Missouri Pacific Railroad in the effort to end the five-day-old strike which has tied up the 7,200-mile rail system, they announced tonight.

Seven Nigerian students who arrived in this country yesterday to attend Lincoln University in Pennsylvania admitted to being "confounded, confused and all mixed up" with New York City. The students were brought here by the African Academy of Arts and Research, 459 West 140th Street, to study medicine, economics and education.

Cornelis Pot, a Dutch engineer whose business is making electric dynamos, is in this country on behalf of his hobby; a system of musical notation that took him twenty years to develop and that breaks with tradition by having its staff lines running vertically instead of horizontally.
