BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 13 -- A highly placed Yugoslav source said tonight the Yugoslav Government was preparing to "unload massive evidence" to expose the forthcoming trial in Budapest of Laszlo Rajk, former Hungarian Minister of Foreign Affairs, and others accused, as one of the worst hoaxes perpetrated by conspirators of the Communist Information Bureau against Yugoslavia.
LAKE SUCCESS, Sept. 13 -- The Soviet Union cast seven vetoes in twenty-four minutes tonight to bar United Nations membership to Portugal, Jordan, Italy, Finland, Ireland, Austria and Ceylon.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was steady yesterday and closed 3 to 14 points net higher than on Monday.

The special committee appointed by Mayor O'Dwyer to hear the views of interested parties on the proposed civil service reclassification and pay study is now preparing its report to the Mayor. Twelve hearings were held and ninety-six witnesses heard. Thousands of words of testimony were taken down in transcript, and on top of this briefs and communications were received.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Sept. 13 -- The International Air Transport Association made serious progress at its meeting today toward adopting American safety practices and devices on lines of the world represented here.
NORFOLK, Va., Sept. 13 -- Secretary Johnson came under direct public fire from a flag-rank naval officer today for the first time in the armed forces controversy.

Supreme Court Justice William C. Hecht Jr. reserved decision yesterday in an action for a temporary injunction brought by tenants of 41 Washington Square South to halt further demolition of the adjacent building at No. 40 to make way for New York University's proposed $3,000,000 law center.

Seven Danish trade union officials, three of them members of the Danish Parliament, arrived at noon yesterday at the New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, to study American industrial techniques and employe-management relations in a four-week tour of plants in this country.

The New Friends of Music will open its fourteenth season of chamber music at Town Hall on Oct. 30. As in the past, there will be sixteen concerts, given in two series, and the complete programs to be performed were announced yesterday.

Sudsless detergents are as efficient in dish-washing as the sudsy type, and sometimes more so, tests by the New York State Agricultural Experiment Station show. Foam is no guide to the cleaning ability of these preparations, as it is with more familiar soaps, according to G. J. Hucker of the station.

The incredible story of the marital and martial mishaps of Pvt. Anthony V. Martino will receive the undivided attention of fourteen officers at a court martial next Tuesday morning, the Army promised yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 -- John L. Lewis threatened today to strike an important sector of the Southern coal fields.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 13 (AP) -- Non-contributory social insurance and pensions for steel workers were termed definitely socialistic today by Hiland G. Batcheller, president of Allegheny Ludlum Steel Corporation.
RENO, Nev., Sept. 13 (AP) -- Mrs. Mary Ellin Burden, daughter of Irving Berlin, the composer, and Airs. Berlin, today divorced Dennis Burden of New York.

YORK, Pa., Sept. 13 -- America has a small combat army today but "it is still the best in quality in the world and the finest in the history of our nation," Gen. Jacob L. Devers, Chief of the Army Field Forces, said in an address here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (AP) -- Randy Gumpert posted his twelfth victory for the White Sox tonight, dealing Washington its fourth straight defeat, 3 -- 2, on seven hits. Dick Weik lost his eleventh successive game for the Senators.

In the most active trading in rubber futures this year on the Commodity Exchange, prices for the natural product advanced 1/2 to 3/4 cent here yesterday. Responsive to higher quotations in London and Singapore, the futures market opened higher and continued upward almost continuously. A total of 2,970 long tons was traded in the course of the day.

BOSTON, Sept. 13 -- Unbeaten in September, winners of eighteen out of twenty and sporting a 10-game string of triumphs, the Tigers moved into Fenway Park today, determined to keep rolling at the expense of the Red Sox. That they would virtually wreck Boston's pennant chances appeared likely, too, when they blasted Jack Kramer for three runs in the opening round.

John J. Broderick, the former Broadway detective who is now seeking a career in politics, walked out of the Midtown Democratic Club with a group of his supporters last night at a meeting at which Gerard V. Murphy was elected unanimously as a sectional Democratic leader in the First Assembly District.
Five members of the American Labor party and one other person were arrested last night on charges of disorderly conduct following an ALP meeting in the Bronx.
JERSEY CITY, N. J., Sept. 13 -- Members of the John R. Longo Association of Hudson County voted 6 to 1 tonight to support Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll for re-election in November.

Formation of a Ladies' Professional Golf Association of America, with Miss Patty Berg as its first president, was announced yesterday by Fred Corcoran, former tournament director of the Men's P. G. A.

With the emphasis in the polio situation shifting from the epidemic aspects of the disease to the phase of after-care, New York public health nurses are tackling the problems of post-polio rehabilitation in the home.

ROME, Sept. 13 -- Italy, which now has 67,000,000 ($270,010,000) of accumulated credits blocked in Britain, was considerably disappointed with the results of the three-cornered United States, British and Canadian financial conference in Washington.

Dr. Vannevar Bush, president of the Carnegie Institution of Washington and wartime head of the Office of Scientific Research and Development, has completed a book on the problems raised by the modern scientific weapons. In "Modern Arms and Free Men" he discusses what the revolutionary change in modern warfare means to the future of war and the future of mankind.

More than $235,000 of the $365,575 estate left by William Floyd, late editor of The Arbitrator, a monthly, eventually will be used for disseminating its ideas which were to outlaw war, abolish poverty, unveil superstition and procure jusitce.

The United States Plywood Corporation had a net profit of $602,900, equal to 39 cents each on 1,428,755 common shares, in the quarter ended on July 31, including its equity in earnings of companies not consolidated, Lawrence Ottinger, president, reported yesterday.

TOPEKA, Kan., Sept. 13 -- Some of the most emotionally disturbed children in the country are being given intensive psychiatric treatment with excellent results at the Southard School, the children's division of the Menninger Foundation.

ALBANY, Sept. 13 -- The Communist party of New York State obtained a court order today temporarily restraining the Board of Regents from further action under the Feinberg Law designed to eliminate from the public school system teachers and others proved guilty of subversive activities.

MINEOLA, L. I., Sept. 14 -- Rain and gusty winds today caused the cancellation of all outdoor events for the opening of the 107th Annual Mineola Fair. However, fair officials estimated that 3,000 persons trudged across the muddy grounds to visit the exhibition buildings and tents.

In Flatbush Magistrate's Court in Brooklyn yesterday Alvin Goldstein's doubts led to a $2 fine for violation of the sanitary code. An ex-GI who lives with his wife at 433 East Forty-eighth Street, Brooklyn, he was accused of dumping household garbage in a street refuse receptacle.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 -- The Department of Agriculture changed today its method of supporting the price of hogs from maintaining weekly support levels at individual markets to maintaining a national support level on a monthly basis.

Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt, holder of 51 per cent of the stock of the Maryland Jockey Club, which operates the Pimlico, Laurel and Timonium race tracks, yesterday confirmed a Baltimore report of the forming of a syndicate to purchase his stock and take over the direction of America's oldest racing association.

The seventh biennial convention of the National Maritime Union, CIO, yesterday moved into its second day in an atmosphere of open hostility between factions. Several sharp verbal exchanges between the platform and the floor occurred.

NEWARK, N. J., Sept. 13 -- A jury in County Court returned today a verdict of guilty of bookmaking, with a recommendation for leniency, but it was of doubtful solace to the defendant, Leo Adessa, 28 years old, who said his predicament resulted from acting as a good samaritan.

Twenty-nine polio cases and no deaths were reported to the city Health Department in the twenty-four hours ended at 9 A. M. yesterday. This compared with the previous day's nineteen cases and four deaths.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 13 -- The Dodgers are not likely to stage two more thrilling last-ditch rallies gain this waning season than they put on tonight under the Crosley Field lights while 12,256 chilled fans sat back and watched in utter disbelief.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (UP) -- Senate Republican leader Kenneth S. Wherry of Nebraska today accused the Administration of by-passing Congress and said the American-British-Canadian dollar talk decisions would cost United States taxpayers at least $175,000,000 a year.

There are signs that the wage-and-cost-of-living spiral may be waning after its hectic post-war existence, but the fifteen-year-long descending spiral of lower yields for fixed-income investors is being resumed at the initiative of the public money managers.

In support of a world-wide campaign to perpetuate the memory and work of Jan Masaryk, the late Foreign Minister of Czechoslovakia, Gen. George C. Marshall, former Secretary of State, has accepted the chairmanship of this country's Masaryk Memorial Fund, it was announced yesterday by the American Association for the United Nations, sponsors for the campaign.

MINEOLA, L. I. Sept. 13 -- Four contracts were awarded here today by Nassau County Executive J. Russel Sprague for work on additions to Meadowbrook Hospital. Mr. Sprague said that the total of $8,756,364 was $880,776 less than the prior bids of $9,637,120, which he rejected last spring because of alleged "discrepancies,"

With the schedule of seventy games listed for each team, the National Hockey League will begin operations Oct. 12 when the Boston Bruins oppose the Detroit Red Wings at Detroit. The slate, which comprises 210 games, is the heaviest in the history of the national loop.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (UP) -- Yugoslavia, cut off from markets in Russia and its "Iron Curtain" satellites, boosted its exports to the United States to a new post-war peak in July, the Bureau of the Census reported today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (UP) -- Maurice Malkin of Brooklyn, N. Y., an avowed former Communist has stated that three Moscow agents are now in the United States directed to reorganize the Communist party of the United States to prevent it from being forced underground.

Rocky Graziano and Charley Fusari will clash tonight in what promises to be the biggest boxing promotion of the New York outdoor season. The East Side middleweight, who once held the championship of his division, will engage the lighter Fusari in a ten-round bout at the Polo Grounds.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Sept. 13 -- Metropolitan Timothy Evangelides has relinquished his appointment as Greek Orthodox Archbishop of New York because of ill health, it was officially announced here today by the Holy Synod of the Ecumenical Patriarchate.

A round-robin letter welcoming a Negro family to Stuyvesant Town and commending lessees who provided apartment space was circulated in the housing project yesterday by the Town and Village Tenants Committee to End Discriminaion there.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Sept. 13 -- Catholic priests will soon be placed under surveillance "by special persons even in the confessional," according to statements made by the secretary of a local Communist party organization in Olomouc, Moravia, Roman Catholic Church sources alleged today.

NUREMBERG, Germany, Sept. 13 (UP) -- The United States Army apologized today to the Air Force, ending a brief dispute that arose between the two branches over Air Force victory claims during current United States maneuvers in Western Germany.

SARANAC INN, N. Y., Sept. 13 (AP) -- Elliott V. Bell, State Superintendent of Banks, said today that large-scale spending for European recovery was contributing toward "a boom." He spoke at the sixty-first annual convention of the New York State Savings and Loan League.

JOHNSTOWN, Pa., Wednesday, Sept. 14 (AP) -- Mrs. Robert L. Coffey, Democrat conceded victory early today to John P. Saylor, Republican, in the special election in the Twenty-sixth Congressional District.

BLAIRSTOWN, N. J., Sept. 13 -- Big Three champion for the past two years, Princeton hopes to make history by extending its suzerainty over Yale and Harvard to a third successive season in the campaign coming up, but Charley Caldwell has his doubts that it can be done.
CHICAGO, Sept. 13 (AP) -- Today's report of the markets in the Union Stock Yards by the United States Department of Agriculture follows:

DETROIT, Sept. 13 -- With each side apparently unwilling to act pending final clarification of the dispute in the steel industry, contract negotiations between the Ford Motor Company and the United Automobile Workers, CIO, were put off today.

The State Committee of the American Labor party decided formally last night to name no candidate for United States Senator or Judge of the Court of Appeals in the November state-wide election. Its action was final and will leave the ALP without a state-wide ticket for the first time since the party was formed, originally by right-wing trade unions, in 1936.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 13 -- The league-leading Cardinals needed only an accidental base hit to beat the Giants tonight at Sportsman's Park, where a crowd of 16,418 saw George Munger spin one of the fanciest games of his career as he blanked Leo Durocher's troupe, 1 to 0, yielding a solitary single.

BONN, Germany, Sept. 12 -- Dr. Theodor Heuss, newly elected first President of the West German Federal Republic, foresaw today the possibility of "progress in peaceful, genuinely democratic German political reconstruction far exceeding that of the short-lived Weimar Republic."

TOKYO. Sept. 13 -- With black market prices falling, Japanese and Occupation authorities are accelerating their plans for removing subsidies for consumer goods. The Government today announced plans for halving food subsidies in the next fiscal year and then abolishing them.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Sept. 13 -- Atlantic City police expressed the belief tonight that arson was the cause of an early morning fire that destroyed half of the "Million Dollar Pier" at the New Jersey resort and caused damage estimated at more than $250,000.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 -- The Senate, in what may be the first move of a session-end speed-up, agreed today to close debate Thursday on the Reciprocal Trade Agreements Bill. As a consequence a sitting scheduled for tonight was canceled and the threat of a Saturday meeting lifted.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (UP) -- Maj. Gen. Herman Feldman said today that he and the Army Quartermaster Corps had "profited fully" from his suspension in connection with the Senate investigation of the capital's "influence industry."

The stock market yesterday confirmed the favorable reaction over the progress of events up to yesterday afternoon in the steel wage situation and the discussions in Washington on international trade problems. An advance of sweeping proportions carried prices through the year's high to the best marks since last November.

HONG KONG, Sept. 13 -- The Central Air Transport Corporation, one of Nationalist China's two airlines, is planning to solve the problem posed by the Communist threat to its present China mainland base at Canton by moving its headquarters to a small island off the Kwangtung coast.

PATERSON, N. J., Sept. 13 -- The Passaic County grand jury, which has been investigating gambling conditions here for several months, today indicted Mayor Michael U. De Vita on a charge of obstruction of justice.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 -- Devaluation of currencies was recommended by the International Monetary Fund today as remedial action for any of its forty-eight member countries that are unable to solve their dollar deficiency problems by other methods.

The time may come when circumstances will dictate the desirability of devaluing the pound sterling, but it is rather jumping to conclusions to assume that a case for such action at this time was made in the annual report of the International Monetary Fund.

As a British business man currently visiting the United States in order principally to promote our exports, I was dismayed at the bitter tone of the letter from George Umpleby in THE TIMES of Sept. 3.
HOBOKEN, N. J., Sept. 13 -- The Stevens Cooperative Playschool, one of the first play groups to include parents, will move into its remodeled apartment this fall, it was announced today.
GENEVA, Sept. 13 -- A draft statute establishing a regime for the exercise of the "full and permanent authority" of the United Nations over Jerusalem was released here today.

The Dutch adage that quarrels between children are better settled without interference from father has been put to good use in achieving Holland's remarkable record for resolving post-war labor disputes, Prof. Barend C. Slotemaker said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 -- The armed services are operating today a communications network -- telephone, telegraph, teletype, radio and every other modern means -- such as would suffice during the first eighteen months of a war, according to preliminary reports reaching the management committee of the Department of Defense.

Hard-hitting selling and advertising drives at this time by American business can shatter one of the main hopes of the Russians for world conquest, Paul G. Hoffman, Economic Cooperation Administrator, said here yesterday.

BONN, Germany, Sept. 13 -- Germany's two top political leaders were hopeful today that the Allied dismantling program might be revised after all. They based their views on talks with John J. McCloy, United States High Commissioner-designate, who disclosed that he had cabled Washington authorities in deference to the German appeal for reconsideration of dismantling.
BUFFALO, Sept. 13 -- Negotiations between the Bell Aircraft Corporation and Local 501, United Automobile Workers, CIO, were resumed here today for the first time in six weeks.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 13 -- The nation's leading motion-picture theatre operators, agitating for abolition of the 20 per cent amusement tax, received scant immediate encouragement today from Secretary of Commerce Charles Sawyer.

A ten-day stay of enforcement of the Feinberg Law for the "elimination of subversive persons from the public school system" was granted yesterday in Albany by a Supreme Court judge acting on petition by the Communist party. This and other proposed court actions will test the constitutionality of the law passed last spring by the New York Legislature.
Scratch a dog fancier, especially a certain breed-of-dog fancier, and you really open the door to trouble, as we have discovered since a recent column written on the Weimeraner.

CAMDEN, N. J., Sept. 13 -- Camden County Prosecutor Mitchell H. Cohen today continued to build the case he will present against Howard B. Unruh, 28-year-old mass murderer, if the war veteran is found sane by psychiatrists now examining him in the New Jersey State Hospital at Trenton.

Despite a heavy rain that drenched speakers and audience, the Board of Education broke ground yesterday for Public School 171, Thirtieth Avenue and Fourteenth Street, Long Island City, Queens. More than 200 persons witnessed the exercises.

The delegates of the American Kennel Club yesterday approved two new and lengthy additions to the rule that bans alterations of a dog's natural appearance for the show ring. The action, taken at the quarterly meeting at the Hotel Commodore, was the culmination of studies a special A. K. C. committee began last March.

PARIS, Sept. 13 (UP) -- Mary Garden, whose soprano voice thrilled the music world a quarter of a century ago, announced today that American opera was on the decline, and that when she goes back there she will try to do something about it.

The 50,000 Christian Arabs living in the ancient town of Bethlehem, scene of the nativity of Jesus, are close to starvation, Yusif el-Bandak, son of Issa Bey el-Bandak, mayor of Bethelehem, said yesterday.

The tangible expression of an artist's philosophic yet adventurous approach to her craft may be studied in an exhibition of textiles by Anni Albers, which opens today at the Museum of Modern Art. Handwoven fabrics by that designer, intended for both household and apparel use, will be in the Northwest Gallery on the first floor through Oct. 30.

PARIS, Sept. 13 -- Official comment here today on the Washington three-power financial accord was guarded, but thinly veiled opinion in informed financial quarters was that the accord offered no solution to the dollar problem and could not save the pound sterling for anything but a breathing space.
CHICAGO, Sept. 13 (AP) -- The retail furniture business has started to boom again, Gen. Lawrence H. Whiting, president of the American Furniture Mart, said today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (UP) -- Senator Guy M. Gillette announced today that the Senate Agriculture subcommittee headed by him would investigate what he called an unreasonable spread between prices received by farmers and those paid by consumers.

ROME, Sept. 13 -- A sharp warning not to try any violence was served upon the Communists today by the official Christian Democratic organ Popolo. The warning attracted particular attention because it is known that it was inspired directly by the Government and, some say, written by Premier Alcide De Gasperi himself.

DETROIT, Sept. 13 -- The Detroit Orchestra, Inc., abandoned plans tonight for a 1949-50 concert season after James C. Petrillo, president of the American Federation of Musicians, refused to intervene in the continuing controversy between the orchestra management and its members.

DETROIT, Wednesday, Sept. 14 -- The voters of the nation's fourth city, in an unprecedented turnout yesterday for a primary election, killed the hopes of Mayor Eugene I. Van Antwerp for a second term by naming Albert E. Cobo, City Treasurer, and George Edwards, President of the Common Council, to fight it out in November for the $25,000-a-year position.
Gen. George C. Marshall visited the Jewish Hospital of Brooklyn yesterday to autograph two murals in the children's wards.

There is reason for mutual congratulations in the outcome of the economic conference between the United States, Great Britain and Canada that has just ended in Washington. The results were expected to confound the early prophecies of doom but that does not make the satisfaction any the less.

CANTON, China, Sept. 13 (AP) -- Gen. Pai Chung-hsi today appealed for United States aid as the storm of a new Communist offensive threatened to break momentarily over his armies defending south China.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 -- The Democratic Senate leaders began today to cut away some of the heavy program that lies ahead for this session of the Eighty-first Congress.

Here's a chowder for the middle of the week, for the lull between last Sunday's joint and next Saturday's bird, that is as easy on the budget as on the cook. It takes only fifteen minutes to make and costs but 15 cents for a generous portion.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 13 -- Fear of a national steel strike developed afresh tonight as industry leaders opposed the recommendation of President Truman's fact-finding board that the steel companies pay the full cost of pension and social insurance benefits for their workers.
The city plans to build a convention hall "where the largest and smallest may be made welcome and comfortable," Mayor O'Dwyer declared yesterday.

John J. Pendergast, Regional Housing Expediter, reported yesterday that 10,825 landlords in the metropolitan area had received rent increases between April 1 and the end of August. In the same period increases were denied to 8,190.

HONG KONG, Sept. 13 -- United States business circles here still interested in attempting to trade with the Communist China of the future are studying for possible backing in Washington a plan under which Economic Cooperation Administration China aid funds still unspent would be used to finance barter commercial dealings in China.

SHANGHAI, Sept. 13 -- The three-month-old labor dispute involving the American - owned Shanghai Evening Post and Mercury, which ran into a hornet's nest of problems when it suspended operations June 14, appeared finally to be settled today.

NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., Sept. 13 -- A charge that Douglas Page-Sharp, third secretary of the Australian mission to the United Nations, drove an automobile at forty-five miles an hour in a twenty-five-mile zone on Main Street here last March 27 was dismissed today by City Judge Thomas N. Fasso when diplomatic immunity was again claimed.

Retail sales of quality occasional and novelty tables have increased sharply in the last several weeks and deliveries are becoming longer, furniture buyers reported yesterday. They said fast-selling items do not arrive for six weeks after orders are placed, in some instances.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 13 -- A new brain operation for "hopeless" patients brought marked relief to more than half of the first thirty-seven persons treated by research workers of Western Reserve University Medical School, it was revealed today in The Journal of Pediatrics.

Reacting even more vigorously than had been anticipated, the pound sterling gained as much as 8 cents in the trading in futures on the foreign exchange market here yesterday. The upswing, which followed on Monday's announcement from Washington of the results of the conference of United States, British and Canadian officials on Britain's economic problems, was sufficient to cancel losses which the pound had experienced in forward quotations since last Aug. 25.

The New York City Housing Authority announced yesterday that it will receive bids until Sept. 20 on $18,615,000 of loan notes for the temporary financing of Lester W. Patterson Houses, a low-rent state-aided project. The notes will be dated Oct. 17, 1949, and will mature on April 17, 1950.
The denching northeaster that lashed this city yesterday caused the deferment to today of the scheduled double-header between the Yankees and the Browns at the Stadium.

CHICAGO, Sept. 13 -- Heavy buying of wheat futures by cash interests which were removing hedges against sales of actual grain to the Government and to commercial users advanced September wheat 21/4 cents a bushel at one time on the Board of Trade today, and that delivery and December sold at the highest prices since January.

Carl Winter testified at the Communist trial yesterday that he still looked up to Premier Joseph Stalin of the Soviet Union as one of the world's greatest teachers of "scientific socialism." United States Attorney John F. X. McGohey brought this out on cross-examination while attacking Winter's testimony that the American Communist party in 1944 and 1945 made a clean break with its prewar teachings.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 -- Eugene R. Black, president of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development, urged today that European countries experiencing economic difficulties should revalue their currencies and cut down governmental costs, including social welfare programs.

The State of Louisiana sold yesterday $3,251,000 of institutional improvement bonds due from Sept. 1, 1952 to 1968, to a banking group headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., at a bid of 100.01 for interest of 5 per cent and 2.30 per cent, a net cost of 2.4366 per cent.

Suspended by Lee Shubert in May because he balked at cooperating with Investigation Commissioner John Mr. Murtagh's theatre ticket inquiry, Jack Pearl, box-office treasurer at the Majestic Theatre, has been officially ousted from that post and will not be re-engaged at any other Shubert house, it was announced yesterday by Mr. Shubert.

A vacant plot 100 by 100 feet adjoining the southeast corner of Central Avenue and Tuckahoe Road, Yonkers, N. Y., was sold for cash by Daniel F. Maguire to the Sylval Holding Corporation for improvement with a taxpayer to contain five stores.
CHICAGO, Sept. 14 -- Trustees of the financially beset Tucker Corporation said today that "reorganization of the Tucker Corporation as an automotive company appears extremely doubtful."

HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Sept. 14 -- Sonja Henie, internationally famous ice-skating star and movie actress, and Winthrop Gardiner Jr., wealthy aviator, obtained a license to marry at the Hempstead Town Hall here this morning. The wedding is expected to take place in New York City tomorrow at a time and place that the couple would not disclose.

Once again the Senate leaders have decided that they do not have time to take a vote in the Senate on repeal of the 63-year-old restrictive and unfair taxes on margarine. In April, 1948, the House passed a repealer by 260 to 106. The Senate Finance Committee reported the bill unanimously, with some minor amendments, but Congress adjourned without Senate action.
Federal Judge Harold R. Medina adjudged a defense lawyer at the Communist trial in contempt of court yesterday and charged another with persistent contemptuous conduct.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- The Republicans asserted today that their party's victory in the Twenty-sixth Pennsylvania Congressional District was an omen of disaster for the Democrats in next year's Congressional elections. In 1950, one-third of the Senate's seats, and all in the House will be at stake.

Reporting on operations of National Bellas Hess, Inc., in the fiscal year ended with last July, George Marks, president, informed shareholders yesterday that despite a nation-wide softening of retail sales, the company had the most successful year in its recent history.

YONKERS, N. Y., Sept. 14 -- Mrs. Edith P. Welty, Yonkers' first woman mayor, already has her plans made for 1950. The term to which she was elected on Monday in a recount of proportional representation ballots cast in 1947, will expire Dec. 31.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 14 -- The nation's petroleum industry was urged today to contribute its best efforts toward reducing the cost of automotive transportation by doing all it can to improve the flow and safety of traffic on highways and city streets.

Four young men living on a pile of rocks in the middle of New York Harbor's lower bay, eleven miles south of Manhattan and two and a half miles off Sandy Hook, N. J., are not so lonely as the average person might think.

ALBANY, Sept. 14 -- Governor Dewey ordered tonight a "complete unlimited and exhaustive" grand jury inquiry into outbreaks of violence near Peekskill on two recent Sundays when Paul Robeson, baritone and left-wing political storm center, appeared there for concerts.

Accusing the leadership of both major parties, national, state and local, of aiding the "profit-hungry real estate crowd" in increasing rents, Representative Vito Marcantonio, American Labor party candidate for Mayor, declared yesterday that he had asked every ALP club in the city to give tenants aid in fighting rent increases.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- Secretary of State Dean Acheson and British Foreign Secretary Ernest Bevin entered the second day of their foreign policy talks today with an hour-long discussion of the seething political situation in the Balkans.

Bent on applying the pressure right up to the hilt in the stretch drive for the American League pennant, the Yankees yesterday advanced two more important strides toward the flag by mowing down the Browns in both ends of a double-header at the Stadium to the delight of a ladies' day crowd of 18,743.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Sept. 14 -- The fight for lower air fares to reach the mass market was stalled here today with the report of the International Air Transport Association's traffic committee, which declared generally that such reduced rates were "uneconomic."

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Sept. 14 -- Tom Robbins of the Winged Foot Golf Club, defending champion, fired a par-equaling 33, 37 -- 70 to lead a field of 121 competitors as the fifteenth annual Westchester Seniors Golf Association championship tournament opened today at Westchester Hills.

The Democratic State leadership last night picked Supreme Court Justice Charles W. Froessel of Queens for nomination for Associate Judge of the Court of Appeals to run against Judge Bruce Bromley, who is now on the bench by appointment of Governor Dewey.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- The struggle over the price of gold took an unexpected turn today when the Union of South Africa wtihdrew its request that the International Monetary Fund permit half of the world's newly mined gold to be sold at the fixed price of $35 an ounce and the other half at a "free-market" price.

With Mayor O'Dwyer turning the first spadeful of earth, the Board of Education broke ground yesterday for a new addition to Public School 16, Wilson Street and Bedford Avenue, in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn. The project, costing $669,884, is the forty-first unit in the board's post-war building program.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- An employe who acts as supervisor part of the work week is to be considered as part of management, the National Labor Relations Board ruled today.

Father Riccardo Lombardi, an Italian Jesuit who is making a speaking tour in this country, has arranged with the Cima Publishing Company to publish his books in the United States. The first, "The Drama of Man's Triumph," will be issued on Dec. 2 and will be followed, six months apart, by "The Marxian Doctrine" and "Salvation of Those Without Faith."

ARDMORE, Pa., Sept. 14 -- The little girl from Los Angeles, 15- year-old Miss Marlene Bauer, continued to be the sensation of the current women's United States golf championship at the Merion Golf Club by gaining the quarter-final round after two victories today.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 14 -- The Cardinals conquered not only the Giants but the elements as well at Sportsman's Park tonight as they maintained their lead of a game and a half over the second-place Dodgers before 10,712 chilled, partly drenched fans.

A technique which will permit advertisers to test the relative sales effectiveness of point-of-purchase advertising displays has been developed by John F. Kurie, vice president of the Association of National Advertisers. It involves continuing checks in two or more comparable retail outlets in which the displays to be tested have been installed.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- John Sherman Cooper, former Republican Senator from Kentucky, who was defeated last November, was nominated by President Truman today to be a member of the United States delegation to the General Assembly of the United Nations.
WEDGEPORT, Nova Scotia, Sept. 14 (AP) -- United States anglers took the lead today in the record-breaking opening session of the sixth annual international tuna tournament.
The American Women's Voluntary Services will not curtail its services to hospitalized and disabled veterans, Mrs. C. Ruxton Love, AWVS national president, declared yesterday.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was quiet most of the session yesterday and closed 6 points higher to 5 points lower.

CHICAGO, Sept. 14 (AP) -- Beef steers reached the highest levels of the year today, but livestock trading in general was thoroughly mixed. Light hogs were 50c to $1 lower. Heavy hogs were but 25c down and sows were steady. Choice steers were 25c to 51.25 higher, but lesser grades closed weak to 50c lower. Today's report of the markets in the Union Stockyards by the United states Department of Agriculture follows:

A concentrated effort by the New York State Food Merchants Association to have wine sales legalized in grocery stores is about to begin, A. F. Guckenberger, executive secretary of the group, announced yesterday. In starting the drive far in advance of the next legislative session, association officials are confident that wine sales will be legalized in January.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 14 -- "Big Country," a feature-length picture consisting of "seven or eight" short photoplays dealing with the idea that American nationality encompasses men of all origins, has been scheduled for production at Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer by Robert Sisk, the studio announced today.

Some twenty-odd years ago Charles Evans Hughes stated his belief that the Supreme Court of the United States "has vindicated the confidence * * * that you can find in imperfect human beings, for the essential administration of justice, a rectitude of purpose, a clarity of vision and a capacity for independence, impartiality and balanced judgment which will render impotent the solicitation of friends, the appeals of erstwhile political associates and the threats of enemies."

The J. Henry Schroder Banking Corporation is about to make its third move to new quarters since it opened here in 1923. Gerald F. Beal, president of the corporation and of the Schroder Trust Company, announced yesterday that the two institutions would move over the week-end and would open for business at 57 Broadway on Monday.

The seven-story building containing thirty-seven apartments and three stores and occupying a plot 75 by 100 feet at 2672 Broadway, southeast corner of West 102d Street, has been sold by the Broadway Corporation to Jacob Glass Son for investment.
It will be a winter for exciting coats, wool costumes and dramatic evening gowns, judging from the fashion show presented by Milgrim during luncheon yesterday at the Hotel St. Regis.

Carl Whitmore, chairman of the board of the New York Telephone Company, was elected president of the Greater New York Fund yesterday, succeeding Henry C. Brunie, who was named chairman of the board of directors of the Fund.
Castillo has entered completely into the spirit of modern times in his fall and winter custom-made collection, created for Elizabeth Arden and presented in her salon yesterday afternoon.

LAKE SUCCESS, Sept. 14 -- Pakistan's chief spokesman at the United Nations today accused India of deliberately blocking agreement on controversies that have divided the two countries since the partition of the Indian subcontinent more than a year ago.

Newbold Morris, Republican-Liberal party nominee for Mayor, charged last night that this city was being run by an "invisible government." Making his second major radio speech, over station WJZ, Mr. Morris declared there were seven bosses of the city -- the five Democratic county chairmen, plus "the two O'Dwyers."

Formation of the Playtex Park Research Institute, which will sponsor a medical research program devoted solely to pediatrics, was announced yesterday at the first meeting of the institute's tentative governing board at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

The Democratic County Committee of New York County re-elected David H. Knott, hotel chain owner, as chairman last night at the organization meeting in the Central Commercial High School, 214 East Forty-second Street. Mr. Knott has held this post in Tammany Hall for thirty years.

GENEVA, Sept. 14 -- The most mysterious point about statements made at the end of the tripartite financial talks in Washington in the opinion of economists here was the assertion of Sir Stafford Cripps, British Chancellor of the Exchequer, that the decisions reached would end Britain's immediate dollar drain.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Sept. 14 -- The press and other criticism here of the recommendation by the United Nations Palestine Conciliation Commission that Jerusalem be internationalized indicates strongly that Israel would resist even to the point of armed force any foreign attempt to sever Jerusalem from the rest of Israel.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 14 -- With their captain and shortstop, Peewee Reese, back in the line-up and Preacher Roe being vulnerable only in the first and final innings, the Dodgers today completed a sweep of the two-game series with the Reds, 4 -- 2.

ESSEX FELLS, N. J., Sept. 14 -- The twenty-eighth annual championships of the New Jersey Senior Golf Association got under way today at the Essex Fells Country Club. Another eighteen-hole round will wind up the tournament tomorrow. Competition was in four age groups.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 14 -- Both film censorship and amusement taxes were attacked today by leaders in the motion-picture industry as unwarranted infringements of free expression.

A "new phase" Father's Day program for 1950, in which participation of some 50,000 retailers and manufacturers will be sought and the promotion budget stepped up to $150,000 from $108,000 this year, was outlined yesterday at a luncheon of co-chairmen of the Father's Day Council at the Statler Hotel.

NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 14 -- Suggestions that school houses and church buildings throughout the country be made available as recreation centers for adults and children were voiced today at the third session of the annual National Recreation Congress.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 14 -- Following is the text of a telegram from Philip Murray, president of the United Steelworkers, to Benjamin F. Fairless, president of United States Steel Corporation, asking an answer on the Presidential Board's peace pattern:

Sales of leading mail order and chain store companies declined 4.5 per cent in August, compared with the same month in 1948, according to a compilation covering forty-two companies made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES.
The Veterans Administration has overpaid $1,500,000 in veterans' benefits to 18,000 New York City ex-servicemen and now the agency wants its money back.

Twelve of the nation's railroads were honored last night for outstanding safety records during 1948 at the thirteenth E. H. Harriman Memorial Awards dinner of the American Museum of Safety at the Ambassador Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- The morale of the Navy is "at its highest," despite delay in pay increases, Francis P. Matthews, Secretary of the Navy, asserted today. His opinion bore directly on current debates arising from statements that Navy morale has suffered because of alleged relegation of the Navy by top defense planners to a minority position in relation to the Air Force and the Army.

We suppose the judicial temperament is fortified by an ardent intellectual curiosity. We are moved to this observation by the strange proceedings in Magistrate Abner Surpless' Flatbush court. An ex-GI, Alvin Goldstein, who lives with his wife in Brooklyn and attends Brooklyn College, was being arraigned on charges of violating the Sanitary Code by dumping household garbage in a street refuse receptacle.

Homemakers who agree with Marcel Breuer in his dissatisfaction with lamps of contemporary design may partly solve their problems by studying the ideas for lighting without lamps that are presented in the newly decorated group of rooms at the Sylvania Lighting Center, 500 Fifth Avenue.

Within the short space of twenty-four minutes at Lake Success on Tuesday evening the Soviet Government cast seven vetoes in the Security Council of the United Nations. This brings to thirty-eight the total number of vetoes exercised by Russia. No other nation except France has ever used the veto power.

In an effort to reduce factory costs, many companies are increasing expenditures on modernization and expansion of plant and equipment, adding to their staffs in order to intensify engineering and research efforts, and adopting other money "outlay" programs. This is revealed in the latest monthly survey on business practices conducted by the National Industrial Conference Board, released yesterday.

PEEKSKILL, N. Y., Sept. 14 -- The drafting of a "Peekskill plan" for communities to follow in handling Communist meetings and propaganda was under consideration here today by city officials and business leaders. A meeting for discussion of the proposal is scheduled for tomorrow at the Chamber of Commerce offices.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Sept. 14 -- Thanks in large part to last year's plebe squad, the strongest and most talented to matriculate at the academy in a long spell, Navy football is on the way up from the nearest thing to a black hole of Calcutta in which any team of modern times has languished.

Adherents and opponents of a general 15 per cent rise in residential rents here and in Nassau and Suffolk Counties presented their arguments from 2 o'clock yesterday afternoon until 12:45 this morning before the New York City Rent Advisory Board at Manhattan Center.

HONOLULU, Sept. 14 (AP) -- Gov. Ingram M. Stainback proposed today that work be resumed immediately on Hawaii's strike-bound docks at a basic longshore wage of $1.54 an hour. The Governor said he also suggested to officials of the striking stevedores of the Congress of Industrial Organizations and the struck dock concerns that negotiations should follow on a new two-year contract to begin April 1.

DETROIT, Sept. 14 -- The Congress of Industrial Organizations suffered a stunning setback in its fourth and most ambitious attempt to elect a Mayor of Detroit. The final tabulations today in yesterday's record-smashing primary revealed a conservative's landslide victory.

Consolidated net income of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation for the first half of this year amountd to $2,413,518, a drop of $2,005,437 from the $4,418,955 reported for the comparable period of last year.

PRETORIA, South Africa, Sept. 14 -- The largest single auction of karakul pelts, better known in America as Persians, was held today at Windhoek, the capital of former German South-West Africa, now integrated in the South African Union. Hitherto Persians have been auctioned in New York and London, but karakul breeders believed better prices might be obtained on the spot.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- A former Communist said today that a direct order from Mrs. Eleanor Roosevelt and former Secretary of State Cordell Hull allowed Mrs. Earl Browder to re-enter the United States despite deportation proceedings.

The Transocean Air Line plane ditched in the sea off the coast of Ireland Aug. 15 overshot that country and was 175 miles out over the Atlantic Ocean at the time it was due to land at Shannon, according to the calculations of the navigator who said he fixed the position by celestial observations an hour and twenty minutes before the crash.

BOSTON, Sept. 14 -- On occasion Ted Williams does hit to left. He did today at Fenway Park, driving a 370-foot homer against the portside screen as the Red Sox kept their flag hopes alive with a 1-0 victory over the Tigers. The wallop, cheered by 13,196 fans, was Williams' thirty-eighth, matching his high of 1946.

LONDON, Sept. 14 -- Prime Minister Clement R. Attlee held a meeting with the Ministers at 10 Downing Street tonight to discuss the implications of the financial talks in Washington. It was not an official Cabinet meeting, but a council of war concerning domestic policy.

The Yankees, Red Sox and Indians, in the American League, and the Cardinals and Dodgers in the National League, yesterday received authority from Baseball Commissioner Albert B. Chandler to print tickets for the world series.

The hearing aid industry has formed an organization, Hearing Foundation, Inc., to carry out educational and ethical projects in the field of hearing, it was announced yesterday by Fred J. Davis, president of the International Hearing Aid Association.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- A funeral service for Associate Justice Wiley Blount Rutledge was held in All Souls Unitarian Church today, with his former colleagues in the Supreme Court acting as honorary pallbearers.

The two stars who will appear in the forthcoming Broadway production of August Strindberg's play, "The Father," are Raymond Massey and Mady Christians, it became known yesterday. The players have reached a verbal agreement with Richard W. Krakeur and Robert L. Joseph, sponsors of the project, and are expected to sign contracts shortly.
Manuel Cabranes, the top official of the Puerto Rican Government in this city, discussed yesterday his proposals for meeting New York's Puerto Rican problem.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 14 -- The United States Steel Corporation rejected the principal recommendations of President Truman's steel fact-finding board tonight. The terms of the rejection were so sweeping as to indicate that nothing short of direct Presidential intervention would vert a national steel strike when the present truce in the industry expires Sept. 25.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- The five-member United States delegation to the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization conference opening in Paris next Monday made a gala departure from Washington airport today, confident that their organization offered the shortest route to peace.
ENGLEWOOD, N. J., Sept. 14 (AP) -- Mrs. Lucille Hubbell, wife of the famous baseball pitcher Carl Hubbell, was in Englewood Hospital today after falling down a flight of stairs.

Rocky Graziano, the "bad boy" of the middleweight division, made his return to home-town competition a successful one last night. He scored a final-round knockout over Charley Fusari of Irvington, N. J., at the Polo Grounds, Referee Ruby Goldstein intervening at 2:04 of the session to rescue Fusari from a barrage of punches.
The most practiced "gray lady" on the roster of the Brooklyn chapter of the American Red Cross is a man.

The World Series will be carried by all television stations within reach of network cable facilities, according to a joint announcement yesterday by A. B. Chandler, Baseball Commissioner; the Gillette Safety Razor Company, sponsor of the telecasts, and the Mutual Broadcasting System.

The 1948 income tax returns of more than 10,000 residents of New York City and Long Island are being scrutinized as part of the first country-wide "spot check" of tax returns ever undertaken by the Treasury Department, it was learned yesterday at district tax collecting offices.

LONDON, Sept. 14 -- Through its Embassy in Athens, the British Government has advised the Greek Government against invading Albania to wipe out the bases of Greek guerrillas who have taken shelter there.

Robert Schuman, French Foreign Minister, arrived here yesterday on the French liner de Grasse, to take part in the opening sessions of the United Nations General Assembly and to discuss with his "colleagues" the political and economic problems facing the world.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Sept. 7, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

BONN, Germany, Sept. 14 -- As expected, Dr. Konrad Adenauer, leader of the Christian Democratic Union and nominal head of a projected right-wing governmental coalition, was formally recommended by President Theodor Heuss today as chancellor of the new Federal Republic of Germany.

Preliminary industry estimates place August factory sales of automatic and conventional standard-size washers at 316,000 units, compared with 199,000 in July, H. P. Nelligan, president of the American Home Laundry Manufacturers Association, said yesterday.

There are so many things to do on Sunday. You can watch the Dodgers at Ebbets Field. You can enjoy a double feature, spend the afternoon in Central Park or help Junior with his homework. But you can't paint a house.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Sept. 14 -- Indonesian representatives at the round-table conference with the Dutch have demanded complete independence from the Netherlands in the field of finance and economic policy. They have presented their views orally to a subcommittee trying to compromise important differences between the two parties, and they will submit them in writing to the subcommittee's next meeting on Friday.

Plans for a shopping center were announced yesterday in connection with the purchase by Hewlett Arcade, Inc., of a plot 240 by 170 feet at the corner of Main Street and Lawson Avenue, in East Rockaway, L. I., through J. H. Kent, Inc., of Woodmere.

Negotiating committees of the United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers, CIO, recommended yesterday that union members employed by the General Electric and Westinghouse Electric Companies consider taking a strike vote.
The death of Justice Rutledge deprives this country of one of its most valuable public servants. I was his law secretary for two years, and I want to give him now the tribute he deserves.

The succession of markdowns in the prices of United States Government securities since last week continued unabated yesterday, depressing the long-term bank-eligible and bank-ineligible issues to price levels removed from recent peak points by from 5/16 to 3/8 point.

Bishop Charles K. Gilbert of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York greeted a group of Anglican bishops at a dinner last night under auspices of the Church Club of New York at the Metropolitan Club, Fifth Avenue and Sixtieth Street.

An impressive exhibition of work by artists who teach -- all of them on the faculty of the Brooklyn Museum Art School -- has opened in the special exhibition galleries of the museum. Nearly 100 entries by forty artists are included, ranging from the powerful paintings by Max Beckmann to delicate fashion drawing by Sylvia Braverman and industrial design by Warren Nardin.

Modification of extreme fashion trends characterized the wearable custom designs shown yesterday by Oldric Royce in his salon at 16 East Fifty-second Street. His suits, many black draped dresses, swishing cocktail and evening gowns, are for sophisticated town living.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 14 (AP) -- Rookie southpaw Bobby Shantz outpitched Bob Feller tonight as the Athletics downed the Indians, 2 -- 1. It marked the first time in the Cleveland right-hander's major league career that he failed to win at least one game in a season from Philadelphia. Feller dropped three decisions to the A's this year.
H. J. Hanbury has been appointed sales manager of Westinghouse photographic lamps and Christmas tree bulbs, effective Oct. 1. He joined the company as a New Jersey lamp sales representative in 1931.

BLUEFIELD, W. Va., Sept. 14 -- Some Southern soft coal operators interpreted John L. Lewis' newest statements today as a threat of a full-fledged strike, but the miners' spokesmen just parried the operators' questions about it.

CHICAGO, Sept. 14 -- The grain markets on the Board of Trade closed irregular today with a marked falling off in activity. There was an absence of the heavy buying of wheat futures by cash interests that featured trading yesterday, although on the break which carried December off around 1 cent a bushel from yesterday's finish there was aggressive bidding by brokers who frequently act for cash interests, and this brought about a fair rally.

Louis Lipsky, chairman of the American Zionist Council, public-relations arm of all Zionist bodies in this country, expressed deep concern yesterday regarding reports that the United States Government "is now pressing for a solution to certain aspects of the problem of the Middle East which we are bound to regard as hostile to the basic interests of Israel."

American foreign trade is declining at an "alarming rate" and this country's merchant marine faces a dubious future as a result, according to Grenville Mellen, vice chairman of the United States Maritime Commission.

The Indiana Harbor Belt Railroad sold yesterday at competitive bidding $2,970,000 of equipment trust certificates maturing annually from Sept. 15 from 1950 to 1964 to a syndicate headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., at an interest cost of about 2.487 per cent.
THE CURRAGH, Ireland, Sept. 14 (AP) -- Brown Rover, American-bred 3-year-old colt owned by William Woodward of New York, won the Irish St. Leger today -- in the stewards' office.

The trend to reintroduce mass violence into the political and economic life of our nation becomes more apparent each day. This ought to be of concern to every reader of THE TIMES. Organized riots, with great frequency, restrict the exercise of free speech; "flying squads" (once called "goons") assault and intimidate both men and women involved in labor disputes, and regular "demonstrations" besmirch the dignity of our courts.
GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 14 -- Skippers from the Indian Harbor Yacht Club today captured the second and third races of their trophy series with sailors representing the Royal Bermuda Yacht Club.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 (AP) -- Bob Kuzava pitched his tenth victory of the season and his fourth at Washington's expense tonight when he limited the Senators to six hits as the White Sox pounded out an 8-1 victory.
Three new directors of Franklin Simon Co., Inc., were elected yesterday at a special meeting of the board, following acquisition last week of Franklin Simon by the City Stores Company.

Original apparel designs will be held inviolate to a much greater extent than at present if garment manufacturers undertake to procure a design patent and make known this fact to retailers, Lawrence C. Kingsland, United States Commissioner of Patents, declared last night.

Albania has been the enfant terrible of the Balkans in more ways than one. Unlike the good child, she is heard and not seen. All frontiers are sealed by "forbidden zones" twelve miles deep, and no Western Powers have diplomatic representation except France and Italy.

ROME, Sept. 14 -- The Italian seamen's strike, which for the last six days has paralyzed almost all of Italy's overseas passenger traffic, entered into a new phase today, when the Minister of the Merchant Marine, Giuseppe Saragat, stated that unless the strike was settled promptly he would take action to protect the ship-owners' rights.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 14 -- The Yugoslav Government tonight officially opened its attack on the forthcoming Budapest trial of Laszlo Rajk and other Hungarian Communist leaders by apparently destroying one whole section of the indictment.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- The United States has exhausted all methods open to it for ending human rights disputes in Bulgaria, Hungary and Rumania and the matter will now go before the General Assembly of the United Nations, it was announced today.

The stock market attempted without success yesterday to further the advance. Traders apparently decided to stand on their previous commitments and, as a result, a smattering of profit-taking brought a mixed close. Although more stocks finished with gains than losses, the price average showed a loss of 0.22 point on the day.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 (AP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission approved today a $49,400,000 refinancing plan for the West Penn Electric Company, New York, to simplify its corporate structure.

The Senate will vote today on a bill that, from a psychological as well as an economic standpoint, is one of the most important facing the Eighty-first Congress. It is the two-year extension of the President's authority to make reciprocal trade agreements. But mere grant of this authority is not sufficient.

Queens civic workers who have been fighting plans of the Bulova Watch Company to erect a factory at Queens and Yellowstone Boulevards, Forest Hills, won a major victory yesterday when the City Planning Commission, meeting at City Hall, rejected two map changes and a rezoning proposal that would have made such a structure possible.

PARIS, Sept. 14 -- In a joint letter to the Catholics of France, the nation's four Cardinals today urged faithful obedience to the July 13 decree of the congregation of the Holy Office "forbidding Catholics from giving their name or lending support to Communist parties."

" Those new English jet and turbo-prop airliners -- astounding." The fellow who tossed off this observation, as he entered our office, was as British looking as if he had just stepped from the show window of one of our best Madison Avenue shops.

Speedy action by immigration authorities followed the introduction of bills yesterday by Senator John Foster Dulles on behalf of the Hungarian political refugees held on Ellis Island for passport and visa investigation.

As the United States Public Health Service reported yesterday that the country-wide polio epidemic was tapering off rapidly, the Sister Elizabeth Kenny Foundation appealed for immediate funds to help rehabilitate paralytic victims of the disease.

Senator Pat McCarran, chairman of the Senate committee that has tied up all moves to liberalize the existing displaced-persons law, sailed for Europe yesterday to study the displaced-persons situation in several countries.
If you have ever tried pushing for railbirds in a driving rain, you will remember it as an experience, but not one you would care to duplicate each time out.
The 36-year-old widow of a slain man won yesterday for her husband's assailant permission to enter a plea of guilty to second-degree murder on an indictment charging murder in the first degree.

An underwriting syndicate headed by White, Weld Co. and the William R. Staats Company has underwritten the offering today of 134,350 shares of common stock of the Van Camp Sea Food Company, Inc., at $11 a share. The company processes and cans seafood.

Department store stocks on hand in the Second Federal Reserve district at the close of business July 31 were 12 per cent below the corresponding date in 1948, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York disclosed yesterday. One of the largest single declines was seen in mattresses, springs and studio beds which were down 24 per cent.

A modern architect and three lamp manufacturers debated yesterday the subjects of contemporary design and architecture in general and portable lamps in particular at a luncheon meeting of the Home Fashions League yesterday in the Roosevelt Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- The Lehigh Valley Railroad Company today asked the Interstate Commerce Commission to approve merger of eleven of its subsidiary companies for direct ownership in the interests of corporate simplification and economy.

Four organizations of importance in educational and civic affairs announced last night that they would not offer arguments at today's Board of Education hearing on procedures to implement the Feinberg Law, even though they are opposed to the teacher loyalty tests.

A comparative research study by the National Federation of American Shipping released yesterday shows the United States privately owned merchant fleet to be composed of newer but on the average smaller units than those of Great Britain.

A wealth of attractive suggestions for fall and winter wardrobes, well selected for fashion importance and diversified to please a variety of tastes, were contained in the showing of Green Room fashions yesterday at Bloomingdale's.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 14 -- The Kingdom of Jordan is pressing steadily ahead with what now seems to be a program to use all the funds that the United Nations is willing to provide for Arab-refugee resettlement and economic development to create the foundations for a Jordanian nation on both sides of the River Jordan.

MOSCOW, Sept. 14 -- Unusual interest was aroused in Moscow among foreign diplomats by the decision of Soviet Foreign Minister Andrei Y. Vishinsky to head the Soviet delegation to the United Nations Assembly session opening at Lake Success Tuesday.

The National Maritime Union's convention, now being held in the St. Nicholas Arena, 69 West Sixty-sixth Street, yesterday elected its second committee and slowly ground its way toward the selection of eight convention committees.

TOKYO, Sept. 14 -- Preliminary steps looking to eventual repayment of the Japanese foreign currency obligations will be taken by the Conservative Government at the forthcoming session of the Diet. This, it is stated, will be the initial move toward implementation of the statement of Premier Shigeru Yoshida on Sept. 3 that Japan must "maintain" her old reputation abroad as a nation that never defaulted on its foreign loans.

CANTON, China, Sept. 14 (UP) -- Angry mobs today hunted outlawed "conscription agents" for China's war lords through the streets of Canton. Two men were kicked, clubbed and beaten near death before police gained control of the situation.

LONDON, Sept. 14 -- The statement yesterday of Eugene R. Black, president of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development, on currency revaluation, encouraged gold share speculators in the stock market here today. Both Cape and London bulls took it as a hint to buy once again and prices rose as much as an eighth.

The platforms at thirty-two local stations of the IRT subway division in Manhattan, the Bronx and Queens have been lengthened to accommodate ten-car trains at a total cost of $13,327,000, William Reid, chairman of the Board of Transportation, announced yesterday.

Prices of rubber futures declined in trading on the Commodity Exchange yesterday, the market closing 32 to 48 points net lower on the day. Trading for the day totaled 1,250 long tons, against the year's record of 2,970 tons set on Tuesday. The September delivery showed relative strength, while distant deliveries led the decline.

RAY NOLTING used to do considerable jolting for the Chicago Bears during his playing days and was as solidly consistent a halfback as the Monsters of the Midway ever had. But now he is serving as backfield coach for the New York Bulldogs, the third professional entry into the already-crowded metropolitan gridiron scene.

A further decline last week of 459,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end they amounted to 104,375,000 barrels, compared with 104,834,000 a week earlier and 93,534,000 on Sept. 11, 1948.

CHICAGO, Sept. 14 (AP) -- The Cubs outlasted the Braves, 8 to 7, today before 2,672 paid -- smallest Wrigley Field crowd of the season. It closed the season series between the clubs with the Braves holding a 12-10 margin.

" Stampede," which arrives at the Palace, is this morning's lone film newcomer. The Western features Rod Cameron, Gale Storm, Don Castle and John Eldredge. Lesley Selander directed and John C. Champion and Blake Edwards produced and wrote the screen play of the Allied Artists production.

WASHINGTON, Sept 14 -- The tripartite "working groups" that were established under the agreement of the British, Canadian and United States Governments on preliminary measures for the relief of the sterling area have a much larger significance than the obvious one.
Godfrey Macdonald, vice president of the Grace Line, yesterday urged export advertisers to step up efforts to increase tourist travel to South America.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 Maurice J. Tobin, Secretary of Labor, today told the Federal Advisory Council on Employment Security that unemployment insurance had kept purchasing power at even keel in New England, "hardest hit" by unemployment.
NUREMBERG, Germany, Sept. 14 (UP) -- The United States Military Command in Germany announced tonight that a permanent Army, Navy and Air Force combined staff might be organized here.

ALBANY, Sept. 14 -- The board of trustees of the State University approved today 1949-50 budgets for the Long Island College of Medicine and the College of Medicine at Syracuse University involving interim state grants-in-aid totaling $1,090,000 by June 30, 1950.

The running battle over the statues of General Simon Bolivar and General Jose de San Martin, the South American liberators, brought yesterday an exchange of verbal cannonading between Park Commissioner Robert Moses and Oren Root, Republican candidate for Manhattan Borough President.

BARKSDALE FIELD, La., Sept. 14 -- Because of the precise instrument training being given to flying instructors in the Air Force, the United States is now ready to carry on air assaults on an all-weather basis. Future potential enemies will no longer be able to take advantage of grounded Allied planes as they did during the Battle of the Bulge in World War II.
The Lemonade Opera wlil continue its run of "The Stranger" and "Down in the Valley" in the Greenwich Mews Playhouse tonight at 8:30 o'clock.
A 12-year-old girl was killed and two other children were injured in two separate auto accidents in Astoria, Queens, yesterday.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 14 -- Optimism prevailed tonight that an end to the strike of 5,200 trainmen against the Missouri Pacific Railroad was in sight after the company renewed a proposal regarding union claims. It included disposal of fifty-nine of them.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- Senate Democrats evidenced some uncertainty today over their prospects of defeating the Millikin "peril point" amendment in tomorrow's showdown on the Reciprocal Trade Agreements Bill. This was a change from an attitude of confidence.
ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 14 -- New Jersey movie-goers soon may be able to see championship prize fights, other sporting contests and special events televised in their favorite neighborhood theatre.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- Maj. Gen. Anthony C. McAuliffe, the hero who had a word for the Germans at Bastogne, was nominated by President Truman today to be Chief of the Army's Chemical Corps. He would replace Maj. Gen. Alden H. Waitt, who retired recently after being involved in the Senate inquiry into "five percenters."

The fact that paintings not specifically planned as decorations for dinnerware may nevertheless be effectively applied to china plates becomes apparent in the current exhibition of Castleton china, which will be at the Associated American Artists Galleries, 711 Fifth Avenue, through Sept. 23.

Several million veterans who still have "credit" due them under the GI Bill may be unable to use their educational privileges, it was learned yesterday. Beginning Nov. 1, all veterans who apply for school or college work or who want to change their courses of studies must get a new certificate of eligibility from the Veterans Administration.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- John L. Lewis charged today that failure of Southern coal operators to continue payments into the Miners' Welfare Fund "may precipitate a convulsion in the mining areas of this country."

CHICAGO, Sept. 14 -- In a surprise meeting tonight, representatives of Chicago Typographical Union, Local 16, and the Chicago Newspaper Publishers Association agreed on a proposal to settle the twenty - two - month - old strike against Chicago's five major daily newspapers -- The Herald-American, The Daily News, The Journal of Commerce, The Sun-Times and The Tribune.

If any statesman in Europe needs all the good luck that can be wished upon him, it is Dr. Konrad Adenauer, who yesterday was formally nominated as Chancellor, or Prime Minister, of the new Western German Republic. It should be a sweet irony for him to be the successor in that title to Adolf Hitler, because he hated the Fuehrer and all that nazism stood for.
SARANAC INN, N. Y., Sept. (AP) -- Donald H. Davenport, Deputy State Commissioner of Commerce, said today there was a "good possibility" of an upswing soon in business activity in New York State.

New York taxicab' owners presented oral arguments yesterday challenging the jurisdiction of the State Labor Relations Board over charges of unfair labor practices and petitions for bargaining elections filed by District 50 of the United Mine Workers.

The issue between the Navy and the Air Force, which has now reached a new peak of bitterness, is not air power but what kind of air power, its control, its employment and its integration with surface forces.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 14 (AP) -- Home run-hungry Pittsburgh fans had baseball indigestion today. They saw red-hot Pirate Ralph Kiner hit his forty-ninth round-tripper of the season, but they also saw homers by Philadelphia's Granville Hamner, Mike Goliat and Ed Sanicki as the Phillies won, 12 -- 4, with fourteen hits against three pitchers.

A vacant irregular plot of land, about 123 by 266 feet, at the northwest corner of Walton Avenue and East 151st Street, the Bronx, has been purchased by the Lakeport Construction Corporation from Claire Freidus and Becky Aaron.

LONDON, Sept. 14 -- Diplomatic officials in London indicated today that, after several unsuccessful attempts, prospects had improved for settling the future of the former Italian colonies in Africa. The issue will arise again at the coming session of the United Nations General Assembly.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 14 -- Union officers at the Sun Shipbuilding Drydock Corporation in near-by Chester said today that the shipyard local, representing more than 4,000 employes, would switch from a Congress of Industrial Organizations union to a rival American Federation of Labor group.

The largest wave of inventory replacement orders in two years is now well under way among industrial supply and machinery distributors throughout the country, it was revealed here yesterday during a canvass of large companies. Among others, Arthur Yorke, president of Hansen Yorke Company, Inc., 90 Warren Street, stated that some standard products which have not been ordered in quantity for about two years have now been placed on order.

INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 14 (AP) -- The Indianapolis. Star said tonight in a dispatch from its Washington bureau that Judge Sherman Minton of Indiana was scheduled to be appointed to the United States Supreme Court tomorrow. At Washington, White House sources said in answer to a query that they knew nothing of the report.

Mingling French adaptations with American designs, Arnold Constable brought together styles for the matron and young fry as well as misses' fashions in a comprehensive fall showing yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

Christopher T. Chenery's Hill Prince, a bobtailed colt bred in old Virginia, hustled around Aqueduct's sloppy racing strip yesterday to a new track record for six and a half furlongs. The occasion was the twenty-seventh Cowdin Stakes for 2-year-olds, and Hill Prince took first money of $15,850 with two and a half lengths to spare.

The Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo comes to the Metropolitan Opera House for two weeks tomorrow. It arrived for food writers a bit in advance. Four members of the troupe met the palate press the other evening at the Russian Tea Room to discuss two Russian arts -- dancing and dining.

In what promises to be one of the most thrilling finals in the history of the tournament, Laddie Sanford's Hurricanes, a 28-goal side, will face the 28-goal El Trebol four in the last round of the thirty-third national open polo championship on International Field of the Meadow Brook Club, Westbury, L. I., Sunday.

BONN, Germany, Sept. 14 -- Charles H. Collison, former deputy chief of the United States Military Government decartelization branch, was recommended for reinstatement by a grievance committee that heard his complaint against his dismissal as a surplus employe, but he was released nevertheless by High Commissioner-designate John J. McCloy.
The Soviet Government dropped Earl Browder, former chief of American communism, from its payroll at the end of July, it was discovered yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- The Administration's principal foreign policy spokesman in Congress, Senator Tom Connally, Democrat, of Texas, declared today that the United States and Britain by the closest comradeship could save the world from "evil forces."

Jurisdiction of the New York Police Department to enforce low-flying regulations was challenged yesterday at the hearing of Capt. George R. Newhouser, who received a "tag" on July 24 at La Guardia Airport for allegedly landing his plane in violation of the established traffic pattern.

Mrs. Isabel Dodge Sloane arrived late and left early, but had a thoroughly enjoyable time at Aqueduct yesterday. Her Brookmeade Stable had a two-for-two afternoon. Sunny Vale, on the main track, and His Boots, in the infield, were the winners.

Some of the public works projects included in the city's current capital budget cannot be carried forward in 1950 unless the proposed $150,000,000 constitutional amendment for the benefit of new hospital construction is approved in the statewide referendum on Nov. 8, Mayor O'Dwyer declared yesterday.

WESTBURY, L. I., Sept. 15 -- Chris Spencer, owned by the Dunbar Bostwick Farm of Shelbourne, Vt., was a surprise winner of the fourth annual $25,000 invitation American trotting championship at Roosevelt Raceway tonight. A crowd of 17,062 was present.

Your editorial in the Sept. 10 issue entitled "The Navy in Spain" arouses my protest, because what you say is designed to foster and maintain public enmity against a friendly country at a time when we need all the friends we can find.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- The United States, Britain and France issued a new call to the Soviet Union today for another meeting on the troublesome Austrian peace treaty.

The owners of tugboats in New York Harbor have won their argument with the city as to the type of bridge to be built from Queens to Welfare Island, and as a result the span will cost the city $1,869,000 more than was originally estimated, it was learned yesterday.

Here from London with the aspiration of eventually becoming a stage director is Phillipa Hastings, youngest daughter of Sir Patrick Hastings, noted British barrister. Sir Patrick also leans toward the stage, occasionally dabbling in playwriting, which may or may not account for his daughter's interest. Phillipa has no hankering to become an actress, though. She said so yesterday.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Sept. 15 -- The defending champion, Tom Robbins of Winged Foot, scored 38, 33 -- 71 today to add to his 70 of yesterday to win his second straight crown in the Westchester Senior Golf Association tournament at the Westchester Hills Country Club. Robbins' 141 total established a new mark in the 36-hole event.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 15 -- Benjamin F. Fairless, president of the United States Steel Corporation, and Philip Murray, president of the United Steelworkers of America, CIO, accused one another of dictatorial conduct today. Each declared the other would be responsible if a strike occurred in the steel industry when the truce expirec Sept. 25.

The outlook for peace in the steel industry, which seemed so bight at the beginning of the week, has suddenly been clouded over by the pension issue. Philip Murray, president of the United Steel Workers, has announced that the union is prepared to negotiate only after the companies have accepted the recommendations of the President's fact-finding board.

Acting on the complaints of various educators, the Veterans Administration in Washington is reviewing the decision of the New York Regional office that the Dramatic Workshop is not "eligible" for veterans.
The city of Philadelphia, Pa., announced yesterday that bids will be received until Oct. 3 for an issue of $5,000,000 of School District bonds dated Oct. 1, 1949 and due from Oct. 1, 1951 to 1974.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (UP) -- Larry E. Kerley, a former Federal Bureau of Investigation agent who now is employed by the editorial department of The New York Journal-American, told Senate investigators today that the State Department had intervened during the war to prevent the arrest of Russian spies operating in this country.
