WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (AP) -Representatives of the automobile industry today voiced outspoken opposition to Government proposals of a nation-wide code to protect car buyers from hidden-price gougers.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 15 -- Referring to Soviet Russia as "the only possible enemy we have in the world," Secretary of Defense Louis Johnson today made a special plea for funds to house United States armed forces in Alaska.

GANTON, England, Sept. 15 (UP) -- Ben Hogan, non-playing captain of the United States Ryder Cup golf team, precipitated a controversy on the eve of the international matches tonight by objecting to a number of the clubs used by the British players.

ATHENS, Sept. 15 -- Considerable diplomatic activity involving the future of the entire Balkan peninsula has been quietly going on in the capitals of both Eastern Europe and the Western world in preparation for the forthcoming session of the United Nations General Assembly.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -France and other participants in the European Recovery Program were assured today of the same arrangements, where applicable, that were extended to Britain and Canada in the tripartite ministers conference on the sterling-dollar crisis.

I was quite surprised to discover, in a Prague dispatch published in THE TIMES on Sept. 3, that I was the "leader" of a "minority group" within the American delegation at the recent Budapest World Youth Festival.

ALEXANDRIA BAY, N. Y., Sept. 15 -- Double parking and "quickie" pauses by motorists for shopping purposes are among the principal factors responsible for New York City's traffic congestion and perils, the New York State Automobile Association was told today.

Eugene Dennis, general secretary of the Communist party in the United States, served notice by implication last night that if the Federal Court verdict goes against him and his ten co-defendants in the conspiracy trial now drawing to a close here, the Communist party will go underground.

A hearing yesterday by the Board of Education brought denunciation of the Feinberg law, which requires teacher loyalty tests throughout this state, from a majority of the teacher and public representatives who spoke, and from one of the board members, Charles J. Bensley of the Bronx.
CRESTWOOD, N. Y., Sept. 15 -Mrs. George J. Brady of Scarsdale recorded her first victory of the season in women's Westchester-Fairfield one-day competition today by carding 42, 41 -- 83 at Leewood.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- Fees paid by nonunion members to support the cost of collective bargaining by a union are illegal, according to a ruling today by a trial examiner of the National Labor Relations Board.

ALBANY Sept. 15 -- Nominated unanimously for the United States Senate at a Republican State Committee meeting here this afternoon, John Foster Dulles opened his campaign tonight with a sharp attack on President Truman's domestic program.

OTTAWA, Sept. 15 -- Canada's twenty-first Parliament opened today and as if to mark this coming of age the government announced that it intended to seek the removal of the last symbols of British tutelage and that this was being done in agreement with Britain.

Postoffice representatives yesterday assured the Sister Elizabeth Kenny Foundation, Inc. that steps would be taken to assure that contributions made through the mails to that organization were not mixed up with contributions for the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis, Inc. Both groups are conducting fund-raising campaigns.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- During the week ended Sept. 14 member bank reserve balances increased $327,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board announced today.

HONG KONG, Sept. 15 -- Controls and restrictions imposed by the Communists have caused a crisis in the affairs of the Kailan Mining Administration, Chinese-British operators of the Kailan coal mines. Situated north of Tientsin, the mines have been the largest coal producers in China for decades and a mainstay of the country's economy.
LAKE SUCCESS, Sept. 15 -- Five countries in the Soviet political sphere were turned down again today for membership in the United Nations.

Supreme Court Justice Ferdinand Pecora, 67-year-old jurist completing a fourteen-year term on the bench, was renominated last night by the Democratic judicial district convention of the First Judicial District, which includes Manhattan and the Bronx, at a meeting at Haaren High School, Fifty-ninth Street and Tenth Avenue.

The Cigar Institute of America will expand its field and step up its activities with the inauguration of a pilot or test paid advertising campaign for 1950, it was announced yesterday by Howard S. Cullman, president. The initial campaign costing $70,000 for 1950 will serve as a pattern for the expansion of future advertising activities of the institute.

Emphasizing the importance of residential and commercial customers on the books of a utility, the California Electric Power Company is serving fewer industrial customers, who have been replaced by more domestic and small business customers.
HONG KONG, Sept. 15 -- The Nationalist Navy received orders to "tighten" its blockade of Communist-held ports in China following a Cabinet meeting in Canton today.

The directors of the Alleghany Corporation, at a meeting held here yesterday, voted to give the company's prior preferred and series A preferred stockholders the right to exchange part of their holdings for certain dividend-paying stocks now in the company's portfolio.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- The Southern states probably have done more planning for development of resources and industry than any other section of the country, the National Planning Association stated here today. The work of the Tennessee Valley Authority was included in this Southern planning.

ARDMORE, Pa., Sept. 15 -- Continuing to play impressively, fifteen-year-old Miss Marlene Bauer of Los Angeles gained the semifinal round of the United States women's championship at the Merion Golf Club today by turning back Miss Betty Mackinnon of Texarkana, Ark., 4 and 2.

One of the most significant steps in the care and treatment of the mentally ill in hospitals is being taken with the establishment of a training school for psychiatric aides in Topeka, Kan. This is a pilot project to provide training for the ward attendants who give the major part of patient care in the mental hospitals of the nation.

Opening ceremonies of the United Nations General Assembly at Flushing Meadows will be televised by the Columbia Broadcasting System on Tuesday in two separate programs covering a period of four hours and fifteen minutes.

Throwing sharp emphasis on the magnitude of the construction program going on throughout the Bell System -- which comprises the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and its twenty-eight subsidiaries -- an executive of the Western Electric Company disclosed yesterday that this manufacturing subsidiary of A. T. T. would show a drop of about $250,000,000 in business for 1949.
The "Battle of the Statues" being waged between Park Commissioner Robert Moses and Oren Root, Republican candidate for Manhattan Borough President, continued hot and heavy yesterday.

The Communist party, in its first formal statement on the city and state campaigns, announced yesterday that its prime objective was the re-election of Benjamin J. Davis, one of the eleven defendants in the Communist conspiracy trial in Federal Court, to the City Council.

For the second time this week a new high in daily volume of trading in rubber futures was recorded on the Commodity Exchange here since the No. 1 contract of the Exchange was introduced almost a year ago. The turnover for the day was 3,590 long tons.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- Getting up state and local "maximum employment committees" in areas of heavy unemployment was urged in one of a series of resolutions to strengthen the national employment system adopted today by the Federal Advisory Council to the Bureau of Employment Security.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- The Senate passed the Administration's Reciprocal Trade Agreements bill without change today by a bipartisan vote of 62 to 19.

ROCKY GRAZIANO, who fights with all the skill, polish and class of a Golden Glover, subnovice division, batted out a tenth-inning home run at the Polo Grounds the other night to beat Charley Fusari. Prior to that he was wilder than Tommy Byrne on a bad day. But once again the Rock proved that he is the most exciting ringman of this generation as he inexorably follows a script in which the suspense motive predominates.

CHICAGO, Sept. 15 -- The terms of the contract made last night between the Chicago Typographical Union, Local 16 and the Chicago Newspaper Publishers Association for ending the twenty-two-month strike against this city's five major dailies conform with the provisions of the Taft-Harley Act, the publishers said today.

GENEVA, Sept. 15 -- The much publicized Polish - Czechoslovak project for producing a binational economic plan for the integrated development of the two economies has virtually broken down, according to exceptionally well-informed sources here.

The flow of investment into Israel is being speeded by the economic policy of the Israeli Government particularly with respect to low land taxes and import duties, it was reported here yesterday by Abraham Dickenstein, managing director of the American Palestine Trading Corporation, who has just returned from a two months' survey in Palestine.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- President Truman announced today that he had chosen as the ninth Justice of the Supreme Court Judge Sherman Minton, a Democrat, of Indiana. Mr. Truman and Mr. Minton entered the Senate at the same time, Jan. 3, 1935, and they remain close friends.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 15 -- The Graphic Arts Research Foundation came into being today with the unveiling of a photographic type-composing machine that Dr. Vannevar Bush, a member of the technical advisory board, said would make "present methods of printing obsolete."

Representative Judd of Minnesota introduced a bill in the House of Representatives several months ago asking to appropriate a certain amount of ECA funds to help the Chinese students here who are in need of money to continue their studies. Many prominent personages, like Gen. Eisenhower, expressed their support of this bill.
Acquisition of one of the new washing machines may solve many problems for the housewife but she needs a certain amount of "education" in using it.
Lou Boudreau's fading world champions apparently are still breathing defiance and yesterday they exhaled so much of it they practically blew the Bombers right off the course.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- John L. Lewis fired another blast at the Cleveland Trust Company today in an effort to compel payments by a large West Virginia coal producer into the miners' welfare fund.

The four tracks of the New York Central Railroad's main line were tied up for more than two hours yesterday afternoon after two empty freight cars jumped the rails in the Kingsbridge Yards, between the Marble Hill and Spuyten Duyvil stations.

In your editorial of Sept. 14 "Report to the Senate" you reiterate your conviction that the Military Aid Bill "has reached the Senate substantially in the form in which it was originally recommended by the Administration." That statement is gravely in error. Section 3 of the original bill gave the President extraordinary, ill-defined and indefensible powers to function as a war lord all over the world.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- Department store sales in the week ended Sept. 10 were 4 per cent lower than sales in the corresponding week last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. The following lists percentage changes from like periods of 1948:

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 15 -- Four striking brotherhoods rejected today another company proposal to settle the week-old walkout which has tied up the 7,200-mile Missouri Pacific Railroad and submitted a counter-proposal for the disposition of eighty-two of the 282 claims which precipitated the strike.

Tenants of 41 Washington Square South lost another legal skirmish yesterday in their battle to halt further demolition of the building at No. 40 when Supreme Court Justice William C. Hecht Jr. denied their motion for a temporary injunction. The buildings are being razed to make way for New York University's $3,000,000 law center.

In an attempt to allay Roman Catholic resentment arising over the controversy on Federal aid to parochial schools former Gov. Herbert H. Lehman, Democratic-Liberal candidate for United States Senator, said yesterday that he favored such aid by allocation of funds to parochial and other private schools for auxiliary services, such as transportation, health and welfare aid, in states whose Constitutions or statutes permit it.

Endorsing the Fair Deal of President Truman, the Democratic State Committee at a meeting in the Music Room of the Biltmore Hotel yesterday nominated former Gov. Herbert H. Lehman for United States Senator for election to the seat vacated by Robert F. Wagner. Supreme Court Justice Charles W. Froessel of Queens was designated for Associate Judge of the Court of Appeals to fill the elective vacancy caused by the resignation of Thomas D. Thacher.

Preliminary registration estimates indicate that there will be approximately 26,500 undergraduate students in the day sessions of the four city colleges for the fall semester, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Ordway Tead, chairman of the Board of Higher Education.
The Union Tank Car Company and its wholly owned subsidiaries reported yesterday for the six months ended on June 30, a net income of $1,508,263 after taxes and all charges.

LONDON, Sept. 15 -- Britain, the United States and Canada are undertaking immediately a factual survey of the world oil situation with a view to reducing the deficit that sterling now incurs by buying petroleum from dollar sources.

The Foreign Ministers of Norway and Denmark arrived by air yesterday from Copenhagen to attend Atlantic Pact conferences tomorrow in Washington. They will also attend the opening sessions of the United Nations General Assembly at Flushing Meadow next week.

A platoon system for coaches, an inevitable development of the widely spreading two-unit style of football, has been inaugurated at Columbia by Lou Little, who recently added two new members to his staff.
Harassed citizens seeking civic improvements were advised yesterday to present a bold, diplomatic front to public officials before quitting City Hall with an air of resignation.

By dusk last night there was no longer a St. Nicholas Church at Fifth Avenue and Forty-eighth Street. The last of a house of worship had been carted away and while outwardly there was the same edifice that had graced the Avenue for seventy-seven years it had become a routine wrecker's job.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Sept. 15 -- The proposed Westchester County grand jury investigation of violence at recent meetings near Peekskill of left-wing followers of Paul Robeson will begin in early October and continue for many weeks, officials indicated this evening.
After a somnolent summer, metropolitan art circles have put on six group shows of painting and graphics.

LONDON, Sept. 15 -- Uncertain whether they are facing a financial Dunkerque or an economic D-Day Britons were reminded today by the roar of bombers and the scream of the jet fighters of another crisis that their traditional solidity and phlegm had enabled them to survive.

LONDON, Sept. 15 -- More than 17,000 shareholders in Tate and Lyle, Britain's largest sugar refiners, voted nearly unanimously today to back their directors in the fight against the threatened nationalization of the sugar refining industry.

A promise that the fight for legalization of the hiring hall system of employment now used in the maritime industry will be continued in Congress was made to the seventh biennial convention of the National Maritime Union, CIO, yesterday morning by Senator Warren G. Magnuson of the Senate Interstate and Foreign Commerce Committee.

The Board of Estimate approved yesterday the creation of a City Parking Authority to finance, construct and operate or lease parking facilities in the five boroughs. It directed Corporation Counsel John P. McGrath to draw up enabling legislation to be submitted to the State Legislature in January.

Speaking last night in Battle Creek ECA Administrator Paul Hoffman asserted "in all candor, and at the risk of being undiplomatic, that our problem is not only to get Europe on its own feet, but off our backs." We want Europe on its own feet because a prosperous Europe is essential to our security and well-being.

LONDON, Sept. 15 -- The prospect of devaluation continued to be discussed in the stock market here today but with so many conflicting reports, the tendency among speculators was to hold off. As a result most sections were quiet.

BATTLE CREEK, Mich., Sept. 15 -- Paul G. Hoffman, Economic Cooperation Administrator, asserted tonight that the United States was ahead of schedule but far from its goal of setting Europe not only "on its feet, but off our backs."

A civil anti-trust suit that if successful would split the Great Atlantic Pacific Tea Company's vast food empire into seven independently owned retail chains was filed by the Department of Justice in Federal Court here yesterday. The suit also would abolish the chain's wholesale sales and purchasing agent and separate its manufacturing and processing from its buying and selling business.

A capsule review of the recent Paris showings was presented to members of the Fashion Group, Inc., during a luncheon yesterday at the Astor Hotel. Mrs. Carmel Snow, editor of Harper's Bazaar, just back from France, gave a general report on Paris fashions seen during August.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Sept. 15 -- Juan T. Trippe, head of Pan American Airways, after a day's discussion here with other operators, believes the concept of a mass market for air travel has been sold to them. He agrees with other United States airline executives that the report of the International Air Transport Association's traffic committee, pronouncing excursion and other lowered rates "uneconomic," is mere verbiage, Mr. Trippe said today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- The United States rescued from oblivion today a resolution of the Union of South Africa proposing that the International Monetary Fund permit half of the world's newly mined gold to be sold at a "free market" price and the other half at the fixed market price of $35 an ounce.

LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., Sept. 15 -- Members of society assembled early at the ringside this morning for the opening classes of the three-day program of the forty-fourth annual Piping Rock Horse Show on the grounds of the Piping Rock Club.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Sept. 10 were 624,197 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 79,733 cars, or 11.3 per cent fewer than for the preceding week, 164,814 cars, or 20.9 per cent fewer than for the corresponding week of last year and 298,182 cars, or 32.3 per cent fewer than during the corresponding week of two years ago.
BALTIMORE, Sept. 15 (AP) -Eastern States Corporation, an investment holding company, today lost its plea for immediate lifting of an injuction brought against it by a dissatisfied shareholder.

High court justices should not be allowed to testify as character witnesses in certain criminal trials even if subpoenaed and at "the risk of jail," I. Maurice Wormser, professor at Fordham Law School, declared here yesterday.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 15 -Twentieth Century-Fox today announced the purchase of screen rights to "The Mudlark," Theodore Bonnet's new novel of Victorian England. The price paid for the property was not disclosed. Nunnally Johnson will adapt the novel to the screen and will produce the film version in England next summer, according to the studio.

WOODSVILLE, N. H., Sept. 15 (AP) -- William C. Felton, 21 years old, of Tiffin, Ohio, suspended Dartmouth College junior and varsity football player, today was indicted on first-degree manslaughter charges in the beating to death last March 18 of a classmate, Raymond J. Cirrotta, also 21, of Linden, N. J.

The first Canadian-made Emerson Radio Phonograph Corporation television and radio receivers will be merchandised by Canadian retailers early next month, Max Abrams, president, Emerson Radio Export Corporation, the concern's export subsidiary, revealed yesterday.

A dining room that seats fourteen and a living room large enough to accommodate two overstuffed sofas, three breakfronts, a game table and chairs as well as assorted incidental furniture are on view in an exhibition that opens today on Altman's seventh floor.

The annual report of the Eastern Sugar Associates and its subsidiaries to be issued today for the fiscal year ended on June 30, disclosed the net profit at $1,137,047, compared with $1,070,408 earned in the preceding fiscal year.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was quiet yesterday and final prices were unchanged to 2 points higher than on Wednesday.

WASHINGTON Sept. 15 (UP) -A Senate labor subcommittee today approved the Administration's Fair Employment Practices Commission bill to outlaw job discrimination but backers saw no chance for passage this year.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Sept. 15 -- Four score years ago the first game of American intercollegiate football was played on the site of the present Rutgers gymnasium and what could be more fitting than that the Scarlet should have a winning team to celebrate the anniversary of that history-making meeting with Princeton and the recent selection of Rutgers as the shrine for the game's Hall of Fame?

LONDON, Sept. 15 -- Diplomatic representatives of the United States, Britain and France have agreed informally that deliveries of industrial plant as reparations from Western Germany to the Soviet Union should cease, it was understood here today.
Yesterday was harvest day in the children's gardens on the grounds of the Rockefeller Institute for Medical Research at York Avenue and Sixty-fifth Street.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Sept. 15 -- The National Soft Coal wage conference met for three hours today and recessed until Sept. 21 after John L. Lewis, president of the United Mine Workers, reportedly told the operators the union would insist on a reduction of one hour in the present eight-hour-day without loss of take-home pay.

MOSCOW, Sept. 15 -- In its leading editorial Pravda predicted today that the economic crisis it foresaw in the United States and Western Europe "promises to be particularly deep." It added that the decline in United States industrial production during the first six months of this year was 13 per cent, "just as much as during the first six months of the 1929-33 crisis."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- President Truman believes that acceptance of the Steel Fact-Finding Board's report as a basis of negotiation is proper method of settling the dispute that threatens a major strike in the steel industry.

The roller-skating rough-and-tumble that carries the name of roller derby will make its debut in Madison Square Garden tonight. Teams representing Brooklyn and Bronx-Philadelphia will meet at 8:30, inaugurating a seven-day round-robin billed as the United States championships.
CHICAGO, Sept. 15 -- A new force in midcontinent finance becomes effective today with the launching of the Midwest Stock Exchange.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 15 -- Mainly as a result of lower industrial operations, business in the Pittsburgh district declined a little more last week, according to the Bureau of Business Research, University of Pittsburgh. Ordinarily, industrial production is reduced over Labor Day; this year, curtailment in many lines was larger than average.

The stock market was set back yesterday by the clouding of the steel labor-management situation. Whereas holders of securities had taken an optimistic view of the steel outlook earlier in the week when it appeared that the problem would be resolved as a result of the report of the President's Fact Finding Board, subsequent statements of union officials and management leaders cooled their hopes.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (AP) -The Agriculture Department denied today producer requests for a 1-cent-a-quart increase in milk prices in major New England markets and New York City for October through December. Similar requests for a price rise for September were turned down the first of this month.

Prices of silver foxes ruled firm at July levels at the sale held yesterday by the New York Auction Company. Platinum foxes brought a top of $20.50 on sales of 70 per cent of 2,000 skins. White-face foxes sold up to $13.50 on an 85 per cent turnover of 900 pelts.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- The United States today used its veto power to kill a resolution in the Far Eastern Commission that would have prevented American officials from carrying out their plan to deliver $80,000,000 in Japanese gold to Thailand and French Indo-China.

CHICAGO, Sept. 15 -- Buying of an estimated 2,000,000 bushels or more wheat futures by cash and export interests, said to reflect additional sales to the Government, today sent September and December wheat up 2 7/8 cents a bushel from the early low on the Board of Trade with the latter within 1/2 cent of the top for the year, and March and May at a new top.

This week's brisker weather so sharpened appetites for substantial meat meals that several cuts of beef and pork again jumped higher in cost, homemakers will find when they do their marketing today and tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (AP) -An official of the American President Steamship Lines said today that new emphasis on the importation of crude rubber made shipping service to the Far East more important than ever.

GENEVA, Sept. 15 -- A demand that the cities of the world, as the "first line of democracy," take up the cudgels for enforcement of the United Nations declaration of human rights was made to the World Mayors' Conference here today by the representative of Milwaukee.

BERLIN, Sept. 15 -- The British authorities here announced this evening that Joseph Reimann, 22-year-old son of the Western German Communist leader, Max Reimann, had been flown out of Berlin to sanctuary in the British zone after he had appealed last Monday for aid in fleeing the Soviet zone police.
ALBANY, Sept. 15 -- Following is the text of the speech by Senator John Foster Dulles accepting the Republican nomination for the Senate:

When Sir Mohammed Zafrullah Khan, Pakistan's Foreign Minister, charged India with having deliberately blocked agreement on a settlement in Kashmir, he was stating the Pakistani case in controversial form. It may be that he was overstating it in an effort to arouse further interest in the much-needed mediation and by now long-awaited plebiscite.
WEDGEPORT, N. S., Sept. 15 (AP) -- Mario Oswald, youthful Brazilian angler, today lifted his team from last to second place behind the United States in the sixth annual international tuna match.

More than 2,000,000 home freezers will be in America homes by the end of this year, Jack Cooper, sales manager of Philco Corporation's home freezer division, predicted yesterday at a meeting of the National Wholesale Frozen Food Distributors Association in the Statler Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- When the death of Justice Rutledge created a second vacancy within a few weeks on the Supreme Court of the United States the President was publicly urged to appoint to this post a lawyer of the type which this newspaper described today as "a disinterested and creative thinker."

More than 50 per cent of the gem diamonds now imported into this country are paid for in "manipulated pound sterling deals" at from $2.50 to $3.10 to the pound, against the official quotation of $4.03, Pieter de Witt, diamond importer, 535 Fifth Avenue, said in an interview yesterday.

In a spurt exceeding any since Dec. 15, last year, business loans made by banks in this area gained $48,000,000 during the week ended on Wednesday, it was disclosed yesterday. Figures issued by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York showed that such borrowings from the reporting New York City member banks, advanced for the third consecutive week, to $4,646,000,000, an increase of $162,000,000 since the low point recorded on July 20, this year.

"Ringside," a comedy melodrama about prizefighting, opens this morning at the Rialto Theatre. Don Barry, Sheila Ryan, Tom Brown, Joey Adams, Tony Canzoneri and Margia Dean are among the principals. Ron Ormond produced and Frank McDonald directed the Screen Guild Productions release from a screen play by Daniel B. Ullman.
Students at the city's four municipal colleges who plan to enter the teaching field may be screened for loyalty, spokesmen for the Board of Higher Education disclosed yesterday.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., Sept. 15 -- After two unsuccessful attempts to get the Atlantic Coast Star Class championship under way on Tuesday, when there was a blast of wind, and yesterday, when there was no wind at all, two races were squeezed in off the Larchmont Yacht Club today.

A small, intense woman from Peru spent most of yesterday burrowing patiently into a 500-pound bundle of dust-laden cloth in search of the body of a clergyman from her native land who was last seen about 3,000 years ago.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 15 (AP) -- If the Cardinals win the National League race and you plan to attend the world series games in St. Louis, you'd better count on bringing along a tent and a cot.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- Francis P. Matthews, Secretary of the Navy, sharply rebuffed the Navy's top admirals tonight by reversing their elevation of Capt. John G. Crommelin Jr., the out spoken critic of defense policy. It was another development in the growing inter-service quarrels over unification of the armed forces.
ALBANY, Sept. 15 -- James C. Hagerty, Governor Dewey's press secretary, said tonight that he had received a leave of absence to handle campaign press relations for Senator John Foster Dulles.

Robert C. La Borde, head of the Investigators Technical Service, and his brother, John, were sentenced yesterday in Kings County Court to penitentiary terms on their conviction last July 5 of illegal wiretapping.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 15 (AP) -- Ted Schroeder and Frank Parker today reached the semi-finals of the Pacific Southwest tennis championships.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 15 -- The Cardinals marked time today, on the eve of their farewell series with the Boston Braves, relieved that combat with the Giants for 1949 had been completed without interfering with their lead in the hot National League pennant fight.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (AP) -- Farmers in every Midwestern state earned less from January through July than in the same seven months last year, the Department of Agriculture reports.

Thirteen games in Madison Square Garden and five out-of-town contests appear on City College's basketball schedule, announced yesterday by Professor Sam Winograd, faculty manager of athletics. The 22-game slate opens in a home game with Queens College on Nov. 26 and closes March 7 in the traditional finale with N. Y. U.

An English version of a comprehensive guide to medieval laws of chivalry that was popular in the fourteenth century will be issued on Sept. 29 by the Harvard University Press. "The Tree of Battles," the work of Honore Bonet which was issued in 1387, has been translated from the French by G. W. Coopland, Emeritus Professor in the University of Liverpool and author of several books in the field of medieval studies.

A resolution opposing any rise in the price of gold above the present level of $35 per ounce, and expressing the hope that the United States and other countries "may follow the wise course of Switzerland by establishing sound monetary units convertible into gold by anyone, anywhere and at any time," was adopted yesterday by the international section of the New York Board of Trade.
BERLIN, Sept. 15 (AP) -- Soviet-licensed Berlin newspapers accused a Hollywood movie company today of making a film in Berlin "to incite anti-Soviet feeling."

BONN, Germany, Sept. 15 -- With not a single vote to spare, Dr. Konrad Adenauer, head of the Christian Democratic Union, was elected Chancellor of the Federal Republic of Germany today. He required 202 votes from the 402-man Bundestag or lower house for confirmation of his nomination by President Theodor Heuss.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg, the Republican foreign policy leader, issued tonight an oblique but unmistakable warning that, for his part, United States mone tary aid to Europe should come to an end.

OFFENBACH, Germany, Sept. 15 -- The Municipal Council of Offenbach barred a physician from the post of city gynecologist because he was Jewish, the Frankfurter Rundschau charged today. Dr. James R. Newman, director of the Office of Military Government for Hesse, has ordered a complete investigation.

Once again the darling of New York boxing fans by virtue of his thrilling tenth-round knockout of Charley Fusari at the Polo Grounds on Wednesday night, Rocky Graziano yesterday was in a position to take any one of a number of attractive future matches.

LONDON, Sept. 15 -- The Economic Cooperation Administration announcement that Britain would be permitted to spend 175,000,000 Marshall Plan dollars to buy Canadian wheat and that another $34,000,000 could be used to defray port charges on British ships in American ports bolstered Sir Stafford Cripps' stock somewhat here tonight.

TOKYO, Sept. 15 -- Japanese and foreign diplomatic circles here tonight received with interest but considerable skepticism Secretary of State Dean Acheson's announcement that he and British Secretary Ernest Bevin had agreed on the urgency of a peace treaty for Japan and intended to review the whole situation in search of a new approach to this goal.

A 26-year-old elevator operator in a Park Avenue apartment house was killed in a freakish accident yesterday morning when a heavy chain more than 150 feet long broke, crashed through the elevator roof and struck him on the head. A boy who was riding with him at the time of the accident was unhurt.
Following is the text of the speech of former Gov. Herbert H. Lehman before the Democratic State Committee at the Biltmore Hotel, accepting the nominating for United State Senator:

Support for the proposed $150,000,000 State bond issue to reconstruct and renovate hospitals here was urged yesterday by Louis H. Pink, president of the Associated Hospital Service -- New York's Blue Cross Plan.
The garden at the Home for Aged and Infirm Hebrews, 121 West 105th Street, was transformed into a Coney Island-like midway yesterday for its first county fair in three years.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 15 -- Gordon R. Clapp, head of the United Nations economic mission to the Middle East, in an address here today declared that the Governments that had been supplying most funds for the Arab refugees felt that relief could not continue indefinitely and that the refugees must be put to work.

Sonja Henie, Norwegian-born ice-skating star with three Olympic championships to her credit, was married yesterday to Winthrop Gardiner Jr., an executive in charge of the aviation department of the Industrial Tape Company of New Brunswick, N. J.

Knitted glove manufacturers yesterday appealed to retailers to support their campaign against Japanese merchandise. Those who feature gloves made in Japan, it was held, are trading down their glove departments and entering a phase of "cut-throat" competition.
The Department of Marine and Aviation is expected to reach a self-sustaining basis for the first time it the city's history of dock operation, figures made public yesterday indicate.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 15 -- Ralph Kiner, who has been belting home runs at a rate which has brought predictions in some quarters that Babe Ruth's record is in jeopardy, probably doesn't look forward to meeeting the Dodgers tomorrow night.

The decision of the American Government to submit to the United Nations the dispute with Bulgaria, Hungary and Rumania on the question of human rights will bring before the General Assembly one of the most fundamental issues it has yet had to deal with.

THE HAGUE, The Netherlands, Sept. 15 -- The Indonesians have submitted the draft of a proposed statute of union with the Netherlands to the round-table conference, offering a conception of the union's permanent organs and of the position of the Crown basically opposed to Dutch ideas.

The vogue for short hair, improved service and styling and, in some instances, lowered prices have combined to increase the beauty salon business that had slumped seriously throughout the country, reports indicated yesterday.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 15 -- A new West Coast test of a phase of the Hawaii longshore strike, involving a barge loaded with 115,000 cases of pineapple, had labor and management groups watching developments today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- President Truman's secret Blair House meeting last July on relations with Great Britain and Canada in the atomic energy field will be carried forward in three-power conferences beginning next Tuesday.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 15 -- The Yugoslav Government issued tonight a 5,000-word statement denouncing the trial oil of Laszlo Rajk, former Hungarian Foreign Minister, and his codefendants which opens tomorrow in Budapest.

The New York Academy of Medicine's Committee on Public Health Relations called upon the Federal Government yesterday to restrict treatment in veterans' hospitals solely to patients whose disabilities were incurred in military service.

Sir John L. Simonsen, director of Great Britain's Colonial Products Research Council, who is scheduled to arrive today at La Guardia Airport, will receive the new $1,000 Fritzsche award for his research in essential oils at the 116th national meeting of the American Chemical Society that opens in Atlantic City on Monday.
The Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York announced yesterday that it would start a campaign for $50,500,000.

United States Attorney John F. X. McGohey made Carl Winter admit at the Communist trial yesterday that party publications recommended study of seven prewar Marxist-Leninist books after 1945. Winter previously had testified the party's 1945 constitution had "repudiated" all "obsolete" books not in keeping with a "new" post-war position.

TORONTO, Sept. 15 (Canadian Press) -- The Westminster Bank, Ltd., of London, England, has made a motion in the Supreme Court of Ontario for leave to institute proceedings in connection with bonds of the Barcelona Traction, Light and Power Company, Ltd.

CHICAGO, Sept. 15 -- Democratic leaders in down-state Illinois today received with gratification the news of President Truman's nomination of Sherman Minton, a Democrat and a judge of the Seventh United States Circuit Court of Appeals, with headquarters in Chicago, to fill the Supreme Court vacancy caused by the death of Justice Wiley P. Rutledge.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- Urging observance of United Nations Day on Oct. 24, President Truman declared today that the United Nations was the only bulwark for assurance of world peace and that support of it was absolutely essential.

Except for a few more warm and sultry spells, the summer is over. These spells, followed at shorter intervals by the practice throws of frost, will increasingly show that winter is on the way. The winter is the time of snow, of red cheeks and skating and coasting, and of sitting in comfort before the open fire.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- Following is the vote by which the Senate today defeated, 43-38, the peril-point amendment to the Reciprocal Trade Bill:

PARIS, Sept. 15 -- The admission of Pakistan and Israel to the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization as member states was announced today by Dr. Jaime Torres Bodet, Director General.

The supposed Soviet effort to apply pressure on American export policy by sharply reducing manganese exports to this country has failed because the United States has been able to meet requirements from other sources, Department of Commerce import figures reveal.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- The latest estimate of this year's expenditures by Class I steam railroads for additions and betterments is $1,297,000,000, made up of actual expenditures for the first half of $711,700,000 and estimated expenditures for the remainder of the year of about $585,000,000.

LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., Sept. 15 -- With railbirds surprised at the quantity as wel as the quality of open jumpers on hand the annual three-day Piping Rock horse show opened today on the grounds of the Piping Rock Club.

Twenty-eight Bishops of the Anglican and Protestant Episcopal communions participated yesterday in the first solemn Eucharist of Thanksgiving ever held in the Cathedral of St. John the Divine. Six thousand worshippers crowded the French Gothic structure to near-capacity.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Sept. 16 -- News of the treason trial of Laszlo Rajk, former Hungarian Foreign Minister, plentifully supplied to Czechoslovak readers, has precipitated some self-examination in Czechoslovakia, the only one of the Communist Information Bureau countries that has suffered no purges in its top party leadership.

LAKE SUCCESS, Sept. 16 -- The election of Brig. Gen. Carlos P. Romulo, the Philippine Ambassador to the United Nations, as President of the General Assembly became a strong probability today when Nasrollah Entezam, the Iranian representative, withdrew in his favor.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., Sept. 16 -- Senator John Foster Dulles accused the Truman Administration tonight of "flagrant disregard" in domestic affairs of the principles it supports internationally as necessary for a just and durable peace.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- The Senate rejected President Truman's nomination of Carl A. Ilgenfritz as chairman of the Munitions Board today, 40 to 28.

"Front Page," a new series of half-hour dramatic shows based on the Ben Hecht-Charles MacArthur play about the newspaper adventures of the managing editor, Walter Burns, and the reporter, Hildy Johnson, will have its premiere showing on the CBS television network on Thursday, Sept. 29, from 8 to 8:30 P. M.

An instance of how a virtual plaything became a valuable instrument for a veteran paralyzed from the neck down was reported yesterday afternoon by Dr. Arthur S. Abramson, assistant chief of rehabilitation at the Bronx Veterans Administration Hospital, Kingsbridge Road.

Irene D. Paden, author of "The Wake of the Prairie Schooner," which traced the pioneer trails to California and Oregon, has another book about the gold trails on Macmillan's list scheduled for Nov. 1 publication. In "Prairie Schooner Detours" she describes two short cuts to the gold mines which led to oblivion, Hasting's Cut-Off and Lassen's.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, Sept. 16 -- Laszlo Rajk, former Hungarian Foreign Minister and Communist leader, confessed fluently today to charges that he had plotted with Americans and others to smash Hungary's Government in an anti-Soviet crusade led by Yugoslav Premier Marshal Tito.
PARIS, Sept. 16 (UP) -- Police said today that they had broken up a ring that tried to smuggle copies of exclusive fashion creations to the United States in the baggage of an American woman.
NEW DELHI, Saturday, Sept. 17 (AP) -- Imports of American motor cars and motorcycles will cease under a restrictive import policy announced today by the Indian Government.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Sept. 16 -Throughout the world, and in Washington, there is a great "conflict" between human liberty and the "doctrine" of Government domination of the daily lives of people, Senator Robert A. Taft, Republican, of Ohio, told the convention of the National Association of Life Underwriters here today.
ATLANTIC, Sept. 16 (AP) -Georgia's Supreme Court today upheld a voter re-registration law frankly aimed against Negro voting.
A dessert that's mixed, baked and served in one and the same dish is practical, and with the season changing into fall, when hot puddings appeal, it's palate-piquing, too.

NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 16 -- National recreation standards and facilities in the field of public housing are "progressing backward," the thirty-first annual National Recreation Congress was advised today at the final session of its five-day conference.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 16 -- Lefty Bill Werle delivered two knockout blows to the Dodgers tonight when he hit Roy Campanella on the head in the second inning and sent the Negro catcher to the hospital, then limited the Brooks to seven hits while the Pirates pounded out a 9-2 triumph before a crowd of 28,202.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 (AP) -- The American Jewish Labor Council today asked the Justice Department to take over the investigation into the recent disorders near Peekskill, N. Y., where rioting resulted from scheduled concerts by Paul Robeson, the Negro singer.

CANTON, China, Sept. 16 (AP) -A small force of Communist regulars -- possibly 1,000 in number -- is attacking 125 miles northeast of this Chinese Nationalist capital, the Defense Ministry disclosed today.
A new air service between Buenos Aires and New York will be opened on Oct. 15 when Flota Aera Mercante Argentina (FAMA) starts once-a-week trips.

HONG KONG, Sept. 16 -- Information available here indicates that the Chinese Communist hierarchy, now that it has established control over most of China, may be shaken by power and ideological conflicts as severe as those experienced at times by Soviet Russians.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 (UP) -- Senator Scott W. Lucas, Democratic leader, breathed some new life back into the Brannan farm program today.

Dedication ceremonies marking the formal opening of the new synagogue unit of the Forest Hills Jewish Center, Sixty-ninth Avenue and Queens Boulevard, will be held at 1 P. M. tomorrow. Mayor O'Dwyer, it was announced, will be guest of honor and principal speaker.

LAKE SUCCESS, Sept. 16 -- Dr. Alberto I. Alvarez, Cuban representative to the United Nations, told fellow Latin-American delegates today that his Government hoped the General Assembly would hold its 1950 session in Havana if it decided to meet outside the United States.

ALBANY, Sept. 16 -- Governor Dewey took the first official step today toward establishing grievance machinery for state employes who under the Condon-Wadlin law are prohibited from strikes to enforce their demands.

ALBANY, N. Y., Sept. 16 (AP) -- Senator Dulles will carry his campaign into New York's southern tier Monday. He will address Republican leaders at a luncheon meeting at Elmira at noon. He will appear at a Broome County Republican dinner at Binghamton in the evening.

The stock market recovered yesterday some of the ground lost on Thursday although increases generally held to a fractional range. The session marked the third switch this week in the market's reaction to the pending negotiations between managements of the steel companies and the union officials.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 (AP) -- Ray Scarborough held Cleveland to seven hits as Washington battered Mike Garcia and Satchel Paige for, twelve and a 5-4 victory tonight.

GANTON, England, Sept. 16 (UP) -- A pair of 41-year-old pros who spent long hours filing down their iron clubs to meet American demands gave Great Britain's Ryder Cup golf team a surprising 3-to-1 lead over the United State today by whipping Sam Snead and Lloyd Mangrum in the last of four Scotch foursomes matches opening the two-day series.

The forty-six members of Mayor O'Dwyer's Committee on Puerto Ricans were sworn in yesterday by the Mayor at a meeting in the Board of Estimate chamber at City Hall. The committee, composed of representatives of public and private welfare agencies and economic,

CHICAGO, Sept. 16 -- The deadline for filing a reorganization plan for the Tucker Corporation or submitting a report that reorganization is impractical was extended by Federal District Judge Michael L. Igoe today to Oct. 4. The deadline had been Sept. 15.

Directors of the Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company of St. Paul elected yesterday as president Richard P. Carlton, former executive vice president in charge of research, engineering and manufacturing. He succeeds William L. McKnight, who held that office since 1929 and was elected to the new post of chairman of the board and also will act as chairman of the finance committee.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- Dean Acheson, Secretary of State, has assailed the McCarran Bill to tighten laws against the immigration of subversive aliens on the ground that it would "drastically" interfere with the conduct of foreign relations and the fulfillment of international commitments.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Sept. 16 -- Grand jurors in the investigation of the recent rioting near Peekskill between alleged Communists and local residents will be drawn from lists of "outstanding" Westchester County residents who have been recommended for grand jury service by tax assessors, supervisors and town councilmen, jury commissioner Ralph T. Mumford said today.

Dollar crisis, sterling crisis, Marshall Plan crisis -- what they all amount to is a trade crisis. Since the war the industrial countries of the West operate in a reduced trade area; while the manufacturing capacity of the United States is vastly expanded all the others except Western Germany produce more than they did before, Britain as much as 50 per cent more in some lines.

Retail sales declined during the week which contained several rainy days and temperatures slightly above average. Department store sales were estimated to be about 5 per cent below the corresponding week last year. Sales last week were 2 per cent above last year.

A syndicate headed by Louis J. Glickman, operator, has purchased the twelve-story office building at 1123 Broadway, northwest corner of West Twenty-fifth Street, from Farholme, Inc., represented by Frederick E. M. Ballon, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- Average primary market prices advanced 1.2 per cent in the week ended Sept. 13, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. The index was 154.6 per cent of the 1926 average, 1.8 per cent above four weeks ago and 9.0 per cent below the comparable week in 1948.

BUFFALO, Sept. 16 (AP) -- The Right Rev. John P. Boland, state mediator in the fourteen-week-old Bell Aircraft Corporation strike, announced tonight that negotiation sessions begun on Tuesday will resume Monday.

LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., Sept. 16 -- Joseph's Coat, handsome 4-Year-old gray gelding owned by Mr. and Mrs. W. Haggin Perry of Cobham, Va., accounted for the first championship of the forty-fourth Piping Rock horse show in the young hunter division today. Reserve was Fair in War, roan mare belonging to Morton W. Smith of Middleburg, Va.

A lessening of restrictions on travel to Germay and a demand for accommodations have resulted in the assignment of the transatlantic liner Washington on a special voyage to Hamburg, the United States Lines announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- The Welfare and Retirement Fund of the United Mine Workers of America today announced temporary suspension of welfare payments beginning tomorrow because of diminished revenues.

BERLIN, Sept. 16 -- One American and three British soldiers, who collectively broke out of a jail in Pankow, in the Soviet sector of Berlin last midnight, returned to their units early this morning with harrowing accounts of undernourishment and maltreatment over a period of many months.

LAKE SUCCESS, Sept. 16 -- The United Nations Security Council turned down today a Russian demand that the United Nations Atomic Energy Commission, whose work has now been suspended, be ordered back into session.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- Pleas for the entry Into this country as displaced persons of 4,000 "Shang-hai refugees," as already provided in the bill which passed the House, were heard today by a Senate Judiciary subcommittee.

Warnings to liquor wholesalers here that they must take action to cut costs and operating expenses to remain in business were made yesterday by Morris O. Alprin, general counsel for the Greater New York Wholesale Liquor Dealers Association. The warnings were sent in the form of a special bulletin to members.

Since I am chairman of the group who "greeted" the British Socialist leaders upon their arrival, may I be given the opportunity of replying to the letter of Peter Kavanagh appearing in your issue of Sept. 10.

Sales of two more dwellings in the Shelter Rock Homes colony in New Hyde Park, L. I., were reported by Harry J. Haback, builder, Lane Realty is the sales agent. Dr. Francis T. Bergan Jr., dentist, bought the house at 18 Lake Drive, and Thomas A. Rogers, a vice president of the Corn Exchange Bank, purchased a specially designed two-story residence at 40 Crest Road.

Repeal of the Taft-Hartley Act, continuance of the hiring hall, a forty-hour work week for seamen and establishment of an employer-financed health and welfare plan were presented yesterday as the principal objectives for the next two years by Joseph Curran, president of the National Maritime Union, CIO, in his report to the union's convention.

The Atomic Energy Labor Relations Panel announced last night that a dispute involving 2,500 employes of the Carbide and Carbon Chemical Corporation at Oak Ridge (Tenn.) National Laboratory had been resolved at the Commodore Hotel on the basis of a proposal by the panel during mediation.

"The Fighting Kentuckian," featuring John Wayne, Vera Ralston, Philip Dorn and Oliver Hardy, will open this morning at the Mayfair. The frontier drama was produced by Wayne for Republic from a script written and directed by George Waggner.

The Isbrandtsen Company, Inc., operators of world-wide cargo services, has negotiated a one-year agreement with the Brotherhood of Marine Engineers, an American Federation of Labor affiliate, it was announced yesterday by Capt. C. H. McLaughlin, marine superintendent of the company.

BOSTON, Sept. 16 -- Still hopeful of a helping hand from Detroit and/or Cleveland, but inwardly convinced that they will have to help themselves in their remaining five games with the Yankees, the Red Sox today kept on the heels of the league-leaders with a 12-4 victory over the Browns.

The three-story factory building at 223 Nevins Street, Brooklyn, formerly used as a sawmill, has been purchased by Lion Brand, Inc., from the Commonwealth Color and Chemical Company. The new owner plans to occupy the building in connection with its office furniture manufacturing business.

MITCHEL AIR FORCE BASE, Sept. 16 -- After undergoing a week-long simulated air bombardment designed to test the efficiency of volunteer civilian spotters, New York and nine other Eastern states came through yesterday without too much theoretical damage.

GLEN COVE, L. I., Sept. 16 -- Finishing with a pair of birdie 3's, C. Raymond Peterson and his guest, George Van Nostrand of Brookville, scored 36, 34 -- 70, even par, to win medal honors during the qualifying round of the Nassau County Club's member-guest golf tournament today.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., Sept. 16 -- After ten and one-quarter miles of tough going, one more race among the Star sloops was concluded today for their Atlantic Coast championship, being sailed from the Larchmont Yacht Club. And in this case tough did not mean wind and sea.

LAKE SUCCESS, Sept. 16 -- The United Nation's first commemorative plaque was unveiled today to honor the memory of Count Folke Bernadotte, the Palestine Mediator who was assassinated on Sept. 17, 1948.

Directors of Columbia Pictures Corporation declared a 50-cent dividend for payment to common stockholders on Oct. 14. The last cash disbursement was made in September, 1947. Since then the only other declaration was a 2 1/2 per cent stock dividend distributed in May, 1948.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- President Truman will go to Kansas City on Sept. 29 for a huge "local-boy-makes-good" party in honor of William M. Boyle Jr., the Irish Catholic newsboy who has become Chairman of the Democratic National Committee.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- Elder Lightfoot Michaux, Washington's famous Negro evangelist, brought the greatest miracle since Election Day to the White House today.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 16 -- American workmen are dissatisfied with our industrial system because management has failed to give them the spiritual satisfaction they need in their work, Wallace F. Bennett, president of the National Association of the Manufacturers declared today.

The Federal Bureau of Investigation announced yesterday the cracking of a ring dealing in stolen American Express Company Travelers' checks with the arrest of David Ribler, 44 years old, of 1001 Bryant Avenue, the Bronx, described as a "part time bookmaker."
LONDON, Sept. 16 -- Pending the statement to be made on Monday by Sir Stafford Cripps, Chancellor of the Exchequer, on his talks in Washington, speculators held off in the stock markets here today.

Pleading for a realistic sterling-dollar exchange rate, the Tanners Council yesterday charged that current conditions penalize United States importers of hides and skins and discriminate against them in world markets.

DAYTON, Ohio, Sept. 16 (AP) -- The B. F. Goodrich Company tonight offered some 16,000 striking members of the United Rubber Workers (CIO) an improved pension-insurance plan, but refused to grant fourth-round wage increases.

In two recent editorials, "Aftermath of Nazism" and "The Ghost of Hitler," you accept the drift of reports from Germany to the effect that nationalism and anti-Semitism are in evidence there to a "discouraging" extent. May I offer an interpretation which tends to relieve the discouragement?
CHICAGO, Sept. 16 (AP) -- Pinch-hitters Mickey Owen, Herm Reich and Forrest Burgess came through with base hits today to give the Chicago Cubs a 5-4 ten-inning victory over the New York Giants.

GLEN RIDGE, N. J., Sept. 16 -- Mrs. Joseph Mason of Ridgewood won low gross honors in the Women's New Jersey Golf Association one-day tournament at Glen Ridge Country Club today when she posted a 36, 39 -- 75. Her 1-over-par effort was the best in a field of sixty and gave Mrs. Mason her second victory in a row.

WASHINGTON, Sept. l6 -- Selden Chapin, former United States Minister to Budapest, describe today as "completely without foundations" allegations that he had discussed a plot to overthrow the Hungarian Government with Laszlo Rajk, now on trial as a spy and traitor.

LONDON, Sept. 16 -- Harold Wilson, president of the Board of Trade, told a group of international bankers at Oxford today that bilateral trading agreements "do not play any part in the kind of trading system to which we are looking forward."

The second price reduction within the past two weeks by a Kentucky distiller was announced yesterday by Brown-Forman Distilleries Corporation. Old Forrester, a premium bottled in bond bourbon, was reduced $5 a case wholesale, which will be reflected at retail here on Nov. 1 with a cut from $6.90 for four-fifths of a quart to $6.12.

Dr. James R. Wilson of the American Medical Association has warned members of the National Agricultural Chemicals Association that there must be more thorough pre-testing of pest poisons if "hastily conceived laws and regulations" are to be avoided. He expressed apprehension over "hasty investigations" and quick legislation.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- A young pilot recently bailed out of a jet plane speeding more than 600 miles an hour and lived to tell about it, the Navy disclosed tonight.

Brig. Gen. Frank L. Howley, United States Military Governor in Berlin since 1945, arrived here yesterday with his wife and four children, receiving an enthusiastic reception when the Army transport Gen. Maurice Rose docked at Stapleton, S. I., and later at City Hall, where he was greeted by Mayor O'Dwyer, himself a former brigadier general.

A sofa with meticulous lines and a comfortable easy chair with a slanting seat, both selected for the current exhibit, "For Modern Living," at the Detroit Institute of Art, are now available through decorators here from Jens Risom Designs, 668 Fifth Avenue.

ALEXANDRIA BAY, N. Y., Sept. 16 -- Strict enforcement of existing motor vehicle laws can solve all the traffic problems of New York or any other city delegates were told today at the closing session here of the annual convention of the New York State Automobile Association.

The current voyage of the Italian Line passenger vessel Vulcania, which has been held at her home port in Genoa by a strike of Italian seamen, has been canceled, according to cable advices received here yesterday by American Export Lines, general agents for the line.
ROCHESTER, N. Y., Sept. 16 (AP) -- Sol Heumann, clothing manufacturer and a bachelor, who died last Saturday, at 66, left his estate to four institutions and twenty-six friends and relatives.
GENEVA, Sept. 16 -- The International Refugee Organization moved refugees to new homelands at the rate of 1,000 daily during July, IRO headquarters announced today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 (AP) -- An announced pricing formula for selling government-owned or controlled farm products in the domestic market during 1949 was found today to be erroneous for cotton.
The city of Miami, Fla., announced yesterday that it would receive bids Oct. 5 on $1,500,000 of sidewalk bonds dated Oct. 1, 1949, and due Oct. 1, 1951 to 1961.

Schrafft's (Frank G. Shattuck 3ompany) will begin its fall advertising schedule on Monday, it was nnounced yesterday by Gerald Shattuck, president. Plans include increased space for such counter items as cakes, ice cream, candy nd pantry products.

HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Sept. 16 -- A boycott of the Prospect Street Elementary School because of alleged "segregation" began today. Parents of absent pupils stood outside passing out handbills and urging children to return home.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Sept. 16 -- Foreign Minister Moshe Sharett told Israeli editors here today that Jerusalem had an indissoluble connection with Israel and that any projected plan to separate the two was merely an illusion.

Seven hundred members of the Teachers Union, Local 555 of the United Public Workers, signed affidavits last night at a meeting at Stuyvesant High School, 345 East Fifteenth Street, joining in as intervenors in a move seeking to enjoin the Board of Education from carrying out the provisions of the Feinberg Law.

WEDGEPORT, N. S., Sept. 16 (UP) -- The United States team, led by George Thomas of Los Angeles and Lou Marron of Brielle, N. J., won the sixth International Tuna Cup match today with a total of 8,391 points, defeating Brazil, its closest rival, by 2,171 points.
For the first time in several years, Tammany is contemplating holding a rally in Madison Square Garden during the last week of the campaign, it was learned yesterday.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 16 -- The Government's invitation to union and management leaders in steel to meet with Federal mediators in Washington Monday brought no break in pessimism over prospects of warding off a strike Sept. 25.

WEST POINT, N. Y., Sept. 16 -- The tradition of Army excellence oh the football field has become so established since the coming of Earl (Red) Blaik to the Military Academy that annually, before the campaign, the cadets automatically are rated among the nation's elect, without regard to losses and replacements in manpower.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- The twelve member nations of the North Atlantic alliance will meet tomorrow to approve a program of common defense that was nearing completion this evening.

A training program for volunteer adult lay leaders has been planned under auspices of the Catholic Youth Organization of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York to be conducted in eleven places starting next month and running until May.

The International Game Fish Association has just reported on the latest status of the world records on various species, and despite the muttered discontent of some anglers, catches made during the past year have established a number of new marks.

A superseding indictment charging first degree murder was returned yesterday against Ralph Edwards Barrows, 19-year-old suspect who had been indicted last Dec. 3 for manslaughter in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel slaying of a Canadian textile executive.

LONDON, Sept. 16 -- By a proclamation issued today in London and Bengazi, the British Government empowered Emir Sayid Idriss el-Senussi, religious and political chief of Cyrenaica, to enact a constitution for his domain, the eastern province of the former Italian colony of Libya in North Africa.

It was sixty years ago yesterday that "Beth Israel Hospital" in Manhattan was opened. The forty immigrants who financed that philanthropic venture -- with contributions of 25 cents a week each -- could hardly fail to be impressed by the present tall building, in which next month Governor Dewey and Mayor O'Dwyer will help celebrate the anniversary.

William Z. Foster, in a deposition read at the Communist trial yesterday, denied the Government's major charges. He testified that the party does not advocate violent revolution, in this country, or teach that it is essential to achieve "socialism."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 (AP) -- A leader of a group opposed to Federal aid for Roman Catholic schools today accused former Gov. Herbert H. Lehman of New York of making "misleading" statements about the Barden aid to education bill.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Sept. 15 -- Members of the International Ruhr Authority, meeting with the Tripartite High Commission for the first time, complained today that they had received no opportunity to implement the powers granted to them, it was reliably reported today.
Tommy Byrne, whose exceptional mound talents on occasion frazzle the nerves of both managers in any given ball game, provided another of his spine-tingling performances yesterday.

The British cruiser Glasgow, which had a long and distinguished record in the late war, docked at sundown yesterday at Pier 54, West Fourteenth Street, on a courtesy visit under the command of Vice Admiral R. V. Symonds-Tayler.
Net earnings of the Continental Motors Corporation and its consolidated subsidiaries amounted to $1,701,005 for the nine months ended on July 31, according to the report released today.

It was a cold December day. But the 9-year-old boy dressed only in summer clothes was strolling nonchalantly along Forty - second Street. Mrs. Emma Alden Rothblatt of the policewomen's bureau walked over to him.
SAN DINGO, Calif., Sept. 16 (UP) -- Every warship and naval air squadron of the Pacific Fleet is outfitted for emergencies that might arise during atomic bombings, the Navy announced tonight.

We have been roaming about the future lately, from 1984 to approximately 2,000,000 A. D., relying upon those prophets who masquerade as writers of science fiction and related genres, the contemporary followers of Jules Verne and even Edward Bellamy.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- John W. Snyder, Secretary of the Treasury, said emphatically today that there would not be any change in the dollar value of gold and that he never exerted pressure on any country to devalue its currency.

A continuance of the decline in forced transfers of property in Manhattan was reported yesterday by the Real Estate Board of New York which said its monthly survey indicated a substantial drop in foreclosures last month as compared with the previous month and with August, 1948.

What are the essentials of a transit improvement program which the voters of New York City might reasonably expect to come from a courageous candidate for Mayor in an election year? An attempt to answer this question with realism cannot wholly ignore politics. To ask too much from a man running for office might be the same as asking him to sign his own political death warrant.

ALBANY, Sept. 16 -- The Board of Regents at its regular meeting today accepted the gift of the William Robertson Coe planting fields and arboretum in the town of Oyster Bay for use by the Long Island Agricultural and Technical Institute at Farmingdale.

LAKE SUCCESS, Sept. 16 -- India cannot accept arbitration on the disarming of the anti-Government rebel forces in Kashmir, according to Sir Benegal Rama Rau, New Delhi's permanent delegate to the United Nations.

LAKE SUCCESS, Sept. 16 -- Following are the items proposed for inclusion on the regular and supplementary agenda of the fourth regular session of the United Nations General Assembly, which will convene at Flushing Meadow on Tuesday. Explanatory material within parentheses was compiled by the United Nations Division of Public Information.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 (UP) -- The Army, Navy and Air Force were warned today that they would have to get along with fewer automobiles and planes in carrying out their official assignments.

GENEVA, N. Y., Sept. 16 (AP) -- Strawberries and raspberries that ripen in the autumn were among the interesting exhibits of the thirty-first annual meeting of the New York State Fruit Testing Association today.

YORK HARBOR, Me., Sept. 16 -Plans to bring natural gas to New England in the not-too-distant future were outlined this afternoon by Gardiner Symonds, president of the Tennessee Gas Transmission Company of Houston, Tex. He addressed the ninety-sixth quarterly meeting of the New England Council at the Marshall House.
Coffee futures continued to advance in active trading on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange yesterday with new seasonal highs established for all delivery positions in both the S and D contracts.

According to stores and designers, the wool fabric in greatest demand in women's clothes this fall is worsted jersey. This includes fashions from top price designs down to the blouse sold on the main floor of department stores for a few dollars.

PARIS, Sept. 16 -- David K. E. Bruce, United States Ambassador to France, inspected the reopened Museum of French-American Cooperation today in the Chateau of Blerancourt, Aisne, at the headquarters of the American Friends of France.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- An effort to force Western Europe to form an international military force was begun today by a bipartisan group of eleven Senators.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 16 -- Agents of the Arab Higher Committee of Haj Amin el-Husseini, exiled Grand Mufti, on the one hand, and of groups allied with King Abdullah of Jordan on the other, are transforming the presence of the United Nations economic mission to the Middle East into a political battle between the familiar two parties in the Arab world.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 (AP) -- The top dividend checks to be sent to World War II veterans on their National Service Life Insurance will be for $528. Dividends will start going out in January.

ATHENS, Sept. 16 -- Premier Alexander Diomides once again restated today his Government's position in regard to Albania and the Communist-led Greek rebels. He denied that Greece had aggressive designs, but at the same time he sounded a warning.
The number of polio cases reported to the city Health Department has declined for the fourth successive week, Dr. Harry S. Mustard, Health Commissioner, announced yesterday.

The election of the first woman Mayor of Yonkers, on a recount of the 1947 vote to fill a resigned term, shows not only that women always have the last word but once again that the ladies are having a pretty good year for "firsts." Georgia Neese Clark, of course, was the first woman in history to become the Treasurer of the United States.

After a hectic week in New York in pursuit of women's and misses' fall apparel that could be made available for quick delivery, visiting buyers left for home yesterday determined to avoid similar experiences later in the season. They have begun to show greater willingness to place orders as far ahead as November and December to insure ample merchandise for holiday promotions, according to resident offices, particularly in better dress and sportswear lines.

Another chapter was written into the sports history of fabulous Madison Square Garden last night as the Roller Derby "world series" started a seven - day stand with a Brooklyn team starting out against a combined Bronx - Philadelphia team.

Differing sharply from views expressed by Mayor O'Dwyer, his Democratic opponent, and by former Gov. Herbert H. Lehman, Senatorial candidate, with whom he is running on the Liberal party, ticket, Newbold Morris, Republican-Liberal-Fusion candidate for Mayor, said yesterday that he favored in principle the Barden bill, now pending in Congress, and was opposed to Federal aid for parochial schools.
ALBANY, Sept. 16 (AP) -- Governor Dewey approved an agreement today to more than double the diversion of Lake Erie water into the canalized Seneca and Oswego Rivers.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- The Federal Government stepped into the steel pension dispute again today, inviting spokesmen for both the steel industry and the CIO United Steel Workers of America to a mediation conference here Monday.

PARIS, Sept. 16 -- The apparent failure of former Emperor Bao Dai, since June head of a Viet Namese government sponsored by France, to improve the French position in war-torn Indo-China is causing increasing concern in responsible quarters here.
AHLEN, Germany, Sept. 16 (UP) -- Joseph Reimann, 23-year-old son of West Germany's Communist boss, today disowned his father and denounced him as ignorant and misguided.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Sept. 16 -- Five Polish youths who had taken passage in a Polish airplane from Gdansk [Danzig] to Lodz, forced the pilot at gunpoint to fly to Sweden. Four of the weapons later proved to be toy pistols and the fifth an old Russian army model revolver.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 16 -- The Progressive Party national committee tonight attributed the ills and alarms of the United States to "the Truman Administration's depression - breeding, war - making program."

Again the E. H. Harriman Memorial Gold Medals have been awarded, under the sponsorship of the American Museum of Safety, to rail lines in various classifications for outstanding performance. On a basis of locomotive mileage performed, the railroads, for the purpose of these awards, are divided into three classes.

DETROIT, Sept. 16 -- A well-informed union source today confirmed reports that the Ford Motor Company and the United Automobile Workers, CIO, had been discussing a pension plan for two days. He refused to elaborate.
MOSCOW, Sept. 16 -- The Soviet press said today in commenting on the Budapest trial of Laszlo Rajk that Premier Marshal Tito of Yugoslavia and his regime were actually on trial as well.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 16 -- The Cardinals were breathing more easily tonight after they had pulled two and one-half games in front in the National League pennant race by conquering the Braves, 7 -- 5, before a gathering of 16,676 under the lights at Sportsman's Park.

LONDON, Sept. 16 -- Sir Stafford Cripps, British Chancellor of the Exchequer, who is flying homeward from the Washington talks on the British dollar shortage presumably to urge the necessity for greater economy in domestic spending, will be met upon his arrival by a growing demand for wage increases from large groups of British labor.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 16 (UP) -- A Brooklyn inventor said today he's developed a process for building houses out of sawdust.

BUDAPEST, Sept. 16 (UP) -- Mr. Rajk named Joseph Cardinal Mindszenty, now in a Hungarian prison, as leader of a Vatican scheme to help him take over the Hungarian Government by inciting anti-Government riots to coincide with a coup to be touched off by the murder of three of Hungary's top Communist leaders.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Sept. 16 -- Gen. Sir Brian Robertson and John J. McCloy conferred tonight in the latter's home following a surprise announcement in Bonn today that the great hall of the Bochumer Verein steel plant would not be dismantled as scheduled if Mr. McCloy, the United States High Commissioner-designate could persuade his British counterpart to agree.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Sept. 16 -- The world air lines ended their thirtieth anniversary meeting here today with a unanimous dedication to the cause of making all travel easy and cheap for the average man.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 (AP) -- Burdened with a surplus, the Agriculture Department today slashed price supports on flaxseed in a move aimed at getting a smaller crop in 1950.

Civil service examinations exist for the purpose of insuring competency in government. But, in the desire to grant preference to veterans in the federal civil service, Congress has leaned so far over in their favor that it has seemed to forget the greater needs of all the people.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept. 16 (AP) -- Billy Southworth will return next season as manager of the Boston Braves, and there will be no "head chopping" among the players of that club, he said today.

ELMSFORD, N. Y., Sept. 16 -- The Westchester District was host to a Metropolitan P.G.A. one-day event at Fairview Country Club today, and Maurice Walsh of Sunningdale, president of the Westchester Chapter of Professional Golfers, left no doubt as to who is top man in the county organization.

Philip (Little Farvel) Cohen, a close lieutenant of Louis (Lepke) Buchalter in the heyday of the Brooklyn murder ring, ended a comeback in crime late Thursday in a Valley Stream, L. I., street with four bullets in his head and neck.

ROME, Sept. 16 -- Strong denunciation of the Communist cam-I paign to create chaos, sabotageI the Marshall Plan and discredit the North Atlantic pact was made by United States Ambassador James Clement Dunn at the in-I auguration of the "Fair of the Levant" in Bari today.

Maybe a traffic cop should be stationed on the first turn for the running of the Beldame Handicap at Aqueduct today. For the end-of-the-meeting feature, which carries $50,000 in added money, has drawn a field of nineteen -- eight 3-year-old fillies, six 4-year-old fillies and a quintet of 5-year-old mares.

Newbold Morris, the Republican-Liberal candidate for Mayor, and his two running mates, Harry Uviller and Matthew J. Diserio, officially became the nominees of the City Fusion party yesterday afternoon when that independent political party filed petitions just before the deadline with the Board of Elections.

A wider application of a wartime method of medical treatment that will fit or restore the patient to an occupation after suffering from illness or injury was advocated yesterday by Dr. Peter J. Macleod, medical superintendent of the Bridge of Earn Hospital in Pertshire, Scotland.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Sept. 16 -- Robert Hoelzle, 21-year-old paraplegic who was wounded while serving with the Marines on Okinawa, received today the keys to the $22,000 house that citizens here built for him "for services rendered."

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 16 (AP) -- A five-run second inning carried the Chicago White Sox to a 6-3 victory and a split of their twinight double-header with the Philadelphia Athletics tonight. Dick Fowler tossed a two-hitter to give the A's a 5-1 first game triumph.

The market for new securities will be dominated by corporate financing transactions next week for the first time since long before Labor Day. Major flotations will consist of new issues of bonds and common stock of the West Penn Electric Company with an aggregate value of nearly $50,000,000.
One thousand persons attended ceremonies yesterday celebrating the 162d anniversary of the signing of the Constitution on the steps of the Sub-Treasury Building.
