WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- The Navy Department asked its officers today to stop talking publicly about the current controversy over strategic defense plans, including the role of naval aviation.

ARDMORE, Pa., Sept. 16 -- The fifteen-year-old girl from Los Angeles, Miss Marlene Bauer, who gained golfing fame this week in the United States women's championship, bowed in the semi-final this afternoon to another Californian, Miss Dorothy Kielty of Long Beach.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 16 -- An appeal to four railway brotherhoods to end their strike against the Missouri Pacific Railroad and join in asking President Truman to name a three-man board to settle major issues was made today by a trustee for the railroad as the walkout of 5,200 trainmen entered its second week.
Honesty was worth $2,300 to four New Yorkers yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 (AP) -- The decision today to terminate payments out of the miners' welfare and retirement fund means that several hundred thousand beneficiaries will have their benefits suspended.

Devaluation of the currencies of western Europe was favorably viewed in two resolutions passed yesterday by the board of directors of the National Association of Steel Exporters, at their third quarterly meeting yesterday at 150 Broadway, the trade group's headquarters.

TRENTON, N. J., Sept. 16 -- Setting partisanship aside for a half-hour, nearly 100 Republican and Democratic candidates for the Governorship and legislative seats took a mass loyalty oath today at the State House. Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll, with his Democratic opponent, State Senator Elmer H. Wene of Vineland, were among those who participated.

The Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo officially opened the dance season last night with the beginning of its two-week engagement at the Metropolitan Opera House. It was not, unhappily, a brilliant occasion. Drab, indeed, would seem to fit the situation with a reasonable degree of accuracy.

Supreme Court Justice Ferdinand Pecora was renominated unanimously last night for a second fourteen-year term by the Republican judicial convention of the First Judicial District, comprising New York and Bronx Counties.

Some doubt existed yesterday as to whether Michael Todd's forthcoming variety entertainment, "Two-A-Day," would open at the Winter Garden on Sept. 24. The report was that Mr. Todd had been unable to line up all the necessary talent and that as a consequence another forthcoming musical had been booked for the Shubert playhouse.

HARROGATE, England, Sept. 16 (UP) -- The annual conference of the Institute of British Journalists today voted unanimously to support the Empire Press Union in asking Britain not to sign the proposed United Nations convention on freedom of information.

CHICAGO, Sept. 16 -- December, March and May wheat sold at new seasonal high prices on the Board of Trade today with prices up 1 7/8 cents a bushel at the extreme as the result of free buying which was attributed to cash interests, exporters and mills.

Mountaintops and deep underground caverns around the world these days are crowded with physicists. Huddled over small black instrument boxes, they are "tuned in" on the universe to record the last faint gasp of electrical signals coming from somewhere beyond the earth.
Forty - eight journalists from fourteen western European countries received a gala New York reception yesterday, the climax of an intensive, two-week coast-to-coast sightseeing tour.

TOKYO, Sept. 16 -- Japanese business men with few reservations praise the tax reform report prepared for the Occupation by Prof. Carl S. Shoup of Columbia University, but American business-men unanimously condemn it.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were steady yesterday, and final prices were 2 points lower to 7 points higher.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 16 (UP) -- Milton J. Drake, vice president of the Detroit, Mich., bank, today was elected president of Robert Morris Associates, national association of bank credit men and lending officers. He succeeds Walter L. Rehfield, vice president of the Mercantile-Commerce Bank Trust Co., of St. Louis.

CHICAGO, Sept. 16 -- Professing that he lived in "the greatest country in the world, and I can trace my ancestry here back 100 years," Maurice E. Travis, secretary of the Mine, Mill and Smelter Workers Union, CIO, told the union's forty-fifth convention today "Why I was a Communist."

Joseph J. Doran, assistant counsel to the Public Service Commission, completed yesterday his cross-examination of three officials of the New York Central Railroad, which is petitioning for fare increases on the Harlem, Hudson and Putnam divisions.
FORT WORTH, Sept. 18 (UP) -- A professional diver found two more bodies today in the wreckage of a B-36 superbomber, world's biggest military airplane, that crashed into Lake Worth last night.

FOR THIS WEEK: Leave a few snapdragon plants, when cleaning up the garden, for bloom next June. . . . Give precedence to peonies, iris, oriental poppy and daylilies for transplanting. . . . Plant bulbs of oxalis a dozen in a fiveinch pot, for winter bloom indoors. . . . Move house plants from the garden to the porch, if not indoors, as soon as possible. . . .

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 17 -- "No welfare, no work" became the slogan of the nation's coal miners today as indications poured in from all parts of the country that a new strike by the 480,000 members of John L. Lewis' United Mine Workers was on.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -- Exhaustive hearings that will affect vitally the future of television broadcasting will start before the Federal Communications Commission Sept. 26.

ONE of the pleasantest boundaries, surely, is a hedge. It is likely to be needed somewhere on almost every property but does not have to be the formally clipped, expensive boxwood or yew that must be sheared frequently.
Cleveland and Detroit echoed the tragedy of the Toronto ship fire yesterday as relatives and friends sought to get transportation to the scene. Many of the victims came from those two cities.

NOT every boy who finds a bear in his backyard has so understanding a father as did young Stephen. It was, to be sure, a most amiable bear. He liked marshmallows, automobile rides and the songs which Stephen's father sang.

A Basic Controversy A showdown is at hand in a fundamental conflict between labor and management. The issue is one of deep and long-range significance in industrial relations. It involves a relatively new principle urged by labor in collective bargaining -- the principle that management should pay the whole cost of protecting its workers against the hazards of illness and old age.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 (UP) -- A hurry-up call for vacationing House members to get back to work aroused speculation today that something big was ready for the legislation mill.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -- Harold E. Stassen will be "happy" to go into Ohio and make speeches in behalf of Senator Robert Taft "if he is asked to do so," his executive secretary disclosed here today. Senator Taft seeks re-election in 1950.

SEATTLE, Sept. 17 (AP) -- An advanced type of a jet-propelled commercial air transport is on the drawing boards at the Boeing Airplane Company. But before Boeing can put it into production to compete with British jet transports in the next few years, it will need some Government financial aid, according to Wellwood E. Beall, Boeing vice president in charge of engineering and sales.

The letter "Paris Encore" is an absolutely ridiculous retort to my accurate emendation of "Not Paris but New York." No one having seen Paris could accept without dissent the exaggerated and definitely disputable comparisons exhibited in that article.

IN order to maintain the standard of the perennial border, it is necessary to add a few new plants each year and to divide and reset many old ones. If this is not done, some will become so dense as not to bloom at all; others will spread over the entire garden.

PAWTUCKET, R. I., Sept. 17 -- Donor gave a capacity crowd of 30,473 fans a pulse-pounding thrill at Narragansett Park today. The game 5-year-old, owned by Mrs. Deering Howe, turned in a fine exhibition to win the $25,000 added Narragansett Special by a head from I. J. Collins' Vulcan's Forge.
JERUSALEM, Sept. 17 -- A territorial exchange between Israel and Jordan in the Jerusalem area is being discussed by the Mixed Armistice Commission, it was learned today.

A $1,000,000 motion picture project intended to teach adherents of all faiths how to frustrate individuals or groups that gnaw a nation's moral fiber was announced yesterday by Father James Keller, founder and director of the Christophers.

LONDON, Sept. 17 -- This will be a week of grave decisions for Britain's Labor Government. It is now agreed that, helpful as the Washington talks have been toward restoration of the trade balance between the Old World and the New by 1952, it still devolves upon Britain's Government to take drastic action to save itself from the impending crisis of dwindling gold and dollar reserves.

Preliminary plans have been completed for a $1,000,000 combination office building and firehouse to be built for the Fire Department as part of the Brooklyn Civic Center improvement, it was announced yesterday by Mayor O'Dwyer and Brooklyn Borough President John Cashmore.
ROSES may be planted in either fall or spring. In spite of hesitancy on the part of many gardeners, experts are unanimous in favoring fall planting, no matter how late.

BRUSSELS, Belgium Sept. 17 -- A select nineteen-member Dutch-Indonesian delegation met at Namur, Belgium, once last night and twice today to try to iron out difficulties that arose at the Hague round-table conference.

THURS WRALDSON leaves an Iowa farm to enter a Michigan college at the start of the story. Thurs -- called "the Big Moose" -- is six feet nine inches in height. The novel offers the usual disclaimer about real persons, and so it is doubtless a mere coincidence that Mr. Feikema himself is six feet nine inches tall and that he attended Calvin College in Grand Rapids.

SAN FRANCISCO -- The 1949 four-day convention and photographic trade show of the Master Photo Dealers and Finishers Association, held at the Civic Auditorium here last week, emphasized the picture-taking rather than the darkroom phases of amateur photography.

IN "The Man Who Carved Women From Wood," Max White has employed the Grand Hotel formula of gathering various characters together and letting them work out their destinies on one another. His characters are eccentric to the point of madness, and his story includes genius, telepathy, kleptomania, drunkenness and murder, but there is hardly a line that does not evoke in the reader a sense of life accurately observed and appraised with wisdom.

AS every American knows from his first reader, the Dutch city of Haarlem was saved in ancient times by little Hans, the boy who thrust his thumb into the hole in the dike and held back the devouring sea. A note from one of our correspondents abroad reports that thousands of our travelers have recently visited Haarlem and inquired for the home of the brave little fellow.

AMONG the finest compositions of the late Bela Bartok are his six string quartets. From the mechanistic patterns of the first, composed in 1908, to the refined simplicity of the last nearly forty years younger, they present a comprehensive picture of his creative life and have been classed by some of his admirers as the greatest efforts in the medium since Beethoven.

ALBANY, Sept. 17 -- A judicial determination as to whether membership in the Communist party or affiliated organizations in itself is enough to disqualify a person from employment in the public school system has been assured through a suit brought in the State Supreme Court to invalidate the Feinberg Law.

The Warner Brothers film history of United States naval aviation, "Task Force," starring Gary Cooper, will receive a two-ocean premiere on Tuesday aboard the aircraft carriers Midway in the Atlantic and the Valley Forge in the Pacific.

As the art season opens, Fifty-seventh Street has a strange new look. The stalwart Parke-Bernet building, which stood as a kind of pivot, is gone. Where you once glanced beyond the green-liveried doorman into the vast marble lobby, you now walk in the gloom of an overhead wood scaffold and catch a glimpse of fluted columns lying in dusty rubble.

SAN FRANCISCO -- A new-type 5-by-7 enlarging camera based on electronic principles was introduced at the Photographic Dealers and Finishers Convention here last week. The Electro-Focus Enlarger, the invention of Mark Kokesnikoff, photographer and engineer, will cost about $450 when distribution arrangements have been completed later this year by Hollywood Television Enterprises, Inc., of Hollywood.
Mrs. Elizabeth P. Dawson has been advanced to personnel director of Lit Brothers, Philadelphia, succeeding Robert L. Dieffenbacher, who has resigned to enter the industrial field.

NEWARK, N. J., Sept. 17 -- Pointing up their refusal to take the Tumulty-Mehorter oath of allegiance, under a recently enacted state law, the constitutionality of which their party is testing in the courts, twenty-eight Progressive party candidates took the New Jersey constitutional oath of allegiance today at their second annual convention in Essex House.

Office furniture dealers are now reordering during a seasonal upswing in business volume, Howard Gatewood, trade relations director of the Wood Office Furniture Institute, Washington, D. C., stated last week in an interview at the Commodore Hotel.

With United States oil companies finding competition increasingly difficult with the British in the foreign markets, the industry here is much concerned over the outcome of the Anglo-American oil conference scheduled to get under way in Washington this week.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 17 (AP) -- A human gazelle named Clyde (Smackover) Scott raced eighty-one yards through a bewildered Chicago Bear defense tonight to give the champion Philadelphia Eagles a 14-to-7 victory in a National Football League exhibition game at Municipal Stadium.

Delegates from four boroughs of the city, excluding Richmond, comprising the New York City Chapter of Americans for Democratic Action, endorsed the candidacy of Newbold Morris for the mayoralty at yesterday's session of their second annual convention, in the Park Sheraton Hotel.

PERCHED steeply on the heights dominating the Rhineland village of Honnef, the trim, snug home of Dr. Konrad Adenauer graphically reflects the personality and characteristics of the Chancellor of the new German Federal Republic. Whoever knows the house knows the man.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 (AP) -- Key Republicans hadn't made up their minds today whether to fight President Truman's appointment of Judge Sherman Minton of Indiana to the Supreme Court.

NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., Sept. 17 -- Howard M. Miller 3d and James O'Neill of Donny Brook, the medalists, and William A. Loock Jr. and Duncan Edwards Jr. of Greenwich, who trailed the leaders by a stroke in qualifying, gained the final of Wykagyl Country Club's fourth annual member-guest best-ball tournament today.

In Leadership of West There was assembled in Washington last week one of the largest groups of high-level foreign diplomats the nation's capital has seen. They had come by plane, train and ship to deal with two sets of problems of vast importance to world relations -- in economic conferences and in political conferences.
VIENNA, Sunday, Sept. 18 (AP) -- Michael Edison Sloane, 18, grandson of Thomas A. Edison, lost a gallant fight for his life on a wind-swept Alpine glacier in Southern Austria last week.

CAMDEN, N. J., Sept. 16 -- Robert A. Seidel, vice president and controller of the W. T. Grant Company, will join the RCA Victor division of the Radio Corporation of America as vice president in charge of distribution, effective Oct. 1, it was announced here today by J. G. Wilson, executive vice president in charge of the division. Mr. Seidel will make his headquarters at the division's home office in Camden.

SHANGHAI, Sept. 17 (UP) -- The United States Information Service announced today it had reached agreement with ninety former employes on dismissal pay for those discharged when the Communist regime forced the service to suspend activities.

Rayon yarn producers, staging a production and delivery comeback after six months of depressed activity, are diligently studying all possibilities in the apparel, home furnishings and industrial fields to expand the market for filament yarn and staple, it was pointed out last week by leading producers.

Prof. E. L. Woodard's able appraisal ("On the Tenth Anniversary of World War II") of the ultimate causes of the war needs some supplementary statements. These concern Britain's and France's blunder in foreign policy which apparently justified Hitler's continuous and increasing bluffs beyond the boldest hopes of his followers.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 17 -- The hopes of Federal mediators for averting a national steel strike received another jolt tonight when Philip Murray, president of the United Steelworkers of America, CIO, accused the industry of applying a double standard in pensions for workers and pensions for executives.

CHICAGO, Sept. 17 -- Fall buying got under way here last week as retail stores inaugurated one of the largest merchandising campaigns since the end of the war. Clear, cool weather spurred consumer purchases of fall clothing and home appliances.

Mrs. Ben F. Whitaker's Miss Request, who was one of the best in the business last year, was the best of the eighteen -- at the weights and under the snarled traffic conditions -- in the $72,200 Beldame Handicap at Aqueduct yesterday.

TOKYO, Sept. 17 -- President Syngman Rhee of the Republic of South Korea, has sent a message to Gen. Douglas MacArthur that the Korean Government favors the conclusion of a peace treaty with Japan at the earliest possible date. This was announced today by Chun Han Pum, head of the Korean liaison mission here, after his return from a visit to Seoul.

The tiger shark is one of the largest, hungriest and fiercest of his genus. To verify some of the tales told about him, Dr. E. W. Gudger of the American Museum of Natural History fished for him in Florida waters, measured him, cut him up and studied his insides. This department is indebted to Dr. Gudger for information on the findings.

BAR HARBOR -- Although Labor Day may traditionally mark the end of the summer season in other parts of the country, that is not generally true here. From Kittery to Calais, and from Rumford to Caribou, activities are continuing as usual.
THE off - Broadway stage, which has often been the training ground for outstanding playwrights and actors, won significant concessions last week from Actors Equity Association.

ONE afternoon in 1927 Harold Ross sent me over to the Algonquin to pick up a timely Robert Benchley "casual," or short funny piece, not too much fun to write. This casual was overdue, and Ross was worried. Things had been known to happen to Benchley. Once he was taken unexpectedly to Europe when a ship sailed at midnight while he was seeing friends off in a merry cabin on A deck.

LAWRENCE, Kan., Sept. 17 (AP) -- Lindy Berry's spotty but timely passing and a methodical ground attack rolled the Texas Christian University Horned Frogs to a 28-0 victory over the Kansas Jayhawks in the football opener for both teams today.

I WONDER whether something really effective could be done by bringing the Equity Library Theatre productions closer to the public. Last season I saw productions of "Noah," a truly great play, and "King John," by Shakespeare.

THE ideal soil is a well-balanced combination of the basic materials of which earth is composed; that is sand, silt, clay, organic matter and humus. Unfortunately, such soil does not exist in a natural state -- but it can be built up.
COLLEGE STATION, Tex., Sept. 17 (AP) -- Villanova inflicted a 35-0 defeat on Texas A. and M. tonight -- the worst setback an Aggie football team has suffered in eighteen years.

THE hundredth anniversary of Chopin's death on Oct. 17 will certainly be roundly commemorated in New York. In fact, it will be almost a battle of the virtuosi. Vladimir Horowitz, Artur Rubinstein and 'Frank Sheridan will play all-Chopin programs that night.

TELEVISION in the theatre as the film exhibitor's best answer to the competition of home television was strongly advocated last week at the convention of the Theatre Owners of America here. Marcus Cohn, TOA television counsel, told exhibitors that five separate surveys during the past year have disclosed that owners of television receiving sets go to motion pictures less often than they used to.
The Canadian Steamship Company, which operated the fire-swept Noronic, also operates nine other vessels on the Great Lakes.
HONG KONG, Sept. 17 -- Sources here with knowledge of the inner politics of Chinese communism believe that at present the radical pro-Soviet faction is in the ascendancy in party councils.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -- The twelve nations bound by the North Atlantic pact created the framework of a Western military organization today in which the United States would participate "actively" in the defense planning of Europe.

ON the day that Chief Petty Officer Harold H. Reese, a young Southerner of 26, was discharged from the Navy four years ago, he read in the news papers that another young Southerner of 26, ex-Lieut. John Roosevelt Robinson, of whom he had never heard, had just been signed to play baseball for his own pre-war organization, the Brooklyn Dodgers.

GLEN COVE, L. I., Sept. 17 -- C. Raymond Petersen and George Van Nostrand of Brookville, the medalists, bowed to Vincent Fitzgerald and Henry J. Kowal, Dutchess, 1 up, in the quarter-final round of the Nassau Country Club member-guest golf tournament today.
BOSTON, Sept. 17 -- The reopening of schools and colleges in the area was uppermost in the minds of a majority of New England parents this week.

Amid the other uncertainties in the nation's labor and economic picture, a darkening of the prospects for more orderly and adequate production of coal can be viewed by the American public only with the greatest concern. The miners east of the Mississippi have, in a sense, been on strike since June 30.

IT is really not difficult to have a beautiful, lawn. Once properly established, a minimum of effort combined with good cultural practice will pay dividends. Although the best time for seeding is from the latter part of August to September 20, October or early November is preferable to spring for sowing grass.

"Compensation deals" are receiving greater attention in certain quarters in the foreign trade field as an apparent solution of the dollar shortage and the handicaps of a muddled foreign exchange situation. The idea itself is not new and has been used to some extent, but Government restrictions here and abroad were said to militate against its use in regular foreign trade channels.
Julius J. Rosen, civilian hearing examiner, is expected to announce his decision tomorrow in the Coast Guard case against Capt. Ragnar Eklund, former master of the American freighter Exmouth.

THOUGH I had made a number of films before the war, it was not until 1942 -- midway during the shooting of yet another of these commercially successful works -- that I realized that "it was no longer business as usual" for me, as, indeed, it was not for many other people.

The scoreboard of economic indicators has not changed materially from its forecast last fall of the continued downward readjustment trend. The semi-annual financial statements of the nation's industrial manufacturers confirmed that fact with a decline of 13 per cent in earnings from the corresponding first half of last year.

The Navy Department has taken a constructive position in requesting its officers to transmit their views on strategic and interservice problems through the usual channels. The mode of the request and the language in which it is couched do credit to the service and should help in avoiding some friction.

American colleges and universities have for many years prepared students for executive positions in business and industry. There has been, however, a need for the training of personnel on the supervisory level of management.

AMERICAN air travelers, who may have gathered from recent reports that they soon would be creeping along in the current piston-engine, transport while British-jet and turbo-propelled airliners zoomed by them, may relax.

JOE DAVID BROWN'S second novel is a turbulent adventure story -- a violent book. Necessarily so, for its hero is Horatio Tench, a red-haired, broad-shouldered, slim-waisted, six-feet-six stalwart with a fiery temper. Born in an English jail, suckled by a half-crazy black slave, reared in a bleak waifs' home and apprenticed at a tender age to a brutal rope maker, this early life did not soften his wild temper.
BOSTON, Sept. 17 -- Thirty-eight of Massachusetts' thirty-nine cities have entered the opening phases of their municipal election campaigns. Beverly, the thirty-ninth, will wait until 1950.

FRANKFORT, Sept. 17 -- One of the precepts of post-war Allied policy and wise German leadership has been that political instability of the Weimar Republic was caused by a multiplicity of parties. Now many observers here feel that a similar, and possibly explosive, situation is being generated in the new German Federal Republic.
BOSTON, Sept. 17 -- Defense, not their vaunted offense, kept the Red Sox in the pennant race as they clung grimly to a 3-2 edge over the Browns before 17,467 fanatics at Fenway Park today.

PLANDOME, L. I., Sept. 17 -- Borden Painter and Tom Foley of North Hills captured the annual member-guest tournament today at the Plandome Golf Club, turning back the favored combine of Jack Lamberti and Frank Strafaci of Pomonok, 1 up, in the final-round match.
In his otherwise interesting review of Elizabeth Janeway's novel, "The Question of Gregory," Mr. James Michener makes some curious statements that seem to me hardly capable of support.

PRAGUE, Sept. 17 -- In the absence of any possibility of agreement, the Communist Government of Czechoslovakia will in the next few weeks impose on the Catholic Church a unilateral "solution" of the issues between them. Against this solution, which is to be passed by Parliament in the form of a law on church salaries and expenses, the Catholic Church is raising a strong protest.

BUFFALO -- The New York State Automobile Dealers at their annual convention here last week called upon state highway officials to push completion of the long-awaited Thruway, the seventy-mile-an-hour express highway that will eventually link New York and Buffalo.

"GENTILITY" is a word rarely used seriously in these days, but nothing else quite so well describes the atmosphere of Elizabeth Daly's novels. Henry Gamadge, her charming and sympathetic bibliophile-detective, is a man so well-bred as to make Lord Peter Wimsey seem a trifle coarse.

Quite a number of large, legitimate theatres have been leased by radio broadcasting companies. This encroachment on the theatre reduces the prospects for the rising actors, besides taking the bread out of the mouths of the professional players.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was quiet yesterday and final prices were 1 to 9 points net lower.
Red Rolfe and his Tigers made their farewell exit at the Stadium yesterday and all but tore the door off the hinges on the way out.

LUXEMBOURG, Sept. 17 -- Negotiations are proceeding between the Luxembourg Government and several airlines looking toward the merger of airline services for greatly increased operations out of this country.

THIS fall many families who have just moved into new homes will be embarking on their first adventures in gardening. As one young woman recently said to me, "We want a flower garden, but we know nothing about, gardening.

ARDMORE, Pa., Sept. 17 -- A few miles from where she first learned to play golf at the age of 11 Mrs. Dorothy Germain Porter today annexed the United States women's amateur championship by vanquishing Miss Dorothy Kielty of Long Beach, Calif., 3 and 2, over the Merion Golf Club's east course.

The Coast Guard has asked for bids for construction of a $450,000 chapel at the United States Coast Guard Academy at New London, Conn., which will honor the memory of the men and women of the service who lost their lives in the last war.

ATHENS, Sept. 17 -- According to information submitted to Minister of Public Order Constantine Rentis by a group known as the Central Committee for Northern Epirus, Nicolas Zachariades, chief of the Greek Communist party, and his "Free Greece Government" are now established in Koritza (Korca) in southeastern Albania.

ONLY Thomas Merton -- Father Louis of the Order of Cistercians of the Strict Observance -- could have written single-handed this history of Trappist monks, for it is a work of diverse gifts and skills, an ardent collaboration of scholar and story-teller, priest and poet.

The Yanks protected their two-and-a-half-game American League pennant lead yesterday by defeating the Tigers, 5 to 4. The second-place Red Sox downed the Browns, 3 -- 2. In the National League, the Dodgers lost to the Pirates, 7 -- 2, but remained two and a half games behind the leading Cards, who were beaten by the Braves, 4 to 2.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Sept. 17 -- More than 10,000 chemists and chemical engineers from all parts of the country will convene here this week for the 116th national meeting of the American Chemical Society.

THE apple has an international flavor, today's recipes seem to say. Experts on three foreign cuisines, where the fruit sustains a role as important as in the pie that sums up American cookery, tell how apple desserts are done "back home."

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 17 -- Negotiations among representatives of four striking brotherhoods and the Missouri Pacific Railroad appeared to be deadlocked today with the unions expected to reject the company's latest proposal for ending the ten-day walkout of 5,200 trainmen.

THE design of this book is both interesting and ambitious. In it Mr. Nicholas has endeavored "to suggest the interplay between the personal life of a man and the overmatching multi-human life of which he is a part." Here history is presented in terms of individual Americans.

LONDON -- At the British Medical Association House in Tavistock Square in the center of London, the problems of the national health system have temporarily been put aside as Britain's medical profession prepares to be host next month to the third general assembly of the World Medical Association.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 17 -- Pennsylvania Railroad carloadings last week dropped to 89,025, reflecting Labor Day lay-offs and fewer loadings the following Saturday. This compares with 125,064 cars loaded a year ago, decrease of 28.8 per cent.

"FERMENT IN THE FAR EAST" surveys the whole restless Orient. As its focus is on China rather than on this country's relationship to China, the book provides an interesting perspective in which to study the State Department's recent White Paper.
THE new season opens with a broadside of nine group shows that run the whole gamut from down to earth naturalism to the ultimate points reached by abstract painting in 1949.

WHITE HORSE, Pa., Sept. 17 -- Alvin Untermyer won a leg on the Redding Furnace Farms Challenge Cup today when his 7-year-old brown gelding, Done Sleeping, triumphed by four lengths at the third annual fall meeting of the Radnor Hunt Club.

Paris has turned a spotlight on the upper part of the torso. Shoulders, after seasons of drooping unobtrusivehess, begin to expand, not by padding this time, but by various artificez applied to the shoulder line, by sleeves. standing away from the arm, by strategically placed tabs, wings or folds.

SHANGHAI, Sept. l7 -- Within two to five years China will be self-sufficient in cotton, Jao Shushih, secretary of the East China Bureau of the Chinese Communist party, said yesterday, according to a report in today's issue of the party organ, Liberation Daily.

THE phenomenon of Richard Strauss is one of the most curious of modern music. It is indeed almost unique in the history of the art. For example: It has long been acknowledged that Richard Strauss had outlived his creative period at least a quarter of a century before he died last week.

PARIS, Sept. 17 -- France in the first nine months of this year has made remarkable progress toward recovery. The leaders of her Government have been making the most of this fact at a time when Premier Henri Queuille and his Cabinet have completed a year in office.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 17 (AP) -- National Champion Richard Gonzales and Wimbledon Ruler Ted Schroeder, picking up where they left off at Forest Hills earlier this month, will meet in the final round of the twenty-third annual Pacific Southwest tennis tournament tomorrow.

DAISY was a young draft horse who imagined herself slim, dainty and graceful as a pony. As she raced across the fields, a little upside-down bird made fun of her clumsy cavorting. One day the farmer groomed the animals for the country fair. Daisy was very happy as she stepped daintily into the ring and reared excitedly. When she found that she was to compete with heavy work horses, she hung her head in shame.

Increased shortages of industrial materials loom as soon as Government buying offices release new orders now held back by lagging legislation in Congress, it was learned here yesterday. The foregoing developed in a canvass of more than twenty industrial producers of equipment and supplies used by Federal agencies.

GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 17 -- Gordon Lindsay and his guest from the Westchester Country Club, Fred Mayer, scored a best-ball round of 33, 34 -- 67, four under par, to lead thirty-four teams in winning the one-day member-guest golf tournament at the Greenwich Country Club today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -- Four and one-half long, frustrating years passed before Franklin Roosevelt could name a man of his own liking to the Supreme Court. Angered and restive over seeing his pet New Deal projects smashed down by the "nine old men," Mr. Roosevelt even attempted the desperate plan of "packing" the highest court.
Seasonal retail trade activity broadened last week, but dollar volume ran under the comparative period of last year. Estimates put department store sales at about 5 per cent under 1948.

A new concept of Christianity as a faith that must be applied in daily life has been given to young German Christians by students from American universities who have been spending their summer vacations at their own expense helping rebuild shattered lives and reconstruct buildings ruined by bombs.

BERKELEY, Calif., Sept. 17 (UP) -- Coach Lynn Waldorf added a pass attack to his famed end sweeps and double reverses today and it paid off as his injury-riddled University of California Bears came from behind to defeat Santa Clara, 21 to 7.

LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., Sept. 17 -- Concluding a competition that was one of the closest in the history of the event, Glen Erin, an Irish-bred 6-year-old, rounded out one of his most successful campaigns since being brought to the United States two years ago by being named conformation hunter champion at the Piping Rock Horse Show today.

THE weather report read: "Clear and cool today; fair and cool tonight; cool tomorrow."

In Mary Roche's "Living in a Glass House," which described the novel home of architectural designer Philip C. Johnson at New Canaan, Conn., one of the photographs showed an over-scale sculpture which, according to the caption, "dominated" part of the house.

An official of the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company, which last weak became the defendant in a civil anti-trust suit, implied yesterday that loss of the case threaten the entire manufacturing and distributing system of the country.

In promotions here last week retailers stressed misses' wool jersey blouses, boys' clothing, rodless curtains and gold rings, according to a survey made especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by the Retail News Bureau, Inc.

GLADYS HASTY CARROLL, author of "As the Earth Turns," has again written about the section of New England that she knows so well. Molly, the heroine of this novel, is a young girl, lonely and unwanted. Brad, the country boy who proposes to her, does so out of kindness.

THE summer's parade of lilies is ending now, with the long slender white trumpets of formosanums on stalks six feet high Before they fade and planting bulbs for next year begins, it might be well to pause and review the past season.

IF you think back to the early Thirties, you will remember a tremendous advertising campaign that was built around the theme that "spit is a horrid word -- put it's worse at the end of a cigar." * * * There is an even more horrid word -- and it's worse at the end of a picture -- "censorship."

Rearmament to fight the Western democracies is one of three major tasks given to the Communist-dominated regimes in the Soviet satellites in Eastern Europe, a Pravda article read over the Moscow radio's home service last Tuesday disclosed.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 17 -- Little Murry Dickson did a tremendous favor for his former Cardinal teammates today when he held the Dodgers to five hits and no earned runs while the Pirates hammered Jack Banta and Erv Palica for a 7-2 victory to sweep the two-game series.
SPRING FIELD, Mass., Sept. 17 (AP) -- Invention of a suitcase-size gadget that tells doctors of the presence of diabetes in their patients in three minutes flat was announced today.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 17 -- Although there were only five trading days during the past week, retail business activity in the Twelfth District held to a moderate loss as compared to a year ago. Reports from larger stores showed losses ranging from 4 per cent in San Diego and Spokane to 12 per cent in the Los Angeles area.

A great many out-of-town buyers visited the wholesale garment market here last week to cover holiday lines and a large number of early orders were placed, according to a report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell Company, resident buying office. Activity in fall merchandise has been excellent, but deliveries of wanted items are poor, it was said.

TO the possible dismay of Catskill resort proprietors, people throughout the nation are about to get the real flavor of the borscht circuit without venturing any farther from home than the neighborhood Bijou.

COBLESKILL, N. Y., Sept. 17 -- State Housing Commissioner Herman. T. Stichman attacked New York City's "non-cash-subsidized" housing program as "feudalistic" today in an address at the laying of the cornerstone for the new residence hall at the New York State Institute of Agriculture and Home Economics.

ROME, Sept. 17 -- Hopes of early settlement of the seamen's strike waned today when the Government authorized the steamship line Italia to lay up the liners Vulcania and Amerigo Vespucci and the steamship line Sitmar to lay up the liner Castelbianco, putting the striking crews ashore.

THIS is the story of Abigail Hawes' first year at Waban Hall. Abby, who has been privately educated abroad, has more than the usual shocks and pleasures ahead of her as she enters her freshman year. Mrs. Woody has a firm hold on the indispensable ingredients of a good story.

NOT the least valuable work English publishers are doing is to issue reprints. These replace the large stocks destroyed in the war and recover a number of minor classics. Two have interested me particularly. First, Raymond Postgate has done a new Boswell's Johnson which has cut out the tedious letters, the analysis of the books, the lists of variant readings and the recommendations of devotional books no longer obtainable or interesting to the ordinary reader.

LIKE the seasonal fluctuation of personnel in a huge office building, the major nighttime radio programs continue to flock back from their summer vacations. The influx this week includes eleven commercial shows which are resuming business, two new sustainers, and one public service series on the United Nations.

TRUST the lovelier sex to have the last word all the time, even with a mayor. Asked to present Mayor O'Dwyer with the first ticket to the New York City Reporters Association party next month, Mary Martin, star of "South Pacific," had a 5:15 P. M. date at City Hall the other day.
OMAHA, Sept. 17 -- Warm debate over how the natural resources of the Missouri River basin shall be developed continued at an accelerated pace this week.

Days shorten toward the length of night and that astronomical moment we call the autumnal equinox approaches. Summer is about to end, officially, and autumn to arrive, though it is difficult to understand just why two minutes difference in the length of daylight and darkness should mark the change of seasons.
"WHY can't we do this more often?" sighs the returning American vacationist, as he packs away his summer shorts and braces himself for the eleven and a half months before his next vacation.
CINCINNATI, Sept. 17 (AP) -- Russ Meyer won his fourteenth game of the season today as he throttled Cincinnati with three hits to give Philadelphia a 4-to-0 victory over the Reds.

George H. Copeland's"Meanings, Official" on standardized cataloguing I of government property serves to emphasize the importance of a uniform and unambiguous nomenclature but implies that the undertaking described is of .recent inception.

RIVERHEAD, L. I., Sept. 17 -- Real estate owned by the bankrupt Long Island Rail Road Company in the towns of Riverhead, Brookhaven, Islip, Huntington and Smithtown is to be advertised by the county of Suffolk for sale for the last half installment of state, county and town taxes levied on Dec. 1, 1948.

SCRANTON, Pa., Sept. 17 -- A new chapter in the history of the so-called "Scranton Plan" was begun here this week when the advisory committee of the Junior Chamber of Commerce voted unanimously to recommend the immediate transfer of its Better Homes Show Fund of $8,400, plus the anticipated net proceeds of the forthcoming October exposition, to the "Scranton New Industry Fund," aimed at further industrial expansion in Scranton.

THE autumn frenzy of bulb ordering is in full swing. Some gardeners have probably ordered so many already that it is hard to imagine where they can be put. The saving grace of this particular form of horticultural excess is that bulbs take up so little room and are appropriate to so many places that there always seems to be some spot that will hold a few more.

The first full year of operation under the higher fares put into effect on the municipal transit lines on July 1, 1948, yielded revenues which exceeded operating expenses by $13,353,085, according to a report made available yesterday by the Board of Transportation.

FROM the outside cover, Gloria Hoffman's "Primitivo" looks as if it might be a folio of anthropological photographic studies. Inside, it is seen at once to be the story, not of a people, some "primitive type," but of a most attractive little Mexican boy, Primitivo, devoted to his dog, Fonzo.

CHICAGO, Sept. 17 (AP) -- Wheat futures on the Board of Trade were firm today on scattered buying after a weak start. Other grains were firm with wheat, while soybeans advanced more than a cent a bushel most of the time.
TORONTO, Sept. 17 -- Following is a list of the first dead in the Noronic disaster to be identified and the known survivors:

BOLTON LANDING, N. Y., Sept. 17 (AP) -- Representative Kenneth B. Keating of Rochester said tonight that the recent "five-per-center" inquiry in Washington indicated that "scandalous conduct in high places" had reached its "full flower."

Twenty-one new cases of poliomyelitis were reported yesterday by the Health Department here during the twenty-four hours ended at 9 A. M. yesterday. This marks a decline from the thirty-two reported for the corresponding period ended at 9 A. M. Friday.

With comparative freedom from crippling strikes (although not relieved of the threat of work stoppage) and with an improving flow of materials, the automobile industry has reached a new peak of production. Preliminary estimates by the Automobile Manufacturers Association show more than 4,200,000 vehicles built in the first eight months of 1949, including 3,400,000 new passenger cars.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 17 -- The break-up of New York negotiations to settle the Hawaiian longshoremen's strike and two hearings on the West Coast dealing with the strike had Coast residents asking two major questions this week: (1) How can the strike, which began May 1, be settled? (2) Can it be settled without further affecting West Coast shipping, already hard hit?

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -- The foreign policy spokesmen of the United States and Britain presented individual but almost uniformly gloomy appraisals of the Chinese situation today in a discussion of Far Eastern affairs with France.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 17 -- The major immediate development in the Arab world is the retreat of the United Nations economic mission to the Middle East from its plan for the resettlement of Palestinian Arab refugees.

FORT DIX, N. J., Sept. 17 -- Thousands of civilians joined the Air Force today in paying tribute to Major Thomas B. McGuire Jr., the Ridgewood, N. J., air hero, in whose memory the McGuire Air Force base was dedicated this afternoon.

The treatment of real estate taxes as accrued deductions from income for Federal income-tax purposes has been complicated by variances in state and local laws as to when such taxes become liens upon property and when assessments become due and payable.

CAMDEN, N. J., Sept. 17 -- Leaders of industry, business and government of an eight-county area in Eastern Pennsylvania and South Jersey will meet next week in an attempt to salvage some of the program of port development wrecked when the Legislatures of Pennsylvania and New Jersey earlier this year failed to create the proposed Delaware River Port Authority.

AFTER television in the summer a Jack Benny joke is nothing to be scorned, but even with the odds in his favor the pride of Waukegan was excessively reluctant last Sunday to go back to work. Returning to CBS radio in the 7 o'clock period, Mr. B's first show ran the gamut of hoary gags from miserliness to Phil Harris' bourbon.

HAVERFORD, Pa., Sept. 17 -- A group of scientists and engineers who propose "to foster throughout the world a tradition of personal moral responsibility for the consequence for humanity of professional activity," formed the Society for Social Responsibility in Science at a meeting here.

CHICAGO, Sept. 17 (AP) -- The long and costly Chicago newspaper printers' strike may be ended tomorrow when the 1,500 striking printers will vote on whether to accept a contract that would give them a $10 weekly wage increase and permit the hiring of experienced non-union employes in composing rooms.

NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 17 -- The Indian Government reiterated today its claim on the three rivers flowing from East Punjab in this Dominion into West Punjab in Pakistan. It declared "internation law has no application in this case" as the sharing of the canal waters of the divided Punjab was governed by an agreement sined by the two governments in May, 1948.
Yugoslavia and China were still the key points last week on the world-wide battlefield of the "cold war."

With the opening of most American colleges and universities during the next ten days, attention has once again turned to the question of overcrowding. During the past four post-war years, veterans have jammed the colleges at a rate of more than a million annually.

RICHMOND, Va., Sept. 17 -- Disappointing prices for flue-cured tobacco caused wide concern in rural areas of the Upper South this week. Markets opened on the "old belt" but tobacco auctioneers, chanting their way down aisles of golden leaf, could not produce bids up to those of last year.

IN his prosperous and extravagantly venerated old age, Whittier gave an inquiring youth the sure-fire formula for success: "My lad, if thou wouldst win success, join thyself to some unpopular but noble cause."

TOKYO, Sept. 12 -- An interesting theory is being advanced here that Japan, fount years after the surrender, now is in a position to feed herself, despite repeated requests for about 2,000,000 tons annually of imported foodstuffs furnished largely by United States relief funds.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -- All of Congress, rather than only half of it as at present, will be back on the job next week when the House returns Wednesday from its prolonged holiday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 (AP) -- The Labor Department reported today that new jobs had opened up for construction workers and that prospects were good for long-range employment in almost all building trades.
BERLIN, Sept. 17 -- Three British soldiers who escaped Thursday night from a Soviet jail admitted today that they were AWOL from their regiments when apprehended in the Soviet sector.

LAKE SUCCESS, Sept. 17 -- The United States will support in the United Nations General Assembly a plan for the parceling of the former Italian colonies that calls for the independence of a united Libya within eighteen months to five years.

In Cambridge, Mass., the other day, Dr. Vannevar Bush sat down at a typewriter keyboard and tapped out a few sentences which were automatically photographed and so transferred to engraved printing plates. Mrs. Tracy S. Voorhees, wife of the Under-Secretary of the Army, has been named secretary of the campaign committee of Brooklyn Borough President John Cashmore, Democratic candidate for re-election, it was announced yesterday at the campaign headquarters, 44 Court Street.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Sept. 17 (AP) -- Michael J. Quill, president of the Transport Workers Union, CIO, today accused Communists of trying to disrupt unions affiliated with the CIO.

WHAT is a house? Is it, as Corbusier with fanatical fervor urges, a living machine, approaching as much as possible to an up-to-date clinic with the furniture suggesting and almost smelling of the operating room? A living machine it was, no doubt, to our paleolithic ancestors, a strictly totalitarian affair, although phenic acid was in the remote future.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Sept. 17 -- Dr. Frantisek Onderik, Apostolic Administrator at Cesky Tesin (Teschen), has issued a statement approving the Government's proposed new church law despite the fact that it has been condemned as unacceptable by the rest of the Catholic hierarchy, the official Czechoslovak news agency announced tonight.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -- Russia has more than 5,000,000 men under arms and is constantly increasing her military strength, the Senate Foreign Relations and Armed Services committees reported today.

SOME time, in every child's life, there comes a turning point when he begins to sense the desirability of order. Suddenly, miraculously, he shows signs of becoming almost neat. Architect Oscar Stonorov, himself the father of three, offered this observation at the symposium on "Designing the Modern Home," held at the Baltimore Museum of Art.

It is regrettable that the Economic and Social Council of the United Nations at its recent meeting in Geneva failed once more to initiate a worldwide inquiry into practices of forced labor. The United States, Britain and other democratic countries in the United Nations have long sought to direct the searchlight of public inquiry into the darkest blot on our civilization -- forced labor.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 17 -- Henry A. Wallace told a national conference arranged by the Progressive Party today that a general welfare state was inevitable and at hand in the United States, and that the attitude of big business would determine whether or not the movement would be Marxist in its concept and execution.

Concessions granted Britain in the way of modifications in United States tariff rates and customs regulations can give only a slight fillip to Britain's efforts to increase exports to this country, bankers and economists said last week.

The burning of the Noronic yesterday ranks as one of the worst peacetime shipping disasters in North American history. It was the first major maritime tragedy in peacetime since the burning of the Morro Castle on Sept. 8, 1934, off Asbury Park, N. J., in which 134 persons perished.

THERE is no balm in New Gilead (Conn.) for Eleanor Shafer, the sensitive and intelligent daughter of that town's most distinguished citizen. Believing herself responsible for the death of her lover, she runs off to Mexico. Here, too, every moment is spent in self-flagellation.
CANTON, China, Sept. 17 (AP) -- A battle was reported raging today for the island of Pingtan, just off the mainland near Communist-held Foochow.

ON the foreign front last week developments were on the cheerful side. The conference on the British "dollar crisis" came off nicely. The Reciprocal Trade Agreements bill was passed by the Senate without the restrictive amendments that were voted by the last Congress.

THE sports situation in television for the coming season continues to be confused. The various networks' commitments for events in Madison Square Garden came to an end in May and have not been renewed with the exception of the Friday night boxing bouts which are carried by NBC-TV and sponsored by the Gillette Safety Razor Co.

MOST of us lose appreciation of how essential fine acting is to the vitalization of a picture -- until we see a superbly acted film. This may be because our natural senses absorb so much average stimuli that a form of esthetic amnesia inevitably sets in -- amnesia, of course, being noted as a definite mechanism of defense.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 (AP) -- A $100 increase in the amount of duty-free goods a United States tourist may bring back from abroad has been approved by the Senate.

Discovery of forty-four original glass plate negatives formerly the property of Matthew B. Brady, famous Civil War photographer, was announced yesterday by the Ansco division of the General Aniline and Film Corporation at Binghamton, N. Y.

A law-science program has been set up by Tulane University, New Orleans, to bring about an effective integration between the fields of law and medicine. New courses and seminars being planned by the university's schools of law and medicine will aim at the more complete training of trial lawyers in the science of proof, handling of personal-injury litigation and in the elements of legal psychiatry.
Looking ahead to the coming campaign, the National Association of Approved Basketball Officials yesterday held its annual rules interpretation meeting at the Hotel Biltmore.

CHICAGO, Sept. 17 -- The Mine, Mill and Smelters Workers, a Leftwing affiliate of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, wound up its week-long convention hero today with the nomination of John Clark of Great Falls, Mont., the incumbent, for president without opposition.

By adding up the number of degrees of heat required to bring the pea crop to maturity under New York conditions, farmers may be able to reduce harvesting gluts. The "heat unit" system for measuring the maturity of crops has been used for several years in Minnesota by one of the world's largest canners of peas, sweet corn and snap beans.

WAKE FOREST, N. C., Sept. 17 -- An alert Wake Forest football team showed that it had the strength to rank with the better outfits in the South this season when it gave Duquesne a 22-to-7 beating today that was much more severe than the score indicated.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Sept. 17 (AP) -- Sam A. Mason 2d's Westhampton, victor in his last two starts here, was a length and one-half winner of the $10,000 added Seashore Stakes, top event on today's card.

CANNES, France, Sept. 17 (AP) -- A. British-made film with two American stars won the Grand Prize of the Cannes Film Festival, judges announced today. The film was "The Third Man," starring Joseph Cotten, Valli, Orson Welles and Siegfried Breuer.
MOST people would be moderately amused -- others a little startled -- if asked whether a T-bone steak and psychiatry could be used interchangeably for the treatment of delinquents.

The meeting of the Foreign Ministers of the Atlantic Pact nations, which opened in Washington yesterday, acted swiftly within its limited terms of reference to set up the provided council and machinery for defense planning. It gave prompt and visible confirmation to a meeting of minds that had already taken place.

WHEN the Western German Republic formally came into existence last week, the development was commemorated with 10-pfennig green and 20pf red stamps, copies of which reached J. H. Stolow here by airmail.

THAT amazing and sometimes amusing branch of the lively arts known as "science fiction" is enjoying, at the moment, a certain respectability. Once relegated almost exclusively to "the pulps," it is currently being promoted as a slick-paper, hardcover variety of literature.

SAN ANTONIO, Sept. 17 -- The first ten weeks of the integration of the white and Negro Air Force enlistees taking their initial training, has been completed without discord, it was stated today by Maj. Gen. Charles W. Lawrence, commanding general of the indoctrination division of the Air Force air training command.

MANILA, Sept. 17 -- Political excitement gripped this country as the Supreme Court ruled against President Elpidio Quirino's use of wartime emergency powers to keep the Government machinery operating despite the failure of Congress to authorize funds for the fiscal year 1949-50.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 (AP) -- The Interstate Commerce Commission said today that the International-Great Northern Railroad should have rights equal to those of the Texas Mexican Railway in the use of the International Bridge over the Rio Grande at Laredo, Tex.

In 1895 Prof. Ludwig Rehn called the attention of German surgeons to his important discovery that out of forty-five workers in an aniline-dye plant three had succumbed to cancer of the bladder. His observations were verified later in Germany, Switzerland and England.

BEHIND the gardener stands an army of hybridizers, and manufacturers and researchers diligently working to lessen his labors and increase his rewards. Their efforts are manifest each year in the debut of new varieties peculiar to the season, not to mention new equipment and insecticides that appear on the marker. Fall, 1949, is no exception.

THE farmer is well aware that a system of rotation of crops is necessary to produce the best harvests. The average home gardener, however, is apt to ignore this principle when it comes to tilling his small vegetable plot.

LAKE SUCCESS, Sept. 17 -- The General Assembly of the United Nations will open its fourth annual session on Tuesday in a vastly more hopeful atmosphere than the one which prevailed a year ago, when the "cold war" was at its height and some delegates even saw a possibility that the Assembly's Paris session might be shortened by some crisis arising out of the Soviet blockade of Berlin.

LONDON, Sept. 17 -- With undiminished optimism, Sir Stafford Cripps, Chancellor of the Exchequer, stepped out of a plane at London Airport tonight and hurried at once to 10 Downing Street to prepare reports to Prime Minister Attlee and the country on what the financial decisions taken in Washington mean to Britain.

IN this handsome and well organized volume Mr. Born applies the tidy, scrupulous methods of European art history to an analysis of the successive phases of our landscape painting from the Revolution to the present. Familiar ground is resurveyed; new ground is broken, with unjustly forgotten artists being resurrected, or inflated reputations brought down to their proper size.

LAWRENCE, Mass., Sept. 17 (AP) -- Five young convicts escaped from Essex County jail today after slugging guards and stealing revolvers from the jail arsenal. In a broadcast throughout New England, police reported that the fugitives were heavily armed.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 (AP) -- Passage of measures by Congress extending reciprocal trade agreements opens the doors of American markets to "a flood tide of imported unemployment," Senator George W. Malone, Republican, of Nevada, said today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 (AP) -- Testimony that "official representatives" of Yugoslavia had directly aided Communist propaganda activity here was made public tonight by a Senate Judiciary subcommittee.

A point by point refutation of charges that the Maritime Commission had departed from the provisions of the Merchant Marine Act of 1936 in awarding subsidies for construction of six new liners, was presented last week to Chairman Porter Hardy Jr. of the House Expenditures subcommittee by Granville Mellen, vice chairman of the commission.

ONE secret of Mr. Tunis' popularity is his ability to write a sports story that is more than a sports story. He discards the old formula to write about people who happen to move in the world of sports. The drama in this new story arises from a conflict between two people, a father and son, both professional ball players.

Whether H. R. Trevor-Roper ("Hitler Reappraised, Ten Years After") is right in attributing to Hitler a mind of great power or whether one sees in him a disastrous freak upshot of a troubled age remains open to discussion.

United States-flag vessels during the first three months of 1949 continued to carry less than 50 per cent of Marshall Plan cargoes, according to the fourth quarterly report of the Economic Cooperation Administration, recently submitted to Congress.

New York steel warehouses are discouraging industrial buyers from engaging in "panicky buying" because of fears of the steel strike threat, since warehouse inventories of steel in this area are estimated to equal about 6 to 8 weeks requirements of customers except for a very few scarce items.

EVEN before Tommy Mardon signed on the Hatteras in San Francisco as an ordinary seaman, he knew trouble was brewing. A ruthless gang was out to take over the ship. Before the Hat teras reached its South American destination, Tommy escaped death a half-dozen times, more than once through the aid of his mysterious watch-mate.

In your Science in Review column in THE NEW YORK TIMES of July 10 there is an interesting discussion of a report submitted to the American Water Works Association on "Tap-Water Fluoride." One sentence reads: "Too much or too little fluoride may have consequences that cannot be foreseen at present."

IN far-off affluent days, a poker game frequently took place at the old Waldorf-Astoria. One of the players -- let's call him Mr. X -- was sometimes induced to join. The method was to have each of the other five or six men give Mr. X a hundred dollars' worth of chips on the condition of his remaining in the game at least an hour.

"There is no authority for assuming that the brain works like a mechanical or electronic machine," says Prof. Geoffrey Jefferson of the University of Manchester, England. "There is definite similarity, especially on the small scale of two nerve cells. But it may be a great mistake to assume that nerve action is the same throughout the infinitely complex human nervous system."

A CINEMATIC counterpart to the little theatre movement is rapidly developing into sizable proportions in this country. Since the war, somewhere in the neighborhood of 200 film societies have been organized by persons whose interest in the film medium goes beyond the purely entertainment functions of the commercial theatre.

SHANGHAI, Sept. 17 -- "Dialectical and Historical Materialism," written by Premier Stalin of the Soviet Union, has been adopted by the Higher Education Commission in Peiping as the basic textbook for teaching the "new philosophy" in North China's colleges and universities, according to the Shanghai newspaper Wen Wei Pao.

Hungary 'Confessional' Gregory Zinovieff, one of the defendants in the Moscow treason trials of the middle Thirties, made these statements in his testimony: "I am determined to tell the truth. * * * I am guiltier than Trotsky because I was here doing the actual work. * * * I am guilty of every charge in the indictment."

The "welfare state" theory is doing more to combat "extremist tendencies" than any other single factor in this country, Rabbi Louis I. Newman said yesterday in his sermon at Temple Rodeph Sholom, 7 West Eighty-third Street.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -- Dr. Roy J. Defarrari, secretary general of The Catholic University of America, was appointed today director of the seventy-two volume series, The Fathers of the Church, in accordance with the wishes of the late Dr. Ludwig Schopp, originator of the project.

PRINCETON, N. J., Sept. 17 -- Coach Charlie Caldwell was still far from satisfied today after watching his Princeton football team battle through a three-hour scrimmage With Columbia in Palmer Stadium.

THE drought damage that is apparent on evergreens this fall may be as nothing compared to the loss that ix apt to result next spring. At that time, evergreens will really show the effects of the 1949 dry spell. Fortunately, something can be done to counteract this prospect.

Contrary to all expectations, housewares retailers may approach last year's record volume or even surpass it, buyers reported last week. Because of unexpectedly good August business, which has continued into the first two weeks of the current month, many stores are now running from 3 to 7 per cent ahead of last year and almost all are breaking even, it was reported.

Registration for "Great Books" discussion groups, for a new science discussion group, for current affairs groups and other free adult education programs sponsored by the New York Public Library, is open in the branches or at the Readers' Adviser's Office at Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street.

HERE is a new collection of sermons and lectures by C. S. Lewis, the Oxford don and the author of "The Screwtape Letters," who in the course of the Nineteen Forties has achieved recognition in England and America as an extraordinarily gifted and significant Christian apologist.

GEORGE WELLER is both a novelist and a reporter. He has won a Pulitzer Prize for his dispatches as foreign correspondent for The Chicago Daily News, and he holds the much rarer distinction of having written (back in the Thirties) one of the really good novels about college life. His new book is the product of Weller's two vocations -- a large-scale political novel of modern Greece.

HACKETTSTOWN, N. J., Sept. 17 -- From the haphazard and often underpaid method of selling livestock to roving dealers conditions in this area have improved to a point where farmers may consign their animals to be sold at competitive bidding in a non-profit organization here.
ALEXANDRIA, Va., Sept. 17 (UP) -- President Truman jumped the gun on the football season here today by presiding at a game between the Quantico Marines and Virginia Polytechnic Institute.

OTTAWA'S 1949 tourist trade promises to beat even the record set in 1948. The Canadian Government Travel Bureau has estimated that this year's tourist revenues will pass the $300,000,000 mark. The vacation industry now ranks second to the export of newsprint as a source of United States dollars.

The New York State Constitution provides that municipal elections be held in odd-numbered years, while election of state and national officers goes on in even-numbered ones. This is a normally successful device designed to separate local issues from state and national ones.

THROUGHOUT the midlands there is already a great deal of activity in preparation for another season of the theatre -- a season that is all but unknown to Broadway, but nevertheless, an important and vital force in the American theatre. Some 176 community theatres, stock companies, college and university theatres have an established season with a repertoire of five to twenty plays drawing an audience of more than 600,000.

FROM these famous lines, Father Norman Weyand, S. J., and his eleven Jesuit contributors take their title for this symposium on Gerard Manley Hopkins. The reason for adding one more critical volume to the already bulging Hopkins shelf is clearly explained in a preface:
WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 (AP) -- Secretary of the Interior Krug authorized the Bureau of Land Management today to sell timber from public lands administered by the Bureau of Reclamation.

Unruh's running amok in Camden has, as was to be expected, stirred up anew the controversial issue of over-all arms registration. We all agree that dangerous souvenir handguns in the hands of irresponsible people should be rendered harmless. But on such occasions there is always the danger of going over the top in efforts for "safety" legislation.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., Sept. 17 -- Emil Mosbacher's International Susan, Dr. James W. Benfield's Herreshoff S boat Nepenthe, Van Wyck Loornis' Atlantic Hound and the 110 Interim, belonging to the Willcox family, were among the winners today in the regatta of the Horseshoe Harbor Yacht Club.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, Sept. 17 (UP) -- Winston Churchill was named today in Hungary's mass treason and espionage trials as one of the top plotters among Britons, Americans and Yugoslavs accused of having schemed to seize the Balkans.

GENERAL impressions by a single observer are fallible and may not be supported by other observers, but he would be a bold man who went against the consensus that the third Edinburgh Festival of Music and Drama has been a success.

AFTER the Doolittle raid on Tokyo in 1942, one of the planes ran out of gasoline and was forced to land in Khabarovsk, Siberia. Although Russia was our ally, she was not then at war with Japan. Having no wish to incur the enmity of that country, she interned the crew of five Americans, and "Guests of the Kremlin" is an account of their thirteen months' imprisonment in the Soviet Union.

SALT LAKE CITY, Sept. 17 -- Utahans were jolted this week by the issuance of an impartial report by Dr. Ira V. Hiscock of Yale University terming Utah's State Health Department problems "the most acute in the nation."
LONDON, Sept. 17 (Reuters) -- The five teams entering today's play undefeated in this season's English League soccer emerged from their frays with records intact.

AT the end of World War II the American mind went home from the scene of its two greatest military victories -- Germany and Japan. There were other preoccupations -- getting back to politics, getting the economy readjusted to peace, just forgetting about war.

WESTBURY, L. I., Sept. 17 -- Laddie Sanford's Hurricanes and Argentina's El Trebol Four, opponents in tomorrow's final round match of the thirty-third National Open polo championship on International Field, engaged in tune-up matches today at the Meadow Brook Club.
CHICAGO, Sept. 17 (AP) -- The Cubs, aided by Hank Sauer's twenty-eighth home run, defeated the Giants, 4 -- 2, today. It was New York's sixth straight loss.

Suspense surrounding the steel-wage controversy and the British dollar crisis eased last week, and sentiment improved in financial markets. This found reflection in a stronger stock market and a check to the decline in the pound sterling.

COLORADO SPRINGS -- Motorists in a hurry to reach California should stick to the main highway routes north or south of Colorado. On the other hand, for those who can spare a few days for pure scenic delight, this is the season of seasons to head for Denver or Colorado Springs, the best starting points for a week's Leisurely ramble through the High Rockies to Salt Lake City.

As the operators of summer theatres put up their shutters, I'd like to sound a warning which, I believe, they would do well to ponder during the long winter months ahead. For it is my belief that summer stock companies may be ruined in the next decade by their concentration on stars.

IN mystery fiction, ex-intelligence men (Naval or OSS or BMI) usually devote their talents to counter-espionage and eschew the slower-moving routines of simple homicide. In "Engaged to Murder," Rick Vanner (a counter-spy from away back) has to help his consul in Buenos Aires with a murder case which, in other surroundings and circumstances, might be beneath his notice.

SAN FRANCISCO -- A new low-priced twin-lens reflex camera, the Royce Reflex, was introduced at the Photographic dealers and finishers convention here last week. The $49.95 camera has a Wollensak Alphax shutter with built-in synchronization and a Wollensak f/4.5 anastigmat taking lens coupled with an f/3.5 viewing lens.

SINCE the summer was torrid enough on its own account, it is a good thing that Joyce Redman was not playing Anne Boleyn here then. The heat she generates in the part would have sent the swollen mercury through the top of the glass. Miss Redman is a brief and slight young lady, as Anne seems also to have been.

FRITZ Peters' meticulous record of what passed through the distorted mind of his protagonist during the brief hospitalization covered by "The World Next Door" will undoubtedly limit his first novel's audience to persons willing to pass up sustained narrative interest for the sake of detailed case-history.

ABE BURROWS gets up late. Not quite so late as the format of his Friday night CBS show would imply -- "Breakfast With Burrows," at 9:30 P. M. -- but tardily enough to be the envy of farmers, members of the armed forces and the average office worker.

FOR many years the brief, daily essays of George Matthew Adams have been popular with newspaper readers. Concerned with such varied topics as first editions, prayer, friendship, roads, dogs, anger, pie, immortality and pencils, the articles have appeared in hundreds of American and Canadian papers.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -- There must be some limit somewhere some day to the spectacular feats Wild Bill Cantrell of Louisville, Ky., can do in a speed boat. But so far there's no stop ping him. Today the same rugged, heavy-footed darevil who also drives fast autos at Indianapolis, hung up two new records in winning the first fifteen-mile heat for the President's Cup, and won it so easily he made it look ridiculously simple.

The American people will extend profound sympathy to those who were bereaved in yesterday's ship fire at Toronto. This sympathy goes to American families and to our Canadian neighbors, for this was a disaster for both peoples.

LONDON, Sept. 17 -- Cornelius Vanderbilt Whitney, Under-Secretary of Commerce, said today that there is a new group of potential tourists in the United States that could be induced with little effort to spend dollars in Europe. He mentioned especially middle income groups and farm families of the Middle West.

Whatever possibility there was for lower steel prices last July when the industry's production took a sharp dip, the chance of a price decline now is extremely remote, several of the major companies reported last week.
ATLANTA, Ga., Sept. 17 -- Optimism took a larger place in the economic picture in this area during this week.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 (UP) -- A National Labor Relations Board examiner, James A. Shaw, today accused a local of the international Union of Mine, Mill and Smelter Workers, CIO, of using violence and "kangaroo court" tactics to force a member to quit his job.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 17 -- Twelve years ago the men who make steel in the giant mills at Homestead, Duquesne and Clairton were poised for a strike that never came. For months the country had been waiting for a bloody showdown between the United States Steel Corporation, historic bastion of the open shop, and the infant Steel Workers Organizing Committee.

MOSCOW, Sept. 17 -- Under such headlines as "Rajk and His Accomplices," "Agents of American Intelligence," "Ties of Tito, Rankovitch and Others with Intelligence Organs of the United States," the Soviet central newspapers published full-page reports today of the proceedings of the Budapest trial of Laszlo Rajk, former Hungarian Interior and Foreign Minister.

FOR the first full week of its brief season at the Metropolitan Opera House, the Ballet Russe has scheduled a number of novelties and near novelties. Tuesday will see the premiere of Alexandra Danilova's revival of the last act of "Paquita," based on the version of the old work that was (and probably still is) done in the Russian theatres, with choreography by Petipa and music by Minkus.

FEW of the characters in this excellent volume will be strangers to those who have read even desultorily of California's early and tumultuous years, but law-abiding folk never weary of the story of those who lived outside the law. Mr. Jackson's exhaustive research into the lives and times of assorted banditti has resulted in a worthy addition to Californiana.

Ever since the stock market bust of 1929, Wall Street has talked about "selling the public." But it remained for one person to make the idea jell. That's Charles E. Merrill, the directing partner of the largest brokerage firm, Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Beane.

LAKE SUCCESS, Sept. 17 -- The Latin-American delegates to the United Nations General Assembly today set up a steering committee to decide on the slate of candidates that they will support on Tuesday when the Assembly convenes at Flushing Meadow.

Israel's capital requirements for the next few years will total $2,000,000,000, according to a new fifty-page brochure entitled "Investing in Israel," issued yesterday by the Jewish Agency for Palestine, 16 East Sixty-sixth Street.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 (AP) -- Government expands freedom when it aims at security for every individual, President Truman said in a letter made public today.

WE, all of us, do a good deal of grumbling about the semantic obscurities of the word "liberal," and about the perversity of other people's use of it, but most of us know a liberal when we meet one. Certainly few would begrudge this word -- still a word of praise -- to Hans Kohn, Professor of History at Smith and one of our most persevering liberals.

TORONTO, Sept. 17 -- The Noronic, largest passenger ship on the Great Lakes, burned at her pier early today in one of the worst disasters of North American maritime history. It was feared that 207 persons had perished in the blaze that swept the 6,905-ton vessel from stem to stern in fifteen minutes after a fire was discovered on C deck aft, near the ship's bar, at 2:38 A. M.

GANTON, England, Sept. 17 -- America's professional golfers crushed Britain's best club swingers in six out of eight singles matches today to retain the treasured Ryder Cup and break the spirits of 12,000 British spectators.

Private employment agencies are receiving an unexpectedly large volume of employer orders for qualified top manufacturing and distribution executives as a result of the rapid upswing in many types of businesses since the middle of August, W. Gail Camp, president, Executive Service Corporation, revealed in an interview last week.

POSTMASTER GENERAL JESSE M. DONALDSON rescinded last week his Sept. 6 authorization for a special 3-cent stamp for the national encampment of the United Confederate Veterans at Little Rock, Ark., on Sept. 27-29.
THE principal characters in this little scene are a young baby, determined to have his way, and a gentle, patient mother who knows the latest theory, but does not know her own mind.

ONE might think that to be related to the late Margaret Fuller on one side of the family and to Norman Douglas on the other would deter any young man from choosing the art of letters as a profession.
