Such illustrious literary connections, however, do not seem to have inhibited Constantine FitzGibbon's talent as a novelist.
Choice French period furniture and decorations will be auctioned on Saturday at the Kende Galleries, 119 West Fifty-seventh Street.

AS crisp autumn weather signals the end of the fruit harvest, home-owners are beginning to think of next year's crop. Perhaps many more trees are wanted than there is space for or, maybe, even time. Above all, the problem of pest control will automatically reduce the number to be planted.

ROME, Sept. l7 -- The concession by Britain of virtual statehood to Cyrenaica has created an unfavorable impression in the Italian press and among the public. It was regarded as an attempt to steal a march on Italy and bring about an accomplished fact favorable to British interests on the eve of United Nations decisions on the final disposition of the former Italian colonies. In official circles, however, it was received calmly.
DETROIT, Sept. 17 -- The Noronic, the largest Canadian passenger vessel on the Great Lakes, had a tumultuous career.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., Sept. 17 -- For the third time, Skip Etchells has won the Atlantic Coast championship of the Star Class. He was the defending titleholder, having led the way last year, and with a second place in Shillalah in the final race this afternoon off the Larchmont Yacht Club he ran up a total of 57 points in the five-contest series.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 2 -- Damascus and Amman are the source of a consistent series of reports that Saudi Arabia has agreed to underwrite the financing of reconstruction of the historic Hejaz pilgrims' railway from Damascus to Medina.

The United Nations General Assembly will open its fourth session Tuesday in an atmosphere of calm that may bring "reasonable men" to agreement, Warren R. Austin, United States delegate, said yesterday.

ZAGREB, Yugoslavia, Sept. 17 -- Foreign diplomats and other foreign observers who attended the formal opening today of the International Trade Fair in this city were able to measure the rate of industrial development in Yugoslavia achieved in the last twelve months despite concerted efforts of the Soviet Government and its allies to strangle this country with an economic blockade.

Two Italian pilots who tried to fly the ocean non-stop from the Azores to New York in a single-engined light plane were still missing last night. A score of planes and two Coast Guard cutters had searched for them all day. At 8 P. M. four Coast Guard planes suspended their operations for the night, but Air Force aircraft continued the search.

THE most lively and vivid account of Shelley's early life remains that of Thomas Jefferson Hogg, who shared his expulsion from Oxford. Too lively it was for Shelley's son and daughter-in- law, who on the appearance, of the first two volumes withdrew papers entrusted to him.
YOU may not have given many serious thoughts, perhaps not even a single stray one, to the 1952 Presidential elections.

RAILROAD and camera fans -- the two seem to go together -- can look forward to a busy fall season of railroad excursions. Of unusual interest is the "Old Fashioned Excursion over the Rutland from Chatham, N. Y., to Rutland, Vt., set for next Sunday.

Senator John Foster Dulles, Republican nominee, has received requests for visits from Republican organizations all over the state and will make an active campaign for election, Alger B. Chapman, his campaign manager, announced yesterday.

MARTHA'S VINEYARD, Mass., Sept. 17 -- The fourth annual striped bass derby got under way with a real splash when one of the local boys showed the visitors how it was done by bringing in a 46-pound 14-ounce striper, which dwarfed the top non-resident entry by more than twenty-five pounds.

More than 85 per cent of the lighting in the average American city is inadequate, according to the National Electrical Manufacturers Association on the basis of a survey just completed of Indianapolis, Ind., by an independent market research agency.

CHICAGO, Sept. 17 -- Negotiations between representatives of Local 44 of the Stock Handlers' Union, CIO, and the Union Stockyards and Transit Company aimed at settling the union's demand for a 10-cent hourly wage increase and other issues reached "a standstill" early this morning, Frank Monaghan, president of the local said today.
Michael J. Quill, president of the Transport Workers Union, CIO, threatened yesterday a slowdown on the city's subway lines in "two or three weeks."

HATTERAS, N. C. -- White-collar adventurers, fishermen, hunters and anyone who seeks late summer and autumn relaxation in friendly. frontier surroundings should plan a visit to North Carolina's lower Outer Banks before civilization, in the form of a road, connects Hatteras with the outside world.

HERE is another light-hearted mystery entertainment, complete with humorous title. Those involved include Emily Murdock, the untidy but attractive owner of a decorating shop in New York's East Sixties; Henry Bryce, her assistant; Link Simpson, who owns the antique shop on the ground floor.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 (AP) -- The Cleveland Indians, fighting to keep alive their American League pennant hopes, slammed out 16 hits today for an easy 8-to-3 victory over the tail-end Washington Senators.
All Conradians will rejoice that so sensitive a barometer of the literary climate as Christopher Morley sees an imminent return of the books of Joseph Conrad to general popularity.

THE brisk sunny days of autumn, which starts officially on Friday, mean a new planting season in gardens, The beginning, actually, is signaled: by no one day. This fall, it is welcomed fully as much by the old hand at gardening who has drought casualties to repair as by the new home-owner who is eager to set out shrubs and trees and to sow a lawn.

TORONTO, Sept. 17 -- Injured passengers from hospital beds and in hospital corridors, and witnesses who gathered near the burned hull of the Noronic as she lay at her dock, told vivid tales of tragedy, heroism, and panic.
CHICAGO, Sept. 17 (AP) -- Dr. John W. C. Wand, Bishop of London, said today that, in its extreme forms, refusal to accept authority would lead to "a complete anarchy,''

THE thirty-fifth annual exhibition of the American Dahlia Society will be held at the Penn Top, Hotel Statler, New York City, on Wednesday and Thursday. Large and small dahlias will compete in 315 classes.

LISBON FALLS, Me. NEWS that the pogy has come to Maine may not cause the world at large to jump and ignore other subjects, but it has its place in life and letters. If your great-grandfather painted a barn red or a tip-cart blue a half-dozen decades or so ago, and the paint hasn't dried yet, then blame the good Maine pogy. You look him up in the dictionary under menhaden.

TORONTO, Sept. 17 -- Most of those who perished when flames enveloped the pleasure steamer Noronic early this morning never left their tiny staterooms. At 1 o'clock a dance had ended, the bar had closed down and late merrymakers had retired. Hundreds of others had gone to their rooms hours before and were sound asleep when the cries of "Fire!" were heard.

THE hot, dry summer that scorched most of the Eastern States this year has added to the difficulty of predicting exactly when the leaves will be most colorful this autumn. Arrival of sharp frosts will really touch off the transformation.

SCHENECTADY, N. Y., Sept. 17 -- Charges that plans for the regulation of rivers in the state forest preserve had been prepared with a view to power development rather than for flood control were made here today by conservationists as a Joint Legislative Committee began a study of river regulating laws.

PARIS -- The bateau mouche that glides away from its anchorage at the Quai Solferino every day on the trip along the Seine is helping to celebrate this year the fiftieth anniversary of the former fleet of Paris water jitneys.
The alertness of a patron in a Queens bar last night resulted in the capture of a burglar who was trying to rob the proprietor's home across the street, the police reported.

The prime rate of interest on commercial loans is likely to be maintained at the current level of 2 per cent despite the prevailing trend toward "easy money," according to three top banking executives from the Northwestern area, now visiting here.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -- The United States may be making progress on the East vs. West diplomatic battlefield, but it appears to be losing for sure in the war of words. As far as penetrating the sound-proofed Soviet Union is concerned, the "Voice" in the State Department's "Voice of America" broadcasts has become "nothing," as Seneca said, "but beaten air."

A FEW years ago, flying north in Africa from Kisumu to Wadi Halfa, I noticed a herd of elephants disporting themselves among the reeds of the Upper Nile. The pilot had seen them too, and, by way of a joke, dived down on the herd. He straightened out only when the horizon seemed to be filled with scampering pachyderms.

I DON'T know why people call in private eyes; it's the sure kiss of death. Johnny the Mick (who was a Ukrainian) wanted a small but delicate errand performed, so he hired Peter Chambers. Right off the bat Chambers finds a blonde corpse (there's a cute switch on this -- she has clothes on), and next thing you know, Johnny the Mick is hanging by the neck in Chambers' bedroom.

WHY is Robert Graves, a writer whose work has been published for thirty years, who has been counted among the best-sellers, who does each job with unquestionable literary merit -- why is such a writer being neglected these days? An answer is bound to tell as much about contemporary readers as it does about the overlooked writer.

MORGANTOWN, W. Va., Sept. 17 (AP) -- West Virginia University's football team scored in every quarter today to open its season with a 42-to-7 victory over Waynesburg, Pa. Mountaineer substitutions were frequent and every player in uniform saw action as West Virginia completely outplayed the Yellow Jackets.

DETROIT, Sept. 18 -- Settlement of the wage dispute between the Ford Motor Company and the United Automobile Workers, CIO, this week was accepted as a certainty today after four successive days of discussion on the company's reported pension offer.
EAST HARTFORD, Conn., Sept. 18 (AP) -- The development of a mechanical stenographer that flies with guided missiles and records electrically dictated test data was announced here today.

OTTAWA, Sept. 18 (Canadian Press) -- Canada's $50,000,000 synthetic rubber plant is in a vigorous battle with world's crude rubber supply. So far, with the aid c scientific research, the fight has gone in Canada's favor.

When the first tang of the autumn is in the air, it is time for a warm dress. This year the woolens are high style, particularly the light-weight tweeds. Incidentally they come in glorious colors, many woven in plaids, which are such a high-style feature this season.
Quotations for cotton in the domestic market were steady last week, with active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange down 1 and up 7 points from the previous week's close.

The interfaith movement is a common "faith in a basic constitution of fundamental rights," Mayor O'Dwyer said yesterday in a brief address at the fourth annual Interfaith Day rally on Central Park Mall. A thousand persons occupied seats in front of the band shell and thousands of others paused in promenades to listen.

Ernest Truex and his wife, Sylvia Fields, will be starred in a new situation comedy television series, "The Truex Family," which will make its debut over WPIX on Thursday, Oct. 13, from 7:30 to 8 P. M. Other regular members of the cast will include the couple's children, Sally and Barry.

Several thoughts are inspired by your appropriate definition on the financial page of Sept. 13 of British money as representing "depreciated pounds" of which the worth is determined by what "willing buyers will pay willing sellers in the world of competitive trade."
BENGAZI, Cyrenaica, Sept. 18 -- Cyrenaica became an independent state today when the ruler of a quarter of a million Senussi Arabs, the Emir Sayid Idris el-Senussi, formally enacted the constitution.

PARIS, Sept. 18 -- One battered American airplane has emerged from behind the Iron Curtain. A Lockheed Constellation with only three of its four engines arrived at Schiphol Airport in Amsterdam from Prague yesterday. Its pilot and co-pilot arrived in Paris today.

LONDON, Sept. 18 -- Many political observers in London thought tonight that devaluation of the pound would have an adverse effect on the Labor Government's chances of re-election despite Sir Stafford Cripps' jaunty assurances to the voters that they would scarcely feel a thing.

NO one really believed Red Rolfe when he made the statement in Florida last March. He sounded suspiciously like the man who was buoying up his courage by whistling his way past the graveyard. "I'm hoping," he had said, "that Art Houtteman will recover in time to pitch the last couple of months of the season." This, obviously, was the most ridiculous kind of optimism.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 (AP) -- Virgil Trucks and Hal Newhouser pitched Detroit into a virtual third-place tie with Cleveland today by taking a doubleheader from Washington. Trucks limited the Senators to three hits in capturing the second game, 5--2, after Newhouser won the opener, 3--2, on eight hits.
Five tankers, with a total of more than 150 years of service, are nearing the end of their long careers at shipbreaking yards in Baltimore, it was learned yesterday.

Last week was one of the busiest of the season in the wholesale garment market here as a great many out-of-town buyers covered showings of holiday lines and filled in on fall requirements, according to reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.

With Mayor O'Dwyer as the principal speaker, the new temple building of the Forest Hills Jewish Center, erected at a cost of $1,500,000 at Sixty-ninth Avenue and Queens Boulvard, was dedicated at an outdoor ceremony yesterday afternoon before 5,000 persons.

We have long waited in vain for an adequate defense of the Police Department's antiquated specifications on New York's taxicabs. We have been disturbed by the official apathy toward demands for modification of these specifications, which have perpetuated the limousine type of cab, with seats for five passengers behind the driver.

James Marshall, member and former president of the Board of Education, accused Mayor O'Dwyer yesterday of making "misleading" statements concerning the condition of the city school system. The Mayor was charged with playing politics with the schools.

Roland Petit's "Ballets de Paris" will open an engagement at the Winter Garden on Thursday, Oct. 6, under the sponsorship of the Messrs. Shubert and Arthur Lesser. The company, which numbers twenty, is headed by Mr. Petit, who is also its choreographer, and Renee Jeanmaire.

Britain's action yesterday in devaluing the pound was grimly appropriate from a historical standpoint. For it was on another Sunday, exactly eighteen years ago, that the London cable carried the momentous tidings to the newspaper offices here that the Bank of England had been forced to suspend gold payments.

Trading in the pound sterling last week developed an "off-the-spot-and-back-again" routine when first the tripartite Ministers' conference passed blithely over any reference to devaluation which brought in its wake a robust advance in forwards, only to have this complacency shattered when the IMF and World Bank later reports revealed support of devaluation via a "realistic evaluation" of the pound.

Mary MacArthur, 19-year-old daughter of Helen Hayes and Charles MacArthur, is a patient in Lenox Hill Hospital, it was learned yesterday. During the summer she had been appearing with her mother in the Theatre Guild's pre-Broadway tryout of William McCleery's comedy, "Good Housekeeping."

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 18 -- Union and management representatives in steel left for Washington tonight, with both sides adamant against any concessions at the conference called for tomorrow morning by Cyrus S. Ching, Director of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service.

Exercises marking the 162d anniversary of the signing of the Constitution were held yesterday in the churchyard of St. Ann's Protestant Episcopal Church, 140th Street and St. Ann's Avenue, the Bronx, and were attended by 2,000 persons. The churchyard contains the grave of Gouverneur Morris, actual penman of the document.
CHICAGO, Sept. 18 (AP) -- Residents of twenty-three United States cities may soon get an increase in fire insurance rates. Another twenty-two cities are in line for a rate cut.

Contents of a checklist entitled "Points for Consideration in Negotiating Television Facilities Contracts" have been released by the American Association of Advertising Agencies. It contains observations and suggestions pertaining to special situations and recognized "problem areas" not covered by either the AAAA Standard Spot Radio Contract, or any of the television station contracts studied in preparing the list.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 18 -- Four striking railway brotherhoods will make tomorrow "a partial acceptance" of the Missouri Pacific Railroad latest proposal for ending the strike of 5,200 trainmen, but will insist upon a review of their claims by the trustee for the railroad before terminating the walkout, it was learned tonight.

The Townsend Harris Medal for outstanding post-graduate achievement in "some significant field of human endeavor" has been awarded to five prominent City College alumni, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Nelson P. Mead, president of the City College Associate Alumni.

SHANGHAI, Sept. 18 -- Preparatory subcommittees in Peiping, which for three months have been drafting the organic law and constitution of China's new People's Democratic Republic, have completed their work, according to a report today by the official New China News Agency.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept.18 (AP) -- Exploding for three touchdowns each in the second and third periods, the San Francisco 49ers racked up a 42-14 victory over the Los Angeles Dons in their All-America Conference football game today.
A stranger in town yesterday who wandered down to Mulberry Street might have thought he had his countries mixed. He would have mused, "This is Italy, not America!"

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Sept. 18 -- Richard Nye's Carina in the Cruising Club Rule Class was the first yacht home in the fourth annual Stratford Shoal race of the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club today. The Indian Harbor craft crossed the line at 9:30:26 A. M.

It is with justifiable pride that Beth Israel Hospital at Stuyvesant Park East, New York 3, stands upon the threshold of its sixtieth birthday with a rich record of service to the lower East Side. Of the forty immigrants who founded the institution by giving 25 cents each to maintain a clinic in the back of a store, not one is alive today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- Deposits and assets of the nation's insured banks declined about $4,500,000,000 each during the first six months of 1949, Maple T. Harl, chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, announced today.

ALEXANDRIA, Ind., Sept. 15 (UP) -- Senator Homer E. Capehart, Republican, of Indiana, said today that President Truman would dismiss Maj. Gen. Harry H. Vaughan, his military aide, if he followed the same code of ethics that he held as a United States Senator.

Listening to the radio announcement by Sir Stafford Cripps yesterday dealing with the devaluation of the pound sterling from $4.03 to $2.80 many persons must have turned back their thoughts to another Sunday exactly eighteen years ago. That day was Sunday, Sept 20, 1931, and it brought the historic announcement that the Bank of England had lost its battle to preserve the gold standard as that standard then existed.

The President's fact-finding board appears to have produced the most intellectually honest and courageous report on labor-management problems which has appeared in a long time. They even went so far as to speak a good word for the lowly unorganized investors.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 18 (AP) -- The second game of the Reds-Braves double-header was called today because of darkness, with the score tied 1 -- 1 in the ninth inning after the Redlegs had won the opener, 7 -- 6. A crowd of 5,926, the smallest twin-bill gathering of the season at Crosley Field, was on hand for the two games.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- The Public Health Service announced $3,250,000 in grants today to aid nine institutions build cancer research facilities.

TORONTO, Sept. 18 -- While the search for the dead continued, provincial and municipal officials sought today to assess responsibility for the fire that early yesterday morning destroyed the Great Lakes steamer Noronic.

A parking lot measuring 50 by 100 feet at 503-05 West Forty-ninth Street was sold by Louis Zazzarino through Foss Dohm, Inc., in conjunction with Herbert Baudesson. Foss Dohm in conjunction with Crosby Blemly sold the four-story private dwelling on a lot 18.9 by 100 feet at 451 West Forty-seventh Street to a buyer for occupancy.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- The International Monetary Fund announced today its concurrence in Britain's action devaluing the pound sterling from $4.03 to $2.80 and in equivalent 30.5 per cent depreciations in the value of the Danish and Norwegian kroner, the Indian rupee and the pounds of Australia, the Union of South Africa and Egypt.

The American nation has become so "security-conscious" that it is being weakened by "unworthy fears," the Rev. Dr. Ralph W. Sockman, minister of Christ Church, Methodist, Park Avenue and Sixtieth Street, said yesterday.

PRINCETON, N. J., Sept. 18 -- Dr. Harold W. Dodds, president of Princeton, speaking at the opening exercises of the university's 203d academic year here today, issued a note of warning against the pressures exerted by large special groups for Government aid.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 18 -- With a flourish that thrilled 24,319 onlookers at Sportsman's Park today, the Cardinals swept to new scoring and slugging heights for the season. They swamped the Phillies, 15 to 3, to maintain their two-and-one-half-game lead in the National League flag race, while all previous attendance records for a single campaign were eclipsed.

MOSCOW, Sept. 18 -- The Soviet press proclaimed today that the primary lesson to be learned from the Budapest spy trial was "vigilance and once again vigilance" against what the papers termed the ever-expanding convolutions of a conspiracy directed by the United States warmongers against the Soviet Union and the "people's democracies."
A watched pot never boils, so it's said. But we ask, "Why watch it?"

The Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service will attempt to speed discussions between longshoremen and their employers in an effort to obtain a contract agreement by Sept. 30. The International Longshoremen's Association, AFL, and the New York Shipping Association have been unable to reach an agreement in several weeks of negotiations.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Sept. 18 (AP) -- A brisk wind helped the New York Giants register two field goals today, but a strong passing attack meant a 21-6 victory for the Detroit Lions in a National Football League exhibition game.

Eight missionaries who are to take posts for five years in Thailand under the Board of Foreign Missions of the Presbyterian Church in the U. S. A. and four children composed the entire passenger list of the Holland-America Line's Schiedyk, a freight and passenger ship, which sailed yesterday afternoon en route to Java. Six of the group will take posts in Bangkok, following preliminary training.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 (UP) -- Senator Burner R. Maybank, Democrat of South Carolina, said today the petroleum industry "should lower gasoline prices" instead of increasing fuel and heating oil prices, as it did recently.

Humanitarianism and observance of the Ten Commandments alone are not sufficient for salvation, Auxiliary Bishop Joseph F. Flannelly, administrator of St. Patrick's Cathedral, warned in a sermon there yesterday at solemn mass, at which Cardinal Spellman presided.
An ex-GI who wagered a dollar that he could carry a German rifle along Columbus Avenue yesterday afternoon without being stopped by the police lost his bet.

The devaluation of the pound and the closing of some European stock exchanges will have no effect on procedure in financial trading here. Emil Schram, president of the New York Stock Exchange, said last night: "Of course, the New York Stock Exchange will open tomorrow." He had no further comment on the foreign developments.

LONDON, Sept. 18 -- Britain devalued her currency tonight by a little more than 30 per cent. Henceforth, the pound sterling, which had been pegged at $4.03, will be worth only $2.80 in the markets of the world.

CHICAGO, Sept. 18 -- The twenty-two month strike of 1,500 printers' against Chicago's five daily newspapers ended today. The long dispute had been complicated by the Taft-Hartley Law and cost the idle composing-room workers $13,000,000 in lost wages and the union an estimated $11,000,000 in strike benefits, loss of dues and court costs.

LONDON, Sept. 18 -- If the London stock market's reaction to the results of the British-Canadian-American economic conference in Washington can be taken as a genuine reflection of the City's opinion, then it can only be said that the ten-point program not only failed to arouse any enthusiasm but fell distinctly flat.
PRETORIA, South Africa, Sept. 18 -- Prime Minister Daniel F. Malan announced the devaluation of the South African pound in the same ratio as the British currency, in a broadcast tonight.

The Cunard White Star Line will soon add two women to the purser staff of the liner Franconia, now operating on the company's Canadian run. This will place the final stamp of approval on a post-war experiment that has seen the employment of women pursers on all the major vessels of the large Cunard passenger fleet.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Sept. 18 -- Delays in concluding the technicalities of forming the Federal German Republic forced a postponement in the turnover of United States occupation authority by the Army to the State Department, it was announced today.
NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 18 (AP) -- Major and Mrs. Hans Hornbostel headed for New York today and a fresh start on a new life.
LAKE SUCCESS, Sept. 18 -- The fourth annual session of the United Nations General Assembly will open Tuesday morning at Flushing Meadow.

DOWNSVILLE, N. Y., Sept. 18 -- Water supply engineers of New York City will take an important step this week toward augmenting water reserves of the city when they direct the turning of the East Branch of the Delaware River into the new diversion tunnel here.
ALBANY, Sept 18 -- Governor Dewey today reported an increase of more than 12 per cent in out-of-state motorists visiting New York during the summer.
Elderly William Tully, who had $21,000 in five banks and lived in a $5-a-week room near Central Park, got up early yesterday and took his last walk in the park. He carried a length of rope.

Blazing with fabulous jewelry from Paris, a triple feature collection including ready-to-wear designs by Bernard Newman and Irene of Hollywood, a group of French originals, as well as a number of ready-made models by Leslie Morris, Mark Mooring and Mary Gleason, was unfolded recently at Bergdorf Goodman.

A move toward closer cooperation between the Wiltwyck School for Boys and the Brooklyn Training School and Home for Young Girls, the only institutions for children of Protestant faith committed by the city Children's Court, may get under way soon, it was predicted yesterday by Ernst Papanek, new executive, director of Wiltwyck.
MADISON, N. J., Sept. 18 -- Miss Margaret Gone Felton, daughter of Prof. and Mrs. Ralph A. Felton of Drew University here, leaves tomorrow for Communist-dominated China.

SHANGHAI, Sept. 18 -- Two United States ships laden with raw materials for Shanghai's hungry industries sailed into this port this morning in broad daylight. They were the first transoceanic cargo-ships to enter this port since the Nationalists in June declared a closure of all ports they had lost to the Communists.
The State Board of the Americans for Democratic Action adopted unanimously yesterday a resolution endorsing former Gov. Herbert H. Lehman, Democratic-Liberal candidate for United States Senator.

Completion of an arrangement by Winthrop-Stearns, Inc., to supply substantial quantities of desoxycholic acid, representing the annual yield from the bile of 200,000 cattle, to Merck Co. for the manufacture of cortisone, was announced yesterday by Dr. Theodore G. Klumpp, president of Winthrop-Stearns, Inc.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 18 -- James B. Carey, secretary of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, charged today that the left-wing credentials committee of the United Electrical Workers had threatened to bar "certain" right-wing delegates from the fourteenth international convention opening tomorrow unless they switched their support to the administration.

"Sweden: Model for a World," another volume in Hudson Strode's interpretations of foreign lands and their people, will be published by Harcourt, Brace on Oct. 17. The author discusses the historical, geographical, cultural, economic and psychological aspects of the country. His previous books dealt with Finland, Cuba and Bermuda.
ELIZABETH, N. J., Sept. 18 -- The historic First Presbyterian Church here, rebuilt from the ruins left by a fire on June 25, 1946, was rededicated this morning, the 285th anniversary of its founding.

TORONTO, Sept. 18 -- Relays of divers worked their way through the filthy water sloshing in the stern of the ruined holiday steamer Noronic today in their search for the bodies of passengers and crewmen possibly trapped there in the flash fire early Saturday morning.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 18 -- The election in 1950 of more members of the Senate and House "who understand the things that President Truman stands for" was put forward tonight by William M. Boyle Jr., Democratic national chairman, as "the great job" now facing the party.
A chain reaction to British devaluation of the pound sterling developed in many parts of the world yesterday.
WESTBURY, L. I., Sept. 18 -- When two such players as Cecil Smith and Roberto Cavanagh ride in the middle of any team's line-up, it's pretty certain there's going to be plenty of scoring.

ZURICH, Sept. 18 -- Prolonged deliberations at the Government level went on all last week in Berne to decide how to best cope with the difficult situation arising from the result of the referendum of Sept. 11, when by a vote of 281,961 to 272,359 and by 12 1/2 cantons against 9 1/2 the Swiss people voted for "a return to direct democracy."

On hand to meet the liner America on her arrival here yesterday were Mrs. Harry Truman and her daughter, Margaret, who boarded the vessel at Pier 61, North River. They came to greet "an old friend," Mrs. Earl Stewart, who was among the 991 passengers from Le Havre and Southampton.

Maximilian Moss, president of the Board of Education, credited Mayor O'Dwyer yesterday with playing an important backstage role in achieving passage of the Palestine-partition plan through the United Nations General Assembly.

The four-story building containing nine apartments and occupying a lot 20 by 86 feet at 1127 Dean Street, in Brooklyn, was sold by Mrs. M. Brown to Albert Grayer for investment in a deal negotiated by the Nostrand Avenue office of the Bulkley Horton Company, brokers.
CLEVELAND, Sept. 18 -- Under circumstances altogether heartbreaking to Red Strader's young team, the Football Yankees' four-year, nine-game record of futility against the Browns was preserved today.

The New York Central Railroad announced yesterday that about 2,400 workers who have been on furlough would be recalled to its four repair shops on Monday, Oct. 3. These would be in addition to the 2,600 locomotive shop employes who returned to work on Sept. 6.
Three thousand persons attended yesterday the dedication of a new $2,500,000 building of the Jewish Sanitarium and Hospital for Chronic Diseases, Rutland Road and East Forty-ninth Street, Brooklyn.

PITTSBURGH, Monday, Sept. 19 -- A mantle of idleness settled over the country's coal fields today as operators received word from local officials of John L. Lewis' United Mine Workers that most of their 480,000 members would stay away from work to protest the halting of pensions and medical payments by the industry's Welfare Fund.
A sweeping program, designed to achieve international currency convertibility as a means of restoring multilateral trade, was recommended yesterday by the National Association of Manufacturers.
Six new films, including three importations, are slated to open in midtown theatres this week. The programs follow:

The Yankees soared over the 2,000,000 home attendance mark for the fourth successive year at the Stadium yesterday, but to the 64,549 onlookers who made this lofty achievement possible the record was only incidental.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- The $1,314,010,000 bill to help non-Communist countries arm themselves against aggression reaches Senate debate tomorrow with its proponents anticipating ultimate approval despite opposition claims that the measure calls for spending too much too soon.

The Coast Guard here announced last night the abandonment of an apparently hopeless search for two Italian fliers and the single-engine airplane in which they had been attempting a transatlantic crossing from the Azores to New York.

Not every vacation spot can be a Riviera, it's true, but the others -- the ones that wind themselves around your heart like a childhood home -- take quite a wrench of goodbyes till another summer. Whether D-for-departure-day comes after the middle two weeks in July or the last possible weekend in September, the ordeal must be faced. Isn't it amazing how a hump of land or a stretch of beach can tighten the throat?

It is time, the garden news columns advise the gardener, to order bulbs for fall planting. It is -- in theory -- always time for the gardener to be doing something. It is time now also, he is told, to start cleaning up his garden, or the part of it that is not flaring up in one last burst of color.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- With the pound sterling valued at $2.80 instead of $4.03, the British will be able to price their goods in the United States market at a reduction of 30 per cent over present prices. But this in itself will not mean a great immediate stimulation in sales of British goods here, government officials and merchandising experts warned today.

PARIS, Sept. 19 -- With the fourth general conference of United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization scheduled to convene in a plenary session at 10 A. M. tomorrow, the agency's executive board tonight unanimously endorsed Director General Jaime Torres Dobet's report for 1949.
DOVER, England, Sept. 18 (AP) -- A Greek Army major, Zason A. Ziganos, completed swimming the English Channel from France to England at 11:45 P. M. (5:45 P. M., EST).

Dr. Philip C. Jessup, United States Ambassador-at-Large, announced yesterday that the United States delegation to the General Assembly would give full support to a United Nations program for technical assistance to under-developed areas.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 18 (AP) -- Pete Suder hit two homers, one with the bases loaded, to help the Philadelphia Athletics sweep a double-header today from the St. Louis Browns, 7 -- 5 and 7 -- 4. Suder's base clearer came during a six-run uprising in the first inning of the opener.

Plans for new building construction work in the city on file with the Department of Housing and Buildings include sketches for new offices costing $275,000 for the Children's Aid Society in Manhattan and a gymnasium costing $700,000 for Mount St. Michael's Academy in the Bronx.
PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Sept. 18 -- Another Roman Catholic Bishop was secretly consecrated here yesterday, authoritative sources disclosed today.

CHICAGO, Sept. 18 -- The Illinois Central Railroad disclosed today that its new refinancing program is designed to replace $52,201,000 of bonds maturing in the next six years with a single mortgage bond issue maturing serially in 1974 and 1979.
Officers and crew of the British light cruiser Glasgow, here on a ten-day visit, played host yesterday afternoon to 1,165 visitors at Pier 54, North River and Fourteenth Street.
OSLO, Norway, Sept. 18 (UP) -- Col. Bernt Balchen, American Arctic explorer and aviator, arrived in Oslo today after a flight across the North Pole from Anchorage, Alaska, in a B-29 Superfortress.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 18 -- A Progressive party conference on "Jobs and the Economic Crisis," finding the nation on the brink of disaster, today offered to the Eighty-first Congress a solution that included $100-a-month pensions for everyone at the age of 60, and a $50,000,000,000 public works program.

ROME, Sept. 18 -- All but the extreme left-wing press today hailed yesterday's meeting of the North Atlantic pact powers in Washington as marking the birth of a more effective cooperation among the participating nations.

YORK HARBOR, Me., Sept. 18 -- The outlook for locating a steel plant in a New England seaport is extremely bright, Frederick S. Blackall Jr., chairman of the New England Council iron and steel supply committee, said here today at the final session of the council's quarterly meeting. Mr. Blackall said in part:

CHICAGO, Sept. 18 -- Making his first start in a month and a day, Ralph Branca this afternoon proved his fitness to take a hand in what remains of the pennant race by shutting out the Cubs until the ninth inning.

The Senate is scheduled to take up again today the foreign military assistance bill. It has received an endorsement of the measure and an urgent recommendation of its adoption from its Foreign Relations and Armed Services Committees. These committees again observed that this program had been evolved independently of the Atlantic treaty but remarked that it would "do much to supplement and strengthen" the pact.

Just as a bright red-orange sun began climbing into the sky yesterday, six members of a Fall River, Mass., family dived into the East River at 6:40 A. M. The group, which included a father and five of his eight children, plunged into the chill waters three blocks south of Wall Street in an attempt to swim to Norton's Point, Coney Island -- a distance of fourteen miles.

Dedication to Christian ideals as complete as that of great artists to their canvases, musical scores and books was urged yesterday on a Harlem congregation by the Rev. Dr. Frank Theodore Wilson, dean of the Howard University School of Religion in Washington.

PARIS, Sept. 17 -- Outside the financial conferences in Washington, there were two main problems which held the attention of economic circles here last week, the chances for the 1950 budget for France and the tension that has been rising over wages and prices.

The New York Legislature at its last session established a six-man committee to investigate river regulation in this state. Formation of this body stemmed in part from the valiant and continuing efforts of conservationists to protect the Adirondack Forest Preserve from encroachments authorized by the Black River Regulating Board in connection with a dam and reservoir for flood-control purposes.
Devaluation of the pound sterling means simply that from now on -- if British prices remain constant -- an American dollar can buy more British goods or services than it could before.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- In connection with the devaluation of the pound the International Monetary Fund announced today the following new parties in terms of gold and in terms of the United States dollar of the weight and fineness in effect on July 1, 1944, for Britain and dependencies and the other nations following the same procedure:

ON the night his mother died young Martin Lynn committed murder. He picked up a heavy brass crucifix and bashed in the head of an elderly priest. Martin, as you can see, was an unusual young man. He is the hero of "The Edge of Doom,"* a sensational, pretentious and entirely unconvincing first novel by Leo Brady.

A surprise featured the opening game of the American Soccer League championship series at Sterling Oval yesterday when the Brookhattan F. C. downed the Philadelphia Nationals, league champions, 4 to 2, after a 1-0 lead at half-time.
In presenting the first important museum show of the new art season, the Whitney Museum honors its late director with an exhibition entitled "Juliana Force and American Art."

LARCHMONT, N. Y., Sept. 18 -- Winding up the mug hunt of championship summer yacht racing on Long Island Sound, the final regatta for all comers as far as classes go was held today by the Horseshoe Harbor Club.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Sept. 18 -- A fourteen-year study of 4,000 diabetic patients has led to the finding that "virtually all adult victims of diabetes can be restored to normal health without insulin injections," according to a report made public here tonight by the American Chemical Society on the eve of the opening of its annual autumn meeting.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 18 (AP) -- National Champion Richard (Pancho) Gonzales fashioned a methodical 6 -- 3, 9 -- 11, 8 -- 6, 6 -- 4 victory over Ted Schroeder today in the men's singles final of the Pacific Southwest tennis championships.

CHICAGO, Sept. 18 -- Liberal purchases of cash wheat and some flour by the Government sent wheat prices soaring on the Board of Trade last week. December, March and May wheat sold at new high levels for the year and the September future came within about 2 3/4 cents a bushel of the seasonal peak.

Yesterday's devaluation was the latest chapter in the history of British money, The Associated Press noted. British currency originated about the year 775 as silver coins known as "sterlings" or pennies in the Saxon kingdoms.
Mayor O'Dwyer and his running mates, Controller Lazarus Joseph and Vincent R. Impellitteri, President of the City Council, will open their campaign for re-election tonight.

PARIS, Sept. 18 -- The realignment of the French franc at a new parity with the dollar as a direct consequence of the devaluation of the pound was considered a certainty tonight after a conference that was held following the hasty return of Premier Henri Queuille to Paris.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 18 (AP) -- The Pittsburgh Pirates and New York Giants broke even in a twin-bill today, the Giants ending a six-game losing streak by taking the opener, 13 -- 4, and the Pirates winning the abbreviated nightcap, 7 -- 2.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 18 -- William C. McMillen, Eagle Lion Films vice president in charge of operations, now on the way to New York after a trip to the Coast to reorganize the company's activities, announced before his departure that contracts had been drawn for the distribution by his firm of five films to be produced independently during ,the remaining months of 1949.
CHICAGO, Sept. 18 -- September corn on the Board of Trade here was under the selling pressure of liquidating longs last week and prices ranged lower after showing early strength when shorts covered.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- The votes of the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on important roll-calls during the period Sept. 10 to 17 are given in the appended tabulation:
LAKE SUCCESS, Sept. 18 -- The United Nations is likely to abandon a year-old proposal to draft a new covenant on freedom of information, it became known today.

The monthly customs report issued yesterday by Harry M. Durning, collector, showed a continued drop in shipping at this port in August but a rise in airport activities. The former was responsible for a decrease of $1,149,113 in customs collections last month, compared with August, 1948.

Alfredo Salmaggi's Popular Price Grand Opera Company opened its winter season at the Brooklyn Academy of Music on Saturday night. The event, which began Mr. Salmaggi's thirty-first season of, opera production in this country, brought an enthusiastic audience, a newly imported soprano and ambitious plans for the season.
OLEAN, N. Y., Sept. 18 (AP) -- St. Bonaventure's Brown Indians opened their 1949 football season today with a 26-to-0 victory over Scranton University's Royals.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N. Y., Sept. 18 -- Mrs. Maud W. Makemson, professor of astronomy at Vassar College, reported today the completion of research providing "all necessary conditions for proving the correctness of any proposed correlation between the Maya and Christian calendars."

BOSTON, Sept. 18 -- Ted Williams blasted two homers and a single and batted in six runs as the Red Sox overwhelmed the White Sox, 11 -- 5 -- it was 11 -- 0 at one stage -- at Fenway Park today. The Chicagoans never had a chance against Ellis Kinder, who coasted to his twenty-first victory of the season.
A plane carrying forty-five Western European journalists home after a two-week sightseeing tour of this country was forced to turn back last night when engine trouble developed near Nantucket, Mass.

TOKYO, Monday, Sept. 19 -- The Japanese business community assumed the yen must be devalued to match sterling. In normal times 60 per cent of this country's trade is with the sterling area. Currently the proportion is lower, but there is where trade must rebuilt and any important currency handicap would be considered unthinkable.

The Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo, which opened its season at the Metropolitan Opera House on Friday in rather limp fashion, gave three performances over the weekend, which honesty compels one to report were no happier. In spite of three or four excellent artists, the company never has been weaker, the productions in less efficient shape or the orchestra more unaccountable.

The opening of the seventh parochial school in the North American jurisdiction of the Greek Orthodox Archdiocese of North and South America was celebrated yesterday afternoon at the Greek Orthodox Cathedral of the Holy Trinity, 319 East Seventy-fourth Street.

LONDON, Sept. 18 -- There were only about fifty persons outside 10 Downing Street tonight when Sir Stafford Cripps made his announcement of devaluation of the pound. They were some of the few in London who knew in advance that the Chancellor of the Exchequer was to speak, and all of them had come in the hope of seeing him leave for Broadcasting House.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- President Harry S. Truman and 150,000 other disappointed spectators along Hains Point seawall and on anchored pleasure craft today saw rough Potomac River water wash out the nineteenth President's Cup regatta.

ALBANY, Sept. 18 -- President Alvin C. Eurich of the State University of New York announced today the appointment of Otto J. Teegen, nationally known architect, to advise him and the university trustees on construction of new facilities and maintenance and improvement of existing structures.

ROME, Sept. 18 -- The announcement that the pound would be devalued by 30 per cent took Italy completely by surprise. Although it was possible that the Italian Government had been informed beforehand, people at large and even financial circles were totally unprepared for any such development. What astonished Italians even more than the mere fact of devaluation was its extent.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 18 -- While public attention has been focused on the remarkable effects of the hormones ACTH and cortisone ("Compound E") on arthritis, these are only two members of an extensive chemical category of vast potentialities, Dr. Harvey E. Billig Jr. said last week at a meeting of the Southern California section of the International College of Surgeons.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 18 -- The national steel ingot rate last week was estimated at 85 per cent of rated capacity, up one point from the week before when the rate was offset slightly by Labor Day curtailments. At the beginning of last week it looked as if the rate would sag to at least 80 per cent because of a threatened railroad strike on one of the United States Steel Corporation's roads.

ALBANY, Sept. 18 -- State Senator Thomas C. Desmond, Republican, of Newburgh, declared today that the problem of providing health, hospitalization or life insurance coverage for persons past 60 was becoming of increasing importance both to the elderly and the taxpaying public.
LONDON, Sept. 18 (AP) -- Following is the text of Sir Stafford Cripps' speech in which he announced the devaluation of the pound sterling:

The first full year of operation of the municipal transit lines at the increased fares that went into effect on July 1, 1948, has substantially justified the increases, in the opinion of William Reid, chairman of the Board of Transportation.

It is fortunate for the democratic world that the Soviet Government is not as wise as it is ruthless and persistent. The Budapest trials throw little light on conditions in Hungary, but considerable on the working of the mind of the Kremlin. Apparently there has not been a new idea or a new method in that walled enclosure in thirty years.

Small wonder that J. H. Newmark of Miami Beach notes in his letter dated Sept. 8 that "nothing of importance is being done" to reduce the mounting death and accident toll on highways and city streets. Mr. Newmark qualifies himself with years of experience in the automotive industry.

Numerous orders for British goods, held up for weeks in anticipation of devaluation of the pound sterling, were reinstated yesterday by importers here in cables to English manufacturers. However, there was no flood of new orders.

Alfred De Franceschi came down from Torrington, Conn., to Times Square yesterday and stopped vehicular and pedestrian traffic cold. Cab drivers got out of their taxis to gape and large crowds gathered wherever Mr. De Franceschi parked.
Canada and France had joined seventeen other nations last night in devaluing their currencies. The British-led slash in money values had spread widely and the end still is not in sight.
Staten Islanders were urged yesterday to vote for Mayor O'Dwyer as Cornelius A. Hall Richmond's Borough President, introduced the Mayor at cornerstone exercises for three new housing projects there.
LARCHMONT, N. Y., Sept. 19 -- In the first race of the series between the Bermuda International Class sloops and those of Long Island Sound, the Sound won today, 22 1/4 points to 14.

The upward trend in the dollar total of outstanding Latin American export drafts was reversed in August for the first time in nine months, while the total number of drafts paid during the month was the largest during the same nine-month period, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday in its monthly summary of export collection experience of fifteen reporting banks.

Immediate response of the rubber futures market to Sunday's announcement of the devaluation of the pound sterling was a precipitate drop of 175 to 185 points in values, equivalent to more than 1 3/4 cents a pound.

Television stations broadcasting the World Series will not receive any compensation even though they will carry commercial announcements throughout the telecast of the baseball classic, it was made known yesterday.
Twenty-five polio cases were reported to the city's Health Department in the forty-eight hours ended at 9 A.M. yesterday. This compared with thirty-one cases recorded here in the previous week-end.

GENEVA, Sept. 19 -- Europe's leading timber-producing and importing nations, excepting the Soviet Union, met here today to consider whether, and to what extent, international regulation of the tim- ber market would be desirable.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 19 -- Transamerica Corporation opened its defense in the monopoly case before the Federal Reserve Board today by calling as its first witness Samuel H. Husbands, Transamerica's president, a former director of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation.
LONDON, Sept. 19 -- The devaluation of sterling has thrown trans-atlantic steamship and airline rates into chaos and stranded thousands of Britons holidaying on the Continent.

DANVILLE, Va., Sept. 19 -- The flue-cured tobacco markets of the South now in full swing, with customary liberal purchases for British manufacturers, showed no reaction to the devaluation of the pound sterling today.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 19 -- Encouraged by first-day successes in the face a right-wing rebellion, the administration of the United Electrical Workers, CIO, moved forward late today with its plan to use the fourteenth international convention as a sounding board for a stinging condemnation of the President's steel fact-finding board.

Capt. Ragnar Frederick-Eklund, former master of the American freighter Exmouth, was permanently deprived of his master's license in a decision handed down yesterday by Julius J. Rosen, Coast Guard civilian hearing examiner.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- The Air Force announced today completion of an experimental three-engine jet bomber, the XB-51, which was designed to answer the Army's demand for more emphasis on tactical air support of ground forces.

Debate on one of the most important measures of the present session of Congress -- the Foreign Military Aid Bill, intended to supplement the North Atlantic Treaty -- was begun in the Senate yesterday with an opening speech by Mr. Connally, chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee.

Baseball Commissioner Albert B. Chandler was questioned as a witness throughout the entire day yesterday by attorneys for the former Giant player, Danny Gardella, in an attempt to prove that organized baseball was in interstate commerce and thus subject to antitrust laws.
LA CROSSE, Wis., Sept. 19 (AP) -- Labor leaders from five plants of the Allis-Chalmers Manufacturing Company charged today that the huge concern "has failed to bargain in good faith."
PITTSBURGH, Sept. 19 -- Western Pennsylvania's 55,000 coal miners began their third stoppage this year with the resignation of men following a familiar routine.

The cessation of coal mining and the issuance of a new strike ultimatum to the steel industry yesterday will not affect steel operations this week, but production schedules of the nation's steel companies will be reduced next week if coal mining is not resumed even though a steel strike does not materialize.

In a letter to Sol A. Schwartz, vice president and general manager of RKO theatres, Governor Dewey hailed the inauguration of National Vaudeville Week, which begins Thursday at the Palace, an RKO branch, it was announced yesterday.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 19 -- Two rookies starred tonight as the Phils beat the Cardinals, 4 -- 3, cutting the Redbirds lead in the National League flag race to a game and a half.

Col. William J. Walsh, who served during World War II as executive officer to the head of selective service here, was arraigned yesterday in Felony Court on a grand larceny complaint charging that he and another defendant had swindled a prominent sculptor out of $2,150.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 19 -- A step ahead of most fall expositions, the Eleventh Annual New Haven Antiques Show opened today in this city's Arena, to offer the old and a touch of the new to questing collectors and bargain hunters.

ALBANY, Sept 19 -- Governor Dewey, in a new year greeting to the state's Jewish citizens, said today there was no excuse for the maneuvering that has prevented a vote in Congress on the pending displaced persons bill. The Jewish year 5,710 will begin Saturday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- Savings in this country continue to pile up at a high rate, according to a report today by the Securities and Exchange Commission. It listed individuals' liquid savings in the second quarter of 1949 at more than $1,000,000,000.

Europe's Jews today are predominantly healthy, Dr. William M. Schmidt, who has served as overseas director of the Joint Distribution Committee medical program, declared yesterday at its world headquarters, 270 Madison Avenue.

By-products of the meat industry are losing out to substitutes, John F. Krey, president of Krey Packing Company and chairman of the board of the American Meat Institute, declared yesterday. He addressed delegates to the forty-fourth annual convention of the association in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
September will be relatively slow, but already the music season has begun. Last night at Town Hall Morton Estrin, pianist from Burlington, Vt., gave the first piano recital of 1949-50.

The 162d anniversary of the adoption of the United States Constitution was observed yesterday at ceremonies in Federal Court House, Foley Square. Seventy-five members of the United States Attorney's staff and members of the bar attended.

More than 1,000 buyers registered at the opening of the holiday showings of infants and children's apparel in the New Yorker Hotel by the Metropolitan Juvenile Style Mart. Buying was brisk, according to exhibiting manufacturers, with shipments to begin in October and run through the middle of December.

CHICAGO, Sept. 18 -- The American people do not want to have the Government control them and their personal lives, and if the traditional American way of life were put to a national vote tomorrow such control would be overwhelmingly defeated, Herman W. Steinkraus, president of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States, said today.

GENEVA, Sept. 19 -- A great burden has been lifted from the European economy by Sir Stafford Cripps' calm and confident announcement of the reasons for the reduction in the dollar value of the pound sterling.
GENEVA, Sept. 19 -- Twenty nations, including the United States, signed a new world road traffic convention here today.

William A. Mitchell, president of the Central Trust Company of Cincinnati, has been appointed chairman of the newly created Committee on Monetary Relations of the United States Council of the International Chamber of Commerce. This was announced yesterday by H. J. Heinz 2d, chairman of the USC-ICC, the American section of the International Chamber.

American motion pictures released in Germany after Jan. 1, which are approved by the Economic Cooperation Administration, will be guaranteed partial dollar convertibility from German earnings from the $10,000,000 Congress has authorized for informational media guarantees, it was announced yesterday after a meeting of the board of directors of Motion Pictures Export Association.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (AP) -- The Army said today that it would dispose of some sites of its Eastern harbors' defense system as an economy measure and emphasized that the action would not jeopardize national security.

PAWTUCKET, R. I., Sept. 19 (AP) -- S. S. Barrett's Auntie, favorite in a field of eleven starters, covered six furlongs in 1:12 to score a two-and-a-half-length victory over the Marlet Stable's Klimie today in the featured sixth race at Narragansett Park.

A sociological development that has had little public notice, perhaps because it has come about gradually rather than overnight, is the increase in longevity in the United States. There may be general awareness that people are living longer but ignorance of the phenomenal rate of the increase.

LAKE SUCCESS, Sept. 19 -- The Republic of Korea appealed today to the United Nations General Assembly to authorize one or more friendly countries to supply military help "which will be sufficient to cope with its security problems, which have become more serious as the result of the communistic expansion in Asia."

The composure of the stock market was only slightly shaken yesterday by the devaluation of the British pound sterling. Although the list was subjected to brisk selling at the opening, a good portion of the losses shrank later and the composite rate dipped only 0.90 point on the day, a decline considered small on the basis of developments.

Westinghouse Electric Corporation has placed nine of its eighteen traffic appliances on allocation to distributors and dealers, Ralph Z. Sorenson, manager of the small appliance department, revealed yesterday. He said the upturn in business since July "has eaten up all our factory stocks and production is now behind retail orders."

Five American executives, directors of Cia Hispano-Americana de Electricidad (CHADE), charged yesterday that Spain was working against its own economic recovery in supporting a move by Spanish nationals who own about 15 per cent of the utility's stock to hold an allegedly illegal meeting of shareholders in Madrid on Sept. 27.
BUDAPEST, Hungary, Sept. 19 (AP) -- Five defendants -- one of them with a faulty memory -- wound up Hungary's treason trial today with uniform pleas of guilt.
Despite the lack of a campus or athletic teams and students was-sailing its fame and traditions, the Fire College has attracted students from all over the world.

The "blocked securities pound" declined here yesterday to $1.77, a markdown from the heavy discount which has prevailed in this type of blocked British money in recent years. "Blocked securities sterling" -- also known as "switch sterling" -- represents the dollar value of restricted sterling balances deriving from the proceeds of sales of British securities owned by non-Britishers.
LAKE SUCCESS, Sept. 19 -- The United Nations General Assembly will open its fourth regular session at Flushing Meadow, Queens, tomorrow under favorable omens.

TOKYO, Sept. 19 -- Through all the Japanese comment on the sterling devaluation runs the foreboding line, "although Japanese exports will drop sharply." But officials generally maintain the classic attitude that the yen must hold its ground.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 19 (AP) -- Construction of a $20,000,000 brewery at Newark, N. J., with a planned annual capacity of 1,250,000 barrels was announced today by Anheuser-Busch, Inc.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 19 -- Following devaluation of sterling, Britain will demand an arrangement that would give her a slice of now wholly United States-held Saudi Arabian oil concessions and a general oil deal in the Middle East to increase the amount of sterling petroleum available and decrease the amount of dollar oil produced in this area, according to the best available expert opinion here.

Elliott V. Bell, State Superintendent of Banks, announced yesterday that he has paid over to the office of State Controller Frank C. Moore more than $1,500,000 of unclaimed funds belonging to former depositors and creditors of the defunct Bank of the United States. The bank was closed on Dec. 11, 1930, and has since been in liquidation.

The American National Theatre and Academy, the Congress-chartered organization devoted to promoting the theatre on a national basis, has decided to grant $1,250 to the Equity Library Theatre, the Actors Equity Association project through which the professional actor may practice his craft.
CANTON, China, Sept. 19 (AP) -- The Chinese Nationalist Defense Ministry announced today that the Communists for the second time had captured Jucheng and Kweitung, 170 and 210 miles north of Canton.
John Gau, lone wolf of the Atlantic, is back in New York again, full of flying fish and a strong ambition to circle the globe on a solo cruise in his thirty-foot ketch, the Atom.

Seeing the De Pinna showing yesterday at the St. Regis Roof was like running through a list of the fashion highlights for fall. There wasn't one important item missing. From the handsome coats, both for town and country, to the long-jacketed suits, the short evening dress and modish theatre costume, they were all there.

OKLAHOMA, CITY, Okla., Sept. 19 -- Consumers definitely want more merchandise information -- information on advertising, on labels and merchandise attachments -- from sales people, it was declared here today by Dr. Kenneth Dameron, director, Committee on Consumer Relations in Advertising.
An American citizen unable to speak anything but Lithuanian was among the 1,319 passengers who arrived here yesterday morning aboard the displaced persons transport General M. L. Hersey.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- Four surveys on women in public service, ocmpleting a series of ten such compilations, were issued today by the Women's Division of the Republican National Committee.

Plans for a five-day industrial exhibit to be held at Roosevelt Field, L. I., in commemoration of the fiftieth anniversary of Nassau County were made known yesterday at a conference at the Wings Club in the Biltmore Hotel. A main object of the exhibition is to stimulate the establishment of new industries in Nassau and Suffolk Counties, according to Arthur T. Roth, president of the Long Island Association, sponsors of the exposition.

A syndicate of 164 investment houses has been formed to underwrite a new issue of 856,895 shares of common stock of the West Penn Electric Company, according to an announcement yesterday by Lehman Brothers, and Goldman, Sachs Co., managers of the group.

BINGHAMTON, N. Y., Sept. 19 -- Senator John Foster Dulles tonight accused former Gov. Herbert H. Lehman, his adversary in this year's special Senate election on the Democratic and Liberal tickets of pulling his punches in the fight to prevent communism from engulfing new areas of the world.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 19 (AP) -- The Athletics pushed across three runs in the eighth inning to defeat the Browns, 7 -- 4, tonight. Dick Fowler went the route to register his fourteenth pitching decision.

On some fine day in late September there will begin again the ritual known as burning-the-leaves. Almost any suburbanite is already aware that the time approaches. He senses it in the cool air, in the enriched color of the trees on his street, in the lonely rustling of a leaf or two that has fallen to the ground.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- Philip Murray declared flatly today that there would be a strike of steel workers at midnight Saturday unless the steel industry agreed to the pension-social insurance plan recommended by a Presidential fact-finding board.
CANBERRA, Australia, Sept. 19 (Reuters) -- The Australian Cabinet will meet here tomorrow to consider the full implications of devaluation.
Following is the text of the address delivered last night by Secretary of State Dean Acheson before the Pan American Society of the United States in the Roosevelt Hotel:

LONDON, Sept. 19 -- British housewives, already hard pressed to make ends meet, are wondering how much of an increase in the cost of living devaluation of the pound sterling will mean. They were told last night that the rise in bread prices would add slightly less than one point to the cost-of-living index, but there already are indications that other food costs will go up.

A scientific paper released Sunday on the eve of the annual meeting of the American Chemical Society in Atlantic City was criticized here yesterday by a spokesman for the Medical Society of the State of New York.

PRETORIA, South Africa, Sept. 19 -- Spokesmen for mining, industrial and commercial interests as well as political leaders made it clear to South Africans today that devaluation of the currency was an expedient, not a panacea. They warned also against the possibility of inflation and the probability of rising costs.

A report recommending the resignation of one of the two trustees for the bankrupt New York, Ontario Western Railroad and asking for other drastic changes was made public yesterday by Federal Judge Edward A. Conger.

ATLANTA, Sept. 19 (AP) -- After fifty-nine minutes' deliberation, a jury tonight acquitted Judge Robert Carpenter after a five-day trial in which witnesses placed the accused and accuser in and out of bedrooms. Immediately after the jury announced its verdict, there was a moment of silence and then the eruption of cheers.

The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange although influenced by other exchanges and by the devaluation of sterling held steady during most of yesterday's session and closed 10 to 14 points net lower than Saturday's final prices.

Making a direct appeal to the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service to intervene in the deadlocked contract negotiations between the National Organization of Masters, Mates and Pilots, AFL, and thirty-eight East Coast and Gulf shipping companies, Frank H. Brown, regional director of the service, followed it here yesterday with the announcement that representatives of both parties would meet at 2 P. M. today with Commissioner Bernard J. Forman at the service's office, 341 Ninth Avenue.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Sept. 19 -- The rate of the Netherlands' devaluation of the guilder was sent by cable for approval today to the International Monetary Fund. It will be announced after Finance Minister Pieter Lieftinck's presentation of the 1950 budget at the opening session of Parliament tomorrow.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 19 (AP) -- Ralph Kiner, Pittsburgh left fielder, smashed his fiftieth home run of the year tonight to establish a National League record but the Giants nipped the Pirates, 6 -- 4, as Dave Williams hit a homer in the first of the tenth with one on.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Sept. 19 -- The sentencing of the secretary to Archbishop Josef Kaerel Matocha by the State Tribunal to ten years' imprisonment on a charge of "high treason" was officially announced today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- The United States today once more called on Bulgaria, Hungary and Rumania to join in the setting up of a commission to resolve a dispute over alleged violations in those countries of the human rights clauses of their respective peace treaties.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- The Export-Import Bank, in its semiannual report to Congress today, showed net earnings of $47,800,000 for the fiscal year and $24,100,000 for the six months ended June 30, 1949, after providing for all operating expenses, interest paid to the United States Treasury on funds borrowed and reserves for losses.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- Former Gov. Herbert H. Lehman will defeat Senator John Foster Dulles, his opponent in the New York special Senatorial election, by 300,000 votes, Paul Fitzpatrick, New York State Democratic Chairman, predicted today.
Seasonal, in view of the sunny Indian-summer weather, was news yesterday from Swift Co. regarding cold cuts.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- Three-power talks on the sharing of atomic energy information will open here tomorrow, with Great Britain and Canada expected to ask this country to impart more information on research and development achieved since the war.

The Diana Stores Corporation, women's apparel chain, attained new high records in sales and earnings in the fiscal year ended last July, Harry Greenburg, president, reported in the annual statement issued for release today.

Eddie Cantor raised $1,253,800 for the United Jewish Appeal yesterday at a luncheon meeting in the Commodore Hotel. Added to $1,800,000 previously contributed since the actor started a "barnstorming" cross-country tour to raise $5,000,000 toward the national appeal goal of $250,000,000, this brings his total to $3,053,800.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 19 -- The Truman Administration in eight months has redeemed its 1948 campaign promises to the West in the field of resources development, Vice President Alben W. Barkley told the Western States Democratic Conference tonight.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 19 (AP) -- Tight pitching by Warren Spahn and a twelve-hit attack on three Cincinnati pitchers gave the Boston Braves a 6-to-2 victory over the Reds today in a contest that attracted only 1,144 fans.
BALDWIN, L. I., Sept. 19 -- Pete Cassella, veteran Brookville pro, was the stand-out performer in today's edition of the Long Island amateur-pro golf tournament held at the Willow Brook Golf Club.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- Southern coal operators charged today that John L. Lewis had, by subterfuge, called out the nation's coal miners on a strike based on false premises.

LONDON, Sept. 19 -- The United States Embassy personnel here was faced today with an increase of 22 1/2 per cent in the cost of meals at their canteen and from tomorrow will have to pay 40 per cent more in British currency for their purchases at the embassy commissary.
The presentation of French imports viewed yesterday at Henri Bendel was replete with the top names of the couture and the most significant trends to come out of the French collections.

EDWARD ELLSBERG, the world's most distinguished naval salvage expert, writes books with the same furious energy and dynamic self-confidence that he applies to raising wrecks from the bottom of the sea. Probably that's why his books are so readable and so popular. Captain Ellsberg is nearly as good a writer as he is a marine engineer.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- Administration Democrats opened today the Senate's debate on the foreign military aid program with statements that 5,000,000 Russian soldiers threatened a free world that nowhere had now the ground troop strength to stay a Soviet attack.
MEXICAN HAT, Utah, Sept. 19 (AP) -- An airplane crash today killed Norman D. Nevills, the noted river runner who had defied treacherous waters in several Western states.

Opening his campaign in the Bronx last night, Newbold Morris, Fusion candidate for Mayor, said that "no political boss, not even the astute Mr. Flynn, can withstand the demands of an aroused electorate" for a political change. Edward J. Flynn is Democratic leader of Bronx County.

The seventh biennial convention of the National Maritime Union, CIO, yesterday adopted its first anti-Communist resolution, which reaffirmed the union's faith in the United States and made it clear that the rank and file would defend this nation "against any enemy, including the Soviet Union."

On July 29 a letter was printed signed by John B. Murphy Jr. This was in relation to the current controversy concerning allocation of proposed federal aid to state school systems. In his letter Mr. Murphy makes two serious misstatements which I believe THE TIMES should permit of correction by printing this letter.

Photoengravers employed on metropolitan New York newspapers abandoned their demand for a fourth-round wage increase of $12 weekly yesterday and agreed to work under their present contract until June 30, 1950.

EDGEWATER, N. J., Sept. 19 -An unauthorized walkout today by about 1,000 workers at the Ford Motor Company plant here affected 2,200 workers and halted operations. The walkout was a protest against the suspension of an employe.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- An immediate expansion of European trade and payments with improved living standards for the Western democracies was predicted today by Paul G. Hoffman, Economic Cooperation Administrator, as a result of Britain's "bold and imaginative" action devaluing the pound sterling.

BERLIN, Sept. 19 -- Acting as Deputy Military Governor, Maj. Gen. George P. Hays protested by letter today to his Russian opposite number, Lieut Gen. M. I. Dratvin, against the "brutal, inhuman treatment" of the United States Army recruit, John J. Sinkiewicz, who escaped last Thursday from a prison in the Soviet sector of Berlin after ten months' detention.

OTTAWA, Sept. 19 -- The Canadian dollar has been "adjusted" on the basis of a 10 per cent premium on the United States dollar, Finance Minister Douglas Abbott announced in the House of Commons this evening.

Anyone under the misapprehension that all hand-woven fabrics must of necessity resemble spongy, flecked, loosely woven tweeds might correct this impression by examining the twenty-seven weavings now being exhibited at the Bertha Schaefer Gallery, 32 East Fifty-seventh Street.

TORONTO, Sept. 19 -- The Canadian Government acted today to get at the full facts in the Noronic fire disaster, declaring that it would hold public hearings to establish whether negligence contributed to the loss of life.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- The Milwaukee Gas Light Company asked the Securities and Exchange Commission today for permission to borrow $4,000,000 from four banks during the next twelve months.
PARIS, Sept. 19 (UP) -- A French secret police official today told how dress pirates stole exclusive designs from such leaders of the Paris haute couture as Christian Dior and Jacques Fath.
LONDON, Sept. 19 (AP) -- Their pockets bulging with devalued pounds, the American Ryder Cup golfers fled to ticket agencies today trying to catch the next ship home.

MONTREAL, Sept. 19 (Canadian Press) -- Issuance of a writ of mandamus to force St. Lawrence Corporation, Ltd., to furnish certain financial information not contained in the organization's annual financial statement was upheld in Superior Court today in a judgment of Justice Arthur I. Smith.
Tie-in sales, which were widespread during the war when sugar was scarce and cabbage plentiful, have been revived with tickets to "South Pacific" as the bait, it was learned yesterday.

Only a head separated first from second and only a neck marked off the difference between place and show in the thirty-sixth running of the Fall Highweight Handicap as the Westchester Racing Association's three-week meeting opened at Belmont Park yesterday.

Col. P. T. Etherton, author of ten books of travel including one about the great deserts of the world, has a new book about deserts on Whittlesey House's list for Oct. 4 publication. "Across the Great Deserts" deals with the Sahara, the Kalahari and the Gobi, their strange peoples, customs and scenery and is illustrated with forty-five photographs.

" Spring in Park Lane," an English-made romantic comedy, which arrives at the Sixtieth Street Trans-Lux, is this morning's lone film newcomer. Anna Neagle and Michael Wilding head the cast of the importation, which is being released by Eagle Lion.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- The Friendly Service Group on Capitol Hill today announced that the 103d birthday of Adelaide Johnson, sculptor, would be celebrated with a reception in her honor next Sunday afternoon at the base of her statue of woman suffrage pioneers.

" Actors' Studio" will return for a second season to the American Broadcasting Company television network on Sept. 28, when the program will present Oscar Wilde's satirical fantasy, "The Canterville Ghost." The plays in the series will be telecast each Wednesday evening from 8 to 8:30 o'clock.

The mothers of a young Brooklyn bridal couple both died within two days of the marriage -- the bridegroom's mother last Thursday and the bride's mother yesterday, while about to attend a requiem mass for the daughter's mother-in-law.

PARIS, Sept. 19 -- Abolition of the present multiple exchange rates for the franc and adoption of a single free market rate of 350 francs to the dollar [.28 of a cent per franc] and 980 francs to the pound were ordered tonight by the French Government.

Following ten years of sales increases, the men's wear industry thus far this year has been fighting a losing battle for its share of the consumer dollar, according to a survey by Market Planning Service, a division of the National Credit Office, Inc.

Several changes in the executive staff of the International Business Machines Corporation were announced yesterday, including numerous promotions affecting its world-wide operations. They were occasioned by the rapid growth of IBM and its program of world expansion, requiring greater division of responsibility and increased executive personnel, Thomas J. Watson said after a meeting of directors.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 19 (AP) -- Cecil Isbell took the graceful way out by resigning today as coach of the battered Baltimore Colts and Walter S.
