Driskill was pulled out of the front office to take the job. Directors of the All-America Conference team emphasized that Isbell resigned after four straight defeats this season.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- The Department of Agriculture went on record today against changing price support rules in the middle of a production season.

New York's annual fuel bill of $400,000,000 can be reduced at least 2 per cent, or $8,000,000 a year, through elimination of smoke, William H. Byrne, director of the Smoke Control Bureau, told the Queens Chamber of Commerce yesterday.

Dean Harry J. Carman of Columbia College welcomed yesterday the largest freshman class in the college's history in McMillin Academic Theatre as Freshman Week activities got under way on the Columbia campus. The 675 freshmen hail from thirty states and twenty-seven foreign countries.

MARTHA'S VINEYARD, Mass., Sept. 19 -- In order to insure being at the right place at the right time, most of the visiting surfcasters practically "live" on the beach, and when the bass hit in close to shore they are ready for them.
LAKE PLACID, N. Y., Sept. 19 (AP) -- A newspaper executive called on publishers today to oppose "complete government control."

ALBANY, Sept. 19 -- Governor Dewey made public today a letter from Owen D. Young, retired industrialist and prominent Democrat, announcing the latter's support of John Foster Dulles, Republican candidate for the Senate.

William Z. Foster, national chairman of the Communist party, admitted yesterday he had used false names and made false statements to get passports for Russia, more times than he could remember. He also acknowledged having made pre-war statements that American Communists owed allegiance to the Soviet Union and the Red flag, and that they advocated violent revolution in this country.

Secretary of State Dean Acheson denounced last night the recent series of "plots and counter-plots" in the Caribbean area as "repugnant to the entire fabric of the inter-American system" and warned that the United States would use its "strongest efforts" to keep the peace of this hemisphere.

After half a century in the Worth Street district, Arthur Beir Co., textile converters, plan to move uptown to 1407 Broadway, where they have leased space in the forty-two-story building under construction at Thirty-ninth Street Announcement of the lease was made by S. M. Hirsch and William Zeckendorf, president and board chairman, respectively, of the 1407 Broadway Realty Corporation.

The Cunard White Star liner Queen Elizabeth arrived here yesterday from Cherbourg and Southampton with 2,225 passengers, among them Princess Barbara Hutton Troubetzkoy, Woolworth heiress, who said she was visiting her native land for the first time in three years for a thorough medical check-up.

Andrei Y. Vishinsky, Soviet Foreign Minister, arrived here yesterday with words of optimism for the success of the United Nations General Assembly's fourth session, which opens today at Flushing Meadow.

LONDON, Sept. 19 -- As Britain's bankers pondered the effects of devaluation behind closed doors today, stockbrokers and jobbers poured into narrow Throgmorton Street outside the closed Stock Exchange and soon had a booming market going in gold-mining, oil and industrial shares.

CHICAGO, Sept. 19 -- Rex Barney today moved within six outs of the second no-hitter of his career before Phil Cavarretta spoiled the magnificent bid with a solid single to right field to open the eighth inning.

PARIS, Sept. 19 -- The fourth general conference of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization was called to order at Unesco House this morning by its interim President, Ahmed Bey Daouk, Lebanese Minister to Paris.

The increasing list of international shipping conferences and related world parleys regularly held abroad has led to the formation of a special committee of American shipping executives to represent the industry in such meetings, the National Federation of American Shipping announced yesterday.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 19 -- Procedure for settling the claims that precipitated the strike Of 5,200 trainmen on the Aissouri Pacific Railroad reached a stalemate today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- A Presidential emergency board sweepingly rejected today the appeal of the Brotherhood of Locomotive Firemen and Enginemen to place an additional fireman on the various types of Diesel locomotives.
Your editorial "The Career and Pay Study," appearing in THE TIMES on Sept. 14, was excellent. It pointed out the need to get the classification study under way.

Edmund H. H. Caddy, Republican candidate for District Attorney of Kings County, accepted yesterday the American Labor party endorsement for the post. He filed his acceptance of the left-wing nomination with the Board of Elections.
DELAWARE, Ohio, Sept. 19 (AP) -- Five horses piled up today on the first turn of the first race as Grand Circuit harness racing got under way at the Delaware County Fair.
Jules Bell has been promoted to treasurer of the FR Corporation. Robert Barth has been promoted to vice president in charge of production.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Sept. 19 -- The dollar-pegged Deutsche mark in Western Germany -- officially worth thirty cents -- undoubtedly will be devalued within a few days, possibly tomorrow or Wednesday, official sources said today.

Odds were estimated at 400 to 1 that the prettily embroidered bundle from Peru's Paracas Peninsula actually contains the mummy of a pre-Inca priest, but the lone chance that it may hide no more than a bag of beans stirred archeologists yesterday.

CHICAGO, Sept. 19 (AP) -- The largest Monday receipts of hogs in seven weeks trimmed prices 25 to 50 cents a hundred pounds today. Cattle were unevenly 50 cents higher to 25 cents lower, however, and sheep were steady to weak.

Mystified at the loss of $200,000 worth of business during the last two years, Sanford Megdall, president of the Fulton Frame Company, of 49 West Twenty-seventh Street, recently appealed to the police and last night got what they said was the explanation.

LONDON, Sept. 19 -- Somewhat dazed by the financial shock, leaders of British labor, business and industry undertook today the difficult task of adjusting their policies to yesterday's drastic devaluation of the pound.

John G. Foster's letter in THE TIMES of Sept. 14 regarding the effect of pensions for industrial workers on the mobility of the labor market deserves the most serious attention. This letter points out that while employers may find it handy to hold workers at low pay by threatening to foreclose on their pension rights, it is economically harmful to the nation.
TEL AVIV, Israel, Sept. 19 -- After devaluation of the soft currencies, Israel today is in a novel economic position.

TOKYO, Sept. 19 -- Formosans in increasing numbers are fleeing to Japan. Their motive is to seek refuge from a possible immediate Communist coup in the island and to protest against the reported mistreatment of Formosan natives by Nationalist troops and administrators from the Chinese mainland.
ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Sept. 19 (AP) -- In a three-way photo finish, Jerry McCarthy Stables' Mint O'Morn captured the six-furlong Trenton Purse, best race on today's program.

ITHACA, N. Y., Sept. 19 -- In his second year as head football coach, George K. (Lefty) James gave Cornell its first Ivy League championship since 1939. This season the Big Red has loftier ambitions. At any rate greatness has been thrust upon it in its designation, with Army, as the pride of the East, and the Ithacans are as willing as Barkis to accept the nomination.
SEOUL, Korea, Sept. 19 -- President Syngman Rhee called today for the establishment of "more satisfactory commercial relations between Korea and Japan."

PROVIDENCE, R. I., Sept. 19 -- The problem of reporting international negotiations was one in which the press should make some concessions, Dr. Philip C. Jessup, United States Ambassador-at-Large, said here today in commenting on the coverage of United Nations sessions.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Sept. 19 -- Public works engineers of the United States are trying to learn how to coordinate the demand for public services, their own planning and the taxpayer's pocketbook. And one of their chief advisers in this effort is a woman, Dr. Mabel L. Walker.

When the General Assembly of the United Nations opens here today there will be relatively little "new business" on its agenda, Most of the problems with which it will deal have been broached before. When the Assembly takes them up again it would be more accurate, however, not to employ the familiar "unfinished business," but to think of them rather as "continuing" business.

GENEVA, Sept. 19 -- Financial quarters here and in Zurich expressed the view today that after having been a source of difficulty to the entire world because of its overvaluation the pound sterling might suddenly become a source of equal difficulty because of undervaluation.
The Democratic campaign in New York City swung into high gear yesterday.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Sept. 19 -- A Governor and a United States Senator today urged the Federal Government to end its encroachment on the powers of the states and to surender to the states sufficient tax sources for the support of necessary services.

The annual fund drive of the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York is particularly signficant this year because much of the $50,500,000 goal is earmarked for rounding out the organization's $54,000,000 building program. Of the necessary building funds, $20,000,000 already is on hand, and of this sum $10,000,000 has been spent on construction work.

BERLIN, Sept. 19 -- The probable devaluation of the West mark was hailed characteristically here today by the Soviet - sponsored press as forecasting "a fearful if not fatal blow" for the administration in the Western sectors of Berlin.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 19 -- Eleanor Parker, Ruth Roman and Patricia Neal will play the leading roles in "Rock Bottom," which Milton Sperling will produce at Warner Brothers from a scenario by Gina Kaus. The photoplay deals with illegitimacy, and Robert Wise will direct it, starting next month.

A temporary order enjoining the Federal Communications Commission from enforcing its order of Aug. 18 banning the broadcasting of give-away programs after Oct. 1 will be granted to three major networks pending ruling of a three-judge court on a permanent injunction, Federal Judge Simon H. Rifkind announced yesterday.
Reduced prices and accelerated sales of British automobiles in this country were forecast yesterday as a result of the devaluation of the pound.

The devaluation of the pound sterling from $4.03 to $2.80, announced on Sunday by Sir Stafford Cripps, was an extraordinarily well-kept secret. The time of the event and the extent of the depreciation both came as a surprise, particularly the latter. Conjecture regarding the new rate seldom placed it below $3, while guesses for the most part ranged from $3.20 to $3.50.

BUDAPEST, Sept. 19 (UP) -- Dr. Szoenyi said that the United States in 1944 had ordered infiltration of Eastern European Communist parties when it became "clear" that the Soviet Army would liberate that area.

Once more the deputies of the Big Four Foreign Ministers are going to dive into the intricacies of reparations, war booty and German assets and try to come up with a draft peace treaty for Austria. This time the meeting is to be held in New York and it will start on Thursday.

The New York State Federation of Labor, AFL, through its nonpartisan committee, formally endorsed former Gov. Herbert H. Lehman yesterday for United States Senator. The action was taken unanimously at a meeting of seventeen of the twenty-four committee members at the Commodore Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- Four-power negotiations on a state treaty for Austria will be resumed in New York Thursday as the result of an agreement reached with Russia, the State Department announced today.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Sept 19 (AP) -- Rutgers University trustees gave official approval today to location of a National football Hall of Fame shrine on the campus here.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (AP) -- Text of the United States note to Rumania, substantially the same as notes also sent to Bulgaria and Hungary, on peace treaty violations:

TRENTON, Sept. 19 -- The Port of New York Authority was requested today by Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll after a conference with a delegation from the Hoboken Chamber of Commerce to negotiate immediately with the Federal Maritime Commission for restoration and operation of the old Hamburg American Line piers at Hoboken.

" Rear Admiral" John Maitland Collins, late of the "S. S. Bowery," was back in the brig yesterday with two more days to dream of faded naval glory before being sentenced on a charge of impersonating a naval officer.

NEWTON, N. C., Sept. 19 (UP) -- The locomotive and six cars of a Southern Railway passenger train left the rails on a sharp curve early today, killing two dining car cooks and sending thirty-four persons to hospitals.
Joe DiMaggio was still missing from the Yankee line-up yesterday, but you would have a time getting Lou Boudreau and his Indians to concede that this in any way slowed down the pace of the Bombers.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- At least one British spokesman in Washington today talked of devaluation of the pound sterling in nothing but the most enthusiastic terms.

Lilly Dache's fall and winter collection is a tour de force, for not only does this vital little French lady turn out some good looking hats -- she also does an excellent dress collection. It is interesting to see unity of thought governing a costume from head to hemline. This showing took place yesterday afternoon in the salon of her apartment, above her establishment at 78 East Fifty-sixth Street.

SCRANTON, Pa., Sept. 19 -- Production of hard coal, already lagging 4,400,000 tons behind estimated demand, was halted today at all but one anthracite colliery by a walkout of about 80,000 members of the United Mine Workers.

New York traders said yesterday that the true effects of devaluation on the United States market would not be known for a week to a month. They also cited a series of factors that might nullify the hoped-for benefits.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores dropped 6 per cent last week below the corresponding week last year, according to the "flash" report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The decline for the four weeks ended last Saturday was 2 per cent.
PITTSBURGH, Sept. 19 -- Nearly all the 480,000 members of John L. Lewis' United Mine Workers quit work today, choking off the production of soft and hard coal in twenty states.

DETROIT, Sept. 19 -- The United Automobile Workers, CIO, today handed the Ford Motor Company an ultimatum to improve its pension offer in ten days or face a strike by its 116,000 hourly paid employes in forty-seven plants in twenty states.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- Senator Joseph C. O'Mahoney, Democrat, of Wyoming, warned today that the United States was headed down the road to totalitarianism as a result of the throttling of competitive enterprise by monopoly.
The financial community here reacted with mixed feelings yesterday to Britain's devaluation of the pound.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- The Senate confirmed by 45 to 25 today President Truman's nomination of John Carson of Michigan to be a member of the Federal Trade Commission.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Sept. 19 -- Private industrial corporations were urged here tonight by Dr. Linus Pauling, president of the American Chemical Society, to create a great foundation for scientific research that would provide $75,000,000 a year for the promotion of basic scientific knowledge in university laboratories.

CHICAGO, Sept. 19 -- All preliminary motions in the Tucker Corporation grand jury case were overruled today by Federal District Judge Walter J. LaBuy, clearing the way for the opening of the trial of eight present and former corporation executives and employes on Oct. 3. Preston Tucker, president of the company, and the seven other defendants were indicted by the jury in June on charges of violating the mail-fraud statute and the Securities Act.

CHICAGO, Sept. 19 -- Commodity prices broke sharply on the Board of Trade today as the result of announcement of devaluation of many foreign currencies. Although there were numerous sharp rallies on short covering the close was around the low for the day with wheat off 5/8 to 2 3/4 cents.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- Reversing the decision of "no contest" made late Sunday when rough waters on the Potomac prevented the second and third heats for the President's Cup, the regatta moguls this morning announced My Sweetie as the official winner for 1949.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., Sept. 20 -- Football at Syracuse has been in a sickly state for some years and any man who can restore it to robust health will be looked upon as a miracle worker by the downtown quarterback faithful in this hotbed of the game.

GENEVA, Sept. 20 -- Europe's "apparent" coal and coke deficit will be reduced nearly 25 per cent in the fourth quarter of 1949, compared to the current quarter, the coal committee of the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe announced today.

NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 20 (UP) -- Two storms have been located in the Gulf of Mexico, one of them near the Louisiana coast, the Weather Bureau said tonight. The forecaster, Welby R. Stevens, located one of them 300 miles south-southwest of New Orleans and the other 150 miles southeast of Galveston, Tex.

DETROIT, Sept. 20 -- The Ford Motor Company announced tonight that it was ready to grant its employes a pension plan in line with the terms outlined by the Presidential fact-finding board in the steel dispute.

In reply to your editorial "Manana on Margarine" in THE NEW YORK TIMES for Sept. 15, the real issue in the butter-oleo controversy seems to have escaped you. That issue is no longer the repeal of federal taxes. Leading dairy and farm organizations have favored repeal of such taxes since October, 1948.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, Sept. 20 (AP) -- A brunette woman officially described as the former mistress of a Yugoslav diplomat testified today that a hunting trip had been the setting for some anti-Hungarian plotting by Yugoslavia's Minister of the Interior, Col. Gen. Alexander Rankovitch.
ALBANY, Sept. 20 -- Although new community and liberal arts colleges are needed in the state, local communities are unable to pay for them, mayors and educational leaders testified here today.

Devaluation jitters, which affected trading in foreign exchange markets here Monday, had pretty well disappeared yesterday and transactions in pounds sterling and other currencies were carried on at the readjusted prices without confusion.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 -- Senator Herbert R. O'Conor, Democrat, of Maryland, accused the State Department today of discouraging efforts to plug immigration loopholes that permit the entry of subversives who "plot with impunity the destruction of our free institutions."

After a warm discussion, the City Council approved yesterday a bill that would give the City Temporary Housing Rent Commission power to pass upon rent increases granted under the Federal net operating income formula.

Directors of the Southern Company, successor in reorganization to the Commonwealth and Southern Corporation, declared yesterday a quarterly dividend of 20 cents each on the 12,020,000 common shares, payable on next Monday, Sept. 26, to Commonwealth Southern, owner of the stock. The announcement was made after the board meeting in Atlanta, Ga., by Eugene A. Yates, president of Southern.
Railroad layoffs resulting from the national coal tie-up rose to more than 28,000 yesterday, and the number was expected to go higher in a few days.

A Peruvian who may have lived a thousand years before Christ was born emerged from dusty wrappings yesterday at noon into the glare of a baby spotlight. Scientists in gray smocks probed with forceps into a brownish heap and scattered pulverized fabric to expose first a knee. Observers were struck by the mottled, greenish appearance of the skin, so tightly drawn that it seemed to be part of the bone.

Revision of its code of ethics governing conduct of brokers and other members to make it more definite and to include even verbal agreements and election of new governors marked the annual meeting of the board of governors of the Real Estate Board of New York yesterday at the Commodore Hotel.

Following the anti-trust suit recently brought against it by the Federal Government, the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company launched yesterday a nation-wide newspaper advertising campaign asking the public if it wants the company put out of business.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 (AP) -- More than 10,000,000 World War II veterans have applied for the special life insurance dividend to be paid next year, the Veterans Administration said today.

The shift from daylight saving time to standard time next Sunday will bring into effect a number of railroad timetable changes designed to speed up services. The change-over will be easiest as usual for the Long Island Rail Road and New York, New Haven Hartford commuter schedules which now run on daylight and will be set back one hour without involving major timetable changes.

Another book by a top Air Force officer is scheduled for publication following shortly after Gen. H. H. (Hap) Arnold's "Global Mission." It is a report on the Pacific air war by Gen. George C. Kenney, wartime commander of the Fifth and Thirteenth Air Forces.

British Foreign Secretary Ernest Bevin said last night that the Western powers would never use their scientific achievements in military fields to attack or destroy other nations. Mr. Bevin told 1,000 leading United Nations delegates and their guests that the Western powers were determined to take every step to avoid using atomic weapons.

NEWARK, N. J., Sept. 20 -- The Federal Grand Jury opened an investigation today of possible criminal responsibility for the explosion and fire in the Holland Tunnel last May 13. Seven witnesses of a list of fifteen were questioned by United States Attorney Alfred A. Modarelli and his first assistant, Charles J. Tyne.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 -- Conversations that may go a long way in determining the future of atomic research by the Western World began today between the United States, Great Britain and Canada.

HONG KONG, Sept. 20 -- Communist acquisition of the big Inner Mongolian province of Suiyuan was revealed in a Communist New China News Agency broadcast from Peiping received here tonight. The agency reported that Suiyuan had been absorbed into the Communist orbit through the decision of Gen. Tung Chi-wu, Suiyuan Governor, to throw in his lot with the Communists.

LONDON, Sept. 20 -- The Cabinet is expected to meet Thursday to plan political and economic strategy for full exploitation of the pound's devaluation. At that session it is expected the Government will accede to the demand of the minority opposition for reconvening of Parliament now in recess for a debate of two or three days next week on Sir Stafford Cripps' handling of the nation's financial crisis.
At sundown on Friday the shofar, or ancient ram's horn trumpet, will sound throughout the world, marking the eve of Rosh ha-Shanah and ushering in the year 5710 in the Hebrew calendar.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Wednesday Sept. 21 -- The Belgian Cabinet decided this morning to devalue the Belgian franc by 12.34 per cent, setting a new rate of 50 francs to the United States dollar. The old rate was 43.8.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 -- The Senate Democratic policy committee, striving to clear measures on the Administration's "must" list, decided today to call up the Anderson farm bill next week, along with bills to liberalize the Displaced Persons Act of 1948.

PARIS, Sept. 20 -- George V. Allen, Assistant Secretary of State for Public Affairs, pledged the United States today to redouble its efforts in behalf of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization, and the goals for which it stood.
A list of commercial and pleasure boats, suitable for port security tasks if war should come again, will be complied soon by the Coast Guard, it was learned yesterday.

A new stainless steel subway train equipped with a public address system, illuminated maps, picture windows, fluorescent lighting and ventilating unit designed to filter and sterilize air was displayed by the Board of Transportation yesterday afternoon at the City Hall station of the BMT subway.
The Bureau of Labor Statistics announced yesterday a major revision in its estimates of employment, hours and earnings.

The performance of "Touch and Go," a musical revue by George Abbott, at the Broadhurst Theatre on Nov. 7 has been taken over by the Sheltering Arms Children's Service. The event will take the place of the annual winter card party and tea given by Mrs. Harold C. Richard in her home at 1060 Fifth Avenue.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 -- Hearings to examine the qualifications of Judge Sherman Minton as an Associate Supreme Court Justice will begin next Tuesday, and continue as long as necessary, committee members announced today. President Truman has designated Judge Minton as successor to the late Associate Justice Wiley B. Rutledge.

Construction was started this month on the New York section of a two-state express highway designed to alleviate the heavy mixed traffic to and from New England along the Boston Post Road, it was learned yesterday.

BOSTON, Sept. 20 -- Charles Munch, arriving today in Boston to begin his duties as conductor of the Boston Symphony Orchestra, said he was planning a series of special concerts commemorating noted composers during his first season as successor to Dr. Serge Koussevitzky.

Dr. Hans Kohn, noted historian, author and authority on nationalism, will assume his duties as Professor of History at City College this week, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Harry N. Wright, president of the college. Professor Kohn comes to the college from Smith College, where he had been Sydenham Clark Parsons Professor of History since 1934.

TOKYO, Sept. 15 -- Although Japan is drawing ambitious plans for shipping expansion, data on the leading steamship companies indicate that extraordinary means must be found to finance the new construction. The shipping companies don't have the money.

The semi-annual report of Montgomery Ward Co. covering the six months ended with last July, issued yesterday, showed a decline of 12.9 per cent in sales from the level of the corresponding period of 1948, and a drop of $15,975,316 or 51.6 per cent in earnings.

Price cuts of 9 1/2 to 20 per cent on several lines of British imports were announced here yesterday. Prices were still withdrawn on a variety of English and other foreign merchandise, particularly textiles, but indications multiplied that the new quotations would not reflect the full cut of 30 per cent in the pound sterling.

Spring Hill Farm's Nell K., back from a Chicago campaign in which she didn't do much more than earn her train fare, was much the best of the seven 3-year-old fillies that competed in Belmont Park's top race yesterday. It was a six-furlong main-course sprint; she won it with two and a half lengths to spare.

LONDON, Sept. 20 -- After months of negotiations, a long-term trade agreement between Britain and Yugoslavia, including a sizable British credit to Premier Marshal Tito's Government, appeared tonight to be on the verge of completion. There was talk in London that the loan would amount to 8,000,000 (about $22,400,000).
LONDON, Sept. 20 -- In a surprise move last week South Africa took repayment in sterling of the whole remainder of her gold loan to Britain.

Modern artillery fire control and other new coast defense methods have made many of New York Harbor's military defenses obsolete, and the Department of the Army is disposing of nineteen coast defense sites, it was announced yesterday.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., Sept. 20 -- One more race was concluded today in the International team yachting match between Bermuda and this country. Another was tried, but two Bermuda sloops were blown out in a blast of wind and tumbling sea, as was one of the Long Island Sound fleet.

A study of hospital staff appointments made by the Hospital Council of Greater New York and released yesterday showed that 170, or 75.6 per cent, of the 225 Negro physicians registered to practice in the city as of Jan. 1, last, have at least one such staff appointment.
CANTON, China, Sept. 20 (AP) -- Chiang Kai-shek today urged every Chinese to join the "life and death struggle" with the Communists and save China from becoming a Russian vassal.

Three leading carpet mills yesterday ruled out price reductions as a result of devaluation of the pound and other currencies and two of them indicated that increases might be put into effect soon. All agreed that devaluation so far had not offset higher carpet wool costs, since reductions were made in June and July in expectation that such wool costs would be lower.

NEWARK, N. J., Sept. 20 -- A new kind of training is necessary "to keep children and adults emotionally stable, in the face of modern radio and television," Dr. Albert Jochen, director of the Middlesex County Vocational High School, New Brunswick, told 200 delegates of the New Jersey Congress of Parents and Teachers today at the annual North Jersey sectional meeting.

ITHACA, N. Y., Sept. 20 -- Senator John Foster Dulles, seeking election to the Senate on the Republican ticket, today pictured former Gov. Herbert H. Lehman, his adversary, as a potential "rubber stamp" for "grandiose" and "fantastic" spending programs of the Truman Administration that would force steep rises in Federal taxes.

KANSAS CITY, Sept. 20 -- City engineers and street commissioners from across the nation today compared problems at second-day sessions of the fifty-fifth annual Public Works Congress. Eight hundred officials are registered for the three-day convention.

Secretary of Defense Louis Johnson's recent brief tiff with Senator Elmer Thomas, Democrat, of Oklahoma, about military air transportation for Congressmen touched lightly upon one area of military operations where savings might be made.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Sept. 20 (UP) -- William Hugh Morris, director of the Federated Ku Klux Klan in Alabama, was released from jail today after serving sixty-seven days for contempt of court.

ALBANY, Sept. 20 -- Governor Dewey's office said today that a member of the Governor's legal staff would meet with a delegation of the groups who plan to "march on the Capitol" tomorrow in protest against the handling of the investigation of disorders that followed the Paul Robeson concert near Peekskill Sept. 4.

Charges that Albert B. Chandler, as baseball commissioner, wields more power in "a state within a state" than any public official and that organized baseball was a "superstructure of monopolistic power" were made yesterday in the second day of a deposition examination of Mr. Chandler preliminary to a hearing in the $300,000 damage suit of former Giant outfielder Danny Gardella.

CHICAGO, Sept. 20 -- Another great pitching performance, this time by Jack Banta, today gave the Dodgers a 5-0 victory over the Cubs for a three-game sweep. It sent the Brooks away to St. Louis for tomorrow's afternoon-night twin bill with the Cards a game and a half back, but still convinced that the pennant can be won.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 -- Upon closer scrutiny of the record, the State Department acknowledged today that Dr. Theodor Heuss, President of the new German Federal Republic, had voted in the Reichstag for the enabling act that gave Hitler his dictatorial powers.

A charge made yesterday by the American Jewish League Against Communism, Inc., that Communists and pro-Communists occupied positions of influence in the New York Public Library, was repudiated by Ralph A. Beals, director of the library.

WARSAW, Sept. 19 -- An ideological offensive against "foxholes of reaction" in Polish universities was announced today by Marian Rybicki, first secretary of the Polish United Workers (Communist) party executive committee, in Cracow.
The last of four thugs accused of abducting, beating and robbing a Harvard youth on June 16 was arrested last night at his Brooklyn home, according to the police.

A combination of domestic labor-management troubles and second-day reaction to the wave of devaluation of foreign currencies produced such a preponderance of selling yesterday that the stock market took its sharpest dive thus far this year. Prices fell 1 to 3 points as buyers stepped aside and allowed stocks to reach their own levels.

Dr. Paul Siple, Antarctic explorer and expert on climate conditions, presented yesterday a report on twenty-seven months' study of weather data on various United States urban centers. As chief of the "climate control project" conducted by House Beautiful, Dr. Siple was a speaker at a forum held by the magazine at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

The next time a curious school child, on a tour of the Bronx Zoo with his class and teacher, asks, "Are apes right or left-handed?" the harassed teacher will know what to say. She may not know the answer herself, but she will know where to send the child for the information.

BUFFALO, N. Y., Sept. 20 -- The Bell Aircraft Corporation accepted tonight the strike settlement formula developed jointly by the New York State Mediation Board and the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service and designed to end the walkout of 1,700 production workers on June 13.

MOSCOW, Sept. 20 -- The newspaper Soviet Sport, charging that the purpose of sport in the United States and other bourgeois countries was to train youth for war, attacked the Young Men's Christian Association in America as designed to poison young minds with racial propaganda and extoll militarism.

You had occasion on Sept 10 to comment upon the subject of "Quotas for Orientals," in which you urged fair play and removal of discriminatory practices by our Government. No doubt you had reference to the repeal of the Chinese Exclusion Laws, giving persons of the Chinese race a small annual quota of 105 and making them racially eligible for naturalization.

TRENTON, N. J., Sept. 20 -- Opening of the 118-mile New Jersey Turnpike, projected north-south artery to relieve through traffic congestion, will take place in November, 1951, according to engineering reports announced today by Paul L. Troast, chairman of the Turnpike Authority.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 -- Philip Murray today postponed the meeting of the United Steelworkers wage-policy meeting for twenty-four hours to permit the Government to make another effort to mediate the dispute over pensions and social insurance that threatens a strike in the steel industry at midnight Saturday.

TADWORTH, England, Sept. 20 (AP) -- Johnny Palmer of Badin N. C., started his revenge campaign for his Ryder Cup defeats today by ousting Bert Williamson of England in a first-round match of the British Professional Golfers Association championships.

Plans for the rehabilitation of Pier 42, North River, at Morton Street, which will be leased to the Norwegian America Line, were announced yesterday by Commissioner G. Joseph Minetti of the Department of Marine and Aviation.

A certain number of persons sniff with mixed feelings at those cool breezes sweeping across Manhattan of late. They may concede that August's heat was dreadful, but they are certain that what is presaged by these chill airs will be, in its way, worse.

Shipping operators and employer stevedores made another offer yesterday to the International Longshoremen's Association, AFL, in an effort to work out a new wage agreement before the end of the month.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 20 -- A new course of action designed to dislodge the Missouri Pacific Railroad from its present position is being considered by the four Railway Brotherhoods whose strike has tied up the 7,200-mile system for twelve days.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 20 -- Stepping up the speed of military planes to 1,500 to 2,000 miles an hour and extending their range at the same time are the chief aims of American aeronautical engineers, it was explained here today.

Declaring that this session of the United Nations General Assembly "coincides with a turning point in post-war international relations," Brig. Gen. Carlos P. Romulo, its newly elected President, yesterday called on the delegates from fifty-nine countries to win for it the title of the "peace Assembly."

It was Allie Reynolds and Joe Page in another of their scintillating pitching tandems at the Stadium yesterday as the Yankees reeled off one more important triumph in their whirlwind dash to the tape.
PITTSBURGH, Sept. 20 (AP) -- The Braves exploded for three runs in the top of the ninth tonight to beat the Pirates, 4 -- 2.

BONN, Germany, Sept. 20 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer presented his first Cabinet to the Bundestag today and delivered a warning that there would be no peace in Europe unless Germany were reunited. His entire policy address was colored by repeated denunciation of Soviet policy on Germany.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 -- President Truman was fascinated today by a report on the biggest jigsaw puzzle in the world, one that will take seven or eight years to complete.

Richard (Pancho) Gonzales, 21-year-old national singles champion from Los Angeles, yesterday joined the professional tennis ranks. The Californian signed a one-year contract to tour as a pro under the direction of Bobby Riggs.

A fashion show of custom designs was presented yesterday afternoon by Sydell of 666 Fifth Avenue. The occasion was the annual women's day luncheon of the Invitation Club, an organization of business men who service hotels.

The director of New York City's Bureau of Smoke Control gave a little lecture on the economics of smoke in addressing the Queens Chamber of Commerce. He put the cost of fuel burned annually in the city at $400,000,000, and estimated that $8,000,000, or 2 per cent, could be saved if the waste in smoke were eliminated.

LONG BRANCH, N. J., Sept. 20 -- Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll tonight told members of the Young Republican Club of Monmouth County that State Senator Elmer Wene, his Democratic opponent, was "bent upon saddling New Jersey with the big-taxing, big-spending rule or ruin practices of his sponsor, the discredited Boss Frank Hague."

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 20 -- Northern coal operators poured $3,000,000 in royalties into the depleted Welfare Fund of John L. Lewis' United Mine Workers today as the union's 480,000 members in the soft and hard coal fields continued their "no welfare, no work" strike for the second day.

Reverberations of Britain's currency devaluation resounded in the Commodity Exchange yesterday where trading in rubber futures set a new post-war record for volume and reaction was even more violent than it was on Monday. Prices for rubber futures were off as much as 115 points following Monday's steep decline, but the market displayed rallying tendencies in the final two hours of trading, and closing levels were only 75 to 95 points net lower.
LAKE SUCCESS, Sept. 20 -- The long dispute between India and Pakistan over the princely state of Kashmir was returned in deadlock today to the United Nations Security Council.

SUMMIT, N. J., Sept. 20 -- Mrs. William Hockenjos Jr. of Baltusrol, defending champion, and Mrs. Catherine Fox Park of Glen Ridge carded 84s to share the medal in the qualifying round of the twenty-fourth New Jersey Golf Association championship at the Canoe Brook Country Club today.

The trial of Laszlo Rajk, former Hungarian Minister of Foreign Affairs, and his associates in Budapest is drawing to a close. There is no winning post for anyone except, perhaps, Josef Stalin. The men involved are running toward their death with an eagerness that must make good men shudder.

Thomas J. Curran, New York County Republican leader, called upon his fellow Republicans last night to elect John Foster Dules to the United States Senate and thus ease the way to draft Governor Dewey for another four-year term next year.

Charges by the Veterans Administration that many veterans are using their GI privileges to take insignificant or useless courses were decried yesterday by Albert A. Senft, chairman of the board of directors of the New York Chapter of the National Association of Private Schools, as a "complete distortion of the excellent job private trade schools are doing."

A brief case that apparently had been blown yesterday from a ledge of the observation tower on the Radio Corporation of America Building at 30 Rockefeller Plaza ended its seventy-story fall on the roof of a Forty-ninth Street crosstown bus. It was returned later, undamaged, to its owner.

Paul Robeson, singer and actor, was called as a defense witness at the Communist trial yesterday, but did not get a chance to testify on anything of importance. On objections by United States Attorney John F. X. McGohey, Federal Judge Harold R. Medina ruled out almost all questions asked by defense counsel as irrelevant.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Sept. 20 -- The Netherlands Government announced today that the guilder would follow the pound and other sterling area currencies with a 30.5 per cent devaluation. The new guilder rate will be 3.8 to the dollar, compared with 2.65 previously.
The State of Pennsylvania announced yesterday that it would receive bids Oct. 4 on an issue of $8,500,000 of series L bonds dated Oct. 1, 1949, and due Oct. 1, 1950 to 1961.

Representative Vito Marcantonio, American Labor party candidate for Mayor, opened his Brooklyn campaign last night with an attack on Brooklyn Borough President Johit Cashmore and Mayor O'Dwyer. He charged that Mr. Cashmore was not "aware" of the problems of housing, discrimination, police brutality against Negroes, or rent control.

Territorial sales restrictions on distributors and dealers handling General Motors products are being revised in selling agreements, officials revealed yesterday. New contracts will affect sales practices of more than 16,000 dealers in trucks, cars and service parts, as well as several thousand dealers in household appliances and diesel engines.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Sept. 20 (Reuters) -- Shouting dealers tried frantically to buy gold shares -- for which only a tenth of the demand could be met -- when the Johannesburg Stock Exchange opened this morning.

PRETORIA, South Africa, Sept. 20 -- Overshadowing the boom in gold shares when the stock exchanges reopened today after devaluation was the announcement of the Government this afternoon that the gold content of cores from certain boreholes had been fraudulently increased last June before assay.

Congress will enact legislation to stiffen the penalties for violators of existing anti-trust and anti-price laws, according to Representative Wright Patman, Democrat, of Texas. He declared yesterday that the House Small Business Committee was studying problems of small business with a view to introduction of remedial measures at the current session of Congress.

A further increase in the short interest on the New York Stock Exchange in the last month carried the position to the highest in seventeen years. On Sept. 15 settlement date, the total was 2,133,700 shares, or 127,581 more than the Aug. 15 figure of 2,006,119 shares, the Exchange reported yesterday.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 20 -- The left-wing administration of the United Electrical Workers, apparently certain of re-election after scoring a 3-to-2 margin in a "decisive" test vote, declared tonight that it would withdraw from the Congress of Industrial Organizations before it would yield on its claims to autonomy in political and economic action.

WATERBURY, Conn., Sept. 20 -- Willie Pep, Hartford featherweight, went through a token defense of his world title at the expense of Eddie Compo of New Haven at Municipal Stadium tonight. Opposing a gladiator who had little to recommend him except courage Pep was returned the victor by a knockout in the seventh of the scheduled fifteen-round fight on his twenty-seventh birthday anniversary.

BLUEFIELD, W. Va., Sept. 20 (AP) -- John L. Lewis' mine union said bluntly today that it will not bargain further on a new wage contract with southern coft coal operators until past-due payments are made to the miners' welfare and pension fund.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 -- The House returns to work tomorrow after almost a month's vacation, with delayed appropriations the first order of business. The rest of its session-end program, however, is undecided.

CHICAGO, Sept. 20 -- Bishop Germanos Polizoides of the Hellenic Orthodox Diocese of New York was nominated today to be Archbishop and Metropolitan of North and South America at a meeting of the Greek Ministers Benevolent Association in Annunciation Church here.
PAWTUCKET, R. I., Sept. 20 (AP) -- A pari-mutuel pay-off of $566.80 for $2 -- largest in the sixteen-year history of New England racing -- went up on the tote board at Narragansett Park today.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Sept. 20 -- Completing a study of the grand jury law as it applies to Westchester, District Attorney George M. Fanelli decided today to ask the regular October grand jury instead of a special grand jury to investigate the recent violence near Peekskill between followers of Paul Robeson and anti-Communist groups of the area.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 20 -- Traders in United States goods here said today the Middle East might be the area in which United States commerce would suffer most severely as a result of sterling area devaluations. The explanation for this prophecy was that there was little chance of any significant increase of sales to the dollar area.
Lower Broadway wasn't lined with cheering thousands or strewn with the snow of ticker tape yesterday noon, but William C. Lebow of Clovis, N. M., didn't mind.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 20 (AP) -- John (Pick) Wagner, 35-year-old auditor for a Wilmette, Ill., fuel company, won the medal in the Western Amateur golf tournament today with a thirty-six-hole score of 145, three strokes over par.

If things work out, as they sometimes do, Burgess Meredith will return to Broadway in "Happy As Larry," it became known yesterday. Besides starring in Donagh MacDonagh's Irish fantasy, written in verse, the actor also will stage the offering, already performed in Dublin and London. His interest in the project is not a spur-of-the-moment infatuation. On the contrary, he has been sizing up the venture nigh onto two years.

LONDON, Sept. 20 -- In the strictest privacy the General Council of the British Trades Union Congress talked for nearly four hours today about the effects of devaluation of the pound, but was still unable to offer any guidance to the 8,000,000 members of the congress, hundreds of thousands of whom are in the mood of revolt.

Recent showings of fabrics for the home give every indication that when it comes to textured, unprinted textiles, those for apparel use and those for the home are becoming more and more closely related. Though perhaps, unintentional, this fact was apparent in three collections of fabrics for decorating shown yesterday.

Yugoslavia's bolt from the solid Slav bloc dominated by the Soviet Union held the spotlight of public attention at the opening session of the United Nations General Assembly at Flushing Meadow yesterday.

Pan American Airways completed arrangements yesterday for a loan of $59,000,000 from a syndicate of thirty of the nation's largest banks, including seven in New York City, in connection with its proposed acquisition of American Overseas Airlines.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 20 -- A suggested platform for every western candidate of the Democratic party in 1950, including a demand for "immediate creation" of a Columbia Valley Administration and a Missouri Valley Authority, was adopted today by the Western States Democratic Conference.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 (UP) -- The Senate Committee on Expenditures in the Executive Departments reported today that the Federal Government's civilian payroll was slowly increasing despite economy efforts.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, who has represented the United States at all of the United Nations' General Assembly sessions, found a new note of "good-feeling and confidence" prevailing yesterday at the opening of the fourth Assembly at Flushing Meadow.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Sept. 20 -- The arrest of more than thirty priests and church functionaries, including a Slovak priest who had refused to perform a marriage of two supporters of the excommunicated "Catholic Action" movement, was reported by reliable sources today.
OTTAWA, Sept. 20 -- In assessing the probable economic effect of the 10 per cent devaluation of their dollar many Canadians tend to believe that they will lose more than they gain.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 (AP) -- A National Education Association commission today accused the Grand Prairie, Texas, school board of "an unwarranted attempt" to deny teachers their civil rights in the firing of five teachers there last month.

The last forty-eight hours of commotion, consternation and bewilderment in many countries of the world is a reminder that devaluation of currencies is much more than a statistical figuration worked out by economists and financiers in their quiet offices. The lives of hundreds of millions of people are going to be directly affected by what has been done in these last few days.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Sept. 20 -- According to official figures, 4,659 carefully picked Germans have received permanent immigration visas for the United States since visa restrictions were lifted last May.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Sept. 20 (AP) -- Sweden's devaluation of the Swedish krona was hailed by the export industry and shipping today, but the home-market industry was concerned over rising prices.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 (AP) -- Civil Aeronautics Board examiner today recommended that Pan American Airways, Inc., be permitted to absorb its parent holding company, the Pan American Airways Corporation.
Three leaders of different industries agreed yesterday in predicting greater farm production and the growth of the food industry.

TRENTON, N. J., Sept. 20 -- Republican party leaders in New Jersey were urged today by Attorney General Theodore D. Parsons to put on a more aggressive campaign for re-election of Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 -- A new civilian components policy board was appointed today by Louis Johnson, Secretary of Defense, to develop unified policies relating to all the reserve military components, which constitute the backbone of the nation's defense policies.
Trading in cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange was quiet and steady yesterday, and final quotations were 1 point lower to 4 points higher than on Monday.

The acceptance by major party candidates of support from the Communist-dominated American Labor party became a full-fledged state campaign issue yesterday. It was provoked by the acceptance of ALP designations by two Republican candidates in Brooklyn -- Edmund H. H. Caddy, nominee for District Attorney, and Francis X. Giaccone, now sitting on the Supreme Court by appointment of Governor Dewey, and seeking election for a full term this fall.

Women everywhere should be stirred by the latest news from Syria. For in Damascus, oldest living city in the world, and throughout that entire country, Arab women at the next elections are to go to the polls and vote. It is good news.

It has been the practice of bond houses competing for new issues of securities to reveal to each other right after the bidding deadline, the sealed offer which each had submitted, but unprecedented twists in yesterday's postponed sale of $4,000,000 of bonds of the Wisconsin Public Service Corporation may lead to an end of the practice.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 -- People are still congratulating President Truman on his startling November election victory. One who came to shake hands on that today was Senator Glen H. Taylor of Idaho.

Henry L. Stimson, who served in the Cabinets of four Presidents, will celebrate his eighty - second birthday today with a family party at his summer home in the West Hills section of Huntington, L. I., it was said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 -- Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg of Michigan, the Republican foreign policy leader, appealed today for the $1,314,010,000 foreign military aid program as "a bargain insurance policy for peace." The project is intended to help arm this country's European partners in the North Atlantic defensive alliance with other non-Communist lands.

TRENTON, N. J., Sept. 20 (AP) -- New Jersey's much investigated Temporary Disability Benefits Fund sold securities for the first time today under a new procedure -- by advertising for competitive bids. Four blocks of securities valued at $817,000 were sold at a net profit of $13,529.13.

Jacob Gross looked out of the window of his new home yesterday and saw America. It was a big place bordered on the corner opposite his grandfather's house at 334 Hopkinson Avenue in Brooklyn, a row of brown tenements and a blue sky. And it bustled with things that seemed odd to the pale child orphaned soon after he was born two years ago in Rumania.

LONDON, Sept. 20 -- As transatlantic ship and air agencies conferred here today for the second day on how to readjust fares in view of Britain's pound devaluation, American shipping operators were said to have won major concessions from their British rivals.

The Yeshiva University Endowment Foundation has increased by $250,000 in the last year and now totals $1,164,774, it was announced last night at the annual dinner of the foundation at the Astor Hotel.

For the twenty-first time since the First World War the country finds itself this week confronted with a fait accompli in the form of a nation-wide stoppage of coal production. This newest stoppage is following the customary Lewis pattern. In other words, it is synthetically spontaneous.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 -- The Department of Commerce announced today that the over-all stability of the national economy was maintained in August with construction continuing as "the principal area of strength in the business picture."
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 20 -- A performance of Puccini's "Tosca," with Fausto Cleva conducting, opened the twenty-seventh annual season of the San Francisco Opera Association tonight.

Republic Pictures will release fifty-three feature pictures in its 1949-50 program, it was announced yesterday. In addition the company will release four serials, and four travel short subjects to be filmed in Trucolor. Among the features will be six films starring Roy Rogers to be photographed in Trucolor, and five productions starring Rex Allen.
PARIS, Sept. 20 -- France has approached Italy, Belgium, the Netherlands and other European countries suggesting that they establish a common monetary system as a means of stabilizing currencies.
POTTSVILLE, Pa., Sept. 20 (AP) -- A train plowed into a gasoline-1 loaded truck toclay, killing two men and injuring three. The truck was split in two.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 20 -- Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer has signed Cary Grant to a one-picture contract under which he will play the title role in "Ferguson," the studio announced today.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 20 -- Directors of the fire association group of companies -- Fire Association of Philadelphia, the Reliance Insurance Company of Philadelphia, Lumbermen's Insurance Company of Philadelphia and the National Insurance Company -- have ordered a special meeting of stockholders to consider action as a result of an act passed by the 1949 Pennsylvania Legislature, it was announced today.

FRANKFORT, German Sept. 20 -- Allied Military Governments here are keeping a "close watch" on the new Bonn Government to make sure that a "democratic civil service law is enacted to prevent present "closed corporation" civil service from perpetuating itself.

A race track is the last place in the world for music lovers to gather for a discourse on great composers. Also, one has to look real hard to find a B-flat trumpeter who has blown a number known as "The First Call" more than 10,000 times since 1941.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 (AP) -- A Senate commerce subcommittee heard opposition today to legislation that would require labeling of fur articles to show the consumer exactly what he is buying.

The news item which appeared in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Sept. 12 outlining the problems of the U. N. in building an international civil service staff should provide food for thought to those of us who are so gravely concerned with the successful administration of our world organization.
CHICAGO, Sept. 20 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 -- The Consolidated Electric and Gas Company, New York, received permission today from the Securities and Exchange Commission to borrow $3,500,000 from the Chase National Bank of the City of New York.

Prices of nonferrous metals in England and Canada yesterday were marked up generally to the same prices in terms of dollars that had prevailed before devaluation. In the London market the price of silver for domestic use was increased to 64d an ounce, or the equivalent to 74.6 cents an ounce in United States currency.

Governor Dewey yesterday opened the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies' campaign for $50,500,000 with a statement that the drive was "a solemn occasion" which competes in importance with currency devaluation or industrial strife.

SARANAC INN, N. Y., Sept. 20 -- Optimism that business conditions will either remain stable or improve during the next twelve months was expressed here today by members of the New York State Society of Certified Public Accountants at their sixteenth annual conference.

The Henry Street Settlement was the beneficiary of a Harvest Ball held last night at the pre-opening of the Cotillion Room of the Pierre for this season. The formal opening of the Cotillion Room will take place tonight. Several cocktail parties were held in private homes and in the Oval Room of the hotel before the benefit.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 -- The United States has agreed to relax enforcement of nondiscrimination provisions of the Anglo-American loan agreement in order to implement devaluation of the pound sterling and assist her drive for increased production and exports.

LONDON, Sept. 20 -- The first check to the gold share devaluation boom, during which millions of pounds were added to values in unofficial street dealings yesterday, came when the stock market reopened officially here today.
A frightened and hungry baby antelope was taken back to its Bronx Park Zoo corral last night after an absence of several hours, but the mystery of its disappearance remained unsolved.

Alexandra Danilova's nostalgia for her early dancing days in Russia has inspired her to reconstruct some divertissements from the last act of "Paquita," in which she used to appear there, and the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo duly presented the little piece last night at the Metropolitan Opera House in its premiere.

The Federal Council of the Churches of Christ in America declared yesterday that the only "sound and practicable" way out of the "legislative stalemate" involving Federal aid to education would be to treat aid to schools and the supplying of welfare services to children as separate projects.

BARCELONA, Spain, Sept. 20 (AP) -- Juan March, mystery man of Spanish high finance, today took over a $350,000,000 company which he had forced into bankruptcy. During a stormy meeting of creditors last night Senor March's three representatives were elected referees for liquidation of the bankrupt Barcelona Traction, Light and Power Company.

A country dog and one of German extraction with the canine equivalent of a college education held part of the attention of several thousand spectators at the observance of National Dog Week in the lower plaza of Rockefeller Center yesterday.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 20 -- Smarting under last night's painful setback, the Cardinals bounded back against the Phillies today at Sportsman's Park and battered three hurlers for fourteen hits and a 7-to-5 triumph.

After a brief ceremony yesterday work started on Columbia University's $2,000,000 cancer research center atop Vanderbilt Clinic at the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center, Broadway and 168th Street. The construction is one of the first major steps in the hospital's $5,100,000 development program.

CHICAGO, Sept. 20 -- Liquidation was on in the grain markets on the Board of Trade today. Wheat broke as much at 3 5/8 cents a bushel; corn, 1 3/4 cents; oats, 2 1/2 cents; rye, 4 3/4 cents, and soybeans, 4 1/2 cents, before rallying strongly in the late trading on short covering.
Your late, peripatetic Dr. John Finley might well have strolled upon the following Harlem street scene and -- as I knew him -- commented editorially on its value to our city.

WHEN Henry Harley Arnold graduated from the United States Military Academy at West Point in 1907 he was so crazy about horses and the cavalry that he threatened to resign from the Army if he were assigned to the Infantry. Luckily for his country and the peace of the world he was persuaded to reconsider, and the future Commander in Chief of the Army Air Forces in World War II remained in uniform.

BOSTON, Sept. 20 -- Great Britain will continue to have recurring dollar crises until the problem is faced with a realistic economic approach instead of what is "politically feasible," James Reston, diplomatic correspondent of the THE NEW YORK TIMES, said today.

Russ Morgan and his orchestra will be featured in a new weekly musical variety show which starts over WOR and the Mutual network Friday, Sept. 30, from 8 to 8:30 P. M. In addition to leading the orchestra Morgan will be the master of ceremonies, introducing guest stars and various entertainers. The broadcast will originate in San Francisco.

WARSAW, Sept. 20 -- The Polish Government has lowered the exchange rate for the British pound and the Polish zloty by approximately 30 per cent, Konstanti Dabrowski, Minister of Finance, announced today. He said that the exchange rates of all the other currencies that had been devalued would be similarly reduced.

CHICAGO, Sept. 20 -- Foreign trade will play a smaller role in America's business life than in the past, Louis Ware, president of the International Minerals and Chemical Corporation, today told the Mortgage Bankers Association of America at its thirty-sixth annual convention.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 -- The steamship General Gordon will arrive at Shanghai on Friday to evacuate up to 1,600 Americans and other foreigners, the State Department announced today.

The Wautaga River Bridge on State Highway 67 in Carter County, Tenn., was cited yesterday by the American Institute of Steel Construction as the most beautiful steel bridge in its class opened to traffic in the United States in 1948. It was the winner in Class I, for spans of 400 feet or more.

Marketing of $9,200,000 of common and preferred stocks of the Carolina Power and Light Company was announced yesterday by underwriters headed by Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Beane and R. S. Dickson Co.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 (AP) -- Greece devalued today the exchange rates for the drachma to 15,000 drachmas for each United States dollar and 42,000 drachmas for each pound sterling.

The opening of the fourth session of the General Assembly brings to Flushing Meadow no less than eighteen Foreign Ministers and the most representative delegations sent to a United Nations meeting since the organization was established. Gathered here this week are the key figures in most of the Governments of the world.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 20 (AP) -- Pete Suder's eleventh home run of the year, hit in the eighth inning with two mates on base, gave the Athletics an 8-to-6 triumph over the Tigers today.

THIS is a story without a moral. Except for the ending it could be held up to the youth of America as a horrible example. So allergic was Pancho Gonzales to school and so deep-seated was his love for tennis that he spent most of his boyhood ducking truant officers who soon learned that the one place to catch the culprit was on the tennis courts.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, Sept. 20 -- Uncertainty prevails about the long-term effects of sterling devaluation, particularly the repercussions on tourism from the United States and Canada. For local residents a rise in living costs in the next six to nine months of between 15 and 20 per cent was forecast.

Visiting buyers registered in the market for the week ended yesterday totaled 2,372, against 2,823 last week and 2,060 in the corresponding week of last year, according to lists published in THE NEW YORK TIMES. There were 948 arrivals yesterday, compared with 1,496 last Tuesday.

The switching of a handful of votes at yesterday afternoon's session of the National Maritime Union's seventh biennial convention placed the organization in the odd position of barring all "Communists, Nazis and Fascists" from admission, but refusing to expel those already in the union.

The devaluation of the pound and other foreign currencies will "present a problem" to American motion-picture producers, Darryl F. Zanuck, vice president and production chief of Twentieth Century-Fox, said yesterday. Mr. Zanuck, who returned Monday after a ten-week trip to Europe, thought that while motion-picture stocks stood up well after the announcement of the devaluation of the pound, "anything that represents a reduction to our revenue presents a problem to American production."
Designs for hand-knitted fashions were presented yesterday afternoon at the Tavern-on-the-Green in Central Park by Mimi Pearce of 23 East Sixty-seventh Street.

Federal Bureau of Investigation figures showing that in 1948 this city had "far fewer" major crimes in proportion to opulation than any other city were cited as proof of the Police Department's efficiency in a report on the department issued by Mayor O'Dwyer yesterday.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 20 -- The Bethlehem Steel Corporation announced tonight that it had cut off all incoming shipments of iron ore and other raw materials in preparation for a steel strike at midnight Saturday.

POINT PLEASANT, N. J., Sept. 20 -- With the exception of a flurry of bass fishing along the beaches from Long Branch to Barnegat Inlet, the New Jersey coastal fishing seems to have fallen into the autumn doldrums.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 -- A minor inquiry into egg price speculation by the Senate Agriculture subcommittee headed by the former Secretary of Agriculture, Senator Clinton P. Anderson, Democrat, of New Mexico, was apparently abandoned today for a later full-scale hearing on changes in the Commodity Exchange Act to curb speculation in all futures markets.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Sept. 20 -- The newest pro in the district took a prominent part in reviving one of the oldest golfing fixtures today. Dick Mayer, who quit the amateur ranks on Aug. 29 today led the field in the Metropolitan Open championship, played for the first time since 1940 over the Metropolis Country Club.

The Battle of Midway, a great turning point in the war, was a victory won by carrier-based planes after land-based bombers had proved "most disappointing," according to the fourth volume of Prof. Samuel Eliot Morison's history of Naval Operations in World War II, published yesterday by Little, Brown Co.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Sept. 20 -- A chemical derived from a bacillus has yielded encouraging results in first clinical tests against a serious and incurable fungus disease prevalent in the Southwest, it was reported here today at the annual autumn meeting of the American Chemical Society.

The "old men" who control film production in Hollywood should "step upstairs" and let younger men run the business, David O. Selznick declared in an interview yesterday in reply to questioning as to what was wrong with American motion pictures.
Robert E. Davis has joined Barclay Knitwear Company, Inc., as executive assistant to the president, Michael Pauker.

NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 21 -Pakistan's decision to hold the Pakistani rupee at its former value of 3.29 to the dollar despite the devaluation of all other sterling-bloc currencies has caused consternation in Indian financial circles.

Experimental projects in care of the aged to be started soon by the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York were outlined yesterday at the second session of the medical and social work institute that opened the federation's campaign for $50,500,000.

Fashion at a price was the keynote of the Milgrim budget department showing which took place yesterday afternoon on the fourth floor. The collection included both misses' and junior sizes and all were priced under $100. The majority fell within a range of from $30 to $70.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- An International Commodity Clearing House to channel agricultural surpluses, already a serious problem in the hard-currency areas, into the soft-currency deficit countries was proposed to the world today by the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations.
Joe DiMaggio will not be able to play for the Yankees when the already badly shell-riddled Bombers face the Red Sox in Boston Saturday and Sunday.

Fifteen firemen suffered cuts and bruises yesterday while fighting two fires in the garment district, one of the men receiving injuries in both fires. Ten were injured when an explosion followed a fire in a shoe-repairing and hat-cleaning store at 312 Seventh Avenue.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- Scott W. Lucas, Senate Democratic leader, believes it would be "useless" to try repealing the Taft-Hartley Act in the Eighty-first Congress, even in the second session that begins next January.

The big new issue of Pennsylvania Turnpike Commisssion bonds to finance extension of the four-lane toll road to the Ohio boundary will reach the market probably on Tuesday of next week. The underwriting managers, consisting of Drexel Co., B. J. Van Ingen Co., Inc., Blyth Co., Inc., and the First Boston Corporation, are arranging for the distribution of the bonds through a selling group of about 215 security dealers.

There will be no need for this generation of schoolboys to ruin their eyes, Lincoln-fashion, when studying late, if a paper on "Appropriate Lighting for Today's Rural Home" scheduled for presentation yesterday at the French Lick Springs Hotel, French Lick, Ind., is heeded.

Henry Winston assumed broad responsibility in yesterday's testimony at the Communist trial for organizing, financing and carrying out the party's post-war "educational" program. This is the program that has formed the essence of the prosecution's case.

Some unusual happenings take a long time coming to light. For instance it took thirty-three years for the general public to be informed that Enrico Caruso, the famous tenor, once sang a bass aria in "La Boheme."

Industrial preparedness for war is being rapidly advanced to provide America with maximum security without militarizing or bankrupting the nation, Secretary of Defense Louis Johnson told 1,650 industrial leaders at the annual dinner of the New York Post of the American Ordnance Association at the Astor Hotel last night.
The change in sentiment of businessmen toward optimism, indicated in surveys in June and July, is shown clearly in an August survey of 1,154 executives by Dun Bradstreet, Inc., released yesterday.

Equipped with automatic transmission the 1950 Airflyte line of automobiles was announced yesterday by the Nash Motor division, Nash-Kelvinator Corporation. Hydra-Matic drive, installed for the first time in Nash cars, will be utilized as an optional feature on the Ambassador series of higher priced units.

With thedevaluation of the British pound, the price of Scotch whiskies is being raised in producing areas to match the former level in dollarB, it was learned here yesterday. The official announcement was made by the Nat/onal Association of Alcoholic Beverage Importers.
PITTSBURGH, Sept. 21 (AP) -Twenty-three acres of blighted land in Pittsburgh's celebrated "golden triangle" are going to be turned into a "Rockefeller Center" more extensive than New York's.

The mystery with which the late Frank F. Arnold, successful linotype school operator, had cloaked himself for more than forty years is gradually being lifted by J. R. Wendt, attorney, who has been searching for heirs to the $250,000 estate that Mr. Arnold left when he died Aug. 16, 1948.

I have just read THE NEW YORK TIMES report of the plans for the internationalization of Jerusalem proposed by the United Nations Palestine Conciliation Committee, and I cannot rid my mind of the memory of two phrases deep-rooted in Christian thought and tradition: "The Earthly Jerusalem" and "The Heavenly Jerusalem."

SCARSDALE, N. Y., Sept. 21 -- One hundred and seventy-five members of the Scarsdale Congregational Church met here tonight and voted to proceed with plans made twenty-two years ago for the construction of a $250,000 church building.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 21 -Charles M. LaFollette, national director of Americans for Democratic Action, today assailed the attitude of some of our "elderly statesmen," who claim America is moving toward mass slavery in a vehicle known as the "welfare stat."

CHICAGO, Sept. 21 -- Major American cities have asked Attorney General J. Howard McGrath and his Department of Justice to help them stop country-wide crime syndicates from seizing control of their local political machines.

The one-story building at 965 Flushing Avenue, northwest corner of Evergreen Avenue, in Brooklyn, has been leased for five years from Saltser Weinsier, Inc., by the Jonat Woodcraft Company of 240 West Fortieth Street, Manhattan.

CHICAGO, Sept. 21 -- The International Harvester Company today notified six locals of the Farm Euipment Workers Union, CIO, that it was willing to bargain centrally for plants in four states or on an individual plant basis, but not both.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (AP) -- Jersey City officials suggest that the Hudson and Manhattan Railroad handle freight in order to build up company revenues.

LONDON, Thursday, Sept. 22 -London's railway workers seemed last night to have lost their enthusiasm for the slowdown strike scheduled to start at midnight in protest against rejection of their wage demands.

Accusations and conclusions "without foundation" were included in a report submitted on Monday on the financial and physical condition of the New York, Ontario Western Railway, the road's two trustees declared in a statement issued yesterday.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 22 -- Splitting shut-outs in an afternoon and night of battling for the National League flag, the Dodgers and Cardinals found themselves right where they had been at sunrise -the Brooks trailing the leading Redbirds by a game and a half.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, Sept. 21 (AP) -- Chief Prosecutor Gyula Alapi today demanded death sentences for Laszlo Rajk, poker-faced former Cabinet minister, and the seven men accused with him of plotting to overthrow Hungary's Communist Government.

Signs that the United Nations is maturing are visible in the calm and businesslike beginning of the fourth session of the General Assembly. It is too much to hope that the international debate which will be staged here during the next two months will continue in the relaxed and dignified atmosphere of the first meetings.

Mayor O'Dwyer appointed yesterday a six-member committee to analyze and report on three proposed local laws, the net effect of which would be to restore all Police and Fire Department pensions to the non-actuarial basis that existed before March 1, 1940.

The arrests of still more Czech priests by the Communist Government is evidence that the struggle between Church and State is approaching a climax and that the Government is thus far losing the battle. The immediate goal sought by the Communists was acceptance of their proposed church law raising salaries of the clergy but at the same time subjecting church appointments to political approval.

Representative Vito Marcantonio, American Labor party candidate for Mayor, declared last night that the economic plight of Puerto Ricans here could not be resolved until Puerto Rico obtained full independence.

BOSTON, Sept. 21 -- Henry M. Blackmer, the Colorado millionaire who fled to France twenty-five years ago to avoid testifying in the Teapot Dome oil scandal, returned unobtrusively today, prepared to face charges still pending against him.

On Saturday, while thousands of Americans are urging Jackie Robinson to steal second, or Yogi Berra to "hit one into the right field stands," a small group of old-timers in Montclair, N. J., will be yelling for their favorites to "curve it in and kiss the jack."

CEDARHURST, L. I., Sept. 21 -- Mrs. J. B. Balding of The Creek Club scored 41, 37 -- 78, five strokes over par, to win the low gross prize during the Women's Long Island Golf Association weekly one-day tournament at the Rockaway Hunting Club today.

Prices in pounds sterling rough diamonds in London likely to be increased, with the result that there will be no reduction in the wholesale prices of diamond in the United States, Louis Frank, executive director of the Diamond Manufacturers and Importers Association of America, said yesterday.

School has begun again, and in a few million homes wan parents will be struggling with homework. This entertainment will follow the day's regular labor, as well as the cooking of supper and the washing of dishes, and it will precede complete exhaustion and nervous insomnia.

TRENTON, N. J., Sept. 21 -- Counsel for six Trenton men who are awaiting a new trial for murder here have requested further information regarding Jerry Griswold, a former employe of the victim, it was learned today. Mario H. Volpe, prosecutor of Mercer County has been asked to produce either Mr. Griswold or his statement concerning the killing.

The American Legion disap-! proves counter-demonstrations by any of its 3,000,000 members against pro-Communist groups and advocates leaving such organizations "strictly alone," George N. Craig, newly elected national commander of the Legion, said yesterday.
Current political campaigns were injected yesterday into the otherwise peaceful session of the National Maritime Union's seventh biennial convention.

The millinery division of the Greater New York Fund's 1949 campaign committee raised $15,000 yesterday at a meeting in the McAlpin Hotel toward the section's quota of $27.500. The balance will be reached through individual efforts of committee members, said Maurice Lewis of the Merrimac Hat Corporation, committee chairman.

CALGARY, Alberta, Sept. 21. The annual convention of the Trades and Labor Congress adopted tonight an amendment to its constitution calling for an oath of allegiance to the Crown for all its officers.
TEANECK, N. J., Sept. 21 -- This northern New Jersey township ended a three-day period as a photographer's model today with all the aplomb of a Conover girl.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Sept. 21 -- Some Czechoslovak priests are planning to refuse to accept the increased salaries provided by a proposed new church law, a source in touch with high Roman Catholic Church authorities said today.

NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., Sept. 21 -- The Army's Continental Air Command notified the First Air Force headquarters at Fort Slocum here today that the headquarters would be moved to the Mitchel Air Force Base on Long Island by Oct. 25.
