HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 21 -- Twentieth Century-Fox has sent the script of "Cheaper by the Dozen" to Myrna Loy in Europe offering her the chief feminine role opposite Clifton Webb, the studio disclosed today. If she accepts the engagement, Miss Loy will be seen as the mother of twelve children.

Currency cuts and dollar shortages were the major topics in United Nations corridors yesterday where many a visiting delegate was calculating how the recent devaluations would affect his Government officially and his pocketbook personally.

As Jews throughout the world prepared to usher in Rosh ha-Shanah tomorrow night, marking the year 5710 in the ancient Hebrew calendar, holiday messages yesterday emphasized the need for supporting Israel and stressed the symbolical significance of the approaching High Holy Days of repentance.

CHESAPEAKE CITY, Md., Sept. 21 -- The new $4,000,000 high level bridge here over the Chesapeake and Delaware Canal, which is expected to become an important link in a new super highway running from near Newark, N. J., to Virginia, was opened officially today.

The arrest of two men yesterday in Buffalo was said by postal inspectors to complete the round-up of a gang of five persons who stole 700 unemployment insurance and social welfare checks from East Side mail boxes in April, May and June of this year.

ALBANY, Sept. 21 -- Three hundred demonstrators, 244 of whom came from New York by special train, marched to the Capitol today to demand that Governor Dewey appoint an unbiased citizens' commission to investigate the disorders in connection with the recent Paul Robeson concert near Peekskill.

BONN, Germany, Sept. 21 -- The Council of the Allied High Commission, representing the United States, British and French governments, came into being today and formally proclaimed the Occupation Statute which is to act in lieu of a peace treaty between the Western occupying powers and the new Federal Republic of Germany.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 21 (AP) -- The Detroit Tigers wound up their season's business with the Athletics today with a 4-1 victory, behind the four-hit hurling of Art Houtteman.

The last trip proved to be the most harrowing and costly one of the season for two Staten Island sailors who walked exhausted into the lonely Sandy Hook Coast Guard lifeboat station minus their dungarees and boat but with a tale of a cold lonely night adrift in Raritan and Sandy Hook Bays.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- Representative Emanuel Celler, Democrat, of Brooklyn, chairman of the House Judiciary Committee, asked President Truman, at the White House today, to appoint a woman, and, specifically, Mrs. Florence Shientag, to one of the four new Federal judgeships created in the Southern District of New York.

Atlantic Coast longshoremen lowered their wage demands on employing stevedores and shipping companies yesterday but the negotiations moved a day nearer the Sept. 30 strike deadline without a new agreement.

BONN, Germany, Sept. 21 -- The epithet "Nazi" was hurled today in the new West German Bundestag in its first session of parliamentary debate, causing an unparliamentary five-minute uproar as President Erich Koehler vainly sought to restore order.
An unprecedented international agreement to mobilize merchant shipping in case of emergency is being set up as a result of a survey being made under auspices of the National Security Resources Board.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (AP) -- Secretary of Air W. Stuart Symington tonight rebuffed a naval court of inquiry that asked him to appear for testimony in an investigation of the now-discredited B-36 memorandum.

LONDON, Sept. 21 -- There is a growing undertone of anxiety among the British people regarding the effect of devaluation on domestic prices. Despite Sir Stafford Cripps' assurance that aside from the increase of a penny in price of bread, price rises will not be severe and are not imminent, there is general fear that they will be considerable when they do come.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (UP) -China's $300,000,000 gold reserve, removed to the island of Formosa by Chiang Kai-shek last November, is being used to stabilize Formosa's economy and halt the advance of the Communists.

Apparently there is a limit to the punishment even such robust characters as the Yankees can withstand and yesterday they seemed to reach the end of their amazing powers of resistance as they crashed to a 10-9 defeat before the White Sox, who were making their farewell appearance of the year at the Stadium.
HAMILTON, N. Y., Sept. 21 -- The football picture at Colgate is definitely on the bright side despite a succession of heavy jolts in the loss of operatives who figured to fill prominent roles.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- Enforcement of the ban against certain types of give-away programs on the radio and television broadcasting chains was indefinitely postponed today by the Federal Communications Commission.

Detectives Katharine (Kitty) Barry and Patrick Murphy, who had sat on an East Side park bench for many days posing as a romantic couple to keep suspects of narcotics peddling under surveillance, were rewarded last night for their play-acting.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 21 -- The threat of a walkout of interstate bus drivers against a Missouri Pacific Railroad subsidiary was revealed today as the strike of 5,200 trainmen on the 7,200-mile rail system entered its thirteenth day.

Asserting that rent control laws passed by the present city administration "gouged" tenants instead of protecting them, Newbold Morris, Republican - Liberal - Fusion candidate for Mayor, last night charged Mayor O'Dwyer, his Democratic opponent, with political trickery.

Arturo Toscanini, 82-year-old musical conductor, returned yeserday on the Home liner Atlanic after spending the summer in Italy, to resume his duties as conductor of the National Broadcasting Company orchestra on Oct. 25.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Sept. 14:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- The General Public Utilities Corporation, New York, asked the Securities and Exchange Commission today for permission to make a $24,000,000 cash capital contribution to its subsidiary, the Associated Electric Company, also of New York.

BERLIN, Sept. 21 -- In his first newspaper interview since assuming his post here, Maj. Gen. Maxwell D. Taylor, United States commandant in Berlin, today cited cooperation of the Bonn Government with the German administrators in the city's western sectors as the best hope for the improvement of the city's crucial economic plight.
The city's relief rolls increased in August for the ninth successive month, Welfare Commissioner Raymond M. Hilliard reported yesterday to Mayor O'Dwyer.

The United States and the United Kingdom will oppose any new meeting of the Big Four Foreign Ministers on German questions until their deputies find a solution to the Austrian treaty problem, spokesmen for both delegations to the United Nations General Assembly said yesterday at Flushing Meadow.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 21 -- Proceedings in the United Nations General Assembly are being watched with exceptional interest here because of the possibility that the Belgrade-Moscow struggle may find expression in one form or another at Flushing Meadow.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 21 -- From sixteen months of monitoring by Army stations in Hawaii and Oregon, not a single treasonable statement came out of "Zero Hour" Broadcasts of Radio Tokyo for introduction at the trial of Iva Togura D'Aquino, the defense told a Federal Court jury today in final argument.

SIOUX RAPIDS, Iowa, Sept. 21 (AP) -- Guy Gabrielson, Republican National Chairman, said today the Republican party must steer a middle-of-the-road course between "radicals at both ends of the social scale."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- James E. Webb, Acting Secretary of State, told the new Federal German Republic today that the occupying nations would use their remaining controls "sparingly" but with sufficient force to prevent the Nazis from returning to power.

Paul E. Fitzpatrick, Democratic State Chairman, broadened yesterday his attack on Republican candidates who have accepted endorsement of the Communist-dominated American Labor party and called upon Senator John Foster Dulles to repudiate such candidates in Rochester and Monroe County.

MINEOLA, L. I., Sept. 21 -- Long Beach residents, concerned over possible property loss and devaluation resulting from a proposed expressway leading into the city from the Atlantic Beach Bridge, were reassured on that score here today by County Executive J. Russel Sprague.

By the end of this year United States industries will have invested about $45,000,000,000 in new plants, improved equipment, expansion and modernization since 1947, Alfred P. Sloan Jr., chairman of the board of the General Motors Corporation, told sixty graduate students from foreign countries yesterday at a luncheon at the Warwick Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- The House returned from a month's vacation today in the mood for a quick wind-up of the session's business and Speaker Sam Rayburn indicated that he would act promptly to obtain an agreement with Senate leaders on an adjournment target.

If there were more standees on hand for last night's performance of "South Pacific" at the Majestic Theatre than Fire Department regulations usually call for there was a pardonable reason for the apparently unwonted breach of rules.

CHICAGO, Sept. 21 -- Manager Frankie Frisch of the Cubs today challenged a $200 fine levied against him by President Ford Frick of the National League for a flareup in yesterday's Brooklyn-Cubs game here.

ELIZABETH, N. J., Sept. 21 -- In four test case decisions today members of Local 401, United Electrical Workers, CIO, who have been on strike against the Singer Manufacturing Company plant here, were held ineligible for state unemployment compensation benefits.

Federal authorities announced yesterday the smashing of a stamp counterfeiting ring with the arrests of three men accused of collaborating in an engraving and printing operation that if successful would have placed 12,000,000 fake 3-cent stamps in circulation.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 21 -- A series of wildcat strikes that threatened to spread into a large-scale revolt against President Truman's request for a further truce in steel took 5,300 workers from their jobs in three steel plants here today.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Sept. 21 -- A simple, low-cost method that makes possible for the first time mass-scale production of the constituents of proteins in a form that can be utilized by the body without passing through the mouth and digestive tract was announced here today by a team of scientists of the National Cancer Institute, United States Public Health Service.

Amid the anguished protests of a half-dozen devotees of monkeys as house pets, Magistrate William E. Ringel ruled yesterday that the animals were "wild beasts" and imposed a suspended five - day workhouse sentence on Jack W. Crawford, 59-year-old chef who housed five monkeys in his midtown apartment.

Whatever one's own view on the wisdom of devaluating the British pound may have been, the hope today is naturally that the result of this and other measures will be to bring about a balance in payments between the sterling and the dollar areas. That hope may not be realized, and measures far more fundamental than this may be necessary to correct the unbalance in this field of the world's economy.

Westinghouse's new home freezer, the first it has ever manufactured, stands upright instead of being cast in the more conventional chest design. Consequently it occupies only five square feet of floor space, no more than a small refrigerator.
CASTEL GANDOLFO, Sept. 21 (AP) -- Establishment of the Christian family spirit "on a national, international and world level" was proposed by Pope Pius XII in a speech made public today.
Commodity markets rallied yesterday in a reaction to the pessimism early this week that drove prices downward in the wake of devaluation of the British pound sterling.
The United States is not combating communism "militantly" enough, Mrs. Ruzena Pelantova, former deputy mayor of Prague, declared yesterday.

Guy Kibbee, last seen here three years ago in "A Joy Forever," was signed yesterday for one of the important roles in "Signor Chicago," the forthcoming comedy by Edward Chodorov based on the Quintero brothers' Spanish play, "The Women Have Their Way."

CHICAGO, Sept. 21 -- Trading in grain futures was relatively slow on the Board of Trade today, but the markets developed a stronger undertone after an easy opening, except for September corn, which was under pressure from liquidating longs.

The New York City Housing Authority was commended yesterday for many aspects of its work in producing low-rent housing. But with this praise the housing committee of the American Institute of Architects' New York chapter combined the admonition that some "barren and barracks-like" Housing Authority projects helped to reconcile the public to similar low standards in privately built large-scale apartment developments.

The water-color rodeo paintings on windows of restaurants and taverns in the vicinity of Madison Square Garden are done by two "sign painting tramps" who "wouldn't trade their type of life for anything else in the world."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- The extreme growth of economic concentration in the United States is pushing this country toward socialism, Representative Emanuel Celler, Democrat, of New York, warned today. He urged a "new look" in the anti-trust laws.

The nation's gasoline stocks declined 1,044,000 barrels last week, according to the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end they were 103,331,000 barrels, compared with 104,375,000 a week earlier and 91,800,000 on Sept. 18, 1948.

Dr. William Jansen, Superintendent of Schools, announced yesterday the nomination of Miss Ethel F. Huggard, a veteran of thirty-six years' service in the city's school system, for the vacant post of associate superintendent. The nomination is expected to be acted upon at the Sept. 29 meeting of the Board of Education.

The Administration, faced with an estimated deficit of from $5,000,000,000 to $8,000,000,000 in 1950, is not likely to be sympathetic to appeals for elimination or reduction of the wartime excise taxes, according to Representative Charles A. Halleck, Republican of Indiana.

Capot of the Greentree Stable prevailed over a classy field in the Jerome Handicap at Belmont Park yesterday. The 3-year-old son of Menow, returning to the turf wars after an absence of almost six weeks, won the eightieth running of the mile fixture in a stirring performance which saw him take the premier honors by the margin of a mere nose over the Addison Stable's Arise.

SHANGHAI, Sept. 21 (UP) -- A group of United States citizens in Shanghai today called on the United States to "establish a sound basis" for friendly relations with the new Chinese Communist Government.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (AP) -- The text of President Truman's letter asking steel company and union officials for a new six-day strike truce follows:
AUBURN, N. Y., Sept. 21 (AP) -The International Harvester Company offered today to sell its Auburn plant to the city for $1.

Mayor O'Dwyer's administration was accused of neglecting vital health and sanitation services in a report of the public health section of the Liberal party made public by A. A. Berle Jr., Liberal State chairman. The report made a number of recommendations for correcting the deficiencies it listed.

Sam Lewis, a pilot who said he lived in Los Angeles, denied yesterday on his arrival at the New York International Airport at Idlewild, Queens, from Europe that he had ever "sneaked" a plane out of the United States. A Paris dispatch to THE NEW YORK TIMES published on Monday reported that Mr. Lewis admitted he had "sneaked" a Lockheed Constellation to the Azores.

ALBANY, Sept. 21 -Because of the changing economic situation, it is doubtful whether any new appropriations for the development of the State University of New York will be included in the state's 1950-51 budget,
CINCINNATI, Sept. 21 -- The Giants went from the ridiculous to the sublime, or a facsimile thereof, on Crosley Field today as they split a doubleheader with the Reds before a slim crowd of 2,292.

Following recommendations by its advertising department, Schenley Distillers, Inc., has decided not to use radio and television for its distilled spirits, it was announced yesterday by J. L. Leban, president. The company will continue to use daily and weekly newspapers, national magazines, trade publications, billboards and other media.

HANOVER, N. H., Sept. 21 -- At exercises opening Dartmouth College's 181st year Dr. John Sloan Dickey, president, declared here today that the United States should work for an international organization strong enough either to attract a more friendly Russian government or discourage any aggressive Soviet regime.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- President Truman today requested the nation's leading steel companies and the United Steelworkers of America, CIO, to resume collective bargaining at once and to extend the present strike truce for six days, from Sept. 25 to Oct. 1.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- Hermann H. Field, a United States architect employed by Western Reserve University, has disappeared in Poland under circumstances that the State Department said tonight were still "unexplained."

A syndicate headed by the National City Bank submitted the best bid yesterday for $12,000,000 of bonds of Houston, Tex., due from Nov. 1, 1950 to 1979. The bid was 100.0001 for interest of 2 1/2 per cent, 3 per cent and 5 per cent, a net cost of 2.5165 per cent.

Charles Rorech, builder, sold the one-story taxpayer containing seven stores at the southeast corner of Covert Avenue and Stewart Court in Stewart Manor, L. I., to William Rand. The property, on a plot 125 by 90 feet, was acquired for cash above two mortgages totaling $62,000.

The gas and electric utilities of the nation must raise about $12,000,000,000 in the five years through 1953, it was declared yesterday. In a study of the problems attending this unprecedented financing the American Gas Association, in conjunction with the Edison Electric Institute, suggested several steps to obviate or to solve the problems.

CHICAGO, Sept. 21 (AP) -- A strike against the 11,000-mile Burlington system has been authorized by four operating brotherhoods in a drive to speed up handling of grievance claims, it was announced today.

Issues of new public utility and railroad securities totaling $44,120,000 will be offered to investors today by underwriting syndicates. All of the issues offered were acquired by the bankers at competitive bidding. The offerings are as follows:

With that same dramatic flare as when the cavaliers of old swept them over their shoulders, capes have invaded the field of fashion for fall. They may swing from the shoulders in dashing full hem length versions as Pauline Trigere handles them, or be combined with a skirt or tossed over the shoulders of a dress as part of a handsome costume.

LONDON, Sept. 21 -- United States and British transatlantic ship operators reached full agreement here today on a new fare structure necessitated by devaluation of the pound and other foreign currencies. At the same time it was learned the United States and fifty-nine other international aviation companies were well on the way to a similar agreement.

Fannie Brice will resume her radio role as "Baby Snooks" over the National Broadcasting Company network Tuesday, Nov. 8, at 8:30 P. M., under a long-term contract being drawn up by NBC and the William Morris Agency, which represents the star.

Dahlias from one to fourteen inches in diameter were brought to the Penn Top of the Statler Hotel yesterday for the thirty-fifth annual show of the American Dahlia Society. Amateur and professional growers traveled as much as 400 miles to enter their finest blooms in this two-day show.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- The State Department has received a new note from Russia protesting Italy's participation in the North Atlantic pact as a violation of the Italian peace treaty.

At the end of two days of effort to mediate the differences between representatives of the steel industry and Philip Murray's steelworkers, Cyrus S. Ching reported to the President yesterday that the negotiations had made no progress. The President has now asked for a second extension of the truce, scheduled to end at midnight Saturday, this one for an additional six days.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (AP) -Beaten eleven straight times, rookie Dick Weik of the Senators pitched a three-hitter tonight to defeat the St. Louis Browns, 7 -- 0. Ed Stewart, with two doubles and a triple, batted in five Washington runs and scored the other two.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Sept. 21 -- Measures aimed to provide uniform procedures on security regulations concerning national defense secrets were outlined here today at the annual autumn meeting of the American Chemical Society before a symposium on "Security Clearance and the Scientist."

Experts of the Bronx Zoo kept a watchful eye yesterday on the baby muntjac that was mysteriously kidnapped from its corral Tuesday evening and held for several hours by boys unknown. The vital question was -- would its mother take it back?

Professional football enters the local picture tonight, with the Brooklyn-New York Yankees of the All-America Conference and the New York Bulldogs of the National League both opening their home seasons in conflicting attractions at the Yankee Stadium and Polo Grounds.

A split in the labor support pledged to Newbold Morris and the Fusion ticket by the Liberal party was indicated last night when Max Zaritsky, president of the United Hatters, Cap and Millinery Workers Union, AFL, came out in favor of the re-election of Mayor O'Dwyer.
TORONTO, Sept. 21 (AP) -- The convention of the United Rubber Workers of America, CIO, reinstated tonight L. S. Buckmaster of Akron, Ohio, as union president. The vote was 840 to 740.

CHICAGO, Sept. 21 -- The mortgage industry must be prepared to reduce monthly payments on outstanding loans to avoid foreclosures when incomes plunge to lower levels, Harry R. Templeton, vice president of the Cleveland Trust Company, said today.

Two new films will open in midtown theatres this morning. At the Capitol, the attraction is "That Midnight Kiss," a Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer musical romance in Technicolor, starring Kathryn Grayson and a newcomer, Mario Lanza. Jose Iturbi, Ethel Barrymore, Keenan Wynn, J. Carrol Naish, Marjorie Reynolds and Jules Munchin are among the principals.

The Yugoslav delegation to the United Nations General Assembly has asked the United States, Britain, and other Western nations to support the election of Yugoslavia to the seat on the Security Council now reserved for a member of the Soviet bloc.

The additional monetary incentive automatically provided for gold mine operators in countries which have devalued their currencies is likely to result in an increase in shipments of gold to this country of as much as $200,000,000 annually, according to estimates in financial circles yesterday.

LONDON, Sept. 21 -- While Sir Stafford Cripps, Chancellor of the Exchequer, is urging exporters to earn more dollars in the United States a rich source of dollars in the United Kingdom remains virtually untapped. It is the American community of soldiers, diplomats and business men who would like to buy British but are prevented by regulations and red tape from doing so.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- Adolf Hitler's plans for invading Czechoslovakia six months before the Munich conference included the deliberate murder of the German Minister for the purpose of creating an "incident" justifying an attack, it was disclosed today.
The Jewish War Veterans directed units throughout the country yesterday to apply the "quarantine treatment" to all public appearances of "Communists, Fas-I cists and other subversive ele-I ments."

Secretary of State Acheson, in a speech that helped to strengthen the prevailing attitude of tempered optimism, urged the United Nations General Assembly yesterday to use patience and common sense in a long-range program for the solution of issues in dispute between the Soviet Union and the Western powers.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Sept. 21 -- Shattering the course record with a 64, Jack Burke Jr. of the Metropolis Country Club moved into the lead at the end of the second round of the Metropolitan Open championship over his home links today with a thirty-six-hole aggregate of 136.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- The rejection by the Senate of the nomination of Carl A. Ilgenfritz as chairman of the Munitions Board creates a potentially serious situation in the important defense field of economic and industrial mobilization.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday closed steady, unchanged to 12 points higher than on Tuesday, with the most pronounced strength in the near months.

DUESSELDORF, Germany, Sept. 21 -- A message from Chancellor Konrad Adenauer, calling upon Jews to take part in "the intellectual, social and political reconstruction of our country," was published tonight in the official organ of German Jews.

WEST HILLS, L. I., Sept. 21 -- Col. Henry L. Stimson, who resigned as Secretary of War on Sept. 18, 1945, when he was 78 years old, celebrated his eighty-second birthday today at High-hold, his home in the hills of this country that also knew the great poet, Walt Whitman.

WARSAW, Sept. 21 -- The Polish United Workers (Communist) party will "wage a merciless battle against all vestiges of rightist or nationalist deviation and social democratism" left in its ranks, Jakob Berman, secretary general of Poland's Political Bureau, declared yesterday.

A lovely mezzo-soprano voice was heard here for the first time last night when Nounouka Franghia sang at Town Hall. The attractive singer comes from Greece, where she has an impressive list of musical accomplishments to her credit.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- Forces seeking to reduce the Administration's $1,314,010,000 foreign military aid program put in powerful thrusts today in the third day of the Senate's debate on the proposal.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -Wheat exports from the United States this crop year will fall 50,000,000 bushels short of the 450,000,000 goal because of the failure of Congress to pass implementing legislation to the International Wheat Agreement, a Department of Agriculture spokesman today told a Senate Agriculture subcommittee.

WILLA CATHER'S fine gift for putting the right word in the right place and -- what is far, far more important -- her miraculous genius for leaving all the wrong words out of all the wrong places -- has not been lavishly matched in our time.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 21 (AP) -Ralph Kiner, Pittsburgh left fielder, hit his 51st and 52d homers of the ear tonight but the Boston Braves, aided by circuit clouts by Jim Russel and Del Crandall, defeated the Pirates, 9 -- 7.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- The renewed conversations among British, Canadian and American officials, to explore ways and means whereby exclusive possession by the United States of the atomic bomb and its final manufacturing processes may be shared with these wartime associates in its discovery, are being held here in a settled atmosphere and on a sound basis.

It is obvious that no comprehensive plan for relieving the traffic situation on the Queensboro Bridge and its approaches can be completely effective until something is done about improving access to Welfare Island. The bridge which the city now proposes to construct between Queens and Welfare Island would seem to be an acceptable solution to this part of the problem.

BOSTON, Sept. 21 -- Doggedly refusing to crack, even when confronted with a 3-run deficit, the Red Sox hammered six Cleveland pitchers for fifteen assorted safeties, including homers by Al Zarilla and Ted Williams, and wound up with a vital ground-gaining 9-6 victory over the Indians today.

Northwest Airlines will begin Stratocruiser service from Seattle to Honolulu on Nov. 5, reducing its present scheduled flying time on the transpacific route by almost four hours, it was announced yesterday. The fast luxury liners will make the westbound flight in less than eleven hours and the return trip in a little over nine hours.

A certified zinc alloy plan by which die casters may identify castings with a certification seal was announced here yesterday by the American Die Casting Institute, following the annual meeting of the association at the Edgewater Beach Hotel in Chicago.

The Class I railroads in the United States in the first eight months of this year installed 1,296 new locomotives, the largest number in any similar period since 1923, the Association of American Railroads reported yesterday. These included 1,249 of the Diesel-type and forty-seven steam.

LONDON, Sept. 21 -- A more cautious tendency prevailed in the gold share section today when the new account opened in the stock market. The factors responsible were weakness in Wall Street, South African taxation, uncertainties and the prospect of higher wages in the mining industry.

TADWORTH, England, Sept. 21 (AP) -- Two American Ryder Cup players fell before inspired British play today in extra-hole matches in the British Professional Golfers' Association championship. Six other Americans advanced, none very easily.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- W. Averell Harriman, roving Ambassador of the Economic Cooperation Administration, said today he expected to see real progress toward the convertibility of currency in Europe by the year's end.

The 1950 population and housing censuses, beginning April 1 next, will constitute "the most comprehensive and important marketing survey ever conducted in the United States," Philip M. Hauser, acting director of the Bureau of the Census of the Department of Commerce, said yesterday.
PORTLAND, Ore., Sept. 21 (AP) -The Western Wool Handlers Association wool sale collapsed today as buyers, fearful of the pound devaluation effect on prices, cut their offers or withheld them.

PARIS, Sept. 21 -- David R. Hardman, chairman of the British delegation to the general conference of United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization, today opposed any increase in the agency's budget for 1950.
Three thousand five hundred women from seventy-six neighboring Long Island communities saw the annual fall fashion review presented yesterday afternoon by Frederick Loeser at the Garden City Hotel.

A diary of travel through ive South American republics by Christopher IsherwSod, author and poet, i will be published by Random House i on Sept. 30, entitled 'The Condor and the Co,J-s," the condor standing for the Andean states and the l cows for Argentina.

HONG KONG, Sept. 21 -- Fresh evidence of a clash of views between Acting President Li Tsung-jen and Chiang Kai-shek was provided in Canton today when the Acting President vetoed the appointment of Gen. Tang En-po as commander of the Nationalist forces in Fukien.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (AP) -The Newport News Shipbuilding and Drydock Company has offered to build the largest Diesel-powered passenger liner ever constructed in the United States for $12,690,000.
In the "not too distant future" all meats will be packaged at central points just as many other food products are now, Joseph B. Hall, president of the Kroger Company, predicted yesterday.

The 1950 population and housing censuses, beginning April 1 next, will constitute "the most comprehensive and important marketing survey ever conducted in the United States," Philip M. Hauser, acting director of the Bureau of the Census of the Department of Commerce, said yesterday.

The Mapleson family tree as far back as the early eighteenth century has had a music librarian. "Look at the tree -- it's studded with sharps and fiats," says Alfred John Mapleson, the current holder of the tradition, and incidentally, the only American-born of the English Maplesons.

The purchase by New York investing interests of the large housing development and shopping center adjoining the plant of the Glenn L. Martin Company, airplane manufacturers, at Middle River, a suburb of Baltimore, Md., was announced here yesterday.

Last night the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo added to its repertoire at the Metropolitan Opera House a revival of David Lichine's "Graduation Ball," which we first saw hereabout nine years ago in the production of the Original Ballet Russe and later were regaled with by the Ballet Theatre.

As the domestic labor outlook brightened yesterday, so did the stock market. A growing belief that the question of pensions in the steel industry could be settled without resort to a strike was translated into a recovery by the share list.
Following is the test of Secretary of State Dean Acheson's address to the United Nations General Assembly yesterday at Flushing Meadow:

The Bank of New York and Fifth Avenue Bank sold the five-story apartment house on a lot 37 by 100 feet at 1462 Wilkins Avenue, the Bronx, to James H. Cruikshank, operator. The property is assessed for $34,000 and was sold subject to a first mortgage of $11,500 for five years at 4 per cent.

SHANGHAI, Thursday, Sept. 22 -- To the cannonading of gun salutes, the "Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference" opened in Peiping last night to put its stamp of approval on the structure of China's new Communist-led Government.
Greek National forces have eliminated organized guerrilla resistance along the northern frontiers of Greece, the United Nations Special Committee on the Balkans reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- Selden Chapin, whose recall as Ambassador to Hungary was forced by that country's Communist government early this year, was nominated by President Truman today to be Ambassador to the Netherlands. He will require Senate confirmation.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., Sept. 21 -- Rigging restored and torn sails either stitched or replaced from the blow yesterday, the Bermudian and Long Island Sound International class sloops held their third series race today and the local team made it three straight victories.

DETROIT, Sept. 21 -- The Ford Motor Company and the United Automobile Workers, CIO, ended a negotiating session of two and a half hours tonight without reporting progress on settlement of their dispute over a new contract to take the place of the one that expired July 15.

MILLBURN, N. J., Sept. 21 -- Mrs. Joanne Barr Tracy of Morristown defeated Mrs. Catherine Fox Park of Glen Ridge, 3 and 1, today as match play began in the twenty-fourth Women's New Jersey Golf Association championship.

In one of the first major price adjustments of important English products since the pound was devalued 30.5 per cent, a large group of English dinnerware manufacturers yesterday notified American importer representatives that they have increased sterling prices to permit only a 10 per cent reduction in retail levels here.
ONEONTA, N. Y., Sept. 21 (AP) -- More than 300 farmers attended a Federal-State hearing today to complain that they were losing money on their milk.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Sept. 21 -- Several hundred pictures of the recent violence between alleged Communists and anti-Communists near Peekskill will be shown to the October grand jury here that is to investigate the disturbances, District Attorney George M. Fanelli said today.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Sept. 21 -- The possibility of another extension of the strike truce in the steel dispute is expected to result in further delaying the start of real collective bargaining in the soft-coal dispute, it was indicated today.
Twelve Waves with the wanderlust -- all veterans who spent the last war on dry land on the home front -- sailed yesterday aboard the Army transport Gen. Maurice Rose from Pier 11, Staten Island.

CHICAGO, Sept. 21 (AP) -- Hank Sauer hit his twenty-ninth home run as the Cubs out-slugged the Phillies, 9---, in the second game of a double-header after a 3-1 loss in the opener today before 5,572 persons.
Bids for Air Force velour cloth, which were scheduled to be opened yesterday, will be returned unopened at the request of the woolen mills, according to trade sources.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 21 -- Research scientists here are grappling with two problems that might limit seriously the number of jet warplanes this nation could build and operate in an emergency, it was learned today.

Soviet Foreign Minister Andrei Y. Vishinsky dropped his recent air of mildness to bombard the United Nations General Assembly's Steering Committee with repeated and forceful charges of "crude violation" of the United Nations Charter as the committee adopted an agenda loaded with sixty-eight items at its first session yesterday at Flushing Meadow.

The unaudited report of Gimbel Brothers, Inc. for the six months ended on July 31, last, issued today by Bernard F. Gimbel, president, showed net sales of $128,222,089, a decrease of 9.2 per cent from the $141,147,283 volume transacted one year earlier.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Sept. 21 -- If the Dutch and Indonesian delegations ratify the results reached by their leaders last week-end, the first major success of the round-table conference -- agreement on the political relationships between the Netherlands and the proposed new republic -- will be in sight.

Your editorial of Sept. 19 re the Beth Israel Hospital succinctly points out the needs for expanding facilities of a voluntary hospital system throughout the city with increasing demands made for ward, clinic and other facilities.
MIAMI, Sept 21 (AP) -- Two small but growing tropical hurricanes brushed close to land in widely separated sections tonight.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended Sept. 17, 1949, totaled 743,022 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.

Burton M. Sloane, a young industrial designer, won a speedy decision yesterday on the question whether it is illegal for a man to drive sixty miles an hour on an almost deserted Henry Hudson Parkway, to get his wife to a hospital ahead of the stork. It seems it isn't.

The stock market virtually completed yesterday its recovery from the sharp relapse of Tuesday. Spurred by aggressive buying in the railroad issues prices rebounded to gains of as much as 3 points, sending the composite average up 0.62 point. Optimism over favorable developments in the labor-management picture was again credited for the rally.

At the end of his direct examination at the Communist trial yesterday, Henry Winston swore he was not even in the United States when the party was reconstituted in 1945, and so could not have voted for the reconstitution.

Price reductions ranging from $73 to $140 were announced yesterday for the 1950 Nash Airflyte line of automobiles by George W. Mason, president, Nash-Kelvinator Corporation. New York City delivered prices, exclusive of sales tax, are:

Paramount Pictures, Inc., has obtained a modification of the consent judgment by which holders of voting trust certificates of the New Theatre Company will be relieved of paying a tax on dividends withheld until the holder qualifies to obtain the stock free of the voting trust restrictions.
Intervention of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service in the Atlantic Coast longshoremen's dispute was sought yesterday by employers and the International Longshoremen's Association, AFL.

The common stock marketing requirements of public utility holding and operating companies keep generating new expedients for distributing the equity shares through the machinery of underwriters and dealers of securities. Just completed are two transactions which employed seasoned marketing tools.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 22 -- The threat of the left-wing United Electrical Workers to stop paying dues to the Congress of Industrial Organizations unless the parent group submits to a UE ultimatum has stiffened the resolve of CIO leaders to crack down on leftist elements at the national CIO convention, opening in Cleveland Oct. 31.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Sept. 22 (AP) -- Roman Catholic Church authorities asserted tonight that the Communist-led Government had organized a spy system to watch virtually every priest in Czechoslovakia.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that it would approve a plan for the distribution of assets by the American Power and Light Company if certain minor amendments to the proposal were filed by the company.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 22 (AP) -- Danny Murtaugh, singled Wally Westlake home with the winning run in the ninth inning tonight as the Pittsburgh Pirates beat the Boston Braves, 1 -- 0, in a tight pitching duel between Johnny Sain and Murry Dickson.

" Thieves Highway," a Twentieth Century Fox drama, starring Richard Conte and Lee J. Cobb and featuring Valentina Cortesa, the Italian actress who is making her Hollywood debut, has its local premiere this morning at the Roxy. Jules Dassin directed and Robert Bassler produced from the screen play by A. I. Bezzerides and his novel, "Thieves Market."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- An Interstate Commerce Commission examiner absolved railroad employes today of any responsibility for alleged black market sales of Pullman accommodations for the New York-Florida tourist trade.
LONDON, Sept. 22 (Reuters) -- The London price of essential silver was reduced today from 64 pence to 62 3/4 pence per ounce.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Sept. 22 (UP) -- The Illinois Parole Board today recommended and Gov. Adlai Stevenson immediately approved a reduction in the sentence of Nathan Leopold, sensational "thrill" killer of the Nineteen Twenties, making him eligible for parole in January, 1953.

The Administration's $1,314,010,000 foreign military aid program had a rough time of it in the Senate, but it has survived, and since the tale has had a happy ending we can feel relieved and dispense with recriminations. However, vigilance is still the watchword, for the House of Representatives cut the authorization for Europe in two, just as Senator George tried to do in the last few days.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 22 -- With Ralph Kiner, the Pittsburgh home run king, in mind, the Cincinnati Reds management announced today that Sunday's double-header will begin at 1 o'clock -- a half hour earlier than usual.
The three major commercial airports of the metropolitan area did about 20 per cent more business in the first eight months of this year than they did in the corresponding period of 1948.

William B. Brown, Treasurer of the Territory of Hawaii, asserted here yesterday that much misinformation was prevalent in New York financial circles as to the effect of the dock strike on the territory's economy. He is making arrangements here for the sale of $8,000,000 of public improvement bonds which the Territory has listed for bidding next Wednesday.

SHANGHAI, Sept. 22 -- The new Government of the "People's Republic of China" will have no President or Cabinet nor will it be models after the Central Government of the Soviet Union, according to speakers at Communist China's constitutional convention, which opened in Peiping yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- The Senate Post Office Committee approved today a bill providing for an annual increase in the postal rates expected to yield $100,000,000. This was $150,000,000 less revenue than rate increases proposed by the Administration would have brought in to offset operating losses of the Post Office Department.

Mr. Vishinsky had a merry time on Wednesday in the U. N. General Assembly picturing the rotund Secretary General Trygve Lie riding a white horse into battle against some sovereign state, at the head of the field service of armed guards with which Mr. Lie has proposed that the U. N. shall equip itself.

Robert Fransko, a private first class in the Marine Corps during the war, received yesterday the Navy Cross for extra-ordinary heroism on Iwo Jima, at a ceremony at the Marine Recruiting Headquarters, 90 Church Street.

MOSCOW, Sept. 22 -- The newspaper Culture and Life published today an announcement by Director K. Ostrovityanov of the Institute of Economics, who is deputy secretary of the institute's party organization, announcing that the Institute, its directors and the party bureau fully concurred with the criticisms of the institute expressed by Culture and Life.

Black took precedence in a collection of French originals and clothes inspired by them in a showing presented yesterday by Russeks in the Terrace Room of the Plaza Hotel at the luncheon hour. As strongly stressed as the color were velvet-trimmed dresses, suits and coats.
LARCHMONT, N. Y., Sept. 22 -- Defeating the Bermuda team again today, the Long Island Sound International Class yacht sailors made it four straight to win their series.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- In the first case of its kind affecting radio, the Federal Government has filed a lawsuit against an Ohio newspaper and four of its officers, charging them with conspiracy to monopolize the dissemination of news, advertising and other information.
SPOKANE, Wash., Sept. 22 -- Low-grade and microscopically fine uranium-bearing pitchblende has been reported found on property of the Sunshine Mining Company near Kellogg, Idaho.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- Department store sales in the week ended Sept. 17 were 7 per cent below sales in the corresponding week of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. The following lists percentages changes from like periods of 1948:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- A day-to-day journal kept during the past eight momentous years by the late James Forrestal, the first Secretary of Defense, is reposing in the White House, it was learned today.

Emil Schram, president of the New York Stock Exchange, hailed the results of the monetary conference in Washington and the devaluation in the sterling area as "an inspiring example of leadership" in an address last night at a dinner meeting of the National Industrial Conference Board.
LONDON, Sept. 22 (AP) -- United States shipbuilders may get larger subsidies as devaluations cheapen building costs abroad, the chairman of the United States Maritime Commission said today.

LONDON, Sept. 22 -- After two days' discussion the world's leading airlines agreed here today to maintain present dollar fares for transatlantic flights and sterling fares for air travel throughout Europe, the Middle and Far East, Africa and Australasia.

LONDON, Friday, Sept. 23 -- In one of those periodic attempts of Fleet Street journals to cheer up the readers by informing them that no matter how austere life may be in Socialist Britain, workers here are better off than in the United States, the Daily Mirror launched a campaign today that seemed doomed to failure.

LANDOVER, Md., Sept. 22 -- Miss Louise Suggs, Carrolton, Ga., professional, took a three-stroke lead in the fourth annual United States women's open golf championship today when she carded a 6 under 36, 33 -- 69 at the Prince George's golf and country club toda.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- Exchange rate adjustments yet to come should make possible an expansion of world trade on a multilateral basis "unless undermined by domestic action in the member countries," Camille Gutt, managing director of the International Monetary Fund, said today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- Gen. George C. Marshall was appointed president of the American Red Cross today by President Truman. He will succeed Basil O'Connor, who will resign on Oct. 1.

PLAINFIELD, N. J., Sept. 22 -- New Jersey's oldest commuter, both in age and years of travel, will be honored tomorrow by the Central Railroad of New Jersey in the celebration of his ninetieth birthday.

There is no immediate prospect that individual or corporation taxes can be reduced, and elimination of excise taxes appears to be a year or two away, Vice President Alben W. Barkley declared yesterday. Notwithstanding that the Administration has been accused of entering a period of "statism," he said, if the Government undertook to reduce expenditures for its settled program, business men would be the first to "rise up" in protest.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 22 -- After decreasing in the three preceding weeks business in the Pittsburgh district showed a small gain last week, according to the Bureau of Business Research, University of Pittsburgh. The rise was due partly to a moderate advance in steel-mill operations and partly to increased coal production; shipments and the volume of trade were down a little after seasonal adjustment.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- Democratic Congressional leaders met with President Truman today to lay the groundwork for adjournment of Congress and subsequently mentioned Oct. 15, 20 and Nov. 1 as possible dates.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Sept. 22 -- Closing with a 4-under-par 67 after a third round of 71, twenty-six-year-old Texas-born Jack Burke Jr., Metropolis Country Club professional, today won the metropolitan open championship over his home course with a seventy-two hole aggregate of 274.

THIS now is the open season on Branch Rickey and some of the trigger-happy boys in the press box are beginning to give it to the Mahatma squarely between the eyes. They are charging that the Deacon of the Dodgers doesn't want the Brooks to win the pennant but is much more pleased when they finish a rousing second.

Dr. T. F. Tsiang, chief of the Chinese delegation to the United Nations, has done a service to his country and a service to the truth by speaking out plainly in the General Assembly. He has dropped diplomatic niceties and has come to grips with the assault on China by the Communists.

The old Metropolitan Club at 1 East Sixtieth Street, opened for the first time in its fifty-eight-year history for such an occasion, provided a brilliant background last night for the presentation of the seventh annual American Fashion Critics Award to Pauline Trigere.
The return of strong optimism among manufacturers of various containers and packages was reported yesterday by the United States Department of Commerce in a quarterly report on the industry.

The Securities and Exchange Commission filed in Federal Court yesterday a motion for a preliminary injunction to restrain the American Chrome and Magnesium Industries, Inc., and its president, Alwyn H. Wild, from public distribution of the company's common shares pending SEC approval.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 22 -- Gordon R. Clapp and the United Nations economic mission to the Middle East that he heads leave tomorrow for Cairo.

As far as Broadway is concerned, nothing really new has emanated from P. G. Wodehouse's facile pen since "Anything Goes" and that was back in 1934. Something ought to be done to rectify this sad state of affairs. The news about Mr. Wodehouse this morning is that the British humorist has accumulated a backlog of great expectations.

Despite a decline in the volume of its sales from the level of the preceding year, the American Sumatra Tobacco Corporation attained a new high record in its earnings for the fiscal year ended on July 31, according to the twenty-third annual report of the company and its subsidiaries issued yesterday by Seton Porter, president.

The Lona Realty Corporation, Frank Slater, president, which recently bought the twelve-story apartment house at 801 West End Avenue through E. Osborne Smith, Inc., broker, has resold the property through the same broker to John Kirscher. There are seventy-one apartments in the property which is assessed for $550,000.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- The $1,314,010,000 bill to help arm a great part of the non-Communist world was approved intact tonight by the Senate, 55 to 24.
The Hudson Manhattan Railroad announced yesterday that it could never save itself by handling freight, a solution being pressed upon it by Jersey City authorities.

After reading the news story in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Sept. 15 regarding the testimony of Howard Rushmore, former Communist, before a Senate Judiciary Committee I am convinced that among the more dismal aspects of the left-wing movement in the United States are the efforts of ex-Communists to whitewash their past at the expense of others.

BONN, Germany, Sept. 22 -- Amid tumultuous scenes of disorder, reflecting the repeated intolerance of minority views on the right and left, the debate in the bundestag of the new West German State degenerated today into oral chaos.

Substantial improvements in the plant, equipment and operation of the Department of Correction since Jan. 1, 1946, were announced yesterday in a report made public by Mayor O'Dwyer. The department operates and controls eleven detention houses and penal institutions as well as numerous court detention pens.
New varieties and awards were featured on the second day of the American Dahlia Society's annual show at the Statler Hotel yesterday. The blooms on exhibition had kept remarkably well.
Edward C. Kelly will manage the new municipal department of Goodbody Co., members of the New York Stock Exchange.
CANTON, China, Friday, Sept. 23 (AP) -- Nationalist air and sea forces have been thrown into the flaming battle for Amoy, vital port on China's southeast coast, pro-Government dispatches said today.

OSLO, Norway, Sept. 22 -- Col. Bernt Balchen of the United States Air Force, an authority on arctic aerial operations, said in an interview today a United States air rescue service would establish a base at the North Pole next spring.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, Sept. 22 (AP) -- All eight defendants in the Hungarian treason trial confessed again in final statements today, and only two begged that they not be hanged. In fact, the primary defendant, Laszlo Rajk, former Foreign Minister and Minister of the Interior, said he had approved the verdict of the five-judge people's court in advance.

Soviet Russia's Fifth Five-Year Plan, expected to begin next year, will continue to emphasize expansion of heavy industry and will probably aim for a 40 to 50 per cent increase in gross industrial production by 1954, American observers believe.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 22 -- Over protests from defense counsel that the action was "unfair and prejudicial," Federal Judge George B. Harris today set Nov. 14 for the start of the perjury and conspiracy trial of Harry R. Bridges, West Coast longshore leader.
Following is the text of the speech delivered yesterday by Dr. T. F. Tsiang, chairman of the Chinese delegation, in general debate at the United Nations Assembly session at Flushing Meadow:

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 22 -- The Missouri Pacific Railroad strike will enter its third week tomorrow with neither the four idle operating unions, nor the carrier's court-appointed trustee seeking resumption of negotiations since last Monday's meeting.

LONDON, Sept. 22 -- Although the stock market as a whole opened in a bright mood today, the early promise was not fulfilled. The opening prices, which were above yesterday's closing levels, encouraged selling, and with brokers reporting little fresh investment business most sections finished dull and unsettled.
A large section of West Manhattan was left without light and power late yesterday afternoon through the failure of a rotary converter at Consolidated-Edison's West Eighty-fourth Street substation.

In their first venture in the housing field in Queens, Simon Bros., Manhattan builders, yesterday announced the purchase of three square blocks of vacant land in Jackson Heights for improvement with apartments representing an investment of about $10,000,000.

NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 22 -- The breakdown of efforts by the United Nations commission on India and Pakistan to bring the two dominions together on the Kashmir issue has resulted in the demand here that the projected plebiscite in the disputed state be abandoned.

SIOUX CITY, Iowa, Sept. 22 -- The Republican party will launch tomorrow a national farm conference in an effort to get a farmer-formulated agricultural program to toss into the 1950 Congressional election campaign.

The United States gave its official blessing yesterday to the United Nations' new treaty on news-gathering, and announced that it was prepared to become the first government to sign the international press pact -- as soon as it is open for signatures.

This is the twentieth year of Lou Little's investiture as head football man at Columbia and never before during his long tenure has he had to roll up his sleeves and do the job of coaching that is called for this time.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 (UP)--The Department of Agriculture said today that the total domestic and foreign demand for United States cotton during the 1949-50 crop year "will be no higher and may be lower" than the 12,600,000-bale consumption of the past crop year.

TORONTO, Sept. 22 (AP) -- The United Rubber Workers of America, CIO, today re-elected as president Leland S. Buckmaster of Akron, Ohio. Mr. Buckmaster declared it was a personal vindication of charges that had resulted in his removal from office four months ago.

The oyster is back. A cheery ice-cold welcome to him, with a slice of lemon and some tabasco on the side. He has returned from summering in pleasant places, in Cape Cod, Blue Point, Chincoteague, and along the Chesapeake.
CHICAGO, Sept. 22 (AP) -- The season's smallest Wrigley Field crowd, 1,813, watched the Chicago Cubs nip the Philadelphia Phils. 3 -- 2, in the last meeting of the season between the two clubs today.

Newbold Morris, Republican-Liberal-Fusion candidate for Mayor, declared last night that the Liberal party might well be the vehicle for the realignment of national political parties which would put conservative and liberal forces in separate camps.

WASHINGTON. Sept. 22 (UP) -- Francis P. Matthews, Secretary of the Navy, tonight ordered a naval court of inquiry to abandon attempts to get W. Stuart Symington, Secretary of Air, to testify "against his will" in connection with hearings on the famous "anonymous" B-36 document.

Anti-Communist forces at the National Maritime Union's seventh biennial convention succeeded yesterday in jamming through a resolution designed to drive left wingers out of the union, after having been balked in an attempt to adopt a constitutional amendment with similar provisions on Tuesday.

The New York Society for the Relief of the Ruptured and Crippled, now at 321 East Forty-second Street, yesterday filed plans for a new hospital for special surgery to be erected on Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive, between East Seventieth and Seventy - first Streets, and to be operated, in affiliation with the New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center.

It takes a skillful designer to create elegance without a hint of age, to manipulate intricately with seeming simplicity. This Tatiana du Plessix achieved with a light but sure hand in designing her enchanting collection of fall custom millinery for Saks Fifth Avenue, received enthusiastically yesterday in a showing at the St. Regis Hotel.

Harvey Johnson's 31-yard field goal, exactly twenty-one seconds before the final gun, gave the Yankees a 10-7 victory over the Los Angeles Dons at the Stadium last night. This All-America Football Conference local opener, contested in the rain, attracted 14,437 fans.

Kenyon Eckhardt, Inc., has been appointed to handle institutional advertising of the Ford Motor Car Company, it was announced yesterday in Dearborn, Mich., by J. R. Davis, vice president -- sales and advertising. J. Walter Thompson will continue to handle both Ford product and dealer accounts while Kenyon Eckhardt will handle the institutional account in addition to Lincoln-Mercury product and dealer advertising.

PARIS, Sept. 22 -- Prospects for the formation of a European monetary bloc with a free system of currencies were considered on the wane today. French officials stated that, according to their information, Belgium had not adopted a free exchange market similar to those in force in France and Italy.

With the end of military government in Germany, an Occupation Statute, administered by an Allied High Commission, takes the place of a peace treaty in defining relations between the Western Powers and the German Federal Republic. The authority of the new state extends over less than two-thirds of the reduced territories left to Germany after the war.
WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Sept. 22 -- John L. Lewis indicated today that the United Mine Workers were back on a policy of "no contract, no work," for the present at least.

MOSCOW, Sept. 22 -- Only by "indefatigable vigilance" can allegedly massive efforts of United States intelligence personnel to infiltrate its agents into the Soviet Union be balked and frustrated, in the opinion of L. Saveliev, whose pamphlet, "Guard Military Secrets," has just been issued by the military publishing house of the Armed Forces Ministry.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Sept. 22 -- The official names of eight man - made chemical elements forged in the fires of atomic energy, seven of which were transmuted by modern alchemy in American atomic furnaces, were announced here today at the annual autumn meeting of the American Chemical Society.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 22 -- The right wing minority group within the United Electrical Workers, CIO, voted tonight to unite as a bloc for any action that the Congress of Industrial Organizations might take at its convention opening here Oct. 31, in retaliation to the stand indicated by the left wing administration re-elected yesterday.
WARSAW, Sept. 22 (AP) -- The United States Embassy said today that Anatole Berton, described as a New York furrier, was being held by Polish authorities on bribery charges.

The Democratic organizations in the five boroughs have joined hands to check the nominating petitions of the City Fusion party, which has nominated Newbold Morris as candidate for Mayor, Harry Uviller for Controller and Matthew J. Diserio for President of the City Council. The three also have the nominations of the Republican-Liberal party.

A better grade of gas at lower cost was promised yesterday to 35,000 residents of Orange County, N. Y., following Public Service Commission approval of the Central Hudson Gas and Electric Corporation's application to construct a forty-mile-long natural gas pipe line from Tuxedo to Poughkeepsie.

Attacking Mayor O'Dwyer for past deals and attempted deals with the Communist-dominated American Labor party, Newbold Morris said yesterday that he would not accept a labor party endorsement and did not approve acceptance of Labor party nominations by Edmund H. H. Caddy, Republican candidate for District Attorney of Kings County, and Supreme Court Justice Francis X. Giaccone, on the bench by appointment of Governor Dewey and Republican candidate for election.

Dr. T. F. Tsiang, Chinese representative, yesterday denounced the Chinese Communist party as an instrument of Russian imperialism, and called on the United Nations General Assembly at Flushing Meadow to "ponder over the present situation in the Far East and the grave dangers to world peace and security."

Rubber futures continued active on the Commodity Exchange yesterday but prices moved within narrow ranges and closing levels were mixed. September delivery closed off 35 points for the day while the active distant months showed small gains.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 22 -- Blasting six pitchers for nineteen hits and twenty-eight total bases the Dodgers more than made sure of winning the vital series from the Cardinals under the Sportsman's Park lights tonight. The final score was 19 -- 6, but at the end of five and a half innings the Brooks had amassed a 16-1 lead.

American prestige throughout the world "is slipping dangerously because of flaws in our democracy," Walter White, secretary-on-leave of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, declared yesterday at the association's offices, 20 West Fortieth Street.

Alfred W. Miles, treasurer and director of the Hoving Corporation and also a director of John David and Bonwit Teller, has been made a member of the board of S. Stroock Co., Inc., to fill a vacancy. He formerly was first vice president and treasurer of Best Co.

A stove painted bright fireman red, a fabric designed by Dali and a sectional sofa upholstered in purple are among the thousands of objects now being put in place at Grand Central Palace for the First National Homefurnishings Show, which will open tomorrow at noon.

CLARKSBURG, W. Va., Sept. 22 (UP) -- A roving band of 1,500 pickets made a riotous five-hour foray through the northern West Virginia coal fields today, closing nonunion mines that were operating in defiance of the miners' walkout.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 22 -- President Truman's request that the national steel strike, scheduled for midnight Saturday, be put off until 12:01 A. M. Oct. 1 was officially approved today by the United Steelworkers of America, CIO. But the union warned that this would be "the last postponement."

A banking syndicate headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., and the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company submitted the best bid yesterday for $10,000,000 of general obligation water bonds of the city and county of Denver, Col.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- In the recent actions under the Sherman law the Department of Justice has approached the problem of monopoly in restraint of trade from two different angles.

The hot glare of floodlights transformed the classroom at the Walt Whitman School, 25 East Seventy-eighth Street, into a Hollywood set. The cast of 5- and 6- year-olds, however, were perfectly at home. They seemed less affected by the commotion and heat than the veteran camera crew.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- Senator Guy M. Gillette, Democrat, of Iowa, today said that his office was being flooded with communications from all over the country on the price spread between farm and table.

TOKYO, Sept. 19 -- The Conservative Japanese Government of Premier Shigeru Yoshida has about dropped its plan to press for a reorganization and an increase in manpower of the National Police Force, as suggested by Lieut. Gen. Robert L. Eichelberger, former commander here of the United States Eighth Army, well-informed political circles assert.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- The Senate Banking and Currency Committee unanimously reported today the Administration bill setting up guarantees for private capital invested abroad against the risks peculiar to such investment.

Directors of Illinois Zinc Company for the second consecutive quarter took no action yesterday on the dividend usually announced at this time. Prior to the second quarter of this year the company had been paying 15 cents a share.

Low bids aggregating $6,729,518 for additional construction work on the $22,500,000 Owl's Head Sewage Treatment Works in South Brooklyn were announced yesterday by Frederick H. Zurmuhlen, Commissioner of Public Works.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 22 -- A ten-member Greater Philadelphia-South Jersey Council was appointed tonight to formulate an over-all program to solve the economic problems of the industrial region.

Supreme Court Justice Murray Hearn in Brooklyn reserved decision yesterday on a motion by the Teachers Union, CIO, for a temporary injunction to restrain the Board of Education from conducting loyalty investigations under the Feinberg Law.

The dull-silvered stainless-steel eight-car subway train that has streaked over BMT lines on "dry-run" tests since early last June, carried paying passengers for the first time yesterday. It ran on the Brighton Beach Line.
YORK HARBOR, Me., Sept. 22 (AP) -- Demand for cotton and rayon goods "may easily run ahead of supply" the president of the National Association of Cotton Manufacturers said today.

Two longshoremen were reported yesterday in Municipal Term Court as not only drawing state unemployment insurance while holding down jobs along the waterfront, but as also being carried on the local home relief rolls.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- Assignment of the Carrie E. Doheny oil and gas interest in California, valued at $35,000,000, to Nassau Associates, Inc., a subsidiary of Dillon, Read Co., of New York, was approved recently by the Department of the Interior.

SEATTLE, Sept. 22--A renewed appeal for more foreign trade was made in Seattle today by Secretary of Commerce Charles Sawyer as he dedicated the Ports of Seattle's new foreign-trade zone at the East Waterway Terminal on Harbor Island.

A weekly television platform on which all political candidates in the forthcoming city elections may air and debate their viewpoints will be offered by WPIX beginning Sunday from 9 to 9:30 P. M. Opposing parties and political candidates each will have fifteen minutes and may use the time in any manner they see fit.

First tangible evidence that the "cold" war in trade between the United States and Russia is abating came here yesterday with word that the United States through the Department of Com merce has approved the immediate export to the Soviet of $500,000 worth of oil field machinery.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 22 (AP) -- The Chinese Communists disclosed today that the new central government they are forming in Peiping would adopt the minimum -- not the maximum -- program of the Communist party.

BERLIN, Sept. 22 -- The population of the Soviet zone of Germany decreased during the twelve months that ended April 1 this year by 124,000, according to the newspaper Neue Zeitung. It reports that the return of about 500,000 German prisoners of war from Russia during that period offset an actual decrease of 625,000, approximately 50 per cent, which drop was accounted for by the fact that the total deaths exceeded the number of births.

ALPINE, N. J., Sept. 22 -- In a sheltered nook atop the Palisades Interstate Park Patrolman Rudolph Hrasdzera found this morning a 14-year-old Brooklyn youth crouched near an open fire. He was sharing a can of tomato soup with a small, injured puppy.

Any wildfowler who has spent from $30 to $50 for the privilege of spending the day in a duck blind on a famous waterfowl marsh will appreciate the problem confronting us in replying to inquiries as to "the location of an open duck shooting area within fifty miles of the city, where a limit shot can be expected."
Obviously the dispute between the coal miners and the mine operators involves a decision that portends much for the future of all, both at home and abroad.

BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 22 (UP) -- President Juan Peron was expected today to sign a bill soon making anyone who showed "disrespect" for high Government officials liable to imprisonment for up to three years.
TADWORTH, Eng., Sept. 22 (AP) -- Three almost unknown Britishers toppled three of America's best today in the third and fourth rounds of the British Professional Golfers' Association championship.

YONKERS, N. Y., Sept. 22 -- Mrs. John H. Bartol of the Greenwhich Country Club, the association champion, made her second appearance today in Women's Westchester-Fairfield Golf Association one-day competition since winning the crown and scored for the second straight time at the Hudson River Country Club.
SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Sept. 22 (AP) -- The Illinois Supreme Court today held invalid the state's Mandatory Fair Trade Liquor Act, which regulates package liquor prices.
OLEAN, N. Y., Sept. 22--The Very Rev. Juvenal Lalor, O.F.M., was installed today as the twelfth president of St. Bonaventure College.

For the first time in seven years time deposits in New York State commercial banks and trust companies declined in the first half of 1949, Elliott V. Bell, Superintendent of Banks, announced yesterday. The shrinkage, which was less than 1 per cent of the 1948 year-end total of $2,200,000,000, was due to a decline in special interest and thrift accounts, Mr. Bell said in a resume of the mid-year statements, which will be issued today.

CHICAGO, Sept. 22 -- Trading in September grain and lard contracts ceased at the close of business today after erratic price changes on the Board of Trade. September corn closed about the bottom with losses of 2 7/8 to 3 3/4 cents a bushel, with the deferred months 1/2 cent down to 1/8 cent up.
TEL AVIV, Israel, Sept. 22 -- Premier David Ben-Gurion said in a Jewish New Year's Eve broadcast tonight: "I hope the day is not far off when Jerusalem will take its destined place in Israel."

The Whitney Museum opens its season with a preview this afternoon, and will open to the public tomorrow an exhibition entitled "Juliana Force and American Art." The event is in the nature of a memorial to the gallant and vital director who guided the institution's course from its beginning until her death a year ago.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- George H. Livengood, a coal miner, 54 years old, filed suit in the Federal District Court today demanding from the trustees of the United Mine Workers Welfare and Retirement Fund an accounting for $140,000,000 alleged to have been spent since 1946.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 22 -- Betty Garrett was named today by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer for the leading feminine role in "The Skipper Surprises His Wife," a screen comedy by Dorothy Kingsley based on a magazine story by W. J. Lederer.

The mother of the baby muntjac that was kidnapped from its corral in the Bronx Zoo Tuesday evening apparently has decided to forgive and forget her infant's contact with the human race, zoo officials said yesterday.

Robert W. Grant's Sun Bath led from the drop of the flag to the click of the finish-line camera in the $11,325 Broad Hollow Steeplechase at Belmont Park yesterday, just as he had done in three stakes at Saratoga last month. Fourth choice at a bit over 5 to 1, he won by half a dozen lengths.

New York City's Board of Transportation, convinced that it is running one of the world's greatest underground railroads, 500 route miles, has invested approximately $50,000 to prove its point, it was learned yesterday.

Former Governor Herbert H. Lehman set the tone for his campaign for United States Senator last night when, in his opening address, he firmly championed the cause of the New Deal of Franklin D. Roosevelt and the Fair Deal of Harry S. Truman, which he contrasted with Republican "inaction" and "reaction."

May I ask you to extend the courtesy of printing some of the facts concerning New York University's time-honored residence on Washington Square? These, I believe, should be of interest to those anxious to preserve the traditions of the older institutions of the city.

DELAWARE, Ohio, Sept. 22 (AP) -- Good Time, owned by William H. Cane of Goshen, N. Y., today won the richest pacing event in history, the fourth annual Little Brown Jug, before 27,000 spectators at the Delaware County Fair.

LONDON, Sept. 22 -- Sam Watson, chairman of the Labor party and Durham mine workers' leader, forthrightly told Britain's higher paid workers today that they could not expect any wage increases from the country's present output, and that the next increases out of higher production must go to the lower paid men.

Mayor O'Dwyer announced yesterday that at the request of school authorities he would ask the Board of Estimate to approve an appropriation of $200,000 for soap and towels to be used by the children in public schools.

LONDON, Sept. 22--With speculation on the chances of an early general election increasing, both Houses of Parliament were recalled today for debate next Tuesday and Wednesday on the Labor Government's handling of Britain's financial affairs.
PORTLAND, Me., Sept. 22 (AP) -- The freighter that sank the dragger Corinthian, with loss of six lives, was doing fourteen knots in heavy fog, the fishing vessel's skipper claims.

Austria's full independence may be restored in a matter of weeks by negotiations opening at the Waldorf-Astoria today among deputies of the Big Four Foreign Ministers, informed United States circles believe. A recent Russian trend toward a more reasonable attitude in international affairs has been most marked in this field it is said.

When Rabbi Joseph Glatzer conducts his first Jewish New Year services tonight and tomorrow in the United Service for the New Americans synagogue at the Marseilles Hotel, he will offer a prayer of thanks to his Catholic as well as Jewish benefactors.

BOSTON, Sept. 22 -- Henry M. Blackmer, who spent twenty-five years in Europe rather than tell what he knew about the Teapot Dome oil scandal, slipped quietly out of Boston today with his wife on a train for Chicago.

LONDON, Sept. 22 -- A contract was awarded in London today for a dam that would create the world's largest reservoir at the headwaters of the White Nile in Central Africa. The dam, with an electric power station, will be erected at Owen Falls in Uganda, at the outlet of Lake Victoria.

There have been beds disguised as storage cabinets, desks that became dining tables, utility shelves that turned into ironing boards. Now the homemaker who is cramped for living space may, if she cares to, buy a single piece of furniture in which all these functions are combined.
CHICAGO, Sept. 22 (AP) -- Today's report of the markets in the Union Stockyards by the United States Department of Agriculture follows:

The first "Giselle" of the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo's season at the Metropolitan Opera House last night had Alexandra Danilova in the title role, Frederic Franklin as Albrecht, and Mary Ellen Moylan as the Queen of the Willis, and a very presentable "Giselle" it turned out to be.
DEVON, Pa., Sept. 22 -- Joseph A. Hale of Greenwich, Conn., today captured top honors with Glen Erin in the middle and heavyweight green hunters class at the Bryn Mawr-Chester County horse show.

BUFFALO, Sept. 22 -- In an abrupt move, Bell Aircraft Corporation today bowed out of present strike negotiations, asserting that its representatives would not meet with mediators until "the union either accepts or rejects the joint mediation services proposal."
One of the year's worst crashes in the wholesale meat market took place this week when dressed pork fell $16 to $18 a hundredweight, the United States Department of Agriculture reported yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 (UP) -- The Veterans Administration today debated a change in its regulations to spare several thousand ex-GI students from suffering a financial loss because of a VA mistake.

PARIS (Friday), Sept. 23 -- French Socialist leaders called early this morning for an end of Government control of wages and for the workers' freedom as soon as possible to bargain collectively. They also recommended the granting of special payments while wage contracts were being drawn up.

Julius Kayser Co. will not follow other brand manufacturers of full-fashioned hosiery in alloting merchandise for the next two months, company officials said yesterday. There will be no reduction in the amount of nylon yarn to be used for Kayser hosiery, they added, and orders will be filled to the full extent of productive capacity.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 22 -- Moshe Piyade of the Yugoslav Politburo defined today the broad principles of Soviet foreign policy in a manner that could be regarded only as an attempt to inform the Governments represented at the United Nations of dangers implicit in the Belgrade-Moscow struggle.

In temples and synagogues here and throughout the world the Jews will usher in at sundown tonight Rosh ha-Shanah heralding the new year, 5710, in the ancient Hebrew calendar. Orthodox and Conservative Jews will observe the holiday for two days and Reform Jews for twenty-four hours.
Archeologists at the American Museum of Natural History measured yesterday a sheet of cotton fabric unwound last Week from a pre-Inca Peruvian mummy and called it the largest ever found.
Royalton Manufacturing Co, floor in 137 W 23d St; American Automatic Typewriter Co, in 120 Greenwich St; Frank-Samberg Co, in 347 5th Ave -- Carstens Linnekin Inc, brokers.

Business loans made by banks here registered their fourth successive weekly rise during the week ended on Wednesday, advancing $69,000,000 in the sharpest upward movement since Oct. 13, 1948. According to the figures issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, the twenty-four reporting member banks now have a total of $4,715,000,000 commercial, industrial and agricultural loans outstanding, or $231,000,000 above the low point touched on July 20, this year.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 22 -- Since emphasis in the Five-Year Plan of Yugoslavia is on heavy industry, the household goods display at the Zagreb Fair this week is mediocre, qualitatively and quantitatively. A very small part of the available space is alloted to consumers' goods and those shown are strictly utilitarian.
